column2: Stock-market trading for the week opened with a reaction among the steel shares and most of the standard industrials. Reichsbank also dropped sharply.
Outside interest in oats, rye and soy beans on the Board of Trade here was relatively small last week, and the movement of prices was dominated largely by the action of wheat and corn.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

The Metropolitan premiere of Gian-Carlo Menotti's "Amelia Goes to the Ball" in English and the season's first performance of "Goetterdaemmerung" will mark the fourteenth week of the opera season next week. The program for the week follows:
The National Football League voted today to abolish the temporary suspension system and to increase from twenty-five to thirty the number of players a club may have on its active playing list.
Bills carrying out Governor Lehman's tax program to finance his $386,364,615 budget are scheduled to be reported this week in the Senate.

The appointment of Simon W. Gerson as assistant to Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan and the domination of home relief by the Workers Alliance, foreshadow an attempt by Communists to get control of the city government, Victor F. Ridder, chairman of the State Board of Social Welfare, asserted yesterday.
Although the end of the week witnessed some increase in activity on the Boerse, the Austrian arrangement, in general, tended to foster reserve.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick St. GeorgeSmith and Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Leach Allen Jr. gave a reception and tea yesterday at the St. GeorgeSmith home, 320 East Fifty-seventh Street, for Miss Marie Louise Smith and Louis S. Allen, who will be married on Friday.
Clarence Wilson Thomas, president for many years of William G. Halkett Company, cotton goods wholesalers, died at his home in Germantown today after a year's illness. He was 64 years old.

Naval headquarters announced today that the minesweeper Swallow ran hard aground on Kanaga Island in the Western Aleutians yesterday, but that its crew of forty reached shore safely. The Coast Guard cutter Spencer has been ordered to the rescue.

Charles A. Munn of Palm Beach and Paris and Mrs. Jacques Allez of Philadelphia and Paris have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Drexel Munn, to George F. Baker Jr., son of Mrs. George F. Baker of Glen Cove, L. I., and New York, and the late Mr. Baker.

WE live in a difficult time and most of us don't Know what to make of it. As at all such periods, there are those who relieve their bewilderment by turning from the present to the dim and legendary past. Franz Werfel does exactly that in a long and sober novel called "Hearken Unto the Voice."*

Rapid transit, street railway, motor bus and Hudson tube lines operating within the city limits carried 731,484,000 passengers in the three months ended Sept. 30, 1937, according to a summary of company reports, made public yesterday by the Transit Commission.
The resignation of British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden has caused much more concern in France than anything that Chancellor Adolf Hitler said today.
Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Highway Safety in New York State," Walter W. Stokes. Town Hall, 11 A. M. "New Explosives in the Far East," Nathaniel Pfeffer.

The Treasurers Club of America held its annual benefit last night at the Imperial Theatre. The fortyseventh of the series was well attended, and netted the sickness and death funds of the organization about $11,500.
There was extremely poor reception of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech from German long and short wave stations throughout Eastern Europe. The speech was not relayed in Poland.
Outclassing a field of seven starters, Ivan Brown and Bob Washbond, Keene Valley, N. Y., bobsledders, today won the North American two-man bobsled crown.

By a vote of almost two to one, Claude M. Baker, exponent of the American Federation of Labor, yesterday won the endorsement of the local organization (Big Six) of the International Typographical Union for the office of international president over Charles P. Howard, incumbent, and secretary of the C. I. O.
FRENCH MOTION PICTURE CORP., 126 W. 46th St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $21,571 and assets of $160,948.

Representatives of the HondurasNicarargua boundary mediation commission will arrive Tuesday. The members are Foreign Minister Tobias Zuniga Montufar of Costa Rica, Dr. Frank P. Corrigan, United States Minister to Panama, and Jose Santiago Rodriquez of Venezuela.

A warning that a continuing decline in the birth rate in New York City will have serious consequences is given by Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, in the current quarterly bulletin issued by the Department of Health.
Strength in cottonseed oil, talk of inflation and a belief that the peak of the Winter movement of hogs had been passed resulted last week in a somewhat sharp upturn in lard futures.

Despite the sharp warning by Prime Minister Mackenzie King last week, apropos a British Columbia Liberal member's bill calling for the exclusion of Japanese from Canada, that the Dominion should do nothing which Japan might interpret as an Expression of British hostility, another Liberal member will revive the subject tomorrow.

Miss Eleanor Ames Field became the bride of Herbert Woodhouse Wells Jr., son of Mrs. H. W. Wells and the late Mr. Wells, yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bronson Field. The Rev. Dr. David McKeith performed the ceremony.

Ever since he became Foreign Secetary in December, 1935, Anthony Eden had been the center of conflict in the British Cabinet arising not only from his own personality but from the apparent duality in British foreign policy.

Almost all of us love our country but few of us can successfully sing our love. The tune of "America" was borrowed from the English, and we might have borrowed a better one. "The StarSpangled Banner" has its moments,

Maison Cola, Inc, ladies' coats and dresses, store at 44 W. 57th St. through Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc, and L. J. Phillips Co.. brokers. Miwa Trading Co., merchandise brokers, in 460 4th Ave; Michael Koplish,
Defense Minister Edouard Daladier told a Radical Socialist party congress today that adequate defense for France depended on ending social unrest.

The National Supply Company, In its first consolidated annual statement giving effect to capital changes and a merger of the National Supply Company of Delaware and Spang, Chalfant Co., Inc., effected in the year, has reported for 1937 a combined net profit of $7,857,500 after depreciation, interest and Federal income and undistributed profits taxes.

The Lima Locomotive Company sold in January and February of last year 29,200 shares of its conmon stock bought in the market, Samuel G. Allen, chairman, disclosed in his annual report, issued yesterday.

The 295th and 296th Infantry of the Puerto Rican National Guard today moved into camp between Ponce and Santa Isabela on the southern coast to operate as units of a provisional brigade to defend the island against attack in the combined army and navy manoeuvres.
Robert D. van Royen, in 430 E 57th St; Mary French, in 230 E 48th St; Philip S. Pepe, in 136 E 36th St; John Emery, in 3 E 77th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, brokers.

The opening of National Brotherhood Week was marked yesterday by a half-hour radio program over the Columbia network. Taking part were George M. Cohan, Lawrence Tibbett, Deems Taylor, with Al Shean and Frank Green of the cast of "Father Malachy's Miracle," and Andre Kostelanetz and an orchestra.
Proposals designed to give New York City real home rule have been submitted to every delegate to the forthcoming Constitutional Convention, the Merchants Association announced yesterday.

The wheat market managed last week to break out of the rut in which it had been for several weeks, but the change was not considered by many traders conclusive as to the immediate trend, although as a result of rainfall and snow in the Southwest in the last few days, sentiment as a whole is more inclined to the bear side than it had been.

Wimmiam J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company, speaking in favor of an adequate national defense program, predicted in a radio address tonight that "efficient" arming cf America "will not spell menace either to ourselves or others."

Any doubt that Senator Barkley, the Administration leader, faces a reelection battle with Governor A. B. Chandler of Kentucky appeared eliminated tonight when Joseph Leib, a resident of the capital, made public a letter he said he had received from the Governor.
It maybe that the present ills of this old world, which used to regard itself as the center of the universe, are due to an inferiority

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden resigned from the British Cabinet tonight, no longer willing to approve or support the methods of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and a majority of his colleagues in seeking settlements with Italy and Germany.

A national agreement, granting sole collective bargaining rights to the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, a C. I. 0. affiliate, in all plants of the General Electric Company in which the union is designated as majority representative, has been worked out by the company and the C. I. O. group, according to a joint statement, issued yesterday.
Chancellor Hitler in a mili, tant speech to the Reichstag yesterday made a strong point of the right of "self-determination" for the 10,000,000 Germans in Austria and Czechoslovakia.
Francis W. Clarke, executive editor of The Atlanta Constitution, died tonight of pneumonia. His age was 52.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,055,238,900. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

O. G. Schwartz, 50, of 822 Macon Street, Brooklyn, a jewelry salesman, died today after being stricken aboard a chartered fishing boat off shore here. Death was ascribed to a heart attack brought on by acute indigestion. He had arrived here yesterday.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, due today from Southampton via Cherbourg, includes Norman Armour, United States Ambassador to Chile; Count Alfred Potocki, Thomas Mann, German author; Adam Gimbel, Mrs.

The Bank of France's report dated Feb. 10 indicates that holdings of gold were unchanged from a week before and the ratio of gold reserve to circulation was slightly better at 48.39 per cent, compared with 48.32 per cent.
Dr. Roberto M. Ortiz was inaugurated the twenty-first constitutional President of the Argentine Republic this afternoon in a colorful ceremony amid widespread popular acclaim.

Miss Jane Worsley Hartzog, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Hartzog of this city, and Richard Edward Wengren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer L. Wengren of Portland, were married yesterday afternoon in the Pro-Cathedral Episcopal Church of the Nativity.

The engagement of Miss Marjorie R. Grossman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Grossman of 111 East Eighty-first Street, to Eugene H. Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Gordon of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents.

The payroll tax imposed under the Federal old-age insurance program is a device for "distributing poverty among the poor," Abraham Epstein, executive secretary of the American Association for Social Security, asserted in a broadcast last night over Station WEVD.
The fifth of the seven productions due the Theatre Guild's local clientele this season arrives tonight in Fifty-second Street-the much traveled, somewhat harassed "Wine of Choice."

The police announced that two boys exploring a stone quarry at Annet-surMarne, near Meaux, yesterday had found two tons of arms and munitions, including three antitank guns and eighteen machine guns hidden in a cave.

Christians should give "according Among to their means and not according to their meanness," the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared his sermon yesterday.

The desire for a peaceful solution of the Arab and Jewish problems in Palestine was stressed at a meeting last night under the auspices of the Zionist Organization of America in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The texts of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's letter of resignation to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and the Prime Minister's reply follow:

Sixto Escobar of Puerto Rico regained the world bantamweight title tonight with a fifteen-round triumph over Harry Jeffra of Baltimore. The bout was hard fought throughout, although Escobar won by a wide margin and scored three knockdowns, two in the eleventh and one in the fourteenth.

Taking issue with persons who contend that one religion is as good as another, the Rev. Robert E. Woods, preaching yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared that outside the Catholic Church no one could be saved."

To support thirty-five volunteer organizers who are making a house-tohouse canvass of working men's homes in Jersey City in an effort to enlist them in C. I. 0. unions, the New Jersey C. I. O. held a benefit variety show at the Mosque Theatre here tonight.

Leon Tuchel, 49 years old, who had a long police record as a burglar and was wanted in Massachusetts for the shooting of an elderly Sunderland couple, hanged himself in a cell at police headquarters here tonight. Deprived of his belt, necktie and shoe-strings, he used strips of his underwear and his socks to fashion the noose.
Robert Forbes Perkins, retired head of the Boston brokerage firm of Bond Goodwin, died today at his home in Framingham Center at the age of 72.
Louis V. Hoffman has resigned as vice president of N. K. Winston Co. to start his own general realty firm under the name of L. V. Hoffman Co., with offices at 62 West Forty-seventh Street. Mr.
Wherever there is contact with God there is life and a new resurgence of hope, the Right Rev. Dr. Robert E. Campbell said yesterday morning in his sermon at the annual confirmation services of the

More than 1,000 persons gathered at the Riverside Church yesterday afternoon for the forty-eighth annual service of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York commemorating the birth of George Washington and in memory of sixty-four members of the society who died in the last year.

Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, will be the speaker at the dinner of the Furniture Manufacturers' Representatives of New York, to be held tonight in the Hotel Piccadilly.

Vic. Ronchetti slender young Chicagoan who learned his ice skating on park lagoons, was crowned today as the first "grand slam" champion in the forty-eight years of National Amateur Skating Union competition.

Although general wholesale market activity showed a slight decline last week, demand was heavy for certain apparel and accessory items. In the women's apparel field, costume suits were reported to be "best-sellers" at retail, and reorders arrived for these in all price ranges.

Following the usual period of rumors, Metro has announced Mervyn Leroy's first production when he joins that organization next month. Papers are expected to be signed this week for William Faulkner's "The Unvanquished," on which an option has been held for a month.

71st St, 116 W, 19.6x100.5; Charlotte Kirkland to Joseph and August Hellmann, 21 W 97th St; 1st mtg $10,000, 2d $5,250 ($2). 74th St, 439 E, 25x102.2; Frank Carlin to Central Savings Bank, consideration $2,000, foreclosure.

Fashions for Winter and early Spring cruises that are becoming increasingly popular among members of society will be a feature of the entertainment and supper to be held Wednesday at La Conga in aid of the Music Education League. Inc.
A 46-31 triumph over the New York A. C. enabled the Penn A. C. to join the University Club and Crescent A. C. in a three-way tie for first place in the Eastern Athletic Club Basketball League today.

Some 300 erstwhile pushcart. peddlers who have become "merchants" since Mayor La Guardia put a roof over their heads met last night at a dinner at the Rumanian Village, 116 Eldridge Street, to praise the new municipal improvement which they declare has elevated them socially and financially.

In making her annual report on the employment of women, Miss Mary Anderson, chief of the Woman's Bureau of the Department of Labor, stated today that there had de- p veloped the unsound practice of replacing men with women at a lower wage, a practice harmful to the in- J terests of all.

It's almost as bad as a moviegoer at a double feature nudging his partner and remarking, "Let's go. Here's where we came in." Every time one looks at a mile race, there is Glenn Cunningham winning again. It's beginning to get slightly embarrassing.

Manhattan's triumph over St. John's was the outstanding upset of the week, while N. Y. U. handed Fordham its fifth straight intracity defeat to remain at the top in the metropolitan intercollegiate basketball standings with five victories in five starts.

John Wayland, who was formerly for forty years superintendent of construction for Norcross Brothers, builders, died late Friday night at his home, 1,840 Harrison Avenue, Bronx, after a year and a half's illness, at the age of 85. A son, John Jr. of this city, survives.
A British military mission headed by Admiral N. A. Wodehouse arrived here today to arrange a definite basis for Anglo-Portuguese military cooperation.

Rivers cresting at stages far lower than predicted, held out a promise today of an early alleviation of Arkansas floods, which have made an estimated 3,000 to 5,000 persons homeless in the past few days.
Mrs. Skinker Matthews will give a dinner Wednesday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Lady Decies, who will depart on March 2 for her home in Paris.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORE TIMES: The recent brief dispatch of one of your Washington correspondents quotes me as having stated before the House Committee on Naval Affairs that a moderate fleet based on the Aleutians, in Alaska, can defend our West Coast and the Panama Canal better and more economically than a fleet based on Honolulu.
Max Sammet, 43 years old, a dentist, said to have been a German political refugee, was found slain today under the steps of an abandoned residence on the West Side.

Birger Ruud, Olympic and world champion from Norway, was pressed to defeat a brilliant international field in the first "open" ski jumping title tournament sponsored by the National Ski Association today on the Brattleboro Outing Club's improved 60-meter hill.

The widespread interest in home building throughout the country was demonstrated by a flood of letters received by the Department of Commerce following its nation-wide broadcast on Feb. 17 on "American Home Building," the seventeenth in a series of broadcasts on "Stories of American Industry," it was announced today.

Casual nods at the Sportsmen's Show. Alex Rogan of the famous "Old Country" fly-tyers at the Alex Taylor booth, busy at his fly-vise showing visitors some of his secrets. If trout like natural flies they'll certainly fight to get at some of those Alex has on display.

All of Russia is wild with delight and pride over the rescue of the four scientists from the polar ice floe, the effect of which is all the more dramatic because it was not expected until the arrival of the ice breaker Yermak at the floe today or tomorrow.

Waging a bitter offensive through the final ten minutes, the New York Americans sought to erase a onegoal lead held by the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
S. Bruce Black, president of the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, has announced that net premiums written by the company in 1937 amounted to $41,234,762, an increase of $7,586,865 from 1936.

The formation eighteen years ago of the Grand Street Boys Association, an organization of men who went up from the lower East Side to prominence in the city and nation, was celebrated last night at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore, where they were asked to rededicate themselves in a troubled world to a spirit of good-will and fair Play.
I know you and the German people expected to be called together on the fifth anniversary of the National Socialist State.

Cooperatives are "the way out for a world that has been thrown into a condition of chaos by a fundamental error in its economic system," the Rev. Dr. M. M. Coady of St. Francis Xavier College, Antigonish, N. S., declared here today at the opening of a three-day conference on consumer cooperatives.
Edward Frederick Lindley Wood, third Viscount Halifax, who was named tonight to fill temporarily the Foreign Secretaryship, resigned by Anthony Eden, has had a distinguished political career.
The temporary White House was completely silent today on President Roosevelt's reaction to the address of Chancellor Hitler to the German Reichstag.

Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Knowles gave a tea at their home here today at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Barrows Knowles, to Victor John Pollock of New York and Springfield, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Pollock of Springfield.

To meet the challenge to freedom, as "the great issue in the world today," we must advance in our understanding and our practice of freedom, according to the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, Chaplain of Columbia University, preaching yesterday in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
Charles Sherman Haight, an admiralty lawyer well known in this city, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital after an illness of two weeks. His age was 67.

Clifford Odets's "Awake and Sing," put on by the Stage Society tonight, with Basil Langton and Joan Miller in the leading parts, was well received. It is admitted that the play suffered somewhat by the mixed English-American cast and, according to The Daily Telegraph, this "probably accounted for the lack of sharp outline in playing."
From the Galapagos Islands of Ecuador a distress call reached the Coast Guard station at San Pedro today asking help for the new San Diego tuna fishing vessel Liberty with a crew of twenty aboard.
Grover Loening, pioneer aircraft designer and manufacturer, has resigned as aeronautical adviser to the Maritime Commission, a post he has held since May.
League of Nations quarters expressed belief today that Adolf Hitler's Reichstag speech "lacked the usual punch." His statement that Germany would never return to the League caused no surprise.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Smith Drury, rector of St. Paul's School, Concord, N. H., died early this morning at Phillips House here after a short illness. He was in his sixtieth year. Dr. Drury had been rector of the school since 1911.

Heaven, Father Divine's Harlem headquarters, is going to move from the ramshackle five-story tenement at 20 East 115th Street. It has been sold out from under the Negro evangelist's banqueters by the renting agent with whom they did business-on a cash basisto a rival evangelist who wants a heaven of his own.

A tea was given yesterday by a group of friends of Mrs. Dunlap Hopkins at the studio of A. MullerUry, 33 West Sixty-seventh Street, where the artist's portrait of Mrs. Hopkins was shown for the first time.

On the eve of consideration by the House Labor Committee of a new wages and hours bill, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, issued a warning today against the creation of a Federal wage board or the appointment of a Federal wage administrator with broad powers.

Inauguration of a government investment program which would utilize the services of the "eleven million unemployed men and women of the country and the billions of unemployed dollars in its banks" was proposed tonight by Senator La Follette in an address before the second annual convention of the National Lawyers Guild.

Money continues scarce on the Paris market because large amounts are locked up in the purchase of foreign exchange. The tendency, nevertheless, is somewhat easier and the call money rate has fallen from 2 3/4 per cent to 2 and 2 1/2 per cent.
The Camden Yellow Jackets today won the Mid-West polo tournament for the Russell Memorial Trophy, defeating the Camden Ramblers in the deciding game, 7 to 6.

Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., State Commissioner of Health, warned today against the premature use of rabbit serums in the treatment of pneumonia until careful tests have proved their value, safety and limitations.

The total cost of Federal, State and local relief, including work relief but exclusive of administration costs, was about $285,000,000 less in 1937 than in 1936, the Social Security Board announced today.

Miss Janet St. Clair Mullan of 225 East Seventy-ninth Street, daughter of the late State Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. George Vincent Mullan, has chosen March 12 as the date for her marriage to Frederick Geller Duncan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Duncan, also of this city.
Governor Earle tonight offered his aid to 150 families faced with eviction from modest homes owned by the Glen Alden Coal Company.

The news of the resignation of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, reached Rome late this evening and quickly spread throughout the city, causing great satisfaction everywhere, as was to be expected.

Tonight's Cabinet crisis caused a postponement of the Anglo-Irish talks scheduled for tomorrow. As a result Prime Minister Eamon de Valera of Ireland and his Ministerial associates will cool their heels at the Piccadilly Hotel until Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain can find time to meet them.

After a dispute with her mother over a party she had attended last night and a trip she had planned for today, 16-year-old Winifred Orr drank from a bottle of insecticide this afternoon and died before medical aid reached her.

Professor Arthur W. Ewell, wartime chief of the A. E. F. Air Corps bomb unit, in a statement today said that Congress "ought to know" that reports on bomb inventions of Lester P. Barlow have been in War Department files since 1918.

The Public Education Association has approved fewer than a fourth of the eighty bills affecting public schools which are now before the Legislature, according to the monthly bulletin of the organization, which will be published .today.
Yesterday's schedule of dance recitals consisted of three events celebrating the art of as many remote sections of the world, namely, Korea, Hawaii and Spain.

The market for corn on the Board of Trade here showed stubborn resistance to pressure last week, all breaks to around 59 cents a bushel for the May delivery resulting in the development of a European demand which was sufficient to check professional selling and provided commission-house support to offset the effect of hedging sales.

Industrial activity in Great Britain in 1937 was 6.8 per cent greater than in 1936, as measured by the Board of Trade's index, based on 1930 as 100. The level was given as 133.1, against 124.6 in 1936.

A warning that there is a "concerted drive" now under way not only to bring back "undeserving pensions granted prior to March 20, 1933," but to set up entirely new awards for widows and dependents of "practically all World War veterans, regardless of war injuries and regardless of need," was sounded today by John C. Gebhart, director of the National Economy League.

The most formidable perils to American democracy are spiritual in character, the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Farber, pastor of the Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue and Ninety-first Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 30 per cent, unchanged from the two weeks preceding.
The West Side Association of Commerce announced yesterday its board of directors had adopted a resolution disapproving the Schwartzwald bill, which would place a license tax on chain stores.

Permission to cremate the body of Leon Sedoff, son of Leon Trotsky, was refused today by the authorities when his funeral procession, accompanied by thousands of Trotsky followers of all nations, arrived at Pere Lachaise Cemetery.

Police emergency squads were kept busy tying down loose objects in the city yesterday as a sleeting windstorm, with the force of a gale, swept the Northeastern States, causing two deaths here and the loss of two fishermen off the New Jersey coast.

The 180th anniversary of the founding of the East Sixty-eighth Street Reformed Church, known as the "Steuben Church," was celebrated yesterday. The attendance of more than 200 included members of the staff of the German Consulate. The Rev. Julius Jaeger,
Japanese interests are seeking iron properties in Western Mexico, it was confirmed here today by an unimpeachable source.

The board of governors of the men's club of Temple Beth-El canceled by unanimous vote today an invitation to Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, to address its members on March 13 as part of a series of lectures on "Clashing Political Philosophies ."
236th St (17-5039): n s. 30 ft e of Richardson Ave, 30x98; Douglas Mathewson, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp, 350 5th Ave. Van Nest Ave, 1,207 (15-4120); Joseph F. Kroppy. referee. to same.

Appearing for the first time under their own auspices, the new, Untitled cooperative group that acted "Plant in the Sun" three weeks ago repeated that play last evening at the Mercury Theatre on a bill with Marc Blitzstein's radio drama, "I've Got the Tune."

Announcement was made today that Miss Isobel Ramsey Nisbet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Nisbet of this place, would be married to Dr. Francis Edward Reinhart of Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Reinhart of this town, on March 26.

A star-studded concert, described deservedly as "gala," was presented last night at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the American Guild of Musical Artists. The capacity audience heard a wide range of music, both vocal and instrumental, classic and contemporary.

Dr. Sigfried Giedion, Swiss historian of art and one of the leading European figures in the promotion of modern architecture and art, has been appointed Charles Eliot Norton Professor of Poetry at Harvard University for the current academic year, it was announced here tonight.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Julia Lane Alexander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Alexander of this place, to Robert Bogue Bell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcul L. Bell of Noroton.

The Board of Trade's annual estimate of Great Britain's overseas balance of visible and invisible trade in 1937 shows that the net result was a deficit of [Pound]52,000,000, compared with a deficit of [Pound]18,000,000 in 1936, a credit of [Pound]32,000,000 in 1935, a deficit of [Pound]7,000,000 in 1934 and an even balance in 1933.

Sterling Products, Inc., has reported for 1937 a net profit of $9,016,243 after all charges, including interest, depreciation and all taxes. This is equivalent to $5.28 a share on 1,705,150 shares outstanding at the end of the year.

The two leading teams of the circuit were upset as the tail-end Visitations trounced the second-place Jewels, 42 to 41, and the Celtics conquered the pace-setting Philadelphia Sphas, 43 to 25, in an American Basketball League doubleheader before a crowd of 5,000 at the Hippdrome last night.

A warning against contemporary paganism and a plea to men and women everywhere to "give fresh consideration to the claims of religion for these critical days" is contained in an open letter to residents of Essex County, made public today by the Essex County Conference of Catholics, Jews and Protestants.
Swiss voted by an overwhelming majority today to establish Romansh as the fourth official language of Switzerland.

A goal by Leroy Goldsworthy with only seventy-one seconds left to play tonight gave the Boston Bruins a spectacular uphill 3-2 victory over the New York Rangers and a commanding 7-point lead in the American division of the National Hockey League.
Led by Martin Fopp, sixteen men broke the former record today in the Parsenn Ski Derby, the world's longest downhill race. The record that was so roughly manhandled had stood for five years.

Because the State of Ohio lacks funds to pay for his return, William Baker, who escaped four years ago from an Ohio penitentiary, where he was serving a ten to twenty year sentence for robbery, will not have to go back there to complete his term, it became known here yesterday.
L. F. Sanman and Roger Fawcett figured in a keen duel for highover-all laurels at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday.

Liberty always has a mob with her but she also needs aristocrats, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, pastor, said in his sermon yesterday at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.

The distinct anti-British tenor of Adolf Hitler's speech came as somewhat of a shock here today, since many persons had expected, in view of the Reichsfuehrer's Austrian triumph, it would be milder in tone.

Losing their footing in a friendly jostling bout early today, Alfred Bowditch Hallowell, 24 years old, a Harvard instructor, and Philip Saltonstall Weld, 22, of Chicago, a fellow-alumnus, plunged two flights down the stairwell of the Porcellian Club in Harvard Square.

Faith must fight fear, which is a dangerously developing complex today, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday.

The Senate leadership is planning another effort tomorrow to set aside the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill which, save for the consideration of the conference reports on the Farm and Housing Bills, has occupied the attention of the Senate since Jan. 3.
Detroit's Red Wings brightened their Stanley Cup play-off chances tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 1 to 0, in a fast and rough National Hockey League battle before 14,650 spectators.

Defeating the Ponta Delgado Football Club of Fall River by 7-0 at Starlight Park yesterday, the Brookhattan soccer team qualified for the semi-finals of the annual National Challenge Cup competition. They will meet the New York Americans next Sunday.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 75.5 on Feb. 16, compared with 76.2 a fortnight before, 77.2 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Gimbel's, Macys, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

In one of the oddest uphill fights on record, Warren Ingersoll of Philadelphia overcame Clarence C. Pell Jr. in the national amateur racquets championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday after E. M. (Ted) Edwards, former titleholder from the same city, had averted defeat by two strokes in the third game to vanquish Raymond Lumb of England at 14-17, 8-15, 15-13, 15-5, 15-11.

Glenwood Jones, 46 years old, of 485 Gramatan Avenue, Mount Vernon, N. Y., died in Roosevelt Hospital last night of injuries received when he was knocked down by an automobile at Broadway and Sixtysixth Street at about 2:30 A. M., Saturday. He never regained consciousness.

Governor A. Harry Moore denied here today that he had vetoed the three Pascoe Assembly bills affecting the gross receipts taxes of public utility companies. Reports of the veto appeared yesterday in dispatches from Trenton.
Because of the present complications in Austria, Chancellor Kurt von Schuschnigg's "Austria Old and New" is being rushed into type for early publication by Knopf.

Of the $11,763,004,000 of investments by 5,266 active national banks in the United States, Alaska, Hawaii and the Virgin Islands, on Dec. 31, only $3,690,122,000 was represented by other than government or municipal securities, according to a digest of the last call for statements of condition by J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, the results of which he made public today.
When the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company acquired the outstanding common stocks of the Nassau and Suffolk Lighting Company and the Long Beach Gas Company in 1927,
In the face of a substantial national surplus, California's Winter orange crop will move into the market in the next four months.

The Museum of Modern Art announces two more exhibitions for the current season-the first of architecture and furniture, by the Finnish designer Alvar Aalto. At the same time there will be shown nearly 100 drawings of the war in Spain by the Spanish artist Luis Quintanilla.

Alex Rose, State executive secretary of the American Labor party, announced yesterday that George Field had resigned as his assistant to become program director of Radio Station WEVD. The appointment will become effective Feb. 28.

Against the advice of the Board of Tax Appeals and the Second Circuit Court, the Interpal Revenue Bureau is trying to tax salaries of employes of the Port of New York Authority and has asked the Supreme Court to consider the question.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 18: CAPTAIN May, H. A., Med. Corps, Philadelphia, Pa., to home and relieved of all active duty, May 19.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Feb. 21 unless specified: At Manila--old Star, Feb. 16; Marblehead, Feb. 18. At San Diego-Wright, Feb. 19; Kanawha, Neches. Singapore to Malampaya Sound-Memphis, Milwaukee, Trenton.
William D. in Goold, head of the carriage making firm which made many of the bodies for the first automobiles, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 83.

A. E. Watt of the New York A. C. gained the semi-final round of the Eastern Association Group I squash racquets championship when he vanquished Ray Fiske, Bayside, 15-8, 17-16, 7-15, 17-14, yesterday at the City A. C.
All buses in this city of 165,000 were idle today as drivers and other employes of the Flint Trolley Coach, Inc., struck for the second time within fourteen months.
For a short while yesterday the aroma of sizzling pancakes brought recollections of camp life to the visitors at the National Sportsmen's Show.

The Alumni Association of Wagner College, on Staten Island, held its first annual dinner last night at the Hotel Beekman Tower. The Rev. George Aus, pastor of Trinity Lutheran Church, Brooklyn, who is president of the association, presided.
Two government agencies--the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Controller of the Currency--are battling each other before the United States Supreme Court.

The Board of Tax Appeals agreed with Richard F. Howe of Chicago and his son, William Deering Howe of Brookville, N. Y., today that their Belmont Park racing stable was a business enterprise for which they could make expense deductions in reports on their taxable income.
The Senate voted to lay aside the Anti-Lynching Bill, ending the thirty-day filibuster, began debate on the $250,000,000 Deficiency Relief Bill and recessed at 5:29 P. M. until noon tomorrow.

Sir Josiah Stamp, chairman and president of the London, Midland Scottish Railway, will speak on "Key Factors in the Economic Outlook" at a luncheon of the British Empire Chamber of Commerce in the British Empire Building on March 1.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Feb. 12 amounted to 304,915,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

Carlo Tresca, veteran radical and leader of the Italian anti-fascists in the United States, appeared yesterday before the Federal grand jury investigating the Robihson-Rubens passport fraud and presented testimony bearing both on the subject of the investigation and the mysterious disappearance. last June of Juliet Stuart Poyntz, former Communist leader.
Dr. Raleigh Russell Huggins, dean of the University of Pittsburgh Medical School, died here yesterday at the age of 68.
Taxes must be paid for 1936 by the trustees of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association of Newark, the State Supreme Court ruled today.
Lead production in the United States in January amounted to 39,196 tons, compared with 49,581 in December and 43,626 in January, 1937, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.

A General Sessions jury acquitted Lawrence Sullivan, 22 years old, of 59 Montgomery Street last night on a first-degree murder indictment in the shooting of Dr. Boris Schwartzburt, 28, on the night of May 31, 1937, in the victim's drug store at 223 Monroe Street. When the verdict was returned Judge George L. Donnellan denounced police tactics in the case.
Mrs. W. Mitchell Digges of Laplata, Md., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Jenkins Digges, to Calvin Harrington Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrington of Cambridge, Md.

Anthony Eden's resignation as British Foreign Secretary coupled with what Russians considered Britain's capitulation to aggressor nations was regarded tonight in Soviet circles as heightening the danger of European war.

A manifesto signed by 170 Protestant ministers condemning antiSemitism as a sin and a threat to democracy and pledging opposition to anti-Jewish trends was made public yesterday by Dr. Robert W. Searle, general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

The Class I railroads have 6,563 freight cars on order from private companies, under construction in Their own shops or in process of rebuilding, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday. This compared with 7,947 on Jan. 1.
Scenes in Vienna streets tonight resulted in an official prohibition of all political meetings except those of the Fatherland Front. The first to be affected will be the legitimists,

Outlining a campaign for greater highway safety in New York, State Senator Walter W. Stokes of Cooperstown stressed a three-point program yesterday before the School of Politics of the Women's National Republican Club at 3 West Fiftyfirst Street.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine a writer spoke of President Roosevelt's "inexplicable" avidity for reading Government reports,

Reassessment of land and property values in Nassau County to increase the present valuation by about onethird will be undertaken soon, J. Russel Sprague, county executive, announced here today at a meeting of the Board of Supervisors.
Action upon the nomination of Robert H. Jackson as Solicitor General was postponed today by the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee because printed reports of a hearing were not available.

General Sessions Judge Freschi yesterday adjourned until next Friday argument on the motion of Samuel Leibowitz, defense counsel, for discharge of the lunacy commission appointed in August to examine Robert Irwin. 29 years old, the sculptor, under three first-degree murder indictments.

Senator Yves Le Trocquer, former Minister of Public Works, died today at his Paris residence. His age was 60. Senator Le Trocquer began his career as an engineer, entering politics in his early forties.

An unconstitutionality plea has been presented to the Cuban Supreme Court by Dr. Rafael Ramos Grau against the recently approved law providing for the settlement of the long defaulted public works obligations.

Three men convicted by a jury Feb. 4 of attempting to extort $250 from a grocery store proprietor at 189 Sutter Avenue, Brooklyn, by promising to withdraw a picket line from in front of the store, were sentenced yesterday to serve penitentiary terms by Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato.

The arrival of the British Trade Mission, which reached Washington yesterday to begin formal negotiations with the United States Government, marks the approaching climax of the Administration's efforts to foster an expansion of international trade by mutual tariff concessions.
Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's resignation is deplored here as the final blow to the League of Nations policy for many years loyally practiced by The Netherlands.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 16:

Members of the Old Guard society of Palm Beach golfers gave their annual dinner tonight at the Breakers, where trophies for all golf tournaments thus far concluded were presented by Blaine Zuver, president. Former Governor A. O.
A "Great Japan Movement," which has been started to promote the spiritual mobilization of the nation, was inaugurated today with much pomp.

The House passed today a bill that would extend the Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Moratorium Act for two years from its expiration date next March 3. Last July the Senate made the Moratorium Act permanent.

The marriage of Miss Zella Weldon Lamont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Garfield Lamont of Flushing, Queens, to Robert Edwin Skippon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Skippon of Brooklyn, took place last night in the Church on the Hill, Flushing.

Legislation pending in Albany which would tax chain stores in the State from $10 to $250 per store is a "serious menace to the economic welfare of New York," according to Frank O'Hara, Jackson Heights realty man and president of the Real Estate Association of New York.

Four men, two of them armed, held up Simon Balitzer in his jewelry store at 435 Knickerbocker Avenue, in the Ridgewood section of Brooklyn, last night, bound the jeweler with wire, gathered up several thousand dollars' worth of articles from his stock and escaped in an automobile.

In the period January through August, 1937, sixty-one persons filed Federal returns covering net incomes of more than $1,000,000, as compared with forty-one in the previous year, the Treasury announced today.
With the end of public hearings on the Administration's $1,000,000,000 naval construction program in sight, the House Committee on Naval Affairs expects to report the bill. . .

The engagement of Miss Jean Taylor Price, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Taylor Price of Cincinnati, to Robert Miner Gillespie, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick Gillespie of Shippan Point, Stamford, Conn., has been announced by her parents.

Nils Eie, world's intercollegiate skiing champion from Norway, cut fancy capers on the fast Mount Whitney course today to annex premier honors in the open giant slalom race that marked the opening of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' seventeenth annual invitation tournament.
George J. Miller, who thirty years ago encircled the globe as a mechanic of a victorious around-theworld race car, died here today at the age of 55.

Although a funeral service and burial for Mrs. Harriet Brown Neilsen, once champion swimmer, were scheduled for yesterday afternoon, officials of the Bellevue Morgue refused to surrender the body and said they intended to hold it for another twenty-four hours, pending word from relatives in California.

Throughout Canada, but more particularly in political circles here, Anthony Eden's resignation as Foreign Secretary at London, following hard on Reichsfuehrer Hitler's minatory speech, caused a profound sensation.
A field of about ninety players is expected to compete in the Mid- S Ocean Golf Club's fifth annual tournament starting Thursday.

Norman Armour, United States Ambassador to Chile, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary with Mrs. Armour after a vacation in Europe. The ambassador said he would go to Washington.

Poland's Golden Cross of Merit was conferred yesterday on Miss Grace Humphrey, author, who is widely known in university circles here, at a ceremony yesterday at the Polish Consulate at 151 East Sixty-seventh Street.

Crispin Oglebay's Question, ridden by Courtney Burton of the Chagrin Valley Hunt, Cleveland, took first place in the working hunter class at the tenth annual hunter trials held today under the auspices of the Camden Hunt.

Tommy Henrich, capable young outfielder acquired by the Yankees after being declared a free agent by Judge Landis last year, is prepared to give Myril Hoag and Jake Powell a battle for a regular berth this season, according to word which came from Massillon, Ohio, yesterday.
The single-family house retains its hold on the affections of the residents of the conservative New England States more strongly than on the families of any other section of the country.

The four-story apartment house at 2 Lockwood Avenue, corner of New Rochelle Road, East Chester, was sold by the Dry Dock Savings Institution to Lockwood Court, Inc. Sale was for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $73,500 for ten years.
The newspaper Hochi Shimbun reported today that the commandant of the Tsurugga fortified zone had forcibly boarded and examined a Russian ship found anchored in the Hakodate harbor after a snowstorm.

Nine 3-year-olds, six of them nominated for the $20,000 added Flamingo Stakes next Saturday, raced in the six-furlong Lake Wales Purse at Hialeah Park today, but none of the eligibles for the big race finished in the money.

Elton E. (Tad) Wieman, for the past six years chief aide to Fritz Crisler, last night was named head football coach at Princeton, filling the vacancy left by Crisler's sudden departure to Michigan less than two weeks ago.

James Butler, founder of the first American chain of grocery stores and for many years a prominent figure of the American turf, left a net estate of $5,091,565 when he died Feb. 28, 1934, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

From the tenor of our dispatches from the Argentine it is clear that the good-will flight of the six huge B-17 planes of the Army Air Corps to Buenos Aires in honor of the inauguration of President Roberto M. Ortiz was a happy inspiration.

The metal report of Brandeis, Goldschmidt Co., Ltd., of London for 1937 estimated that the world consumption of raw copper last year was 2.230,000 tons, a new high level. Consumption outside the United States was placed at 1,500,000 tons, also a record, and in the United States was estimated at 730,000 tons.

Members of Columbia College's student board, after a conference yesterday afternoon with Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, university president, announced that Dr. Butler had promised a written reply to their request that he apologize to the Young Communist League for denying permission to Robert Burke, ousted student, to speak at a campus meeting of the organization Friday night.

The National Maritime Union accepted formally a charter from the Committee for Industrial Organizatio- at a mass meeting last night of members of all three of its branches, at the Manhattan Plaza, 66 East Fourth Street.

The first "casualty" in the campaign for President that Paul V. McNutt, High Commissioner to the Philippines, has returned home to promote is Lieut. Col. Davenport Johnson, an outstanding army aviator and commandant at Hamilton Field, Calif.

Alfred Warner Dater, vice chairman of the board of the Connecticut Power Company, and chairman of the Stamford Gas and Electric divisional committee of the company, died at his home, 178 Strawberry Hill Avenue, this morning. He was 65 years old.

Arthur D. Langlie, Mayoralty candidate opposing this city's powerful labor forces, swept the city with a landslide vote in today's municipal primary election, previously described as of possible national significance.
Renominations of six members of the State Judicial Council were confirmed tonight by the Senate soon after their transmission by Governor Lehman.

At yesterday's meeting of the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the outgoing class of trustees, consisting of Stephen Carlton Clark, Arnold Whitridge, Myron C. Taylor and Elihu Root Jr., was re-elected as the class of 1945.

GEHRUNG, FREDERICK (Dec. 29). Estate, not more than $10,000. To Henrietta Gehrung, widow and executrix, 31 Hamilton Ter. JONUSCHEIT, JOHANNA (Nov. 23). Estate, less than $10,000. To Bertha Blatter, sister, and executrix, 1,689 2d Ave., residue.
Twenty-five carpenters who volunteered their services, without pay, were at work today rebuilding the plant of the Salem Box Manufacturing Company, which was destroyed by fire set by labor arsonists.

The stock market here, affected by the political developments at home and abroad, was generally quiet today and dullness was evident in most sections. Gilt-edge issues lost ground, but among the foreign loans German bonds advanced.

A report opposing abolition of the blue-ribbon jury system was accepted yesterday by the City Club of New York. Prepared by the courts committee of the club and presented by Howard C. Kelly, the chairman, the report declared that there is a real need for special juries, pending certain improvements in the jury system.
The Rev. Martin Niemoeller, it is understood on fairly reliable authority, is receiving much better treatment from the court since the resumption of his trial Friday.

A three-day "boycott strike" of twenty-five or more National Press Club members, in protest against suspension of a bartender who allegedly gave away a drink in violation of a standing order, ended tonight.

Destruction of coffee in Brazil in 1937 reached the high figure of 17,196,428 bags, swelling to 56,728,914 bags the total eliminated since June, 1931, according to a consular report from Rio de Janeiro made public today by the Department of Commerce. Stocks at Brazilian ports at the end of last year amounted to 3,210,865 bags.

The National Labor Relations Board ordered the Zenite Metal Corporation of Indianapolis, manufacturer of auto stampings, moldings, grilles and other metal products, today, to set aside its closed shop contract with the International Association of Machinists, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, and to bargain with the United Auto Workers of America, a C. I. O. unit.

The upward movement, which has been under way since the pre-notice day covering of March obligations became general two weeks ago, swept prices on the Cotton Exchange into new high ground yesterday, and to the highest levels since mid-September.

For more than three hours today the Court of Appeals heard arguments on a test case to decide whether New York City must operate during 1938 on the budget approved by the Democratic Board of Estimate or that approved by the Fusion board which came into control this year.

Mike Jacobs, head of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club of New York, not only lost the services of a champion but money when Sixto Escobar took the world bantamweight title from Harry Jeffra last night. The gate grossed only $13,900, it was learned today.

Harry Cooper, on top from the first nine holes, rode par through stiff north winds today to beat his field by four strokes and win the $5,000 72-hole Crescent City open tournament. He pocketed $1,200 first money.
The Acampo Winery and Distilleries, Inc., Acampo, Calif., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 37,596 shares of $5 par common stock,
The Senate today ended the thirty-day Southern filibuster against the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill by voting, 58 to 22, to lay it aside to take up the $250,000,000

Gifts to the Yale Gallery of Fine Arts which will be placed on exhibition in honor of the twenty-fifth annual Alumni Day tomorrow were announced today. The donors will include Richard C. Hunt, New York City, Yale Law School, '08; Edward B. Greene, '00, of Cleveland; Mrs.
Several hundred persons were present tonight at the third dance of the Winter series at the naval training station and auditorium in observance of the Washington Birthday anniversary. Captain H. E.

Germany's decision to recognize Manchukuo is considered here, both by Chinese and foreign observers, the most powerful push to the Left that China has received since the Sian coup against Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek fourteen months ago.

Joseph T. Zingalis, 21 years old, who lent money to ERB clients at what amounted to 1,040 per cent a year, was sentenced to thirty days in the work house yesterday in Queens Special Sessions Court. Zingalis had pleaded guilty to violating the State Banking Laws in that he was not licensed to make loans and charged usurious interest.

Stocks disregarded European news and closed steady and higher; turnover, 758,871 shares. Austrian and Philippine railway bonds declined sharply, other issues dull in smallest dealings in six months; transactions, $4,536,525.

A capacity audience including many women of prominence in society is expected at the benefit performance of "Tristan und Isolde" this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. The performance has been taken over in behalf of the New York Diet Kitchen Association to aid that organization's

Among the apartment leases reported yesterday was one for eleven rooms in the new apartment house at 19 East Seventy-second Street, taken by Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade, Inc.
The Chinese Government strongly protested today against German recognition of Manchukuo, the Japanese dominated State carved out of China's Manchurian provinces in 1931-33.

As a preliminary to the contemplated conscription of all German girls for the women's labor service, Field Marshal Hermann Goering, as the head of the Four-Year Plan, announced today the formal introduction of one-year service duty in household or farm work for all working girls under 25.
The Interstate Commerce Commission ratified today the appointment of H. B. Stewart Jr. as trustee for the Akron, Canton Youngstown Railway Company and the Northern Ohio Railway Company.

Representatives of several civic and trade groups will attend a meeting of the Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards tomorrow at 4 P. M. at the Hotel Commodore to protest against the Bulkley-Ives bill now before the Legislature.
Mr. and Mrs. William Russell Grace, who have been passing the Winter in Aiken, S. C., will return Friday to be at the Waldorf-Astoria before going to The Crossroads, their home in Old Westbury.

A son, their second child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Ashley Chanler of 141 East Nineteenth Street, yesterday at the Doctors Hospital. Mrs. Chanler is the former Princess Maria Antonia de Braganga, daughter of the late Duke Miguel de Braganca and his second wife, the late Duchess Theresa de Braganca.

Applicants eligible for benefits under the State Unemployment Insurance Law who have lost their jobs because of a strike, lockout or other industrial controversy in the establishment in which they were employed will not be subject to a waiting period of more than three weeks after the controversy is ended, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, announced today.

Fifteen hundred delegates to National Retail Liquor Package Stores Association today were warned against illegal and unethical trade practices by Captain Wilford S. Alexander, Administrator of the Federal Alcohol Administration, who told them that already the government is planning new laws for stricter control of the liquor business throughout the country.

The Merchants Association or New York protested today to members of the New York Congressional delegation a proposal to authorize the Maritime Commission to regulate rates on the New York State barge canal system without extending the regulation to other inland waterway systems.
About 200 Hungarian Nazis of the group headed by Major Ferenc Szalasi were arrested tonight in a police raid of their headquarters. Two truckloads of propaganda and lists of members were seized.

The Assembly passed unanimously tonight the Wadsworth bill prohibiting either the State or local Civil Service Commissions from fixing arbitrary age limits for entrance into the civil service, except for positions requiring unusual physical ability, such as those of policeman and fireman.

More than 300 attended the Washington Birthday dance of the Century Club tonight at the Miami Biltmore Country Club. Guests of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril A. Vivian included Mrs. Robert E. Lee, widow of a grandson of the general.

BARNETT--Amanda May on Feb. 21, 1938; survived by three brothers and three sisters. Services to be held at her residence. S9-20 98th St., Woodhaven, on Wednesday, 8 P. M. Funeral Thursday, 2 P. M Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery.
Clear weather and slowly rising temperatures were promised for today, the 206th anniversary of the birth of George Washington, first President of the United States.
An extraordinary grand jury began its once-postponed inquiry into Buffalo city affairs today after Supreme Court Justice George A. Larkin declined to question the legality of its two women members.
A lame duck without known political affiliations caused a mild uproar about 5:15 P. M. yesterday in a car of a B. M. T. Sea Beach train between Fourteenth and Thirty-fourth Streets.
Postmaster General James A. Farley has sold his autobiography to The American Magazine, it was learned yesterday, and it will appear soon in that periodical in serial form.

Several parcels of vacant and improved properties will be sold at auction by Joseph P. Day March 1, in the Vesey Street salesroom. The properties include the five story flat at the southeast corner of Columbus Avenue and 103d Street and the adjoining residence
5th St, 815 E, 6-story tenement, 26.8x97; Bank of New York and Trust Co against Anna Josephson; due, $20,510; taxes, etc, $845; to plaintiff for $20,158.

The National League ball of 1938, designed to differ slightly from that used by the American League, will travel just as far this year when hit right as the ball used jointly by the two leagues last season.

A man and a woman, listed by the police as Joseph Gerschner, 36 years old, and Josephine Kotva, 30, both of 55 Central Park West, were arrested yesterday in connection with the theft of jewelry valued at $9,000 last Jan. 30 from the apartment of Louis Baumgold at the Central Park West address.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that the Republican-controlled Common Council of Yonkers must adopt the 1938 municipal budget of $16,375,411 submitted to it by Mayor Joseph F. Loehr. Democrat.
A net profit of $1,505,430 was reported yesterday for the year 1937 by the American News Company and its subsidiaries, after deductions for depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges.

The stock market turned in a typical pre-holiday session yesterday, and after exhibiting some slight nervousness at the opening, settled down to a dull day of trading. Prices at the close were up as much as 2 points in the more active issues.

A general right face westward by the Japanese columns that have been pushing southward in Northern Honan Province was reported at local Chinese military headquarters yesterday. It was said the Japanese had generally slowed down their southward drive at all points and were - spreading out across the province toward the Shansi border.
General Stanislas Skwarzynski, leader of the National movement, tonight followed up Chancellor Hitler's demand for colonies with a declaration that Poland also needed more territory.

Buying interest in real estate is keener now than it has been for Ba several months despite the fact that the market, as gauged by the number and quality of recorded transactions, appears to be devoid of color or promise, W. J. Brede points out in the March market letter of the New York Title Insurance Company.

Peter Archdeacon Grevatt of 220 Christopher Street died here today in the Mountainside Hospital of heart disease at the age of 63. He was president of Grevatt Brothers, Inc., general exporters, 73 West Street, New York, and of the Plaza Provision Company of San Juan, Puerto Rico.
Following is the text of the address of Anthony Eden, former Foreign Secretary, in the House of Commons today:

A Federal statutory court of three judges heard argument today on a petition for an injunction against enforcement of an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission excluding Newark, Elizabeth, Linden, Carteret and Perth Amboy from the New York metropolitan trucking zone.
The designation of Jose Maria Cantilo as Minister of Foreign Affairs in the new Argentine Government has found almost unanimous approval here.

More than $1,000,000,000 a year is spent by Americans in illegal lotteries, policy games and other gambling, both domestic and foreign according to Mrs. Oliver C. Hare riman, president of the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries.
Explosions heard from within Teruel tonight indicated Government forces surrounded in the besieged city were blowing up their munitions dumps as fighting raged at close quarters in the outskirts.
Announcements by New York brokerage firms which will be open for business today follow: Thomson McKinnon will be open all day for foreign and Canadian business.
J. Donald Budge, returning from a tour of Australia with three other California tennis associates, made it plain today that he had no thought of turning professional this year.

Advisory Master in Chancery Dougal Herr granted permission here today to Julius Frankel of Linden, N. J., to attend a hearing scheduled for next Friday in Children's Court, Brooklyn, to determine who shall have custody of Howard Frankel, his 12-year-old son.

The German appetite for expansion of territory and power will not be satisfied with the Nazification of Austria, and this will be succeeded by more bold steps, William E. Dodd, former United States Ambassador to Berlin, said here tonight.
The 265 nurses on the staff of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service made 545,900 visits to the homes of 92,554 patients in 1937, according to a report made public yesterday.

MANHATTAN BUTLER, JAMES (Feb. 20, 1934). Gross assets, $7,618,019; net, $5,091,565. To Convent of the Sacred Heart of Mary. Tarrytown, N. Y., $100,000; the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum of New York, $10,000; Frederick S. Rogan, William P. Rogan, Ann J. Rogan and Elizabeth M. Rogan, $5,000 each; Beatrice K. Mcguire, Genevieve F. Travers,
The Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn recently disposed of thirty-one Brooklyn and Queens properties, announces R. D. Barker.
The Philadelphia Record this morning in a dispatch from

Dr. Samuel Smith Drury, rector of St. Paul's School, Concord, N. H., and a noted churchman, educator and author, died early today of a blood clot in an artery near his heart at the Phillips House of the Massachusetts General Hospital. His age was 59.
Harry Richards, who piloted Rosemont to victory in the Santa Anita Handicap last year, today became the outstanding candidate to ride Seabiscuit in the $100,000-added race on March 5.

Westchester County is not the unusually expensive place to live that most residents believe, County Budget Commissioner William D. Folger said today in releasing the first of four tables he is preparing on comparative living costs in the metropolitan area.
Fred Heneberry, Australian middleweight, outpointed Young Stuhley of California in a twelve-round

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for March 10 at its offices here on an application by the Greenville Electric Company, Greenville, Ohio, for exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration covering the issuance of three promissory notes in the amount of $354,332,

Final rehearsals are being held for the production of the historical pageant, "England's Hourglass," to be presented on Sunday night at the Lyceum Theatre under the auspices of the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York.

Elizabeth Ernst Fosbinder has purchased from the estate of S. Harold Freeman a tract of 223 acres with extensive frontage on Hardscrabble Road, lying partly in Bernards Township, Somerset County, and partly in Harding Township, Morris County, N. J.
Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's retirement from the British Cabinet has drawn no tears in German official quarters.

Cocker spaniels held the attention of a large gallery this afternoon at Mechanics Building, this being the breed with the largest entry in the twenty-sixth annual exhibition of the Eastern Dog Club, which opened this morning and will continue through tomorrow evening.
Osaka Shosen Kaisha has fourteen fast motorships, including two silk express boats for the Japan-Los Angeles-New York run, under construction in Japan, according to reliable reports here.

There will be a hearing today before the Assembly Judiciary Committee on the bills carrying out the recommendations of the Judicial Council to abolish special juries. These measures have been passed by the Senate, possibly in the expectation that they would be killed in the Assembly.

An indirect blood transfusion between Robert L. Ferguson Jr., twenty-two-year-old Canadian, who incurred a charge of illegal entry to aid his ill sister, and the girl, Mrs. Hazel Dumagan, 18, was accomplished in the psychiatric division of Bellevue Hospital shortly after 8 o'clock last night.

Manhattan Alterations 101st St, 60 E; to two 5-story tenements; C. Rouse Estate, 43 Leonard St, owner; W. L. Rouse, architect; cost $4,000. Madison Ave, 1; to 11-story offices; Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, premises, owner; N. A. Richards, engineer; cost, $5,000. 3d St, 85 E; to 5-story tenement and store; Elak Realty Corp, 188 Avenue B, owner; E. K. Herzog, architect; cost, $54,000.

Speaker Herbert J. Pascoe of the House of Assembly issued warrants tonight for three members of the election board of the Ninth district of the Third Ward in Jersey City and directed that the State police produce them before the Young investigating committee at the Essex County Court House in Newark on Wednesday at 11 A. M.

Directors of the Motor Products Corporation, scheduled to meet tomorrow, have postponed their meeting because of inability to obtain a quorum. Robert F. Camden has joined the municipal department of Doyle, O'Connor Co.

Knocked down for a nine count in the first round, Abe Simon, gigantic New York heavyweight, came back tonight and won the decision in ten rounds from Big Jim Thompson, California Negro. Simon weighed 250, Thompson 232 3/4.
Replying to Mayor La Guardia's attack on the Transit Commission in his address before the City Affairs Committee, the commission yesterday issued a statement charging that the Mayor's opposition...

Prime Minister Chamberlain, helped by Italian acceptance of the British plan on "volunteers" in Spain, yesterday whipped his large majority in the House of Commons into line behind his policy of conciliating the dictatorships.

Hadji Butu, religious head of all Mohammedans in the southern Philippine archipelago, died today at his residence at Jolo. Princess Dayang Dayang, sister of the late Sultan of Sulu and now one of the two Sultanas of Sulu, was at his bedside when he died of a kidney ailment.

Major L. L. B. Angas, British economist and an investment consultant, now situated in New York, testified before the House Banking and Currency Committee today in favor of Representative Goldsborough's bill for the control of commodity prices through the issue of $10,000,000,000 in "interbank" currency as a revolving fund for the maintenance of buying power among retail consumers.

Exercise by the Federal Government of broader powers for the regulation and restriction of business and for the protection of the people of the country in their civil and economic rights was predicted today by Representative Maury Maverick, Texas Democrat, and demanded in resolutions adopted at the second annual convention of the National Lawyers Guild.
The American Federation of Hosiery Workers has won a closed-shop agreement at the Apex Hosiery Company's mill, largest in the city, effective March 4.

The Boys High School basketball team strengthened its hold on third place in the. Brooklyn Section I race in the P. S. A. L. when it defeated Franklin K. Lane, 35 to 19, on the winner's court yesterday. It marked the seventh victory in ten starts. Bert Smith of Boys led the scorers with 10 points.

The situation in Europe resulting from Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech of Sunday and the resignation of Great Britain's Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, followed by the turbulent session in the House of Commons, provoked suggestions of a crisis in European affairs which was featured yesterday by a flight

Supreme Court Justice Henry G. Wenzel Jr. in Brooklyn granted yesterday a temporary injunction restraining the Retail Dairy, Grocers and Fruit Employes Union, Local 338, a C. I. O. affiliate, from picketing the Buy-Wise Markets, Inc., of 824 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

Reargument of the case of White, Weld Co., et al., charged with the manipulation of the stock of the A. O. Smith Corporation on the New York Curb in 1935 while the firm held an option for the placement of 10,000 shares with investors,
A $7,000 mortgage on 1,854 2d Ave, held by the trustees of the will of Rose Gruening from the Second Avenue Dev. Co, Inc, was extended to Feb 1, 1943, at 5%.
A Washington's Birthday dance was held at the Town Hall Club last night for members and their guests.

An exhibition of landscapes Dy Renoir opened yesterday at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street. It will continue until March 18, but the gallery will be closed today. There are eleven canvases, belonging to various periods;
General agreement with prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's thesis that conversations with Italy do not mean that Britain is knuckling under to her was expressed in pro-government newspapers today.

Several more non-union workers, completing cumulative testimony begun last week, testified today at the Federal Labor Board hearing of the Bethlehem Steel case that the great majority of employes themselves refused to work with certain C. I. O. men after last June's strike, and that the company had nothing to do with the agitation against these strikers.
The annual drive for funds for the Brooklyn Council of the Boy Scouts of America was begun at a luncheon yesterday at the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn.

Miss Jean Pearsall and Robert Buck, air transport pilot, were married this evening in the First Methodist Church here after a postponement from Saturday because of the grounding of a plane on which Mr. Buck was traveling as a passenger from the West.
Referring to Austria as the "Ethiopia of Europe," Thomas Mann, German author who won the Nobel Prize in literature and who now is a voluntary exile from the Third

President Roosevelt reaffirmed his intention to further "a constructive and fruitful policy of inter-American cooperation" in a cordial letter of congratulations to Roberto M. Ortiz on the occasion of the latter's inauguration as President of Argentina.
Sir Josiah Stamp, British economist, expressed belief today that developments in Europe are threatening democratic institutions and that successful democracies should stand together.

John G. Bragman, formerly with the Kempner Realty Corporation, and William C. Schuhr of J. Edgar Leaycraft Co. have formed their own realty company under the name of William C. Schuhr Company, with offices at 103 East 125th Street.

Adolph Davis, 67 years old, of 941 East 156th Street, the Bronx, who described himself as a linguist and "expert" real estate salesman although admitting he could neither read nor write, testified for the prosecution yesterday in the General Sessions conspiracy trial of two women, ten men and ten corporations in the alleged $2,000,000 land frauds in Slovak Manor, L. I.

Mrs. Alanson Caswell, who when a student at a private academy in Paris, during the Franco-Prussian War, met the Empress Eugenie a short time before the Empress escaped from the city as the invading army was approaching, died here late last night at the home of her son, the Rev. Wilbur Caswell, pastor of St. Paul's Episcopal Church. Her age was 81.

Under an agreement reached by Republican legislative leaders and Governor Moore, Democrat, a bill was introduced in the Senate tonight to enable New Jersey to seek a WPA grant of $20,000,000 for employment of 20,000 relief clients on a project to improve secondary roads.

Stanley Howe, secretary to Mayor La Guardia, received a 4 1/2-foot walnut tree at City Hall yesterday as a gift to the Mayor from officials of the Golden Gate International Exposition in San Francisco.
Dr. George Ellery Hale, one of the world's most renowned astronomers, died of heart trouble today in the Las Encinas Sanitarium. He was 69 years old, born In Chicago June 29, 1868.

Dollar volume declines of 5 to 6 per cent compared with the correspending period a year ago were reported by retail grocers last week, according to the survey of trade activity issued yesterday by the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.

Continued unsettlement in the market for foreign dollar bonds in reflection of the week-end political developments in Central Europe was the only noteworthy feature of an exceptionally dull bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
Following a week in which denims had been sold at the basis of 10 cents for 2.20s, one leading producer withdrew goods from sale yesterday and another advanced 1/2 cent.

ON Washington's Birthday, and once in a while through the year, it might be remembered that the man who was "First in war, first in peace and first in the hearts of his countrymen" also was first in the field sports of his younger day.

At the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, on the site formerly occupied by the Union League Club, the F. W. Woolworth Company has just completed the largest unit in its chain of more than 2,000 stores.
A continued low general death rate for New York City for the week ended last Saturday was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of the Department of Health.

Walter E. Shinn, tackle from Parlin, N. J., was elected captain of the University of Pennsylvania football team at a dinner given by Head Coach George A. Munger for the varsity, junior varsity and freshman football teams today.

Before this, Sascha Gorodnitzki, who gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall, had demonstrated exceptional talent. At a time when most young pianists are learning their notes he gave proof of an individual and authoritative grasp of his art.

H. C. Wright, president of the Chicago Flexible Shaft Company, said at the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday that domestic sales for eight weeks ended on Feb. 19 were $1,164,000, compared with $717,500 in the 1937 period, a gain of 62 per cent.

The Show goes on. Jim Deren, the "major-domo" of the Kirtland booth, has not only gathered feathers from the far corners of the earth in order that the fly-tiers can practice their craft, he's brought in Rube Cross and Elizabeth Greig to show the amateurs how the flies should be tied.

The War Department made public today congratulatory messages exchanged between the Minister of War of the Argentine Republic, General Basilio B. Pertine, and Secretary Woodring on Saturday, incidental to the installation of President Ortiz yesterday at Buenos Aires.

Mrs. Margaret Layden, 38 years old, ended her life by inhaling gas some time early this morning or late last night and three of her small sons, whom she apparently had not intended for death, went with her. Her fourth son also was overcome by the fumes, but he was reported tonight to be recovering.

Nicaragua purchased more merchandise in 1937 from the United States than from all other countries combined. Imports from the United States constituted 54 per cent of the total, according to an official report.
The annual Golden Gloves boxing tournament, which has grown to be New York's blue ribbon amateur boxing event, entered its final stages at the New York Hippodrome last night.
