Robert Grant 3d lost his first game of the season to an amateur yesterday as he gained the final round of the national amateur racquets championship with J. Richard Leonard of Tuxedo. They will meet at 2 o'clock today at the Racquet and Tennis Club, with Grant favored to retain his crown.
Castle Hill Ave, 1,709, 25x105.2, irreg; Home Owners Loan Corp against Selma Swanson; due, $9,535; taxes, etc., $998; to plaintiff for $4,500.

LAKELAND TERRIERS Winners, Dogs, and Best of Winners-Pauline Arnold White's Stonewall Souse. Winners, Bitches-Hickrill Kennels' Hickrill Angel. Best of Breed-Hickrill Kennels' Ch. KavaHer of Kinniside of Hickrill.

A possible glimpse into the sunnier and more open city of the future is shown in the plans and drawings for the development proposed by the New York City Housing Authority for the Red Hook section of Brooklyn.

Echoes of the heavy opening-day firing in the major leagues scarcely will have died away before the minor detonations begin in the International League with the start of that circuit's 1938 campaign on four fronts.

Benjamin Marvin of Hollis, former magistrate, was elected chairman of the Central Queens Passover Fund Campaign for 1938 ?? a meeting held yesterday at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association of Jamaica, 153-14 Ninetieth Avenue, Jamaica.
A number of more or less cryptic matters came to light yesterday, all but one as an aftermath of the recent convention of the National Puzzlers League in Cincinnati.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In Mr. Duranty's fictional account of the interview between Mrs. Rubens and the American charge d'affaires in Russia there are some alleged facts about Soviet police methods which are calculated to rob the prisoners of the GPU of the one hope they have-the pressure brought to bear upon the Soviet regime by an outraged world opinion.
Contracts with the government for the exploitation of the natural wealth of Ecuador do not have the same effect as civil contracts when the rights acquired diminish the sovereignty of the State,
Automobile production increased last week, running counter to the seasonal trend, and the adjusted index advanced to 67.2 from 63.1. The figure for the week ended Feb. 20, 1937, was 108.8.
Lord Beaverbrook, owner of The Daily Express of London, yesterday said he was too uncertain about developments in Britain to make any comment on the resignation of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden.
Lawrenceville suffered its third defeat of the season as the Nichols School sextet of Buffalo triumphed, 3-0, at Baker Rink today.

Pensioned The following member of the force is relieved from duty and retired from the police force and is placed on the roll of the Pension Fund (on his own application). To take effect 12 midnight, Feb. 19: PATROLMAN -- Albert H. Johnson, 18th Division, M. O. D., Brooklyn, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 24, 1910.

Mayor La Guardia's speech on Saturday, attacking the State Transit Commission in particular and the Legislature in general, had repercussions tonight when Harry A. Reoux, Republican, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, rose in the Assembly to state his resentment of some of the Mayor's remarks.

A revamped Dartmouth basketball team took the whole first period to find itself tonight and then went ahead in the last ten minutes of the game' to defeat Columbia, 46 to 36, and move another notch closer to the Eastern Intercollegiate League title.

The New York Rangers hope to make up some lost ground in the American Group of the National Hockey League race tonight when they oppose the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden. The Blue Shirts, who were only three points out of first place in their division a week ago, are now trailing the leading Boston Bruin sextet by seven points.

Taking the lead at the outset, the Rhode Island State Teachers College women's basketball team defeated the Savage combination on the losers' court, 22 to 18, yesterday to register its eighteenth straight triumph of the campaign.
Four British officers and the British ship Asian were reported today to have been detained by a Japanese destroyer for more than a week at Port Mako, Pescadores Islands.

Manhattan and Brooklyn joined stage, exhibition and concert performers in providing entertainment last night at the benefit ball given in the Hotel Roosevelt by the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc.

The annual report of the Ohio bell Telephone Company for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all expenses and charges of $9,800,141, comparing with a net of $10,278,177 in 1936. Earnings for 1937 were at the rate of $7.54 a common share, against $7.90 a share in the preceding year.

Cummings Hatfield Tucker Jr., a retired hardware merchant who was an elder of the West End Collegiate Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street, died yesterday at his residence, 131 Riverside Drive, after a year's ness. His age was 80.
Myron Behr, trustee in bankruptcy of Jacob S. Kaplan, sold to Ruth Kaplan, the two, four-story flats on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 271-273 Jackson Avenue, Jersey City.

The Soviet ice-breakers Taimyr and Murman sighted the Yermak at midnight last night and as the big ice-breaker approached the others she sent rockets blazing into the polar sky to greet the rescued scientists on the two ships and their rescuers.
Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag signed yesterday an order directing Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan and the Municipal Civil Service Commission to show cause

The Ways and Means Committee approved today several changes in the sixty- three recommendations for tax revisions contained in its subcommittee's report, and defeated by a vote of 15 to 10 a resolution to drop the new section providing for a special undistributed profits surtax on closely held corporations.

Enthusiastic approval of the United States Housing Authority's program was given by the Furniture Manufacturers Representatives of New York at their annual George Washington dinner held last night in the Hotel Piccadilly.
Mrs. Raymond J. White, wife of the acting clerk to the City Council, is chairman of the annual bridge party and dance of St. Pascal's Guild to be held tonight at the George Washington Hotel.

Mr. and Mrs. George W. van Siclen gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for their debutante daughter, Miss D. Elise van Siclen, to celebrate her cluded Miss Ruth Burchell, Miss Lois Burchall, Bayard Magear, Philip B. Pool and Sterling Pile Jr.

The demand of the "100 per cent patriots" for the removal of Simon W. Gerson from his job in the office of Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs is an "attempt to impose a Fascist principle in the very heart of American democracy,"

The State Labor Relations Board last night called a conference of representatives of. the management and the Electrical Workers Union Local 3 for tomorrow morning in another effort to settle the strike of electricians and maintenance men at Rockefeller Center.

Miss Helen Lasher, 20 years old, a student nurse at Bellevue Hospital, rescued a 13-year-old boy from the East River at Twentysixth Street yesterday afternoon after he had fallen off the dock near the nurses' home.

Houghton Mifflin have signed a contract with Klaus and Erika Mann, son and daughter of the Nobel Prize winner, Thomas Mann, for the publication in the Fall of 1938 of a non-fiction volume to be entitled "Escape to Life."
Henry Bradley Plant of New London, Conn., and New York, member of a family noted as a developer of Florida's gulf coast, died here today aboard his yacht, the Mascotte, at the age of 42.

Coincident with the final lick of hard training for the heavyweight championship battle between Joe Louis, the titleholder, and Nathan Mann, New Haven challenger, scheduled for tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden, there came yesterday a gradual drop in the odds on the battle.

Late Winter styles for motorcycle policemen will be introduced today with a new type of overcoat to be worn by the knights on wheels. The chopped off appearance of short military jackets will be replaced by the suave effect of flowing tails to protect their legs.
While London anxiously watched the political crisis caused by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's resignation, Queen Elizabeth today quietly attended the opening of the British Industries Fair.

Discussing "Effective Retail Advertising" yesterday at the annual convention of the Virginia Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, Albert J. Silberstein, head of the advertising agency bearing his name, declared that in the main he favored newspaper advertising as the most effective medium.

Turpentine firm, 26 1/4c; sales. 88 barrels; receipts, 19 barrels; no shipments; stock, 25,736 barrels Resin firm: sales, 262; receipts, 448; no shipments stock, 75,134. Quote: B, D. E, $3.75; F. $4.75: G, $4.95; H, $5.00; I, $5.10; K, $5.20; M, $5.35; N, $5.50; WG, $6.70; WW, X, $7.10.
An elaborate plan for a special court of railroad reorganization, with dictatorial authority over all roads in receivership, has been prepared in the inner circles of the New Deal left wing.

President Roosevelt's request for a $250,000,000 emergency relief appropriation, although apparently sure of Congressional approval, led to demands in the Senate today that some permanent solution be found for the unemployment problem.
Brook Ave (11-2896) w s, 50 ft n of 170th St, 37x90; W. A. Holding Corp to B. F. E. Realty Corp, 3,120 3d Ave.

Roles in two of Columbia's more imposing projects of the season were cast today from the ranks of the dark horses. Frank Capra selected Spring Byington, hitherto not mentioned for the part, as Penelope Sycamore in 'You Can't Take It With You."

Thomas Lindsay Buick, historian and novelist, died today at the age of 71. In his younger days Mr. Buick was broke part proprietor of two New Zealand newspapers, The Manawatu Daily Standard and The Danevirke Advocate.

The Crescent A. C. triumphed over Fordham, 32-28, in overtime, and the New York A. C. defeated Georgetown, 33-27, to give the clubmen both ends of a college-club basketball double-header held last night in Fordham gymnasium.

Harry J. Brewer, retired real estate broker and former chairman of the Building Commission of Mamaroneck Township, died of pneumonia today in the New Rochelle Hospital at the age of 65. He lived at 33 Fernwood Road.
Bleecker St, 407, 21x50; trustees, will of Abraham Bijur, to Elizabeth B. Stuch, 155 E 72d St; consideration, $12,917.
The House postponed today until the end of the week consideration of the Interior Department Appropriation Bill, and thereby saved the taxpayers $500.

Declaring that the problems of labor and capital were "identical," Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., in a speech last night, criticized as "one of the most popular fallacies of our day" the idea that there must always be irreconcilable strife between labor and capital.
Internal revenue figures for January, made public today, show large decreases from the corresponding month of 1937 in some classifications of taxes, reflecting current business conditions.

Tentative rules, to be submitted to the Federal Trade Commission at its trade practice conference on the silk industry on March 4, were sent to members of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., for study and comment yesterday, by G. H. Conze, president of the Federation.
Appointment of Francis C. Leupold as superintendent of Jamaica Hospital was announced yesterday by the board of trustees of the institution and its vice president, Howard O. Wood.
The delegates of the British Empire sent here in response to an invitation of the State Department to negotiate a trade treaty arrived this afternoon.

Dr. and Mrs. Abraham S. Elterman of East Rockaway, L. I., gave a dinner last night in the Yacht Room of the Astor at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice A. Elterman, to Harold Winkler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Winkler of Lynbrook, L. I.

James D. C. Murray, attorney for J. Richard (Dixie) Davis and George Weinberg, alleged successors to Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer in the policy racket, indicated yesterday that he hoped to get the twelve felony counts in the indictments against them reduced to misdemeanors.

Through the purchase of the entire issue of certificates in Series B and M 170,846, amounting to $55,000, R. H. Marwin Co., Inc., has acquired from the certificate holders free and clear ownership of the four-story apartment house at 125 Schenectady Avenue, Brooklyn.

Garland S. Ferguson Jr., chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, today wrote to Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, New York, in answer to a telegram last Thursday in which Mr. Besse informed the commission the association would not participate in the trade conference for the wool industry to be held here March 8.

An insurance policy issued to President James A. Garfield just before his assassination was found today in an attic at Waldron by Paul Monroe. President Garfield was shot by a disappointed office-seeker July 2, 1881, and died Sept. 19.
An insolvent individual or corporation has the right to revive a debt outlawed by the statute of limitation even though that action may be to the detriment of creditors whose claims still stand,

Hitler's reference in his speech to ten million Germans in neighboring countries whom the peace treaties prevent from reuniting with the Reich is a very grave matter for us," said an official Czechoslovak spokesman today.
President Roosevelt nominated Max O'Rell Truitt of Missouri today to the position on the Maritime Commission vacated by the resignation of Joseph P. Kennedy, Ambassador to Great Britain.
Prompt national approval has been asked by King Carol for the drastically revised Constitution, centering greater power in the crown, that he has offered to Rumanians.

Police of the Missing Persons Bureau have sent out a city-wide alarm for Patrolman Max Gross, 33 years old, of 175 Woodbine Street, Brooklyn, who disappeared about midnight, Feb. 14, from the Ralph Avenue station in Brooklyn.
Ab Kirwan, former University of Kentucky football star, said tonight he had accepted an offer to become head football coach at his Alma Mater, succeeding Chet Wynne, who resigned Friday.

It has long been evident that the chief importance of the "Rome-Berlin axis" was its nuisance value. The two nations at the opposite ends of that axis are not natural allies. To be sure, both are dictatorships.

Kay Francis, actress, drew the top salary of $209,100 on the Warner Brothers movie lot last year, the corporation reported to the Securities Exchange Commission today. Miss Francis also was the highest paid Warner Brothers employee in 1936, when she received $227,500.

As the site for a six-story apartment building, the plot, 205 by 112 feet, on the south side of Martel Place, 115 feet west of Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, L. I., has been purchased by Martel Manor, Inc., representing Charles S. Freeman and Joseph Gerla, from the Cord Meyer Development Company.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 19: COLONELS Brown, O. G., Med. Corps, three months' leave, Feb. 28. Relieved from duty at Ft. Sill, Okla., on May 31 and ordered to retirement.

In observance of Washington's Birthday, all of the securities and commodity markets and banks throughout the United States will be closed today. Livestock markets in Chicago and New York, however, will remain open.

Deaths Reported Fireman 1st Grade Harry H. Kolbenheyer H. L. Co. 45, died Feb. 20. Funeral from Cooke's Funeral Parlors, 1 W. 190th St., the Bronx, 9:30 A. M., Thursday, Feb. 24 Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. No escort desired.

The $370,000,000 Engineers Public Service Company announced yesterday afternoon that it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission in compliance with the provisions of the Publio Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

Operations in the steel industry are scheduled at 30.4 per cent of capacity this week, compared with 31.0 per cent last week, a decline of 0.6 point, or 1.9 per cent. This is the sixth consecutive week of virtually stabilized operations at about 30 per cent of capacity.
The Federal Court of Appeals today suspended government-fixed minimum soft coal prices affecting the 1,462 members of the Associated Industries of New York State, Inc.

Edward T. Newell, president of the American Numismatic Society, Broadway and 156th Street, announced yesterday that the society would hold an exhibition of Roman coins of the period of Augustus Caesar in the Spring to commemorate the 2,000th anniversary of the birth of Augustus.

Philip R. Kraushaar, active for many years in the building of higher-priced homes on Long Island, announced yesterday that he would start work next week on a new home community to be known as Fair Oaks, at Woodmere, L. I., on land formerly known as the Lord estate.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. declared yesterday an interim dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock for the first quarter of 1938, compared to an interim dividend of 75 cents a share paid in the first quarter of 1937.

Douglas C. Fonda of Orange, N. J., national champion making his Florida racing debut, captured two of the four outboard races today in the Palm Beach Yacht Club's thirty-first annual Washington's Birthday regatta.
Jackson Curtis of Boston bought yesterday an issue of $200,000 of temporary loan notes of Watertown, Mass., at 0.345 per cent. The notes will become due and payable on Nov. 25.

Counselor Leo Duff, 49 years old, secretary of Judge Morris E. Barison of the Juvenile Court here, summoned an ambulance to his home, 15 Bentley Avenue, at 5:30 o'clock this morning, but died before medical aid arrived.
Listing of 148,524 additional common shares of Monsanto Chemical Company was authorized yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. They will not necessarily be Immediately admitted to dealings.

WASHINGTON.--As a means of encouraging the growth of American varieties of cotton and cotton seed, the. Government of Iraq has exempted all such products grown in that country from the istihlak and land tax, according to a consular report to the Department of Commerce from Baghdad.
France's reply to Chancellor Hitler's speech and the resignation of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, will be made tomorrow when the French Cabinet will meet at 10 o'clock.

Herbert H. Rice, 43 years old, of 361 Forty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, a postoffice letter carrier for seven years, who told government authorities he had taken $40 from a registered letter Jan. 10 to bet on horse races, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn to serve one year and one day in a Federal penitentiary, He was employed at the Bay Ridge station in Brooklyn.

Mrs. Enid Goelet obtained a divorce today from Ogden Goelet of Roslyn, L. I., on grounds of desertion in January last year. The suit was uncontested. Agreement was reached out of court on the custody of their one child, Enid, 3 years old.

A strike called late last night at the plant here of Lever Brothers, manufacturers of soap and edible oils, was settled this evening after a series of conferences between the management and the Soap, Glycerine and Edible Oil Union, A. F. of L.
Operation of one of the country's shortest short-line railroads for at least another year was assured today following presentation of the line's annual report.

Abruzzo in Brooklyn to serve one year and one day in a Federal penitentiary, He was employed at the Bay Ridge station in Brooklyn.

Mrs. Enid Goelet obtained a divorce today from Ogden Goelet of Roslyn, L. I., on grounds of desertion in January last year. The suit was uncontested. Agreement was reached out of court on the custody of their one child, Enid, 3 years old.

A strike called late last night at the plant here of Lever Brothers, manufacturers of soap and edible oils, was settled this evening after a series of conferences between the management and the Soap, Glycerine and Edible Oil Union, A. F. of L.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Authority was granted to the Pittsburgh West Virginia Railway Company by the Interstate Commerce Commission today to issue as much as S250,000 of its unsecured promissory notes and to reissue them if necessary, but at no time to have more than $250,000 outstanding.

Phillips Avery, attorneys, who for thirty-three years have been located at 41 Park Row, have leased more than 5,000 square feet of space in 1 Wall Street and will move there upon completion of extensive alterations The Cruikshank Company, agents, negotiated the lease.
Frank W. Regan, medalist and favorite to win the eighth annual New York A. C. midwinter golf tournament, advanced to the semi-finals today by winning two matches.
Howard S. Heitkamp of Chatham, former vice president of the Gilbert Manufacturing Company of New York, died in Overlook Hospital today following an operation. His age was 69.
Putnam Hill Chapter, D. A. R., will hold open house and a reception tomorrow at historic Putnam Cottage here in observance of Washington's birthday.

Herbert Courtney of Brooklyn scored his second victory in the national amateur pocket billiard championship yesterday, beating Dominick Caridi of Astoria, L. I., 125-59, in twenty-five innings at the Strand Academy.

" Father Malachy's Miracle" will close its run at the St. James Theatre on the evening of March 5, completing a run of about 125 performances. It will open the following Monday at the Nixon Theatre, Pittsburgh, moving to the Harris Theatre in Chicago on March 14.

Italian press comment deals fully and in many columns with Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech, but entirely neglects the resignation of British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, which is relegated to a distinctly secondary position.
Nels Stewart may be getting around the age where National Hockey Leaguers exchange stick and puck for armchair and pipe and a good book, but he's still Old Poison to goalies.
The application of consolidations to improve the railroads' situation, as discussed in Administration circles in Washington, found railroad officials in a receptive mood yesterday.

IN honor of the patriotic day, three books*-a Washington narrative by Katherine Mayo (of "Mother India" fame), a new edition of "The Federalist" and a biography of Governor George Clinton by E. Wilder Spaulding.

An impartial wage board refused today the demand of Full Fashioned Hosiery Manufacturers for a general wage reduction in the organized section of the industry, including about 15,000 workers in this city. Several adjustments were authorized. however.
Following is the text of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's address on the conflict over foreign relations before the House of Commons today:

Miss Elizabeth Abbot Sargent, daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth Abbot Sargent of Pine Ridge Farm, this place, and Chebaco Island, Essex, Mass., was married to John Sleeper Hartwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Martin Hartwell of Bronxville, N. Y., tonight in the First Parish Church here.

While Stephen D. Cossey, 34 years old, of Tottenville, S. I., was testifying today in Supreme Court in support of his plea for an Enoch Arden dissolution of his marriage, based on his asserted belief that his wife died ten years ago, Mrs. Elizabeth Fitzgerald Cossey, the "dead" wife, walked into the court room.

Aston Villa will play Manchester City in the sixth round of the English football cup competition March 5. The Villans today beat Charlton Athletic, 4-1, in the second replay of their fifth-round match.

Despite sharp declines in the number of traffic fatalities last week and week-end as compared with those of the corresponding period last year, slight increases in the number of injuries marred the record of the current campaign for greater street safety, according to tables made public by the Poilce Department.

Since today is the first anniversary of the creation .of the Camp of National Unity by Marshal Edward SmiglyRydz, the presidents of its provincial branches convened here and made a pilgrimage to the late Marshal Josef Pilsudski's residence in the Belvedere and also visited President Iqnaz Moscicki and Marshal Smigly-Rydz.

Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas in January fell off about 2 per cent compared with January, 1937, and more than 50 per cent compared with December, the Department of Commerce reported today.

A movement has been started among lawyers in Westchester County to increase by two the number of Supreme Court Justices in the Ninth Judicial District, which includes Putnam, Dutchess, Orange and Rockland Counties, as well as Westchester.

The rival to Father Divine, who has bought for $20,000 the "main heaven" at 20-22 West 115th Street, from where the little Negro evangelist who calls himself God has directed his Harlem flock for several years, apparently intends to contend for the spiritual leadership of the Divine followers.

The Church League for Industrial Democracy, an unofficial Protestant Episcopal organization, which was assailed last year by Bishop William T. Manning for its "militantly partisan and radical character," adopted yesterday a new declaration of principles omitting some controversial statements made earlier in a pamphlet issued in answer to the attacks of Bishop Manning and others.

Sears, Roebuck Co. has readjusted its prices in line with farm commodity prices by announcing an average cut of 5.57 per cent for merchandising listed in its new Spring and Summer general catalogue as compared with the Fall and Winter general catalogue, which made its appearance late last Summer.
While a dozen ranking officials of the State Department spent today reading and evaluating reports of the exciting week-end in London and Berlin,
Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels today laid the cornerstone of the State Academy of the Film, which will teach film production in all its branches, including acting.

Chanting "Allah is great, there is no other Allah but Allah!" several hundred armed terrorists entered the city of Jenin in Northern Palestine last night and fired on government offices and police headquarters. They also hit dozens of houses and shattered street lamps.

Fourth conference on educational policies, Horace Mann Auditorium, Teachers College, 9:30 A. M. Speakers: Dean William F. Russell, Mark M. Jones, George H. Houston, H. W. Prentis Jr., Dr. Harold Stonier.

Three men who sought to organize a social club under the name of Club Satan were denied a certificate of incorporation yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Henry G. Wenzel Jr. in Brooklyn, who ruled that the title had an "anti-religious significance" and therefore was not acceptable.

COMMERCIAL PAPER Yesterday. Friday. For the best names ...... 1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months' paper. Holiday Cuts Buyers' Total Due to the holiday the number of visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended today was well below the preceding week.

The "humanizing" of great historic personalities has gone so far in our time as often to lead one to wonder that they were able tc perform the notable actions with which they are credited. Washington has suffered with the others.

Financial quarters disclosed today that Harrison, Ltd., a London concern, had signed a contract with the General Petroleum Administration for the purchase of about 1,000,000 barrels of government oil.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has extended his holdings in the blocks just north of Rockefeller Center. Deeds filed in the Register's office yesterday showed that he had taken title to the vacant property at 20 West Fifty-third Street, just across the street from the Fifty-third Street frontage of the new Museum of Modern Art, on which work is now in progress.

The United States State Department has requested the Mexican Government to make good its promises delivered by Ambassador Francisco Castillo Najera at Washington that Mexico's prohibitive tariffs established in January be lowered by the Mexican Congress meeting March 1, it was learned authoritatively today.

An increase from a six-cent to a ten-cent fare on the Hudson Manhattan's Cortlandt Street tubes would divert more than 50 per cent of the railroad's downtown passenger traffic to competing ferry lines, the Interstate Commerce Commission was told yesterday.

The engagement of Miss Edna Marion Berger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest R. Berger of Hawthorne, N. Y., and Daytona Beach, Fla., to William S. Pricher of this city has been announced by her parents.

At a meeting of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at the Hotel Lincoln yesterday it was decided that to the winner of the N. Y. U.-C. C. N. Y. game on March 2 will be issued an invitation to compete as metropolitan representative in the national intercollegiate invitation tournament which will be held at Madison Square Garden next month under the auspices of the organization.

Members of the headquarters auxiliary of the Brooklyn Children's Aid Society have taken over a preview performance of James Bridie's comedy, "The Black Eye," by the Brattleboro Theatre Group in the St. Felix Street Theatre, Brooklyn, on March 5. Proceeds from the benefit will aid the work of the society.
The second itinerary exhibition of "City Gardens and Penthouse Terraces in Winter," arranged for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, will be held on Thursday.
Rain started to fall again in Arkansas late today, adding uncertainty to a flood situation that had appeared almost under control.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Dyke Bixby of Huntington Bay, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Esther Ela Bixby, to Peter Vivian Owen-Evans of Vancouver, B. C., son of Mrs. OwenEvans and of the late Colonel A. Owen-Evans of Dale Fort, Pembrokeshire, Wales.

With sales of Japanese goods sharply reduced and those of Chinese products rising and Central European developments threatening to affect Austrian and Czechoslovak merchandise, international affairs overshadowed domestic questions at the opening of the seventeenth semi-annual New York Gift Show at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne of New York proved yesterday that you can still catch a two-pound trout right in the heart of the metropolis.

More and more States are limiting the chances of error or defects in the planning and erection of buildings by requiring registration and examination of all persons engaged in the practice of architecture.

The marriage of Miss Harriet Talcott Clarke, daughter of Mrs. Talcott Hunt Clarke of Garden City, L. I., and the late Major Clarke, U. S. A., to Winthrop Humphrey of Louisville, Ky., son of Mrs. Louise George Humphrey of Upper Montclair, N. J., and the late Charles J. Humphrey, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street.
Soft X-rays, under which the digestion of living insects has been seen for the first time, have revealed at Cornell University the fact that insects may never fully recover from starvation.

Harold Crowell Mitchell of 3,495 Broadway, a lawyer, who served four consecutive terms as a Republican member of the New York State Assembly, 1916-20, died yesterday in the Knickerbocker Hospital after a brief illness of heart disease. He was 62 years old.

With the Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, and other distinguished guests present, St. Peter's Episcopal Church, at 344 West Twentieth Street, celebrated its 100th anniversary last night at a special service at the church.

The annual report of the International Harvester Company for its fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, 1937, shows net income of $32,492,763, equal, after preferred dividends, to $6.31 a share on the common stock, compared with $29,760,372, or $5.77 a common share, after eleven

The Bronx Scots, leaders in the first division of the Metropolitan Soccer League, tied the New York Americans, semi-finalists in the National Cup championships, 2-2, at Starlight Park yesterday. The exhibition was witnessed by 2,000 fans.

King George and Queen Elizabeth, with other members of the royal family, went shopping today at the gigantic British Industries Fair. Surrounded by policemen, detectives, reporters and crowds, they spent two hours at the fair.

General John J. Pershing, 77-yearold World War Commander, suffered his second relapse in twelve hours late tonight, but physicians said they were "definitely optimistic" regarding his chances of recovering. He has a rheumatic ailment complicated by a heart condition.
Following are summaries of the addresses in the House of Commons today by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlvin, David Lloyd George and Winston Churchill, with the principal passages rendered textually.

Eunice Cole was imprisoned in 1656 for witchcraft and now Hampton Beach voters have been asked to approve in town meeting an article declaring her "unjustly accused" and restoring "her rightful place as a citizen."

Teruel was definitely restored today to the two-thirds of Spain 12,000,0 controlled by Generalissimo Francisco Franco. However, fewer than 1,000 of the civilians who formerly inhabited the city and managed to escape to Insurgent lines early in January can return to their homes if these are still standing in the partly devstated city.

The daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,369,250 barrels, compared with 3,324,500 in the preceding week, an increase of 44,750, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

Yesterday's holiday matinees were well attended, as is usually the case, Washington's Birthday being regarded as the height of the theatrical season. Thirty of the thirtyone current offerings held matinees (the exception was "Wine of Choice," which opened only

In a broadcast unique in that, an American Cabinet officer for the first time was directly addressing the people of Great Britain and the British dominions, Secretary Ickes pleaded today for vigilance by the world's democracies to escape communism and fascism.

Led by the Hassett brothers and Bernard Kearney, the Manhattan Prep basketball team yesterday defeated the visiting Fordham Prep quintet, 28 to 18, and moved into first place in the Manhattan-Bronx division of the C. H. S. A. A.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Mary Mahon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Mahon of West Orange, to Robert F. Leonard, son of Michael Leonard of Newark, took place this morning at a nuptial mass in Our Lady of Lourdes Church here.

A Yale hockey team that forgot it had not won a game in the International Intercollegiate Ice Hockey League spoiled Alumni Day for hundreds of returning Princeton graduates at Baker Rink tonight by scoring three goals in the first six minutes against the Tigers tonight and recording an 8-to-4 victory.
Prices held steady to strong on the stock market here today, particularly in mining issues. Trading was featured by heavy turnovers in MacLeod Cockshutt, Hard Rock and Preston, all up 10 to 25 cents.

W. E. Long, head of the Long Foundation of Research and of the Long Advertising Agency, who introduced such innovations in the baking industry as the wrapping and slicing of bread, offered today to 1,500 delegates to the Associated Bakers of America in convention a new plan of distribution to increase the consumption of bread.

Boston's hustling Bruins tonight extended their winning streak to seven games-the National Hockey League's longest of the season-by turning back the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 to 0, before another sellout crowd of 15,381.

Shattering par by three strokes and coming within a stroke of equaling the course record, Miss Patty Berg, 20-year-old Minneapolis sensation, led a select field of sixtytwo starters to win the qualifying medal in the annual South Atlantic women's golf championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today.

Maxie Berger, 139 1/2, Bronx, gained the decision over Eddie Brink, 138 3/4, Scranton, last night in the feature eight-round bout on the weekly boxing card at the New York Coliseum before a crowd of 8,000.

The marriage of Miss Cornelia F. O'Grady, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Cornelius E. O'Grady of New York, to John F. Hennessy, son of Mrs. Michael Hennessy of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Hennessy, took place yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Raymond, the Bronx.
The Czechs are a strong-nerved people. The ground under their feet has been shaken by a series of shocks, culminating in the resignation of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Britain.

Endorsement of the proposal by David Schenker of the Securities and Exchange Commission staff, that a census be taken of investment counsel and advisory firms has been voted by the Investment Counsel Association of America, according to an announcement by Dwight C. Rose, president of the organization.

An advance sale of $80,000 was announced yesterday by Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club for the heavyweight title bout of fifteen rounds between Joe Louis, the champion, and Nathan Mann, New Haven challenger, in Madison Square Garden tonight.

The new government of Argentina has created an excellent impression by announcing the end of the secrecy and censorship that surrounded the regime of former President Agustin P. Justo especially in its later years.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Poda of this city observed the fifty-seventh anniversary of their wedding this evening at their home. They were hosts at a dinner for their seven children, twenty-one grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

After a twoday surrender of the streets to the Nazis the police began today to take serious action. Defying last night's government prohibition the Nazis started at 10 o'clock this morning to demonstrate against patriotic students on Dollfuss Square after the students had cheered Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg and sung the Dollfuss anthem inside and outside the university.
A VISION, by W. B. Yeats. (Macmillan, $3.) Mr. Yeats discusses the principles and experiences that have inspired much of his poetry and prose.
John Roberts, a retired contractor, father of Mrs. William S. Hirschberg, wife of Judge Hirschberg of Greenwich, died here at his home last night of pneumonia, aged 85 years.

Theodore Murray moved into second place in the national amateur pocket billiard championship by defeating Arthur Cranfield, 125 to 100, in twenty-nine innings at the Strand Academy yesterday. Dominick Caridi vanquished Sol Traeger, 125 to 101, in thirty-four frames. Cranfield's high run

After 570 bouts had been fenced over a period of six and one-half hours in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium at Yale University tonight, the Salle Santelli of New York City was declared the winner of the annual invitation Washington's Birthday tournament with a record of 34 bouts won.

Today's major events: Joseph Szigeti, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera House, evening; Katherine Meisle, contralto, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Composers' ForumLaboratory, Federal Music Theatre, evening.

Frederick W. Smith of the class of '02 at Rutgers University was nominated for membership on the university hoard of trustees at a meeting of the Alumni Council here today. The council meeting was a feature of the annual Alumni Day program, for which about 500 graduates returned to the campus.

Details of the equipment which Stewart, James Co., Inc., recently appointed as purchasing agents in the United States for the Mexican Government, will purchase were made public here yesterday by George F. Dixon, president of the company, upon his return from Mexico City. Mr. Dixon said his

Thirtyone railroad passengers were injured today when a Wabash train traveling north at seventy miles an hour, struck a truck at a suburban crossing, killing the driver, Frank Gregson, 40, of Chicago.

The world's only "horse marines" passed out of existence here today. This mounted detachment of the United States Embassy marine guard passed in a last review before a record crowd of Americans and other foreigners at Breckenridge Field before disbanding forever.

For its next dinner meeting, on March 1 in the Park Central Hotel, the Commodity Club of New York has arranged for a "cotton evening." The program will be of an educational character and will set forth the history of cotton, from growth to marketing, in pictures.

Members of the Miami colony were guests of the Biscayne Bay Yacht Club today for the club's fifty-first annual chowder party on Key Biscayne. Mr. and Mrs. George Ratzy of Larchmont, N. Y., were guests of Commodore W. Overton Snyder of the club and Mrs. Snyder.

Business activity in Canada in the first half of 1938 should not be expected to compare favorably with the same period last year, Graham Towers, governor of the Bank of Canada, told the third annual meeting of the shareholders today.

Mrs. Katherine M. Nolan, mother of Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan and widow of Dan C. Nolan, former Yonkers publisher and former chairman of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors, died today in her home here at the age of 69.
The "mystery" transit unification plan that the Transit Commission declares has been agreed to by the private interests involved was challenged yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

President Roosevelt called Joseph P. Kennedy to his home here today for an unexpected last-minute canvassing of Anglo-American relations and domestic business conditions on the eve of the envoy's departure for London to take up his new post. The two were together several hours.

Doggedly giving chase on his bicycle, Robert Bottcher, 22 years old, a Western Union messenger, of 651 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, brought about the capture last night of two suspects in connection with the attempted hold-up of John Gallagher, 37, of 551 1/2 Lafayette Avenue, by three men.

Asserting that the Republican party must change its method of raising campaign funds if it would "become again the party of the plain folks of America," Frank Knox, the party's 1936 Vice Presidential nominee, proposed tonight that ational campaign contributions be limited to $1,000.

The Hamilton College hockey team scored a 3-to-2 victory over Cornell tonight in an exciting contest that was forced into overtime for a decision. With the score deadlocked at 2-all, Hayes made the winning tally in 1:08. Rogers and Pooley had made the other points for the winners.

Ferenc Szalasi, Hungarian Nazi leader, and seventy-two of his principal supporters and lieutenants, including the 30-year-old Count Louis Zechenyi, were arrested today in a raid on their headquarters here.
Milt Aron, 147, Chicago, defeated Vincent Pimpinella, 148, South Brooklyn, in the feature eightround event at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night before 3,500 spectators.

Three industrialists and a banker, rallying yesterday to reply to criticism of private enterprise by liberal educators, criticized American public education and charged that educators had "let the business man down" by neglecting their responsibility to teach appreciation of the existing social order.

The three election officials of Hudson County for whose arrest Assembly Speaker Herbert J. Pascoe issued warrants in Trenton last night agreed here today to appear before the Young committee tomorrow morning at the Essex County court house in Newark, although their counsel said they would refuse to answer any questions on the last Gubernatorial election in Hudson County, which the Young committee is investigating.
The first and second prizes of $100,000 and $50,000 in the second Old Gold puzzle contest were awarded yesterday to a Boston clerk and a West Orange (N. J. ) stenographer.

The Williams College hockey team displayed a fast passing attack to beat Middlebury by 3-1 on the Cole Field rink today. Johnny Jay, George Oldham and Captain Jeff Young scored the goals for the Purple, and Wyman, Middlebury captain, tallied for the invaders from a scrimmage in front of the cage. The line-up:
Carl Mattison Chapin, 58, of Manchester, Vt., newspaper man and author, died here tonight at the home of his sister, Mrs. Barbara C. Russell.

Forrest (Spec) Towns and Allen Tolmich will renew their spectacular hurdles rivalry Saturday night at the national A. A. U. indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden. The Olympic king and the national A. A. U. outdoor titleholder head a starstudded entry list for the timbertopping event.

The North American premiere here tonight of Mazo de la Roche's "Whiteoaks" with Ethel Barrymore and Stephen Haggard in the leading roles, revealed a workmanlike adaptation from the novel of that name by the author herself.

In a letter to the Iron Guard, explaining its sudden dissolution, its leader, Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, says it was compelled to take this step yesterday, as today all State employes must sign declarations that they had severed all connection with former political parties or resign.

With Princeton's undergraduate body augmented today by hundreds of returning graduates here for alumni day, the visitor is impressed with the completeness of agreement on the naming of Elton (Tad) Wieman to succeed Fritz Crisler as head coach of football.

Steel ingot production was unchanged for the third successive week, although an increase was indicated seasonally, and the adjusted index eased further to 39.4. This compared with 41.0 for the previous week and 113.9 for the week ended Feb. 20, 1937.

The Teachers Union of Salvador, which was organized to combat fascist propaganda, attributed to foreign Catholic priests, is holding its national convention here with delegates from local unions in all parts of the country.

The Cotton Textile Institute of New York City has filed with the Tariff Commission's Committee for Reciprocity Information a brief urging that it recommend in connection with the proposed trade treaty with Great Britain no tariff concession "which would accelerate any possible loss of production by domestic cotton mills."

THOUGH Harry Scherman is president of the Book-of-the-Month Club and hence not an economist by trade, he has written a remarkable book on economics for the layman. Its ultimate conclusion, so far as it has one, seems to me highly debatable, but it is still a remarkable book, full of sharp detail and written with vigor and enthusiasm. Those who read it will understand,

" If politics and morals had progressed as much in the last two decades as medical science there would be far less consumption of gunpowder today," Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University, declared yesterday at a gathering of alumni of the College of Medicine.

The Commercial National Bank and Trust Company has been appointed temporary successor trustee of the second mortgage extended gold 5 per cent bonds, due on Sept. 1, 1939, of the New York Erie Railroad Company.
Outclassed in the first period, a scrappy Harvard basketball team came back in the second half to defeat Cornell, 40 to 30, in an Eastern League game tonight.

The marriage of Miss Martha Mary Funk, daughter of Mrs. Joseph A. Funk of Laurelton, L. I., to James William Foote, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Foote of Syracuse, took place here yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis of Assisi.

American astronomers and astrophysicists long recognized the late Dr. George Ellery Hale as their dean, not because he thrust himself at their head but because of his outstanding ability as a research scientist, his infectious enthusiasm, his energy in establishing in this country the finest observatories that the world has ever seen.

With a full enrollment of twentyfour young women representing twelve States, the first Girl Scout national training course of 1938 for candidates contemplating a professional career in the movement will open today at the New York School of Social Work, 122 East Twentysecond Street.

The new type overcoat to be worn by motor cycle policemen will be three-quarter length, of blue broadcloth, with dyed baby lamb collars and linings to match. To protect the legs against chill winds, the coats will have flowing tails.
The stock market here recovered for the most part today and most sections advanced. Gilt-edge issues were in demand while among the foreign bonds Continental European issues were better.

Industrial production in January, on a seasonally adjusted basis, averaged slightly lower than in the final month of 1937, according to the monthly report of the National Industrial Conference Board, issued yesterday.

Mrs. Winfield Scott Schley of New York, widow of Admiral Schley, who is visiting Mrs. H. Blake Jackson of Cedarwood Drive, Greenwich, was among the guests who attended an open house and reception given by Putnam Hall Chapter, D. A. R., at the historic Putnam Cottage of Revolutionary fame this afternoon in observance of Washington's birthday.

ADAMS--Catherine, on Feb. 20, formerly of 431 West 24th St. Funeral from J. Molloy Sons, 319 West 25th, Thursday, 9:30 A. M. Mass St. Columba Church, 10 o'clock. ADLER--At her home, 970 Park Ave., on Feb. 22, Frederica Mayer Adler, beloved wife of Morton L. Adler and sister of Jennie M. Breitenbach and Magdelene M. Klingenstein; daughter of the late David and Mary Mayer. Services at her late

When the Seattle municipal campaign began it seemed to be a contest between the American Federation of Labor and the C. I. O.-that is, between their leaders, Dave Beck of the teamsters and Harry Bridges of the longshoremen, the man who wants to abolish employers. Mayor Dore,

Mexico is seriously endangered by a fascist movement within her present regime, as well as without, according to the nation's most powerful labor leader, Vicente Lombardo Toledano, speaking today at the opening of the congress of the C. T. M. [Federation of Mexican Workers].
Educators from all parts of the country were arriving here tonight for the opening tomorrow of a series of conventions that will continue through March 3.

A tall, attractive and well dressed girl about 16 years old walked into the Alexander Avenue Police Station in the Bronx shortly after 9 o'clock last night and told detectives that while she was riding on an uptown Pelham Park subway train she had suddenly realized she did not know her name, where she had been, or where she was going.
An audience unwittingly walked out here on Josef Hofmann, concert pianist, last night, and today lack of programs was blamed for the situation.

The new museum at the Morristown National Historical Park was opened to the public today, and was inspected by more than 2,000 persons. The museum is at the rear of the Ford Mansion, which George Washington used as his army headquarters for a time during the Revolutionary War.
Yale fashioned a victory from impending defeat tonight when it overcame a 24-15 deficit at intermission to defeat Princeton in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game, 41--34.
The spectacular crackup of Tops II, holder of three 225 hydroplane world records, enlivened the closing program in the Palm Beach Yacht Club's thirty-first annual Washington's Birthday regatta today.
Dr. R. L. Blackmon defeated Frank W. Regan, medalist, 1 up, today to win the New York A. C. mid-Winter golf tournament held on the Belleview Biltmore No. 1 course.

The third annual Middle Atlantic men's and women's doubles championship, which was played yesterday on the new courts of the Manhattan Badminton Club, resulted in victories for both of the defending teams.
Robert Grant 3d completed his conquest of all the honors in racquets on this side of the Atlantic yesterday.
The Soviet answer to Chancellor Hitler of Germany was given tonight in no uncertain form by War Commissar Klementy E. Voroshiloff in an address to 5,000 picked officers and soldiers of the Red Army.

THERE is no law against trying, wherefor the Mann Who Would Be King is to be allowed and even encouraged to fire away this evening at Shufflin' Joe Louis, the reigning monarch of the heavyweight boxing realm.
American foreign affairs will be directly affected by the sharp reorientation of British policy, although there will be no change in the peace program of Secretary of State Cordell Hull. Henceforth,

The Senate devoted almost its entire session today to debate on two bills relating to New York City. One was the McNaboe bill abolishing the present system of lunacy commissions, and the other the Joseph bill peremitting the city to demolish, after obtaining a court order, unoccupied tenements which are considered menaces to the public health and safety.

Webster Hall, on East Eleventh Street, which was gutted by fire yesterday morning, began by seeing redcheeked debutantes introduced to society and ended-if ended it has-by seeing red-nosed bohemians thumbing defiance at society.

Angry because the Municipal Civil Service Commission passed only one of 114 candidates applying for the post of school examiner here, city school officials challenged the commission yesterday to make public the reasons why "so many able men" were rejected.

An ambulance, stolen during the night from the United States Naval Hospital in Brooklyn, was wrecked yesterday morning at Delancey and Eldridge Streets after it had collided with a private automobile and smashed the plate glass window of a shoe repairing shop.

Two Cunard White Star steamships arrived yesterday with 250 passengers from Europe. The Andania, from Southampton via Havre, brought five clerks, four women and one man, to join the British Board of Trade delegation that arrived Monday on the Queen Mary. They left in the afternoon for Washington.

This city of nearly half a million population, long beset by labor difficulties and known for years as a hotbed of radicalism, has taken a definite swing to the right, political observers said today as they studied the results of yesterday's municipal primary.

W. B. Adsit of the Ardsley Country Club defeated J. H. Holmes Jr., 15-11, 13-15, 16-13, 15-5 today, to win the Class A title of the Westchester Division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association on the courts of the Sleepy Hollow C. C.

Winners, Dogs (not exceeding 13 inches)William E. Deane's Applegates Monarch. Winners, Bitches and Best of Winners (not exceeding 13 inches)-Foxcatcher Beagles' Foxcatcher Joyful. Winners, Dogs and Best of Winners (13 to 15 inches) and Best of Breed-Amos Oatman's Bishop's Minor. Winners. Bitches (13 to 15 inches)-G. Penfield Strelinger Jr.'s Larmagils's Annabelle Ice.

The name of Wendell Willkie, president of Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, entered testimony today before an Ohio Senate committee which is investigating State purchases and purported contributions to the 1934 campaign of Governor Martin L. Davey.

Senator Rogers, co-author of the RogersAllen Milk Law now in effect, made public today a letter to Representative George E. Kelly, asking him to present to the Federal Trade Commission in Washington, a picture of organized activities of milk dealers and distributors to wreck the State law.

Mr. and Mrs. De Forest Stull of Paulin Boulevard, Leonia, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Gertrude Stull, to William Hotchkiss Potter, son of Roderick Potter of Buffalo.

The College of Mount Saint Vincent, in Riverdale, the Bronx, made public yesterday the dean's scholastic honor lists for the second semester. Seventy-one students were named on the general honors list, which includes those who received an average of 90 per cent in all subjects.

Charles B. Hayward, retired editor and engineer, died suddenly of a heart attack in the yard of his home here early this morning while returning from the home of a neighbor. He was in his sixty-seventh year.
New York City, in serious as well as festive mood, joined yesterday with the rest of the country and Americans abroad in celebrating Washington's Birthday.

Ira J. Taylor, Democratic State chairman and former penitentiary warden, and Tony Phelan, former prison clerk, were indicted by the Ada County grand jury yesterday on charges of misuse of public funds and embezzlement.

The New York Rovers suffered their first shut-out this season when they bowed to the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 2 to 0, in the star contest of the amateur holiday doubleheader at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
Foreigners bought American chewing gum of the value of $1,177,527 in 1937, export trade statistics showed today.

Webster Hall, traditional scene of many a bohemian revel at 119 East Eleventh Street, was the scene early yesterday of a fire that burned out the interior and killed a watchman and a porter, who were asleep inside.
Arkansas' flood "danger point" shifted suddenly today to the extreme southwestern corner of the State, where two main levees on the Red River broke and took two lives.

The names of an even two dozen Dodgers who have signed contracts were announced yesterday by-Larry MacPhail, executive vice president of the Brooklyn club. MacPhail's holdout troubles are not ended, however.

The British Ambassador, the Earl of Perth, leaves tomorrow morning for London, where he will arrive late Thursday. After receiving instructions from his government Friday he will leave for Rome again on Saturday, to be back at his post in time to begin negotiations with the Italian Government Monday.

Faced with the threat of an open battle at a meeting of the Democratic State Committee in Harrisburg Friday, Pennsylvania party leaders made another futile attempt last night to end factional differences and agree on a compromise candidate for Governor.

Joseph P. Kennedy, newly appointed Ambassador to Great Britain and former chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, will sail today for London on the steamship Manhattan of the United States Lines to take up his post.

Dr. Earle G. Brown, Director of Public Health and Welfare of Arlington County, Va., and former Health Commissioner of the State of Kansas, will become Health Commissioner of Nassau County, a post created under the new charter that became effective Jan. 1, according to announcement tonight by Dr. Benjamin R. Allison, chairman of the county Board of Health.

Following are excerpts from my diary, written while our party of four were on the icefloe: Feb. 18.-Ships already are approaching and we are communicating with Ostaltseff [leader of the rescue expedition] aboard the Taimyr several times daily.

Six priests representing separate Oriental, or Eastern, rites of the Catholic Church participated yesterday in a mass of concelebration at the Church of St. John the Baptist in West Thirtieth Street near Seventh Avenue. It is the first time that a service of this kind has been held in this city.

All three members of the crew were killed when a German Junkers night mail plane on the Cologne-Paris route crashed shortly before it was due to land at Le Bourget at 5 o'clock this morning. It is believed that fog

Elliot Paul, whose "The Life and Death of a Spanish Town" was one of last season's best sellers, has written a new novel, "Concert Pitch," which Random House will publish on March 17. Music in the modern world is the substance of this novel; Paris is the locale.

According to frank statements in the German press today, Chancellor Adolf Hitler has decided to hold foreign governments responsible for the good behavior of the press of their countries in all matters affecting Germany.

Yale must have a "strengthened faculty" so that it may capture the "ideal opportunity for bringing to a common ground the teaching enthusiasm of the faculty and the learning capacity of the undergraduate," President Seymour declared today.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Rose Berresford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur William Berresford, to John McClusky Blayney Jr., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 50 Central Park West. The Rev.
Sadie F., 5-year-old daughter of Donnacona, who has been in the habit of quitting, carried her speed for the full six furlongs today to win the feature race at the Fair Grounds.

A constant defense against rival ports and proposals affecting the commerce and transportation lines that link the port with the rest of the world is urged by the Port of New York Authority in its annual report, which will be submitted next month to the Governors of New York and New Jersey.
Performance of an operetta satirizing the New Deal was canceled by the board of governors of Detroit's Fine Art Society today, after a cast of sixty persons had been rehearsing for two weeks.

The famous Slingin' Sam Baugh of football fame has been signed to a St. Louis Cardinal baseball contract. The information was wired to the Cards' office today by General Manager Branch Rickey, who said Baugh would report March 2 to the St. Petersburg (Fla.) Spring training camp.

Joseph B. Keenan, Assistant Attorney General, told the Kansas Democratic Club tonight that "our Republican opponents agree with the ambitions and purposes of the New Deal, but refuse to follow the program, although they have no plan of their own."

Countess Mercati, who had been passing the Winter in Athens, is expected to arrive today on the Champlain. She will pass several weeks in this city and Tuxedo Park before returning in the Spring to Athens, where her husband, Count Mercati, is Grand Marshal of the court.

Following is the text of Secretary Ickes's radio address today: May I say at the outset that I am speaking as a private citizen. In no respect do I express the views of the American Government or of President Roosevelt, who, under our Constitution, is charged with responsibility for foreign affairs.

Patrick A. Boyle, treasurer of the People's Savings and Trust Company of Hazleton, died of a heart attack this afternoon at a meeting of the Boy Scout Council of the Roman Catholic diocese of Scranton in the Catholic Club at Scranton. He was 55.

Revision of New Jersey's tax system and "more rigid equalization of assessed values throughout the State" were recommended today by J. H. Thayer Martin, State Tax Commissioner, in his annual report to the Legislature.

The House Ways and Means Committee has spoiled a record for substantial tax improvement by a 15-to-10 vote to retain the unsound "third basket" tax. The modifications made from the tax as originally proposed are of little importance compared with the retention of the principle.

James Loucheim, Village Clerk Emeritus, celebrated his ninetythird birthday today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Harry Rascover, at 53 Washington Avenue. He said he did not feel as he did fifty years ago, but still he felt pretty good.

Led by Clarence (Buddy) Combs, who scored twelve goals, the pacesetting Evergreen Farms team topped Squadron C, 18-12, in their Metropolitan Indoor Polo League Senior Division clash at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night.

The annual report of the First Reinsurance Company of Hartford, Issued yesterday, showed that net premiums written in 1937 were 50.6 per cent larger than in 1936 and that the ratio of losses incurred to premiums earned in 1937 was 43.4 per cent, against 50.3 per cent in 1936.

Professor Paul Haertl, well-known balneologist, died here today at the age of 59. Director of the Bavarian laboratory for hot mineral spring research at Bad Kissingen, he was a member of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation and visited President Roosevelt in 1934.
The will of Michael H. Sauser, Cascade farmer and lumber dealer, would pay "dividends" on the indebtedness of twenty-five persons if it were held valid, relatives declared today.

Unbeaten Hireling, purchased early in the meeting by the Maemere Farm of DeWitt Page, captured the Nursery Stakes No. 1 for colts and geldings at Hialeah Park today. He had a length to spare at the end of a roughly run three furlongs, with Ariel Toy, the favorite, second home after he had been shut off. Cherry Jam, third, suffered even sharper interference.
Five meet records were broken today as St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn retained the team title in the fourth annual national Catholic invitation scholastic swimming meet.

The chief trouble with the youth of America today is that too many of them are taught that the world owes them a living, Captain Eddie Rickenbacker of New York, World War ace and now president of the Eastern Air Lines, said here today in a luncheon speech before a group of University of North Carolina officials and civic leaders.

The organization of boys and girls throughout the State into neighborhood units was announced yesterday by Lester D. O'Dell, president of the Federal McGuffey Society, Inc., 9 Rockefeller Plaza. One object of the units will be to provide children with wholesome books, such as the McGuffey Readers.

Idleness brings more persons afoul of the law than any other cause, Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing Prison, who has handled criminals for the last twenty-five years, said here in an interview today.

A Brighton Beach housewife was accused yesterday of being the "finger woman," or inside informant, of the three gunmen who held up ten women and one man at a poker party in the .apartment of Mrs. Anna Berg at 3,031 Brighton Fourteenth Street, Brighton Beach, on Saturday afternoon and took $3,000. worth of jewelry and $400 in cash.
Nazis tonight expected that an AngloGerman accord would follow on the heels of a settlement of British and Italian differences in a move for pacification of Europe.
Maxwell Howard's Stagehand captured the fourth running of the $60,275 Santa Anita Derby today, outracing a crack field of 3-year-olds to the wild excitement of more than 52,000 spectators.

Laurence G. Tighe, vice president of Brown, Harriman Co. of Boston, was today announced by President Charles Seymour of Yale as associate treasurer of the university. He will join the staff in April, becoming the third officer in the university treasury, where George P. Day is treasurer and Thomas W. Farnam is associate treasurer and controller of the university's budget.

Supported by a court ruling today, Michael Edelman, a Philadelphia attorney, was ready to force the Commonwealth to start escheat proceedings which might yield him fees of $4,000,000 or more as an informant.

Manhattan properties involved in deals reported yesterday principally consisted of residential parcels. Several recently underwent alterations to remove violations in accordance with the Multiple Dwellings Law.

The body of Mrs. Harriet Brown Neilson, former aquatic star, now in the Bellevue Hospital morgue, will be cremated if the directions of her sister, Katharine Irwin of Santa Ana, Calif., are followed by Dr. Thomas A. Gonzales,

Miss Marie Louise McIlhenny, daughter of Mrs. Edgar Allan Poe of Ropsley, Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to Bayard Henry Roberts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac W. Roberts of Snowdon, Bala Cynwyd.
Piling up its highest scoring total of the season, the Brooklyn College basketball team last night defeated the Lowell Textile quintet, 54 to 41, at the Brooklyn court.

Miss Virginia Mandeville of Summit, N. J., gave a dinner last night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis in honor of Miss Lidie Lane Sloan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Scott Sloan of Brooklyn, and Andrew M. McBurney Jr. of Philadelphia, whose marriage will take place here on Saturday in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

The marriage of Miss Alice Lassner, daughter of Mrs. Albert Lassner of New York and the late Mr. Lassner, to Leonard Goldenson, also of this city, took place yesterday afternoon at the SherryNetherland.

The vote of confidence which Mr. Chamberlain received last evening in the House of Commons was clearly foreshadowed by the decision of the Conservative party in caucus to give him its support. At the end of a two

General Hugh S. Johnson, first head of the NRA for President Roosevelt, declared here yesterday that the Administration is now attempting to "change the old minority Democratic party into a new, permanent majority party of the submerged classes."
A one-man show of water-colors, oils and drawings by John Marin opened yesterday at. An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue, to remain until March 27.

As a result of the recent meeting of small business men here and the presentation of resolutions to President Roosevelt, Washington's "newest lobby" was set up today under the name of the American Small Business Council.
Senator Copeland told the Senate today that the utility industry was prepared to spend $4,000,000,000 on expansion and replacements if "proper encouragement" were given by the government.
Twentieth national conference of the Progressive Education Association will open at the Hotel Pennsylvania at 10 A. M. and continue through Saturday.

Euretta J. Kellett Fellowships of Columbia College have been given to Donald W. O'Connell of Elmhurst, Queens, and Richard C. Rowland of Wayne, Pa., it was announced yesterday by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes. Awarded annually to

Winning eight of nine events, the New York University swimming 13 team swept to a 51-to-24 victory over Brooklyn College yesterday in the latter's pool. John Calitri captured two tests for the Violet in the one-sided triumph.

The Italian Ambassador, Vicenzo Lojacono, today presented to War Minister Eurico Caspar Dutra as "a friendly gesture to a sister Latin nation" the plane in which Bruno Mussolini flew here from Rome last month.

The report of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System, including the Brooklyn Queens Transit Company, for the seven months through January, made public yesterday, shows a net income, after expenses and charges, of $715,229, compared with one of $2,818,610 in the first seven months of its preceding fiscal year.

After having declared that the League of Nations was incapable of enforcing collective security, Prime Minister Chamberlain was upheld, 330 to 168, in the House of Commons yesterday on his policy of working with the dictators.

The holiday spirit fastened a firm grip upon this famed health resort today. The sun, for the first time since the Giants' preliminary squad arrived here, burst out in all its splendor and thawed things out in almost record time.
A Scottish terrier, Heather Gloria, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Stalter of Hohokus, N. J., tonight was named best in the twenty-sixth annual all breed show of the Eastern Dog Club.

The fast-skating Canadiens of Montreal handed the New York Rangers a 2-to-1 defeat at Madison Square Garden last night. Jumping into the lead early in the game, the Frenchmen held a 1-to-O advantage over the New Yorkers until the third period.

George Copeland, a pianist of unique gifts, if not of consistently balanced performance, played for a large audience last night in Carnegie Hall. Long known as a eight Debussy interpreter of especial sensitiveness, he included many works of that composer on his program, to the obvious pleasure of the gathering.

The Department of Hospitals announced yesterday that, with the approval of the Board of Estimate, it had completed preliminary plans for an important addition to Riverside Hospital, on North Brother Island. The hospital, originally for the treatment of contagious diseases, is now almost exclusively a tuberculosis hospital.

With the crisis over Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's resignation quieted down, formal discussions of an Anglo-Irish treaty will be resumed tomorrow afternoon, when Premier Eamon de Valera of Eire [Ireland] calls on Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain at the House of Commons.

The Turkish Government, which has embarked upon an extensive land, sea and air rearmament program, has approached American companies in tentative attempts to arrange for the purchase of arms or military equipment in this country, it was discovered yesterday.
A trio of brilliant schoolboy stars lived up to advance expectations today as records were topped in the third annual Dartmouth interscholastic track meet.
The Japanese columns that are driving southward toward the Lung-Hai Railway were reported today to have made important gains at the eastern and western ends of the battle front.

Credit for tonight's successful opening of "Dodsworth" at the Palace Theatre is awarded to the unseen writers and technicians-to Sinclair Lewis, the author; Sidney Howard. the adapter; Clifford Pember,

A surplus of 10,000,000 pesos (about $3,300,000 at the official rate of exchange) was shown by the Argentine Government for 1937, according to an announcement yesterday by the Argentine Information Bureau.

Hugh Lloyd Thomas, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary in the British Embassy in Paris and one of the world's leading amateur jockeys, was killed today when his horse, Periwinkle II, fell after taking the last fence in the three-mile steeplechase here.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, taxes and other charges, amounting to $24,170,205, compared with $24,750,723 earned in the preceding twelve months, a decrease of $580,518.

District Attorneys Thomas E. Dewey of Manhattan and William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn, as well as representatives of New York City bar and civic associations expressed today their unqualified opposition to bills passed by the Senate and pending in the Assembly which would abolish "blue-ribbon" juries in the city and Westchester County.

Bill Speary of Philadelphia, one of the best 112-pounders seen during three hectic sessions of the Golden Gloves tournament, emerged as a semi-finalist at the close of the quarter-finals at the Hippodrome last night.

Moving rapidly to define and legalize his personal dictatorship, the Rumanian King has presented his people with a new Constitution. Thereby, under the guise of creating "firmer' legal foundations for our country and the conduct of public life along a secure, free and healthy course," Carol would acquire nearly absolute power.
Richard K. Mellon's Escape III won the Master's Flask, feature race of the Camden Hunt Washington's Birthday program at the historic Springdale course. A crowd of 10,000 watched the sport.

An attempt to increase from $250,000,000 to $400,000,000 the supplemental relief appropriation asked by President Roosevelt was defeated in the Senate today, 53 to 22. Senator Bone offered the amendment, but only fifteen other Democrats rallied to his support.

It takes more than the decision of the scoutmaster to dampen the vernal emotions in the nature study troop of the Kips Bay Boys Club at 301 East Fifty-second Street. Yesterday morning William Bryant, leader of the troop, led his lads, thirty-eight strong, on what was to be an ordinary hike.

Returning to the scene where he first gained world-wide fame in 1932 by capturing the Olympic championship, the dynamic Birger Ruud gave another masterful ski jumping performance today at the Intervales 6-meter hill.
Young Corbett, 33-year-old former welterweight boxing champion, won a slashing ten-round decision from Freddie Apostoli, nine years his junior, today.

Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, was asked by THE NEW YORK TIMES to comment t on the report from Washington, published on Monday, that Federal agencies, including the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Securities and

The excellent performances put on by Frank Hogan's retrievers at the Sportsmen's Show are drawing a lot of comment from the visitors, and if his dogs will put on as good a performance in the open Hogan is going to be in great demand as a trainer.

Columbia's track and field forces, pointing for the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. indoor championships, in which the Lions will be the defending titleholders, on March 5, yesterday captured top honors in the fourth annual Polar Bear Meet, outscoring Princeton and Pennsylvania in the outdoor triangular competition on the new board track at South Field.

Washington's Birthday was celebrated in the nation's capital and its vicinity with speeches, memorial services, pilgrimages to Mount Vernon and the reading in both Houses of Congress of Washington's Farewell Address.

Lee Tracy who was presented by the screen in the early thirties as the typical newspaper reporter in "Blessed Event" and other films of similar stripe is to recreate his romantic portrayal of the press in "What's Your Number?" at RKO.

As is the custom in the Manhasset Bay Dinghy Association fleet, the winners in today's racing, which attracted eighteen boats, were Bud Moxham in Class B and Leonard Romagna in Class D. Their pursuers were not even close.
Foreign Minister Ortega Frier today announced that the Dominican Government would file a proposal for an American League of Nations with the Pan-American Union in Washington on March 1.

About seventy players from the United States, Canada and Bermuda swung through a special eighteenhole handicap as a preliminary to the Mid-Ocean Golf Club's fiftieth annual tournament over the Tuckerstown links today.

Dr. Glenn Frank, chairman of the policy committee of the Republican party, outlined his ideas of the remedies for what he said were the political and economic ills of the country tonight at a dinner of 500 members of the McKinley Association.
Senator James Hamilton Lewis of Illinois

The volunteer fire departments of Long Island communities joined with Brooklyn's volunteer firemen for the forty-seventh annual paradeof the Kings County Volunteer Firemen's Association yesterday morning, the highlight of the boroughh celebration of Washington's Birthday.

Represented by two brothers, Miguel and Jose de Capriles, the former an ex-national champion and the latter a ranking star for several years, and by Ted Gold, present intercollegiate titleholder, the Salle Santelli "A" team won the open epee team competition yesterday from a record entry at the Fencers Club.

Old school acquaintance, long forgot-for seventy-two years, to be exact-was renewed yesterday at the alumni day celebration marking the seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of Adelphi Academy, 282 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn.

Setting a pool record, the Rutgers medley trio led its swimming team to a 45-to-30 victory over Brown University tonight. Frank Paret, Al Timko and Ken MacWhinney, swimming the backstroke, breast-stroke and free style, respectively, clipped six-tenths of a second from the 1931 record, finishing in 3:08.2.

Dr. Guillermo J. Machado, a first cousin of former President Gerardo' Machado of Cuba, died in Kingston, Jamaica, yesterday. His widow, the former Anna S. Mayhew of Philadelphia, and their son, Horatio, were notified of his death as they boarded an airplane at Miami to fly to his bedside. He was 58 years old.

Transatlantic air travel will draw 15,000 passengers annually soon after non-stop flying boat service is established between the United States and Europe, W. H. Coverdale, president of American Export Lines, estimated yesterday in a statement advocating a government subsidy for an aeromarine service.
More than 500 members of the National Retail Liquor Package Stores Association, in annual convention here, were the guests today of Maryland distilling corporations.

Firms engaged in the various branches of the apparel industry figured largely in the commercial leases reported yesterday. They included dealers in men's and women's clothing, underwear, furs and hosiery.
