After warning that he would be "tactless" in his remarks, Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, told 1,750 teachers attending the eleventh anniversary luncheon of the Jewish Teachers Association at the Hotel Commodore yesterday that he could see no reason for the existence of their organization.

Dr. Orrin Sage Wightman of New York entertained at dinner tonight at the Sea Island Yacht Club. His guests included Mrs. James Butler, Mrs. Henry C. Merritt, Dr. John Rogers, Judge F. D. Fuller, Mr. and Mrs. James Allen, Mr. and Mrs. George Alfred Cluett, all of New York;
Before a distinguished audience two American.editors were honored today at the annual commemoration exercises of Johns Hopkins University.

George MacDonald was host to a large group for cocktails today at the penthouse at Whitehall, which he shares with his brother, Henry MacDonald. The guests of honor were members of the Gulf Stream polo team, mostly army officers, who will leave Saturday for Kingston, Jamaica, to play the English team captained by Lord Louis Mountbatten.
Frank Lamson-Scribner, retired Department of Agriculture scientist, died at a Washington hospital today. Pneumonia was the cause of his death. He was 86 years old.

Six firemen were overcome by smoke and a seventh was cut on the hand at a fire yesterday in the basement of 90-26 Jamaica Avenue, Woodhaven, Queens. All were able to remain on duty after being treated at the scene.
The French Government decided today to act prudently in the situation created by Chancellor Hitler's declaration of German policy and Anthony Eden's resignation as British Foreign Secretary.

At least 12,000 workers have been killed in the border clashes between Haitians and Dominicans, according to John W. Vandercook, author of "Black Majesty," who returned yesterday on the. Grace liner Santa Paula from his seventh visit to the West Indies.

Tumultuous seas tonight clutched at four distressed freighters in or near midocean. The 1,200-ton British motorship Lycia, bound for Philadelphia and Norfolk, Va., from Fowey, England, had engine trouble 750 miles east of Bermuda, the Foundation Maritime, Ltd., reported here.

The M. Taylor Pyne honor prize, the highest general distinction award that Princeton University confers on an undergraduate, was presented this morning to Frank W. Rounds Jr., '38, of Winchester, Mass. Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university, made the presentation at the annual Washington's Birthday meeting of the National Alumni Association in Nassau Hall.

An East Side narcotics ring was believed smashed last night with the arrest of three men and the confiscation by the police of a quantity of heroin valued at $10,000. The men, arrested in various parts of the city, described themselves as Philip Seltzer, 25 years old, of 414 Fox Street, the Bronx:

Accused of soliciting alms while they pushed a cart containing their 2-year-old boy through the Yorkville section, Ernest Smith, 45, employed at $56 a month as a WPA gardener, and his wife, Mildred, 26, of 449 West Forty-fourth Street, were paroled in their own custody for a hearing next Monday when arraigned in Night Court last night before Magistrate Morris Rothenberg charged with disorderly conduct. Smith pleaded guilty, but his

An unexpected rally in Liverpool, strength in overseas commodity markets and rumors of political tension in Rumania stimulated today a rally in prices of wheat on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange and erased early losses. Final quotations were 1 1/4

Performing on a slide covered with pulverized ice, Olaf Aasen, star flier from the Staten Island Ski Club, carried off the top honors in Class A as the Norswift Ski Club staged its annual metropolitan jumping tournament on its hill in Silver Lake Park today.

One of the most heavily subscribed theatre benefits of the season will take place tonight when the performance of "Once Is Enough" at Henry Miller's Theatre will be given in aid of the health program conducted by the Frontier Nursing Service in isolated sections of a large area in the Kentucky mountains.
The City College varsity basketball team overwhelmed Villanova in a rough game by the unexpectedly one-sided margin of 46-27 in the Lavender gymnasium last night.
To save Europe and the whole structure of our civilization from Bolshevism the gentlemen operating the two ends of the Berlin-Rome axis have employed the same highly original technique.

Ashton C. Shallenberger, former Democratic Governor of Nebraska and former Representative, collapsed in the middle of a speech before 1,000 farmers today and died a few moments later. He was 75 years old.
With more than 1,200 entries, Bloomingdale's will open its seventh annual pet dog show today. The judging will start at 1:30 P. M., with toy dogs the first class on the program.
Army's polo team had little trouble in defeating Pennsylvania Military College in the Cadet riding hall today, when it scored in every d period except the second to win by 8-3.

Three thousand persons lined Los Cerrillos Airfield when five United States Army "flying fortresses" landed at 1 P. M. today after a record-breaking trans-Andean flight of more than 700 miles from Buenos Aires, Argentina, in 4 hours 38 minutes.

Sam Wetherill, who has guided yachts in seven Bermuda races, as well as one transatlantic and a Fastnet struggle, came forth today in the sailing dinghy regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club to take three of four events for the Class X craft.

Three hundred Indiana political leaders headed by Governor Townsend are in Washington tonight as the advance guard of a movement to obtain for Paul V. McNutt the Democratic nomination for President in 1940.

Whether Ignatio Lupo (Lupo, the Wolf) will be permitted to carry to the Supreme Court a fight for freedom may be decided by the justices at their regular conference Saturday, according to reports today.

On the eve of his departure today for London to assume his new. duties as Ambassador to the Court of St. James, Joseph P. Kennedy was denounced by a group of C. I. O. maritime labor unions yesterday for his views on maritime labor as expressed before the Senate Committees on Commerce and Labor on Feb. 16 in Washington.
Seabiscuit headed a held of twentytwo named today to run in the $7,500 San Antonio handicap at a mile and a furlong Saturday at Santa Anita.

The only public mention here to date of Pastor Martin Niemoeller's trial appeared today in Schwarze Kops. This official organ of the Hitler Elite Guard refers to Pastor Niemoeller as a man wholly devoid of honor. It says:

New Republic Radio Corporation, a subsidiary of the Duro-Test Corporation, North Bergen, N. J., will start immediate production of radio receiving tubes for the retail market. Charles Mandera, radio engineer will be in charge of production.
An immediate boycott applied to Japan would stop the Asiatic war in three months, William E. Dodd, former Ambassador to Germany, declared yesterday.

Trust busters of the Roosevelt Administration will meet in New York City Thursday night for an anti-monopoly rally, in an attempt to turn the tide from the Richberg plan for a cooperative effort between government and business.
The Brown University wrestling team won six out of eight matches today to defeat Rutgers University, 24 to 6, before 600 Scarlet "old grads" gathered for the annual Rutgers alumni day.

A girl was killed and two other per- P sons were injured, one of them n seriously, when the automobile in n which they were riding crashed through the gate at the Broadway crossing of the Long Island Railroad here tonight and was struck by a westbound train.

Rube H. Helsel, veteran gunner of Long Island City, won the George L. Lyon Memorial Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Helsel won by breaking 198 out of a possible 200 targets.

German and Italian intervention in the Spanish civil war and Japan's undeclared war on China were denounced as "unprovoked aggression" and condemned as "treaty violations gravely endangering world peace," in a resolution adopted at the closing session today of the convention of the National Lawyers Guild.

With growing Japanese aggression in the Far East generally considered a threat to the safety of the Philippines, and with High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt now conferring in Washington on island affairs, the much debated question of Philippine independence has taken on fresh importance.

Breaking of world peace would affect all securities of life insurance companies, G. Robley Mackay, assistant treasurer of the Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada, declared here today at the mid-Winter meeting of the Financial Section of the American Life Convention.
The Senate Democrats decided at a general conference today on Governor Lehman's "program bills" to scrap his recommendation for greater home rule for cities.

Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, decried "nationalistic programs of self-sufficiency" today and said that "at least a part of present-day war-mongering is due directly to the clogging of the channels of world trade."

The ensemble cleaner carton and cleaning tool kit of the Hoover Company, North Canton, Ohio, designed by Henry Dreyfuss, has been awarded the Irwin D. Wolf Trophy in the seventh competition for distinctive merit in packaging, according to the American Management Association, sponsoring

Myron Hammon, in 471 Park Ave: Mrs. Helen Morton, in 74 E 56th St: Frances Teller, in 795 Madison Ave; James Todd, in 63 W 56th St: Alice Arvine. in 341 E 34th St; Earl Harding, through William A. White Sons, in the Ardea, 31 W 12th St; Huberth Huberth, Inc. broker.

Breaking of world peace would affect all securities of life insurance companies, G. Robley Mackay, assistant treasurer of the Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada, declared here today at the mid-Winter meeting of the Financial Section of the American Life Convention.
The Senate Democrats decided at a general conference today on Governor Lehman's "program bills" to scrap his recommendation for greater home rule for cities.

Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, decried "nationalistic programs of self-sufficiency" today and said that "at least a part of present-day war-mongering is due directly to the clogging of the channels of world trade."

The ensemble cleaner carton and cleaning tool kit of the Hoover Company, North Canton, Ohio, designed by Henry Dreyfuss, has been awarded the Irwin D. Wolf Trophy in the seventh competition for distinctive merit in packaging, according to the American Management Association, sponsoring

Myron Hammon, in 471 Park Ave: Mrs. Helen Morton, in 74 E 56th St: Frances Teller, in 795 Madison Ave; James Todd, in 63 W 56th St: Alice Arvine. in 341 E 34th St; Earl Harding, through William A. White Sons, in the Ardea, 31 W 12th St; Huberth Huberth, Inc. broker.
Reuben A. Lazarus, assistant to Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, will be the speaker at a luncheon meeting tomorrow of the West of Central Park Association at the Hotel Empire.

Mr. and Mrs. Fred E. Rogers of this place celebrated today their fiftieth wedding anniversary with a dinner party at their home. Guests included Mr. Rogers's sister, Mrs. William E. Weaver of Whitestone, L. I., who attended their wedding on Feb. 22, 1888, in Altay, N. Y.;

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The various conferences that the President requested with large industrial leaders and representatives of smaller business are a matter of past history. Mr. Roosevelt has had meetings of a similar nature regularly ever since he became President in 1933.

Harley L. Clarke, ousted head of the $400,000,000 Utilities Power and Light Corporation, was charged with fraud in a complicated $2,000,000 stock and loan transaction of the corporation and its subsidiaries and holding companies, in a memorandum issued today by Federal Judge William H. Holly.

Cooperating in the drive against social disease, all of the 240 co-educational students of Wagner College, Staten Island, a non-sectarian school under the sponsorship of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, started yesterday to take the Wassermann test.
Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Feb. 23, unless specified: San Juan to Bridgetown Bar: Badger, Decatur, Dickerson, Fairfax, Schenck, Tattnall.
Today's major events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; "Siegfried," afternoon, and "Traviata," evening, Metropolitan Opera House.

Should the Interstate Commerce Commission grant the pending application for a general rise of 15 per cent in freight rates, the revenues of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad would be increased by $3,500,000 a year, J. M. Davis, president, said at the annual meeting of the Lackawanna yesterday.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Elizabeth Jane Parks, daughter of Mrs. Grace L. Parks of New York, formerly of Kew Gardens, Queens, and of Harold A. Parks of New Haven, Conn., to Alan Mills MacQuarrie, son of Mr. and Mrs. David W. MacQuarrie of Upper Montclair, N. J.

A strong demand from consumer organizations for a requirement that percentage of weighting in silk fabrics be incorporated in the Federal Trade Commission's fairtrade-practice rules for the silk industry loomed yesterday, and it was learned that a substantial number of manufacturers of quality silks will support the demand.

The post-season competition which will culminate in the series for the Stanley Cup and the world's hockey championship will get under way on March 22, it was announced at a meeting of the National Hockey League at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

Former President Herbert Hoover, on the last day of a "sentimental journey" to Belgium, whose wartime suffering he helped ease as relief administrator, today received the Vermeil meda of honor, which only one other living person, King Leopold of the Belgians, possesses.
Deals involving large apartment houses on the upper West Side in Manhattan and the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn were announced yesterday by brokers.

The KnickerBocker Guild will give a performance of "Accent on Youth" on Sunday night at the Cort Theatre to assist Knickerbocker Hospital. The guild, organized three years ago, is composed of amateur players whose aim is to raise funds for the hospital.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

Thomas E. Harrop, secretary of the Rhode Island division of horse racing, today announced the formal granting of 1938 racing rates to Narragansett Park. The dates are Aug. 1 to Sept. 10 and Oct. 10 to Nov. 12.
The complicated film quota bill, many provisions of which have been rewritten in committee, was brought back to the House of Commons tonight for final passage.

Major Lovic P. Hodnette, Infantry, in relived from further duty as a member of the Corps of Instructors for the Command and General Staff Extension School. Major Charles M. Parkin, 65th Infantry, is designated as a member of the Corps of Instructors for the Command and General Staff Extension School.

Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the Zionist Organization of America, and Louis Lipsky, American member of the World Zionist Executive, sailed yesterday for London on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, accompanied by Dr. Bernard Joseph, legal adviser of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

Reflecting political developments in Europe, both domestic and foreign copper markets were unusually active yesterday. Abroad the price of the metal advanced to 10.40 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports, the highest level since Jan. 18.

Thomas Dimond, special racket investigator on the District Attorney's staff here and a former chief investigator for the District Attorney of Essex County, N. Y., died in a hospital today of a heart ailment. Mr. Dimond was an inspector with Scotland Yard in 1933.

Some 800 persons turned out for the second annual dinner of the New York Rod and Gun Editors Association in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore last night. A number of officials and honored guests were seated on the dais.
At the request of Leon Trotsky it was decided today to perform a second autopsy on the body of his son, Leon Sedoff, who died last week.

The Southern Pacific Company asked the Interstate Commerce. Commission today for permission to guarantee $2,500,000 of first-mortgage bonds of the El Paso Rock Island Railway Company and $577,000 of bonds of the Dawson Railway and Coal Company.
The new City Commission of Wildwood held its reorganization meeting today, electing George W. Krogman as Mayor and voting to reduce the salaries of the three members by a total of $1,950.
Colonel John R. R. Hannay, Quartermaster Corps, U. S. A., who was stationed at Governors Island, N. Y., died at Walter Reed General Hospital here today.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey reduced yesterday the price of gasoline in tank cars and tank wagon lots in Virginia 1/2 cent a gallon. The company said the reduction was made to meet comDetitive conditions.

Among the score of Giants doing their preliminary exercises here before advancing upon the main training base at Baton Rouge next week, there is perhaps none going about his daily tasks with greater enthusiasm and determination than one Walter Brown, the massive right-hander who can toss a safe or a baseball with almost equal facility.

Governor Lehman's bill appropriating $21,335,000 of the $40,000,000 bond issue for new public construction was the subject of examination today by the Assembly Ways and Means Committee at a public hearing.

The negotiations toward a contract between the League of New York Theatres and the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union apparently have reached an impasse, with arbitration likely as the next step.

Mr. and Mrs. Armistead Peter 3d have come from Washington to the Commodore. Mrs. George L. Degener and her sister, Miss Elizabeth Schmidt, have gone to Jamaica, B. W. I., whence they will leave on a South Sea Islands cruise.

Almost 500 singers, dancers, members of the chorus and the orchestra and stagehands have spent the last twenty-four hours in the Warsaw Opera House, where they intend to remain until Saturday in a sit-down strike called when the management announced its inability to pay February salaries.
Lee Bradley, witness for the Senate "graft-hunting" committee, surrendered to Police Chief L. G. Corlett of East Cleveland on a warrant charging prejury.
The Senate Commerce Committee gave its approval today to a resolution by Senator Bailey proposing a sub-

Wesleyan conquered Williams at basketball for the second time this season tonight, 38 to 36. With the score tied at 11-all late in the first half Wesleyan forged ahead to lead 22 to 16 at the intermission.

Edward Rogers, defending national amateur pocket billiard champion, lost his third straight match in the current title tournament last night at the Strand Academy, bowing to Arthur Cranfield, 125-47, in twelve innings.

Ellsworth Vines defeated Fred Perry, 6-1, 6-4, today to take a 13-10 lead in the current series between the pro tennis stars. Perry and Berkeley Bell defeated Vines and Walter Senior, 7-5, 7-5, in a doubles exhibition.

The Union Cooperative Shoe Association, organized by shoe workers and supported by the State Federation of Labor, has failed and is to be liquidated. It was organized in February, 1937, many union men and women being stockholders.

The Petroleum Heat and Power Company has called a special meeting of stockholders for March 10 to revise its capital structure in order to bring about the acquisition of a large block of its own outstanding stock.

Sweepalot, the Dixiana's fleet 4-year-old gelding, outran the Blue Moon Stable's Warfellow to win the Eureka Handicap for older horses that featured today's program at Santa Anita Park. Amor Brujo, South American racer. finished third.

Contributions totaling $52,000 have been received by the committee with which Mayor La Guardia is working to raise funds for the completion and opening of the entire interior of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, it was reported yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning at a meeting at the cathedral.

Theodore Mitchell, founder and president of the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, died at 7 A. M. yesterday at his home, 11-07 154th Street, Beechhurst, Queens. He was 63 years old.

Aiming at more effective methods in preventing the spread of tuberculosis, investigations devoted to the chemistry of the tuberculosis germ, carried on cooperatively for ten years in the Sterling Chemistry Laboratory of Yale University- under auspices of the medical research committee of the National Tuberculosis Association, were described today by Rudolph J. Anderson, Professor of Chemistry.

The filing of a revised all-purpose general service gas rate by the Queens Borough Gas and Electric by Company was announced yesterday by the Public Service Commission. The new rate will apply to territory including the Fifth Ward of Queens and the southwestern part of Nassau County.
The one-man show of paintings by Philip Evergood at the A. C. A. Gallery, 52 West Eighth Street, serves to reinforce this artist's already established reputation.

To make clear the terms of its debt settlement proposals submitted recently to the State Department, the Hungarian Government, through its Minister, John Pelenyi, made public today a copy of the aide memoire.

The Canadian Pacific Building, twenty-one story office, store and church structure, comprising most of the block front on the west side of Madison Avenue, between Fortythird and Forty-fourth Streets, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street Salesrooms.

Max Baer, former heavyweight champion, yesterday renewed his license as a boxer in this State when he appeared before a meeting of the State Athletic Commission accompanied by his manager, Ancil Hoffman.

Lily Pons, Metropolitan Opera star, went yesterday on the Crusader, a streamlined train operated by the Reading Company and the Central Railroad of New Jersey, with E. W. Scheer, president of the two companies, and other officials, to participate in the ceremony of naming the train in Philadelphia.

Directors of Remington Rand, Inc., voted yesterday to declare a year-end interim cash dividend of 25 cents a share to holders of common stock, in addition to an extra common dividend of 1-100 share of $4.50 cumulative preferred stock.
Residents of this Western Pennsylvania borough of 2,000 have seen the light, through darkness. A month ago the treasury was exhausted so the Council ordered all street lights darkened.
Arrangements were made yesterday for the transfer of a membership on the New York Stock Exchange for $70,000, an advance of $3,000 from the last previous sale.
Tuesday night a 22-year-old Western Union messenger on his bicycle boldly pursued two men from the scene of an attempted hold-up in Brooklyn until he was able to have them arrested.

Confronted with increasing demands on its services and the need to extend facilities to unserved areas of the city, the Legal Aid Socity, supported mainly by lawyers in the past, will seek to raise at least $25,000 this year from laymen.

Representative Thompson of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee that will hold public hearings on the Boylan Bill to require license fees for radio broacasting stations based on the watt power assigned, said today that hearings would be held at this session.
A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Casey Jones" tonight at the Fulton Theatre for the benefit of Greenwich House.

American higher education was accused of deliberately evading its responsibility to public service in an address today at the annual convention of the American Council of Guidance and Personnel Associations at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall here.

The Canadian Pacific Railway reported yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had agreed to acquire from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation $6,162,245 of secured promissory notes of the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie (Soo) Railway,

Rear Admiral James M. Moore, United States Coast Guard, retired, died yesterday at the age of 76. Admiral Moore, a native of Baltimore, served for years in the Arctic and during the World War commanded the station at Arundel Cove. Baltimore.
Sales of California navel oranges in January were in line with the size of the crop, running ahead of five of the past six years, the California Fruit Growers Exchange reported today.
The Navy's war games in the Pacific will involve a "highly confidential" problem and will be carried out under war-time secrecy, officials said today.

Shooting sub-par golf, Miss Patty Berg, 20-year-old Minneapolis sensation and winner of the qualifying medal yesterday, chalked up an easy triumph in the first round of match play for the annual South Atlantic women's golf championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today.
Miss Marie Cummings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin S. Cummings of this city, was married tonight to O. Lee Lundemann of Prospect Park.

The Legislature recessed tonight until tomorrow night without the Republican majority being able to agree on a method of making effective the plan of Governor Moore, Democrat, to take 20,000 employable men from the relief rolls and put them to work improving secondary roads.

The war between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization was heightened when President William Green of the federation today revoked the charter of the Pennsylvania State Federation of Labor.
The visitor from Mars said he was getting on fine with his study of municipal government in New York, but he said every little

Plans were filed yesterday for a two-story office and parking space in South William Street to cost $40,000. Other plans included alterations in Manhattan, a gasoline station in the Bronx and several homes in Queens.
It is a fact of very large significance that under various pressures of various kinds the budget estimates which Mr. Roosevelt submitted to Congress last month are melting gradually away.

With arrival of General Iwane Matsui at a Japanese port today the Japanese public learned of the sweeping change in the high command in Central China. The commander-in-chief and his two principal divisional commanders, Lieut. Gen. Prince Yashuhiko Asaka and Lieut. Gen. Heisuke Yanagawa have been recalled.

Continued reductions in employment and payrolls, reflecting more than seasonal losses of non-agricultural jobs since October, and a decrease of nearly $20,000,000 in weekly wages between Dec. 15 and Jan. 15, were reported today by Secretary Perkins.

Charles G. Hensley, a patent lawyer who maintained an office at 150 Nassau Street for the last twenty years, died of an apoplectic stroke yesterday as he was on his way to his office. He was 57 years old.

Count Doynel de Saint-Quentin, the new French Ambassador to the United States, who succeeds Georges Bonnet, now Minister of State, arrived from Paris last night on the French liner Champlain. He will go to Washington today.
George C. Stebbins of Catskill, noted writer of hymns, will celebrate his ninety-second birthday anniversary Saturday.

Joe Louis paid tribute to Nathan Mann's gameness and punching ability after the fight last night. "That boy packs a great right hand," commented the Brown Bomber. 'I must admit he hurt me with it in that second round.

Miss Doris Helen Cornehlsen, daughter of Christian Cornehlsen of 254 Cumberland Street, Brooklyn, and the late Mrs. Cornehlsen, was married last evening in St. Luke's Lutheran Church, Brooklyn, to Rodney Edwards, son of Mrs. Alfred B. Edwards of Plandome and East Marion, L. I., and the late Mr. Edwards.

Beekman Pool of the Harvard Club, second in the association's Class A ranking, and Conway Hoffman, another Class A player, were among the victors last night as the first round in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's doubles championship was completed at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn.

Hackley easily defeated Scarsdale High School in basketball today, 30--16. Bill Loock and Bob Taylor were high scorers with 10 and 9 points, respectively. The score at half time stood at 18--11 in favor of the Gray and Black.

The battle for possession of the Lung-Hai Railway has developed an almost continuous front, 300 miles long, stretching across China from east to west from a point east of Hsuchow to the vicinity of Loyang in Western Honan Province.

Avenging an early-season defeat in New York, Long Island University's Blackbirds defeated Marshall College's Buckeye Conference basketball champions tonight, 38 to 33. A record-breaking crowd of 5,000 witnessed the game.

A proposal for amendment of the anti-trust laws to enable small business to meet big business in equal competition was accepted without dissent yesterday at the annual convention of the National Paper Trade Association in the Waldorf Astoria.

Fortified by renewed assurances in recent days that full French support can be counted on against any attempt to undermine the independence of Czechoslovakia, the government is prepared to take a firm attitude in reply to certain points in Chancellor Hitler's declaration of policy.

The Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment today killed the Buckley bill, sponsored by the New York State Conference of Mayors, which would cut down the certiorari proceedings for tax assessment reductions.
The East Stroudsburg Teachers basketball team yesterday defeated the girls of. New College, 29 to 28, in a closely contested game in Thompson Gymnasium.
Three men were killed and eighteen persons were injured in a fire that swept the mining village of Maguarichic, Chihuahua State, yesterday. Dispatches estimated the damage at nearly $280,000.

Assailing Hitlerism as "fundamentally anti-German and antiChristian" and picturing the Nazi regime as "the Antichrist" and the enemy of Western civilization, Dr. Ernst Wilhelm Meyer, for sixteen years a member of the German diplomatic service, announced to the public last night his resignation as first secretary of the German Embassy in Washington.
A questionnaire on the safest system for starting races is being sent to horsemen throughout the country, Herbert Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, announced yesterday. Mr.

Lawrin, the 3-year-old colt that had run two indifferent races here, presumably because of a strain suffered at the post, was a decisive winner of the Grade B handicap at Hialeah Park today over four highly rated Widener Challege Cup eligibles.

The Newtown High five clinched first place in the Queens Division of the P. S. A. L. tournament when it defeated Richmond Hill, 46-29, yesterday on the loser's court. It was the fourteenth straight league victory for the visitors. John Carroll of the winners was high scorer with 14 points.
Demands for a "new deal" for consumers will be presented to President Roosevelt tomorrow by a delegation representative of the buyers of the country.

The Lake Placid Club Sno Birds canceled today's 14-kilometer crosscountry run, the final event of their seventeenth annual invitation ski tournament. There was a snow fall, but it wasn't heavy enough to provide good running conditions.

Sales of aluminum, increasingly used in industry, are off compared with last year, but not so much so as steel, and the Southern California figures show a better average than the rest of the country because of the growth of airplane manufacturing industry here.

Controversy developed yesterday among members of the City Council committee investigating Councilman Michael J. Quill when counsel for Mr. Quill accused John Cashmore, Council Democrat from Brooklyn, of having employed a strike-breaking detective agency to investigate his client.
The firm of W. H. Goadby Co., one of the oldest houses on the New York Stock Exchange, on April 1 will absorb the firm of Loew Co. and will move to the offices of the latter at 2 Wall Street.

The discharge of Colonel John G. Grimley, commanding officer of the 369th Infantry, New York National Guard, was ordered today by Governor Lehman on the unanimous recommendation of a special examining board.

MANHATTAN BLUAM, DAVID (June 30, 1937). Gross assets, $107,662; net, $96,574. To Annie Blum, widow, life estate in residue with right to invade principal; other specific and remainder bequests. Chief assets, mortgages. notes, cash and insurance, $72,822. Steckler, Frank Steckler, attornevs. 11 Broadway.

A 17-year-old girl who had fatally stabbed her father six weeks ago and who recently pleaded guilty to a charge of manslaughter received a suspended sentence and was freed on parole today with the sympathy of Judge Robert V. Kinkead in the Court of Common Pleas here.

An important conference will be held at the White House in the near future concerning the plight of the railroads. It is widely expected that the Interstate Commerce Commission will grant at least a large part of the "$517,000,000 rate increase" for which the roads have asked.

The official opening of American leathers, sponsored by the Tanners Council of America, and the shoe style conference for Fall, 1938, under the direction of the National Shoe Retailers Association, will be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on March 28 and 29.

Revised general fund estimates for 1938 totaling $124,098,396 were submitted yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick to the City Council, which must fix the basic tax rate for the year by March 3.

According to your news columns Chairman Morgan of TVA has transmitted to certain members of Congress copies of an unofficial letter written to a friend by J. D. Ross, administrator of the government-owned Bonneville power project. Dr. Morgan describes the letter as outlining what in Mr. Ross's view "constitutes a sound policy for the acquisition of power systems."

With only one dissenting vote, the Senate today passed the $250,000,000 Supplemental Relief Appropriation Bill requested by President Roosevelt to expand the relief rolls from 1,950,000 to an average of 2,300,000 persons between now and the end of the fiscal year on June 30.

Following the example of New York City policemen, who recently received legislative permission to purchase their uniforms through a cooperative association, other uniformed city employes moved today to obtain similar rights.

While the last three to four weeks have been characterized by increases in prices in nearly all of the fur markets of the world, due in part to a technical situation brought about by a shortage in fresh supplies, optimism on the outlook should be tempered pending strike developments in the New York market, according to the report issued yesterday by the merchandise committee of the American Fur Merchants Association, Inc.

Motor fuel stocks in the United States, including the amount of unfinished gasoline contained in naphtha distillates, at the close of last week amounted to 89,774,000 barrels, compared with 87,813,000 at the end of the previous week, an increase of 1,961.000, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Ernest Krenkel, wireless operator on the drifting Soviet weather station, suffered pneumonia during his polar sojourn and did not know it, it was revealed today after a special medical examination by Ship's Surgeon Chechulin.
Henry H. Rogers owes his father's estate $25,000, Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee ruled yesterday.

Newark police today sent out an eightState teletype alarm for the apprehension of two men who allegedly swindled Frank Walters, 55 years old, of 59-30 Palmetto Street, Glendale, Queens, of $9,000. Police would not reveal the names of the alleged swindlers.

Representatives of larger stores in all parts of the country appeared at the Hotel Pennsylvania to attend the New York Gift Show for the first time since the opening on Monday. Such higher-price goods as antique Russian ikons and English silver started to sell.

A "stoppage" of work tomorrow for 2,000 millinery workers in forty shops in twenty-five New Jersey municipalities, including this city, to await the signing by bat manufacturers of new contracts with the United Hat and Millinery Workers

A benefit midnight fashion show entitled "A Trip to Bermuda" was held last night at La Conga. A percentage of the proceeds will be turned over to the Music Education League, Inc., which, in the last fifteen years, has furthered the musical progress of more than 200,000 New York children.

Sales of seven consumer cooperative wholesale associations, affiliated with the Cooperative League of the U. S. A., totaled $27,551,759 in 1937, an increase of $5,275,578, or 23.6 per cent over 1936, the league announced yesterday.
Thepurchase by the King and Queen of two sets of the new five-suit bridge cards at the British Industries Fair yesterday gave a royal fillip to the popularity of this bridge novelty.

An assertion that a monopoly of the transit workers' labor movement had resulted from the recent closed shop decision of the New York Court of Appeals was made in a brief filed with the Supreme Court today.

Buyers who express disappointment in the recent Paris fashion showings because they offered "nothing new" fail to understand Spring merchandising requirements, according to A. W. Lasher, president of Mary Lee Frocks, Inc.

How wise the French Government has been to take several days for reflection over the situation created by Chancellor Hitler's speech and Anthony Eden's resignation as British Foreign Secretary has been shown by the division of French opinion.

In a torrid game in which the lead shifted frequently, Dartmouth scored a 7-to-6 overtime victory over Harvard in their International Intercollegiate Hockey League contest at the Boston Garden tonight before 2,500 spectators.
Houghton Mifflin will publish on March 15 Gaudens Megaro's "Mussolini in the Making," which they say is a "complete and uncensored" account of Mussolini's career as a young man.

Commercial Paper Yesterday. Tuesday. For the best names..... 1% Legal Holiday The quotation is for four-six months' paper. To Issue Retail Figures Later The local Federal Reserve Bank report on weekly sales in the metropolitan area and two up-State cities, usually issued on Wednesday for publication Thursday, will now be available either for Friday or Saturday publication, it was stated at the bank yesterday.

Las Parfums d'Isabey, Inc., and the Fioret Sales Company, Inc., 245 Fifth Avenue, have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue the practice of representing through the use of any foreign words or phrases that perfumes compounded, bottled and packaged in the United States are made or compounded in France or any other foreign country, or are imported.

F. A. Seiberling has resigned as president of the Seiberling Rubber Company of Cleveland to become chairman of the board. He has been succeeded as president by his son, J. Penfield Seiberling. Colonel J.

Miss Mollie Porter Cullum of Pittsburgh, her fiance, Charles Freeman Shelden of New York and members of the party for their wedding in Indian Creek Club, which will take place on Saturday, were guests today at a garden party at the Nautilus Hotel given by Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Splane of Tulsa, Okla.

In England's present Cabinet crisis observers everywhere are wondering whether British public opinion supports Anthony Eden, the "White Knight" of the League of Nations, or Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, who calls the League impotent and favors a deal with the fascist powers now outside the League.

Lafayette was forced to resort to long shots tonight to defeat the close-guarding Stevens Tech five by a 41-37 score. Benjamin made five from the middle of the floor and Lentz and Thon also contributed with long shots.

Greater activity in the intermediate capital market on the part of the Chicago Corporation, the Middle West's largest investing company, was indicated today by Richard Wagner, president, at the company's annual meeting. Mr. Wagner said the corporation has the only large fund of such capital available in Chicago.

E. R. Oliver, vice president of the Southern Railway, told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville (Monon) Railway "could not exist" without affiliation with strong main trunk lines.

Carrying the Far Eastern war to Japanese territory for the first time, twelve Chinese bombers spanned open water on their way to attack Kyushu, one of the main Japanese islands, after other Chinese planes had bombed three cities on the island of Formosa.

President Roosevelt arrived back late this evening from Hyde Park. The Senate passed the $250,000,000 Relief Deficiency Bill, confirmed the nomination of Max O. Truitt to the Maritime Commission and recessed at 4.59 P. M. until noon tomorrow.

Miss Sherman Olmsted will be married in June to George Graham de la Poer Horsley Beresford of New York, a nephew of Lord Decies. She is a daughter of Mrs. Charles H. Wacker of Chicago and Biarritz, France, with whom she is at present living at 30 Fifth Avenue, and of Francis Howard Olmsted of New York.
Taking of evidence was completed today in the trial of the Rev. Martin Niemoeller on charges of disrespect and disobedience toward the Nazi regime. A verdict is expected next Monday.

James Bleaing, 28 years old, found life in a mansion thrilling while it lasted. There was no response when he knocked at the door of the Schwinn mansion Monday in search of a handout. Ignaz Schwinn, wealthy manufacturer, his family and servants were in Florida on vacation.

Dizzy Dean ended his annual salary squabble with the Cardinals today by signing a contract for 1938. Ole Diz motored here from his Bradenton Winter home, shook hands with Branch Rickey, vice president and general manager of the St. Louis club, went into a hotel room huddle with the boss and signed on the dotted line, all within two and a half hours.

The expected happened last night in Madison Square Garden. Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, knocked out Nathan Mann, New Haven's bold pretender to the throne, in the third round of what was scheduled to be a fifteen-round battle before a crowd which packed the Garden to capacity.
Mrs. Maie L. MacLean, chief organizer and former president of the Teacher-Clerks Association of the City of New York, died of heart disease Tuesday afternoon in her home, 554 West 114th Street.
St. Peter's College basketball team dropped a 43-to-39 decision to Canisins College of Buffalo tonight. It was the thirteenth defeat for the home team this season.
With the problem of the two Irelands no nearer a solution than ever, the history of the first day of last month's Anglo-Irish negotiations was repeated today when the discussions were resumed.

Mary E. Kettler, 22 years old, former motion-picture theatre usher and waitress, collapsed in General Sessions yesterday after Judge Bohan had committed her to an indeterminate term in the Women's Reformatory at Bedford Hills for her part in a store robbery last Christmas Eve.
Making the first start of his 5-yearold campaign, Mrs. F. S. Harris's Singers Folly came through with a surprise victory in the mile-and-asixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds today.

An elastic defense of the south bank of the Yellow River in Honan Province is planned by General Shang Chen, former polo-playing Governor of Hopei. He recently was assigned to defend a 250-mile front on the Yellow River.
Purchase of an estimated 2,500,000 bushels of Australian wheat for shipment to Vladivostok and around 1,500,000 bushels by Spain attracted the attention of traders on the Board of Trade here today.

A committee of seven Columbia University officials was named yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, "to consider all phases of radio with reference to courses of study, to broadcasting on the part of the university, or any groups or parts of it, and to the relation of radio to the educational services of the university."

President Roosevelt returned to the White House tonight from Hyde Park after five days of rest, his visit having been interrupted only by a conference with Joseph P. Kennedy, Ambassador to Great Britain.
The Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for approval of its application to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan of $1,800,000.

Establishment of a high school of science, to train students in technical and scientific fields, was voted yesterday by the Board of Education. This action followed a recommendation from the Board of Superintendents that a science school was needed in this city.
The Pierpont Morgan Library, 29-33 East Thirty-sixth Street, will open to the public today what might be termed a Lenten pictorial Passion Play.

Major Reginald Alexander Brooks, nephew of Lord and Lady Astor; Princess Hohenlohe, the Hon. Oliver M. Wallop, Count L. LimburgStirum van Noordwijk and the Countess, and Arnold P. Mowitz, German consul in Philadelphia, are passengers due today from the Channel Ports on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.
Noel Coward's "Private Lives" is to join the industry's parade of remakes of past successes and will be used as Fernand Gravet's first vehicle under the Metro banner, Mervyn Leroy disclosed today.

Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., a member of the United States Davis Cup squad, and Donald McNeill of Oklahoma City were seeded first and second, respectively, among the sixty-four players drawn yesterday for the men's national indoor tennis championship.
Audrey O'Leary, 16 years old, of 3,723 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, remembered who she was yesterday afternoon in Bellevue Hospital and soon afterward was on her way home with her mother.
In London people cannot understand yet the change that has come over the political situation. Especially, they have not yet grasped the essential differences in outlook of Prime

At a meeting at which President Roosevelt and Mayor La Guardia were attacked as "well-known enemies of private property," 200 representatives of real estate interests adopted a resolution yesterday urging defeat of "confiscatory" tax legislation relating to real estate.
The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday the selection of the slogan, "Don't Mark TimeMake Time, Use the Lincoln Tunnel" as its first choice among 3,500 slogans submitted by employes.

Asked how much it would cost to build an Atlantic Fleet of strength comparable to that now in the Pacific, Rear Admiral William G. DuBose, chief of the naval bureau of construction and repair, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today that, with existing material and labor costs, it would be about $3,200,000,000.
Father James R. Cox, who once led a "hunger" march on Washington, was indicted with thirteen other persons today on charges of conspiracy and use of the mails in furtherance of a lottery.

The Women's National Republican Club, at 3 West Fifty-first Street, will inaugurate tonight a series of fortnightly dinner dances arranged under the auspices jointly of the senior and junior members. Mrs. William B. Chapin Jr. of this city and Greenwich, Conn., heads the arrangements committee.
The Tennessee Valley Authority added four municipalities today to its potential power customers by approval of contracts with Clarksville, Etowah and Lewisburg, Tenn., and Albertville, Ala.

Embarking on the most comprehensive program of rezoning in the city since the original Zoning Resolutions were adopted in 1916, the City Planning Commission set March 16 yesterday as the date for a public hearing on rezoning the east side waterfront for predominantly residential use from East Fourteenth Street south to the Brooklyn Bridge east of Avenue C, Pitt and Division Streets.

Ross E. King is with Amott, Baker Co., Inc. The directors of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company have elected Aubrey H. Mellinger president to succeed Floyd 0. Hale, who was made chairman of the board.

Sir Josiah Stamp, British economist and a director of the Bank of England, will address the British Empire Chamber of Commerce at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore on next Tuesday on "Key Factors in the Economic Outlook."

In addition to new standards in construction, lighting and air-conditioning equipment, the new and largest unit of the F. W. Woolworth Company, at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, focuses attention on the expanded merchandising trends becoming evident in the variety goods field, it was indicated yesterday at the pre-view, attended by a large number of executives of department stores, chains and other business establishments.

Addressing about 800 guests in the Hotel Astor last night at a testimonial dinner for Robert V. Santangelo, who had been one of his assistants, former District Attorney William C. Dodge made a vehement but indirect attack on District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, charging him with losing "case after case in General Sessions."
Registering its fifth straight victory, Amherst defeated Bates at basketball, 53 to 38, in Pratt cage tonight.

Three relay races, which are likely to produce new world records in the national A. A. U. indoor championships meet at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, are the 1,000-meter Swedish sprint, the 1,600-meter and 2,900-meter events.

Seymour Parker Gilbert's career was an unusual instance of rapid rise to public importance both at home and abroad, not through achievement in home politics, but through individual energy, judgment and mastery of the highly complicated problems of national and international finance.

S. Parker Gilbert, a partner in J. P. Morgan Co. since 1931 and for six years previously Agent General for Reparations. Payments, died yesterday noon in the Doctors Hospital, East, End Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street. He was 45 years old.

A one-man crusade against New York City dog owners who failed to comply with the frequently posted request to "curb your dog" was started in the Assembly today by Bernard J. Moran, Brooklyn Democrat, who introduced a bill to increase the annual fee for a dog license from $1 to $10.

More than 700 picked Legionnaires gathered in uniform at the clubhouse of the Elmhurst Post, 88-24 Forty-third Street, Elmhurst, Queens, last night in the first test of an emergency mobilization plan developed by Fred Schroeder, County Commander of the American Legion.
Tomorrow the Estonian Republic will celebrate the twentieth anniversary of the declaration of the country's independence and the severance of the old political ties with the Russian Empire.
Clarification of the steel price structure, which many buyers have been awaiting, has not aided business broadly, although a few companies have had the best volume of orders in weeks,

Turpentine firm 26 1/2c; sales 20 barrels; receipts 121 barrels; shipments 159 barrels; stock 25,698 barrels. Resin firm: sales 221: receipts 1,395; shipments 2.120; stock 74,409. Quote: B, D, E. $3.75; F. $4.60; G, $4.75; H. $4.85: I, $4.95; K, $5; M. $5.15; N, $5.25; WG, $6.50; WW, X, $6.75.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 21: MAJOR GENERAL Parsons, J. K., Fort Sam Houston, Texas, to duty at headquarters. Baltimore, Md. BRIGADIER GENERAL Beck, R. M., Jr., Fort Bliss, Texas, to office of Chief of Staff, Washington, D.C.

Police Commissioner Valentine is scheduled to take the witness stand today in Supreme Court and describe the circumstances leading up to the appointment of Hiram C. Todd as special prosecutor in the Druckman murder case in Brooklyn.

The Kings and New York-Bronx County A. A. U. basketball championship tournament leading up to the metropolitan championship, won last year by Long Island University, opened last night on three fronts with twelve of the twentynine leading clubs and colleges entered going into action.
With John J. Dunnigan, majority leader, wielding the whip, the Senate today cleared the way for speedy action on a number of Governor Lehman's program bills and his tax proposals as well.

Lawrence W. Campbell, secretary of the Citizens Committee organized during last June's "little steel" strike, testified at the National Labor Relations Board hearing today that the failure of the State police to prevent violence on the picket lines and the resentment of citizens against Governor Earle's

Britain's political storm over the resignation of Foreign Secretary Eden abated yesterday, but threatened to spring up again today when the House of Lords will debate the issue and tomorrow when Mr. Eden himself will give a speech defending his position and possibly explaining the reported Italian "now or never" approach to Britain.

Mr. and Mrs. Barclay Kountze Douglas gave a luncheon at their villa for Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Hitt, Mr. and Mrs. Byrnes MacDonald, Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas, Mr. and Mrs. C. Mathews Dick, Mr. and Mrs. G. Huntington Hartford 2d and Miss Aerielle Frazer.
Peter Redler of Chicago was re-elected president of the Associated Bakers of America tonight at the organization's convention.
The fledgling boom of Paul V. McNutt, High Commissioner of the Philippines, for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1940 was launched tonight on a floodtide of caviar, canape and cocktails.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents and teachers, recommends the following film programs for the week-end as suitable for young audiences. Unless otherwise noted, the pictures will be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday. The list is:
Mayor S. Davis Wilson's move to seize the municipal gas works at midnight on Dec. 31 was without any basis in law, Judge Thomas D. Finletter asserted in Common Pleas Court today.
George H. Bucher, executive vice president of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, was elected yesterday president of the company at a meeting of the board of directors.

The early days of lower Manhattan, when the residential center of the city was just north of the Battery and the business life of the city was concentrated in a few waterfront landings and market places near what is now the lower end of Broadway, were brought to mind yesterday, when plans to observe April 6 as "Bowling Green Day" were announced by a committee representing well-known firms in that district.

Hampered by court injunctions, the Bituminous Coal Commission voted today to revoke its minimum price scales for the entire soft coal industry, and to proceed to hearings and the eventual enactment of new price schedules, marketing rules and regulations.

Delays of one to three weeks in the issuance of State unemployment insurance checks are forcing many jobless persons here to accept a "second-grade type of relief" at a time when they had expected social security benefits to free them from the need for relief altogether, officers of several trade unions complained yesterday.

President Roosevelt's message transmitting the report of the Advisory Committee on Education to Congress was as follows: The public-school system in the United States greatly needs improvement. Glaring inequalities characterize educational opportunities and expenditures for schools throughout the nation.

George A. Szermer, a 24-year-old fireman with one year of service in the department, climbed a clothesline pole yesterday in the rear of 79 Eldridge Street and from it leaped across a space of about four feet to rescue a man trapped in a burning building.
Frightened residents of this little town in the extreme southwestern corner of Arkansas moved to the hills today while the Red River gained on workmen fighting to save a mile stretch of levee.

Grave academic issues and major pedagogical problems vanished yesterday, willingly sidetacked for the Dionne quintuplets by 2,000 educators gathered here from all parts of the country for the twentieth national convention of the Progressive Education Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Miss Mary Porter Jones, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. P. Jones of Inglecress, near University of Virginia, was married this evening at Christ Episcopal Church to Robert Schlesinger, son of H. J. Schlesinger of Milwaukee, and Mrs Harrison Williams of New York. Dr.

A public hearing will be held on March 16 on an application of the New York Curb Exchange to strike from listing and registration the common stock, 50 cents par value, of Cusi Mexicana Mining Company, Duluth, Minn., the SEC reported today.

Abolition of the trial of seamen by ships' committees for offenses considered injurious to the prestige of the union will be considered by the National Maritime Union in a referendum of the entire membership, it was learned yesterday.

The Governorship booms of Robert H. Jackson and Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. will be pushed forward tonight at dinners for the two avowed candidates, that for Mr. Jackson at the Hotel Commodore, and that for Mr. Bennett at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.

Richard Delaney, 25 years old, and Andrew Lunse, 23, were found guilty by a General Sessions jury yesterday of first degree murder as participants in the shooting of Patrolman Frank E. Zaccor on Jan. 6 in the hold-up of McElroy's bar and grill at 30 West Thirty-first Street.
Judge Bascom S. Deaver ruled today that Robert Tyre (Bobby) Jones Jr., retired golf champion, could not recover $53,339.37 income taxes for 1931 and 1933.

Passengers carried in January on the subway and elevated railroads operated by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company numbered 83,177,069, a decrease of 1,756,957, or 2.07 per cent, compared to January, 1937,
The first of five United States "flying fortresses" appeared over the Lima Airport at 4:15 this afternoon and circled until the others arrived.

The National Distillers Products Corporation reported yesterday the acquisition of 55,000 shares of Train McIntyre, Ltd., of Glasgow, Scotland, at a cost of $814,491, on Nov. 2, 1937. This is 95 per cent of the ordinary stock outstanding.

Episcopal funeral services were held here today in St. Paul's School chapel for the Rev. Dr. Samuel Smith Drury, for twenty-seven years rector of the school, who died early Sunday morning of a blood clot at the age of 59.

The Senate, acting under the whip of Mr. Dunnigan, cleared the decks for speedy action on the Governor's program bills. The tax bills were reported out of committee and are scheduled for passage tomorrow.

As the result of vigorous protests by members of the Fifth Avenue Association against the proposed "motorcade" advertising the World's Fair in a "preview" on Fifth Avenue on April 30, Police Commissioner Valentine agreed yesterday to withhold the parade permit until he has an opportunity to hear both sides at a public hearing to be held on a date not yet determined.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the five days ended Feb. 17 increased in all five trade groups over the totals for the corresponding period of 1937, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed comparisons follow:

Willoughby G. Walling, president of the Personal Loan and Savings Bank, died here today in Presbyterian Hospital of an embolism, from which he had been suffering for several weeks. He was 59 years old. His home was in Winnetka, Ill.

General Sessions Judge William Allen established a record sentence for a narcotic purveyor yesterday when he imposed a Sing Sing term of ten to twenty years on Uderico Rojas, 30 years old, a Puerto Rican ex-convict, on his recent conviction of selling marijuana cigarettes and heroin to a detective.
In a hard-fought game the St. Francis College basketball team upset the strong Villanova College team, 43-37, before a capacity crowd on the victors' court last night.

The Interdepartmental Committee of Economists which reported Thursday to President Roosevelt on the disparity in various commodity price levels continued its studies at a conference today with Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury.

Yesterday's bombing of the capital and other cities of Formosa by Chinese planes is a fresh indication that the end of the Sino-Japanese War may not be near. The air raids, said to have been participated in by a number of planes, could hardly have served any direct military purpose.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31, released yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after all expenses and charges, of $14,619,484.

Officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission conferred today with the Senate Banking and Currency Committee on proposed amendments to the Maloney bill for regulation of over-the-counter security dealers.

The House Labor Committee will start consideration tomorrow of two wage and hours measures, one closely resembling that passed by the Senate and recommitted to the House Labor Committee during the special session last year, and the other based on the NRA code wage standards of 1934.

Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Where Will Hitler Stop?" James G. McDonald. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Art of Flanders: The School of Antwerp," Roberta M. Fansler, 11 A. M.; collection of Roman art (general tour), 2 P. M.

Relief clients who own automobiles must turn in their license tags to the relief director's office in exchange for food orders. The Borough Council laid down this rule last night in reply to a question of Mayor Lucius W. Parker, "Why should we support persons who have cars?"

POSSIBLY Professor Lancelot Hogben should add another chapter to his book "Mathematics for the Million." New mathematical problems are popping up every day to bewilder the public, and not all of them are coming out of Washington, D. C.

Sixteen representatives of grocers' associations in the city agreed yesterday to support the drive of William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, for a standardization of the weight and price of bread sold at retail in the city.
Two Insurgent warships, believed to be the cruisers Canarias and Baleares, this morning shelled the Catalan coast towns of San Feliu de Guixols and Palamos, north of Barcelona.

Resuming business after the holiday, security and commodity markets were active and higher yesterday. Generally speaking, they took their cue from the action of prices in the principal foreign marts, where substantial additions were made to the gains of Tuesday and Monday.
Joe Louis weighed an even 200 pounds and Nathan Mann 193 1/2 for the heavyweight title contest in Madison Square Garden last night.

Manhattan KORFF. KURT (Jan. 30). Estate, more than $10,000. To Margerite Korff, widow, executrix, 112 Central Park South. LEVY, JACOB (Feb. 12). Estate, more than $10,000. To Annie Levy, widow, executrix. 345 W. 88th St.

A parti-colored 5-year-old Pekingese named Parti Boi, owned and exhibited by Mrs. C. E. Robbins of New York, was designated best toy dog as Bloomingdale's seventh annual pet dog show opened yesterday with a record entry.

The condition of General John J. Pershing was regarded as favorable today by his physicians, Dr. Roland Davison and Lieut. Col. S. U. Murrietta, after an afternoon examination. Their bulletin at 5 o'clock said:

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Sollers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Peterson Sollers, to the Rev. Duncan Fraser of Middletown, R. I., son of Mrs. Donald Fraser of Johnstown, N. Y., and the late Mr. Fraser, took place at noon today in Memorial Protestant Episcopal Church. The Rev. Dr. Benjamin B. Lovett performed the ceremony.

The Australian press generally deplores the resignation of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, whose statesmanship and high-mindedness it warmly praises, but nevertheless it regards it as a victory for realism, permitting future foreign policy to be shaped according to the hard facts of the international situation.

J. B. Snow's Americanowned Delachance was made the favorite for the Grand National in a callover at the Victoria Club tonight. Delachance was backed at 100 to 8 for the March 25 steeplechase handicap at Aintree, while Arthur Sainsbury's Blue Shirt, who won his third straight at Windsor today, was made second choice at 15 to 1.

President Roosevelt has decided to attempt the role of peacemaker in the warfare over selection of a Democratic primary ticket in Pennsylvania, a controversy which hours of further conferences here today failed to dissipate.
Elaborate preparations were progressing today to make Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's speech tomorrow an occasion for a great demonstration for Austria's independence.

Strength in foreign wheat markets over the holiday here and the improved European political news led to fairly active buying of futures on the Board of Trade today, and at no time were prices as low as Monday's finish.
Field Marshal Hermann Goering of Germany arrived this morning for his annual hunting in Bialowieza Forest on President Ignaz Moscicki's invitation. He spent today in Warsaw,

A recommendation that the courts be empowered to regulate the contingent fees paid to attorneys, particularly in personal injury cases, as a curb on so-called "ambulance chasing," was adopted last night by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York on the report of a special committee to a meeting of the organization in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Fortyfourth Street.

Georgetown a defeated Carnegie Tech, 45 to 41, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Conference basketball game tonight. Lagging at the half, 21 to 33, Georgetown staged a spirited rally in the second period and won the game in the final few minutes.

The Board of Governors of the New York Curb Exchange has approved listing of the following securities: George A. Fuller Company-24,186 issued shares of 4 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, $100 par value; 17,507 issued shares of $3 convertible stock.

Trustees of St. Paul's School tonight announced the appointment of Henry C. Kittredge of the faculty as acting rector, following the funeral of Dr. Samuel S. Drury, who had served as rector since 1911.

The Blair five avenged its only Eastern Private Schools League defeat by turning back Irving today, 45 to 31. The league leaders clinched at least a tie for the title by winning. Beck and Bud Witte paced Blair with 12 and 10 points, respectively, while Fitzgerald's long shots for 10 points led Irving.
The Agricultural Adjustment Administration said today that fluecured and dark-fired or air-cured tobaccos probably would be the only types for which 1938 marketing quotas would be proposed.
Camp accessories and equipment, vital parts of any fishing or hunting expedition, are receiving a full share of attention from visitors to the National Sportsmen's Show at the Grand Central Palace.
The stock market here was generally strong today, with most sections making fresh headway. Gilt-edged issues were in good demand, while among the foreign loans most European bonds did better.
Class A Two-Mile--Won by Joe Dille, Continental S. C.: Gene McCann, Brooklyn Ice Palace, second; Joe Bree, New York Curb Exchange A. A., third, Time--6:36.

The marriage of Miss Frances Hollister St. John, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sterling St. John of 452 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, to Edward Thomas Kemp, son of John Bartlett Kemp of Ridgewood, N. J., took place here yesterday morning in the chapel of Old Trinity Church.

The crowd at the Sportsmen's Show yesterday was so large that it reminded us of the opening day of trout season on the Esopus. The only difference was that yesterday's crowd went home satisfied, which is not always the case on opening day.

Gross operating revenues of the Twin City Rapid Transit Company thus far this year have averaged 10 per cent below those in the corresponding period a year ago, D. J. Strouse, president of the company, told shareholders at the annual meeting held yesterday in Jersey City.

The Brooklyn Bruins gained the third round of the New York Amateur Hockey Association play-offs last night when they defeated the Columbia Lions, 4 to 3, in an overtime engagement at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.
Frederick W. Dunbar, president of F. W. Dunbar Co., New York crude rubber importers, died last night in his home here.

A. E. Watt of the New York A. C. moved into the final of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association's Group I championship yesterday by beating James Eder of Midston House in a well-played four-game match at the City A. C.

Stocks closed strong with warmaterial issues leading; trading heavier; turnover, 1,299,315 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds higher, central European issues off sharply; transactions, $8,313,900.

In its secret trial of Pastor Martin Niemoeller, as in Chancellor Hitler's recent denunciations of the "utterly mad, stupid and imprudent" statements of the foreign press, the Nazi Government of Germany admits that it does fear public opinion.

The La Guardia Transit Bill was amended today by its sponsor in the Senate, Thomas C. Desmond, to provide that employes of the Transit Commission, should that agency be abolished, would be put on a special preferred list,
Governors of the New York Curb Exchange took action yesterday to follow the New York Stock Exchange's lead in reorganization.

A group composed of the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, Goldman, Sachs Co. and Charles Clark Co. obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $280,000 of voting machine bonds of Union County, N. J., on a bid of 100.11 for 2.20s.

With no deliveries on the first notice day for the March position and 117,000 bales open interest still unsettled, prices on the Cotton Exchange here-moved upward again yesterday to end with gains of 5 to 14 points. Influenced by higher.

A permanent set-up for unemployment relief, which would handle such problems as arise in ordinary times and form the framework for an emergency force that might be called into action on a national scale, was outlined yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator for this city.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens and the Associated Merchants and Property Owners, Inc., 570 Seventh Avenue, went on record yesterday in opposition to the Kleinfeld-McCreery bill in the Legislature designed to abolish special or so-called blue-ribbon juries.

The pound sterling was stronger in terms of the dollar yesterday as the more acute stage of Britain's Cabinet crisis was surmounted. Other important European exchanges likewise gained against the dollar except the French franc, which fell 2 1/2 points to 3.26 cents.

Receipts 14,000, including 2,000 directs Market strong to 10 cents higher than Tuesday's average, with most upturn on weights upward from 210 pounds. Top $9.20; good and choice, 160-230 pounds, SS.90-$9.15; 240-260 pounds, $8.75-.95; 270350 pounds, $8.25-.70; good medium weight and heavy packing sows, $7.15-.45; light butcher kinds, up to $7.60. Shippers 3,000; estimated holdover 1,000.

Increasing public consumption in the face of sharp reduction in production of cotton goods will shortly bring a "decided improvement in market balance, favorable to both price and volume," W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, declared yesterday.

American Participations, Inc., Springfield, Mo., an investment trust, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 400 monthly payment participation certificates, with insurance,

Death Announced Fireman 1st Grade John T. Sullivan (2), of H. L. Co. 164, died Feb. 21. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 48-55 Forty-sixth St., Woodside, Queens, at 10 A. M., Thursday, Feb. 24. Interment at St. John's Cemetery.
The executive committee and the board of directors of the Chrysler Corporation will hold their quarterly meeting this afternoon, at which time a dividend will be discussed.
One national and six New England swimming records were broken for the twenty-yard pool as Harvard's crack team defeated Springfield, 60-15, tonight. The cantabs won every event on the program.

Refusing to answer questions of the Assembly Committee investigating the last Gubernatorial election in Hudson County, three members of the election board in the Ninth District, Third Ward, of Jersey City were arrested here today on misdemeanor charges and held in $500 bail each for the grand jury.

In the first move to fill the twenty-six scheduled vacancies of the highranking army officers during the year, President Roosevelt. upon the recommendation of General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff, sent to the Senate today for confirmation the names of nine "selected" officers.

Charged with arson, a member of the Gerrittsen Beach Volunteer Fire Department, William M. Velsor, 32 years old, of 113 Astor Court, Brooklyn, was booked yesterday afternoon at the Snyder Avenue police station, Brooklyn.

Trading was fairly active to slow. The lamb market was strong to higher and fresh pork cuts steady to higher: other classes of traefa meats showed little change. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb to be steady. other classes weak as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
Lord Beaverbrook, London newspaper owner, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after spending three months in Nassau and Florida. He said he would return next November.

The current trend of business is downward or sidewise, in the opinion of six out of seven business leaders whose opinions have been canvassed by Banking, official publication of the American Bankers Association, according to the latest issue of that magazine.
R. L. Pearman, a Negro cabinet-maker, has had a pleasant surprise here. When needing a piece of mahogany to finish a job he started knocking apart an old desk owned by his family for generations.

Federal Judge Charles D. Davis ruled today that first-term and unifying mortgage bonds of the Cotton Belt Railroad were payable for their face amount, $21,638,000, and that the provision making them payable in Dutch guilders, now worth $37,335,525 in United States currency, was invalid.
Mrs. Skinker Matthews gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Lady Decies. Other guests were Mr. and
Patrons of the annual Junior Promenade of Columbia College, to be held tomorrow evening at the Essex House, 160 Central Park South, were announced yesterday.
City Council was asked today to sign an agreement with the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, a C. I. 0. union, estabfishing a closed shop among municipal workers.

The first national advertising campaign ever conducted by the Ben Franklin Stores, and believed to be among the first attempts to promote nationally the services of a large voluntary chain of independently owned small units, will break in the May 14 issue of one national weekly and will continue for ten to twelve weeks thereafter.

The New York Association for the Blind paid $103,328 to blind persons for work, wages, relief, guide and other expenses in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, according to its annual report, made public yesterday. With its headquarters at the Lighthouse,

New Federal grants to the States for educational purposes, beginning with $70,000,000 in 1939 and increasing to $199,000,000 annually by 1944, a total of $855,500,000, were recommended today in a report by the Advisory Committee on Education made to President Roosevelt and transmitted by the White House to the Senate and House.
SKYE HIGH, by Hesketh Pearson and Hugh Kingsmill. (Oxford University Press, $3.) The record of a tour through Scotland.

Maintenance of present tariff rates on imported axminster, chenille axminster, wilton and velvet weaves of carpets and rugs was urged by the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, Inc., in a brief field Saturday with the Committee for Reciprocity Information in Washington.
The secret execution of two former commanders of the Soviet navy was disclosed today in published versions of a speech by Marshal Klementy E. Voroshiloff, Commissar of War.

A big field, starting play on the courts of the Yale, University and Squash Clubs, opened the metropolitan squash racquets Class B singles championship yesterday, and most of the first round was completed.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 19:

Three departments of the Federal Government, the army, the navy and the Treasury, voiced their opposition today to a bill sponsored by Senator Lee of Oklahoma to draft the nation's wealth in the event of war.

Kathryn Meisle, the Metropolitan contralto, who gave a recital in Town Hall last night, found no difficulty in winning the hearty approbation of her audience because of the sympathetic, expressive character of her singing and the fine musicianship which informed all of her work.

Campbell Dickson will follow Head Football Coach Herbert O. Crisler from Princeton University to the University of Michigan. Crisler, recently named to succeed Harry Kipke as Michigan coach, announced today the appointment of Dickson as end coach to succeed Bennie Oosterbaan.

Playing steady golf from the first of the match, Louis Miller of Chester, Nova Scotia, and Mrs. W. H. D. Nichols of Staffordshire, England, easily led a field of thirty teams to win the Don Parker trophy twoball mixed foursomes at the Tuckerstown course today.

Senator Walsh today requested the Senate to reject a bill providing a pension of $5,000 per year for Mrs. Benjamin Harrison, widow of the former President, who married him after he had left the White House.
Pensioned On his own application. To take effect 12 midnight. Feb. 28: PATROLMAN-George J. Ratzmann, 110th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 24, 1912.
The Most Rev. Michael Joseph Spratt, Catholic Archbishop of Kingston, died here today at the age of 84. He had been in a hospital for most of the last fourteen years.

The Earl of Perth left for London this morning to receive the instructions of his government before opening official negotiations next week with the Italian Government for elimination of difficulties that have kept Rome and London apart the last two years and more.

Mrs. Lawrence Townsend, known as a discoverer and promoter of musical talent, was invited to the German Embassy today to receive the Handel medal, bestowed annually for service in behalf of Handel's music.
A constitutional amendment implementing plans for reorganization of the New York Stock Exchange was received yesterday by that organization's governing committee.
A broad advance in bond values on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was marred only by further weakness in selected Central European dollar obligations.

Wisconsin rallied in the last five minutes to defeat the Pennsylvania quintet at the Palestra tonight, 52-44, before a crowd of 4,000. This was the first time the Badgers ever played a basketball game in theEast.
The dull routine of Jefferson Market Court was enlivened by a Greek coincidence yesterday when the name "James Pappas" was called and two men stepped up before Magistrate Edgar Bromberger.
Charles H. Weeks, Deputy State Labor Commissioner for fifteen years, died last night in his home here.

Ed White, former national intercollegiate champion who had to be persuaded to play because his game had been "sour," shot a 69 over rain-sodden fairways to take medal honors in the Houston Country Club invitation golf tournament today.
