The annual report of the St. Joseph Lead Company and subsidiaries, made public yesterday, shows a net profit for 1937 amounting to $7,127,945 after interest, depreciation, abandoned leases, depletion, Federal income taxes and other charges. This was equal to $3.64 a share on the outstanding stock.

THE proud publishers of "Skye High,"* by Hesketh Pearson and Hugh Kingsmill, label it one of the most entertaining books ever. That is a powerful, not to say sweeping, statement, and I wouldn't go so far as to agree.
Frank F. Walker of Eastman, Dillon Co. has been elected chairman of the District 13 committee of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

Marston Taylor Bogert, Professor of Organic Chemistry in Columbia University, has been appointed an official delegate of the United States to the thirteenth conference of the International Union of Chemistry and the tenth International Congress of Chemistry, to be held jointly in Rome next May.

Federal Judge William H. Holly today appointed Jay Samuel Hartt of Madison, Wis., head of an engineering firm bearing his name, as trustee of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, succeeding Willoughby G. Walling, who died yesterday. The bond was fixed at $25,000.
Belisario Salazar, chief of the mechanical division of El Salvador's military aviation, is leaving soon for Italy to enter a school of aviation mechanics.

Former Justice Townsend Scudder and his wife won a preliminary skirmish in their fight to keep their seventy cocker spaniels on their Greenwich estate today, when Superior Court Judge Edward J. Quinlan refused to dissolve a temporary injunction restraining the town of Greenwich from enforcing an order that the Scudders get rid of all but ten of the animals.
Four races, including the annual Poughkeepsie regatta, are on the 1938 program of the Cornell varsity crew, according to an announcement today by Athletic Director James Lynah.
Stocks heavy, closed lower in less active trading; turnover, 719,007 shares. United States Government issues higher, other bonds irregular; transactions, $6,193,000.

A request by railroads that the 50year-old "long-and-short haul" rule be abandoned in fixing rates brought today a charge of "inconsistency" from Senator Wheeler of Montana, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee.

Governor Lehman renewed his plea for economy in the State government tonight, in an address at the annual dinner of the State Civil Service Employes Association. Mr. Lehman stressed the need for being conservative in, estimating future financial requirements of the State.

Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's speech, which was broadcast throughout Germany tonight and in which he gave his interpretation of his agreement with Chancellor Adolf Hitler, created amazement and dismay in National Socialist quarters.

Lady Fairhaven left the Plaza yesterday for Charleston, S. C. Miss Mary Olive Winslow will give a dinner tonight in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Rcsanne L. Wigham, who will be married to Nicholas C. Jenks on March 12.

Dr. Lillian Welsh, one of the pioneer women physicians in America and medical adviser and Professor of Physiology and Hygiene at Goucher College for thirty years, died yesterday at her home in Columbia, Pa. She would have been 80 years old on March 6.

Horace E. Buel, former Republican leader of Richmond County and former Republican State Committeeman, died yesterday at the Staten Island Hospital in New Brighton after a brief illness. He was 85 years old and resided in Port Richmond S. I.

In a resolution to be sent to Albany today, the Associated Merchants and Property Owners, Inc., yesterday went on record against the pending chain store tax bill, W. F. McShane, vice president and executive secretary, announced.

Paul V. McNutt, High Commissioner of the Philippines, went to the White House today to discuss with President Roosevelt for half an hour such diverse subjects as politics, economics and the Far -Eastern situation.

The general level of wholesale prices declined again in the week ended on Feb. 19, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. There was a slight rise in food prices, but all other categories either declined or remained stationary.

Terms of the sale of $43,000,000 of New York City serial bonds, which will be made on next Tuesday, were formally announced yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick. The Controller disclosed that in addition to the $43,000,000 of bonds to be offered for public subscription, a total of $6,500,000 of serial bonds, maturing in thirty-one to forty years will be reserved for private sale to the city sinking fund.

A five-point program for action by the Administration to promote business recovery was presented by John L. Redmond of the Crompton-Richmond Company, president of the New York Credit Men's Association, at that organization's annual banquet at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night.

Hedy Lamarr, star of the controversial "Ecstasy," has been borrowed from Metro by Walter Wanger for one of the feminine leads in Charles Boyer's "Algiers," adapted from "Pepe Le Moko," and which will be directed by John Cromwell.

The Montreal Maroons came from behind twice tonight to gain a 2-2 tie and maintain their jinx over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game before 7,761 spectators. It was the tail-end teams' third deadlock of the season in five meetings.

The German Embassy said today it was not surprised at the attack on Hitlerism by Dr. Ernst Meyer, former first secretary of the embassy, in an address in New York last night. Dr. Meyer resigned last May from the Foreign Service, in which he had served for sixteen years.

Failure of the foreign stock markets to continue the recovery of the last few days, particularly in the light of the brisk gains scored here on Wednesday, induced profit-taking in our security markets yesterday. Stocks were heavy in tone from the start and closed with losses of fractions to 2 points.

The need of advertising to heed its inescapable public responsibility is today stronger than at any other period in its history, Raymond Rubicam, chairman of the board of Young Rubicam, Inc., declared last night at the Annual Advertising Awards dinner, sponsored by Advertising and Selling Magazine, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Federal deficit has passed the $1,000,000,000 point and the debt has risen to a new record high of $37,616,605,571, the Treasury said today. On Feb. 21, expenditures exceeded income by $1,008,685,794.

Congressional proponents of increasing Federal aid for education moved swiftly into action today following President Roosevelt's transmission yesterday of a report of his Advisory Committee on Education recommending such a step.

The Mortgage Commission, as trustee for certificate holders, extended these mortgages: $563,500 on 29-39 W 90th St, owned by Elmorton Holding Corp, Abraham Karmel, president, to Feb. 16, 1943, at 4 3/4 per cent; $7,940 on 81 E 108th St, Louis Watkin, owner, to Feb. 14. 1943, 4 1/2 per cent; $7,500 on 60 E 126th St, owned by Dorice Realty Corp, Benjamin Applebau, president.
Physicians administered heart stimulants to General John J. Pershing early today and reported a short time later that his blood pressure was slightly better.

Noble John Moore, convicted confidence man, who twice testified for the government in unsuccessful prosecutions of William J. Graham and James C. McKay, Reno gamblers, only to appear at their third trial on charges of mail fraud and assert that he had committed perjury, received a prison sentence yesterday of seven years for violation of parole.

The list of the Holland America liner Statendam, leaving today for an eighteen-day cruise to the West Indies and South America, includes: Miss Virginia Althouse, Mr. and Mrs. Wiley Brown, Mrs. Pierpont E. Dutcher, Miss Dorothea Dutcher, Mr. and Mrs. T. Walter Williams, Mrs. Oscar Dey Williams, Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Sweeney, Rensselar W. Bartram Jr. and Mrs. L. L. Pendleton.

Election of Joseph E. Pridday to the presidency of Frederick Loeser Co., Inc., Brooklyn; was. announced yesterday by the board. of directors. Mr. Pridday, who has resigned as vice president, treasurer, director and member of the executive committee of Associated Dry Goods Corporation, succeeds Lewis M. Gibb, who resigned on Wednesday.
Queen Elizabeth and Queen Mary shunned extravagance when they visited the British Industries Fair at Olympia today.

A general meeting of the New York Security Dealers Association at the Bankers Club yesterday adopted the plans and suggestions presented by the board of governors regarding arrangements made by them with the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., principally for membership in the latter organization.

President Arturo Alessandri, who is staying here for a month, declared today through a spokesman for the Liberal party that under no conditions would he allow changes to be introduced in the Constitution that would permit him to stay in office for another term.

A third juror was selected yesterday in Bronx County Court to try Mrs. Patricia Ryan, 21 years old, who is alleged to have murdered her husband, Patrolman Michael Ryan, on Oct. 31 in their home at 1,350 Purdy Street, the Bronx.

Mrs. Leonard Vining, who rescued three children when fire destroyed their Catskill Mountain home, was in a grave condition in a hospital here today from burns and smoke. Dr. Mahlon H. Atkinson said that she had a "fifty-fifty" chance of survival.

Picked Spanish Insurgent shock troops tonight reached the "gate to Valencia," the mountain pass of Escandon, in their drive toward the Mediterranean coast. [Valencia is about seventy miles to the southeast.]

Spokesmen for water transportation interests warned yesterday that proposals of the Navy Department for improvement of the East River would endanger the movement of a large volume of commercial traffic, at a hearing before Lieut. Col. David McCoach of the Army engineers.

" Follow the Plow," a film showing the training of city youths in farming methods at the Bowdoin farm of the Children's Aid Society at New Hamburg, N. Y.. was viewed yesterday by 100 educators and social service workers in the United Charities Building at 105 East Twenty-second Street.

The text of Robert H. Jackson's address last night at the dinner of the Young Democratic Club of New York at the Hotel Commodore follows: There are particular reasons why I am grateful for this opportunity to speak tonight to the Young Democratic Club of New York and this gathering of wellwishers.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

Mrs. Irene Rucker Sheridan, widow of General Philip H. Sheridan of Civil War fame, died at her residence here today after a long illness. She was the daughter of General Daniel H. Rucker. Her age was 88.

A spokesman announced that a protest was lodged at noon today with the German Embassy and simultaneously cabled to the Chinese Embassy in Berlin against the recognition of Manchukuo. The text will not be given out until tomorrow.

The world production of crude oil and related fuels last year reached a high record of 2,109,820,000 barrels, ac compared with 1,864,997,000 in 1936, an increase of 144,823,000, according to a compilation made by V. R. Garfias, R. V. Whetsel and J. W. Ristori of the Cities Service Company.

Mrs. Mary Sage Bolton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Sage of 1,192 Park Avenue and Quogue, L. I., was married to Richard W. Lawrence of this city yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents here. The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman performed the ceremony in the presence of members of the two families.

Declaring that the city had already exceeded its ability to finance relief and that the situation was "precarious," Mayor La Guardia joined other members of the Board of Estimate yesterday in a strong appeal to legislative leaders for additional help from the State.

The National Hockey League's giant-killers, the Canadiens, ended the Bruins' winning streak at seven straight games tonight by coming from behind in the third period to gain a 1-1 overtime tie as 7,000 fans looked on.

Despite clear, brisk weather which gave the Giants' corps of batterymen another sparkling workout, a number of other developments came to pass today which may have an even more important bearing upon Colonel Bill Terry's bid for a third straight National League pennant this year.

The occupational rehabilitation of persons who have been thrown out of jobs by the invention of new machinery and the establishment of new services is increasingly becoming the responsibility of the nation's schools and colleges, according to Dr. Edwin A. Lee, director of the National Occupational Conference, who spoke today before the National Vocational Guidance Association at its annual convention.
The N. Y. U. swimming team reversed an earlier defeat at the hands of -Fordham by beating the Maroon in the Fordham pool yesterday, 43-28.

OUT in Indiana they know how the Crowe flies. He flies from Lafayette to Notre Dame. Six of the seven Crowe brothers followed the migration route that brought them from the family nesting place at Lafayette to the Notre Dame campus and athletic fields. One brother stayed right at home and went to Purdue. The other brothers don't say much about him. Maybe he couldn't fly.
Senator Truman of Missouri criticized today the action of the Wabash Railway Company in "siphoning" funds from subsidiaries to make its own cash position appear in a better light in 1930.
The Coast Guard announced the following changes during the week ended Feb. 23:
Republican legislative leaders turned their attention today to the coming constitutional convention, and completed the first draft of a bill to pave the way for opening the convention.

The Baton Rouge Electric Company, the Louisiana Steam Generating Corporation and the Gulf States Utilities Company, all subsidiaries of the Engineers Public Service Company, will be merged at an early date, it was announced late yesterday.
Cold weather swept over Newfoundland today, solidifying ice floes that stretched in all directions off the coast, holding up six ships fighting to enter port here.

A. J. Hain, managing editor of the magazine Steel, said today that "the best opinion in the industry" was that this year's steel-works operations would average about 50 per cent of capacity, contrasting with 72.3 in 1937.

Turpentine firm 25 1/2 c; sales, 46 barrels; receipts, 52 barrels; shipments, 140 barrels; stock, 25,610 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 223; receipts, 915; shipments, 411; stock, 74,913. Quote: B, D, E, $3.75; F, $4.50; G, $4.60; H, $4.70; I, $4.80; K. $4.85; M, $5; N, $5.10; WG, $6.50; WW, X, $6.75.

While Democratic party leaders sought to bring harmony within their ranks in anticipation of an election in which labor threatens to play an important part, rival labor chieftains of Pennsylvania moved tonight to meet the situation created by the revocation of the charter of the State Federation of Labor by William Green.

Slum clearance and the provision of low-rent housing through private enterprise cannot be realized, and the solution of these problems must be reached through governmental subsidies to local housing authorities, Donald Jones, real estate adviser to the United States Housing Authority, declared yesterday.

To clarify the regulations applicable to branch office managers, customers' men and other registered employes, the committee on customers' men of the New York Stock Exchange has adopted new rules embodying restrictions previously contained in the form of-an agreement which registered employes have been required to sign at the time of approval of their employment by the committee.
A minor burst of applause from the gallery greeted the action of the City Council today in passing over Mayor Wilson's veto two supplementary sales tax ordinances.

In a last-minute appeal designed to perpetuate the Alleghany Corporation's control of the Missouri Pacific Railroad against the desires of opposing insurance companies and savings banks, the Missouri Pacific's management issued yesterday to its stockholders a request for funds to continue the contest.

The council of the Balkan Entente, comprising Yugoslavia, Rumania, Greece and Turkey, is reassembling at Angora tomorrow following its postponement because of the change in the government of Rumania. It is expected that the council will define the attitude 'of the four countries toward the League of Nations.

Harrison Hewitt, former president of the State and County Bar Associations, died yesterday following a cerebral hemorrhage. Mr. Hewitt was formerly Corporation Counsel of the city of New Haven. He was 61 years old and was graduated from Yale University in 1897.

A shoring crew worked through last night to keep standing the two buildings at 199 and 201 Avenue C, between Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets, which early yesterday began to collapse before the eyes of the ten families inhabiting them.
Harassed by a threatened boycott of the 1940 Olympic Games, Japan may make a "deal" with Italy to shift the games from Tokyo to Rome.

The possibility of a malaria epidemic among Chinese troops in North China is causing grave concern to army commanders. Malaria is being spread in North China by troops from the southern provinces, most of whom are a little infected but have built up resistance to the disease and are not incapacitated.

William B. Dailey, president of the Dailey Corporation of Verona, N. J., manufacturers of photographic film, and former member of the local City Council, died yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital in Newark after a nine months' illness. Mr. Dailey,

William T. Hetler, 47, cashier of the defunct Nescopeck National Bank, was arrested on complaint of Federal Bank examiners today and charged with embezzlement, misapplication of funds and making false entries. The warrant was issued by United States Commissioner Carlon O'Malley.

An old barn on the estate of John S. Phipps on Old Westbury Road here was destroyed by fire shortly after noon today. There were no animals in the barn, which of late years had been used for storage purposes.

Samuel H. Ordway Jr., the only Republican member of the Civil Service Commission, disclosed today that he had made private suggestions to President Roosevelt for revision of the Byrnes Reorganization Bill, which he called "a definite threat" to the civil service.

This coming week-end will be a critical one for France. Internal peace and peace abroad will be discussed. Simultaneously with the debate on the foreign situation, beginning tomorrow in the Chamber of Deputies, there will be a debate in the Senate and Chamber on the government's labor charter about which the two houses are far from agreement.

The New York Maritime Council announced yesterday a boycott by its eight component C. I. O. unions against the tugs of the Dalzell Towing Company, charging that the company had discharged three employes for failing to join the Harbor Towboatmen's Union, an affiliate of the A. F. of L.

The $1,270,000,000 Cities Service Company, one of the largest single holding companies in the United States, capitulated yesterday to the requirements of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 by registering the company's two major utility systems with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Department of Akershus, Norway, which surrounds Oslo, filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933, covering the issuance of $7,000,000 of thirty-year 4 per cent sinkingfund external-loan bonds, due on March 1, 1963, the first registered by a foreign issuer of this type in some time.
Lord and Lady Plunket of London, and T. J. (Tex) Phillips, pilot, were killed today in a crash of an airplane a mile and a half south of the Hearst Airport at San Luis Obispo.

Miss Helen Keller, Miss Rachel Crothers, Georgia O'Keefe and Inez Haynes Irwin, all of New York, and Mrs. Avery Conley will be sponsors of the "Amelia Earhart Fund for Equal Rights," established last month by the National Woman's Party.

Government must regulate business for the sake of the nation, Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General and designee for Solicitor General of the United States, asserted last night at a dinner in his honor given by the New York Young Democratic Club at the Hotel Commodore.

President Roosevelt discussed politics and the Far Eastern situation with Paul V. McNutt, High Commissioner to the Philippines; recovery problems with John D. Biggers, director of the unemployment census, and also conferred with Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland banker, and with a delegation representing the Consumers National Federation.

The statement that this country must have a navy "second to none" if it wishes its foreign policies to be successful and its rights to be respected abroad was made by Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, commandmant of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy tonight.
The former Conservative dictator of Ecuador, Federico Paez, once said stupidity was his chief problem, adding that there were too many illiterates in the country.
Six United States Army bombers, returning from Buenos Aires, Argentina, are due to leave early tomorrow for Panama after overhauling and refueling.
Archbishop Athenagoras, head of the Greek Orthodox Church in North and South America, became a citizen of the United States yesterday before Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Brooklyn.

The Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street, was decorated entirely with Spring blossoms and foliage for the marriage of Miss Ella Dunlevy Milbank and William Ward Foshay, which took place there yesterday afternoon.
Fernand Leger's art has been going through a process of considerable change, as attested by this well-known French modernist's exhibition at the Pierre Matisse Gallery, 51 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Health Day was observed yesterday by New York City's 1,250,000 public school children. Teachers stressed the importance of health and the pupils were tested for defects in vision, hearing, height, weight and other physical characteristics.

A consolidated net profit of $1,081,513 was reported yesterday by the Douglas Aircraft Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on Nov. 30 after write-off of $789,530 for experimental costs, provision for depreciation, normal Federal income tax and surtax on undistributed profits.

Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson approved today a settlement under which banks here and in New York paid $4,635,088 to the trustees of Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and the Corporation Securities Company, huge investment trusts which Samuel Insull set up in the days of utility company big deals to perpetuate the interest of himself and his family in his utility holdings.
Two weeks before publication Houghton Mifflin have ordered a second large printing of Ben Ames Williams's new novel, "The Strumpet Sea," thus bringing the total number of copies printed up to 10,000.

A previously quiet diabetic patient of St. Vincent's Hospital, armed with a kitchen knife, last night terrorized a section of the hospital, stole a taxicab and led the police a fifteen-minute chase through Greenwich Village, during which dozens of shots were fired over the heads of frightened pedestrians.

Arthur M. Tasker, Republican leader of Greenport, collapsed shortly after noon today as he was driving along Main Street here. His automobile glanced off a telegraph pole and crashed into a tree. A physician found that he was dead, apparently of a heart attack.

With his trainers predicting he would fight again in six weeks, Harry Jeffra, former bantamweight champion of the world,- sailed for New York today still showing signs of the beating he took Sunday night from Sixto Escobar in their title fight, Though he had a swollen left jaw and wore dark glasses, Jeffra was cheerful.
In a defiant speech in which he pledged himself to defend Austria's independence, Chancellor Schuschnigg declared yesterday that Chancellor Hitler of Germany had promised to respect it.

One hundred students at Lafayette College won places on the Dean's List for the second term. Under the ruling of the faculty they are put on-their own responsibility for attendance to classes during the current term.

Governor George H. Earle was charged with using the power of the State government to close the Bethlehem Steel Mills here last June in order to help the C. I. O. after the strike had failed in testimony given at the National Labor Relations Board hearing today by Lawrence W. Campbell, secretary of the Citizens Committee and managing director of the chamber of commerce.

William S. Swingle, for thirteen years director of the foreign department and manager of the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men, has been named a vice president of the National Foreign Trade Council, James A. Farrell, chairman of the Council announced yesterday.

The United States Steel Corporation has practically completed the production of three industrial films, two of which, in color, will be distributed through theatres and the third, in black and white, in film houses in the steel areas and to clubs, schools and colleges.

The tenth annual dance of the Strykers Lane Community Center tonight at the American Women's Association Building will be the first in a series of events planned to celebrate the twentieth anniversary of the founding of the West Side center.

Harry Hickey, collector of the Fourteenth Internal Revenue District, said today that Joseph Kelly, inspector of the New Rochelle Bureau, had been relieved temporarily of his duties pending an investigation.

Miss Elizabeth Middleton Gibson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Huntley Gibson, was married to Stewart Bryan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Stewart Bryan of Laburnum, here today in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church. The Right Rev. St.

Flying Lee, a Pennant filly from the Hal Price Headley barn that scored at long odds earlier in the meeting, came back today at Hialeah Park with another victory. This one was worth $23.50 for each $2 mutuel ticket, as well as a $700 purse to Owner Headley.
The Senate today took up the $1,412,000,000 Independent Offices Appropriations Bill and restored a $385,000 committee cut in the funds for the National Labor Relations Board.

The Annalist reports that its index of wholesale commodity prices rose 0.6 point in the week ended on Wednesday to 83.0, the sharpest increase since the second week in September. A year ago the index was 92.2.

Federal aid in establishing a better balance between production and consumption in the interest of the ultimate consumer was urged upon President Roosevelt today by a delegation representing the Consumers National Federation of New York, which recommended the creation of a central consumer agency in the Federal Administration.
Mrs. Lulu M. O'Beirne, a daughter of the late William H. Moyer, warden of Sing Sing during the World War and former warden of the Federal Penitentiary in Atlanta, died Tuesday in Ossining Hospital.
Benny Davis and a company of proteges are gathered this week at Loew's State Theatre, where they constitute that section of the program devoted to vaudeville. Mr.

Handicapped by high winds that placed a premium on skill, eightyone players from the United States, Canada and Bermuda struggled through the eighteen-hole qualifying round in the Mid-Ocean Golf Club's fifth annual tournament at Tuckerstown today.

The proposed plan for the organization of a community fund has to do with the supplementary financing of private charities. But it has a purpose and a value far beyond that in the uniting of all religious, business or social associations in a common spiritual effort, in loving our neighbors as ourselves.
Literary Digest, the weekly news magazine, yesterday announced the suspension of publication for two weeks. The next issue of the magazine, it was said, is expected to appear on March 12.

Discussion of the long-slumbering question of the war debts is certain to be revived by the proposal which one of the debtors has now made to the United States. It comes from a small debtor, and the total amount involved is less than our own Government spends in a few hours of a single day.

The Schenley Distillers Corporation and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net profit in 1937 of $7,320,903 after all taxes, including $328,683 surtax, and other charges, but before dividends on the preferred stock had been paid, according to the annual report, to be issued today by Harold Jacobi,
Although the German "People's Car" has not yet appeared, other types already in production are making such inroads in the British market as to cause anxiety among local manufacturers.

The old Manhattan Opera House, an eight-story building at 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, was purchased yesterday by Abraham Ellis, a concessionaire who holds a lease on the upper part of the building, from the Consistory of New York City of t Ancient and Accepted Scottish Rite of Freemasonry.

The original idea for the 1939 World's Fair was claimed yesterday by Joseph F. Shadgen, a consulting engineer, who began a $1,000,000 suit in Queens against fair officials, with the assertion that after he started the ball rolling, all he got out of it was a job sharpening pencils and coloring maps, and he was discharged even from that.

The pulp and paper industry of the country is "on the way out of this temporary slump," according to D. C. Everest, president of the American Paper and Pulp Association, at its sixty-first annual convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.
The steel oil barge Hygrade 16, loaded with 997,000 gallons of gasoline, caught fire today in Long Island Sound, leaving one man missing and believed burned to death.

Captain E. W. McKee, director of athletics at the Naval Academy, today announced the appointment of Keith Molesworth, quarterback of the Chicago Bears, as assistant backfield coach of the Navy football team.

The 1937 annual report of the New York Telephone Company, controlled by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, forwarded to stockholders yesterday, shows a net income of $34,415,352 after all expenses and charges.

Mrs. Mary Gertrude Crittenden Henry, the wife of Colonel Dominick Henry, retired Deputy Chief Inspector of the New York Police Department, died on Wednesday night at their home at 320 Central Park West after a long illness.

A Seminole tribe apparently invoked its "law of the Everglades" today and executed a trouble-making member. Victim of the summary shotgun execution was John Billy, 30, who had met tribal discipline for previous malefactions, including the fatal stabbing of a fellow-brave in a drunken brawl near the town of Everglades several years ago.
The writer is able to state that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain lost no time in acting after Chancellor Hitler's speech before the Reichstag Sunday.

The magic name of Notre Dame will attract 16,000 persons to Madison Square Garden tonight, when the Indianans clash with New York University in what has come to be accepted as the city's basketball classic of the season.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Alan Ramsay Hawley, American balloonist and aeronautical pioneer, who died on Feb. 16, left his residuary estate of undetermined value for the establishment of "the Alan R. and William Hawley Prizes for the Encouragement of Studious Effort" for students attending Trinity School for Boys at 139 West Ninetyffrst Street and St. Agatha School for Girls at 553 West End Avenue.

Attacking the concept of the totalitarian State as obstructing freedom of religion, three speakers, representing Catholics, Jews and Protestants, today addressed Dickinson College's Forum on Interreligious Cooperation, which is designed to oppose attempts by dictatorships to get an American foothold.
The Erasmus Hall High School quintet assured itself of at least a tie for the Section 2, Brooklyn P. S. A. L., crown by defeating Manual Training, 37 to 20, on the losers' floor yesterday.

A first mortgage loan of $700,000 at 4 per cent for ten years has been made by the Prudential Insurance Company to the Broadway Improvement Company, George E. Roosevelt president, on the eightstory and twenty-story buildings occupying the block front on the west side of Broadway, from Thirteenth to Fourteenth Streets.
Fordham snapped a four-game losing streak and gained revenge for an early-season -defeat from Canisius by subduing the Griffins on the Fordham court last night, 39--30.
The General Reinsurance Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1937 a consolidated net profit of $886,244, equal to $4.43 a share, compared to $1,143,000, or $5 a share, for 1936.

Additional service on the subway and elevated lines of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, as recommended by engineers of the Transit Commission, would cost the company an additional $248,365 a year in wages alone, according to testimony given yesterday at a public hearing before Commissioner M. Maldwin Fertig.

No improvement was apparent last month in the international economic outlook, according to the monthly survey of foreign conditions by The Annalist, issued today. World industrial activity, even outside the United States,
Former President Herbert Hoover today was named an honorary citizen of Lisle and this afternoon he received an honorary doctorate at the local university. The rector made the presentation.

When you gather about 800 anglers and hunters in one room, it's doubtful that you could isolate the sound of a boiler factory in the general uproar, but when Art Keyes gave his revolver exhibition at the Rod and Gun Editors dinner Wednesday night you could have heard the sound made by the dropping of a No. 18 hook on a plush rug.

The syndics of Cambridge University Press tonight opened Bentley House, their new publishing house, on Euston Road. A tablet at the entrance of the hall sums up the four centuries' history of the Cambridge University Press thus:

Bronx Park E (16-4424), e s, 100 ft n of Waring- Ave, 125x131; Randolph Associates, Inc. to Manufacturers Trust Co. installments, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent; $24,500. Trinity Ave 764 (10-2636); Ethel Morrison to Webb institute of Naval Architecture, Webb and Sedgwick Aves, Bronx, extends mtge to Jan. 1, 1943, at 4 1/2 per cent; $44,000.

Captain Frederick W. Parkinson, who at his retirement in 1934 was dean of the steamboat captains in the city employ, died Wednesday at his home, 2,922 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, after a short illness. He was 66 years old.

Wheat futures held within a range of 1/2 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade here today, with trading the dullest in some time. Easiness in Liverpool and in securities and commodities in general were the main depressing influences.

Taking an early lead and maintaining the advantage throughout the game, Upsala defeated the Cathedral five tonight, 51-40. The Vikings set the pace at the half, 24-16. Jerry Nolan of Cathedral took individual scoring honors with 26 points.

Yesterday.Wednesday. For the best names.... 1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months' paper. * * * Store Collections Off 1.33% Collection percentages of twenty key stores for January showed an average of 49.87 per cent, compared with 51.20 per cent for January, 1937, or a decrease of 1.33 per cent, according to the index of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, issued yesterday.
The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders, dated Feb. 21: CAPTAINS Bunkley, J. W., Navy Department, to duty as commander Destroyer Squadron 10.

The up-State WPA has been asked by the recruiting service of the United States Army to draw up lists of able-bodied, single young men on home and work relief, with a view to their enlistment for military service, it was learned yesterday.
Charles A. Edison, assistant secretary of the navy, called on the "Godmothers of the fleet" today to help support the Administration in its national defense efforts.

At the meeting of the National Socialist Teachers League today it was proposed to abolish the designations "before Christ" or "after Christ" used in historic chtronology and adopt instead the terms "before or after the time of counting."
Mrs. Helen G. Ten Eyck, mother of Andrew Ten Eyck, lawyer and formerly confidential assistant to President Roosevelt, died here yesterday after a short illness.

Henry J. Patten, former treasurer of Bartlett, Frazier Co., grain brokers, died early today in the Passavant Hospital from complications resulting from a fall in which he broke his arm several weeks ago.

A merger of the Lawyers Title Corporation with the New York Title Insurance Company was approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred H. Frankenthaler. The two companies are engaged in the title insurance business and are subsidiaries of the Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company and the New York Title and Mortgage Company, respectively.
Mrs. Jessie Spearing, 80 years old, died here yesterday. She was the widow of the Rev. James Spearing, Episcopal rector and founder of the University of the South at Sewanee. Tenn.

Pearl St, n w cor Vandewater St, 48.6x 161.1; Mortgage Commission Realty Corp to John J. Cray, as trustee, 141 Broadway. 47th St, 107 W. 20x80; same to Daniel W. Blumenthal, trustee, 475 5th Ave. Mott St. 167, 24.9x100: Bowery Savings Bank to Rose Luca, 232 Bowery ($4.50). 64th St, 27-31 W, 75x100.5; N. Y. State Teachers' Retirement System to Park-64th St, Inc, 511 5th Ave ($55).
Dr. Charles Orin Day, ear, nose and throat specialist and consultant of many leading Boston hospitals, died yesterday at Baker Memorial Hospital, Boston, of pneumonia. His age was 58.

In his speech before the Austrian legislative bodies tonight Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg began by saying that at a decisive and historic moment in the country's history he had asked the Federal President to summon the Federal Council to an extraordinary session to be attended also by all members of the State's other advisory councils and by the leading officials of the Fatherland Front.
Germany accepted today the new British formula for the withdrawal of foreign combatants from Spain and the granting of belligerent rights to both sides.

Office, store and showroom space in the midtown section of Manhattan formed the bulk of business leases reported yesterday. Beatrice Sohiller, Inc., furrier, for many years at Broadway and Eighty-second Street, took two stores at 693 and 695 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Sixty-second Street.
Backwoods Night was celebrated with a costume dinner dance at Le Coq Rouge, 72 East Fifty-sixth Street, last evening for the benefit of the Madison Square Boys Club.

A glance at the map is enough to show what a mistake it was to let the lower East River waterfront be practically monopolized for business uses. In the long run no one gained much, for the waterfront went to seed and much of the area behind it became slums from which people moved away as soon as they could afford homes elsewhere.
Lower prices for cotton in Liverpool, following the recent steady rise, caused yesterday a setback in quotations on the Cotton Exchange here and the list closed with losses of 5 to 10 points.

Joe Louis left New York last night for Chicago, pointing for another defense of his world heavyweight boxing title after attending a testimonial dinner to James J. Braddock, former champion, in Union City, N. J.

The official title of Simon W. Gerson has been changed from "assistant to the President" to "confidential examiner" in the office of Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, in order to remove any legal questions as to the validity of his tenure of office, it was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court.

The future security of Western civilization depends upon our educational institutions, which must produce leaders who are imbued with both idealistic and realistic values, Dr. Henry W. A. Hanson, president of Gettysburg College, declared last night.

A divorce was granted at Carson City today to Mrs. Eleanor Post Close Rand from George C. Rand of New York on the ground of cruelty. Mrs. Rand is a daughter of Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, wife of the Ambassador to Belgium.

Crane Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange that the option granted to Charles B. Nolte, its president, to buy 50,000 common shares at $10 each has been exercised to the extent of 2,000 additional shares, leaving 33,000 available.
Ulen Co. Series A preferred stock, no-par value, and Series B preferred stock, no-par value, have been admitted to listing by the New York Curb Exchange.
The fifth annual all-day meeting of the Mortgage Conference of New York, composed of savings banks, insurance companies and other lending institutions, will be held today in the Hotel Commodore.

Manhattan 115th St, 74 E; 25x100.11; for 1-story garage; H. S. Oil Co, Inc. 95 E 116th St, owner; R. Teichman, architect; cost, $9,000. Alterations 101st St, 233 E; to 4-story tenement; Salvatore La Porta, 303 E 106th St. owner; D. S. Lang, architect; cost, $3,900. 9th Ave, 859-61; to two 6-story tenements and stores; Solian Corp, 149 Broadway. owner; same architect; cost, $9,600.

The imposing three-story mansion and the neighboring stables on the estate of the late Percy A. Rockefeller, fronting on Lake Avenue in Greenwich, Conn., are to be torn down as part of the plan to develop the 312-acre property into a residential community of small estates.
Miss Arlene Leins of 150 Claremont Avenue, a teacher at Public School 105, Manhattan, died on Wednesday night in the Park East Hospital after a brief illness. She was 38 years old.

With good skiing conditions hard to find in most of the spots favored by metropolitan Winter sports enthusiasts, there will be a comparatively small exodus of skiers from New York this week-end. The only group movement over the New York Central Railroad lines will be a day-coach excursion to the Laurentians.
A new bill, guaranteeing part of the British market to British films, by methods similar to those of the present act, was passed by the House of Commons tonight and sent to the House of Lords.
Electric power production increased last week when a decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index moved upward to 93.9 from 93.2. The figure for the week ended Feb. 20, 1937, was 106.6.

Walter Emery of Houston dropped Reynolds Smith, Walker Cup star, from the Houston Country Club invitation tourney today with an amazing series of golf shots. Barely able to squeeze into match play after being forced to go four holes in a play-off after the qualify-
During the week ended Feb. 23 member bank reserve balances increased $24,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $6,000,000 in Treasury cash, $32,
Movement of livestock in the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follows:
To take effect 8 A. M., March 1: LIEUTENANTS--Harry Kent from 6th Precinct to 19th Division, office of chief inspector, assignment to desk duty discontinues.

Attorney General John J. Bennett told 1,200 persons at a dinner in Brooklyn last night that if more attention were given to the care and development of the nation's children than to the attempts to destroy American institutions there would be no fears for the future of the country.

The Marine Corps announced the following changes during the week ended Feb. 21: COLONELS Clarke, T. S., Second Marine Brigade, ordered returned to San Diego, Calif., and treatment Naval Hospital, San Diego. Randall, A. E., detached Guam, to San Diego, Calif.

Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, announced today the appointment of Chester R. Blakelock as executive secretary of the commission to succeed the late Benjamin L. Van Schaick. Mr. Blakelock has been a contract engineer for the commission for the last eight years. He lives here with his wife and a son.

Today's major events: Joaquin Nin-Culmell, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Max Rosen, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera House, evening; New York Civic Orchestra, Federal Music Theatre, evening.
The Long Island University basketball team of Brooklyn defeated Toledo University, 41 to 35, tonight before 4,500 fans. The home team held a 21-to-20 halftime advantage.

A meeting of hide dealers, packers, tanners and shoe manufacturers will be held soon to formulate a plan for adding a hide trading board to the facilities of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, it was announced today. The date for the meeting has not been set.

The action of the State Senate committee on taxation and retrenchment in unanimously rejecting the Buckley-Ives bill, which would have denied property owners the right to ask lower valuations solely on the ground of overassessment, was lauded yesterday by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

There was keen disappointment in brokerage circles yesterday over the inability of the market to hold to its volume of the previous day. The slight reaction that set in on prices naturally contributed to the erasing of the smiles of Wednesday, but the decline in prices did not produce such intense gloom as did the cut in sales.

The "civil estimates," the first installment of the announcements which will tell the British taxpayer how much the government will cost him during the coming fiscal year, were featured today by the disclosure of a sharp increase in expenditures on gas masks and other defenses against bombing attacks.

Eight young men were ordained to the priesthood yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street. There were 1,600 relatives and friends present. The officiating prelate was the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Gates of this place have announced the marriage in Paris on Monday of their daughter, Miss Frances Laura Gates, to Willem Ewout Prins, son of Mrs. W. E. Prins-Hinzen of Hilversum, The Netherlands.

Charles Howard, owner of the Santa Anita $100,000 Handicap favorite, Seabiscuit, said today he rejected a $100,000 offer from Colonel E. R. Bradley of Kentucky for the thoroughbred after the race here March 5.

With adoption yesterday of a constitutional amendment changing voting procedure to require a ballot to express affirmation, the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange received the report of the committee named to draft a new constitution for the second time.

With snow conditions improved over those of last week, devotees of skiing can look forward to another active period this week-end, as number of important competitions are scheduled. The program will get under way tomorrow with the Colgate college tournament.

Secretary Morgenthau gave notice this afternoon that the Treasury would offer two series of bills aggregating $100,000,000, with bids receivable up to 2 P. M. Eastern standard time, on Monday at Federal Reserve Banks or their branches.

Phillip D. Thurston, secretary of the City Planning Commission, said yesterday that the map published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday showing the proposed rezoning of the lower East Side had carried incorrect listings of the districts involved in the change.

The seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of the national banking system will be observed today at meetings and dinners to be held in each of the twelve Federal Reserve Districts and in Washington, it was announced yesterday by Luther K. Roberts, Chief National Bank Examiner of the Second Federal Reserve District, of which New York is the headquarters.
Last Summer 300,000 visitors came to Callander to see the Dionne girls. One recent Winter morning,

Thomas Dimond, lieutenant of Essex County detectives, who was a nationally known investigator of fraud and rackets cases, died yesterday in Los Angeles where he was aiding District Attorney Buron Fitts in an investigation of rackets in that city.

The Interstate Commerce Commission modified today an order previously issued to permit the Bangor Aroostook Railroad Company to sell $117,000 of consolidated-refunding-mortgage 4 per cent bonds at prices ranging from 103 to 106, exclusive of interest.
Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Pell gave a luncheon yesterday at the Madison for Mrs. M. Taylor Pyne Jr., Mrs. Robert E. Tod, Mrs. Talbot Ewart, Mrs. Elisha Walker and Mrs. Ansel Phelps.

The sharp recession in recent months in activities on the national securities exchanges was emphasized today by a report by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the dollar value of sales on all registered exchanges in January had dropped to $1,087,714,713, a decrease of 21 per cent, compared with December, and of 63.4 per cent, compared with January, 1937. Stock sales,
President Roosevelt was told today by John N. Biggers, director of the Unemployment Census, that the worst of the business recession was passing.
John H. R. Gulick, a member of one of the oldest families in this section, died late this afternoon at his home here on the PrincetonKingston Road after a heart attack. His age was 40.

MacAndrew Red Lake Gold Mines, Ltd., Toronto, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 1,300,000 shares of $1 par value common stock to be offered at $1.25 a share.

The Administration's experiment in bituminous coal has temporarily broken down. The immediate reason is not economic but legal. Railroads, manufacturers and city governments had complained that the Bituminous Coal Commission put minimum prices into effect without holding public hearings, and that the prices were therefore illegal.
The motorship Santa Rita of the Grace Line is returning to port with a fire in her No. 3 hold. The fire is reported to be under control.
The report of the Western Electric Company, Inc., for 1937, issued today, shows consolidated net earnings of $19,514,197 as compared with $18,698,049 in 1936.

The girls' basketball team of East Stroudsburg Teachers College yesterday scored its ninth triumph in eleven starts by defeating the New York University sextet, 25 to 11, in the Evangeline Gymnasium on West Thirteenth Street.

Mrs. Matalida Butler Hand, widow of the Rev. Aaron W. Hand, died at her home here yesterday after a brief illness. Born seventy-four years ago in Paterson, she was the daughter of the late Henry A. Williams and Mary Louisa Vansaun Williams.

The reappointment of Frank McManamy to the Interstate Commerce Commission was urged upon President Roosevelt today by George Harrison, head of the Association of Railway Labor Executives, and David Robertson, president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Engineers.
Japanese planes yesterday raided Chinese airdromes on the southeast China coast in search for the base from which Chinese on Wednesday bombarded the Japanese island of Formosa.

The case against Patrolman Joseph J. McGarry of the West 100th Street Station. charged with driving while intoxicated, leaving the scene of an accident and third degree assault, was dismissed yesterday for lack of evidence, by Magistrate Louis Brodsky in Bronx Intoxication Court.
The annual Butterfly Ball Dinner Dance will take place April 22 at the Ritz-Carlton, and, as in past years, will be for the benefit of the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge, near Yonkers.

The War Department issued the following orders dated Feb. 23: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Read, B. Y., Adjutant General's Department, two days' leave, Feb. 23. Busbee, C. M., F. A., General Staff Corps, three days' leave, Feb. 26. Andrus, C., F. A., General Staff Corps, five days' leave, March 12 and five days March 29.

Courageous is the word applied throughout the French press today to Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's speech in the Austrian Diet. French opinion notes with satisfaction his insistence upon Austria's independence.

In an advisory opinion to the Securities and Exchange Commission on applications by the Philadelphia Stock Exchange for unlisted trading in the common stocks of the Atlas Corporation and the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, Robert P. Reeder, examiner, emphasized today the importance of such unlisted trading to the smaller exchange.
The House Labor Committee discussed proposals for a new hours and wages bill today without reaching any decision.
The Rumanian plebiscite- with its oral ballot produced this result in Bucharest-of 226,782 voters only 277 citizens dared to stand against King Carol's new dictatorial Constitution.

After voting 19 to 0 late tonight for the Highway Department's annual appropriations bill, with $3,300,000 included as the State's share of a $20,000,000 WPA work relief project, the Senate blocked passage of a bill to divert $3,000,000 of road money to direct relief.

Unrepresented on Broadway since "As Thousands Cheer" (1933-34), Irving Berlin telegraphed this column yesterday from Los Angeles that "I am planning to do a musical some time next season" although "nothing is definitely decided on."
The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today that Secretary Wallace had approved loans to tobacco grower associations on firecured and dark air-cured tobacco amounting to $2,750,000.
Vincent C. Hoye, a Boston lawyer and former baseball captain at Brown University, died yesterday after he collapsed in a store near his home in Brookline. His age was 54.
John F. Ryan, retired New York public accountant, died yesterday in the Mount Vernon Hospital of injuries suffered in a fall on New Year's Day. He was 74 years old.

By B. HOLLANDER SON Manida St, 744, 2-story dwelling, 25x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Gussie Marel; due, $12,596; to plaintiff for $3,250. By THOMAS J. LUNNEY 232d St, W. s e cor Independence Ave, vacant, 189.9x106.8, irreg; Henry A. Kroger, executor, against Pauline L. Williams; due, $12,175: taxes, etc. $1,848; to plaintiff for $1,000.

A terrorist's bomb today blew out the front of the building occupied by the American-registered, anti-Japanese newspaper Hwa Mei Wan Pao, of which Hal P. Mills of New Orleans is publisher. Two persons were killed and ten injured.

Funeral services for S. Parker Gilbert, a partner in J. P. Morgan Co. and former agent general for reparations payments, who died Wednesday, will be conducted by th Right Rev. J. I. Blair Larned, Suffragan Bishop of Long Island, at IC A. M. tomorrow in the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

An appeal for a boycott of Japanese goods, signed by more than 100 public officials, educators, clergymen and others, was issued yesterday by the Committee for a Boycott Against Japanese Aggression, with offices at 5 Maiden Lane.

The creation of a city-wide philanthropic organization to undertake the effective financing and planning of private health and social welfare work in the city was disclosed last night by a group of distinguished speakers, including Mayor La Guardia, John D. Rockefeller Jr., James G. Blaine, Alfred E. Smith and Joseph M. Proskauer.

Luncheon, Modern Management Group, Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Governor Francis P. Murphy of New Hampshire, Charles P. McCormick, Paul S. Willis, Dr. Richard T. Ely, Robert H. Armstrong, Thomas F. Woodlock, Ordway Tead, Alvin E. Dodd.

Fulton's river folk appeared victors by inches tonight in a grim battle with the swollen Red River. After flooding wide areas of plantation country east and west of here, the stream was beginning a slow drop from the row of 30,000 sandbags piled atop the main levee in front of the town. The bulwark was holding sturdily.

THE book reviewer unlimbered the typewriter that rose like a coast defense gun out of the side of his desk. He put a double sheet of copy paper on the roller and tapped the space bar seven times for the first paragraph. Then he sat back and looked earnestly at the paper. He had been looking at it for about nine minutes when the caller dropped in.

Rose Pauly, who made a sensational American debut last season with the Philharmonic- Symphony Orchestra, assisted the same organization last night in Carnegie Hall, under the baton of John Barbirolli, in a Strauss program.

Part-time paid officers of unions may receive State unemployment insurance benefits, Attorney General Bennett ruled today in an opinion requested by Paul Sifton, Administrator of the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance in the Labor Department.
At the annual meeting of the Industrial Rayon Corporation, Grover Higgins was elected a director, succeeding Frank H. Ginn, deceased.

The "cash position" of Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc., which the corporation's accountant has since confessed to inflating for 1934, 1935 and 1936, "fired my enthusiasm," Leo A. Bercow, former columnist on the New York Daily Investment News, testified yesterday in Attorney General Bennett's inquiry.
The trustees of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to borrow $2,235,000 to purchase equipment.

1st Lt. Herman J. Meury, Inf.-Res., Route 1, Trenton, N. J., (D). 78th Div., is ordered to active duty, effective Feb. 27 at Camp Dix, N. J., for training. Date of rank: Feb. 27, 1938. He will revert to an inactive status on March 12.

For the second time during this session of the Diet disorder broke out yesterday over the government's National Mobilization Bill and the day's proceedings ended with the House angry and dissatisfied.

The downward trend of local bank credit was resumed in the week ended on Wednesday, covered in the condition statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, issued yesterday.
The world championship pocket billiard tournament, scheduled to open Monday night at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy, will not have Champion Ralph Greenleaf as one of the competitors.
Thomas Gann, discoverer of several Maya cities and an authority on tropical medicine, died today in a hospital here at the age of 70.

TODAY--New England: Partly cloudy and slightly colder, freezing temperatures in all parts during the morning and continuing below freezing over northern part during the day. New York State: Partly cloudy and slightly colder,

The directors of Chrysler Corporation omitted yesterday a quarterly dividend for the first time since the second quarter of 1933. This, with the first quarter of 1933, is the third quarter in the company's history in which -no dividends have been declared since the initial payment of 75 cents a share on April 2, 1926.
BROOKS, FANNIE BELLE (Dec. 27). Estate, $2,000. To Godfrey B. Almquist and Anne Bartlette Tubbs, executrix, both of 100 Northern Ave., about $1,000 each; other varying bequests.
Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade today adopted a resolution which will eliminate the necessity for trading in old and new July and September contracts in grain.

February 22 is always a day of glorious memories. For the first time in history it was succeeded this year by two days of glorious hopes. On Feb. 23 Senator Minton gave a gorgeous-East coming-out party to the illustrious proconsul on leave, the Hoosier Bird of Paradise. He outshone the. lights.

With public construction up 106 per cent over a year ago, engineering construction awards in the current week totaled $40,161,000, according to Engineering News-Record, which points out that this is a short week because of the Washington's Birthday holiday.

Thirty-nine cadets of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy will receive diplomas at the seventy-eighth graduation exercises of the academy at 2:30 P. M. today at the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.

The Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark, N. J., reported yesterday a gain of more than $27,000,000 in 1937 in admitted assets, bringing the total to $645,881,531, the highest in the company's history. Contingency reserves at the end of the year stood at $28,532.226.

Two briefs, both insisting upon the maintenance of prevailing tariff rates against British-made textile goods, were made public here by trade groups representing industries which fear a reduction in duties as a result of the pending Anglo-American trade treaty.
Losing much of the buoyancy that had characterized trading on Wednesday, the bond market turned irregular yesterday in slower trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Feb. 24 unless specified: At Bridgetown Bar: Badger, Decatur, Fair fax, Dickerson, Jacob Jones, Schenck, Tattnail.

The five-suit bridge invented by Dr. Walther Marseilles, Vienna scientist and psychologist, has been endorsed by Paul Stern, captain of the Austrian national bridge team and the winners of last year's world championship.
Production of gold in Australia in 1937 was 1,380,481 fine ounces, valued at [Pound]11,986,859, the largest since 1917, but only one-third of the maximum of 3,898,000 ounces mined in 1903.
The AngloIrish talks and with them the prospects for a settlement of the four major problems involving the two countries hung in the balance tonight.

At a time when American dealers are conducting a drive to unload excesses of used cars, a report made public today by the Department of Commerce said that used car dealers in Manchester, England, have induced an insurance company to insure certified used cars sold by. recognized dealers.

A six-story apartment house will rise on the site of the former home of James W. Gerard, one-time Ambassador to Germany, at 17 Gramercy Park South. Plans for a building to contain sixty rooms, divided into apartments of one and a half to three rooms, and estimated to cost about $100,000, were announced yesterday.

Al Crawford, who holds the national A. A. U. 174-pound title, gained one of the few falls in the invitation wrestling meet at the New York A. C. last night, when he threw Italo Orio, Winged Foot grappler, in 2:27 of the first extra period in the 191-pound final.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions ALPHA NOVELTY AND BUTTON WORKS. INC., 39-47 W. 19th St.--Voluntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $26,232 and assets of $30,780. Petitions Filed--Against A. H. K. LUNCH BAR, 322 3d Ave., by George Doerr Jr., for $668; Levantine Importing Co., $321; Gregory Macar Son Co., Inc., $391..
Three bills designed to cut down the pension costs for New York City were introduced in the Assembly today by William T. Middleton, Manhattan Republican.
Lumber production increased less than seasonally last week and the adjusted index eased to 52.3 from 53.1 It stood at 75.3 for the week ended Feb. 20, 1937.

The New York Kangers emerged from their slump at the expense of the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. Paced by Clint Smith, who registered two goals in the opening period, the Blue Shirts scored their first victory in four games, 6 to 3.
Play started last night on the courts of the Columbia University Club in the national Class B squash tennis championship, with the field moving through the first round.
Harry Bowly Hollins, who organized the banking and brokerage firm of H. B. Hollins Co. in 1878, died yesterday at his home, 14 East Sixtieth Street, at the age of 84.

Edgar T. McCormick last night captured his adjourned game with Alexander Simchow to give the Marshall Club the lead in the Metropolitan Chess League match with the Empire City-International Chess Club. Thereupon,
President and Mrs. Roosevelt held tonight the last State reception on the White House schedule, entertaining in honor of the army and navy.

Although new orders for lumber last month were considerably below a year ago, bookings have been larger since the middle of January than in any previous weeks since last October, according to the twenty-seventh quarterly report of the Lumber Survey Committee, issued today by the Department of Commerce.

The Senate passed today, without debate, and with a maximum of four votes in opposition to any of the bills, Governor Lehman's tax program for the coming fiscal year, except the bills for the two-cent emergency tax on gasoline.

Richard C. Stout, an executive of the Heywood-Wakefield Company, furniture manufacturers, died early yesterday in New York Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 53. His home was at 4 Bennett Street, Wakefield, Mass.

Hugh J. Sheeran, president of the New York City Omnibus Corporation, the Eighth Avenue Coach Corporation and the Madison Avenue Coach Company, Inc., died yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Hospital of coronary thrombosis.
A sharp drop in bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday, compared with the preceding fiveday week, is revealed in reports to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Mr. and Mrs. Ross Beason of New York entertained 100 tonight at the Thursday informal boxing dinner at the Surf Club.

A letter in which he threatened violence to United States District Judge Robert Cooper unless the judge promised lenience to nationalists who might appear before him in the future has brought about the indictment of Ramon Gomez Gutierrez.

Richard E. Kroeber of 197 Trenor Drive, New Rochelle, treasurer of the Robert Brautigam Company, Brooklyn manufacturer of filter cloth, died on Wednesday of a heart attack at the St. Moritz Hotel. He was 60 years old.
Sale and distribution of Kent's Brushes to the retail trade in the United States has been transferred from London House, Ltd., to the Cosby Brush Company, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

A large number of members and their guests attended the All-American ball tonight at the Everglades Club, marked by a pageant set to music depicting the American scene from ante bellum days to the present, written by Hugh Dillman, who designed the costumes and part of the scenery. Participating were Mrs.

In a restatement of its educational objectives, the Progressive Education Association, holding its twentieth national convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania, indicated yesterday that school leaders must become vitally concerned with the social and economic problems facing this country.

Trading was fair to slow. The lamb market was not quite as strong as quoted early Wednesday. Cow and bull were stronger: some top prices of steer cuts lower; fresh pork cuts strong to slightly higher: other classes unchanged. Trading in kosher meats was confined mostly to lamb at full steady prices, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Mrs. A. C. Goodyear, Lewis Larsen, Hall Adams, J. C. Stephens, Mrs. Robert McKay, in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park S; Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers. Robert S. Conahy Jr. in 480 Park Ave; John O. Thayer, in 1,229 Madison Ave; Mark Varley, in 530 E 88th St; Nora L. Bullitt, in 210 E 68th St; Pease Elliman, Inc, brokers.

The Egyptian Cabinet has decided to approach the British Government with a request under Article VI of the Anglo-Egyptian treaty to participate in the coming Anglo-Italian talks, especially concerning the defense of the Suez Canal and Nile sources in the Lake Tsana region.
Men and women figure skaters from the East, Midwest and Far West cut fancy curves in the ice today as a final tune-up for the United States amateur championships opening tomorrow.

Profit-sharing plans for executives have proved more successful than similar-plans covering wageearners, according to the findings of a study made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Seven former Ministers among whom were the Agrarian leader, Dimitri Gitscheff, and the Socialist-leader, Pasturoff, were arrested today when meeting at a colleague's home to discuss the protest to be sent to King Boris against the regime's terroristic methods in connection with the forthcoming parliamentary elections.

Perry Terhune of Park Ridge has purchased, through William Gottlieb, broker, the property on the corner of Madison Street and Magnolia Avenue, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, in Park Ridge, N. J. The building, which contains five stores and four apartments, is to be altered extensively by the new owner.

To make "Siegfried" fit Metropolitan time limits, that work has been subjected to more lopping and slicing than any other member of the "Ring" tetralogy. Yesterday afternoon it was offered once more in its uncut form as the fourth event in the current Wagner cycle.

Regardless of economic developments of the next few years, the Port of New York Authority has sufficient funds on hand or credit available to complete the Lincoln Tunnel, according to its official annual statement, which was issued yesterday at the offices of the Authority at 111 Eighth Avenue.

Officials of Washington County, Va., sold yesterday to Minnich, Wright Co. and Scott, Horner Mason, Inc., a new issue of $340,000 of county sanitary district No. 1 bonds, on their bid of 102.058 for a fixed rate of 4 per cent. The bonds will be dated July 1, 1937, and will mature serially on July 1, 1939 to 1967.
Eight years ago today Charles Evans Hughes was sworn in as Chief Justice of the United States. Congratulatory letters and telegrams reached him today from many who remembered the anniversary.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

Japanese invasion is hastening modernization and unification of China which would otherwise take a generation to achieve, Dr. P. C. Chang, professor in Nankai University at Tientsin, declared yesterday before more than 200 members of the Institute of Arts and Sciences and the Women's Graduate Club in Philosophy Hall, Columbia University.
Memberm of the House who are opposing the passage of the administration's $1,000,000,000 Naval Construction Bill assailed the bill in committee and from the floor of the House today.

Fox St. 1.042 (10-2726); Helenka Realty Corp to Bertha Mlodinoff. 1,215 University Ave. LELAND AVE, 443 (14-3497); James H. Goggin, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp. Radcliff Ave. 2,547 (16-4445): Walter A. Lynch, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.

The marriage of Miss Winifred Whitney of Philadelphia, daughter of the late Rev. and Mrs. Walter R. Whitney of that city, to Harold Bedford Atkins of New York, took place this morning at St. Edward's Church with the Rev. James A. Greeley officiating.
President Lazaro Cardenas today opened a campaign for the support of labor in Mexico and abroad for "the difficult economic situation" he said Mexico must meet.

Mural paintings depicting "The Role of the Immigrant in the Industrial Development of America" were presented to the immigration station at Ellis Island yesterday afternoon by the Federal Art Project of the WPA.

Representative Scott, Democrat, of California, told the House Judiciary Committee today that former President Hoover was a principal stockholder of the Pacific Dock Company, holder of land in California to which the Federal Government was seeking title.

Fire and life insurance companies will not be permitted to solicit insurance unless they have been authorized and licensed by the Nicaraguan Government, the companies must deposit in the National Bank of Nicaragua a certain amount of national and foreign bonds and the form of their policies must be submitted to the government, President Anastasio Somoza announced today.

Aubrey Williams, acting Works Progress Administrator, told a group from New York representing labor unions and the Workers Alliance who came here today to discuss methods of administering relief that the man to take their troubles to was the New York Administrators, Colonel Somervell.
Senator Borah indicated belief today that settlement of Hungary's debt to this country would be blocked by fear of establishing precedents that might apply to larger war debts.

Bipartisan demands that Congress hold up construction of a TVA dam at Gilbertsville, Ky., pending further study brought from Senator Norris today the assertion that the "power trust" had inspired opposition to the project.

More than 1,300 city employes attended the opening lecture last night of the course on city finances and accounting being given at City College under the sponsorship of Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, who wants to promote a career service among civil service employes in his office.
John Herrick, Overseer of the Poor, started something when he offered to every man who came for town food orders an axe to chop down trees in the community forest.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Architecture cannot make a great fair, but architects can break one. This aphorism is evoked by the knowledge that, from present indications, the forthcoming New York World's Fair appears to be "in the bornin' " of the dictates of the Board of Design.

Senator Lodge proposed an amendment to the Social Security Act today to decrease old-age taxes on workers and employers and to start a "pay-as-you-go" policy to eliminate the contemplated $47,000,000,000 reserve fund. Mr. Lodge told the Senate his amendment would do these things:

Five private gardens in the east midtown area, covered with boughs and leaves for the Winter but giving promise of early beauty with crocus shoots and nascent buds, were thrown open to public inspection yesterday afternoon.

The text of the addresses at the meeting of civic leaders at the Center Theatre last night follow: James G. Blaine This meeting is a milestone of - importance in the development of our great city's charities.

Various features of the rubber futures market on the Commodity Exchange, Inc., were discussed yesterday afternoon by Charles Slaughter, former president of the Rubber Exchange of New York and governor of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., in the second of a series of discussions on commodities being sponsored by the Commodity Club of New York.
Dr. Francis E. Townsend, who came back to the capital today to serve a thirty-day jail sentence for contempt of a Congressional committee, said he would appeal to the

Retail ALLENTOWN--Hess Bros.: Miss V. Kercher, gifts, lamps; 128 W. 31st (Arkwright, Inc.). ATLANTA, Ga.-The Mirror: E. Weinberg, accessories; 225 W. 34th (Marizon Rosenberg Co.). ATLANTA, Ga.-Rich's. Inc.; J. P. Flynn, domestics, silks. cottons, flannels; Mrs. J. R. Hall, junior wear: 128 W. 31st (Kirby, Block Co.).
Slight increases in Dominion Government deposits and holdings of United States dollars and sterling were shown today in the Bank of Canada's report for the week ended yesterday.

37th St, 302 W; 9-story apartment, 67x 100.8; Union Dime Savings Bank against 302 West 87th St. Inc; due $278,000; to plaintiff for $100,000. Lexington Ave, 130; 5-story dwelling 49.5x 19; Harlem Savings Bank against 130 East Thirty-seventh Street Corp; due $58,332; taxes, etc, $51; to plaintiff for $2,000.

New York's amateur dog owners had a busy afternoon and evening of competition at Bloomingdale's yesterday, while canine enthusiasts assembled five and six deep around the judging ring to witness the second day's program in the store's annual pet dog show.
Inspector Joseph P. Loonam, who was appointed to the Police Department by Theodore Roosevelt on Dec. 1, 1896, has applied for retirement effective next Monday. His pension pay would be $2,900 a year.

Glenn Cunningham will break the world outdoor mile record this Summer and probably will drive the mark down to 4:03 or thereabouts. That was the prophecy made yesterday to the Track Writers Association by Archie San Romani, the racing shadow and the boon companion. of the cantering Kansan, at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Paramount.
Although some sections of the stock markets here showed today an easier tendency, the tone generally was cheerful. Gilt-edge issues lost ground

Senator Joseph F. Guffey eliminated himself as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Pennsylvania today after four Pennsylvania Democratic leaders had conferred with President Roosevelt.

The new University of Berlin that Chancellor Hitler is constructing on the outskirts of the city (he recently laid the cornerstone for the first building, dedicated to the faculty of military science) will be named "Adolf Hitler University."
Mrs. Sanford S. Cox, wife of the treasurer of the Todd Shipbuilding Corporation, was found dead of gas poisoning last evening in the
A squad of youngsters ranging from 10 to 16 years of age held the spotlight at the National Sportsmen's Show yesterday with a clever exhibition of casting.

The annual report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries for 1937, which is being forwarded to shareholders today, shows a consolidated net income of $35,662,563, after all expenses and charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements and minority interest charges, to $2.17 a share on the outstanding common stock.

The G. A. Kleissler Company, engravers, bought for expansion from Rosanna Batchelor a plot of land at 170 1/2 Wilson Avenue, Newark, N. J., through Louis Schlesinger, Inc., broker. The Batchelor family acquired the property a decade before the Civil War.

The offer of the Hungarian Government, in an aide-memoire to the State Department, to refund its post-war indebtedness to the United States by paying a total of $1,207,000 over a period of thirty years was declared tonight by Eugene Havas, financial adviser of the Hungarian Legation, to be more favorable to the United States than the AustroAmerican debt settlement, if all circumstances are taken into consideration.

Emphasizing the current deadlock in the new capital market, the volume of bonds placed here this week was the smallest for any similar period in about sixteen months. Restricted for the third consecutive week to the tax-exempt field, new offerings amounted to only $807,000 principal amount as compared with $6,361,000 in new bonds placed last week and with a total of $18,615,000 marketed during this week a year ago.

Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. proposed yesterday that a system of "demerit rating" be used by casualty insurance companies to penalize careless automobile drivers. This, he pointed out, would be added compensation to the careful driver who now receives a discount in his rates.

An all-black cocker spaniel and a red chow topped their respective groups during the third day of Bloomingdale's annual pet dog exhibition yesterday and thas qualified for the best-in-show competition which will climax today's program.

Purchases by investors of the Federal Intermediate Credit Banks' short-term debentures, which supply most of the funds used by the banks for lending purposes, amounted to $354,775,000 in 1937, the largest volume in the history of the banks, Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent of the banks and the Federal Land Banks, said yesterday in a review of the system's operations last year. Those purchases compared with $246,560.000 in 1936.

The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Southern Pacific Company today to pledge as security for notes until Dec. 31, 1939, various bonds previously issued. These bonds are $360,000 of Central Pacific Railway Company Through Shortline first mortgage 4 per cent gold bonds;

Daily average sales of fluid milk during January were 2.36 per cent below the volume of January, 1937, according to figures issued yesterday by the Milk Industry Foundation, based on reports from 136 leading markets.
