Magistrate David L. Malbin in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn, served notice yesterday that henceforth in cases involving the possession of policy slips he would give the benefit of any doubt of the guilt of the defendant "to the public interest." Holding ten men,
Jacob Blum, a retired leather goods salesman, died on Wednesday at his home, 1,175 Gerard Avenue, the Bronx, after a long illness. A native of Germany, Mr. Blum was 71 years old.

Department store sales in New York and Brooklyn last week were 8.5 per cent lower than a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday. In the preceding week the decline was 3.4 per cent. With Newark reporting the largest decline for last week at 11 per cent under a year ago, the total drop for the four major areas in this district was 8.4 per cent.
In the all-student elections, held yesterday at Barnard College, Jean Allison, Margaret Boyle and Ruth Taubenhaus were elected president, treasurer and Secretary of the undergraduate association.

William M. Hughes, Minister of External Affairs, announced today that he was asking the Italian Government through Acting Consul General Cavaliere Arrighi to express regret for the assault on Frigo Orlando, Italian resident of Melbourne, by members of the crew of the Italian cruiser Raimondo Montecuccoli when Mr. Orlando visited the ship at a public inspection Feb. 15.

Dearers in municipal securities who have opposed the proposed bill for overthe-counter market regulation and are seeking exemption from its provisions were sharply criticized tonight by Senator Maloney of Connecticut, author of the measure, in a radio address over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Breaking his own record of 4 minutes 51 seconds to shuck one hundred oysters, a mark he made last year, Manuel Tavares of Warren, R. I., yesterday repeated his triumph at the National Sportsmen's Show, which comes to a close tonight after focusing the attention of thousands on Grand Central Palace during its session.

Howard Frankel, 12-year-old boy who refuses to live with his mother, was placed in his father's custody yesterday by Justice Herbert A. O'Brien of the Children's Court in Brooklyn under the terms of a general agreement stipulating that the mother may have her son's companionship one day a week, one week-end a month, every second legal holiday of New York State and one full week in the Summer.
Mr. and Mrs. Murray Earle of Chestnut Hill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Earle, to Britton Chance, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Chance of By the Way, Haverford.

ALBERTI, FRANK (Feb. 15). Estate, not more than $10,000. To Kate Alberti, widow, executrix, 74 Washington Pl., life estate in residue; Rose A., Frank J. and Lucy M. Alberti, children, 74 Washington Pl., remainder in residue.
The outstanding health record made by the wage-earning population in 1937 has continued into 1938, according to the statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, made public yesterday.

A national nutrition policy to aid the undernourished, similar to the government housing program to provide better homes, was recommended yesterday by Viscount Astor at a luncheon given in his honor by the Foreign Policy Association in the Henry Street Settlement, 99 Park Avenue.

The United American Petroleum Company, Dallas, Texas, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 25,000 shares of Class A common stock, no par value, and 25,000 shares of $2 cumulative Class B common, no par value, to be offered in units of one share of each at $40 a unit.

Miss Juliette F. Crawford, a retired public school teacher who taught the 1A grade in Public School 72, Brooklyn, for thirty-eight years, died yesterday at her home, 789 St. Mark's Avenue, at the age of 72. She retired from the school system in 1927.

A. D. Weekes of the Harvard Club Ten and E. L. Kilroe the Columbia Club won first-round matches in the National Squash Tennis Association the C Class B championship at the Co- off o lumbia Club yesterday. Weekes, seeded No. 6, won from M. Cohn, conte City A. C., 15-6, 8-15, 15-8, and Kilroe, ranked just below Weekes, defeated E. M. Rosenthal of the City A. C., 15-10, 15-9.

Crowds of readers in the Division of Economics and Sociology and in the corridors of the Public Library, at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, were thrown into an uproar at 6:45 o'clock last night when a man wielding a small carpenter's hatchet felled and critically injured another with whom he had been arguing.

James W. Holler Sr., president of the Holler Ice Manufacturing Company, has purchased from the trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company a plot of vacant land containing about 76,000 square feet on Boston Road, the Bronx.

Earl K. Shawe and Martin I. Rose, counsel for the National Labor Relations Board, read into the record at today's hearing on the board's charges of Wagner Act violations against the Bethlehem -Steel Company part of an editorial -from yesterday's Johnstown Democrat charging that the sole purpose of the organization of the Johnstown Citizens Committee was to break the "Little Steel" strike here last June.

Playing at times with brilliance as eye-filling as anything that has been seen in Madison Square Garden basketball games, Notre Dame vanquished New York University, 50 to 38, before a gathering of 17,463 last night, but it was not the runaway so many had expected.

Jerry Cardi-Nale, 23-year-old WPA ditchdigger, made his operatic debut in the leading tenor role of Alfredo in "Traviata" last night with the New York Hippodrome Opera Company. His musical aspirations were generously encouraged by a good-sized house.

Plans for the coming State campaign and possible candidates for Governor were discussed yesterday at a conference of leading members of the Republican State Executive Committee with State Chairman William S. Murray at the Hotel Roosevelt. Mr. Murray said reports from all sections of the State had made him optimistic on the chance of electing the Republican State ticket.
The Rev. Edward M. Corbett, S. J., connected with Weston College, the philosophical and theological seminary for Jesuits of New England, died today at the age of 74.

A new drive for pensions-pensions for the widows and dependents of all World. War veterans regardless of the cause of the veteran's death-is gaining momentum in official Washington today me following the favorable report of a bill to the House of Representatives by the Committee on Pensions.
Seabiscuit, handicap king of the nation in 1937, will pack top weight of 130 pounds and a strange rider in tomorrow's $7.500 added San Antonio handicap at a mile and one furlong at Santa Anita Park.

Al Woods comes back to the wars this evening, and, at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, is sponsoring "Censored," by Conrad Seiler and Max Marcin. All about an actor and a gangster, with the cast including Percy Kilbride, Marian Shockley, Frank Lovejoy, Marjorie Peterson, Don Costello and Bram Nossen.

The National Mobilization Act, designed by the army and the bureaucrats to lay the basis for a totalitarian regime in Japan, is meeting vigorous opposition in the Diet. Not even the warning of the War Minister that "the situation is very grave; the fate of the nation hangs on this occasion" was sufficient to stem the flood of criticism.

Federal Judge Abruzzo in Brooklyn dismissed yesterday three of six counts in the indictment charging John L. Lotsch, former chairman of the board of directors of the defunct Fort Greene National Bank, with having accepted fees from persons seeking loans from the bank.

Everything was in readiness tonight for the two-day United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association championships that will start tomorrow with the cross-country phase of the combined title test. A heavy snowfall that has blanketed the Belknap Mountain recreational center, a 4720,000 Winter sports project, under a one-foot cover has assured perfect conditions for the important tournament that has attracted a record entry of 100 skiers from some thirty clubs.

Although hopes of early betterment in flat glass are stronger than they were. operations this week continued on a minimum basis, according to the American Glass Review. In pressed and blown glassware, operations slowed up, instead of improving.

The cry that Austria.. may have to be saved from bolshevism has suddenly been raised here. It has appeared together with protective assurances that the Bolshevists probably are too late, but the door is clearly left open for German

The marriage of Mrs. Eve Ella Green, widow of Arthur M. Green and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Sherpick of Mineola, L. I., to Harry B. Helmsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Helmsley of New York, took place here last night in the Church of the Transfiguration.

County Judge William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn, who rose from the police force to the judiciary, has been elected grand marshal of this year's St. Patrick's Day parade by 400 delegates of Irish societies and county organizations, according to an announcement yesterday by John J. Sheahan, chairman of the arrangements committee.

An honorary committee in New York to aid in the participation of The Netherlands in the New York World's Fair was installed yesterday at an informal luncheon given at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel by H. M. van Haersma de With, Minister of The Netherlands to the United the States and president of the committee.

In a step to strengthen the export business in pottery, the Japanese Government soon will exert control over all exports, whether or not They are made by members of the Pottery Export Association, said a consular report from Tokyo made public today by the Department of Commerce.
Another attempt is to be made this year to stop roughness in connection with the carnival, which begins Sunday.

With two of the country's high ranking players included in the entry of sixty-four contenders, the men's national indoor tennis championship will start this morning at 11 o'clock on the board courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty- sixth Street.
Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, disclaimed yesterday any intention of coercing WPA workers into military service, on returning from a one-day trip to Washington.

Mrs. Mary Spry, 50 years old, of 224 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, was acquitted last night by a blue-ribbon jury in Kings County Court of a charge of slaying her husband, John, 41, a taxi chauffeur, in their home on Nov. 9, last. The jury deliberated four and a half hours.

George E. Kinney, Bermuda banker, formerly-of New York and Boston, likes apple pie, a fact known to his friend, Herbert E. Stone, a Boston banker. Mr. Stone had a pie baked last night, put it aboard a plane for Newark while it was still hot.

With unfavorable weather and the spread of unemployment slowing distribution and deep price cuts failing to attract consumer interest, retail sales this week dropped 3 to 8 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Cautious buying kept wholesale markets static and volume was estimated at 8 to 15 per cent below the same week of 1937.

Winning six of the nine first places, the New York University3 swimming team conquered Manhattan College, 41 to 34, in a dual meet in the Park Central pool yesterday. Junius Calitri starred for the Violet, taking the 200-yard free style in 2:34.4 and finishing in a dead heat with his team-mate, Henry Pferr, in the 150-yard back-stroke test. The time for the back-stroke was 2:13.

The government obtained a monopoly of the nation's known supplies of helium today by buying for $537,975 helium-producing land at Dexter; Kan., and Thatcher, Col. This land, the only known source of the gas outside the government-owned area at Amarillo, Texas, was bought from the Girdler Corporation of Louisville.

The leader of a gang of bank robbers who boasted that he would never be taken alive, but who was arrested Thursday night at Second Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, made good yesterday a promise he made at the time of his arrest...

Harry Bridges, West Coast director of the Committee for Industrial Organization and president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehouseman's Union, a CIO affiliate, arrived in Washington today and offered himself for examination by members of Congress and Labor Department officials on charges affecting his right to remain in this country, an opportunity of which none has thus far taken advantage.

Count Robert van der StratenPonthoz, the Belgian Ambassador, and Countess van der Straten-Ponthoz and J. T. Johnston Mali, the Belgian Consul General, and Mrs. Mail were guests of honor at a dance given by the Belgian Benevolent Society of New York last night at the Plaza.

A new Yale record was created by Eli mermen in the 300-yard medley race as the home team defeated Dartmouth, 46-29, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League meet today. Joe Burns, Newton Steers and Johnny Good finished in 3:02.2 to clip the former mark of 3:02.6 recently created by Burns, Steers and Johnny Macionis.
Sally Ryan, granddaughter of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan of New York, disclosed today she had paid [Pound]1,500 [$7,500] for one of Jacob Epstein's main controversial sculptures.

The adjutant general released the following orders today: These officers, having qualified, are placed on duty: Webb, Capt. Charles C., will report to commanding officer, 106th F. A., for assignment to headquarters as plans and training officer.

Election of Raphael B. Malsin as president of Lane Bryant, Inc., succeeding Harry Liverman, who becomes chairman of the board, was announced yesterday by Mr. Liverman. Mr. Malsin, who is 38 years old, is the son of Mrs. Lane Bryant Malsin, founder of the business, who is still active in the business as vice president.

Park Commissioner Moses and Borough President Harvey of Queens traded verbal punches yesterday over the Bayside High School, the Park Commissioner threatening to "crack you over the head whenever you sling mud at us," and Mr. Harvey retorting that Mr. Moses "can dish it out but cannot take it."

The Most Rev. Paul Salman, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Transjordania, who has been on a tour of the United States, will be the guest of honor at a dinner at 7:30 o'clock tonight at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the St. Mary's Ladies Society of the Church of the Virgin Mary, Brooklyn.

The Manufacturers Trust Company is registrar for the George A. Fuller Company's 24,186 shares of 4 per cent cumulative convertible preferred, 17,507 shares of $3 convertible and 62,413 shares of common stock.

Ten matches in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association's Group II singles championship at the Crescent Athletic Club were run off on schedule yesterday to complete the first round. Second-round contests are slated to start at 1 o'clock this afternoon.

Mrs. Charalambos Simopoulos, wife of the Greek Minister to London, has arrived from England and is at the Waldorf-Astoria before going to Washington to visit friends. Mr. and Mrs. Julian S. L. Humphrys of the Savoy-Plaza will return next week from Nassau, B. W. I.

Second Lieut. Clark V. Britton, Engr.-Res., 212 Springfield Ave., Hasbrouck Heights, N. J., 373d Engineers, is ordered to active duty, effective Feb. 27, at Headquarters Newark Reserve District, Post Office Building, East Orange, N. J., for training. Date of rank: Feb. 13, 1938. He will revert to an inactive status on March 12.

The blue ribbon attraction of the indoor track season, the fiftieth annual championships of the Amateur Athletic Union, will draw the picked athletes of the nation to Madison Square Garden tonight, with world records certain to fall before the headlong rush of the performers for the sixteen titles at stake.
Expecting early completion of Congressional action on an appropriation of $250,000,000 for the Works Progress Administration, New Jersey put in a formal application today for a grant of $35,000,000.

A committee has been formed for the protection of holders of convertible debenture 4 3/4 per cent notes of the Auburn Automobile Company in any plan of reorganization of the company. The committee consists of Bennington R. Gordon of Rogers, Gordon Co., Inc., chairman, and Melvyn H. Hecht of Kempshall Hecht, Inc., secretary.

The City Commission adopted today the budget which provides for $28,039,348 to be raised by taxation, an increase of $1,769,793 over last year. The budget will cause an increase in the tax rate of $3 for each $1,000 of assessed valuation. The tax rate last year was $44.27 a $1,000.

Pay cuts of 10 per cent and upward for salaried officers and employes, effective March 1, were announced today by General Motors. It was estimated that upward of 50,000 persons would be affected, and that the total would exceed $10,000,000 a year.

Princeton and Rutgers, whose teams played the first game of American football here on Nov. 6, 1869, will dedicate the new milliondollar Rutgers athletic plant and stadium 69 years later almost to the day when the Tiger meets the Scarlet eleven in the Rutgers Stadium next Nov. 5.

Lawson Robertson, coach of several United States Olympic track squads, said tonight he would have nothing to do with the next Olympic Games if they are held in Japan. Robertson, track coach at the University of Pennsylvania,' told a meeting of Pennsylvania Club of Suburban New Jersey members that the Japanese proved themselves unsportsmanlike because of their air bombings of defenseless Chinese.

A piano recital outstanding in a perspective of concerts by the younger generation of virtuosos was given last night in Town Hall by the young Spanish pianist, Joaquin Nin-Culmell, whose father, the composer and editor, is known in this country.

Edward Howard Hutchinson, Buffalo banker and philanthropist, died early this morning after an illness of one week. His age was 85. With his wife, who died several years ago, Mr. Hutchinson donated the site upon which Hutchinson High School was erected.
Al Davis is a promising young boxer, considered one of the brightest prospects in the business today. Nickey Jerome is a conscientious pugilist who apparently does not have as much ability as Davis.

Mr. and Mrs. David J. Main of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Louise Main, to Henry W. Keyes Jr., son of former United States Senator and Mrs. Henry W. Keyes of North Haverhill, N. H.

More than $50,000 was earned by 1,141 Hunter College students in positions obtained by the College Bureau of Occupations-during the Fall semester, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Dean Smith Schloss, in charge of undergraduate placements for the Hunter bureau.
Young Byron Nelson of Reading, Pa., smoothly stroked into a commanding lead over the field in the $3,000 Thomasville open golf tournament with a great 66 today.

The Pennsylvania Railroad had a net loss of $2,400,000 after all deductions in January, in contrast with a net income of $700,000 in January, 1937, M. W. Clement, president. said yesterday in Washington. The company's statement of gross revenues and net operating income in January follows:

An amendment to the State Constitution permitting municipalities to operate lotteries for funds to maintain city hospitals was proposed yesterday by Oscar S. Cox, assistant corporation counsel, in a speech at the fifth annual meeting of the Mortgage Conference of New York.

The B. F. Goodrich Company reported yesterday for 1937 a net lose of $878,580 after provision for Federal income and undistributed profits taxes and after a write-down of $5,652,935 to reduce to market prices as of Dec. 31 raw materials on hand and on commitment and the material content of unfinished and finished goods on hand.

Luther Byron Willsie, a proofreader for newspapers in the metropolitan area and from 1931 to 1935 employed in this capacity by THE NEW YORK TIMES, died last night in his home here after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

Anthony Eden, in a speech to his constituents yesterday, pledged himself not to engage in a campaign against the Chamberlain government. refusing to split the Conservative party. He insisted, however, that Italy delivered a "now or never threat" to Britain.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

Business booked by the structural steel industry in January amounted to 71,619 tons, the smallest since the 62,267 tons booked in October, 1937, and compared to 99,070 tons booked in Decemberand to 153,806 tons in January, 1937.

Hopeless, is the word, says Representative Lambertson of Kansas. He began a speech in the House today on the "hopelessness of balancing the budget," but digressed soon to the hopelessness of getting members into the House to listen to it.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Feb. 19 amounted to 535,790 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 7,201 cars, or 1.3 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week...

The season appears to have entered a determinedly abstract phase. For about a fortnight the American Abstract Artists' exhibition, installed at the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, has been attracting crowds (George L. K. Morris reports an attendance to date of more than 5,000).

64th St, 112-14 W, 37x100.5; Street and Avenue Realty Corp to Light and power Meter Corp, 505 5th Ave. 65th St, 132-34 W. 36.5x100.5: same to same. 8th Ave, 2,580, 25x80; Joseph K. Guerin to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp; consideration $1,000, foreclosure. 2d St, n s, 290 ft e of Avenue B, 48x105.11; Helen S. Satterlee et al to Union Square Savings Bank: mtg $16,000 held by bank.

Fifty-four of the city's most distinguished financiers, industrialists, educators and labor leaders have accepted membership on the board of directors of the Greater New York Fund, James G. Blaine, president of the fund, announced yesterday. Mayor La Guardia and five department heads will represent the city government as honorary members of the board.

More than 36,000 needy children received care last year in the seventy-four children's agencies affiliated with the New York Catholic Charities, the Rev. Bryan J. McEntegart, director of the group's division of children, said yesterday in his annual report.

The principal foreign exchanges rose in terms of the dollar yesterday, indicating a continued outflow of short-term capital from this country. The pound sterling advanced 11/16 cent to $5.02 5/16, the franc was up 1 1/2 points to 3.26 3/4 cents, the guilder gained 6 1/2 points to 56.01 cents, the belga rose 1 1/2 points
B. A. Lipman, president of the Doria Realty Corporation and Rittenhouse Estates, Inc., has resold fifteen vacant lots in Manhattan out of twenty-five he bought recently from a financial institution.

Colonel Joseph A. S. Mundy, chief of staff of the Twenty-seventh Division, National Guard, has been named to command the 369th Infantry Regiment of Harlem, succeeding Colonel John Grimley, who was removed as unfit recently by Governor Lehman, it was announced yesterday. Colonel Mundy,

The Federal Government has penetrated so deeply into the banking business that it will be years, if ever, before the banking business regains its former independence, Thomas R. Dwyer, executive vice president of the Liberty Bank of Buffalo, told some 270 national bank examiners and bank executives at a dinner last night in the Hotel Roosevelt.
Mrs. Mary C. Lynch, vocalist, golfer and wife of J. Paul Lynch, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. She had been ill for about three weeks.

Eddie Linz and Fred Coyle of the New York Athletic Club, defending titleholders, reached the finals of the New York State four-wall handball doubles championship by defeating Thomas Ginty and Kay Shifferson of the Pastime A. C., 2-21, 21-13, 21-9, at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. yesterday.
The Minnesota Conservation Department has hit upon an excellent method of observing Wild Life Restoration Week, which will be marked throughout the country from March 20 to 26.

The tragic story of the means by WGich the German pacifist, Karl von Ossietsky, lost all but 18,500 marks of the 103,000 mark Nobel Peace Prize awarded to him in 1935 was u-nrolled in a Berlin criminal courtr day.
The Twentieth Century-Fox Employes Credit Union, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street, New York, has filed an organization certificate with the Banking Department, it was disclosed today.
Dr. Thomas B. Futcher, diagnostician, died unexpectedly while on a routine round of duty at the Johns Hopkins Hospital today, where he had worked since 1894. His age was 67.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, in its annual report for 1937, made public yesterday, shows a net profit of $4,788,799 after depreciation, depletion, interest, Federal and State income taxes and $10,000 surtax on undistributed earnings.

Led by Ed O'Connor, who made 14 points, the St. Francis Prep quintet clinched the Brooklyn division C. H. S. A. A. crown yesterday by triumphing over Brooklyn Prep, 37-34, on the Franciscans' court. The victory was the eleventh in thirteen league games for the Red and Blue.
Fifteen players saw action for Colgate tonight as its basketball team defeated Alfred, 59-43. Ray Buckley, Alfred guard, led the scoring with 20 points. Ray Dieffenbach of Colgate made 17.

Forty of the General Electric Company's 70,000 employes yesterday received the highest honors the company bestows, namely, awards by the Charles A. Coffin Foundation for outstanding contributions to the electrical industry.

Germany's resentment over the turn which affairs have taken in Austria is unmistakable. Only a few days ago it was confidently asserted in Berlin that Hitler's latest coup would soon be followed by a political and economic union between Germany and Austria which Austria was pictured as desiring ardently. But now Dr. Schuschnigg,

A plan for industrial management under which he believes employes of a company can be confident of promotion on their merits, was outlined to industrial and business leaders yesterday by Charles P. McCormick, president of McCormick Co., Baltimore, manufacturers of spices and other grocery products, at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The admission of women to jury duty in the Municipal Courts of Manhattan and Brooklyn in 1937 and their pending admission in the other three boroughs has posed a new problem of housing for the already overcrowded courts, President Justice Pelham St. George Bissell said in his annual report made public yesterday.

The official news agency says that Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, will deliver a speech on currency problems to the general stockholders' meeting of the Reichsbank on March 11 and that this meeting will concern itself solely with replacement elections for the bank's central committee.

On the dark blue ice of the recently completed rink of the Philadelphia Skating Club and Humane Society forty-four figure skaters from the East, Midwest and Pacific Coast today began the quest for five mingles championships.
A nominal decline in cotton-mill activity last week, when the seasonal trend was upward, lowered the adjusted index to 87.7 from 90.6. The figure for the week ended Feb. 20, 1937, was 139.4.

Trainer Earl Sande said today Stagehand, winner of the $50,000 Anita Derby, would run in the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap March 5. The 3-year-old will run as an entry with Maxwell Howard's other crack racer, Sceneshifter, a 4year-old.
Robert Hancock, 50-year-old California airplane pilot, was killed today in a take-off crash that injured his employer, Adolph B. Spreckels Jr. of San Francisco.

Voicing what he termed the protest of humanity against war and the totalitarian State, Thomas Mann, German author and Nobel Prize winner, announced in a Francis Bergen Memorial lecture at Yale University today that he planned to make the cause of democracy and peace his life effort.
RETAIL DENVER-Denver D. G. Co.: W. A. Govton, ready-to-wear, basement; 1,412 Bway (Cavendish Trading Corp.). HARTFORD--Sage-Allen Co.; 8, Kroopnick, men's furnishings: 50 W 35th (Syndicate-Alliance).

Once Kipling told in the days of old Of Jubal and Tubal Cain; And he put new life in their ancient strife With a rippling, running strain. These are not the sins of the Texas twins As they run their rivals down; For firm and fond is the home-grown bond 'Twixt Elmer and Delmer Brown.
The boards of trustees of Western Reserve University and Cleveland College are planning to establish a permanent memorial in honor of Newton D. Baker, former member and chairman of these boards.

Bradford A. Gibson, president of the Leicester Savings Bank and former president of the Central Building Corporation of Worcester, died today at his home here after a heart attack. He was 68 years old.
Shakespeare Ave. 1,372, n e cor Boscobel Ave, 5-story tenement; Cecilia W. Donohue against F. F. Brennan Realty, Inc.; due, $33,777; taxes, etc., $3,318; to plaintiff for $1,000.
The Timken Roller Bearing Company has reported for 1937 net profits of $10,837,366, equal to $4.49 a share. Dividends of $12,056,900 were paid.
At the invitation of Mrs. Roosevelt, the national sponsors' committee of the Amelia Earhart Foundation, started by Thiel College in Pennsylvania, met today at the White House.
Sidney Mitchell, an industrialist, died early this morning at Flower Hospital after a brief illness. He was 62 years old. He lived at the Union League Club and he had offices at 171 Madison Avenue.

Countercharges of simple assault growing out of a head-on collision between automobiles driven by Prince Serge Obolensky, 47 years old, of 120 East End Avenue, and William Prohinsie, 47, of 151 East Eighty-ninth Street, in Central Park last Saturday, were withdrawn yesterday in Homicide Court.

Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today Commissioner Paul A. Walker had completed drafting his report in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company investigation and had submitted it to the full commission. Mr. McNinch said he had not yet read the report.

Promoting sixty-seven members of the Fire Department yesterday, Commissioner John J. McElligott advanced two battalion chiefs to the rank of deputy chief and five captains to the rank of battalion chief. The appointments,
To take effect 8 A. M., Feb. 25: LIEUTENANT Christopher G. Hodge, from 18th Division, 3d Detective District, to 15th Division, assigned to desk duty.

The women's fencing team of New York University scored its fourth successive victory of the season at its own center yesterday by defeating Brooklyn College, 5 to 4. It was the first match of the season for Brooklyn College.
Irreconcilable differences between various proposed bills for Congressional regulation of wages and hours prompted the House Labor Committee today to decide to try to write a new bill.
Purchases of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday exceeded sales after four consecutive trading days in which sales had been in excess of purchases.

Watson, vice president and Western manager of Ruthrauff Ryan Advertising Agency, will talk on "Development of Copy Themes" at the second midwinter dinner meeting of the Midwest chapter of the American Marketing Association at the Stevens Building Restaurant next Tuesday, according to announcement today by S. Teitelman,

Lyman Francis Gray, member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1902 and a partner in Lloyd Co., 111 Broadway, New York, since 1917, died here today at his home, 103 Laurel Place, after an illness of six months. His age was 74.

President Roosevelt said at a press conference that battleships were still the most effective weapon of naval attack and defense, and indicated that he was not apprehensive over reports of increased battleship vulnerability due to military aviation developments.

It was learned from Linz this morning that there had been big Nazi demonstrations there last night, although nothing to compare with those in Graz, where the situation is so serious that there is likely to be a general shakeup among the local authorities. Already the Mayor of Graz has been sent on "sick leave."

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
The annual report of the Radio Corporation of America for 1937, which is being sent to shareholders today, shows a net profit after operating expenses and fixed charges, of $9,024,858.

New York State's most important job of law-making since 1894, when the sixth State constitutional convention submitted amendments which were later adopted by the voters, will begin on April 5, when the 168 delegates to the eighth constitutional convention meet in Albany.
Miss Harriet Furniss Fernald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Luther Dana Fernald of this place, was married tonight to Theodore Erskine Tuck, son of Theodore Calvin Tuck of New Rochelle and the late Mrs.

Announcement nas Deen maae of the marriage of Miss Roselle M. Montgomery, daughter of John Seymour Montgomery of this city and the late Mrs. Roselle Mercier Montgomery, to N. Marks Bump, son of Austin S. Bump of Binghamton, N. Y.,

Princeton University's freshmen swimming forces gained their sixth victory of the season this afternoon by turning back Tome School of Point Deposit, Md., 35-30, in Brokaw Pool. Ned Parke, yearling captain, provided the highlight of the meet by traversing the 100-yard free-style distance in 0:54.4 for a new university freshman record.

The modern airplane has not supplanted battleships, cruisers, destroyers and submarines as the American first line of defense but has added "tremendously to the power and the effectiveness of the United States Fleet," Rear Admiral Arthur B. Cook, Chief of the Naval Bureau of Aeronautics, testified today before the House Committee on Naval Affairs.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Stanley of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Talcott Stanley, to John Deming Stout Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Stout of Hartford. Miss Stanley attended the Ethel Walker School in Simsbury, Conn.,

Mayor La Guardia held the first general press interview of his new term at City Hall yesterday to inform newspaper men that the city would have to cut relief unless it got an additional $12,000,000 from the Legislature.

Representative Hoffman of Michigan criticized President Roosevelt in the House today for "selling" some of the transcripts of his semiweekly press conferences. "Using his Presidential office as his advertising agency-and this without cost to him personally."

The 348th meeting of the American Mathematical Society, Columbia University, Physics Building, 10 A. M., 2 P. M. and 3:15 P. M. Annual luncheon and research symposia of the High School Teachers Association and the High School Principals Association, Hotel Commodore, 10 A. M. and 1 P. M. Speakers at luncheon: Dr. Frederic Ernst, Dr. Livingston Farrand, Henry C. Turner, Dr. George M. Wiley, John E. Wade.

Joseph C. Kauffmann applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to hold the position of general attorney with the Chesapeake Ohio Railway in addition to the same position which he now occupies with the Pere Marquette Railway.

George R. Barse, artist, whose pictures hang in many museums, was found dead on his forty-acre estate here today. He had committed suicide by inhaling monoxide fumes from the engine of his automobile after sealing his garage with rags, according to Medical Examiner Amos O. Squire. Mr. Barse,

Japan claimed today to have struck China's air force a paralyzing blow in a great air battle over the Nanchang airfield in Kiangsi Province. The Chinese, however, disputed the--Japanese version of the battle in which about 100 planes were said to have been engaged simultaneously.

The age-old problem of "what'll we name the baby" is being attacked in practical fashion by the Brooklyn Public Library, which is offering such gems as Aviezer, Cello, Earthline, Heminous, Nervertia, Zipperath and even Ordinary, as names for the prospective future citizens of Kings County.

This country was visibly cheered by Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg's speech last night. The Czech crowd listening intensely to the broadcast in a big cafe enthusiastically cheered the Austrian Chancellor when he had finished. Afterward among the hurrying throngs in windy Wenceslas Square people hailed one another to comment on the "good news" from Vienna.

Leading women in seven countries yesterday discussed over the radio the importance of their sex in national and international affairs and in the promotion of world peace. The occasion was an International Day broadcast under the auspices of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women, carried throughout this country over WJZ and WABC networks, with simultaneous observances in many other countries.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Feb. 25, unless specified: At San Pedro: Lexington, Feb. 24; Teal. Acushnet, naval. operating base, Norfolk, to Yorktown, Feb. 23. Barker, Amoy to Hong Kong, Feb. 24. Bobolink, San Pedro to San Diego. Chaumont, Manila to Guam. Helm, at Colon. Louisville, at Hobart.

President Roosevelt declared his faith in the battleship as the most effective naval weapon despite the menace of the airplane. [Page 1.] Admiral Cook told the House Naval Affairs Committee that warships were still the first line of defense,

Many of the sermons tomorrow will be pre-Lenten discourses in preparation for the forty days of the penitential season. Sermons will also be in preparation for the World Day of Prayer for Missions, which is next Friday. A number of missionaries.

Bond values moved moderately higher over a broad front yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. A buoyant tone prevailed in a few selected groups, notably United States Government obligations, Central European dollar bonds and individual domestic corporate issues.

The Oberman Clothing Manufacturing Company, one of the largest plants of its kind in the country, and closed for three months as a result of a strike, will be reopened, it was announced today by T. O. Oberman, president. Mr. Oberman,
A ticket headed by Governor George H. Earle for Senator and Charles A. Jones of Pittsburgh for Governor, was approved by the Democratic State Committee today for the primary election in May.

Jamaica High broke a deadlock with Brooklyn Tech and gained undisputed possession of first place in the race for the P. S. A. L. hockey championship by blanking the Blue and White skaters, 1 to O, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The lone goal was made by Frank Zigmund.

The hearing scheduled for March 1 before the SEC to determine whether the registration of the 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, $11 par value, and the common stock $100 par value of Missouri Pacific Railway Company on
Pennsylvania's Public Utility Commission has scheduled in New York on March 3 a joint hearing with the Interstate Commerce Commission to consider railroad freight rates for carrying anthracite.
Theodore Murray, Burlington, Vt., and Edward Rogers, Glen Cove, turned in victories in the national amateur pocket billiard championship tournament at the Strand Academy yesterday.
A rally in the second half carried the New York University women's basketball team to a victory over. Wagner yesterday by a score of 20 to 15 in a game played on its own court.
Miss Carol Alessandroni, home club representative, won the Mildred Fish gold medal by defeating Mrs. Jerry Vokral of Philadelphia in a fence-off, 5-4, at the Fencers Club last night.
Tokyo Welcomed General Iwane Matsui, former commander of Japanese forces in the Yangtze Valley, this afternoon with seemly but unexcessive enthusiasm. The triumphal arch,

Gerrit Smith Griswold, publisher of The Daily News of Batavia, died last night at his home here at the age of 79. He had been ill a year. Mr. Griswold, one of the original members of The Associated Press, was one of two partners who had published The Daily News for more than half a century.
The thirteen-acre estate of Miss E. A. Volk on Mount Airy Road, in the town of Cortlandt, Westchester, has been purchased by Dr. Otto Steinbrocker of New York.

Notice has been served on Japan in an emphatic note delivered in Tokyo by Joseph C. Grew, the United States Ambassador, that she will be held responsible by the United States Government for injuries or damage caused to Americans or their interests by the Japanese armed forces in China.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today orders suspending the effectiveness of three registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by the T. I. S. Management Corporation, Jersey City.
D. A. Schulte, Inc., has leased from the plans the corner store in the two-story building to be erected at the southeast corner of Broadway and Seventy-second Street.

Outshot by a deliberate Universtity of Texas law student, Johnny Goodman, national amateur champion, was eliminated from the Houston Country Club's invitation tournament today after a battle that stretched to the second extra hole.

Unanimous agreement that taxes are too high featured a luncheon symposium on the subject yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria, under the auspices of the Consumers Tax Committee of the Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries.

Arthur G. Fisk, former San Francisco postmaster and California politician, died today at the home of a daughter in Pasadena. His death was the third in recent weeks of former San Francisco postmasters who took a prominent part in city and State politics, the others being Harry L. Todd and Charles Fay.
Now it may be seen clearly that, while the difference between Great Britain and Italy is mainly psychological, Britain is separated from Germany by a deep cleavage due to material causes.

Many supper parties were given last night in connection with the annual supper dance for the Little Italy Neighborhood Association of Brooklyn which was held at Sherry's under the auspices of the junior committee of the organization.

The ninety-eighth annual charity ball of the Emerald Association of Brooklyn was held in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night. The ball has long been one of the outstanding Catholic social functions of Brooklyn.

Trading was generally only fair on most classes of traefa meats and prices mostly unchanged. All kosher markets opening slow with lamb lower and other classes about steady as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Business slackened to small proportions in the subdued stock markets here today, but the undertone was firm. Gilt-edge issues were comparatively steady, while a feature among the foreign bonds was a sharp advance in Austrian loans.

As the site for several one-family houses to be erected under the Federal Housing Administration plan, a plot 240 by 100 feet on the north side of East Seventh Street, between Guider Avenue and Avenue Z, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Stadberg Realty Corporation to Abraham Benenson. It is assessed at $11,000 and was sold for cash through Meller Shalita, Inc., brokers.

C. K. Davis, president of the Remington Arms Company, Inc., of Bridgeport, Conn., said yesterday that "the Remington Arms Company has not manufactured or sold any military rifles to any European country since the World War."

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange developed decided irregularity yesterday, with fluctuations extending over a 10-point range to end at losses of 6 to 10 points. After overcoming an early decline, the list held at around the previous closing quotations, but again yielded in the last hour under active selling operations on the part of the Cooperative Association.
The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Feb. 15 shows that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation rose from 121.08 per cent on Jan. 31 to 122.08 per cent.

Milo G. Miller Jr., attorney, died last night in his home here at the age of 34. He had attended Penn Charter School and Princeton University and was graduated from the University of Pennsylvania Law School in 1931.

President Roosevelt nominated Arthur G. Jaeger of New York today to be United States Marshal for the Eastern New York district. The President also nominated Elwood Hamilton of Kentucky to be a judge of the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals to succeed the late Judge Charles H. Moorman.

Alexander Hamilton High's quintet clinched the Section 1, Brooklyn P. S. A. L., championship yesterday by downing Thomas Jefferson High, 32-28, on the losers' floor. The victory was the tenth in eleven starts for the Scarlet and Gray tossers.

The little Republic of Estonia has just celebrated the twentieth anniversary of its independence. The most significant fact in the independent life of this nation is that it has passed through a period of fascism and has emerged as a democratic republic by the decision of the people, with whom the supreme power now rests.

Operations of the International Business Machines Corporation last year resulted in a net income of $8,082,512 after deducting $737,021 blocked foreign profits and $2,330,000 estimated Federal taxes, including $633,000 surtax on undistributed profits, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Thomas J. Watson, president.

Eleven, including the great rivals Lawrin and Lavengro, have been named for the $20,000 added Flamingo Stakes, Hialeah Park's leading 3-year-old feature, which will be decided tomorrow at a mile and an eighth.

The pulpwood industry was warned yesterday that it faced government regulation and control unless it adopted "reasonable conservation practices," particularly in the South. Addressing the annual convention of the American Pulpwood Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, H. A. Smith, forester for South Carolina, deplored the reputation which, he said, the pulp industry had in the South of "devastation."

A warning that certain provisions of the report of the President's Advisory Committee on Education advocating $855,000,000 in Federal funds for education may be the "entering wedge" to bring about government-controlled school policies was given yesterday by prominent educators here.
Arthur S. Kleeman Co., Ltd., has been named to handle the export marketing of the mine and industrial cars made by the Watt Car and Wheel Company, Barnesville, Ohio.

Investigation of the jury which last Friday acquitted Mary O'Connor in the death of 5-year-old Nancy Glenn was ordered today by the trial judge, Joseph Sloane. He placed the inquiry in the hands of the Ruth legislative investigating committee, which decided upon an investigation yesterday.

Lieut Col. James Roosevelt, the President's son and secretary, left in a marine plane today en route to Cuba to start his first active military training as a Marine Corps Reserve officer. For two weeks the 6-foot, 30-yearold son of the President will undergo the same training ashore and aboard a warship as is required of hundreds of other Reserve officers.

Councilman Michael J. Quill testified in his own behalf before a City Council investigating committee yesterday and declared that he had lived in the Bronx since last April and had used a Manhattan business address only because he could be reached there more readily.

Sales reported by the subsidiary store companies of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation for the fifty-two weeks ended on Jan. 29 increased 5.2 per cent to $58,407,949 from sales of $55,538,612 in the responding period of the previous year.

Herbert Orrin Crisler, newly appointed head football coach at the University of Michigan, attended the dinner given in honor of Dr. James Rowland Angell, former president of Yale University, at the Waldorf-Astoria last night by the University of Michigan Club of New York.

Miss Constance Thayer, daughter of Mrs. Charles M. Thayer of this city and the late Mr. Thayer, was married here this afternoon in All Saints Protestant Episcopal Church to David Cleveland Cory, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Cory of Englewood, N. J., by the Rev. Richard G. Preston.
Sir Eric Phipps, British Ambassador to France, went to the Palais Bourbon yesterday while the foreign policy debate was proceeding and conferred with Premier Camille Chautemps.

The Italian liner Rex, leaving today for Mediterranean ports, will have on board James H. R. Cromwell, on the way to meet his wife, who has been buying Moroccan tiles for their Hawaiian home; Wallace Beery, Luigi Del Gaizo, Thomas W. Lamont, Tito Schipa and J. De Forest Richards.

Wheat made a strong start and a tame finish today. Prices advanced around 11/2 cents a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade here on buying induced by reports of a good foreign demand for domestic hard Winter wheat and firmness in Liverpool, but the market flattened out later and selling developed from houses which had been on the buying side.

West Farms Rd (10-2753), n w s, 51 ft s w of Home St. 150x91; Marber Holding Co, Inc. to Claflin Realty Co, Inc, 475 5th Ave; mtg, $55,000. Bronx Park South (11-3129). s s, 194 ft w of Vyse Ave, 80x120: Sarah Rotkowitz to 932 Park South Realty Co, Inc; mtg, $80,500. Oxford Ave (13-3409D), e s, 85 ft s of 235th St, 40x100: Howard J. Gibbs, referee. to Loretta Burrough, Montrose, N. Y.

In striking contrast with last Sunday's meeting of the Reichstag, with its single uncontradictable orator, the French Chamber of Deputies began today debating the international situation and no fewer than fourteen speakers addressed the House. These,

Old-timers who remember when William J. Bryan declared that humanity should not be crucified upon a cross of gold must have read with interest the Washington report that Federal and private research men are trying to find new uses for silver.

A revision in Samuel Goldwyn's production staff is under way. The producer announced today the elevation of J. B. L. Lawrence, head of his exploitation department, to Goldwyn's executive staff and the appointment of Al Vaughan as head of publicity. Sam Marx,

A partial text of the statement of Rear Admiral A. B. Cook before the House Naval Affairs Committee today is as follows: Under the present national defense policy, the navy is the first or primary defense, and the shore defenses, including troops and aircraft, are the secondary defense.
The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the "decline in business activity, which had been active during the last quarter of 1937, continued in January, but at a slower rate."

Flying in perfect formation, the six giant United States bombers returning from their record flight to Buenos Aires, arrived over Albrook Field at 3 o'clock this afternoon, completing a non-stop flight Df 2,000 miles that they started at Lima, Peru, at 6 A. M.

An unequivocal statement of Mayor La Guardia's attitude toward recognition of a bona-fide labor organization as collective bargaining agent for the 4,500 employes of the city's Independent subway system, or for employes on a system resulting from unification of all rapid transit lines, will be asked by the' Transport Workers Union at a hearing before the joint legislative committee on public utilities in Albany on Wednesday.

C. J. Devine Co., Inc., purchased yesterday an issue of $4,000,000 of temporary loan notes of Boston on a 1.24 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $52. The notes, dated Feb. 28 and due on Nov. 4, were reoffered on a 1.05 per cent interest basis and reported by the bankers to have been sold in an hour.
The firm of Walter L. Frank has been reorganized and will henceforth be known as Walter L. Frank Management Corporation. Walter L. Frank is president of the corporation and Leo Birnbach is secretary.

Plans for a nation-wide promotional campaign aimed at increasing the sale of gas ranges will be discussed at a special meeting of the domestic gas range division of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers on Monday at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

A large group attended tonight's Tropical Ball at the Palm Beach Biltmore for the children's milk fund of the Salvation Army. Cellophane palms hung with gold and silver coconuts adorned the muleteer grille.

" The Devil Learns to Vote:- The Story of Montana," by Christopher P. Connolly, will be published by Covici early in March. The book treats of such characters as Colonel Broadwater, Henry Plummer, Thomas J. Walsh, Marcus Daly, Senator William A. Clark and other personages well known in Montana history.

After almost two years of wrangling over the reorganization of the $900,000,000 Standard Gas and Electric Company, the various protective committees engaged in formulating a plan to remove the utility from jurisdiction of the courts under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act concurred yesterday in a modified plan, which was presented to the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., by Bernard W. Lynch, president of the company.

James F. Duffy, an attorney, of 2,922 Grand Concourse, died yesterday of a bullet wound received late Thursday night when policemen chased him through Greenwich Village after he left St. Vincent's Hospital, apparently temporarily crazed, and stole a taxicab.

City College, by winning seven of the nine events, completed its dual swimming season with a 53-22 conquest of Brooklyn College last night in the C. C. N. Y. pool. The victory gave the Beavers a record of four triumphs and two defeats..

Miss Jean McCallum Cameron, a niece of Mr. and Mrs. William McCallum Cameron of 465 Park Avenue and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Donald Cameron of Portland, Ore., was married yesterday afternoon in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, to Stephen Hotchkiss Hartshorn.

The marriage of Miss Marie Louise Smith of Charlotte, N. C., formerly of Newark, N. J., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Smith 3d of Newark, to Louis Sutherland Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Leach Allen of New York and Westhampton, L. I.,

The market for new State and municipal bonds will emerge from its recent period of inactivity next week with a total of $108,388,714 in new issues scheduled for sale. They will represent thirty-seven municipalities. This will compare with the revised total of only $6,939,900 in new loans this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $20,929,834.
Dr. Louis C. Schroeder, associate professor of pediatrics at Cornell Medical School and attending pediatrist at New York Hospital, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 56 years old.

Members of the New York Curb Exchange have been requested to appear before that organization's committee on commissions to give their views regarding a possible revision in present rates. The committee, according to a letter sent to members last night, is "considering the possibility of revising the commission rates."

Having shot a wolf, fox and more than a dozen wild boar in Bialowieza Forest as President Ignaz Moscicki's guest, Field Marshal Hermann Goering returned this afternoon to Warsaw where he stayed only a few hours on his way back to Berlin.
ASSISTANT GARDENER-Salary, $5.50 a day; pension; vacation. Vacancies: Occur from time to time; 327 appointments made from last list (entire list). Ages: 21 through 40, on March 16, 1938.

Due largely to reductions in the prices of yellow pine and fir, construction costs in thirty representative cities in the United States showed a slight decline in January, according to the index of the American Appraisal Company.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 23: COMMANDERS Campbell, C., the Hannibal, to San Francisco. Calif., June 11. Clay, A. T., the Argonne, to home, relieved all active duty, April 30. Gunther, E. L., Patrol Wing 3, to the Wasp and in command when commissioned. McCrea, J. L., to duty as assistant to Judge Advocate General, Navy Dept., Washington, D. C.

Bankers who attend the annual Spring savings conference of the American Bankers Association, which is to be held at the Hotel Roosevelt here next Thursday and Friday, will inspect the World's Fair grounds next Saturday morning, it was announced yesterday by Henry S. Sherman, president of the savings division of the association.

Swarthmore College romped to a 41-13 decision over the Haverford quintet on the Little Quaker court tonight in the nineteenth annual game of the series. It was Swarthmore's eleventh straight victory of the season. Ed Jakle paced the Garnet attack with 15 points.

With the work of getting his batterymen and others in condition moving along satisfactorily and nothing new developing in the mystifying case of Clydell Castleman, his convalescing and obdurate right-hander, Colonel Bill Terry today turned his attention upon other matters pertaining to the 1938 pennant chances of his Giants.

Imports of gold in the week ended on Feb. 18 were valued at $1,250,380 compared with $3,131,555 in the previous week, the Department of Commerce announced today. Exports were valued at $55,113 compared with $92,042.

More than 250 couples attended Cal the annual Junior Promenade of Columbia College last night in the Colonades of the Essex House. of Among the faculty guests were the Dean and Mrs. Herbert E. Hawkes, Associate Dean and Mrs. Nicholas McD. McKnight, the Rev. and Mrs.

A Brooklyn Navy Yard delegation appealed to naval authorities today to relieve unemployment there. Accompanies by Senator Wagner, the group urged Assistant Secretary Charles Edison and other officials to allot repair work to the yard, pending delivery of delayed warship building material.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 24 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Seven Americans were among those who received the Carlos Manuel de Cespedes Decoration conferred by decree by President Federico Laredo Bru yesterday according to the usual custom on the national holiday known as "Grito de Baire," according to the list made public today.

Today's major events: "Rheingold," evening, "Aida," afternoon, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Syinphony Youth Concert, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Toscha Seidel, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 3 P. M.; Alexander Brailowsky, pianist, last of Chopin series, Town Hall, afternoon; Gladys Avery, soprano, Town Hall, evening.

As the result of a brisk Grand National play today, the odds on James V. Rank's Cooleen and Lord Mildmay's Davy Jones were reduced to 20 to 1. Cooleen formerly was held at 22 to 1 and Davy Jones at 25 to 1. Bookmakers also reported
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 24:

Following months of study of many warcontrol proposals, the House Military Affairs Committee today reported a bill which would put virtually complete control of all business activity under the President with powers far greater than those President Wilson exercised during the World War.

Wilbert (Dutch) Hiller, brilliant left wing for the New York Rovers in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League, was moved up to the New York Rangers yesterday. Hiller was called in by Manager Lester Patrick to take the place of Butch Keeling,

So long as we must have these musicals-and Mr. Zanuck of Twentieth Century-Fox keeps insisting we must-we suppose they might as well be like "Sally, Irene and Mary" (not related, except by title, to the old Eddie Dowling show),
The moments of the past are loosening Like rotted shingles from the bitter times: The star lights in the wells of heaven fling The glittering Winter's cloven tongues of chimes.

Amid charges that it was setting up a "political pie counter," the Senate voted to itself -today the right to confirm appointments of non-civil service "experts" and lawyers paid $5,000 a year or more by independent government agencies.

A gloomy picture of the effect of the business recession on jobs was sketched today by Robert Hoppock, assistant to the director of the National Occupational Conference, in disclosing the results of a recent survey in ten large industrial cities.

Two of the seeded players were eliminated and John S. Harrison, first-ranking star from the Squash Club, was forced to five sets before he was able to triumph in the metropolitan Class B squash racquets championship at the Yale Club yesterday.
Thomas Wareham Smith, for many years advertising manager of The Daily Mail in London and one of the powers of Fleet Street, died while on a vacation here at the age of 63.

President Manuel Quezon asked the National Assembly today to pass an enabling act permitting development of oil resources in the Philippine Islands. The President asked legislation to permit the Commonwealth to enter a contract with Socony-Vacuum Company or some other American or Philippine oil company.

The perfect "chain of command" was forged via telephone yesterday afternoon from the War Department in Washington to the nine army corps areas in the United States and thence to the corps area staffs when what was probably the largest "telephone conference" that has ever taken place was demonstrated.

Three officers were named by War Department orders today for promotion to the rank of brigadier general. Colonel Roger Brooke, Medical Corps, commanding the Letterman General Hospital, and Lieutenant Colonel Leigh Cole Fairbank, Dental Corps, were promoted in the Medical Corps, in conformity with the January 29, 1938,

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The suggestion by President Roosevelt that the principle of excess condemnation be adopted for the future construction of highways and other public works involving the expropriation of land is no new idea. The method is in general use in Europe.

THE latest novel to be compared to "A Farewell to Arms"-and literary actuaries tell me there have been only 11,703 in the course of the last eight years-is Pamela Hansford Johnson's excellent story, "World's End."* This is (a) a compliment to Miss Johnson, (b) further evidence that Hemingway's novel has become a classic and a standard in our time and (c) pretty thoroughly beside the point.

Six graduate students of the class of February, 1938, and nine undergraduates enrolled as seniors were elected to the City College Gamma chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, national honorary scholastic fraternity.

The prospect that railroads controlled by the Alleghany Corporation and now in reorganization may slip permanently from the control of the group headed by Robert R. Young was brought into the open today by a conflict over the Missouri Pacific.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, replying to an undergraduate protest against his ban last week on a campus speech by Robert Burke, ousted student, declared yesterday in a letter to Columbia College's student board it was imperative that "the good name and repute of Columbia" be protected from publicity "as to ultra-radical and Communist demonstrations."

Charles Edmeston Robertson of the Hotel Suburban, East Orange, N. J., a member of the New York Stock Exchange and war-time Deputy New York State Fuel Administrator, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at the Mountainside Hospital here. His age was 72.

While waiting the decision of the Mexican Supreme Court in their appeal against the finding of the Federal Labor Board, British oil companies in Mexico are treating with reserve reports that which ever way the decision goes they will be "bled by white" by labor.

What life last night's performance of Verdi's "Rigoletto" at the Metropolitan possessed it owed mainly to Jan Kiepura's portrayal of the Duke of Mantua. As long as Mr. Kiepura was on stage there was an animation about the proceedings which at other times was sorely missing.

Major Frederick D. Burpee, president of the Ottawa Electric Railway Company and an expert on electric railways, died here tonight at the age of 61. During the war he was engaged on the British front constructing standard and narrow gauge railways.

Donald C. Barnes, president of the Engineers Public Service Company, which recently registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission as a public utility holding company, announced yesterday that applications have been filed with the Federal Power Commission and the SEC for approval of a plan to consolidate and merge the properties of three subsidiaries. The units are the Gulf States Utilities Company, the Baton Rouge Electric Company and the Louisiana Steam Generating Corporation.

The deputy chiefs of the 2d division and the battalion chiefs of the 5th, 9th and 25th Battalions, are placed under the ThreePlatoon Ten-Group system, effective at 12:01 A. M. March 1. The Three-Platoon Ten-Group System is
An all-day conference on "The Church and War" will be held on Tuesday, beginning at 11 A. M., in the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street.

The 1938 Cuban sugar crop has been limited by Presidential decree to 2,950,000 long Spanish tons, the foodstuffs division of the Department of Commerce reported today. The amount to be exported to the United States was fixed at a maximum of 1,418,174 long Spanish tons, and 500,000 tons will be retained as a reserve for orders to this country.

On its traditional date-the Saturday before Ash Wednesday-the second of the Knickerbocker Assemblies for this season will take place tonight in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The first of the Knickerbockers is held the Saturday after Thanksgiving and the third on the Saturday following Easter Sunday.

Four child violinists were selected from some 2,000 competitors as national winners in the National Federation of Music Clubs contest by a jury consisting of Mrs. Edgar Stillman-Kelley, former national president of the federation;

Manhattan Gramercy Park S, 17. 33.1x113.6. for 6story tenement; George Schor, 239 W 145th St. owner; J. Lewis Mayers, architect; costs, $90,000. Alterations 8th St. 60-62 E. two 1-story stores: trustees of the Sailors Snug Harbor, 202 Greene St, owner; Corbett MacMurray, architects; cost. $12,000.

General John J. Pershing, 77year-old World War commander, waging a desperate battle for life, lost additional ground early today, his physicians announced in a bulletin issued at 1:45 A. M. (3:45 A. M. Eastern Standard time).
Mrs. Katherine Wallace, active in Democratio politics in the Ridgewood section of Queens, died yesterday in her home at 19-38 Woodbine Street, Ridgewood, of a heart attack. Mrs. Wallace,

World C Featherweight Champion Henry Armstrong caught up with Everette (Young) Rightmire of Sioux City, Iowa, in the third round tonight to batter out a technical knockout triumph-the, thirty-third time in his last thirty-four fights in which an Armstrong foe failed to go the distance. The bout was a non-title contest.

Advertising linage will begin to improve definitely in the Fall, the president of one of the large food companies declared yesterday, in discussing the outlook for ad budgets during the balance of the year.
The second annual music confic ence of the New York University School of Education at Washington Square East will be held today in the university auditorium, 41 We Fourth Street.

The Sixth accordance Regiment of United States Marines under Brig. Gen. John C. Beaumont sailed today for Honolulu aboard the navy transport Chaumont. The 1,500 marines recently were ordered withdrawn from Shanghai for an indefinite tour of duty in the Hawaiian Islands.

Mr. and Mrs. Willard Palmer Whitlock Jr. of Elizabeth, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Louise Whitlock, to James Home Harris Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Home Harris, also of Elizabeth.

Viscount Halifax, Lord President of the Council, today became the first peer to receive the vital post of Foreign Secretary since the late Lord Reading held office for a few months in 1931. For a real precedent it is necessary to go back to Lord Curzon who had a stormy time as Foreign Secretary from 1920 to 1924.

The large response last year to the call for young men to be pilots in the Royal Air Force as a result of the government's air defense expension program has been exceeded this year, when the number of vacancies was again larger.

The city received $1.220,197 yesterday from thirteen utility companies in the Consolidated Edison System in settlement of pending litigation over emergency relief taxes. About $624,000 of the payments will go into the special fund for emergency relief purposes and about $596,000 will be turned over to the general fund for budgetary purposes.

Long Island University's five skyrocketed into an 8-2 lead in the first six minutes tonight and then played some alert basketball to defeat an aggressive Wayne University team, 44 to 39, before 4000 spectators.

Harry L. Barck, hard-bitten overseer of Hoboken's poor for forty-two years, was stabbed and killed with a desk spike today in his City Hall office. a According to Police Chief Edward J. McFeely, Mr. Barck was the victim of an unemployed man, who had gone to him seeking relief.
Mayor La Guardia went to South Ferry yesterday at noon to accept a painting which had been presented to the city for display on the new ferryboat Mary Murray.

Governor Lehman today signed the Budget Bill authorizing appropriations of $46,000,000 for unemployment relief in the State for the fiscal year starting July 1, 1938. The sum will be granted to the Social Welfare Department from the $386,364, 515 State budget for the year 1938-39.

Consideration of the Interior Department's 1939 supply bill began in the House today and passage is expected Monday. The bill carries $124,990,730 or $7,947,557 less than the appropriation for the current year and $2,490,535 less than budget estimates.

Two leaflets, alighting by chance on the same desk, have a story to tell of America's evolution from pioneer times to these latter days. One is "Connecticut Woodlands," a publication of the Connecticut Forest and Park Association. The other deals with the "Death Valley National Monument" and is gotten out by the National Park Service.

President Kemal Ataturk moved today to make Turkey stronger in the Eastern Mediterranean when he approved an extensive five-year rearmament plan. The program will hasten completion of four submarines in Turkish shipyards and provide a
The first dribble of 1937 income tax payments encouraged Treasury officials today in their hopes of collecting from $725,000,000 to $750,000,000 next month.

Seattle's primary election for Mayor might be cited by the C. I. O. in reply to charges that it is a Communist organization. The C. I. 0. candidate in the primary was Lieutenant Governor Meyers, who used to be leader of a jazz band.
A payment of nearly $300,000, or about 11 per cent of the face value of the entire issue, will be made to holders of Series Q-1 certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company on Feb. 28.

ELYSIAN FIELDS, by Salvador de Madariaga. (Oxford University Press, $1.) Imaginary converstations on present events by Goethe, Voltaire, Napoleon and others. POLITICAL INSTITUTIONS, by Edward McChesney Sait. (Appleton-Century, $4.50.) A study of their history and environment.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The downward trend of wool values has been halted by the belief that the government, through the Commodity Credit Corporation, is to make substantial loans to the wool producers on both the 1937 and 1938 wools.

Administration forces, brushing 3 aside protests from a bipartisan a opposition group, pushed through the Senate today an appropriation to start construction of a $112,000,000 TVA dam at Gilbertsville, Ky. The chamber then approved other amendments to the $1,400,000,000

Walter C. Gale, organist, composer and music teacher, died yesterday at the home of his sister, Mrs. A. D. Rockwell, 19 Brookside Drive, Greenwich, Conn., after an illness of more than a year. He was 66 years old.

2d Ave, 77-79; 6-story tenement; Flagor Realty Corp against Norman Winston; due, $18,000; subject to mtg of $66,000; to plaintiff for $1,000. By DANIEL GREENWALD Mulberry St, 215; 5-story tenement: Annie M. Verry against Triros Realty Co; due, $13,566; to plaintiff for S500.

Max Rosen, violinist, was heard in recital last night at Carnegie Hall before a large audience. He played the Cesar Franck Sonata, the Dvorak A minor concerto, the Bach chaconne and smaller pieces by Tartini-Kreisler, Joseph Achron and Sarasate. Harry Kaufman was the accompanist.

Merrill N. Davis of Bradford, Pa., Dartmouth football captain during the past season, retained his college heavyweight boxing championship ci for the third successive year tonight as he defeated Joe Armanini of Santa Cruz. Calif.,

Although more than eight months have passed since the Board of Estimate created a revolving fund of $500,000 to finance the required repairs to old tenements under the Multiple Dwelling Law, comparitively few buildings have been improved thus far under this arrangement.

Farmers who comply with the new crop-control program this year will receive a government subsidy of 2.4 cents a pound on their cotton and 12 cents a bushel on their wheat, officials of the Department of Agriculture decided tentatively today. Payments for tobacco may range
Temple's Eastern Conference championship basketball team tonight turned the tables on the only league team to beat it this season, giving Georgetown a 51-to-34 defeat.

The ranks of Yankee hold-outs thinned to a stubborn seven yesterday when Joe Glenn, understudy for Bill Dickey, sent in his signed contract. Ernie Koy, recruit outfielder who has been brought back from Oakland, and Warren Rosar, rookie catcher from Newark, also signed, it was announced by Business Manager Ed Barrow.

The Cabinet's difficulties over the National Mobilization Bill were relived when the parties agreed to close interpellations last night and seek amendments in the committee stage, which will begin immediately. The government promised to be better prepared in committee than it was in the House of Representatives.

Export copper prices declined sharply yesterday. Around midday sales were reported as low as 9.97 cents a pound c.i.f. the European base ports, but later they recovered to around 10.075 cents. Late Thursday, sales of the metal were made at 10.30 cents. In the domestic market, the price was unchanged at 10 cents.

Those who have studied the new constitution that probably will be submitted to members of the New York Stock Exchange on next Thursday see every indication in that document that the trading body probably will be without a president during the first month or so of its operation under the document.

Theodore Zelinski, a deputy to John Ferguson, Superintendent of Elections in Hudson County, testified here today before the Assembly committee investigating the last Gubernatorial election in Hudson County, that he had been struck in the face by City Commissioner William McGovern of Jersey City when he protested election procedures in the First District of the First Ward of Jersey City.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted a new regulation to cover exemption from registration under the Securities Act of 1933 of offerings of $100,000 or less of certificates of interest or participation in oil-royalty and similar types of trusts.

Ancient Elmwood Music Hall, one of upState New York's historic convention halls, was locked and barred today, a few hours before a college basketball game, when engineers discovered that the roof was weak.

For the fourth consecutive year, Robin Lee, 18-year-old skater from Chicago, captured the men's national figure-skating championship today. In marked contrast to his triumph of 1937, when he hobbled from the rink after competing with an injured knee,

HE is an old-time theatrical manager, and he sat in an office lined with pictures of old-time stars. He puffed a cloud of smoke from a cigar he could no longer really afford, looked out of a window into the Times Square maelstrom and said:
Tiny Rose Island may replace Pago Pago, American Samoa, as central base station when Pan American Airways resumes Honolulu-Auckland Clipper flights, observers here said today.

Ranging up on the leader at the turn for home, Lawrin, from the Woolford Farm of Herbert Woolf, today drove through Hialeah Park's stretch to the cheers of 20,000 persons as he thrust himself into the forefront of the 3-year-old situation for 1938.

Miss Catherine Reed Loizeaux, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Gilmore Loizeaux of this city, was married here this afternoon to Richard Collins Marder, son of Mrs. Walter S. Marder, also of Plainfield, and the late Mr. Marder, at the Monday Afternoon Club. The Rev. Ralph Carr, pastor of the Hydewood Park Baptist Church, North Plainfield, performed the ceremony.

A fighting Squadron A trio, staving off their opponents' brilliant last-half rally, defeated the New York Athletic Club combination, 17 to 15, in a Metropolitan Indoor Polo League game which featured the weekly program at the Squadron A Armory last night. The clubmen allotted their opponents seven goals by handicap.
Five steamship companies operating in the coastal trades have formed an association to meet their common problems with representative action, it was learned yesterday.

According to a report just received from the Yonkers Federation of Rod and Gun Clubs, there is some idea of uniting this group with the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, with nothing definite accomplished as yet toward the consolidation.

The Yankee vanguard-one regular pitcher, a rookie and a batting practice hurler-left from Penn Station yesterday for the champions' St. Petersburg (Fla.) training camp on the road to what the team's supporters expect will be another American League pennant and, perhaps, another smashing world series triumph.

Miss Nancy Montgomery Dallam, daughter of Mrs. Charles S. Townsend of Bryn Mawr and the late D. English Dallam Jr., was married this afternoon to Charles Sinkler 2d, son of Mrs. S. Deas Sinkler of Ithan and the late Mr. Sinkler.

Miss Jean Tegder, eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Carl Tegder of this city, was married here this afternoon to Alpheus Crosby Beane Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., son of Mrs. Marion B. Beane and the late A. C. Beane. The ceremony, which took place at the home of the bride's parents, was performed by the Rev. Dr. Lindsay McNair.
NEW ways of putting designs on fabrics offer the homemaker a wide range of effects in an important medium of decoration.
Evergreen Farms maintained un disputed possession of first place in the Senior Metropolitan Indoo: Polo League by trouncing Squadrol C, 18--10, at the latter's armory ii Brooklyn last night.

With the selection of students of Georgian Court College to serve as models and committee members, plans have been completed for the fourth annual bridge tea and fashion show, to be held March. 12 in Newark, for the benefit of the institution's endowment fund.
