The opinions or assertions contained herein are the private ones of the writer and are not to be construed as official or reflecting the views of the Navy Department or the naval service at large.
By decree of the Supreme Court the mortgage moratorium, now in its sixth year, is invalid and the emergency declared by the State Legislature as its justification is at an end.

The seizure of an illegal still and the arrest of five men near Marlboro in Ulster County -was announced yesterday by W. E. Dunnigan, in charge of the enforcement division of the Alcohol Tax Unit of the United States Bureau ot Internal Revenue.
A PLACE where collegiate, past and present, are wont to give evidence that they never really graduate is the history-fragrant German American Rathskeller, at Third Avenue and Seventeenth Street.

" THE PLOUGH AND THE SWORD" is the direct descendant of an already long line of undistinguished ancestors. "Impartiality,' in the sense of pretending not to have social values, has been impossible," writes Dr. Schmidt, an instructor at Columbia College.
HERE is a mystery story that has many unusual features. The body of a young girl is found in a snowdrift on Fifth Avenue and the autopsy indicates that she has died from a heart stroke.

Photographs illustrating the activities of the 116 institutions affiliated with the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities will be on view today from 2 to 6 P. M. at the Jacques Seligmann Galleries, 3 East Fiftyfirst Street. The exhibition will continue tomorrow and Tuesday from noon to 6 P. M.
The semi-annual robbery at H. P. Davis's haberdashery store was a bit early this year. Usually the robberies, which have been going on for ten years, come around Easter and Thanksgiving.

After he had signed a waiver of extradition, Kenneth C. Meirdiercks, 37 years old, who described himself as a salesman of 95 North Ridgewood Road, South Orange, N. J., was turned over to New Jersey authorities yesterday for questioning in connection with a charge of defrauding an East Orange woman of $5,000.

To Francis G. Benedict of the nutrition laboratory of the Carnegie Institution of Washington a human being, any animal, in fact, is a living power plant. Food is its fuel. But unlike a power plant the living body converts some of the fuel into muscle and fat and some into heat and mechanical energy. Metabolism is the scientific name for the process.

THE British Broadcasting Corporation having opened its new series "America Speaks," with Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of Interior, denouncing fascism and communism, has announced a list of other Americans, who by short wave will enable England "to get in touch with America."

liams defeated the Hamilton College sextet tonight, 3 to 1, after being held scoreless for almost two periods. Jay of Williams tallied first with less than two minutes left in the second frame. In the last, Young scored after twenty seconds of play from a mix-up in front of the cage.

Members of the committee in charge of the Knickerbocker Assemblies made up the receiving line at the second of these events for the season held last night in the grand ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. They included Mrs. Frederick W. Longfellow, chairman; Mrs. J.

An account of the part he played in the famous Dreyfus case has been written by Philippe Bunau-Varilla, noted engineer. He was concerned in the publication in the Matin of the "bordeteau," supposed proof of the guilt of Captain Alfred Dreyf us, which finally led to the proof of his innocence.

Captain Alvah Sulloway's exciting four-game victory over Bernie Ridder in the No. 1 match, broke a 2-2 tie and gave the Harvard varsity squash racquets team a 3-2 triumph over Princeton today at the university squash courts.
Scoring once in each period, the St. Francis Prep hockey team defeated New Utrecht, 3 to 0, yesterday at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

The Rangers and Toronto Maple Leafs put on a wild National Hockey League game tonight with the New Yorkers earning a 4-to-2 victory after establishing a three-goal lead in the first two periods. Eighteen penalties marked the duel.
West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company first-mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1952 have been admitted to the New York Stock Exchange list.
The job of deepening the cellar under an old house was completed today-with the aid of a pile of buried gold-but it was a task too well done, the contractor decided.

A man tentatively identified through papers in his pockets as Louis Fisher, 45 years old, a war veteran, of 88-35 Elmhurst Avenue, Elmhurst, L. I., fell or jumped off the Washington Bridge over the Harlem River at 181st Street at 10:15 P. M. yesterday.

The annual Senior Ball of New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance at Washington Square East was held last night at the Hotel Pierre. More than 200 couples attended the annual supper-dance affair.

The country is in the grip of what Administration spokesmen have described as a recession. The problems of unemployment and relief once more are becoming acute. Yet there has been no apparent resurgence of the depression-born cults of economic optimists;

Victor over Wales and Ireland, Scotland now needs only 1 point to capture the international rugby championship. The Scots followed their 8-6 triumph over Wales earlier in the month by trouncing Ireland, 23-14, at Murrayfield today to forge ahead and can take the title by drawing with England at Twickenham, March 19.

Dr. and Mrs. Luther Holden Kice of Garden City have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Janith Stewart Kice, to Dr. Raymond Francis Smith, also of Garden City. Dr. Smith is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Smith of Mineola.
BAUMIAN-RECHTIMIAN-Mr. and Mrs. David Rechtman announce the engagement of their daughter, Bernice, to Arnold Bauman, son of Mrs. Betty Bauman and the late William Bauman.
The Boston Olympics, defending champions in the National A. A. U. hockey championship, qualified for the second round tonight by overwhelming the Cochituate Hockey Club, 11-2, at the Arena.
Every one interested in the railroad problem is indebted to you for the space you have given to this subject. It is curious that in all the plans set forth the real investor is wholly forgotten.

A State-wide conference on New Jersey's parole system will be held tomorrow at the First Congregational Church, Montclair, under the auspices of the legal status department of the New Jersey League of Women Voters. Mrs. Leonard H. Robbins of Montclair, State president, will preside.

Gone is the freshman dink at Lehigh University, and with it most of the rules affecting freshman behavior. In their place next Fall will be a sedate appearing brown hat ahd almost Utopian freedom from requirements imposed by a sophomore vigilante committee.

Brig. General George C. Marshall, commandant at Vancouver Barracks, left here for Washington, D. C., by plane today following an order received by radio from General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff, to report for special duty.

A memorial meeting for Professor George Meason Whicher, former head of the Latin and Greek department at Hunter College, has been planned for Thursday night in the Hunter College Auditorium, Sixty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue, Professor E. Adelaide Hahn, head of the Latin and Greek Department and chairman of the meeting, announced yesterday.

The legislative committee of the Citizens Union announced yesterday approval of the Murray-Carroll and Middleton bills to amend the city home rule law. At present the law provides that no local law shall supersede any act of the Legislature relating to the property; affairs and government of cities passed on emergency message from the Governor.

Old-fashioned plants are advocated as part of the decorative setting for old-fashioned furniture. Doubtless the waxplant (Hoya carnosa) will be one of those with which indoor gardeners will become again familiar.

Five graduate students who were selected for this first experimental year in the course in Personnel Administration at Radcliffe College will devote the remainder of their college year to field work, thus rounding out the practical experience which they had gained in their shorter periods of field work last Summer and Fall The course began last July, to for eleven months.

Europe today is like a runaway train gathering speed. The political landscape changes so fast that to helpless and frightened passengers it seems as if history itself had gone multiple-motored, streamlined and non-stop, as bent as modern science on killing time and erasing space.
Wisconsin telephone subscribers, represented by the State Public Service Commission, lost a long battle for rate reductions today when Circuit Judge A. C. Hoppmann vacated orders by the commission.

To the Drama Editor: I have just received a press cutting from THE NEW YORK TMIES of Jan. 23 in which it is suggested that, apropos of the banning of my play, "Mr. Gladstone," my "irritation emerges in the preface to the published play."
Barbara Stanwyck, film actress, told police today that $9,365 worth of jewelry was taken from her suburban home while two servants slept.

Canada's exports in the ten months ended with January were valued at $935,853,799, against $898,063,781 in the same period of the preceding fiscal year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics has reported. This was an increase of 4.2 per cent.

The announcement last week that the House Ways and Means Committee will soon consider the Payne-Boylan bill to place a special tax on radio broadcasting stations in effect raises the entire question of what the relationship of Government should be to radio broadcasting.

The War Departmerlt released the following orders today, dated Feb. 25: MAJOR GENERAL Lynch, G. A., Chief of Infantry, 8 days' leave, March 6. BRIGADIER GENERAL Brant, G. C. (Colonel), Air Corps, one month leave, March 1.
Almost unnoticed in a fortnight of fundamental European changes King Carol has established himself as dictator of Rumania, relying on the army's support.

THE first performance ever given of Dvorak's first opera, "Alfred," took the shape of a broadcast from Prague on Feb. 6. The work was done in an abbreviated form, with the choruses and ballet music omitted, yet sufficient remained to furnish a good idea of the score. It is not a score which deserves the oblivion that has been its share till now.

Operating deficits in January have been shown by several of the thirtyone railroads that so far have reported their earnings for that month. Among those showing deficits were the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe, the Boston Maine, the Chicago North Western, the Northern Pacific, the Wabash and the Western Pacific.

Sir Charles Vyner Brooke, white Rajah of Sarawak, said today he had restored to his daughter, the Princess Baba, the $3,000 annual allowance he stopped when she married the wrestler, Bob Gregory, last November.
A cadet wag of 1898 gave General John J. Pershing the nickname "Black Jack," which stuck to him through his army career. A friend said today that the general often chuckled over the incident.
White Cockade, packing the light impost of 106 pounds, led a field of eleven sprinters in the $2,000 added Rex Handicap at the Fair Grounds today to win in the good time of 1:11 3/5 for six furlongs.

Several residents of New York and its near-by communities are on the list of patrons and patronesses for a dance concert to be held here on March 11 at the Peabody Playhouse under the auspices of the Boston alumnae of Marot Junior College and the Howe-Marot School of Thompson, Conn.
MR. LARSSON'S first novel. "Our Daily Bread," was full of interest and promise, and that is just what one must say of his second.
A new process for the preservation, moth-proofing and protection of fabrics has been developed by William E. Wilson, research director of the Allied Textiles Research Society.

Degrees and certificates were voted by the Board of Higher Education to 561 students at City College who have completed their undergraduate and graduate work at the college as of Feb. 1, 1938, according to an announcement issued by the day session office.

THERE has been new and modern music on the programs of every great orchestra this season. More Stravinsky and Shostakovich, more Sibelius, Kodaly, Ravel and Prokofieff, and some new Americans whose names we have never heard before.

During the last three months 355 of the 2,500 students registered in the women's trade and technical classes of the WPA adult education program of the New York City Board of Education have found employment as a result of their retraining.

Out of the chaos in our present world problems I have been trying for some time to discover from various discussions, debates and editorials the basis for a possible agreement among intelligent persons in certain general principles which by proper emphasis might help to guide us toward some practical objective. I suggest the following:

Major Gen. James E. Fechet, formerly chief of the United States Army Air Corps, studied airplane crashes statistically and discovered that less than 5' per cent can be attributed to mechanical failure.
A new field station of the School of Chemical Engineering Practice of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology will be opened in the near future at Parlin, N. J.

In a supplemental brief on the proposed Anglo - American trade treaty filed yesterday with the Committee for Reciprocity Information, the National Foreign Trade Council again attacked the British system of classifying certain American

THE guitars are going full tilt in Mexico. The country enters its fiesta season elated by prospects of a record tourist influx. Between now and April 1 more than a hundred tours to Mexico by rail, boat and bus will be conducted from the United States.

It is hardly conceivable that either the Treasury experts or the members of the House subcommittee on taxation could feel any real sense of complacency in respect to their recommendations for the revision of the revenue laws. And this impresses one as being particularly so in respect to taxes sought to be imposed on corporations.
THE new Heinkel fighter, armed with two wing cannon, two rapid-fire machine guns and six bombs, may be one of the reasons Germany is reported to be slow in the development of artillery.

The current dean's list of honor students at Stevens Institute of Technology, announced by Dean Franklin DeRonde Furman, includes names of sixty-four students whose work was "consistently excellent during the first term of the college year."

Singapore Island, suddenly precipitated on the international political and military stage by the formal opening of the naval base, is one of man's last Gardens of Eden in this troubled world, and well do the residents, white, yellow and brown, realize the fact.

While the seasonal upswing in paper, with the exception of newsprint, started to take place last week, manufacturers predicted that it would be below the normal rise. Current manufacturing operations are at 65 to 70 per cent of capacity, as against 90 per cent a year ago, it was said.

Miss Mona Lombard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Lombard of Port Huron, Mich., was married to Dr. Joseph Y. Roberts, son of Dr. and Mrs. William A. Roberts of this city, yesterday afternoon at the Bedford Park Presbyterian Church, the Bronx. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. George Mair.

ALTHOUGH S. N. Behrman fritters away most of "Wine of Choice" on a parcel of Long Island gadabouts he has something positive to say about liberalism in one or two brief moment scenes. His liberal is Ryder.

By an overwhelming vote, in which the extreme Left joined, the French Chamber of Deputies last night upheld the government's foreign policy. Yvon Delbos, Foreign Minister, gave assurance that France would fulfill her obligations to Czechoslovakia and warned that any hegemony in the Danube Valley "was not possible."

Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma, after conferring today with the Social Security Board, announced that his State probably would be cut off from further Federal grants for assistance to the aged and the blind and to dependent children under the Social Security Act until it reformed its State administrative agency and acceded to the terms of the board.

The substitution of patriotism for politics and a reversion to a government of the people instead of the "government of men" we now have was urged yesterday by former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley at the forty-ninth annual luncheon of the Woman's Press Club of New York in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Laura E. Richards, a grand old lady of New England literature, will celebrate her eighty-eighth birthday here tomorrow. With the members of her family about her, she will receive a few guests at afternoon tea.

COMPACTNESS and comfort are two of the chief aims of the small Colonial cottage which is one of two model homes to be erected soon in the 113th Regiment Armory, Newark, N. J., as a feature of the third annual New Jersey National Home Show, March 19 to 26.

What promises to become the greatest series of battles since those culminating in the capture of Nanking last December are developing in Southern Shansi Province, where by quick thrusts the Japanese Army has placed the Chinese force of nearly 250,000 men in grave jeopardy.
THE strange ways of time being the latest subject for great thinkers north of Thirty-ninth Street, consider Sam H. Grisman. There were Mr. Grisman and others with a play he thought was "important."

The wedding of Miss Jean Kolbe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Kolbe of this city, to Charles Latimer Berry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Berry, also of New Rochelle, took place this evening in Trinity Episcopal Church.

A dinner dance under the auspices of the flag committee of the Society of Mayflower Descendants, comprising younger members of the organization, will take place Friday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Many dinners will be given in conjunction with the event.

With final decision of the constitutional status of the Public UtilIty Holding Company Act of 1935 believed near, the $14,000,000,000 public-utility industry finds itself facing a new era of regulation which is expected to cover virtually every phase of its corporate and even its physical activity.
A material increase in savings invested in the Federal Savings and Loan Associations of the country during 1937 over the previous year is reported by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

Preliminary results of a poll conducted in England by the British Institute of Publio Opinion, affiliate of the American Institute, show that Prime Minister Chamberlain's proposed foreign policy is opposed by a majority of English voters.

The following foreign service changes, since Feb. 11, vere announced by the State Department today: E. Allan Lightner of Mountain Lakes, N. J., vice consul at Buenos Aires. assigned as vice consul and third secretary of legation at Riga, Latvia.

Mrs. T. Channing Moore, delegate to the constitutional convention, will speak on the electorate's duty to a delegate at a forum on the convention Friday at 8 P. M., sponsored by the Ninth District of the State Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs. The meeting will be held in the Davis High School, Gramatan Avenue, Mount Vernon.

Trailing by seven points early in the first half, Columbia's basketball team rallied to take the lead midway in the period and held the advantage for the rest of the game to gain a merited victory over Dartmouth by 48-37 in an Eastern intercollegiate contest at the Morningside gymnasium last night.

To aid taxpayers in preparing income tax returns, deputy collectors and agents will be stationed in buildings in various parts of Manhattan by the Collectors of Internal Revenue of the Second and Third New York Districts, embracing the boroughs, for periods from Tuesday to March 15 and March 8 to 15.

AERONAUTICAL experts who have had the thrill of watching those courageous test pilots J. Lankester Parker and H. L. Piper "unhook" the two component parts of the Mayo composite aircraft in midair are convinced that a step forward has been made in the technique of high-speed long-distance flying.

Daniel W. Tierney, banker, former New Rochelle Commissioner of Public Works and a large holder of real estate here, died today in his home at 124 Center Avenue after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

Execution with benefit of clergy is now the normal thing in this capital of so-called "Red" Spain, despite the fact that the churches remain closed and Catholic religious services are still held only in private.
E. P. Feeley, with 97 out of 100, led in a field of twenty at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. The score was excellent, considering the handicap provided by a high wind.

Replying to the criticism of Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. of the high automobile liability rate in New York City, William Leslie, general manager of the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters, said yesterday that the magistrate's "technical grasp of insurance rate making left something to be desired."

The government will soon improve the channel of the San Juan del Norte River, one of the most important sections of the proposed interoceanic canal. General Camilo Gonzalez, Under-Secretary of Public Works and former Director General of Communications, will supervise the work.

Theodore Kaufmann, a founder and former president of the Kaufmann Baer department store in Pittsburgh, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack which overcame him while he was walking along Sixtieth Street, east of Park Avenue. His age was 68.

UNDERLYING reasons for America's bad automobile accident record in 1937 were "too much speed and too little courtesy," according to a booklet, "Death Begins at 40," just issued by the Travelers Insurance Company.

An attack upon the accident problem from the angle of a new approach to motor vehicle operators' examinations is outlined in the following article, the author of which was formerly Motor Vehicle Commissioner of Connecticut and is now Research Professor in Transportation at Yale University.
Dr. Richard Archbold, research associate of the American Museum of Natural History, landed his new $250,000 flying boat here today after a non-stop shakedown cruise from San Diego, Calif.

Miss Nancy Norton, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George P. Norton, was married today to John Conynham Stevens Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Conynham Stevens of Jenkintown, Pa., in Christ Church by the Rev. Dr. A. Vincent Bennett.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Mary Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence K. Stone of Ossining to Carl Wynne Pilat, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Pilat, also of Ossining, took place this afternoon at St. Mary's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Dr. Charles W. Baldwin, the rector, performed the ceremony.

Defense lawyers and prosecutors wrangled today as Donald A. Campbell and John E. McGee, labor leaders charged with extortion, called six witnesses to the stand in an effort to show that they did not call workmen off a job at the Stouffer Restaurant, as the .State charges, in an attempt to collect $1,200.

Students at the University of Rochester are using a Wise old tomcat as a psychology textbook these days in an effort to determine whether the psychological processes of a cat are comparable to those of the human.

A trade paper for grave diggers was discovered in Norway by W. Alvin Schaffner of H. N. Elterich, Inc., in studying the advertising scene there, he reported last week to the home office of the agency here.

Pensioned On his own application. To take effect 12 midnight, Feb. 28: INSPECTOR-Joseph P. Loonam, 8th Division, at $2,950 per annum. Appointed Dec. 1, 1896. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., March 1: LIEUTENANTS - Michael J. Boyle, from 6th Division to 78th Precinct, designated as acting captain. Assignment to duty as Supervisor of plain clothes patrolmen discontinued.

The month now drawing to its close marks the sixth since the present "recession" began. Although we have come rather to expect the government to take the lead at such a time, the past halfyear has been notable both for the relative absence of government measures designed to bring about recovery and for the unimportance, from the recovery point of view, of those steps that have been taken.

The National Bureau of Standards has a new mechanical baby of such delicate parts that it will not behave satisfactorily unless there is a complete absence of drafts, according to the Department of Commerce.

Plans for an active campaign for a residential construction program in the Bronx will be formulated at a meeting Thursday afternoon of the Bronx Better Housing Committee at the Bronx Board of Trade, 349 East 149th Street, Roderick Stephens, chairman of the committee and president of the board, announced yesterday. Julian M. Gerard, assistant to the Federal Housing Administrator, will be the principal speaker.

Bernhard K. Schaefer, a member of the board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and president of the Colormbian-American Chamber of Commerce, will deliver a lecture on coffee at a meeting to be held under the auspices of the Commodity Club of New York in the New York State Chamber of Commerce Building on Thursday, it was announced yesterday.
In the Boeing and Douglas factories new giants of air travel are nearing the moment of trying their wings aloft. The lanes they will take from coast to coast will be very much "upstairs."

The formation of Austria's first part-Nazi government and the legalization within limits of Nazi political activities enable one to form an idea of the movement's development during its four years of suppression.
THE Teton-Jackson Hole country in Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming, already known as a mountaineering and dude ranch center, is to be a Winter-sports region.

Fifty Girl Scouts and Brownies will hold a house-warming tea today in the new post house made available for the unit on Governors Island. The new meeting place is a five-room house, completely equipped, where the members will follow the home practice activities prescribed in the program.

Bail of $100,000 each was set yesterday by United States Commissioner Isaac Platt for Peter (Cowboy) Colavecchio, reputed ringleader of a gang of bank robbers, and for his alleged accomplice, Guido D'Allesandro, who were arrested Thursday by Department of Justice agents.

The Ridgewood Country Club in New Jersey, scene of the last Ryder Cup matches played in America and home club of George Jacobus, president of the P. G. A., has been and awarded the metropolitan amateur championship for the year, according to an announcement by the M. G. A., yesterday.

Miss Ruth Helen Marschalk, daughter of Mrs. Katherine Schnaufer Marschalk of this place and of Harry C. Marschalk of New York and Stamford, Conn., was married here tonight in the First Presbyterian Church to Dr. Emil Edward Napp of New York. The Rev. Robert C. Whitehead of Mount Vernon performed the ceremony.

An agreement between Italy and Great Britain, in Italian opinion, will open a new chapter in European post-war history only if it is made the starting point for the conclusion of a wider agreement embracing all the principal European powers or of what,

American sportsmen paid $10,466,237.37 for State hunting licenses and $603,623 for Federal migratory bird hunting stamps in 1936, according to figures published today by the Department of Agriculture. The total for 1937 has not been compiled, but the 1936 figures were said to have exceeded those for 1935 by almost $1,000,000.

The body of a man who committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting himself in the head in a third-floor washroom of a building at 152 Madison Avenue was identified at the morgue last night as that of Martin J. Pizer, 42 years old, a salesman, of 245 East Seventy-second Street.

PARISIAN beauty treatment has been prescribed for Ottawa, small but charming capital of the northern half of this North American continent. A French architect laid out Washington. Another has just secured Federal approval of his plan for the development of this sister seat of government.

PROBABLY we shall have. in the next few years, a good many novels about the civil war in Spain. "The Painted Bed" by Helen Nicholson-in private life Baroness de Zglinitzki-is one of the first. One is willing to venture that it will remain one of the strangest and most beautiful. In no ordinary sense is this a political novel.

New York City will borrow approximately $100,000,000 on longterm obligations in the current year, including the $43,000,000 of serial bonds to be sold to the public and $10,000,000 to the city sinking funds on Tuesday; Joseph D. McGoldrick, Controller, said yesterday in commenting on the city's debt situation.

Joseph Scutellaro, 36-year-old jobless mason, accused of stabbing to death Harry L. Barck, overseer of the poor, with a spike-file in the latter's office yesterday during a dispute over relief, will plead selfdefense or temporary insanity, it was indicated by his relatives following a preliminary hearing in Police Court today, at which Scutellaro was held without bail on a charge of murder to await action by the Hudson County grand jury.

Morosely silent all during his arraignment, Charles Frankel, 1,841 Marion Avenue, the Bronx, was held without bail yesterday for further examination on March 7 in Felony Court in the attack on John C. Abbott, efficiency engineer, in the Public Library at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue Friday evening.

William Buch, a retired clerk of the New York Postoffice, who sold more than $250,000 worth of War Savings Stamps in 1918, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home, 1,203 Frisco Avenue, Far Rockaway, after a long illness. He was born In Greenwich Village, Mlanhattan, 69 years ago.

Annual corporate communion of the Carroll Club at St. Patrick's Cathedral at 9 A. M. to be followed by breakfast at Hotel Biltmore, 10:30 A. M., at which speakeres will be: Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Rev. Robert I. Gannon, Anne Sarachon Hooley, James Stephens, Marquesa de Cienguegos, Mrs. William J. Baington Macaulay.
The Supreme Court may rule Monday on the Electric Bond and Share Company's challenge of the constitutionality of the 1935 act regulating public utility holding companies.
A stirring last-period rally just fell short of enabling the Yale hockey team to overtake the Harvard sextet in a combined Quadrangular League and International Intercollegiate League battle tonight.

THERE is the screaming of steel on ice, lost instantly in the excited yelp of the spectators. One of the defenders, skating back to check an enemy attack, has poked the black rubber puck loose, dug his skates instinctively into the ice, turned, leaped high over the stick of his opponent and, in the time it takes to draw a breath, lashed out on the attack himself.

Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., had his introduction to indoor championship play yesterday as the national tennis tournament started on the board courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Coming from far behind in the final game, Rowland B. Haines yesterday won the national veterans' squash tennis title for the second straight year by defeating Lester A. Strasser of the City Athletic Club on the Princeton Club courts. The scores were 15-6, 9-15 and 18-14.

A set of principles which it believes should govern the setting up of State banking boards has been drawn up by the research council of the American Bankers Association on the basis of a study of such boards in the thirty-one States which have boards, it was announced yesterday.
Special relief for American intercoastal shipping was discussed with President Roosevelt by Senator McAdoo today.

FROM U-BOAT TO PULPIT. By Martin Niemoeller. Translated by Commander D. Hastie Smith. With an Appendix, FROM PULPIT TO PRISON, by Henry Smith Leiper. Illustrated. 223 pp. Chicago: Willett, Clark Co. $2.

Georges Dorio, assistant dean of Harvard Business School, said today that it was "childish and ridiculous to believe that France is not run by a small minority of organized 'gangsters taking orders from Amsterdam and Moscow."
SAMUEL GOLDWYN'S announced decision to make pictures exclusively in color has set a final seal upon Hollywood's acceptance of the newly perfected Technicolor process.

Organizations aided with funds supplied by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee assisted 7,953 persons to emigrate from Germany during 1937, according to a report received here and announced yesterday by the committee, which assists with funds the Central Organization of Jews in Germany..
The Princeton wrestling team defeated Harvard, 24 to 8, in the university gymnasium tonight. It was the Tigers' twenty-first consecutive dual meet victory.

Mrs. Eleanor Alston Dulaney, 84, member of a prominent Maryland family and mother of Grafton L. Dulaney, who was found dead, shot in the temple, in his home late yesterday, died today in the Dulaney home.

Additional evidence of the readiness of banking institutions to make loans for home modernization to responsible borrowers was presented yesterday by Thomas G. Grace, New York State FHA director, who announced that he had received a letter from Gilbert R. Hendrickson, president of the Jamaiea National
ABBEY--Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Abbey (nee Ruth Mikola) announce the birth of Richard Herbert, on Feb. 20.
Captain Freddy Schweizer led the Amherst basketball team to an exciting 27-22 victory over Williams in their traditional Little Three battle tonight.

Hughie Starr, picturesque Irishman who formerly owned Starr's Hotel in Jamaica and Starr's Hotel in Queens Village, Queens, died suddenly Friday night of a heart attack at his home, 94-24 Hollis Court Boulevard, Bellaire, Queens. He was born in Ireland sixty-one years ago.
Harry Boniface, former Philadelphia electrical contractor who for thirty years has owned and operated the New Clarion Hotel here, died today of a heart ailment. His age was 75.

Plans for the largest international playground in the world were described today by Ernest C. Oberholtzer, executive secretary of President Roosevelt's committee which is investigating possibilities of the great project.

Trade continued spotty throughout the week, and despite the fact that sales held up in rural sections, the average for the country may have been as much as 10 per cent below a. year ago, making the poorest comparative showing of the year. Price reductions helped clear stocks of some types of merchandise, but some clearance sales met with poor response.
An outbreak of sore throat, which the State Health Department says has affected 300 persons and caused two deaths in Norwood, St. Lawrence County, was reported "definitely" under control today.

A verdict awarding $35,000 for injuries suffered by Miss Kathleen Doughty, former Oyster Bay High School teacher, in an automobile accident three years ago has been returned by a State Supreme Court jury.
A FLOATING pageant will be an outstanding feature of the mammoth celebration on the Mississippi River of the 400th anniversary of the river's discovery in May, 1541, by Hernando de Soto
Joseph Ungar of Brooklyn, driving a car borrowed from a friend, struck an icy stretch of highway and skidded into a ditch.

As long as a student is taught the truth, what he is taught is less important than how he is taught, Dr. Livingston Farrand, former president of Cornell University, said yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Codmmodore.

College students must be taught how to obtain as well as appreciate the finer things in life, Harry E. Stone, head of the placement service of the University of West Virginia, told the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Council of Guidance and Personnel Associations, in ChalfonteHaddon Hall, today.

Miss Mary Davis Weatherley, daughter of Mr and Mrs. G. Frank Weatherley of Mount Washington, Baltimore, was married today to Otway Lee Clark son of Mr. and Mrs. James Booker Clark of Elkridge Farm, at the Shrine of the Sacred Heart at Mount Washington.
MRS. MILLER makes this an exciting story of manslaughter. It is not an ordinary mystery tale, though the suspense is as keen as in the best of the thrillers. Helen.

IN Eleanor Farjeon's "Martin Pippin in the Apple Orchard," which appeared sixteen years ago, after seven stories had been told and six fair milkmaids had fled from the orchard each with the lad of her choice, Martin Pippin caught Gillian by the hand

Funds for examining 100,000 persons a year by X-ray and for providing 5,000 more hospital beds for tuberculosis sufferers are necessary if tuberculosis is to be brought under control in this city, Dr. Herbert R. Edwards, director of the Health Department's tuberculosis bureau, writes in the March 1 issue of Neighborhood Health.

Believing that a critical situation exists for American women in the proposed Equal Rights Amendmnt, and in the widespread lack of information on its implications, a national campaign to "fight it to the last ditch" has been organized by ten New York women.

" IS science enough?" May we depend wholly upon it to explain man's nature? Can science determine what is good for us by analyzing what we are and how we think and feel? This Professor Adler believes to be the chief issue in contemporary thought. For "the view which one takes of human nature determines how one lives as a man alone and with other."

More than 100 Barnard College undergraduates and their escorts attended the annual sophomore dance held last night in the Casa Italiana. Among the guests of honor were Professor and- Mrs. David Muzzey, Mr. and Mrs. Kurt von Forstmeyer, Miss Mary F. McBride, Dr. and Mrs. Donald Read, Miss Elsbeth Davies, undergraduate president and Miss Evelyn Hagmoe, president of the sophomore class.

The chief result so far in Washington from the events in Europe last week-end, wherein Great Britain underwent a sharp reorientation of policy toward Germany and Italy, was to increase the fervor and possibly the argumentative basis of that highly vocal group which insists that the United States should keep completely out of the affairs of other nations.
The rules committee of the International Amateur Athletic Federation today put sixteen world records made by American athletes on the official agenda for approval at the federation's meeting Monday.

The old four-story brick tenements at 199 and 201 Avenue C which began to collapse Thursday, routing their tenants, are being demolished by workmen on the order of A. N. Van Vleck, First Deputy Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, who decided they were unsafe and unfit for repair.
The New York A. C. swimming team proved too strong for the Yale junior varsity last night and won dual-meet honors, 53 to 22, in the Winged Foot pool.

Miss Charlotte Serena Butler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Ives Butler of Meriden, Conn., was married here this afternoon in the Cathedral of the Incarnation to James Andrew Plummer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry E. Plummer of New York, by Canon Rockland Tyng Homans.

A newly appointed committee which will direct the Housekeeper Service as a project of the Children's Aid Society will meet Tuesday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Juan T. Trippe, committee chairman, at 117 East Seventy-second Street, to consider means of raising funds for the service.
Manhattan defeated Fordham, 34 to 31, last night in a thrill-packed basketball game before 3,000 fans at the Rams' gymnasium in the Bronx. Although the Jaspers led,
The Department of Commerce announced today that imports into the Republic of Panama in 1937 were "the highest in point of value for any year since the foundation of the republic."

President Getulio Vargas said today that he believes the time has arrived for national capital to take the place in Brazil's development heretofore reserved and occupied exclusively by, foreign capital. "However," Dr. Vargas declared, "that does not mean that Brazil will antagonize foreign capital and investments."

NEAR the town of Nish in Yugoslavia recent excava tions have revealed an ancient city believed to be the "Town of the Emperors," which the Roman Emperor Justinian is said to have built in the sixth century.

Twenty 9-year-old children at Manumit School in Pawling are taking full care of 500 laying hens and providing a community of 100 with eggs and poultry. Receiving a regular wage for work performed, the class sells from 60 to 200 eggs daily to the school kitchen at current wholesale prices.

Miss Clara Elizabeth Davis, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Joseph Davis of 128 Willow Street, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Davis, was married to John G. Hegenwald, son of Mrs. John G. Hegenwald of Montgomery, Ala., and the late Mr. Hegenwald, yesterday noon in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn.
With old Cy Young casting an appraising and appreciative eye upon his work, Carl Hubbell unveiled his famed screw ball today for the first time this year.

William (Cowboy) Orman ended today his spectacular career of four years as a member of the North Castle Police Department here and said that after March 15 he would be running down clues in Hollywood instead of chasing crime suspects through the backwoods of Westchester. He hopes to become a special investigatoP for the District Attorney's office in Los Angeles.

The proposal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science to form a world association of national scientific societies is rapidly gaining ground in Europe. The association is to serve the double purpose of studying the social effects of scientific advance and to resist encroachment on the democratic right of science to express itself freely.

A Professor of Political Economy who also is adept at conjuring and legerdemain will perform feats of magic on a program to be given at the Maplewood Woman's Club, Friday at 8:15 P. M. at the clubhouse.
Blair Academy's wrestling team successfully closed its dual meet season today by defeating the Columbia freshmen, 29 1/2-4 1/2.

OR Hall L. Hibbard, young chief engineer and vice president of the Lockheed Air craft Corporation of Burbank, Calif., designing a 100-passenger airplane in response to Pan American Airways' plea for bids may become the realization of a longtime scientific dream.

Notwithstanding the marked impetus which has been given to the construction of low-cost homes in Queens and other sections of Long Island, it is significant to note that several builders of the higher priced home types predict that a larger number of dwellings costing $15,000 and more will be sold this year than was the case in 1937.

Brazil and Bolivia jointly will exploit the oil deposits in the foothills of the Andes Mountains in Bolivia. Under an agreement signed at the Foreign Office here Brazil and Bolivia agree to undertake geological studies and soundings in order to locate and ascertain the true worth of the oil deposits in Bolivia near the Brazilian border.

Stanley R. White, district director of the Federal Housing Administration, told the members of the Jamaica Real Estate Board at their meeting last week that the restoration of modernization credit loans will probably be of more importance to a larger number of people than any other change recently made in the National Housing Act.

Michigan and Indiana are in open warfare over beer. The Wolverine State has placed a ban on the sale of Hoosier brew in Michigan, effective March 14, and Indiana officials have retaliated in similar fashion.
The fourteen national honor societies on the Rutgers University campus will hold a formal dinner meeting Thursday, with Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of the university, presiding.

A survey of the rural districts of Kiangsu Province between Shanghai; Sunkiang, Wusih and Soochow reveals that hundreds of thousands of Chinese peasants have returned to farms and villages. Plowing and sowing are being hastened.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Mary Kilroy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Philip Kilroy of Bloomfield, to Edgar Louis Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Smith of Newark, took place here this evening in Old First Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Archibald Sinclair.

William "Concord Bill" Mathues, 83, has become a father for the seventeenth time. Two of the children have come within two years. "I hope it's the last," he said proudly, with a glance at the latest arrival, an eight-and-a-half-pound girl.

An intercollegiate symposium on "Spain" will be held at St. Peter's College in Jersey City Friday evening, March 25. Fordham, New Rochelle, St. Elizabeth's, Notre Dame and St. Peter's College will participate.
GEORGE MASON, CONSTITUTIONALIST By Helen Hill. 300 pp. Cambridge: Harvard University Press. $3.50.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Goodwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard V. Goodwin of 329 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, to Dr. Lewis Tilton Bennett, son of Dr. Henry Welles Bennett of Manchester, N. H., and the late Mrs. Bennett, took place last night in Emmanuel Baptist Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the former pastor, the Rev. George Arthur Clarke of Malden, Mass., who was assisted by the pastor, the Rev. John Leslie Hart.

With the cost of illness and premature death in this country amounting to about $10,000,000,000 annually and with more sickness among the poor than among those who are in better economic circumstances, "there is need and occasion now for the development of a national health program," according to a report issued today by a special committee of the Public Health Service.

So much has been published recently about battleships of over 40,000 tons, and so many statements have been made as to the inability of ships of such huge size to transit the Panama Canal, that a little clearing of the air seems necessary.
Gasoline, kerosene and fuel oil valued at $385,009 were brought by ship into the Atlantic City harbor during December, according to a report completed by Captain Morrell Van Sant, harbor master.

Nearly every seat has been purchased for the performance of Ibsen's "A Doll's House," with Ruth Gordon in the leading role, tomorrow night at the Broadhurst Theatre, which has been taken over by members of the Tiny Tim Society of the House of St. Giles the Cripple to raise funds for that institution. The net proceeds will be used in furthering the care and relief of crippled children.

Welfare expenditures and rates for electricity, gas, water and fire insurance are somewhat higher in Westchester County than in other comparable districts of the metropolitan area, according to County Budget Commissioner William B. Folger, who has made a survey of living costs here.
Mrs. Beulah Chapman Laneri of this town received a divorce today on intolerable cruelty from James N. Lakneri, airplane pilot for the Martin Johnson expedition to Borneo.

Superiority with the saber enabled the New York University fencing team to register its fifth straight triumph yesterday, when it defeated St. John's, 16 to 11, in the DeGray gymnasium. St. John's surprised with a 5-to-4 triumph in foils, but the Violet evened the count by winning by the same score in epee.

Major Gen. Fred T. Austin, U. S. A.., retired, former chief of field artillery, died in Walter Reed General Hospital today at the age of 71. During the Spanish-American WVar he served as a first lieutenant in the First Massachusetets Infantry,

Nomination blanks are being sent out by the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England for the $1,000 big four novice stake of 1938 to be judged at the club's annual specialty show next November in Boston. Nominations will close May 1, the fee being $1 for each doge.
WASHINGTON. - The superintendent of documents finds many persons interested in the love life of the bullfrog and philately, few in the government budget.
MPORTANT American shows held here and there about the country have been numerous this season. At least half a dozen of these out-of-town events are still current and others loom.

THE majority of people lack any sense of curiosity about the things to which they are accustomed The average person never considers how much a study of words and their derivations reveals of the habits and life of their ancestors.

Frank E. Gannett, publisher of the Gannett chain of newspapers, has called for united national nonpartisan action for a mandate to Congress to defeat the pending executive reorganization bill. He has issued the call as chairman of the National Committee to Uphold Constitutional Government, which took a leading part in the campaign against the reorganization of the Supreme Court.

In the recommendations for Federal aid to schools made last week by President Roosevelt's Advisory Committee on Education organized schoolmen of the country were met by proposals both more and less magnificent than those they struggled for last year in the HarrisonBlack-Fletcher bill.

Miss Gertrude Fawcett of South Norwalk, student at the Rosemary Hall School, Greenwich, won the championship in the thirteenth annual Midwinter junior riding competition, held at the Round Hill Stables today.

Some of the best women golfers in the country, including Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis and Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., will tee off Tuesday in the qualifying round of the fourteenth annual Florida East Coast championship at St. Augustine, Fla.
WHEN Napoleon was placed in command of the army of Italy, the army which was to electrify all Europe. he took with him three men: Marmont, a gunner; Murat. the foremost cavalry leader, and Berthier,

Figures presented yesterday to the New York State Mortgage Commission by William L. Whitfield, vice president and controller of the Mortgage Commission Servicing Corporation, show that in the last year the commission's subsidiary disbursed $32,427,116 on account of mortgages serviced and properties managed by it.

Miss Selworthy, owned by E. R. Harriman of New York and driven by Mrs. Harriman, won the 3-year-old trot in Aiken's inaugural meet today with a time of 2:302-5 in the first heat and 2:343-10 in the second heat over the mile track.

While waiting for the reporting in the Legislature of a bill making jury service for women mandatory, the New York League of Women Voters is furthering its campaign for extension of the present permissive law with plans for an "experience meeting" of jury women.

I know tonight (and how I know it only they can tell Who know the speech of rain, the eloquence of wind) That all the dead from all the perished years Stir blindly in the dust, or move abroad At this, the ancient summons of the Spring.
PROGRESSIVE education, America's most discussed philosophy of learning, has just marked its twentieth birthday as an organized movement with a four-day celebration in New York.

Opposition to "the use of the WPA and emergency relief agencies as recruiting stations for the army" was expressed yesterday by Allan S. Haywood, regional director of the Committee for industrial Organization.
With Captain F. Skiddy von Stade finding hard, and the whole team driving with clocklike precision, the Harvard polo trio overcame an 8-5 deficit to defeat Yale, 17-12, today.

FOLLOWING in the steps of other nations, France, in addition to opening a new radio phone circuit to the United States, has recently completed the construction of several new short-wave stations which, it is expected, will improve Parisian reception here.

In solitary majesty Glenn Cunningham strode to a new world indoor record for 1,500 meters last night while a thrill-sated crowd of 14,000 at the fiftieth annual national championships of the Amateur Athletic Union rocked the rafters of Madison Square Garden with the bedlam of its applause.
More than a million pounds of tree seed have been collected by CCC members at six soil conservation camps, the regional headquarters reported today.

In a new booklet, "Controlled Installment Credit," the Household Finance Company, Chicago, last week urged more conservative terms in time sales, criticized the highpressure selling to families with incomes under $2,000 and suggested a plan to mitigate credit losses.

THOSE who live in Europe and study international relations frequently receive from the United States anxious inquiries regarding the prospects of continued peace. There have been many occasions for disquietude as Europe has come to be increasingly dominated by what is euphemistically called "power politics." Europe appears to be seething with unrest and fanaticism, bowed down by armaments,

The United States' excess of exports over imports, commonly called a favorable trade balance, continued to increase in January, further reversing the situation that existed a year ago, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Two small children were killed on the Penns Grove-Salem road near here this morning when they fell to the roadway from the rear seat of an automobile driven by their father. They were Virginia, 5 years old, and Patricia, 6, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Albert R. Hamerslag. Wensly Drive, Great Neck, L. I.
Jackson B. Hayden's thoughts went back today to World War days when he was personal driver for General John J. Pershing.

A century of progress in transportation as well as in education is tersely recorded in the 101 catalogues issued by Mount Holyoke College since it first opened its doors as a seminary in the Fall of 1837.

Sharp inventory write-downs in the final quarter of 1937, following four consecutive months of commodity price declines, were chiefly responsible for holding corporation earnings down to about 12 per cent last year, according to accountants last week.

The $250,000,000 appropriation approved by Congress last week to supplement WPA funds permits some encouraging light to shine through the dark clouds which have been gathering over the city's relief set-up in recent months.

Leading pistol shots of military organizations in the Second Corps Area will compete for more than sixteen trophies and medals during this year, according to an announcement issued by the Commanding 'General of the Second Corps Area.

Five of its components falling, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has declined to 79.0 for the week ended Feb. 19. This compares with 79.7 for the previous week and 104.9 for the week ended Feb. 20, 1937.
Private Berlin advices to the newspaper Algemeen Handelsblad indicate that the prosecutor in the trial of the Rev. Martin Niemoeller asked a penalty of twenty months in prison.
Panegyrics bestowed upon Senator Joseph F. Guffey at the Democratic State Committee meeting in Harrisburg today were but balm for his wounds.

Called as the final witness in support of the administration's $1,100,000,000 naval-construction program, Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, told the House Committee on Naval Affairs today that the future peace and tranquillity of the United States was "directly dependent" upon the maintenance of a navy so strong in ships and with a personnel so expertly trained that no other nation in the world would hazard "a war with us."

The boom of a sixteen-inch gun, the desolation of a sharecropper's shack and the beauty of the Rhine Valley, all these and other phases of life beyond college walls now are brought to undergraduates at Hobart and William Smith Colleges through the medium of sound motion pictures.
