THE American Artists Congress wishes to express its appreciation of the support you have given to the idea of an adequate exhibition of contemporary American art on the grounds of the World's Fair, 1939, Inc.
Colonel and Mrs. William W. Hicks of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cornelia Hicks, to Lieutenant Le Roy Lutes Jr., Fifth Field Artillery, U. S. A.
TODAY is Helen Keller Sunday and ministers throughout the country will take as the topic of their sermons a woman's triumph over darkness. For this year marks the fiftieth

Army defeated Navy, 44 to 36, today in the.wind-up basketball game for both teams. Thirty-six hundred spectators were assembled in the Cadet gymnasium to watch the contest,. which was featured by the hard play usually incident to Army-Navy sport competition.

Activity in the wholesale market was improved last week as apparel buyers returned for second Spring trips, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.
ORVILLE WOODRUFF, dreamer of wide spaces and bungling clerk in a San Francisco office, received a letter from his father saying that he had struck a bonanza.
Cardinal Innitzer, Archbishop of Vienna. issued a pastoral letter today ordering special prayers and periodical masses in all churches for Austria's freedom and the neace of the world.
LAWYERS' LEADER: In opposition to the older and more conservative American Bar Association, a group of lawyers organized late in 1936 the National Lawyers
WHAT will novelists think of next? Homer Croy has written a novel about a mule. It is called "Sixteen Hands." and it will be published on March 1 by Harper Brothers.
HE twelfth annual Eastern championships begin tomorrow afternoon at the Park Central Hotel and will continue through next Sunday night. Six different titles are at stake.

THE formula of Paramount's annual extravaganza varies not at all, whatever the year. It must have the radio motif, ninety-five diaphragm laughs from the top funny man, musichall acts of a lunatic tinge, tunes in between and the whole hypothec must be shunted upon the screen on the eve of the vernal equinox.

FEDERICO GARCIA LORCA, the greatest poet of twentieth - century Spain, was in August of 1936 dragged through the walled streets of Granada to face the Fascist firing squad. Since his death his poetry, in translation, has attracted much attention both in England and in America. He had published four books, the last only the year before he was killed.

A renewal of the labor war between the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, and the League of New York Theatres, organization of producers, ended yesterday afternoon in a truce until 1 P. M. tomorrow after the Martin Beck Theatre, 302 West Forty-fifth Street, was picketed for an hour.

Walter J. Brett, 58, of 2,973 Briggs Avenue, the Bronx, crossing Bainbridge Avenue at Mosholu Parkway, the Bronx, last night, was struck by a truck driven by Nicholas Salinardi, 40, of 1,733 Eightieth Street, 'Brooklyn, and died two hours later in Fordham Hospital.

Emphasizing the importance of proper health and fire protection to prevent epidemics and other dangers among visitors to the World's Fair in 1939, Mayor La Guardia has written letters to hotel and lodginghouse proprietors urging them to have experts check up their sanitary and fire-protection equipment, it was announced yesterday at City Hall.

With a smooth and satisfying performance of "Das Rheingold," the evening series devoted to Wagner's "Ring" tetralogy was inaugurated at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The generous policy pursued by the management in presenting this opera at popular prices

For many years one of the world's foremost skiers, Walter Prager, youthful Swiss instructor of the Dartmouth College team, turned in a remarkable performance in capturing the open division of the crosscountry race that marked the opening of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's annual championships today.

A Brunswick School dance in the series for members of the younger set will be held Friday night at the school. Mrs. George Farnham Kunhardt heads the group arranging the series, which will also include dances on April 1 and May 6. Assisting her are Mrs. Carl A. Hatheway, Mrs. Lawrence Chamberlain, Mrs. William Beverly White and Mrs. George D. Dixon.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 24: REAR ADMIRAL Marshall. A. W.. president Naval Examining Board. Washington. D. C.. about March 1 to home, relieved all active duty.
The British public has hardly yet recovered its breath after the shock of this week's extraordinary events. It is still bewildered by Adolf Hitler's coup in Austria, so quickly followed

" Introduction to Gardening." a lecture course conducted by P. J. McKenna, will be given in the museum building of the New York Botanical Garden for eight consecutive Thursday evenings, starting this week.

SICILY, where winds play softly and fruits, birds and flowers thrive in sunlight, welcomes visitors above all in March and April to its delightful "Primavera." The island is never more alluring than in the Spring, when nature is at full bloom.

Victorious in its first pitched battle with the government over the drastic Gen- and e1al Mobilization Bill, the Diet sub committee to which it was sent for revision avoided discussion of it in brief session today.

The Brooklyn Real Estate Board announced yesterday that it is supporting the State's Joint Legislative Committee's program to continue the present mortgage moratorium until 1940 and to abolish deficiency judgments. Roy M. Hart will represent the board at the hearing Tuesday on the mortgage moratorium bills before the Mortgage and Real Estate Commltttee of the Assembly.

Secretary Wallace has started in the Department of Agriculture a school for instruction in the administration of democratic principles. This, he hopes, will educate first his own large staff and also the public in the proper method of working out what he terms a "democratic economy."

Walter Hoving, president of Lord Taylor, has accepted the post of assistant chairman of the men's committee of the 1938 Citizen's Appeal of the Salvation Army, it was announced yesterday by Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., chairman of the committee.
DESPITE occasional portents of Spring, only a rash weather prophet would suggest that little stormy weather lies in the immediate future. Gusty winds will play tricks
The State Parole Board today denied a parole to Warren K. Billings, convicted with Thomas J. Mooney of the 1916 Preparedness Day parade bombing in San Francisco.

The radio as a means of instructing elementary school children and adults to appreciate and understand the finer types of music was championed yesterday in a panel discussion at the' Second Annual Music Conference, sponsored by New York University's School of Education.
A blood test disclosed that General John J. Pershing is suffering from uremic poisoning of "considerable magnitude," Dr. Roland Davison, his personal physician, announced early today.

The National Labor Relations Board has filed a petition in the United States Court of Appeals at Philadelphia requesting enforcement of an order against the Botany Worsted Mills, Inc., of Passaic, issued in December.

Coroner Chris Adank reported that at least five persons were killed and more than a score were Injured when a fast Burlington frieght train eastbound crashed late today into the rear of a work train carrying about 300 railroad shop employes.

Miss Anna G. Sampson of this city, a descendant of Paul Revere, was married to Charles R. Hagan, son of Mrs. Arthur F. Hagan of 27 Washington Square West, and the late Dr. Hagan, yesterday morning in the rectory of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, 138 Waverly Place. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George B. Fagan.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, were among the passengers who left for Nassau yesterday on the liner Carinthia of the Cunard White Star Line.

Wilford Bacon Hoggatt of 400 West 118th Street, who was Governor of Alaska from 1906 to 1909, died yesterday morning in the United States Veterans Hospital in the Bronx after two years of failing health.

An investigation of the connection between crime and politics, the operation of the Elections Law throughout the city and the activities of the Board of Elections in the last five years is being conducted by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation.

Members of Local 301, United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers Union, employed by the General Electric Company here, unanimously ratified today a proposed contract providing for arbitration preceding any strike or lockout.

Among those who gave dinners at a Mardi Gras ball held here tonight at the Scarsdale Golf Club were Mr. and Mrs. Harris L. Wofford, Mr. and Mrs. P. J. Murphy, Mr. and Mrs. J. D. Lester, Mr. and Mrs. D. Notzel, Mr. and Mrs. F. K. Allston, Mr. and Mrs. S. M. Dow and Mr. and Mrs. S. E. Darby.
Toronto University's sextet tightened its hold on third place in the International Intercollegiate Hockey League today with a 6-2 victory over the cellar-dwelling University of Montreal team.

THIS is a well-told yarn, full of luck and action, about tiger hunts and "human fly" experiments, about dynamiting Mexicans, about accidents involving manta rays and man-killing sharks. Mr. Craig was only 34 years old when his book was finished, but for many years he had been earning his living by, in effect, leading with his chin.

Seven 'steamers have been held outside this port all the week by a huge icefield which extends from the Labrador coast to Cape Race and.is 100 miles wide in places. The Furness liner Nova. Scotia from Liverpool and the Dromore from Boston are held outside the ice.
Yale students of engineering, with apparatus set up by themselves, will demonstrate at an exhibit next week scientific processes to which they have given months of study.

Two high-goal indoor polo games will be played here next week in the interests of a widely known philanthropic project. On the night of March 8 at the Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, the squadron team will meet Boulder Brook and Winston Guest's Optimists will play the New York Athletic Club team.
Although competitors closed in around him over Glen Arven's fairways, young Byron Nelson of Reading, Pa., remained in front. today in the $3,000 Thomasville open golf tournament.

Although the billion-dollar textile industry of the United States suffered one of the most drastic setbacks in its history in the second half of last year, the immediate outlook is by no means so unfavorable as annual reports now being published for leading companies might indicate.
Clemson College of Clemson, S. C., fought its way to the 1938 Southern Conference boxing championship tonight, defeating the Citadel by 5 points.

After a three-hour executive meeting in City Hall, the Council committee investigating the charge that Councilman Hugh Quinn, Democrat, was not a resident of Queens when elected from that borough, yesterday designated Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d, chairman, to draft a report of "findings" to be submitted to the Council.

Norman McClintock, photo naturalist and member of the faculty of Rutgers University at New Bruns wick, N. J., died at a holpotal here late tonight. He underwent an operation two weeks ago. His age was 69.

Several well-known entertainers will contribute their services for a floor show to be held in conjunction with a tea today in the Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center. The event is the annual benefit for the Authors' League Fund, which, since its incorporation in 1917, has aided many members of the league in financial distress.

Russell T. Fisher, president of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers, declared today that any reduction in the tariff on cotton textiles through a trade pact with Great Britain would "heighten the gravity of the unemployment situation" in this country.

The Hudson County Committee for Labor Defense and Civil Rights adopted a resolution protesting the "denial" of civil liberties in Jersey City at a meeting here tonight in Fairmount Hall, 718 Bergen Avenue.

Shopping for new things in the houseware departments is a lot of fun just now, because there is so much that is unusual and because one's first reaction to some of the ingenious gadgets is likely to be mild amusement.

A "bundle bridge party," offering an afternoon's diversion at bridge or backgammon, has been planned by the junior committee of the Kips Bay Boys' Club for Tuesday at the clubhouse, 301 East Fiftysecond Street.

Miss Dorothea Maxine Kaesche, a great-granddaughter of the late Theodore A. Havemeyer of New York and Newport, was married here yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria to John Forster Abeel by the Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan. The ceremony took place in the Jade Room, which was transformed into a chapel for the occasion.
Columbia's well-balanced swimming team defeated Pennsylvania in an Eastern Intercollegiate League meet at Hutchinson Pool today, 45 to 30.
AT the foot of Capitol Hill a small, dingy bar displays the chirpy little slogan, "We have it and we can mix it."

Denying that there had been any collapse in furniture prices, officials of the New York Furniture Exchange said yesterday that advertising of a large department store which appeared here last week was misleading.

Mrs. Stanley Reed is the most unorthodox and pleasantest acquisition to date, in the family circle of the country's highest tribunal. Strangers meet the wife of the newest Supreme Court Justice with a slight sense of shock at her youthfulness and attractiveness - as though it were a mite outrageous of her to shatter so thoroughly a popular conception of lavender and old lace as appropriate to the wives of the Justices.

Miss Janet Milne, 17-year-old champion from Saranac Lake, N. Y., fell on a turn today and lost the opportunity of winning the Sir William Johnson bicentennial speed skating laurels and her seventh meet victory of the season.
A special meeting of the Board of Education will be held Friday at 4 P. M. to consider the appointment of Joseph J. Jablonower as a member of the Board of Examiners.

The robin, unlike the groundhog, is a bird without a sense of responsibility. His appearance may mean Spring or it may mean only that he is interested in Winter sports, is too lazy to fly south, or just likes to fool people.
Grizzled grandparents and tiny youngsters, with adults and chil-] dren of all ages in between, eighty in all, combined in a holiday week

The destruction of the rights of all citizens would follow a destruction of the rights of "the meanest citizen, religious, economic or political," Rabbi Morris Lazaron of Baltimore told a weekly discussion group at a luncheon at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street, yesterday afternoon.

Nine Spanlards and three Cubans were arrested today on charges of organizing a secret society to aid the Spanish Loyalist forces. Cuba dissolved such organizations some time ago, fearing clashes between the two Spanish factions.

Chapman's Landing, historic 700acre estate in Southern Maryland, on which was located the ferry which Washington and other early statesmen used to cross the Potomac into Virginia, has been sold by Philemon Dickinson of Philadelphia, member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Smith Barney.

The New York Americans all but eliminated the Montreal Maroons from the National Hockey League playoff race tonight with a 5-1 victory over the Red Shirts before a slim crowd of 4,500. It was the New Yorkers' sixth straight victory over the Maroons this season.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Jane Wyeth, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Austin Wyeth of New York and Faraway Farm, Hanover, N. H., to Dr. Richard Van Dyck Knight, son of Mrs. William Knight, also of this city, and the late Mr. Knight.

The practice of euthanasia, or "mercy killing," was condemned as a "pagan philosophy" in a resolution adopted yesterday by the Supreme Board of National Officers of the Catholic Daughters of America, holding their semi-annaul meeting at the organization headquarters, 10 West Seventy-first Street.

WALT KUHN, in a most in teresting pamphlet published a few days ago, reminds us that this month marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of an event of singular significance--the opening of the famous Armory Show in New York on the evening of Feb. 17, 1913.

In an unexpected reversal of earlier action and in repudiation of an agreement with manufacturers, Philadelphia members of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers voted today to strike on Monday against a revised wage schedule prepared by an impartial board of arbitration.

Expansion of Russian influence inChina reflected in reports from Kashgar Sinkiang, which indicate that some form of political alliance is being established between the Sinkiang provincial government and the Chinese province of Kansu.
MILITANT words, words of packed into powerful electric beams, stabbed out from Europe during the past week like the fan-shaped fingers of great searchlights waving a warning through the darkness.

To assist the New York Kindergarten Association's maintenance of kindergartens and nursery schools where children in congested districts of the city have opportunities for physical growth and educational guidance, a benefit performance of Mozart's opera, "Cosi Fan Tutti," will be presented by the Salzburg Opera Guild on the night of March 18 at Carnegie Hall.

AS any one who doubles between the bard's shrine and Shubert Alley will tell you, the Cassius of Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar" should be played by an Equity member both lank and lean, whose mask betrays a restless and consuming hunger.

The Rev. Hiromichi Kosaki, Japanese Christian leader, died today at the age of 82. He was a former president of the Japan Federation of Christian Churches and established scores of churches throughout the empire.

While playing "cowboy," E. Heston Wallace, 13-year-old son of a Marshallton farmer, was killed today by a rifle bullet. A companion, Charles Dunford, 16, was quoted by Assistant District Attorney Phillip J. Reilly as saying that he thought the rifle was unloaded, and that he had fired through an onen door.
Silk insulation that exhibits thirteen and one-half to seventeen times more electrical resistance than ordinary silk is revealed in a patent granted to Alfred C. Goodings of Toronto, Ont.
IT seems a pity that, while verbatim reports are regularly published of the proceedings in Parliament and Congress, no full account is ever availableof the debates at the EnglishSpeaking Union.

Stocks moved narrowly in dull trading yesterday and closed irregularly lower. Trading on the Stock Exchange during the two-hour session amounted to only 303,000 shares, the second smallest turnover since October.

The Truesdale Lake Corporation, developer of Truesdale Lake, South Salem, Westchester County, reports that four new houses have been erected and several others are in the course of construction. In addition three lake front plots have been sold and Lake Shore Drive, a new fifty-foot wide road is nearing completion.

Senator Robert R. Reynolds of North Carolina said today that the good-will trip of six "flying fortresses" to South America was "one of the most momentous flights ever made by army aviators of any country upon the face of the earth."

Belief spread tonight that Japan might offer a plan to end the world naval rearmament race. "An important question now existing between Japan, the United States and Great Britain is the naval program," Foreign Minister Koki Hirota told Parliament in answer to questions on foreign policy.
Charles Greenhauff, president of the Paragon Builders, announced yesterday that his firm is erecting fifty bungalows of three, four and five rooms at Woodbury,
Pet dogs of varieties which almost never persuade their owners to enter them in dog shows had their day-their day and a quantity of prizes-yesterday at Bloomingdale's annual show especially for them.

A sharp conflict on the issue of whether a provision for disclosure of percentage of weighting of silk fabrics should be made mandatory or permissive in the proposed trade practice rules for the silk industry will develop at the hearing on the rules before the Federal Trade Commission next Friday, it was indicated yesterday.

More than two months after she quit the bamboo jungles of Szechwan Province on the Tibetan border of Northwest China, Mrs. William Hale Harkness Jr., New York explorer, arrived yesterday morning from Chicago, where she left her quarry, "Diana" nicknamed "Mei-Mel," the second baby giant panda to be taken alive, resting comfortably at the Brookfield Zoological Gardens.

Led by Eddie Sadowski of Westfield, Mass., the Notre Dame basketball team defeated Colgate, 49 to 38, on the State Armory court tonight. A crowd of 5,000 fans turned out for the first big time college game in Albany.

Leslie MacMitchell, George Washington High School's ace, completed the "hat trick" yesterday when he won his third crown in as many years at the fifth annual national A. A. U. high and prep school indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden.
IN spite of the still unfavorable reports from other industries, the first flush of revival which was noted in the automotive industry a few weeks ago is taking on a rosier hue.
Spring activity has really started at the MacGregor Arctic Expedition base with the return of the sun at noon-day over the rim of the southern horizon.

Cooperation of the South Shore Trust Company of Rockville Center, L. I., in the housing program under the new FHA regulations was announced yesterday by George W. Loft, chairman of the board, who stated that the institution would make mortgages under the 90 per cent provisions of the act for low-cost homes.
The British have been asked not to fly planes over- scenes of Japanese naval operations in China.

Sixteen chemistry students from Wellesley College and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology will give a "chemistry concert" Wednesday evening Which will unite the science and art as they have not been related for 300

At a tea given today by Mr. and Mrs. Sydnor Barksdale Penick of this place, the announcement was made of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Penick, to Giles St. Clair, son of Harry Hull St. Clair, also of Montclair, and the late Mrs. Ethel Erskine St. Clair.

THE last gasps of Winter bring the beginning of the high season along the Georgia coast. To this "Land of the Golden Isles of Guale," so named by the Spanish explorers of the sixteenth century, come vacationists from colder regions, and Florida sojourners returning to their homes in the North.

Herman Lissner, 65 - year - old wealthy pants manufacturer, philanthropist and member of the board of trustees of Montefiore Hospital, was found dead yesterday morning in the bathroom of his home at 88 Central Park West.
The "vast possibilities" for development of a new Manhattan residential center in the East tHarlem neighborhood were emphasized last week by Stanley M. Isaacs,

Failing in a last-minute attempt at a rally, the Peddie School quintet was defeated by the powerful Blair Academy team, 33-31, today. The Peddie high scorer was Bill Bleicher, who made 10 points, as compared to Blair's Beck, who tallied 11. This victory makes Blair the probable winner of the Eastern Private Schools League trophy.

THE world is better off by exactly the number of laughs caused by Leonard Ross's magnificent night school hero, H*Y*M*A*N K*A*P*L*A*N. whose you-can't-tell-me-anything attitude toward adult education appeared in book form.
The fourteenth annual exhibition of the Kennel Club of Buffalo opened today at the Broadway Auditorium with an entry of 821 dogs.

WITH the Academy awards having been resolved into a free-for-all by the injection into the voting for the first time of 10,000 extras, the political acumen of the studios has been centered on the contest for the Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award "for the most consistent high quality of production achievement by an individual producer."

Rear Admiral Clark H. WoodWard, commandant of the Third Naval District, told thirty-nine cadets of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy at their commencement exercises in lower Manhattan yesterday that the merchant marine was no longer a purely commercial organization and that the navy was deeply concerned about the quality of young men going to sea as merchant ship officers.

English business men are not happy about the pending trade agreement with this country because they fear concessions granted by the United States will prove valueless in view of the current business recession here,

Hidden in the body of the new constitution for the New York Stock Exchange, which probably will be submitted to the membership on Thursday, are important changes in what is almost certainly the oldest system of commercial arbitration in the United States.

City College's varsity basketball team brought its home season to a brilliant close at the C. C. N. Y. gymnasium last night, piling up its biggest score of the Winter to conquer Providence College, 57-33.

Mr. and Mrs. Peter Martense Cornell of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Theodora Hart Cornell, to S. Lloyd Sammis of Naugatuck, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hewitt G. Sammis of Huntington, L. I.
The discovery of huge currency smuggling activities--a crime for which German law provides the death penalty--was reported by authorities here today.
The Huron Club of Greater New York will conduct an amateur boxing tournament at the Ridgewood Grove Sports Club, Brooklyn, on March 23.
Senator Berry, Tennessee's junior member, announced today that he would be a candidate for the Democratic nomination to succeed himself.
A Yogi "youth-maker"-himself 172 years old by his own count-exultantly reported today he had turned back the years for an aged follower of Mohandas K. Gandhi.

The Interstate Commerce Commission took under advisement today an application by the Hartford Connecticut Western Railroad, a part of the New Haven System, for permission to abandon about ninety-five miles of line, much of it Dutchess and Columbia Counties, N. Y. It was said a decision could not be expected for several weeks.

The annual Westchester County Home Show for the present year will be held in the White Plains County Center during the week beginning June 8, announced Leo H. Fuller yesterday. Mr. Fuller is president of the Foundation for Better Homes, under whose auspices the exhibition will be conducted.

PARTLY due to her precocity--her first book was published when she was only 22--but more to the fact that her talent is genuinely individual, Pamela Hansford Johnson has attracted considerable attention in England.

Mrs. Katherine Sullivan Maxwell of Durham, Natal, South Africa, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Muriel Sullivan Maxwell, to the Rev. Thomas LeRoy Crosby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Newton L. Crosby of Picayune, Miss. Miss Maxwell was graduated from Carleton College, Northfield, Minn., in 1935, and is now studying for a master's degree in nursing at Yale University.
Believed to have been married longer than any other couple in the town of Huntington, Deacon and Mrs. Edward Baylis of this place today observed the sixty-fourth anniversary of their wedding.
In the past twenty years the Palestine Foundation fund of the United Palestine Appeal has spent $5.229,575 for the establishment and maintenance of the Jewish school system in the Holy land,

The thirteen-room residence of English Tudor design at 2 South Drive, Larchmont, Westchester County, has been leased to K. K. Kimball, reports Previews, Inc. Mrs. Lemuel James Ostrander is the owner. W. C. Burbank, broker, negotiated the lease.
Presentees looking forward to the royal courts to be held this Spring and Summer in Buckingham Palace will have an opportunity to view representative gowns at the Lord Chamberlain's office.
I DOUBT whether anything is more difficult in motion picture production than shooting a film on location with a cast of animals and natural types.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis Jacques Balsan will arrive today from their Winter place on Hypoluxo Island, Palm Beach, and will be at the Waldorf-Astoria until they sail for France on March 7. Mrs. Charles H. Baetjer has come from Baltimore to the Chatham.

Franklin E. Tyrrell, Forest Hills (L. I.) broker, reports that FHA insured mortgages have been placed upon one-family dwellings with the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company at 650-52 Saunders Street. Forest Hills West;

In a second housewarming for the Women's University Club, installed last month in a wing of the Hotel Biltmore, more than 500 members drawn from universities countrywide will attend a dinner tomorrow evening in the ballroom.

The recent manifesto of 170 Protestant clergymen of the Greater New York Federation of Churches condemning anti-Semitism as a sin evoked expressions of gratitude by rabbis in sermons here yesterday. Reaffirmation of the ideals of George Washington and a boycott of Japanese goods were advocated in other sermons.

An attack on the constitutionality of 1935 amendments to the New York Workmen's Compensation Law, which limits medical practice under the act to physicians specially authorized by the State Industrial Commissioner; will be heard by the United States Supreme Court tomorrow.

The flat lands of Southeastern Colorado, cradle of many a fierce dust storm in recent years, were moist and partly covered by snow today, but agricultural leaders were guarded in predictions that the dust threat had been whipped.

Ownership of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad as of Dec. 31 was explained today by the railroad to the Interstate Commerce Commission in reply to a questionnaire on its application to extend its Pond Fork subdivision to a new coal field in Boone County. W. Va.
WHAT is America, anyway? Ask a geogrpher, he will probably say that it is a sizable section of the earth's surface, of varied topography and climate, a region with resources of unmatched

A method that promises to open new avenues of approach to the study of the fundamental life process whereby nerve impulses are transmitted between the brain and the rest of the body, a process generally believed to contain the key to the mystery of consciousness, was described yesterday before the joint meeting of the American Physical Society and the Optical Society of America at Columbia University.
THE Boston Symphony Orchestra will give the next New York concerts on Thursday night, March 10, and Saturday afternoon, March 12, in Carnegie Hall.

MANHATTAN BUCHMAN, SARAH (Nov. 16). Estate, more than $10.000. To Marian Lamm, daughter, 315 W. 107th St., life estate; Moses R. Buchman, son, executor, Scarsdale, N. Y.; Sidney Buchman, son, Los Angeles, and Harold Buchman, son, West Los Angeles, equal remainder interests.

Jim Timoney led the Columbus Council, K. of C., quintet to a 30-28 triumph over St. Peter's College last night on the victors' floor. Pimoney contributed 14 points to the winning total, while Tom Woods was high for St. Peter's with 10.
Australia's cricket team which will tour England this Summer made 411 runs for six wickets today in a match against Tasmania. Stanley McCabe and Don Bradman were high scorers for the touring team.

Arrangements are being made at Tampico to load 100,000 barrels of oil on the giant modern Japanese oil tanker Itsu Kushima Maru. the oil was sold by the National Petroleum administration, a Mexican Government organization competing with private United States and British companies.

In endorsing private industry's program to induce home owners to improve and modernize their properties, Charles A. Jones, general manager of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, announced yesterday that the corporation's policy of reconditioning acquired homes before offering them for sale has proved profitable.

To the Radio Editor: Isn't it time that justice was done to the intelligence of the American housewife ? During the morning and afternoon, Monday through Friday, there are presented, from the two stations of this locality, twenty serial stories over the networks. Considering the hours, it is reasonable to assume that such programs are primarily intended for the ears of housewives.

Just thirty-six years to the day from the time when he received his first promotion in the armythat from private to corporalColonel Karl Truesdell, commanding officer of the Sixteenth Infantry, Fort Jay, Governors Island, will become a brigadier general, it was- learned yesterday.

A dramatic miscellany assembled to suit the most diversified tastes will be offered by members of the Lakeview Players, formerly known as the Junior Branch Players, for their annual theatrical presentation in behalf of the New York Women's League for Animals.

THIS book is the personal record of a white trader who, to a marked degree and in a real sense, "went native" in Darkest Africa. But, be it noted at once, it is not the kind of story that those words suggest, nor does it point the expected moral.

Miss Helen Louise Fairchild, daughter of the late Julian P. Fairchild and of the late Mrs. Helen Fitch Fairchild, was married yesterday afternoon to Stanley Edward Young Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Young of Ossining, N. Y.

Strong sentiment developed today in the Senate Finance Committee for downward revision of rates in the Administration-approved tax revision bill.

A first official step toward counteracting foreign radio propaganda in South America was taken by the Administration today with an announcement by Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, of the appointment of a committee by President Roosevelt to study international broadcasting.
The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today the designation of 566 counties in twelve Midwestern States as the 1938 commercial corn-producing area under terms of the new Farm Act.

Definite organization of a Lower West Side Congress to campaign for improvements in living conditions, with the lowering of retail milk prices through establishment of a consumers' cooperative as its first aim, was perfected at a meeting.at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, yesterday afternoon.

If it were possible to contrive a composite index of security and commodity prices, of industrial and trade activity, and weight this average by Wall Street sentiment, it could be shown that February witnessed some improvement.
IN days of old, when the seas were uncharted and mysterious reaches of water, news began to spread of a marvelous island where jewels were found in lavish quantities.

Miss Dorothy de Mercado, daughter Lionel de Mercado of Kingsto Jamaica, B. W. I., and the late Mrs. de Mercado, was married to Albert Leslie Wadley, son of Arthur C. Wadley of this city, formerly of the afternoon Newmarket, N. J., and Bartholomew's late Mrs. Wadley, yesterday noon in the chapel of St. holomew's Church. The cerewas performed by the rector,

" Nothing can subdue us," exclaimed Premier Milan Hodza last Tuesday when an honorary degree was conferred upon him by venerable Prague University. "Our country exemplifies disciplined, cooperative democracy," he continued.

THE report is definite this morning that Rosa Ponselle will not appear at the Metropolitan Opera House this season, nor will she take part in the tour. She is on her way tO California, presumably to Hollywood, and there are rumors that she is interested in an impending screening of "Carmen."

The balance of payments in Great Britain's foreign trade, visible and invisible, was received last week. It showed a net debit balance against Great Britain on all accounts of 52,000,000, the sixth which has occurred in our time; the others being in 1936, in 1934, in 1932, in 1931 and in 1926.

A European spy corps that bored from within the United States Army in an attempt to carry out a far-flung espionage program, embracing such matters as mobilization plans for defense of the Panama Canal and passing its agents into Soviet Russia on forged American passports, was shattered yesterday, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, with the arrest of two soldiers and a German woman.

AT noon on the first Saturday of March, when "the bluebirds have picked the last berries from the cedar trees," a group of some 200 followers of the sport of fox-hunting have gathered every year for many years to re-enact the chase which Bayard Taylor described in "The Story of Kennett."

The fatal shooting.of James Duffy of 2,922. Grand Concourse, the Bronx, on Thursday night; has been thoroughly investigated, it was announced yesterday at the office of E District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, and no criminal action will be taken.

Williams defeated Wesleyan, 56 to 19, in a Little Three swimming meet today. Davis and Pettit were the only Wesleyan men to place first, the former in the 220-yard free style and the latter in the 200yard breast-stroke event. Williams won both relays.

The Williamson bill, now in the State Legislature, which would prevent property owners from claiming overvaluation in seeking a reduction of assessments through certiorari proceedings, was denounced as "vicious" yesterday by L. O. .Rostenberg, head of RostenbergAssociates, Inc., White Plains brokers.

Staging a rally on the second half, Miss Patty Berg, 20-year-old Minneapolis golf sensation, won the South Atlantic championship for the first time by defeating Mrs. William Hockenjos of Lake Hopatcong, N. J., in the eighteen-hole final at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today. The margin was 1 up.
WASHINGTON.-The crime situation in the capital of the nation has assumed the proportions of a major problem.
WORKMEN excavating for extensions to Sadler's Wells Theatre in London, the famous home of British opera and ballet, have discovered a buried river.

Miss Elizabeth Rhoda Vroman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Amos Jackson Vroman of Maplewood, was married to William E. Buckley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Buckley of Westfield, in the rectory of Holy Trinity Catholic Church here today. The Rev. Henry J.

WASHINGTON.--The Division of Maps and Charts of the National Archives has made much progress toward placing scattered Federal map records in a central depository. The search for governmental records has exhumed many maps and charts of historical significance;
THE Italian Government has recently obtained the originaldies of the Maria Theresa thaler from Austria, and is now minting these coins for Ethiopia.

With reference to the article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine regarding Europe's changing skyline, I think your contributor is slightly misinformed in giving the credit, if credit it be, to Sweden for erecting the first skyscraper in Europe.

The opinion that the Greater New York Fund, which will seek to raise $10,000,000 among business establishments and their employes in its first campaign next May, represented a long step toward the alleviation of human suffering was expressed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy in approving the fund's certificate of incorporation.
The American Medical Association viewed with skepticism today a national health program proposed by President Roosevelt's special committee on medical care.

Governor Lehman signed today the Ives bill authorizing the State to participate in a Federal program of flood control. The State instead of the counties will now pay the costs of relocation and reconstruction of property used in connection with such projects.
In a broadcast tonight Premier Juan Negrin threw out to the country and to all the world Loyalist Spain's challenge to international "conspirators" against her independence.

Representatives of five cities and the District of Columbia advanced in the Eastern table tennis championships tonight. Miss Emily Fuller, New York, and Miss Mae Clouther, Arlington, Mass., each defeated three opponents, earning the right to meet for the women's singles title.

Teachers should become aware of the "insidious" propaganda influences that are shaping the policies of this country, 2,500 educators were told yesterday at the closing session of the Progressive Education Association's twentieth national convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
All phases of junior college education will be discussed at the annual convention of the American Association of Junior Colleges to be held in Philadelphia Friday and Saturday.

Russell Page, sales director of the "Easy-to-Own" Homes Organization, points out that, despite the wide interest recently aroused over the low down payment requirements for small homes purchased under FHA regulations, a trend toward higher down payments has been noticeable in sales made this month by that organization.

Magistrate Louis Brodsky appeared startled yesterday when James Healy, 46 years old, recorded by police as having no home, declared in Bronx Magistrates Court that exhaustion from his duties on a WPA project had caused him to fall asleep on a bench at the northern end of the White Plains Interborough Subway, 241st Street and White Plains Avenue, the Bronx.

THIS is one more volume in that "one more system of philosophy" which Santayana began in his "Skepticism and Animal Faith," continued in "The Realm of Essence" and "The Realm of Matter," and is to be brought to its conclusion in 'The Realm of Spirit."

Miss Lidie Lane Sloan and Andrew M. McBurney Jr., in whose honor many prenuptial parties have been given, were married yesterday afternoon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington. Calla lilies and banks of cybotium palms and ferns decorated the church.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors. c., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Officials of the Wabash Railway told a Senate committee today that the road hade more than doubled the salary of the chairman of its board, paid him a $100,000 special fee and declared a dividend a year before it went into receivership in 1931.

Miss Ida Clarke, former president of Advertising Women of New York, Inc., and for thirty-nine years connected with Scott Bowne of Bloomfield, N. J., manufacturers of emulsion, died of heart disease in her home, 140 West Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday morning after a short illness. Her age was 62.

Further confirmation was given today to the belief that the Soviet Government is not alarmed by recent changes in the European situation. An article in the newspaper Pravda, mouthpiece of the Kremlin, discusses the situation under the heading "From Anglo-Italian Negotiations to FourPower Pact," and nowhere does it betray encitement or alarm.

Mrs. Edna Harrison continued her winning streak in the preliminaries for the Hazel Allen championship trophy at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday, defeating Miss Dora Lesley in the seventh round. Mrs. Harrison now has scored 6 1/2 points.

MY feeling about clothes this Spring is that they must have color." So said one of New York's most brilliant young designers. "Why fear beautiful tone harmonies that blend? They give one a lift. Spring colors should merge with the Spring background."

Doctors expressed hope of recovery today for Mrs. Lois Clarke de Ruyter Spreckels Clinton, seriously hurt yesterday when the airplane of Adolph B. Spreckels Jr., her former husband, crashed, killing the pilot.

In response to the prevailing demand for more compact apartment suites, the new seventeen-story and penthouse apartment building under construction at 955 Fifth Avenue, between Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Streets, will contain new apartment types
Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in the smallest volume in many months, reflecting in part the Washington's Birthday holiday and also the inactivity in the new issue market.

Sixty-six New York architects th have been appointed to serve on twenty committees of the local chapter of the American Institute of Architects for the current year, announces Arthur L. Harmon, chapter president. Representatives to six municipal and academic bodies also were named.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N. H.-Snugly settled in its comfortable new building on the summit of Mount Washington, the Mount Washington Observatory today seems more assured of permanency than at any time since it was established as a pioneer venture five Winters ago.

John T. Farrell. a fireman for fifty-one years, will retire from his post as battalion chief April 1. Because of the numerous injuries he received as a fire-fighter, he sought a pension of two-thirds of his annual salary, but the claim was not allowed, and he will receive $2,650 annually, or half pay, according to a recent Fire Department order.
Winnipeg police decided today to keep sharp watch at hockey games and other public meetings just in case the man with the whistle makes his appearance.
BENJAMIN--BERGEN--Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Bergen announce marriage of daughter, Sonya, to Irving Benjamin, Feb. 21, Broadway Central Hotel, Rabbi J. M. Lawn officiated.

ALBANIA has taken on new interest for travelers, following the announcement of King Zog's engagement to Countess Geraldine Apponyi of Hungary, whose mother is an American. While practically unknown to tourists up to 1920,

A complete four-and-a-half-room apartment suite will be erected on the floor of the Long Island National Home Show by the Queensboro Corporation of Jackson Heights, Edward F. Hosinger, general chairman of the show, announced yesterday.

Provided service is resumed at once on the New York, Westchester Boston Railway, the 350 former employes are willing to work without compensation until the line is reorganized and placed on a sound financial basis, representatives of the employes informed William L. Moran, assistant corporation counsel of New Rochelle.

The 250 specially selected elementary school graduates who in February, 1936, formed the entering class of the High School of Music and Art have this month begun the second half of their high school course.

The synthetic wool which the Germans tell us they have been developing is made from the casein of milk, this for the reason that casein consists of albumen or protein molecules which arrange themselves in strings or chains. In fact, natural wool also is composed of protein, so that the chemical connection is clear.

PINEHURST, N. C.--The first week in March brings a solid program of sports events to Pinehurst for the remainder of the season. Opening the Country Club events for the month is the eighteenth annual seniors' golf tournament, scheduled for March 8, 9, 10 and 11.

Princeton University's Theatre Intime, campus dramatic organization now in the midst of its seventeenth season, will carry forward next Monday evening its tradition of annually presenting one undergraduate-written play with the opening of "The Undiscovered Country," by William G. Robinson, '39 of Elizabeth, N. J.

The foreign exchange market was irregular yesterday, with the pound sterling and the franc cheaper in terms of the dollar, but some other currencies higher. The pound fell 3/16 cent to $5.02'1, at which price it showed a net rise of 5/16 cent in the week. The franc at 3.26 3/8 cents was off 3/8 point in the day and 21/2 points in the week.

The Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. championships, a meet with a flavor and distinctiveness of its own, will be staged in Madison Square Garden on Saturday. This is the only track carnival of the season in which the team race is all-important, individuals in every instance being subordinated to the team as whole.

Announcement in the real estate columns, that the old Manhattan Opera House building in West Thirty-fourth Street has been sold, and that its dismantled stage may be re-equipped, awakens interesting memories.

PALM BEACH, Fla.-Winter residents here again this week will have the opportunity to be patrons for several important charity affairs. One of the events will be the thirteenth annual Kiwanis benefit at the Paramount Theatre tomorrow night for the maintenance of free medical, surgical, eye, ear, nose and throat clinics for underprivileged children of the county.

The Desert Sanatorium, to which General John J. Pershing was taken when his illness became grave, is in CITES the foothills of the Catalina Mountains about seven miles from the city of Tucson.

THIS writer, a few weeks ago, assumed that sculpture at its fullest development was a communal, heroic art, butthat today a lack of intelligent publio support deflected many an able artist from his own intent to ennoble a city and to enlarge the vision of its citizens.
Federal, provincial and municipal financing in Canada for the first two months of 1938 amounted to $230,151,121, according to figures compiled by Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd.

Despite the box-office success of socially illuminating films, the American motion-picture industry continues to produce "vehicles for pseudo-realities, incorrect generalizations and misleading stereotypes" that play significant parts in propaganda, it is charged in the March letter of the Institute for Propaganda Analysis, 132 Morningside Drive.

Propaganda to emphasize advantages of capitalism and weaknesses of socialism and thereby to return the balance of American voters to their "traditional position" just right of center, was urged last night by Dr. Ruth Alexander, Chicago economist, before 1,500 persons at the thirty-seventh annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

GIIAN-CARLO MENOTTI'S opera "Amelia Goes to the Ball" will be given its first Metropolitan performance Thursday night. The opera will be sung in English, with Muriel Dickson, Mario Chamlee and John Brownlee in the leading roles.
The Spanish conflict has confirmed the judgment of the army's high command that the usefulness of the tank in modern warfare is limited, officials said today.

THIS new Heinkel fighter is one of Germany's most formidable air weapons. Its armament includes two one-inch cannon, which make it virtually a piece of artillery with wings. Powered by a Diesel engine of 685 horsepower, it flies more than 325 miles an hour with great range and manoeuvrability. Details of the plane are as follows:

Announcement has been made to friends here by Mr. and Mrs. Seth Worth Morton of Albany and Saratoga Springs of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Charlotte Morton, to John H. Griffin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Griffin, also of Albany.
Latest returns show that sixty-three government candidates were elected to the Estonian first Chamber, for which elections ended last night, against seventeen Opposition members.

The art of wood and stone carving, so popular in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, is being revived by New York City's Board of Education. High school boys are taught handicraft as a means of earning their livelihood.

It is desirable to accept tne objectives of the recent report of former Premier Paul. van Zeeland of Belgium, as a goal, rather than to assume that these objectives are impracticable and thus to discourage proponents of international reconstruction, the New York Trust Compan says in the current issue of its publication, The Index.
MAHRDI GRAS visitors to New Orleans this year will find plenty of genuine fiesta spirit in the "French Quarter," but very little French.

Within the past two weeks French prestige and policy in Europe have been dealt three successive blows. There was, first, the Berchtesgaden interview when Chancellor Hitler imposed his choice of a Minister of Interior on Austria.

The Board of Realtors of the Oranges and Maplewood announces that more than forty members have registered for an eight-weeks' course in real estate to be conducted under the auspices of theeducational committee, composed of Gertrude Cook Meyer, chairman; Howard M. Raymond Jr., J. Ransom Forsythe, Voltaire Karam and R. Herbert Connolly.

French Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos's foreign political expose and the larger part of the whole debate in the Chamber of Deputies are characterized in German quarters as a danger to the peaceful development of Europe because French statesmen continue to hold fast to such -in German eyes-antiquated ideas as the League of Nations, alliances and especially the pact with Soviet Russia.
Cornell's polo team outclassed Penn Military College in the riding hall tonight, taking the lead in the second period and winning, 28-12, to score its eighth victory in sixteen gamies.

Stuyvesant High, defending champion, and New Utrecht gained undisputed possession of the lead in their respective divisions by scoring victories in the P. S. A. L. team fencing tournament at the Washington Irving High School gymnasium yesterday.
Bucharest reports that several Rumanian political leaders did not participate in yesterday's plebiscite which produced a vote of 4,500,000 to 5,000 in favor of a new dictatorial Constitution.

George L. McKenna, Assistant Chief of the New York Fire Department in. charge of the Fire College at 32-18 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, started 264 rookie firemen on the- last course of training yesterday.
A. C. Ebie, one of the organizers of the Magnolia Petroleum Company here and its vice president and general manager until he retired in 1928, died at his home here today. He was 74 years old.
THE Balkan Entente stamps which Turkey and Yugoslavia released in 1937 have been supplemented by similar postal paper issued by Rumania and Greece. Rumania's offerings,

You have recently published two articles by Ellery Sedgwick, who writes in his capacity of editor of The Atlantic Monthly, a purported liberal, impartial American magazine. Yet Mr. Sedgwick writes an approval and endorsement of fascism and the fascist State which sounds as if it came from the pen of a press agent.

About 125 students representing twenty New England colleges gathered at Providence College today for the annual conference of the New England Student Peace Federation, a branch of the Catholic Association for International
Rallying in the second half, Pennsylvania defeated Harvard at basketball in the Palestra tonight, 40-35, squaring the season's series with the Cantabs.
Inspector Charles C. Carmody, head of the Detroit Police Department Identification Bureau, and a fingerprint expert, died of a heart attack this morning. He was 58 years old.

Feasibility of transmitting two programs simultaneously over one short-wave radio channel is scheduled to undergo a test soon in the New York area by W. G. H. Finch, inventor, head of the Finch Telecommunications Laboratories, 35 West Fifty-seventh Street, it was announed yesterday.
When the committee on program created by the Republican National Committee in November will hold its first session Monday and Tuesday its hands will be left free to draw- up its own program.
Maury Maverick of this city faces possible opposition for his House seat in the July Democratic primaries from the city's Chief of Police, Owen W. Kilday.

Leaders of the worlds of finance, business and diplomacy paid tribute yesterday morning to the late S. Parker Gilbert, J. P. Morgan Co. partner and former Agent General for Reparations Payments, at funeral services held in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street. Burial was in Southampton, L. I. Mr. Gilbert died Wednesday after a brief illness.

GIOVANNI MARTINELLI has become virtually a permanent fixture of the American operatic scene. Other singers have come and gone since he made his New York debut; now he is rounding out his twenty-fifth year as a leading artist at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The National Sportsmen's Show, which has simulated the great outdoors for New Yorkers, bringing the woods of Maine, New Brunswick and elsewhere to their doorsteps and reminding them that fishing, sailing, camping and hunting are "just around the corner," closed last night with a 'noisy demonstration.
Clarence Franklin Hughes, who has been secretary of the Westminster Kennel Club for the last thirty-two years, died yesterday afternoon in St. Vincent's Hospital of a heart ailment at the age of 62.

Giovanni Martinelli, one of the leading tenors of the Metropolitan Opera Association, suddenly collapsed during the singing of the first principal aria in Verdi's opera, "Aida," which was being broadcast yesterday afternoon over a nationwide network from the Metropolitan Opera House.

THE reorganized National Association of Broadcasters with Philip G. Loucks at the helm temporarily, has deferred action on the selection of a paid president, possibly for a month at least. In the meantime an administrative staff will be set up.
Mrs. Mary Ella Briggs Morris-Smith, wife of Prescott MorrisSmith, a New York broker, has filed divorce proceedings in Superior Court here, alleging cruelty.

Another William Jennings Bryan soon will enter government service, more than twenty years after his father resigned from President Wilson's Cabinet in protest against entry by the United States into the World War.

Action of the wheat market on the Board of Trade here was disappointing to all classes of traders, prices declining about 1/2 cent a bushel in the early trading in sympathy with Liverpool, but week-end evening-up by shorts wiped out part of the losses.

Miss Virginia Lou Porterfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Austin Porterfield, was married to Wilmon Whilldin Hartman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. Hartman, this afternoon in Emmanuel Protestant Episcopal Church.

Miss Mary W. Dewson, member of the Social Security Board and former vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Miss Marion E. Martin, assistant to the chairman of the Republican National Committee, discussed yesterday the subject of modern education. As former Wellesley students, both were honor guests of the New York Wellesley Club at its annual luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore, and both adroitly skirted the topic of their varying political views.

Strife within the Democratic party leadership of Pennsylvania, unhealed by the unanimous endorsement of a primary ticket by the State committee at Harrisburg yesterday, came to the surface late today with an announcement by Matthew H. McCloskey Jr., co-leader of the Philadelphia organization, that because of an accusation by a fellowDemocrat, he was quitting politics "forever and a day."

Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Clark Feathers of New York and Lenox, Mass., who were among those entertaining at tonight's Circus Ball at the Surf Club, honored Mrs. Robert Golden Donaldson of Washington, who is visiting them.

Already assured of the Quadrangular League championship, Dartmouth recorded its sixth victory in nine International Intercollegiate Ice Hockey League starts tonight by conquering Princeton before 2,000 spectators at Davis Rink. 4 to 1.

" The Death of General Wolfe, 1771," regarded as the masterpiece of the famous eighteenthcentury American painter, which is included in an exhibition, opening March 5, at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, the first comprehensive showing of his work which has ever been held in his native country.

SAVE ME THE WALTZ--Tomorrow evening at the Martin Beck Theatre. A comedy, having to do with dictators, royalty, etc., by Katharine Dayton, with a cast including Laura Hope Crews, Jane Wyatt, Mady. Christians, Leo G. Carroll, John Emery, Arnold Korff, Reginald Bach, Martha Sleeper, Brenda Forbes and Francis Pierlot.

Still advocating purchases only for current 'needs, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, reporting on industrial activity of the current month, finds a generally mixed feeling among manufacturers concerning the immediate future.
Several factors existing at the present time which will have a favorable effect on real estate in the near future were outlined in a statement yesterday by I. Jerome Riker, president of Riker Co.

Submicroscopic particles of silver-used in such small quantity that their presence is scarcely detectable by usual analytic methods-will rapidly age whiskies, brandies, wines and also will mellow perfumes, it is asserted in a patent just awarded to Georg Alexander Krause of Munich, Germany.

A generally reassuring picture of the situation in Europe in the light of recent events in Germany and England was painted yesterday by the three principal speakers at the semi-monthly luncheon meeting of the Foreign Policy Association in the Hotel Astor, discussing "Germany's Next Step."

Whether a bagpiper can insert a few "hot-licks" of swing music is a debatable question that will not be determined when the pipers' bands march up Fifth Avenue on St. Patrick's Day. Nor will the brasses "go to town" or "swing it." There will be no ragtime and that Is official.

Several dinners were given tonight before the Piccadilly dance at the Bellevue Stratford for the benefit of the social service department of the Orthopaedic Hospital. Guests at the dance were received by Mrs. Franklin D'Olier Jr. and Mrs. Edgar B. Howard.

A gap of fifty years between scientific knowledge and health practices must be bridged by education, according to Miss Sally Lucas Jean, president of the Association of Women in Public Health and chairman of a committee developing a program for the Women's International Exposition of Arts and Industries. Cooperating are seventeen professional health units.

Members of the Carroll Club will receive communion at St. Patrick's Cathedral this morning in honor of Mary Carroll, for whom the club was named by her daughter, Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, Mrs. Macaulay, wife of the Irish Minister to Rome, will be one of the speakers at the breakfast to follow at the Biltmore Hotel.
The Hershey Bears moved into first place in the Eastern Hockey League by defeating the Baltimore Orioles, 5 to 3.

Red Bank takes all palms for the most extraordinary midwinter yachting dinner on record. At its fifty-ninth annual Washington's Birthday affair of the Monmouth Boat Club, believe it or not, nary a speech was uttered, although several were attempted during the three-hour gathering on the Shrewsbury River.

Seabiscuit came back to the racing wars today after a three-month layoff and was beaten by a nose by Aneroid in the fourth running of the $7,500 San Antonio Handicap. It was a battle among candidates slated to race in the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap next week.

The general trade recession continues to exert a marked effect on the open-market sales of Manhattan real estate, according to the report of January deals compiled by the Real Estate Board of New York.

THE first of fifty-six reconditioning clinics for used cars was held last week in Chicago by the Chrysler Corporation. The purpose of the clinics, T. W. Moss, general service manager of the company, explained, is to acquaint dealers with modern methods for reconditioning used cars quickly, efficiently and cheaply.

Today's round of games in the English Football League saw the Wolverhampton Wanderers forge ahead of Arsenal in the drive for First Divison leadership, while Aston Villa's three-day grip on the top rung in the Second Division was broken by Sheffield United.
Senator Wheeler of Montana predicted today that the President could have a third term nomination if he wanted it, but that he never could win the election.

Former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley will speak at the second session of the Spring realty lecture course, sponsored by the Westchester County Realty Board, to be held tomorrow evening at 32 Depot Plaza, White Plains.
Worth Boggeman of Fort Worth, Texas, and Paul Wearly of Muncie, Ind., shared honors today in an outboard motor-boat program curtailed because of rough water.

Prime Minister Eamon de Valera of Ireland left London today accompanied by some members of the Irish delegation to the Anglo-Irish treaty conference. He will return Wednesday for a resumption of the talks.

Mrs. William Browne Hale of Chicago gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Mary Hale, Miss Ruth Weyburn and Henry Preston, Granger Kenly and George E. Hale 2d.

DETECTION: Arizona's Senator Ashurst last week told how to decide whether a man is a monetary expert. "If he talks an hour about money and makes you listen," the Senator said, "and when he's through you ask yourself 'What in the hell is he talking about?' then you know that man understands the money situation."

EARINGS are set to begin ti in Washington tomorrow on the Coffee bill (H. R. 9102) "to provide a permanent Bureau of Fine Arts," and since the dance is one of the six subjects in which "creative, interpretive, research and teaching" activities are provided for in the bill, it becomes at once a matter of paramount interest not alone to the professional workers in the art but also to the ever-increasing national audience.
Conservatism was the dominant trend this week, as the people of this Far Western center of labor unrest voted in what has generally been regarded as its most crucial Mayoralty primary.

" Real Estate Selling and Leasing" is the title of a book written by Nelson L. North, New York real estate lawyer, and just published by Prentice-Hall, Inc. Various ideas for promoting sales are included in one chapter under the heading of "Sixty-eight Sales Pointers." The book contains various realty forms, including rental sheets, leases and deeds of sale.

With the approach of Lent--Ash Wednesday falls on March 2--women of society, to whom the penitential period means a curtailment of social activity, are turning their attention to philanthropic endeavors. Chief among these are the Lenten sewing classes, several of which have been in existence for many years.
THE author of "The Wind and the Rain," Merton Hodge, has a new play, "The Island," which will appear at the Comedy Theatre a few hours too late for any comment on it to be included in this article.

THE famous historian Hermann Oncken has again given a work of high caliber to the German public. Unlike his last volume, this book deals not with German internal affairs but with matters that concern every country pulsing with vigorous life.

New York's oldest charity fair, known for generations as St. Valentine's Kettledrum, will take place on April 8 at the Plaza. Although for many years this event has been held in St. Valentine's Day or as near that date as possible, circumstances necessitated its postponement this year.
The controversy over the resignation of Anthony Eden as Foreign Secretary and over the highly contentious appointment of Viscount Halifax that followed is kept fully alive in the Sunday press.
The St. Joseph girls' basketball team scored its third consecutive victory yesterday by defeating the Brooklyn College girls, 35 to 16, on the St. Joseph courts.
Two senior metropolitan A. A. U. swimming championships will be contested at the Women's Swimming Association this afternoon, the 100-yard back-stroke and the 500yard free style.
Harvard's freshman basketball team crushed Tabor Academy, 4013, at the Harvard indoor athletic building today. Harvard led, 26-6, at half time.

Upposed to a third term for President Roosevelt are 70 per cent of the Brothers College students at Drew University, according to a poll on subjects tanging from politics to marriage conducted by The Drew Acorn, student newspaper,
Three pitfalls in the path of the ideal administration of a civil service act were pointed out by Mayor La Guardia of New York in a speech today before the Michigan Merit System Association.
Great Britain has decided to permit India to keep her annual defense contribution of more than [Pound]100,000 to build up her own bulwarks against war in the Orient.

LIKENESSES of two men who are additions to philately's expanding gallery are presented on the one-filler deep violet of the series which Hungary has released to commemorate the 900th anniversary of the death of Stephen I (St. Stephen) on Aug. 15, 1038.

The Rev. Dr. Julius A. Nieuwland, late dean of the College of Science of Notre Dame University and renowned for his synthesis of rubber, has just been posthumously awarded a patent for a new chemical compound-a catalyctic agent-which may play an important part in the commercial manufacture of synthetic rubber.

In the mix months which have elapsed since Generalissimo Francisco Franco opened his drive on Santander last August a chaos of many fronts in the Spanish civil war has been reduced to a struggle across a single line.
