The girls' basketball teams of Manhattanville and Swarthmore played a 23-23 tie game in the Manhattanville gymnasium yesterdays. Miss Dana had a chance to win the game for the visitors with a foul shot with one minute to play but the toss went wide and the deadlock remained. Girls do not play overtime periods.

The new government of President Roberto M. Ortiz finds the United States Government and people more closely associated with its beginnings than with any other South American inauguration in recent years.
More than 1,000 paintings by children, the largest exhibition of its type ever held, will go on display Saturday at Rockefeller Center.

The legal objections that led the courts to invalidate the appointment of former Mayor James J. Walker as assistant counsel to the Transit Commission do not apply in the move to oust Simon W. Gerson from the office of Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan, according to a brief filed yesterday by Assistant Corporation Counsel William S. Gaud Jr. in the Supreme Court.
William May Garland of Los Angeles and Frederic R. Coudert of New york sailed yesterday on the Italian liner Rex for the meeting of the International Olympic Committee at Cairo, Egypt, on March 10.

A President Roosevelt's invitation, group of interested persons wil meet at the White House soon to discuss one of the gravest problems now before Washington-how to take the black clouds out of the na tion's railroad picture.

Another session of irregular price changes took place yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, and, after recessions that carried the list off $1 a bale from recent high levels, the market closed with net changes ranging from a loss of 3 points to a gain of 1 point.

After trailing until only nine minutes of play remained, Villanova's basketball team won its twenty-fourth game in twenty-seven starts by defeating the Rutgers quintet, 43-33, before 3,500 persons in the Rutgers gymnasium tonight.

A check-up to determine accurately the response given by consumers, retailers and wholesalers to the current promotion of National Brands Week was started yesterday by the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc.
TO stimulate Interest in autograph collecting as a hobby, a traveling museum devoted to signatures has been organized and will make a tour of important French cities.

Miss Louise Hedwig Kraft, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph George Kraft of this city, was married today to Philip Sylvester Criblet, son of Mrs. Paul Criblet of Baltimore. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Church by the Rev. Thomas Kenney Burke.

Official commendation of the report of President Roosevelt's advisory committee on education, proposing $855,000,000 Federal aid for schools, was announced here today by the executive committee of the legislative commission of the National Education Association, largest and most influential teachers' organization in the country.

The Andover Academy basketball team defeated the Massachusetts Institute of Technology freshmen, 50-35, today. Smith's first-half shooting and edefensive work gave Andover a commaanding, lead, and Dudan's last-half shooting kept the school-boys in the van despite Samuel's brilliant work for Tech.
The French liner Normandie is to return today from a twenty-two-day cruise to South American ports, the largest ship ever to go below the Equator. Among her prominent passengers are:

THE watt, the unit of electricpower derived by multiplying voltage by amperage, now beomes the unit of tax proposed for broadcasting stations in the United States. The tax, according to a bill introduced by Representative John J. Boylan of New York, would be derived by multiplying a station's watts by one, two or three dollars, depending upon the "size" of the station.

Lent begins on Wednesday and many markets are planning special Lenten offerings of fish and cheese and other foods that serve as substitutes for meat. Fish prices, rather cheap so far this year, depend as usual upon "fisherman's luck" in Atlantic and Southern waters.

Will American youths ever be galvanited into such intense enthusiasm and devotion to a cause as are those of Russia, Italy, Germany, France and other aroused countries of the world? Could anything except their own good times excite Whole-hearted enthusiasm in our youths? If not, are we content that they are unconcerned?
Senator Copeland said today that he had a mass of evidence on "subversive and communistic influences" to give to a special Senate committee which will investigate maritime labor troubles.
George C. Stebbins, whose musical compositions set a background for the late Dwight L. Moody's campaign to "Reduce the Population of Hell by a Million Souls," celebrated his 92d birthday today.

The Fieldston School basketball team captured first place in the northern division of the M.A.A.P.S. League yesterday, defeating Lincoln School, 38 to 27, in a play-off on the loser's court. Dick Shapiro led the attack with 14 points.

Capturing the 400-yard relay by a foot, Colgate brought about the first defeat for Amherst in Pratt pool. The score was 44--31. Gil Wright of the Jeffs led the scorers by taking the 220-yard freestyle and 150-yard backstroke races.

TWO parts of Thomas Mann's re-creation of the biblical story of Joseph have been published "Joseph and His Brothers" and "Young Joseph" With the publication of the third part, "Joseph in Egypt," it becomes fully evident that here is a literary event of the first magnitude, the revitalization of ancient mythical material in terms of universal and therefore also in terms of contemporary needs.

The Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral, decorated with green foliage and white blossoms, was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Miss Doris Lane Laidlaw to William Edward Dillmeier. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Vincent J. Hart.

The American Council on Education has just embarked on a fiveyear study of teacher education financed by a $200,000 grant from the General Education Board. The following article by the president of the council describes the objectives of the new project.

Two long-sought goals of American justice, reduction in the cost of appeals and expedition of their movement to higher courts, appear to be nearing achievement-- through- a steel tape that. will record. judicial proceedings and reproduce them verbatim.

Title to the 240,000-acre Trinchera ranch in Southern Colorado has been acquired by Mrs. Ruth Hanna McCormick Sims, publisher, and her husband, Albert Sims. Attorneys said they would take immediate possession but would continue their residence in Albuquerque, N. M. Part of the consideration, they added, was the Ruth Hanna McCormick cattle breeding ranch of 1,600 acres near Rockford, Ill.

The Toscanini concert with the NBC Symphony Orchestra, his tenth of the series given last night in Studio H-8 of Radio City, had the vitality and the creative quality which makes the listener feel that the particular concert he attends is different from all the other Toscanini concerts of the season.

AFTER a considerable interval, Eugene Ormandy returns to the lists, conducting the Philadelphia Orchestra in a most welcome recording of Beethoven's First symphony. Though few months elapse without a fresh version of one of the nine, in all recent re-recording cycles the First has been overlooked.

Furniture, Georgian silver, rugs and other furnishings from the estate of Eben J. Knowlton, together with property from other sources, will be sold at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

Mrs. James P. Hooper of Baltimore has sent out invitations for the wedding of her daughter, Miss Mathilde Benan Hooper, to Duncan Ives McNeill of Montreal, which will take place on March 5 at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Redeemer here.
With a record point score, Yale won the quadrangular indoor track and field meet from Harvard, Cornell and Dartmouth at the Boston Garden tonight before 4,500 spectators.

Victory by a yard in the 200-yard relay, the final event on the program, gave the undefeated Harvard freshman swimmers a 38-28 decision over Andover Academy today. It was the Harvard team's ninth triumph.

A shortage in domestic workers will be discussed at a meeting on Wednesday called by Mayor Charles A. Schaefer of Middletown, Conn. Representatives of sixty women's organizations have been invited to attend the conference, called for 3 P. M. in the Municipal Building.
Shoot-offs dominated the opening of the Middle Atlantic skeet-shooting championships at the Loantaka Skeet Club today as new titleholders were crowned in three divisions.

So much of paragraph 1, special orders 25, dated Feb. 21, 1938, as pertains to Capt. George F. Fisher, Inf.-Res., is revoked. Capt. George F. Fisher, Inf.-Res., 425 Fulton St.. Brooklyn, N. Y.. unassigned, is attached for training to the 77th Division. Each of the following reserve officers, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated:

National Socialism declared war on Christian Science on many counts today, but chiefly "because Mary Baker Eddy's philosophy from its roots up is neither German nor can it be brought into harmony with the principles of the party and of the Weltanschauung [philosophy] on which the State is founded."
Bill Kendall of Australia, Harvard sophomore and the fastest free-style swimmer in the British Empire, tonight set a world record for the 150-yard swim in the Harvard pool.
MONTREAL.-Canada's outsanding ski race, the Que bec Kandahar, will be help next Sunday down the steel slopes of Mont Tremblant, near St. Jovite, in the Laurentian Moun tains.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Feb. 23, aggregated $5,867,000,000, or 17 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 34 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.
MUCH of the present tension in international relations is being attributed to the refusal or inability of statesmen to give effective recognition to the fact that change is the rule in history.

Make-up was still tan on the plump face of Alexander Woollcott and his shirt was still off as he confirmed in a dressing-room interview late yesterday afternoon that he was a candidate for library trustee in the village of Castleton, Vt.

There are rumors in Moscow tonight that one of the highest officers of the Red Army, Marshal Alexander I. Yegoroff, is under a cloud as well as two distinguished generals whose names cannot yet be mentioned.

Last Wednesday night, when several hundred hoarse-voiced Hoosiers yelled and whooped and thousands of others milled about the swank Mayflower Hotel to partake of food and drink set out in honor of Paul Vories McNutt, the question arose in the minds of citizens all over the country: "Who is McNutt?"

Two resolutions calling upon Congress to adopt constitutional amendments eliminating tax exemptions on Federal securities and salaries of public officials will be introduced in the Legislature Monday evening by Perley A Pitcher, Republican minority leader of the Senate, and Abbot Low Moffat, Manhattan Republican, who is chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee.

WELL, it was a great campaign while it lasted and, even if he has nothing else to show for it, Samuel Goldwyn can boast a bulky scrapbook. Was it in 1932 or 1933 that he first announced "The Goldwyn Follies"? We disremember the year, but not the occasion.
Cornell's skiers won the two-day meet sponsored by the New York State Intercollegiate Ski Association held on the Colgate courses near here.

Except for a further recovery in Central European loans and continued strength in United States Government obligations. trading in bonds was routine in character in the two-hour trading period yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Checking a late rally, Penn State's basketball team defeated Syracuse tonight, 38 to 32. State moved ahead early as Sol Miehoff and Charley Prosser paced the attack and gained a 22-to-9 advantage at half time. The Orange came back strongly, however, making 16 points in the last ten minutes.

Colonel Noble Brandon Judah, who fought with distinction in the World War, was former Ambassador to Cuba and served in the fields of business, law and politics, died today at his home here. He was 53 years old.

ONE of the youngest men ever to have had his opera produced by the Metropolitan Opera Association is Gian-Carlo Menotti. His one-act comedy "Amelia Goes to the Ball," to be given Thursday evening, was begun when he was 22 years old. But that is not all.
Justice W. E. Middleton, who is deciding which Toronto mothers will share in the $500,000 Millar will baby derby, indicated day that he did not look sympathetically on Mrs. Pauline Mae
W. Gordon Furlong of Albany has announced to friends here the engagement of his sister, Miss M. Britta Furlong, to Donald M. Terry, son of Dr. and Mrs. Minor J. Terry, also of Albany.

ADOLF HITLER, Chancellor of the Third Reich and Fuehrer of the German people, served notice on the world last Sunday that Germany was again a great power which demands her place in the sun and that if this place was denied to her she had the military and economic means to obtain it by her own will and strength.
The Rutgers freshman swimming team vanquished the Columbia yearlings in the losers' pool yesterday, 36 to 30. William Buckley and Robert Faulkner starred for the Winners.
Joe Fontana, 129, East Side, outpointed Nickey Jerome, 126 1/2, Ridgewood, in the eight-round feature event at the Ridgewood Grove last night before a crowd of 3,000.

BALBOA, C. Z.--Interest in and participation in athletic sports probably have been the greatest aid in the emancipation of Latin American women from the cloistered life imposed upon them for generations by customs transplanted from Spain.

The ancient city of Van, capital of the kingdom of the same name and a flourishing trade center of Asia Minor until its destruction by Scythian armies about 600 B. C., will be the scene of excavations this Summer under the direction of a joint archaeological expedition of Brown University and the University of Pennsylvania.
When H. G. Wells wrote "The War of the Worlds,' more than a generation ago, he pictured his invaders from Mars as a good deal like octopi--a brain equipped with tentacles.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor K. Fry, daughter of Mrs. Wilfred W. Fry of this city and the late Mr. Fry, to Randall H. Decker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Randall H. Decker of Montclair, N. J., took place here this afternoon at Ayer House, the home of the bride's mother.

Expenditures of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and Vicinity exceeded receipts last year by $36,609, according to the annual report and financial statement sent to the union's 3,226 members yesterday by Joseph Simons, president.

A written message was received here this morning from the American yacht Discovery II, which has been stranded for several days on Joulters Cay, north of Andros Island. A Bahamas Airways plane was sent out at midday and will probably take the party to Miami, Fla.
At the end of an ill-starred adventure that cost him the savings of ten years, John Gau, 35, a cook, returned from Europe yesterday on the United States liner President Roosevelt to go back to work.
Opportunities for sales of tires in South Africa were pointed out today in a statement by the leather and rubber division of the Department of Commerce.

Although officials of thirty-four States have approved the use of case-hardened glass in passenger automobiles, and although automobile manufacturers have approved the use of this type of glass, an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner has recommended that the commission bar its use as unsafe for buses and trucks engaged in interstate commerce.

The Roosevelt Administration took a step today toward sharing helium gas with other countries of the world. Its action was in accord with a promise made shortly after the explosion of the hydrogen-filled German zeppelin Hindenburg at Lakehurst, N. J., last year.
THAT hardy tribe of hurrying commuters who come and go by ferryboat will soon suffer a sharp decrease in membership. In a few months ferryboat...

Handshaking, once a gentle gesture of agreement, peace or friendship, continues in modern times to develop painful consequences--as the retiring Governor of New Jersey recently discovered when the ceremony raised a blister on his right hand.

After numerous last-minute obstacles, Rosamund Lehmann's dramatization of her own novel, "No More Music," will be given its first stage presentation by the International Theatre Club at the Duke of York's Theatre on Sunday and the two following Sundays.
A question being constantly asked is: "What is likely to be the practical effect at this stage of the Civil War of an agreement for the withdrawal of foreign 'volunteers' from Spain?"
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Continuation of a long list of National conventions of various educators' associations finds thousands of delegates planning to remain here through next Thursday.
The tense spring with which a sprint champion responds to the crack of the gun is demonstrated by Perrin Walker, who won the 100-meter N. A. A. U. championship at Milwaukee last July.

A large contribution to the development of military and civil aviation has been made by the relief agencies of the government, which, in five years, has expended more than $100,000,000 in the construction of hundreds of airports throughout the country.

The Women's Field Army, organized two years ago under the American Society for the Control of Cancer and sponsored by the General Federation of Women's Clubs, has withdrawn from New York City, leaving the City Cancer Committee under Dr. John C. A. Gerster in charge of a program with a similar goal. The State cancer program will be administered from Rochester.

The international scene, viewed from the German end of the Rome-Berlin axis, remains essentially unclarified, though the Austro-German agreement of Feb. 12 and the foreshadowed reorientation of British foreign policy suggest progress toward a European settlement.

Anthony Valentino, 21 years old, obeyed an impulse last night that has tempted all moviegoers. Disturbed by the floundering about of two men in front of him in the Allerton Theatre, 744 Allerton Avenue, the Bronx, he hit one of them in the eye.

A net profit of $1,426,413 for 1937 was reported yesterday by the INational Acme Company after deductions for depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and provisions of $182,000 for surtax on undistributed earnings. The profit was equal to $2.85 each on 500,000 shares of $1 par capital stock and compared with $688,373, or $1.37 a share, earned in 1936.

Thomas (Ching) Hare, Ontario racetrack owner, died of apoplexy here last night at the age of 72. Mr. Hare owned the Long Branch and Dufferin Park tracks at Toronto, Queens Park at London and Kenilworth at Windsor.
The Stevens Tech five downed a visiting Bard team, 41-26, in the closing game of the season for Stevens. The lead changed five times in a close first half, Stevens emerging on top, 20-16.

Members of the Bronxville Women's Club will hear a lecture by George Sokolsky tomorrow at 10 A. M. at the clubhouse on the subject of "Labor's Fight for Power." The civic department of the club, meeting jointly with the Bronxville League for Service, Wednesday at 8:30 P. M., will hear Dr. Matthias Nicoll Jr., retiring county health commissioner, discuss "Facts of Health and Disease Control."

Senator Edward R. Burke, Nebraska Democrat, called upon America tonight to preserve free enterprise. Speaking at a banquet to William E. Benswanger, retiring as president of the Amen Corner, Senator Burke declared that the need was a union of "progressive conservatives," a union in which there should be no room for either the reactionary or the radical.

Tiger Jack Fox, 182 1/2, Spokane, stopped Gene Mickens, 182, Weehawken, last night at the Rockland Palace when Referee Jack O'Sulivan halted the scheduled tenround engagement in 2:11 of the first before a crowd of 2,800.

Confidence that the State Legislature will appropriate $345,000 next week to begin construction of a $750,000 extension of the Cross County Parkway at Dunwoodie, Yonkers, was expressed here today by Westchester members of the Legislature.

FOX, JAMES J. (Aug. 24, 1936). Gross estate, $130,775; net, $123,367. To wife, Therese Fox, dower interest in estate: residuary to a number of nieces and nephews. Chief assets, real estate, 570,000; stocks and bonds, $66,012. James H. Gilvarry, 26 Court St.; Harvey O. Dobson, 189 Montague St., and Ed. J. Flandrey, 44 Court St. attorneys.

The glory of the theatre in the Nineties will be revived tonight in a celebration of the forty-fifth birthday of the Professional Women's League-one of the oldest theatrical organizations among women in America. In the clubrooms at the Hotel Ansonia, festivities will get under way at 9 P. M., with a program of music and song and the exchange of reminiscences among celebrities of another day and those who are still trouping.

Founder's Day will be celebrated at the Chapin Home for the Aged and Infirm on Thursday afternoon at the headquarters of the home 165th Street and Chapin Parkway Jamaica, Queens. The occasion will mark the sixty-ninth anniversary of the founding of the institution.

Miss Mollie Porter Cullum, daughter of Mrs. J. Barlow Cullum of Pittsburgh and Reading, Pa., also of New York, and of the late Mr. Cullum, was married to Charles Freeman Shelden of New York this afternoon in the Great Hall of the Indian Creek Club.

A secret agreement among sixty prominent singers and conductors of the Metropolitan Opera Company, during the dark days of 1934-35, to carry on the performances, come what may, led to the arrangement with the Juilliard Foundation that made it unnecessary for the famed opera house

Business was at a low ebb in the foreign exchange market here today. The tendency to close commitments pending an official pronouncement on French foreign policy caused a generally firm tone in the franc. The spot rate improved to 153 21-32 francs to the pound sterling and the three-month discount to 4 3/8 francs.

THE wonder is, remarks the author of this book, that in the history of the sea mutinies have been comparatively so few. With bad living conditions, the stigma of an evil reputation whether it was deserved or not, long hours of hard work

ARNIVAL at Huejotzingo, a sleepy, predominantly Indian town on the Mexico City Puebla highway, takes the form not of a battle of flowers, but of a battle with blank cartridges, in which the sound of musketry and the smell of powder fill the air.

Now that March is almost here, Winter is virtually over and the women golfers who have been campaigning in Florida for the past two months will be planning for tournaments they will enter on their homeward journey.

Following a two-hour conference with President Roosevelt on the Philippine Islands, Paul V. McNutt, High Commissioner, indicated that no change in the government or economy of the islands is planned at this time.
SIMILAR to developments in the United States, the automobile in Germany is more and more becoming one of the mainstays of German industry.

CONGRESS has been hearing again about American food. The last time the subject was apple pie; this time it is cheese. When cheese was served in the Senate restaurant recently-with the compliments of the Senators from New York-a Wisconsin Senator rose to say a few words from the floor about the product of his home State.

A CONTEST offering three cash prizes totaling $175 for the best pictures of dancers in action is now being conducted by the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences in the Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn.

One of the features of War Commissar Klementy E. Voroshiloff's speech on the twentieth anniversary of the Red Army was the stress he laid on the connection between the army and the Communist party in Soviet Russia.

Students at the University of Pennsylvania will have no difficulty in achieving a state of art consciousness during the coming month. Seven special exhibits are to be open to them on the campus in March.
A bitter squabble which may develop into a row of the first magnitude has broken out in the Democratic party of Massachusetts. Governor Charles F. Hurley wants a second term.

Operators of three new passenger and freight ships that are scheduled to enter the transatlantic service flying the flags of Great Britain, Holland and Norway, received reports of progress from the shipyards last week as the ships approached completion.

Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury entertained today with a large reception at El Mirasol in celebration of Mr. Stotesbury's eighty-ninth birthday. George MacDonald gave a dinner at Whitehall for Surrogate and Mrs. James A. Foley, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Howland Graham, Mrs. Charles Lewis Harding, Mrs. Glenn Hodges, Henry MacDonald and Prince George of Russia.

The Boot and Shoe Workers Union, A. F. of L., was chosen by employes of the Novelty Slipper Company, 121 West Nineteenth Street, as their collective bargaining representative in a National Labor Relations Board election, the results of which were announced yesterday.

The Boot and Shoe Workers Union, A. F. of L., was chosen by employes of the Novelty Slipper Company, 121 West Nineteenth Street, as their collective bargaining representative in a National Labor Relations Board election, the results of which were announced yesterday.
Al Stevens's successful free toss brought the Yale basketball forces a 39-38 victory over Georgetown in a thrilling overtime battle before 750 fans in the Payne Whitney gymnasium tonight.

A legislative investigation of the profit-sharing system as it exists in industry and of "self-government of industry through self-regulation" will be asked by Irving M. Ives, Republican majority leader of the Assembly, in a resolution to be submitted Monday night.
SCOUT training in observation and tracking in the out-of-doors has often proved of real value to the community on those occasions when the police need help in their search for missing persons.

LONDON. --Great difficulty has developed recently in filling vacancies in the London police force. The Metropolitan Police Force is over 1,800 short of its authorized strength of 20,000 and enlistments continue to decline.

Because of improvements made recently by the trustees for the Series B-K mortgage certificate issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, the gross rent roll of the properties controlled by the trust estate has increased 7 per cent and the actual rents collected have increased 4.3 per cent, according to a report filed yesterday with Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.
Charles J. Schmidt Jr., 19, surrendered this afternoon in the investigation of the ambush killing Thursday night of his father's business partner, Edward C. Richard, 59.

Miss Edythe Mae Kolter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis D. Kolter of this place, was married to Walter Hugh Whiteman, son of Mrs. Walter R. Whiteman, this afternoon in Westminster Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Raymond W. Smiley.
Associate Justice Hugo L. Black, youngest member of the Supreme Court, will be 52 years old tomorrow. Any observance of the occasion, associates indicated, will be a quiet family affair.

Declaring that no study of the effect of fair trade laws upon living costs can be complete if it is confined merely to items which formerly were loss-leaders, William H. Ingersoll, fair-trade consultant and leader in the movement

Professor P. W. Bridgman of Harvard, famous for his discoveries about the way water and common metals act when subjected to pressures of hundreds of tons to the square inch, recently told the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers that he has increased the working range of his apparatus.

Three apple green and gold Sevres porcelain vases were sold yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries for $925. The vases were the property of Captain Reginald S. Jaffray, who on Coronation day last May in London hung a banner outside his apartment reading, "God Save the Duke of Windsor."

PLANS for an organization that would protect the American composer and assure him of a reasonable return for his creative product were partiallyoutlined on this page of THE TIMES a month ago. These plans have been completed and they are briefly summarized in a statement just issued by the American Composers Alliance.

If one looked only at the surface, the so-called ultimatum of Hitler to Austria, which led to the inclusion of Nazis in key posts in the Vienna Cabinet, seemed to mark a great success for the German dictator and thus a new success for fascist government. However, the ominous quiet which marked other European capitals indicated at the time that something might be developing which did not momentarily appear on the surface.

Professor John F. Haines, educator, died today at the age of 81. He was a teacher for sixty years, organized the first boys' corn club and was the first instructor to introduce manual training and domestic science in Indiana schools.
The National Small Business Men's Association, Inc., tentatively has set the first week in June as the date of its national convention to be held in some Midwestern city.

Fifteen members of the propaganda center of Major Ferenc Szalasi's Nazis were arrested here today and pamphlets destined for distribution tomorrow containing virulent attacks on the Premier and his Cabinet were seized.

Since pioneer experiments in growing seedlings in sand were described on this page two years ago several improvements have been made in the method. These result in less labor and more certain seedling growth.

Professor Frank Schlesinger of Yale University and Mrs. Schlesinger today announced the engagement of Mrs. Schlesinger's daughter, Miss Katharine Rawling Wilcox, to William Wright Matthews of New York.
Building construction contracts awarded during January for work in the metropolitan area aggregated $44,250,000, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.
Consul General Clarence E. Gauss today made representations to the Japanese against the sealing of Americans' warehouses in foreign areas of Shanghai.
PAUL HINDEMITH will be the assisting artist at the pair of concerts to be given this Thursday night and Friday afternoon by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, under Hans Lange, in Chicago.
A forum on drugs, with pharmacist, consumer, physician and manufacturer participating, has been arranged for Tuesday at 8 P. M. by the Advertising Women of New York.
Five thousand secondary school students throughout the United States are expected to register for series of College entrance and scholarship tests to be given by the College Entrance Examination

The eighteenth annual enrollment campaign for the Citizens Military Training Camps will open Tuesday in New York, New Jersey and Delaware, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of Major Gen, Frank R. McCoy, commanding the Second Corps Area. Places will be open for 6,800 men.

The stock market here was dull but steady early this week; later it was more active and fairly firm.
A program "to keep America out of war" was made public yesterday over the signatures of 300 civic, labor, educational and religious leaders in this city.

Louisa Viviani, 9 years old, of 721 East 219th Street, was burned to death at 1 o'clock this morning and her aunt, Mrs. Rosa Celantino, 38, was severely burned when fire destroyed the two-story frame house in which they lived.
James A. McCarthy, who was with the Fifth Avenue Association for thirteen years, will begin tomorrow his new duties as executive secretary of the Hotel Association of New York City.

The Smiths and the Browns were breaking a law when they sat down to their weekly game of bridge here today. So were the storekeeper who sold candy and the restaurateur who served oysters with his Sunday dinner.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph Fort Newton will become rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Luke and the Epiphany here on April 1.

Both right and left-wing educator in an unusual line-up went on record here today as opposing the section of the report of President Roosevelt's Advisory Committee on Edu. cation that recommends allocation of Federal funds to parochial and other non-public schools.

Stem Dress Shop, store at 2,423 Broadway; A. V. Amy Co., brokers. Louis B. Ladoux, upholstery, in 220 5th Ave; William Charton, photographer; Mizrachi Organization of America, in 1.133 Broadway; Max and Joseph Silverman, furriers, in 312 7th Ave: Lincoln Paper Co., store at 104 Bleecker St: Regent Schiffle Embroidery Co., in 124 Bleecker St; Spear Co., brokers.
Beneficial rains fell over the Texas Panhandle last week, but the moisture received elsewhere in the Winter wheat belt was confined largely to the more eastern sections.

To night all is quiet on the eastern coast of the Caribbean. "War" may be declared any time after 10 o'clock tomorrow morning. It will be a wa?? employing every available means o?? attack and defense that Uncle Sam?? has on the Atlantic Coast from New?? England to the Canal Zone, from battleships to submarines and from airplanes to tanks.

What will be next? This morning a man brought us a patent form to show he had obtained Patent No. 2,103,222 on a fishing float that "talks" when the angler gets a bite. We say "talks," but actually the float makes a noise that you'd probably spell "phluuup" as the fish pulls it beneath the surface.
Paul A. Wright walked out of the county jail into a pelting rain and freedom today as California's courts dropped prosecution of him forkilling his wife and his friend, John Kimmel.

Mr. and Mrs. William Russell Grace of the Waldorf-Astoria, who have been visiting New York friends, will return today to Aiken, S. C., accompanied by their daughters, the Misses Elise and Patricia Grace.

Minus a defending titleholder, the world pocket billiard championship tournament will get under way tonight at the Capitol Bowling and Billard Academy, where for the next two weeks twelve of the leading cue experts will see action in the roundrobin tourney. Sixty-six matches are on the schedule.

Five hundred members of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, C. I. O. union of civil service workers, will travel to Albany in two contingents today and Wednesday to press for passage of the organization's legislative program.

Sergei Eisenstein, once the best known cinema producer in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, whose "Potemkin" was the first Soviet film to win world-wide fame, has just arrived in Leningrad to produce a new patriotic film, "Russ."

The Opportunity Shop, a subsidiary of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor located at 46 West Forty-seventh Street, will hold a special sale this week. Articles on sale will be a group of antiques including the complete furnishings of a nineteenroom home which were recently bequeathed to the shop.
Walter Emery pounded out invincible golf today to unseat Edwin McClure, 5 and 4, as defending champion in the Houston Country Club's invitation tournament.

The engagement of Miss Florence Dodd Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Sullivan of this place, to Edmund Ambrose Lynch of New York and Cedarhurst, son of Mrs. Edmund A. Lynch of New York and the late Mr. Lynch, has been announced by her parents.

No change in the economic picture occurred last week; none had been expected. Steel production decreased slightly from 31 per cent of capacity to 30, which compared with 32 1/2 at the end of January, the highest thus far in 1938 and with the lowest, 25 1/2, in the first week of January.
Morris L. Shapera, orthodox Jewish leader and president of the Anshe Sholom congregation, died of a heart attack Saturday at Miami, Fla. He was 53 years old.
Hypocrisy, we have been taught, is the homage that vice pays to virtue. Similarly it might be said that a plebiscite is the homage which modern despotism pays to democracy.

The White Plains Nursing Association will be the beneficiary of a concert and dance Friday night at the Westchester Country Club here. Proceeds of the event, which will be featured by a program of songs by the Amherst College Glee Club, will be used to found a hospitalization fund for nurses of the association.

Royal Air Force planes today resumed search for Great Britain's missing mystery plane on receipt of a report that wreckage had been seen in the Cheviot Hills, near Langholm, on Scotland's southern border.
The beginning of the Lenten perior on Wednesday will be the signal for numerous advertising campaigns to promote substitutes for meat, agency executives said here yesterday.

Declaring that the Securities and Exchange Commission already has, under Section 15-C of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, complete authority to deal with any fraudulent or deceptive practices by over-thecounter security dealers, including dealers in State and municipal securities,
William Greenebaum, formerly with Pioneer Suspender Company, has been appointed production manager of Frank Braces, and is in charge of the plant at Attleboro, Mass.

Citing "so-called scientific proof," the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday that he believed literally in the story of Jonah and the whale.

Led by Miss Helen Pedersen of Stamford, a field of thirty-two players will start out in the women's national indoor tennis championships at 11 A. M. today at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.
Dr. John H. Wilday of 140 West Sixty-ninth Street, retired captain in the 244th Coast Artillery, New York National Guard, died at Kings Park Hospital on Saturday at the age of 71.

Removal of divisional barriers in the Republican party and the formation of social and athletic programs to stimulate the interest of youth were recommended informally today by several National Young Republican leaders.
Mr. and Mrs. E. Martin Browne and Ashley Dukes, who are here from London, were the guests of honor at a tea and reception given yesterday by Mrs. Cornelius J. Sullivan at her studio, 460 Park Avenue.

The missionaries throughout the world have probably the most responsible tasks in the universe, not excluding even diplomatic services or the League of Nations, John J. De Valdis, missionary serving in Katpadi, India, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street.
The annual coronation service of St. Mary's Court, Order of Sir Galahad, was held at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon at St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Church, 521 West 126th Street.

The new business of this evening, at the Martin Beck Theatre, is "Save Me the Waltz," or Kathanihe Dayton's comedy about romance in a totalitarian State. This is the Miss Dayton who, with George S. Kaufman, wrote "First Lady" in 1935; her name alone is signed to this one, with Mr. Kaufman in the background as a sort of consultant..

Prices of lard on the Board of Trade were on the upgrade last week and reached the highest levels since early in November in sympathy with cottonseed oil, which advanced to the highest points of the season.
Charles Christman, for forty-two years a court stenographer in this city, died Saturday night at his home, 93-07 Hollis Court Boulevard, Hollis, after a two weeks' illness.
Pennsylvania's Department of Banking distributed $377,252 to creditors and shareholders of 348 closed building and loan associations in 1937, Governor George H. Earle announced today.
The discovery of their five bodies disclosed today the mass slaying of a prominent Indian patriot and members of his family.

Social, vocational and educational problems. of young people were discussed at a conference on youth, under sponsorship of the metropolitan section of the Jewish Welfare Board, at the community house of Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixtyfifth Street, yesterday afternoon and evening.
Asbjorn Ruud of Norway won the world ski jumping championship at Lahti today with 226.4 points. A crowd of 50,000 saw the event.

Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General, will address the Bond Club of New York at its luncheon meeting on March 9 in the Bankers Club. George F. Ainslie Jr., manager of the Columbus (Ohio) branch of the American Surety Company of New York and the New York Casualty Company,

The rise on the Paris Bourse at the beginning of the week indicates the great hopes that the new British policy brings to financial circles here in view of the maintenance of peace, and it is believed that the risks of war have diminished for the moment.

THOMAS MANN'S magnificent story of "Joseph in Egypt"* towers over most of this century's novels very much as the pyramids tower over the Egyptian land. It is the third part of a sweeping work on a vast plan, and it is still far from any final ending.
The German index of wholesale prices on Feb. 16 stood at 105.5, unchanged from the week before.
A saving to the New York Central Railroad through the enactment of the present railway pension law is indicated in the detailed statement of its proft-and-loss account for 1937.
The robin, the crocus and the skunk cabbage may engage in a race to reveal the earliest news of Spring, but two infallible signs of the season appeared in the papers last Friday.

The New Year's Eve theft of a collection of ancient Central American art from Harvard University's Peabody Museum and nearly a score of burglaries in Greater Boston within the past few months were believed solved tonight with the arrest of a Cambridge house painter, who told police he was forced to resort to crime to save his wife and three children from starvation.

Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General in this city, and Lady Campbell gave a luncheon yesterday in the Gold Room of the Plaza for Sir Josiah Stamp, economist and director of the Bank of England, and Lady Stamp, who arrived here Saturday on their way back from Australia to London.

Mayor La Guardia's appeal to legislative leaders for additional funds from the State to enable the city to handle adequately what he termed a "precarious" relief situation appears destined to meet with rejection this week.

The Armstrong Cork Company reports net income for 1937 of $5,157,886, after interest, depreciation and allowance for Federal income taxes and the surtax on undistributed profits. This was equivalent to $3.99 a share on the common stock. Net income for 1936 was $5,277,534, or $4.36 a share.

Troops, police and armored cars were sent to Graz, capital of Styria, last night by the government in view of the serious situation created there by the plans of local Nazis for a parade of 60,000 under the slogan "against Communist manoeuvres In the Fatherland Front."
Montreal's Canadiens came from behind in the third period to gain a 1-1 overtime tie with the last-place Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game played before 8,700 spectators tonight.

Former residents of Evanston, Ill., now living in New York or near-by communities will meet Wednesday at the New York Junior League Club House, 221 East Seventy-first Street, for their fourth annual luncheon. Mrs. Ernest V.

The wheat market fluctuated in a most erratic manner last week, with prices averaging somewhat higher. largely because of a sharp advance on Wednesday, when there was a wave of general buying based on unexpected strength in foreign markets over the Washington Birthday holiday and a stronger undertone in securities and commodities in general.
Charging that the large milk distributors had used the provisions of the Rogers-Allen act only to organize themselves and that it left the little man, whether distributor or farmer,

Although Germany's politicians acclaimed the changes in the British Foreign Office as favoring the Reich, the financial markets remained cold. There was, indeed, some transient firmness in stocks, but this was derived from the signs of improvement in Wall Street.
Captain Wendell J. Wilson, former Port of Seattle engineer, who received the French Military Medal simultaneously with General John J. Pershing, died here today at the age of 58.

Champion Nonquitt Notable, black cocker spaniel owned by Mrs. Henry A. Ross of Philadelphia and handled by Tom Godfrey, won the special for the best in show tonight at the close of the fourteenth annual allbreed dog show of the Kennel Club of Buffalo, Inc.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A Western educator said in a recent speech: "Americans have many opinions, but few ideas." An article in The Economist of London on the Administration's economic theories would indicate that other peoples also are subject to the same qualification.

With the George Washington Bridge established as a utilitarian success, the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it was ready to go forward with plans to improve its esthetic appearance.
Shooting in almost local darkness tonight, Dave Sklaar of Brooklyn won the individual Middle Atlantic all-gauge skeet-shooting championship in a third shoot-off.
Associate Justice Hugo L. Black was 52 years old today. Friends said that the youngest member of the Supreme Court spent his birthday quietly at his Virginia home across the Potomac from Washington.
Dr. James A. Spalding, oldest alumnus of Dartmouth College, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 91 years old.

JOSEPH IN EGYPT, by Thomas Mann. (Knopf, $5.) The story of Joseph and Potiphar's wife. THOMAS MANN'S JOSEPH STORY, by Harry Slochower. (Knopf, $1.) an interpretation with a biographical and bibliographical appendix.

Pleas for the orderly development of tolerance and democracy in the United States, despite the tendency toward totalitarian forms of government abroad, were made last night at a symposium in the auditorium of the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged, 813 Howard Avenue.

A communique issued today after the close of the Balkan Entente sessions here declared that the member States-Yugoslavia, Rumania, Greece and Turkey-were determined to remain faithful to the League of Nations.
The big ski carnival Los Angeles had planned today in the Coliseum, with five snow machines providing the surface, had to be postponed because of rain.

The particular interest taken in the British Board of Trade's annual report of England's balance of payments during 1937, on "visible" and "invisible" account, arose from the year's unusually large surplus of merchandise imports over exports.

A 19-year-old interscholastic star, Edward Gignae of Kimball Union Academy of Meriden, N. H., today furnished the biggest upset in the sixteen-year competitive history of the United States Amateur Ski Association.

Michael F. Shanley, for forty years a business man here, died last night at his home at the age of 71. He was formerly associated with his cousins, the Shanley brothers, restaurant owners of New York, in the ownership and control of the Lighthouse Point property until the city of New Haven purchased it for the Public Park.
Four of Wagner's great music-dramas will be presented during next week, the penultimate week of the Metropolitan Opera season. The week's schedule follows:

The slow advance of India toward responsible self-government is threatened with a new and perhaps serious setback. Two of the seven Congress (independence) party provincial Cabinets, which took office last Summer under the new Constitution, have resigned because the British Governors, invoking their "safeguard" powers, vetoed the immediate release of all political prisoners.

Sir Wilfred Grenfell-better known as "Grenfell of Labrador"-will no doubt be as ready on this his seventythird birthday as he was three years ago to subscribe to the statement which he then made in an interview upon his arrival here on his way to his frigid field of work:

A children's matinee performance of the Passion play "Veronica's Veil" was presented in Veronica's Veil Auditorium here today by the St. Paul cast. The official opening for the season will be next Sunday evening.

The nation's traffic fatalities in January showed a decline of 17 per cent from a year ago and 30 per cent from December, 1937, the National Safety Council reported today, calling this "an encouraging start for 1938."

Dalies Frantz, who made a brilliant first appearance on the local scene five years ago, still promises to become one of America's firstrate pianists. In his recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon-he indicated that he has made advances in some directions,

Qualities which make a leader in public life outstanding, and which spur men of greatness to attain their goals when others fail, were analyzed by the Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires yesterday morning. The Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Long Island spoke at St. Thomas

John C. Abbott, 32 years old, of 19 West Thirty-fourth Street, who, during an altercation on Friday in the New York Public Library, Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue, was struck three times on the head with a hatchet wielded by Charles Frankel,

The existence in the United States of a "blacklist" of religious and political leaders active against subversive forces, compiled by radicals, was charged by the Marquesa Anderson de Cienfuegos, formerly Jane Anderson, war correspondent,
General Frank T. Hines will be honored at a dinner Tuesday night on the completion of fifteen years as Administrator of Veterans' Affairs.

ALBANY-John C. Myers Co.; Miss M. L. Bindheitel, handbags; 11 W. 42d (F. Atkins). ALBANY-John G. Myers Co.; D. A. Rappaport, millinery; 9 E. 37th. ATLANTA-Davison-Paxon Co.; Mrs. G. Ford, C. B. Willard, Mrs. P. Rutherford, millinery; 9 E. 37th. ALTOONA-Wm. F. Gable Co.; R. C. Peck, millinery; 9 E. 37th.
Dr. Claude Granville Crane, a surgeon specializing in diseases of the throat, ear and nose, who had practiced in Brooklyn for many years, died yesterday at his home, 353 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn.
The government candidate, Sir John Anderson, today won the House of Commons seat left vacant by the death of J. Ramsay MacDonald, former Prime Minister.

Here is the February supplement of the United States Official Postal Guide, that ancient and valued visitor. It is curmudgeonly to quarrel with a guest; and our cause is of the smallest, save to those conservatives who hold the doctrine of the elder world, of "primitive" peoples, now that names are an essential part of the named and subject to the processes of magic. Mr.

John Beck, 69 years old, a caretaker, died of smoke inhalation today in a fire in the basement of the century-old Weir mansion at 949 Danielson Street here. The cause of the blaze, which was quickly extinguished after two alarms were sounded, was undetermined.

The advance guard of the Cleveland Indians opened Spring training today with a light one-hour workout. On hand were Manager Oscar Vitt, Coach Wally Schang, Pitchers Bob Feller, Denny Galehouse, Ken Jungles,

Speculative interest in grains on the Board of Trade last week was the smallest so far this year, the average daily volume of sales being about 17,000,000 bushels, or 7,500,000 less than in the preceding week and 23,000,000 less than a year ago.

Opposition of some delegates led today to reports that Jesse Owens's times of 10.2 and 10.3 seconds for 100 meters might not be recognized as world record performances when the International Amateur Athletic Federation meets tomorrow.

Staving off a closing rally by the losers, the New York Athletic Club triumphed over the Brooklyn Bruins, 5--4, in the first of the twogame, total-goal semi-final playoff for the New York Amateur Hockey Association championship yesterday at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

The theatre has turned to religion and the church has turned to politics, the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

Officially designated as a day for celebration of triumphs in sports in a proclamation issued by Governor Winship, Puerto Rico tomorrow will honor Sixto Escobar's recapture of the bantamweight title from Harry Jeffra and the return of the island athletes from Panama.
Brazil is facing an era of business and industrial expansion, in the opinion of American business men who returned on the French liner Normandie yesterday after a visit to Rio de Janeiro.

New York University's varsity baseball team will play twenty games this Spring, according to the schedule announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics. The Violet will open its campaign April 2 against the alumni at Ohio Field and close at home against Fordham on May 30.

Fred Perry defeated Ellsworth Vines, 4-6, 7-5, 6-3, today to pull within two matches of the Californian in their current professional tennis series. Vines has won fourteen matches and Perry twelve. They played a backcourt game, with Vines frequently netting his returns.

The West Side Association of Commerce, by order of its executive committee, has written to Police Commissioner Valentine, opposing the holding of the proposed "preview" parade of the World's Fair, on April 30, on Seventh or Eighth Avenues.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls built up an early lead tonight and coasted to a 5-to-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League contest. The Orioles made no threat until the final period, when they scored their only goals.

Ground was broken yesterday afternoon for the new building of the Grace Methodist Episcopal Church at 114th Avenue and 200th Street, St. Albans. Laurence W. Thurber, chairman of the building committee, turned the first spadefull of earth.
L. A. Downs, president of the Illinois Central system, announced today that the headquarters of the board of directors of the railroad company would be transferred here from New York.
The Spanish Government reported today that Insurgent attacks on the Eastern front had been repulsed with heavy losses for Generalissimo Francisco Franco's troops.

The first in a series of card parties to aid in the care and clothing of the needy in the district of the Polyclinic Medical School and Hospital, 341 West Fiftieth Street, will be held this afternoon in the Assembly Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France for Feb. 17 shows no change in gold reserves or in advances to the State. Aggregate loans and discounts fell approximately 400,000,000 francs on the week.
Mrs. Blanche McLane of the Ski Club Carcajou won the women's Eastern slalom championship in the Balch Hill course today. Miss Maria Volkhardt of the same club was second, only 2.2 seconds behind.

The Players' fifteenth annual Spring revival will be a program of eight or ten scenes from plays in which its sounder, Edwin Booth, had important roles. The plan was revealed last night at a "Pipe Night" at the club,

The organization of religious services under the direction of Rome now has been established in the Barcelona Diocese by authority of the Vicar General, under whom about 2,500 priests registered in Barcelona are allowed to perform religious services in private.

Present-day peace movements are motivated by "childlike" fear of war and have no constructive programs based upon a clear understanding of the causes of war, Algernon D. Black. instructor in ethics at the Fieldston School, said yesterday in a talk at the Society of Ethical Culture, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

With the 185-pound captain of Columbia's football team cast as Mae West and an assortment of knobbykneed undergraduates prancing in chorus routine, the Columbia varsity show will return this Spring to its all-male tradition after a sad experience with bona fide ingenues and chorus girls.

Three leading members of the New York State Assembly, representing the parties that make up the lower house, emphasized the harmony and close cooperation that have prevailed among all parties during the 1938 session in reporting last night on behalf of their legislative groups over Station WNYC.

Dr. Thomas S. McCabe, a surgeon on the staff of St. James Hospital here and a captain in the Medical Corps during the World War, died last night of pneumonia at his home, 26 Renner Avenue, after a week's illness.

Making a clean sweep of the six races, Leonard Romagna sailed Jenny to a decisive victory over the Class D ten-footers in the Manhasset Bay Dinghy Association's racing off this place today in the rain and a streaky southwest breeze.
The wholesale price index on Feb. 19 was 611, compared with 607 on Feb. 12 and with 610 on Feb. 5. The rise was due chiefly to higher world prices and to the decline of the franc.
CENSORED, a melodramatic comedy in three acts, by Conrad Seiler and Max Marcin. Staged by Mr. Marcin; settings by Nicholas Yellenti; produced by A. H. Woods. At the Forty-sixth Street Theatre.

Mrs. Cora Morlang, 64 years old, of 353 Livingston Avenue, Lyndhurst, was stricken with a heart attack this afternoon while attending a vesper service at the Rutherford Baptist Church in Rutherford and died a few minutes later.

Undeterred by warnings from manufacturers and national union officials alike, 15,000 Philadelphia hosiery workers prepared tonight to begin a city-wide strike tomorrow morning, with a view to' tying up the operations of sixty-five factories.

Dr. Sam Atkinson of the International Catholic Truth Society will speak on the need for better understanding between Jews and Christians at the first of a series of annual good-will dinners for Roman Catholics. Jews and Protestants,

BARRECA-Rocco, on Feb. 26, devoted father of D. F. Barreca, loving grandfather of June, Lillian and Robert. Funeral from the Edward D. Lynch, Inc., Funeral Home, 43-07 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, on Tuesday, at 9:45 A. M. Solemn Requiem Mass St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church, 10 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

If Filipino leaders are pleased or displeased by Washington dispatches hinting at the possible postponement beyond 1946 of independence from the United States because of upset Far Eastern conditions they are 'not saying much about it.

The Riverhead Savings Bank sold to Sara. Hershkowitz and Bertha Wieder the two-story factory on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 32-36 Morton Street, Brooklyn, through Frank r. Fischer, broker. The buyers leased the building to the Imperial-Wonder Dye Works.

The consolidated net income of the Freeport Sulphur Company last year amounted to $2,703,742 after all charges, according to the annual report to be made public today by Langbourne M. Williams Jr., president.

Supreme Court Justice Algeron I. Nova was elected yesterday for a third successive term as president of the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities at the organization's twenty-eighth annual meeting in Union Temple, 17 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

Reduction of costs, repeal or modification of unsound tax laws and restoration of confidence are the problems facing government, industry and labor in their efforts to restore the construction industry to its rightful place in the general recover movement,

Chaarles Whitehead of Plainfield, N. J., and his partner, Frank Allan of Pittston, Pa., won the annual Miami Biltmore amateur four-ball golf tournament today, defeating S. C. Anderson and T. E. Price, both of Coral Gables, by 3 and 2 in the 36-hole final. Whitehead has been a co-winner of the tourney four times in the last five years.
The congregation of the Immanuel Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Eighty-eighth Street, started a celebration of the church's diamond jubilee yesterday morning at a special festival service.

The Brooklyn Jewels gained undisputed possession of the lead by defeating Kate Smith's Celtics, 37 to 36, while the Jersey Reds vanquished the Brooklyn Visitations, 40 to 37, in an American Basketball League double-header before a crowd of 4,000 at the Hippodrome last night.

Harry Sussman and Michael Schnitzel of 512 Smith Street, Brooklyn, have entered into a stipulation with the Federal Trade Commission agreeing to stop representing their putty as containing linseed oil when such is not the fact, the commission announced today.

As the third prospective payless pay day of the year for the 19,000 city-county employes approached, City Controller Robert C. White said today he would not ask the Supreme Court to authorize payment as he has done twice before. The payroll, due tomorrow, is tied up as a result of the City Council's failure to adopt a 1938 budget. Mr.
Thom Cooper of Kansas City whipped his Class F outboard motor boat around Lake Hollingsworth late today to establish the first record of the 1938 Florida racing season.

The arrest of alleged spies in New York has increased Moscow's interest in espionage activities in the Soviet Union, especially because one prisoner is accused of attempting to obtain United States passports for German spies in Russia.
Man's quest for mistaken happiness has caused all the unhappiness in the world today and in past centuries, the Rev. Thomas L. Graham declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
An exhibition entitled "Architecture and the Construction of Cities in the U. S. S. R." will be opened this afternoon at the Architectural League of New York, 115 East Fortieth Street.
For the first time since Congress convened eight weeks ago, both houses will be occupied this week on measures of the greatest importance to the Administration.

Winning from the powerful Brookhattan eleven by 4 to 3 before a crowd of 4,000 at Starlight Park yesterday, the New York Americans, national champions, reached the Eastern final of the United States Football Association's annual competition for the Dewar Trophy.

Joseph Kornfelt, 45 years old, of 137 Hudson Street, Hackensack, N. J., who was on his way to at-. tend a wedding at the Broadway Central Hotel, Broadway near Bond Street, with his wife, Rachel, and a friend, Oscar Weinman of 89 Willett Street,

Peter Hamlin, 39 years old, a North Bergen fireman, was killed and two other men were critically injured early today in an automobile collision at Eleventh Street and Park Avenue here. A car operated by Hamlin, who lived at 920 Courtland Street,

Action of the Board of Education's law committee approving one bill and disapproving eleven others affecting the New York City school system that have been introduced in Albany recently was announced yesterday by James Marshall, vice president of the board and chairman of its law committee.

Milan Hodza, 60-year-old Premier of Czechoslovakia, is the author of a plan for a Danubian Federation which up to a fortnight ago seemed to be making some headway as the most practical among multiplying projects for the restoration of the Austrian Empire on an economic pane.

Less than two months after reoccupying a nine-room twelfthfloor apartment at 333 Central Park West in the hope of establishing a sort of rest sanatorium, Mrs. Molly R. Wish, 47-year-old registered nurse, was found dead of poison there between 1 and 2 A. M. yesterday.

Savings and loan associations which are members of the Federal Savings and Loan System ended January with $859,548,400 in outstanding share investments, a gain of $16,376,200 from the end of December, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

Disaster threatens California's sugarbeet industry, as well as a halfdozen other ranch industries, if Secretary of Agriculture Wallace's recommendations for paying 55 cents an hour to field laborers replaces the present piece-work basis,

Paced by Bobby Reinacher, who tallied eleven points, the New York Athletic Club defeated the Columbus Council K. of C., 54 to 36, in an Eastern Athletic Club Basketball League game played on the former's court yesterday.
Mrs. Douglas Gibbons of 430 Park Avenue has been reappointed by Cardinal Hayes as chairman of the women's division of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity for the Catholic Charities' annual appeal.

The French liner Normandie's gala cruise to South America ended yesterday when the ship landed her 975 passengers at West Forty-eighth Street and the crew of 1,400 relaxed and sought their first uninterrupted rest in twenty-two days.
New York City spent $14,126,255 more than it received in 1937, it was shown by a report made public yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick.

Leading from start to finish, young Byron Nelson of Reading, Pa., a member of the United States Ryder Cup team, won the Thomasville open golf tournament today with a score of 280, eight strokes under par at Glen Arven.

Bloomfield police believe they have captured the eccentric burglar who robbed homes and when he did not fancy the loot, mailed it back, postage collect, to the owner if he could remember his name and, if not, to some other person he had robbed.

The task of the settlement house is to give proper direction to current discontent and to augment "our ridiculous system of education," Councilman B. Charney Vladeck said last night at Madison House, 226 Madison Street, which is celebrating its fortieth anniversary.

Purchase of the plant of the American Flying Company of Chicago, for thirty years manufacturer of miniature electric trains and equipment, was announced here today by the A. C. Gilbert Company, maker of novelties, which recently built a large extension to its factory at Cedar Hill.

Funeral services of the Hoboken Lodge of Elks and the United Spanish War Veterans were held this evening at Volk's chapel for Harry L. Barck, Hoboken's Overseer of the Poor, who was stabbed to death by a relief applicant in his office on Friday.

Bermuda captured an international team tournament at the Mid-Ocean Golf Club today, registering 22 points. The United States group, which included the former homerun king ef baseball, Babe Ruth, was the runner-up, beaten by a single point. The Canadians tallied 11 and the British Army and Navy squad trailed with 6.

The Institute of Trade Research describes the setback in world export trade since the middle of 1937 as cyclical. It believes that the pace of reaction is increasing, however, and says that so far the decline has mainly affected Europe.

Foreign Minister Gabriel Tourbay, replying to a speech delivered in the Senate by Senator Jose Combariza, told the Senate today that he saw no danger of the infiltration of fascism into Colombia, adding that he placed dependence on public opinion and the country's long democratic history.

Far from the icy isolation of Labrador and North Newfoundland, where he has served for forty-five years as a voluntary medical missionary, Sir Wilfred T. Grenfell, founder of the International Grenfell Association, will celebrate his seventy-third birthday today, resting in the warm sea air of St. Simon's Island off the coast of Georgia.

Methods of uniting the various factions of the Democratic party in New York City will be discussed at a meeting of the Committee for United Democracy at the Hotel Astor on March 9, James F. Sullivan, chairman of its program committee, announced yesterday.

With a background of four months in Spain, during which he engaged in child-feeding work both in Nationalist and Loyalist territory, Dan West, a representative of the American Friends Service Committee, today pictured needy conditions in some parts of the country this Winter as alarming and voiced the belief that the need would be even greater next Winter on both sides.

Lawrence Gautreux of Dallas, Texas, 26-yearold American sailor on leave from the flagship Raleigh today was a principal in the first Salvation Army wedding held for an American in Nice. A French girl, Yvonne Sinian. 20. of Nice, was the bride.

Detective Lieutenant Edward Gephardt of the Morris County Prosecutor's staff reported tonight that two pistol shells were the only tangible clues in the murder last night of Gilbert Y. Hopler, 60-year-old operator of a general store on Main Street here.
Virgil Healy, 65, veteran doorkeeper of the Senate, killed himself today shortly after remarking that "after E man reaches 60 he isn't much good."

Walter Brattlund of Iron Mountain, Mich., won the national senior class ski championship today with leaps of 125 and 147 feet for 139.6 points in the feature event of the Gogebic Range Ski Club's tournament on its new slide.

The failure of the Interstate Commerce Commission to hand down its railroad rate decision last week may have been a tacit declaration of independence by the commission, in the opinion of observers viewing the situation in the light of recent developments.

NAME of a pipe! La Belle France is aflame again. It is over an incident in a game of rugby at Chalon-sur-Sadne. The French Rugby Federation had it under consideration the last this observer heard and, if it isn't settled there, it may get into the Chamber of Deputies and bring about the fall of another ministry.

A campaign for assistance from Manhattan residents which would make it possible for Jews of Poland, Germany, Rumania and other European countries to migrate to Palestine was announced yesterday by the United Palestine Appeal.

Members of the Cabinet took oaths under the new Constitution in the Royal Palace today. King Carol and the Premier, Patriarch Miron Cristea of the Orthodox Church, spoke emphasizing the importance of the new era in which party strife no longer exists and the fact that the new Constitution was adopted almost unanimously in a plebiscite.

The British Cabinet's sudden change in policy has taken the European markets by surprise. Like the policy hitherto pursued, it has not contributed in the least to appeasement of the political tension in Europe.
Formation of Douglas Bradford and Associates, with offices at 30 Broad Street, to act as a security holders relations council, was announced yesterday.
The Metropolitan A. A. U. basketball tournament, open to all registered college and club teams, will get under way during the week of March 13.

Names that spelled theatrical glamour in the Nineties and at the turn of the century were represented last night as the. Professional Women's League, one of the oldest theatrical women's organizations in America, celebrated its forty-fifth birthday with a party in its clubrooms at Hotel Ansonia last night.

Japanese today removed the seals from an American-leased warehouse in the International Settlement after their action in closing it had drawn a vigorous protest from United States Consul General Clarence E. Gauss.

A SLIGHT CASE OF MURDER, based on the play by Damon Runyon and Howard Lindsay; screen play by Earl Baldwin and Joseph Schrank; music and lyrics by M. K. Jerome and Jack Scholl; directed by Lloyd Bacon for Warner Bros. At the Strand.
Members of the Nicaragua Chamber of Commerce agreed today not to pay more than 4 cordobas 50 cents for one United States dollar in controlled exchange and 5 for $1 at the free, or street, rate.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:
Dr. William Slocum Davenport Sr., American dentist who had been practicing here, died suddenly at his Malmaison home near Paris last night at the age of 70.
Ten thousand demonstrators marched to the Ital- 3 ian Embassy this afternoon with a resolution condemning the "surrender" of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain to "Italian threats."

The National Labor Relations Board said today that the United Mail Tube Workers Local Industrial Union 474 has been certified as the exclusive collective bargaining agency for mail handlers, maintenance men and repair men employed by the New York Mail and Newspaper Transportation Company. The union is a C. I. O. affiliate.

The Most Rev. Edmund F. Gibbons, Bishop of the Albany Diocese, will break ground Tuesday for the first permanent building of the new Franciscan College at near-by Loudonville. It will be a three-story, Georgian Colonial structure.

The abolition of minimum wages of $15 to $18 a week for their taxi drivers and a reduction of 2 1/2 per cent in the basic commission for bookings were made effective yesterday by the Atlas-Liberty and Sunshine-Radio Fleet Owners Associations. The two groups say they operate about 5,000 cabs and employ approximately 10,000 men.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today $2,302,000 of Chicago Park District 31/2 and 4 per cent bonds. The 31/2s will be priced to yield 3.10 per cent to the optional date of 1946 and 31/2 per cent thereafter until redeemed or until final maturity in 1956.

Ted Shawn, who has been kept busy during the last few seasons by extensive tours with his company of men dancers, returned to New York last night in the first of a series of five Sunday evening reitals at the Majestic Theatre.

Indications of what the welldressed man is likely to wear during the coming year will appear today in the nineteenth annual men's style show of the New York Custom Cutters Club in the East Ballroom of the Hotel Commodore.
After two years of directing her husband's air force, Mme. Chiang Kaishek is authoritatively understood to be relinquishing the position.

Operations in the oats, rye and soy bean futures markets were greatly restricted last week. Oats showed a net gain of 1/4 cent a bushel for the week. Rye futures were 3/8 to 1 cent a bushel higher for the week, with only small export sales reported.

Less than twenty-four hours after she had won the national championship at the distance, Miss Helene Rains, the 13-year-old sensation from the Women's Swimming Association, captured the metropolitan senior 500-yard freestyle championship yesterday at the W. S. A. pool.

Overabundance in the money market is illustrated clearly by non-interestbearing current accounts of The Netherlands Bank, which are constantly rising. The present situation in the money market being to a considerable extent

Sterllng exchange has been swayed by the week's developments in the British political situation, but in terms of the dollar it has at the week-end depreciated little from the position it held immediately before the crisis.

Charles P. Howard, international president of the International Typographical Union, told the union's Philadelphia Local No. 2 today that his support of the Committee for Industrial Organization had given the union a protection "if things get hot between the C. I. 0. and the American Federation of Labor."

One of Japan's leading naval authorities declared in a magazine article today that Japan had defeated the United States in naval building with the result that "America is unable to have anything like confidence in her navy's ability to cope with Japan."
Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,055,495,900.
A luncheon was given yesterday by Mrs. Busch Greenough in the Penthouse of the St. Regis for Lady Decies, who will sail on Wednesday on the Normandie for her home in Paris.
Five little English cocker spaniels tonight were snug and warm, nursed by a foster mother that was rushed to their aid from a Washington "dog hotel" by a specially chartered airplane.

Owen McGlinchey, in 1,840 Sedgwick Ave; Sol Spasser. in 1,465 Townsend Ave; Margaret Boothroyd, in 6 W 190th St; Seymour Goldstein, in 984 Sherman Ave; Jessie Shirwindt, in 1,487 College Ave; Herman A Acker Corp, broker.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday. are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

Public support of a requests that the Constitutional Convention provide for the establishment of a State Department of the Consumer, to be "the clearing house of all consumer problems as they affect the 11,000,000 consumers in New York State," was urged yesterday by Louis Waldman, a member of the State Executive Committee of the American Labor party.

John D. Rockefeller Jr., four of his five sons and his son-in-law will be guests of honor at the tenth annual dinner of the Chamber of Commerce of Irvington, Tarrytown and North Tarrytown in the Westchester Country Club at Rye on April 4, it was announced today by Harry L. Bassett, executive secretary of the chamber.

A series of meetings at which the problems of maintaining old housing facilities and building new homes will be discussed by architects, landlords, realty men and tenants has been arranged by the Citizens Housing Council, it was announced yesterday.
William N. Cohen, a former Supreme Court Justice and for many years one of the leading trial counsel of the New York bar, died yesterday in Atlantic City, N. J., in his eighty-first year.
John Masefield's plan for a revival of the ancient custom of reading poetry in public houses has now been tried over a period of six months with considerable success.

"Unjustifiably high prevailing rates of wages set by the State Labor Department and the City Controller are holding up public contracts in excess of $60,000,000," the Citizens Budget Commission asserted yesterday.

Pointing out that several new taxes have been levied since the city sales tax went into effect, the Merchants Association has requested the Municipal Assembly to extend the time allowed for quarterly returns from fifteen to thirty days after the end of each quarter.

Representative Brewster, former Governor of Maine, speaking on the WOR weekly radio forum, appealed tonight to the mothers of the nation to write to President Roosevelt to ask the withdrawal of American gunboats from the Yangtze.

Lieut. Col. Elijah Walker Halford, who rose from "printer's devil" to become editor of The Indianapolis Journal at 24, private secretary to President Benjamin Harrison in 1889, and a high military officer in 1893, died at his home here today at the age of 95.
Mr. and Mrs. William Jennings Weller of New York entertained a company of sixty today at the Surf Club at a farewell luncheon for Mr. and Mrs. C. Leonard O'Connor of Cortland, N. Y.

A small, travel-stained band of Yankees reached this center of southern sunshine tonight, preliminary to opening tomorrow the club's fourteenth annual training visit. At the station the new arrivals were met by an unofficial committee of natives and tourists, led by Al Long.

Announcement has been made by Brig. Gen. and Mrs. William Wright Harts of Madison, Conn., who are here for the Winter, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Pruden Harts, to Lieutenant Alan Boyd Banister, U. S. N.

Helen Keller, the deaf and blind woman who was rescued, as she says, from the "hopeless darkness which no knowledge or beauty might enter" by the late Mrs. Anne Sullivan Macy, whom she met fifty years ago, has just sent a letter in Braille to other sightless people.

Otto Loree of Whitestone, L. I., sailed his Dolce IX to victory in the sixth of a series of ice boat races sponsored by the Greenwood Lake Ice Boat and Yacht Club today to take first place in the season's standing.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 30 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the three preceding weeks.
The statue of Abraham de Peyster, Mayor of New York from 1691 to 1695, again looks south toward the Battery and bay, after long years of facing north.
