Scoring four goals in the last period to wipe out a 3-1 deficit, the New York Rovers subdued the Hershey Bears, 5 to 4, in an Eastern Hockey League game, feature of the amateur double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

An autopsy performed yesterday on Harold F. Oatman, 26-year-old research chemist of New York University, who died Saturday morning in French Hospital after collapsing on Friday night while working in the Washington Square laboratory of the university,

Stan Laurel, film comedian, and Vera Shuvalova, Russian dancer, were remarried here today by Ed Winn, justice of the peace. Mr. Winn married them Jan. 1 but the couple decided to have another ceremony
A man and a woman who were arrested here last night will be arraigned before a United States Commissioner tomorrow on charges of operating an illicit still.

Big industry has moved to extend the health benefits developed for workers in large manufacturing establishments to smaller plants which have not had the time or money to install them, the National Association of Manufacturers announced today.

Changes in the national farm program to make it accord with the provisions of the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938, including the establishment of a 12-cent per bushel payment for wheat for farmers who cooperate in the program, were announced today by J. B. Hutson, Assistant Administrator of the AAA.

Jean Gau, a 36-year-old mariner who left a job as cook here to attempt a lone trip around the world in a 40-foot schooner, was back in New York yesterday after an eightmonth absence with a tale of adventure.

Of the 949 loan-insurance applications, amounting to $4,389,400, received by the Federal Housing Administration office here between Feb. 3 and 23, 437 covered financing of new homes and 512 applied to homes already built.

An unusual evening of motion pictures has been planned by members of the Florence Nightingale Federation, Inc., for their annual benefit in aid of the Methodist Episcopal Hospital of Brooklyn which will take place on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Little change was shown in the corn market last week, the foreign demand being largely of a routine character, while country offerings showed a tendency to increase when the May delivery sold above 60 cents a bushel.

Long Island University and C. C. N. Y. continued their excellent work during the week and, with the season drawing to a close in metropolitan intercollegiate basketball circles, are out in front in the general records of the local collezes.

The greatest obstacles of the Christian missionary in India are the caste system and a lack of resources, according to Miss Jessie Thomas, Lutheran missionary in Guntur, South India, for thirty years, who spoke yesterday morning in Christ Lutheran Church, 406 East Nineteenth Street.

Although his father denied them, rumors persisted here tonight that Peter Levine, 12 years old, of 11 Slocum Street,was still missing and the object of a search by agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Defeating the West Side Y. M. C. A. by 11-5 in the third round, the champion Marshall C. C. team yesterday moved into a tie at the top with the Manhattan C. C. in the annual championship series of the Metropolitan Chess League.

The youth of Mexico today is heart-sick and disillusioned, torn from an old faith, seeking a new one and finding none, the Rev. Bancroft Reifsnyder, a missionary in Villa Obregon, D. F., Mexico, declared yesterday morning at the Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue and Ninety-first Street.
While the European press has devoted much space to Italy's alleged demands to Britain for participation in control of the Suez Canal, the Egyptian press has not appeared greatly perturbed.

Objectives of the national convention to be held here May 13 to 16 by the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, representing 2,500 congregations with 1,000,000 members, were drawn yesterday at a conference in the Riverside Plaza Hotel, 253 West Seventythird Street.
Masonic funeral services were held here tonight at his home for Dr. Alexander A. Stern, for forty-nine years a physician and surgeon here.

For the fourth consecutive week, cotton prices advanced last week and reached the highest levels since the early part of last September. The net gains, however, were much smaller than in either of the three previous weeks.

The city's new $1,000,000 ferryboat, the Mary Murray, named after the revolutionary war heroine, was put into service at South Ferry yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock. She will make regular runs between Whitehall Street, at South Ferry,

A meeting of 150 dancing teachers called to discuss proposed amendments to the Coffee Bill, which would set up a Federal Bureau of Fine Arts, ended last night in a deadlock between teachers opposing the bill in its entirety and those
Mrs. Leita Stewart of New York and Miami Beach and Edwin F. Raynor of Coral Gables were married here late yesterday by Judge W. F. Blanton in the presence of relatives and friends.

A woman accused of looting the home of Paul Blanshard, former Commissioner of Accounts, at 410 Park Avenue, of linens and other articles valued at $400 while she was employed there as a servant last December, was arrested yesterday because she "did not think that detectives worked on Sunday."

The tragedy of the little churches becomes more apparent in these days of recession, the Rev. John B. Langstaff, rector of St. Edmund's Protestant Episcopal Church, Morris Avenue and 177th Street, the Bronx, said in his sermon yesterday.

St. Francis College vs. Brooklyn Poly, at St. Francis gymnasium, Butler and Court Streets, Brooklyn .............8:30 P. M. Girls' game, New College vs. Hunter, at Thompson Gymnasium, 120th Street and Broadway ................ . 4 P. M. Kings County A. A. U. tournament games, Flatbush Boys Club vs. St. John's Reserves and Williamsburg Y. M. H. A. vs.

Despite a sharp drop in January exports of iron and steel products, excluding scrap, from the December levels, the January shipments were virtually double those of January, 1937, the Metals and Minerals Division of the Department of Commerce announced today.

Mournfully nibbling at a dish of plain risotto and sipping a glass of champagne, Giovanni Martinelli, weak from a light diet enforced by physicians but fully recovered from the attack of acute indigestion that caused his collapse on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House Saturday afternoon, exclaimed yesterday in eloquent Italian:

The Right Rev. Daniel Mageean, Roman Catholic Bishop of Down and Connor, in a Lenten pastoral letter read in the churches of his diocese today denounced the Parliament of Northern Ireland for "partisanship and bigoted discrimination."

A program calling for speedier and "more human" relief to the needy unemployed is being mapped by the Fusion-Labor bloc in the City Council, Councilman Louis Hollander, spokesman for the coalition on relief matters, disclosed yesterday.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, speaking last night over a national-wide network of the National Broadcasting Company, declared that the greatest contribution toward balancing the Federal budget would be the restoration of an adequate foreign trade.
With the beginning of March the graph of the season reveals a sharp upward turn in the number of exhibitions, more than thirty being on the calendar for the present week.
Supply contracts valued at $8,580,087 were awarded in the week ended on Feb. 24 by seven Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor has announced.

Three more men of prominence in business and philanthropic cirches have accepted appointment as vice chairmen of the campaign committee of the Greater New York Fund, Inc., and will aid in the drive which the organization is to start in May for support of city welfare and health organizations, according to an announcement yesterday.

Miss Alice Welles Goodrich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Goodrich of this place, was married here yesterday to Robert Nelson Davis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Davis of Northport, L. I., in the First Church of Christ. The Rev. Russell McGown performed the ceremony.
This week the movements on the Bourse and on the exchange market were influenced above all by foreign events and by the new orientation of British foreign policy.

Ralph Flanagan, Miami middle-distance swimming star, opened his assault on national sprint records today by clipping 1.4 seconds off Johnny Weissmuller's 12-yearold mark for the 150-yard free style over a 20-yard course.

A drive to sweep the American automobile industry out of the recession and stimulate business generally was announced here yesterday by Alvin Macauley, speaking for the automobile manufacturers and the nation's 46,000 automobile dealers.
The Gomatal Realty Corporation, which recently bought the three five-story buildings at 27, 29 and 31 West Sixty-fourth Street, near Central Park West, has resold them to a builder.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Alexander Macdonald 3d of the engagement of Mrs. Macdonald's sister, Miss Patricia Lavelle of 325 East Fiftieth Street, to Dr. Basil Cuddihy of Montreal, son of Mrs. Michael Cuddihy of Montreal and Boston, and the late Mr. Cuddihy.
Marshal Italo Balbo, Governor of Libya, reported today that he had found the Italian aviator Count Franco Mazzoti, who with two companions had been missing in the Libyan desert three days.

There is a tendency for devoted followers to forget the principles for which their hero stood, the Rev. Dr. William P, Merrill, pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, said in a sermon yesterday.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Janet Price, daughter of Guernsey Price of 333 East Forty-third Street, this city, and Sunapee, N. H., and of Mrs. Clayton E. Rich of Woodpecker Ridge Farm, North Stamford, Conn., to Howard John Helleberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Helleberg of Arlington, N. J., and Osterberg, Pa.

The American Radio Telegraphists Association, a C. I. 0. affiliate, has filed with the National Labor Relations Board a demand for oral argument on its decision last week setting a national collective bargaining election among the employes of the Postal Telegraph Company.

A dedication ceremony marking the completion of the four-year plan to preserve the Old North Church, from the belfry of which shone the lantern that sped Paul Revere on his famous ride, will be held some time in March.

Professor Chester Noyes Greenough, Professor of English at Harvard University and dean of the college from 1921 to 1927, died suddenly yesterday at his home on Juniper Road, Belmont, at the age of 64.
The Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women at Hillside, Ossining, was the beneficiary of a historical pageant entitled "England's Hourglass" last night at the Lyceum Theatre.

A special department for the treatment of rheumatism and sciatica will be opened tomorrow at the Stuyvesant Polyclinic, 137 Second Avenue, under the direction of Dr. Arnold J. Galarie, specialist in rheumatic diseases, which are described as on the increase among the industrial population of the city.
Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's invigorated air force was reported today to have broken up Japanese troop concentrations on the north bank of the Yellow River.

War can be averted only by an extension of democracy, and democracy must defend itself by a firm opposition to fascist aggression, James Waterman Wise declared yesterday in the second of two weekly addresses on "Spanish Freedom and World Peace" at the Free Synagogue meeting in Carnegie Hall.

F. A. Scola won the high-over-all prize at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday, taking a second extra string from L. F. Sanman, 25-24, after a tie at 98. In the first 25-target shoot-off the rivals tied at 24.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

Out of the distress and the horror of war the Christian church in China will rise again, declared Dr. C. Stanley Smith, vice president of the Nanking Theological Seminary, in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.
Strengthened by the big vote of confidence he got in the Chamber of Deputies yesterday for his foreign policy, Premier Camille Chautemps cracked the whip today over the Senate.

Domestic politics, for a change, have been the dominating influence in the financial markets here. The crisis which arose so suddenly last week-end naturally aroused considerable anxiety and caused general weakness in the markets, but the manner in which a quick solution was found produced a swift reaction and a budding confidence which must have been extremely gratifying to the government, especially to the Premier.

With December production of copper at 24,620 tons for the Dominion, output for 1937 was brought up to 264,886 tons, according to the monthly report issued by the mining branch of the Department of Trade and Commerce.

The greatest and most startling of the Soviet treason trials will begin publicly in Moscow on Wednesday. The list of the twenty-one accused includes names that once stood highest in the Soviet land, but in addition to charges of espionage, sabotage, etc., there is a grim new accusation -of murder by doctors of such former eminence as L. G. Levin, former chief, of the Kremlin Hospital.

In 1937 it cost $176,213 to maintain St. Patrick's Cathedral, including special repairs, and to support its philanthropies, Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, now in his fifty-first year as rector, announced yesterday in a letter to parishioners and friends of the cathedral.
The three sisters of King Zog of Albania, the Princess Ruhije, Maxhide and Myzeyen, will arrive today on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia for their first visit to this country.
The example of the Rev. John Dennis Mitchell, who was ordained last week and celebrated his first solemn mass yesterday, "brings home the supremacy of God over the spirit of the world," said the Rev.
Current fluctuations in the Bank of England's circulation are of such an order as to indicate that the abnormal situation which arose at the year-end has now disappeared entirely.

Banks were the center of the week's financial interest here. A large increase in clearings and deposits, and a dividend rise by the Commerz-und-Privat Bank were favorably taken and all bank stocks on the Boerse responded by advances.

Little Davie Kerr gave the finest net-minding exhibition of the season tonight as the speedy New York Rangers trounced the skidding Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 1, in a wellplayed National Hockey League battle before 13,500 spectators.

A strike call affecting 6,000 hosiery workers in the New York-New Jersey district was issued this evening by the district council of the American Federation of Full-Fashioned Hosiery Workers at a meeting at the headquarters of Branch 7 here.

In one of Winter's drizzling Southwesters, which chilled even bones, twenty-one weather-defiant dinghies were out sailing today in the regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club, and the finishes were shiverclose.
Associate Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo of the Supreme Court, who has been ill for months, "is now in the convalescent stage and is making steady progress," physicians said today.
A bill providing for the compulsory grading of all meats sold in this city will be presented in the City Council today, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, announced yesterday.
Delegates from seven South American "immigration" nations and eight "emigration" nations, including Japan, were gathered in Geneva tonight on the eve of a conference on immigration to South America.
Meeting, New York City League of Women Voters, 151 East Fiftieth Street, 10:30 A. M. "Collective Bargaining-Labor," Helen Blanchard.

The School Nature League, which maintains many "nature exhibits" in the city schools, will hold its annual meeting and tea this afternoon at the American Museum of Natural History. Dr. Henry K. Svenson, curator of the herbarium at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, will give an illustrated talk on "Flowering Plants Around New York."

An investing client of Grudin Sawitch, brokers, bought from the Joypol Relaties, Inc., J. Polsky, president, the five-story apartment house for forty-eight families at 1,068 Gerard Avenue, near 165 Street, in the West Bronx.
The Association of American Railroads announced today that on Jan. 1 Class I railroads and the Pullman Company had 11,168 air-conditioned passenger cars in operation.

The Brooklyn Young Women's Christian Association celebrated its fiftieth anniversary yesterday afternoon at a service in the Central Branch, 30 Third Avenue. Mrs. Robert L. Dickinson, one of two founders who established the first unit in 1888, participated.
George Hale's International Ice Revue, starring Miss Maribel Y. Vinson and Guy Owen, had its world premiere at the Imperial Arena tonight and was enthusiastically received by a gathering of 1,800.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83, which compares with 82.4 a week ago, 82.4 two weeks ago, 82.6 three weeks ago and 83.1 four weeks ago.

There have been three orchards in my life That cut my memory like a knife: One, by the house where I was born, Was a better crop to me than corn; I could tell you an apple, if you wanted to know, Redder than red and whiter than snow; Then there was another, ten acres big, Where cider grew on every twig.

Miss Anne Rankin Brown, daughter of Mrs. Ralph Manning Brown of 67 Georgian Court and the late Mr. Brown, has chosen March 26 as the date of her marriage to Clement Olmstead Davidson, son of Mrs. Edward Crawford Davidson and the late Mr. Davidson.

Francis P. Gallagher, for eighteen years with George B. Gibbons Co.,Inc.,has become associated with Kidder, Peabody Co. as manager of the municipal bond department in their office here, according to an announcement by the latter firm.
Business on the Amsterdam Bourse has dwindled to a minimum recently, except for this week's short recovery. Despite the plethora of money, the highly uncertain economic
Dr. T. R. Glover of Cambridge University is known as a ripe classical scholar in Canada and the United States, in both of which he has been a professor, almost as well as in his own country.

Karl Ringer of Germany won the Canadian slalom championship before 4,000 fans today, finishing in 1 minute 15 seconds. Bud Clark of the Ottawa Ski Club was second in 1:18.1 and J. Houghton of the McGill Ski Club of Montreal third in 1:22.
Abandoning its policy of retention of its foreign stars for Metro's exclusive use, MGM has made its second loan of an imported player within a week.

The need for a great awakening of faith was stressed by the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of New York, in his sermon yesterday morning to the confirmation class of nineteen at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy, 26 West Eightyfourth Street.

A novel experience indeed befell the Montreal Maroons last night. They won a hockey game. The victory-starved Gorman sextet, which in its ten previous ventures could do no better than earn one tie while losing nine times, astonished the New York Americans
Mr. and Mrs. Harris Fahnestock gave a musical and reception yesterday at their home, 15 East Sixtysixth Street. Artists were Isabel French, soprano, and Rene Le Roy, flutist.

While environment exerts an important influence on character, the final word is in the spirit of the man, Dr. George A. Buttrick declared yesterday in his sermon before the congregation of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue at East Seventy-third Street.

The Catholic Poetry Society of America last night gave a dinner at the Hotel Ambassador in honor of its president, Dr. Katherine Bregy of Philadelphia, author of "Bridges." C. John McCole, chairman of the society's executive board, presided, and the speakers were the Right Rev. Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, John Gilland Brunini, editor of the society's magazine "Spirit," and the Rev. Francis Talbot, editor of "America" and the first chaplain of the society.
Stefan Osusky, Czechoslovak Minister to France, declared today that nations of Central Europe could not be "denationalized."

Peter Garrett of the Yale University Outing Club today won the Massachusetts amateur downhill ski title in a field of thirty-four contestants on Mount Greylock's Thunderbolt Run, slowed by falling snow.

Frederick Eugene Powell, accredited dean of American magicians, died here today on the eve of his eightysecond birthday. The first to afford serious competition to the noted Kellar and Herrmann the Great, Mr. Powell was one of the best known members of his profession until his retirement several years ago.

Sterling Pile gave a luncheon here today at his home on Shelter Rock Road at which he announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Audrey Elizabeth Pile, to Harry J. Miller Jr., son of Mr. Miller of Pittsburgh and the late Mrs. Miller.

The Boston Olympics, scoring twenty-eight goals against the four rivals they encountered in the two-day tournament, tonight retained their National A. A. U. hockey championship by overwhelming the tired Brock-Hall team from New Haven, 8-0, in the title game at the Arena.

The first half of the semi-final round bouts in the Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament will be held at the Ridgewood Grove Sports Club, Brooklyn, tonight. A program of twenty-three bouts in all divisions will be presented.

The good-will of the home must reach to the rest of the world, said the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street. "When man can answer the question, 'Who is my neighbor?' the salvation of the world will be found," he said.

The doctrine of redemption from sin has been taken too lightly, the Rev. John R. Atkinson, member of the staff of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said in the preLenten sermon there yesterday morning.

Charles H. Russell, chairman of the campaign committee of the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany Building Fund, announced yesterday that gifts and pledges amounting to more than $83,000 had been received.

Joseph Vigorous, 24, Mississippi Gulf gangster, wanted for questioning about numerous robberies and four kidnappings of citizens with their automobiles, was captured this morning in a swamp near the Mobile-Jackson County, Mississippi, line.
Some improvement was noted in wholesale apparel business last week as buyers arrived on their second Spring trips, in preparation for pre-Easter selling.

After rallying briefly yesterday, General John J. Pershing began to "lose ground," Dr. Roland Davison, his personal physician, said in a bulletin early this morning. The bulletin, issued at 12:40 A. M., said:

Mrs. Althea F. Miller, widow of William Webster Miller and daughter of the late Xavier M. Schmid and Althea Keyser Schmid, and a lifelong resident of New York, died on Saturday at the Midtown Hospital.
His battery corps boiled down to specifications, Colonel Bill Terry and his vanguard of Giants evacuated this resort today in high spirits, excellent health and with only one invalid.
The following dispatch is from the President of the Commission of Foreign Affairs of the French Chamber of Deputies. The foreign policy of France is, in part, determined by this commission.

In a report opposing legislation to suspend the right of a taxpayer to have an assessment on his property reviewed through certiorari proceedings on the ground of overvaluation, two committees of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York suggest greater economy to solve the financial difficulties of municipalities.

The national championships have moved into the past, a conspicuous milestone in the fifty-year history of the Amateur Athletic Union. They left in their wake a batch of shattered records, the reputation of being once more the best meet of the season and gave a very clear intimation of the set-up for the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. title games at the Garden next Saturday.

Average operations in rayon weaving mills in the week ended Feb. 19 increased slightly to 63 per cent of capacity, according to the weekly report issued by the National Rayon Weaving Association, Inc.

The marriage of Miss Terry Wolff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max S. Wolff, to Leon Shusterman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Shusterman of this city, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 470 West End Avenue. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Nathan Stern.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, apparently in full command of a spy hunt that already has resulted in the arrest of two soldiers and a women as foreign agents, yesterday put in an active day in search of two, and possibly three, more members of the group accused of furnishing United States Army information to a foreign power.
The tendency of the franc was again rather unsatisfactory this week, although there was no large-scale exporting of capital.

George M. Cohan was honored as "America's number one trouper" at last night's benefit for the National Variety Artists, held at the Alvin Theatre. Mr. Cohan was unable to be present and appear on the program, as had been scheduled, because of a cold. The occasion, however, was dedicated to him.
Alexander Kerensky, who was Premier of the Russian Provisional Government following the fall of the Czarist regime, will arrive here tomorrow on the Berengaria, to give a series of lectures.

The squadron of six "flying fortresses" landed at Langley Field, Va., at 5:05 P. M., today, after a non-stop flight from the Panama Canal Zone. They completed a 12,000-mile good-will flight to Buenos Aires, Argentina, and return.

President Roosevelt canvassed the Kentucky political situation and furthered the re-election campaign of the Senate majority leader, Mr. Barkley, in conference with Attorney General Cummings and Thomas S. Rhea, Kentucky political leader.

A new Tarzan is in the offing. Sol Lesser failed to take up the option on Glenn Morris, decathalon champion of the last Olympics, who was featured with Eleanor Holm in "Tarzan's Revenge." Lesser has a second yarn, "

The Haitian Government has received a check for $250,000 from the Dominican Government representing the initial payment of indemnities totaling $750,000 for the killings of Haitians in Dominican territory last October.

A 400 per cent increase in sales of fur scarfs over last year, at marked pick-up in calls for navy coats, dresses and millinery, and a growing preference for the less formal types of evening gowns were among the facts revealed in an analysis of February apparel sales released yesterday by Lord Taylor.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Chief Magistrate Schurman is to be praised for his challenging and thoughtful address before the Insurance Society of New York. As citizens and insurance men we endorse his views on the helpfulness of the Municipal Courts and the Police Department in bringing about more effective traffic control and traffic law enforcement in the City of New York.

Thirty-sixth annual meeting and conference on tuberculosis of the New York 'Tuberculosis and Health Association, Hotel Pennsylvania, 9:30 A. M. Luncheon, 12:45 P. M. Speakers: Commissioner John' L.' Rice, Bailey B. Burritt, Dr. J. Arthur Myers, Dr. I. Ogden Woodruff.

A request that the trial of Alexei Rykoff, Nikolai Bukharin and nineteen others on charges of treason, murder and conspiracy be postponed for six weeks to permit the arrival in Moscow of an international committee to witness and report on the trial was addressed yesterday to the Soviet Government by a group of prominent Americans, including Will Irwin, Oswald Garrison Villard and John Haynes Holmes.

After vainly trying to kill herself by slashing her wrists and taking poison, Mrs. Rebacca Skinner, 55 years old, widow of a former president of the Educational Pictures Corporation, plunged to death at 9:15 A. M., yesterday from her room on the eighth floor of the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: PATENTS 3892-Irving P. Whitehouse v. Curt Saurer. Opinion by Judge Garrett. Board of Appeals decision affirmed.

Among the defendants in Moscow's latest treason trial is a group of Kremlin doctors who stand charged with murder. Two of their alleged victims are Menzhinsky, chief of the G. P. U., and the eminent writer, Maxim Gorky. One can understand a band of antiStalin conspirators turning their weapons against the head of Stalin's secret police. But as for Maxim Gorky,

Professor T. E. Palesske of Wagner College, Staten Island, won the first prize in a translation contest of a scene from the second act of Richard Wagner's "Siegfried," it was announced yesterday. The contest was conducted by the Richard Wagner Society. The first prize is $150.

Thomas Heflin jumped back into Alabama politics tonight. The former Senator announced that he would oppose Representative Joe Starnes of Guntersville. Mr. Heflin, recently defeated by Lister Hill for the Senate, is recovering from a serious illness.

With a message from President Roomevelt indicating that he looks to the schools as a bulwark of democracy in the midst of changes affecting popular government abroad, 10,000 educators opened here today the first formal sessions of the American Association of School Adminisitrator.
Jim McMillen, former University of Illinois football star, threw Bobby Bruns of Germany in 40:55 of the feature match carded for a finish before 3,000 persons at the Hippodrome last night.

With the main detachment of batterymen swooping down from Hot Springs, Ark., and the others straggling in from their homes during the early hours, the entire Giant cast was in Louisiana's capital today to commence serious training for the 1938 pennant race.

While the Labor Bureau's preliminary index of employment in manufacturing industries, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Sunday, showed for mid-January a decline of 6.9 per cent from December and 14.5 per cent from January, 1937, the-decrease in payrolls, now shown by the bureau's published bulletin, turns out to have been still larger.

With the selection of a jury of ten married men and two women, in addition to two alternate jurors, the stage was set here today for the first-degree murder trial of John Rylowicz, 39-year-old former Lyndhurst (N. J.) gasoline station proprietor. Rylowicz,

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the five days ended Feb. 24 was 246, compared with 263 for the five-day period preceding and 166 for the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Colonel H. C. Rickaby, counsel for the Atlas Corporation, proponent of a plan of reorganization for the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corportion, told Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday that a change in the company's business condition had made certain amendments to the plan seem necessary.

A national drive in opposition to Representative Wright Patman's chain store tax bill and similar State legislation will be initiated at a meeting of New York business, civic and consumer organizations at the Hotel Astor at 4 P. M. today, it was announced yesterday by Percy C.. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade, who called-the meeting. A similar rally

Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti has been suggested for leader of the Democratic minority in the coming constitutional convention, it was learned yesterday. Justice Poletti was formerly counsel to Governor Lehman, who is reported to look with favor on his selection.

Directors of the Johns-Manville Corporation took no action yesterday with respect to a dividend on the common stock but declared the regular quarterly dividend of $1.75 a share on the 7 per cent preferred. Lewis H. Brown,

Charles C. Wright of the brokerage firm of Wright Sexton of New York was expelled today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, effective on April 30, from membership in the New York Stock, New York Curb,

Movements of gold at the Port of New York in February were confined to a single import of $275,000 from India. This was the smallest influx of gold in a month since September, 1934, when only $115,600 was received.

After a shaky start that cost him the first two holes, C. Everett Bacon of Montclair, N. J., 1935 winner of the Mid-Ocean golf tournament, regained his form and defeated Samuel N. Pierson of Stamford, Conn., today in the semifinal round of the current renewal of the competition. The score was 6 and 5.

Emphasis upon style was recommended as "the most effective medium for combating adverse business trends" by Samuel L. Deitsch of Deitsch, Wersba Coppola, Inc., president of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., at the council's annual meeting last night at the Hotel New Yorker.

George De Camp, chairman of the board and Federal Reserve agent of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland from 1926 to 1933, died this afternoon of a heart attack at his home in Newark, Ohio. His age was 69.

A Cabinet shake-up today resulted in the removal of Hector Valdes from the post of Minister of Government and Jose Lefevre from that of Foreign Relations and the appointment of Leopoldo Arosemena, brother of the President, to the first post and of Narciso Garay to the second.
Nazi spokesmen indicated today that the laws forbidding employment of "Aryan" women less than 45 years of age in Jewish households soon would be extended to include manikins.

Department store sales in the New York Federal Reserve District during the first three weeks of February were 4.6 per cent below the corresponding period a year ago, according to the monthly review of business conditions issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Bonds called for redemption prior to maturity in February totaled only $31,690,000, the smallest volume of retirements for any month since. December, 1934, when $27,391,000 in bonds were redeemed.

Miss Helen Talcott Hope, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Ewing Hope of 43 East Seventieth Street, has completed plans for her marriage to David Edward Austen of this city, which will take place on the afternoon of March 18 in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The pastor of the church, the Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick, will perform the ceremony.

Selwyn Eddy, assistant sales manager of Shell Union Oil Corporation, has been appointed sales manager of the company, it was announced yesterday by L. T. Kittinger, vice president in charge of marketing.

Wholesale and retail dress business continued poor last week, bringing to a close "the worst February in years" for the New York market as a whole, the research department of the Joint Board, Dress and Waistmakers Union, declared yesterday in its weekly report.

Maurice Alvin Long, president of the engineering contracting company bearing his name, former assistant chief of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company and a director in banks and trust companies, died last night at his home here at the age of 63.
The $250,000,000 Deficiency Relief Bill passed its final hurdles in Congress today and awaited only formal engrossing to be passed on to President Roosevelt for his signature.

Unanimous approval of collection by the Federal Government of income taxes on salaries of four quasi-official State employes whose incomes came from private funds was granted by the Supreme Court today.
Hope returned today to the little Apache lodge of the desert sanatorium where for the last six days General John J. Pershing has been fighting for his life against a complication of ailments.

Charges preferred by two special committees of the Chicago Board of Trade against John H. Macmillan Jr., president, and Edward J. Grimes and Philip C. Sayles, vice presidents of the Cargill Grain Company of Illinois, alleging violations of the rules of the Exchange in deals in corn futures of September, 1937, will be heard tomorrow by the directors of the Grain Exchange.

A repetition of Rossini's "Barber of Seville" with some changes of cast fast night in the Metropolitan Opera House did not throw new and blinding light upon the significance of the various roles, but it did thrill us again and summon laughter and wonder at the genius and wit of the great Rossini.

Assignment: Donald R. Fuselman, H. L. Co. 20. Advancements in Grade To take effect at 9 A. M. on date specified. Fourth to 3d grade, March 3, James M. Haven, H. L. Co., 146. Third to 2d grade, March 9, Chester F. Eklund, Engine Co. 13.

Miss Mary Edith Carroll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Carroll of 105 East Fifty-third Street, formerly of Pittsburgh, has chosen May 7 as the day of her marriage to Paul L. Grambs of this city and Bismarck, N. D. The wedding will take place in the chantry of St. Thomas Church.
The Greater New York Fund, Inc., 52 Broadway, announced yesterday the appointment as its executive director of Douglas Falconer, general secretary of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities.

Miss Jeanne Righter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Righter of this place, was married to Peter C. Wright, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton M. Wright, also of Rutherford, this evening in the Baptist Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frederick Holloway, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Rutherford.

In imposing Sing Sing terms of five to fifteen years each on two youths, declared by the police to be members of a desperate hold-up gang, Judge John J. Freschi, in General Sessions yesterday, commented that most of those who had been brought before him in the last month for similar crimes were from 19 to 27 years old.

Former President Herbert Hoover spent most of today at the seat of the League of Nations without visiting it. Asked by the press why he had come here he said: "I came to visit my old friend, Ignace Jan Paderewski, whom I have known for forty years."

Exports and imports of the United States by classified groups of merchandise during January, as announced by the Department of Commerce, are compared herewith with those of December and January, 1937.

The Grace Line announced yesterday the addition of Kingston, Jamaica and Cristobal, Panama Canal Zone, to the itinerary of its weekly cruise service to the Caribbean and South America, effective with the sailing on next Friday of the liner Santa Elena.

Herbert L. Chipman, publisher of The Cape Cod News and real estate executive, died today at the age of 71. He was the founder of The Cape Cod News which at one time covered the Cape with eight editions.

The first criminal charges against city sales tax evaders were disclosed yesterday with the announcement by District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn that seventeen informations naming seventeen individuals and five corporations as violators have been returned by the December Kings County grand jury.
John Zahanek of the New York A. C. won the New York State highboard fancy diving championship, feature of the meet in the St. George pool, last night from Sol Shrebaick of the St. George Dragon Club.

The Court of Appeals upheld yesterday the legality of the 1938 budget adopted last year by the Democratic Board of Estimate. Promptly the new Fusion-controlled board met at City Hall and voted to reduce the budget by $477,915.

Without passing in any way upon the merits of the closed shop, the Supreme Court through a formal order today dismissed the appeal of six New York Rapid Transit employes against a closed shop contract between the Transport Workers Union and the New York Rapid Transit Corporation and three subsidiaries.

Lefferts Mason Dashiell, treasurer of the Rockefeller Foundation and several other philanthropic organizations, died suddenly at his home here this morning. His death was due to a stroke. He had seemed to be enjoying perfect health last evening. His age was 63.
The TwomeyNewell bill requiring serological blood tests for syphilis for all pregnant women was unanimously passed tonight in the Senate.

Correspondence between the United States, Canadian and Ontario Governments on construction of the St. Lawrence waterway, preservation of the scenic splendors of Niagara Falls and proposed water diversion by the Ontario Government for power purposes between Niagara and the head of the lakes was tabled in the House of Commons today preliminary to tomorrow's discussion of a bill to give Parliament control over the export of Canadian power.

The Federal Trade Commission today moved to break up an alleged pricefixing combination in the sale of golf balls when it ordered eight leading golf ball manufacturers and their trade association, together with the Professional Golfers' Association of America, to stop fixing prices and discriminating as to prices to certain purchasers.

SAVE ME THE WALTZ, a comedy in three acts, by Katharine Dayton. Staged by Robert B. Sinclair; settings by Jo Mielziner; costumes designed by John Hambleton; produced by Max Gordon, in association with Sam H. Harris. At the Martin Beck Theatre.

Captain Evans Carlson, a United States Marine Corps intelligence officer, returned here today from Shansi, where during the past three months he had marched the length and breadth of that province with units of the formerly Communist Eighth Route Army.

Burr Co., Inc., have acquired control of Eli T. Watson Co., Inc., and the business heretofore conducted by the latter concern in New York and Philadelphia will be conducted under the name of Burr Co., Inc., according to a joint announcement made yesterday.

The main body of bonds drifted moderately lower yesterday in extremely dull trading on the New York Stock Exchange. A few selected foreign dollar obligations stood out as the only bright spots as the market generally reflected an atmosphere of "anxious wait-

Carmine St, 23, 25x100; Francesco Di Maggio and wife to All Town Enterprises, Inc. 63 Carmine St; mtg $7,000 ($3.50). Spring St, 6, 25.2x102.4; S. Theodore Granik to Central Savings Bank, consideration $1,000 foreclosure.

The opening debate on the Senate version of the Administration bill to grant the President authority to reorganize Federal agencies gave a graphic example today of differences which divide the Senate Democrats over how far the Congress should go in delegating this function.
Beginning today and continuing every Tuesday at 4 P. M. for the next two months a course on "Finance and Economics" will be given to the Young Women's

The radio "super power" issue will come up at a hearing ordered today for May 16 by Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, on the proposed amendment of the commission's Rule 117 to make 50 kilowatts the minimum instead of the maximum authorized power of a dominant clear channel station.

A Communist's determination to show his contempt for religion impelled him to murder a Catholic priest yesterday. The victim was a Lubon Province priest, Stanislav Streich, shot to death while delivering a children's sermon in church.
Wilson Follett, writing in The Atlantic Monthly, has his serious doubts about the American Language.

Six Republicans joined with the Democratic minority in the Senate tonight to prevent passage of a bill introduced by Senator Lester H. Clee, Essex County Republican, to substitute judges of elections for the present election superintendents and registration commissioners in Hudson and Essex Counties.

Hoyt A. Moore, chief counsel for the Bethlehem Steel Company, indirectly charged today that the closing of the company's mills here by Governor George H. Earle, in the steel strike last June was part of a "major conspiracy" by the Governor, C. I. O. leaders and others to force President Roosevelt to intervene on the side of the strikers.

The Museum of Modern Art has received gifts of three paintings, to be placed on exhibition this morning in its galleries at 14 West Forty-ninth Street. The pictures are "Homestead," by Thomas Benton, painted in 1934 in tempera on composition board, a gift of Marshall Field;
The Trust Company of New Jersey sold to Dr. Albert Lefcourt the apartment and store building at 305 Jackson Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., through the George J. Wolf Realty Company.
Sir Frederick Eley, Bart., of London, will arrive today on the Berengaria. He will be at the WaldorfAstoria. Mr. and Mrs. Clement A. Griscom 3d have come from Haverford, Pa., to the Savoy-Plaza.

Representatives Rich of Pennsylvania and Taber of New York today conducted a day-long drive to reduce appropriations in the $125,000,000 Interior Department Appropriation Bill, but were uniformly unsuccessful. Lack of attendance so angered Mr. Rich that near the end of the day he threatened to try to hold the House in session all night with repeated demands for quorum calls.

The Illinois Appellate Court today denied a contention by Samuel Insull, Samuel Insull Jr. and other directors of the Corporation Securities Company that a suit charging them with unlawfully wasting the company's for funds should be dismissed.

A smoky fire which spread quickly from the basement of a fourstory rooming house at 319 West 126th Street to the top floor cost one woman her life yesterday and caused slight injuries to four other women. The victim,

Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y., triumphed over Joe Procita of Gloversville, N. Y., 125 to 90, in twenty-nine innings last night in the opening match of the world pocket-billiards championship at the Capitol Bowling and Billiards Academy.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 26: COLONELS Curry, J. F. (Air Corps). General Staff Corps, 14 days' leave, Feb. 26. Peterson, V. L., Engrs., Detroit, Mich., to Headquarters, Chicago, Ill., March 21.
In opening the committee stage of the national mobilization bill yesterday the government offered no tangible concessions, although the hostile mood of the members had undergone no abatement.

Accused of robbing Irving P. Kartell of 1,035 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, an attorney and son-in-law of Municipal Court Justice Nathan Sweedler, of $395 on Jan. 8 while he was collecting rents in an apartment house at 1,967 Sixty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, George Schulmacker, 18 years old, of 533 Bushwick Avenue. Brooklyn:

MANHATTAN BARBER, VIOLA MESSINGER (June 18). Estate, less than $1,000. To Guthrie Y. Barber, executor, 35 E. 30th St. BENJAMIN, SOPHIE (Feb. 7). Estate, more than $10,000. To Ruth Benjamin. daughter, 333 W. 86th St., jewelry and personal effects; Max Benjamin,

Movements of vessels follow; all dates Feb. 27, unless specified: At Culebra: Arkansas, Antares, Badger, Decatur, Dickerson, Fairfax, Jacob Jones, New York, S-42, 44, 46, 47, Schenck, Wyoming. At San Pedro: Balch. Kanawha, Feb. 28; Porter. At Sal. Diego, Feb. 28: Holland, Vega.

Those unfortunates who writhe almost daily at being addressed by strangers as "Pop" may take a special interest in the proceedings of the National Young Republican Federation in session at Chicago. The chairman of the federation is Mr. Henry A. Bubb of Topeka.

From various sources comes reassuring evidence that ample funds will be provided by new and old lending agencies to finance expanded residential building operations under the amended National Housing Act.

A group of Wall Street and aviation interests is negotiating to buy Eastern Air Lines from North American Aviation, Inc., of which the General Motors Corporation owns virtually 30 per cent of the capital stock. Kuhn, Loeb Co.
Somewhere in the blue waters of the Caribbean tonight there was a rendezvous of the "enemy" "Blue" force that will attack Puerto Rico before Friday in the United States' war game.

Mrs. Mary A. Combs, who was widely known here and in France for her philanthropies, died in her apartment at the Warwick today after an illness of more than a year. She had lived here since the death of her husband, John Francis Combs, in 1932.
Gian-Carlo Menotti's one-act comic opera, "Amelia Goes to the Ball," which will have its Metropolitan Opera premiere on Thursday evening, was presented in a dress rehearsal yesterday morning.
President Roosevelt's long-delayed plan for a reorganization of the National Government was brought before the Senate yesterday. Months have passed since it last had the center of the stage.
Boller Ave, e s, 250 ft n of Stillwell Ave, 19x20, 1-story dwelling; Marion Schnabel, 2,301 Boller Ave, owner; J. L. Kling, architect; cost, $2,800.

Capt. Benjamin Perricone, Q.M. Res., 3 Hawthorne Ave., Port Richmond, S. L, is relieved from assignment to the 54th Quartermaster Battalion and is assigned to the let Division. Major Aage Woldike, M.I.-Res. (A), 50 Broad St., New York, N. Y., is relieved from attachment for training to the 77th Division.

Albert Warner, motion picture producer, reported to police today the theft of jewelry he valued at $90,000 from his Winter home. Detective Chief Earl D. Carpenter said the thief gained entrance through a second-floor window by

Creating a little empire of their own beneath tropic skies where orchids grow wild and geraniums are rare, an American mining engineer and his wife, a former school teacher, are slashing a clearing in an impenetrable jungle of ancient citrus trees high on the volcanic slopes of Floreana Island, in the Galapagos Archipelago.
Nicaragua for the second time in six months har been invaded by locusts. A swarm twentyfour miles long and halt a mile wide passed over Masaya yesterday afternoon, Obscuring the sun.

A bill providing that the Bronx River Parkway be given to New York State and operated by the Taconic State Park Commission was submitted to the Westchester County Board of Supervisors here today by the board's legislative committee.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today the following proceedings were had: 365--Noah Adair, petr., v. Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association. On writ of cert. to the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals.

Fodor Butenko, after a very brief appearance in Rome, has vanished again and nobody seems to know his whereabouts, except that he is almost certainly no longer here. According to circles close to the government, he is in the country somewhere engaged in writing a book revealing the state of affairs in Soviet Russia.

Young women recuperating from pulmonary tuberculosis will be aided by a luncheon and fashion show which has been arranged for March 24 at the Park Lane by members of the Social Service Auxiliary of Stony Wold Sanatorium. Costumes for Spring wear will be displayed by a group of members of society. Mrs. Irving Smith heads the benefit committee.

Operations of the steel industry are scheduled at 29.3 per cent of capacity this week, as compared to 30.4 per cent last week, a decline of 1.1 point, or 3.6 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports. This is the lowest rate since the week of Jan. 10, when it was 27.8 per cent.

Outlining the task before the Republican program committee at its organization meeting today, Dr. Glenn Frank, chairman of the group which is to formulate a party policy, declared that the nation was in need of a "sweeping reeducation in political and economic realities in this era in which the economic machine is stalled."

Firms in the clothing and allied trades furnished a major part of the activity in commercial leasing reported here yesterday. The three-story building at 868 Flatbush Avenue, near Church Avenue, Brooklyn, was leased for fifteen years by the Mazog Specialty Stores, Inc.,

Dartmouth College's vaunted basketball forces, current pace-setters in. the Eastern Intercollegiate League, met unexpected opposition tonight and dropped a 47--38 decision to the Princeton Tigers in a fast encounter staged before some 1,500 spectators.
Recent rumors of sabotage attempts on. Great Britain's. huge new bombing planes, now undergoing test flights, were admitted by the Air Ministry tonight.

A nation-wide organization of retailers, with State groups formed into a central federation, was declared essential today by Dr. David R. Craig of Washington, to produce a better understanding between the retail industry and government.

Mrs. Mary Hazelhurst Burke or this resort, widow of Robert Law Burke, was married to Earl Biglow of Greenwich, Conn., and New York, son of Mrs. Horatio Biglow, this afternoon in the Miami Beach Community Church by the Rev. Elisha A. King, the pastor.

Two members of the United States delegation to the Fourth International Leprosy Conference, to be held at Cairo, Egypt, the latter part of this month, will depart today on board the Exeter. Fifteen persons from this country will attend the ten-day conference. A third delegate will sail tomorrow on the Conte di Savoia.

Lefty Vernon Gomez and big Charley Ruffing signed Yankee contracts today. This pleasant news, transmitted over the telephone from the home office in New York, heightened Manager Joe McCarthy's satisfaction over a brisk workout by sixteen athletes at Huggins Field as the team began training for the 1938 season.

Henry Armstrong, world's featherweight champion, made it thirtyfour knockouts out of his lastthirtyfive starts by putting away Charley Burns of Johnstown, Pa., in the second round of their scheduled ten-round non-title fight tonight. Armstrong weighed 133, Burns 136 1/2.

The bank property of the defunct Bank of Europe Trust Company, at 1,429 First Avenue, corner of Seventy-fourth Street, has been sold by the State Superintendent of Banks to the Manufacturers Trust Company for $89,000 cash.
The State's Attorney has asked that the Rev. Martin Niemoeller be sentenced to twenty-two months' imprisonment on charges of sedition and misuse of his pulpit.

The St. Francis College basketball team recorded its fourteenth victory in twenty-one games this season, conquering Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, 58 to 37, in the St. Francis gymnasium last night. At the half, the winners led, 39 to 17.

Automobile production declined more than seasonably last week, and the adjusted index eased to 65.2 from 67.2. The figure for the week ended Feb. 27, 1937, was 128.5. The week's output was estimated by Ward's Automotive Reports at 56,677 units, compared with 59,100 in the previous week and 115,360 for the corresponding week last year.

Dr. Robert H. Fowler has leased the two four-story houses at 145-7 East Sixty-second Street to Frederick L. Stagg. The former is on a plot 12.6 by 90.5 feet and the latter occupies a 15 by 91.1 foot plot.

A suave man of 42 was locked up at the West Forty-seventh Street police station early this morning after he had admitted, according to police, of the systematic robbery of rooms in about twenty-five hotels over the last year, stealing furs and jewelry which he estimated were worth $50,000.

The bid of the New York Americans for a second place berth in the National Hockey League play-offs will be continued tonight at Madison Square Garden when they clash with the Canadiens, who are one peg above them in the international group standing.

The statement of the American Reserve Insurance Company for 1937 showed a net earned operating profit of $42,699 after all loss claims and operating costs and after deducting the increase of $164,762 in the reserve for unexpired premiums.

Cloaking their activities in secrecy, agents for the Federal Bureau of Investigation pushed their search yesterday for additional members of the alleged spy ring disclosed Saturday by the revelation that two men and a woman were under arrest on charges of having sought United States Army secrets for a European power.
Officers of the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre and a special benefit committee have taken over the performance of "Save Me The. Waltz" tonight at the Martin Beck Theatre.

In Big Ten basketball games reported last night by The Associated Press, Purdue crushed Chicago, 6433; Ohio State topped Northwestern, 41-36; Illinois conquered Michigan, 36--32; Wisconsin vanquished Indiana, 34--32, and Minnesota turned back Iowa, 30-29. .

The stock market was heavy in tone yesterday from the start, and leading issues closed with losses ranging from fractions to more than 2 points. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was only 560,000 shares, compared with 897,000 on Friday.

Ernest Smith, 45 years old, employed at $56 a month as a WPA gardener, and his wife, Mildred, 26, of 449 West Forty-fourth Street, received a suspended sentence from Magistrate Earl Smith in Night Court last night on disorderly conduct charges placed against them by police last Tuesday following their arrest for soliciting alms as they trundled a perambulator containing their 2 1/2-year-old baby through Yorkville streets. Mrs.

Werther Arcelli of Boston outpointed Bobby Pacho of California in the feature bout of eight rounds before 3,000 persons at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. The winner led most of the way, peppering his rival with lefts and rights continually and proving an elusive target. The winner weighed 145 1/2, Pacho 148 1/2.

The lest week of the Miami Jockey Club's forty-six-day meeting opened at Hialeah Park today, with the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup mile and a quarter handicap next Saturday the chief topic of the racing fans. Today's feature,
Myzejen, Ruhie and Maxhide, sisters of King Zog I of Albania, were ensconced last night in a suite at the Ritz-Carlton, with a reputation for royal dignity apparently established.

After trailing, 16 to 12, at the intermission, the New College girls' basketball team rallied and defeated Hunter College, 43-28, at Thompson Gymnasium yesterday. The Misses Jeanne Andrews and Hildegarde Gross were the high scorers for the winners, registering 15 and 14 points, respectively.

At a meeting of holders of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railway Company 5 per cent fifty-year bonds, Series A, due in 1975, held yesterday in the Hotel Commodore under the sponsorship of the Guaranty Trust Company and Merrel P. Callaway, as trustees, it was voted to petition the Interstate Commerce Commission for an adjournment of the next hearing on reorganization of the Milwaukee for at least two months beyond March 21.

The proposed Patman Chain Store Tax Bill would set up in the government a form of "destruction by taxation," Irving C. Fox, counsel for the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared in an address before the Rochester Advertising Club today.

As required by the new city Charter, Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, issued yesterday for the first time a statement summarizing the cash receipts and disbursements of the city for January. The report said in part:

Steamship owners will continue their efforts to obtain a single type of wage contract with the unions representing their unlicensed personnel despite the failure of recent negotiations in which a committee of the American Steamship Owners Association submitted terms to the unions, it was learned yesterday.

A style show entitled. "Boutonniere of. Spring Fashions," the gay colors of which will be reproduced in boutonnieres to be presented to all guests, will be given during luncheon today in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery.

Dividend payments ordered last month amounted to $309,970,361 for 842 companies, compared with $363,175,368 for 865 companies in February, 1937, and with $281,714,493 for 936 companies in January, 1938.

MANHATTAN AUB, HELEN (Sept. 8, 1937). Gross assets, $123,134; net, $119,922. To Elizabeth Lindemann, $20 per month for life; Edward C. Mack, grandson, $25,000; Della A. Mack, daughter, residue. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $120,812. Stroock Stroock, attorneys. 61 Broadway.

Resumption of theatrical warfare that threatened to affect more than a score of legitimate theatres in the Broadway area was averted yes terday when the labor committee of the League of New York Theatres conceded jurisdiction over company and house managers to the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.
Dr. Fred M. Lowe, city physician of Newton for thirty years prior to his retirement in March, 1935, died today at Newton Hospital of pneumonia at the age of 78.

A place to sit and rest near the World's Fair lagoon will be provided for visitors, Miss Henrietta Addition, director of welfare of the fair, said yesterday morning in an address to the school of politics of the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

Believing that it has successfully sold the idea of more colorful clothes to American men, the New York Custom Cutters Club, opening its nineteenth annual style show at the Hotel Commmodore, yesterday launched on a campaign to make its patrons more design conscious.

After an absence of two weeks from the capital, it is still apparent that the key log in the industrial jam is that one labeled "tax revision." It must move in the right downstream current before any break in the recession can be expected.

Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday ordered the issuance of subpoenas calling for Winthrop P. Aldrich, president of the Chase National Bank, and others to submit to examination here by Referee Peter B. Olney Jr. in connection with the reorganization in Illinois of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation.

All German officers ever in service before, during or after the World War learned by a decree issued today that they might be drafted at any time. The age limit is inoperative for either present or former officers.

January exports of food products from the United States totaled $40,278,000 in value, an increase of 208 per cent above the January, 1937, level of $13,096,000, and a gain of $6,320,000 over December, the Department of Commerce 'announced today.

More than 500 persons attended a dinner given last night for Thomas F. Murray, a retired police captain, in the Hotel Astor and presented a miniature gold captain's shield to him. He was in the department forty-three years.

In the sixth annual invitation golf week of the Jekyll Island Club the following were among the winners of the several events: Finlay S. Douglas, C. Tiffany Richardson, Frederick H. Haggerson, Francis D. Bartow, Frederick F. De Rham, Bernon S. Prentice, William H. Conroy, Edward C. Lindley and William D. Mitchell.

Four members of the election board of the First District, First Ward, in Jersey City, were arrested here today because they allegedly violated a State law making it a misdemeanor to refuse to testify before a State investigating committee.
Appointment of Viscount Hallfax as British Foreign Secretary was approved by the House of Commons yesterday when, after Opposition attacks, confidence in the government was voted 226 to 99.
Raging Winter weather returned to this city on a fierce gale that caused widespread damage yesterday as furious March weather came in like a lion a day ahead of schedule.

Charles Douglas Graham, who was believed to have been the last surviving Alderman of the old City ran of Brooklyn, died on Saturday at his home, 1,133 East Twenty-fourth Street, Broklyn, after a long illness. Mr. Graham would have been 92 owned years old next Thursday.

A four-hour strike in the fortysix-story office building at 1,450 Broadway, called by Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes Union, affiliated with the A. F. of L., was settled at 4:30 P. M. yesterday and the forty-four strikers, including elevator operators, returned to work after hundreds of persons had been unable to get to the upper floors.
Peace education, in the school, the home and the community, was discussed last night at a meeting of the United Parents Association of New York City, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
When a man bites a dog it's news, and when professional football accuses college football of luring pro players-well, it's George Preston Marshall.
Twelve-year-old Peter Levine of 11 Slocum Street, New Rochelle, son of a New York attorney, has been kidnapped, Philip S. Tilden, Director of Public Safety of New Rochelle, declared last night.

There were 2,772 cases under observation on Jan. 1 by the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children, according to its annual report for 1937, made public yesterday. The total included 1,351 in Manhattan, 1,038 in the Bronx and 383 in Queens.

The Coca-Cola Company and its subsidiaries showed a net income of $24,681,616 for 1937, after depreciation, Federal income taxes, Federal surtax on undistributed profits and other charges, according to the preliminary annual statement, made public yesterday. The net income in 1936 amounted to $20,398,078.

Dr. William Hazen Freeman, Professor Emeritus at the New York Homeopathic College, for many years a New York specialist in diseases of the stomach, died at his home in Ashland, Greene County, yesterday. His age was 66.
General Motors cars and trucks sold to dealers overseas in January numbered 29,855, a gain of 10.6 per cent, compared with the same month in 1937 and a new high record for a January.
Edouard Champion, writer and historian, died at his home here today. From his father he inherited the publishing house which specialized in medieval Renaissance literature.

Chancellor Schuschnigg's firm handling of the Nazi demonstration in Graz on Sunday leaves no room for doubt that he intends to insist on the enforcement of the Berchtesgaden agreement that those (Nazis) who formerly had been working illegally in Austria would get no protection outside the country and could not expect toleration from the Austrian Government; that, on the contrary, every illegal activity would be severely punished according to the law.

After a month of public hearings on the Administration's $1,100,000,000 Naval Construction Bill, the House Committee on Naval Affairs will meet in executive session tomorrow and is expected to vote to report the bill to the House with a recommendation that it be passed.

Travelers by railroad and automobile passing Lake Huascacocha near the Moroccoeha mining camp belonging to the Cerro de Pasco Copper Corporation have been mystified recently at seeing a snow-covered seaplane riding on the surface of the lake at an elevation of approximately 15,000 feet, high in the Sierras of Central Peru.

All except a half dozen of the city's sixty-five or more hosiery mills were idle today as a result of a "stoppage of work" movement which national officers of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers denounced as an "illegal strike."

In citing the number of canned food groups that are using advertising to overcome price resistance, the American Institute of Food Distribution declared yesterday that such advertising, if persistently continued, is effective.

Declaring that he was wanted in Phenix City, Ala., a man who described himself as Alfred D. Phillips, 31 years old, a homeless counterman, surrendered himself in the West Twentieth Street police station yesterday morning.
Duncan Campbell Lyle, head master of the McDonough School, with which he had been connected for more than sixty years, died today at the age of 90.

Relatively unnoticed among local court operatives this season is one of the most effective performers in town. He is Bernie Fliegel, the City College captain, who is the best scorer in the metropolis even though the records might indicate to the contrary.

Development of an airport at New Hackensack, N. Y., in Dutchess County near President Roosevelt's Hyde Park estate, was added today to the list of Works Progress Administration projects eligible for construction.

Business activity in the furniture industry has leveled off after several months of sharp declines, Seidman Seidman, certified. public accountants, reported yesterday in a bulletin analyzing January business sent to the trade yesterday.

Speculative. interest in the grain markets today was light except for a brief flurry of selling in wheat at the opening. Weakness in securities and commodities, a decline of 3/4 to 1 1/5 cents a bushel in Liverpool and a lack of export demand combined with a forecast of rain overnight in Western Kansas and Oklahoma furnished the bearish incentive.

Mrs. Winifred L. Milner, widow of John Milner, financier, who died last year, and Bert Clark, vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York, today applied here for a marriage license. They will be married on Saturday and sail for Honolulu on their wedding trip. Mr. Clark is a widower.
The pack is closing in slowly on Gordie Drilion of Toronto, but as yet the Maple Leaf winger is in no great peril of yielding his National Hockey League scoring leadership.

Five hundred members and friends of the Women's. University Club celebrated the opening of the club's new rooms in the Hotel Biltmore last night at a dinner-party in the grand ballroom where problems of education for women were discussed by three college presidents and other speakers.

The New York Rovers were buried under an avalanche of goals as they lost to the rejuvenated Baltimore Orioles, 7 to 2, in an Eastern Hockey League game, the main attraction of an amateur doubleheader at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 2,000 was present.

A program of mass mobilization, based on Kwangsi Province principles of political organization and designed to checkmate Japanese penetration, is being rapidly pushed to a conclusion in the Fifth War Area, embracing Shantung and parts of Anhwei and Kiangsu.

In a letter made public yesterday, Samuel Untermyer, one-time special counsel to the Transit Commission, supported the commission in its disagreement with Mayor La Guardia over the unification of the city's subway and elevated lines.
The Senate adopted a $1,402,404,022 Treasury-Postoffice Appropriations Bill today after defeating overwhelmingly a two-man "economy drive" to reduce the bill arbitrarily by 10 per cent.
Governor Lehman sent to the Legislature a special message asking passage of the Livingston-Piper Savings Bank Life Insurance Bill, one of his program measures.

Oscar Schaefer and Walter Karpowich tallied twenty-five and sixteen points respectively as the Dwight School basketball team closed its season by conquering Brooklyn Academy, 66 to 36, on the Seventy-first Regiment Armory court yesterday. Harwitz with eighteen markers starred on the attack for the losers.

Members of the junior auxiliary and the welfare committee of the Orphan Asylm Society of the City of Brooklyn will give their annual joint benefit bridge party on April 26-at the home, Kingston and Atlantic Avenues, Brooklyn.

Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford gave a dinner last night at Sherry's for Lady Decies of London. Other guests included Mrs. Richard T. Wilson, Henry Theodore Leggett, Albert Morris Bagby, Andrew Bibby and Emanuel List.

A mortgage for $27,750 on 356 W 44th St, held by Margaret Hoff from the 356 West 44th Street Corp. Jacob Price, president, was extended to Dec. 1, 1942, at 5 per cent. The owner agrees to remove all violations by next Oct. 1.

The dollar value of retail financing of new passenger automobiles in January showed a decrease of almost 48 per cent from the same month a year earlier and a decrease of 34 per cent from December, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Some 600 dealers from all sections of the country attended the opening yesterday of the annual exhibit of the Automotive Accessories Manufacturers Association at Commerce Hall, Port of New York Authority Building.

Following an attack upon the City College literary publication by the Very Rev. William R. McCann in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Dean Justin H. Moore yesterday banned the sale of the March issue in the college's School of Business.
The Independent Petroleum Association of America has appointed its committee for this year on balance of supply with demand, Charles F. Roeser, president of the association, announced here yesterday.
Mortimer J. Frey is with Paine, Webber Co. E. V. Griffin, Earle C. Babbitt and Edward .B. Breen are with Amott, Baker Co., Inc. W. R. Longshore is with Poor's Publishing Company in Chicago.

Princess Hermine, the former Kaiser's wife, will eavee for Bavaria tomorrow for a rest cure, on medical advice. It is reported that the strain of so many family parties here recently has been too great for the Princess and that she needs several weeks' rest.
The apartment house at 2,250 Haviland Avenue, the Bronx, was purchased by the Field Dale Realty Corporation from the estate of Gustavia A. Senff for cash above mortgages aggregating $24,500.

Arthur Cranfield of Syracuse defeated Ted Murray of Burlington, Vt., 128 to 72, in fourteen innings last night at the Strand Academy in the opening session of their 375point, three-block play-off for the national amateur pocket-billiard championship. Cranfield's high run was 42 and Murray's 30.

Pensioned On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight, Feb. 28: PATROLMAN--Adam Weissheier, 4th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Nov. 18, 1897. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., March 1, 1938:

The stock market here had an extremely small turnover today and most sections sagged. Gilt-edge issues attracted little support, but among the foreign loans German bonds were firm. Transatlantic stocks lost ground; United States Steel and International Nickel fell.

The total tonnage of food moved into consumption last week equaled that of a year ago, despite a 5 to 6 per cent decline in dollar volume among grocery retailers, according to the weekly survey report of the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.

The post of property clerk in the Police Department, vacant for four years for reasons of economy, was given to Colonel Maurice Simmons, an attorney and former national commander of the Spanish War Veterans, Jan. 18, it was learned yesterday at Police Headquarters.

A decision was taken today to build the world's highest cable way or "air ferry" at Chamonix, France, to provide skiers with all year-round sport in the Alps. The new air ferry will extend to the Col du Midi, 12,000 feet high, the one that now ends at the glacier station on a flank of the Aguille du Midi, 7,500 feet up.
The Helvetia Coal Mining Company has called $36,000 of its first mortgage 5 per cent bonds due on Oct. 1, 1938, for redemption on April 1 at 105 at the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company.

Francis J. Trown, a dog show judge who retired in 1935 as vice president of the Raisbeck Electrotype Company of New York, died at his home here today after a long illness. Born in Sheffield, England, sixty-five years ago, he came to this country in 1898.
By JOSEPH P. DAY 46th St, 433 W, 5-story tenement, 26.4x 100.5; Joseph Ferigo against Two One Three Realty Corp; due, $25,980; taxes, etc, $944; to plaintiff for $26,000.

The run of "A Doll's House," originally scheduled to close on March 12, has been extended two weeks until March 26 at least. Elsa Maxwell is entering the Broadway production ranks tonight with the sponsorship of Leonard Sillman's latest endeavor, "Who's Who."

Shipments of gold from Japan to this country have been- resumed after a lapse of about two months. A consignment of $4,358,000 of the metal is en route to San Francisco and is expected to arrive there about March 10, according to reports received by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Back upon the bench after a two weeks' absence, the Justices -of the Supreme Court were thought to have set a record for speed when today they handed down nineteen formal decisions in a little less than half an hour.

Several residential and commercial properties were included in the Brooklyn realty transactions announced yesterday. The four-story apartment at 2,408 Clarendon Road was sold for the Harrison Holding Corporation by Hy. D. Agar, Inc., brokers.

Fred Tilden Elsey, president of the American Trust Company, San Francisco financier and one of the leading Pacific Coast bankers, died today of a heart attack at his home here at the age of 61. He also was a leader in civic affairs.
Stocks heavy, closed lower in less active trading; turnover, 560,610 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds easier, foreign issues mixed; trading quiet; transactions, $4,886,400.
Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick will receive today at least two syndicate bids for all or none of the $43,000,000 of New York City serial bonds that will be offered.

A large and admirable loan exhibition called "Great Portraits from Impressionism to Modernism" will open with a private view today and to the public tomorrow at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. Mrs. Sam A. Lewisohn is chairman of the exhibition committee.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey yesterday reduced the tank car price of numbers 2 and 4 fuel oil at Bayonne and Bayway, N. J. 1/4 cent a gallon to 4 2/4 cents. The barge price on heating oils in New York harbor also was reduced to 4 5/8 cents.

Edward H. Sherwood notified the New York Curb Exchange yesterday that he was unable to meet engagements and in accordance with the constitution of the Exchange he was suspended from membership. It was said his indebtedness was almost entirely to brokers.
George C. Beresford, original McTurk in Kipling's "Staiky Co.," died at Brighton on Feb. 21, but it was not known here until today. He was 72 years old.

T. V. Soong, Mme. Chiang Kai-shek's brother and former Finance Minister, will not resume that portfolio and will not actively rejoin the Chinese Government unless the Hankow leaders meet his three imperative demands.

Multi-family housing projects renting to families with yearly incomes of $1,800 to $3,000 will be the most important field for investment in new home construction in the next three years, in the opinion of C. J. Devine, president of C. J. Devine Co., Inc., Wall Street brokerage firm.

Open-market money quotations were unchanged again last month, as they had been for many months. The call money rates of 1 per cent on the New York Stock Exchange and 1 1/2 per cent on the New York Curb Exchange, which have been in effect since May, 1936, were continued and time money was offered, without takers, at 1 1/4 per cent for sixty and ninety-day loans and 1 1/2 per cent for six-month loans.
A Senate finance subcommittee acted today to halt a foreign invasion of unfinished hats by deleting a single word from the Tariff Act of 1930.
Tobacco and Allied Stocks, Inc., reports a liquidating value of $63.16 a share on 52,761 shares outstanding at the close of 1937, as compared to $78.33 on 49,358 shares the year before.
After holding for several hours in a narrow range, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced sharply yesterday in the late dealings to end with net gains of 3 to 8 points.

Jacob Steelman Disston of Philadelphia, a director of the steel tool manufacturing company that bears his name, died at Belleview today. His age was 76. Mr. Disston had been at his Winter cottage there since December.
Theodore Dreiser, author, asked the Court of Appeals today for permission to appeal a judgment -of $16,393.69 obtained against him in State Supreme Court by the Liveright Publishing Company.

The undefeated Northwood School hockey team kept its slate clean today by defeating Lawrenceville School in Hobey Baker rink, 5-1. Paced by Bud Goff, Northwood scored in all three periods, completely thwarting the Red and Black attack.
