The Maine Central Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to pledge and repledge certain bonds as collateral for notes of not more than $1,000,000 until June 30, 1940.

Lieut. Col. Robert Olds walked into the White House Executive Offices today after a record-breaking 12,000mile round-trip flight to Buenos Aires to receive the personal congratulation of President Roosevelt and to hand him a message of felicitation from President Roberto M. Ortiz of Argentina. THE GOOD-WILL FLIGHT TIMES made by the "flying fortresses" goin to and coming from Bueons Aires, are Shown.

Verle Davis, a curly-haired youngster from Kankakee, Ill., touched off the knock-out fireworks tonight in the opening-session of the Golden Gloves tournament of champions, finishing off two lightweight opponents with a grand total of three punches, before 14,000 spectators in the Chicago Stadium.

The discovery that no suitable drum was immediately available for the concert to be conducted by Arturo Toscanini for the benefit of unemployed musicians Friday night at Carnegie Hall, caused the National Broadcasting Company to make arrangements for the drum of the Chicago University Band to be. hurried to New York for a tryout.
Opposition to the bills now in the State Legislature which would restrict the rights of property owners in certiorari proceedings, was registered yesterday by several more groups.

Hans Dieckhoff, the German Ambassador, called on Secretary Hull at the State Department today and informed him that the German Government had again warned its nationals resident in this country against membership in the Amerika-Deutsche Volksbund or any "possible substitute organizations of that kind."
In order to accommodate the increasing number of women who seek to serve as jurors in Queens, County Clerk Paul Livoti announced yesterday a special arrangement.
The failure of the Interstate Commerce Commission to hand down its railroad rate decision last week has been interpreted by some persons as a tacit declaration of independence by that body.

Mary LaVilla, 23-year-old strike sympathizer, of 137 Meeker Avenue, Brooklyn, was fined $100; Henry Beckman, 43, an organizer, of 402 South Third Street, Brooklyn, was convicted on an assault charge, and Beckman and two others were acquitted in Queens Special Sessions yesterday in cases growing out of the picketing of the Krug Baking Company plant at Ninety-fifth Avenue and 138th Place, Richmond Hill. Justices Gresser, Walling and DeLuca were presiding.

The twenty-fifth season of Giovanni Martinelli's association with the Metropolitan Opera will be observed Sunday evening, March 20, at the Opera House with a special "gala performance." Leading members of the company will take part and scenes and acts from various operas will be performed.

Ishbel MacDonald and her village handyman fiance, Norman Ridgley, were married in semi-secrecy today at Hampstead Town Hall in London. The wedding caine only two weeks after the announcement of Miss MacDonald's. engagement, which caused general surprise in Britain.

The city of Jacksonville, Fla., will be in the market on March 16 with a new issue of $1,000,000 of electric revenue bonds. They will be dated April 1, 1938, and will mature serially from April 1, 1939 to 1948. Bidders are to name a rate of interest not exceeding 6 per cent.
The crow situation seems to be interesting more than the usual amount of hunters this year, and we've had any number of queries as to the methods which bring the best results.

234th St (12-3375), n s, 147 w of Katona Ave., 37x100; Minnie Scheier to Helen S. Fuhn, 275 E 234th St.. Simpson St (10-2726); w s, 397 s of 167th St, 37x100; Ray Abrams to 1,075 Simpson Realty Corp, 1,075 Simpson St; mtg $20,000.

Frankie Frisch, hampered by two broken bones in his right foot, plans to direct his Cardinal pitchers and catchers, who arrive tomorrow at the club's Spring base, from a grandstand box at Waterfront Park.

The comparative calm of the past few days in Palestine was broken this afternoon with the murder of Abraham Goldshloeger by a band of Arab terrorists. Mr. Goldshloeger, 38 years old, had, for eighteen years in Palestine, served as a guide and teacher to the young American communal settlement at Juara near Mishmar Haemek, at the northern border of the proposed Jewish State.

The International Amateur Athletic Union Federation, at the opening session of its convention today, accepted Jesse Owens's 100-meter sprint record of 10.2 seconds. The previous world mark of 0:10.3, in which five men shared, thus was wiped off the record books.

Representatives of the theatre and the literary and the musical worlds urged at a hearing by a Senate subcommittee on education and labor today passage of the PepperCoffee bill to establish a Federal bureau of fine arts.

A number of properties on the upper West Side and in Harlem changed lands in the Manhattan transactions reported yesterday. Aaron Weiss, operator, sold the new law apartment at 211-13 West 108th Street to a client of Frederick and Jerome Weiss,

The efforts now being made by the Cuban Government to settle old debts is a preliminary to the establishment of Cuba's own bank of issue in an independent currency system, Dr. Pedro Martinez Fraga, the Cuban Ambassador, said in an interview this afternoon.
Southern Blvd (10-2742), n @ cor of 163d St, 511x200 irreg; Joseph P. Day, Inc. to Bowery Savings Bank; extends mtg to Feb. 1, 1943, at 5 per cent; $300,000.
The parking ban creating ten new "express" streets in downtown Manhattan became effective yesterday, a day ahead of schedule, speeding traffic -through the financial. district....

Net profit of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company and subsidiaries for 1937 amounted to $6,253,380, including $1,504,268 profit on the sale of securities, the annual report, issued yesterday, revealed.

Informal conferences of the three signatories of the 1936 naval treaty will begin tomorrow when diplomats and naval attaches of France, Britain and the United States will meet at the Foreign Office to discuss the procedure to be followed now that Japan has refused to reveal her building program.

Opponents of the appointment of Simon W. Gerson by Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs decided yesterday to continue their fight for his removal by filing charges against Mr. Isaacs with Governor Lehman, by holding a parade as a demonstration of public opinion and by asking for a State legislative investigation of the appointment and of subversive activities in general.

Connecticut Light and Power Company (Controlled by United Gas Improvement Company) - For 1937: Net income after all expenses and charges, $4,173,644, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $3.31 a common share, against $4,531,473, or $3.35 a common share, in 1936.
Classes at Temple University were dismissed when six engine room employes unexpectedly walked out on a strike today, one of the coldest of the year.

Dr. Manley 0. Hudson, American member of the Permanent Court of International Justice, reviewed the history of the World Court and deacribed its functions yesterday at a luncheon of the League of Nations Association at the Murray Hill Hotel, Park Avenue and Fortietl Street.
Panzer won both games of a basketball double-header from Upsala on the Panzer court tonight. The men's team triumphed, 62 to 43, and the women's team prevailed, 52 to 10.

The former Pritchard estate of about five acres, in the Greenfield Hill section of Fairfield, Conn., ?? been purchased by James S. Adams vice president of Benton Bowls advertising agency. William C Codman Jr., was the broker.

More than 300 WPA associates of Hamilton L. Shields, retiring deputy liaison officer between Mayor La Guardia and the Works Progress Administration, attended last night a dinner given for him in Gallagher's Steak House, 228 West Fifty-second Street.
Hermann W. Merkel, general superintendent of the Westchester County Park Commission and former New York City park official, died early today in the Ossining Hospital. He was 64 years old.

Concerned over a shortage of city funds for relief financing, the Board of Estimate voted a relief appropriation yesterday amounting to 25 per cent of the March budget, which will carry disbursements through the first week of this month only.

Mrs. Rosalind Abramson Nirenberg, Albany artist and etcher, died today in Albany Hospital after an illness of more than three months. While Mrs. Nirenberg was ill, her painting of Kenneth Harder, son of the Woodstock. N. Y.,

A new link in world aviation came into prospect here today when it was announced the United States Government has approved negotiations between the Philippine Commonwealth and The Netherlands Government for a Philippines-Dutch Indies service.

Dennis J. Haylon, managing editor of The Berkshire Eagle, and Joseph Hollister, associate editor and columnist, were the honored guests at a dinner given here by fifty friends tonight at the Hotel Wendell. Mr.

The annual report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal operating subsidiaries for 1937, which will be forwarded today to the concern's 642,000 shareholders, shows a consolidated net income of $182,342,866 after all expenses and charges.

Pending decision on an application for review in the State Supreme Court of forty indictments returned against thirty-one persons here in an investigation of this city's affairs, Common Pleas Judge Dallas Flannagan postponed the trial date for the defendants today until March 28. Mayor Meyer Ellenstein.

Richard Lewis, director of the organizing committee of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, affiliated with the C. I. O., held a conference yesterday with Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, concerning unemployment conditions in the financial community.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted an application by the Chicago Curb Exchange for permission to withdraw its registration as a national securities exchange, effective on March 15, upon the condition that notice to that effect be served prior to March 10 by the Exchange on all issuers having securities listed on it.

The volume of trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in February was the smallest of any month since February, 1935. The largest business for a day last month was 1,299.315 shares, on Feb. 23, and Feb. 11 was the slowest day in three years, with 387,210 shares sold.
Charlotte K. Demorest and Frank lin F. Howe have been elected to the board of directors of Potter Hamilton Co., Inc. Dana dePeyster Whipple has joined the commercial department of the same firm.
In a report of the death of William B. Bailey of East Orange, N. J., published in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Friday, it was stated that the Gevaert Company had been absorbed by the Agfa-Ansco interests.

State Controller Morris Tremaine today sent a check for $32,667,291 to New York City education authorities. The check represented the second payment of the State aid for schools during the 1937-38 academic year.
Mrs. Alice Schieffelin Sabine Coles of this city, widow of Francis Woodhull Coles Jr., was married here yesterday to August Rubsamen of Murray Hill, N. J., by the Rev. Telford L. Russell.

Transfer of a part of an eye of a dead man in what was described by the surgeon as the first operation of its kind in the United States has given partial restora-tion of sight to Father Antonio Santandreu.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow. HOGS Receipts 13,000, including 3,500 directs. Market very active. 15-25c higher than the

Mrs. M. Fleischer, in 45 W 81st St; William C. Brenman, in 127 W 96th St; Margaret Casey, in 245 W 75th St; J. J. Connolly, in 250 Riverside Dr; H. H. Fiske, in 25 Prospect Pl; Apartment Renting Co, Inc, broker.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions GUY HUNTER CO., INC., men's neckwear manufacturer, 9 E. 38th St.-Voluntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $24,959 and assets of $37,959. Petitions Filed-By

The report of H. M. Byllesby Co. for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net loss of $609,876 after expenses, taxes, interest and, depreciation to market of trading securities, in contrast with a net profit of $424,341, on the same basis, in 1936.

On Feb. 1 THE NEW YORK TIMES named Louis Kaufman, 585 Osborne Street, Brooklyn, as among several defendants charged with alleged workmen's compensation insurance frauds. This information was containted in a formal release given to newspaper men by District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan.
Two teas for prospective members of sororities will open the rushing season at Hunter College today and tomorrow, according to Priscilla Avery, chairman of the PanHellenic Society.
A Senate Finance subcommittee under the chairmanship of Senator Connally has undertaken the formulation of a permanent tax policy "to take the profit out of war."

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 25: CAPTAIN Bruce, B. H., Navy Yard, Washington, D. C. to duty as naval inspector of machinery, Babcock Wilcox Co., Barberton, Ohio. COMMANDERS Burrough, E. W., Newport, R. I., to the staff of the Commander in Chief of the U. S. Fleet, as engineer officer.

The Duke of Genoa and Countess Maria Luisa di Ricaldone were married today in the presence of Italy's King and Queen and other members of the royal family. The 53-year-old Duke, who is Prince Ferdinando of Savoy-Genoa, is an admiral inthe Italian Navy and commander of the upper Adriatic area.

Mrs. Richard H. Dana and Mrs. Hall Park McCullough gave a reception yesterday afternoon at Mrs. Dana's home, 340 East Seventy-second Street, for members of committees actively interested in plans for a concert .to be given by the Dessoff Choir and the Philharmonic Symphony Chamber Orchestra on April 19 at Carnegie Hall in aid of the Bethlehem Day Nursery.
The American Institute of Electrical Engineers announced yesterday the award of its 1937 Lamme Medal to Dr. Robert E. Doherty, president of the Carnegie Institute of Technology, Pittsburgh.
Mrs. Evelyn Fahnestock Steele obtained a divorce here today from George S. Steele of New York on grounds of cruelty. Custody of their two children and property rights were covered in an agreement.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 23:
The Throckmorton Hotel on Norwood Avenue Loch Arbour, N. J., overlooking Deal Lake, has been sold to Herbert I. Moyer of Allentown, Pa.
The Chamber of Deputies, by a vote of 398 to 158, tonight adopted the Labor Code with certain revisions in the text rejected by the Senate.

John Early, North Carolina mountaineer, whose escape from ' the leper colony here and subsequent appearance before a Congressional committee some years ago created a sensation, died today. He was 64 years old.

Turpentine firm, 25c; sales, 27 barrels; receipts, 64 barrels; shipments, 160 barrels; stock, 25, 527 barrels. Resin Steady; no sales; receipts, 800; shipments, 570; stock, 75,778. Quote: B, D, E, $3.75l F, $4.40; G, $4.50; H, $4.60; I, $4.70; K, $4.75; M, $4.90; N, $5; WG, $6.50; WW; X, $6.75.

THE reports from the baseball training camps are coming in. It's about time to check up on their problems. What are the prospects this year and how do they differ from last season? Figuring that all the holdouts will come in as usual, the Yankees of 1938 should be about the same team they were in 1937, which is a dreadful conclusion for the other clubs in the American League to face.

Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming announced today that Robert O'Brien, assistant director of the registration division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, would be the first witness tomorrow when a judiciary subcommittee opens hearings on the BorahO'Mahoney Federal Licensing Bill.

Further evidence of administration concern over the re-election prospects of Alben W. Barkley, majority leader in the Senate, was provided today at a White House conference participated in by President Roosevelt, Attorney General Cummings and Thomas S. Rhea, of Kentucky, who was defeated by Governor A. B. Chandler in the 1936 Gubernatorial campaign.

Trading was fair to slow. Steer hind and rib prices were strong to slightly higher, Fresh pork cuts, steady to slightly lower. Other classes, steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb prices to be strong to slightly higher. Other classes steady quality considered, as reported yesterday by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Led by Jim Lancaster, former N. Y. U. captain, the Police Department basketball team clinched the Municipal Athletic League championship last night by defeating the Department of Sanitation five 33 to 24, at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company gymnasium. Lancaster accounted for 15 points.
Sir Gerald Campbell, Consul General of Great Britain, yesterday opened an exhibition of paintings by Nagash Yawalkar, 23-year-old Indian artist, at the Delphic Studios, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street.

The dollar volume of wholesale trade declined 12 per cent in January as compared with the same month last year, according to a joint study by the National Association of Credit Men and the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, made public today

Dr. Mariano Suarez, editor of the Conservative newspaper Debate, and Alfonso Equiguren have been imprisoned for alleged revolutionary activities in behalf of former President Jose M. Velasco Ibarra, according to the newspaper Universo.

J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, the top ranking player in the Eastern Association, was eliminated from the national indoor tennis championship yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.
Twelve men today worked through their eleventh consecutive day trying to rescue a little fox terrier imprisoned in a fox hole. As night fell they believed they were nearing success.

JUNIOR VETERINARIAN, $2,000 a year, Bureau of Animal Industry, Department of Agriculture, Applications must be on file not later than March 31, if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, washington, Wyoming, and not later than March 28, from all other states.
Dr. Glenn Frank in outlining the purposes of the Republican program committee and his views on trends, spoke in part as follows:

Mrs. William Carter Dickerman, vice president of the New York Kindergarten Association, gave a reception and tea yesterday at her home, 6 East Seventy-ninth Street, for committee members and subscribers for the association's benefit performance of the Mozart opera, "Cosi fan tutte," by the Salzburg Opera Guild, on March 11 at Carnegie Hall.
The Treasury will have no additional "new money" issues in connection with its financing on March 15, Secretary Morgenthau announced at his press conference this afternoon.

McGill's Redmen trounced the University of Toronto, 7-2, tonight to win the International Intercollegiate Hockey League championship. The Montrealers finished a game ahead of Queens University of Kingston, Ont.

The Jewish community of America must make a determined effort to impress Great Britain with the need of maintaining an open doorin Palestine to provide a haven for oppressed Central and Eastern European Jews, Pierre Van Paassen, foreign correspondent and lecturer, said last night.

The city's 1938 basic tax rate to be set by the City Council at City Hall today is expected to be substantially higher than the 1937 basic rate of $2.64 per $100 of assessed valuation. Mayor La Guardia called a special meeting of the Council for noon today to set the tax rate.

Into this morning's broadcast leapt groups as far apart as within the polar circle, the Arctic Siberian stations and Krivoirog miners in the Southern Ukraine to assure Soviet listeners how thoroughly they approved the coming trial of Alexei Rykoff, Nikolai Bukharin and the nineteen others accused and how they firmly demanded punishment for them.

The firm name of Maloney, Anderson Block of 50 Broadway is to be changed today to Block, Maloney Co. William B. Anderson is withdrawing as a special partner and J. Lewis Hay is being admitted as a special partner.

Allen R. Brown, New York economist, told the House Banking Committee today the Goldsborough Retail Discount Bill would provide a "release from restraint on normal processes of production and consumption."

Premier Juan Negrin's earnest words in his radio appeal, pledging republican Spain to retake Terue as a symbol of victory, were having their effect today. This was principally noted in declarations that various labor unions and parties would lay aside all differences, knuckle down to work and produce arms and munitions.

Glenn Cunningham will attempt an incredible double at the Knights of Columbus carnival in Madison Square Garden a week from Saturday, when he seeks a new world record in the Columbian Mile, then matches strides with Jim Herbert and company in the Casey 600.

A plea to Mayor La Guardia to reduce the number of fleet-owned taxicabs in New York City was made yesterday by Samuel Ostroff, attorney for two cab fleet companies against which a strike is threatened on the grounds that they abrogated contracts that do not expire until Dec. 31.
Employes of the Eastman Kodak Company will receive checks tomorrow amounting to $3,425,000 in payment of the largest wage dividend since the company's profitsharing plan was adopted in 1912.

The Balkan Entente's decision to advise the two members not having yet done soTurkey and Greece--to recognize the Italian conquest of Ethiopia will increase to more than thirty the number of governments that either have recognized or are about to recognize in one form or another the new situation in East Africa.

A substantial volume of man orders came into the local merchandise markets yesterday, with the demand for dresses showing its first definite improvement in many weeks, manufacturers and resident offices reported. Coats and suits continued active and, while numerous calls developed for colors, black was outstanding.

After nearly two months of inaction the British Government has finally selected three of the four members of the "technical commission" that is to go out to Palestine to make a new study of the partition question.

Seeming to forecast the formation of a national third party, Governor Philip F. La Follette of Wisconsin declared last evening there was a new American political movement under way determined that the form of democracy should not be used to stifle democracy and refusing to accept another war as a false solution of American problems.

Miss Ellenor Brigham Colgate, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Craig Colgate of Flushing, has set April 23 as the date for her marriage to Benjamin Loring Young -Jr., son of Mrs. Mary Coolidge Young of Santa Barbara, Calif., and of B. Loring Young of Weston, Mass. The ceremony will take place in St. John's Church, Flushing.

CHARLES ALLEN SMART'S R. F. D."* is a book that every townsman who has ever thought of living the year round in the country will want to read. For Mr. Smart, who left this perfidious island of Manhattan more than three years ago to live and work and write on an Ohio farm, is the most eloquent Book-of-the-Month Club Theocritus we have had in years.

Mrs. Carrie F. Cooley Brush, widow of Charles F. Brush, former Professor of Civil Engineering in New York University, died yesterday at her home, 260 West End Avenue, after an illness of several months.

Flotations of new securities here during February were in the smallest volume for that month since 1985. The marketing of two large issues of public utility bonds, however, brought the month's total offerings well above the three preceding months, but they were still substantially smaller than in February last year.

A marked increase in the number of fatalities, accidents and injuries in the last week, including the week-end, compared with the corresponding period of 1937 was reported yesterday by the Safety Bureau of the Police Department.

Mrs. Carrie F. Cooley Brush, widow of Charles F. Brush, former Professor of Civil Engineering in New York University, died yesterday at her home, 260 West End Avenue, after an illness of several months.

Flotations of new securities here during February were in the smallest volume for that month since 1985. The marketing of two large issues of public utility bonds, however, brought the month's total offerings well above the three preceding months, but they were still substantially smaller than in February last year.
Contract bridge enthusiasts assembled yesterday afternoon and evening in the Park Central Hotel ballroom for a week's tourney in the twelfth annual Eastern bridge championshipss.

Czechoslovakia's reply to Chancellor Adolf Hitler, which will be made by Premier Milan Hodza before the Chamber of Deputies on Thursday or Friday, will be expressed in much firmer terms than if it had been delivered a week ago.

Funeral services for Charles Christman, stenographer of the Felony Court of Queens, will be held at 8:30 o'clock tonight in the Hollis Avenue . Congregational Church, Bellaire, Queens, of which he was a member.

Cathedrals and churches will hold special services tomorrow to celeorate Ash Wednesday, and there will be special services daily in many of the churches throughout the forty days of Lent. Easter is April 17, ending the season of fasting and prayer.

On March 11 Doubleday, Doran will bring out "The Greatest Show on Earth," by S. A. Spencer. It is a photographic history of man's struggle for wealth and an exposition of our economic cycle. There are more than 120 full-page illustrations from photographs taken by Margaret Bourke-White, Sarra, Keppler, Aarons, Rothstein and others.
Mrs. Richard Trimble of 1,020 Madison Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Randolph Trimble, to Count Giovanni, Revedin of the Italian Diplomatic Service.

Bernard M. Baruch, testifying before the Senate Committee on Unemployment today, declared that the United States must choose between the profits system and the hope of gain and "the new European idea of State regulation and the fear of punishment."

A group of 650 men and women representing Poland's 20,000,000 peasants, or 70 per cent of the total population, met here today at the annual Populist party congress to demand political rights for the farmers and a large share in the government.

M. L. Wilson, Under-Secretary- of Agriculture, wrote Senator McKellar today that his proposal to construct "superhighways" across the nation, to be financed by tolls, "would not be in accord with the program of the President."

Miss Nancy Clay Hancock, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Hancock of this place; was married to Douglas Farley Cox Jr. of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J., this afternoon in the Paris Presbyterian Church, by the Rev. J. W. Flotfelter.

Australia's cricket team, slated to tour England this Summer, compiled 477 runs against Tasmania today and followed with a second innings score of 150 for three wickets when play was adjourned for the day. Tasmania was dismissed for a first innings' total of 112.

With the Ohio State Senate voting today to extend its session so that an investigation of the State government could continue, announcement was made that petitions were being circulated asking for the removal of Governor Martin L. Davey.
Governor Lehman tonight nominated James C. Bonbright of New York City for reappointment as trustee of the Power Authority of the State of New York and the Senate confirmed the nomination.
The Bell Oil and Gas Company has bought the eighty-one shallow oil-producing wells of the Continental Oil Company in the Burkburnett field near Wichita Falls, Texas, it was reported here yesterday.
Acting to forestall a threatened jam on one of his program bills, Governor Lehman sent to the Legislature tonight a special message demanding the passage of the Savings Bank Life Insurance measure.

John S. Harrison of the Squash Club and John H. Doeg of the Union League Club, seeded No. 1 and No. 4, respectively, were among the victors last night in the quarter-finals of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Class B title tourney at the Yale Club courts.

The situation here today would be virtually normal-if this were a city of Nazi Germany. For a city that still belongs to independent Austria the situation is anything but normal. The writ of Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's government does not run in this city any further than the Nazis and Dr. Arthur SeyssInquart, Nazi Minister of the Interior, permit.

Passage of the bill appropriating $2,700,000 for the construction of parkways in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx has been urged by the Park Association of New York City, Inc., in letters to Jeremiah F. Twomey, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Abbot Low Moffat, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the Assembly.

President Roosevelt replied today to recovery suggestions of 1.900 "little business men" by quoting from a letter of transmittal by Daniel C. Roper in which the Secretary of Commerce observed that "it is an interesting thing that self-help

The terms on which Premier Benito Mussolini is expected to insist in the coming Anglo-Italian "friendship talks" were reported to the inner circle of the Cabinet today by the Earl of Perth, British Ambassador to Rome.

Senator Carter Glass plans to introduce tomorrow a bill providing for the regulation and limitation of bank holding companies, he said today after conferring with President Roosevelt. Senator Glass declined to discuss details of his proposed legislation,

Arnaldo Pacanins, electrical engineer and son of Dr. Carlos Pacanins, Minister of Public Works in Venezuela, arrived yesterday on-the Grace liner Santa Elena to make a three- month study of electrical equipment manufacture in the United States.
The Metropolitan Opera premiere of the one-act comedy, "Amelia Goes to the Ball," by Gian-Carlo Menotti, will take place tomorrow evening.
March appeared early yesterday morning in the habiliments of the proverbial lion, but before the day was over was wearing lamb's wool.
There are too many deer in Atlantic, Bur-lington and Ocean Counties, the State Fish and Game Commission was told today by farmers and berry growers, who want something done about it.

Miss Etta Marguerite Lindley, a pioneer woman teacher of physical education and a lecturer on the subject, died last night after a lingering illness at her home, 55 East Ninety-third Street, in her eightyfifth year.

Store units for retail businesses in various parts of the city predominated in the reports of commercial rentals submitted yesterday. After a tenancy of fifty-six years at 160 Seventh Avenue, Eli E. Schavrien, wholesale and retail cigar dealer, has taken a store in 194 Seventh Avenue.
The La Guardia administration sent to Albany today a new bill laying the foundation for bargaining with the State Government on the division of money from the tax on gross income of public utilities.

The world today has all the fighting it can find use for, and some thing left over. Just the same, it is good to see the lively fight between conservative teachers and progressive teachers now in convention assembled.

Senators Lodge and Walsh joined today in introducing a resolution calling for a Senatorial investigation of foreign imports and the possible connection between them and unemDlovment in the United States.

Funeral services for Hermann W. Merkel of this place, general superintendent of the Westchester County Park Commission, who died in Ossining Hospital yesterday, will be held at 2:30 P. M. Thursday in the Ferncliff Chapel, Dobbs Ferry.
The Shansi Province army of General Yen Hsi-shan is falling back in Southeastern Shansi as the Japanese continue to press their offensive into the Western and Southwestern sections of the province.

Consolidated net income of the Crane Company amounted to $9,765,126 after all charges including Federal and foreign income taxes and $353,190 surtax on undistributed profits, according to the annual statement for 1937 released yesterday by Charles B. Nolte, president.

A third-period surge which netted three goals enabled the New York Americans to defeat the Canadiens of Montreal in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Going into the last session tied at 1-all, the Spangled skaters broke

Stocks recovered previous day's losses and closed generally higher, chemical issues leading; turnover, 534,140 shares. United States Government bonds higher, other groups irregular; transactions, $4,586,275.

Pilgrim Ave, 1,969, dwelling, 50x95; Home Owners Loan Corp against Francesco Amaturo, due, $9,954; to plaintiff for $500. By NAT V. ROTHENBERG 3d Ave, 2,562. 3-story store, 27.3x92.11x irreg; Edgar T. Appleby against Garfinkel Steinberg Corp, due. $14?? taxes etc., $357; to plaintiff for $3,000.

Because of the broadening interest in the housing problem and particularly in the question of supplying adequate quarters for families of low income, wide attention is being given to a report on housing studies in Northern Europe, just prepared for the American Institute of Architects by George H. Gray of New Haven, Conn., a former regional director of the organization.

Foreseeing a ready market for tung oil as a result of the war in China and cessation of shipments from that country, Brazil has launched into an extensive program ?? producing the oil, Carol H. Forster, American Consul General at Sao Paulo, Brazil, told the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc.,

Six matches were played in the metropolitan squash tennis Class B championship on the courts of the Columbia University Club last night. All three of the seeded players who saw action, Don Noble of the Crescent A. C.,

Attacks on the National Mobilization Bill continued today with undiminished vigor. If the fate of the measure depended on the debate, its opponents would have reason to be satisfied with their display.

The ten-year Greco-Turkish treaty, which is virtually a political and military alliance, was initialed at Angora yesterday before the departure of Marshal John Metaxas, the Greek Premier, and will be signed in Athens in April by Jelal Bayar, the Turkish Prime Minister, and Tewfik Rushden Aras, the Turkish Foreign Minister.
In a defiance of official orders that amounted to rebellion, 15,000 Nazis paraded through Graz, Austria, last night in honor of the Nazi Interior Minister, Dr. Seyss-Inquart,

The trial of John Rylowicz, also known as Reo, who is charged with the murder on Jan. 12 of Mrs. Celind?? Waite, 52 years old, and Miss Jeanette Schuellain, 18, in Mrs. Waite's home in Elmont, L. I., began here today before County Judge Cortland A. Johnson and a jury Of ten men and two women.
Dr. Francis Bayer, despondent over his ill health, committed suicide by hanging, this morning in the garage at the rear of his home, 25 Cumberland Drive, according to the police.

Alan Bruce Fairchild, 21 years old, who gave his occupation as a clerk, attempted suicide by slashing both of his wrists yesterday afternoon in his room at the West Side Y. M. C. A., 5 West Sixty-third Street.
Arturo Toscanini has made a new three-year agreement with the National Broadcasting Company, it was learned yesterday.
Gabriele d'Annunzio died suddenly from a cerebral hemorrhage at 8:05 o'clock this evening in his villa on Lake Garda, in which, except for brief intervals,...

The Senate by a vote of 45 to 3 passed the Williamson bill to make bridegrooms tell the truth. The measure makes it a misdemeanor for a bridegroom to swear falsely to data concerning his bride when he obtains a marriage license.

Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, recently retired as chief of the Army Engineers, was formally sworn in as Commissioner of Public Works by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday, though he Has been performing the duties of the office since Feb. 11.

The lowly Detroit Red Wings held the Boston Bruins under control for 35 minutes, only to crack wide open and receive a 6-1 setback tonight before a 10,000 crowd in a National League hockey game at the Boston Garden. It was the Bruins' eighth victory in nine undefeated starts.
A mass elopement of six under-age couples was balked today by Paul Martens, chief juvenile probation officer. They had planned to wed in Alabama, he said.
General Cornelius Vanderbilt and his daughter, Mrs. Vanderbilt Davis, were dinner hosts tonight to Mr. and Mrs. James H. R. Cromwell aboard the Vanderbilt yacht, Winchester.
Clarence H. Collins Jr., a former member of the faculty of Roselle Park High School and baseball coach, died last night in Memorial Hospital, Orange, after a brief illness.

The classic one-mile relay, always the outstanding race of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. championships, has drawn entries from fifteen colleges for the seventeenth annual games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Chairman Asa S. Bushnell.

The Chinese air force has been steadily expanded in recent months. The recent addition of fast new ships given foreign and Chinese fliers new confidence, evidenced by destructive bombing raids on Japanese troop and supply bases and successful challenges offered to Japanese squadrons in air battles.

Cash dividend payments by the companies in the Standard Oil group for the first quarter of this year will aggregate $23,551,120, compared to $25,437,708 in the similar period last year, according to a compilation made by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

An unusual fashion show of apparel for women and children, which has been arranged by Mrs. Fenton Taylor, will be presented at a luncheon under the auspices of the Arts and Interests Committee of the Junior League on Monday at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

Raymond Fisher, 38-year-old guard in the Hudson County Penitentiary, who once served a prison term for murdering his uncle, killed his wife with a razor and then fatally shot himself here today at their home, 316 Grace Street, according to the police.

The formation of a new sales division, known as the Resale Department, to serve a market consisting of more than 200,000 electrical manufacturers was announced yesterday by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.

The following are appointed as ununlformed firemen, with compensation each at the rate of $2,000 per annum, for a probationary period of three months, to take effect at 12:01 A. M., March 2, and they shall be charged to the code noted below.

Robert Wright, a former building contractor of this city, died today in his home here. He was 81 years old. A resident of this city for more than sixty years, he built many of the Summer homes on the beach front here and at Monmouth Beach.
Maximilian Henry Peiler, retired actuary of the Aetna Life Insurance Company, with which he was connected more than sixty years, died today at him home here. He was 88 years old.

Charged with using rubber hose to flail a school teacher whom she accused of whipping her 8-year-old daughter, Mrs. Andrew Schultz of Normansville has been fined $5. The fine was imposed by George W. Casey, justice of the peace.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer entertained with a large dinner at Capricho. Mr. and Mrs. Robert McCoskry Butt were hosts at a cocktail party at the Everglades Club for Mr. and Mrs. Robert Louis Aste.

The Premier, Patriarch Miron Cristea, will make an official visit to Poland soon, according to a government announcement today. This seems to scotch all rumors of his impending resignation as Premier.

Willie Smith of the Salem Crescent A. C., international 126-pound champion last year, was upset in the semi-finals of the Golden Gloves tournament sponsored by Daily News A. A. at the Hippodrome last night. A crowd of 5,500 saw Smith drop a three-round decision to Tony Saraullo of Philadelphia.

Godfrey S. Rockefeller, J. Stillman Rockefeller and J. Sterling Rockefeller, trustees under the will of William G. Rockefeller, have sold two plots of land on Round Hill Road, Greenwich, belonging to the Rockefeller estate to George Skakel. The purchase price was $31,968.

Philip H. Philbin Jr., former stock broker, who was hunting lions with the Maharajah of Rajpipla and riding camels in Egypt while Federal agents waited two years for him to return to the United States, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of mail fraud and violation of the Securities Act under which he may be imprisoned for sixty-four years and fined $27,000.

Premier Camille Chautemps, coaxing and threatening and making concessions, succeeded today in getting portions of his conciliation and arbitration provisions through both the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate.

John L. Lewis, head of the C. I. O., will get a "warm reception" if and when he comes to Oregon, Governor Charles H. Martin said at a board meeting today. "I've got some good news for you, boys," he said. "John L. Lewis is coming out here."

The three 5-story tenements on thes e. cor of Hudson and Grove Sts, 73.5 on the former and 59 on the latter, were sold by Florence Vassar and Natalie Vassar MacDonald of Lakewood, N J, to Old Chapel Properties, Inc. William C MacDonald, Lakewood, president, for a consideration indicated as $48,000.
Seabiscuit got a new rider today and it stopped raining, all of which brought new twists to the preface arguments over the Santa Anita Handicap Saturday.

Staving off a last-period rally, the Montclair State Teachers College basketball team closed a successful court campaign tonight by winning from St. Peter's College of Jersey City, 55-54. It was Montclair's sixteenth victory as against five defeats.

More than 350 students at Columbia University, in a campus mass meeting, adopted resolutions yesterday censuring Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler for "infraction of the right of freedom of speech at Columbia" in banning a speech by Robert Burke, an ousted student.

The Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve Board today reelected Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board, as its chairman and George L. Harrison, president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, as vice chairman.
The plan which Governor Lehman has recommended, to permit savings banks in this State to write life insurance policies up to individual amounts of $1,000, cannot be called merely experimental.
" Traviata" will be given tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House, with Helen Jepson as Violetta and Nino Martini as Alfredo.

Dr. Otho Fulton, pioneer in the field of facsimile transmission of pictures and printed matter over radio or wire lines, a leading experimenter in this field for more than twenty-five years, died here Monday night of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

The outright and unconditional repeal of the undistributed profits tax, drastic modification of the tax on capital gains and the elimination of a new tax on closely held corporations were advocated in a

Following the policy recently announced by the United States Steel Corporation, the Jones Laughlin Steel Company and others, the Republic Steel Corporation has reduced. the working week for office employes from five and one-half to five days, with a loss of pay for the half day.

On the eve of the publication of the government report on the position of British civil aviation, Sir Francis Shelmerdine, Britain's civil air chief, suffered a nervous breakdown and received an extended sick leave.
The American business recession was seen yesterday by Sir Josiah Stamp, British economist, as the immediate and "most important" factor affecting world trade.

In the belief that a second world war "does not seem far off, "216 Protestant ministers and rabbis out of nearly 1,400 in the metropolitan area have pledged themselves to renounce war and "never" to support another conflict.

Democratic members of the City Council, eager to claim first credit for housing developments in the city, put through a resolution yesterday calling for a housing survey just as Mayor La Guardia was preparing to call a conference of real estate men on housing at City Hall next Tuesday.

The extensive collection of Napoleonic autographed letters and documents assembled by Louis Alexandre Berthier, one of the emperor's ablest marshals, who fought in the American Revolution, was sold at Sotheby's today.

Delegates of the Metropolitan Cooperative Milk Producers Bargaining Agency today voted for continuance of the current $2.20 hundredweight fluid price for milk shipped into New York City and endorsed the plan for a Federal order to regulate produced prices.
Wilfred D. Blood of Rutherford, head of W. D. Blood Co., 36 Pearl Street, New York, exporters of automotive vehicles, died yesterday in the Passaic General Hospital of acute appendicitis.
Miss Elizabeth Christine Cook, Associate Professor of English at Teachers College, Columbia University, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was born in Northampton, Mass., sixty-one years ago.

Every phase of the complicated legislation affecting the even more complicated real estate and mortgage situation in the State was debated this afternoon before a joint session of the Mortgage and Real Estate Committees of the Senate and Assembly.

Mrs. Mary Fitzgerald of 652 Seventy-sixth Street, Brooklyn, died last night in the Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn. Mrs. Fitzgerald was the mother of the Rev. Edmund Fitzgerald, pastor of Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church in Mineola.

Smarter of garb but even more remote of manner than when they arrived here Monday, the three sisters of King Zog of Albania got little satisfaction yesterday for their professed curiosity about this country.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Wadsworth Mead, daughter of Mrs. Elmore Roy Mead of Adrian, Mich., to Donald Robert Norris of Lamoille, Ill., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarkson Norris, which took place on Saturday in Christ Church, Rye, N. Y.

A start was made last night in the metropolitan Class C squash tennis championship on the courts of the New York Athletic Club. Only one seeded player went into action. He was J. P. Leo Jr. of the home club, who had little trouble eliminating J. Hanley of Delta Kappa Epsilon, 15-3. 15-8.

Avery Brundage, American delegate to the International Amateur Athletic Federation congress here, voiced strong opposition today to a Japanese suggestion that the dates for the 1940 Olympic Games in Tokyo be changed because of hot weather during the months of August and September.

Organization of the small business men of this State, Northern New Jersey and Southern Connecticut into an association intended to "foster, disseminate and effectuate those matters which will promote and safeguard the general economic and business welfare of smaller

Governor Lehman signed several private and local bills and conferred with legislative leaders on the furtherance of program bills. The Senate passed the Mortgage Bank Bill, the Mortgage Moratorium Extension Bill and the third and fourth cent gasoline taxes.

Physical Culture Shoe Company will open new stores on Friday at 300 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, and at 221 East 167th Street, the Bronx, it was announced yesterday by L. A. Leopold, general manager of the chain.

Two hundred and seventy seriousminded young men, ranging in age from 17 to 21, started their final examinations yesterday at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street, for entrance to the United States Military Academy at West Point, next July 1.

Two city detectives were assigned to guard the wife of State Senator Walter H. Gardner today after she disclosed she had received a telephoned threat in connection with her husband's sponsorship of a narcotic control bill.

The demand for tickets for this year's nineday season of the Metropolitan Opera Company here is greater than ever before, and more Boston music lovers will be disappointed through inability to obtain tickets.

Frank A. Shea, 1,100 Park Avenue, New York City, sold to the Overlook Realty Company, Inc., Charles Small, president, the two dwellings, a filling station and a garage on a plot 75 by 99 feet at 132-136 Forty-third Street, Union City.
Through an error, Professor Robert S. Hillyer was credited by THE NEW YORK TIMES with collaborating with the late Professor Chester Noyes Greenough in preparing the college text "Writing

Sales of ice refrigerators last year reached more than 600,000 units, an increase of 200,000 compared with the preceding twelve months, and the industry aims at a total of 800,000 this year, according to a forecast made yesterday by officials of the Eastern States Ice Association, in annual convention in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Mrs. Anna Hudson Condict, floriculturist, died late last night in her home here after a short illness. She was 82 years old.

Winston Guest remains at the top of the Indoor Polo Association handicap list, but the changes announced last night by the handicap committee made one of his teammates a companion at the 9-goal figure.
The salaries of officers and employes of the Ruberoid Company will be reduced on a sliding scale on March 15, Herbert Abraham, president, announced yesterday.

Class I railroads of the United States in January had a net railway operating income of $6,919,879, or at the annual rate of 0.49 per cent on their property investment, compared to $38,889,878, or 2.73 per cent, in January, 1937, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

For the third successive year, Miss Patty Berg, 20-year-old Minneapolis golfer, won the medal today in the qualifying round of the fourteenth annual Florida East Coast championship on St. Augustine links. The red-haired schoolgirl star notched five strokes from women's par to lead the large field with a score of 36, 39-75.

Ten thousand shares of 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Cumberland County Power and Light Company were offered yesterday by a group of investment firms headed by H. M. Payson Co. of Portland, Me., acting as agents for the company.
Charges that the Rykoff-Bukharin trial, scheduled to begin in Moscow today, was a frame-up were made here yesterday as Soviet Ambassador Alexander A. Troyanovsky in
Several adverse factors face Alaskan salmon packers for the 1938 season, with much of the 1937 pack still on hand and possible labor trouble as a result of jurisdictional disputes and tie-ups.

Athletic officials at the University of Michigan tonight announced the appointment of Clarence Munn, line coach at the University of Syracuse and former Minnesota All-America guard, as Wolverine line coach.
Arthur W. Ramsdell, who has been associated with the sales department of the Borden Company for the last year, has been appointed director of sales for the company in the United States and Canada,

For the third successive year, Conway Hoffman of the Montclair A. C. found himself a member of the champion metropolitan squash racquets doubles team as he and Beekman Pool, Harvard Club ace, captured the final last night at the Heights Casino.

The four heavier divisions went into action tonight in the second round of the eleventh annual Golden Gloves tournament of champions and recorded thirty knockouts and technical knockouts for the benefit of 15,000 spectators in the Chicago Stadium.

Charges by a newly formed group of teachers, terming themselves "essentialists," that progressive education methods are weakening the public schools brought swift replies from Dr. John Dewey and Professor William H. Kilpatrick of Columbia University, chief exponents of those methods, at the convention of the American Association of School Administrators here today.

The Walter McMeekan interests, through the Realty Freehold Corporation, have purchased the threestory apartment and store building at 1,498 Flatbush Avenue, near Glenwood Road, Brooklyn, from the Walden Holden Corporation (Paul Ohnewald and Jason P. Denlinger).
The Erasmus Hall High School basketball team clinched first place in the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. Division 2 race yesterday by defeating New Utrecht, 32 to 24, on the winner's court.

The stock market was extremely quiet today, and yesterday's dullness in Wall Street caused an easier tendency in most sections here. Gilt-edge issues fell. Among the foreign loans Austrian bonds made some headway. Transatlantic stocks were weak although there was some recovery at the close, and United States Steel went ahead.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I note that the Associated Merchants and Property Owners have prepared a resolution against the chain store tax bill now pending in the Legislature. The resolution charges that the bill "would sound the death-knell of every chain store in New York State and would

Carl H. Berets of 440 West End Avenue, president of C. H. Berets Co., Inc., and of Berets, Bezer Co., Inc., dealers in investment securities, died on Monday night of a heart ailment at the Sydenham Hospital after a long illness. Mr.

The tax rate of this city will be $4.84 higher in 1938 than it was in 1937 if the City Commission adopts the tentative budget submitted today by Bert Daly, Director of Revenue and Finance. The commission will hold a public hearing March 23.

The $250,000,000 emergency relief appropriation, overwhelmingly approved by Congress, went to the White House today for quick signature by President Roosevelt. Congressional action was completed when the House accepted, 336 to 9, a conference committee's compromise.
Percy L. Dunn has been appointed Scout Executive of the Manhattan Council of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday by Percy Jackson, president of the council.

The German Air Force today celebrated the third anniversary of its official creation with military parades and festivities that reached a climax in a remarkable speech by Air Minister Hermann Goering at the Air Ministry before heads of the Reich, the National Socialist party and the armed forces.

Mr. and Mrs. F. Randolph Dunn of Maplewood have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Helen Carolyn Dunn, to Dr. Frank Albert Disney, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Disney of Rockville Centre, L. I.

Dr. Ivan Wright, Professor of Economics and Finance at the University of Illinois and a member of the Economists National Committee on Monetary Policy, has been retained as consultant by Granbery. Marache Lord.

The American ORT Federation, 212 Fifth Avenue, opened yesterday a national campaign to raise $450,000 to provide technical and agricultural training for Jewish victims of social and economic discrimination in Poland, Germany,

The marriage of Miss Suzanne Cort, daughter of Mrs. Harry Lindsley Cort of 102 East Twenty-second Street and the late Mr. Cort, to John Walter Wood, also of this city, took place yesterday afternoon at the Gramercy Park Hotel. The Rev.

A vivid six-week drama of war in the Pacific starts March 14. It is the annual manoeuvres of the United States fleet. "Fleet problem nineteen" is the title. The players are 3,600 officers and 55,000 men aboard 150 surface ships and 500 fighting airplanes.

D'Annunzio seemed like some incredible hero of legend or of some splendid unwritten Latin film. If there were elements of the charlatan in him, he believed immeasurably in himself. He created and staged for himself striking parts in literature and in life.
Mrs. Barbara Monell Glaze, formerly of New York, was married to Henry A. Hoder of Victor, Col., dude rancher and biggame hunter, here today by Justice J. H. Gowdy.

Employes of Stephen Ransom, Inc., of New York, a ship-repairing concern, have been directed by the National Labor Relations Board to hold an election within fifteen days to determine whether they wish to be represented for purposes of collective

Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch of Yugoslavia returning from the Balkan conference at Angora, Turkey, conversed on the train with the Bulgarian Premier, George Kiosseivanoff, who had awaited him at the Greek frontier and accompanied him to Sofia.

WHO'S WHO, a revue in two acts and thirty-two scenes. Sketches mostly by Everett Marcy and Leonard Sillman. Music mostly by Baldwin Bergersen, James Shelton, Irvin Graham and Paul McGrane. Lyrics mostly by June Sillman, Mr. Graham and Mr. Shelton. Scenery by Mercedes;

Representatives of religious, business and professional organizations throughout the State expressed today at a public hearing their "whole-hearted" approval of the Desmond-Breitbart bill requiring of men and women a serological blood test for syphilis before the issuance of a marriage license.

Charles H. Regnault, formerly with the Central Savings Bank In New York for thirty-five years, died suddenly this morning at a hotel in St. Petersburg, Fla., after a brief illness. He was born in New York fifty-nine years ago.

Traffic in Lexington Avenue between Thirty-eighth and Fortieth Streets was cut off for an hour and a quarter yesterday afternoon when a workman digging in the roadway with an air compressor drill touched an underground low-tension cable and caused a short circuit.

Superior Judge Reuben Schmidt today cited Harry Bridges, head of the C. I. O. International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, and four others to appear before him March 17 and show cause why they should not be adjudged in contempt of court for describing a recent anti-C. I. O. decision as "outrageous."

Jewish Board of Guardians second annual conference of Jewish prison chaplains of City, State and Federal institutions, Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, 9 A. M. Speakers: Commissioner William J. Ellis, William Portner.
Buddy Hassett and the Brooklyn Dodgers failed to reach a decision yesterday on the matter of his salary for the coming season.

Unemployment throughout the nation totaled 10,342,000 in January and represented an increase of 1,427,000 over December, 1937, the National Industrial Conference Board reported in estimates made public yesterday.
Stockholders of the American Can Company, the American Chicle Company, the United States Realty and Improvement Company and other corporations held their annual meetings yesterday.

A sharp criticism of the "fear appeal" as used in current advertising campaigns for drugs and pharmaceutical products, voiced by Mrs. William Dick Sporborg, chairman of the department of legislation of the General Federation of Women's Clubs,

A large plot fronting about 700 feet on Willets Point Boulevard at Northern Boulevard, opposite the World's Fair parking grounds, Flushing, has been purchased by a client of Frank L. Starke, Flushing attorney.
The New York State Athletic Commission, at its meeting yesterday, amended its rules regarding the amount of bandages to be used by boxers.

Thousands lined the streets of Jerusalem early this morning to see Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, the retiring high commissioner, drive en route to Ramleh air field, whence he flew to Egypt to board a steamer for England.

Hearing in removal proceedings for Peter (Cowboy) Covaleecehio and Guido D'Allesandro, alleged bank robbers wanted in New Jersey, was postponed yesterday by Isaac N. Plant, United States Commissioner until next Tuesday.

The stock market recovered yesterday most of the ground lost on Monday and on Saturday, but the volume of trading declined. The day's business on the Stock Exchange was 534,000 shares, the smallest for a full day since Feb. 16. Monday's total was 560,000.

Charles F. Noyes has added to his personal realty holdings in the downtown district and has completed the assembly of a corner plot by the purchase of about 1,000 square feet at 221 Pearl Street from the Christian G. Euler Estate.

The marriage of Miss Marie Peets of New York, daughter of William F. Peets of Albany and the late Mrs. Peets, to William Wallace, son of Mrs. William T. Wallace, also of this city, and the late Mr. Wallace, took place yesterday noon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The strike in effect in Rockefeller Center for the last twelve days, called by Local 3 of the Electrical Workers Union, affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, was settled last night, Gerald Duffy,

Trading was only fair to slow. The lamb market was strong to 50 cents higher and other classes of traefa meats showed little change in price. The kosher markets opened about in line with Monday's close, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The University of Rochester basketball team inflicted upon Hobart College the first defeat of its home campaign tonight, 44 to 32. The visitors led by 12 points at the half and retained their advantage.

The East Tennessee Light and Power Company, Bristol, Tenn.; the Toledo Light and Power Company, Jersey City, and the Central Arkansas Public Service Company, New York City, subsidiaries of the Cities Service Power and Light Company, have registered under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

Miss Irene Lewisohn of 113 West Eleventh Street gave a supper party last night at her home for Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt after the performance of "Save Me the Waltz" at the Martin Beck Theatre, which was taken over by the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre for the benefit of its scholarship fund.

Dr. Robert Staunton Adams, restdent physician for about thirty years at the old Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Thirty-fourth Street, who treated many celebrities there, died on Monday in the home of his sister, Mrs. A. A.- MacLachlan, in Pittsburgh after a long illness, according to word received here yesterday.

Miss Ella von Stamwitz, youngest daughter of George C. von Stamwitz of 165 East Sixty-sixth Street and the late Mrs. von Stamwitz, was married to Francis Girard, son of Mrs. Francis Girard of Lawrence, L. I., and the late Mr. Girard, yesterday afternoon in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer by the Rev. Stanley McGovern of Irvington-onHudson.
In the 300-yard, individual medley race of the Yale swimming carnival tonight Miss Helene Rains of New York City broke a national record in defeating Miss Doris Brennan of Providence.
An Arab was killed and a Jew was wounded last night when an armed band of Arabs attacked the Orthodox Zionist settlement of Kirath Zvi in Beisan Valley.
Maximum discounts for Agfa Ansco photographic films and cameras were sent in notices received yesterday by 27,000 retail outlets in the forty-two States which have fair trade statutes.

Moving at terrific pace all the way, Columbia trounced Harvard, 58 to 34, in an Eastern League game at the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night, assured Dartmouth of at least a tie for the title and added minor complications in the race for runner-up honors.
A mother and three children were burned fatally and four other members of the family were injured in a fire which swept a six-room clapboard house at 43 Ogden Avenue here this morning.

The bankers' forum of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Banking will hold the first of a series of Spring meetings at the chapter headquarters in the Woolworth Building tonight, it was announced yesterday.

The market for wheat futures fluctuated within a range of 5/8 cent a bushel today on the Board of Trade here and closed at the high point with net gains of 1/4 to 5/8 cent, the latter on the May, which was bought on the disclosure that there was only about 1,000,000 bushels of No. 2 red Winter available for delivery purposes in public and Federally licensed elevators.

The Cunard White Star liner Berengaria will arrive today from Channel ports. On board are Raymond Loewy, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur T. Vanderbilt, Countess Fira Ilinska, Mr. and Mrs. F. Stansfield, Miss Astra Desmond, Miss Harriet, Hutchins, Brian Franks, Mr. and Mrs. R. L. Burdon-Sanderson and G. F. C. Caswell.

The Supreme Court decision this week upholding the 2 per cent tax in New Mexico on gross receipts from out-of-the-State advertising in newspapers and magazines created anxiety in publishing circles because they foresaw other States attempting to adopt similar legislation.

The Commonwealth Film Censors 1937 report records a decline in the import of British films from 27 per cent in 1934 to 20 per cent in 1937. It also points out that while the objectionable features in American films show a marked decline, the British. films remain the same.

Many reservations have been made for the annual card party, tea and fashion show under the auspices of the Greater New York and Long Island Chapter of the College of New Rochelle Alumnae Association on Saturday afternoon at the Plaza.

Captain Joseph Woitkoski, left fielder; John Druze, first baseman, and Albert Gurske, pitcher, all three of whom were football players, have been declared ineligible for varsity baseball at Fordham this year.

Eight "enemy" prisoners from the "Blue" army are here tonight in the "White army headquarters prison. They were identified as an officer and three men from the Eighteenth Infantry in the attacking forces and an officer and three men from the Fifth Marines.

The grievance board of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group has suspended one member for failing to comply with a ruling of the board and has imposed fines amounting to $1,250 upon three other manufacturers for violations of the returns regulations of the organization, it was announced yesterday by Louis Rubin, executive director.

" There's Always a Breeze," or Edward Caulfield's tale of a C. Milquetoast and a glamour girl, will open this evening at the Windsor Theatre, with William Lynn, Cecilia Loftus, Leona Powers and Blanche Sweet in the company. Direction by Harry Wagstaff Gribble, and curtain at 8:30.

While the secretary of the New York Stock Exchange has dutifully followed the advice of the Conway committee that a study be made of the question of service charges and has sent out a questionnaire for the members to fill in, there is still no guarantee that the ensuing pencilchewing will result in anything

After forty years in one ownership, the property at 462 East 167th Street, the Bronx, consisting of a three-story building with store, has been purchased by a client of Charles W. Brown from the estate of W. Stebbins Smith.

The three-story clubhouse of the National Athletic Club, at 11-13 Cedar Street, Brooklyn, where members recently celebrated its fiftieth anniversary and which has been famous for years as training quarters for many well-known athletes, was wrecked by fire early yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Anna May Falck, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Falck of Chicago, to Joseph Wilshire 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wilshire of this city and Greenwich, Conn., took place secretly yesterday morning in Elkton, Md., performed by the Rev. C. M. Cope in his home.

On the basis of reports from 148 of its 216 member institutions, the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations estimated yesterday that the 286 savings and loan associations in the State showed assets of about $373,828,315 at the end of 1937.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States during the five days ended Feb. 24 increased in four trade groups, compared with the same period a year ago, but showed a decline in construction, the fifth group, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Enrollment of 6,800 young men in the 1938 Citizens Military Training Camps to be held at five regular army posts in New York and New Jersey in July and August, was started yesterday at the headquarters of the Second Corps Area at Governors Island.
Mrs. Isabel Metz, formerly of the Famous Barr Company, St. Louis, has joined Lord Taylor as buyer for the negligee department, effective March 7, it was announced yesterday.

After leaving a note in a tenthfloor room of the Hotel Lincoln yesterday morning a woman who had registered as Evelyn Zaiss of Irvington, N. J., plunged to her death on the roof of a third-floor extension in the rear of the hotel. Police reported she "either jumped or fell."
Testimonials in honor of Michael MacWhite, retiring Minister of Ireland to the United States, who will sail on the Berengaria tomorrow for his new post in Rome, were voiced here yesterday by friends.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 28: MAJOR GENERAL Tschappat, W. H., Chief of Ordnance, 1 month's leave, March 4.

A total of 21,598 employes or former employes of the General Electric Company hold $25,364,870 principal amount of General Electric Employes Securities Corporation bonds, an increase in one year of 5,716 in the number of persons and $3,132,270 in the total invested, according to an announcement yesterday by the company.

The following surgeon has been designated to act as Chief Surgeon: To take effect March 1-Charles J. Dillon. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., March 2: PATROLMEN--John T. Sullivan, from 67th Prec. to 84th Prec.; William C. Oser,

Traffic on the nine downtown streets upon which parking is now banned has been greatly speeded, according to police tests made public yesterday. Test runs were made by police cars on Feb. 24 at 9 A. M. and 5 P. M.,

THERE are books that make one glad and grateful that the sheer loveliness of words hasn't been forgotten. For that reason, if for no' other, Mary Ellen Chase will be cherished for the beautiful little story, covering only 115 pages, which she calls, against the Cornish background of the Tristram legend, "Dawn in Lyonesse."

New York University's varsity track and field squad will engage in four dual meets this Spring in addition to competing in the Penn relays, the metropolitan intercollegiate championships, and the I. C.

Ten Broeck M. Terhune, 50 years old, of 45 East Sixty-sixth Street, whose name is listed in the Social Register, was arrested yesterday by detectives of the East Fifty-first Street police station, and charged with grand larceny.

A small exhibition designed to show the influence of the ancient Egyptian style in the art of Eastern Mediterranean civilization many centuries B. C. has been arranged in Gallery E-15 at the Metropolitan Museum, where it may be seen by the public beginning today.
Defeating Trinity, 57 to 28, tonight, Wesleyan concluded a basketball season marked by only two defeats, both administered by Amherst in the Little Three series.

M. L. Martin of the Commercial Credit Council appeared before the Assembly Codes Committee today to urge the passage of the Austin bill, lightening the registration requirements for businesses carried on under assumed names.

A struggle that is expected to decide the future of foreign investments in Mexico and the internal problem of whether Mexico can continue her present course began today when the Supreme Court ruled against seventeen United States and British oil concerns in their wage controversy.

Mrs. Donald McClave was a luncheon bridge hostess today at the home of her mother, Mrs. C. T. Wills, in Belle Haven, Greenwich. Besides Mrs. Wills, the guests included Mrs. Rudolph Goepel, Mrs. Robert McCord, Mrs. F. D. Hendrickson, Mrs. J. T. Foster, Mrs. Frederic Achelis, Mrs. Evelyn Richardson, Mrs. Lee Maxwell, Mrs.

Judging from preliminary information, there appears to have been no substantial further decline in the general level of production and trade in February, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its monthly review, issued yesterday.

The business recession, its cause and cure, will be the first question studied by the Republican Program Committes. which completed its organizatiol today with the appointment of regional committees and the
The Mardi Gras Circus Ball of 1938 took place tonight in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. The Rush Hospital was beneficiary of the event.
The composite price average of 200 real estate bond issues on properties in Eastern cities at the end of February remained at $326, the figure for Dec. 31, 1937, according to Amott, Baker Co., Inc.
William H. Campbell, secretary of the Rochester Rotary Club, said today that the organization's second civic achievement award would go to Frank E. Gannett, publisher.

The employes of six large Nice hotels, which are crowded with British and American tourists, began a sit-down strike this morning and eleven more will join the movement tomorrow unless a settlement is reached.

Pointing to the sharp shrinkage in the market for new capital, John Haskell, executive secretary to the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange, said last night at a meeting of the Accountants Club of America that the Securities and Exchange Commission, the accountants and the Stock Exchange could play parts in ameliorating the situation.

Frank H. Plaisted of Chicago, freight traffic manager for the Southern Pacific Lines, told the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee to-day that relief for the railroads from the long-and-shorthaul rule would "enable the distressed interior producers to re-enter the Western markets."

Putting on a great rally in the last two rounds Al Reid, 126 1/2, Bronx, earned a draw with Mike Belloise, 127 1/2, Bronx, last night in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum. A crowd of 12,000 persons, the largest of the current season, was present.
The Diamond Match Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income for 1937 of $2,111,959 after deductions for depreciation, Federal takes and other charges.
Donald B Gunn Ross, a salesman for the John M. Hart Company of New York, died suddenly on Sunday in his home at 48 Lynden Street here. He was 40 years old.

The course of prices on the Cotton Exchange was influenced yesterday by a reversal of straddle operations between New York and Bombay which created more selling pressure and left quotations here with losses of 7 to 12 points.

Questionnaires on service charges on inactive New York Stock Exchange accounts were sent yesterday to the members of that institution. Firms were urged to compile statistics for the letters "B" and "S" in their security accounts (these letters having been found to

That recent times have brought a new drive against the church in Russia can hardly be denied. The newspaper Godless, which has been allowed to sink into desuetude, has been revived and the so-called religious danger has once more been brought to the forefront.

Miss Mary Thompson Swann of New York, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. M. W. Swann of Bennettsville, S. C., was married at noon today to Robert William Smith of Greensburg, Pa., in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here.

48th St, 16 E, 25x100.5; Frederick Katz to Hawxhurst Realty Co, Inc, 67 Wall St; consideration $53,000 over mtgs for $50,000; foreclosure. 134th St, 116 W, 28x100: Arkro Holding Corp to Edthom Realty Corp, 598 W 191st St; mtg. $8,250 (2).

John L. Lotsch, former chairman of the board of directors of the defunct Fort Greene National Bank of Brooklyn, was found guilty yesterday by a jury before Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo, in the Federal court in Brooklyn,

After six months of eligibility for service in the jury box, some of New York's active women citizens who have taken advantage of their new prerogative pooled their experiences before the New York League of Women Voters yesterday and handed out advice for prospective women jurors and a few suggestions for the improvement of the judicial system.

Arthur Cranfield of Syracuse captured the national amateur pocket billiards championship when he defeated Ted Murray of Burlington, Vt., in two engagements yesterday at the Strand Billiard Academy. This ended a play-off for 375 points after both players had been deadlocked following the regular roundrobin last week.

R. Warren Loewi retired from Schatzkin, Loewi Co. on Feb. 28. Arrangements were made yesterday for sale of a New York Stock Exchange seat for $67,000, down $3,000 from the previous sale, made on Feb. 24.
A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., obtained yesterday an issue of $2,600,000 of Water Works System certificates of indebtedness of the city of Chicago.

Largely due to an increase in bronchopneumonia, deaths of infants in this city rose during the week ended last Saturday to 59.4 per 1,000 live births, the highest mortality rate for children under the age of 1 year since last April, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner.
One man was shot and several suffered minor injuries today when 100 Sheriff's deputies used. tear gas to rout almost 500 persons near the Northwestern Barb Wire Company plant.
Hope Eternal, 6-year-old mare owned by Mrs. Samuel Orr, easily captured the $2,700 Mardi Gras Handicap by two lengths at the Fair Grounds today.

American Business Shares, Inc., Jersey City, an investment trust, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 2,569,044 shares of $1-par capital stock, to be sold at the market. The aggregate amount of the proposed cash offering was estimated at $9,402,701.

Last week we ran a few paragraphs on Alex Price and the combined salmon fishing and bear hunting that can be had in New Brunswick, Canada (some thought we meant New Brunswick, N. J.) from April to July.
In a meet that was closely contested until the decisive 400-yard relay, St. Francis's swimming team defeated Fordham in the losers' pool yesterday, 42-29.

Fundamental changes in marketing and trade activities, as the result of the growing traffic congestion in business districts in the centers of large cities, were predicted yesterday by Dr. Miller McOlintock, auditor of the Traffic Audit Bureau and director of the Bureau of Street Traffic Research, in addressing the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.
Miss May G. Ferrall, president of the Nassau Guild, will give a tea on Saturday at her home, 109 East Thirty-seventh Street, for members of the organization.

The House of Commons approved today a bill authorizing Transcanada Air Line planes to fly over Maine, and to establish three or four international connections with the United States as part of a plan by which the air line, wholly owned by the Canadian National Railways, will have financial share in the company that is to operate the proposed transatlantic air service.
Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw will give a dinner on Monday at her home, 60 East Sixty-sixth Street, for Sir Gerald Campbell, the British Consul General, and Lady Campbell.
" Spotty," a little black and white fox terrier, was rescued alive and apparently in good condition today from a fox den in which he had been entombed for 2601/2 hours.

Bruno Walter, arriving from Vienna to conduct Mahler's Ninth symphony with Mengelberg's orchestra, told reporters he was determined to remain in Austria, although admitting American invitations were extremely tempting.

Greta Garbo, motion-picture actress, and Leopold Stokowski, the orchestra conductor, who once denied there was a romance budding, returned here tonight after spending a day together at the Island of Capri in the Bay of Naples. They were identified by the Mayor of Ravello.

An official admission that German as well as Italian "volunteers" are fighting in Spain is contained in an article by Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, in the periodical Wille und Macht, issued by Baldur von Schirach as an organ for Germen youth.
