BOSCH, HENRY (Sept. 18, 1937). Gross assets, $297,911; net, $267,984. To Marie Johanna Yaple, daughter. Chief assets, real estate, $201,000. Edward J. Krug, attorney, 2,804 3d Ave.

Negotiations have been started for the purchase of the United Shipyards, Inc., by the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation, Ltd., a subsidiary of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, it was learned yesterday.
The legislative leaders, luring their followers with promises of adjournment in the next two weeks, steered the Senate and Assembly through their busiest day today,

New York City property owners will pay taxes this year under the highest basic rate in the city's history, which was reported as $2.80 per $100 of assessed valuation yesterday by the finance committee of the City Council.

Coincident with the arrival at the Yankees' training camp of Jake Powell, fleet-footed outfielder, Manager Joe McCarthy announced today that Frankie Crosetti and Spurgeon Chandler had signed contracts and were on the way.
Movements of vessels follow. All dates are March 1 unless specified: At San Diego, Arctic, Rail. At Mare Island, Feb. 27, Balch, Porter. Acushnet, Yorktown to Naval Operating Base. Norfolk.

A series of 110 daily radio broadcasts, conducted by the New York City Board of Education to supplement classroom teaching, got under way yesterday. Every morning, between 11 and 11:15 o'clock, pupils and teachers will listen to dramatized presentations of various elementary and high school subjects.
A three-member Federal commission reported tonight that the marble properties of Senator Berry and his associates in the TVA's Norris Dam area were "commercially worthless."

Mrs. Bessie Mersky, 65 years old, a widow, was found dead at 7:45 A. M. yesterday in the living room of her three-room basement apartment at 871 Park Avenue, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, where she lived alone.

The minority report of the House Ways and Means Committee on the new tax bill follows in part: We, the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee, submit the following statement of our views respecting the pending bill.
The old Eastview schoolhouse, a one-room building that was built in 1897, burned to the ground this afternoon despite efforts of the Elmsford and Valhalla Fire Departments to save it.

With the formal redemption today by the Chicago Park District of $6,644,000 of its bonds, the retirements of bonded debts by the major governments in Cook County, Ill., reached $26,715,500 in the last two months.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 26: COMMANDERS Calhoun, W. C., New York Shipbuilding Corp., Camden, N. J., to instruction, Naval War College, Newport, R. I., in June.

Richard H. Wood, who retired several years ago after having served for fifty-three years with the Erie Railroad, died last night in a convalescent home after a long illness. For the last sixteen years he had resided here with his son, Charles E. Wood.

Retail sales in the United States in 1937 totaled $39,930,000,000, an increase of slightly more than 5 per cent over the 1936 total, according to a final estimate announced by the Commerce Department today.

Steel ingot output continued at its previous level last week, when a small seasonal easing was anticipated, and the adjusted index advanced to 40.0 from 39.4. The figure for the week ended Feb. 27, 1937, was 115.8.

Eugene Ertle, City Clerk of Jersey City, was subpoenaed today by the Assembly committee investigating the last gubernatorial election- in Hudson County to appear- before the committee at 10 o'clock tomorrow in the Essex County.
A group of Temple University students was dispersed by police today when the students attempted to distribute on the campus leaflets supporting six engineers who went on strike yesterday.

General John J. Pershing continued his improvement to-day and for the first time since his illness became acute was conceded to have a chance to recover. Everything now depends on the 77-year-old World War leader's heart. While weak,

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,322,800 barrels, compared to 3,369,250 in the previous week, a decline of 46,450, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
William Randall of Yale University won the national junior individual epee championship in a field of fourteen contestants on the J strips of the Salle d'Armes Vince last night.

Charging discrimination against the Bronx, in the establishment of rates for shipments to and from Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington, the Bronx Board of Trade has filed a protest with the Middle Atlantic States Motor Carrier Conference, Inc., with reference to rates which the trade board alleges establishes arbitraries of 10 and 15 cents per hundredweight.
Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals has been suggested for the Republican nomination for Governor, it became known yesterday. William S. Murray, State chairman,

2d Ave, 2,244; 4-story tenement and stores, 20x80; Mortgage Commission of N. Y. against Nicola Camerino; due $8,054; taxes, etc. $569; to plaintiff for $1,000. Manhattan Ave, 421; 5-story tenement, 100.11x25; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against William R. Smith; due $39,135; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Davey Day, lightweight from Chicago, will trade punches with Charley Gomer of Baltimore in the feature bout of ten rounds. at the New York Hippodrome tonight. Both boxers. have been performing well of late, and the contest is expected to be an interesting one.

Sale of a New York Curb Exchange membership for $12,000, down $3,000 from the previous transaction, was reported yesterday. The price equaled the 1935 low mark and is the lowest since 1925, when $8,500 was recorded.

A committee representing some thirty-six New York trade associations will appear today at a legislative hearing at Albany to oppose a bill which would impose a tax ranging from $10 to $550 per unit on chain stores operating in this State, as a result of a conference of trade association executives at the Hotel Astor yesterday afternoon.

Eddie Mead, manager of Henry Armstrong, featherweight boxing champion, said today. the fighter sprained his right wrist in knocking out Charley Burns here last night in two rounds and would ask postponements of an exhibition at

Miss Helen Pedersen of Stamford, the top-ranking player in the women's singles, and Bernard Coghlan of California made their exits from the national indoor tennis championships yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Mrs. U. S. Epperson could not go to the Philharmonic concert, so the concert went to her. Mrs. Epperson, one of the women most responsible for organizing the Kansas City orchestra, has been ill two years.
Listing of ten security issues on the New York Stock Exchange was authorized yesterday by the committee on stock list. All will not necessarily be admitted immediately to dealings.

Tne pamphlet report for 1937 of the Beech-Nut Packing Company and its subsidiaries, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $2,741,203 after depreciation, Federal income taxes, minority interest, surtax on undistributed earnings and other charges.
John Hope Doeg, former national lawn tennis champion, gained the final round yesterday in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's Class B title tournament at the Yale Club.

A study made public today by the Brookings Institution deals with the question of how long foreign payments on loans and investments held in the United States can continue unless more foreign goods and services are bought by Americans.

Colonel Ituarte Monasterio, commander of Spanish Insurgent troops on the Teruel front, today sent crack Navarrese cavalry units into the hills with orders to crush bands of government soldiers threatening Insurgent positions on the road to Valencia.

Grand Concourse (11-2831), e s, 215 ft n of 169th St, 100x100; Ben-dor Corp to Dorrit Concourse Corp, 285 Madison Ave; mtg, $84,000. Beach Ave (15-3899). s e cor of Archer St, 50x92; Taybeach Realty Corp to O'Leary Estates, Inc, 384 E 149th St; mtg, $68,600.

Purchases of Alleghany Corporation bonds of 1950 in the market, in accordance with a plan recently approved by the holders, will be made at prices not higher than 61, according to an appraisal of collateral behind the bonds made

The American Sugar Refining Company and domestic and Cuban subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $4,143,138, or $2.20 a common share, for 1937, against $4,352,563, or $2.67 a share, in 1936. Net sales and miscellaneous revenue amounted to $113,058,747, against $91,944,000.

Plans for a non-sectarian Temple of Religion, costing $300,000 for erection and maintenance, on a site of 50,000 square feet at the World's Fair, were announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, at a luncheon attended by clerical and lay religious leaders of various faiths in the Administration Building at Flushing Meadow Park.

Elthan Edward Paul, a retired New York building contractor who was president of the New Rochelle Board of Education, 1914-1918, died today in the New Rochelle Hospital after a three weeks' illness. Born in Toronto on March 31, 1864, he had lived in the United States since childhood.

A strong and more active market for United States Government obligations followed official confirmation of the report that the Treasury's March financing would be restricted to the refunding of the maturing 3 per cent notes and featured an otherwise dull trading session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

After a bitter debate, in which it was held that the measure would "curtail the freedom of the press," the Senate defeated today, 35 to 7, the Williamson bill to make it a misdemeanor for any newspaper or person to print,
Regarded as the first of its kind in the nation, a free adult public school, to run day and night for the teaching and recreation of men and women residing in the heart of the lower East Side,
The German-American League, which the German Ambassador has proscribed for German nationals in this country, replied yesterday: "We take orders from no one, German or otherwise."

Brown defeated the Columbia Lions, 2 to 1, in hockey tonight. Most of the action was confined to the first and third periods. Brown's second line accounted for both Bruin scores, and Sam Calkins scored on a solo thrust for Columbia.

A field of twelve teams contending for the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy in the tournament of the Eastern Bridge Championship was narrowed to eight teams of four players each in the second qualifying round last night at the Hotel Park Central.
Governor Lehman reappointed today Edmond J. Butler of New York City, Edward C. Blum of Brooklyn and Morris J. Gladke of Elmira as members of the State Probation Commission.
With the metropolitan championship at stake, City College and N. Y. U. will clash in their traditional basketball meeting before an estimated crowd of 16,000 at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Fifty-four packaging authorities will discuss important current problems in packaging, packing and shipping at the conference to be held concurrently with the eighth Packaging Exposition at the Palmer House, Chicago, March 22 to 25.
Fritz Reiner has been appointed musical director of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra for next season, it was announced yesterday by Edward Specter, manager of the Pittsburgh Symphony Society.

A pick-up in business is definitely due soon, according to Isaac Liberman, president of Arnold Constable Co., who returned to New York yesterday after an absence of several weeks on a trip through the West.
President Roosevelt said today he would send to Congress soon an informative message on the world phosphate situation, a subject which he described as of tremendous importance.

Montana-Dakota Utilities Company--For 1937: Net income after expenses and charges, $840,330, equal, after preferred dividends, to 64 cents a common share. This is compared to a net of $756,328, or 52 cents a common share, in 1936.

Provisional President Alberto Enriquez announced today his determination to maintain public order and prevent political disturbances until the Constitutional Congress meets in August and elects his successor, when he will resign as Chief Executive.

After being in the line-up yesterday morning, Donald McFaden, 42 years old, who was picked up Monday night by the police in a midtown hotel bar and admitted many thefts in hotels that amounted to many thousands of dollars, took detectives on a tour of about a dozen pawn shops and one check room.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Feb. 19 totaled 305,219,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

A jury of eight men and three women in Supreme Court yesterday awarded to Hiram C. Todd an additional fee of $11,000 from the city for his first seven months' work as special assistant attorney general in charge of the Drukman case investigations and prosecutions in Brooklyn.

The Bowery Savings Bank sold the three-story dwelling at 1,323 Ditmas Avenue, Brooklyn, containing eleven rooms and two baths, to a buyer for occupancy. The house is in the lower Flatbush section and occupies a plot 109 by 100 feet.

The trial of John H. MacMillan Jr., president of the Cargill Grain Company of Illinois, and E. J. Grimes and Philip C Sayles, vice presidents, charged with violating rules of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Commodity Exchange Act by their operations
John Koif of Wenonah, N. J., who has been in a hospital since the explosion last August aboard the U. S. S. Cassin, learned today that he was the winner of the Navy Cross for heroism.
Sarah Beecher De Luppe, American-born wife of Count JeanBertrand De Luppe, renounced her title and regained.her American citizenship in District Court today.

Senator Bankhead of Alabama reported agreement by the Senate Banking Committee today on exempting "all municipal securities" from the Maloney bill for self-regulation of over-the-counter. dealers in securities.
Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name:
A fight by a strong minority of Democrats and the handful of Republicans against the Administration Reorganization Bill opened in the Senate today with a speech by Senator Byrd,
The marriage of Miss Sally Levin of Philadelphia to Ray Shore of Brooklyn, Dickinson College halfback for the last three years, took place on Friday, it was announced here today.

John Benyo, Stafford X. Comber, apartments in 127 Cedar St, completing the renting of this building, which recently was renovated; Cushman Wakefield, brokers. Douglas Ward, from Mrs. Emma H. Orvis, and Mrs. Iris J. Gray, from Milton L. Sternberg, in 1,060 Park. Ave; Potter, Hamilton Co. brokers.
Mrs. Elisha C. Towers gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Lady Decies, who sails today for London.

Unusually active bidding was noted for the property at 49-51 Downing Street, a four-story stable and loft building on a plot 39.6 by 90 feet, when it was put up for auction by Joseph P. Day yesterday in an executors' sale for the estate of Maria Costa.

Twelve battery candidates for Manhattan's varsity baseball squad reported to Coach Bert Daniels for the first indoor practice session, held yesterday in the Jasper gymnasium. Daniels, a former Yankee fielder, is starting his eighth season as mentor of the Jasper nine.

The Central Committee of California Petroleum Producers adopted today the recommendations of the United States Bureau of Mines by fixing the allowable production of crude oil for this State in March at 694,000 barrels daily, an advance of 9,900 over the allowance in February.

Moishe Oysher, 32-year-old star of the Yiddish motion picture "The Cantor's Son," was injured slightly last night when the taxicab in which he was riding with his father, Selig, 58, was in collision with a privately owned automobile at Eastern Boulevard and Elder Avenue, the Bronx.
Regular transatlantic air transportation between the United States and Great Britain by 1940 was foreseen here tonight by Joseph P. Kennedy, new United States Ambassador to Great Britain.

Staving off a strong closing rally by the Brooklyn Bruins, the New York Athletic Club hockey team scored a 6-to-5 victory at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night and thereby gained a place in the final playoff for the New York Amateur Hockey Association championship.

The State Board of Tax Appeals heard argument today on a motion to dismiss a petition for reinstatement of a $300,000,000 assessment in Newark against personal property of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

" The Education of a Diplomat," by Hugh Wilson, Ambassador to Germany, will be published by Longmans, Green on March 25. The book covers the author's experiences between 1911 and 1917 in Paris, Guatemala, Lisbon, Buenos Aires, Berlin, Vienna and Switzerland.
The Oratorio Society of New York, directed by Albert Stoessel, presented its twelfth complete performance of Bach's B minor Mass at Carnegie Hall last night.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today adjourned to June 28 hearings in the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad reorganization. proceedings so as to give bondholders' committees time to work out a plan of their own.
Pope Plus received today a report of the church situation in Germany from Count Konrad von Preysing, the Bishop of Berlin.

Guided by the formula that was so successful in "A Star Is Born," Selznick-International is to pry into the lives of the screen's younger generation with "Heartbreak Town," in which Tommy Kelly and Ann Gillis of "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" will be starred.

Members of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., at a meeting yesterday at the Garment Center Club, decided to eliminate supplementary or second Spring showings and to concentrate on merchandise for a separate Summer season to be launched during the week of March 21.
According to The Daily Sketch, moves began in political circles tonight that may result in the appointment of former Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden as Ambassador to Washington.

At a hearing yesterday before Judge Mortimer W. Byers in the Federal court in Brooklyn, creditors and mortgage certificate holders approved a modified plan of reorganization of Adelphi College of Garden City, L. I., under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

The Rev. Dr. George T. Scott, secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, was informed here yesterday of the death of his brother, Arthur Tressler Scott, 65, and his sister-in-law, Mrs. Scott, 63, in an auto-train collision at Tampa, Fla., according to The Associated Press.
A subcommittee of the House Labor Committee was named today by Representative Norton, the chairman, to write a maximum hour-minimum wage bill.
Irritated by published charges that President Roosevelt was using his office for personal profit in writing, Stephen T. Early, his secretary, said today that,

One of the important sections of the Reorganization Bill now before Congress proposes a shake-up in the civil service. For more than half a century responsibility for the administration of the merit system has rested in the hands of a bipartisan Civil Service Commission.

Net premiums written by the Rossia Insurance Company of America in 1937 amounted to $3,814,054, a gain of $85,662 from 1936, C. F. Sturhahn, president, said in his annual report, made public yesterday. Net premiums on the company's American business increased $661,814, or almost 23 per cent.
A banking group headed by the Chase National Bank was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $43,000,000 of New York City serial bonds that will mature in one to thirty years.

N. K. Winston Co., who recently acquired about seventy-eight acres of the Holmes Airport property in Queens, have leased this land back to Air Terminal Properties, Inc., operating company for the airport, headed by. E. H. Holmes.

In the Constitution of the State of New York (Article IX) it is stated that "The Legislature shall provide for the maintenance and support of a system of free common schools, wherein all the children of this State may be educated."

After four years, C. Everett Bacon of Montclair, N. J., regained the Mid-Ocean golf title today, defeating Kenneth F. Sheldon of Glen Cove, L. I., by 2 up in the eighteen-hole final, played under windy conditions.

A burglar refusing to surrender when trapped by police was shot and wounded critically yesterday by Sergeant Harold Moore, who in 1932 killed Edward (Fats) McCarthy, notorious Coll gangster, in a pistol battle near Albany.
Directors of the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company yesterday elected Harold C. Dean as vice president and assistant to the vice chairman of the board of directors.

New Jersey tavern keepers will not be permitted to dispense alcoholic beverages on the basis of all the customer can consume for a stated sum, D. Frederick Burnett, State Alcoholic Beverage Control Commissioner, declared in a ruling made public at his office here today. Mr.
State Department officials tonight were noncommittal regarding a proposed inter-American league of nations, pending the receipt of official information on the joint Colombian-Dominican project.

Labeling the New York State school system as antiquated and inefficient, the special committee of the Board of Regents, appointed two years ago to conduct an inquiry into the character and cost of public education in this State, severely indicted the system and outlined plans for bringing about "equal educational opportunities for all."

The Japanese freighter Bordeaux Maru, the first ship to pass through the Panama Canal under the new rules as to measurement under the new tolls rate, paid $934 less than she had paid under the former rules and rates.

Banks throughout the country were asked today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, to cooperate with the corporation in stimulating business and reducing unemployment by adopting a more liberal policy in making loans to business.
The Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation may go bankrupt if its taxes are not reduced, William S. Menden, B. M. T. president, declared yesterday in a letter to Governor Lehman.
Ferdinand S. Schenck, a vice president of Albert Frank-Guenther Law, Inc., advertising agents, died suddenly at his home here yesterday morning of a heart attack at the age of 49.
Terrance Doogan, 35 years old, of 1,039 Simpson Street, the Bronx, died in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, yesterday, the first victim of a fatal accident since the

Mrs. Anna Devaney, whose large family includes a great-great-grandchild, celebrated her 105th birthday here today at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Patrick Conlon, with whom she lives at 155 Grant Avenue.

Colonel Bill Terry became the professor today, as under the lee of the Louisiana State University buildings he put his Giants through their second day of intensive training in the new Leche Stadium, which lies just off the college campus.
In the face of the expressed opposition of President Roosevelt, the House Naval Affairs Committee today allocated to aircraft $10,000,000 out of a total of $30,000,000 provided in
The trustee for the Denver Rio Grande Railroad was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue $2,000,000 of trustee certificates to pay part of the cost of the improvements.

The Duross Company leased the vacant plot at 90-92 Bradhurst Avenue to the General Outdoor Sign Company. Louis L. Gans, formerly with the Charles F. Noyes Company and Pease Elliman, has joined the leasing department of Fass Wolper.

Colonel Horatio B. Hackett, former Director of Housing of the Public Works Administration, has been elected president of Thompson-Starrett, Inc., according to an announcement made yesterday by L. J. Fischer, chairman of the board of directors of the company. Mr. Hackett was also elected a director.
His back criss-crossed with welts raised by twenty lashes from a cat-o'-nine tails, received at the whipping post today. Clyde Miller, 37-year-old printer, lay face down tonight in the jail hospital;
Bernie Friedkin, 133 1/2, Brownsville, won the decision over Jimmy Lancaster, 1294, Wilmington, Del., in the main eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena last night before 3,500 spectators.
Opposition to the proposed Anglo-American trade treaty flared up in the House of Commons today.

The six-story apartment house at 324 West Ninety-sixth Street has been leased for ten years by the 324 West Ninety-sixth Street Corporation, Nathan Lidsky president, to the M. A. Leasing Corporation, represented by David Natelson, attorney, at a reported gross rental of about $75,000.

Miss Daphne-Jean Stewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Stewart of 29 Arleigh Road, this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Herbert Bell Urquhart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Urquhart of Birkdale, Lancashire, England, which will take place on March 26 in St. Paul's Church here.

That the terrier breed winners will provide the sharpest competition in the variety group judging tomorrow was indicated today during the first sessions of the second annual allbreed exhibition of the Genesee Val-ley Kennel Club.
With law-enforcement agencies still officially maintaining a handsoff policy, the disappearance of 12year-old Peter D. Levine of 11 Slocum Street, New Rochelle, remained a mystery last night.
" Goetterdaemmerung," the finale of the "Ring," and an opera that towers to the sublime, was performed at the special matinee yesterday in the Metropolitan Opera House.

Of the four former titleholders competing in the current world's pocket billiard championship tour nament, only Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia escaped unscathed as the first round was completed yesterday.
The American Smelting and Refining Company declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents on its common stock. The last payment, on Feb. 28, was 75 cents a share. No regular rate is maintained.

Didoric, R. Lehman's American-owned Grand National candidate, won the $1,500 Stayers Steeplechase over a three-mile-and-three-furlong route today. Didoric paid 6 to 1 and finished a length ahead of V. H. Smith's Rockquilla, which paid 10 to 1 to place. J. Sugden's Frankie, at 25 to 1, was third.

football schedule listing nine opponents, on which home games alternate for most of the season with contests away, was announced for Lafayette today by Henry W. Clark, director of athletics. The schedule:

The marriage of Miss Helen Marie Schrafft, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Schrafft of South Orange, to Leonard B. Zusi Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Zusi of Maplewood, took place this afternoon here in Our Lady of Sorrows Church.

Revenue of between $15,000,000 and $20,000,000 has been lost to the State during the present business recession because of the capital gains and losses tax, Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission,
In a recent poster contest sponsored by the Opera News of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, Peggy Brendgord and George Blackwell of the Dwight Morrow High School, Englewood, N. J., were selected winners.

The National Labor Relations Board issued a complaint tonight against the Atlantic Greyhound Lines, Inc., of Charleston, W. Va., charging interference with an election by employes to determine their bargaining agent.

Miss Muriel A. Williams, daughter of Mrs. John L. Williams of this city and the late Mr. Williams, has selected April 23 as the date for her marriage to William Stuart Allison Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Stuart Allison. also of Elizabeth.

The Treasury's statement for Feb. 26, made available today, showed that $13,042,377 had been taken from the inactive gold fund of the government, bringing the total of the socalled sterilized gold in the fund to $1,200,560,560.

Charles A. Smith, controller for the American Trust Company, dropped dead today while walking from the ferry building to his office. His death followed by twenty-four hours that of Fred T. Elsey, president of the bank, who also died suddenly. He was in his fifty-fifth year.

THOUGH it was written in jest, it still seems true that "some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em." This popped into mind when scanning the approved list of new world's records for track performances issued the other day in Paris by the International Amateur Athletic Federation.
The report of the Technical Committee on Medical Care tells us nothing about the sad state of the medically indigent that we did not know before.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Allan Hudson Church of this place, formerly of Elizabeth, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hester Dey Church, to Oswald Elmer of Elizabeth, son of Mrs. John Olrich Elmer of Egg Harbor and the late Dr. Elmer.
U. S. ONE: FROM MAINE TO FLORIDA, compiled by the WPA Federal Writers Project. (Modern Age, 95c.) The first of the Highway Tour Books of the American Guide Series.

Burning Star, second in the weights for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup next Saturday, had his first race since last November in the Trade Winds Purse at Hialeah Park today and finished a fast-going third back of Palamede and-Corinto.
The Rev. A. Maurice Morgan, retired Methodist Episcopal minister, died in his home here yesterday.

ADAMS-At the residence of his sister, Mrs. A. A. MacLachlan, Pittsburgh, Pa., on Monday evening, Feb. 28, 1938, Dr. Robert Staunton Adams. Remains will arrive in New York Thursday. Services at Greenwood Cemetery Chapel, Brooklyn, N. Y., Thursday afternoon at 3 o'clock. Interment Greenwood Cemetery.

Informal discussions between representatives of Great Britain, the United States and France began at the Foreign Office here this afternoon on the question of whether existing restrictions on the size and gun power of their battleships and cruisers should be continued.

Four prizes in the National Book Awards for 1937 were announced yesterday by Clifton Fadiman at the book award luncheon of the American Booksellers Association at the Hotel Astor. Mr. Fadiman remarked that he was not interested in what the Pulitzer Prize Committee would do about these selections.

Continuing his testimony before the Senate Committee on Unemployment today, Bernard M. Baruch said he was opposed to attacks on the business system on a broad front for the sole purpose of breaking it into smaller pieces,...

In the Supreme Court of the United States today the following proceedings were had: 502-John N. Shannahan and Claude J. Jackson, as trustees of the property of Chicago, South Shore South Bend Railroad, et al., applts., v. the United States, et al. Argued for both.

Lewis Arthur Cushman Sr., founder and chairman of the board of Cushman's Sons, Inc., retail bakery chain, left a net estate of $1,017,533 when he died on March 10, 1936, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.
Australia's cricket test team proved far too strong for a representative Tasmanian eleven today, winning by 386 runs after declaring with only four second-innings wickets down.

American airplane lines carried 1,267,580 passengers and 8,914,067 pounds of express in 1937, the Bureau of Air Commerce said today. This was an increasee of 119,000 passengers and 564,000 pounds of express over 1936.

Frank Herbst, a senior, of 1,346 Forty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, was elected president of the Student Council of City College, Commerce Center, yesterday. Joseph Brody was elected vice president and George Weissman secretary.
Laborite Members of Parliament became suspicious in the House of Commons this afternoon about the request for an additional [Pound]5,000 for government hospitality.

President Roosevelt evinced gratification today toward one section of the automobile industry and annoyance at another for their reactions to his recent suggestions for self-regulation of this important part of American business.

Health and hospital officials engaged in reducing "the morbidity and mortality" caused by tuberculosis criticized yesterday the lack of hospitalization facilities for patients suffering from this disease in the New York City area.

M. A. Mittelman, owner of Russeks, Detroit, has been appointed to represent the National Shoe Retailers Association on the board of trustees of the American Retail Federation, it was announced yesterday by L. E. Langston, executive vice president of the shoe retailers. Mr. Mittelman is a past president of the N. S. R. A.

COSTELLO, MARIA (Feb. 22). Estate, less than $10,000. To George Hebron, nephew, 364 W. 53d St., about $2,000; Patrick Costello, husband, executor, 1,865 Park Ave., residue of about $8,000; five varying bequests.

Three and a half months after this Congress was summoned in extra session, and almost two months after the regular session began, the Ways and Means Committee today introduced its tax revision measure to the House.

Testimony that State laws are inadequate to protect investors and stockholders of corporations in interstate commerce was given today at the opening of hearings on the C'Mahoney-Borah bill, which seeks to force the licensing of all corporations not doing a purely intrastate, business.

James M. Golding was sworn in yesterday as an Assistant District Attorney on the staff of William F. X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney, in the office of Mr. Geoghan by John N. Harman, Kings County Clerk.

Senator Pat McCarran, Nevada Democrat, sponsor of a measure to place the regulation of air transport under the Interstate Commerce Commission, completed and had printed today the eighth revision of an amendment to the measure he has made in as many weks.
The art collection of William Randolph Hearst, which has achieved almost fabulous proportions in popular report, is to be broken up.

Rutgers defeated Lehigh in a fast and exciting game tonight by 32 to 30. In the first half the Scarlet quintet rolled up a substantial margin, leading, 22 to 13, at the intermission and maintained this advantage for the first ten minutes of play of the second period.
A program for strict regulation of bank holding companies and the prevention of their growth. as well as establishment of new ones, was promulgated today in a bill introduced by Senator Glass.

The rising cost of government, accompanied by increasing taxation, was attributed to Federal bureaucracy rather than relief measures yesterday by Rush D. Holt, West Virginia Senator, at a luncheon in the Downtown Athletic Club.

The business situation showed no pronounced change in February, either in facts or sentiment, the either in facts or sentiment, the National City- Bank of New York says in its monthly letter. Preliminary figures show that the industries have been running at about the same rate as in the preceding month. Retail trade figures,

KINGS AMES, CHARLES H. (Oct. 6, 1937). Gross assets, $37,272; net, $33,753. To wife, Dorothy R. Ames. Chief assets, cash, $187; stocks, $36,150; miscellaneous property, $935. Oscar J. Heig, attorney, 2 rector St., Manhattan.

Councilman Joseph Clark Baldwin, whose residence qualifications are under investigation by the same Council committee that is investigating Councilman Michael J. Quill, appeared as a witness before the committee at City Hall yesterday.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today the following proceedings were had: 687-Edson M. Walker, petr., v. United States. 688-John H. Drummond, petr., v. United States. 689-John A. Luteran, petr., v. United States. 690-Frank H. Adams, petr., v. United States.

The other day, in writing on crow shooting, we explained that those wishing to engage in this sport in New Jersey were prohibited by a law which made it illegal to carry a gun except during the open game season.

Governor Moore is cruel. The New Jersey Legislature did a three-day stint last week. Monday night it adjourned till next week. The Governor called the Senate to meet in special session last night because it had failed to confirm his nomination of a banking insurance commissioner made on Jan. 31, but by agreement with the Republican majority this action was put over until next Monday.
Cornell came back in the second half to defeat Syracuse, 40-38, at basketball tonight and prevail over the Orange and Colgate for Central New York honors.
The Interstate Commerce Commission sent today to Congress recommendations for minor amendments to the Motor Carrier Act of 1935 intended to facilitate its work in regulating the industry.
Henry F. Kunkel, 38-year-old bank teller, who had been ill for a month, was found dead of gas poisoning yesterday morning by his wife, Claire, in their home, 7,814 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Mrs.

Eugene McCann captured the fivemile metropolitan speed - skating championship last night before a large crowd at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. The defending titleholder, Joe Bree of the New York Curb Exchange A. A., finished third. The winner's time was 17:37. Second place went to Tom McCarthy of the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

To aid the 1938 Campaign of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairman, will leave tomorrow on a speaking tour which will carry him through Southwestern and Pacific Coast States.

Officials of the National Association of Manufacturers denied today before the LaFollette Civil Liberties Committee of the Senate that the association had fostered policies inimical to the rights of employes.
A room at the Philadelphia Lying-In Hospital has been engaged by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., for July, it became known today.

The Equity Fund, Inc., in its report for 1937 showed a net liquidating value of $3.09 a share for the year-end, against $5.39 a share at the end of 1936. The number of shares rose last year from 305,883 to 407,325.

To the editor of THE TIMES: In regard to the article in THE NEW YORK TIMES, Feb. 27, under the caption "Strike Is Voted in Hosiery Mills" you quoted me as follows: "And they'll go along with Philadelphia, I'm sure.

An opinion confirming the plan of reorganization of the Standard Gas anal Electric company. one of the largest public utility holding companies in the United States, was handed down late today by Judge John P. Nields in the United States District Court.

Murray Levine, whose 12-year-old son Peter has been missing from their New Rochelle home since last Thursday after school, refused wearily in a telephone conversation last night to discuss any of the popular theories as to the case.

Mrs. David De Sola Pool, first national vice president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, sailed on the French liner Normandie yesterday to attend, as Hadassah delegate, the extraordinary meeting of the actions committee of the World Zionist Organization in London. The-meeting opens Tuesday.

In the same leisurely fashion that characterized their activities during two preceding days, the trio of Albanian Princesses, sisters of King Zog, spent yesterday afternoon acquainting themselves with a few more of the sights New York offers.

Turpentine firm, 241/2c; sales, 16 barrels; receipts, 45 barrels; shipments, 296 barrels; stock, 24,631 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 905 barrels; receipts, 459 barrels; shipments, 3,541 barrels; stock, 70,450 barrels.

Twelve hundred miles of flight from Aklavik over the Alaskan mountains in perfect sunshine and visibility failed today to disclose any trace of Sigismund Levanevsky and his five Soviet companions who were lost last August on a flight from Moscow to Fairbanks, Alaska.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Barbara Dempsey Chase, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Stuart Chase of this city, to George Mercer Nairne, son of Lady Violet Astor of London, which will take place the afternoon of March 18 in All

The annual meeting of stockholders of the National Aviation Corporation has been postponed until March 30. Armin A. Schlesinger, president of Newport Industries, Inc., Pensacola, Fla., was elected a director of the Square D Company to fill a vacancy.

The following text of the indictment of the twenty-one members of the "Bloc of Rights and Trotskyists" who went on trial yesterday in Moscow was supplied to THE NEW YORK TIMES by Tass, Soviet news agency:

Louis Rae "Riley" Murdock, news editor of The Boston Sunday Advertiser and for thirty-two years an employee of the Hearst newspapers, tonight died of a heart attack while walking home with his wife from a physician's office. He would have been 62 on Sunday.

The Chorus Equity Association's charter over chorus girls in night clubs, hotels and vaudeville presenstation houses was revoked yesterday by the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, the American Federation of Labor parent of all actor unions.

Mal Elward, into whose hands Purdue University's football fortunes fell last year after illness had laid low Head Coach Noble E. Kizer, today was appointed head coach. The appointment was announced by President Edward C4 Elliott, who said Kizer, convalescing at Tucson, Ariz., had asked to be relieved. Kizer,

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

Common Pleas Judge Thomas F. Meaney found guilty today Horace Condit Johnson, 53 years old, of 821 Park Avenue, Hoboken, on fourteen charges of receiving stolen goods. Johnson was on trial before Judge Meaney without a jury. Sentence will be imposed March 10.

State Department experts decreed today that President Roosevelt must wear formal attire when Count Rene Doynel de Saint-Quentin, the new French Ambassador, presnts his credentials tomorrow. That means diplomatic dress for the Ambassador also.
Landscapes and country scenes were voted the most popular subjects for subway art at the recent balloting held at the exhibition of subway art at the Museum of Modern Art.

The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $1,930,184,698 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price a share of all listed stocks on March 1 was $28.94, compared with $27.59 at the beginning of February.
The Social Security Board dropped Oklahoma's old-age pensioners from the Federal payroll today, charging "flagrant misuse of public funds" in administration of the State's pension plan.

Albany, N. Y., will be in the market on March 15 with a new issue of $2,415,400 of various municipal bonds, it became known here yesterday. The bonds will be dated March 1, 1938, and will mature serially from March 1, 1939, to 1978. Bidders have been asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent.
Women who lose theirs jobs be-cause they marry or smoke cigarettes may collect unemployment compensation benefits, under a State ruling today. Ralph M. Bashore, Secretary of Labor and Industry, said:
Duncan Mackenzie Stewart, well known illustrator of men's clothing, died Tuesday night at the PostGraduate Hospital after an extended illness, in his fifty-fifth year.

The Hun School five defeated Newman School on the Newman court today, 32-27, shutting out the losers in the first period while tallying 12 points. High scorers of the contest were Bob Peters of Hun and Dick Turner of Newman, who tallied 11 points each. The line-up:
The $100,000 added Santa, Anita Handicap on Saturday may turn into an equine swimming carnival and a headache for horsemen who neglect to send their mounts into the race equipped with waterwings.

The annual report of the Boston Edison Company for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $5,381,879, equal to $8.72 a share on the outstanding capital stock. This compares with a net of $5,170,907,

Samuel L. Gaines and William L. Jarvis, who are under sentence of two years each for mail fraud committed in Boston, received prison sentences of four and five years, respectively, and fines of $7,500 and $10,000 yesterday.

In its report on the proposed revenue bill for 1938, the Ways and Means Committee dwells at length on its reasons for retaining the undistributed profits tax principle for all corporations earning more than $25,000 and for adding a special surtax on the undistributed profits of closely held or so-called family corporations with net incomes of $75,000 or more distributing less than 57 per cent of that income.

Movements of vessels follow. All dates are March 2 unless specified: Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, March 1. Brooklyn, at- New York Navy Yard, New York, N. Y. Balch, Navy Yard, Mare Island, to San Diego, via San Pedro. Babbitt, Cristobal to Cartagena, Calif. Chaumont, at Guam.

Only two positions seemed secure as the St. Louis Cardinals went through their baptismal workout of 1938 today. Left field, Joe Medwick's bailiwick, is one. First base, Johnny Mize's berth, is the other.

The House Naval Affairs Committee, which is- considering the Administration's $1,100,000,000 Naval Construction Bill, rejected today by a vote of 16 to 2 an amendment by Representative Kniffin, Democrat, of Ohio, that would have fixed a naval frontier for the United States.

The government today estimated Great Britain's bill for an invigorated national defense during the next twelve months at 343,250,000--65,000,000 greater than the current fiscal year, when the per capital expenditure on armaments was four times greater than that in the United States.
Taking half the present students out of our universities and replacing them with young persons of more talent and less means would benefit this country, Dr. James B.

At a meeting of the directors yesterday of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., a dividend of $4.50 a share on the outstanding capital stock was voted. This is the final dividend payable for the fiscal year which ends on March 31.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 28: COMMANDERS Ballentine, J. J., staff, Commander Aircraft, Battle Force, in June, to staff, Commander Aircraft, Battle Force, as Operations Officer.

Alfred E. Merritt, in 40 5th Ave; Robert E. Crotty, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. in 277 Park Ave; Edmund Bainbridge, in 230 E 48th St; Plerre Brissaud, in 400 E 59th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, broker.

As an -aftermath of an explosion in August aboard the destroyer Cassin, which resulted in the deaths of seven men, a general secret court-martial of Lieutenant Henry Morris Marshall, 34-year-old- engineering officer, is in progress, it was learned today.
Ash Wednesday, opening the forty days of Lent, which will end with Easter on April 17, was more widely observed yesterday than for many years in this city.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher-in-training in day secondary schools other than junior high schools in the subjects as indicated, be issued, as of Feb. 28, 1938, to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore.

A total of 35,000 window displays, distributed according to the latest formula in the 982 cities having more than 10,000 population, will give maximum coverage in these centers, Frederick L. Wertz, president of Window Advertising, Inc., yesterday told the luncheon meeting of the International Display Executives Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
After a slight decline at the opening of trading, prices on the Cotton Exchange shot upward $1 a bale yesterday and ended with gains of 6 to 8 points, or 30 to 40 cents.

Fifty-three men reported to Coach Jim Crowley for the beginning of Spring football practice at Ford ham yesterday. With the practice field too muddy, the players gathereu on the gymnasium floor and after a short talk by Crowley, in which he outlined the work to be accomplished for the next five weeks, the squad was divided ac cording to positions for group Work.

The Ocean Steamship Company of Savannah has been authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission to extend its present services by establishment of a water route between New York City, New York lighterage points and Boston.

After years of persecution culminating in arrest, a charge of treason, followed by months of imprisonment and a secret trial, the verdict of "guilty," with its light sentence, rendered yesterday against Pastor Martin Niemoeller is in effect a moral vindication of the man, and possibly indicates an intention on the part of the Nazi regime to ease its anti-church campaign.

In the first round of the Bermuda women's annual title golf touranment today Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo defeated Mrs. S. Sonnenchein of the United States, 8 and 6.

President Roosevelt was reported today to- have decided on a change of strategy in dealing with Congress. For the time being, at least, it is said, he will not try to induce the legislative branch to enact measures unwelcome to a majority of the members of his party in each House.

The Consolidated Coal Company will pay on April 1 the full 2 1/2 per cent interest for the six months ended on Dec. 31, 1937, on its twenty-five-year 5 per cent bonds due on July 1, 1960, out of available net earnings, according to a notice sent yesterday to bondholders.

Pensloned On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight, Feb. 28: SERGEANT--John J. McLaughlin, 18th Division, 7th Detective District, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed Aug. 12, 1903. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., March 3: PATROLMIEN-William J. Martin, from 46th Precinct to 7th Division, assigned to duty as chauffeur.

The Rev. and Mrs. Nils J. Wessell of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, MissValdis A. Wessell, to Olyphant Mills Talbot, son of Mrs. Harriette Snow Talbot of Slingerland, N. Y.
Sir Robert Johnson, controller of the royal mint, died suddenly today at the age of 63. He had extended the work of the mint, which since 1923 has rarely been without a foreign order.

The Missing Persons Bureau of the Police Department yesterday cancelled an eight-State alarm for Ralph Carter, 14-year-old son of Mrs. Elise Schreiber Carter of 135 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, who' had been missing since Jan. 2.

Rosenblum ($12). 80th St. 131 W. 21x102.2: Young Men's Christian Association Retirement Fund to Gustave Kindler and wife, 102 W 76th St ($18.50). Deaths Announced Fireman 1st Grade Merritt C. Simpon, of H. L. Co. 45, died March 1. Funeral will take place from Cooke's Funeral Home, 1 West 190th St., Bronx, at 9:30 A. M., Friday, March 4. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

The members of a six-piece Ger man band, arrested for disorderly conduct, charmed an Irish-born magistrate with Irish melodies yes terday from the detention pen in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, and got suspended sentences.

Charges that the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is engaged in a "campaign of terror" to break up its agents' union, and that it frequently dismisses agents for failing to increase the sales of industrial insurance, were made today at a hearing on the Quinn resolutions proposing a legislative investigation of life insurance companies and industrial insurance.

The $8,000,000,000 super-highway program sponsored by Senator Bulkley and having the interest of President Roosevelt received a setback today in a Senate vote on a technicality which virtually removed it from the realm of active legislation.

Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, will serve as mediator in an effort to settle the controversy between the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, and the Atlas-Liberty and Sunshine-Radio Taxi Fleet Owners Associations, it was indicated last night.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 1: BRIGADIER GENERALS Humphrey, E. H., Philippine Dept., to command New York Port of Embarkation, Brooklyn, N. Y. Grant, W. S., New York Port of Embarkation, Brooklyn, N Y., to command Ft. Stotesburg, Philippine Islands, sailing from New York about March 25.

The report of the Amerex Holding Corporation for 1937, certified by independent auditors, which was issued yesterday, showed net income of $900,872 after charges and taxes. This was equal to $1.22 on the 740.000 shares of capital stock outstanding. It is compared to net income of $722,765, or 97 cents a share, in 1936.

The senate, by 46 to 3, passed the Crews bill establishing the New York City Parkway Authority recommended by Commissioner Moses. It defeated the Joseph resolution transferring the powers of commutation and pardon from the Governor to a board named by the Legislature.
Mrs. Inness Hartley of Southampton, L. I., was honored by Mrs. A. Carver Livingston and her son, William L. Livingston, at a large party in their villa today.

Arguments for and against the Schwartzwald bill, which would impose an annual State tax ranging from $10 to $550 per unit on chain stores were presented to the Senate Taxation Committee at a hearing today at which Senator John L. Buckley of New York City, chairman, presided.

Because of the refusal of the hotel proprietors in Nice to meet sitdown strikers' demands a general hotel strike in all of the French Riviera is expected tomorrow. Some proprietors said they would close their hotels.

MANHATTAN BATJER, EVA B. (Feb. 14). Estate, $3,459. To John Batjer, husband, executor, 238 W. 48th St. BEALL, JEREMIAH (Feb. 17). Estate, more than $20,000. To Charles W. Mr. and Mrs. William Albert Harbison of Clovelly, this place, formerly of Pittsburgh, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Courtney Harbison, to Carl William Heye, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl T. Heye, also of White Plains.

HAITI. a play in three acts, by William Du Bois. Staged by Maurice Clark; scenery by Perry Watkins; incidental score by Leonard de Paur; costumes designed by James Cochran; lighted by Byron Webb; produced by the Federal Theatre Project. At the Lafayette Theatre. 131st Street and Seventh Avenue.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company has invited all major carbuilding concerns to submit bids for furnishing fifty new subway cars to be used for service to the World's Fair grounds in 1939, Federal Receiver Thomas E. Murray Jr. announced yesterday.
With Prime Minister Prince Fumimaro Konoye in attendance, the Diet's debate on the national mobilization bill continued today in a more amicable atmosphere.

Glenn Cunningham, one of the greatest milers of all time, will attempt to set a record of 4:05 in his specialty over the Dartmouth track tomorrow night. Cunningham arrived today and limbered upon the track, which Harry Hillman, Dartmouth's veteran coach, has described as the fastest indoor track in America.
The new 10,000-ton light cruiser Brooklyn, Captain William D. Brereton Jr., commanding, completed her "shake-down" cruise yesterday morning at the navy yard in Brooklyn.

The Jewish Agricultural Society, Inc., which aids Jews in settling on farms and then helps them with an educational and extension program, has granted 12,313 farm loans totaling $7,513,857 since its founding in 1900, it was announced yesterday. During last year,

Although Ten Broeck M. Terhune, 50 years old, a socially prominent realty broker, admitted in the lineup at Police Headquarters yesterday that he had misappropriated $6,000 in jewelry obtained on memoranda to sell to friends, in the Felony Court later his lawyer entered a plea of not guilty to a specific charge of theft involving $950 in Jewelry.

The preponderance of solid black and white in the recent Paris fashion showings gave the Spring openings almost the appearance of Fall events, according to Miss Ethel Frankau and Miss Jessica Daube, dress and millinery buyers respectively for Bergdorf Goodman Company, who returned here yesterday on the Berengaria.

These are the principal provisions of the Tax Revision Bill, to be debated in the House tomorrow: 1. An income tax of 12 1/2 to 16 per cent on corporations with incomes of $25,000 a year or less. They would pay no undistributed profits tax.

A group of fifteen Atlantio Coast ferryboat operators organized the United States Ferryboat Operators Association and discussed plans of a campaign to popularize the use of ferryboats by automobile drivers, at a meeting yesterday in the offices of the New York Tugboat Exchange, 17 Battery Place.

Tonight's major events: "Amelia Goes to the Ball," Metropolitan Opera premiere, 8 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M. Emanuel Feuermann, 'cellist, will appear in recital tonight at the Washington Irving High School, playing Brahms, Locatelli, Stravinsky and transcriptions of his own.

Electric power production declined last week, running counter to seasonal and long-term trends, and the adjusted index has dropped to 93.2 from 93.9. The figure for the week ended Feb. 27, 1937, was 109.7.

Karl Gerstl, executive secretary of the National' Association of Leather Glove Manufacturers, died in his home here today at the age of 43.

Dean Detton, former heavyweight wrestling champion of the world, signed yesterday to meet Dick Daviscourt of California in the semifinal to the meeting between Jim Londos and Jim McMillen at the New York Hippodrome on Monday night.

John L. Schoenfeld of the State Commission of Correction recommended in a report today that "more satisfactory arrangements" be made in the prison wards of Bellevue Hospital to relieve overcrowded conditions.
John Barry Ryan Jr., and Joseph Schenck 3d, both of New York City, were halted in the annual Palm Beach golf championship today.

Barkley Ave (18-5425), a w cor of Hollywood Ave, 25x100: Joseph Bosch to Railroad Federal Savings Loan Assn, 441 Lexington Ave; installments, 5 per cent; $10,500. Morris Ave (11-2816), s w cor of 170th St, 75x200; First Daniel Corp to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, extends mtgs to Jan. 3, 1943, at 4 1/2 per cent: $180,000.

General John J. Pershing had recovered sufficiently to sit up in bed and to eat soft foods and drink milk and fruit juices, Dr. Roland Davison announced to-day. The physician said that immediate danger of the 77-year-old general's death had passed, but he said there was still the possibility of a relapse.

The Senate Public Lands Committee overrode objections by Senator Pittman and reported favorably today on the nomination of Ebert K. Burlew as First Assistant Secretary of the Interior. Mr. Pittman's vote was reported to have been the only dissenting one cast in an executive session.
The Rev. Dr. L. Morgan Chambers, pastor of the State Street Methodist Episcopal Church here, died tonight in McKinley Hospital at the age of 56. He had been ill since Thursday.
Immediately after a crackling warning, a wooden pedestrian bridge spanning the mouth of the swirling Los Angeles River collapsed late today and hurled at least ten persons to death.

George H. Houston, president of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, and Ralph E. F?? member of the Business Advisory Council of the Department of Commerce, addressing the Senate Committee on Unemployment today,

The number of persons employed in the steel industry in January averaged 475,000, compared with 508,000 in December, a decline of 6.5 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Employment in January, last year, averaged 548,000.
For the first time since its holdings were intensively developed, the Trinity Church Corporation has assumed the direct management of all of its property.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 1st Lt. Joseph O. Battiato, Inf.-Res., Bldg. 22, Qr. 38, Governors Island, N. Y. (Temporary address: 437 Home Ave., Rosebank, S. I.), 18th Infantry (D), is ordered to active duty, effective March 6, at Fort Wadsworth, N. Y., for training. Date of rank: Feb. 21, 1937. He will revert to an inactive status on March 19.

A letter from Mr. Harper Sibley, lately president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, should be read in every community in America where appeal is being made for the relief of the Chinese, who are suffering woes beyond all description.
Authorization to create 20,000 new WPA jobs in this city was received from Washington yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator.
William J. Kent, an inventor employed by the United States Rubber Company for thirty years before he retired in 1931, died here last night at his home, Hickory Bluff. He was 77 years old.

HELEN'S TOWER, by Harold Nicolson. (Harcourt, Brace, $3.50.) A study of Lord Dufferin, the author's uncle by marriage, with autobiographical overtones. ANABASIS by St.-J. Perse. (Harcourt, Brace, $1.25.) A poem translated from the French by T. S Eliot.

After more than thirty years of military service Colonel Henry D. Cushing, regimental commander of New York's 539th Coast Artillery (Ant-aircraft), United States Army Reserve, was relieved of his command Tuesday at his own request and transferred to the Inactive Reserve.
Contract awards on cotton textiles and hosiery, bids on which were opened here a few days ago, were announced today at the Army Quartermaster Depot as follows:

The United Brewers Industrial Foundation will launch a test campaign in newspapers of several cities within "forty-five to ninety" days as a prelude to its national drive, Edward L. Bernays, public relations counsel to the group, said yesterday.
Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy formally approved yesterday the certificate of incorporation of the Smaller Business Association for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, Inc.

Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y.; Marcel Camp of Detroit and Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia recorded their second straight victories in the world's. pocket billiards championship at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy yesterday and moved into a three-cornered deadlock for the lead.

Charges of extravagence and exorbitant spending were laid at Mayor La Guardia's door yesterday by Democratic members of the City Council as the Council met in City Hall and fixed the 1938 basic tax rate at $2.80 on each $100 of assessed valuation.

Mr. and Mrs. Gustavus T. Kirby have returned from Camden, S. C., and are at the Ritz Tower before going to their home in Bedford Hills.

" Bringing Up Baby," the new Katharine Hepburn picture, will open today at the Radio City Musio Hall. Cary Grant, May Robson, Charles Ruggles, Barry Fitzgerald and Walter Catlett are among the featured players. "Quintupland,"
A rally in the second half enabled the girls' basketball team of New I College to defeat Manhattanville on the floor of the victors yesterday. The score was 22 to 18.

A company enjoying a monopoly of its business because it is the only one equipped to supply the service it sells tossed in the sponge yesterday, unable to endure the indirect competition of working conditions set up by the Federal Government.

More than 200 officers and 1,000 enlisted men, with a force of 125 airplanes, will participate in the annual manoeuvres of the Second Wing of the General Headquarters Air Force in Central Florida from March 12 to 31.

A thorough investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority by a joint committee of the House and Senate was demanded today by Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, chairman, as the long-standing breach between him and the other two members of the board,...

Joe Louis, heavyweight boxing champion, was relieved of the necessity of giving up training in Stevensville, Mich., and coming here to appear in a civil suit against him by a decision yesterday of Municipal Court Justice John J. Sullivan.

General Cornelius Vanderbilt and his guests aboard his yacht, Winchester, including his daughter, Mrs. Vanderbilt Davis, Captain Edward T. Constien of New York and John Wanamaker 3d of Philadelphia were today guests at Hialeah Park of

In the hushed atmosphere of a room in the Wadsworth Hospital, at 629 West 185th Street, two nurses and three doctors enacted a oneminute drama Tuesday night which brought life to a first-born infant and left one of the doctors unconscious and in a serious condition.

Federal Insurance Company-As of Dec. 31: Total admitted assets, $20,089,730, against $21,646,021 a year earlier; surplus, $10,973,824, against $12,848,785; unearned premiums, $2,724,679, against $2,226,265; premiums earned last year, $4,178,669, against $3,454,657 in 1936.

The W. A. Hathaway Company, furniture dealers, bought from the Chase National Bank the six-story building on a plot 75 by 100 feet and the one-story garage on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 517-523 West Twentyninth Street.
Stocks slightly lower in third slowest day's business in three years; turnover, 406,315 shares. United States Government and other bonds irregularly lower; transactions, $4,851,250.

After three afternoons of close play in the Eastern Contract Bridge Championships, Philip Hart and his sister, Miss Peggy Hart, emerged victorious yesterday in the final round of the novice competition in the week-long program at the Park Central Hotel.
Under an agreement settling a labor dispute at the Dartmouth Woolen Mills, Claremont, N. H., thirty-six discharged union employes will receive $9,000 in back pay from March, 1936.
Alfredo C. Janni, Italian-born American consulting civil engineer, died on Saturday in his home, 360 East Fifty-fifth Street, after a brief illness. His age was 68.
The appointment of T. V. Soong, former Finance Minister, as head of the Chinese air force was announced by the government at its temporary capital here today.

Defense Minister Daladier, outlining defense plans before the Chamber of Deputies finance commission today, estimated that France would need supplementary credits for armaments of about 4.000.000.000 francs.

Twelve patrolmen attached to the Fort Hamilton station in Brooklyn went on trial yesterday before Third Deputy Police Commissioner Michael A. Lyons in Brooklyn Police Headquarters on charges of failing to observe a car containing the bodies of two murder victims,

Two securities dealers were arrested and five others enjoined from further transactions yesterday in there separate actions instituted by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., who alleged frauds were practiced upon customers of security concerns in each case.

The young men of England probably would refuse to "join up" to defend either the Austrian or the Czechoslovak cause, according to Sir Josiah Stamp, British economist and frequent visitor to the United States, who sailed yesterday on the French liner Normandie for home. Sir Josiah,
The New York Rangers will engage the Detroit Red Wings, holders of the Stanley Cup and the world's hockey championship, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.
Frank J. Bryan, for more than thirty years racing secretary and steward at Pimlico, announced today he had severed his connection with the Maryland Jockey Club.
Bond values drifted irregularly lower over a broad front in another exceedingly dull trading session yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace,

Darkness and storm tonight halted searchers for a missing airliner and its six passengers and crew of three soon after the sighting of mystery lights and a white object near a mountainside scar an the area where the storm-battered plane was last reported last night.

Fifty years ago Helen Keller, then a deaf, blind and speechless child of 6, met Anne Sullivan, a partly blind girl of 20, who later became Mrs. Anne Sullivan Macy. by The latter died in 1936 but because of her years of effort Miss Keller can now speak, and today the two women are being honored.
Completion of plans by the State Agricultural Department to publish a monthly survey of living costs in New Jersey was announced here today by W. H. Allen, secretary of the department.

The Metropolitan Savings Bank sold to Rittenhouse Estates, Inc, Bud A. Lipman, press, the 3-story building at 477 East Houston St, 20x50; at a price shown as $2,000, and Rittenhouse simultaneously sold it to Sonia Robinson, of the Hotel Holland, who gave back a p m mortgage for $600, payable $100 a month at 6 per cent.

Bond Stores, Inc., chain-store clothiers, plan one of their largest stores in the Lincoln Building, 56 East Forty-second Street, where they have leased about 19,000 square feet of space, including practically the entire basement.
Mrs. Anna Belinda Philbrick Jeffery, widow of George M. Jeffery, formerly a member of the New York Produce Exchange, died in her home here last night after a brief illness. Her age was 91.

Sharp gains in almost every department of its business are revealed in the 1937 report of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, to be presented to shareholders at the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., on April 12. Net income of $31.819.596 is compared to $13,901,006 for 1936, equivalent to $7.64 a share of common stock. against $2.09 for the year before.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain told the House of Commons tonight that juridically there was nothing to support the argument that Austria's independence had been alien-
The preliminary adjusted index of the value of retail sales of new passenger automobiles declined sharply from December to January, according to the Department of Commerce.

The House today passed the $125,086,690.84 Interior Department Appropriation Bill after it had turned from the subject for half an hour to discuss the writing and other private .activities of :the President and his family.

There can be no more damning argument against a tax than that it bankrupts those who pay it. This appears to be the case with the levy on the gross receipts of limited fare transit companies, as it is applied to the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation-better known as the B. M. T.

Merchandising methods designed to find new uses for cotton and thus move into consumption the heavy carryover of American cotton will be discussed at the Cotton Conference which will be held today at the Hotel Biltmore in Atlanta.

The Rutgers swimming team overwhelmed Penn before 1,000 spectators tonight, 54 to 21, to end its dual meet competition with six victories in eight starts: The Scarlet captured eight of the nine events.
William Beller, pianist, who has appeared here frequently in recital, was heard in Town Hall last night before a large and friendly audience.

Huddled over the counsel table in Bronx County Court, where she is on trial for the murder of her husband, Mrs. Patricia Ryan heard herself characterized variously yesterday as an "unusually calm" murderer and as a "loving and devoted wife" who endured her husband's drunkenness and brutality until his excessive demands became insupportable.

A rousing City College rally that just missed its mark provided a thrilling finale to the Madison Square Garden basketball doubleheader last night as a crowd of 17,529 saw N. Y. U. come through a hair-raising battle to a 39-37 upset victory over the Beavers.

The 800 miles of new rural electric distribution lines which the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation expects to construct in New York State this year, when added to the 13,800 miles of rural lines already operated,

The new tax bill proposed by the House Ways and Means Committee contains one substantial improvement. For the great bulk of corporations it reduces the tax on undistributed profits to a nominal figure.
A gift by the Vail estate of four brick residences to Russell Sage College for Women was announced today. The estate is owned by Mrs. Thomas Vail of Troy, Miss Martha Card
The Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company was permitted today to elect as directors four representatives of bondholders. The company is under reorganization in Federal court.

Champion Nancolleth Marquis, the heavily marked white and liver pointer dog owned by the Giralda Farms of Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge of Madison, N. J., and handled by McClure Halley, tonight was named best in show at the annual allbreed exhibition of the Genesee Valley Kennel Club.

Little progress was made in Parliament today toward agreement between the chambers on Premier Camille Chautemps's "labor charter." By a series of conferences with outside organizations, however, political leaders prepared the way for some sort of compromise tomorrow.

Steel manufacturers this week have found some signs of improvement in business, according to The Iro. Age. Despite the fact that the national steel ingot rate is unchanged from the 30 per cent of the previous week, the publication states that sales offices in many steel-consuming areas are finding a better feeling among consumers and report that actual buying for February shows gains ranging as high as 30 per cent over January.
By WILLIAM KENNEDY. 67th St, 220 W. 5-story tenement, 25x100.5; Citizens Savings Bank against 66th 7th, Inc.; due, $15,023; to plaintiff for $1,000.
Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the board of the National Steel Corporation, conferred with President Roosevelt on the business situation today.

New Utrecht gained 9 points in the competition for the city P. S. A. L. senior high school indoor track and field team title yesterday as Sammy Taylor and Samuel Hannin placed one-two in the shot-put event contested in the Textile High School gymnasium.

On Tuesday the German Air Minister, Field Marshal Goering, delivered a remarkable speech in Berlin. In the course of it he said that "even if, as Germans and as human beings, we passionately desire peace, as soldiers of the youngest armnd force we burn to prove to the Fuehrer and the country that in defiance of all foes this air force is invincible."
The Baltimore Orioles scored in an extra period tonight to beat the New York Rovers, 2 to 1, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game.
Before an audience of members of the Public Service Committees of both branches of the Legislature, and in a setting of the austere Senate chamber,

Mrs. Maude Hough Welles Danforth, organizer of the Essex County Auxiliary of the American Legion and leader of welfare and religious groups in this area, died last night in her home here. Her age was 77.

Plans of the East Lampeter Township School Board to sell at auction Saturday ten of the eleven "little red schoolhouses" which Lancaster County Amish children formerly attended were blocked today by the Federal District Court.

With play at a standstill for the day in the singles, the courts of the Seventh Regiment Armorywere given over entirely to the doubles yesterday in the national indoor tennis championships.

Changes in the order of events and in time schedule, many of them very significant, have been made by the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. for its seventeenth annual track and field championships at Madison Sauare Garden Saturday.

The new Moscow trial is designed to bolster with more impressive arguments the shaken world confidence in Stalin's "justice." One can not doubt that to a significant degree the trial is Joseph Stalin's dramatized answer to the verdict of the inquiry commission headed by John Dewey.

Melvin Ott, perennial boy wonder of the Polo Grounds, celebrated his twenty-ninth birthday today, began his thirteenth training campaign with the Giants and modestly pronounced himself ready for whatever tasks Manager Bill Terry may have in store for him.

Mrs. Watson B. Robinson of the Croydon, this city, and Belle Haven, Greenwich, Conn., who is now in Paris, has announced from that city the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Dorita Robinson, to Albert Edward Holland of Berlin.
The Columbia wrestling team ended its dual meet season last night by defeating Pennsylvania, 21-13, in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. The Lions took five of eight tests.
Gerard B. Lambert, owner of the America's Cup yachts Yankee and Vanitie, is going in for small yacht racing next Summer-at least small in comparison to the big sloops.

Plans for the celebration of the fifteenth annual National Music Week, to be held this year beginning May 1, the customary period, are now being formed, according to the announcement made yesterday from the headquarters of the National Music Week Committee in New York.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's "realistic" plan to bargain with Italy faced possible disaster tonight through a quarrel developing in the Non-Intervention Committee over withdrawal of foreign fighters from Spain.

Gold in the amount of $1,125,500 which previously had been held under earmark for foreign account was released yesterday, according to the daily gold statement of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Frank D. Fuller of Springfield, Mass., will announce tomorrow night at Hobe Sound the engagement of his daughter, Miss Christine Fuller, to Hudson Holland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Clarke Holland of New York.

Macmillan announces for early publication two books about Ireland: "The Rocky Road to Dublin," by Seumas MacManus, an account of the author's Irish boyhood, and "Green Fields," by Stephen Rynne, a picture of the life of an Irish landowner and farmer.
James F. Foster, 23 years old, a Rutgers University junior, of Mahwah, N. J., was reported missing today in a police alarm. The dean's office said Foster had been missing from classes since Friday.
