Announcement was made here yesterday of the death of Albert L. Diament of Strafford, Pa., in the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital after a short illness at the age of 72.

A new procedure for filing license applications has been decided upon by the New York State Liquor Authority in an effort to eliminate unnecessary expense to the public, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the Authority.

The Soviet Union's third great public treason trial within the past eighteen months began today in a casually grim atmosphere in the trivial setting of the one-time supper room of the Nobles Club of Czarist days, now the House of Trade Unions, used for concerts, meetings and trials.

An unidentified hold-up man, blamed for a score of robberies in the southern part of the Bronx during the last two months, was shot and killed by two detectives just before 11 o'clock last night in a drug store at 466 Brook Avenue.

A default in the payment of $1,072,000 principal amount of bonds of the Galveston Terminal Railway bearing the guarantee of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway and a subsidiary of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, became known yesterday through the issuance of notices by the Bankers Trust Company, trustee for the issue.
Mrs. George C. Remey, widow of Rear Admiral Remey, U. S. N., died Tuesday at the home of her elder son, Charles Mason Remey, 2,440 Massachusetts Avenue, Washington, D. C., after a long illness.

Chicago, with six stalwarts making the grade, led a parade of twenty-one cities into the semi-finals of the eleventh annual Golden Gloves tournament of champions tonight before a crowd of 16,500 spectators in the Chicago Stadium.

Alexander F. Kerensky, former Russian Premier, who led in the revolution that brought the downfall of the Czar more than twenty years ago and was in turn overthrown by the Bolsheviki, arrived in New York yesterday from Paris on the liner Berengaria.

Swimming has beer. designated as a major sport at Harvard by the committee on regulation of athletic sports. The change in the status of swimming from a minor sport to the Crimson's seventh major activity is effective immediately and major letters will be awarded this year.

The Rev. Martin Niemoeller, the most famous of the Protestant leaders of the opposition to the totalitarian State, was released from prison today by the emergency court that had tried him on sedition and other charges, but he was immediately rearrested by the secret political police and taken to Alexanderplatz Prison.
Four more election board officials of Hudson County were arrested today for refusing to testify before the Young Assembly committee, bringing the total arrested so far to eleven.
WPA officials authorized their State Administrators today to hire 500,000 more relief workers this month, to offset part of the unemployment increase attributed to the business recession.

Philip Zito, 57 years old, accused of stabbing to death his wife, Teresa, 53, during a quarrel in their home at 482 Court Street, Brooklyn, Tuesday night, was held without bail yesterday by Magistrate James A. Blanchfield in felony court, Brooklyn, on a charge of murder.

Premier Benito Mussolini, accompanied by Foreign Minister Count Galeazzo Ciano and two other members of the Cabinet, arrived here this afternoon to pay their last tribute of affection to Gabriele d'Annunzio, who was one of their close associates in the early days of the Fascist movement and during the Fiume occupation.

Breaking through a tight Yale defense in the second half, Amherst came from behind to defeat the Blue, 32-25, tonight. Trailing at the half, 16-8, the Jeffs rallied early in the second half, and after nine minutes to play caught Yale at 20-all.

THE astonishing stained-glass-window manner of writing that Isak Dinesen- used in her "Seven Gothic Tales" four or five years ago is considerably modified in her new book, "Out of Africa."* This is an account of her life on a coffee farm near Nairobi. The horn of the biggame hunter is heard in those hills. But Isak. Dinesen was also able to record far subtler melodies there.
The first public response by the Administration to testimony of Bernard M. Baruch before the Senate Unemployment Committee came today from Secretary Wallace.
Mrs. Rand Adams of 1,245 Madison Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Adams, to Hugh Howat Butler, son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Butler of Brooklyn.
Flood and landslides dealt death and destruction throughout a wide area today as Southern California's most torrential rainstorm in a quarter century was entering its fifth day.

President Roosevelt signed the $250,000,000 Deficiency Relief Bill and a bill amending the criminal code to provide punishment for impersonation of officers or employes of government-owned or government-controlled corporations.

Columbiana, last year's winner of the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup that will be renewed on Saturday, was out to the last ounce to beat a $5,000 selling plater in the Grade B Handicap at Hialeah Park today, but doubtless will go to the post on the week-end nevertheless.

Mr. and Mrs. Curtis R. Burnett of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Faith Burnett, to George Jenks Scranton, son of Mrs. Gilmore J. Scranton of Detroit and Harbour Beach, Mich., and the late Mr. Scranton.

Acting Captain John A. McIlhargy, a member of the Police Department since 1902 and commander of detectives in the southern half of the Bronx since April 1, 1930, died yesterday in his home, 1,501 Undercliff Avenue, the Bronx, after an illness of several months. He was 57 years old.

College students would rather violate the King's English with such rugged expressions as "ain't I" than speak correctly at the risk of appearing affected and "sissified," according to the report of a vocabulary survey by J. M. Steadman Jr. of Emory University, in the current issue of American Speech, linguistic quarterly.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

Charles Devens, former Harvard baseball star, who once was a member of the Yankee pitching staff, and C. H. Stockton of Boston advanced to the second round of the United States court tennis championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

The Presidential decree specifying the conditions under which banking institutions may present bids next Monday to act as fiscal agent in the conversion of defaulted public works obligations into the new $85,000,000 bond issue will be modified, it is learned.
Wheat fu tures on the Board of Trade here closed today 5/8 to 3/4 cent a bushe lower after a dull and featureless session. Speculative interest in the market continued highly restricted

Leading American authorities are strongly opposed to the suggested postponement of the 1940 Olympics from their contemplated opening on Aug. 24 to one a month later, it was revealed yesterday by Frederick W. Rubien, secretary of the American Olympic Committee.

Ten men, two women and four corporations, all of Brooklyn, were arraigned yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn as defendants in the first criminal cases against city sales tax evaders.
Tomorrow will be the fifth anniversary of the day on which the banking holiday of 1933 reached its climax with the closing of the New York banks, including the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A client of William I. Alpert, attorney, has purchased the six-story apartment at 150 Crown Street, on the southeast corner of Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, from the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York, as liquidator of the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company, for cash above a mortgage of $475,000.

President Getulio Vargas today appointed Colonel Oswaldo Cordeiro de Faria Federal interventor for the State of Rio Grande do Sul. He succeeds the late General Manoel Cerquiera Daltro, who replaced J. A. Flores de Cunha when the latter fled to Uruguay.

Unemployment insurance checks totaling more than $7,000,000 have' been prepared by the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department for distribution to New York's jobless, it was announced last night.

The Senate defeated today the Joseph resolution providing for a constitutional amendment to shift the power of commutation in death penalties and pardons from the hands of the Governor to a board appointed by the Legislature.
The Japanese detachments that are driving west from Fenyang through Lishih along the main highway connecting Shansi and Shensi Provinces have captured Chuntu on the Yellow River.

Proposals for the closer cooperation and possibly the affiliation of the -Socialist party of New York State with the American Labor party are being seriously considered by the Socialist leadership and may be made the subject of -a referendum of the party membership, it was learned yesterday.

Spurgeon Chandler, young pitcher; Joe Glenn, regular understudy to Catcher Bill Dickey, and Myril Hoag, outfielder, donned uniforms today atHuggins Field. There are now twenty Yankees in training here. Another large crowd of tourists and natives watched the third training workout.

This city's annual Flower Show, with a million Spring flowers in full bloom and cyclorama of color and fragrance, will be held in Commercial Museum March 21 to 27 inclusive, W. Atlee Burpee Jr., announced today.

The winning march of Miss Patty Berg, 20-year-old Minneapolis star, finally was halted on the St. Augustine Links today by Mrs. Jane Cothran Jameson of West Palm Beach in the first round of the fourteenth annual Florida East Coast championship.
Tuesday night, March 22, is the date selected by Philip Dunning for "Schoolhouse on the Lot," with five previews slated for the preceding week. The house, as announced, is the Ritz.
Led by Miss Constance Hanf and Miss Bernice Lapp, the undefeated New York University girls' varsity swimming team defeated the Fieldston School squad, 39 to 19, in the latter's pool yesterday.
Joe Crail, who represented the Tenth California district in Congress from 1927 to 1933, died today after a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

E. V. Rickenbacker and associates tentatively have concluded negotiations for the purchase of Eastern Air Lines from North American Aviation, Inc.. for a consideration of approximately $3,500.000. Smith, Barney Co. and Kuhn, Loeb Co.

Arguments between members of the New York State Nurses' Association and nurses of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, a C. I. 0. affiliate, marked a public hearing held here today by the Assembly Committee on Education on the Todd-Feld bill providing for licensing of registered and practical nurses.

Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade today resumed consideration of the evidence presented by two special committees of the Exchange in support of charges alleging the Cargill Grain Company of Illinois and three of its officials had violated the rules of the board and the Commodity Exchange Act in operations in September (1937) corn contracts.

John Alexander Low Waddell, one of the leading bridge engineers of the United States, died early this morning in his apartment in the Hotel Earle, Washington Square, from the effects of a stroke suffered last Nov. 15. He was born in Port Hope, Ont., eighty-four years ago.

Sir Harcourt Butler, whose name had been mentioned as a possible Viceroy of India during his brilliant career of more than forty years as an Indian administrator, died in London today at the age of 68.

The tax revision bill, containing more than 900 sections, will be brought to the floor of the House tomorrow, accompanied by a seventy-page report, in which the Democratic majority on the Ways and Means Committee explains the proposed changes without attempting to answer the Republican charges,

With seven Democrats bolting, the Assembly today passed Governor Lehman's bill to continue the third and fourth cent gasoline tax for another year. Legislative action now has been completed on all of the tax measures recommended by the Governor to meet the $386,000,000 budget.

Davey Day, Chicago lightweight who aspires to the crown now worn by Lou Ambers, scored a decisive triumph over Charley Gomer of Brooklyn in the feature bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome last night.
Three stipulations by companies to discontinue certain practices, two of them involving alleged lottery schemes, were announced today by the Federal Trade Commission.

Mrs. Clayton Rich of North Stamford, Conn., gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the RitzCarlton for her daughter, Miss Janet Price, whose engagement to Howard John Helleberg was recently announced.

Two women who were about to jump from the top floor of a burning two-story building early yesterday morning were saved by an alert superintendent who raised a fifteenfoot ladder and assisted them down from their position on a long window box.

44th St, 316-20 W; to 5-story tenement; Scribner Realty Co, 597 5th Ave. owner; L. E. Jallade, architect; cost, $50,000. 50th St, 309-13 E; to three 3-story furnished rooms; the Fifth Avenue Bank of New York and Lillie M. Schuster, trustees, 530 5th Ave, owner; Van Wart Ackerman, architect; cost, $5,000.

Michael MacWhite, Irish Minister to the United States, will sail for home today on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others listed for Cherbourg and Southampton on this ship are Lord and Lady Dawson of Penn, Lady Fisher, Mr.
The Benjamin Franklin High School basketball team continued its drive toward first place yesterday when it defeated Haaren, 47 to 16, on the Commerce court.

Princeton University's surprising basketball team continued to wreak havoc on the Eastern Intercollegiate League front tonight and in an important game for Pennsylvania scuttled the Red and Blue's championship hopes by squeezing out a 38-36 triumph in the closing seconds of play.

An attack upon Robert H. Jackson as the "type of man" who would proceed along the lines of "centralization of government and regimentation of the people," was made by Senator Austin today as the Senate began consideration of Mr. Jackson's nomination as Solicitor General by President Roosevelt five weeks ago.
With one exception, the concluding matches of the third round in the national squash tennis Class B championship ran true to form at the Columbia University Club last night.

Joseph J. Baker, former president of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn and the candidate of the Recovery party for the Brooklyn Borough Presidency in 1933, died yesterday in his home, 558 First Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 57, after an illness of two months.
Kay Francis, screen star, said today that she plans to be married to Baron Raven Erik Barnekow, in whose company she has been seen frequently during the last three months.

Chauncey M. Brewer, president of the California-Oregon Power Company, died at his home in Medford, Ore., today at the age of 56. He had been an executive of utility companies in the mid-West and on the Pacifio Coast for more than thirty years.

School children should be taught the truth of city politics and the facts about the C. I. O. and Hitler, Dr. Rollo Reynolds, principal of Horace Mann School and professor at Teachers College, Columbia University, said yesterday.

Ralph S. Neuburger, since 1917 the representative of the American Metal Company in Santiago, Chile, died there yesterday after a brief illness at the age of 53, according to- word received here by relatives.

William A. Dolan, president of the Wilbur Products Company, Inc., of this city and Sumner A. Mead, president of the DwinellWright Company, Boston, were elected directors of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., at a meeting of the board at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

After a hard day of negotiation with the Styrian Nazis, who presented far-reaching demands in a very aggressive manner, Dr. Arthur SeyssInquart, the Minister of the Interior, left for Vienna on the evening train.

A strong indictment against "oversupply" of new laws, "conflicting statements" of government officials and "complexities" of Federal tax legislation has been put before the Administration by "small business men" as a sequel to their-conference here a month ago.

A specially appointed board of the Federal Bureau of Marine Insection and Navigation heard charges yesterday of improper conduct at sea on the part of an engineer officer and a watertender of the government-owned freighter Algic during a recent trip to South America.

The dominance of Mr. Roosevelt over the processes of administration and legislation endured for so many years that every fact concerning the President long outweighed any other information obtainable in Washington.
Turning in a two-under-par card of 69, Johnny Revolta set the pace through the opening round of the $3,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament today.

The Tower of Religion planned for the World's Fair is a symbol to all people of every language and religion who visit it that the hurt of Babel has been so far healed that they may all find this a temple of understanding and peace in its cloistered garden.

In a surprise attack before daybreak the "Blue" army of Marines landed troops at Puenta Cuchara, west of Ponce, rapidly gaining machine-gun positions and artillery bases in the foothills overlooking the city.

The vanguard of the Brooklyn Dodgers departed for the Clearwater, Fla., training base yesterday, three rookie pitchers making up the official party. They included Wally Signer, Jack Kimball and Alta Cohen.

Jascha Heifetz, violinist, sailed on the French liner Normandie yesterday for a month's concert tour of France, The Netherlands, Czechoslovakia, England and Hungary. He will also play at the Spring Festival in Budapest on his first visit to the Hungarian capital in five years.
The Decorators Picture Gallery opens to the public today a new exhibition in the series of shows designed to show rooms as backgrounds for paintings.

The creation of a $3,000,000 system of bridges in Suffolk County, Long Island, linking Shelter Island with Greenport on the north and Sag Harbor to the south came nearer fulfillment today when the Assembly passed a bill of authorizing a commission to undertake the project.

Four hundred and sixty-seven Princeton sophomores have been elected to membership in the seventeen private upperclass eating clubs of the university, it was announced today by Kenneth M. Lynch, '38, of Charleston, S. C., president of the undergraduate interclub committee.
Three officials of Heilbut-Symons Company, Ltd., were sentenced today after conviction of "a new, dangerous form of fraud" in connection with granting loans abroad.

Chairman John Hamilton of the Republican National Committee described as a "curious irresponsibility" today Secretary Roper's observation that "self-help" seemed to be lacking in suggestions offered by small business men to combat the recession.

Misericordia Hospital receives a bequest of $25,000 in the will of Mrs. Harriet Brady Mathieu, widow of George E. Mathieu and sister of the late James Buchanan (Diamond Jim) Brady, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mrs. Mathieu, who lived at 995 Fifth Avenue, died on Feb. 14.
On the fleets of Chancellor Hitler's announcement of a further increase in German armaments, the government issued three decrees today designed to mobilize additional labor reserves.

Passage of the Savings Bank Life Insurance Bill in the Legislature this session appeared tonight to hinge on the ability of Governor Lehman to whip into line recalcitrant Democratic Senators, who openly and privately expressed their disapproval of the measure.
Secretary Ickes was not the first man to point out that this country has been far behind Great Britain in social security legislation,

COOMMERCIAL PAPER Yesterday.Tuesday. For the best names........ 1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months' paper. Consumer Named to Hat Board Election of Mrs. Richard J. Bernhard as a consumer representative on the Millinery Stabilization Committee. was announced yesterday by Max Meyer, chairman of the commission.

The successors of P. T. Barnum, the late circus impresario, who drew an analogy between the birthrate of a certain fresh water fish of the family Catosmidae and that of human easy-marks, must have had his words in mind when they filed income tax returns for the years 1918 to 1932 inclusive, the government charged yesterday.

Harry Thomas, Chicago and Eagle Bend (Minn.) heavyweight, got in a few practice swings for his April 1 engagement with Champion Joe Louis tonight and scored a third-round knockout over Ed (Unknown) Winston, Hartford (Conn.) Negro.

A bill to nullify the recent action of the Board of Estimate in ending the bonding system on city construction contracts was advanced to third reading in the Senate today. It is sponsored by Senator Duncan T. O'Brien.

The annual Lady Cubitt Birthday Ball was held at the Princess Hotel last night and among members of the committee were Mrs. Vincent Astor, Miss Julia Ryan, Mrs. Dwight Wiman, Mrs. Philip P. Gardiner and Mrs. Jerome Hilborn of New York.

The long-smoldering issue of the sovereignty of islands In the South Pacific promises to break out soon in a diplomatic exchange with Great Britain along lines now being carefully laid by the State and Navy Departments.

Trading in the wholesale markets was affected by the advent of the lenten season and business was only fair to slow. Lamb prices were strong to 50c higher; other classes were steady with the exception of fresh pork cuts, which showed some unevenness. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be strong to slightly higher; other classes about steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

More than 00 persons were stranded in three trains under the Hudson River and crowds of other travelers left their trains in New Jersey and crossed to New York on ferryboats soon after 9 A. M. yesterday when a Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company train was disabled near the New York side of the tube, causing a twenty-minute delay.

A preliminary meeting of the European steel cartel took place here today and another is to be held tomorrow. According to The Economic Review, published here, the whole question of whether the steel cartel is to be continued may be under discussion.

Charles Edmunds Kimball, a trust officer of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, died yesterday at Post-Graduate Hospital after a long illness. Mr. Kimball, who lived on Riversville Road, Greenwich, Conn., was 47 years old.

In one of the most trying days experienced by the favorites in years in the national indoor tennis championships Miss Norma Taubele, Mrs. Virginia Rice Johnson of Boston and Miss Helen Germaine were eliminated from the women's singles yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
Four physicians are accused of having assassinated two Soviet functionaries, Valerian V. Quibesheff and Vyacheslaff Menzhinsky, and the writer Maxim Gorky.

Paul Tomko, trading as Garlic Tablet Company, 110 West Fortieth Street, New York, has stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to stop representing that his garlic tablets constitute an effective remedy for high blood pressure and certain other ailments, and that his product is fortified with essential bodybuilding minerals, the commission announced today.
Isoh Abe, leader of the Social Mass party, was savagely beaten this morning in his home by four ruffians apparently of the type commonly called patriotic bullies.
The China Clipper, which took off for Alameda, Calif., at 12:30 P. M. (6 P. M. Eastern standard time) today, turned back forty-five minutes later on orders of Pan
The stock markets here suffered from general weakness today. Gilt-edge issues lost ground on budget fears, while foreign loans held little of interest.

An appeal by Joseph J. Rempsen, in his fight against the condemnation of his property for reservoir purposes by the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company, was in the records of the Supreme Court of Errors today for a hearing later.

A convict's civil rights are restored automatically when his prison sentence is commuted by the Governor, even though he may continue on parole, according to a decision issued yesterday by Justice Emanuel Green- T berg of the State Court of Claims.
The Board of Estimate received Mayor La Guardia's recommendations yesterday for additional cuts of $131,585 in the budget and voted to make` reductions aggregating the $42,515 immediately.

The last obstadle to the passage of resolutions providing for constitutional amendments to put the State's credit behind a housing and slum-clearance program was cleared up today when it became known that Governor Lehman had agreed to the Republican plan to increase the proposed revolving fund from $100,000,000 to $200,000,000.

There can be little doubt that Glenn Cunningham is the greatest miler that ever lived. The consistency of his performances, if nothing else, is sufficient to attest to such rating for the man who ran the mile in 4:04.4, fastest in footracing history, at Hanover, N. H., last night.

The status of French and Japanese as well as British islands in the Pacific is involved in the investigation which State and Navy Department geographic experts are making to decide where claims of priority to sovereignty would rest should the issue be raised in diplomatic channels.

First editions of American authors from the libraries of Morris L. Parrish, Dormy House, Pine Valley, N. J., and another collector brought $17,175- last night at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc.

Whether this city was captured by Rear Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn's attack force or successfully defended by the United states-Puerto Rican brigade in the final operation of the joint navy and army manoeuvres in the Caribbean must be determined by the umpires.

Mrs. Merle Rutherford DeRuyter obtained a final divorce decree today from John Lewis DeRuyter of New York. She testified that they were married in New York in 1935 and that her husband never supported her, but borrowed money which her aunt furnished her.
The Panama Pacific Line has filed notice with the Intercoastal Freight Shipping Association of its intention to withdraw from membership in sixty days, it was learned yesterday.

Bernhard K. Schaefer, a member of the board of governors of the New York Coffee Exchange, said yesterday at a meeting in the headquarters here of the New York State Chamber of Commerce that Brazil's new coffee policy would lead eventually to elimination of the uneconomic producer and of much of the poor quality of coffee now produced in excess of demand.

The United States liner Washington, arriving today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh, has as. passengers William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France; Jo Davidson, Gilbert White, Paul Bry and Bozidar Stojanovich, Consul General of Yugoslavia at New York.
President Roosevelt and his official family will relive tomorrow a part of the day on which he was first inaugurated.
William Hurd Lawrence, artist and illustrator for many national magazines, died yesterday in Richmond Memorial Hospital, Prince's Bay, S. I., after a long illness. He was'72 years old.

Premature subdivision of real estate in city and suburban areas in advance of need is increasing in the State and is causing higher taxes and reduction of land values, the State Planning Division said today in a report sent to Governor Lehman.

Officials of Erie County, N. Y., will consider tenders on March 14 for a new issue of $2,750,000 of various purpose bones, maturing serially from March 15, 1939 to 1953. The financing will consist of county ja, tax revenue, home relief and general improvement bonds.
Karl Moses of Chicago was found dead in bed in his room in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday by a hotel employe. Heart disease was believed to be the cause of his death. He was 57 years old.
Eight, acres of land with a long frontage on 911apartus Road, in the town of New Castle, Westchester County, have been sold by the Elda Corporation,
ACTION AT AQUILA, by Hervey Allen. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) A romance of the Civil War. MEET ME ON THE BARRICADES, by Charles Yale Harrison. (Scribner, $2.) A fantasy of revolution.

A message tonight from Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, and diplomatic officials in Washington will start the use of the PanAmerican channel recently assigned to the General Electric Company of Schenectady for non-commercial programs of good-will between the Americas, it was announced yesterday.

The six defendants in Kansas City's eleventh vote fraud trial were convicted late today by a jury in Federal Judge Merrill E. Otis's court. Leniency was recommended for Ellis Buck, 30, a Democratic judge, and for Mrs. Ruth Tucker, 33, a Democratic clerk,

A drive to promote new uses and increased consumption of cotton was launched here today when the Cotton Consumption Council was organized by a gathering of cotton growers, manufacturers and distributors.

Title to the "fireproof, up-to-date" and entirely modern "heaven" of Father Divine, Harlem cult leader, was taken yesterday by a friendly Negro rival by the name of "Bishop" Charles Manuel Grace (he is also known as "Daddy"), who plans to set up headquarters here to attract followers-including Father Divine's if they wish to follow.

Trading was mostly slow. The lamb market was higher, fresh pork and steer cuts steady to lower, veal weak, other classes steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb to be sharply higher and a few sales steer beef 50e or more higher, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
Radio amateurs of the country functioned as a group yesterday in establishing communications between flooded Los Angeles and the rest of the country.

Heather Gloria, attractive Scottish terrier, who was named the best in show at Boston last week, accounted for another brilliant triumph tonight as she carried off the chief prize in the first annual all-breed fixture sponsored by the Southern Tier Kennel Club.
Raymond Moley, one of the President's early advisers and now a magazine editor, accused the New Deal Administration of eight major failures in an address here today.

After almost half a century at 308-10 West Fifty-ninth Street, the Savage School for Physical Education will move to the vicinity of McComb's Dam Park, where it has leased the five-story William McKinley Masonic Temple at 454 West 155th Street..
GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name.

Investors in the $13,000,000 Series B-K issue of mortgage certificates guaranteed by the New York Title and Mortgage Company may expect to recover their entire original investments, according to a report of the trustees for the issue filed yesterday with Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler.

Israel Convisser, attorney, of 66 Court Street, Brooklyn, was reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday as being "of the League for Insurance Reform" and as telling the State Senate Insurance Committee: "The Metropolitan has engaged in a campaign of terror to break up our union."
Reports from the North country yesterday indicated that the most promising snow conditions in more than five weeks are in store for the many skiers who will flee the city this week-end.
Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Harriet Chase of 177 East Seventy-fourth Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Chase of Holyoke, Mass., to Gerald M. Hicks,

The United States Coast Guard reported receipt of a radio message from the S. S. Pennsylvania early today that Robert Paine Scripps of the Scripps-Howard newspaper chain died on his yacht. His body was transferred aboard the Pennsylvania off the Lower California coast.
More members of the New York Stock Exchange were born in Germany than in any country other than the United States, according to the institution's year book, released yesterday.
With fifteen seconds left to play, Edwards took a pass from Sievard and slammed the puck into the net to give the New York A. C. a tie with the St. Nicks. 4--4, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

Madison St, 222, 26.1x100; Isaac Cohn et al to Metropolitan Savings Bank; mtg $14,000 held by bank. Broome St, n e cor Sullivan St, 8Ox31: Metropolitan Savings Bank to Alfred Stern, 600 E 178th St, Bronx ($5).
The board of directors of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company at a meeting yesterday declared a 25cent, dividend to its shareholders. The company paid $1 a share on April 1 last year.

A brochure entitled "Why Independent Merchants Fail" was issued yesterday by the Institute of Distribution, 570 Seventh Avenue. The pamphlet covers the results of surveys made in seventeen widely varied sections of the country.

A barrage of bricks, thrown by angry hosiery workers, interrupted an auction of equipment today at the closed hosiery mill of Brownhill Kramer, Inc. Windows were shattered by the missiles hurled by part of a crowd of 4,000 persons,

An eighteen-game baseball schedule, featured by the annual home-and-home series with Princeton, Lehigh and Lafayette, was announced today for the Rutgers team by George E. Little, director of athletics.
The casualties in the Southern California flood disaster included the following: Identified Dead Mrs. Henry Lackey of Pomona. Jack Lackey of Pomona, her son. H. R. Wessing of San Jose.
There is an urgent and unmistakable need of such a Congressional investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority as its chairman, Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, has demanded.

Appealing unqualifiedly to "those holding my boy," Murray Levine, attorney whose 12-year-old son, Peter, was kidnapped after leaving school in New Rochelle a week ago yesterday afternoon, indicated last night his willingness to pay a ransom and his eagerness to hear from the kidnappers.
During the week ended March 2 member bank reserve balances decreased $25,000,000. Reductions in member

The following Marine Corps changes, dated Feb. 28, were announced today: Sweet, Capt. W., Norfolk, Va., to home, to retire on May 1. Dyer, Capt. E. C., Annapolis, Md., to temporary duty at Anacostia, D. C., on May 28, then to duty at University of California. Berkeley.
Fingerprints on a teapot were slim clues by which police sought tonight to solve the mysterious slaying today of an elderly nurse in the suburban home of her employer.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today. Henry G. Wood, Stephen E. Rice and Alexander C. Neave of New York City, were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 511-The Negro Alliance, et al., petrs., v. Sanitary Grocery Company, Inc. Argued for both.

Dunham Wheeler, who designed many well-known homes in the metropolitan area, and who was an uncle of Colonel Henry L. Stimson, died here this morning in his home after a short illness. He was 76 years old.
Firs of unexplained origin was discovered at 3:15 A. M. yesterday in the main lounge of the liner Berengaria, the third largest ship in the world, as she lay at her West Fiftieth Street pier.

Sheriff Edward C. Dormann is in Jacksonville, Fla., seeking the extradition of John Alden Ward, 29 years old, who is wanted in Rockland County on an indictment charging abandonment of his wife and three children last November, District Attorney Dorsey announced today.

The Federal Labor Board today served formal notice on seventeen American and British petroleum companies that the new wage scale and operating program approved Tuesday by the Supreme Court would become effective at noon Monday.

A long floor goal by Johnny Acropolis in the last few minutes broke a 29-29 tie and gave-the University Club of Stamford, Conn., a 31-to-29 decision over the New York Athletic Club in an Eastern Athletic Club League game on the Winged Footers' court last night.
General John J. Pershing "made satisfactory progress today," Dr. Roland Davison said in a bulletin tonight. The bulletin read:
Large-scale smuggling of opium, morphine and similar drugs into Chile for continent-wide distribution is being investigated by sanitary police authorities, it was admitted here this afternoon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York Westchester Boston Railroad should be taken over by the city and reopened as soon as possible. It could probably be purchased at a bargain and with a comparatively small investment converted into a rapid transit line of high capacity, the value of which to the' East and North Bronx and to the adjoining suburban communities could hardly be overestimated.

Sales of copper were made late yesterday in the export market at 10.08 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports. Most of the business, however, was done in the range of 10.025 to 10.04 cents, where some 5,000 tons of the metal were reported sold. On Wednesday,

2:00-3:00 P. M.-Damrosch Music Appreciation Hour-WEAF, WJZ. 3:00-3:30 P. M.-United States Marine Band Concert-WABC. 3:30-3:45 P. M.-"Railroad Reorganization," Senator Harry S. Truman oT Missouri-WABC.
King George, bareheaded in the Spring sunshine, drove to St. James's Palace in a gold and glass coach today to open the first levee of the season.
The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company has borrowed $12,500,000 from banks in this city for two and three year periods, it was announced yesterday by Frank Purnell, president of the company.

The Stock Exchange Brokers, paced by Harry Sniffen, turned back the Crescent A. C. in a Metropolitan Amateur Hockey League contest at Madison Square Garden yesterday Sniffen scored four goals to lead his team to a 5-2 triumph over the Brooklyn organization.

S. Earl Honig, associated with William S. Sussman, Inc., for the past eighteen years and executive vice president of that well-known downtown realty firm for the past nine years, has become president of the company.

The replacement of 195 "old and obsolete" school buildings in this city at a cost of nearly $200,000,000 was recommended yesterday by James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education. These buildings now house 175,000 elementary and junior high school children.

St. Joe Paper Company, Port St. Joe. Fla., has agreed to purchase the Thames River paperboard mill of Robert Gair Company, Inc., located at New London, Conn., and the Gair Company has agreed to purchase from the St. Joe concern. over a period of years,

It will be New York University against Long Island University and Temple against Bradley Tech of Peoria, Ill., in the first round of the national invitation intercollegiate basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden next Wednesday night.

A new company is to be formed to own the properties and assets of Eastern Air Lines, which Captain Eddie V. Rickenbacker and associates are purchasing from North American Aviation, Inc., an affililate of the General Motors Corporation, for $3,500,000 in cash.

An employee on a weekly wage, who refused to be dismissed, led Jay C. Hormel, Austin, Minn., packer, to work out a method of guaranteeing an annual wage based on the assumption that the employer's duty is to make every effort to keep men at work.

James T. Farrell has completed a novel which the Vanguard Press will publish in the Fall. The novel, as yet untitled, deals with the O'Neills and. O'Flahertys about whom "A World I Never Made" centered.
The wedding of King Zog of Albania and Countess Geraldine Apponyi, whose mother was an American, was set today for April 25 in the Tirana palace.
Weather conditions in most sections of the country are holding back initial Spring promotions in ready-to-wear and accessories, buyers in the market- here reported yesterday.

The Building Service Employes International Union, Local 32-A, called a strike yesterday morning in the six-story building at 2,612 Broadway, near Ninety-ninth Street, and according to union officials about twenty walked out.

Nikolai N. Krestinsky, who yesterday, alone of all the twenty-one defendants in the treason trial, pleaded not guilty, repudiated the confession he had made to NKVD [secret police] investigators and defied his accusers, broke down overnight.

THE Civil War was our Trojan War, Edward Weeks once remarked. And our best-seller lists have often been directories of its Homers. The newest of these is Hervey Allen, whose "Action at Aquila"* is destined for enormous popularity.
A. D. Weekes, seeded No. 1, captured his second-round match in the national Class C squash tennis championship at the New York A C. yesterday. He vanquished Newton Kutner, City A. C., by 15-7 17-14.

Fire Island, thirty-seven-mile strip of oceanfront sand dunes, soon will be linked to Suffolk County by a bridge, according to plans of the bridge and causeway committee of the Board of Supervisors, it was learned today.

The Sultan of Muscat and Oman, who is on a trip around the world, arrived her today for an official visit of three days and was received with the military and diplomatic honors due a ruling sovereign.

In the face of repeated objections by defense counsel, Assistant District Attorney Martin Frank launched yesterday a triple offensive against Mrs. Patricia Ryan, who is on trial in Bronx County Court for the murder of her husband, Patrolman Michael Ryan.

Republicans here expressed satisfaction today over the announcement by W. Warren Barbour of his Senate candidacy. Senator McNary, minority leader, said: "Mr. Barbour should receive a majority of the votes from the good people of New Jersey on account of his splendid record of previous service as a Senator."

More than 300 applications from newspaper men throughout the country have been received by Harvard University for scholarships to be granted under the will of Mrs. Lucius W. Nieman, widow of the founder of The Milwaukee Journal.
Secretary Morgenthau declined today to discuss reductions in the Treasury's sterilized gold fund which occurred in the past week.
BRINGING UP BABY, from a short story by Hagar Wilde; screen play by Dudley Nichols and Mr. Wilde; directed and produced by Howard Hawks for RKO Radio. At the Radio City Music Hall.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works held today the first annual meeting under the approved reorganization plan and the voting trustees for the new $13-par-value common stock, who had sole voting power at the meeting, elected a new board of directors.

A deal in the Carl Schurz Park section was reported by Douglas Gibbons Co., brokers, who leased for Dr. Edward J. Rogers to Wil-son C. McCarty for occupancy the three-story dwelling at 150 East End Avenue.

One hundred and thirty-five entries from nineteen high and preparatory schools have been received for the eighteenth annual Rutgers interscholastic swimming championships to be held in the Rutgers gymnasium pool Saturday at 2 P. M., Jim Reilly, coach of the Rutgers swimming team and manager of the meet, announced today as entries closed.

Three new appointments in the New York offices of the Insurance Company of North America were announced yesterday, effective March 1. Bernard Graham was appointed assistant manager of the fire metropolitan department,

Glenn Cunningham plotted his race almost to the exact tenth-second tonight, when he ran a 4:04.4 mile, fastest on record for man, indoors or out, on Dartmouth College's springy board track, which measures 6 2-3 laps to the mile.

A court here ruled today that a German national might not marry a girl who would be a "nonAryan" under Germany's Nuremberg laws even though there Is nothing in The Netherlands laws recognizing racial distinctions.

Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., the defending titleholder, advanced to the semi-finals of the Florida East Coast championship for the Mrs. William R. Kenan Jr. Trophy by defeating Miss Jean Bauer, former New York State ruler, on St. Augustine Links today. The golf queen of the Carolinas won by 5 and 4.

Proverbial March winds with continued cold are predicted for today by the Weather Bureau following a sharp drop in temperature from a high of 48 degrees at 12:01 A. M. yesterday to 14 degrees at 10 o'clock last night.
The Eighth Avenue Temple halted the Brooklyn Y. M. H. A., 35-25, at the Brooklyn Jewish Center, in the quarter-final round of the Kings County A. A. U. basketball tournament last night.

Next Wednesday, March 9, will be the final day for filing applications for the army's flying cadet class at the "West Point of the Air," the Air Corps training center at Randolph Field, Texas, it was announced yesterday.

Graphic descriptions of inundated areas of residential districts and fertile farm lands in and around metropolitan Los Angeles were given here today by the pilot and passengers of the first plane in from Southern California in two days.

Yesterday's agreement between Dr. Arthur Seyss-Inquart, the Minister of the Interior, and the Styrian Nazi leader, Professor Armin Dardieu, was repudiated by the government today, and the wearing of the swastika and the use of the "Heil Hitler" greeting are still banned.

Possibility of the re-establishment of the brick industry here was indicated today when it became known that the Rockland County Board of Supervisors had called a special meeting for next Tuesday to consider an offer for its share in tax arrears on property formerly owned by the North River Brick Company.

Department store sales in St. Louis in the week ended last Saturday were 34.8 per cent above the previous week, but 13.3 per cent below last year, as against a decline of 10 per cent in the previous week from a year

Organization of a new cooperative for the printing industry, the Allied Graphic Arts Cooperative Corporation, with a membership of several established printing houses, was announced yesterday by M. M. Greenwald, president and general manager.
Bowling Green Park, which is being restored to something resembling its eighteenth century appearance, will be dedicated with a costume pageant by a committee of patriotic societies on April 6.

A charge that the Life Underwriters Association was conducting a telegram campaign against the Savings Bank Life Insurance Bill similar to that conducted by the utilities v against the death sentence for hold-

Ann Cooper Hewitt Gay, heiress, filed suit today for divorce from Ronald M. Gay, charging that he caused her "grievous mental suffering" and that- she and her- husband were temperamentally incompatible.

Michael D. Lieberman, a lawyer, of 353 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, testified most of yesterday as a State witness in the General Sessions trial of two women, ten men and ten corporations on the indictment in the alleged $2,000,000. Slovak Manor land fraud conspiracy.

Candidates in the examination for promotion to the rank of lieutenant, whose application numbers are from 501 to 1,000, and who are entitled to credit in that examination in record and seniority on account of military service, shall be directed to report at Room 1428, Muniicpal Building,

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Smith of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Mary Lillian Smith, to Henry Bull Root, son of Mrs. Arthur Root of New York and the late Mr. Root on Saturday in Florida.

The rector, church wardens and vestrymen of St. George's Church in the City of New York have leased to H. Seidman the church property on the new Boardwalk at Beach 110th Street, Rockaway Park, Queens, through Lewis H. May Company, agents for the church.
The motion-picture industry today attempted to dig itself out of the debris left by the storm, and in those studios where production was attempted only skeleton staffs were in evidence

Former President Herbert Hoover today received from Vienna Technical University the honorary degree of Doctor of Technical Sciences, an honor seldom awarded. "If statesmen can give us peace, engineers can give us civilization," Mr. Hoover told the audience.

Arving Management, Inc., of New York City, Robert Wasserman, president, sold to Louis Levin the two twenty-family apartment houses at 474-480 Bramhall Avenue, Jersey City. The buildings occupy a plot 111 by 112 feet.

No plan for transit unification can be imposed upon New York City without the city's consent. Neither, under existing laws, can any plan be carried out by the city without the approval of the Transit Commission.

Mere expectation of the announcement of a favorable offer by the Treasury for an exchange of securities for the maturing 3 per cent notes was sufficient yesterday to lift prices of outstanding government bonds moderately higher in relatively quiet trading.
Historians and laymen are pretty well agreed that in Soviet Russia it is once more a case of revolution devouring her own chil-

William N. Cohen, former Supreme Court Justice and for many years one of the leading trial counsel of the New York bar, who died at Atlantic City on Feb. 27, named four charitable and educational institutions and United States Supreme Court Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo among the legatees in his will, which was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

The Johns-Manville Corporation showed a net profit for 1937 of $5,451,843 after depreciation, depletion, obsolescence, Federal taxes and $7,500 provision for surtax on undistributed income, according to the annual report of Lewis H. Brown, president, mailed to stockholders last night.

Of overshadowing importance, despite current reports of large reverses in the battle north of the Yellow River, is the adoption by the Chinese Government of the program of mass mobilization, urged ever since the beginning of the war by the former Chinese Communists.
Rear Admiral Wilson Brown, Superintendent of the Naval Academy, announced today that Lieutenant Harry J. Hardwick would continue as head coach of football.
The Salzburg Festival Committee announced today that it has been impossible to persuade Arturo Toscanini to change his decision not to come to Salzburg for the next festival.
A new shop in Allentown, Pa., to be known as Louise Allen, has been added to the Jane Engel chain. The shop will be under the direction of H. B. Sigal Co.

The plain oak coffin containing Gabriele d'Annunzio's body, after a simple funeral ceremony in the village church, lies on the foredeck of the warship Puglia, the bow of which rises majestically from the lawn of the villa in which he spent the last days of his life.

An investigation of the administration and policies of the Tennessee Valley Authority became highly probable today as a result of the demand by Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, TVA chairman, for a thorough inquiry in the interest of "honesty, openness, decency and fairness in government."

A new figurepiece, "The Prayer," by Malvina Hoffman, is included in the exhibition current at the English Bookshop, 64 East Fifty-fifth Street.

Swirling waters swept today through five counties of Southern California, including some of the richest agricultural, and orchard lands in the country, as a five-day rainstorm reached a tragic climax in the worst flood in the history of the State.
The British Army's share of the [Pound]343,250,000 which the country will spend for defense in the coming twelve months will be f106,500,000, as compared with the [Pound]82,174,000 allotted

Production of men's and youths' suits made wholly or partly of wool by 1,025 manufacturers during the four weeks ended Dec. 25 totaled 765,123, compared with 564,549 in the four-week period ended Nov. 27, according to figures issued by the Bureau of the Census.

A victory by Andrew Ponzi, creating a four-way tie for first place, and a sensational high run of 111 by Jimmy Caras featured yesterday's play in the world pocket billiard championship tourney at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.
There has developed out of the Moscow trials a rift between the Communist and Socialist allies of the French Popular Front majority which may have important political consequences in this country.

The Maloney bill for regulation of overthe-counter markets was reported favorably to the Senate today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee after the bill had been modified to exempt dealers in Fed-

OF the two performing Baers in the heavyweight circus, most of the fight fans will now take Buddy. Tommy Farr, who apparently differs with everybody about everything, plans to take Max next week. But, as Kipling said, that's another story. The preference of the fans is for Buddy.
Chance Ray, 6-year-old gelding owned by C. E. Davison, reversed his usual style of running today, coming from behind to annex the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds.
Leon Berard was received by the French Academy this afternoon in the traditional, brilliant ceremony that President Albert Lebrun attended.

Evidence contradicting a vital point in the indictment on which twenty-one leading Bolsheviki are now being tried in Moscow was offered yesterday to Alexander Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador, by Dr. John Dewey, chairman of the commission of inquiry that investigated the previous Moscow trials and pronounced them frameups.

Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Transportation have no objection to the enactment of a State law giving to the 5,400 employes of the city's Independent Subway System the right of collective bargaining, through labor organizations of their own choosing,

Power Memorial Academy's quintet finished its Manhattan-Richmond C. H. S. A. A. schedule in a deadlock for second place with La Salle Academy by beating Cathedral Boys High, 36-24, on the winners' court yesterday.
A record severing of communications between San Francisco and Los Angeles followed the Southern California storms.

Trustees for the Prudence Company, Inc., now being reorganized, moved yesterday to collect a part of the $255,207 deficiency judgment against Supreme Court Justice Algeron I. Nova by docketing his name in the Queens County Clerk's office, where the original judgment was recorded in 1932 minus his name.
Introducing himself to Chancellor Adolf Hitler with the phrase: "The President of the United States accredits me near you," Hugh R. Wilson, former Under-Secretary of State,
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The new product to be introduced by Zenith Radio Manufacturing Corporation has been revealed as an inter-communcation system for homes or offices. Transmitter and speaker use the orthodox house wiring.
A message that Los Angeles had not "suffered a major disaster in any sense of the word" was broadcast over the Columbia System yesterday by Mayor Frank L. Shaw of the California city.

Police promotions, including the appointment of an inspector, a deputy inspector, three captains, nine lieutenants and fifteen sergeants, will be announced during the week of March 21, simultaneously with the graduation exercises of the Police Academy, Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday.
A twin-motored United Air Lines passenger plane took off for New York tonight with 3,000 pounds of air mail, 90 per cent of it from the flood-ravaged Los Angeles area.
Police Commissioner Valentine, in a general order issued yesterday, placed assessments on the salaries of all members of the department to create a fund to be used for charitable purposes.

The annual report of the J. C. Penney Company for 1937 shows net earnings of $16,575,164, equal to $6.52 a share on 2,543,984 common shares, compared to $18,712,488, or $7.36 a share, for 1936. Total sales were $275,375,137, against $258,322,479, a gain of 6.6 per cent.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City rose $7,000,000 to $7,833,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of the banks, published yesterday.

Wager Swayne, pianist and teacher, bought the five-story fireproof dwelling at 1 East Sixty-second Street, adjoining the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue, from a client of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam Roberts, attorneys. Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., negotiated the sale.

Current sharp increases in sales of automatic heating equipment are due in large measure to the fact that prices on the heating products are much lower than for most other building equipment, E. L. Sylvester of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation declared yesterday.

Bruce Wallis, captain of the Columbia University fencing team, became the new national junior saber champion when he defeated Cornell. Wilde of the Salle d'Armes Vince, 5-1, in a fence-off on the strips of the Salle Santelli last night.

Forecast for rain or snow in Kansas, pressure from commission houses with Eastern connections and private reports estimating the prospective Winter wheat crop at 659,000,000 bushels, or 29,000,000 in excess of the Department of Agriculture's Dec. 1 tentative figure, resulted in the wheat market on the Board of Thade here developing a weaker undertone today.
With the first game of the exhibition schedule, against the Athletics at Lake Charles, only two days away, Manager Bill Terry cracked down more vigorously on his Giants today.
A block of 28,600 shares of the common stock of the Union Carbide and Carbon Company was distributed yesterday by the First Boston Corporation
Conversations between the British and German Governments on the European situation were resumed today when Chancellor Hitler received Ambassador Sir Nevile Henderson in private audience.

Very quietly, a plan has been launched whereby Margery Sharp's successful light novel, "The Nutmeg Tree," would become a Broadway play-and this despite the fact that the screen rights to it already have been acquired by MetroGoldwyn-Mayer.
Three entire floors in the building at 22 East Fortieth Street have been leased by the American Dyewood Company, which for many years has been located in the Pershing Square Building.

Secretary Morgenthau said today that the bill introduced yesterday by Senator Glass to regulate and curtail bank holding companies was not approved by the interdepartmental committee on banking legislation, which has been discussing bank holding company legislation.
Stocks of lead held by domestic smelters and refiners on Feb. 1 were 211,087 tons, compared with 208,803 a month earlier, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.

Approval of plans to go ahead with a cooperative program of developing certified colors for cosmetics in advance of pending legislation was voiced yesterday in a report submitted to the executive board of the Toilet Goods Association by the bureau of standards of the industry, according to Dr. H. Gregory Thomas, director of the bureau.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 2: BRIGADIER GENERALS Burnett, F. C., assistant to the adjutant general. 1 month and 25 days leave,

The preliminary report of the New Jersey State Planning Board on the large amount of idle subdivided land in that State has focused attention anew on the value of long-term regional planning for rural as well as urban and suburban properties.

CAPORALE, JOSEPH (Dec. 21, 1937). Gross assets, $17,314; net, $15,930. To wife, Pauline Caporale, one-third of residuary estate; son, Philip J. Caporale, and daughters, Mary Kiely, Agnes, Theresa and Rose Caporale, equal interest in twothirds of residuary estate. Chief assets,

Robert V. Hassmiller of Bayonne, N. J., was elected captain of next season's Fordham basketball team yesterday by a unanimous vote of the letter men and John S. Murray of Brooklyn was named assistant manager.

Rather than submit to what he called unjustified interference by union officials with the running of his business, Julius Michael, president and treasurer of the Fast Line Transportation Company, 416 East Twenty-third Street, announced last night that he would close his place and go out of business.

The St. Joe Paper Company of Port St. Joe, Fla., jointly owned by the Mead Corporation and the Almours Securities Company, has agreed to purchase the Thames River paperboard mill of Robert Gair Company, Inc., at New London, Conn.

Albert D. Phelps, Inc. has arranged a first mortgage of $118,000 on the six-story apartment at 1,460 College Ave, the Bronx. for the Harley Development Corporation with the New York State Teachers Retirement System.
Total revenues from ultimate customers of the electric light and power industry in December, last, were $189,229,000, compared to $184,
To take effect 8 A. M., March 4: SERGEANTS 18th Division, detective districts, designated as acting lieutenants: Daniel J. Mahoney 1, Francis J. Watterson Jr., 4.

The small estate owned by the estate of Julian P. Fairchild in Meadow Spring, Glen Cove, L. I., has been purchased by William R. Coe through Warren Murdock, broker. The property consists of three acres,
The weekly statement. of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

Backwaters from swollen Red River crept over lowlands south of Shreveport today, forcing sixty families from their homes and sending Red Cross relief workers into the area. The inundation was worse at Colfax where Bayou Darrow had evicted thirty-five families.
White Tollett, 26 years old, and Church Lester, 44, of Pikeville, Tenn., were convicted today and sentenced to the electric chair for the dynamite deaths of three little girls.
There was almost no change in the level of business in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

The executive council of the National University of El Salvador has opened an international competition for plans for a new building and information regarding it has been sent to all legations and consulates.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Platt Daniels of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of their younger daughter, Miss Josephine Sheffield Daniels, to Charles Belknap Lockwood of this city, son of Mrs. Charles Belknap Lockwood of Richmond, Mass.

The Grand Street Boys Association presented yesterday to James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education, a medal for "unselfish service-to the City of New York." Former General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein, president of the association, made the award at his offices in 291 Broadway.

Roger Touhy, under sentence of 99 years for the ransom kidnapping of John Factor in Chicago in 1933, appealed to the Supreme Court today in an effort to gain his freedom. Touhy's petition said that his conviction was void because
Cora Lee Cheatham, 6, ran to the home of a neighbor today to tell her mother that a younger brother had set a mattress afire in the Cheatham tenant home near here. The mother,- Mrs. Nolan Cheatham,

The Yankees reached up to New Hampshire today and bagged Red Robert Rolfe of Penacook. The urge to come down here where the sun always shines, a rise in pay or a little of both induced the agile thirdbaseman to sign a 1938 contract.
The bitterness of the Spanish civil war has left room for few acts of gallantry between foes, but on the Aragon front yesterday there was one.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, and unior Hadassah have donated $40,000 toward the purchase of 5,000 acres of land in Upper Galilee, Palestine, according to an announcement yesterday by Mrs. Herman Shulman, national secretary of Hadassah.

Pressing forward through Yuanchu from Tsiyuan, in Honan Province, a Japanese column occupied late yesterday Wensi, about forty-six miles south of Linfen, the former Shansi provincial headquarters of the Chinese, according to dispatches received here today.
More labor strife on Eastern waterfronts appeared likely tonight after I Harry Bridges stated that he was moving into Atlantic and Gulf, ports with his C. I. O. longshoremen's union.

The fifth anniversary of the beginning of Cordell Hull's service as Secretary of State, which comes tomorrow, was marked by the issuance tonight by the State Department of a review of his administration which emphasized not only his economic program, but also his ti efforts for peace.

A communique was issued at the conclusion of yesterday's meeting of the International Steel Cartel in Brussels announcing that prices would be maintained and that a subcommittee with wide powers was to be established in London to assure the carrying out of agreements concluded recently between steel companies here and abroad.

A "sit-down" strike of the highjumpers and pole-vaulters in, the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. championships at Madison Square Garden tomorrow may result if officials do not change their plans to hold qualifying trials in these events in the afternoon.
J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, reported today to President Roosevelt that national banks had more of their assets in commercial loans than in government bonds.

At the suggestion of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, the Federal Advisory Council has undertaken to query member banks of the system for suggestions as to how the Reserve System may increase the value or scope of its services.
Ten thousand persons in Los Angeles County are receiving emergency relief from the Red Cross.

Ferry rates for pleasure cars, including any number of occupants, were slashed to a new low yesterday by the New York Central Railroad, which announced that, beginning Monday, 25 cents would be charged for passage on the West Shore Railroad ferryboats between New York and Weehawken.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 1: CAPTAIN Noyes. L., the Lexington, to duty as Chief of Staff and Aide, Commander Aircraft, Battle Force, in June.

Voters of seventy-four municipalities located in twenty-five States approved in the month of February municipal bond issues aggregating $4,900,600, as compared with $3,603,771 approved in January, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The largest item was $1,600,000 by voters of Road District No. 1 of Duval County, Texas.

The belief that fair-trade laws raise prices to the consumer is fallacious, since they merely eliminate price-cutting, which previously had been compensated by higher markups on non-competing items, Earl Means of the Bristol-Myers Company declared yesterday.
A bond issue of 120,000,000 marks ($48,000,000) was offered today for public subscription by the Braunkohlen Benzin Corporation.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Confronted with a mass of evidence, directors of the Chicago Board of Trade said today that it probably would be nearly a month before they could render a decision in the case of the Cargill Grain Company and three of its officers who are accused of violation of regulations of the Exchange and of the Commodity Exchange Act in their operations in September (1937) corn contracts.

Today the Clearwater ball park was in the finest condition, the clubhouse was spick and span, the Dodger trainer had all his liniments and unguents neatly laid out and the weather was excellent-but there was no baseball club on hand.

Irving Epstein and his three youthful partners at contract bridge yesterday became the youngest team ever to enter the final round of a team-of-four contest in the twelve years of the Eastern championships, which are in progress at the Park Central Hotel.

The United States Customs Court has no jurisdiction over suits for recovery of import compensating taxes collected under the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1933, now invalidated by the Supreme Court, the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals has ruled in a suit by Marshall Field Co. to recover such taxes, it was learned today.

More trouble with stevedors started this afternoon when workers walked off the steamer Coamo, New York-bound, after having been called on strike by Mario Miranda, a member of the committee that conducted the successful six-week strike that ended three weeks ago.
Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Adams will give a dinner tonight at their home, 165 East Eighty-third Street, for Miss Rosamund Hodges and her fiance, Stirling S. Adams.

Sweden, so far, 'has not felt the depression, but Swedish prosperity, contrary to widespread belief, is no proof of the virtues of "managed money," Professor Eli Heckscher of the University of Stockholm told a group of economists and financial writers yesterday at the Harvard Club, 27 West Forty-fourth Street.

Effective Nov. 1, 1937, the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company changed its basis of providing for depreciation and obsolescence of durable manufacturing equipment, it was announced yesterday.

Following is a summary of the results of the California flood: LOS ANGELES--Thousands homeless; property damage heavy; several bridges destroyed; death list growing. HOLLYWOOD--Movie studios were hard hit by rising waters; houses of many film celebrities were damaged. LONG BEACH--Ten reported drowned when bridge collapsed; 100 evacuated from homes.

Paul Fenn, retired New York stock broker, of 31 Trinity Place, Montclair, and Bay Head, N. J., died Tuesday in Mountainside Hospital after a brief illness.
A new world's record for women anglers was recorded this week by Mrs. Michael Pym of Coconut Grove, Fla., when she entered the 34-pound jack crevalle in the metropolitan Miami fishing tournament.

Buddy Baer, younger brother of Max, former heavyweight champion of the world, will seek to establish himself as a contender for the title tonight when he tackles Gunnar Barlund of Finland in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

Joseph M. Medwick, 1937 National League batting champion who stepped from a New Jersey high school into prominence as a member of the Gas House Gang, today signed his Cardinal contract--for a rise in pay.

Robert H. Jackson is "the fair-haired hope" of the White House for the Democratic nomination as Governor of New York, Senator Bridges asserted in the Senate today during a-speech opposing Mr. Jackson's nomination as Solicitor General.
Bank clearings for the full week ended on Wednesday showed a sharp increase over the total for the five-day week preceding, as a result of payments incident to the first of the month.
Stocks continued depressed and closed slightly aswer in quiet trading; turnover, 466,880 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly lower, other issues down; transactions, $4,797,600.

The six-story apartment house at 118-80 Metropolitan Avenue, adjoining the corner of Lefferts Boulevard, Kew Gardens, L. I., has been purchased by Charles Walzer, operator, from Adelphi Homes, Inc., who built it about five years ago.

Notified today that the Works Progress Ad-ministration had rejected New Jersey's application for a grant of $35,000,000, the State House Commission met in special session and voted to modify the request to $20,000,000.' If this money is allotted,

Fifty-two operators of large numbers of automotive and horse-drawn vehicles, whose drivers completed the last six months of 1937 with the fewest accidents, received certificates of award yesterday denoting first prizes in their respective groups.

Athletes representing thirty-four schools will compete in the thirtyfifth annual P. S. A. L. city senior high indoor track and field championships at the 245th Coast Defense Armory-the Old Thirteenthin Brooklyn tonight.
The Treasury will offer bonds in exchange for the approximately $455,000,000 of 3 per cent notes which will mature on March 15, Secretary Morgenthau announced this afternoon.

In spite of the marked preference for black shown this season by the Paris couture, navy is still the leader for daytime wear in the opinion of local apparel manufacturers, an examination of import collections which arrived on the Berengaria revealed yesterday.

Ramon Ayala, Consul General of Venezuela in New York, and Mrs. Ayala entertained at dinner last night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis for Dr. Jose Abel Montilla, Venezuelan Minister to Mexico. Other guests were Dr. and Mrs. Adriano Riera, Mrs. Maria Garcia Uslar, Dr. Oscar Garcia Velutini and Dr. Alejandro Rivas Vazquez.

The trend to conservatism in installment credit, which started last year when the rate of its growth caused some concern, was intensified with the recession, according to a study made public by the Department of Commerce today.

H. Richard Niebuhr, Associate Prolessor of the Yale Divinity School, was today promoted to be Professor of Christian Ethics. He was previously president of Elmhurst College and Professor of the Philosophy of Religion at Eden Theological Seminary.
Samuel Schwartzbard, Ukrainian Jewish poet who was acquitted of a charge of murder after shooting the anti-Soviet General Simon Petlura to death on a Paris street in 1926, died today.

Town Hall, 11 A. M. "On Behalf of Democracy," Alexander Kerensky. Metropolitan conference on adult education of the New York Adult Education Council and American Association for Adult Education will open at the Hotel Astor at 3:30 P. M. and continue tomorrow.

Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were the narrowest in some time, but the list ended with gains of 3 to 5 points. Foreign buying, with price-fixing by domestic mills; held quotations within a range of a few points following an opening improvement, and further progress was made in terminating March commitments, which are now reduced below 58,000 bales.

A preliminary study of the Bank Holding Company Act of 1938, introduced in the Senate on Wednesday by Senator Glass, disclosed yesterday to bankers here some apparently far-reaching consequences of the measure that had not been anticipated.

Joseph J. Weiss, attorney, with offices at 276 Fifth Avenue, was convicted by a Federal court jury last night as the master mind of a widespread ring of disability insurance swindlers. Martin Gross, insurance broker, of 2,523 Wallace Avenue, the Bronx, also was convicted as a "chaser" for the ring.

Dr. Charles N. Gelber, former president of the New York Physicians Society and candidate for Councilman in Manhattan in the November elections, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at his 'office, 30 East Fortieth' Street. He was 46 years old.

Mrs. Marion Lippincott Loomis, widow of the Rev. Dr. Samuel Lane Loomis, died yesterday at Orlando, Fla., according to word received here by her brother, Charles S. Lippincott of 11 East Thirty-second Street. Mrs. Loomis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Lippincott, was born in Steubenville; Ohio, and was married to Dr. Loomis in 1887. Dr. Loomis died last Jan. 12.

Joseph Murphy, 31 years old, of 450 Metropolitan Avenue, West New Brighton, S. I., and John Goggin Jr., 31, of 235 Vanderbilt Avenue, Stapleton, both employes of the Park Department, were found guilty at 12:15 A. M. today of attempted rape by a jury of nine men and three women in Richmond County Court at St. George.

Charges that government departments maintained a patronage "blacklist" of members of Congress opposed to administration policies were made by Senators in debate today on the Administration Reorganization Bill.

A call for development of the smaller Stock Exchanges, because the small local company cannot be expected "to go to the national investment market for its capital," was made tonight before the Boston Stock Exchange by Ganson Purcell,

Fighting desperately to remain in the running for a play-off berth in the American Group of the National Hockey League, the Red Wings made a gallant but vain stand against the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night.

A bond trader who places a commission order on one side of a bond deal in one of the cabinets on the New York Stock Exchange floor and then receives an order on the opposite side may "cross" the orders, according to a ruling made yesterday by the Exchange's committee on bonds.

The fifteen-story apartment house at 311-17 West 106th Street was sold at auction yesterday on a bid of $100,000. The New York Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff in an action against the 106 Realty Corporation to satisfy a judgment of $731,026, was the successful bidder.

The report on odd-lot trading on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Feb. 26, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, was the first to show over a weekly range, since publication of such data was begun last June, an excess of sales over purchases.

AMELIA GOES TO THE BALL, comic opera in English in one act. Music and Italian text by Gian-Carlo Menoti, translation by george Mead. conductor, ettore panizza; stage director, Leopold seachse: chorus master, Fausto Cieva. Presented at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time.

President Roosevelt assured more than 1,000 diners celebrating the twentyfifth anniversary of the Department of Labor tonight that the Administration program for the workers would bring extended benefits not only to the wage-earners but "to all our people in the years to come."

Cole Porter's new musical play, "You Never Know," featuring Toby Wing, Lupe Velez, Libby Holman, Clifton Webb, Rex O'Malley and Charles Kempner, drew a capacity crowd tonight to the Shubert Theatre. It was well received.

Gustavus T. Kirby, who with his father, the late Thomas E. Kirby, long was prominent in the art auction business here, has resigned as a director of the newly formed Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 742 Fifth Avenue, it was learned yesterday.
The Controller General's office has sent to Congress a report citing about 100 examples of alleged "illegal contracts and expenditures" by government agencies, it became known tonight.

TODAY-New England: Clear to partly cloudy and cold during morning but with rising temperatures over all sections; temperatures rising to above freezing during afternoon over southern and central portions. New York State:

Concessions for the development of bananas in the interior of Nicaragua have been presented to Congress. Experts believe that the interior, with irrigation, would be suitable for the production of large quantities of bananas and less subject to diseases than other regions because of the dryness of the soil.

" Group" or "chain" banking under bank holding companies should not be confused with branch banking. In the latter, one central institution establishes branches and accepts responsibility for their deposits; in the former, the stock of a number of banks is under common control,

Chiefly as a result of an increase of $19.000,000 in money in circulation over the month-end, the reserve balances of member banks were reduced $25,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, covered by yesterday's Federal Reserve report.
Vast stretches of one-time sunny Hollywood look like the tag end of a super South Sea storm melodrama, as a result of a four-day storm, followed by a young cloudburst.
Forty high-scoring teams from Illinois, Wisconsin and Indiana opened the thirty-eighth annual American Bowling Congress tournament tonight. Chicago's Coliseum, scene of the biggest meet in A. B. C.

President Arturo Alessandri decorated today Paul S. Kruger of San Bernardino, Calif., a figure in the Chilean nitrate industry, with the Medal of Merit in recognition of his services in promoting good will between American capital invested here and associated Chilean interests.

In the two weeks which started yesterday members of the New York Stock Exchange will ballot on the passage of their new constitution, which makes radical changes in the organization of the trading body.

Dr. Bela Schick, discoverer of the Schick Test for determining susceptibility to diphtheria in 1913, and one of the world's most eminent pediatricians, received the Gold Medal of the New York Academy of Medicine last night at a meeting at the academy attended by a distinguished gathering of several hundred physicians.
