The Governor, by agreeing to the Republican proposal to increase the proposed State revolving fund from $100,000,000 to $200,000,000, removed the last obstacle to the passage of the constitutional amendments by the Assembly putting the State's credit behind a housing and alum clearance program.
Durlacend Brothers, internationally famous firm of London art dealers, will cease business at the end of March after almost a century of activity. The passing of the house,
Mayor La Guardia offered yesterday to resign if any part of the city budget under his control could be found to contain an unnecessary expenditure of as much as five cents.

What is said to be the first Long Island home on which final negotiations have been closed for a 90 per cent FHA insured mortgage loan has been made by the Washington Irving Trust Company of Tarrytown.

William Wyer, secretary-treasurer of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, said today that stockholders had given a good response to a plea for funds to push a reorganization plan designed to remove the road from trusteeship.

With the highest total for any February since 1929, engineering construction awards last month reached a volume of $210,801,000, a rise of 11 per cent above the February, 1937, figure of $189,197,000, according to The Engineering News-Record.
Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that the regulations prohibiting parking on ten midtown streets, put into effect temporarily on Jan. 3, will be permanent.
Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of the United States and Mme. Sylvia Henrotin of France today became the women's singles finalists in the Bermudiana Hotel's annual tennis tournament.
The permanent establishment of a Bureau of Industrial Economics in the Department of Commerce was proposed last night by Donald R. Richberg, former NRA administrator,

Asserting that the greatest hope for increased highway safety lay in the compulsory safety education of children now in force in the school system, Charles A. Harnett, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, added yesterday that there were three immediate steps which could be taken to cut the accident toll.
It requires thirty-five pages of the Congressional Directory, in small type, to list the names and personnel of what are termed the "Independent Offices and Establishments" of the Federal Government.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad completed last year the liquidation of a loan from the Railroad Credit Corporation which originally amounted to $1,500,000, D. K. Kerr, president, disclosed yesterday in the first annual report he has issued since assuming the position.
The New York Americans made sure of a National Hockey League play-off berth tonight by holding the Canadiens to a 1-1 score in a hard game featured by two brief fist fights.

A charge that four corporations fix the price of food was made today by Senator Borah, when the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee resumed hearings on the O'Mahoney-Borah bill for Federal licensing of corporations.

President Roosevelt conferred with Representatives Rayburn and Whittington on flood control legislation. The Sultan of Muscat and Oman was his guest at luncheon. He sent a letter to Secretary Perkins, read at a dinner of the Department of Labor,

George D. Strohmeyer, president of the Childs Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that due to the downtrend in the company's business in the last two months, which have been profitless,

Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Stiassni of Vienna gave a cocktail party at their apartment for Mr. and Mrs. Earl E. T. Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Wesson Seyburn, Mr. and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson, Mr. and Mrs. William Rhinelander Stewart, Mr. and Mrs. Wolcott Blair, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Frelinghuysen, Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Miller and Mr. and Mrs. John Barry Ryan Jr.

A new flood-control measure involving a change in Federal policy of financing such projects was tentatively added today to the legislative program of the present session of Congress at a White House conference in which President Roosevelt, Representative Rayburn, majority leader, and Representative Whittington, chairman of the Flood Control Committee, participated.

An ardent plea in the name of democracy and peace for Franco-American friendship at a time when France is "in the middle of the hurricane" of present-day problems was made today by Count Rene de SaintQuentin in presenting his letters o?? credence as Ambassador of France to President Roosevelt.

Representative Barton of New York told a House subcommittee considering wage and hour legislation today that Republicans were not opposed to the principle of a wages and hours bill, but were against "setting up another bureaucracy."

BRUNO, AMELIA (Feb. 24). Estate, less than $5,000. To Abraham M. Bruno, Chalfonte Hotel; Emma Bruno, Orleans Hotel; Henrietta J. Bruno, Endicott Hotel; Alfred Bruno, address undetermined, and Edwin W. Bruno, executor, 35 Montgomery Circle, New Rochelle. children, residue equally.
The steamship Norfolk, aground off Penikese Island, near Cuttyhunk, Mass., called for assistance early today and the Coast Guard ordered the cutter Argo and the patrol boat Faunce to her aid.

For the second successive period The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices advanced in the week ended on Wednesday and stood at 83.3, contrasted with 83.0 a week before, and 82.4 on Feb. 16. A year ago the average stood at 92.8.

Army and Navy have broadened the field of their athletic rivalry, it was announced today by Lieut. Col. Jacob L. Devers, graduate manager of athletics at West Point. Teams representing the institutions henceforth will meet in golf, swimming and tennis in addition to the sports previously scheduled.
The residence at 23 Brite Avenue, I Fox Meadow, Westchester County, has been purchased by Gordon C. Sleeper from Meadowbrite Properties, Inc. Fish Loomis acted as brokers.
Major General Charles D. Herron, commander of the Hawaiian Division, was assigned today to the command of the Hawaiian Department of the army, effective March 17.
Councilors, class agents, college and Alumnae Association representatives, numbering about one hundred in all, will attend the annual alumnae council at Mount Holyoke College this week-end.

The complaint that caricatures of Premier Benito Mussolini and Chancellor. Adolf Hitler published in the newspaper Patria and the weekly magazine Bohemia were insulting was dismissed today by Judge Alfredo Herrera.
Wholesale prices, on the average, rose during the week ended on Feb. 26, the first increase in the general level in six weeks, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
The secret political police, who are still holding the Rev. Martin Niemoeller in Alexanderplatz Prison, let it be known today that they had rearrested him yesterday to prevent his preaching.
Those in attendance at last night's concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, conducted by John Barbirolli, had a surprise awaiting them. The stage had been

Mayor LaGuardia has apparently lost on the two principal proposals which he has asked the Legislature to pass. The first is the bill for the abolition of the Transit Commission, and the second is the attempt on the part of the Mayor, in two separate bills, to get more relief funds for New York City.

The undistributed profits tax and the proposed surtax on the undistributed profits of closely held corporations--the "third basket"--were vigorously defended by Administration leaders today as debate opened in the House on the tax bill.

Heartening as was the statement of the National Safety Council that the year had started well in point of highway fatality reduction, the disturbing fact remains that the motor vehicle deaths for 1937, estimated at 39,700, showed an actual increase of 4 per cent over 1936.

In a ruling which was said to set a precedent in the city, County Judge Harry Stackell yesterday decided that the court was compelled to heed the plea of a jury for clemency for a defendant convicted of a felony murder and lacked the right to sentence the prisoner to the electric chair.

Judge Robert A. Inch in the Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday set March 21 as the date for trial of Albert Marinelli, former County Clerk of New York County, who is under indictment on a charge of having harbored a fugitive from justice. The fugitive,

The charge that punitive taxation on chain stores would eliminate substantial savings to consumers which result from the chain method is contained in a resolution presented to the Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment in Albany by Charles Rosenbaum, general counsel for the American Manufacturers Institute, Inc.

Delegates from seventy-seven Irish societies reported that an estimated 50,000 persons will participate in the annual St. Patrick's Day parade on Fifth Avenue on Thursday, March 17, at a meeting last night of the St. Patrick's Day
The National Maritime Union began yesterday an investigation of the efforts of owners of American flag ships to abide by Federal safety regulations.

John J. Forshaw Company, Inc., brokers, are now located at 163-06 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, Queens. The four buildings comprising Chelsea Gardens, the 171-family apartment house development which opened for occupancy on Oct. 1,
The report of the Potomac Electric Power Company for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $4,886,974, comparing with a net of $4.446.306 in 1936.

Clifford E. Paige, president of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, told shareholders yesterday afternoon at their annual meeting that he could not predict what action would be taken by the company regarding dividends.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March Duplicating his sub-par performance of the opening round, Johnny Revolta shot another 69 today for a total of 138 to lead the field at the half-way mark of the $3,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament.

The Rev. John Baumeister, president of the North Classis of Long Island of the Reformed Church in America, died of a heart attack earl. yesterday morning in his home, 149-11 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing Queens, at the age of 75.

" National Coordinator." who would strive to bring about voluntary cooperation among industrial groups in the United States, was proposed tonight by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd as a possible means of alleviating the nation's economic difficulties.
The hotel strike ended today and the tourist exodus halted.' Hotel workers, jubilant over acceptance of their terms, credit King Gustaf of Sweden with having aided their victory.

Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, advocated yesterday immediate retrenchment by the city administration in a statement explaining that the new tax rate meant a per-capita cost of city government amounting to $91.07 this year.

Duke Power Company--For 1937: Net income after expenses and charges, $4,660,474, equal, after preferred dividend charges, to $4.59 a common share, and comparing with a net of $4,860,591, or $4.79 a common share, in 1936.

Turpentine firm, 25c: sales, 16 barrels: receipts, 65 barrels; shipments, 30 barrels; stock, 24,666 barrels. Resin firm; sales 216: receipts 375; shipments 186: stock 7U,639. Quote: B. D. $3.50; E, $3.75: F. $4.15: G. $4.25: H, $4.35: I. $4.45: K, S4.50: M, $4.60; N, $4.70; WG, $6.20; WW, X, $6.50.

Ogden Phipps, holder of the United States court tennis title, and William Rand, with whom he won the national doubles crown last year, have advanced to the semifinals of doubles championship without having raised a racquet.

Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Frederick Elmes of 1,067 Fifth Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy Elmes, to Thomas Hastings Cooke, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Paul Cooke of Honolulu.

After it had seemed certain for three hours that Premier Camille Chautemps's majority would be split and his government would resign, the Cabinet at 3 o'clock this morning obtained a unanimous vote in the Chamber of Deputies that will enable it to get the arbitration and conciliation provisions of the labor charter through the Senate later in the day. The vote, however, has no political significance whatever.
Wool goods demand this week was spotty, sales being confined mostly to goods for near-by delivery, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service declared yesterday in its weekly review.

The city's public buildings, numbering more than seventy and representing an investment of more than $100,000,000 and a yearly outlay of $2,000,000 for maintenance, will be placed under the supervision of an experienced building management engineer, Major Gen.

Glenn Cunningham's world record mile in 4:04.4, run at Hanover, N. H., last night, marked the eighth time the great Kansan bettered 4:10 for the distance and the eighteenth time in track and field history that 4:10 time had been bettered.

Mgr. William A. Griffin, director of missionary activities in the Archdiocese of Newark, today was named auxiliary to the Archbishop of Newark. Mgr. Griffin succeeds Bishotp Thomas H. McLaughlin, recently made Bishop of the new Paterson Diocese.

Nine yachts already have been entered for this year's Bermuda race, which will start from Newport on June 20. That was made known by Herbert L. Stone, chairman of the race committee, at the dinner of the Cruising Club last night in the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.

F. J. Podesta of the Columbia University Club scored an upset in the national Class B squash tennis championship at the Columbia University Club courts last night by defeating the top-seeded player, O. D. Noble of the Crescent A. C. Podestra won by 15-10, 15-12, to gain the semi-final round.
Commerce Department figures indicated today that a huge reservoir of business profits has helped stabilize the nation's purchasing power in recent months despite increased unemployment.

A delegation of thirty-five tenants, who said. they represented the CityWide Tenants League and all the 476 families in Academy Houses at Lacombe and Rosedale Avenues, the Bronx, protested to the State Housing Board at the State Office Building yesterday against what they described as a?? unwarranted increase in rents.

After long debate, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors voted 28 to 9 this afternoon to give the Bronx River Parkway to New York State conditionally. Opposition votes were cast .by the Ossining and Scarsdale supervisors and by some representing Yonkers and New Rochelle.
Seventy-five representatives of every branch of the baking industry in the city agreed yesterday to support a proposed local law for standardization of the weight of bread sold at retail.

After a delay by the Foreign Office in fixing the date, which some feared might produce a diplomatic incident, Jaroslav Novak presented his credentials to day as envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary of Czechoslovakia.
War Admiral looms as the shortest priced favorite of the Florida season for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup, according to predictions made by price makers and officials at Hialeah today.
Hard hitting by C. L. Badcock and Don Bradman featured the opening day's play between a representative Tasmanian eleven and the Australian cricket team which will tour England this Summer.
Miss Elizabeth Leeds Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everett H. Brown, has chosen May 14 as the date for her marriage to Robert J. Carson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carson of Germantown.

Entries from six colleges, with the possibility of a seventh team, from the West, being added, and the award of the year's indoor championship to New York were announced last night by the tournament committee of the Intercollegiate Polo Association.

The administration's billion-dollar naval construction bill, the second largest naval authorization bill in the history of the United States, was approved today by the House Naval Affairs Committee by a vote of 20 to 3.

Aerial searchers joined ground parties late today in a comprehensive effort to find the missing skyliner which presumably crashed in the. mountains northeast of here Tuesday night with nine persons aboard.
Rallying on the incoming journey after the match had been squared four times up to the half-way mark, Fred Hannon of Wollaston, Mass., winner of the qualifying medal, eliminated Hugh L. Willoughby 3d

A luncheon was given at the Mayflower Hotel today by Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State in charge of trade agreement negotiations, to the British delegation which has come here to negotiate a reciprocal trade agreement with the United States.

The principle of a managed currency might be welcomed by American bankers as a solution for many economic ills except for their fear of "unintelligent experimentation" by the Federal Government in such a case, according to Edward K. Woodworth, president of the New Hampshire Savings Banks Association.

Twenty Spanish ships which, with skeleton crews, have been lying in Bristol Channel ports more than six months, will be taken over soon by the Barcelona Government as a result of a legal decision by the Housen

Demand for fresh pork cuts was most active for the week Demand for other classes was only fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were stronger, lamb higher, other classes mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated some beef cuts to be higher and others lower. Kosher veal opened strong to higher and lamb sharply higher, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Share prices moved indecisively yesterday until the final hour, when increased selling pressure led to a slightly lower closing. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was larger than on Thursday and on Wednesday but amounted to only 488,000 shares.

Investment deals formed the bulk of the trading in Bronx apartment properties yesterday. Among the houses figuring in the deals was the six-story building at 1,104-6 Morris Avenue, corner of 166th Street, which was acquired by an investing client of Morris A. Crausman from Davar Holdings, Inc.

The outline of a plan for the city's purchase of the rapid transit properties and rights of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company for a total price of $170,213,508, payable in 50-year bonds of the city bearing 3 per cent interest, was made public yesterday by Chester W. Cuthell, associate special counsel for the Transit Commission.

On the fifth anniversary of his inauguration, President Roosevelt declared that "the old ship of state is still on the same course." His rededication of his Administration to the objectives of its outset-the "more abundant life"came after his return from St. John's Episcopal Church, where he attended services to ask Divine guidance on the beginning of his sixth year as head of the nation.

The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America announced yesterday that an agreement ending the sixmonth strike against Spotless, Inc., chain of sixty cleaning and dyeing stores in Manhattan and the Bronx, had been negotiated by its affiliated Cleaners and Dyers Union, Local 239.

Separate sentences to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing in the week beginning April 11 were imposed by General Sessions Judge Nott yesterday on Andrew Lunse, 23 years old, of 433 West Twentyfourth Street, and Richard Delaney, 25, of 422 West Twenty-seventh Street.

Amid the horror and desolation of the flood, as the waters of the Santa Ana, the San Gabriel and the Los Angeles Rivers poured destructively to the sea, Mayor Frank L. Shaw of Los Angeles stepped to the microphone to tell the world that "we have not suffered a major disaster" and that "the sun is shining over Southern California today."

The shortage of exchange in Uruguay is retarding imports from all countries, but particularly from the United States, said a consular report from Montevideo made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Jose Morales, Cuban Ambassador to France, Richard Sherman, Elizabeth Davis. Walton Lynch, Mrs. L. Manry Fuller, in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc. broker. Dr. Paul Schwarzkopf, in 136 E 64th St: Jack Aron, in 17 E 89th St; Horace H. Lord, in 36 E 40th St; Brown, Wheelock. Harris, Stevens, Inc. broker.

General Gen Sugiyama, the War Minister, appeared yesterday before the committee studying the National Mobilization Bill and apologized for the action of Lieut. Col. Masaki Sato, who had told members of the committee to "shut up" when they heckled him while he was speaking on the bill as a War Office expert.

Joseph Conlon, chief clerk of the Mayor's office and a star athlete of the Nineties, started yesterday on the one-year extension granted. to him last Thursday by the Board of Estimate as he neared the age of 70.

Lt. Col Bowyer B. Browne, Corps of Engineers, is authorized to make, not to exceed, one trip per month during March, April and May from Governors Island, N. Y., to Wilmington, Del., on temporary duty in connection with Organized Reserves activities and upon completion of this temporary duty to return to his proper station, Governors Island, N. Y.

With the holiday season over and Lent in progress, a number of Broadway's weaker children are departing the local scene after the evening's display. Most popular of them is "Father Malachy's Miracle," a success with 125 performances to its credit, and a tour to the Middle West and elsewhere in the book of its immediate future.

Registration by the United Corporation under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, in the event that the United States Supreme Court hands down a decision favorable to the government in its case against the Electric Bond and Share Company,

General John J. Pershing has so definitely held the ground he has gained in the past few days and progressed so rapidly in the past twenty-four hours that Dr. Roland Davison said tonight that he was "anticipating recovery."

Church architecture. "must shed the trappings of a mistaken and sentimental adherence to the past" if it is to become a truly vital force, Maurice Lavanoux, secretary of the Liturgical Arts Society, yesterday told a meeting-of the North American Conference on Church Architecture at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Close to 100 ministers and architects were present.

" If we are to be faced by the necessity of defending ourselves, Czechoslovakia will defend, defend, defend herself!" declared Premier Milan Hodza today to the frantically applauding members of the Chamber of Deputies. This thrice-repeated "defend" was the high point of his exposition of this country's foreign policy.
Henry Henry Grutzius of Chicago became the target today in the American Bowling Congress tournament singles competition by rolling 632 for first place.

The offices of the State Council of Parks in the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, were ransacked and robbed of a small sum in stamps and cash on Feb. 15, it became known yesterday. Park Commissioner Robert Moses confirmed the story of the robbery.
Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo, former New York State champion, bowed to Mrs. John Rogers of Toronto, women's Canadian champion, in the semi-finals of the Bermuda women's golf championship today.

President Roosevelt, it is understood, has prepared an Executive order for formally taking over in the name of the United States the islands of Canton and Enderbury of the Phoenix group in the Central Pacific.

Benjamin Leslie Behr, Chicago sportsman, well known in Maryland, New York and Virginia hunt club circles, died this morning of a kidney disease at Johns Hopkins Hospital. With him at his death were his wife, their three children, Benjamin L. Behr Jr., John L. Behr and Mrs. Edwin Stanley, and his brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. T. G. Barstow of St. Louis.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,209,000 bales, against 1,192,000 a week ago; 1,192,000 two weeks ago, 1,184,000 three weeks ago and 969,000 a year ago; of which American, 781,000 bales, against 787,000 a week ago, 794,000 two weeks ago, 787,000 three weeks ago and 415,000 a year ago.

Three men were killed and seventeen injured, burned or felled by ammonia fumes in an explosion and fire that wrecked the boiler house of the Horton Pilsener Brewing Company on West 128th Street between Amsterdam and Convent Avenues at 1:20 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
Eleven planes scanned hundreds of miles of jagged, snow-blanketed terrain today in the search for the Transcontinental and Western skyliner lost with nine aboard in Tuesday night's storm.

Cotton-mill activity eased last' week. Daily average -operations, however, increased more than seasonally, and the adjusted index moved upward to 89.2 from 88.7, the revised figure for the previous week. It stood at 134.5 for the week ended Feb. 27, 1937.

Harvard students and their debutante guests donned old clothes, made up their faces and put on red wigs tonight for the annual costume party and dance of the Hasty Pudding Club, the last of the Winter festivities.
The House Merchant Marine Committee today reported unanimously a bill amending the Merchant Marine Act of 1936, but shorn of controversial labor provisions asked by the Maritime Commission.

Net profit of the American Metal Company, Ltd., and subsidiaries 80 per cent or more owned, amounted to $4,345,186 last year. This figure was after depreciation, depletion, interest, Federal income and undistribute profits taxes, minority interest and other charges, according to the annual report for 1937 submitted yesterday by Otto Sussman, chairman, and Harold K. Hochschild, president.
Gusman Parker, 60, tossed his three small grandchildren to safety from a second-story window today but perished when fire destroyed his six-room frame home.

In his first annual report since being elected president of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, J. H. Nuelle disclosed yesterday that the company incurred a consolidated net loss of $306,510 in 1937, compared with a met income of $651,465, or 34 cents a share, in 1936.

George and Henry Steneck, brothers, and former Hoboken bankers, have pleaded guilty to an indictment charging them with evasion of Federal income taxes, Assistant United States Attorney William F. Smith disclosed here today.
Estate, $500. To Leona Victoria Boldus Clarke, friend, executrix, 254 Vanderbilt Ave., Brooklyn. FULLE, EILLIEN M. (Feb. 27). Estate, more than $10,000.

In the wee, small hours this morning Lefty Vernon Gomez pulled up at the Suwannee Hotel after a three-and-one-half-day trip from Los Angeles. At noon -the southpaw, who won twenty-one games for the Yankees in their pennant drive last year, was in uniform, a bright, new contract for $20,000 ahead.
Chandler Harper, Richmond professional, came from behind with two sub-par rounds today to tie Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., for first honors in the $3,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament.

How many millions the flood will cost Southern California could only be guessed tonight. Partial surveys by official and unofficial sources in the five most seriously affected counties put the public property loss-to highways, roads, bridges, sewers and drainage systems-at $15,000,000.

Charles Neider, editor of the City College Monthly, which was banned from the School of Business by Dean Justin H. Moore and criticized for containing anti-Catholic sentiment by Mgr. William A. McCann, submitted his resignation yesterday in a letter addressed to Professor Jarvis Keiley, faculty adviser.
Sheriff Maurice A. Fitzgerald of Queens, who took office Jan. 1, is entitled to serve a full three-year term, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. ruled today in a formal opinion.

The firm of H. O. Peat Co. will be formed in Kansas City, according to a proposal which will be considered by the New York Stock Exchange committee on quotations and commissions on March 17. It will also consider admission of Robert DeForest Boomer to Auchincloss, Parker Redpath and of William B. Shattuck to Sweetser Co.

Charles A. MacDonald, head of a South Bend, Ind., advertising agency, told the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today of selling advertising copy to various industrial communities to "promote harmony" between labor and industry. Newspapers and chambers of commerce obtained local sponsorship, he said, and in most cases the agency's fee was paid by newspapers in the communities where the ads were run.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES last week J. Charles Tracy of Chestnut Hill, Pa., wrote Marquette University out of the tournament being held by the New York Basketball Writers Association.

A contract was awarded by the War Deapartment today to the Switlik Parachute and Equipment Company of Trenton, N. J., for the purchase of parachutes and equipment at a cost of $159,828.50. The parachutes and accessories will be used as replace ments.

Provisional President Alberto Enriquez published a decree today forbidding access of foreign ships to Galapagos Island without legal permission. Fishing boats must obtain permits from consulates in Panama, San Francisco or San Diego.

George W. Bunce, who began as a messenger with the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company on Jan. 14, 1907, was appointed yesterday manager of the Forty-second Street Branch of the company at Fortysecond Street and Eighth Avenue. He had been assistant manager of the branch eight years.

Santa Anita's fabulous $100,000 handicap captured the fancy of the nation's turf following today, and a record-breaking crowd of more than 60,000 is expected to watch the fourth running of the classic tomorrow.

Application of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, New York, to maintain a branch office in London, England, has been filed with the State Banking Department, the department's weekly bulletin announced today.

President Roosevelt, on the fifth anniversary of his first inauguration, said his ideals were the same as in 1933, "the more abundant life," and asked the public again not to confuse. objectives and methods.

Fire caused damage estimated at $150,000 to the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, 85 Livingston Street, yesterday morning. About 450 men students who were in the building when the blaze was discovered at 9:30 o'clock left in safety with their instructors.

Because Chancellor Hitler of Germany anticipates the triumphal entry being prepared for him in Rome, it is understood here, he may be counted on to make no further move in this direction until after his visit to Italy in May.

Unless all signs and portents fail, Columbia will be crowned indoor champion of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. for the second successive year when the seventeenth annual title games on boards of America's oldest sports governing body are staged at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Lions were favored a year ago and triumphed with ease. They should win again.

The Atlantic Commission Company, 102 Warren Street, New York, is charged with violation of the brokerage clause of the RobinsonPatman act, in a complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission, the commission announced today.

The 1938 budget for Hudson County, calling for a total appropriation of $16,336,330, was adopted unanimously by the County Board of Freeholders at a meeting today in the court house here. No opposition to the budget was voiced at the public hearing called by Director William P. Heffron.

Seven of the twelve schools competing inthe third annual academy and preparatory school wrestling championships sponsored by Lehigh University will be represented in the finals to be waged tomorrow afternoon.

Attorney General Cummings said today following a conference with Mayor La Guardia that the Department of Justice would file suit against New York City for $3,000,000 within a few days. The controversy involves New York's financial responsibility to the Government for its "enticing" of Federal officials into vacating the site of the old postoffice building in favor of a new location.

Although 1937 witnessed a number of additional restrictive measures on international trade, notably in Japan, Germany, Italy, France and Mexico, these trends toward restriction were paralleled and more than offset by moves toward trade barrier liberalization, Eugene P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council, declared tonight in an address at a dinner meeting of the Buffalo Exporters Association the Hotel Statler.

Joseph, P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association and national vice president of the American Federation of Labor, replied yesterday to the threat of Harry Bridges, C. I. O.'s Pacific Coast leader, to invade Atlantic seaboard ports with a rival union of pier workers.

M. P. Bickley has been appointed traffic manager of United Air Lines in New York and the metropolitan area. He was formerly district traffic manager in Philadelphia. Robert K. Christenberry has been re-elected vice president and general manager of the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday by Fred ??. Muschenheim, president.

The Leonil Realty Company bought the three-story building, containing four apartments and four stores at 4,924 Thirteenth Avenue, corner of Fiftieth Street, Brooklyn, through Clark-Robinson Co., brokers, who placed with the Kings Highway Savings Bank a new first mortgage of $12,500 on the property.

Cloudbursts and electric storms that have been hitting the northern Chilean cities of Copiapo, Calama, Caldera and Vallenar as far as the Bolivian frontier for three days with unusual violence continue unabated.
The Cuban Government tonight made preparations for tomorrow's elections, at which the nation Will choose eightyone Representatives and one Senator.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Former Premier Paul van Zeeland, in his recent report on the possibility of obtaining a general reduction of obstacles to international trade, sets forth two facets of the proposition with admirable brevity and clearness: "As regards the principle of collaboration in order to reduce the obstacles to international economic relations, not a single discordant voice was heard. * * *
Foreign Minister Koki Hirota urged world naval reduction by the abolition of all capital warships today in a renewed bid for friendship with the United States.
Stiffening Chinese resistance in Shansi Province is indicated by reports to Hankow. The Japanese are said to have made little headway along the TatungPuchow Railway since the capture of Linfen.

A large loan exhibition of paintings and drawings by one of our most distinguished early American painters, Benjamin West, opened with a private view this evening at the Pennsylvania Museum. It contains sixty canvases, representative of all periods in the painter's career, among them the famous "Death of General Wolfe" and "Penn's Treaty With the Indians";

The Rev. Arthur S. Hart, S. J., for twenty-one years assistant rector of old St. Joseph's Catholic Church, Fourth Street and Willings Alley, died today at St. Agnes Hospital of a heart ailment. His age was 68. Father Hart, a spiritual director of the Converts League, was credited with the conversion of more than 1,600 persons to the Cathollo Church.

The Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation decided yesterday that the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria was unfit to carry passengers and forced the company an hour before sailing time to withdraw 319 passengers and send the vessel out empty.

Acting Controller Richard-N. Elliott sent to Congress today a bulky report on alleged illegal government expenditures which captured the immediate attention of Senators debating the future of his office.

The Rev. Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, director of the National Conference of Jews and Christians, with headquarters at 300 Fourth Avenue, ao companies by a rabbi and a Roman Catholic priest, will spend two weeks speaking on "The Future for Intergroup Relations in America" at the ten Massachusetts State teachers' colleges.

Senator Truman of Missouri, a member of a committee investigating railroad finance, said today that a financial overhauling was the only effective cure for the nation's "very sick rail transportation system."

Dr. Charles Alexander Clinton, a member of an old New York family and a-physician in this city for many years, died suddenly yesterday at his office, 205 East Fortysecond Street, at the age of 73. Born here, Dr. Clinton was a great-great-grandson of Brig. Gen. Joseph Clinton of the Continental Army, who was the father of De Witt Clinton.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry DeWitt Smith of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Cass Smith, to Alfred F. Sanford 2d. Miss Smith attended the Hartridge School, was graduated from the Masters School and is a provisional member of the Plainfield Junior League. She is a granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Clinton Burke.

An intermediary, bearing $30,000 demanded as the ransom of 12-yearold Peter D. Levine in a note from his kidnappers, was unable to establish contact with them at a rendezvous somewhere in New York City, it became known in New Rochelle yesterday.

Flying into Los Angeles from Phoenix today, one saw the evidence of the devastating nature of Southern California's flood spread out below. Washed out bridges, dangling railroad trestles, toppled telephone poles and marooned communities were to be seen everywhere.

At a press conference in New York following his arrival from Europe last week, Dr. Thomas Mann revealed that he had temporarily abandoned work on his Joseph series, the third part of which, "Joseph in Egypt," has just been published by Knopf. Dr.

Samuel Bernstein has leased for fifteen years the five-story building at 127-9 Newark Avenue, Jersey City, from the Go-Lit Realty Company, through Jules E. Merson. When alterations now under way are completed the lessee will operate the building as Lloyds Department Store.

Bronx River Ave, 1,359, dwelling, 25x129.6 x irreg; Home Owners Loan Corp against Belgrado Realty, Inc.; due, $13,973; to plaintiff for $500. By JAMES R. MURPHY Theriot Ave, 1,212, dwelling, 50x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against David Rothkopf. due $11,790, taxes, etc, $1,279; to plaintiff for $500.

Colonel Michael Joseph Reagan, a veteran of the Spanish American War and since 1906 an industrial mediator of the New York State Department of Labor, died yesterday at the Veterans Hospital, the Bronx, after an illness of three weeks. Colonel Reagan, who lived at 253 South Fulton Street, Mount Vernon, was 71 years old.
United States marines were reported by the police today to have halted a force of seventy-five Japanese soldiers at the Bubbling Well Road boundary of the American defense sector.

Paul Scheffer, accused in the testimony of Mikhail A. Chernoff in the Soviet treason trial of carrying on espionage activities as Moscow correspondent of the Berliner Tageblatt, denied yesterday that he had ever met or communicated with the former Soviet Commissar of Agriculture, now one of the twentyone accused.

Division St, 129, 25x62.6; Harry Bijur to Ida Weissglass, 3,101 Avenue I, Brooklyn; consideration $1,000, foreclosing tax lien. Mary Rudner quit claims. Division St, 127-1271/2, 25x62.5; also 129 Division St, 25x62.6; Ida Weissglass to Irps Realty Corp, 127 Division St ($2.50). Roosevelt St, 18-20, 34.91/2x133.10; trustees will of James Poggi and others to North River Savings Bank, mortgagee ($16.50).

Two of twelve high-speed tankers which the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey is building under an agreement with the United States Maritime Commission to meet the requirements of the navy have been allocated to the Keystone Tankship Corporation of Philadelphia, the commission said today.

With four score known dead, thousands homeless and communication with the rest of the world limited and uncertain, Los Angeles, glittering Hollywood and scores of other communities in Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, San Bernardino and Ventura Counties today surveyed the ruin left by the worst flood in Southern California's history and began to rebuild as soon as the waters receded.
Senator Vandenberg opened- a barrage of Republican criticism of the Administration Reorganization Bill today by calling it "a symbol" of "the New Deal's march toward a totalitarian State."

Competition from both the Federal Government and from thrift departments of commercial banks is the most serious problem facing the nation's savings banks today, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University, declared yesterday at the concluding session of the two-day annual Spring Savings Conference of the American Bankers Association in the Hotel Roosevelt.

About 3,400 children, representing public, private and parochial schools from New York City and from seventeen New Jersey - communities, stormed the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon to attend-Rossini's "The Barber of Seville," given under the auspices of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

Vocational education can do much to alleviate the problem of unemployment by helping unemployed persons adjust themselves to new jobs which are available, Dr. J. C. Wright, Assistant United States Commissioner of Education, told members of local education boards of the metropolitan area yesterday.

Mrs. Mary Morgan Mosher, who for more than twenty-four years was connected with Teachers College of Columbia University, died Wednesday in St. Luke's Hospital after a short illness. Funeral services were held last night. Until she was taken ill two weeks ago, Mrs. Mosher was employed by Teachers College to play the piano for students at Horace Mann School during their dance exercises.
Three more district election board members of Hudson County were arrested here today on misdemeanor charges for refusing to testify before the Young Assembly Committee.

1:30-2:00 P. M.-National Republican Club Discussion: Topic, "shall Government Aid Low-Rent Housing and Slum Clearance by Grants and Loans at Cost?"-WEAF. 1:55-5:00 P. M.-Metropolitan Opera: Verdi's "Rigoletto"-WJZ. 3:00-3:30 P. M.--"Dilemma of Modern Civilization," Dr. William E. Dodd, Former Ambassador to Germany-WEAF, WABC. 3:30-4:30 P. M.-National Indoor Tennis Championships at Seventh Regiment Armory-WABC (Again at 5:50 P. M.).

Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, announced yesterday, following a meeting of the board of directors, that the quarterly dividend on the common stock had been reduced to 30 cents a share. In the first quarter of last year, 40 cents a common share was paid.

Robert P. Scripps inherited a great enterprise and with the assistance of Mr. Roy Howard notably enlarged and improved it. He died all too early, but he had developed early. College bred, he got a better education in the school of experience.

The undefeated Harvard varsity swimming team took the measure of Navy in the Harvard pool tonight by a score of 55 to 20. By its victory, Harvard went into a tie with Princeton for the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate League swimming competition.

When the closing gong on the floor of the Chicago Curb Exchange sounds at 2 P. M., March 14, trading will cease permanently. The Curb, which came into existence nearly ten years ago at the height of the stock boom, will end operations because of lack of business.

Arturo Toscanini's performance of the Verdi "Requiem," with the chorus of the Schola Cantorum and a quartet of excellent singers and one great one, took place last night in Carnegie Hall. Superlatives are not only dangerous but wearisome.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

Full details of a plot to capture the Kremlin and headquarters building of the NKVD (formerly the Ogpu) and kill Joseph Stalin and other Soviet leaders in a military coup d'etat, to have been led by the late Marshal Mikhail N. Tukhachevsky, were told tonight at the treason trial here.

Assuming that the cordial reception given to the new constitution for the New York Stock Exchange means certain passage of that instrument, the nominating committee of the Exchange is acting under it already. Yesterday it invited the membership to attend three of its meetings on March 14, 17 and 21, to suggest nominees for chairman of the board, fifteen member governors, six non-member governors, six out-of-town governors and a trustee of the gratuity fund.

The board of stewards of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association approved license applications for seven amateur riders, eight jockeys -and nine trainers, it was announced yesterday by Frank J. Bryan, secretary of the association.

Mrs. Dorothea M. Knight, a former member of the Democratic County Committee and an election district captain in Manhattan since women first received suffrage, died on Thursday at Morrisania Hospital after a short illness at the age of 63. Mrs. Knight, the wife of Charles A. Knight, lived at 615 Fort Washington Avenue.

Albania's three touring princesses met President Roosevelt today when they called at the White House to see Mrs. Roosevelt. The President had tea in the green room with the three sisters of King Zog, Myzejen, Ruhie and Maxhide, and the Albanian Minister, Faik Konitza. All talked French.

A group of small business men met yesterday at a luncheon in the Engineers Club and agreed that the "committee of twelve" elected at their recent Washington conference should act quickly to form a national body and forestall many "rackets" now Being organized in the name of "small business."

Robert H. Jackson was confirmed as Solicitor General today by the vote of 62 to 4 just after three Senators had discussed him as a possible President of the United States. His only opponents in the vote were Senators McNary, Hale and Austin, Republicans, and King, Democrat.

The world gold production in January, excluding Russia, amounted to 2,394,000 fine ounces, compared with 2,534,000 in December and 2,405,000 in January, 1937, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. Output in the United States was 361,000 ounces, against 398,000 in December and 328,000 in January, last year.
Joseph P. Kennedy, the United States Ambassador, went for a ride today on a rented horse, and went to 10 Downing Street to call on Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain.

ColtWorthington Oil Works, Inc., of Garden City, L. I., has stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to stop making certain representations concerning its product, Pyion, a lubricating oil containing a collodial graphite, of which the Federal Trade Commission complained, the commission announced today.

The Storm Troops' official organ, the S.A. Mann, today proclaims the doctrine that it is the duty of all National Socialists to hate everything anywhere that cannot be made National Socialist. A frontpage editorial says:

They have a unique way of stocking their remote lakes up in Quebec--they drop the fish from airplanes at a height of from 100 to 1,000 feet. This certainly sounds like a fish story, but according to the "Office du Tourisme" of the province it is nothing but the truth.

A jury in Federal Court, which late Thursday night convicted an attorney and an insurance broker of mail fraud and conspiracy growing out of the filing of claims for simulated disability, brought in a verdict of guilty yesterday against two physicians who were defendants in the same trial.

The marketing of $43,000,000 of 9 New York City 3 per cent serial bonds on Tuesday lifted the total of new bond offerings this week to $49,982,000, the largest volume for any week in just a month, or since the period ended Feb. 4, when bond financing amounted to $70,257,262.

Directors of Mead, Johnson Co. yesterday declared an extra dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock in addition to the regular quarterly distribution of the same amount. Last year the company paid 75 cents extra in each of the first three quarters and $1.75 extra in the final quarter, together with the regular quarterly payments.

Navy estimates totaling [Pound]123,707,000 for the British fiscal year beginning April 1, which is [Pound]18,642,000 greater than the estimated expenditure for the current fiscal year, were submitted to Parliament today.

Kirk A. Landon, in 10 Jefferson Rd, Scarsdale, Westchester; Walter H. Acher, in 9 Hamilton Rd; Louise 0. Meuer, Inc, broker. William Simpson, through Mildred Sanford, .n 45 Stuyvesant Ave, Larchmont; R. T. Waid, through Genevieve Carroll, in 97 Murray Ave: from Home Owners Loan Corp, Thomas B. Sutton Corp, broker.

Mrs. William Marston Seabury of 47 East Sixty-first Street has returned to New York after a threemonth visit in Japan with her sonin-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Savage Crocker. Mr. Crocker is second secretary of the United States Embassy at Tokyo.

The silk manufacturers, retailers and rayon manufacturers present today at the Federal Trade Commission's trade practice conference for the silk industry took somewhat different positions on important elements of proposed trade practice rules, leaving the commission the problem of drafting a satisfactory set of requirements.

Check exchanges at 194 clearing houses of the country in February totaled $19,680,017,707, a decline of 19 per cent from the preceding month, and 24.5 per cent under that in February, 1937. It was the ?? allest monthly total since November, 1934.
A cry of alarm about the rapid decrease in German exports was voiced today by the Deutsche Volkswirt, which is regarded as the mouthpiece of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, President of the Reichsbank.

Repeal of the. long and short haul clause of the Interstate Commerce Act was urged today before a Senate committee on the. ground that it would effect economies. R. G. Hawkinson, assistant to the traffic manager of the Chicago Great Western Railroad,

Funeral services for Joseph J. Baker, Brooklyn lawyer, who died Wednesday, were held yesterday morning in the Union Temple, 17 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn. More than 1,500 persons attended. Burial was in the Mount Hope Cemetery, Cypress Hills, Queens.

Great Britain's jobless are to receive increased doles amounting to nearly [Pound]2,000,000 annually as a result of the prosperous condition of the unemployment insurance fund, to which workers and employers make weekly contributions.

The Canadian Supreme Court by a unanimous decision today knocked the foundations from under the Social Credit dream castle which Premier William C. Aberhart has been trying for two years to erect in the Prairie Province of Alberta.

Police headquarters here received a reply yesterday to a "wanted" circular that was issued more than fifteen years ago, in September, 1922. The reply came from L. B. Maddox, Chief of Police at Beaumont, Texas.
The Treasury has modified the instructions recently issued to Internal Revenue Collectors requiring "net worth" statements from each taxpayer with an annual net income of $100,000 or more.

The Savage School of Physical Education girls' basketball team gained its eleventh victory in twelve starts this season by vanquishing the New York University sextet, 24--17, at the Evangeline Gymnasium yesterday.

The Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute basketball team registered a 48-to-40 triumph over Pratt Institute last night as both teams completed their schedules in the Pratt gymnasium, Brooklyn. Hank Johnson with 16 points led the attack for the winners, who were ahead at the intermission, 24-21.
Ominous red placards in Berlin today announced that Ewald Funk, 32 years old, of Wuppertal-Elberfeld, in the Ruhr, was guillotined this morning because of preparations for high treason.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today. dated March 2: COMMANDERS Beary, D. B., the Colorado, to command the Richmond, May 5. Maples, H. L., the Melville, to Naval Acadedy, June 18.

This little New England village bustled with activity today as competitors and spectators from all parts of the country began to pour in for the national open and amateur downhill and slalom skiing championships to be contested tomorrow and Sunday.

Member trading in round lots for their own accounts on the New York Stock Exchange represented 21.22 per cent of total volume in the week ended on Feb. 5, compared with 19.54 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Harlem River Terrace (11-3233), e s, 93 ft s of Fordham Rd, 100x100; Adele Realty Corp to Northpel Realty Corp, 391 E 149th St. Tiemann Ave (16-4773), e s, 100 ft n of Adee Ave, 75x95; Ren-Viv Realty Corp to Dorothy Monheit, 3,623 Mermaid Ave, Brooklyn. Bronx River Ave (15-3861), w s, 700 it n of 172d St, 25x125; Yetta Y. Schenker, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.
A sentence of twenty years to life imprisonment as a fourth offender was imposed by Judge Nott in General Sessions yesterday on Michael Roche, 41 years old, formerly of 162 West Sixty-first Street.

The marriage of Miss Pamela Crawford, daughter of Professor Jack R. Crawford of Yale University and Mrs. Crawford, to Richard Vincent Holahan of Darien, took place this afternoon in the Church of Our Lady of Pompeii at Foxon Park, New Haven. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Father T. Lawrason Riggs, chaplain of the Catholic students of Yale.

George K. McKenzie has been elected secretary of the Flintkote Company. F. H. Neher, former secretary and vice president, remains as vice president and has been elected a director of the company. It was stated incorrectly yesterday that Mr. Neher had been elected secretary.

The American Federation of Labor favors prompt enactment of the Burchill bill, now pending in Albany, providing for collective bargaining rights for the 5,400 employes of the city's Independent Subway System, according to messages sent to legislative leaders yesterday by William Collins, the federation's New York representative.

The stock markets here displayed today a better tendency but business remained small owing to the end of the account. Gilt-edge issues rallied but foreign loans were idle. Among the transatlantic stocks United States Steel and International Nickel improved.

DICTATORS may be a little rough at times, but once you get to know them as well as G. Ward Price does you realize what fine fellows they really are. That is, you do if you are like Mr. Price. To find out what Mr. Price is like you have only to read his book.*

Steps toward greater uniformity and stiffening of the motor vehicle laws were taken yesterday by representatives of eight Eastern States at an all-day meeting at the Hotel Biltmore of the third Regional Highway Safety Conference.

Thomas E. Fitzsimmons, Newark attorney and until recently an official of the South Orange Trust Company of South Orange, and Paul V. Bailey, another former official of the bank, were arrested today on charges of embezzling a total of $102,100 from the institution.

While the California flood and windstorm were responsible for a curtailment of advertising schedules in the affected areas, they also resulted in bringing out new campaigns, designed to capitalize on the resulting destruction. Four clients of the Gerth-Knollin Advertising Agency, San Francisco, timed special campaigns to appear immediately after the disaster.

Arturo Toscanini's definite refusal to go to Salzburg, though not unexpected, has produced a painful impression. The conductor's impulsiveness and his inflexibility in matters of principle are fully known and respected among his Austrian worshipers.

Following a moderate increase In inquiry, several tanners have advanced their lists on side upper leathers by 1/2 to 1 cent a foot, it was reported yesterday, and, although several others still were accepting business at last week's prices, the action was regarded as significant because it was the first upturn in standard shoe leathers in several months.

On Wednesday, March- 9, a hearing will be held at Albany before the Assembly Banking Committee on the Mortgage Bank Bill. The measure has already passed the Senate by a vote of 33 to 4. A similar measure passed the Senate last year by a vote of 34 to 7, only to meet defeat in the Assembly.

H. C. Hatch of Toronto will resume the presidency of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and will retain the office of chairman of the board of directors, the company announced today. Howard R. Walton of Detroit was appointed general manager and Ward Wright of Toronto was elected a director.

With Burgess Whitehead not yet out of a hospital, following his recent appendicitis operation, and Dick Bartell still of a mind to carry on his salary war, Colonel Bill Terry found himself today confronted with the necessity of opening the Giants' exhibition schedule tomorrow with quite a makeshift infield.

Aaron I. Raisman, engineer in charge of the division of design of the Board of Transportation, will retire on pension on April 1, after 38 years of service in the field of subway design the board announced yesterday. Mr. Raisman has headed the board's division since it was established in 1924.
Mr. Roosevelt's first article in Liberty is supposed to take 22 minutes 5 seconds in the reading.

William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France, returned on the liner Washington yesterday for a vacation and a visit with his daughter, Anne, who is attending school in Virginia. He said he planned to go to Philadelphia last night and to Washington in a few days. Later he and his daughter will go to Florida for the Easter holidays.

George Foster Peabody, retired banker, who was widely known for his philanthropies, educational and religious work, died of a heart ailment today at his Winter home, Pine Glade. He was 85 years old. He suffered a severe case of influenza in January, 1937.

The New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company, controlled by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, applied yesterday to the Public Service Commission for authority to issue $10,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds maturing in 1968.

Serious, careful playing of a noble and unusual program gave the concert of the Durieux Chamber Music Ensemble at Town Hall last night more than ordinary interest. The group, consisting of nine young wonen performers of stringed instruments, was conducted by Willem Durieux, a Dutch 'cellist long resident in this city, who founded the ensemble seven years ago.

Retired fireman William H. McGrath, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 146, residing at 1,102 Lorimer St., Brooklyn, died March 3. Funeral will take place from his late residence, at 11:30 A. M., Saturday, March 5. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.

Upsetting pre-meet predictions, Stuyvesant High School, a "dark horse" entrant, won the team championship at the thirty-fifth annual Public Schools Athletic League senior high track and field games at the 245th Coast Defense Regimert Armory-the old Thirteenthin Brooklyn last night.

In view of the Nazis' threatening demeanor in Upper Austria, of which Linz is the capital, Dr. Arthur Seyss-Inquart, the Interior Minister, will come here tomorrow to talk to Nazi leaders from all parts of Austria.

The principal operating subsidiaries in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company System had a net gain of 30,000 telephones in service in February, according to the company. The gain for these units, comprising the Bell System, totaled 92,000 instruments in February, 1937.

A $150,000 fire which threatened this historic army post today destroyed one company's barracks and damaged another. Thirteensoldiers and volunteer firemen were treated at the post hospital for frost-bite, collapse from smoke, burns or injuries from falling debris.

Metropolitan Conference of New York Adult Education Council and American Association for Adult Education, Hotel Astor, 10 A. M. Luncheon 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Dr. Joseph D. McGoldrick, Dr. John H. Finley, Jennie Flexner, Dr. Gustav F. Beck, Mrs. Garet Smith and Remo Bufano.

A town house in an area of fashionable homes on the East Side passed to new hands yesterday with the sale by the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of the City of New York of the five-story limestone front dwelling at 54 East Sixty-eighth Street.

An unfortunate misstep that interrupted his procession through the opening set checked Wayne Sabin in his first bid for the national indoor tennis championship yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixtysixth Street.

Over the objection of Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, Democratic member of the Board of Education, Joseph Jablonower of the Ethical Culture Schools was appointed an examiner in the New York City school system at a special meeting of the board yesterday afternoon.

United Drug, Inc. and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1937 a net profit of $1,312,314 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes, $128,506 surtax on undistribute income, loss on guaranteed leases and other charges.

Emile Allais of France and Fraeulein Cristel Cranz of Germany, world champion man and woman skiers, will defend their titles here tomorrow in the downhill event and on Sunday in the slalom against rivals from fourteen countries, including the United States and Canada.

A sharp curtailment of activity in the municipal bond market is indicated for next week when a total of only $6,669,392 of new State and municipal bonds is scheduled for sale. They will be represented by fiftythree municipalities.

Operations last year of the Wheeling Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries resulted in a net profit of $4,238,488 after deductions for depreciation, depletion, interest, Federal income taxes and $67,977 provision for surtax on undistributed income.

Two-family houses usually are looked upon as a product of intensive land development in major population centers, where even in the outskirts owners may consider it a wise move to provide space for a tenant family whose rent will help to pay off the mortgage.

Immediately after being delivered by two bank messengers, a $2,500 payrQll was snatched yesterday afternoon from a desk in the offices of the Julius Altschul Shoe Compan, 117 Grattan Street, Brooklyn, by three thugs.

Today's major events: "Walkuere," evening; "Rigoletto," afternoon, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; National Orchestral Association, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Rose Bampton, soprano, Town Hall, afternoon; Mary Bambery, pianist, Town Hall, evening, "Rigoletto," New York Hippodrome Opera Company, evening.

Police Lieutenant William Higgins, for thirty-two years a member of the Yonkers Police Department and in former years a detective, died this morning at his residence at the age of 56. He was born in Yonkers. He was at one time in the train service department of the New York Central Railroad. For years Mr.

John J. Hickey, world traveler, author and a former member of the New York police force, died yesterday morning in Bellevue Hospital after a long illness. A widower, 77 years old, he had lived at the Grand Union Hotel. Mr. Hiokey was born in Ireland, but he adopted New York as his home and the scene of his writings.

Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, yesterday denounced action by the Municipal Civil Service Commission taking jurisdiction over qualifying examinations for internes from the medical boards of city hospitals.

An urgent search was started in twenty British cities by radio and telegraph tonight for passengers who had debarked from the British liner Cathay at Marseilles, France; Gibraltar and Plymouth and who, it was learned later, had been in contact with a virulent case of smallpox.

In the present trial in Mosco it is charged that the writer of these lines became an agent of Germany as far back as in 1921, when he was a member of the Political Bureau and chief of the Red Army and when Germany was not yet Fascist. At this point we are entering the realm of psychopathology.

La Salle's basketball team tonight I came from behind to score a surprise 36-to-35 victory over Long Island University, one of the East's outstanding quintets. La Sale, which earlier in the season had scored a similar upset triumph over St. Joseph's, won the game in the last two minutes on Ed Krupa's sixth basket.

The scene of the intradirectorate row in the Tennessee Valley Authority shifted to the White House today when President Roosevelt authorized publication of a memorandum from the other two directors saying they could work no longer with Chairman Arthur E. Morgan and suggesting that he retire to private life.

El Salvador commemorated today with religious and civil ceremonies the centenary of the death of the Salvadorean priest, Jose Simeon Canas, who freed the slaves in Central America and was a leader in the cause of the independence of the Isthmus.

A banking group composed of the First Boston Corporation, the Haris Trust and Savings Bank and Newton, Abbe Co. has obtained he award of a new issue of $729,000 of high school bonds of Malden, Mass., paying 101.909 for 2 1/4s. The ponds, dated Feb. 1, 1938, will mature serially from Feb. 1, 1939, to 958.

Gross assets, $16,101; net, $5,297. To wife, Martha Andersen, dower right; sons, J. Adrian and Raymond Andersen, and daughters, Anna S. Nielsen and Beatrice and Marylin J. Andersen, one-fifth of balance each. Chief assets, real estate.

Live poultry dealers must pay a license fee to the Department of Markets, in addition to the fee which they pay to the Department of Health, Magistrate Troy ruled in Flatbush court, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Joseph Clark Baldwin, chairman of the Council committee investigating the residence qualifications of Councilman Hugh Quinn, presented his report at an executive session of the committee in City Hall yesterday.

Elizabeth Reibel, 6 years old, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Valentine Reibel, was burned to death here today at 2 P. M. in the basement of her home when fire swept through the two-story frame house at Grand and Ray Avenues.
Monopoly control of prices over large areas of the American business economy was blamed today by two economists for the present business recession.

Violence broke out last night in the strike of employes of two New York taxicab companies called earlier in the day by the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. 0. affiliate. Three cabs were reported burned in various parts of the city and the seats of a fourth were slashed.

Playing in defense of the title she won here a year ago, Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., defeated Mrs. Charles Newbold of Wichita, Kan., in the semi-finals of the Florida East Coast championship on St. Augustine links today, 4 and 3.

The Commercial Bulletin will say to- rep morrow: "The wool market has been more or less in a state of suspense during the current week, waiting to see what happens with respect to the loan which has been sought by the wool growers from the Commodities Credit Corporation.

Overcoming a 13-point lead and staging a whirlwind drive in the last two minutes of play, the Dartmouth basketball team, paced by Bob MacLeod, defeated a tiring Tufts five, 49 to 46, before a. 2,500 crowd in. the Cousins Gymnasium tonight.

Citing three sections of the city's budget in which he said a saving or at least 156,250,000 nickels might be made, Lawrence B. Elliman, realty man, replied yesterday to Mayor La Guardia's offer to resign if any part of the budget under the Mayor's control could be found to contain an unnecessary expenditure of as much as five cents.

178th St, 156 E (11-2808), 156 East 178th Street Corp to Mutual Life Insurance Co, 34 Nassau St; due as per bond; $13,000. Alexander Ave, 307 (9-2315); Tenement Rehabilitation Corp to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; due on demand; interest as per bond; $21,000. Tinton Ave, 1,181 (10-2662); Louis J. Schneiderman to Franklin Savings Bank; installments, 4 to 41/2 per cent; $37,000.
Prime Minister J. B. M. Hertzog announced today that general elections would be held May 18. Parliament will be dissolved April 11 and nomination day was set for April 26. In the last election,

Albert Crawford, national 174pound A. A. U. champion, stepped up among heavier opposition and performed sensationally in the metropolitan senior A. A. U. wrestling championships last night at the New york Athletic Club.

Listed bond prices drifted to moderately lower levels yesterday in another dull and featureless session. Indications of a delay of perhaps several weeks in the I. C. C.'s decision on higher freight rates caused further impatient selling of railroad obligations,

The memorandum of Harcourt A. Morgan and David E. Lilienthal criticizing Chairman Arthur E. Morgan of the Tennessee Valley Authority, made public today at the instance of President Roosevelt, follows:

Colonel Sandford Sellers Sr., president of Wentworth Military Academy here for fifty-eight years, died today at the age of 83. Colonel Sellers became head of the school upon its founding in 1880 by Stephen G. Wentworth. It was the second military academy established west of the Mississippi River.

Gunnar Barlund battered the massive Buddy Baer to a knockout defeat in their scheduled ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night. Spotting the Californian more than forty pounds in weight and six inches in height, the lion-hearted Finn survived a first-round pummeling to beat his towering foe in seven rounds.

Charles C. Alexander Jr., a motorboat racing official, died today at the Long Branch Memorial Hospital of streptococcus infection. His age was 35 and his home was in Avon, N. J. He had been secretary of the Middle Atlantio Outboard Association, chairman of the regatta committee of the National Outboard Sweepstakes, most of which were held in the Shrewsbury River near Red Bank.

More comfortable shopping weather enabled retail distribution this week to advance 1 to 3 per cent over the preceding week, but the decline from the corresponding period last year, when Easter buying was starting, widened to 5 to 11 per cent, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The first step toward employment of 20,000 new WPA workers in this city was taken yesterday when the home relief division of the Department of Welfare sent 1,300 persons to the WPA offices at 70 Columbus Avenue for interviews.

Governor Lehman practically completed action on his tax program today by signing seven of the nine tax bills continuing for another year all emergency taxes. Revenue collected from these taxes will be used for support of the State's $386,364,000 budget for the year 1938-1939, which has already been approved.

Paced by Angelo (Hank) Luisetti, who set a new national four-year high-scoring record, Stanford won the Southern Division basketball championship of the Coast Conference- tonight, crushing the University of California, 63 to 42.

La Salle Military Academy of Oakdale, L. I., and La Salle Academy of New York were victorious as first-round play in Manhattan College's invitation interscholastic basketball tournament opened at the Jasper gymnasium last night. The Cadets vanquished De La Salle, 32 to 29, in overtime, while the Second Street five routed St. Augustine, 31 to 17.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt were the honor guests tonight of the members of the Cabinet, who entertained for them at dinner at the Mayflower Hotel. Vice President and Mrs. Garner, who always are invited and always attend these dinners, were present tonight.

Alonzo James, long a resident of this community and president of the Irvington Packing Company, died at 6:45 o'clock tonight at his home here of arteriosclerosis. His age was 77. A son of Alonzo James and Eliza George James, he was born Jan. 14, 1861, in near-by Whitestone and was educated in private schools.

The Turkish Government is purchasing $12,800,000 of locomotives and freight and passenger cars for the Turkish State Railways, according to a report from Istanbul made public today by the Department of Commerce.

A political, economic and cultural counter-offensive 'by democratic countries, cooperating together, against the totalitarian dictatorships of fascism, nazism and communism was urged yesterday in an address by Alexander Kerensky at a meeting of the League for Political Education in Town Hall.

The National Horse Show, held annually at Madison Square Garwill not start this year on the den, will not start this year on the day after Election Day, as has been the custom, but on Saturday, Nov. 5, it was announced yesterday by Whitney Stone, vice president and secretary of the association.

Factory hands and management have teamed up here to raise the sales of furniture, this city's principal product. Members of the local Upholsterers Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate, mapped an advertising campaign to be started Monday in an effort to stimulate consumption of the goods they manufacture.

Whether or not Glenn Cunningham's amazing 4:04.4 clocking for the mile will receive official recognition by the Amateur Athletic Union as a world indoor record depends upon the conditions under which the performance was made, Dan Ferris, national secretarytreasurer, said yesterday.
Shouting protests against the Moscow treason trials, eighty members of the Socialist Workers party picketed the consulate of the Soviet Union at 7 East Sixty-first Street yesterday.
Edwin H. Stewart, chairman of the board of Hahne Co., Newark, will succeed Joseph Pridday as vice president and treasurer of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation,

Warners today announced that Boris Karloff would appear in "The Witches Sabbath," the story' of a German robber baron and his satanic operations in the seventeenth century. The legend is being put in script form by Anthony Coldewey and Dr. Manley P. Hall.

BRIGHT college cheers will make the I. C. 4-A. indoor championships a stirring athletic festival this evening, as always. But, at the moment, putting on a track meet without Glenn Cunningham seems almost like producing Hamlet without the Melancholy Dane.

Miss Jean G. Moment, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. John J. Moment of Plainfield, has selected May 6 as the date for her marriage to Walter Spalding Douglas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Douglas, also of this place. The ceremony will be performed by her father in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church, of which he is pastor.

On police surgeon's certificate, to take effect 12 midnight, March 6. PATROLMAN-William Stranch, 111th Precinct, at $1,200 per annum. Appointed March 6, 1922. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-Michael J. Smith, from 42d Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A.

No one will accuse the La Guardia Administration of raising the tax rate just for the fun of watching the taxpayer squirm. A Mayor of infinitely less integrity than Mr. La Guardia would have hesitated to do that, for our taxpayers, who are chiefly owners of real estate, are, and have a right to be, organized and vocal.

Playing their first match in defense of their doubles title, which they have held for the past four years, Ogden Phipps and William Rand yesterday defeated Charles Devens and C. H. Stockton of Boston to advance into the final round of the annual national doubles court tennis championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

After a few days' ownership, Loomis J. Grossman has sold the six-story garden apartment building at 1,465 Midland Avenue, Fleetwood, Westchester, to the Froro Realty Corporation through Low Gross. The house contains 179 rooms, divided into forty-six suites.

Easier foreign cotton quotations and lower outside markets caused declines of 14 to 16 points in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Differences between New York and Liverpool were the narrowest and between New York and Bombay the widest of the season, bringing arbitrage selling in sufficient volume to close the list at the bottom.

A suggestion that business men-ought to tell Congress what they think is the best method of limiting monopolies and curbing abuses came today from Senator Austin of Vermont during hearings on the O'MahoneyBorah Federal Corporation Licensing Bill.

Because tomorrow is the first Sunday in Lent many pastors will begin a special series of sermons to continue through Easter. The discourses will stress devotional subjects and will include recommendations for special Lenten resolutions of a self-disciplinary nature. Everywhere prayers will be offered for the California flood sufferers.

Alexander Smallens, conductor; Noel Straus of the music staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and Lee Orean Smith, editor of Carl Fischer, Inc., are the judges for the American Composer's Award of $1,000 offered by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society for a work of symphonic length.

Miss Ruth Wilcox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Wilcox of Tenafly, was married this afternoon to James Lincoln Dawes, son of Mrs. Lewis D. Dawes of Marlboro, N. H., and Englewood, and the late Mr. Dawes, in the chapel of St. Paul's Episcopal l Church here. The Rev. James A. Mitchell, the rector, performed the ceremony.
Buddy Hassett visited the offices of the Dodgers yesterday and after a half-hour chat with Larry MacPhail, executive vice president of the Brooklyn club, signed his contract for the coming season.

The State rested its case yesterday afternoon against Mrs. Patricia Ryan, 21 years old, who is on trial in Bronx County Court for the murder of her husband, Patrolman Michael Ryan, on Oct. 31 in their home at 1,350 Purdy Street, the Bronx.

A drive for elimination from the revenue bill of the section providing for a 20 per cent surtax on the undistributed profits of closely held corporations was started on the House floor today by Representative McCormack, Democrat, of Massachusetts, member of the Ways and Means Committee and also on its subcommittee on taxation.

The marriage of Miss Kathryn Louise Quillin, daughter of Mrs. W. Edward Quillin and the late Mr. Quillin, to Joseph Theodore Clauss Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clauss of Forest Hills, took place yesterday morning at the home of the bride's mother, 15 Olive Place, Forest Hills.
West New York High School won the. Hudson -County Basketball Conference championship tonight by defeating Weehawken High, 37 to 35, before a crowd of 3,000 at the Dickinson High gymnasium.

Plans of the World's Fair Corporation for a publicity parade of 20,000 persons with floats from Washington Square to the fair grounds in Flushing on April 30 met difficulties yesterday when Robert Moses, as chairman of the Triborough Bridge Authority, refused to authorize use of the bridge or Grand Central Parkway for the purpose.

Following discovery of a shortage of $5,527 since April, 1934, in the accounts of the Richmond County Clerk's office, Walter Hurst, Deputy County Clerk and a veteran of thirty years' service in the office, and two other employes were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Charles Keutgen on charges of misappropriation of public funds and conspiracy to embezzle public funds.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 26 amounted to 511,930 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 23,860 cars, or 4.5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 180,463 cars, or 26.1 per cent,

The American Ice Company and subsidiaries reported a net profit of $339,216 in 1937, against $155,978 in 1936. Gross, which was derived from the sale of ice, ice refrigerators, oilburning equipment, coal, fuel oil, etc., amounted to $13,222,840, against $13,222,628.
