Three unbeaten contestants tallied their third victories in the world pocket billiard championship tournament at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy yesterday to share first place. They were Marcel Camp of Detroit, Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y., and Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia.

Jo Davidson, American sculptor, returned from his home in Paris yesterday to visit relatives. He said that his seven and a half foot statue of Will Rogers would probably be finished by the end of the year. It will be placed in Statuary Hall in Washington. by- Oklahoma.
The Corn Products Refining Corporation in its report for 1937, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $8,100,521 after charges, taxes and reserves for depreciation.

The general offices of the ScrippsHoward Newspapers in this city made it clear yesterday that the sudden death of Robert P. Scripps, controlling stockholder, aboard his yacht, Novia Del Mar, off Santa Margarita Island in Magdalena Bay on Thursday at 4 P. M. would occasion no change in the management of that organization.

A trade practice conference for the paint and varnish brush manufacturing industry will be held at Atlantic City on March 25 at the Traymore Hotel, the Federal Trade Commission announced today. The industry comprises approximately forty-five concerns, which have aggregate annual sales of more than $13,000,000.

Phillips Brothers have purchased from the Dooley-Stapleton Corporation sixty lots fronting on Commonwealth Boulevard, Eighty-fourth, Eighty-fifth and Eighty-sixth Avenues, Bellerose Grove, Queens, through the Halleran Agency, broker. The tract will be improved with a number of six-room dwellings.

The AngloIrish talks are continuing to make heavy weather, with neither side disposed to give way. Two meetings were held today, the first in the Prime Minister's room in the House of Commons, lasting threequarters of an hour, and a second at the Dominions office, attended by the Ministers who are especially concerned with trade.

President Roosevelt said today that publication of salaries and bonuses paid by corporations to their managers and directors was a matter of public morality, and expressed his disappointment that a provision

General liquidation by tired holders of wheat futures today caused the sharpest decline witnessed in some time on the Board of Trade. The May delivery dropped 21/2 cents a bushel from the previous close and touched 901/4 cents, the lowest figure here since Jan. 3, when sales were made at 893/4 cents.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reelected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Debate in the House of Representatives on the new tax bill has brought out one interesting point. Many of those members who insist most strongly on retaining the present profits tax "in principle" freely admit that it has worked badly in practice.

The flag committee of the Society of Mayflower Descendants, comprising younger members of the society, gave a dinner dance last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Miss Alla ChandlerSmith was chairman of the dance committee and was a hostess at one of the many dinners given in connection. with the party.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and forthcoming marriage of Countess Alice Hoyos of 22 Beekman Place, daughter of Colonel Clarence Browning Smith, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Smith, to John C. Ten Eyck Jr., son of Mrs. John C. Ten Eyck of 455 East Fifty-seventh Street and the late Mr. Ten Eyck.

Rear Admiral David McD. LeBreton, formerly Chief of Staff of the United States Fleet, arrived today to take over command of the United States Yangtze River Patrol from Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart.

For the first time since the decision of the Mexican Supreme Court was handed down upholding the labor policy of the government toward foreign oil companies, the position of American companies concerned was placed before the State Department today.

Richard Pyke, an expert on British typographical practice and a member of the International Secretariat of the Institute of Pacific Relations, died Thursday morning of pneumonia in Shanghai, China, according to word received here by the institute's New York office. He was 39 years old.

Mrs. Wesson Seyburn entertained with a large dinner tonight at Casa Giravento for Mrs. Dodge Sloane, who has returned from a South American cruise. Captain and Mrs. Cyrus R. Miller were hosts for cocktails at their villa.

Jamaica defeated Manual Training, 4 to 0, while New Utrecht and Brooklyn Tech and Boys High and Textile played to 1-1 ties at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night as the P. S. A. L. hockey tournament came to a close.

The National Squash Tennis Association's Class C championship continued last- night at the New York Athletic Club, where a total of nine matches accounted for the concluding four in the second round and five in the third.
Royal Mail, 1937 winner of the Grand National, owned by the estate of H. Lloyd Thomas, today became unofficial favorite to make it two straight when the steeplechase is renewed at Aintree, March 25.

The Woodmere Academy basketball team captured the Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools championship when it tri- ton, umphed over Fieldston, 26 to 25, in a play-off-game in the Lincoln School gymnasium yesterday.
The New York Adult Education Council, in its function as an information service, has answered the inquiries of more than 40,000 adults who are seeking new knowledge and new training.
More new highways will be built in the next ten years than were constructed in the past twenty-five years, Arthur W. Brandt, State Highway Commissioner, told the tion, in a three-day session here.

Julius Forstmann, president of the Forstmann Woolen Company, announced yesterday he had written Secretary Roper of the Deapartment of Commerce protesting against the inclusion of the name of Werner Van Bergen of that company in a list of acceptors of Commercial Standards CS 65-38 for wool and part wool fabrics.

R. S. Agee, for the last three years in charge of utility and dealer sales training and promotion for the Washington Gas Light Company, has been appointed promotional sales manager for the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers, according to announcement yesterday by Merrill N. Davis, president of the association.

The marriage of Miss Phyllis Richert Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hervey B. Phillips of South Orange, to John Fowler Ackerman of Ellsworth, Me., son of Mrs. Irving Ackerman of Paterson, took place here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church. The Rev. George A. Edmison, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

Charles D. Poey, who has resigned as illuminating engineer and manager of the lighting bureau of Consolidated Edison to become chief engineer of the illuminating division of Greist Manufacturing Company, was tendered a testimonial dinner last night at the Gramercy Park South Hotel by members of- the Consolidated Edison engineering staff. Mr. Poey, who will join the Greist company on Monday, had been with Consolidated for twenty years.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 3; MAJOR GENERALS Herron, C. D., Schofield Barracks, to command the Hawaiian Department.

Department store trade last week in the metropolitan area did not fall under last year's figures as sharply as in the preceding week, but the decline was notably greater in the up-State cities of Buffalo and Rochester, according to the report issued yetserday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Federal Judge John M. Woolsey yesterday granted an injunction sought by the Securities and Exchange Commission to restrain Torr Co., brokers; Ellery W. Mann and others from violating Section 9A-2 of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 and Section 17A-2 of the Securities Act of 1933.
Theodore P. Harding and Adolphine Voegelin, both of New York City, are two of 282 students who have attained the Dean's List at the University of Maine for the Spring semester.

A battle has been raging since 11 o'clock this morning in the Jenin district between a band of Arab terrorists and more than 1,000 British troops, in which one soldier was killed and one officer seriously wounded. The casualties among the terrorists are believed to be large.

Bethlehem Steel Corporation's capital expenditures for modernization and expansion of facilities during the fifteen-year period from 1923 to 1937, inclusive, amounted to $332,000,000, according to the Bethlehem Review, distributed to employes today.

A collection of paintings was sold at auction last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., for $23,180. Most of them came from the International Galleries of London and Paris and are said to have been acquired from private collections in Russia.

Warren Arthur Smadbeck, Inc., added yesterday to their extensive holdings of real estate in this city by purchasing four Harlem apartment houses at 265 to 273 West 146th Street, on which they intend to spend about $80,000 for alterations. The buildings, which occupy a plot 100 by 99.11 feet, were sold for cash by clients of Wilson, Huntington Lord.

The long announced charges by the American Legion for the removal of Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Borough President, because he appointed and retained Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, on his staff, will be taken to Albany Monday by a delegation of three, Maurice Stember, State adjutant, announced yesterday.
Movements of vessels follow; all dates are March 4 unless specified: San Diego to Navy Yard, Mare Island, Calif., via San Pedro: Arctic, Melville, Partridge, Robin.

Revelations at the Moscow trial regarding plots by alleged Trotskyists to undermine China's resistance to Japan were predicted here today by the Chinese Communist daily Hsin Hua Jih Pao. The paper says the trial will show the alleged plotters were following the orders of Japanese to assist the conquest of China.

The Rev. Dr. Raymond W. Smiley, pastor of Westminster Presbyterian Church, died suddenly this morning of a heart attack. He was 44 years old. Dr. Smiley returned to his home, 451 Franklin Street, last night from the annual minstrel show of the men's Bible class and the men's league of the church, and soon after midnight was stricken in his room.

The Evander Childs High School basketball team gained the upper Manhattan-Bronx division crown and Benjamin Franklin went into a first-place tie with Seward Park in the lower Manhattan competition as play in the Public Schools Athletic League tournament neared its close yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Patricia de Fabeck Burgoyne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lennox S. Burgoyne of London and Virginia Waters, Surrey, England, to Elliott A. Dingee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Amerman Dingee of Old Greenwich, Conn.,

Pastor Martin Niemoeller, who was placed in a concentration camp at Sachsenhausen,, twenty miles from Berlin, last night, is now reported to owe his rearrest on Wednesday to Chancellor Adolf Hitler's personal orders.

Compared with their masculine contemporaries professional women command almost ridiculously low salaries considering the time, expense and effort involved in acquiring degrees and completing graduate work of many kinds, Miss Dorothy Kenyon informed members of the Women's University Club yesterday.

In the supreme Court of the United States today Bernard Goodwin, Harold C. Jesse, Otto H. Marquer and Abraham W. Lilienthal, New York, were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

A jury of ten men and two women returned at 1:50 o'clock this morning a verdict of guilty of first degree murder against John Rylowicz, also known as John Reo, 59-year-old mechanic, in the killing of Mrs. Celinda Waite, 59, a widow, who, with Miss Jeanette Schuellain, her 19-year-old friend, was found shot to death in the Waite home in Elmont on Jan. 12.

Announcement was made yesterday of the creation of the Adolph S. Ochs Memorial Post of the American Legion, which has received a .temporary charter from the executive committee of the Bronx County American Legion, pending final action by the national organization.

Transcontinental airlines operating out of the flood-stricken Los Angeles area were besieged again yesterday by passengers in numbers far beyond the capacity of regular schedules and were sending extra planes there to meet the demand, New York representatives of the companies reported.
Dissolution of the Chesapeake Corporation and liquidation of its assets are under consideration, Robert R. Young, chairman, said yesterday. He added, however, that the plans were not in final form.

Seventeen, including Man o' War's greatest son, the top-weighted War Admiral, have been named for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup race, to be run at Hialeah Park tomorrow before an expected crowd of 25,000 persons.

Expressions of good-will and the desire for closer intellectual ties between this country and Brazil were exchanged last night between American and Brazilian officials in speeches at the opening of the PanAmerican radio broadcasting channel recently assigned to the International General Electric Company of Schenectady, N. Y.

Several hundred persons attended a dance tonight in the Palm Gardens of the Roney Plaza Cabana Sun Club to aid the cancer clinic of Jackson Memorial Hospital, Miami. Among those entertaining there were Mr. and Mrs. George Nelson Ostrander of Saratoga, N. Y.;

Ralph E. Taggart, president of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, announced that the resignation of P. N. Guthrie Jr. as president of the Reading Iron Company has been received. He added that it has not yet been presented to the board.

American Home Fire Assurance Company-As of Dec. 31: Total admitted assets, $3,179,744, compared with $4,025,250 at the end of 1936; surplus, $992,713, against $1,909,212; unearned premiums, $841,395, against $770,437.

The Presbytery of New York will clebrate its 200th anniversary benning with a service for reprentatives of all the sixty congregaons composing it on May 8 at P. M. in the First Church, Fifth venue between Eleventh and welfth Streets.

The Hamburg-American liner Hamburg, arriving today from Germany and Channel ports, has among her passengers Ellery Sedgwick, editor of The Atlantic Monthly, who has been in Spain on a tour of Insurgent territory.

The team-of-four title of the Eastern bridge championships was won yesterday by S. Garton Churchill, Charles Lockridge, John Rau and Sam Fry Jr. in a runaway thirtysix-board match against a team of youngsters led by Irving Epstein.

Reports from many of the leading building operators in Queens andother sections of Long Island indicate that the low down-payment facilities afforded by the new FHA housing regulations have stimulated the buying of homes within the $6,000 price range, in addition to a noticeable trend toward dwellings of the $10,000 type. Construction

Problems of Jewish refugees and opportunities existing for them in other countries is the subject of a series of talks to be given by the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, opening tomorrow morning at the Jewish Theological Seminary, 122d Street and Broadway. George Backer,
Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye told the Diet today that the Chinese-Japanese conflict may force Japan to cancel her 1940 international exposition.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Foster Chaffee of Pelham, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss June Compton Chaffee, to Durando Miller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Durando Miller of Pelham Manor.

The pending trade pact with Great Britain has, for the first time, centered the attention of consumer organizations on the effect of such agreements on the standard of living and consumer prices in this country, it was reported here yesterday.
Vincent Hartley, 34-year-old Lancashire clerk, claims to have solved the difficult task of planting a lawn by first attaching seed tO a soluble tissue paper.

Building Inspector William J. Conlin of Scarsdale reports that permits for seven new residences to cost $78,900 were filed there last month. In the same month last year plans were filed for ten new homes to cost $162,000.

Formal dances this week-end at the College of William and Mary in the George Preston Blow Memorial Gymnasium were sponsored by the president's aides, W. W. Woodbridge, Seattle, Wash., being the newly appointed chief aide.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charlemagne Loughran of Kew Gardens of the engagejorie Loughran, to George Taylor, son of Frank J. Taylor, former Controller of the City of New York, and Mrs. Taylor of Brooklyn.

Faculty members and their neighbors residing in the Columbia University section have organized themselves into a community association which supplies nursery care, musical training, athletics and other recreational and educational services for its members.

EMPHASIS on the modern was clearly to the fore in the exhibitions of the last week. J. B. Neumann, perhaps mindful of the saying that one hopeful sign of a step forward is a look backward, has opened for the month a show of paintings by artists whose work he exhibited in Berlin a quarter of a century agoat the time the famous Armory Show was making revolutionary art history in New York. He has
Novel machinery has been set in motion designed to endow the Republican party with a program of wide appeal and to bolster it for the elections of 1938 and 1940.

Harold F. Thibault, former Westchester County Commander of the American Legion and director of the Joint Veterans Relief Committee in Yonkers, died last night in Veterans Hospital, the Bronx, of World War wounds. He was 38 years old.

In a demonstration of recent scientific developments, Dr. Gerald Wendt, director of the American Institute of the City of New York, will expound some of the laboratory's aids in warfare, medicine and industry on Wednesday evening to members of the American Woman's Association,

Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, mother-in-law of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, and her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey Niel Morgan, were here in a special car early this morning on their way to Tucson. Ariz.. and Mexico.

An opportunity to learn more about metal prices probably will be presented to the financial and industrial community soon. It is expected that a Senate investigation of prices under a resolution by Senator Bailey will be launched within a month, and leading corporate executives undoubtedly will be called upon to testify on the source of prices in their respective industries.

The undeclared war that started as a night skirmish near Peiping last July 7 and has evolved, after many vicissitudes, into a type of guerrilla conflict is approaching the end of another bloody chapter.

Young women in society will participate in a pageant of gowns entitled "Cinderella in Modern Dress," which will be presented on Thursday evening during the dinner hour at Cafe Louis Fourteenth, Rockefeller Center. The event will augment the scholarship fund of the George Junior Republic.

Flood waters receded here today after inundating fourteen square miles of residential and outlying area, but the rising San Joaquin River menaced Firebaugh, refuge of 500 migratory workers who had been forced to flee from a labor camn.

SHANGHAI.-When a Japanese volunteers the information that nothing could be more depressing than spending even a week in a Chinese city which is under Japanese military occupation, then things must be pretty bad indeed.

A parade of college-girl types, including the "smoothie," the "prom trotter," the student and the athlete, was part of the original musical show, "From Pen to Coop," presented today by juniors at New Jersey College for Women as a feature of the annual Junior Promenade week-end.

A Columbia University trio, consisting of John Finnerty, Justin Callahan and John Vergeichik, won the New York State A. A. U. 300yard medley relay championship to provide the feature of a swimming carnival in the 75-foot pool of the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. last night.

Discussing government aid for low-rent housing and slum clearance, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, declared yesterday at a meeting at the National Republican Club that a wider tax basis was necessary to relieve real estate of the burden and suggested a housing tax similar to the city sales tax for relief purposes.

The international steel cartel, concerned over the tremendous gains made by the United States in exports of iron, steel and related products in the last year, has retaliated by reducing its prices, according to a consular report from Paris made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Banns were published here today for the marriage of Pierre Cot, French Minister of Commerce, and Mrs. Luisa Phelps, a United States citizen. Mr. Cot, at 43, is one of the youngest members of the French Government.

The number of mail orders received in the wholesale market last week increased, according to aspecial summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyer. However, these were chiefly for small quantities of "fillin" goods to cover immediate requirements.

Voters of Ohio appear to be in for the greatest deluge of words in their history. It is all over the charges that have been hurled at Governor Martin Luther Davey by a committee of the Ohio Senate which conducted an investigation of State departments under the Governor and of political activities generally covering four years.

To advance preparations for the "Ball of Tomorrow" many members of the Junior League of New York are now forming committees for the undertaking, which is to aid the league's welfare fund. The ball will be given on the night of April 29 in the Business Administration Building at the grounds of the New York World's Fair.

Alfred E. Forstall Jr. of the foreign credit department of the New York Trust Company died at his home here today at the age of 41. A graduate of Lehigh, he served overseas in the World War, sailing with the first convoy from New York as a transport clerk and later becoming a second lieutenant in the Quartermaster's Corps.
THE third annual Three-Choir festival will be held March 25 and 26 at Temple Emanu-El under the auspices of Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York and its choir committee. Elaborate
The second annual meeting of the Secondary Schools International Relations Conference will be held at Brothers College of Drew University March 19, Dean Frank Glenn Lankard announced today.

With many grumbles and much confusion, Philadelphia is becoming penny-conscious. When the 2 per cent sales tax was passed by the City Council a few weeks ago, then repassed over the veto of Mayor S. Davis Wilson, the public, after early signs of revolt, apparently lost interest.

Changes in the listing of securities of the George A. Fuller Company were announced yesterday. George A. Fuller Company $6 cumulative and participating prior preferred stock, no par value, and $6 cumulative and participating second preference stock, no par value, are to be suspended tomorrow from dealings on the New York Stock Exchange.

A group of Greenwich women will leave here on Southern Memorial Day, April 26, in a chartered bus to attend the United States Constitution Sesquicentennial pilgrimage to Independence Hall, Philadelphia, the Library of Congress in Washington and Stratford Hall in Virginia.

ABRAMIOWVITZ-Rebecca, March 5, 1938, beloved mother of Joseph, Joel, Arthur, Sophie and Mary. Funeral from Schwartz Parlors, 1,665 Lexington Ave., today, 2 P. M. AHRENS-Walter F., beloved husband of Mary Fulton Ahrens. Service at his home. 46 Concord Ave., Larchmont, N. Y., 4:30 P. M., Sunday.

Dr. Ray Allen, who once proposed uniting the Presbyterian and Methodist Episcopal Churches, died at his home in suburban Kenmore last night. He was 77 years old. At his death he was treasurer of the Genesee Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

Determined to recapture his prisoner alive rather than shoot him, Detective John Rokee extended the full weight of his 200 pounds in a chase of 800 feet down the block from Brooklyn Police Headquarters to Carlton Avenue, at 9 o'clock last night.

Miss Sarah Keith Robertson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh W. Robertson of this city and South Norwalk, Conn., has selected March 26 for her marriage to Lyman Emerson Russell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Russell, also of White Plains, in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church here. The Rev.

On March 6, 1838, Andrew B. Brinckerhoff and seventy-two fellow New Yorkers formed a cavalry company to supplement the rifle companies of the Seventh Regiment. The cavalry company changed to infantry during the Civil War but maintained its identity.
Four venturesome boys, prowling around Pennsylvania Station just after noon yesterday, found the elevator car vacant in the single shaft connecting Track 19 with the main concourse.

At a dinner party at their home tonight, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Faraday Weston of this place announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cornelia Weston, to Phillip H. Cummings, son of Mrs. Addie Cummings and the late Harry Foster Cummings of Hardwick, Vt.

While the proposed League of American Nations is not receiving a great deal, of sympathy here, there is a possibility that a plan for an Inter-American Court of Justice will be suggested If the present Mediation Commission succeeds in settling the Nicaraguan-Honduran boundary controversy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It has been said that a country which has a dictator needs a dictator. When political and economic progress ceases among a people in any land because no one knows what to do, or knowing will not let it be done, the danger flag of coming dictatorship is flying high at the mast:
WORD has come from Hollywood that Samuel Goldwyn is considering the screen possibilities of General John J. Pershing's unpublished autobiography.
Two school children filed with the Supreme Court today a challenge, of the constitutionality of a New Jersey law requiring pupils to salute the American flag.

The eleventh and final Toscanini concert of this season with the NBC Symphony Orchestra, following the incomparable performance of Verdi's Requiem given with the same orchestra the preceding evening at Carnegie Hall, took place last night in Studio H-8 in Radio City.

Tokyo representative of Tass Ithe Russian news agency has been deprived at the request of the police of his office in the Domei [Japanese news agency building, where all other foreign news agency representatives have their headquarters.

One of the largest home-building projects by private interests to be undertaken in Westchester County for some time was announced yesterday by the County Housing Corporation, which stated that, after a careful study into the needs of the modern small home owner, plans had been perfected for the early erection of fifty medium-priced dwellings in White Plains and Pleasantville. The program involves

Miss Doris Janet Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Spencer Brown of this city, formerly of Brooklyn, has selected the evening of March 26 for her marriage to Donald Frederick Habich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Habich of Blue Island, Ill.

Joseph A. Daly, for a number of years until his retirement in 1928 one of the city's best known detectives, died yesterday at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, 190th Street and Fort Washington Avenue, after an abdominal operation. He was 58 years old.

There is profound satisfaction throughout India at the settlement by compromise of the constitutional impasse in the United Provinces and Bihar that arose in February when the governors rejected the demands of their Congress Ministers for immediate, general and unconditional release of "political prisoners."

Dartmouth. College's hockey team again asserted its supremacy in the Quadrangular League today on the Hobey Baker Rink before 1,200 persons and completed its season undefeated in circuit competition by turning back Princeton, 3-2, in a contest decided in the final min utes of play.

Brooklyn realty men and builders, already feeling the effects of the more liberal financing terms under the FHA mortgage insurance program, are preparing to reap the benefits of the heavier demand for homes in their borough.

IP and Scootie, the disciples of that seasoned old cowpuncher, Uncle Bill, make their third appearance in this book, and those two ardent converts to life on the range are scarcely off the Westbound train before their adventures begin.

EARLY in 1800 Johann Anton Andre, third son of the founder of the famous music publishing house in Offenbach-on-the-Main, bought from Mozart's widow, Constanze, at the instance, it is said, of Haydn, a packet of three hundred manuscripts of the deceased composer.

Opening of the Lincoln Tunnel and completion of the West Side elevated highway with its connections to the Westchester County Parkway have brought an increased need for construction of a ramp approach to the elevated highway at or near Thirty-fourth Street, according to William F. H. Koelsch, president of the Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association.

The Burroughs Adding Machine Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1937 a net income of $8,163,404 after depreciation, domestic and foreign income taxes, surtax on undistributed profits and other charges.

THE amateur photographer of ten finds himself in the doldrums in the early Spring. He surrenders to the feeling that photographing a bare landscape is scarcely worth while and turns to other fields until the greater inspiration of the more completely perfect scene shall return.

Thirty navigators of the New York Power Squadron may henceforth use the initials "A. P." after their names, at least on yachting literature and bulletins. They have completed the second-year course of study which began in the Fall and have passed the examination for advanced pilots under the regulations of the United States Power Squadrons.
IF an American had written this story of a G-man after a murderer or two and a gang of counterfeiters it would be just a rattling good tale. By an Englishman it is amazing.

Deposits of the new London branch of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, which opened for business last Tuesday, amounted to $2,337,000, according to the weekly statement of members of the New York Clearing House Association.

Electric razors hare been provided by Sheriff William J. Dempsey for the use of prisoners in the Richmond County Jail at Dongan Hills, S. I. According to the State Commissioner of Correction, Sheriff Dempsey is the first to install these devices in county jails.
Four men, against whom complaints had been made by Kearny residents for the sale of memberships in the National Automobile Club of New Brunswick, N. J., were arrested today.

SURREALISM'S latest demonstration, in the International Exhibition held at the Galerie Beaux-Arts, has left the public unenlightened as to whether the show is intended to display the movement or whether it is a burlesque by-Surrealists on Surrealism.

English furniture, silver and rugs sold Friday and yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries netted $25,045, the final session bringing $16,232.50. The principal owners represented were the late Eben J. Knowlton, Edward M. Bratter and Miss S. E. Norton.
Foreign Minister Josef Beck left this morning for Rome, where he will spend five, days as the guest of Premier Benito Mussolini and Foreign Minister Count Galeazzo Ciano.

Dr. Arthur Seyss-Inquart, Minister of Interior, arrived here this afternoon and in a speech to 500 Upper Austrian Nazi leaders told them negotiations were under way to establish a basis for the legal use of Nazi emblems, salute, songs and flags.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Marnie Holcombe, daughter of Judge Charles Andrews Holcombe of this city and the late Mrs. Holcombe, to Alan Adair Wright of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. D. Wright of Spartanburg, S. C.

Art property collected by the late Mr. and Mrs. Percy A. Rockefeller, including tapestries, oriental rugs, furniture and decorative objects, will be sold at auction at the ParkeBernet Galleries on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and the department stores organizing committee of the C. I. O. have entered into an agreement covering employes in the company's Thirtythird Street store and warehouses, it was announced yesterday.

Two bills aimed at the promotion of safety on the highways and the protection of motorists from car losses by theft will be recommended to the Legislature by the Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation, it was announced yesterday by Assemblyman Harold G. Ostertag, chairman of the group.

Victory in the 200-yard relay test enabled the Penn Hall Junior College swimming team to emerge victorious in a triangular meet with New York University and Hunter College yesterday in the London Terrace pool.

Freshening winds sped thirteen yachts southward late today in a 284-mile race from St. Petersburg to Havana. Conditions indicated, however, that the record set last year by the Sirocco, 44-foot cutter owned by Roger Robinson of New Haven, Conn., was not endangered.
Seventy years ago this week a minor masculine snub to a newspaper woman indirectly precipitated that major feminine movement known as women's clubs.

Preparations are being made for the Spring season which will get under way here within a few weeks. Nearly all houses were kept open this Winter as there were fewer residents than ever going to the Winter resorts or abroad.

JUJITSU, the Japanese national sport, came into the headlines recently when the Japanese Ambassador to France, Yotaro Sugimura, gave a jujitsu exhibition before Parisian - diplomats, social leaders and members of royalty. Although 53 years old,

As a result of the work of the National Urban League, Negroes will be engaged as civil service employes in several Southern States for the first time, Eugene Kinckle Jones, executive secretary of the League, declared in the twentyseventh annual report just made public.

SUPPOSE it is time to answer some of the pot-shots which are being taken at the Pepper-Coffee-Sirovich bill, now in committees of both House and Senate. This bill needs the same defense all progressive measures do.

Miss Teodolinda Gonzalez, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jose Ignacio Gonzalez of Diriamba, Nicaragua, was married to Harold M. Becklin of New York yesterday. The bride was educated in the United States, France and England.

BEFORE plunging into the affairs of blustery March, there are a few matters left over from February which seem to call for comment. First of these is the problem of color which Robert Edmond Jones brought up in these pages last Sunday.
Williams won Little Three honors in the wrestling tournament tonight with a total of 30 points. Wesleyan finished second with 26 and Am-. herst trailed with 23.

Defeating Princeton by 4-1 in a team match on five boards yesterday, the chess players of New York University gained their third consecutive victory since the annual intercollegiates during the Christmas holidays.

Retailers plan a selective building up of stocks during the period directly ahead, but nothing approaching a return of heavy forward ordering is in sight, according to the views of merchants here last week.

THIS is fascinating bok that will add to its author's high reputation for readability. From cover to cover, the narrative is pleasantly irresistible. The structure of the story is solidly worth while. The statements of fact are crystal clear and not a sentence is slipshod.

The upper floors of the old Wanamaker mansion at Chelsea and Pacific Avenues, a four-story frame structure now operated as the Villa D'Esta Hotel, were destroyed here today by a two-alarm fire of undetermined cause.
British soldiers pushed mopping up operations today after nine Royal Air Force planes bombed and machinegunned a band of Arabs, killing between fifty and sixty of their number in the encounter.

Mrs. Warren Gladstone Houston of this city gave a luncheon today at the William Pitt Tavern in Chatham at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Houston, to Thomas Waldron Bishop, son of Mr. and Mrs. Waldron M. BishoP of Caldwell.

The man over 40-particularly he of the generous girth-has been neglected too long by health officials in favor of children and their lessserious diseases, 200 physical directors of the Young Men's Christian Association were told yesterday morning as they opened their annual two-day Eastern Region Conference on Physical Education at the William Sloane House, 356 West Thirty-fourth Street.

That "the experiment in bituminous coal has temporarily broken down," as stated in your editorial "Coal Control Cracks," is more or less typical of the sinister fate pursuing this unfortunate industry. And it is a bit ironical that "the immediate reason is not economic but legal," as a result of the Coal Commission's apparent. misinterpretation of the statute.

Roaring down the course with a recklessness that saved precious seconds on the many tricky turns, Ulrich Beutter of the visiting German Universties ski team captured the national open and amateur downhill championship today.

With the Spring selling season scheduled to be launched by most men's wear retailers next week, clothing stocks have been cut to a point 10 to 15 per cent below those of a year ago, store executives reported yesterday.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the Diual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Protesting the action of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors who voted last Thursday to transfer to the State title to the Bronx River Parkway, the chairman and two other members of the Westchester County Park Commission resigned today.

Johnny Revolta, former P. G. A. champion of Evanston, Ill., won the St. Petersburg open golf I championship today by defeating Chandler Harper, 23-year-old Portsmouth, Va., professional, by two strokes in an 18-hole playoff. Revolta had a 75, four over par.
Miss Jane Soames, daughter of the late Rev. Gordon Soames and Mrs. Soames, was married to Hoffman Nickerson, American author, at the Caxton Hall Register Office here today.

Foreign central banks or stabilization funds are again taking steps to convert their dollar balances into .gold, it became known last week, when the Treasury's inactive gold fund was reduced about $23,000,000.
A petition for reorganization of the Hudson Coal Company, a huge anthracite-mining concern, under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act was on file today in United States District Court here.
The functions of the architect are explained in a leaflet just issued by the committee on public informa tion of the American- Institute of Architects, of which William Orr Ludlow is chairman.

IN the swift succession of anniversaries during the last few weeks there was one that was practically overlooked. Observers will readily agree that the oversight was considerable, too. The anniversary occurred last Friday, March 4, and was commemorative of what may well be appraised in later years as the most important day in the history of these times. It was the fifth birthday of the New Deal.
The British steamer Estumia sent a wireless message to Constanza harbor authorities that it had found in the Black Sea the wreck of a yacht named Lady I flying the United States flag.
Evan Williams, the Welsh jockey who rode Royal Mail to victory in the 1937 Grand National, broke his collarbone today when Royal Mail fell during a gallop over the Lingfield Park fences.

The engagement has been an-nounced of Miss Dorothy Markel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Markel of 225 East Seventy-third Street, to Frederick Adolph Prahl Jr., son of Mrs. Betty S. Prahl, also of this city, and of Frederick A. Prahl of Peru, Vt.
Members of the editorial staff of the Manhattan College student weekly. The Quadrangle, are in several other extracurricular activities on the campus, a recent survey disclosed.

UNEASINESS in the Danube Valley is reflected in several remarkable books which have recently come out of Hungary. Their authors are young people who have set out to discover their native country, and have found a cracked world order.

Colonel and Mrs. Roy Ivan Taylor announced at a party given at their home here today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cornelia Trumbull Taylor, to E. Kenneth Hadden of 157 East Seventy-fifth Street, New York.
OLD FRIENDS: In a four-storied villa overlooking Lake Geneva there was a reunion last week of old friends when former President Hoover called

Considerable importance is attached in official circles here to revelations made last night by Defense Minister Indalecio Prieto relative to the cooperation of German submarines and other naval units in Insurgent war operations.

The importance of making nursery schools an integral part of education in this country was emphasized yesterday by speakers at a symposium at the Ethical Culture School, Central Park West and Sixty-third Street.

Many new country homes in the North Shore colonies will be ready for occupancy by. members of society when they return from their Winter sojourns in the South, ocean cruises and their town residences after Easter and, according to builders and architects in charge of these projects, there has been record speed in construction during the Winter because of favorable weather.

The Spring dance in the series of Dolphin Dances for young women who will be introduced to society within the next three years will take place at the Pierre on March 28 instead of on April 4, as origfinally planned.

The Toronto Maple Leafs boosted their International Group lead in the National Hockey League to seven points tonight by blanking the Montreal Maroons, 2 to 0, before a crowd of 9,128, smallest turnout of the season here.

Wheat prices on the Board of Trade fluctuated erratically today within a range of 3/4 to 7/8 cent a bushel. The opening was steady to 1/2 cent higher than yesterday's final quotations as the result of strength in Liverpool, reports of a good export business yesterday in dark hard Winter wheat and the failure of predicted rain to fall in the Southwest.
A great figure in American life has gone from the national landscape in the passing of George Foster Peabody, who was a Titan with a Promethean interest in mankind.

Milk that is more readily digestible and hence of special value in feeding infants and convalescents can be made by subjecting ordinary cow's milk to "sound" waves such as are used for determining ocean depths by means of the fathometer, according to a patent just granted to Edward W. Smith of Melrose, Mass. The process consists of a special method of reducing the "curd tension," or "hardness" of milk.

A PERIODICAL visitor to the Royal Opera during the past half decade can hardly fail to notice a great improvement in the artistic standards of this theatre, intended to become Italy's foremost lyric stage.

Groups of Columbia University students, participating in a new plan of foreign language study, will embark for Europe next Summer to live for six weeks with French, German and Italian families and receive instruction in language, history, geography, literature and art from faculty members of the Universities of Poitiers, Munich and Perugia.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin R. Jenkins of Hollis, Queens, have announced the engagement-of their daughter, Miss Jean Natalie Jenkins, to David Irwin Hosmer of Buffalo, son of Professor Ralph S. Hosmer of Cornell University and Mrs. Hosmer.
"Room Service" makes way at the Strand Theatre for Basil Dean's production of "Death on the Table," a comedy thriller by Guy Beauchamp and Michael Pertwee, which opens Wednesday. Hartley Power, who

A real estate conference has been called by the National Association of Real Estate Boards to meet in Washington, D. C., March 17, 18 and 19 for the purpose of discussing methods whereby operators, builders, brokers and mortgage lenders may employ the new provisions for mortgage insurance as provided for in the amended Housing Act.
Two local claimants to the $877,500 fortune of Mrs. Ida E. Wood of New York, "the little widow of Herald Square," today presented evidence of their claims to Martin Conboy, New York attorney.
CHARLES YALE HARRISON follows up "Generals Die in Bed" with a new adventure in iconoclasm.

Prince Wilhelm of Schaumberg-Lippe, lieutenant in the German Air Force and a member of the family that ruled the Principality of Schaumberg-Lippe until 1918, was killed yesterday when his bombing plane crashed near Neu-Brandenberg.

Among the officers chosen last week by Sweet Briar College students to head their organizations the coming year are Mary Mackintosh of Bronxville, N. Y., president of the Student Government Association, and Jean McKenney of New York City. editor of The Sweet Briar News.

If Maxim Gorky died from other than natural causes, suspicion might first fall on Joseph Stalin, because relations between the pair were strained to the point where Stalin refused to give Gorky permission to go to Paris to attend the International Convention of Anti-Fascist Authors, according to W. W. Krivitzsky, former head of the Soviet War Industries Institute in Moscow, in an interview published yesterday by a Russian emigres' newspaper.
The body of Robert P. Scripps, newspaper publisher, who died last Thursday-aboard his yacht off the Mexican coast near Magdalena Bay, was brought here today aboard the Pacific liner Pennsylvania.
Shoe retailers last week placed appreciable commitments for women's shoes in Spring models, after several weeks of delay, and their ordering still reflected extreme caution.
After exactly 100 days in the Sante prison, Duke Pozzo di Borga, held in connection with the concealed arms plot investigation, was released this evening.

Manager Joe McCarthy today viewed with unconcealed contentment his world champion Yankees and his rookies in training at Huggins Field. He has under his direction as fine an array of athletes as a Yankee manager has had in training in years.
A home-coming celebration at Clark University today had as its chief feature the dedication of the alumni gymnasium, first unit of the new building program of the institution.

College players from Ohio carried off the major honors in the national indoor tennis tournament yesterday. at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Donald McNeill of Oklahoma City, Okla., 19 year-old junior from Kenyon College, and Miss Virginia Hollinger. of Dayton, a student at Wittenberg College, were crowned as the new champions for 1938.

Dr. Reginald Bryant Allen, head of the Mathematics Department of Kenyon College since 1906, died at his home here yesterday of a coronary thrombosis after an illness of several months. He was born in Medford, N. J., sixty-six years ago.
Lent is the time when the oyster is at its seasonal best-plumping, ready to spawn. It is the time when the giant frog croaks to be taken from the Southern bayous to grace Northern tables;

Declines in, retail. trade volume became more general and were deeper last week, and the solitary district reporting a gain was Texas, where the increase was slight. Merchants continued to feature low prices on late Winter merchandise to clear stocks. Early offerings of Spring apparel met a moderate response in some areas.
Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was dull and prices generally were irregular yesterday. in a session which rounded rout the smallest week's bond trading in twenty years.

Miss Maria Cerra, young Hunter sophomore representing the Salle d'Armes Vince, won the Greco Fencing Trophy by annexing seven bouts in the final round-robin on the strips of the Greco Fencing Academy yesterday afternoon.

British Hong Kong is today, in effect, the capital of China. Crowded into its thirty-two square miles are the leaders. the brains, the wealth and the whole witch's caldron of Chinese finance, strategy, intrigue, plot and counterplot.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Johnston of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Esther Johnston, to Frederick Lincoln Heinrich, son of Mrs. W. T. L. Dickie of Sea Cliff, L. I., and of the late Frederick William Heinrich.

To the Drama Editor: In THE TIMES of Feb. 13, in an article concerning Arthur Arent, author of "One-third of a Nation," one encounters a reference to Arent's early experience in Summer camp theatres, or in "the 'borscht circuit,' as these camps are affectionately known to the theatrical world." I should like to do
One hundred and fifty couples attended the annual senior prom of New York University's Washington Square College at Sherry's last night.

With all their recent gains in- North Honan threatened by increasingly successful Chinese rear and flank attacks, Japanese troops, who ten days ago began driving into Southeast Shansi from North Honan, are reported to be turning back to the Honan area north of the Yellow River to support the thinly held communication lines and reinforce the weakly occupied strategic centers.

A widened program of intramural athletics, having as its aim the development of personality and to give the advantage of athletics for those of mediocre ability, was started at the City College last week.

The Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation announced today that it would purchase eggs to stabilize the market for that product. It said it would operate at any market or exchange where surpluses became larger than normal and prices declined below present levels Or failed to advance according to the season.

The semi-final brackets in the men's and women's metropolitan Class B badminton championships were filled yesterday at the Old Sixty-ninth Badminton and Tennis Club. In the men's section Wayne Sikes of the home club, seeded first, defeated Charles Wagner, New Rochelle B. C., 15-8, 15-7.

William G. Willmann, a retired paper manufacturer, Who owned what he believed to be the largest star sapphire in the world, died at his home here today of a relapse that followed an apparent recovery from pneumonia. He was born in New York in 1865.

Colonel Rowan P. Lemly, commander of the Tenth Infantry at Fort Thomas, Ky., died at that post last night at the age of 53. He had been instructor of many National Guard and Reserve officers since the World War.

Negotiations have been completed since Jan. 1 by the real estate bureau of the State Banking Department, under special deputy, Willard K. Denton, for the payment of $336,099 in satisfaction of ten mortgages, Superintendent of Banks, William R. White, announced yesterday.
HOLLAND'S placid, storied towns and picturesque backwater lure the wandering vacationist. Few countries present more diversified sights in so small a territory.
hance Ray, a gelding claimed by E. Davison earlier in the meetng, raced to his second straight victory at the Fair Grounds today ?? the $2,000 added Spanish Fort handicap .

Theodore J. Siener of Indianapolis came up with the best games of his bowling career in the A. B. C. tournament today, rolling a 688, to take the lead in the individual standings. Leadership of the two-man event changed hands frequently.

On the estate of R. R. M. Carpenter in Benton, Md., the American Chesapeake Club will hold its annual Spring field trial meeting Thursday, Friday and Saturday next week. For Chesapeake Bay dogs there will be open all-age, novice, amateur handlers and local stakes.

The following WPA Federal Art Project exhibitions are on view this week: Adelphi Theatre, 152 West Fifty-fourth Street--Twenty children's paintings. Bureau of Child Guidance, 46 Forsythe Street--Twenty children's paintings, ten children's prints.

THE simultaneous -appearance of independently recorded sets of Brahms's "Liebes lieder-Walzer," Op. 52, and "Zigeunerlieder," Op. 103, complete and more or less in their authentic form, can only be regarded as extraordinary coincidence. Hitherto,
HANSON W. BALDWIN makes three things clear in this brilliant and condensed study of the present gigantic race for armaments in Europe.

The Borg-Warner Corporation omitted yesterday the common dividend due at this time. The company's announcement said "approximately 70 per cent of last year's earnings were paid out in dividends, but the present volume of sales and the immediate general outlook do not warrant a payment at this time."

Mr. and Mrs. James E. Light of Westport, Conn., formerly of Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Audrey Marie Light, to Lee Fleming O'Meara, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas O'Meara of Brooklyn.

Miss Stella Barbara Becker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barnett L. Becker of 915 West End Avenue, will be married to Robert Edward Newman, son of Samuel Newman of Buffalo and the late Mrs. Newman, this afternoon at Temple Ansche Chesed, 251 West 100th Street, by the Rev. Dr. Joseph Zeitlin.

Columbia University. which opened an elementary course in baseball last Summer, with such luminaries as Lou Gehrig and Bill Terry as mentors, will take the logical step forward next July and offer "Physical Education s160D--Coaching of Baseball (Advanced)."

Prompt passage of the Burchill bill providing for collective bargaining for the 5,400 employes of New York City's Independent Subway System was advocated today by the American Federation of Labor. The bill is in the Senate Public Service Committee.
Innovations in taxation are necessarilly experiments. The enactment of -the undistributed-profits -tax in the Revenue Act of 1936 was essentally an experiment.

Florida is at the peak of the greatest Winter tourist season of its history. All resort centers report record gatherings of Winter visitors, and one State official estimated some 2,200,000 persons will have come by the time the season ends.

Substitute teachers of the elementary, junior and senior high schools of the city, to whom permanent status has been denied after many years of continuous service, will petition the session of the Education Assembly Committee tomorrow evening at Albany for the passage of several bills designed to improve conditions in the school system.

By an overwhelming majority, New York City school teachers have voted to change the method of electing their delegates to the Retirement Board from the indirect to the direct system, Dr. Abraham Lefkowitz, legislative representative of the Teachers Guild, announces.
Dr. Thomas K. Robertson of Ridgewood died today in Paterson General Hospital. He was 69 years old. Dr. Robertson retired four years ago as superintendent of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary.

Professor James H. Osborne, member of the faculty of Wabash College here for more than fifty years, died this morning in his home. He was 80 years old. He suffered a stroke of paralysis two weeks ago at his Winter home in Vero Beach, Fla.

Seventy - four municipalities in twenty-five States approved bond issues aggregating $4,900,600 February, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compared with $3,603,771 of municipal issues approved in January and $6,736,400 approved in Feburary, 1937.
Neil Sullivan and Roy Coffin of Philadelphia, seeking their sixth straight national squash racquets doubles championship, today led the field into the semi-final round.

Leon Trotsky, former Bolshevist leader who has been accused in Moscow's current treason trial of having received more than $1,000,000 from Soviet officials for "Trotskyite work," demanded from exile here tonight that documentary evidence be brought to support the charge.
land and America will be represented tomorrow at the eighteen-hole best-ball tournamcnt at the Seminole Club, with members and their guests and members of the Gulf Stream Club as the gallery.

Former Senator J. Thomas Heflin has announced his candidacy for the seat in the lower house of Congress which he won thirty-four years ago and held for sixteen years thereafter until he entered the Senate 1920.

Restriction of production in the major textile industries will continue for at least a month and probably well into the Spring, a survey of the markets yesterday indicated. With production running far behind a year ago and well under "normal," manufacturers of cotton and wool goods and of rayon yarns have found their stocks gradually increasing.

POTTERFIELD'S Drug Store stands on the corner of Capitol and Kanawha Streets, just a block from the Great Kanawha River and the town's levee. Old Man Boggs established it where it is about seventy-five years ago, when the country people came to town more by river than by road. When the store prospered,

The non-sectarian Temple of Religion to be erected at the New York World's Fair of 1939 was proclaimed "one of the greatest contributions the fair will offer to posterity" by Rabbi B. A. Tintner of Mount Zion Congregation, 257 West Ninety-third Street, in his sermon yesterday.

Stagehand, a mere colt, but amighty one, captured 'the fourth running of the richest horse race in the' world, the $137,300 Santa Anita Handicap. More than 50,000 saw the rollicking 3-year-old drop the curtain on the 19-10 favorite, Seabiscuit, in a head-to-head battle down the stretch and in camera finish by a nose 'today.

Three homes are under. construction for Summer occupancy at Lake Packanack, Passaic County, N. J., announces Ira C. Jones, sales manager for the property, and several plots overlooking, the lake have been purchased for early improvement.
Lawrenceville's champion polo team defeated the fighting Yale jayvees today 17-16. The first half was dominated by Lawrenveville, 10-4. Captain Rose scored' six goals.

A goal by William Dance in the third period enabled the Poly Prep hockey team to turn back St. Francis, 1 to 0, yesterday at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. The winning tally was made unassisted after three minutes of the session had elapsed.

Princeton basketball team overwhelmed Harvard, 37-20, in the university gymnasium tonight for Nassau's third Eastern Intercollegiate League victory of the week. The triumph gave the Tigers a record of four circuit triumphs and six losses.

Southern California's worst flood, with its appalling toll of life and property, means that nature won in a race with engineers in which Los Angeles County had already invested $60,000,000 and in which the Federal Government is now investing $70,000,000 more.
The recital given by Rose Bampton, Metropolitan soprano, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall attracted one of the most ardently enthusiastic audiences seen in that auditorium during the present season.

The Rev. and Mrs. Nils J. Wessell of Plainfield, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Valdis A. Wessell to Olyphant Mills Talbot, son of Mrs. Harriette Snow Talbot of Slingerlands, N. Y.

JOHN DICKSON CARR, skillful and sophisticated, always tells a good story, and tells it well. Apparently without effort, moreover, in the simple recital of what was said and done, he can invest his incidents with a suggestion of the horrible., the haunting, or the bizarre;
Mr. and Mrs. George Gale Foster of Greenwich, Conn., were among those entertaining at the Surf Club's "East Side, West Side" gala dinner dance tonight.
A trickle of persons who had been in Los Angeles during the flood began to arrive at Newark Airport yesterday as air travel, although hampered by bad weather west of Chicago, was partially resumed.

The Port of New York Authority has filed protest with the Maritime Commission against an increase of 5 cents per 100 pounds on sugar moving from Pacific Coast terminals to the Port of New York in the ships of intercoastal lines.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Early Spring vacationers are starting to arrive and Atlantic City assumes the role of the ?? to rest up during the off season, that period between the end of the round of Winter affairs and the start of the Spring and Summer events.

Spurred on by a spanking gale that wafted seven home runs into the adjacent plains and wound up the performance in a downpour of rain, the Giants opened their 1938 exhibition schedule today by outscrambling Connie Mack's Athletics by a score of 11 to 10.

About 600 Queens residents attended funeral services at the First Reformed Church, Bowne Street and Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, yesterday afternoon for the Rev. John Baumeister, head of the North Classis of Long Island, who died Tuesday at his home, 149-11 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing. Burial was in Flushing Cemetery.

EVERY good camera man has in the back of his head at least one picture he intends to make one day, simple, sincere, uncolossal, and budgetless very much the sort of picture, in fact, which Stacy and Horace Woodard have calledn "The Adventures of Chico," and have placed on view at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse.
Penn State defeated Navy, 17 to 9, in the Midshipmen's closing wrestling match today. Penn State won a fall and four decisions and Navy three decisions.
Mrs. Merle Waymire of Independence, looking over a second-hand dresser she had just bought at auction for $2.50, tugged at a drawer and could not open it.

FOUR factors which helped Arturo Toscanini in deciding to return to New York next season to lead another series of concerts were 6,437 letters from the radio audience, the ovations of the studio audience, 50,000 requests for studio tickets and the excellence of transmission.

BARRETT-GOLDSTEIN--Mr. and Mrs. Harry Goldstein of 75 East 22st St., Brooklyn, announce the marrage of their daughter, Ruth, on March 5, 1938, to Matthew I. Barrett of Pottsville, Pa., son of Mrs. Charles H. Bernstein and the late Charles H. Bernstein.

THERE is probably little if any material relating to John Keats which has not already been brought to light. In "Adonais" Dorothy Hewlett prints some early writings of his not before published and some unpublished verses by the poet's friends, Bailey, Rice and Reynolds.

A committee of 1,142 members, representative of all walks of community life, to sponsor the Greater New York Fund, Inc., formed to increase the effectiveness and supplement the finances of the city's private health and welfare agencies, was announced yesterday by Winthrop Rockefeller, executive vice chairman.

The three five-story tenement houses at 316-18 East Eighty-sixth Street, on a plot 60 by 102.2 feet, near Second Avenue, will be sold at auction Wednesday in the Vesey Street salesroom, by B. Hollander Son.

The only evening performance this season of Wagner's consecrational festival play, "Parsifal," by the Metropolitan Opera Company has been taken over for the benefit of the Music School of , the Henry Street Settlement.

EDDIE DOWLING is assembling units for his coming series of one-acters, with Item A pretty definitely Sean O'Casey's "The End of the Beginning." A rustic comedy of forty minutes in running time and with an Irish background, this one may have (at least, so Mr. Dowling hopes) the acting services of Barry Fitzgerald.

After sixty-two years of almost constant student increase the Johns Hopkins University has adopted a policy of limitation in the undergraduate departments, with a limit of about 500 in the College of Arts and Sciences, and 500 in the School of Engineering and the School of Business Economics together.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, March 5-A group of American archaeologists from the Chicago Institute of Persian Art has chartered a Douglas plane with a Netherlands crew from the Royal Dutch Airways for a flight over Iraq and Persia about March 15. The excursion, to be made at the invitation of. James Cromwell, will be conducted by Professor Arthur Upham Pope.

The third annual exhibition of children's art entitled "Young America Paints" was opened yesterday morning in the International Building of Rochefeller Center. It includes more than 1,100 pictures by children from kindergarten to high school ages.

Miss Marjorie Wainwright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Wainwright of this city, was married to Charles W. Varney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Varney of Rochester, N. H., yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Dr. George S. Brookes, pastor of Union Congregational Church.

TWO rural Scouts of New York recently won the ?oveted American Agriculturist Achievement Award medal-popularly known as the "4-A Award." Governor Lehman presented the medals to Eagle Scouts Lee Franklin Phillips of Troop 22, Newfane, and

EVER since the first rugs from Turkey and Persia were brought into Europe back in the sixteenth-century days of Queen Elizabeth. Near Eastern art has had a strong influence on European and American decoration.

A central planning board to coordinate Federal, State and city programs on unemployment and relief was proposed yesterday by Councilman Louis Hollander, spokesman on relief matters for the Fusion-Labor bloc in the City Council.

THERE has emerged lately a volume of collecting lore by one of the lay brethren in the fraternity of bibliophiles, Winslow L. Webber. The book, entitled. "Books About Books," was published by Hale. Cushman Flint of Boston at $2.50 a copy.

Now, when garden planning is in the air-and on paper-the experienced flower lover takes care to provide a special plot for blooms for cutting. The plot for a cutting garden need not be extensive. In a space no larger than 10 by 20 feet one can produce an astonishing amount of cutting material.

The Hershey Bears tonight defeated the New York Rovers, 4 to 3, before 7,500 in an Eastern Hockey League game. Each team scored a goal in the opening session. Blinco, on a pass from Kawalski, added another for Hershey in the second.
ALISCH-Mr. and Mrs. Emil, announce birth of a daughter, March 3, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital. BALDWIN--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T., announce birth of a son, March 1, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital.

The City Council committee investigating the charge that Councilman Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d of Manhattan is a resident of Mount Kisco completed its hearings yesterday and announced it will report to the Council on Tuesday.

Mrs. Dorothy Davidson Dupont, wife of Pierre Dupont, French vice consul in New York, died on Wednesday at the French Hospital after an illness of three months. She was 32 years old and lived at 5 Dartmouth Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

In the most exciting game of the season in Metropolitan League play, the Squadron A riders defeated the leading Evergreen Farms team, 14 to 13, and practically assured them selves of a place in the indoor pol?? play-off. It required three minutes of an extra "sudden death" period for the Squadron to work the up set.

W. R. Grace Co. announced yesterday the 1938 awards of six engineering scholarships given annually by the company as an exchange of American and South American ideas and to further understanding between the two continents.

That a healthy market exists for small repossessed homes in the metropolitan area is indicated by the sales record of the Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association for the year ending Feb. 28, last, reports George E. Palmer, secretary-manager.

Sale of the Louis R. Page estate of more than thirty-four acres at Bryn Mawr, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia, to Graeme Lorimer of Fox Chase, Pa., was reported yesterday by Previews, Inc. Mears Brown of Philadelphia were the brokers.

The following Foreign Service changes since Feb. 25 were announced by the State Department today: Troy L. Perkins of Lexington, Ky., language officer at Peiping, China, hAS been designated third secretary of the embassy there.

Officials of the New Jersey Home Show to be held in Newark, March 19 to 26, announce that a duplicate of the model home to be erected on the floor of the 113th Regiment Armory will be constructed in the Ridgeview home - community at New Providence under development by Harry J. Stevens.

A brusque disregard for the social amenities of East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, brought to a close Friday night the extra-legal career of John Shumsky, a young boxer who said he had eked out his earnings of the last two years by committing about a dozen robberies. Up to Friday night, he had managed to avoid interfering with the social lives of his victims.
Dr. Richard Archbold, scientist of the American Museum of Natural History of New York, completed today a round-trip flight to St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, to test his $250,000 flying laboratory.

That New Yorkers are taking increasing interest in recording the city's history is evidenced by gifts in 1937 of 9,130 objects to the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets.
Republican Congressional prospects are showing sharp improvement. With the November elections eight months away, the trend of public opinion continues to show a decline in Democratic party strength.

Corliss Lamont, chairman of the American Friends of the Soviet Union, charged yesterday that the Dewey commission, which recently requested postponement of the current trial in Moscow, had "abandoned even the pretense of impartiality" and had become "a mouthpiece" for the Trotskyists in this country.

A costume Mi-Careme supper dance will be-given by the BeauxArts Institute of Design on March 24 at the institute building, 304 East Forty-fourth Street, for the benefit of the organization's educational work.
Westchester County will pay tribute to Miss Jane H. Todd, the only woman member of the State Assembly, at a testimonial dinner arranged for Wednesday at 7 P. M. at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Congress created the Tennessee Valley Authority, now publicly engaged in a long-suppressed feud among its three directors. Congress also created the Federal Trade Commission, which-ever since the President sought to dismiss the late Commissioner Humphrey because his mind "did not go along"-has given Mr. Roosevelt no trouble of any kind.

The Atlas-Liberty and SunshineRadio Taxicab Owners Associations, composed of fifty independent fleet operators, withdrew from service yesterday most of the 4,000 cabs controlled by the two groups and locked out nearly all the 6,000 men who drove them.

The long-anticipated initiative petition to incorporate Oregon's labor unions appeared this week as police and Shariffs neared the completion of one of the most extensive roundups of alleged labor racketeers ever to take place in the Far West.

Dr. John Dewey, from whose theories the progressive education movement took form, last week restated his philosophy under the title "Experience and Education" in the annual lecture given for the honorary educational fraternity, Kappa Delta Pi.

Little if any cessation in demand for farms, country homes and acreage tracts in the western section of Connecticut has been noticed as a result of the recent decline in business prosperity, declares Donald M. Joseph, president of the Danbury realty firm bearing his name.

BROADCASTING a strong wave from lands near the Finland Gulf, Estonia, which on Feb. 24 celebrated its twentieth anniversary as an independent State, now joins the ranks of the sixty-odd nations assembled on radio's short waves.
A sports carnival featured by basketball victories over Lehigh by the varsity and freshman teams, provided entertainment for the annual Dads' Day at Lafayette College today.

Formal claim has been asserted by President Roosevelt for the United States to sovereignty over Canton and Enderbury Islands in the Central. Pacific Ocean and to lands first visited by Americans in the Antarctic Continent.
Representatives from seventeen colleges of the Middle Atlantic States will meet at Rosemont College Saturday for the first Catholic Student Peace Federation.

TURN to the "help-wanted" columns of any newspaper in any large city and the eye falls upon advertisements like these: Young man, exp'd retail automobile, tire, battery and ignition shop. Capable taking charge, do selling; steady position. Z 2435, Gazette Office.
The New York State Labor Relations Board, in the first eight months of its existence, settled about sixty strikes involving 5,000 workers, the board reports.

ALTHOUGH card players dislike noting so much as a suggested change in the standard change in the standard deck of playing cards, the unusual publicity accorded to the "five-suit" deck recently intorduced has forced them to take notice.

The following is the chart showing how the Santa Anita Handicap was run today: SIXTH RACE--The Santa Anita Handicap; $100,000 added; 3-year-olds and upward; one mile and a quarter (out of chute).Start 'good; won driving; place same. Went to post 4:33, off 4:36. Winner.xb. c. 3, -by Sickle-Stagecraft. Trainer, MEarl Sande. Net values to winner, $91,450; second, $20,000; third,- $10000; fourth, $5,000. Time--0:224/5, 0:461/3, 1:111/3, 1:364/3.4/5 2:013/5 (new track record). Weather clear; track fast.
Manhattanville's basketball team turned back the visiting girls' sextet from William and Mary College of Williamsburg, Va., by a 34-to-22 score at the Benziger Gymnasium yesterday.

One of the marvels of American education has been the enormous growth of the college population, which has multiplied itself about eight times since the turn of the century. Depressions tend to slow down the rate of expansion, prosperity to hasten it, but there is no sign that the end is in sight.
Rate's hockey team, fighting an uphill battle most of the way, gained a sweet victory over Harvard tonight in the Garden to tie their annual series at one game each. The score was 3 to 2.

The Blair Academy quintet, holder of the Eastern Private Schools League title, suffered its second league defeat of the season at the hands of Horace Mann today, 38 to 25. The visitors, led by Hasslinger, easily overcame an early Blair lead in the second quarter.
Applications are invited for the post of GENERAL MANAGER of the Irish National air transport company, Aer-Rianta, Teoranta, and its subsidiaries.

Record-breaking crowds ??aw three famous clubs go into the ??emi-final for the English Football ??up today. Sunderland, the cup ??older, Preston North End and Ason Villa were the successful teams n the sixth round. York City and Huddersfield will replay a scoreless draw next week.

Syracuse and Columbia will resume their traditional football rivalry in 1940, following a oneyear lapse in 1939, Lewis P. Andreas, Syracuse's director of athletics, announced today. The 1940 date will be Oct. 26 at Baker Field, New York City.
The impact of the business recession on organized labor has raised two important questions, one dealing with immediate "bread and butter" issues and the other with long-range policy.

Commenting on the recent announcement by the Gramatan National Bank and Trust Company of Bronxville that it would grant 90 per cent loans on small homes under the new FHA insured mortgage regulations, Thomas G. Grace, State FHA director, said yesterday that this action will be of great importance for Westchester County.

The Royal Military College of Kingston, Ontario, the Canadian "West Point," defeated Army at hockey tonight, 1 to 0. Two thousand spectators, a capacity crowd, witnessed the game. It was the final of the season for the losers. Although the play of both teams was hard all the way, there were no penalties.

Miss Barbara Anne Carrington, daughter of Mrs. Ellsworth Torrey Carrington of this city and the late Mr. Carrington, has chosen the afternoon of April 22 for her marriage to Robert H. Halsey Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert H. Halsey of New York and Derby, Vt.
Purdue won outright possession of the Western Conference basketball championship for 1938 tonight, defeating Northwestern, 42 to 39, to end the season with a record of ten victories and two losses.

Holding a special meeting today for the purpose, the French Parliament passed a bill creating a special extrabudgetary investment fund for national defense. By this bill the government aims to finance the supplementary armament expenditures that are considered necessary in view of the international armaments race.
The German people are living through anxious days, in which decisive events in Europe chase one another, knowing little of what is going on but suspecting everything.

The "third-basket" provision of the new tax bill will fall heavily on many stores which have been developed and owned as a family business, with the profits left in the business from year to year, it waS reported in retail circles yesterday.

PARIS AFRENCH fashion expert recently remarked upon the "baroque variety" displayed by the new Paris Summer fashions. This is an apt description, for 1938 does seem to be the beginning of a new baroque period.

United States Consul General Clarence E. Gauss protested to Japanese Army authorities today against the action of a Japanese sentry in striking Miss Grace Brady, teacher at St. Mary's Hail Episcopal School.

The marriage of Miss Elsie Louise Luker of this city, formerly of Brookline, Mass., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William J. Luker, to Dow H. Drukker of Passaic, N. J., took place here yesterday morning in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr.

Formation of a Webb-Pomerene act corporation through which American exporters could agree upon contract terms for deliveries, performance guarantees and other provisions, exclusive of prices, in sales to the Soviet Government was advanced here last week by export authorities as a means of meeting problems growing out of current transactions with Russia.

VLADIMIR KOUDREY was an unusual sort of young man to find himself in the position of a commissar in the early days of the Bolshevik revolution. He came of a good family, was cultured, and he planned to work in the theatre, for which he had a passion.
Bill Lloyd and Howard Vocke teamed in the last two minutes of play to give St. John's University a brilliant 31-28 basketball victory over Villanova College before 2,000 fans tonight.
THINGS were pretty bad in eighteen-century London: and the word "things" must be understood to include almost every province of life.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 2 aggregated $8,572,000,000, or 46 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week, which included only five business days,

A testimonial dinner for Dr. Walter Damrosch will be given tonight at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, under the auspices of the arts committee of the organization. Besides the guest of honor speakers will include Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the College of the City of New York; Dr. John Erskine, Otis Skinner, Dr. John H. Finley and George Blumenthal.

Columbia's swimming team defeated Cornell, 48-27, in the Morningside pool yesterday for its third consecutive victory. The light-Blue mermen won seven of nine events, Cornell breaking through in. the 50-yard free style and the 400-yard relay.
A new series of entertainments entitled the "Magic Dances" will be .-inaugurated by H. G. Clay Hill and a committee of younger members of society on April 22 at the Wellington.
AN aloof, long-faced young Englishman sat in the News room of THE NEW YORK TIMES. His work was over for the night and he was ruminating, completely detached from his surroundings.
PARIS. THIS city of museums is soon to have another. Next month visitors may see the folk art of many nations at the Musee de l'Homme, in a wing of the rebuilt Palais de Trocadero. A few halls
