Gifts and bequests totalling $1,066,605.37, including $943,252.09 for endowment, were received by Princeton University during the sixmonths' period from May 31, 1937 to Nov. 30, 1937, Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university reported today.
CANADA is in the process of building a broadcasting system that loyally adheres to the slogan, "Canada for Canadians."
Sammy, a six-ton Indian elephant, was put to -death at the zoo here today by seven shots from two rifles. "He was just too mean to live," said John T. Miller, director of the Zoological Park.
ONE of philately's most attractive miniature sheets is Belgium's "special" released on the recent anniversary of the death of King Albert I. It is a 2.45 plus 7.55 franc brown-violet.
In the United States Court of Claims today the following calendar for Monday, March 7, was announced:

Nikolai I. Bukharin, former member of the Communist Political Bureau, who after the assassination of Sergei Kiroff In 1934 demanded in a bloodthirsty editorial in Izvestia the destruction of all concerned in that crime, was called for the first time tonight as a direct witness in the treason trial of twenty-one men.

New York University's fencing team, last year's intercollegiate three-weapon champion, narrowly averted its first defeat in six starts this season by breaking even with Columbia, 13 1/2--13 1/2, on the Violet's strips at the Washington Square center yesterday.

Trinity College, presenting another in the series of organ recitals to show the history of the composition of organ music, under the direction of Clarence E. Watters, organist and Assistant Professor of Music, will illustrate the works of four modern French organ composers.

The drive of the National Association of Credit Men to raise $400,000 for its educational campaign has passed the 65 per cent mark, according to a report last week by the association. This total has been reached, despite the fact that some of the local associations have not, as yet, gotten their campaigns fully under way.

This city has been terrorized by seven Rebel air raids and one attempted raid in the last twenty-four hours. One of the three bombing attacks carried out this evening is in progress as these lines are being written by candle light.

New York A. C. wrestlers swept six of the eight individual championships and retained the team title last night as the Metropolitan A. A. U. championship tournament was completed in the Winged Foot gymnasium.

Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow Celanese Corp. of America. Endicott-Johnson Corp. Internatl. Nickel Co. of Canada. Lambert Co.
Sir James MacBrien, Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, died here tonight after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

"Immortality, Ltd," a comedy relating to the enrollment quandaries of Middlewest Paradise College, was tonight presented by the Yale Department of Drama at the University Theatre, directed by Elizabeth Winslow Stearns, for the last two Summers producer, manager, director and actress with the Lake Placid Players.

Despite the current clamor on tne part of small business men for loans, in the last half year only about twenty-five applications a month have been received by the Federal Reserve Banks, which in the last three and a half years have loaned more than $150,000,000 to industry, William H. Pouch, president of the Concrete Steel Company and chairman of the advisory committee on loans in this district, reported yesterday.

Pushing over a grueling, hazardous course with the stamina that already has won him national recognition, Dartmouth College's Warren Chivers today won the eighteenkilometer cross-country ski run at this hill city's annual Winter Carnival.

Led by the hard-hitting F. Skiddy Von Stade Jr., Harvard's indoor polo trio routed Yale, 13 to 5, tonight. The Crimson tallied at least three times in each period and never was headed, getting off to a 4-0 lead in the opening chukker.

Glenn Cunningham, now the world's fastest miler in fact as well as in name, will essay a new distance Saturday when he races against Jim Herbert of New York University in the classic Casey 600 that will feature the annual Knights of Columbus carnival at Madison Square Garden.

Mr. and Mrs. Fred P. Rankin of Clifton Park, Lakewood, have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Mary Jane Rankin, to Richard Noel Statham of Cleveland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Noel Statham of Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y.

BECAUSE of letters which I received since Mr. Henry Hazlitt's review of my book, "The Folklore of Capitalism," it would be most convenient if I could print a brief restatement of certain of my own attitudes which Mr. Hazlitt has misinterpreted in his review.

Recommendations for rehabilitating old-law tenements in this city will be submitted tomorrow for public discussion at the first of a series of meetings to be held at the Town Hall Club by the Citizens Housing Council, a group representing leading real estate interests, savings banks, builders and civic organizations. They are contained in a ten-

Every month or so a report comes Dut of Russia to tell the world of triumphal Soviet progress in using the preserved blood of suicides and victims of accidents for emergency transfusions. Always there is the implication that the Soviet physicians were the first to think of canning blood and taking it out of the refrigerator when needed.

The executive committee of the Popular Front comprising all Leftist groups, today passed a resolution to urge the cooperation of all Leftist associations in Latin America to create an international union to "support democracy."
Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt left yesterday for Miami, Fla., where she will join Brig. Gen. Vanderbilt aboard their yacht, Winchester. Lord and Lady Glenconner of London are at the Savoy-Plaza.

The Anchor Line announced yesterday that it had leased the new city-owned pier at West Tenth Street and would occupy it on March 15. The line operates five passenger and freight ships between New York, Boston and Belfast, Cobh, Dublin and Londonderry.

Representatives of real estate boards, banks, civic organizatians and educational institutions throughout the State, together with several State officials friendly to the measure, will attend the hearing in Albany Wednesday on the Mortgage Banks Bill.

Smith College girls from all four classes and their escorts attended the annual Smith College supper dance, held simultaneously last night in twenty-six campus houses. This dance, which drew a crowd of nearly 3,000 is one of the three chief such events of the year. It differs from the charity ball and junior promenade in that supper and dancing are held in the individual houses.
The supreme paradox in the Moscow state trials of the last two years has, to do not with persons but with Soviet

Hastening to rebuild broken highways and washed out bridges, the residents of scores of Southern California towns watched flood waters recede today and hoped the worst was over. L. H. Daingerfield, government meteorologist here, warned, however, that new storms were forming off the coast.
Mrs. Alexandra Louise Bruen Ide, widow of Rear Admiral George E. Ide, who died in 1917, died last night of a heart ailment in her home at the Plaza Hotel. She was in her eighty-fifth year.

To the Music Editor: The illuminating statement in last Sunday's TIMES on the problems of the American Composers Alliance is a big step toward their solution. For what the "serious composer" most needs is an informed public opinion. No one has acquired less
Buddy Hassett will play left field for the Dodgers in 1938 and he is arriving in camp tomorrow so that he may get a lot of practice at the job before the season opens.

Acting in behalf of various creditors, Archibald L. Jackson, attorney for the General Finance Corportion, urged Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant yesterday to permit reorganization of the United Traction Company of Albany.
A stirring and well-balanced performance of Wagner's "Die Walkuere" was given at the Metropolitan last .night as the second event in the evening "Ring" cycle.

The St. Francis College basketball team concluded its season last night by defeating Rider, 29 to 24, in the St. Francis gymnasium, Brooklyn. Lynch and O'Neil shared the scoring honors with 6 points apiece for the winners, who trailed at the half, 17-14.

Gathering-clouds in the higher altitudes and a forecast of more snow threatened today to restrict the farflung search for the airliner which vanished. in. the mountains near here Tuesday night with nine persons aboard.
Taking the first three places in both the slalom and downhill, St. Lawrence University today defeated the Hamilton and Clarkson teams to win the first intercollegiate ski meet ever staged here.

Robert Chatkin and Myron Fuchs of New York, who never before had figured in the title brackets of an Eastern bridge championship, last night won the most coveted title of the tournament, the open pairs championship, in a whirlwind finish on the last twenty-eight boards.

In 1940 the Francis Amory Septennial Prize of $10,000 will be awarded by the American Academy of Arts and Sciences of Boston "for outstanding work with reference to the alleviation or cure of diseases affecting the human genital organs."

THE United States Department of Labor has just celebrated its twenty-fifth birthday. When it was established it consisted of the bureaus of labor statistics, immigration. naturalization. and conciliation. together with a special division concerned with children.
Playing his first round on a British golf course today, United States Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy did a hole-in-one.

The stock market last week failed to follow up February's brisk advance. The downward drift of share prices was relieved only by a small rally on Tuesday, so that THE, NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks showed on the week a net decline of 2.10 points; the week before there was a net gain of 2.65 points.

SIXTH RACE-The Widener; $50,000 added; handicap; 3-year-olds and upward; one mile and a quarter. Start bad; won easily; place driving. Went to post 4:38, off 4:43. Winner, br. c., 4, by Man 0' War-Brushup. Trainer, G. Conway. Net value to winner, $49,550; second, $8,000; third, $4,000; fourth, $2,000. Time-0:23 3/5, 0:47 1/3,, 1:11 3/5, 1:37, 2:03%.

"Paris. et Nous" is the name which has been given to a fashion show of Spring styles to be held on March 22 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event, in conjunction with a luncheon, will aid the West Side Thrift Shop.

Unable to overcome a 21-13 half-time lead, Williams dropped a hardfought game to Amherat, 48-37, tonight to close seasons for both teams. Amherst broke into an early, lead when baskets by Otis- and Schweizer were followed by two field goals and a brace of fouls by Keesey, while Williams was able to tally only once.

Willoughby House Settlement In Brooklyn will be the beneficiary of a Spring party to be known as an "April Fool's Frolic," which will be held the night of April 1 at the headquarters of the organization, 97 Lawrence Street, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the junior board of the settlement.
At no time in the quarter-century of history of the International Flower Show have the numerous organizations interested made plans for it on so grand a scale.

WORLD-ART, the organization which is sponsoring the new Ballet Russe, of which Leonide Massine is the guiding spirit, is cooperating in the formation of a subsidiary body to be known as the Ballet Guild, Inc., one of the purposes of
A coroner's jury recommended today that Theodore Danielsen Jr., 16-year-old high school boy, be held for the grand jury on a charge of murder.
The National Retail Lumber Dealers Association has announced that it obtained what was said to be the first mortgage insurance commitment under the revised National Housing Act.

Members of the Bronx Better Housing Committee, of which Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx Board of Trade, was recently appointed chairman by Stewart McDonald, FHA Administrator, met for their initial meeting in the board rooms last week to discuss plans for a comprehensive residential construction and modernization program in that borough.
R. B. Bennett, in a hushed silence at the national Conservative conference this afternoon, said that he suffered a heart condition which made his continuance as party leader impossible.
COMPOSITIONS by Ernest Bloch will be given in Town Hall Saturday night under the auspices of Mailamm, with the cooperation of the Ernest Bloch Society.

Against a mere 3 per cent not dependent on their jobs or maintenance, 48 per cent of the business and professional women in the country have relatives whom they support, in whole or in part, by their earnings.

BUFFALO hunting, a vanished sport in the United States, continues to flourish in Australia.' The vast Northern Territory lists the buffalo as Public Enemy No. i, ahead of even wild pig and crocodile. The buffalo in Australia.
THROUGH the greater part of the Orient a boat is the cradle and the bier of a family, and the fascination of these craft and their masters is inevitable.
A drive in the last ten minutes during which they outscored Brown, 12-7, gave Dartmouth's basketball team a 45-40 decision over the Bears in a rough, exciting game tonight before 1,200.

Returning to mid-season form, the Syracuse basketball team defeated Colgate tonight, 46-36, with a smashing second-half offense. It was the final game for both schools and Syracuse's second victory in the traditional' home-and-home series.

"Very moving" pictures, in production, were shown tonight by the Women's National Press Club at their annual Stunt Party dinner, for the entertainment of their members and guests, headed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and including more than 300 women from all parts of the country.
WITH the coming of Lent cookbooks are being searched for methods of preparing appetizing, meatless menus. One of the best of methods derives from that old-fashioned direction. "take eggs."

Miss Elizabeth Bergen Hart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Hart of Pelham Manor, has completed plans for her marriage to Osmond Tolmie Baxter, also of Pelham Manor, which will take place the night of April 22 in the Huguenot Memorial Church, Pelham Manor.

LONDON. - President Roosevelt's pronunciation of English should set the standard for the English-speaking world, according to Professor Lloyd James, linguistic adviser to the British Broadcasting Corporation.

The Yale varsity wrestling team had too much power for the Harvard matmen in the final meet of the season for both teams today, winning by a 15-to-11 score. The Harvard freshman team battled to a draw with the Eli yearlings, 16 to 16.

Two weeks from today will mark the opening of National Wildlife Restoration Week. To many Americans it will mean "just another of those campaign weeks," but to every sportsman it should mean an opportunity to gain converts to the cause of wildlife conservation and restoration.

A hew Yale record of 1:37.8 in the 150-yard back-stroke race by Joe Burns of Yale, who broke his own mark of 1:38.2, featured a YaleNavy swimming meet tonight which the Blue captured, 51 to 24. Leading throughout, Burns easily beat Romer Good, his teammate.
General John J. Pershing's heart is growing stronger and the action is "more satisfactory," his physicians reported today.
WITH paster-of-paris molds, zinc-and-lead dies and a huge drop hammer the Ryan Aeronautical Company of San Diego last week sought to introduce the era of the "fliwerplane."

Physical skills acquired in Summer camps are a necessary supplement to public school education, Dr. Jesse F. Williams, professor of health and physical education at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday at the afternoon session of the three-day convention of the American Camping Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

An honorary Doctorate of Philosophy was conferred today on Herbert Hoover by Prague University in the presence of Foreign Minister Kamil Krofta and an assembly of prominent Czechs that included Presidents of both houses of Parliament.

A COUPLE of Sundays ago-several questions were raised in these columns apropos of the group of "Tragic Painters" at the Bignou; questions to which it may be profitable from time to time to return. How often-

WASHINGTON. - About 100,000 veterans are still eligible for World War "bonus" bonds, Veterans Administrator Hines estimates. The amount due them, if they apply, totals some $84,000,000. The law permits applications up to 1940.

A court tennis partnership that began several years ago brought the national doubles title for the fifth consecutive time to Ogden Phipps and William Rand yesterday when they defeated their two most dangerous challengers, James Van Alen and his brother, W. L., at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Pensioned On His Own Application-To take effect 12 noon.' March 16: LIEUTENANT-Michael Coughlin, 120th Precinct, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed Aug. 12, 1903. On Police Surgeon's Certificate-To take effect 12 midnight, March 5: PATROLMEN-John J. Whalen, 17th Precinct. at $2,250 per annum. Appointed May 5. 1920. H

Increased passenger and mail carriage was reported yesterday for 1937 by North American Aviation, Inc., and subsidiaries. A profit from manufacturing in 1937, in contrast to a net loss in 1936, was reported.

The new act which authorizes the expenditure of $4,000,000 to find new uses for surplus crops and timber will result in the creation of four research laboratories. In all probability one laboratory will be established in the Northeast,

More than four hundred members of the Coral Gables Winter colony are expected to attend the Mardi Gras ball at the Century Club Tuesday night. The ballroom and terraces will be decorated and the choosing and crowning of a king and queen of the Mardi Gras will climax the festivities.

MINIATURE camera owners troubled with grain when making large prints have adopted many tricks. One of the most practical methods, it is declared, is to stretch a piece of silk bolting cloth across a wood frame,

The University of Rochester basketball team brought its season to a close with its tenth straight victory tonight, defeating Hamilton College, 41 to 24, in a game featured by the scoring of Captain Bud Spies.

A legislative and relief program to meet the needs of thousands of unemployed and partly employed railroad workers was drafted yesterday morning at a conference of representatives of thirty railroad lodges, affiliated with the A. F.
A group of clubwomen will go to Hoboken on Tuesday to see laboratory tests made in determining the durability of shoes, rugs, hosiery and other materials.
FEW if any clubs have a longer waiting list for membership than the Marylebone Cricket Club in London. At present the list contains about 10,000 names.

"Carefree youth" is no longer a phrase easily to be applied to America's younger generation, according to the picture drawn by Dr. Homer P. Rainey, director of the American Youth Commission, at the convention of the American Association of School Administrators which has just closed in Atlantio City.

Plans looking to the negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement with Australia were discussed by President Roosevelt today at a conference with Cordell Hull, Secretary of State; Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, and Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State in charge of trade agreements.

Enactment of the Administration's $1,121,000,000 Naval Construction Bill will provide only a minimum of the national defense necessary to "maintain our national security and preserve our Republic," the House was told today by a majority of the members of its Committee on Naval Affairs.

ANGLO-ITALIAN relations serve as a fresh reminder of the one-man rule toward which the system of Cabinet government in Great Britain seems to be tending. In order to impose his view that the best way to keep the peace is by agreement with Italy,
Appointment instead of election of judges of the higher courts is provided in a complete draft of a proposed new State Constitution, made public yesterday by the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce.
Stocks moved listlessly and closed mixed, in lightest trading since last June; turnover, 222,000 shares. All groups of bonds irregular in dull trading; transactions.

To further the welfare of needy Russian families in this country, a committee under the chairmanship of Princess Alexis Obolensky is now arranging a dinner dance for the night. of March 17 in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Net proceeds will be donated to the Russian Nobility Association, of which Prince Alexis Obolensky is president.

Anne Milman has been elected honor board chairman and Ninetta di Benedetto has been chosen as president of the athletic association in the all-college elections at Barnard College. They will be installed on April 9.

Without any perceptible reverberations in the sky over Central Park, an irreverent question was raised here last week whether Thor, the thunder god of Scandinavian mythology, from whom Thursday takes its name, was actually a true Nordic.

A legal question that has existed in New York State since corporations first began to function here was answered Friday afternoon when the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court handed down a decision requiring corporate bodies to be represented in court by duly licensed attorneys.
Outdaring the devil on skis, a 17-year-old French lad, James Couttet nosed out his coach, the defending world champion, Emile Allais of France, in a hair-raising downhill race today.
Mrs. Harold E. Dahl, wife of the Champaign (Ill.), aviator held in Spain as a prisoner by the Insurgents, conceded tonight that he likely would be held until the end of the civil war.
BLOCK, ROSE NORRIS (Feb. 22). Estate, less than $10,000. To Juliet L. Johnstone, sister, executrix, Douglas Manor, Queens, residue; eight minor bequests.

IT'S strange how ideas upon up. A gory Gunnar Barlund made Buddy Baer say "Uncle!" in the Garden ring the other night and the thought that immediately came to mind was that a fellow named Stephen Crane once wrote a book entitled "The Red badge of Courage."

AFTER holding up fairly well since the holidays, retail trade sagged more sharply last week in many sections. This might have been due to weather conditions and the later Easter or to other special circumstances.
A slim sophomore from Missouri stole the spotlight tonight as the Nebraska Cornhuskers won their third straight Big Six indoor track and field championship with a total of 38 points.

The value of bullion produced by Ontario's gold mines in January, at $7,638,375, was the second best for a month in the Province's history, exceeded only in the previous month, when output was valued at $7,774,581. In January, 1937, production was valued at $7,120,010.

Accused of possessing ten ounces of heroin and two loaded revolvers, a prisoner who said he was William Vincent, 34 years old, of 130 Second Avenue, was held Without bail for action of the grand jury yesterday by Magistrate Aurelio in Felony Court.
LEGISLATION held the attention of the aviation industry last week with its principal interest centered in aircraft allotments proposed in the billion-dollar Naval Construction Bill. Glenn L. Martin,

Plans for the Hospital Ball, to be given by the Woman's Auxiliary of the Moore County Hospital on March 29, are rapidly taking shape. Mrs. Heman Gifford of Millbrook, chairman of the ball, announced this week the names of thirty-six members of the auxiliary who will serve as patronesses.

The New York Americans will skate against their city rivals, the Rangers, in the fifth game of the series between the teams this season at Madison Square Garden tonight. With interest in the fortunes of both sextets at a high pitch, the contest figures to attract a capacity crowd of 16,000 fans.

A well-balanced Mercersburg wrestling team, undefeated in dual meet competition, crowned five individual champions and gained the team title in the third annual academy and preparatory school championships concluded at Lehigh University today.

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity were in substantially larger volume than in the preceding period, when retirements announced were in the smallest volume for many months. The new redemptions were principally for parts of foreign and municipal issues and were for payment in future months.
Tony Mischo's all-around play helped Pennsylvania defeat Columbia in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game at the Palestra tonight, 40-33.

N. J. S. Stoney, attorney- for the Philadelphia Restaurant Association, announced today that he would appeal to the City Council to eliminate from the city sales tax ordinance provisions taxin'g restau-rant foods.

The First Division trio of J. A. Nichols, George Sherman and Warren Sackman broke a losing streak of seven games last night by defeating Squadron C, 17-12, in a Metropolitan Indoor Polo League game at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn. As a result the First Division moved into fifth place.

There has been a sudden rise lately in the number of prisoners at Rikers Island Penitentiary, according to Austin H. MacCormick, Commissioner of Correction. The institution was built to hold 2,100 persons but now has 2,700.

Labor can best solve its problems through intelligent leadership and through "a real constructive program," Mayor La Guardia told more than 800 delegates to the first annual national convention of the Jewish Labor Committee yesterday.
James Howell Post, sugar refiner, financier, philanthropist and civic leader, died yesterday in his home at 88 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, after a short illness. He was 78 years old.
The freshman class of Stevens Institute of Technology will hold its annual banquet on Tuesday night at the Roger Smith Restaurant, 40 East Forty-first Street, New York. Dr.

FAR beneath the Cornish sea, so legends tell us, lies the lost land of Lyonesse. Some say that in very calm weather, if you look deep down into the clear water you can see the tops of the church steeples of drowned cities, and that in stor their bells may be heard, tolling a requiem, perhaps, for the souls of those lost at sea.

Members of the Eastern States Council of Jewish Chaplains, an organization of rabbis who serve as religious counselors in penal institutions, characterized the rehabilitation of criminals as an community responsibility at the second annual conference of the council last week at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixtyfifth Street.

A plan for the purchase by municipalities and power districts of existing private electric facilities in a broad area surrounding the basin of the Tennessee River has been proposed to utility executives by David E. Lilienthal, a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority. He said that he had discussed the plan with President Roosevelt.

Mr. and Mrs. Efrem Zimblistannounced yesterday the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maria Virginia Zimbalist, to Ogden Goelet, son of Robert Goelet and bf Mrs. Henry Clews of Cannes, France. The wedding will take place in the near future.

SLAPSTICK comedy, the substance on which the screen was built and which nurtured an entire generation of cinemagoers, is returning in refined form to provide the current season with a substantial portion of its fare.

The First Baptist Church of Pittsfield will be one of the richest Baptist churches in the United States when it comes into possession within a few months of $380,000 bequeathed by Nelson J. Lawton of this city.
The New York A. C. and St. Nicholas Hockey Club will start on a three-game series today at the Broooklyn Ice Palace to decide the New York Amateur Hockey Association title.

The powerful Harvard varsity swimming team defeated Princeton, 52-23, in the Harvard pool tonight before a capacity gathering of 1,800. Thq victory gave Harvard undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League.

Italians are convinced that all negotiations about to be undertaken with Britain will without doubt lead to an agreement. They believe that no fundamental questions divide Italy and Britain and that all problems between the two countries can be solved without much trouble in the new atmosphere created by Anthony Eden's resignation as Foreign Secretary.

The American Federation of Labor today filed a protest with the Interstate Commerce Commission against the commission's proposed rules for regulating working hours on trucks and buses, holding that the rules were "not reasonable" and "in complete disregard" of the intent of Congress.

Williams conquered Amherst tonight, 61-14, and became Little Three swimming champion for the first time since 1934. It was the seventh victory of the season for the Purple. Tommy Creede excelled for the home team, setting a new college mark in the 50-yard free-style event. Benson of Williams broke the 150yard back-stroke record.

The marriage of Miss Laura Norton Collord, daughter of Mrs. James V. Davison of New York and of George L. Collord of Pittsburgh, to Chamberlain Hoyt Woodruff, son of Mrs. Carroll Stetson of Bronxville, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

LIKE people, animals have different personalities. Contrary to general opinion, lions are among the most cowardly of the big beasts. Any violence a lion displays results from the beast's fear that he's cornered and in danger. Tigers are much the same,

THROUGH the cooperation of the universities and colleges with the Highway Safety Commission, Connecticut will hold its first State-wide conference on highway safety at New Haven on April 4. National agencies which will par-

ALTHOUGH amateurs are listening to music, practicing the art and composing to an extent hitherto unknown in this country, the number singing and playing would be vastly increased if there were enough teachers and leaders to instruct them. So states

Cutting schedules in the coat and suit market should be planned only up until March 15 or 20, Joseph L. Dubow, executive director, advised members of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association yesterday.
Jim Howell, 205 1/4, Harlem, fought to a draw with Tiger Jack Fox, 180 1/2, Spokane, in the ten-round feature engagement at the Rockland Palace last night before 3,000 fans.

REGULARLY at this season of the year Albany responds to a new tempo of activity in the group of buildings on the hill which looks down on the city's main business section. The Legislature is in session. Throughout the year there is activity at the Education Building, of Grecian lines, off to the left of the group on "the Hill";

The Blizzard Men of 1888, an organization of survivors of New York City's most severe snowstorm, will hold the fiftieth anniversary reunion luncheon on Saturday in the grand ballroom of the Hotel the Hotel Pennsylvania. Personal experiences will be narrated by survivors of the great storm.

A LONG, luxurious trip in a fast ship is the newest note in the Winter cruise. Details of the Rex's and the Normandie's recent voyages are fresh in the news, as the Aquitania, third of the big transatlantic, liners to turn South this Winter, reaches Rio de Jaueiro this morning.

A strong finish gave Irving School a 43-to-34 victory over Poly Prep in an Eastern Private Schools Basketball League contest on the losers' court in Brooklyn yesterday. Trailing, 23-14, at the intermission, Irving pulled the game out of the fire with a second-half rally.

A NOVEL and thus far successful bidder for the cabaretgoer's cash has emerged in the establishment of Le Ruban Bleu, at 4 East Fifty-sixth Street, where Herbert Jacoby has quietly violated night lite convention by giving the town a retreat with a Continental flavor that is Continental and not press agent malarkey. There's no dance orchestra, a carpet covers what might be a dance floor and two candlesticks provide the central lighting motif.
Louis J. Reilly, managing editor of The Bridgeport Post and Telegram and one of the best known newspaper men in Connecticut, died of a heart attack today in his home here at the age of 48.

About a year ago Dr. Volney C. Wilson of the University of Chicago attracted attention by reporting the results of his experiments with cosmic rays deep down in a copper mine at Mohawk, Mich. His- instrument responded to the rays at a depth of 1,106.7 meters (3,630 feet), which is equivalent to 2,220 meters (7,812 feet) of water.

The importance of music in the life of Vassar College is emphasized by the department in its enrollment totals, its listing of extra-curricular musical organizations and the schedule of concerts given on the campus.

Harvard University alumni here, as well as their families and friends, are looking forward to the annual. New York presentation of the Hasty Pudding Club show, which will take place on the night of April 8 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

George Howe, president of George Howe, Inc. considers the most important influence of last year on real estate in Westcheste` County and near-by Connecticut the placing in operation of the. West Side express highway in New York City.
The twentythird annual all-breed show of the Detroit Kennel Club opened today at Convention Hall with an entry of 973 dogs. Despite inclement weather a large crowd witnessed the competition.

A dinner and evening of songs will be held on March 17 at the Roosevelt to pay tribute to Lorenzo Camilieri, conductor of the People's Chorus of New York, Inc. The event has been arranged in an effort to show how the group was first organized by Mr. Camilieri and has been carried on under his direction for more than twenty years.
Pennsylvania's 12,000 organized hosiery workers in the Reading area today had their wages put on a "parity" with Philadelphia workers by an arbitration decision.
THE book which Isak Dinesen has made from her life on an African farm is a suprising piece of writing to come from the author of "Seven Gothic Tales."

Mrs. Lewis Sanders of New York and Mrs. Charles D. Thomas of Hempstead are candidates for State president of the Daughters of the British Empire, to be presented at the annual State meeting of the society Wednesday at the Hotel Biltmore.
Inspired by the little business men's conference recently in Washington, seventy of Rochester's little business men were banded together today in a permanent organization.

Some eight years ago, in the WestInghouse laboratories at Bloomfield, N. J., Dr. Harvey C. Rentschler, director of research, developed a simple device for quantitatively measuring the bands in the ultraviolet spectrum, particularly those with germ-killing properties.
John Johnson and I returned to camp yesterday after spending eight days on the ice in Kane Basin and Smith Sound in an attempt to reach Ellesmere Land, Canada, to lay out an airplane landing field.

If the junior college movement is to have a "unique and highly significant role" in American education its central problem should be "adaptation of the materials of general education to the mass mind," according to Professor William C. Bagley of Teachers College, Columbia University.

About this time of year the tailors, smelling Spring in the air, announce hopefully that they are going to give their men customers a little more color and variety. That there has been some drift in this direction, even the most conservative cannot deny.

MONTREAL, Que.-One of the most strenuous ski competitions, a fifty-kilometer crosscountry race, will be held next Sunday in the Laurentian Mountains over a thirty-one-mile course from Ste. Agathe to St. Sauveur.

Spring--and the flower shows These two terms, during the last decade, have come to be almost synonymous. It is impossible to think of one without the other. For gardeners the country over the new year starts with the flower shows.

Frank Falkowski was richer by $5 today after pleading guilty to a charge of petit larceny. Arraigned before Judge Charles T. Yeager on the charge of stealing one dollar's worth of coal in a railroad yard, Falkoski said:

An intercollegiate symposium on Spain will be held at the College of New Rochelle tomorrow evening under the auspices of the college sodality, of which Miss Frances Sanchez of Staten Island is president.

AT the public hearing on the Administration's billion-dollar Naval Construction Bill at Washington recently, Rear Admiral Cook, chief of the Naval Bureau of Aeronautics, was called upon to testify as to the source of supply of our military airplane engines. Adroitly questioned by Rep-

New York's "Cellar Clubs," Tres Bons Amis, Chicquettes, Blue Heaven, Dew Droppettes and thousands of others, once the butt of police attacks, are rising from their lowly estate and organizing into neighborhood federations.
Close of racing at Hialeah Park today was featured by many luncheon and box parties. Joseph E. Widener, president of the Miami Jockey Club, was host this afternoon to a large party.
More than seventy-five Barnard College freshmen and their escorts attended the annual Freshman Dance at the Casa Italiana last night.
Max Baer, who by his own admission is a changed man, will seek to re-establish himself in the front rank of contenders for the world's heavyweight championship on Friday night.

The narcissus show of the Garden Club of Virginia, sponsored by the Garden Club of Alexandria, will be held in the armory here April 20-21 and will take the form of a memorial to Mrs. Floyd Harris, who died a few months ago.

THAT ubiquitous American institution, the used car, has become the problem child of the automobile industry. The problem arises from its very numbers and from its influence upon the production and sale of new cars.

Professor Edwin G. Conklin, biologist, of Princeton University, will speak at the Founders' Day celebration Saturday, when RandolphMacon Woman's College dedicates its new Fernando Wood Martin Science Building.

AN owl drowsing in the cool shade of a tree on a Missouri farm one afterLnoon thirty years ago influenced the career of a man and helped fashion the fantasy of an era. Blinking in the uncomfortable light, the bird felt hands encircling it.
NASSAU, Bahamas.-The finals of the round robin tennis matches on the British Colonial courts will be held today, with Charles Harris of Palm Beach, ranking amateur No. 15;

Municipalities in the metropolitan area, whose sewage sludge is dumped at sea, face a sharp increase in barging costs as a result of new navy regulations providing that after April 1 the dumping spot must be at least twenty miles southeast of Scotland Lightship.
Legislation granting President Roosevelt's reqeust for power to veto individual items in appropriation bills was refused today by a Senate-House conference committee.

The student-managed social service committee at Barnard College reported a new high record for student volunteers and placements in social service work this term. Out of fifty-nine undergraduates who applied for positions, forty-three got volunteer jobs with hospitals, settlement houses and charitable organizations and it is expected that the rest will be placed before the end of the month, Beatrice Wise, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday.
USED car exchange week is under way - a concerted drive by manufacturers and dealers to break the gain that has been slowing all business.

The post of Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Anti-Trust Division, vacated today by Robert H. Jackson when he took the oath as Solicitor General, was offered by Attorney General Cummings to Professor Thurman W. Arnold of Yale University.
James Harvey Gray, test pilot for Curtiss-Wright, crashed while landing at the military airfield at Mendoza this afternoon. He escaped uninjured but the plane was badly damaged.

Public figures of the city, State and nation, from President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia down were the subjects of satire in song and dialogue before 1,200 public officials, politicians and other prominent guests at the annual stunt dinner of the Inner Circle last night in the Waldort-Astoria.

Designed for mothers interested in guiding the development of their children during the early formative years, two new courses entitled "The First Six Years" and "Story Telling" will be added to the program of non-credit courses for women recently instituted by the New York University Division of General Education, it was announced yesterday.
THE final fortnight of opera at the Metropolitan will open with "Goetterdaemmerung," given for the second time this season, tomorrow night.

Merrill P. Northington, vice president and director of McKesson Robbins, Inc., died at his home here toddy after a long illness. His age was 62. He had been in the wholesale drug business in Birmingham more than twenty years.

The extra-curricular activities that have sprouted at Harvard recently from undergraduate interest in the social sciences were increased this week by the organization of the Harvard Congress, modeled along the lines of the Oxford Union and the Yale Political Union.

While a fourth victim died yesterday as a result of the explosion Friday afternoon in the Horton Pilsener Brewing Company that rocked a section of Harlem, caused widespread damage and brought injuries to sixteen other persons, Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy reported to Commissioner McElligott he had definitely established that the blast was caused by the ignition of pitch fuel dust by a spark.
THE chances are that a good many book buyers will be asking for this title within the next few weeks. When they do they should pronounce the last word Ak-wy-la.

Indiana and Notre Dame furnished he record-breaking thrills. and Bill lcLane of Southeastern Missouri teacherss came up with the big inividual job tonight as the Illinois elay carnival, dormant these past even years. was revived.

Realistic "journeys" of exploration to the North and South Poles will be portrayed through March at the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History. The planetarium chamber has virtually become the cabin of a gigantic airliner which, at the speed of 5,000 miles a minute, transports spectators to the North Pole.

The condition of the real estate market during 1938 will depend to a large extent upon the attitude taken by government toward business in general, -states J. H. N. Potter, president of Pottr. Hamilton Co.
Andover Academy and Exeter Academy each won one event today, with Andover's basketball team dropping a hard-fought game, 2825, and the Andover track team running off with a 50-31 victory.

We have made just over three thousand miles in flight from Aklavik during our search of the Alaskan mountains for Sigismund Levanevsky. The mountains from Long. 141 degrees to 154 degrees W. have been covered without revealing a sign of the missing plane.

An attempt to extort $5,000 from an American, Nicolas Huff, owner of the Palo Bonito farm near Santo Domingo, in Santa Clara Province, resulted in the death of Pablo Chinea, a Haitian Negro late last night.

Miss Elise Pumpelly Gregg, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. James Edgar Gregg of Waterbury, has chosen Miss Mary R. Heard of Cambridge, Mass., as maid of honor for her wedding March 19 at the First Congregational Church to Dr. Emir Allen Gaw of Columbus, Ohio.

Mrs. Henry W. Taft, honorary president of the Catholic Center for the Blind, will give a tea on Thursday at her home, 300 Park Avenue, for officers and directors of the organization. At this time plans will be discussed for the performance of "Bachelor Born" on April 20, which has been taken over in behalf of the center.

Two hundred debutantes will act as maids of honor to the Duchess of Gloucester when she performs the annual ceremony of cutting the huge birthday cake at the Queen Charlotte hospital ball in Grosvenor House on May 9.

VAIN would be the average young lady who became incensed over approving comment of her underpinnings but, in the case of Kitty Carlisle, even such an arch partisan of feminine limbs as a ship news photographer might acknowledge that her indignation was material and relevant and with the weight of evidence.
His two-year penitentiary term for racketeering in the fresh water fish industry still unfinished, Joe (Socks) Lanza, one-time gangster boss, will begin a vacation from prison tomorrow.

The Rev. Martin Niemoeller's trial, his sentence this week, his release and his immediate rearrest and internment in Sachsenhausen concentration camp presented a remarkable study in miniature of the present state of affairs in the Third Reich.

Glenn Cunningham, hailed as "the world's fastest miler," came from behind tonight to win the Governor's Mile before 5,000 spectators at the University of Maryland-Fifth Regiment indoor games and remain unbeaten this season.

It was learned here today that King George and Queen Elizabeth of England will pay The Netherlands an official visit. The date has not been announced officially, but it is understood the King and Queen will come here after the celebration in August of Queen Wilhelmina's forty years on the throne.

The Rev. Francis W. O'Hara, teacher of Latin and Greek at Fordham Preparatory School, died in St. Francis Hospital, Miami Beach, Fla., early yesterday. He left New York three weeks ago suffering from a heart ailment. He was 47 years old.

The cost of operating West Side apartment houses is higher at this time than it was a year ago, due chiefly to higher wages for building employes and the rise in the tax rate, points out Frederick A. Wyckoff, president of Wood, Dolson Company, Inc., managing many apartment buildings.

DETROIT. MOVING forward in a nationwide drive, the automotive industry and its 46,000 dealers this week are making a concerted attempt to move its heavy stocks of used cars and clear the way for an expected Spring pickup in new-car sales. This effort

A Nazi decree today forbade brewing of bock beer, porter and other very heavy beers except for export. The object of the order was to conserve barley to feed livestock. Beer sellers were permitted to serve present supplies until they are exhausted.

The foreign exchange market found little business to contract today and movements consequently were small, although mostly against sterling. There was some demand for dollars, which improved to $5.01% to the pound. The franc also closed slightly stronger at 153 31-32 to the pound.

LONDON. THE reviewing of books raises many ethical problems. An unusual one has just comne to the front through the refusal of Charles Grey Grey, founder and editor of The Aeroplane, to review Amelia Earhart's "Last Flight" in that journal.

Nearly 2,500 young journalists, representing school publications in twenty-five States, will arrive in New York this week to participate in the fourteenth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association. The three-day convention will open Thursday at Columbia University.

Pablo Mendoza, 55 years old, of Chacraseca, a small town twenty miles from Leon, walked into the office of an attorney in Leon and said: "I am well, but since the day before yesterday I have had a premonition that I am going to die and I wish to arrange my affairs. I eat and sleep well.
Modernization under Title I of the National Housing Act is speeding up, according to A..R. Herske, vice president and general manager of sales for the American Radiator Company.
Mars Shield, classy 4-year-old filly from the Milky Way Farms of Mrs. Ethel V. Mars, triumphed by a head in the Memphis Day Handicap that featured the racing at Oaklawn Park today.

A trucking company performing pickup and delivery service under an exclusive contract with a railroad and not engaged in other trucking activities is to be regulated under Part I of the Interstate Commerce Act as- a railroad service and not under the Motor Carrier Act, the Interstate Commerce Commission held today in a divided decision.

In a two-hour, thirty-nine-game duel, Mme. Sylvia Henrotin of France defeated Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of Stamford, Conn., in the final of the Bermudiana Hotel's fourth annual tennis tournament today. The score was 3-6, 10-8, 7-5.

IF you are looking for the glossiest disk and the most modern production, then leave us as we enter a certain small room down in the Thirties, and Mr. N. Seltsam of Bridgeport, Conn., who founded the Record Collectors' Club in 1932, fishes out records of a bygone period, as another host might reveal a bottle of golden wine, and invites us to listen.

Whatever else may be said about the revenue bill for 1938, it misses by a wide margin meeting the demands of American business and industry as those views have been presented in hearings before the Ways and Means Committee,

IN this little volume the author of "Mother India" tells, with great literary art, one of the most emotionally appealing stories of the Revolutionary War, adds a footnote to history buttressed by exhaustive research in two continents, and exhibits George Washington struggling in the toils of his greatest and well-nigh his only error of judgment and of character-an error hitherto denied or ignored by biographers.
A large gathering attended tonight's gypsy carnival at Whitehall where Beatrice Lillie, who is there for several days with Mrs.. Robert Ames of New York, appeared.

A woman's auxiliary of the Stamford Museum, Stamford, Conn., which charter members have joined will be formally organized tomorrow morning at a meeting in the museum when officers will be elected. The new group will raise funds and stimulate interest in the institution.

Grocery .manufacturers checked reports of sharp sales gains here yesterday in an attempt to get an accurate gauge of the effectiveness of the special "National Brands Week" promotions concluded by retail grocers yesterday. Official figures regarding the effectiveness of the sales will not be available for some time.
THE British Government's second mammoth effort to come to the aid of the native film industry was presented to the House of Commons for final pas sage this week amid -a deafening absence of applause.

The New England Journal of Medicine reported today that 100 thin men and women, suffering from malnutrition, showed striking improvement through the use of insulin, gaining immediately in weight and appetite.

THE television transmitter of the National Broadcasting Company atop the Empire State Building is expected t, be back on the air for a few hours test this week, after several month. of silence while the apparatus wa overhauled.

Roy A. Cheney, managing director of the Underwear Institute, will hold a preliminary conference with officials of the Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday and Thursday preparatory to a public hearing on proposals for trade practice rules for the underwear industry.
TINY islands in the Pacific, many of them uninhabited and most of them forgotten except by the map makers, have recently assumed international importance. For some time

Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Borough President, acknowledged publicly yesterday the receipt of hundreds of letters from college professors, labor leaders, ministers and citizens supporting his refusal to oust Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, from his staff, as demanded by the American Legion and other patriotic and religious organizations.

While it is indubitably correct to regard Austria as fighting with her back to the wall against full Nazification, it is still over-early to say that the game is up. Within and without Austria, forces are assembling against the threat of Germany's expansion.
Political partisanship and labor factionalism mark the closing days of the campaign in Seattle's supposedly nonpartisan municipal election.

Miss Ruth Davison, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Davison of this city and the late Mr. Davison, has chosen May 7 as the date of her marriage to A. Merthyn Nicholls, son of Arthur Nicholls of Roselle and the late Mrs. Nicholls.

I AM MY YOUTH-Tomorrow evening at the Playhouse. A play about William Godwin and Percy Bysshe Shelley, by Ernest Pascal and Edwin Harvey Blum. In the cast are Charles Waldron, Frank Lawton, Linda Watkins, Viola Roache, Robert Vivian, Sylvia Weld, Jean Bellows, Arden Young and Gordon Richards.
Philadelphians learned today that a 15-cent restaurant bill is sometimes 16, but not if they knew the proper trick of evading the city's 2 per cent sales tax.

One reason that the Moscow treason trials, of which the largest and most startling is now being held in the former Nobles Club, are incomprehensible to many persons abroad is that the procedure is unlike that of their own courts.
A FEW seasons back Ethel Boileau -- then an unknown writer -- published an agreeable little story of English domestic life which was greeted in this country with wide-eyed approbation.
Harlem was inclined to laugh last night over the career of Robert Scroggs, 35-year-old Negro, of 316 West 116th Street. But between 7:30 and 9 P. M. the affair had serious implications.

Albert H. Flaig and the securities concern of which he is president, Albert H. Flaig Co., Inc., of 420 Lexington Avenue, were enjoined permanently by Supreme Court Justice Aaron Levy yesterday from dealing in securities in this State.
Charles Fitch Jr. of the City A. C. and E. L. Kilroe of the Columbia University Club gained the final round of the national Class B squash tennis championship yesterday.

A comparatively new golf competitor, Miss Dorothy Jones of Bermuda and Detroit, sprang a surprise today by beating Mrs. John Rogers, Canadian women's open champion, 3 and 2, in the thirty-six hole final of the Bermuda women's golf championship on the Riddell's Bay course.

Attention was directed by the Securities and Exchange Commission today to a decision handed down yesterday in New York by the Federal District Court permanently enjoining sixteen individual defendants and one co-partnership from manipulative activities in connection with the distribution of common stock of the Trans-Lux Daylight Picture Screen Corporation on the New York Curb Exchange.

Eighty-one Representatives were elected by Cuba today in an atmosphere of the most extreme indifference that has ever characterized an election in the island. Havana Province also chose a Senator to fill the vacancy created by the death of Dr. Ricardo Dolz several months ago.

LOYALTIES: In London last week were auctioned papers once belonging to the Napoleonic Marshal Berthier. Among the documents was the consent of Marie Louise to the marriage arranged by her father, the Emperor of Austria, to Napoleon.

AN innovation in automobile road maps which encourages the motorist to think in terms of reasonable driving time between given points rather than mileage to be covered, was announced last week by the Continental Oil Company. Maps of the new type are being issued by the company's travel bureau at Denver, Col.
The average maximum age at which employers in this State will hire new workers is 35, according to results of a survey announced here today by the State League of Economics.

One of the largest transactions In Jersey City for some time was announced yesterday by the realty firm of J. I. Kislak in the sale of the well-known Perkins home site, at the northwest corner of Bergen and Kensington Avenues, to the Hudson Building Company, which is having plans prepared for the erection in the Spring of two apartment houses.

After more than a year's vacillation President Lazaro Cardenas ratified today the protocol of the Buenos Aires Pan-American Conference reiterating the American nations' agreement that "no State has the right to intervene in the internal or external affairs of another."
The Long Island University quintet defeated Brooklyn College, 5334, before a capacity crowd in the losers' gymnasium last night. The game concluded the regular schedules of both teams.
Joe Stripp, veteran St. Louis infielder, said today he may retire from organized baseball unless the Cardinals meet his demand for a $10,000 salary.
Relatively steadier foreign markets contributed to a recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, the list ending with gains of 6 to 9 points.
THAT band of musical enthusiasts, the New Friends of Music, Inc., is in a huddle about its plans for next season-its third. Though no public in-

Managements of companies with shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange are entering the annual "headache season," when industry goes proxy-hunting, with clear eyes, better color and a less distracted outlook on life.

The Earl of Perth left London for Rome, carrying terms for Anglo-Italian amity, and will start talks with Foreign Minister Ciano tomorrow. London heard Britain would refuse to concede naval equality in the Mediterranean to Italy and would not discuss defense of Austria. At the same time London was laying the foundation for talks with Germany. [Page 1.]
A proposal that the site of the old Postoffice Building on lower Broadway be named Pershing Park after the building is demolished was made yesterday by the 307th Infantry Post of the American Legion.

Increases in four components of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity were more than offset by losses in three for the week ended Feb. 26, and the combined index eased to-78.9 from 79.0.
Australia's cricket team that will shortly leave for England routed Tasmania today by 485 runs. Great performances by W. A. Brown, J. H. Fingleton and W. J. O'Reilly featured the runaway victory.

The engagement of Miss Doris Marilynn Cherry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William John Cherry of this place, to Robert Alden Klock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Klock of Yonkers, has been announced by her parents.

County chairmen for New York, New Jersey and Delaware were named today by Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commanding the army's Second Corps Area, in a tri-State all-civilian organization, which will act as the principal agency to carry out the enrollment of 6,800 youths for the eighteenth annual Citizens Military Training Camps.

Road End, the estate of W. Emerton Heitland, located on a peninsula jutting out into Five Mile River at Darien, Conn., has been purchased by G. W. Baehne of New York, through Leon Fish, broker, according to Previews, Inc.

THE old rail maxim, "Only the rich can afford fast travel," fell further into discard the other day when a light allcoach Diesel-electric streamliner left Chicago's Dearborn Station and streaked West on its inaugural run to Los Angeles.

William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday that since Jan. 1 the real estate bureau of the State Banking Department, under Special Deputy Willard K. Denton, has completed negotiations for the sale of nine properties in the metropolitan area for an aggregate price of $173,000, the cash consideration being $119,750.

Mr. and Mrs. Gustav H. Niemeyer of 817 Fifth Avenue and Westport, Conn., gave a dinner at their home here last night at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucille Niemeyer, to William H. Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Hart of East Orange, N. J.

This week's Community Mobilization for Human Needs in Washington and the recent organization here of the Greater New York Fund, Inc., mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the first modern community chest, founded in Cleveland in March, 1913.

As in the past, it was War Admiral all the way today in the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup. The champion son of Man o' War shouldered 130 pounds and gave distance as well as weight to his opposition, yet he won eased up at the end of a mile and a quarter in one of the most remarkable exhibitions a thoroughbred has given in years.

Exceptions for hotel laundry workers from the minimum wage standards for women laundry workers generally were asked yesterday by Frank A. K. Boland, counsel for the New York State and New York City Hotel Associations, at the final public hearing on the laundry wage held by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews in the State Office Building.
A wide assortment of hobbles, from amateur gardening to collecting Anthony Trollope, was suggested yesterday as satisfying leisure time pursuits for busy men and women.

The texts of a statement made yesterday by David E. Lilienthal, director of the TVA, and of an anSwering letter by Wendell L. Willkie of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, dealing with the proposed resumption of negotiations for the purchase of public utility properties in the Tennessee Valley, were as follows:

THIS essay is, as is stated in its subtitle, a tribute to Offenbach, and its title and much of its text celebrate the Offenbach opera of the same name. It is also a re-creation of that "vie Parisienne" of the Second Empire, of which the production of the Offenbach opera bouffe was a part.

Ellen Styring Lyman, 15-year-old daughter of Lauren D. and Mabel-S. Lyman, died today at the Washington Sanatorium in Takoma Park, Md., following an illness of a week. Her father is a member of THE NEW YORK TIMES staff attached to the WaRhington bureau.

An ice carnival will take place next Sunday and Monday nights at Playland Casino here to aid the Rock Hill Summer camp of the Westchester Girl Scouts at Lake Mahopac. On Monday Dr. Friedrich Fischerauer, Austrian consul general, will attend the performance. The carnival is being presented by the Figure Skating Club of Rye.

Mayor La Guardia dismissed, yesterday, as a figment of the imagination, the tentative plan for the city's purchase of the Interborough Rapid Transit system for $170,213,508 in city bonds, as proposed by Chester W. Cuthell, associate special counsel for the Transit Commission, which the Mayor seeks to abolish.

A hearing on deportation charges against Harry Bridges, West Coast longshoremen's leader, will be held in San Francisco April 25. Commissioner Houghteling of the Bureau of Immigration announced today.
THAT brilliant and independent spirit which guides the editorial progress of Time and Tide finds expression here in a sheaf of little essays, well worth garnering.

Commenting on the mortgage situation existing at the present time, Walter A. Davis, vice president of the Charles F. Noyes Company, points out that one of the lessons taught by the depression is the fallacy of making mortgages without amortization.

Stressing the importance of the retail personnel director in the management of the retail store and the desirability of employee representation, Major Benjamin HNamm, head of the Namm Store, Brooklyn, yesterday cited three "responsibilities" which underlie the policy in force in that store.
An agreement between Soviet Russia and Germany to close all consulates in each other's territory was announced officially tonight.

The Dalhousie Club of New York, composed of graduates of Dalhousie University of Halifax, N. S., who live in this city, will hold its annual dinner next Saturday evening in the Canadian Club at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
The turnover of shares on the New York Stock Exchange last week amounted to but 2,678,875 units, the smallest since the week ended on July 14, 1923, when 2,110,380 changed hands.

WARD PRICE, who for a number of years has been privileged to sit at the right hand of Lord Rothermere, proprietor of The London Daily Mail, is probably better qualified than almost any other foreigner to write in personal terms of the two foreost men in Europe today.

Using a new electrical instrument for detesting the presence of radium called "The Hen" because it "clucks" when on a hot scent, doctors searching the cinder path in the grounds of the Royal Victoria Hospital at Newcastle on Tyne have recovered eight milligrams of radium inadvertently thrown into the incinerator in 1930.
Miss Julia Elizabeth Lee of Newark, formerly of this place, was married this afternoon in Vincent Methodist Church here to Robert Burnet Spier of Clifton.

A TRANSATLANTIC spelling bee is scheduled for today, from noon to 12:45 P. M., between New York and London. Two-way short-wave circuits will link the spellers while broadcasters may eavesdrop through WJZ's network. Paul Wing will pronounce the words at Radio City and Tom Woodrooffe will be the spelling master on the other side of the sea.

Younger members of society will take part in the varied theatrical entertainment to be given by members of the Lakeview Players, formerly known as the Junior Branch Players, the night of March 16 and the afternoon of March 19 at the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventythird Street, for the benefit of the New York Women's. League for Animals.

PROPOSALS for a vast new public playground, consisting of about ten million acres of lakes and woodlands in Northeastern Minnesota and Western Ontario, were last week placed before President Roosevelt by a committee which has been studying the project for three and a half years.

A summary of Rutgers Alumni Clubs, made public by William S. Powers, assistant alumni secretary, disclosed today that 5,035 graduates are members of thirty-one clubs, fifteen of which are in New Jersey.

Leo W. Quick, 37-year-old business agent of the Boilermakers and Laundry Workers Union, was found shot to death in his own back yard early today. Police said that seven pistol bullets were found in the body.

Duncan MacD. Little will present his ninth annual "Movie Party" on March 23 at the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway at 116th Street, as a part of "Motion Picture Parade," a series conducted by the Division of Film Study of Columbia University, it was announced yesterday. :

Unless the young woman of today implements her hope to "live happily ever after" with training which will give vocational satisfaction when her home no longer absorbs her energies she is threatened with being a problem to herself after 40, according to Mrs. Grace Loucks Elliott, psychologist.

The evolution of housing since the Stone Age to what the homemaker may expect in 1960 will be dramatized at the seventeenth annual Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries at Grand Central Palace, March 28 to April 2, Mrs. Robert W. Aldrich Rodger, chairman of the exposition's housing division, announced yesterday. The housing exhibit will occupy the entire first floor of the Palace.
Princeton's wrestling team tonight suffered its first defeat in three years when Lehigh triumphed, 17 to 11, before 2,500 fans,

PINEHURST, N. C.-Continued warm weather is drawing a large number of resort colonists to this Midsouth resort. Many of the native shrubs and trees are flowering prematurely, lending an early Spring touch. Golf, the chief outdoor preoccupation here, is receiving much attention on the seven golf courses in the region.
A luncheon was given yesterday by Mrs. Wendell Phillips Colton at Sherry's for Miss Margaret Frances Hull, whose engagement to John Harrison Hammett was recently announced.

STAMPS long promised have been received which postally reflect Italy's action in poitically merging Ethiopia (philately's Abyssinia), Eritrea and Italian Somaliland under the title Italian East Africa-"Africa Orientale Italiana" is inscribed on the new postal paper, which comprises twenty values for regular postage, eleven for air mail and two for combination air mail and special delivery. No longer will the three possessions have their own individual adhesives.

Leo W. Quick, 37-year-old business agent of the Boilermakers and Laundry Workers Union, was found shot to death in his own back yard early today. Police said that seven pistol bullets were found in the body.

Duncan MacD. Little will present his ninth annual "Movie Party" on March 23 at the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway at 116th Street, as a part of "Motion Picture Parade," a series conducted by the Division of Film Study of Columbia University, it was announced yesterday. :

Many of the native shrubs and trees are flowering prematurely, lending an early Spring touch. Golf, the chief outdoor preoccupation here, is receiving much attention on the seven golf courses in the region.
A luncheon was given yesterday by Mrs. Wendell Phillips Colton at Sherry's for Miss Margaret Frances Hull, whose engagement to John Harrison Hammett was recently announced.

STAMPS long promised have been received which postally reflect Italy's action in poitically merging Ethiopia (philately's Abyssinia), Eritrea and Italian Somaliland under the title Italian East Africa-"Africa Orientale Italiana" is inscribed on the new postal paper, which comprises twenty values for regular postage, eleven for air mail and two for combination air mail and special delivery. No longer will the three possessions have their own individual adhesives.
Nathan H. Hart, long active in Republican circles in Sussex County, died at the Newton Memorial Hospital last night of a heart attack. He was 73 years old.
A "paper-shrapnel" hand grenade that requires less explosive and bursts with greater ease-has been developed by an army private, it is revealed in a patent just granted here.

Despite its political unrest and unsettled economic situation, Mexico City is experiencing a boom in the construction of homes, according to C. Grant Keck, Long Island City broker, who has just returned from Mexico. Hundreds

Dr. Walter Damrosch, orchestra conductor, criticized the Pepper bill again yesterday before the National Arts Conference in the Hotel Astor. He voiced. opposition to the measure last week at a Senate hearing in Washington.

BOSTON. THE Lantern League of the Old North Church, from the tower of which Paul Revere "watched with eager search" on the night of April 18, 1775, for the signal lantern that sent him on his famous ride, is diligently continuing its task of making that building safe for posterity.
An unusual exhibition of Japanese Flower Arrangements will be open to the public at Yamanaka Co., 680 Fifth Avenue, New York City, beginning on Monday and lasting until March 26.

THE aviation experts in three separate departments of the government were at loggerheads. They had been asked to work out a new program to improve the economic health of this country's commerical air transportlines.
Police Department contributions to charitable causes my be doubled, under the new system of collecting a certain sum from every member of the department, according to Commissioner Valentine.
The General Motors Acoeptance Corporation and subsidiaries. reported yesterday for 1937 a net in come of $14,492,238 after all deduetions, including $435,022 tax on undistributed profits.

High -pressure selling will prove an important factor in lifting the country out of the present recession, Harry Boyd Brown, merchandising manager of the Philco Radio and Television Corporation, declared on his return this week from a tour of key business centers throughout the country.

Citing the likelihood that the reduction in the down payment for homes from 20 to 10 per cent, in the case of dwellings of the $6,000 price range, will bring into the buying market many thousands of potential home owners, officials of the Federal Housing Administration ad-
Meeting of the Jewish Labor Committee, Hotel Capitol, 1:30 P. M. Speakers: Senator Robert F. Wagner, Louis Hollander, City Councilman.
Floral Murals. Decorators Club Gallery. 745 Fifth Avenue, until March 18. Hand-painted panels of various decorative wall treatments by George Stonehill.

Leaders in the field of music, radio, the theatre and education will gather for a two-day conference beginning Friday at the Lincoln School Auditorium of Teachers College, Columbia University, to analyze the factors and trends in American recreation and entertainment, Mrs. Dorothy L. McFadden, director of Junior Programs, announced yesterday.

The new slant that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain has given to British foreign policy in the past fortnight has found few more enthusiastic supporters than the American-born woman who will go down in history as the first of her sex ever to be elected to the House of Commons.
Verily, Verily! To the Screen Editor: My attention has been called to an article which appeared in the Sunday TIMES of Feb. 6, called "The Little Cinema Marches On," written by Harold Lefkovits.
Tax revision, spurred by last Fall's special Congressional session, came nearer the statute books last week with the introduction of a new tax bill in the House of Representatives.

Shocking sufferers from schizophrenia (split personality) with insulin has been accepted as one of the greatest advances ever made in psychiatry. But why is the treatment occasionally successful? Dr. Frederick Hoelzel (Chicago) wonders in Science whether the explanation may not be found in a physiologic improvement in mental efficiency, just as fasting seems to sharpen the mind.

Fred Jacoby of North Bergen, N. J., was high point man today in outboard motorboat races on the first day's program of the fourth annual Manatee River regatta. The river was too rough for record speeds, but a double spill enlivened the races.
The press censorship, now applied more strictly than before by the new dictatorial regime, proved once again this week that such methods often cause misunderstanding and blunders.
Among the 741 patents granted this week by the United States Patent Office to inventors here and abroad, the following attract attention for their unusual slant:

Miss Maude Adams, dean of American actresses, who spent three months here last year as a teacher of dramatics at Stephen's College, will resume her work next Fall, W. P. Shofstall, dean of administration, said today.
Trading on the Stock Exchange in yesterday's short session amounted to only 222,000 shares, the smallest turnover since June 19 last. Net changes were inconsequential, and the closing was irregillar.

IF Mr. Tobenkin is right when he maintains that, in spite of the formidable power of the totalitarian governments in Europe, they do not represent the hope and the will of their hypnotized and overawed peoples,

Out of a welter of upsets and stunning surprises right down the line, Columbia staggered to its second successive team championship of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. before a wildly excited crowd of 12,000 in Madison Square Garden last night.

The George Andreichin mentioned in the current Moscow trial as a Trotskyist spy in Great Britain in 1924 was identified in New York last night as a former American who moved largely in American circles in Moscow and who was well known to distinguished American visitors and to foreign-correspondents.

The annual Yale junior promenade will be held Friday night in the large amphitheater of the Payne Whitney gymnasium, the only enclosure of the university building spacious enough for the thousand couples expected to attend.

Miss Mathilde Bevan Hooper, daughter of Mrs. James P. Hooper of Glengariff, Ruxton, near Baltimore, was married to Duncan Ives McNeill of Montreal, son of Judge and Mrs. Edward T. McNeill of Calgary, Alberta, this afternoon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

To the Art Editor: THE Artists Coordination Committee recognizes and appreciates the value of the excellent article written by Mr. Jewell in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sunday, Jan. 30, in which he extend support to the seventeen artists' societies now engaged in efforts to obtain land and adequate housing for a comprehensive national exhibition of contemporary American art at the New York World's Fair of 1939.
Councilman Albert D. Schanzer of Brooklyn will introduce a resolution at the next Council meeting calling for establishment of a Department of Youth Welfare in the city government.

On the anniversary last week of his first inauguration as Chief Executive, President Roosevelt declared that "the old ship of state is still on the same course." By this he meant, as he went on to explain, that while the methods of his Administration have changed from time to time, during five adventurous years, its objectives have remained essentially the same.

TRAVANCORE, India.-The women of India practice an art of make-up whose secrets have been handed down from mother to daughter for numberless generations. Hollywood could learn a thing or two from the dusky beauties of Hindustan.
Recent evidence has set French Surete Nationale agents on a new track in the investigation of the more-than-ayear-old mystery of the assassination of the Russian publicist Dimitri Navachine.

Miss Miriam Talley will give a luncheon tomorrow at Sherry's for members of the group serving with her in behalf of the annual supper dance for the New York Foundling Hospital to be held April 23 at the same restaurant under the auspices of the Almoners.

The sport of greyhound racing came into the picture in New York State again yesterday with a luncheon at the Madison Square Garden Club, at which the officers of the newly formed Greyhound Racing Association of New York made public their plans and the bill which they have sent to legislative leaders at Albany, which would legalize dog tracks in New York.

George Putnam Stowitts, engineer for the New York region of the PWA and former chief engineer of the inspection division of PWA for the United States, died of a heart attack early today at the Montclair terminal of the Lackawanna Railroad a few minutes after alighting from a train.

Arthur J. Griffin of 19 Grace Court, Brooklyn, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Janice Griffin, to Joseph James Fitzgerald, son of Mrs. George J. Fitzgerald of Scarsdale, N. Y., and the late Mr. Fitzgerald.

Koman Daranyi announced Hungary's rearmament today in an address on the government's internal and external policies. "At the present moment," he said, "the Hungarian Army, although excellent, is not equipped with modern weapons.

Budgeting of household expenses, both within the limits of a relief check and for an average income, is included in a new program devised for a domestic training school, designed to supplant three similar Manhattan schools under W. P. A. auspices which will close their doors on Saturday.
BARON VON BLIXEN-FINECKE went out to british East Africa a few years before the war, with his young wife,

DISCUSSION stirred in radio circles by the Payne-Boylan bill to tax broadcasters, with the watt as the unit to be taxed, indicates that opposition to the bill will be argued on the basis that such a levy is a blow at freedom of the air.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 4: MAJOR GENERAL Birnie. U. Jr., chief of field artillery, four months and twenty-one days leave, March 26, with permission to visit foreign countries.

Some of the transactions by which the Chesapeake Ohio Railway took over control of the Erie and the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroads on Jan. 29 were among those in that month by officers, directors and principal stockholders in equity securities reported in a summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

THERE'S a man at the Warner studio who likes to shoot the tires off speeding automobiles. He doesn't get as many opportunities as formerly because gangster pictures (in case you haven't heard) are dying out.

In an unprecedented move, the State Athletic Commission announced today that Young Corbett had been recognized in California as world middleweight boxing champion. Chairman George Payne said the Fresno left-hander was recognized because of his ten-round upset decision over Fred Apostoli here last month.

THE case of Marie Tempest is the most mysterious in our theatre.
