Since the celebration of her stage jubilee she has been made a Dame of the British Empire-an honor which in women corresponds to that of a knighthood in men, and, for better or for worse, sets upon her achievement the seal of official recognition.
Representative Schulte of Indiana reported to police today that three bandits had robbed him of $16 in cash, three checks totaling $1,839 and two watches.
Episopal funeral services were held here today for George Foster Peabody, philanthropist who died at his warm Springs, Ga., Winter home yesterday of a heart ailment. His age was 85.

Princeton undergraduates will compete in a contest for a new Tiger song to be played by the university band in the football season. The contest will close on June 17, during Reunion Week, and the winner will be announced in October.
Dr. John Nelson Teeter, who until his retirement three years ago had been chief of the medical staff at Englewood Hospital, died at his home here this morning. His age was 67.
Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Brazilian envoy to the United States, today accepted the Foreign Ministery portfolio in the Vargas government. He will be inducted next week, probably on Wednesday.

The Canadian Government, faced with- an embarrassing demand from a large bloc of its own British Columbia members of Parliament for the exclusion of Japanese subjects from this country, has promised a police inquiry into the alleged illegal entry of Nipponese and a departmental examination of the whole situation.
A one-time Greek Foreign Office stenographer and the sweetheart to whom she allegedly betrayed Greek military secrets both were convicted of espionage today and sentenced to prison.

The Savage basketball team concluded its campaign yesterday on its home court by beating the Brooklyn College of Pharpnacy, 39 to 29. The winners were paced by Mike Werner, who tallied 15 points. Savage led at the half, 20 to 12.

WHAT'S going to happen to Czechoslovakia? Anxious Europe would like to know. Englishmen, when they are asked, say they are sorry about Czechoslovakia, but, after all, whatever happens is no business of theirs. Frenchmen, with their prestige in Europe at stake, sometimes hardly know what to answer and what to do.

Mrs. Clare Hoyt, president of the State Federation of Women's Clubs, will speak on "A Changing Woman's Club in a Changing World" to members of the Ossining Woman's Club on Thursday, when she will be guest of honor at a tea.

The fossil human bones found in a cave of Mount Carmel, Palestine, by an expedition which was led by Miss Dorothy Garrod and Dr. T. D. McCown and which was financed by the British School of Archaeology in Jerusalem and the American School of Prehistoric Research have now been so thoroughly studied that Sir Arthur Keith was able to explain their significance in a lecture before the Royal College of Surgeons in London.

A suit asking damages of $25,000 from Local 807, International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court by Harold S. Lyman, president of the L. L. Transportation Company, 20 Renwick Street, operator of a fleet of trucks between New York and Boston.
The long-expected fight over governmental reorganization broke on the floor of the Senate this week. The President had sent a message to Congress early last year suggesting a plan of reorganization.

An additional group of patronesses has been added to the one already lending its support to the ninth annual Spring bridge party to be held on Saturday at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the Woman's Advisory Board of the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

Stuyvesant High, team champion, and New Utrecht remained undefeated and continued to set the pace in their respective divisions in the P.S.A.L. fencing competition at the Washington Irving High School gymnasium yesterday.

Mrs. Mary Gallagher Phillips of 130 East Thirty-eighth Street, wife of H. I. Phillips, conductor of The Sun Dial column in The Sun, died yesterday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, Broadway and 168th Street. Her age was 52 years.

Examinations for license as teacher-in-training in general and special high school subjects were announced yesterday by the Board of Examiners. All applications must be filed with the board by Tuesday.

Arthur B. Daniels, manufacturer and civic leader of Adams, died today of a heart ailment at Plunkett Memorial Hospital in Adams. Mr. Daniels was president of the L. Brown Paper Company, with which he had been associated for sixty years. He was 77 years old.
Rensselaer Poly scored 12 points in the last two minutes but could not overcome the Union College quintet, which won, 40 to 36, tonight in the fiftieth encounter between the old rivals since 1889.

Miss Rebekah Mary Shipler, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Guy Emery Shipler of the Vicarage, this place, was married here tonight to William John Myers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Earl Myers of Los Angeles, in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church by her father, who is the rector.
NGLAND'S broadcasts to the Arabs in North Africa, Arabia and Palestine are being intercepted in the United States from 12:20 to 1:15 P. M. on the 9.58 megacycle channel.
Few changes, none of importance, were registered in yesterday's business in the foreign exchange market. For the entire week all the leading foreign moneys were considerably cheaper.

The Rye Country Day School equestrian team of Rye, N. Y., coached by Frank J. Carroll, defeated the Ethel Walker School of Simsbury, Conn., in a six-phase horsemanship contest, feature of the first interscholastic horse show held today at the Hobby Horse Stables.

ARON--HERTZ-Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Hertz announce the engagement of their daughter. Lillian, to Harold Aron, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Aron. GRENTHAL--OREF--Mrs. Emil Koref announces the engagement of her daughter, Mina, to Hon. Abraham Grenthal, son of Michael Grenthal.

MERCURY THEATRE--The repertory bill this week at the National notes "The Shoemakers' Holiday" on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Saturday evenings and Wednesday afternoon, and "Julius Caesar" for the rest of the week's performances.
Interest in Albany centered this week on the fate of the Savings Bank Life Insurance Bill favored by Governor Lehman.

The United Rubber Workers Union was warned today by the B. F. Goodrich Company to accept hourly wage reductions or face further decentralization of the plant, which would mean the loss of 5,000 more jobs in Akron.

Dr. Harry James Carman, head of the History Department of Columbia College, was appointed yesterday a member of the Board of Higher Education by Mayor La Guardia. He fills the vacancy caused when Joseph D. McGoldrick, also a Columbia professor, resigned on being elected Controller.

Dr. Leonard A. Jaslow, who suffered a cerebral hemorrhage Tuesday night while operating on a difficult maternity case at the Wadsworth Hospital, 629 West .185th Street, died early yesterday at the hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 571 West 139th Street.
Italy's naval estimates for the 1938-39 budget total 2,013,000,000 lire, an increase of 155,000,000 lire over the figure for the current year.

ARON--HERTZ-Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Hertz announce the engagement of their daughter. Lillian, to Harold Aron, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Aron. GRENTHAL--OREF--Mrs. Emil Koref announces the engagement of her daughter, Mina, to Hon. Abraham Grenthal, son of Michael Grenthal.

MERCURY THEATRE--The repertory bill this week at the National notes "The Shoemakers' Holiday" on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Saturday evenings and Wednesday afternoon, and "Julius Caesar" for the rest of the week's performances.
Interest in Albany centered this week on the fate of the Savings Bank Life Insurance Bill favored by Governor Lehman.

The United Rubber Workers Union was warned today by the B. F. Goodrich Company to accept hourly wage reductions or face further decentralization of the plant, which would mean the loss of 5,000 more jobs in Akron.

Dr. Harry James Carman, head of the History Department of Columbia College, was appointed yesterday a member of the Board of Higher Education by Mayor La Guardia. He fills the vacancy caused when Joseph D. McGoldrick, also a Columbia professor, resigned on being elected Controller.

Dr. Leonard A. Jaslow, who suffered a cerebral hemorrhage Tuesday night while operating on a difficult maternity case at the Wadsworth Hospital, 629 West .185th Street, died early yesterday at the hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 571 West 139th Street.
Italy's naval estimates for the 1938-39 budget total 2,013,000,000 lire, an increase of 155,000,000 lire over the figure for the current year.
Gutzon Borglum said today he expected to return to Atlanta "in near future" to finish carving memorial to the Confederacy on face of Stone Mountain.

Harry Thoens set the pace at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. He began his good work by breaking 98 out of 100 to win the high-over-all cup, then gained a leg on the distance prize with 24 out of 25 from the 21yard mark.

The Tribuna today says that it possesses information concerning plans of the United States to protect the Panama Canal by means of a naval base in Central America. The information is said to come from a source that must be kept secret.

LONDON. THE war in China seems so far to have had surprisingly little effect on the world's tea trade. Fifty years ago it might have been disastrous. In those days China dominated the trade. Since then some of the biggest markets have turned to stronger teas, though Russia still depends on the Chinese supply.

Out of committee rooms where plans to perfect the State's basic laws have been argued pro and con for many months finally emerged yesterday the first comprehensive list of recommendations from women's organizations to the coming Constitutional Convention.

The wicked Queen who sought by black magic to visit evil on her stepdaughter, the beauteous Snow White, gained yesterday the lasting enmity of 3,800 Brooklyn orphans, who hissed her mercilessly in a showing of Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" at the eighth annual party of seventeen orphan homes in the Brooklyn Strand Theatre.

The Bureau of. Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 3: COMMANDERS Duncan, D. B., aircraft, Battle Force, to Naval Air Station, Pensacola, Fla., as executive officer in June. Ruble, W. J., Washington, D. C., to duty as Pacific communication officer, San Francisco, Calif.. in June.
THS book is a study of that field of hiring and firing and all that goes with it and lies between, which is called Personal.
Louis A. Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, said in an interview tonight that the army had perfected an automatic landing device which eliminates the danger of fogs at airports.

Theodore Dreiser's first work published in book form was not "Sister Carrie," as generally supposed, but consisted of two compilations of success stories, according to John F. Huth Jr., writing in the Winter issue of The Colophon, a quarterly, issued today.
Emile Allais of France remains the world champion all-round skier. He is the first man to hold the title two successive years since the Federation Internationale du Ski began awarding it.

Little or no rain fell in the dry sections of Western Kansas last week and there was a resumption of soil drifting. The more eastern territory, however, received further beneficial moisture and both private and official reports indicate an improvement in the outlook for the new crop.
THE OTHER SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN, by James Ramsey Ullman. (Carrick Evans, $3.) Travel and adventure in the South American jungle.

Miss Louise Maunsell Field will give, under the patronage of wellknown members of society, a series of Wednesday morning book talks, to be known as "Books of the Hour," during this month in the drawing rooms of private houses.

Louis Cochand of the Laurentian Cross-country Ski Club won the Quebec Kandahar Trophy today. Doug Mann and Bob Johannsen, both of McGill University, finished second and third and Bill Houghton of the Red Birds Ski Club was fourth.

Arturo Toscanini, Internationally known conductor, received yesterday the 1937 American Hebrew Medal, awarded for the promotion of better understanding between Jews and Christians. Joseph H. Biben, editor and publisher of The American Hebrew, made the presentation in Mr. Toscanini's suite at the Hotel Astor.

Many cities and counties are in no position financially to meet their relief obligations for any extended period on the present level of expenditures, the State Board of Social Welfare warned today in its annual report to Governor Lehman and the Legislature.

Mrs. Thurlow M. Gordon, president of the Radcliffe Club of New York, and Mr. Gordon gave a buffet supper last night at their home, 435 East Fifty-second Street, before the performance of the Jooss European Ballet at Carnegie Hall.
A fundamental step toward knowledge of the nature of electric current appears to have been taken in an experiment reported today by the United States Bureau of Standards in its Journal of Research.

Thom Cooper, Kansas City motor boat racer, registered the highest speed for outboards today in the fourth annual regatta. Finishing first in all three heats of the Class X race, Cooper averaged 49.505 miles per hour in the first round. As yesterday, choppy waters balked drivers in their quest for new records.
The Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., will pay $1.96 per hundred pounds for milk testing 3.5 per cent butterfat delivered to its plants in four States in February.

French financiers.make no secret of their concern over the increased perils denoted in the foreign situation and over the threats of war. Furthermore, no symptoms of improvement are discernible in the tense political situation at home.

J. W. Dugan, formerly with the certificate trustee department of the Brooklyn Trust Company, has joined the management and investment sales department of the Roman-Caswell Company of Long Island City. Low vacancies in Queens apartments, improvement in home construction and buying under the amended FHA plan. and continued influx of new tenants point to a better market for Long Island real estate. in Mr. Dugan's opinion.
A tea was given yesterday by the New York Branch of the English Speaking Union at 30 Rockefeller Plaza for Miss Balbina Brainina, Russian pianist. The guest of honor played selections.

Two series of lectures by J. LeRoy Davidson, a member of the lecture division of the WPA Art Project, will be given at the Harlem Community Art Center, 290 Lenox Avenue. The lectures have been arranged for members of the Art Teachers Institute, a unit of the project.

According to an official estimate issued this week, the area under Winter wheat in Germany is 4 per cent larger than it was a year ago, and the area seeded to rye is 1.6 per cent larger than at this time last year.

Roland Redmond, counsel to the New York Stock Exchange, in an analysis of the administrative implications of the Securities Exchange Act in the current issue of the Yale Law Journal, says there is a real danger in vesting more power in administrative tribunals.
The most delightful event of the year has just occurred at Hartford, Conn., but, the perversity of human nature being what it is, some of its beneficiaries may even be annoyed at their good fortune.

There was no Yankee baseball activity to disturb the Sabbath calm today. The athletes, on the one Sunday they could expect off between now and October, unless rain comes to upset the playing schedule, gave their attention to fishing expeditions out in the Gulf, patronized some of the near-by golf links, or just idled the time away at movies or playing cards.

A smoky fire which started in a ventilating shaft running the full height of the forty-two-story Hotel New Yorker, at Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, disturbed about 2,000 guests early yesterday morning, but failed to impair service at the hotel. No one was injured as firemen quickly subdued the flames, which were confined to the shaft.

HERE, some days after the scheduled thriceannual date, are notes on those books published since Nov. 1 that made a particular impression upon this particular reviewer. The order of listing is haphazard. Gunnar Gunnarsson's "Ships in the Sky" (BobbsMerrill). A warm and delicate novel of an Icelandic boyhood, written with superb grace.

The report of the Pure Oil Company for 1937, released for publication today, shows a net income of $11,403,805 after all charges, taxes and reserves. The total was the highest since 1926, when the net profit amounted to $12,922,000. Net profits last year were equal after dividend requirements on the preferred stock to $2.15 each on the 3,982,031 shares of common stock outstanding at the end of the year.

After its endof-the-month expansion, the money market in France remained rather narrow because of the volume of capital exported and the withdrawal from the market of money for subscriptions to the new Treasury loan.

Jim Londos, one of the most popular heavyweight wrestlers, will be seen in action at the New York Hippodrome tonight. He will exchange holds with Jim McMillen, former University of Illinois football player, in the feature bout of a show arranged for the benefit of the House of Calvary Cancer Hospital.

The jewelencrusted crown of conquered Ethiopia today was presented to Premier Benito Mussolini. He received the symbol of vanished Ethiopian glory from Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, former Italian Viceroy of Ethiopia, who brought' it from Addis Ababa, together with the former Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie's imperial scepter.
Scots-Americans 2, N. Y. Americans 1. St. Mary's Celtics 3, Paterson Caledonians 0. Irish Americans 3, Brookhattans 2. Passon (Phila.) 1, Phila. German-Americans 1.

A testimonial dinner to Dr. Walter Damrosch, conductor and pioneer for good music, at the National Arts Club last night developed into a fresh attack on the Pepper-Coffee bill for the creation of a Federal Bureau of Fine Arts, with Jonas Lie and Herbert Adams,

The financial press here is critical of President Rooseevlt's policy of maintaining wages and cheapening capital goods as ambiguous. It declares that Washington must be deflationist or reflationist, and the opinion is that, at heart, the latter obtains.

Two dance events divided last evening between them when the Jooss European Ballet gave its New York performance for two years at Carnegie Hall and Ted Shawn and his ensemble of men dancers presented their second program of the season at the Majestic Theatre.

Persons Interested in the welfare of Hudson Guild, a neighborhood house at 436 West Twenty-seventh Street, have taken over for its benefit the boxes for Marion Anderson's recital the evening of April 13 at Carnegie Hall. Mrs. Clarence H. Low and Frederick M. Heimerdinger are co-chairmen of arrangements.

Bruno Gargulla and Mette Standish of Detroit, with 1,203, took second place in the doubles standings at the American Bowling Congress tourney today and trailed John Colombo and Jules Benetti of Clinton, Ind., by only six pins. Charles Kopp and Elmer -Schnell of St. Louis rolled 1,200, good for third.

With the legislative leaders preparing for the final adjournment drive, the fate of two of the proposals on Governor Lehman's program remains in doubt and what happens to them will mark, to an extent, the real accomplishments of the session.

The franc has improved slightly this week. Fluctuations were, however, somewhat irregular and the stabilization fund was obliged to intervene to peg the currency. On the other hand, the fund also bought foreign funds in periods of franc strength. The premium on forward pounds and dollars became much cheaper, seemingly indicating a liquidating of hear positions in the franc.

Viewed in perspective, the problem of relief is two-sided. On the one hand, we wish to help as much as possible those who are out of work through no fault of their own. On the other hand, we do not wish to remove the incentive for or the pressure upon these people to find work as soon as possible.

Mrs. Eugene M. Sawyer of 1,349 Lexington Avenue, formerly of Tyrone, N. M., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Caroline L. Sawyer to Lieutenant Sam W. Agee Jr. Field Artillery, U. S. A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Agee of Silver City, N. M.

Wagner's "Parsifal" will be added to the repertoire as the Metropolitan Opera presents the sixteenth and final week of the season next week. The program for the week follows; MONDAY-"Amelia Goes to the Ball" and "Salome," the former with Dickson, Chamlee, Brownlee and Cordon; the latter with Lawrence, Manski, Maison and Huehn. Panizza conducting both operas.

Mrs. John C. Ten Eyck gave a tea yesterday at her home, 455 East Fifty-seventh Street, for Countess Alice Hoyos, whose marriage to Mrs. Ten Eyck's son, John C. Ten Eyck Jr., takes place on March 17. Assisting the hostess in receiving was the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Clarence Browning Smith.

Joe Bree of Tuckahoe, representing the Curb Exchange, won the Gold Skates Trophy, emblematic of the.tri-State Indoor speed skating championship, for the second consecutive year at the third annual races sponsored by tile Middle Atlantic Skating Association at Playland tonight.
A special Spring market week will be staged at the merchandise mart beginning on March 14 for the housewares-. and major appliance industries. More than 1,500 buyers are expected to attend it.
Five policemen killed in battles with criminals since Oct. 25, 1937, received posthumous awards of honorable mention in general orders issued yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine.
Realty deals announced in the city over the week-end indicated a demand for houses by investors. Several of the properties were sold by savings banks. Much of the activity centered in Harlem.

The St. Mary's Celtics turned back the Paterson Caledonians, 3-0, in an American League soccer match at Celtic Park, Brooklyn, as 2,500 looked on yesterday. Three members of the McEwan family saw action for the home team and all figured prominently in the victory.

William W. Matthias, former soldier, Indian fighter and retired hardware dealer, died today at his home, 5,007 Ventnor Avenue. His age was 80. Mr. Matthias was a member of the United States Army from 1875 until 1884 and participated in several campaigns against the Indians. Following his discharge from the army he engaged in the hardware business.
The week's stock market was almost without feature, so inactive was it, in fact, that minor selling for the emigrant account caused a reaction. On the whole the week's financial aspect was weak.

The universal application of pension laws and health insurance and the widespread ownership of small homes in England have given the working masses an "immense financial stake in the country and are making working class psychology a thing of the past," Dr. Horace J.

Jerome B. Sullivan of Larchmont has become a general partner in Easland Co. of Hartford, Conn. Clarence Hebb, who was editor of The New York Daily Investment News since it was founded in 1929, has established a stock market analysis service.

Replying to what he said was "the major intellectual attack on Christianity today," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said it rested upon materialistic presuppositions which were becoming increasingly incredible, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

The cotton market here was comparatively quiet last week, due in part to the distractions of the local Mardi Gras carnival and a disposition of traders to await the action of Congress on the tax bill and other pending measures.

AKRON-Akron D. G. Co.: L. C. Bornstein, mdse. mgr., ready-to-wear; Miss M. Cross, sportswear, underwear; 218 W. 40th (B. F. Levis). ALBANY-John G. Myers Co.; P. J. Carbine, laces, embroideries, ribbons, hand-' kerchiefs: 11 W. 42d (F. Atkins). BALTIMORE-Fannie Lipsich; Miss F. Lipsich, dresses; Pennsylvania. BALTIMORE-Schleisner Co.; S.J. Schleisner, mdse. mgr. coats, dresses; 450 7th Ave. (J. Braunstein).

Lieutenant Charles Koehler, 54 years old, a member of the Elizabeth Fire Department for twenty years, was injured fatally and two other firemen were hurt when the roof of a rear porch of a two-story dwelling at 408 Rahway Avenue collapsed during a fire about 10 A. M. today. Lieutenant Koehler died in an ambulance on the way to a hospital.

Civic leaders from more than 150 cities will attend a conference in Washington Friday and Saturday to discuss the plan for relief and public welfare advanced by the National Citizens Committee of the Community Mobilization for Human Needs.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 75.6 on March 2, compared with 75.5 a fortnight before, 76.2 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The difficulties of the domestic situation are all the more regrettable, according to financial circles here, as they deprive the Government of the freedom of action necessary to face the dangers of the foreign situation.

Demonstrating once again that, regardless of what difficulties they may experience with the head of the American League, the other extremity of the Harridge loop holds no terrors for them, the Giants polished off the Athletics with consummate ease today to make a clean sweep of the two-game exhibition series.
The Scots-Americans defeated the New York Americans, 2 to 1, in an American Soccer League match at Scots Field today. The line-up:

At the Playhouse this evening the drama will start talking about Percy Bysshe Shelley and the Godwins-chiefly William Godwin-the occasion being "I Am My Youth," a new biographical play by Ernest Pascal and Edwin Harvey Blum.

President Roosevelt will soon lecture the nation through a message to Congress on the vital subject of phosphate. He will recommend no plan, it is understood, but will present a picture of the world phosphate situation, giving the facts about this indispensable chemical for which there is said to be no substitute.
John Foster Dulles, noted New York attorney and international finance expert, arrived here today, accompanying a group of Chinese bankers in a special plane from Hong Kong. Mr. Dulles lunched with T.

Max Baer went at his training with added vigor today, spurred by the promise of Promoter Mike Jacobs, who has pledged himself to promote a bout between the former heavyweight champion of the world and Gunnar Barlund should Max defeat Tommy Farr at Madison Square Garden on Friday night.

The Republic of Colombia could and should make payments on its external bonded debt, according to a bulletin to be issued today by Dean John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance.

Views of the trade outlook in Great Britain still are mixed, but that is because business evidence also is mixed. It seems in some respects to support the view that trade has entered a serious decline, but also the view that only a minor recession from a period of high activity is being experienced.

Deprived of his human rights and stripped of the dignity of his origin and purpose, man is expiring today on a cross of "bad thinking," victim of "the greatest crucifixion since Calvary," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

One of the busier weeks of th New York art season opens today: with some twoscore shows on th?? calendar. Work by European matters old and new and by American school children is to be found in the roster of exhibitions, with both group and one-man shows a museums and galleries included in the list. Sculpture, oils,
The wholesale price index for Germany on Feb. 23 was 105.7 against 105.5 the week before.
General John J. Pershing spent a comfortable day and progressed very satisfactorily today, according to Dr. Donald Davison, who at 8:30 P. M. issued this bulletin:

Contending that Councilman Hugh Quinn is not entitled to sit in the City Council because he was not a bona fide Queens resident when he was elected from that borough, C. D. Williams, counsel to the committee that investigated Mr. Quinn, urged his removal in a report submitted to the committee yesterday.

Nils Hanson. 27 years old, 171 East Ninety-fifth Street, died yesterday in Knickerbocker Hospital of second-degree burns he received in the explosion and fire in the Horton Pilsener Brewery Company plant at 479 West 128th Street on Friday.

James Reilly of Queens was appointed president of the Brooklyn Diocesan Holy Name Union yesterday by Mgr. Francis T. Connolly, spiritual leader of the union, at the organization's fifty-sixth annual meeting in the Church of Our Lady of Refuge, Ocean and Froster Avenues, Brooklyn.

Mrs. Jennie Longmorre Stevens, mother-in-law of Governor A. Harry Moore, died here of a heart attack today at her home, 62 Bramhall Avenue. Mrs. Stevens, a native of Ireland, was the oldest parishioner in years of membership of the Lafayette Reformed Church, where Governor Moore and her daughter, Mrs. Jennie Moore, teach Bible classes.
The Japanese spokesman contends that the Shansi Province invaders are continuing their advances along the most important lines of communications, which are now virtually entirely in their hands.
Liquidation Oat by tired longs was largely responsible for lower prices last week in the oats, rye and soy bean markets on the Board of Trade. Trading in those commodities was unusually light.

A set of rules by the State Labor Department governing radium painting is being observed so well throughout the industry in this State that not one compensation insurance claim based on radium poisoning has been filed since 1934, it was announced yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.
The Nicaraguan Government today gave the mining concession to William M. Vogts to develop the mines near San Ramon and Santo Domingo in the Departments of Matagalpa and Chontales.

With the receipt of acceptance yesterday from the University of Colorado and Oklahoma A. and M., the six-team field for the national invitation intercollegiate basketball tournament, which will open at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, was pronounced complete by the sponsoring Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association.

Our forefathers regarded work as the chief secular object of man's existence. A gloomy economics reduced us to the status of animals, breeding to the limits of subsistence, struggling ever with the reluctant earth. By the sweat of our brows were we to gain our bread. If we did not plant we should not reap.

John S. Simmons died yesterday at his home, 45 Gramercy Park. He was 71 years old. Mr. Simmons retired last year as vice president and treasurer of the John Simmons Company of New York and Long Island City, dealers in pipes, fittings and plumbing supplies.

Always when he could afford it, John Pichny, an elevator operator, had worn a gardenia in his lapel in the manner of the Wall Street brokers who rode in his elevator. Pichny died Friday night, loser in a two-year fight against tuberculosis,

Charges in connection with a demand for the removal of Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs are to be laid before Governor Lehman in Albany tomorrow. The Borough President is accused of violating his loath of office and failing in the Support of the Constitution by appointing Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, as an assistant.

Marie Gabriel Arakian, who appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night, disclosed a soprano voice of distinctive quality. As sheer voice it ranks among the most agreeable unveiled by a newcomer this season. It is equal and pure throughout an extensive range, ample in size and velvety in texture.

Elections for the new Parliament-the first to be elected since the establishment of the semi-dictatorial regime-have started in Shumen and Nova Zagora districts. According to an official statement the voting took place without any disturbances.
Supply contracts valued at $3,872,512 were awarded in the week ended on March 3 by ten Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts. Act, the Department of Labor has announced.

Dr. Bradford Oliver McIntire, Dickinson College Professor Emeritus of English and long recognized as an American authority on Elizabethan literature and Shakespearean drama, died here early today after a three weeks' illness with a heart ailment. His age was 81.

Bernard H. Ridder, '38, of New York, captain of the Princeton squash racquets team, won the university championship today by defeating Stanley W. Pearson Jr., 41, of Chestnut Hill in a five-game final. Dropping the first two games, 9--15, 11-15, Ridder rallied ?? triumph, 15-9, 15-12, 15-10.

The controversial frontier treaty -between Iraq and Iran, initialed last July in Teheran by the Ministers for Foreign Affairs of the two countries, was ratified today by a vote of 81 to 10 in the Chamber of Deputies. Seventeen Deputies abstained from voting.

English spellers regained yesterday morning the prestige lost five weeks before in the first transatlantic bee conducted by the National Broadcasting Company and the British Broadcasting Corporation. Where Oxford students failed against a Harvard-Radcliffe team, a varied group in London made the second international test a procession at the expense of Americans in corresponding walks of life.

Christians commit a grave mistake when they accept the belief that Jesus Christ came into the world to make things easy for His followers, the Right Rev. Dr. Charles Fiske declared in a sermon yesterday morning.
Orthodox international relations fell into the background as an influence in this week's financial markets, the Moscow trial instead occupying the center of the propaganda and agitation stage.

The decision of the directors of the Allen-A Company, for forty-six years one of the largest mills in the textile industry, to abandon operation of its plant here and transfer manufacturing to its plant at Bennington, Vt., was revealed yesterday by the local Hosiery Workers Union, whose members were notified to call for their tools. The mill has been idle.

Dr. Hirsch Loeb Gordon, in 10 W 86th St; Leonilda Durleux, in 2,728 Spuyten Duyvil Parkway, the Bronx; First Madison Corp. broker. D. J. Moynihan, in Manor House, Tudor City, from the Fred F. French Management Co.; Houghton Co., broker.

Bullish enthusiasm among traders in lard was dampened last week by further increases in supplies at leading markets and easiness in cottonseed oil, and at the close of trading yesterday on the Board of Trade net losses ranged from 121/2 to 321/2 cents a hundredweight.
New capital issues in Great Britain showed a considerable revival in February, amounting to [Pound]19,248,438, against [Pound]7,464,872 in January and [Pound]10,671,858 in February, 1937.

Walter Elster, 63, was found dead this afternoon sitting in a grave he was digging in a cemetery here. He was found by Fred Pomeroy, a pallbearer for the man for whom the grave was being dug. Coroner M. G. Burch said Elster had been dead for about three hours and death was from natural causes.

Hardy Wilbank, Philadelphia, won the Elliott Memorial Flyer Handicap Trophy in the interstate trapshooting tournament today. Wilbank tied with Alec Schwarz, also of Philadelphia, hitting 25 targets in the regular flyer shoot, but won a shoot-off, 10 to 9.
Twenty thousand boxing fans will pack Madison Square Garden tonight to witness the finals of the Golden Gloves-New York's leading amateur program of the year.

World events had a depressing influence on the Bourse this week and transactions were on an insignificant scale. All departments shared in the general dullness. On Thursday, prices hardened somewhat after intervention by the fund in the rentes market, but the rise evaporated with the week.

Walt McDougall, 80, cartoonist, was found dead of a bullet wound this afternoon in his home here. A revolver was at his side. Medical Examiner Frank M. Dunn and. State Troopers, who investigated, said Mr. McDougall's death was suicide and that he had been dead since Friday afternoon, when he was last seen by neighbors.
German steel markets are active, and the supplies, generally, have improved. Output, according to reports, is expected to increase.

Murray Levine, whose 12-year-old son, Peter, was kidnapped from near their home at 11 Slocum Street, New Rochelle, a week ago last Thursday, plainly showed the effect of the strain yesterday in his promised conversations with a spokesman for newspaper men at New Rochelle headquarters..

The Winter training period for the navy and army in the Caribbean area is rapidly coming to a close, with the naval vessels in the training detachment, commanded by Rear Admiral Alfred W. Johnson, scheduled to sail northward this week.

An expedition from the American Museum of Natural History will make a trip through territory southwest of the Teita district in Kenya Colony, British East Africa, following a route no white man has taken since Stanley cut the trail in his search for Dr. Livingston, it was announced yesterday.
Brooklyn fandom's four-year plea for a powerful pull hitter who swings from the port side was answered today by Larry MacPhail, new director 'of the Dodger destinies.

A radio alarm was broadcast over a local station early today for a person who inadvertently picked up a package of potassium cyanide crystals, a deadly poison, while buying baby food at a drug store here.

A strike of banana workers in the State of Magdalena was averted by an agreement signed yesterday by the Minister of Industries, the head of the National Labor Office, representatives of the Banana Workers Union and plantation owners, including the Magdalena Fruit Company. a United Fruit subsidiary.

The international inquiry commission headed by John Dewey that investigated the ZinovieffKameneff and Radek-Piatakoff trials and pronounced them frameups yesterday addressed a letter to Alexander Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador in -Washington, informing him that the commission had evidence contradicting the testimony

Stephen W. (Judge) McKeever president since 1932 and principal owner of the Dodgers, the Brooklyr baseball club in theNational League died early today at his home at 31 Maple Street, Brooklyn. He was 84 years old. He also had been an officer of the club for a quarter of a century.

The upward movement of cotton prices was halted last week. No great selling pressure developed, but demand was more limited than previously. On the New York Cotton Exchange, active futures contracts showed net changes for the week ranging from 1 point advance to 4 points decline.

Rallying to defeat his opponent, in seventeen innings, Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia assumed the lead in the current world's championship pocket billiard tournament as he conquered Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland, 125 to 120, to record his fourth straight victory and remain

Food store sales increased 4 per cent in 1937, reaching a total of $10,600,000,000, the largest volume since 1930, according to the results of the eighth annual survey, issued today by The Progressive Grocer.

Officials of the Greater New York Fund, Inc., announced yesterday that Leon Fraser had accepted the chairmanship of the committee on contributions of the campaign. Mr. Fraser, who is president of the First National. Bank of New York, will be in direct charge of all solicitation of funds.

Mr. David Sarnoff, who began his life in America as a messenger boy, has again glorified his office. Last Saturday night, when the closing concert of the transcendent Toscanini symphony air series was nearing its end, came Mr. Sarnoff with the news that plans had been perfected for a like series next year,

Hon. Fiorello H. La Guardia, Mayor of the City of New York, City Hall, New York City. Dear Mayor La Guardia: In the Summer of 1937 you appointed this board to report on problems arising from the transfer of the work of the Emergency Relief Administration to the Department of Public Welfare.

The Presidents recent assertion that the battleship is still queen of blue water has not only failed to calm the old controversy about the relative merits of the battleship and the plane, but seems to have intensified it.

Defeating the Bronx Chess Club by 10 1/2 to 4 1/2, with one game adjourned, in the semi-final round, the champion Marshall Club took a temporary lead in the Metropolitan Chess League yesterday. The Manhattan Club, tied with Marshall, failed to reach a decision with Empire City-International.
The Toronto Maple Leafs poured through Montreal Canadiens' defense for a 6-3 victory tonight and all but assured themselves of first place in the National Hockey League's International Group.

Details of a plan for the development of the University of Newark and the procedure to be followed in raising $1,000,000 for that purpose will be announced at a dinner to be given by the trustees of the institution at Essex House here on March

The Most Rev. Henry Joseph O'Leary, Archbishop of Edmonton, one of the leaders of the Roman Catholic Church in Canada, died here last night of a heart attack. He would have been 59 years old on March 13. Born in Richibucto, N. B., in 1879, he attended the University of St. Joseph at Memramcook, N. B.;
Eastern Baseball League club owners spent more than eight hours in executive session today at their annual meeting.

The possibility that the organized dental profession here will find at least a partial solution to the problem of caring for low income groups became apparent yesterday from the first returns of a questionnaire on the problem.

Charles F. Chapman, oldest living ex-chief of the Patchogue volunteer fire department, died at Community Hospital here late yesterday, following a short illness of pneumonia. He was 88 years old. A native of New York, Mr. Chapman had lived in Patchogue nearly all his life.

A large number of orders arrived in the wholesale market last week, but sales volume continued to run under last year's. Requests were chiefly for fill-in goods for immediate selling, with very little purchased to cover future requirements. A lag in dress demand was attributed partially to the imminence of new showings.

An alarming increase in sex crimes in New York City and throughout the United States was revealed yesterday in an analytical report made public by the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York, Harry F. Guggenheim, president. The study does not include commercialized vice.

AMES-In New York City, on March 6, 1938, Frank Darwin Ames, in his seventieth year. Funeral service at Central Presbyterian Church, 64th St. and Park Ave., on Tuesday, March 8, at 1 P. M. Interment Somerville, N. J. AMUNDSEN-James N.. beloved husband of Mary H. Amundsen, and father of Grace E. Crispens and Eric G., at his home, 414 6th Ave., North Pelham, N. Y. Services Geo. T. Davis Memorial,

C. Frank Murphy, 38 years old, personnel supervisor for the Treasury Department in Albany, died today of injuries suffered a week ago in an automobile accident, unaware his wife had died two hours before of injuries received in the same crash. Mrs. Murphy, the former Ethel Stacey of Albany, was employed in the State Insurance Department.
Sammy Baugh, famous football star, said tonight he would forsake the gridiron if he made good with the St. Louis Cardinals.
Dr. Mary Ely Lyman of New York City, Miss Mary E. Manchester of New Haven and Mrs. H. K. Hainter of Minneapolis were nominated yesterday for alumna trustee of Mount Holyoke College.

A Japanese Army spokesman said today that the Japanese sentry accused of slapping Miss Grace Brady, an American school teacher here, reported that he merely "deterred her by touching her coat collar."

Termination of the mortgage moratorium, except on small owner-occupied dwellings and business properties, on July 1 was advocated by the City Club of New York in a report made public yesterday. The City Club recommended that the moratorium as to the latter properties be extended until July 1, 1939.
Robert E. Simpson, 69-year-old retired assistant vice president of the Southern Railway, died at a hospital here today. He spent fifty-six years in railroad work.

An assertion that practices of the Biddle Purchasing Company of New York, first concern convicted of violating the brokerage clause of the Robinson-Patman Chain Store Act, are "a deceit upon the competitors of both the buyer and the seller" is made in a brief of the Federal Trade Commission to be filed tomorrow with the United States Circuit Court of Appeals at New York.

The Rev. Melville Young Bovard, retired Methodist Episcopal minister who was pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church in Bayonne, N. J., 1916-21, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 125 West Twelfth Street, at the age of 85. During most of his long career in the ministry he held pastorates in or near New York.
Unemployment insurance benefits are not deducted from old-age insurance, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Federal Social Security Board, announced yesterday.

Belief that, final Federal approval of the city's low-cost housing projects in Brooklyn and Queens would be obtained within two weeks was expressed yesterday by Alfred Rheinstein, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

The government's plan to create an autonomous fund for armaments is designed to facilitate the issuance of loans which will have to be raised this year to meet the nation's defense requirements. It is hoped that the public will subscribe more freely if it is assured that the proceeds of the bonds are to be earmarked for such a purpose.

Ch. Grapeside Gamble, a beagle owned by L. S. Knechtel of Athol, Mass., and handled by Miss Mabel Pyle of Pittsburgh, won the special for best in. show at the close of the twentythird annual all-breed exhibition of the Detroit Kennel Club in Convention. Hall tonight. The judge was Alva Rosenberg of New York City.

Chairman Arthur E. Morgan of the Tennessee Valley Authority strongly indicated today that he would not resign, as his two TVA colleagues suggested. He replied to them by making public a letter he wrote to Representative Maury Maverick in which he assailed the tactics of his fellow-directors and declared that only a Congressional investigation could "clean up" the situation within the TVA.

After a conference of Westchester County Republican leaders this afternoon, it was indicated that the County Board of Supervisors would be asked at its meeting tomorrow afternoon to rescind its resolution for transfer of the Bronx River Parkway to the State and call a Public hearing on the proposal.

The Board of Foreign Missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church made public yesterday a report it had received from the Rev. Lyman L. Hale of Manlius, N. Y., missionary-principal of William Nast Academy, a Methodist school for boys, at Kiukiang, China.

The "misuse" of power by Mussolini and Stalin for fascist and communist ends and by Americans for capitalistic aggrandizement was assailed yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer in his sermon at the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West at Sixty-fifth Street.

Miss Alison Bruere will give a luncheon on Friday at Sherry's for Miss Susanna W. P. Wilson, who will be married to David Meredith Hare on Saturday in the Church of the Resurrection. Miss Wilson is the daughter of Paul C. Wilson of Washington and Mrs. Wilson (Secretary Frances Perkins).

Four hundred and ninety degrees will be conferred tonight on 268 women and 222 men at the eleventh commencement exercises of Brooklyn College to be held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Lafayette Avenue and St. Felix Place.
Five thousand Italian troops landed at Cadiz, Spain, during the past week, the Gibraltar correspondent of The Daily Herald reported tonight on the eve of the opening of AngloItalian friendship talks.

John A. Coleman, executive chairman of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity for the 1938 Catholic Charities Appeal, announced yesterday that Frank C. Walker, former treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, would serve as treasurer of the campaign committee.

Lafayette St, n e cor 4th St. 100x117.6 irreg; trustee will of Roswll Smith to Walter Peek Paper Corp. 30 Main St, Brooklyn: consideration $15,000 over mtg, for $77,500. 37th St, 148 E. 20x98.9; trustees will of Anton C. G. Hupfel to Gilbert H. Montague, 152 E 37th St ($22).

Officers and men of the Fire Department will vote this week on a proposal that they make monthly contributions of not more than 25 cents each to establish a fund for charitable purposes, Richard F. Warner, secretary of the department, announced yesterday.

Four persons were killed when a Junkers plane crashed in the Andes Mountains Friday. The bodies of the two German pilots, Fritz Hammer and Conrad Butscher, and Marco Aguirre and Ricardo Weiss, Ecuadorian members of the crew, were found in the wreckage near Guaranda.

Labor unions and the unemployed were urged to picket for more jobs by William J. Carney, regional director of the C. I. O., at a joint meeting here today of 400 members of the Newark Trade Union Committee on the Unemployed and the Workers Alliance of Essex County.

The French wholesale price index on Feb. 26 stood at 613, compared with 611 on Feb. 19 and 607 on Feb. 12. All groups in the index were affected by the rise. The gold index for raw materials on Feb. 26 was 43.7, compared with 43.8 a week earlier and 43 on Feb. 12.

If war abroad should curtail our foreign trade, the United States can resort to a program of government employment to meet the emergency here, Senator Robert M. La Follette of Wisconsin said yesterday. Senator La Follette addressed about 4,500 persons at an anti-war rally
Members of the Legislature from the metropolitan area voted on important legislation last week as follows:

Describing the completion of the Cathedral of St.. John the Divine as "a great demonstration of the power of religion in these troublous times," Bishop William T. Manning spoke yesterday morning on "The Lenten Message" at the morning communion service in the cathedral.

Industrial reports indicate that the Winter setback included many enterprises not usually considered in the seasonal category, in particular the engineering, electrical, iron wares and, textiles branches.

The Amateur Athletic Union has accepted an invitation to send a team of wrestlers to Europe next Fall for matches in Scandinavian countries, Chairman George M. Pinneo announced yesterday through Daniel J. Ferris.

Following skirmishes and discussions that have been going on for eight months, Metro has signed a contract with Technicolor to make six films for the new season, the first to be Kenneth Roberts's "Northwest Passage." MGM's capitulation leaves Twentieth Century-Fox as the only major concern without color films on its program.

A forum meeting of 700 young Catholic laymen called yesterday afternoon at Corpus Christi Church, 535 West 121st Street, by the New York Province of the Federation of College Catholic Clubs to discuss the ownership of public utilities, vociferously overrode attempts of Province officers to prevent adoption of a resolution sharply criticizing the labor policy of the Consolidated Edison Company and advocating eventual acquisition of the company by the city.

Nine undergraduate students at City College have been elected to Lock and Key, junior and senior honorary society for students prominent in extracurricular activities, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Janovsky, chancellor of the society.

The recent act of Congress canceling Reconstruction Finance Corporation notes given to the Treasury for moneys disbursed at the direction of Congress for relief and to other governmental agencies, "and about which the directors of the RFC had no choice," has been erroneously construed by some persons as a write-off of loans, Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC, declared in a statement today.

Fear that the drinking water in parts of San Bernardino and Orange Counties is contaminated was added today to the troubles of those floodstricken communities. Light rains fell in Los Angeles County and more rain was predicted later in the week, but flood control engineers said that the dams and reservoirs high in the Sierra Madre Range back of Los Angeles had been emptied sufficiently to handle any normal rainfall.

The establishment of a Jewi State outside of Palestine, as cently proposed by the Italian Gc ??ernment, with a hint that one Italy's African possessions may offered for this purpose, would contrary to the interests of t Zionist movement, according to ?? Israel Goldstein, acting preside of the Zionist Organization America.

Announcement of the largely increased amount to be spent for Great Britain's defense in the coming fiscal year has come as a shock to the City, temporarily, but rather severely, depressing the security markets.

In a game fraught with bristling action and tense situations, the New York Americans did last night what they had been unable to do four times previously this season. They conquered their intracity rivals in the National Hockey League, the Rangers, by 3 to 1 before a wildly cheering crowd of 15,500 at Madison Square Garden.

The Rev. Martin Niemoeller in the hands of the Nazis was compared today with Jesus in the hands of the multitude in the first Sunday services since the militant Protestant pastor was thrown into a concentration camp by the secret police.

Those who say it is "time for another war" are ignoring "the essential conviction of all high religion that man can live here and now the eternal life with God, and in God's power alter the predicted stream of events,"
" The comforts of Christian civilization today are often mistaken for Christianity," the Rev. Charles C. Cole declared yesterday morning at the Grace Methodist Church, 131 West 104th Street.

Walter (Rube) Lutzke, former third baseman for the Cleveland baseball club of the American League, died at his home here today at the age of 40. He had been in poor health for a year. Mr. Lutzke, after a long career with the Indians, concluded organized league play with Chattanooga of the Southern Association in 1931.

Barron K. Throckmorton, formerly vice president and sales manager of the Star Brush Company, has been named vice president and general manager of J. C. Pushee Sons, Inc., brush manufacturers, Boston, Mass. Frank E. Gallagher, formerly of the Rubberset Company, becomes sales manager; Samuel D. Childs, special representative in charge of the Western division, and J. F. Gallagher and A. F. Wheeler, territorial representatives.
British authorities today captured a number of noted Arab brigands in a follow-up to an encounter in which more than a hundred Arabs were slain Friday.

A new form of degeneration "in the area that used to be Hell's Kitchen" needs treatment with settlement house technique, Algernon D. Black, leader of the Society for Ethical Culture, said yesterday afternoon.

The final program of the young people's concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next Saturday morning has been devised after a vote of the children. It includes Tchaikovsky's "Nutcracker Suite,"

Wayne Sikes of the home club gained the metropolitan Class B badminton championship yesterday when he defeated Julian Burgess of Garden City, 15-9, 7-15, 15--3, on the courts of the Old Sixty-ninth Badminton and Tennis Club.

Members of the New York Circle, International Federation of Catholic Alumnae, will hold their annual card party and fashion show the afternoon of March 19 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Proceeds will further the program of Catholic education sponsored by the International Body.

Stocks irregularly lower, in the slowest trading for a week since 1923; turnover, 2,678,875 shares. United States Government and foreign bonds mixed; corporate issues lower, with week's trading the smallest since 1918; transactions, $26,935,375.

Mrs. Glen Seymour Treglown of 940 Glenwood Avenue, has sent out invitations to the marriage of her daughter, Miss Jane Elizabeth Treglown, to William Sillo MacFarlane of New York. The ceremony will take place March 24 in the chapel of the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. John J. Moment, pastor, will perform the ceremony.

William Slack and Hunter Lott won the national squash racquets doubles championship tonight by defeating two fellow Philadelphians, Don Strachan and A. Willing Pattersop, in the final of two-day tournament.

John Macrae, president of E. P Dutton Co., returned recently from a six weeks' stay in England. Among the books that Mr. Macrae brought back was Prince Albert's "Letters of the Prince Consort, 1831-1861," selected and edited by the archivist, Dr. Kurt Jagow.
An offering of ten and one-half year 2 1/2 per cent Treasury bonds of 1948 in exchange for $455,175,500 of maturing 3 per cent Treasury notes was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau.

Persons interested in making it possible for low-paid wage earners to improve their own condition were urged last night by William Jay Schieffelin, chairman of the Citizens Union and president of the Savings Bank Life Insurance League of New York, to ask their Senator and Assemblyman to vote for the State Savings Bank Life Insurance Bill.

Professor Carl F. Schreiber of Yale University and Mrs. Schreiber announced today that their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Schreiber, would be married to George Sullivan Stearns Jr., son of Mrs. Naomi C. Stearns of Miami, Fla., and the late Mr. Stearns of Cincinnati, on March 26, in Marquand chapel of the Yale Divinity School.

Plans for a third attempt to elect a Bishop-Coadjutor for the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Central New York will be made here tomorrow--morning when a special committee, appointed by Bishop Edward H. Coley of Utica, will consider candidates. In May, 1937,

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Elton Waterbury Clark of Forest Hills of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Lang Clark, to William Booth Trainer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Trainer of Sewickley Heights, Pa.

All that can be said of last week's markets was that production remained unchanged - steel output holding for the second successive week at 30 per cent of capacityand that Stock Exchange averages, having risen 5-8 point, fell back 3, recovering slightly afterward.

Word was received here today of the death of J. Fred Cowperthwaite, a resident of this town for the last fifty years, at his Winter home at Jacksonville, Fla. Mr. Cowperthwaite, a retired wool manufacturer, was 82 years old. A native of New York, he had been in business there until his retirement twenty years ago.

The Ludlum Steel Company reports for 1937 a net profit of $1,120,422, compared with $1,041,245 for 1936, the best previous year. Net sales for 1937 were $13,054,202, a high record, despite the recession in the fourth quarter of the year, and compare with $10,829,000 for 1936.

In preparing to build more battleships "we are not traveling the road to peace and brotherhood, but the road to war and chaos," the Rev. Arthur M. Crawford declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 29 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the rate in the four preceding weeks. and equal to the average in January.

The issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES for Sunday, Feb. 6, was belatedly delivered in Tokyo today, minus the Book Review section. The Department of Communications states that a review is under examination because it is suspected that part of its contents consists of prohibited matter.

With a salesman, a chemist and a printing company executive in the principal roles, the twenty-fourth season of the Passion Play opened officially in Veronica's Veil Auditorium here tonight before an audience estimated at 1,200 persons.

The first international business "Who's Who" will appear today, according to an announcement by the Institute for Research in Biography, Inc., 205 East Forty-second Street. The volume, "Who's Who in Commerce and Industry,"

Herbie Lewis blasted three goals past the National Hockey League's leading goalie tonight to give Detroit's downtrodden champion Red Wings a 4-to-3 victory over the Boston Bruins, pacemakers of the American group.
Improvement in steel buying is slight and irregular, according to the magazine Steel, which adds that "most mills find somewhat broader demand and a gradual, though slow, tendency upward."

Nikolai Bukharin is on trial for his life: Bukharin the great interpreter of Marxist theory, Bukharin who inspired the Five-Year Plans and made the scientific method a part of the Soviet approach to the technological development of Russia.
Mrs. Gertrude Neumann Rock, wife of Rear Admiral George H. Rock, U.S.N., retired, died Saturday night at her home, Webb and Sedgwick Avenues, after a brief illness. She was 68 years old.

Slightly freshening winds from the north gave skippers in the St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race new hope tonight after a day of slow sailing. A fog which had prevailed during the day lifted and the weather was reported clear by Coast Guard craft accompanying the fleet.

Brig. Gen. Wade Hampton Hayes of London, a former commanding officer of the 107th Infantry Regiment, N. Y. N. G., will be honored Wednesday night by the regiment at a review in the armory at 643 Park Avenue.

Hannibal Hamlin, son of Lincoln's Vice President of the same name and a former Attorney General of Maine, died in a hospital tonight of injuries received Feb. 25 in a fall down the cellar stairs of his Ellsworth residence. He was 79 years of age. Although' out of the public eye, politically, for several years, Mr. Hamlin had acquired several education honors in recent years.

The pilot of an airplane searching Lake Erie for the missing fishing tug Cecil M. found the vessel fast in an ice field today, about twenty-five miles due south of Port Burwell. The pilot reported the tug's crew of two alive. The men have been without food for nearly five days.
The Irish-Americans of Kearny, N. J., defeated the Brookhattans, 3-2, yesterday before 5,000 fans at Starlight Park in an American League soccer game and clinched third place in the play-offs.

Herbert M. Kopf will launch Manhattan's new football regime today when forty candidates will report for Spring practice in the gymnasium. Seventeen lettermen will be among those trying for varsity positions.

An opportunity to lay sure foundations for world peace faces the British Government under Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, said the Rev. Moses Richardson Lovell, who preached his first sermon yesterday morning at Central Congregational Church, Hancock Street near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, as successor to the late Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman.

The annual report of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation for 1937, released today, shows a consolidated net income of $10,502,271, after all expenses and charges, which, on the basis of the present capitalization, was equal to 84 cents a share on the common stock after preferred dividend deductions.

Mayor La Guardia called upon the State yesterday to undertake the full burden of relief financing if it was unwilling to restore to the city directly or indirectly the revenue from the 3 per cent tax on the gross income of public utilities.

Dick Bertram, sailing Seabiscuit, and Jack Prokop in Popover, were the winning skippers among the few who braved a cold northwest wind and choppy sea to compete In the weekly frostbite dinghy racing on Manhasset Bay today.

Cohen, Goldman Co., men's clothing manufacturers, will launch their Spring advertising campaign in newspapers on Sunday, according to Hirshon-Garfield, Inc., advertising agency for the company. Fullpage copy will appear in rotagravure sections of newspapers of about fifteen key cities, with approximately four insertions scheduled for each paper. In several cities, color will be used.

With Rollin Home and Preeminent looming as joint choices in the featured Pan-American Handicap, the final race meeting of the Florida season will begin tomorrow at Tropical Park. Seven are named, but most interest is sure to be divided between the two favorites. Other contenders are Sir Oracle,

Dartmouth and New York University made the basketball news last week, which marked the end of the campaign for all except a few-of the leading teams. The Indians clinched the Eastern Intercollegiate League championship, while the Violet gained the unofficial metroDolitan title.

Seven hundred employes of the Thermoid Company, members of the United Rubber Workers of America, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, voted today to call off a self-imposed "holiday" and return to work tomorrow with a 5 per cent wage reduction.

The minorities of the world are reviving their ancient cultures for use in their fight for political liberation, Ludwig Lewisohn, author, declared in an address before the congregation of the Free Synagogue in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning.

Former President Hoover will arrive here from Prague tomorrow evening and will visit Chancellor Adolf Hitler at the Chancellery Tuesday noon. The conversation is not expected to be long because Mr. Hoover has a luncheon engagement with Hans-Georg Viktor von Mackensen, Under-Secretary in the Foreign Ministry.
The National Wool Growers Association protested today the standards for wool published on March 2 by the Bureau of Standards of the Department of Commerce.

The treason trial has reached the half-way point and paused today, this being the Soviet rest day. The four days of the trial already past have been filled with sensations. The trial should be finished sometime this week and from all appearances the days to come will be filled with as much sensation as the days past.

Forty-two boxers, representing seven Eastern colleges, were paired yesterday for the opening of the Eastern Intercollegiate Boxing Association championships at State College, Pa., Friday, according to The Associated Press.

The meeting place for the Anglo-Irish negotiations was transferred today to the country home of Malcolm MacDonald, Secretary of State for the Dominions, who entertained Premier Eamon de Valera and High Commissioner John Whelan Dulanty at luncheon. No definite program has been arranged, but a plenary meeting likely will be held tomorrow night.

In a memorandum, copies of which were sent to every member of the Legislature, the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, denounced yesterday the Burchill bill purporting to grant the right of genuine collective bargaining to the 5,400 employes of the city's Independent Subway System.

A ticket headed by Senator Robert F. Wagner as the candidate for Governor and Governor Lehman as the candidate for Senator is under consideration by leading members of the Democratic State organization, it became known yesterday.

The United States has received a distorted impression of events in Spain because of the flood of Loyalist propaganda, student representatives of five Catholic colleges agreed in a symposium on Spain held tonight before the student body of the College of New Rochelle. The Rev. Francis X. Talbot,

Edward Anthony Mechling, chemical company official and former Olympic athlete, died of a heart attack at his home here yesterday. He was 60 years old. Mr. Mechling was assistant general manager of the Mechling Brothers chemicals division of the General Chemical Company, with his offices in Camden.

In the proceedings at Moscow are being tried not only shattered and broken people, morally semi-corpses, but also actually deceased ones. The specters of Marshal Mikhail N. Tukhachevsky, of Generals I. E. Yakir, J. P. Uborevich, A. I. Kork and other assassinated generals share the prisoners' dock.

The former Evelyn Granville, known in the Nineties as "the most photographed girl in New York," died here last week, penniless and alone. Few were aware that the 66-yearold Mrs. Evelyn G. Scott, until last December employed on a WPA sewing project, was the former stage beauty who had appeared before the turn of the century with Lillian Russell.
Many reservations have been made for the annual Mi-Careme luncheon and card party for the benefit of the Jesuit Houses of Study which will take place March 14 at the Ambassador.

The New York Dock Company yesterday notified holders of $4,386,000 of 5 per cent serial notes that the notes cannot be paid when they mature on April 1, and that refinancing with a new issue has been found to be impossible at this time.

In rough and tough going out on Long Island Sound today, Howard McMichael, sailing his B boat Ordeal in the Larchmont Yacht Club regatta, took four races to lead his division, and Dick Hill led the X craft at the helm of his wife's dinghy, Dunker.

Miss Martha Victoria Ray, daughter of Mrs. George A. Ray of West Hartford, was married to Charles ??aninwegen Cuddeback yesterday afternoon in the Second Congregaonal Church here. The ceremony ??as performed by the Rev. Warren ??eymour Archibald.

The restless soul of man in his hunger is turning to spiritual themes of life, the Rev. C. Everett Wagner, the pastor, said yesterday morning at the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, Forty-eighth Street just west of Broadway. One evidence of this, he said, was the increasing number of plays with such themes.
In Vienna political events are marked by the marching of children. There were many little boys among the bareheaded, barelegged cheering youths who marched around the Ring yesterday and today.
The report of the American Smelting and Refining Company for 1937 released for publication today shows a consolidated net income of $18,285,425 after charges, taxes and reserves. This was equal,

The Artef Players are calling the season at their house in Sixty-third Street ended as of March 27, thereby canceling plans to move elsewhere. Until then they will have performances every Friday, Saturday and Sunday night and Sunday afternoon; also,

The refreshing idealism of Anthony Eden is a virtue we should all admire. He fought as a crusader for collective security through the League of Nations. It is his creed that law and treaties are sacred and must be respected. In this his stand is unassailable provided the treaties are workable from an economic standpoint.

Arturo Toscanini, world-famous conductor, declared himself deeply impressed with the general artistic plans of the New York World's Fair of 1939, and particularly pleased with the music program contemplated for the exposition, during an inspection tour of the fair site in Flushing Meadow Park yesterday.

Walther Funk, new Economics Minister, opened the Leipzig Fair today with a speech in which he appealed to the United States for an improvement in American-German trade relations. At the same time, however, he pledged Germany to a continuation and even intensification of the present economic policy, which Washington has always viewed as a principal obstacle to such improvement.

Ordinarily considered a necessary, though pleasant, daily item or an outright epicurean delight, food was nominated for a new mission in life yesterday by Gilbert Seldes, author and critic. He put it forward as an insidious social weapon, offering a more refined torturehence a more thorough social chastisement-than could be obtained by words or action.

R. B. Bennett's announcement yesterday of his impending retirement from the leadership of the Conservative party leaves the dilemma of the party unchanged. Its problem is to find a policy on which it can hope to succeed, for the choice of a policy will determine the choice of a leader.
Dartmouth's Warren Chivers and Raymond Lambert of Lebanon today shared honors as the nation's largest ski jump was opened to Olympic tryout competition at this city's annual Winter carnival.

Corn futures on the Board of Trade here held within narrow limits last week. Breaks below 59 cents a bushel for May drew in fairly aggressive buying, which the trade attributed toexport business, while around 60 cents there was a marked increase in country offering of cash grain for deferred shipment.

The Baleares and the Canarias, one of which was torpedoed yesterday in the naval battle off Southeastern Spain, were laid down at Ferrol, Aug. 15, 1928. The Caharias, except for some installations was completed in 1935, the Baleares in 1937. They are sister ships.

In a memorandum, copies of which were sent to every member of the Legislature, the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, denounced yesterday the Burchill bill purporting to grant the right of genuine collective bargaining to the 5,400 employes of the city's Independent Subway System.

A ticket headed by Senator Robert F. Wagner as the candidate for Governor and Governor Lehman as the candidate for Senator is under consideration by leading members of the Democratic State organization, it became known yesterday.

The United States has received a distorted impression of events in Spain because of the flood of Loyalist propaganda, student representatives of five Catholic colleges agreed in a symposium on Spain held tonight before the student body of the College of New Rochelle. The Rev. Francis X. Talbot,

Edward Anthony Mechling, chemical company official and former Olympic athlete, died of a heart attack at his home here yesterday. He was 60 years old. Mr. Mechling was assistant general manager of the Mechling Brothers chemicals division of the General Chemical Company, with his offices in Camden.

In the proceedings at Moscow are being tried not only shattered and broken people, morally semi-corpses, but also actually deceased ones. The specters of Marshal Mikhail N. Tukhachevsky, of Generals I. E. Yakir, J. P. Uborevich, A. I. Kork and other assassinated generals share the prisoners' dock.

Irving E. Manchester, for more than twenty years identified with The Winsted Evening Citizen and once its managing editor, president and treasurer, died today in a convalescent home here. His age was 67. Mr. Manchester, who was graduated from Wesleyan University in 1896, started with The Citizen in 1897 and left temporarily in 1904 to go with The Commercial Bulletin in Hartford. Besides The Citizen.

Tests of strength on important phases of the government reorganization and revenue bills will come tomorrow and Tuesday, as the Administration leadership in the Senate and House endeavors to keep these measures from drastic amendment in the final stages of debate.

The Celanese Corporation of America reports a net income of $4,461,227 for 1937 after all deductions, equal, after prior-preferred dividends and provisions of $8.53 a share on the 7 per cent participating-preferred stock, to $2.04 a share on 1,000,000 common shares, compared to $4,406,993, or $2.25 a share, allowing for participation, in 1936.

The Old Westbury polo team continued its conquest of Southern California aggregations by defeating the Los Indios quartet today at Midwick Country Club, 13 to 8. Cecil Smith was the star for the Easterners, getting eight goals. His team-mate, Stewart Iglehart, scored four. Darryl Zanuck, captain of Los Indios, tallied three goals.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83, which compares with 83 a week ago, 82.4 two weeks ago, 82.4 three weeks ago and 82.6 four weeks ago. The average of 83.9 in the second week of January was the highest of the year to date; the average of the first and second weeks of February, 82.4, was the lowest.

The Transport Workers Union announced yesterday that the taxicab drivers locked out on Saturday by the Atlas-Liberty and SunshineRadio Taxicab Owners Association had been placed with other large fleet operators.

Harrison Ave (11-3206), e 5 165 it n for 180th St, 55x100: 2116 Harrison Ave Corp to 943 Whitlock Ave Corp. 1,900 Grand Concourse: mtg, 542,250. Gunther Ave (17-5007), new cor or Bussing Ave 90x30: Philip Paglin to William A. Jones 2,970 Marion Ave.
The team of Miss Helen Bonwit, Mrs. Estelle Drescher, Howard Schenken and Morrie Elis last night won the mixed team-of-four title and the Whitehead Cup in the Eastern contract bridge championships.

Ninety-eight patrolmen, working in two daily shifts, will begin enforcement at 8 o'clock this morning of the city's new ban on parking on ten downtown streets, the Traffic Division of Police Headquarters announced last night.

Communist activity and propaganda were denounced at the closing sessions yesterday of the first national convention of the Jewish Labor Committee at the Capitol Hotel, Eighth Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street.

The Federal Trade Commission has announced hearings to be held at 45 Broadway, New York, this week in the cases indicated as follows: Wednesday-El Moro Cigar Company, Greensboro, N. C.; Grand Gas Light, Inc., New York.

The Fraro Realty Corporation, which bought recently front Loomis J. Grossman the six-story apartment house at 1,465 Midland Avenue, Fleetwood, Westchester County, has resold it to an investing client of A. Robinson Co. The property consists of forty-six apartments and a large garage. Low Gross, Inc., negotiated the sale and resale.

Karl Baadsvick, Peterborough, Ont., and Karl Fahrner, Buffalo, shared top honors today at the New York State ski meet. More than 1,500 watched the meet in Alleghany State Park, although unfavorable weather caused two of the events, the downhill and slalom races, to be called off.

Frank Darwin Ames, a real estate broker and developer, died yesterday in the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital of a complication of ailments which included heart disease and arterial sclerosis. He was 69 years old. No member of his immediate family survives.

Thirteen thousand fans yelled themselves hoarse as the New York Rovers counted five times in the third period to down the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 6 to 4, in a slambang Eastern Hockey League battle, the feature of the amateur twin bill at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith will open formally this morning the new banking, quarters of the Lawyers Trust Company, of which he is chairman, at 135 Broadway. He will unlock the doors of the bank's new home at 9:30 A. M. in the presence of directors of the institution and guests.

The text of the letter written by Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, to Representative Maury Maverick of Texas, outlining the situation prevailing among the members of the Authority on matters of policy, follows:

With Pete Grace, former Yale star, playing a stellar game as goalie, the St. Nicholas Hockey Club scored a 12-to-1 victory over the New York Athletic Club at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday. The contest was the replay of the first game of a three-game play-off series for the New York Amateur Hockey Association.

Mrs. Henry Leroy Finch will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 46 East Seventy-fourth Street, for members of a committee of which she is chairman for the Butterfly Ball to be held on April 22 at the Ritz-Carlton.

The American Legion was assailed last night as "one of the costliest results of the last war" by the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie. He spoke at the first of five Sunday evening Lenten services in the Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, of which he is rector.
