The Baltimore Orioles tied the Hershey Bears, 3 to 3, in an Eastern Amateur Ice Hockey League game tonight. An extra period was called with the score tied at 2-2, after a late Oriole rally had overcome a 2-to-0 Hershey lead.

Active aid to China in the form of an official embargo or boycott of Japan by foreign nations would lead to an involvement in the war and would leave China no better off, Dr. Nathaniel Peffer of Columbia University, authority on Far Eastern affairs, declared yesterday at-the Community Church in Town Hall.

The views of financial London on Great Britain's adverse balance of foreign payments, which last year increased from [Pound]18,000,000 to [Pound]52,000,000, now are crystallizing into definite expressions of opinion.

The British Ambassador, the Earl of Perth, arrived here this evening after a full week of conferences in London with Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Viscount Halifax, Foreign Minister, in which presumably all aspects of the pending Italo-British negotiations were thoroughly discussed.

Harry Thoens captured high gun laurels for the second day in a row at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. Breaking 97 in the 100-target event, Thoens led in a large field. He scored Saturday with 98.

The price of grapefruit last week took a sudden upturn on the nation's markets and the Texas market control group reduced the weekly allowable for next week. The opinion of leaders in the industry, generally, is that control of the Texas crop is here to stay.

Lawrence Iverson, 41 years old, a member of the Council of Shrewsbury Borough and chairman of its finance committee, was killed about 8:30 o'clock tonight in a collision of the automobile in which he was riding alone and a New Yorkbound passenger train of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

The tenth annual Army Day parade will be held the afternoon of Saturday, April 9, on upper Fifth Avenue, proceeding south from Ninetieth Street to Sixty-third Street, Rear Admiral Reginald R. Belknap, U. S. N., retired, announced yesterday.

Richard Durrance, the Dartmouth ski star who has been recognized as this country's foremost downhill and slalom runner, lost his laurels today. as the national open championships came to an end on the famous Nose Dive Trail at Mount Mansfield.

A 10,000-ton Rebel cruiser, either the Canarias or the Baleares, was torpedoed and set afire by a Loyalist destroyer and later bombed off Cartagena, Spain, in a naval battle yesterday morning. A sister ship of the victim was reported hit by a bomb in the airplane operations.

AFIGHTER looked down from his corner at the faces in the front press row and suddenly grinned and waved "hello." This was at Madison Square Garden. The fighter was from St. Louis. It was a telegrapher who acknowledged the salute.

2:00-3:00 P. M.-United States Navy Band Concert-WJZ. 3:00-4:00 P. M.-Rochester Civic Orchestra Concert-WJZ. 3:15-3:45 P. M.-"Shall City Civil Courts Be Consolidated by Constitutional Convention?"-Judge Frank E. Johnson of the Municipal Court; Julius Applebaum, Brooklyn Bar Association-WNYC. 8:00-8:30 P. M.-Variety Show: Lou Holtz, Comedian-WABC. 8:30-9:00P. M.-Richard Crooks, Tenor; Symphony Orchestra, Alfred Wallenstein, Conductor--WEAF.

On rare occasions in sport the one who is vanquished proves a bigger and better story than the one who wins. Such a situation developed on Saturday at the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. championships when Manhattan College, a rank outsider, came perilously close to upsetting highly favored Columbia for the indoor track crowns.

A conference of representatives from fifty professional groups adopted resolutions yesterday afternoon asking that the Works Progress Administration be made permanent and expanded to provide 3,500,000 new jobs, 100,000 of them in New York City.

The Honor Brand Frosted Foods Corporation of this city has sold a minority stock interest in the corporation to Stokely Brothers Co., Inc., leading growers and canners, Indianapolis, according to. an announcement. made today by Max Waterman, president of the corporation.

Econonmic boycotts of foreign nations are dangerous and tend to create estrangements that may lead to more serious consequences, Senator Borah said today in a statement in which he urged that the movement in the United States to 'boycott Japan be abandoned.

A public controversy of large proportions, appeared to be brewing tonight over suggestions that the United States grant tariff reductions on imports of textiles and other manufactured goods from the United Kingdom.
The 6,000ton German cruiser Koeln with 700 men aboard radioed for assistance in entering Trondhjem Fjord off the Norwegian Coast today after a raging North Atlantic storm had crippled her engines.

Lemuel L. Stewart, 54 years old, drowned in flood waters in Long Beach, Calif., was identified today as a retired advertising manager for Paramount-Publix Theatres in New York. He had come here from New York preparatory to taking a South Seas trip.

President Roosevelt accepted on Wednesday the resignation of Judge Charles Harwood of the United States District court of the Panama Canal Zone. Mr. Harwood said he resigned to do special work for the Department of Justice, but did not indicate the nature of the new assignment.
The stock market followed yesterday the pattern of the four sessions immediately preceding, in that prices sagged and trading was dull.

The Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company has filed with the Public Service Commission an application for a re-hearing and a rescission or a modification of the commission's order in connection with the purchase of the common stock of the Nassau and Suffolk Lighting Company and the Long Beach (Gas Company, Inc.,

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Color in Chinese Porcelain," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; American wing (general tour), noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Design in Decorative Fabrics," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "Painting and Poetry of the T'ang Dynasty," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 4 P. M.

Sharp rises in accidents and injuries in city traffic in the last week and week-end as compared with the corresponding periods of last year were announced yesterday by the safety bureau of the Police Department.
State Attorney General William McCraw filed 'suit' today seeking cancellation of charters and penalties aggregating possibly $30,000,000, against six major cement manufacturing companies.

When the sale of the former residence of the late Frederic A. Juilliard at 11 West Fifty-seventh Street was announced recently the buyer was shown as an investor. Recording of the transaction in the office of the New York County Register yesterday revealed that the parcel was purchased for $112,
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
Carrier Corporation's sales for February were within 5 per cent of the total for February, 1937, according to a report yesterday by L. R. Boulware, vice president and general manager,

Joseph (Socks) Lanza, deposed czar of the Fulton Fish Market, who is serving a two-year prison sentence for violating the anti-trust law in the fresh water fish industry, appeared yesterday in Federal Court and pleaded guilty to an indictment accusing him of similar violations in the salt water fish industry.
Secondary railroad issues suffered a fresh sinking spell yesterday in relatively quiet trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. Some traders were inclined

The terms on the Treasury's new bonds to be issued in exchange for the $455,000,000 of Treasury 3 per cent notes, maturing on March 15, were about in line with expectations and reflected the improvement in the government bond market since last December.

22d St, 320-30 E, 155x97.6; Sophie N. Wemple to Colen Garages, Inc., 416 E 95th St; mtg $109,500 ($16). 53d St, n a, 75 ft e of 10th Ave, 100x100.5: Seamen's Bank for Savings to Cynthia Kuser Herbst, Bernardsville, N. J. ($90).

Whatever the fate of the Westchester County Park Commission its past is secure. The achievement of that body is one of the monumental American contributions of engineering and landscaping to the enhancing of democracy's estate, for the roads and parks are a very considerable part of the property which it has kept for public use.
Four persons were killed and one wounded tonight at Camarones, near the Cabanas Fortress across the bay from Havana, during an armed clash between soldiers and alleged conspirators.

Five American companies presented bids today to the Cuban Government for appointment as fiscal agent in the proposed exchange of a new $85,000,000 bond issue for the outstanding defaulted public works obligations.

A business property in the Bronx passed to new control when Milton R. Leader and Francis J. Kleban leased from William D. Cameron the one-stpry building at 2,306-12 Grand Concourse, near the 183d Street station of the Eighth Avenue subway.
The New York Stock Exchange corrected yesterday a previous announcement that Twining Tousley had retired from Reimer, Terry Co. on March 1. Mr. Tousley will continue as a partner in the firm.

Serious impairment, if not a breakdown, in the administration of State unemployment insurance laws may be expected if the Federal Government's contemplated cuts in administrative allowances are made, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, declared yesterday.

Representative Vinson, chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee which drafted the Tax Revision Bill, has remarked in a radio talk that, should a motion prevail to strike out Section 1-B--the "third basket" taxthe base rate on corporation incomes would have to be Increased from 20 to 22 1/2 per cent or other taxes included to make up the lost revenue.

The governments claiming of Canton and Enderbury Islands in the Pacific Ocean has no connection with war or war plans, but was motivated by a desire to meet the needs of commercial aviation, the White House announced today.

British unemployment, which has been mounting steadily, showed a decrease in February for the first time in four months, according to a report issued tonight by the Ministry of Labor. The gain, however, is slight and in view of the normal February upturn the figures are considered disappointing.

William J. Dwyer, president of the Franklin Society, in announcing the observance today of the fiftieth anniversary of the society, said that from a modest membership of 600 at its founding on March 8, 1888, it has grown to more than 50,000 accounts and resources now exceeding $22,000,000.

Working calmly and methodically with one hand, Mrs. Margarette Thomsen, 25 years old, smothered her two young children to death here today and then, with a borrowed nickel, walked six blocks to a telephone and notified the police.
Erno Balogh, who appeared in piano recital at the Town Hall last night, is endowed with a technique whose outstanding attributes are speed and dexterity of fingerwork.

After Democrats had declared it would create an additional fire hazard, the bill of Assemblyman Middleton, New York Republican, to permit the storage of automobiles in basements..of multiple dwellings, was passed tonight in the Assembly, 81 to 64.
The Walden School quintet concluded its season yesterday by turning back the Lincoln School team, 14 to 10, on the Walden court. Chris Sherman, with six points, was high scorer for the winners.

With party lines split, the Assembly passed tonight, 40 to 14, a bill curbing the powers of the Court of Chancery in Issuance of labor injunctions. The measure, introduced by Assemblyman Harold A. Pierson, Morris County Republican, would require that witnesses be heard in open court before granting of an injunction in a labor dispute.

An open letter signed by 115 American educators declared yesterday that there was "shocking" indifference to education in the Insurgent area of Spain in contrast with a campaign against illiteracy that the Loyalist Government carries even into the front line.

The Mortgage Commission extended these mortgages: $456,508 on 17-21 W 67th St, held from the Fair-Deal Realty Co, Mose Goodman, president, to Aug. 1, 1941, 41/2 to 5 per cent amortized $1,163,75 to $1,745.63 quarterly $25,837.50 on 148 E 53d St, Ernestine Linder, owner. to Feb. 21, 1941, 51/2 per cent, to be reduced $162.50 quarterly.

A committee of three has been appointed to study the advisability of the Symington-Gould Corporation acquiring the assets of the McConway . Torley Corporation, C. J. Symington, president of Symington-Gould, announced yesterday. The committee was formed following the raising of objections to the plan.
Food brokers made the best showing of any division of the grocery trade last week, according to the report on sales volume made public yesterday by the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.

In response to a request from Attorney General Cummings, Thurman W. Arnold, Yale professor, has notified the Department of Justice that he would accept a nomination as Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division.

Robert H. Jackson made his first appearance before the Supreme Court today as Solicitor General of the United States. Just as attorneys were to be admitted to practice before the court, James W. Morris, assistant attorney general, rose.

Herbert Hoover entered Germany today for the first time since his post-war relief work here in 1919. He spent the afternoon motoring slowly from the Czechoslovak border near Carlsbad via Dresden to Berlin, where he arrived in the evening.

When you take a sailfish that goes more than ten feet in length you have quite a fish on your hands, but according to one of our friends who just returned from Acapulco, Mexico, it isn't at all unusual to take them that large-and larger.

The Supreme Court dismissed today an attack on New York legislation requiring physicians to obtain authorization from the State Industrial Commissioner before they render medical care and treatment in workmen's compensation cases.

WHEN Harriet Monroe went off to South America in 1936, she left behind the manuscript of her autobiography. It was not quite complete, but it covered the most important years of her long career-those of her youth in Chicago and her first decade as editor of Poetry: A Magazine of Verse.
Word was received here today of the death on Saturday of Douglas A. Collie-MacNeill at Guadalajara, where he was British Consul. During his final illness he dictated his own obituary,

The appointment of Luigi Federzoni as president of the Royal Academy of Italy to succeed the late Gabriele d'Annunzio was interpreted tonight as a political move toward reorganization of the Chamber of Deputies as a corporative chamber.

Charles E. Mitchell, once chairman of the board of the National City Bank, must pay a fraud penalty of $364,254 in addition to the $728,709 deficiency levied in connection with his 1929 income tax return, the Supreme Court ruled today.
Matthews Ave, n w cor of Morris Park Ave, 1-story brick gas station, 25x20; Frank E. Gillis, 1,832 Radcliffe Ave, owner; Charles W. Van Keuren, architect; cost, $2,500.

Mr. and Mrs. C. Maxwell Dering of St. Louis were hosts to 200 at a tea dance at the Surf Club today. Among those having luncheon parties at the Surf Club yesterday were Mr. and Mrs. Ross Beason of New York, Mr. and Mrs. Norman L. Noteman of New Rochelle, N. Y., and Mr. and Mrs. W. Alton Jones of Forest Hills, L. I.

Offering will be made to the public today of a new issue of 21,500 shares of convertible preferred stock, with subscription warrants to 43,000 shares of common stock, of the Piper Aircraft Corporation.
The University of Wisconsin has been added to the Columbia University football schedule for the 1940 campaign, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Edward S. Elliott, director of athletics at Columbia.

A POET'S LIFE, by Harriet Monroe. (Macmillan, $5). An autobiography. COMPOSERS IN AMERICA, by Claire Reis. (Macmillan, $3.50). Biographical sketches of living composers, with a record of their works, 1912-37.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates March 7 unless specified: At Navy Yard, Mare Island: Arctic, Robin. At Shangai: Oahu, March 5; Parrott, March 6. Babbitt, Cartagena, Col., to San Blas Island.

It is the friends of TVA, and not its enemies, who have most to gain through a prompt Congressional investigation of the charges brought by TVA's chairman, Dr. Morgan. They will gain if it is shown that the charges are unfounded.

With Alaskan fishermen threatening violence upon Japanese and Pacific Coast labor planning a general boycott of Japanese unless they cease their salmon fishing operations off the Alaskan coast, an intimation came from the State Department today that negotiations with Japan for an amicable settlement of the controversy had reached a satisfactory conclusion.

Northern States Power Company (Minnesota) and Subsidiaries-For 1937: Preliminary net income, $7,250,378, compared with $4,990,456 for 1936. Increase of $2,259,922 due principally to the reduction of $1,890,007 in interest charges on funded debt and reduction of $380,400 in income taxes due to refunding.

Although only about 18 per cent more ballots were cast in Hudson County in the last Gubernatorial election than in Essex County, the 1938 payroll in the office of the Hudson County Commissioner of Registration will be more than four times greater than that of the Essex County registration office for 1937,

The 112 institutions of the savings and loan type in the Second Federal Home Loan Bank District in which savings are insured by the Federal Savings and Loin Insurance Corporation had resources of $169,155,281 on Dec. 31 last, according to the report of George L. Bliss, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, which serves as a regional agent for the corporation.

John L. Lewis, as head of the C. I. O. and the United Mine Workers of America, will test his political strength behind the candidacy of Thomas Kennedy for the nomination for Governor in the Pennsylvania Democratic primaries on May 17.

Sylvanuas Apps of the Maple Leafs, whose point- making prowess has been overshadowed all season by Gordon Drillon, is starting to give his teammate a real run for the National Hockey League scoring championship.

Governor Lehman, accusing Mayor La Guardia of presenting an inaccurate and erroneous picture of the relief tax situation, tonight told the Mayor bluntly that the city had broad tax powers which made unnecessary any reduction of the amount or standards of relief.
The engagement of Miss Betty Franklin to Lieut. Comdr. Edward Leyland Pemberton of the Royal Navy has been announced. The wedding will take place early in May.

Chemists will solve the problem of converting farm crops into substitutes for coal, petroleum and natural gas before these resources are exhausted, Dr. Frank C. Whitmore, president of the American Chemical Society, predicted tonight in an address before the Rochester section of the society.

The Sorosis Society held its seventieth anniversary breakfast yesterday at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria. More than 150 women, including the heads of numerous organizations, attended. There was a birthday cake with seventy candies.

A $99,000 first mortgage for 5 years at 41/2% has been arranged by Kidder Fitzpatrick, broker, on the recently completed Stephan Hall Annex, a 6-story apartment house on the w s of 82d St, 100 ft n of Polk Ave, Jackson Heights, L. I. The E. M. G. Realty Corp. George Goldberg, president, is the owner of the building.

Czechoslovakia was hailed as "a fortress of democracy set in the raging waters of autocracy," by Dr. David S. Muzzey, Professor of History at Columbia College, speaking to an audience of 2,500 at a memorial meeting in Carnegie Hall last night in tribute to the late President-Liberator of Czechoslovakia, Thomas Garrigue Masaryk.

Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw entertaine with a dinner for Sir Gerald Campbell, the British Consul General, and Lady Campbell, last night at he- home, 60 East Sixty-sixth Street, and later took her guests to the opera.

Market ciosed lower for fifth consecutive day in light trading; turnover, 619,950 shares. United States Treasury issues mixed, corporate bonds lower, rails weakened, foreign loans dull; transactions, $4,859,000.
A bill providing for the establishment of grayhound racing tracks in four counties of the Stte for a one-year period was introduced tonight ijn the Senate by Elmer F. Quinn, Manhattan Democrat.
Strong winds of gale and hurricane force struck the MacGregor Arctic Camp early this morning. Considerable damage was done to the buildings and instruments.

Commander Guillermo Andrade, a retired naval officer, and Major Pazmino, a retired army officer, arrested recently in connection with alleged subversive activities, will both lose their pensions and be exiled to the Galapagos Islands, according to a Quito dispatch to the Telegrafo.
Master Time, far back in his previous outing, carried E. Drillon's silks to victory over seven other racers in the feature at the Fair Grounds today.
Governor Lehman's reply to the Mayor on the relief situation in New York City was as follows:
Senator Borah, intermittently with Senator Johnson of California, is again harassing those in the Executive branch of the government who are charged with the conduct of foreign policy.

Liqullatlon developed in all North American wheat markets today, with the September declining to new low prices for the season, while the May on the Board of Trade here dropped about 1 3/4 cents a bushel at the extreme to 89 1/8 cents, equaling the low point of last December and into new low ground at this period of the year since March, 1934.

Shipments of steel office furniture during January, 1938, amounted to $1,989,632, compared with $2,125,222 in December, 1937, and $2,270,960 in January, 1937, according to figures issued by the Bureau of the Census.

With advertising associations of four countries having adopted the International Code of Advertising Practice formulated by the International Chamber of Commerce last year, the program has received widespread recognition in all parts of the world, according to the chamber yesterday.

Baycity Holding Company, Isak Greenberg, president, sold to the Greenfield Realty Company the four-story apartment on a plot 50 by 190 feet at 44-46 West Thirtythird Street and the two four-story flats at 60-162 Avenue C, Bayonne,
In the United States Court of Claims today the following proceedings were had: Announcements: 248-A-Willie Crockett Wright Admr., petition dismissed.

Opportunity to meet the objections raised by business men to a policy of government support of agriculture will be provided to canners, wholesalers, chains, supermarkets and independent growers in their marketing of the 1938 cling
Uncertainty regarding the Mexican market is responsible for a recent tightening of credit facilities by a number of companies shipping goods into that country.

Fireman 1st grade Frederick G. Boerke of H. L. 140, March 5, is hereby announced to the department. Funeral will take place from the Funeral Parlors of Weigand Brothers, 1,015 Halsey St., Brooklyn, at 2 P. M., Wednesday, March 9. Interment at Cypress Hills Cemetery.

An assurance that the British Government would under "no circumstances" interfere with the freedom of the press was given in the House of Commons today by R. A. Butler, Under-Secretary of the Foreign Office.

Dr. Oswaldo Aranha's acceptance of the Foreign Ministry portfolio will be welcomed throughout the Americas. He is so stanch a democrat that his entrance into the Cabinet of President Getulio Vargas is construed as an assurance that that regime is not modeled on the European fascist dictatorships.

Persons charged with the custody of churches and convents still occasionally find in them great amounts of stocks, bonds, currency and treasures, said Paulino Romero, General Commissioner of Public Order, in an interview today. From a vault in his office Senor Romero took a zinc box full of musty books and papers.

A delegation representing a dozen or more religious and patriotic organizations will accompany Jeremiah F. Cross, New York State Commander of the American Legion, to Albany this morning to petition Governor Lehman to remove

President Roosevelt received twentyfive Representatives who urged him to support an $80,000,000 flood-control program for the Ohio Valley, and discussed with Senator Green the proposed appropriation to permit expansion of the Navy Torpedo Station at Newport R. I.

The will of S. Parker Gilbert of Manhattan and Southampton, a partner in the firms of J. P. Morgan Co. and Drexel Co., was filed for probate here today with Surrogate Richard W. Hawkins of Suffolk County by Davis, Polk, Wardell,

The five-cent fare costs the city government so much that other needed services such as hospitals and schools are likely to suffer, according to a memorandum sent to members of the State Legislature yesterday by the Merchants Association of New York.

The Red Cross urged quick response today to its appeal for Southern California flood relief contributions, emphasizing that the $300,000 fund sought will be the only money available for direct relief of individual sufferers.

The Governor, in a letter to Mayor La Guardia, charged him with presenting an inaccurate and erroneous picture of the relief tax situation and asserted that the city had broad tax powers which made it unnecessary to reduce funds for or standards of relief.
John Foster Dulles, New York attorney and financial expert, was received here today by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek. Nothing of special significance is said to have been discussed.
Major events today: Philadelphia Orchestra, evening, Carnegie Hall; Maurice Bialkin, 'cellist, afternoon, Town Hall; Fordham University Glee Club, evening, Town Hall.

Mrs. Dorothy Andrus and Everett Freisenbruch of Bermuda won the final of the Bermudian Hotel's fourth annual mixed doubles tennis tournament today by defeating Miss Gladys Hutchings and William Freisenbruch of Bermuda, 6--1, 6--2.

Pitcher John (Footsie) Marcum reached the Red Sox camp today and signed his contract. Only Pitcher Archie McKain and Infielder Eric McNair are unsigned. The main squad of infielders and outfielders starts work tomorrow. Manager Joe Cronin has ordered two workouts daily.

Sixteen West Tennessee communities signified their-willingness today to buy the distribution and generating facilities of the West Tennessee Power and Light Company for the purpose of distributing Tennpessee Valley Authority power.
Following are the principal points made by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain in a speech before the House of Commons today in defense of his foreign and defense policies:
Unfavorable weather in most sections of the country spoiled last Saturday as the first day for the offering of some Spring apparel lines, manufacturers reported yesterday.

The dollar advanced strongly yesterday against all important foreign exchanges. Sterling fell to $5.00 3/4, its cheapest price in two weeks, and closed at $5.00 7/8, off % cent. The franc, which was especially under pressure, dropped to 3.23 1/8 cents, its lowest price since Jan. 27, and closed at 3.23 3/8 cents, off 2 1/4 points.
The first of a series of Made in America industrial expositions to be held throughout the country will open at Bloomingdale's on Thursday morning.

Despite Arturo Toscanini's final refusal to come to Salzburg this Summer, the festival committee has not abandoned hope that he may be induced to change his mind. Mr. Toscanini is expected to be in Italy before he conducts in Palestine at the end of March.

Spanish Insurgent war planes struck fiercely at the port of Cartagena today in swift retaliation for a government naval victory that was hailed here as a blow that had broken the Insurgent blockade of the Spanish Eastern Coast.
The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that entries of sugar from off-shore areas in the first two months of this year amounted to 671,042 short tons.

The annual report of the Central Reserve Bank of Peru for the year Ended on Dec. 31 showed that net profits amounted to 933,342 soles. (The sole is currently worth 24.50 cents.) This was an increase over 1936 of 14,184 soles.
Tewfik Nessim Pasha, thrice Prime Minister of Egypt and a leading figure in Egypt's postwar struggle for independence and parliamentary government, died here of a heart ailment today. His age was 64.

Harry Scheck, 60 years old, a suave, medium-sized ex-convict, who used four prominent lawyers in this city as mediums to defraud jewelers of about $1,700 in diamond rings he pretended to purchase for relatives, was remanded to the Tombs yesterday pending grand jury action when he waived examination in Felony Court.

A group of investors, represented by Edward M. Goldman, attorney, purchased the five-story apartment house with stores, on a plot 100 by 50, at 198-212 Gramatan Avenue, Mount Vernon, Westchester County. The seller was the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

Colonel E. L. Dailey, army engineer, announced yesterday that he had submitted an unfavorable report to the Board of Engineers for Rivers and Harbors on the proposal for improvement of the waterway between Albany and Schenectady by way of the Hudson and Mohawk Rivers.
Automobile output continued to decline last week, when a sharp seasonal increase was anticipated, and the adjusted index dropped to its lowest point since the week ended Sept. 28, 1935.

Miss Madeline Befuhs, 30 years old, of 439A MacDonough Street, Brooklyn, was placed in the observation ward of Kings County Hospital yesterday and charged with felonious assault after, the police said, she had slashed the throat of her 5-year-old nephew, Francis Fairburn, with a razor blade. The child is in Bushwick Hospital and is expected to recover.

Mrs. Jackson A. Dykman and Mrs. Louis W. Noel, two socially prominent players who never before had won a major bridge title, yesterday ran away with the women's pair event of the Eastern championships, closing event of the 1938 tournament.
American exporters yesterday were inclined to minimize the threat of Italian penetration into Central America through the bartering of airplanes for coffee and other raw materials.
The Treasury received an average price of 0.073 per cent on its regular ninety-one-day bills and 0.059 per cent on its ninety-nine-day "new money" bills, Secretary Morganthau announced tonight.

Conditions in the Rockland State Hospital for the Insane were described as shocking, at a resumed public hearing yesterday in the Supreme Court building before the joint legislative committee on law enforcement.

Sergeant John W. Reilly, 46 years old, of the Clinton Street police station, died of a heart attack last night while riding in a radio car patrolling the precinct with Patrolman Michael Golden, the driver.

President Anastasio Somoza has issued an executive decree authorizing a commission to control foreign exchange operations. The group consists of Jose Benito Ramirez, Colonel Irving A. Lindberg and James H. Edwards,

An attorney accused of being the "master mind" of a ring that swindled insurance companies of millions of dollars by the filing of claims for faked disability; an insurance broker who acted as "chaser" for the ring; and two physicians,

Colonel Frederick Marsh, U.S.A., retired, died today at the Army and Navy Club at the age of 85. Colonel Marsh was graduated from the United States Military Academy and commissioned a second lieutenant of artillery on June 16, 1877.
J. B. A. Robertson, Governor of Oklahoma from 1919 to 1923, died at his home today of a tumor. His age was 66. At his death he was chief counsel for the State Corporation Commission.
Maxie Farber, 134, East Side, knocked out George Levy, 138 1/2, Trenton, in 2:55 of the fourth of an eight-round engagement at the St. Nicholas Palace last night, before a crowd of 2,500 persons.
Tryding in Manhattan realty reported yesterday included various types of properties and was spread aver a wide area of the borough, although a number of the parcels were in the midtown district.

The number of business failures in the United States for the week ended March 3 was 242, compared with 246 for the five-day period preceding and 174 for the corresponding week a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet. Inc.

Minority stockholders of the old Northern Pacific Railroad company lost in United States District Court today their petition to intervene in the present Northern Pacific Railway Company's long-contested landgrant case against the government.

Rising up in protest against the trustee's failure to discharge Dean Cletus L. Goodling, the 175 students of the National Farm School today declared a strike, refusing to attend classes or carry out industrial assignments.

Mrs. Adeline Frances Slade Fitz, ex-President General of the national society of the D. A. R., one of the incorporators of the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities and a member of the Society of Colonial Dames, died early today in a hospital at suburban Melrose.

The sale of stock in a perpetualmotion machine was stopped yesterday through an action in the Supreme Court by John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, who disregarded the appeals of investors who had bought $37,000 of certificates of ownership in the invention.

It is learned here that an overwhelming victory in Bulgaria for the old political parties over the government was revealed today with the publication of complete results of the parliamentary elections in the Provinces of Shumen and Stara-Zagora.

Major John Jacob Astor, member of Parliament and proprietor of The Times of London, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary en route to California to attend the wedding of his stepson, George Mercer Nairne.

The Citizens Housing Council of New York tentatively proposed yesterday that the New York Housing Authority purchase for rehabilitation old-law tenements in charted areas. The old housing committee of the council submitted this and other recommendations at a meeting of more than 250 representatives

Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., won the medal in the qualifying round of the annual Belleair women's golf championship today. Miss Miley notched two strokes from women's par to lead the large field with a score of 40, 38-78.

Damage estimated at $150,000 resulted from a fire of undetermined origin that wrecked the North End Hotel in Ocean Grove near here today. Eight firemen received minor injuries during the six-hour battle to keep the flames from consuming the entire $250,000 boardwalk structure and near-by Summer homes.
Warm weather and a heated campaign brought the prediction tonight of a record vote-of up to 150,000 in tomorrow's Mayoralty election.

Paul Vincent Carroll, 37-year-old Irish playwright, whose "Shadow and Substance" is one of the Broadway hits this season, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary on his first visit to this country.
Love of the sea brought death to Lemuel L. Stewart, for ten years a resident of the Hotel Shelton in New York and a former advertising manager of Paramount Pictures, Inc.

A drop of more than 10 per cent in Philadelphia's retail business last week, the first week of the 2 per cent sales tax, was reported today by F. Raymond Johnson, chairman of the Retail Merchants Committee of the Chamber of Commerce.
Anglo-Italian negotiations are opening with high hopes, but chastened by uncertainty as to what exactly is going to happen and how. The main issues between the two countries are simple.

Mrs. Harvey Hubbell of Bridgeport, Conn., widow of a manufacturer, who has been visiting Mrs. Earle Perry Charlton, was married this morning to James T. Roche of Fairfield, Conn., who arrived yesterday at the Breakers, by Judge Richard P. Robbins in his chambers. They will be at the Breakers the remainder of this season.
The minimum wage rates for women and minors in the laundry industry, effective next Monday, were announced yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had:

Barnet Quart, a member of the bar of the State of New York and also a clerk in the Bureau of Construction and Maintenance of the Board of Education, was accused yesterday of setting up a private law office in a dimly lit and illventilated storeroom near the elevators on the seventh floor of the Department of Education's building at 49 Flatbush Avenue Extension in Brooklyn.

The new board of directors of the Baldwin Locomotive Works at an organization meeting today re-elected former officers, including Samuel M. Vauclain, chairman of the board, and George H. Houston, president.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today George Slaff, William H. K. Davey. John G. Clancy. Samuel Lloyd and Mordecai Knowitz of New York were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

The adjutant general released the following orders today: These officers, having qualified, are placed on duty: Trexler. Chaplain (Lt. Col.) Charle D., is to report to commanding officer, 1O1st Cavalry. for assignment to headquarters.
For the first time since the thirty-eighth annual American Bowling Congress opened, there were no newcomers among the divisional leaders today.
Sir Reginald Fleming Johnson, tutor to the Manchu Emperor, Pu Y1 of Manchukub, 1919 to 1925, and one the greatest European students of Chinese literature, died yesterday at the age of 64.

Directors of the Celanese Corporation of America declared a dividend of $1.53 a share on the 7 per cent cumulative first participating preferred stock. This distribution, which will be made on April 1, will cover participating accruals to Dec. 31, 1937.
Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, said yesterday that he would ask the Council today to consider the limiting of taxicab service to ten hours for each cab each day.

Miss Elisabeth Stearns Bradford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Bradford of this place, will be married on March 26 to Robert Duane Handley, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Handley of Scarsdale The ceremony will be performed in the Church of St. James the Less.

The five-story apartment house at 281 Quincy Street, Brooklyn, was purchased by the Quincy Housing Corporation from the Stern-Green Realty Company, Inc. Purchase was subject to a first mortgage of $33,400.

Marshall Field has been elected president of Greenwich House, succeeding Gerard Swope, who will continue as a member of the board of managers, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Field has been treasurer more than ten years.
District Judge E. B. Chappell sentenced Lieutenant Governor Walter H. Jurgensen today to two to five years at hard labor in the Nebraska penitentiary. Jurgensen was convicted of embezzlement Feb. 9.
A package of poison taken from a drug store by a man who bought a can of prepared baby food was returned to the store today, after a night of anxiety on the part of police and the pharmacist.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your indictment of the organized medical profession in the editorial of March 2, "Again the Nation's Health," cannot pass unchallenged. There is no maintenance of a laissezfaire policy, nor is there any implication that the laws of nature and economy compel sickness to stalk hand-in-hand with poverty.

Railroad workers asked the Senate Commerce subcommittee today to "give the railroads a break" by approving the long-and-short-haul bill to permit the roads to adjust rates to meet competition from Other forms of transportation.
Jim Londos, 205, St. Louis, threw Jim McMillen, 225, Illinois, in 36:14 of the feature bout last night before a crowd of 3,500 persons at the New York Hippodrome.
Money in circulation at the end of February amounted to $6,334,091,700, compared with $6,320,199,614 on Jan. 31, and increase of $13,892,086, the Treasury announced today.

Another unit of the chain of Schrafft's restaurants will open Thursday at 155 East Seventy-ninth Street, just east of Lexington Avenue, in the one-story building just completed for the firm by Robert Johnson, Inc., builders, from plans by Bloch Hesse, architects.

Following Premier Koloman Daranyi's speech on Saturday, political circles believe he intends to tighten the so-called "Christian and Nationalist" government line in order to take the wind from the sails of the growing revolutionary Nazi movement. This is the explanation of the announcement of moderate anti-Semitic measures, it is claimed.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 2:

The Greater New York Chapter of the Society of Residential Appraisers will meet Thursday evening at the Hotel Lexington. Barnes Compton of the Johns-Manville Company will show moving pictures depicting new home construction and modernization.
A decline in Liverpool, Bombay and Alexandria, together with a lower stock market, caused yesterday declines of 3 to 5 points at the closing of the Cotton Exchange.

The Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament, which has come to be regarded as the outstanding program of its kind in New York, closed last night in Madison Square Garden. A crowd of 19,000 fans, their appetites whetted through following the progress of the warriors through two months of preliminary skirmishes, watched the program.
Perhaps the most fantastic element in the entire series of Moscow judicial phantasmagoria is the inclusion of Henry G. Yagoda, for many years head of the GPU, as a "conspirator"

Rowland St (15-3979), s w cor of Gleebe Ave, 95x60; Ella C. Barry to Susan A. Barry, 1 W 64th St. Rochambeau Ave (12-3337), w S, 175 ft s of 210th St. 41x100; Anthony W. Zeborowski to Mariano Liucci, 3,329 Rochambeau Ave; mtg, $13,175.
Tony Oklend, the former Chicago laborer who went prospecting for lack of a better job and discovered one of the richest mines in Ontario, died today at Miami Beach, Fla. He was 54 years old.
Drifted snow tonight continued to hide the fate of the Transcontinental and Western Air passenger liner which vanished a week ago tonight with nine persons aboard.

At the opening of the March term of the Suffolk County Court here today, Judge L. Barron Hill received a black silk robe from the Suffolk County Bar Association. Harry H. Reeve, an attorney of Greenport, made the presentation.

Starting a new practice in the relations of a corporation to its employes, the Johns-Manville Corporation yesterday issued an annual report to its 11,200 jobholders, just as in the past it has made a report each year to its 7,100 stockholders.

Dissatisfaction over the transfer of a fireman, who made a heroic rescue, from one hospital to another was expressed last night throughout the Fire Department. No official complaint, however, was made.

Bradley Tech of Peoria, Ill., the dark-horse entrant in the national invitation college basketball tournament that starts at Madison Square Garden tomorrow, engaged in its first practice workout at the West Side Y. M. C. A. yesterday and promptly convinced a group of sports writers that they had made no mistake in naming the hard-driving Midwesterners.
Two prominent newspaper men may have been guilty of belittling their profession the other day. It was a question of the Washington

The State Supreme Court ordered the Borough of Fort Lee today to levy $35,020 in taxes for 1938 to pay the Hackensack Trust Company and' other holders of its Board of Education bonds. Interest delinquent and due on $2,823,798 in Fort Lee securities held by the estate of Claudia Lea Phelps, also was ordered levied this year.

The trial of Mrs. Patricia Ryan for the murder of her husband, Patrolman Michael Ryan, was halted in Bronx County Court shortly after noon yesterday after her counsel pleaded with Judge Lester W. Patterson that his client was too distraught to take the witness stand.

The stock market here was generally weak today and most sections lost ground. Gilt-edge issues were in some demand, while among the foreign bonds German issues improved slightly. Transatlantic stocks, after early dullness, became firmer in late dealings but prices were lower than Saturday's closing at the finish.

The Maritime Commission today ordered an investigation of "the rules, regulations, practices and agreements" of the Pacific Coast European Conference which covers steamship lines from the Pacific Coast to all European countries.

Presidential support for an $80,000,000 appropriation for flood control projects in the Ohio Valley was asked today by a delegation of twenty-five House members who called to report on the extent floods have damaged that area.

Substitution of the term "Christian democracy" for the word "democracy" because Of misinterpretations of the latter was urged last night by Father John La Farge, Jesuit writer and educator, speaking at a public forum of the New York Chapter of the Knights of Columbus at tile Hotel Capitol.

People are always growling about the weather. How often are they grateful for its good conduct? Nobody proposed a testimonial to February after he had left us. He deserved one. Little snow, little rain, clear air-as becomes what to the Romans was a month of purification.

Establishment of standard definitions for such familiar terms as F.A.S., F.O.B. and C.I.F. used in foreign trade will be discussed by the Joint Committee for Foreign Trade Action at its regular meeting here on Friday.
Sir Oracel, California sprinter owned by Norman W. Church, captured the featured Pan American Handicap as Tropical Park opened its thirty-day meeting today.

The appointment of Franklin C. Cappon, Assistant Director of Athletics at the University of Michigan since 1930, as head basketball coach and varsity backfield coach at Princeton was announced tonight by Professor Burnham N. Dell, '12, chairman of the university Council on Athletics.

In the act of handing a telephone across the desk of Acting Captain Richard J. Fennelly of the safe and loft squad, in Police Headquarters, Detective James J. Kissane collapsed yesterday in his chair and was dead before aid could be summoned.

The overseas trade balance for the eight months ended Feb. 28 was [Pound]16,000,000 less than in the corresponding period of 1936-37. Exports totaled [Pound]73,586,000, as compared with [Pound]75,841,000 in the previous period; imports, [Pound]75,049,000, as compared with f59,423,000. The favorable balance all told was [Pound]6,458,000, as compared with [Pound]22,451,000.

The Stage Relief Fund will receive a percentage of the proceeds derived from a luncheon and fashion show entitled "Fashions for the Dance Style Revue," which will be given today in the Caprice Room of Weylin.

The names of 168 additional members of the committee which will be sponsor for the campaign of the Greater New York Fund, Inc., to raise $10,000,000 for the city's private health and welfare agencies, were made public yesterday by Winthrop Rockefeller, executive vice chairman.

Turning in a card of 31, 33-64, on a handicap basis, Jimmy Hines of Garden City, L. I., and his amateur partner, John Daly of Boston, won the professional-amateur bestball golf competition at the Seminole Golf Club today.

James N. Mundsen, real estate and insurance broker, a former member of the Westchester Republican Committee, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 75. He served on the North Pelham Board of Assessors for ten years.

The penultimate week of the Metropolitan Opera season began last night with a performance of Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung." A capacity audience, including many persons who stood from 7:30 P. M., when the performance began until about 11:45 when it ended,
Trading was only fair in the wholesale markets. Demand for steer hinds and ribs at last week's close was very active and most slaughter houses are sold up to Friday's kill.

Led by Miss Hildegarde Gross, who tallied eleven field goals and five fouls for a total of 27 points, the New College girls' basketball team scored a 43-to-21 Lriumph over William and Mary College at Thompson Gymnasium yesterday.

Subscription books for the ten and onehalf-year 2 1/2 per cent Treasury bonds offered in exchange for $455,175,500 of maturing 3 per cent Treasury notes will close at the close of business on Wednesday, Secretary Morgenthau announced this afternoon.

Republican members of the House Naval Affairs Committee, who fought a losing battle in committee in an effort to prevent a favorable report on the administration's billion dollar naval construction bill, filed a minority report in the House tonight in which they asserted that "the circumstances indicate that the bill originated in the White House for the purpose of putting into the hands of the President the power to implement his foreign policies."

A special committee of the National Maritime Union, affiliate of the C. I. O., appointed recently to negotiate with steamship owners for new wage contracts, will have its first session with a group of owners today at the offices of the American Steamship Owners Association, 11 Broadway.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, March 4: CAPTAINS Cummings, D. E., to duty as Chief of Staff and aide to the commandant of the 13th Naval District, June 29.

" We'll make a lot more double plays this year with that kid out there." A Yankee veteran, one of a group of puffing, perspiring athletes, was sitting on the bench at Huggins Field, speaking his thoughts.
Colonel Dorsey Cullen, U. S. A. retired, died today at Walter Reed Hospital after an illness of nearly a year. He was 70 years of age.
Press nonaggression pacts concluded between governments on a basis of mutual respect and understanding are the National Socialist solution for the comity of nations.

The annual bridge party and tea for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York will take place today in the Gold Room of Sherry's. Net proceeds from the event will be applied to the maintenance of the society's shelter, which serves as a clearing house for the placement of animals. Mrs. W. H.

Many large parties were given at tonight's "Night of Nations" pageant at the Everglades Club, sponscored by the Students International Union to obtain funds for scholarships. Mrs. Alexander M. Hadden, vice president of the union, was in charge.

Highly elated over the excellent manner in which his charges deported themselves grabbing the opening two games of the exhibition schedule from Connie Mack's Athletics over the week-end, Colonel Bill Terry swung the Giants briskly into their second week of training today.
The week of grace for parking automobiles in the ten restricted streets below Houston Street expired yesterday at 7 A. M., and the police began giving out summonses to all parkers there.

All deceased Presidents of the United States, including twelve not previously honored with special postage stamp issues, and Benjamin Franklin and Martha Washington, will be commemorated in the regular series to be issued during this year in the first revision of designs since 1922-23, it was announced today by Postmaster General Farley.

The American Iron and Steel Institute issued yesterday a report of steel production in February, showing output at a rate 9 per cent above that for January, and issued its weekly estimate showing operations of the industry scheduled at 29.9 per cent of capacity for the current week, slightly above the average production in January.

Adolf A. Berle Jr., named temporarily as chairman of the City Planning Commission, resigned yesterday, explaining in a letter to Mayor La Guardia that he was leaving to assume the position of Assistant Secretary of State in Washington.

After being headed for a premiere at the Mansfield on March 23, "Dramatic School" has been postponed indefinitely. Late yesterday afternoon the cast was informed by Watson Barratt, co-producer with Rufus Phillips, that too much rewriting was required to permit an opening within two weeks. In revised form, the play would be submitted later to the backers, he said.

Corrington Gill, assistant WPA administrator, told the Senate Committee on Unemployment today that at least 3,500,000 rural families, or more than one of every four such families in the United States, received public assistance at some time during the depression.

A move to oust Councilman Hugh Quinn as a member of the City Council at today's meeting was forecast yesterday when the majorlty members of the committee appointed to investigate his residence concluded that he was not a bona fide resident of Queens when he was elected from that borough last Fall.

Discussion in the Senate of the civil service provisions of the bill for the reorganization of the executive departments gave Mr. Guffey of Pennsylvania an opportunity to declare that, as is well known, "he is a believer in civil service."

An arrangement under which Italy will trade airplanes to Salvador for coffee has been completed, and suggests to observers here the possibility that the former country is adopting the barter system now in use by Germany to promote economic political penetration of Central America.

Alan Marshal, a stage graduate who has had an active two years in the films, was assigned today to the role of Duncan McGrath in I. A. R. Wylie's "Young in Heart" adapted from "The Gay Banditti" at Selznick-International.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation, burdened with the ownership of a constantly increasing number of dwellings, is making a more determined effort to find buyers for these properties.
Baron Gottfried von Cramm, Germany's leading tennis player, is being detained by the criminal police on suspicion of being guilty of "moral delinquency."
THE BLACK EYE, a play in three acts, by James Bridle. Staged by Robert Ross; settings by Albert E. Ward Jr.; produced by the Brattleboro Theatre. At the St. Felix Street Playhouse, Brooklyn.

Cary D. Waters, president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, announced yesterday the appointment of a chamber committee T which will give advice and information to chamber members on problems relating to the prevention of accidents in industry.
The supremacy of the United States in commercial aviation and our great progress as a producer of airplanes were shown in reports made public today by the Commerce Department.

A special committee appointed by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, has recommended that radio broadcasts of partisan political speeches, propaganda and commercial programs be barred from the public schools, it was learned yesterday.

Philip H. Philbin, a big game hunter and stock manipulator, who was hunting lions with a maharajah when Federal agents were looking for him several years ago, received a prison sentence of eighteen months yesterday from Federal Judge John C. Knox, following his plea of guilty last week to an indictment charging him and others with mail fraud and conspiracy in the sale of stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation.

Faced with figures from Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick showing the city already beyond its means in financing relief, members of the Board of Estimate authorized yesterday $2,448,887 for relief for the second week of March.

The New York Rangers will seek to move a step nearer first place in the American group of the National Hockey League race when they oppose the fast-skating Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden tonight.
Nikolai Bukharin fought all day and all evening through the fifth day of the treason trial of twenty-one men, some of them famous figures of the Bolshevist revolution.
Reports received here today declare that Japanese forces operating in Shansi Province entered Puchow, southern terminus of the Tatung-Puchow Railway, yesterday afternoon.

Convinced that his son, Peter, who has been missing eleven days, is still alive, Murray Levine flatly contradicted yesterday reports that various law-enforcement agencies had begun to work on the case, and pressed for an opportunity to reestablish contact with the kidnappers.

The Czechoslovak trade agreement granting that country substantial tariff concessions on American imports of shoes and other manufactured products in return for similar concessions on several agricultural and industrial exports from this country was signed at the State Department today by Secretary Hull and Vlacimir Hurban, the Czechoslovak Minister.

President Anastasio Somoza will submit to Congress a project for cooperative stores throughout the republic to reduce the cost of living. Because of exchange conditions many merchants are charging excessive prices for necessities and the President wishes the price of foods and of cheaper grades of clothing and shoes reduced.

Under arrest for the forty-first time since 1914, Joseph Moore, 42 years old, who said he was a clerk, of 218 East Eighteenth Street, will spend his next 100 days in the workhouse. Magistrate Earl Smith so decreed yesterday in Essex

Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday a communication sent to Police Commissioner Valentine directing him to inform operators of out-of-town buses that within a short time .they would be forbidden to stop in New York City streets to take on passengers.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain struck back angrily today at critics who had been taunting him for a fortnight on his "surrender" to the Fascist dictators. And the House of Commons gave him a vote of confidence in rejecting, 351 to 134, a labor motion to amend a bill implementing Great Britain's huge rearmament program and later in approving by 347 votes to 133 his statement on foreign policy.

The West Long Beach Development Company, Inc., reported yesterday that ten lots at Atlantic Beach, L. I., have been sold to the Park Avenue Building Corporation, which plans to improve them with houses. Karelsen Karelsen.were the attorneys in the deal.

A proposal to change this town's 117-year-old name to Arundel, its original name publicized in historical novels by Kenneth Roberts, a resident, was defeated today in town meeting. Proponents of the change had contended that Arundel

When speaking of his own meet, Frank Brennan, promoter of the Knights of Columbus athletic carnival at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, is a visionary man. He can see a world record in every event on the program except, perhaps, the four-lap parochial sc??ol relay.
William Norman Boase, who until recently, as chairman of the championship committee of St. Andrews, was virtual ruler of the golfing world, died today in Scotland. His age was 67.

City commissions cannot retain direct jurisdiction over subordinate subdivisions of municipal governments, but must place them under various departments, Supreme Court Justice Ralph W. E. Donges ruled today in ordering the Newark City Commission to distribute six agencies and place them under control of departments.

The first part of the important library of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop will be dispersed at auction at the American Art AssociationAnderson Galleries, Inc., on April 4, 5, 6 and 7, according to an announcement yesterday by Mitchell Kennerley, president of the galleries.

The Spanish GovernmentNews Agency reported today that nineteen persons had been killed and 168 injured when the Lerida-Tarragona train collided Saturday night with a freight train near Tarragona, about fifty miles southwest of here.

The Democratic majority in the House today beat down three efforts to amend the pending tax revision bill, with the big fight over Title 1B, the "third basket" provision dealing with family or other closely held corporations, still to come.
I AM MY YOUTH, a "biographical drama" in three acts, by Ernest Pascal and Edwin Harvey Blum. Staged and produced by Alfred de Liagre Jr. At the Playhouse.

Miss Helen Louise Hood, president emeritus of the Illinois Woman's Christian Temperance Union, early associate of Frances E. Willard and a leading supporter of prohibition, died at her home at Highland Park, near here, tonight in her ninetieth year. She was a native of Milwaukee.
The Court of Appeals heard arguments today in a preliminary proceeding to test the State mortgage foreclosure moratorium in effect since July 1, 1933.

Net income of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation and domestic subsidiary companies for 1937 was $1,621,979, compared with $752,575 for 1936. Earnings last year, after provision for dividends on four preferred issues, were equivalent to $3.78 on each of the 245,932 common shares outstanding at the year-end.
COHEN, MOLLIE (Feb. 26). Estate, $2,929. Louis Cowan, son. executor 303 West St. Seventeen specific bequests. COOK, ELIZABETH CHRISTINE (March 1). Estate, more than $10,000.

After hours of acrimonious debate here this afternoon, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors voted to reconsider its action of last Thursday, when it approved a bill providing for the transfer of the Bronx River Parkway from the county to New York State.

Forty-two candidates for Manhattan's varsity football squad reported for the first Spring practice yesterday afternoon, as Coach Herb Kopf's football regime got under way. Seventeen lettermen were among those working out on the soggy turf of Manhattan Field.
War Admiral and Seabiscult, last year's top-money winners and champions respectively of the 3-year-old and handicap divisions, who beat nearly every headline horse except each other,

The Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School basketball team of Brooklyn scored a 40-to-20 victory over Cathedral Boys High in a Manhattan College invitation interscholastic basketball tournament game at the Manhattan gymnasium last night.

Mayor La Guardia today openly took sides with the State Federation of Labor against the C. I. O. in the dispute now current on what collective bargaining provisions should be written into the law for the protection of transit employes.
Each of the following, now on active duty with the CCC, is, with his consent, continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name:
General Pershing's heart was reported to be perfectly regular today by Dr. Roland Davison.

An important development in the struggle to preserve Austrian independence occurred tonight when for the first time since the suppression of the parliamentary and democratic right of free speech by the late Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss in 1934 a free assembly of workers' delegates met to consider the line Austrian labor should take in defense of the nation's independence.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 5: COLONELS Mitchell, H. D., Adjutant General's Dept., one month's leave, March 10. Adams, E. S., Adjutant general's Dept., Atlanta, Ga., to the Adjutant General's Office. Washington, D. C.. April 12.
Knopf has ordered a second printing of Karl Ekman's "Jean Sibelius: His Life and Personality," the authorized biography of the Finnish composer, which was published last January.

The pigeons of 163d Street fluttered forlornly yesterday, picking at food from unfamiliar hands, for Mrs. Bertha von Zastrow, "the pigeon mother of Washington Heights," who had fed them almost daily for fifteen years, had left them forever.

Mrs. Evangel Allen Alberti, wife of William Maxson Alberti and former dean of the Department of Acting at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, died in a New York hospital on Sunday after a long illness.

Henry Clay Butcher, business man, Civil War veteran and oldest member of the Union League of Philadelphia, died in an Atlantic City hotel tonight after an illness of several months. His age was 93. Mr. Clay had been a frequent guest at the Summer home of Mr. Butcher's father at Cape May, N. J.
Joseph D. McGoldrick, controller, announced yesterday the sale of an issue of $10,000,000 of New York City special revenue bills to the Bank of the Manhattan Company.
Bunji Suzuki, Laborite, has returned from a tour of the United States as a "people's envoy" impressed with the need for cultivating a Japanese spirit among American-born Japanese.

Officials of the National Association of Manufacturers disputed today a contention by Senate investigators that the organization had encouraged the use of "citizens committees" and "back-to-work" movements to combat strikes.
The Winter-resort belt county of Dougherty voted 1,274 to 197 to legalize liquor today, ending Georgia's twenty-two-year-old ban against whisky.
Walter Dent Smith, president and general manager of the Delaware Safety Council for several years, will become executive vice president of the Greater New York Safety Council on March 15.

Torn and eaten by a succession of gales which carried away her propeller ??nd drove her 900 miles off her curse for eight days in the North ??tlantic, the freighter Azalea City, ??ith eleven passengers, five of ??em women, was towed to a ??erth at East Boston late today.

Senator Pepper of Florida proposed today Federal aid in establishment of regional industrial banks to make loans to small businesses. He appeared before a Senate banking subcommittee in support of his bill to provide for insurance of business loans up to $100,000.
Charles Fletcher, 62 years old, a retired embalmer, was found dead of gas poisoning today in the kitchen of his home at 2,700 Hudson Boulevard.

CARTER, IRENE (March 16, 1937). Gross assets, $8,820; net, $6,871. To Margaret F. Carter, daughter, and Stephen Carter, son, one-half residue in trust each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $5,523. Fraser, Speir, Meyer Kidder, attorneys, 49 Wall St.

The government placed an embargo today upon the bank accounts of seventeen foreign oil companies sufficient to cover 75 per cent of the wages due for the twelve days of the national petroleum strike last May.
Governor Lehman completed action on his 1938-39 tax program tonight by signing two bills continuing the 6 per cent emergency franchise tax on business corporations and the

C. M. Baker Jr. of the Plainfield C. C., seeded third, and F. p. Frantz, Cornell Club, ranked seventh, gained the third round of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C championship tourney yesterday on the courts of the Downtown Athletic Club.

The speech of Economics Minister Walther Funk at the Leipzig Fair yesterday was hailed in German quarters today as an abrogation of the Versailles economic fetters and as confirmation of Germany's economic equality with the rest of the big powers.

The report for 1937 of the American Tobacco Company, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $26,197,493 after charges, taxes, depreciation and a deduction of $289,910 for flood losses. This was $6,013,672 larger.

The Whitney Museum open with a preview yesterday aftern?? its 1938 exhibition of contempora?? American sculpture, water-colo?? drawings and prints. In the pa a biennial, this show (like the o?? composed of work in oil) is now annual.

The youth of America and all democratic countries must replace indifference with enthusiasm and a new idealism if democracy is to stave off disaster, Dr. Leland Rex Robinson of Columbia University said last night in his commencement address to 490 men and women in the graduating class of Brooklyn College at the eleventh commencement exercises, held in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

The rayon greige goods market last week was active, carrying forward the improvement of the previous week and indicating a better market for the next several weeks, Nickel, Barrett, Lieberman Quinn, textile brokers, declared yesterday in their weekly review.

Today's drills at the Dodgers' training camp were canceled because of the death of President Stephen W. McKeever in Brooklyn. Larry MacPhail, executive vice president of the club, in a long telegram to Secretary John McDonaid about the Dolph Camilli deal, said:

Copies of THE NEW YORK TIMES dispatched from New York Feb. 22, including THE TIMES of that date, were delivered in the Hawaiian Islands two days later, it was made known yesterday by a letter from Honolulu describing the speedy transit.
The Senate tonight passed without a dissenting vote the Garrity bill appropriating $875,000 to extend the Cross-County Parkway in Westchester and construct a new viaduct at Fleetwood.

Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, announced yesterday. that the proposed Manhattan midtown underpass, variously estimated to cost between $20,000,000 and $60,00,000 would actually cost $35,000,000, according to estimates made from a report by Walter D. Binger, Commissioner of Borough Works.
Frank C. Boardman, who was Professor of Sculpture in the Yale School of Fine Arts for several years until 1905, died at his home here last night at the age of 71, after a long illness.

Jirius Issa Katina, a 25-year-old American citizen, and Wadiah Hadad, a Palestinian Arab, came up for trial this afternoon before the Jerusalem Military Court on a charge of throwing a bomb near a cooperative restaurant of the Jewish Labor Federation on Jan. 16.

Provided the international sugar agreement concluded last May finally goes into force, the government will continue for the five years for which the agreement is effective, the additional colonial preference of 3s a hundredweight of sugar on a quota of 360,000 tons, Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said in the Commons today.

The major part of the third floor of the building at 232 Madison Avenue and 17 East Thirty-seventh Street has been leased by the International Handkerchief Manufacturing Company, Charles I. Kahn, vice president.
A solemn mass of requiem will be celebrated at 10 A. M. on Thursday at the Church of St. Francis of Assisi, Nostrand Avenue and Lincoin Road, Brooklyn, for Stephen W. (Judge) McKeever,

More than 700 men and women of the Lower East Side, including many foreign-born still unable to speak English, attended last night's exercises opening a free adult public school in the building formerly occupied by Public School 97 at 135 Mangin Street.
It was still a wide open race tonight in the ninth annual St. Petersburg-Havana yachting classic as leaders of the fleet neared the Cuban capital.

Continuing the rapid pace on routine business which it established when the anti-lynching bill filibuster ended, the Senate quickly approved today a partial conference report on the $1,412,000,000 Independent Offices Bill, and passed and sent to conference a bill carrying $48,166,000 for the District of Columbia.

John J. Dunnigan, Majority Leader, announced tonight postponement of Senate action on the Savings Bank Life Insurance Bill. The bill, a Governor's program measure, was on the calendar for advancement to third reading, and,
Reversing two long-established principles of tax law, the Supreme Court decided today by 5 to 2 that the Federal Government can tax income derived from oil and gas lands leased from a State.

The nation is on the verge of a new and harmonious period in its industrial life, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, predicted last night at the tenth jubilee assembly of the School of the Jewish Woman, 251 West 100th Street, in the Center Hotel, 108 West Forty-third Street.

Jacob Joshua Jablons of 22 West Ninety-sixth Street, a retired woolen manufacturer and merchant, who was active in Jewish affairs, G died yesterday of pneumonia at Roosevelt Hospital after a threeday illness. His age was 74.

Edmond S. La Rose, assistant controller of the Bausch Lomb Optical Company, will speak on "Making Cost Results More Vivid and Effective" at the March meeting of the New York Chapter, National Association of Cost Accountants tonight at the Builders Club, 2 Park Avenue.
Kurt Wannow, a Berlin lawyer, was sentenced to two years at hard labor today for embezzling a large part of the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize awarded to Carl von Ossietzky, German pacifist.

A "ham" radio operator claimed today the distinction of being the first American to communicate by wireless with Pitcairn Island, the isolated dot in the South Pacific settled 148 years ago by mutineers of the Bounty.
General Chow Feng-chi, former commander of the Chinese Twentieth Route Army, was shot to death today by two unidentified men as he was leaving his home in the French Concession.
Government scientists batted out the theory today that the wallop, not the baseball, is the major factor in home runs.

Five of America's best-known playwrights-Maxwell Anderson, S. N. Behrman, Sidney Howard, Elmer Rice and Robert E. Sherwood--announced yesterday that they had formed an organization to produce their own new plays.
Industry, by hesitating to initiate a campaign of public relations because of its fear that to tell its story may mean acknowledgement of the validity of attack, is merely inviting attack,

Cornelius Furgueson, a former Municipal Court Justice, died on Sunday in the Victory Memorial Hospital at the age of 80. He had been ill with a heart disease for several weeks. Since his retirement from the bench in 1929, after thirty-two years of service, he had been active as an official referee.
Aaron Waldheim, philanthropist, died today at his home, 5,925 Lindell Boulevard. He was 74 years old, and had been in poor health. since last Summer.

United States manufacturers of motor vehicles shipped 205,100 cars and. trucks from their factories in February, according to a preliminary estimate for the month issued yesterday by the Automobile Manufacturers Association, a decline of 10 per cent from January, when shipments were 228,074 units.

Four men narrowly escaped today when the thirty-foot fishing cruiser Marcella caught fire and burned at sea about four miles off St. Lucie inlet. The fishermen were Dr. Elvin H. Killheffer of the du Pont Chemical Works at Wilmington; S.

Mrs. E. Maitland Armstrong has come from Kingscote, her home in Newport, to the Berkshire. The Hon. Marguerite Shaughnessy, sister of Baron Shaughnessy of. Montreal, is at the Carlyle. Mr. and Mrs. George L. Wrenn have returned from Florida to the Drake.

THE Brooklyn Dodgers got Dolf Camilli and lost "Judge" McKeever. No matter how many homers Dolf may hit, it wasn't an even trade. There was a character, old Steve, called "Judge" by all and sundry though the only bench he sat on with any authority was the kind they have in baseball dugouts.

Besides a final review of the naval squadron by Rear Admiral Alfred W. Johnson on the flagship New York today, marine aircraft paraded over all the United States' islands in the Eastern Caribbean, including St. Thomas, St. Croix, Viequez, Culebra and Puerto Rico, marking the end of the Caribbean Winter manoeuvres.

The intra-administration dispute in the Tennessee Valley Authority is expected to claim the attention of the Senate tomorrow when Senator Norris, author of the act creating it, moves for an investigation by the Federal Trade Commission of the charges made by Chairman Arthur E. Morgan against the other two directors.

George Holmes, lawyer, president of the Raritan River Railroad Company, with offices in Jersey City, N. J., and former general counsel to the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey, died here today at his home, Brook Ledge, Brookside Drive. He had been ill for six weeks. His age was 80.

Saks Fifth Avenue gave a Spring fashion show on the third floor yesterday afternoon. The store's executives unveiled one of the most spectacular collections of the season. Imports from the great houses of Paris, tagged with famous names, circled the showroom, weaving past fresh, gay gowns from the store's own Salon Moderne, otherwise unidentified but holding their own with jaunty assurance in such distinguished company.
The Court of Claims unanimously awarded $25,000 damages today to the widow of Dr. John F. W. Meagher, New York psychiatrist, who was killed at Tobyhanna. Pa.

Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Farley Cox Jr. of New York, who were married last week in Paris, Ky., are visiting at the Ray Alan VanCliefs' home in Paget. Mrs. Cox is the former Miss Nancy Clay Hancock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Boyd Hancock of Paris, Ky, and Mr. Cox is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas F. Cox of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Sunday at his home in Hartford, Conn., of Russell H. Shailer, metal goods manufacturer, for many years representative of the E. N. Welch Clock Company. He was 89 years old.

Results of a survey of automobile accidents involving intoxicated drivers, which resulted in 3,488 drivers' license revocations and 3,009 suspensions, were announced today by Charles A. Harnett, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
Max Baer did four rounds of diligent ring work at his training camp today in preparation for his fifteenround bout with Tommy Farr at Madison Square Garden on Friday night.

White Plains and Pelham Memorial advanced to the quarterfinal round of the sixth annual Westchester County invitation high school basketball tournament at the County Center tonight. White Plains defeated Mount St. Michael's of the Bronx, 35-9, and Pelham halted F. E. Bellows of Mamaroneck, 46-27.
One of those twenty-four-hour "boat train" parties such as some Americans stage before leaving Paris for home did not turn out well for three French youngsters.

Despite the unsettlement of stocks in the early trading on the news of the suspension of Richard Whitney Co. from the Stock Exchange and the Curb, no important blocks of stock were dislodged, and the market firmed up moderately in the final hour. The closing, however,

In the United State Court of Claims today the following proceedings were had: LAW CASES ARGUED AND SUBMITTED 43485--Frederick A. Ruf. Argument concluded for plaintiff; argued for defendant. C-62-National Electric Signaling Co. Argued for both.

A boy weighing nineteen pounds was born Monday to a family, then on relief, living near Wayne. The baby, exactly 24 inches long, is, according to the records of the American Medical Association, the largest child ever born alive and in normal health in this country.

Alarm against the continued prosperity of Jewish firms in Germany, despite four years of Nazi effort to crowd them out, was sounded today by the Stuermer, weekly organ of Julius Streicher, Germany's No. 1 Jew-baiter.

The Agriculture Department reported the other day that while 1937 was a year of bumper crops for the nation it was the fifth year of heavy drought losses for a large portion of the Western Plains region.

Patrick McNulty, 39-year-old railroad worker, who rented out rooms in his seven-room apartment at 295 Lenox Avenue, Harlem, was shot and killed yesterday in an argument with one of his lodgers who came home intoxicated.

Edward M. West, a member of the research department here of Sears, Roebuck Co. and a former advertising executive and newspaper man, died on Monday night at his home, 241 Central Park West, after a year's illness. His age was 62.

The popular Spring season which has been presented at the Metropolitan Opera House for two years will be omitted this year, it was announced yesterday by Lee Pattison, general manager of the Spring season.
A further severe decline in secondary railroad issues unsettled the entire market for domestic corporation bonds yesterday in more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

In a decision that may affect seriously the bonded indebtedness of every irrigation district in California, Superior Court Judge Emmet H.
