Wilson in Los Angeles ruled that the court in appropriate proceedings may take jurisdiction of the financial affairs of a district and, instead of ordering a levy of taxes sufficient to pay the entire delinquency on bonds, may direct levies in successive amounts within the ability of the landowners to pay.

Gilbert E. Mosher, president since 1917, today was elected chairman of the board of the Haloid Company, manufacturer of photographic papers and equipment. Joseph R. Wilson, formerly vice president in charge of sales, was elected president.

Many luncheon parties were given yesterday in conjunction with the novel entertainment entitled, "Fashions for the Dance Style Revue," in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Stage Relief Fund.

Three British state carriages with coachmen, footmen and outriders in top hats and long scarlet cloaks carried Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy and his staff to Buckingham Palace this morning, where he presented his credentials to the King.
Playing at top form, Charles Fitch of the City Athletic Club yesterday won the Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis title by defeating E. L. K. Kilroe of the Columbia Club at the Columbia Club.

Stockholders of the J. I. Case Company at their annual meeting in Racine, Wis., on April 6 will be asked to reduce the authorized preferred stock from 200,000 to 101,825 shares and increase the authorized common stock from 200,000 to 300,000 shares.

Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., has instituted a program of building a minimum of two tankers a year for ten years for orderly replacement of its forty-two-vessel oil fleet in North Atlantic and intercoastal service.

Running for the first time in the red and black silks of C. S. Bromley, Philadelphia sportsman, the 8-1 shot Quincy today won the featured Santa Rosa Purse before another good-sized crowd at Tropical Park.

WASHINGTON, March 8.-The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 5: COMMANDERS Addoms, A. H., the Moffet. to District Communication Officer, 3d Naval District, New York N Y Craven, F. S., the Arizona, to command the Altair.

An angry scene between William OrmsbyGore, Secretary of State for the Colonies, and Colonel Josiah Wedgwood, Laborite champion of the Zionists, enlivened an inconclusive debate in the House of Commons today on the government's Palestine policy.
A story of murders and murder plots, with a secret poison laboratory in the NKVD (secret police) headquarters, where chemists under Henry G. Yagoda's direction concocted
The German Government has officially admitted one case of ill treatment in a German prison, expressed regret and given assurance that the officials responsible will be punished.

Commander Henry Allen Pearson, United States Navy, retired, veteran of the Spanish-American and World Wars, died on Sunday of pneumonia in the Brooklyn Naval Hospital after a brief illness. He lived in Great Neck, L. I. His age was 68.
At its meeting yesterday afternoon the Municipal Art Commission gave final approval to six WPA Federal Art Project mural paintings for hospitals in the New York area.

Members of the women's committee of the 1938 Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army met at Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South, yesterday to make plans for the $600,000 campaign that will open with a dinner at the Pierre on March 22.

Solly Krieger of Bensonhurst knocked out Stanley Hasrato of Yonkers in 1:26 of the seventh round of their scheduled eightround feature bout at the Coliseum last night. Krieger weighed 164 and Hasrato 162 1/4. A crowd of 9,000 saw the bout.

A resolution calling upon President Roosevelt to propose to other powers a cessation of all naval construction until Jan. 1, 1940, and call an arms limitation conference here about Oct. 1, this year, was introduced in the House today by Representative Ludlow of Indiana.

Westminster Hall, the six-story apartment building at the corner of Third and Maple Streets, in Great Neck,. L. I., has been purchase from the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company by Bud A. Lipman.

Former Governor James M. Curley said today he' would seek "through the courts" to clear his name of a court ruling that he "corruptly accepted $30,000" in settlement of a claim against Boston while he was Mayor.
Councilman Arthur B. Langlie was overwhelmingly elected Mayor today over Lieutenant Governor Victor A. Meyers. Complete unofficial returns tonight gave Langlie 78,997 votes to 48,114 for Meyers.

Members of the Actors Equity Association's council unanimously agreed yesterday afternoon to refrain from participating in any secret-meetings or electioneering until the selection on March 18 of a nominating committee to pick a slate of candidates for office.

The five-story apartment house at 5 West Fourth Street, Mount Vernon, N. Y., on a plot 100 by 105 feet at the corner of South Fourth Avenue, has been purchased by Plaza Properties, Inc., of which Loomis J. Grossman is president. Hardy Braunels acted as brokers.

Mrs. Caroline Starin Carroll, widow of General Howard Carroll and granddaughter of the late John H. Starin, wealthy steamboat operator, died Monday after a short illness at her home at 11 East Eightysixth Street. She was in her seventyninth year.

The New York Athletic Club polo team furnished something of a surprise with a defeat of Winston Guest's Optimists, 15 to 13, in the feature of last night's specially arranged matches at Squadron A Armory.

The taxi fleet operators who locked out about 4,500 cab drivers in a wage dispute several days ago announced last night that they had agreed to the demand of the Transport Workers Union that they.reinstate the locked-out drivers and put their cabs back on the street before starting wage negotiations with the New York State Labor Mediation Board.
Todd Wool, secretary of the P. Lorillard Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that the company has suffered

The Canadian hockey team tonight suffered its first defeat in a long European tour- a 4-3 loss to Great Britain before 12,000 at Harringay arena. The Canadians, who play as the Sudbury Wolves, traveled all day from Belgium,...

Expenditures of more than $5,000,000 by the Tennessee Valley Authority have been questioned by the Controller General's office and listed in a preliminary report being prepared for submission to the TVA and Congress.

Colonel Ful-gencio Batista, the army Chief of Staff, asserted tonight that the alleged conspiracy that resulted in the death of four and the wounding of one last night in an armed clash when soldiers surprised a meeting of plotters had been completely broken up.

Broome St, 426, 25x109; Effie Price Gladding to Thomas S. Gladding and wife, Easton, Md.: mtg $20.500. 97th St, 152 E, 25.11x101; Thekla Schrottmann to trustees will of Edna Wilson, Merion, Pa., care G. Searing Wilson; mtg $15,000, held by trustees. 87th St. 151 W, 16.8x100.8 1/2; Rexhold Realty Corp to Geza Oze and wife, 507 E 79th St: mtg $6,500 ($6): grantees gave
Vic Tocwish of Chicago, rolling five games above 200 in a row in doubles and singles competition today, effected the first change in the American Bowling Congress standings since Sunday.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of Dr. Joseph H. Hertz as Chief Rabbi of the United Hebrew Congregations of the British Empire was marked yesterday afternoon by the Jewish Theological Seminary of America in a broadcast from Radio Station WHN. Dr. Hertz is the first graduate of the seminary.

A 125-107 victory by Andrew Ponzi over Onofrio Lauri of Brooklyn last night at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy sent the popular Philadelphian, for the time being at least, into the lead for the world's pocket billiard championship.

The city of Helsingfors, throughBrown Brothers Harriman Co., fiscal agents for the city's thirtyyear 6 1/2 per cent external sinking fund bonds due in 1960, announced yesterday that $72,000 of these bonds have been drawn for redemption on April 1 at par, through operation of the sinking fund.

The Sherwin --Williams Company, paint manufacturers, has purchased part of the old Pusey Jones shipyard here, it was announced today. H. J. Haines of Cleveland, vice president of the company, said a new plant will be erected for the extraction from foreign ores of white pigment used in paint manufacture.

Continued high mortality from broncho-pneumonia kept the infant mortality rate above 50 to each 1,000 live births for the second week this year, Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner, reported yesterday in his review of the vital statistics for the week ended last Saturday.

Sweeping reforms in the Department of Civil Aviation and doubled subsidies for air transport were announced tonight with the publication of a scathing report by Lord Cadman's committee of inquiry into charges of inefficiency at the Air Ministry and in Imperial Airways, Ltd., the government's first chosen instrument for air transport.

If human memory were more tenacious, the Moscow trials would be absolutely impossible. The GPU breaks the spine of defendants, and one has become accustomed to this. But in the same breath the GPU attempts also to break the spine of historical processes: that is more difficult.
To stimulate the munitions industry the Commerce Ministry has prepared a bill for subsidizing firms engaged in the manufacture of machinery and machine tools to encourage them to install new plants.
Shelterbelt planting in the Plains States in 1938 will amount to 65 per cent more than in 1935, 1936 and 1937 combined, the Agricultural Department announced today.

A new training system designed to provide officers for the merchant marine and to encourage youths to make a career of the sea has been formulated by the United States Maritime Commission and will become effective on Tuesday of next week.

Senator Borah made it plain today that he intended to have an intensive inquiry made into the views on antitrust laws held by Professor Thurman W. Arnold of Yale, nominated by President Roosevelt to succeed Robert H. Jackson as Assistant Attorney General and head of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice.
The action of the Legislature in exempting applicants for the State police from competitive examinations was held unconstitutional today by the Court of Appeals.

With nearly one-third of the country's railway mileage in the hands of receivers or trustees in bankruptcy, it is not difficult to understand why the Interstate Commerce Commission granted yesterday an increase in freight rates.

The report of the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company for 1937 shows a net profit of $5,020,903, the largest since 1929, while in the selling of iron ore and power the company had the best year in its history.
An unidentified Brooklyn boy who was bitten by a dog Monday was the object of a police search last night. The animal, suspected of three attacks on children, was found to have had rabies.

A number of uptown residential buildings figured in the city realty changing hands in deals announced yesterday Several of the parcels traded will undergo alterations by the new owners. Arthur Cutler bought from the United States Life Insurance Company the six-story apartment at 80 East 116th Street, on the southwest corner, of Park Avenue, for cash abcv a mortgage of $225,000, through Pearce Mayer, brokers.

Establishment of mortgage banks financed by private capital, as provided in bills introduced in the Legislature by Senator Joseph and Assemblyman Stephens, is approved. by the Merchants Association of New York, it was announced yesterday.
General John J. Pershing kept up his improvement today, the physician's bulletin at 10:30 P. M. saying: "General Pershing has had a good day.
In its efforts to mobilize additional labor reserves for its increased rearmament program the government announced today the initiation of the following measures:

Abraham Hess, Union veteran of the Civil War, died Sunday in a hospital. He would have been 98 years old on March 27. . For fifteen years he had been color-bearer in every patriotic parade.- Last December he recovered after a truck ran over him.

Roslyn's so-called system of progressive education was praised in some respects and criticized in others in the long-awaited report by the State Department of Education, submitted to the taxpayers tonight.

Minas Geraes, an inland State, is to have an Atlantic port. The State of Rio de Janeiro has granted to Minas Geraes use of the port of Angra dos Reis, which will be connected by direct railroad to Minas Geraes.

Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council, assailed the O'Mahoney-Borah Corporation Licensing Bill today as an interference of government with business, and a measure that would put "all industry in bondage."

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended March 3 increased in three trade groups, compared with the same week last year, and declined in the other two divisions, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Two five-story buildings at 916 Stebbins Avenue and 894 East 163d Street, the Bronx, were purchased by Morris Luskin Son, operators, from a client of Julius Irving Krefetz, attorney. The buildings are on one plot, 154 by 80 feet, contain twelve stores and forty-eight apartments, and have an annual rent roll of $26.000.

Richard Whitney Co., headed by Richard Whitney, five times president of the New York Stock Exchange, was suspended by that institution yesterday for insolvency. Announcement of the suspension was accompanied by a Stock Exchange statement that Mr. Whitney

Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Steamship Owners Association, asked the National Maritime Union, C. I. O. affiliate, yesterday to ban all strikes for a period of two weeks pending the outcome of negotiations for wage contracts with the ship lines.

Many an ola-timer must have dropped a nostalgic tear on learning that State Attorney General Bennett had found it necessary to stop the sale of stock in a perpetual-motion machine. The idea is so venerable, so crammed with associations.

William Penn wrote to the Pennsylvanians of his time that he was "sorry at heart for your animosities." He would be sorrier now. Mr. John Lewis ordered the Democrats to nominate Lieutenant Governor Tom Kennedy of the M. W. U. for Governor.

Henry Armstrong, Los Angeles boxer who holds the featherweight championship of the world, was signed yesterday by Promoter Mike Jacobs to fight Barney Ross for the latter's world welterweight championship, it was announced yesterday.

Garbage removal was discontinued and fire protection withdrawn today from forty-eight tax delinquent homes and business buildings. Occupants were notified that unless they removed garbage at their own expense they would be taken into Municipal Court, presided over by Mayor Dave Shapard, sponsor of the drastic tax collection policy begun yesterday.
President Roosevelt announced he would confer on Friday with the directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority and demand the facts in the dispute between the directors over TVA practices and policies.

When Richard Hovey wrote of "the islands of desire" toward the sunset he made his imaginary journey in a ship that was in the offing "with her topsails shot with fire." And he made no question as to the "rights" of any one nation in these diminutive territories in the far-off seas.

No sound question can be raised as to the propriety and necessity of the inquiry the President intends to hold next Friday morning into the facts in the controversy among the directors of the Tennessee Vallev Authoritv.

In a furious exchange of personal attacks, Councilman Michael J. Quill, Laborite, called Councilman William A. Carroll, Tammany member, a liar at yesterday's Council meeting for having said that Quill laid no income tax though his Brokerage account showed he was worth $16,000 last year.

Directors of the Western Electric Company declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock. Payments last year were 60 cents on March 31, 75 cents each. on June 30 and Sept. 30 and 90 cents on Dec. 28.
The government issued a new decree tonight ordering revision of all citizenship of Jews in Rumania and of Christians who were Jews before Dec. 1, 1918.

Existing State machinery is not geared to an effective low-rent housing or slum-clearance program, and steps will be taken at the coming Constitutional Convention to remedy this situation, Harold Riegelman, a delegate to the convention, declared yesterday.

Trading was fair to mostly slow. The lamb market was sharply higher, other classes traefa meats were steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb to be higher, other classes mostly steady, quality considered, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora approved yesterday an accounting made by Charles E. Dunlap, George Whitney and Edwin S. S. Snderland for a $16,717,949 trust created by the late Edward J. Berwind, capitalist and financier, during his life.

Sales of used cars by Ford dealers last Saturday, the opening day of the national used-car sales drive, amounted to $2,500,000, compared with $788,000 daily average for the ten-day period preceding, according to John R. Davis,

Plans for extended newspaper, direct mail and outdoor advertising, to further establish its position in the lowest price automobile field, were outlined yesterday before 150 Willys Overland dealers in the New York region at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania. W. C.

The automobile industry was the steel industry's best customer again last year, by a wide margin, according to the annual survey of distribution of finished steel made by Iron Age, based on detailed reports received from steel companies having 95.8 per cent of the total ingot producing capacity of the United States.

President Roosevelt's recent suggestion for guaranteed-- annual wages in the building trades, perhaps as a-means of lowering unit costs and at the same time giving steadier work in the construction field, has been widely discussed in both labor and contracting circles, but no tangible results in that direction yet have been noted.
Senator Wheeler made a determined attack on the Administration Reorganization Bill on the Senate floor today when he pressed an amendment which would limit its scope.

The John L. Lewis labor group, promoting the candidacy of Thomas Kennedy, secretary-treasurer of the United Mine Workers, for the Democratic nominati for Governor of Pennsylvania, will not oppose the selection of Governor Earle for the Senate if the latter keeps his hands off the Gubernatorial contest.

Captain Josef Leopold, for years the head of the illegal Nazi movement in Austria, left Vienna tonight for the second time since the Berchtesgaden agreement, under which he was supposed to quit the country immediately and finally.

Winthrop Rockefeller, executive vice chairman of the Greater New York Fund, announced yesterday the appointment of two new committee chairmen who will direct their appeals to the business and employee groups in May, as part of the campaign to raise $10,000,000 to supplement the finances of private health and welfare agencies.

Capt. Julian B. Anuskewicz, Q. M.-Res., now on active duty with CCC Co. 210, Camp SP-9, Katonah, N. Y., is continued on active duty with the CCC until Sept. 10, 1938. Date of rank, June 12, 1934. Capt. Anuskewicz is authorized to command line troops on duty with the CCC.

Captain Richard L. Reiss, member of the housing committee of the London County Council, told members of the National Public Housing Conference here yesterday that the development of new sites in outlying areas was to be preferred to slum clearance, "provided the vacant site is reasonably accessible." The meeting was held at 99 Park Avenue.

The old folksong isn't what it used to be for the blueberry pickers of that sandy region of New Jersey that stretches from Lakewood to Atlantic City, where, before the Revolution and for 125 years afterward, the isolated denizens of the area continued to sing the ballads of ancient origin-most of them British-brought over by the early settlers.

The nine-story apartment house at 743 Fifth Avenue, near Fiftyseventh Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. It was bought in by the Bank for Savings in the City of New York, as plaintiff, for $100,000.

A play about Lincoln, from his young manhood to the Civil War, likely will be the first play to be produced by the five playwrights who have banded together to put on their own dramas. Without a title as yet, it is the work of Robert E. Sherwood, member of the organization along with Maxwell Anderson, S. N. Behrman, Sidney Howard and Elmer Rice.
Another political-financial crisis is fast approaching in France.

Warren C. Giles, vice president and general manager of the Reds, remained in a hospital tonight for an X-ray examination of injuries suffered when he was felled by a line drive by Norman Small, rookie outfielder.
A delegation of Jewish Deputies and Senators called on the Minister of the Interior today to request protection for Jewish-owned businesses in Warsaw against renewed antiSemitic rioting.

Sometimes old styles in music A sound newer than recent ones. This was the case when Ida Krehm played Alexandre Tansman's Second piano concerto at the concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, last night in Carnegie Hall.

The index of wholesale commodity prices compiled by the National Fertilizer Association for the week ended March 5 advanced to 76.8 per cent of the 1926-28 average, compared with 76.5 per cent in the preceding week. The figure for the same week last year was 86.4 per cent.
Harry Van Dyke Bootes, a veteran of the Spanish-American War and secretary of the Bird-Archer Company, chemical manufacturers, died today at his home of a heart ailment. He was 65 years old.

Reportedly acting on a New York tip the French police have uncovered a vast mail order business in narcotics in which local dealers were said to have sent heroin to United States customers. Eight suspects have been arrested and thirteen more will be indicted.

The coaches themselves were designated as college football's most dangerous enemies by Herbert O. (Fritz) Crisler, new Michigan head coach, at a luncheon tendered him today by the Michigan Club of Boston.

An ambulance purchased for the Spanish Loyalists with funds raised through the Federated Faculty Committees for Aid to Spain was displayed yesterday on the City College campus. Seventy-five students attended a noon-hour meeting in behalf of the fund and donated $6.

Two scholarships for graduate study in the field of home economics have been awarded to Miriam Firstenberg and, Bridget Euphemia by the Home Economics Club of Hunter College. Both alumnae were graduated from Hunter in January.

The War Department released the following orders today. dated March 7: MAJOR GENERALS Kromer, L. B., Chief Cavalry, four days leave, March 17. Conner, F., U. S. A., three months leave account sickness, about March 10.
Steel ingot output was unchanged again last week, although a seasonal increase was anticipated, and the adjusted index eased to 39.3 from 40.0. The figure was 115.9 for the week ended March 6, 1937.

Judge Manuel Bartlett of the First District Court this afternoon issued a temporary injunction restraining the Federal Labor Board from enforcing the Supreme Court decision granting wage increases to the employes o seventeen American and British oil companies.

John J. McElligott, Fire Commissioner, angered by what he declared was the "callous" treatment of a fireman taken to New York Hospital for emergency treatment for immersion, who was transferred by that hospital to City Hospital on Welfare Island, ordered a full investigation of the incident yesterday and announced he would take up the matter with Mayor La Guardia today.

The State of California will offer for sale today an issue of $1,015,818 of registered warrants. The issue, which represents the usual tax anticipation financing, will be dated March 12, and will become payable on or about Aug. 3, 1938.
The Princesses Myzejen, Ruhie and Maxhide, sisters of King Zog of Albania, who are visiting the United States, were greeted by Mayor La Guardia yesterday morning in his office at City Hall.

170th St, 426 E (11-2894); Kalman Hurwitz to Empire City Savings Bank; installments, 4 per cent: $193,000. Webster Ave. 2,673 (12-3277): S. J. Stein Realty Corp to Bowery Savings Bank: extends mtg to Nov. 1, 1940, at 3 per cent; $16,100. Grand Ave, 1,615 (11-2866); also Macomps Rd. 1,630; Seaman Associates, Inc, to Bowery Savings Bank; extends mtg to Feb. 1. 1943. at 4 1/2 per cent; $163.000.

A generally favorable reaction to provisions of the American-Czechoslovak reciprocal trade agreement, announced in Washington Monday, was evident among individual domestic manufacturers, importers and exporters here yesterday.

A new and permanent Exposition of Conservation, reflecting the ninety years' work of the Department of the Interior in the conservation of natural resources, was completed today. Beginning tomorrow it will be open to the public.

With the opposition cutting across party lines, the Assembly, by a vote of 100 to 32, passed the Wadsworth bill today to provide scholarships financed by Federal funds for local and State welfare employes. By the same vote the Assembly passed the

Representative Barton of New York said today that the revision of postage stamp designs and denominations announced by Postmaster General Farley was a "scheme to make sure that all Republicans are forgotten."

The following members having been tried before Francis X. Glaccane, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on Feb. 28, for violation of Rules and Regulations, 1937., the following decisions are rendered by the Fire Chief and Commissioner:
Harlee Branch, second assistant postmaster general, returned from Puerto Rico yesterday, accompanied by S. A. Sisler, general superintendent of the Railway Mail Service.

While his mates are toiling with great determination under Florida's tropical sun, Lou Gehrig is sitting at home in Scarsdale toying with the perplexing problem of whether he will play first base for the Yankees this year for $39,000.

Chinese reported today that guerrilla bands had recaptured twelve towns in conquered territory north of the Yellow River. Most of the towns were along the HonanHopeh border, forty to sixty miles behind the Japanese Yellow River lines.

President Roosevelt has summoned all three directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority to the White House on Friday for an investigation of his own into the facts behind the long-standing dispute within the administration of the New Deal experimental project.

Led by a rise of 17.4 per cent in books, there has been an increase within the past year of 14 per cent in the retail price of over 3,500 items as the result of "price-fixing" under the Feld-Crawford act and the Tydings-Miller amendment to the Sherman act,
Canada's interest in the Empire Company, which will. operate a transatlantic air service, after experimental flights during the coming Summer, is to be exercised through TransCanada Air Lines,

Although the stock market here was generally dull today, there were few sellers in evidence and some sections made small gains. Gilt-edge issues lost ground, while among the foreign loans German bonds were a weak spot. Transatlantic stocks,

The life of a game protector isn't all "bread and jam" as so many sportsmen are inclined to believe, and those who doubt this only need ask Game Protector Marcus Hinkley of Narrowsburg, N. Y., who with Joseph Rudd, a Pennsylvania protector, spent three hours the other night in rescuing a deer from the Delaware River.
Justus George Botbyl, retired banker, died of a heart attack yesterday morning in his home here. He was 73 years old.

Sir Cyril Cobb, Member of Parliament for West Fulham, died today, and the election of a successor may provide the first .actual test of British sentiment toward Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's foreign policy.
THE husky, genial, middle-aged gentleman was presented as Alfred J. Robertson, the basketball coach of Bradley Polytechnic Institute of Peoria, Ill. Bradley-- er-- Bradley-- oh, yes, to be sure.
Winston Guest, famous North American polo star, today paid through a representative here the record price of 20,000 pesos for Luis Nelson's 6-year-old polo pony Rabincho.

While no plans have been laid as yet, a substantial increase in advertising of Czechoslovakian products in this country will probably result from the reciprocal trade treaty signed this week, according to the American-Czechoslovak Chamber of Commerce here yesterday.

Although they enjoyed a commanding lead early in the third period, the Rangers were extended considerably to beat the Toronto Maple Leafs in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

BOULIN, CAMILLE H. (Feb. 16). Estate, about $4,000. To Jean J. Boulin, 22 John St., Chatham, N. J., and Victor J. Boulin, executor, 4 Drake Rd., Scarsdale, N. Y., brothers, residue equally. DIEDERICHS, SUSANNA (Sept. 12). Estate, more than $10,000. To Susie Unhoch, 230 E. 78th St., $2,000, household and personal effects; Arnolde Margarete Lang, daughter, 125 Wachmannstrasse, Bremen, Germany, residue; several specific bequests. George Unhoch, 190-18 35th Ave., Flushing. L. I., executor,

The Salle Santelli A trio, composed of Jose and Miguel de Capriles and Warren Dow, won the national senior foils team championship for the second consecutive year last night by defeating the New York Athletic Club team of Dr. John R. Huffman,
State and municipal financing for February totaled $59,761,146, as compared with $42,750,783 in February last year. Such financing for the first two months of this year amounted to $111,648,570.

President Roosevelt said today that New England need have no fears that any of its industries would be crippled by the contemplated recriprocal trade agreement with Great Britain or by such agreements with other countries.

Rehabilitation of 135,000 city tenements requiring repair was urged Upon 200 real estate owners who gathered in City Hall yesterday for their first meeting as members of the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement.
Dr. Michael A. Burns, Professor of Neurology at Jefferson Medical College, died in Jefferson Hospital yesterday of a heart ailment. He was 53 years old

Announcement has been made to friends here of the engagement of Miss Monica Rainbault of this city, daughter of Mrs. Charles Victor Rainbault of Sao Paulo, Brazil, and the late Mr. Rainbault, to John Ogilvy-Rennie of London and New York.
The St. Nicks last night captured the New York Amateur Hockey Association title by defeating the New York A. C. skaters in the final of the play-off games at the Brooklyn Ice Palace, 3 to 2.

Mayor La Guardia sent to the Legislature today another tax bill, this time for the financing of non-Federal housing projects. It would permit the city to levy an earmarked special tax, of a variety to be decided upon by the city, to pay the interest on but not the amortization of housing project costs.

Wheat prices dipped to new low levels on the current downturn on the May delivery in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today. The break to 88 3/4 cents a bushel, the lowest figure quoted since November, uncovered a much better export demand and also brought the domestic trade into the market for supplies of flour, and prices rallied sharply.
Striking students of the National Farm School voted early today to accept a compromise by which the board of trustees virtually acceds to their demands.
Recommendations for revising the system of selecting juries and sentencing those convicted in criminal trials were made today by President Judge Curtis Bok of Common Pleas Court,
One eye closed tightly and the other narrowed to a slit, Rollie Hemsley, Indians' catcher, sat in his hotel room today in purple pajamas breathing the strains of "Sugar Blues" into a mouth organ.

Manuel Maldonaldo, 35 years old, who, with three other men and two women, all members of the Workers Alliance, was accused of kicking and striking a policeman who sought to break up a sit-down strike at a relief station last April, was convicted of assault last night by a jury before Judge John J. Fitzgerald in Kings County Court, Brooklyn.

Bluffing passers-by into thinking they were greeting an old friend, three robbers, one of whom had a pistol, stole a payroll of $3,357 from a garment company's bookkeeper in the West Twenty-eighth Street station of the I. R. T. at 3:10 P. M. yesterday and escaped after intimidating their victim into boarding a southbound train, according to reports to the police.

Thirty-one Princeton University upper class men, twenty-two seniors and nine juniors, have been nominated for election to the Phi Beta Kappa national honorary society, it was announced today by Dr. Robert K. Root, dean of the Princeton faculty.

Mrs. Anne Morrow Lindbergh was among 150 relatives and friends who attended funeral services today for her maternal grandmother, Mrs. Annie E. Cutter. The services were held in the home where Mrs. Cutter died Sunday of pneumonia at the age of 92.

Milk distributors' profits range from 13 to 27 per cent of their costs, with the prices "dictated" by a small group, Governor Lehman and the State Legislature were told yesterday in a report by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. of his investigation of the milk industry in this State.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 13,000 including 3,000 directs. Market unevenly 10c-25c lower than Monday's average, mostly 15c-25c off; closed dull at full decline. Top $9.80; bulk 170250 lbs $9.50-$9.80; 260-325 lbs. $9.25-$9.50;

Shipments of all grades of zinc from domestic plants in February amounted to 21,540 tons, compared to 24,931 in January and 46,943 in February last year, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.

The United States and Great Britain understand in detail tach other's attitude with regard to the Pacific islands, Secretary Hull said today. Asked whether this government had given Great Britain advance notice of American occupation of Canton and Enderbury Islands, the Secretary replied in general terms that both governments had fairly accurate views about each other's position.

The New York Curb Exchange, in a tabulation issued yesterday, showed that all stocks on the Exchange had a market value on Feb. 28, of $10,446,963,234, against $10,034,425,782 on Jan. 31. The average price of each share was $13.99, compared with $13.46.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 8, unless specified: Babbitt, at San Bias Islands. Charleston, at Charleston. Hannibal, at Port of Spain. Henderson, at San Pedro. Melville, at Navy Yard, Mare Island, March 6. Tatnuck, Dutch Harbor to Kanaga, March 7. Vega. San Pedro to Mare Island.

C. B.. Snyder Realty Company sold for Carl K.- Withers, Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, in charge of the Esenbe Building and Loan Association, to the Stanley Leather Products Company the one-story factory, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, at 323-29 Twelfth Street, West New York.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Supertendent of Schools, announced yesterday the suspension from the school system of Barnet Quart, a clerk in the Bureau of Construction and Maintenance of the Board of Education.

The decline in sales of the leading mail-order and chain-store companies which began in January increased last month. The best showings were made by the drug and shoe groups, which scored slight increases.

Ellis H. Parker, for many years chief of detectives in Burlington County, N. J.; his son, Ellis Parker Jr., and three others were named in an indictment handed up yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn. The defendants are charged with kidnapping Paul H. Wendel, former attorney of Trenton.

War Minister General Gen Sugiyama's recommendation that the 1940 Olympic games be cancelled was described today by high Japanese Olympic officials as a "matter of propriety" and not to be regarded as a reflection of the government's attitude.

The verdict of the people on the 1936 election had its reflection in the decisions of the United States Supreme Court in 1937, President Roosevelt declares in this week's installment of Liberty Magazine of his introduction to the forthcoming publication of his State papers.

While the French franc, continuing its weakness of the previous day, fell yesterday to the lowest levels in more than eleven years, other important foreign exchanges advanced strongly in terms of the dollar.

Formal action on the recent suggestion for the formation of a union of real property owners is expected shortly to result from the study now being made by real estate organizations. Many letters concerning the proposed organization are being received daily, according to Charles F. Noyes, who advanced the idea.

The Real Estate Board of New York has offered its aid to the City Tax Commission on the commission's proposal to obtain what it considers a proper equalization tax rating for property here in the tables of the State Tax Commission.
" Unknown parties" have damaged the Spanish Loyalist submarine C-2 just as the vessel was ready to put to sea after lengthy repairs.

The Marx brothers, who made two of their successful pictures, "A Night at the Opera" and "A Day at the Races," under the Metro banner, but who were dropped last year by the studio in a disagreement over money matters, are to return to the MGM fold.

A further decline in foreign cotton markets facilitated yesterday the reversal of straddle accounts and contracts were released in sufficient volume on the Cotton Exchange to result in losses of 3 to 7 points.
Mrs. James Roosevelt will give a musical on Friday night at her home, 47 East Sixty-fifth Street. Mrs. Dwight Davis of Washington is at the Ritz Tower.

The six-family house on a plot 27 by 100 feet at 47-19 Forty-fourth Street, Long Island City, L. I., was sold for cash' above a first mortgage of $13,500 to a client of Hosinger Bode, Inc., broker In the transaction. The Newburgh Savings Bank was the seller.

The agenda for the long-awaited Anglo-Italian negotiations were taken up this evening when the British Ambassador, the Earl of Perth, accompanied by Maurice Ingram, formerly counselor of the Rome Embassy and now head of the Department for Southern Europe at the British Foreign Office, called on Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, at the Palazzo Chigi, remaining in conversation for an hour and twenty-five minutes.

IT depends largely upon where one sits. From the expensive seats every prospect pleases and only standees are vile. From the dress-circle the view is likewise good; and even from the first balcony. It is only in the top gallery that one begins to squint and angrily cup one's ear.

A strike of the sixty-five service employes of the San Remo Apartments, a twenty-seven-story structure on Central Park West, between Seventy-fourth and Seventy-fifth Streets, was halted temporarily at 6:50 P. M. yesterday when the men voted unanimously to return to work pending mediation today.
Returning to Loyalist Spain after four weeks' absence, this writer finds every one more excited and happier over the sinking of the Insurgent cruiser Baleares than discourage over the loss of Teruel.
Advisory Master Dougal Herr reduced today the alimony that Julius Frankel must pay to his former wife, Rose, of 2,018 Voorhis Avenue, Brooklyn, N. Y., to $10 weekly.

The value of all textile fibers consumed in the United States last year was $1,084,600,000, which was the highest since 1929, according to figures issued by the Rayon Organon yesterday. It was higher than that of 1936 by about $5,000,000.

Through the cooperation of a group of sponsors associated with Greenwich House, one of the best known settlements in the city, a philanthropic motif has been applied to the third annual "Young America Paints" art exhibition now on view in the International Building at Rockefeller Center.
Rents on stores in the Harlem and Williamsburg low-rental housing projects, built with Federal funds and being managed by the New York City Housing Authority, have been reduced 50 per cent.
A. Brooklyn housewife, who acted as the "finger woman," or inside informant, and two men pleaded guilty yesterday in Kings County Court to the hold-up of ten women and a man at a poker party in a

Twenty-fifth anniversary greetings from President Roosevelt to the United Synagogue of America, were made public by the organization yesterday. The United Synagogue will hold its silver jubilee convention May 6 to 10 in Chicago. The President's letter,

The annual report of the American Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $5,642,959 after all expenses and charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.75 a share on the outstanding common stock.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Valerie Edmonds of this city and Toronto, daughter of Mr.-and Mrs. Reginald H. Edmonds of Toronto, to Collier H. Young, also of New York, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Riverside Church.
Plans to resume weekly publication of The Literary Digest with the issue of March 26 were announced yesterday.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, sailing today for Cherbourg and Southampton, will have among her passengers Arturo Toscanini, Michael MacWhite, Irish Minister to the United States, accompanied by Mrs. MacWhite; Charles F. Urschel of Oklahoma City; Lord Essendon, chairman of Furness, Withy Cc.;
The Boston Bruins bounced out of their brief slump by overwhelming New York's short-handed Americans for a 7-0 triumph before 13,000 persons at the Boston Garden tonight.

Something extraordinary in Spring training activities tossed the usually well-conducted affairs of the Giants into a mild uproar today when it was learned that some time during the dark hours of the night, while Colonel Bill Terry and all his charges were sleeping the sleep of

Paul Williams. of Pennsylvania continues to be the leading individual high scorer in the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League with 57 points, having held his advantage against all rivals in the past week.

Charles Herman, field supervisor of the FHA, will address a meeting of the Real Estate Owners Association tonight at the New York Turn Hall, 150 East Eighty-fifth Street. Real estate appraising will be the subject of a talk tonight by John C. Tredwell, a member of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, at the West Side Y. M. C. A.

M`ore than 16,000 questions regarding business, social, political, financial, theatrical and other matters in France were asked and answered through the French information center in New York during the past year, according to a report by General de Chambrun to the annual meeting of this institution here today under the presidency of Marshal Philippe Petain.

Mrs. Patricia Ryan took the witness stand in Bronx County Court yesterday and for more than an hour related in a halting voice the story of her three years of married life with Patrolman Michael Ryan, whom she is alleged to have murdered Oct. 31 in their home at 1,350 Purdy Street.
Sales programs of direct selling organizations for the coming year should be planned to allow for frequent adjustments, Walter AlwynSchmidt, economist of Arthur Rosenberg Company,

Mrs. Linn M. A. Evans and Mrs. Homer L. Loomis gave a luncheon and card party yesterday at Sherry's for Princess Irbain-Kahn Kaplanoff, Mrs. James Hope Caldwell, Miss Ethel Stetson, Mrs. Ryder Henry, Princess Vladimir Koudacheff, Mrs. Nathaniel A. Campbell, Miss Sara Lippincott Richards, Mrs. William J. Hutchinson, Miss Emily Stevens, Mrs. Noah MacDowell, Mrs. Edgar M. Williams and Miss Emily Jackson.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3.339,700 barrels, compared with 3,322,800 in the previous week, an increase of 16,900, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

A petition asking the removal of Stanley M. Isaacs as Borough President of Manhattan on the charge that he violated both the letter and spirit of his oath of office and betrayed the public trust by appointing and retaining Simon W. Gerson,
The threat of a horse-racing war that has been hanging over the sport in New England for the past three years became a reality today when the New Hampshire Jockey Club, Inc.,

Larry MacPhal now may have what he terms "the best defensive infield in the National League," but there still remains the important item of getting the two leading members of it to put their names on contracts.

The crack Hurlingham polo team sailed for England tonight after having defeated Jamaica polo teams in four straight matches. On the same ship were fourteen members of a representative Jamaican football team en route to Port au Prince, Haiti, for a series of matches with Hawaiian teams. The Hurlingham players.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, commenting on Governor Lehman's statement in a letter to Mayor La Guardia that the city had broad tax powers for relief needs, said yesterday the city faced "an estimated deficit in emergency revenues of about $21,200,000 for the current year."
Robert Paine Scripps, who was principal stockholder and editorial director of the Scripps-Howard newspapers, was buried -yesterday at his Miramar ranch.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Philip Sheridan McNally and Herman Oliphant of New York City were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 455-Frederick S. Deltrick, Receiver, etc., et al., petrs. v. Standard Surety and Casualty Co. of New York. Argument continued for respondent and concluded for petitioners.
Harold Jacobi, chairman of the Greater New York Campaign of the United Palestine Appeal, announced yesterday the election of Leo Spitz, president of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation,
The International Broadcasting Office announced today that there were 69,700,000 radio sets in use in the world at the end of 1937, compared with 63,450,000 at the end of 1936.

General Sessions Judge John J. Freschi refused yesterday to dismiss the lunacy commission appointed last August to examine Robert Irwin, indicted for the murder of Mrs. Mary Gedeon, her daughter, Veronica, and a boarder, Frank Byrnes, last Easter morning in their home in East Fifty-first Street.

Threats of more rain came today to this area flooded by nearly a foot of precipitation last week. A new storm centered 1,000 miles out in the Pacific and sweeping toward the mainland caused the Weather Bureau to predict variable weather with probable rains during the latter part of the week.

L. C. Vass, the Securities and Exchange Commission's expert on investment banking, advised Senators today that small business enterprises need "machinery other than investment banking" to supply them with long-term credit.

Expansion and popularization- of the work of the Marketing Research Division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce was announced today with the appointment of Professor Herbert F. Taggart of the University of Michigan as consultant on distribution cost accounting.

An agreement calling for a permanent 5-cent fare on the buses of the Third Avenue Railway system here was ratified today by the Mount Vernon Board of Estimate and became effective at once. The agreement was approved by the

A fight which promises plenty of action will be staged at the New York Hippodrome tonight when Salvy Saban, hard-hitting Greenwhich Village welterweight, trades punches with Frankie Cavanna, durable battler from the East Side. It will be the second between the pair.

The Transit Commission's plan to purchase the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company for $170,213,508 was denounced yesterday as a "hoax upon the public" by Samuel Seabury and Adolf A. Berle Jr., whose transit unification plan was rejected by the Transit Commission in 1937.

Encouraged by the success or the no-parking regulations on twenty crosstown "express" streets, Police Commissioner Valentine added ten more express streets in the midtown area yesterday. No-parking regulations will become effective on these streets on March 21.

Mrs. Ruth Kinsey Schmuck of New York City filed suit here today for divorce from Thomas Kirby Schmuck. She charged cruelty. They were married in 1913 at Cincinnati and have a son, Thomas Kirby Jr., about 21. Property rights were settled by agreement in January.
Eunice Goody Cole, who in 1656 was sentenced to Boston jail for witchcraft, was exonerated today when townspeople voted unanimously to restore her, after 282 years. to citizenship.

With Peter D. Levine, 12 years old, of New Rochelle, missing for the twelfth day and no word coming from his father, Murray Levine, as to the results of efforts to renew contact with the kidnappers, at least three New Rochelle officials indicated yesterday their belief that it was time for the police to enter the case.
Former Mayor James J. Walker and a "double" for the well-known New Yorker, arriving on the same train, gave Hot Springs officials some embarrassing moments today.
Net income of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company amounted to $11,589,281 after depreciation, amortization and Federal income taxes, it was announced in the annual report for 1937 made public today.

To take effect 8 A. M., March 9: SECOND-GRADE DETECTIVE - Joseph S. McCarthy, from 18th Division, 10th Detective District, to 79th Precinct. Designation as second-grade detective revoked. PATROLMAN-Frank C. Smetak, from 19th Division, office of Chief Inspector, to 10th Precinct, assignment to duty in Safety Bureau discontinued.

Because the courts rejected the budget proposed by Mayor La Guardia and upheld the budget passed over his veto by the old Board of Aldermen, Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran, Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission; Civil Service Commissioner Ferdinand Q. Morton, and Magistrate James E. Finegan, former president of the commission, will have to make salary refunds to the city, it developed yesterday.

The Nazis who would force Austria to join the Reich are quite unwittingly creating the condition for peace between Chancellor Schuschnigg and the Socialist trade unions, thus preparing a formidable barrier to Anschluss.

Because of the clearness of vision and admirable steadfastness of purpose that have distinguished his course from the beginning, Secretary Hull is now able to announce the seventeenth agreement signed by the United States under the Reciprocal Trade Act, and the seventh to be concluded with a European country.
Eight men were arrested and two were injured today in a series of encounters between working and striking employes of the American Valve Company here.
Three hundred Civilian Conservation Corps camps will be closed before June 1 and the enrollees transferred by assignment to the 1,200 camps remaining in the reduced-work program.
Asserting that the Democratic party of this State in naming a candidate fo Governor must be free from dictation, Dudley Field Malone began tonight a campaign for the nomination for Governor and
A battle for life between the entire crew of the fishing trawler Boston and a sea monster was described today by the crew, with the arrival of the vessel at the fish pier.
After a tempestuous session this morning at which there appeared no hope for agreement, leading representatives of the nation's woolen industry this afternoon became conciliatory,

Eight strapping young men, making up one of the biggest Oxford crews in years, made their first appearance on the Thames tideway today to begin the final and most important phase of training for the varsity race with Cambridge April 2.

Stocks closed firmer but generally lower for the sixth consecutive session; turnover, 737,590 shares. United States Government and foreign bonds irregular, rail issues lower; transactions, $7,141,200.

Turpentine firm, 25c: sales 12 barrels; receipts 161 barrels; shipments 67 barrels; stock 24,582 barrels. Resin firm: no sales: receipts 604: shipments 696: stock 65,912. Quote: B to D, $3.55; E, $3.15; F, $4.25; G, $4.40; H, $4.50; I, K, $4.60; M, $4.65; N, $4.70; WG, $6.20; WW, X, $6.50.

Since the Interstate Commerce Commission never has authorized a blanket rise in freight rates, its decision yesterday on the application of the railroads for a general rise of 15 per cent in these rates was according to precedent. However,

Clinical sessions dealing with speech defects, oral pathology and maladjustments of children's teeth were features of the final meeting yesterday of the Spring conference of the New York Society of Orthodontists at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Securities and Exchange Commission received evidence today on an application by the Teck-Hughes Gold Mines, Ltd., for permission to remove its common stock from the New York Curb Exchange. Decision was reserved. The Curb,
Harry F. Wolf, the outstanding player in the sport for the last eight years, began his quest yesterday at the Crescent A. C. for his ninth consecutive national squash tennis title.

Edgar McPhail Smith, for more than forty years librettist of musical comedy hits, including many in which Weber and Fields starred, died yesterday in his home, 36-14 208th Street, Bayside, Queens. His age was 80.

Columbia's Spring football practice got under way yesterday, with forty candidates reporting for a two-hour session in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. The group was made up of an equal number of letter men and freshmen.

Roosevelt High School of Yonkers and Mount Kisco High School joined Pelham Memorial and White Plains, W. I. A. A. champion, in the open class semi-final brackets of the sixth annual Westchester County High School invitation basketball tournament at the county center tonight.

While in some respects the decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission on the petition of the railroads for a blanket freight rate increase of nearly 15 per cent follow precedents, in general, the reaction to it yesterday was one of disappointment.

As far as the taxpayer is concerned a dispute between the city government and the State government over a tax levy is a quarrel between the right pocket and the left pocket. Of State relies appropriations, as Governor Lehman said in his letter to Mayor La

The theatre this evening will be looking at the life, if not particularly the loves, of Catherine the Great of Russia. Call it "Empress of Destiny," the authors being Jesicca Lee and Joseph Lee Walsh.

Wiliam H. Kelly, Collector of Internal Revenue for Northern New Jersey, is expected to resign very soon, it was learned here today. It is understood Mr. Kelly's resignation was requested by President Roosevelt.

Starlight, 44-foot cutter, owned and skippered by Albert Fay of Houston, Texas, the first entry in the ninth annual St. Petersburg to Havana yacht race to complete the course, crossed the finishing line in the harbor at 10:32:30 this morning to win the cutter and sloop division as well as fleet honors.

The gravity of the issues in this proceeding has impelled us to press it to a conclusion with all the speed which is possible in a case involving every freight rate and charge in the country, consistently with the development of the requisite facts and hearing all parties interested in the result. From the entire record, including the matters herein before recited, certain facts are inescapable, and we so find.

William S. Heming, who received half a dozen medals for meritorious service during the Civil War, was found dead early Sunday morning in his furnished room at 163 East 124th Street, where he had lived for twelve years. He was 96 years old.
A long lost statuette by Michelangelo has been found in New York City, according to Dr. W. R. Valentiner, well-known art authority and director of the Detroit Institute of Arts.

Miss Marguerite Stengel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Ivan Stengel of this place, was married to J. Winston Kouwenhoven of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Kouwenhoven of Melbourne, Fla., this morning in the Larchmont Avenue Church here.

Trinity's basketball team defeated Horace Mann, 31 to 25, yesterday on the loser's court in the final game of the Eastern Private Schools League. Bill Rector of the winners was the high scorer with 15 points.
Otto Louis Dommerich of 50 East Sixty-ninth Street, senior partner in L. F. Dommerich Co., factors, of 271 Madison Avenue, died yesterday after a lingering illness.
William L. Blumberg, former Mayor of Cedarhurst, died here last night in his home at 402 Rugby Road, after an illness of several months He was 61 years old.

Grandmother's hoops are news again. They undulated into the fashion scene last night at Bergdorf-Goodman's, where a showing of Spring modes was reviewed by an audience of style authorities and the press.

Lauritz Melchior, one of the leading tenors of the Metropolitan Opera Company, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner of the Town Hall Club of New York, 123 West Forty-third Street, in celebration of the Danish tenor's twentyfifth year on the concert and operatic stages.

The reresignation of Ernest Angell, for two years director of its New York regional office, was accepted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. No definite date was fixed, Mr. Angell agreeing to remain at his post for a short time until some matters he is handling have been concluded.

Timing his visit to coincide with the start of the Anglo-Italian negotiations in Rome, Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, will arrive in London tomorrow for a series of talks that will show whether or not Anglo-German negotiations are possible also in the near future.

Although the prior event has now receded several years into mists that will one day be spoken of as "the long ago," still the Boldini exhibition just opened at the Newhouse Galleries, 5 East Fifty-seventh Street, may for many of us serve as a supplement to the admirable "full-length" affair arranged in 1933 by Maud Dale at Wildenstein's.

Spokesmen for the urban unemployed and for the Southern tenant farmers and sharecroppers drew dismal pictures of the plight of millions in these groups before the Senate Committee on Unemployment today.

Fteley Ave, 1,152 (14-3748); Bowery SavIngs Bank to John Korpe, 514 W 184th St. Fteley Ave, 1,150 (14-3748); Bowery Savings Bank to James Artopiades, 595 3d Ave. 192d St (11-3201), s w cor of Jerome Ave, 114x236; Irvin Panker, referee, to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

Testimony intended to show an official inter-relationship between the Celotex Corporation, the Phoenix Securities Corporation and the Certain-teed Products Corporation was offered yesterday by Celotex stockholders' counsel in a suit to bar a stock deal between the companies.

Sixty-five delegates to the American Kennel Club, representing kennel organizations all over the United States, attended the annual meeting of the governing body of dogdom held yesterday at headquarters, 221 Fourth Avenue.
Orval W. Adams, president of the American Bankers Association, asserted in a Rotary Club speech today "taxation is almost to the point of confiscation by the Federal Government."

To reduce the high cost and redtape connected with buying library books for schools, the finance and budget committee of the Board of Education will ask authority of the Board of Estimate to dispense with public bidding for books. A resolution to this effect is on the calendar for today's Board of Education meeting.

Angus MacMillan Fraser, the most widely known bagpiper in the city, died on a bus early Sunday morning, it was announced yesterday by George D. Baillie, president of the Federation of Scottish Societies. His age was 64.

The first annual national invitation college basketball tourney sponsored by the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association will get under way tonight at Madison Square Garden with New York University opposing Long Island University and Temple playing Bradley Tech. The latter contest will be first on the program, starting at 8:15 o'clock.
Four hundred persons attended the Mardi Gras masque ball given by the Century Club in the Miami-Biltmore Country Club tonight.

The Senate Committee on Public Service reported out today the Burchill bill for collective bargaining on the city subway system. This is the State Federation of Labor bill which has the support of Mayor La Guardia and which is opposed by the C. I. O. and its affiliate, the Transport Workers Union.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Will we ever see an end to these socalled "surveys" of medical conditions in this country? Do we not already know, and without further expense, that persons with inadequate incomes cannot buy necessary medical services or even the necessities of life? Our present
Hitherto he has been first in war, first in peace, first in the hearts of his countrymen, and first on the paper currency of his

Arthur O. Burger of 670 West End Avenue, New York City, was found dead of gas poisoning today in a room at the Hotel Slade here. Police Captain Clarence V. Mooney, who listed the death as suicide, said Mr. Burger registered at the hotel on Feb. 25, saying he had come here for his health.

The Quarter Century Club, composed of officers and employes of the National City Bank organization who have served twenty-five years or more. held its second annual dinner last night in the Hotel Astor. James H. Perkins, chairman of the bank's hoard, presided.

" The Yearling," by Marjorie Kinran Rawlings, has been announced by the Book-of-the-Month Club as its April selection. Like its predecessor, "South Moon Under," which was also a Book-of-the-Month Club selection, "The Yearling" has for its locale the wild hammock country of inland Florida, and the action of the novel takes place in the 1870's. Scribner will publish the book April 1.

Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., who won the medal in the Belleair women's golf championship yesterday, took her first-round match today by defeating Miss Frances Hadfield of St. Petersburg, Fla,, 3 and 2.

Captain Ben Pine of the Gloucester schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud challenged Captain Angust Walters of the Canadian champion Bluenose today to a series of races off Boston next August for the International Fishermen's Trophy. Captain Walters accepted.
Two Cleveland labor leaders were convicted today of extortion in a $1,200 "shakedown," and within a few hours were on their way to Ohio State Penitentiary under one-tofive-year sentences.

Dark clouds over the Sierras again balked the week-long search for a missing airliner and its nine occupants today, but reports came in undiminished volume from people who said they saw the storm-buffeted- ship Tuesday night.

A collection of original drawings by Jean de Brunhoff, illustrator of children's books, who died last October, have been received from Paris by Durlacher Brothers, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, where they will be placed on exhibition on March 22.

George D. Lynn of New York City and W. A. Zachritz of St. Louis won- a hard-fought match in the first round of the annual two-ball foursome tournament at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. They vanquished A. E. Wilson of Detroit and H. E. Ferguson of West Palm Beach by 3 and 1.

Former President Herbert Hoover appears to have given Chancellor Adolf Hitler at noon today the unusual experience of hearing doubt cast on the fundamental ideas of. National Socialism and on the likelihood that it will be a successful system of government.

Manhattan Alterations 43d St, 340 E; to 3-story tenement; Fred F. French Investing Co. Inc. 551 5th Ave, owner: Sugarman Berger, architects; cost $12.000. 41st St, 33T E; to 3-story tenement; same owner; same architect; cost $12,000. 42d St, 336 E; to 3-story dwelling and recreation rooms: same owner; same architect: cost $4.800.

Registration of out of town buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was considerably below the preceding week but slightly ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

February sales of General Motors ars to dealers in the United States and Canada and shipments overseas totaled 94,449, as compared to 74,567 in the same month last year and to 94,267 in January. Sales for the first two months in 1938 were 188,716, as compared to 178,235 for the 1937 period.
Dr. William P. Brooks, a former acting president of Massachusetts State College and one-time head of the Imperial College of Agriculture in Japan, died today at a hospital here after a long illness.
After adopting thirty-five measures in rapidfire order, the New Jersey Assembly adjourned early this evening to reconvene with the Senate next Monday night.

The Archbishop of York was among the signatories of a letter published today in The Times of London who "feel deeply concerned lest what is happening in Germany's concentration camps should become a new and formidable obstacle in the way of Anglo-German understanding."
Alexander D. Naylor of Pelham, treasurer of the Child Education Foundation of New York for the last ten years, died last night in the Mount Vernon Hospital of a heart ailment at the age of 65.
The California Assembly, in he an unprecedented move, ordered today that Thomas J. Mooney be quit brought before it in connection with a resolution seeking a pardon for the convicted parade bomber.
Edward F. Barrett, president of the Long Island Lighting Company, indicated yesterday at the annual meeting of shareholders that the concern, as parent of the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company,

Elisabeth Cobb, daughter of Irvin S. Cobb, writer, and Cameron Rogers, member of a socially prominent Santa Barbara, Calif., family, filed notice here today of intention to wed. They said they would be married within a month.

Another in the series of Junior League dinner dances for this season will take place tomorrow night in the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. Mrs. Bayard Stout is chairman of the committee.

After negotiations lasting nine months, Maricus Co., jewelers, have leased through Harold C. Samuels Co., brokers, the store, mezzanine, basement and part of the second and ninth floors of the building at 681 Fifth Avenue.

James V. Peppe, in 277 Park Ave; Mildred O'Quinn, in 709 Park Ave: Margaret Grounder, in 163 E 46th St: Brown, Wheelock. Harris, Stevens, Inc, broker. Miss Terry Vance, in 127 E 64th St: M. Morgenthau-Seixas Co, Inc, broker. Jean Pruyn Van Alstyne, Mrs. Hubert E. Odem, in 150 W 58th St: Brett Wyckoff, Inc. broker.

After twice rejecting proposals to restore provisions for publicity of corporation salaries in the pending Tax Bill, the House finally voted today to require public report of all such salaries of $75,000 and more a year.

The Maritime Association protested yesterday to Representative Robert L. Doughton, chairman of the House Committee on Ways and Means, against the proposal to increase the Federal tax on fuel oil by 1 cent a gallon, which is contained in a bill now being considered by the committee.

A hearing was called today by the SEC for March 22 on applications by Engineers Public Service Company, Gulf States, Utilities Company, Baton Rouge Electric Company and Louisiana Steam Generation Corporation regarding transactions incident to a plan for the consolidation of the business and

The Reichsbank's report for 1937, which will be placed before a shareholders' meeting Friday, declares German foreign trade expanded to such an extent during the year that the raw materials situation has imProved.
Representative Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, introduced a resolution today for an investigation of government publicity operations.
The Kleinfeld-McCreery bills abolishing special "blue ribbon" juries were killed in the Assembly Judiciary Committee today. The measures had previously been passed in the Senate.

The Interstate Commerce Commission granted increases in railroad freight rates today estimated by experts of the Association of American Railroads at upward of $175,000,000, instead of the $469,000,000 for which the roads applied.

John Rylowicz, also known as John Reo, 39-year-old former gasoline station proprietor of Lyndhurst, N. J., arrived at Sing Sing Prison this afternoon after having been sentenced earlier in the day to die in the electric chair the week of April 18 by Judge Cortland A. Johnson of Nassau County in Mineola, L. I., this morning.

The seventeen-week strike of eight editorial department employes at The Bayonne Times came to an end early today when an agreement was reached providing for a five-day, forty-hour week and wage increases.
Baron Gottfried von Cramm, Germany's greatest tennis player, today was reported confined in a jail infirmary as the result of a nervous collapse following his arrest on a morals charge.

Sulphur dioxide fumes which were accidentally released from a broken valve in a tank in the nine-story factory building at 150 Bay Street here today routed all of the 300 employes of manufacturing plants in the building, according to police.

Offering will be made today through an underwriting group headed by Bonbright Co., Inc., and including Paine, Webber Co. and Mitchum, Tully Co., of 17,291 shares of $6 cumulative preferred stock, no par value, of the Indiana Associated Telephone Corporation. The stock will be priced at $98 a share.
Bicknell Young, a member of the board of lectureship of the Mother Church, the First Church of Christ, Scientist, in Boston, died on Saturday in Carmel, friends here learned today.
The Vatican City news service announced today that Pope Pius had made J. P. Morgan and Thomas W. Lamont of the Morgan banking house Knights of St. Gregory the Great.
Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld entertained with a large dinner at their villa for their house guests, Mrs. Lewis Bell Whelen and Mrs. L. Wister Randolph of Philadelphia.
The American Federation of Labor estimated today that total unemployment in January was 10,973,000, compared with 9,241,000 in January, 1937.

Students enrolled in Columbia University for the academic year 1937-38 number 32,354, an increase of 675 over the previous year, Edward J. Grant, university registrar, announced yesterday. The largest gain was reported in University Extension, with a registration of 5,686.

District or preliminary auditions for soloists in the contest of the Music Education League will open tomorrow evening at Steinway Hall and will continue there throughout the month, it is announced by the league. These auditions will not be for elimination but for written criticisms, which will be received by each contestant from the jury.

Charging the State was "niggardly" and was offering Westchester County a "mess of pottage," members of the Westchester County Park Commission urged the County Board of Supervisors tonight to refuse to turn over to the State title to the Bronx River Parkway.

Italy will defy the international steel scrap merchants by using iron ore to an increasing extent to supply the raw material needs of her steel industry, according to a consular report from Milan made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Headed by Hal Price Headley's Menow. first in the Belmont Futurity and the acknowledged juvenile champion last year, and Maxwell Howard's Stagehand, winner of the Santa Anita Handicap as well as the Santa Anita Derby, 103 roots,

President Roosevelt received a delegation of building trades representatives and endorsed their "Build America" campaign to induce private capital into construction and provide steadier employment for 6,000,000 workers.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation asked the help today of 800 dentists, attending a five - State post-graduate clinic, in solving a three-year-old triple slaying.
Surplus available for the common stock of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation paper manufacturer and subsidiaries for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1937,

A committee, headed by Gordon Merritt, who is president, was chosen to study the possibility of a processing tax on cotton goods and its effects upon the industry, at a meeting of the Corset and Brassiere Association at the Hotel Vanderbilt yesterday.

THE war spirit is spreading. If one baseball club official had been hit on the head in a Southern training camp, it might have been an accident. But when two staff men are bowled over, it begins to look like sabotage. Warren Giles, the general manager of the Cincinnati Reds, was basking quietly in the Tampa sunshine when a batted ball came along to bounce off his sconce.
By B. HOLLANDER SON 86th St, 316-20 E; 3 5-story tenements and stores, 60x102.2; Dry Dock Sarings Institution against 320 E 86th St Corp; due $109,903; to plaintiff for $1,000.

THE KENTUCKY DERBY (sixty-fourth running)-One mile and a quarter, for 3year-olds, by subscription of $25 each, with additional starting fee of $500 apiece: $50.000 added, of which $6,000 to second, $3,000 to third and $1,000 to fourth. Owner of winner also will receive gold trophy. Starters will be named through entry box day before race at usual closing time. Colts and geldings will carry 126 pounds and fillies 121.

Duchess, 37-foot cutter owned by Harry Burgess of Tampa and skippered by Carl D. Borein, arrived here at 9:57:32 this morning, the last to finish of twelve yachts competing in the ninth annual St. Petersburg to Havana race of 284 miles.

An unofficial summary of pre-election voting in the International Typographical Union, announced today from the organization's headquarters, showed that C. M. Baker of San Francisco had the endorsement of 478 local unions, and Charles P. Howard of Chicago, that of 204 in the contest for president.

Little interest is evidenced here in the cotton trade over the vote to be taken by the Department of Agriculture on Saturday on invoking the control provisions of the recently enacted Agricultural Adjustment Act.
Trading in railroad loans again featured the turnover yesterday in the bond market on the New York stock Exchange with obligations of the carriers selling off, in some cases as much as 4 points,

Dr. Clyde Brooks of Louisiana State University demonstrated before the New Orleans Graduate Medical Assembly today a new technique for diagnosis of human blood which he said was simpler and more accurate than the old process.

The annual meeting of Independent Pneumatic Tool Company scheduled to be held at Pittsburgh yesterday was adjourned to April 7 for lack of quorum. The directors adjourned until March 15 consideration of the dividend ordinarily payable April 1.

Officers and men of the -107th Infantry (old Seventh Regiment) paraded once again for Brig. Gen. Wade Hampton Hayes, N. Y. N. G., retired, their regimental commander from 1919 to 1929, in a review last night at the 107th Infantry Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.
An inspired Harvard varsity basketball team defeated the leagueleading Dartmouth five tonight, 46 to 39.
A girl trapper and a 15-yearold high school boy will be among the ten competitors in Fairbanks' annual three-day dog sled racing derby, beginning Friday.

Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, announced today that he would earmark funds for housing projects up to the full amount of the $500,000,000 provided in the act in order to enable cities to complete long-range

Net profit of the National Steel Corporation and subsidiaries for 1937 amounted to $17,801,893, equal to $8.21 a share on the capital stock, after providing $1,715,000, or 79 cents a share, as surtax on undistributed profits.
Penn State's basketball team routed Rutgers,- 53-18, in the Rutgers gym tonight before-1,700 fans in a game closing the season for both teams.

Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe have gone to their Winter home, Cherokee Plantation, Yemassee, S. C., where they will remain until the middle of April. Mrs. George C. Moore and the Misses Eleanor and Emma Moore of Waverly, R. I., are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A fashion show of cotton clothes for all occasions will be presented Tuesday afternoon under the auspices of the Vassar Club in its clubrooms at the New Weston. Miss Gertrude Ladd Pratt heads the committee in charge, assisted by Mrs. Mildred Nell, Mrs. Earle Kress Williams and Miss Betty Willguss.
Donald Lawler, who yesterday was hailed as establishing a record for birth at nineteen pounds, was found today after several reweighings to tip the scales at only 12 pounds 6 ounces.

Adoption of rules prohibiting former members of its staff from representing clients before it in matters which were pending during their employment, without first having received the commission's consent, were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, effective on March 21.

As a feature of National Used Car Exchange Week, an active effort on the part of dealers and manufacturers to break the log jam of used automobile stocks, eighteen used vehicles of various vintages going back to 1914 paraded down Broadway yesterday morning from 215th Street to Columbus Circle.

At a tumultuous meeting, marke by acrimonious criticisms and the breaking of political ties, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors voted 19 to 19 this afternoon on a resolution to give the thirteenmile Bronx River Parkway to New York State.

Richard Whitney declared himself "solely responsible" yesterday after the cashier of the insolvent and suspended brokerage firm of Richard Whitney Co. had testified that "the senior partner" had taken his customers' securities without their knowledge.
A giraffe at the Brookfield Zoo developed a sore throat today. The victim, named Isiolo, was put in an isolated stall.

The Colbert County Sportsmen's Association of Alabama has supplied the rest of this country with an illustration of what may be accomplished in the way of farmersportsmen cooperation. In addition to this they supply an example of sane conservation.
The two-family dwelling at 8,013 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold for cash by R. H. Marwin Co., Inc., to Rose Latof. The house stands on a plot 24 by 90 feet.

Professor Laurence M. Larson, a faculty member of the University of Illinois for thirty years until his retirement last September as head of the History Department, a post he assumed in 1923, died at his home here today of acute bronchitis. He was 69 years old.

Listing of 696,000 shares of Victor Chemical Works stock and 403,250 shares of Ex-Cell-O Corporation common stock was approved yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The shares will not necessarily be admitted to dealings immediately.

Bobby Jones, one of the nation's leading jockeys until he was injured in a fall at Tanforan track a year ago, was found dead in bed today at the home of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred L. Jones, at San Ysidora. His father, a former horseman, raises thoroughbreds.

Premier Eamon de Valera of Ireland conferred today with Sir Samuel Hoare, who, as Home Secretary, is directly responsible for government of the six northern counties which Mr. de Valera is determined must eventually be joined to Ireland.
