Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States from 1935 to 1937, was elected a director of the New York Life Insurance Company yesterday, according to an announcement by Thomas A. Buckner, chairman, following the regular monthly meeting of the board.

Reporting favorable results for the new proxy rules adopted last December, the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday a clarification of them which will have the effect of making the new proxy-gathering machinery available to a greater range of companies.
Taking unprecedented action, the Screen Directors Guild has protested to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for excluding the government-produced documentary film, "The River,"
Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., March 9: LIEUTENANT-Charles F. Armstrong, 18th Division, 7th Detective District, designated as Acting Captain.
Two recitals by Thomas Wilfred on the clavilux will be given, this evening and tomorrow evening at 8:30 o'clock, at the Art Institute of Light, 480 Lexington Avenue.

On the record of one ball game, played here today by a flock of pitchers, three catchers, two outfielders, one infielder and one minor league manager, Van Lingle Mungo is the Dodgers' best first baseman and longest home-run hitter.

Among this Saturday night's closings include "Many Mansions," which will wind up at the Fortyfourth Street after 157 Broadway performances. An extended road tour is definitely scheduled for next Fall, according to Chandos Sweet, general manager.
Miss Louise McCarthy of Pennsylvania was appointed today by Secretary Ickes as regional counsel for PWA Region No. 1, with headquarters in New York.
Severance of Waitt Bond, Inc., from the combination of tobacco companies that included also the Porto Rican American Tobacco Company and the Congress Cigar Company, Inc., was announced today.

The 10 per cent freight-rate increase granted the railroads will cost the department stores of the country about $6,500,000 annually, according to estimates made yesterday by Leonard Mongeon, director of the traffic group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue ruled today that the temporary emergency tax imposed by the State of New York on unincorporated businesses must be deducted from Federal income taxes for the year during which the income is earned.

The Wells Fargo Bank and Union Trust Company of San Francisco purchased yesterday on an interest basis of 0.75 per cent plus a premium of $1,083.43 an issue of $1,015,818 of registered warrants of the State of California.

Amendment Paragraph III, Special Order 38, dated Feb. 24, 1938, in so far as it relates to the days on which summonses are returnable in the First District Court, Queens, during the month of March, 1938, is amended to read:

The local branch of the United States Steel Products Company, the export division of the United States Steel Corporation, has suspended all operations because of inability to do business under the 3 per cent surtax on imports established last July.

Sir George and Lady Prescott gave a dinner tonight at the Patio, having as guests Mr. and Mrs. Philip Hill, whom they are visiting, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Sanford, Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien, Captain and Mrs. Percy Lawson-Johnston, Mrs. W. Palmer Dixon, Mrs. Jean Cochran Atwell, Countess Edith di Zoppola, Robert Sweeny Jr., Captain, the Hon. Charles Winn, Charles Munn and Captain Alastair Mackintosh.
Three Ministers to Latin-American countries were shifted to new posts by President Roosevelt in nominations sent to the Senate today.
The New York Rovers of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 3 to 2, tonight. The Rovers were making their last appearance of the season here.

Lady Florise, 43-1 shot, owned by Samuel Briskin, won today's $10,000 added Santa Catalina CaliforniaBred Championship Stakes at Santa Anita Park and paid $88.80, $26.60 and $11.60 for $2 across the board.

A forest of upraised arms greeted Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, when he arrived at Victoria Station today for a series of talks that will show whether Anglo-German negotiations are possible in the immediate future.

By a very large majority the people of Seattle rejected on Tuesday a candidate for Mayor backed by the C. I. O. and elected instead a more conservative candidate who had pledged himself "to re-establish the city's reputation as a law-abiding community, to restore its financial credit, to suppress intimidation, violence and labor racket eering and to use the power of the Mayor's office to restore industrial peace and prosperity."
Several hundred "back-to-work" advocates stormed the strike-bound Roberts Mander foundry here tonight with tear gas, bricks and iron bars. They drove out 150 strikers who were holding the plant.

The Johns-Manville Corporation has set a good precedent in issuing a speciai annual report to its 11,200 jobholders. The report points out that the amount received by the company for products, less the cost of materials and transportation during the year, came to a little less than $40,000,000.
A high school football player cannot collect damages for injuries suffered on the playing field, District Judge Hugh Means held today.

The Lawrenceville School's powerful polo forces continued their winning ways today and overwhelmed the Princeton varsity, 22-10, in the R. O. T. C. Riding Hall. It was the Tiger trio's second loss of the season to the victors and marked the ninth time this Winter that the schoolboys have taken the measure of a Nassau polo team.

The consolidated annual report of the Manufacturers Mutual Fire Insurance Company and associated companies for 1937 shows a gain of $175,000,000 in insurance in force, the largest increase in seventeen years except for 1928.

The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette formally dedicated its new $1,500,000 plant at Grant Street and the Boulevard of the Allies today, and without interruption of its mechanical or business functions, continued publication as it has been doing for 152 years.

Espionage in Russia on behalf of foreign powers, which several of the twentyone defendants of the Moscow treason trial have confessed, was gone into in considerable detail at a long secret session this afternoon. A brief communique issued this evening said:

Premier Camille Chautemps and his Cabinet will, as proposed yesterday, go before the Senate and Chamber of Deputies tomorrow to demand full powers to restore the financial and economic situation in France and assure the success of the forthcoming armaments loan.
The quota of $325,000 in the 1937 annual roll call of New York Chapter, American Red Cross, was exceeded by $484, Leon Fraser, general chairman of the campaign, announced yesterday.

F. Neff Stroup, former Superintendent of Newark Schools, whose illness three years ago forced him to retire, died today at his home here. He was 53 years old. Mr. Stroup came here as Superintendent of Schools in 1921 after serving as principal of Palmyra High School.

Analyzing what it termed the "most encouraging" year of its four years of operation, the State Liquor Authority reported to Governor Lehman yesterday that its receipts had totaled $19,173,005.28 in 1937.

Beginning its clean-up drive as adjournment nears, the Legislature today mauled, battered, and otherwise maltreated bills submitted to it by Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, and the American Labor party.

The wife and five of the nine children of Joseph P. Kennedy, United States Ambassador to England, sailed yesterday on the liner Washington to join him in London. Mrs. Kennedy and her children occupied six staterooms, while a nurse and governess traveled in a seventh.
Michael MacWhite. who has been the Irish Free State Minister In I Washington for the last nine years, sailed on the Queen Mary yesterday to become Ireland's first envoy to Italy.

Anthony Eden's vacant seat at the Cabinet table was filled today by the appointment of Lord Maugham, 71year-old jurist, a brother of Somerset Maugham, novelist and playwright, to the [Pound]10,000 a year post of Lord High Chancellor.

Nation-wide department store sales declined 8 per cent in February and were 6 per cent lower for the first two months of -this year in comparison with the same period of 1937, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board.
Senator Vandenberg introduced an amendment to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation Act today to increase from $300,000,000 to $1,000,000,000 the funds available for industrial loans.

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., revealed yesterday that the utility was planning to issue $60,000,000 of new debentures bearing interest at not more than 3 1/2 per cent to refund an outstanding issue of 4 1/2 per cent gold bonds of the same amount, due on June 1, 1951.

A bronze bust of the baritone Antonio Scotti, by Gennaro Cifariello, has been added to the collection of art representations of great operatic figures of the past which has been assembled at the Metropolitan Opera House by the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

Resolutions denouncing the Moscow trial as a frame-up were adopted at a meeting at the Hotel Center, 108 West Forty-third Street, last night. More than 1,500 persons assembled under the auspices of the American Committee for the Defense of Leon Trotsky unanimously adopted the resolutions.

Thomas P. Graham of 260 Derrom Avenue, Paterson, N. J., a 'real estate dealer with offices at 92 Liberty Street, this city, died here yesterday in the Knickerbocker Hospital from the effects of a stroke which overcame him as he was motoring from his office to his home in Paterson on Monday afternoon.

Retail food distributors all over the country are in the grip of the worst price war which has afflicted the industry in years, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., asserted here yesterday.

The customary schedule of fortytwo championship games for the seven teams in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League was announced through The Associated Press yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, executive officer of the central office for Eastern intercollegiate athletics.

Chicago's share in the results from the $1,250,000 spent by the automotive industry in advertising the current National Used Car Exchange Week, in the daily newspapers and at the point of sale, was well spent, according to advance figures released by the Chicago Automobile Trade Association.

The United States Weather Bureau's weekly report of crop conditions, issued yesterday, follows: The condition of Winter wheat is fair to good in most Northeastern States, with continued improvement noted in the lower Ohio Valley and in Tennessee, where condition is excellent.
Prices of wheat declined more than 2 cents a bushel at the extreme today on general liquidation induced by rains over the greater part of the Winter wheat belt east of the Rocky Mountains.
Several contracts for space in multi-family dwellings on Park Avenue were reported yesterday by brokers.

The newly appointed Foreign Minister, Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, will be inducted into office next Tuesday. Brazilians became acquainted with Dr. Aranha's appointment only today when newspapers printed the announcement on their front pages.

Pitting its zone defense against the man-toman strategy of Brown's quintet tonight, Yale triumphed by 56-46 after a 26-all tie at the intermission. This was the highest score of the season for the Elis.

Declaring that facilities for the care of cancer patients are "wholly inadequate" in some sections of the State, the State Legislature Cancer Survey Commission in a report to Governor Lehman and the Legislature today urged a broad reorganization and expansion of the cancer control division of the State Department of Health.

Senator Wheeler of Montana asserted today that in 1932 the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had lent $4,500,000 to the insolvent Wabash Railway Company to help it "salvage a margin account that had gone sour."

About 500 forgotten "little men" of the Democratic organization in New York City, who feel that the plight of their party affects them more than it does the "big" leaders, launched with indignant oratory at the Hotel Astor last night a movement to "restore the party to its rightful custodians, the 2,289,213 enrolled Democrats of the city."

The need for more research among producers of nationally advertised clothing was stressed here yesterday by the research director of a large department store, who declared that its lack was hampering successful merchandising by these companies.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 7: CAPTAIN Kays, H. E., Destroyer Squadron 14, to duty as commander Destroyer Squadron 4, about May 14.

Twelve relay races will comprise that phase of the program at the nineteenth annual Knights of Columbus track and field carnival at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, Director Frank A. Brennan announced yesterday.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 8: COLONEL Love, A. G., Med. Corps, Philadelphia, Pa., to office of Surgeon General, Washington, D. C., March 31.

A police drive against labor terrorism, already marked by ninetyseven arrests, brought from the county grand jury today indictments naming eleven union members, while another former union official reversed his plea of innocence to an assault charge.
The great offensive for which the Insurgents have been preparing since the battle of Teruel was launched today at three points along a seventy-mile Aragon front from Alfambra to Fuentes de Ebro.

ATTENTION: MISS WELLS, by Sylvia Paul Jerman. (Harcourt, Brace, A romantic novel. BRITISH WAR MISSIONS TO THE UNITED STATES: 1914-1918, by Colonel W. G. Lyddon. (Oxford University Press, $4.) A account of their genesis and growth.
The House vote today against a surtax on closely held corporations spilled the "eggs" in one of Representative Vinson's three baskets.

Robert Dunn Douglass, aged 93, a director of the firm of Dun Bradstreet, died here tonight. He is survived by his wife, Alice B. Douglass a son, Robert Graham D. Douglas of Douglaston, L. I., and a granddaughter, Mrs. Gardner Prime of Stamford, Conn.

J. N. Trainer Jr. of the Harvard Club sprang a surprise yesterday when he defeated A. M. Moody, Yale Club player who was seeded No. 2, in the quarter-final round of the-Class C metropolitan squash racquets championship at the Downtown A. C.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:
The value of the property of the Humble Pipe Line Company used for carrier purposes on Dec. 31, 1934, was determined tentatively today by the Interstate Commerce Commission as $59,500,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: William Leslie, general manager of the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters, was good enough to communicate with THE TIMES regarding an address which I made before the Insurance Society of New York.
Park Ave (9-2332), n e cor of 135th St, 455x200; George H. Storm to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, extends mtgs to March 3, 1941, at 5 per cent; $65,000.

Trading was fairly active to slow. The markets, though somewhat uneven, were mostly steady to higher. Early trading in kosher meats indicated prices to be about in line with Tuesday's close, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
The eighteen-acre Fort Salonga, L. I., farm of the late Jessie Smith Noyes has been sold at auction to Mrs. Dorothy S. Bedell and Edith S. Noyes, daughters of Mrs. Noyes, for $50,000.
George Hoyt Allen, world traveler, writer, lecturer and inventor, died in his home here yesterday at the age of 80.
Announcement was made here last night of the death on Tuesday in his home in Winter Park, Fla., of Francis Meredith Whitehouse of 340 Park Avenue; last surviving son of the late Bishop Whitehouse.
Aeronautic exports in January were val- B ued at $3,190,281, compared with $2,212,400 in January, 1937, the B aeronautics trade section of the Bureau-of Foreign and Domestic Commerce announced today.

Harvard physicists announced today the perfection of a new "telescope" to study the mysterious break-up of recently discovered fundamental particles of matter which rush at the earth with terrific energies, and then disintegrate for reasons not yet known.
The United States is wasting its soil resources faster than any nation in the world, H. H. Bennett, Chief of the Soil Conservation Service, told the Senate Committee on Unemployment today.

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High of Brooklyn and La Salle Military Academy of Oakdale, L. I., gained the final round of the Manhattan College invitation interscholastic basketball tournament by scoring semi-final victories last night at the Manhattan gymnasium.

Charges of Senator Bridges of New Hampshire that the Tennessee Valley Authority is a "rotten outfit" and should be subjected to a broad congressional inquiry started a bitter debate in the Senate today. The situation was also discussed in the House.

181st St, (11-3062) s e cor of La Fontaine Ave, 95x44; Amelia Bender to John Reisz, 1,761 Bronxdale Ave. Wilkins Ave (11-2976), w s, 271 ft s of Intervale Ave, 80x101; Harold Realty Co, Inc, to 1,317 Wilkins Corp, 912 Tiffany St; mtg $54,587.
Brooklyn Prep closed its basketball season, with. a 29-to-23. victory over Poly Prep in the, Brooklyn Prep gymnasium yesterday. At half time the winners led, 18 to 10.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today gave a flat denial in the House of Commons that any connection existed between the British intelligence service and the names mentioned in the current Soviet trial.

Two high school journalists out of the West, in New York for the fourteenth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association, called yesterday at City Hall with official greetings to Mayor La Guardia from the Mayors of San Diego, Calif., and Tucson, Ariz., where the youths edit school newspapers.
John J. Lauben, president of the Russell Rutter Company, bookbinders in NewYork, died today of a heart attack at his home in the Cragswold. Apartments here. His age was 68.

Shipping rates on the New York State barge canal system, which includes the Hudson River, would be subject to the approval of the Maritime Commission under a bill introduced today by Senator Copeland, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee.

Clinton J. Ruch of the law firm of Frueauff, Burns, O'Brien Ruch has purchased from the Empire City Savings Bank the twelveroom residence, with an acre, at 101 Prospect Street, White Plains. Westchester. The property.
Colonel and Mrs. Robert H. Montgomery of Greenwich, Conn., are among those who will entertain large groups at the Sorcerers Ball at the Surf Club Saturday.

Asserting that he was acting on the requests of "hundreds of New York City florists," Senator Williamson, Westchester County Republican, today introduced a bill in the upper house which would compel all florist shops to close on Sunday, in order to allow the store owners and their employes to have one day of rest a week.

Electric power production increased last week. Daily average output declined, but less than seasonally, and after adjustment had been made for a rising normal growth trend the index moved upward to 94.1 from 93.2.

The Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today that municipally owned railroads subject to regulation by the Interstate Commerce Commission must pay taxes to the Federal Railroad Retirement Fund the same as other railroads.

John Saville, 65 years old, one of ten persons injured in a fire in the four-story apartment house at 5 Thorne Street here last night, died at the Medical Center this morning of the effects of smoke and shock.
The "third basket" surtax on closely held or family corporations, which was sponsored by Administration forces in Congress, was defeated in the House today.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at her home in Chicago of Mrs. Nettie C. Kenner, who was Grand Matron of the Grand Chapter of Illinois, Order of the Eastern Star, in 1893, and had been Grand Secretary since 1906.

A nationwide tieup of road transport is threatened a fortnight hence unless the employers' associations grant 200,000 truck drivers an increase of six shillings a week, accept the principle of collective bargaining and recast the basis of the 48-hour week.

The Princesses Myzejen and Ruhie, sister of King Zog of Albania, met officials of the AlbanianAmerican Institute yesterday afternoon at a tea given in their honor at the headquarters of the Near East Foundation, 2 West Fortysixth Street.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wright Frear of 65 Second Street, this city, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne. Frances Frear, to Lieutenant William Campbell Gibson Church, U. S. N., son of Captain Albert Thomas Church, U. S. N., and Mrs. Church.
Gross assets, $6,961; net, $4,293. To sister, Anna L. Carmody. Chief assets, real estate, $6,400; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $561. Gross Keck, attorneys, 16 Court St.

The appointment of Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, to a post as confidential examiner in his office was a "'mistake," Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan confessed last night at a meeting of the New York Young Republican Club held at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

William C. Rungee, former judge of probate and active in fraternal orders, died of a heart attack in his home here this morning at the age of 64. He is survived by hiswidow; twin daughters, Mrs. Raymond M. Owen Jr. and Mrs. William Barton Chapin Jr.; five brothers and two sisters.
Should Congress wholly reject the measure offered by Senator Byrnes to modernize the Executive branch of the government, many useful lessons of experience would be sacrificed.

Johnny Longden, only dangerous rival of Eddie Arcaro for riding honors in Florida this Winter, accomplished the unique feat of piloting both winners in the $148.40 for $2 daily double on the first two contests and completed a triple in the last event of the eight-race card at Tropical Park today.

Tributes to Albert Ottinger, former State Senator and Attorney General from 1925 to 1929, were paid today by Governor Lehman and Attorney General Bennett at ceremonies held in Mr. Bennett's office where a bronze plaque honoring the memory of Mr. Ottinger and presented to the State by his friends was unveiled.
The Oxford and Cambridge crews appeared on the Thames Tideway together for the first time today as the final stages of training approach for the annual race April 2.

Nine persons, imperiled by a cracked wall that caused an inspector to declare the building in danger of collapse, were ordered from their homes in an old-law tenement at 82 St. Mark's Place last night, while the police roped off the sidewalk to keep passers-by from possible injury.

As representative of the New York Cotton Exchange, Charles F. Noyes Company, broker, has arranged an extension of a first mortgage loan of $1,050,000 at 4 1/2 per cent for five years on the twentyfour-story New York Cotton Exchange Building at 60 Beaver Street, corner of William Street.
Mrs. Mrs. Anne Van Syckel Tennant, wife of George G. Tennant, a lawyer, died today at her residence, 613 Bergen Avenue, at the age of 67.

Horton Smith of Chicago,. who dropped out of the Winter golfing caravan for a physical check-up, rejoined it today in a big way-with a five-under-par 66 for the first-round lead in the $3,000 Hollywood open.

Dr. Charles M. McDowell, Professor Emeritus of Physiology at the New York Medical College and Flower Hospital, and Dr. Orlando S. Ritch, a trustee of that institution, were honored yesterday by their former colleagues at a luncheon held in the college dining room at Sixty-fourth Street and York Avenue.
The arbitration board seeking a final settlement of the stevedores' strike, which lasted six weeks, today instructed the steamship representatives to produce their books and other documents.

Miss Eileen Herrick was the guest of honor at a tea yesterday given by Gavin Welby at his home, 310 East Forty-fourth Street. Miss Herrick is leaving soon for Palm Beach, where she will visit Miss Joy Plummer and Miss Jane Kaufman.
Dr. Gilbert Slater, who devoted his gifts as author and economist to the study of rural economics in England and India, died in Oxford today at the age of 73.
The Americans will attempt to square themselves with the Bruins tonight when the teams meet in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

Tonight's major events: Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; "Die Walkuere," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P. M. The second "junior" performance of "The Barber of Seville" will be given this afternoon at the Metropolitan under the sponsorship of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

The New York Curb Exchange has listed 30,444 shares of Valspar Corporation $4 cumulative convertible preferred stock, $5 par value, and 152,220 shares of common stock, $1 par value, in substitution for the present $6 cumulative convertible preferred stock, $5 par value.
Tommy Goodwin of Mamaroneck, N. Y., and Edward G. Lauder Jr. of New York were upset in the second round of the annual two-ball foursome tournament at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.

State Representative William J. Munley of Archbald, dean of the Lackawanna County members in the Legislature, died today in the State hospital here at the age of 53. A Democrat, he-was one of the most prominent political figures in Northeastern Pennsylvania.

" We are surrounded now by friends. We have maintained all our alliances and gained new friends. We have assumed no new obligations that would conflict with old ones," declared Premier Milan Stoyadinovich today in explaining Yugoslavia's foreign policy in Parliament.

A delegation of officials and members of the New York Credit Men's Association, headed by John L. Redmond of the Crompton-Richmond Company, president, went to Albany yesterday to protest against passage by the Senate of a bill already passed by the House amending the Creditor Law.
Building projects submitted yesterday by architects included plans for an apartment house on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx to cost $400,000 and several small dwellings for sites in Brooklyn.

" We were too scared to pray, too wet to cry and too darned cold to swear," said Mrs. John Troy, wife of the Governor of Alaska, as she reached safety today after a week of terror in the flooded north fork of the San Gabriel Canyon.
Newark's tax ratables will be about $105,000,000 less for 1938 than last year, when the total was $961,938,274, according to a preliminary report of the City Tax Board today.
Senate leaders have abandoned all efforts at compromise on the Administration's Governmental Reorganization Bill, it became apparent today, and will press for a show-down as soon as possible.
Miss Marion Miley, Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, Miss Patty Berg and Miss Bernice Wall advanced to the semifinal round today in the Belleair women's golf championship.
In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Michael S. McPhillips, F. Mizell Wilson and Carol Clement Johnson of New York were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

In a wild and woolly finish that had a crowd of 13,829 rocking the rafters of Madison Square Garden with the bedlam of its acclaim, N. Y. U. came surging up in the last minute and forty seconds to upset highly favored L. I. U. in the opening round of the national invitation college basketball tournament last night.
Governor Lehman participated in the unveiling of a memorial to the late Albert Ottinger in the Capitol, and worked at his desk throughout the day in conference with the legislative leaders.

Ten Broeck M. Terhune, 50 years old, the socially prominent realty broker who was alleged to have defrauded five jewelers of about $17,000 in gems recently, was committed to the Bellevue Hospital psychiatric division for ten days' observation yesterday by General Sessions Judge Bohan.

Former President Herbert Hoover issued a statemen to the press today in which he said that Germany and other nations he has visited in Europe had, "despite their difficulties, done more in public health and housing for the lower-income groups than we have in America."

R. N. Elliott, acting Controller General, declared inoperative today a provision of the new Farm Act directing immediate payment of about $10 a bale to growers who surrendered to the government title to loan cotton.

EMPRESS OF DESTINY, a play in three acts and six scenes, by Jesicca Lee and Joseph Lee Walsh. Staged by Ilia Mottyleff; settings and costumes by Robert Van Rosen; produced by Frederick W. Ayer and Mr. Mottyleff. At the St. James Theater.
Funeral services for Mrs. Amy Kirk Kingsbury, who died on Sunday, were held here this afternoon. Mrs. Kingsbury was born in Brooklyn eighty-seven years ago.

An eighteen-game schedule has been arranged for Manhattan's baseball team, it was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics. Eight of the contests will be played at Manhattan Field.
Out of every dollar spent for amusement by American families in 140 villages studied by the Bureau of Home Economics of the Department of Agriculture, 29 cents went for movies.

The St, Champion Paper and Fibre Company, Hamilton, Ohio, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering $5,500,000 of sinking-fund debentures due on Sept. 1, 1950, and 7,819 shares of $100-par 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock, the interest on the debentures to be specified later.

Herbert R. Houghton of the Houghton Company and vice president of the Westchester County Realty Board will deliver the third in the board's Spring series of lectures on Monday. He will discuss listings.
Citrus fruits are subject to a 5 per cent increase under the Interstate Commerce Commission's freight rate decision, officials of the commission said informally today.

Niagara Falls Power Company and Subsidiaries-For 1937: Net income after all expenses and charges, $4,167,696, equal to $5.61 a share on the outstanding capital stock, compared with $3,478,068, or $4.68 a capital share, in 1936.

President Felix Paiva tonight appointed General Jose Felix Estigarribia as Minister to the United States. The new Minister probably will sail for Buenos Aires, Argentina, on Sunday to leave for Washington.
Rules of the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange were amended yesterday to permit certain convertible bonds to be dealt in on a "regular-way delayeddelivery basis."

The protective committee for S. W. Straus Co. mortgage bonds headed by Lewis N. Pounds was cleared yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Harris of charges of abusing its powers in connection with its sale of bonds secured by the Hotel Delmonico mortgage to the Nielmo Realty Corporation.
Louis Fischer, 47 years old, of 7,522 Nineteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, president of the Continental Shoe Manufacturing Company, Inc., pleaded ot guilty yesterday before Judge Robert A.

Completion of liquidation of two banks in New Jersey was announced today by J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency. The First National Bank of Sea Isle City, which was placed in receivership on Nov. 11, 1931, paid depositors and other creditors, including offsets, $184,043, representing 55.16 per cent of total liabilities established.

While committees of both branches of the Legislature were working at full speed today, the Senate and Assembly passed a series of measures of local and general concern and advanced others to final reading.

Members of Auxiliary 4 of Stony Wold Sanatorium have taken over the performance of "The Fireman's Flame" the night of March 29 at the American Music Hall to raise funds for furthering the work of Stony Wold Sanatorium.

The stock market here, influenced by early signs of strength in Wall Street, was more cheerful in general today and most sections advanced. Gilt-edge issues were strong while among the foreign bonds German loans were a good spot.

Funeral services for Hugo Bulowa of 470 West End Avenue, president of the Arrow Manufacturing Company, Inc., of Hoboken, N. J., were held yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Temple Emanu-El, Sixtyfifth Street and Fifth Avenue. Mr.

The Provident Institution for Savings of Jersey City sold to the Lawrence Paint Corporation, Morris Jaffe president, the dwelling and one-story brick warehouse on a plot 56 by 100 feet at 256-58 Cambridge Avenue, Jersey City.

Additional claims for part of Supreme Court Justice Algeron I. Nova's salary of $25,000 were made yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court before Justice James T. Hallinan. Justice Nova, who recently filed an affidavit in the Brooklyn Federal Court stating that he owed $381,000, attributed his financial difficulties to the drop in the real estate market.

In a return engagement that renewed a neighborhood rivalry, Salvy Saban of Greenwich Village outfought Frankie Cavanna of the East Side and gained the decision in their ten-round bout at the Hippodrome last night. Saban weighed 1471/2 and Cavanna 1463/4.

A cash payment of $1,001, the largest yet made by the Social Security Board, has just been collected by an executive of seven public utility holding companies, with offices in this city, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Federal agency, disclosed yesterday.

The Cunard White Star liner Queer. Mary sailed for Cherbourg and Southampton yesterday with 1,115 passengers, including nearly 400 who had been transferred from the Berengaria because of a fire in her lounge last week.

Dr. Sanford M. Withers, director and radiation therapist of the Denver Cancer Clinic and the owner of patents on appliances widely used in radium and X-ray therapy, died of aplastic anemia and bronchial pneumonia on Tuesday in the hospital of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

Patrolman Edward Maney, who had changed into civilian clothing after a quiet night of duty, let his coffee get cold as he sat in a "diner" at Northern Boulevard and Farrington Street, Flushing, early yesterday and listened intently as the counterman told another customer about a "stickup I was in five years ago in Los Angeles."

White Plains High School Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association basketball champion, and Pelham Memorial High School advanced to the final round of the open-class competition in the Westchester County Recreation Commission's sixth annual invitation high school basketball tournament at the County Center tonight.

The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered today a hearing here on March 18 into the qualifications of Charles E. Danney, president of the Erie ??, and John A. Hadden of Cleveland, a lawyer, for appointment as trustees of the Erie.

Miss Elizabeth Wise Macy, daughter of Mrs. Josiah Macy of this place, will be married to James Suydam Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Jones of Far Hills, on the afternoon of March 18 in St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church here.

The decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission raising railroad freight rates, including an increase on steel products, may have the effect of stimulating some immediate buying of steel for prompt delivery,
The Phoenix, a new 10,000-ton treaty cruiser, will be launched at the New York Shipbuilding Company's plant here on Saturday at 10 A. M., it was announced today.

Kurt Walwer, 50-year-old vice president of the chemical apparatus company of Pfaltz Bauer, Inc., with offices in the Empire State Building, was found dead early yesterday morning at his desk on the thirtieth floor by a night watchman.

Turpentine firm, 26c; sales, 5 barrels; receipts, 38 barrels; shipments, 32 barrels; stock, 24,588 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 57; receipts, 187; shipments, 2,006; stock. 64,093. Quote: B, D, $3.65; E, $3.85; F, $4.40; G, $4.50; H, I, $4.65; K, $4.70; M, $4.75; N, $4.85; WG, $6.00; WW, X, $6.25.

Hope was abandoned today of finding Airplane Pilot Burton Hall alive. Officials of the Philippine Aerial Taxi Company said they were convinced that the former Tucson (Ariz.) resident plunged into the sea on Feb. 28 near Alabat Island.

The first Yankee scrub ball game of the year was played at Huggins Field today. Besides proving that the hitters were way ahead of the pitchers, the game aroused speculation on Manager Joe McCarthy's 1938 outfield, and Jake Powell was hurt.

Robert A. Cooke, traffic manager of the Publishers Association of New York, was elected chairman of the Shippers Conference of Greater New York at its monthly meeting yesterday in the assembly room of the Merchants Association.

The annual dinner of the Savings Bank Women of the Metropolitan Area will be held next Wednesday in the Colonnades of Essex House, 325 East Forty-first Street. Genevieve B. Earle, member of the new City Council, will speak on "A Woman's Share in Government."

For a long time slum clearance and rehousing have been like the weathermuch talk and little accomplished. Now it begins to seem that the dam has broken, and that not only the Federal Government but States and cities are ready to move.
Day before yesterday in Washington it was the reporters' turn to roar with laughter while the President looked

Miss Mary Kendel, who is to be married in Riverside Church on Saturday to Hugh Randolph Conklin, a junior executive of the General Foods Corporation, was guest of honor yesterday at a tea given by the Misses Louise Strasser and Roberta Rogers in their home at 57 West Fifty-eighth Street.

Mrs. Bettie Morris Shearn, daughter of Robert and Cordelia Buckner Morris, early settlers of Houston, Texas, died today in New Haven Hospital after a short illness. She has lived recently with her daughter, Mrs. T. A. D. Jones of this city. She was 71 years old.

Consolidated net profit of $12,190,649 is reported by the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and subsidiaries for 1937, equal after regular preferred dividends to $6.79 a share on 1,675,008 common shares, as compared to $10,564,501, or $7.03 a share, on 1,384,752 common shares earned in 1936.

The vote of the House in rejecting the "third-basket," that discriminatory tax on family-owned corporations, by a vote of 180 to 124, is extremely reassuring. It is not merely that it marks a setback for a proposed tax that would have been very harmful. The vote is have been very harmful.

Our Senator Copeland made an able and a comprehensive speech Monday on the salmon fisheries of Alaska and the Bering Sea. He poured out stores of information about the three-mile limit, the value of fish as food, the sugar industry and so on.

The first in a series of Lenten sewing classes under the auspices of the Little Mothers Aid Association was held yesterday morning at the headquarters of the organization, 236 Second Avenue. Subsequent classes in the series will be held on Wednesday mornings throughout the Lenten season. Mrs.
A father who was separated from his young son in Russia at the outbreak of the World War was reunited with him today by an advertisement that traveled half way around the world.

Counsel for the Celotex Corporation, at a hearing in a stockholders' suit to bar a proposed stock transaction by the company, offered an exhibit yesterday to show that 105,000 votes were recorded in favor of the deal, as against 19,000 opposing it, at a recent stockholders' meeting.
The announcement that there would be a plebiscite in Austria on Sunday took Germany so completely by surprise today that political quarters were left speechless.

The force of public disapproval will defeat the proposal of Congressman Patman to eliminate chain stores through taxation, Godfrey M. Lebhar, editor of Chain Store Age, told the Cincinnati Advertisers Club at the Hotel Gibson today.

The annual report of the Crucible Steel Company of America and subsidiaries for 1937, issued yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $4,017,931, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $5.21 a share on 450,000 common shares, compared .with $3,067,156, or $3.22 a share, earned in 1936.
For the first time in fourteen years, Princeton conquered Yale in swimming tonight, recording a breathtaking 38-to-37 victory.

Delancey St, n w cor Willett St, 88x44.8; Lydecker Van Riper to Emigrant Bank; consideration, $1,000; foreclosure. Bowery, 157 1/2-159, 36.11x74.10; Edward Levine to Joseph J. Cohen, 925 Prospect Place, Brooklyn; mtg, $27,000; Sidney Cohen, quitclaims.

Miss Hazel Adele Foreman of this city, daughter of Mrs. Jacob Harry Foreman of Nashville, Tenn., and the late Mr. Foreman, was married to Dr. Louis Segal of Brooklyn, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Segal, yesterday morning in the Elizabethan Salon of Essex House.
The world must retrace its steps and remove economic trade barriers to avoid. inevitable war, Secretary Woodring told members of the Commercial Club tonight.

Warning that economic pressure may force the closing of some of the branches of the New York Public Library and cause special reading rooms in the Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building to be closed in the evenings, is given in the annual report of the library, presented yesterday to the board of trustees.

Czechoslovakia, with which the United States has just negotiated a reciprocal trade agreement, imported machinery valued at $24,730,000 during 1937, a gain of 61.5 per cent over the preceding year, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from Prague, made public today.

The Food Machinery Corporation has declared a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, compared to quarterly dividends of 25 cents each for the first two quarters of 1937, an extra of $1.50 on Aug. 25, quarterly dividends of 62 1/2 cents each for the second two quarters of 1937 and an extra of 37 1/2 cents on Sept. 30.

A plea of guilty to operating a bucket shop at 141 Broadway for five months in 1932 was accepted in General Sessions yesterday from Alexander C. Lawrence, 37 years old, of 511 West 151st Street. Judge Collins, at the suggestion of the District Attorney's office, released him in $1,000 bail, pending sentence May 3.

Dr. Alfred Newton Richards, introduced by a fellow-scientist as a "discoverer of the secrets of life who has made possible more accurate diagnoses and successful treatment of some of the most serious diseases of mankind," tonight became the seventeenth recipient of the Philadelphia Award, the city's "Nobel Prize."

As an aftermath of a $15,000 damage award paid by the school system to a pupil for the loss of an eye, the Board of Education at its meeting yesterday directed that the high school principal and teacher concerned be publicly reprimanded. This is the first time in recent years that the board has taken a step of this kind.

A concurrent resolution amending the State Constitution to permit pari-mutuel betting at race tracks throughout the State was introduced in the Senate today by John J.: Dunnigan, Democratic majority leader of the upper house.

Mrs. Elizabeth R. Sharp, wife of William E. Sharp, an official of the Lehigh Valley Railroad and former president of the Union County Federation of Holy Name Societies, died this morning in Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield.
Miss Kathleen Hackett, described as "a tall, slim, tremendously attractive young London girl," has been chosen by the Duke of Windsor as his personal private secretary, according to The Daily Mirror.

Charles A. Hoeing, retired dean of the University of Rochester, died in a hospital here tonight. He was 67 years old. He is survived by his widow and a son, Frederick Hoeing of the faculty of the College of William and Mary.

Arthur T. Vanderbilt, president of the American Bar Association, declared last night that the greatest danger facing the nation today was the granting of subordinate legislative and judicial powers to independent administrative agencies headed by Commissioners chosen for "political reasons."

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

Finding the marriage license bureau of the City Clerk's office "grossly overmanned," the Municipal Civil Service Commission moved yesterday to abolish the forty-one unclassified legislative jobs in the bureau and to substitute fifteen competitive civil service jobs.

A new shortage of- skilled mechanics for WPA duty came to light yesterday when Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, ordered notices posted on all official bulletin boards that there were vacancies for skilled workers.

Mr. and Mrs. George F. Dominick Jr. of Old Church Road, Greenwich, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucy Wilcox Dominick, to John Rodney Wilson, son of Mrs. Oliver T. Wilson of Lake Forest, Ill., and the late Mr. Wilson.

Benjamin Franklin turned back Seward Park, 27 to 21, in the playoff for the Lower Manhattan P. S. A. L. basketball title, while Alexander Hamilton advanced to the semifinals of the city championship tournament by defeating Erasmus Hall, 36 to 22, in a matinee doubleheader at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Plans for the rezoning of another large district in Manhattan are being worked out by city officials with the cooperation of realty and civic organizations representing owners and residents of the area involved.
Sir Raymond Crawfurd, registrar of the Royal College of Physicians and author of several medical studies for the general reader, died of a heart attack today at the age of 72.

" Knights of the Round Table," which has been on and off Paramount's schedule for two years, today became a definite part of the studio's Autumn program when Henry Hathaway was named as director and Talbot Jennings was assigned to the screen play.

The New York Air Brake Company incurred a net loss of $68,000 in the first two months of 1938, contrasted with a net income of $295,000 in the same period of 1937, Lowell R. Burch, president, said at the annual meeting yesterday.

Vernon Anderson of St. Petersburg, Fla., died last night on board the Artemis, an entry in the ninth annual St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race, several hours before the vessel reached Havana. He was 22 years old.

National and local executives of the Girl Scouts witnessed the presentation yesterday by Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, chairman of the national board, of awards to the winners of an international dolldressing contest among the Scout troops in Manhattan.

Premier Koloman Daranyi's decision to raise $200,000,000 for rearmament and public works resulted today in reconstruction of the Cabinet. He presented the resignation of the whole Cabinet to the regent, Admiral Nicholas Horthy, who asked him to form a new one.

William H. Barnes, librarian of the Suffolk County Supreme Court, died in his home here today. He F was 76 years old. Mr. Barnes was born in East Windsor, Conn., a descendant of T one of the founders of Southampton Town in 1640 and of one of the founders of Amherst. Mass.
George Romano, one of the group convicted of the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr., of Albany, hanged himself in his cell in the State prison at Charleston today.

A 26-year-old woman, suffering from a lingering illness, who said she turned to burglary to feed and clothe her two children and unemployed husband, was placed on probation for three years today by Common Pleas Judge Daniel Brennan.

Mayor La Guardia directed Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner, yesterday to investigate the circumstances under which New York Hospital, a private institution, handled the cases of a city fireman and an 8-year-old boy he rescued from the East River last Monday.
Wide differences in the charges for identical quantities of electric energy were shown in the report issued today by the Federal Power Commission.

More than 100 delegates from twenty-six or more colleges will attend the annual Model Senate Association meetings at Colgate University Friday and Saturday and discuss bills on anti-lynching, neutrality and capital gains and excess profits taxes.

Phil Moore of the Montclair A. C., seeded No. 2 in the tournament, was among the winners yesterday in the second round of the national amateur squash tennis championship in progress at the Crescent Athletic Club courts.

Industrial building plans submitted during the month of February to the State Department of Labor at Albany rose 7 per cent above the preceding month with a total of ninety-three, involving estimated expenditures of $940,845.
After an ownership of only a few days, Reuben Horowitz, operator, has resold the five-story apartment house at 1,317 Wilkins Avenue, the Bronx, to an investing client of Hyman Grill, lawyer.

William H. Corbin, former Tax Commissioner of Connecticut, testified yesterday as a government witness at the trial of John M. Kelley, general counsel for Ringling Brothers-Barnum Bailey Combined Shows, and others accused of filing false income tax returns for the circus.
Frank Henry Healey, well known in international trade union circles in Canada and the United States, died today after a brief illness. He was 60 years of age.

A decentralized attack on business problems by large organizations was urged yesterday by Arthur W. Ramsdell, director of sales of the Borden Company, in an address yesterday before the Executives Club at the Hotel Biltmore.

Stocks closed irregular after recovering opening losses; turnover, 561,800 shares. United States Government issues higher and quiet, rail bonds weakened, other groups irregular; transactions. $6,189,000.

Intensification of SinoJapanese hostilities in Western Suiyuan Province were reported today in messages to Sian, the capital of Shensi, from General Ma Chanshan, the commander of one of China's northwestern armies.

Accusing party "bosses" of ignoring labor in drafting the Democratic organization's primary ticket, Lieut. Gov. Thomas Kennedy, secretarytreasurer of the United Mine Workers, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

The following committee chairmen have been appointed in connection with the twenty-first annual convention of the American Association of Advertising Agencies: Mark O'Dea of O'Dea, Sheldon Canaday, convention program; H.
The International Olympic Committee, sole judge of where and how the Olympic Games are staged, will open a nine-day conference tomorrow to consider the threatened boycott of the 1940 Tokyo games.
Melville Stoltz, retired showman whose colorful career included early associations with David Warfield and Florenz Ziegfeld, died of heart disease in his home here today. He was 79 years old.
Railroad securities were depressed yesterday as a result of the overnight news of the freight-rate increase, which was termed "disappointing" by leading carrier executives.
The Borden Company reports net income of $6,290,652 for 1937 after all deductions, equivalent to $1.43 a share earned on 4,396,704 capital shares, a decline of $1,630,838 from 1936.
Great Britain formally reserved her right over the islands of Canton and Enderbury in the central Pacific Ocean in a note delivered to the State Department today by Sir Ronald Lindsay,

The annual Wagner matinee cycle, which is one of the Metropolitan Opera's principal adornments, came to a radiant and jubilant close yesterday. "Die Meistersinger," with its joy and its sunlight, its mellowness and humanity, was the sixth and final presentation.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Peter Paul Rubens," Roberta M. Fansler, 11 A. M., Egyptian collection (general tour), 2 P. M. Women's City Club of New York, 20 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "The Negro. Southern Farm Tenancy and the Labor Movement," Dr. J. Raymond Walsh.

Chester W. Cuthell, associate special counsel for the Transit Commission, charged Samuel Seabury and former City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr. yesterday with misrepresentation and inaccuracy in their message to the Board of Estimate describing as a "hoax" his memorandum of understanding for the city's purchase of the Interborougn rapid transit subway and elevated lines for $170,213,580 in city bonds.

Mrs. William Francis Gibbs of 170 East Seventy-ninth Street entertained with a luncheon yesterday at her home for members of the Neighborhood Playhouse Associates after the private showing of the Jules Bache art collection at 814 Fifth Avenue. Guests included Mrs.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow. HOGS Receipts, 13,000, including 4,000 directs. Market mostly 25c lower than Tuesday's average, following a few early sales around 15c off; top, $9.60; bulk good and choice 170-220 lbs., $9.25-50:

Mrs. Patricia Ryan recalled from the witness stand yesterday in Bronx County Court the vivid details of her quarrel with her "drunken" and "abusive" husband and told how she fought off his "unnatural advances" on the morning of Oct. 31, when he was killed.
The Treasury Procurement Division awarded about $1,000,000worth of contracts today to seventeen companies to furnish all the tires needed by the government in the next six months.

With his son, Peter. missing two weeks today, Murray Levine denied yesterday at his home in New Rochelle that the $30,000 ransom he has raised was paid Tuesday night. Before then he had made it clear that no contact had been established.

Two large charts, each five feet high and five feet wide, were used yesterday in General Sessions by William E. Schwanda, a lawyer, in the third day of his testimony as a State witness in the trial of two women and ten men in the so-called $2,000,000 Slovak Manor land fraud conspiracy.
Pig iron production in February, according to The Iron Age, made the infinitesimal gain of 0.6 per cent, based on the daily rate of 46,367 gross tons, compared with 46,100 tons in January.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 9, unless specified: At San Pedro: Henderson, Kanawha, Neches. Brazos, San Pedro to Navy Yard, Pearl Harbor.

The board of directors of the Henry Street Settlement and Visiting Nurse Service of New York has sent a message of greeting to Miss Lillian D. Waid, president emeritus of the organization, who will celebrate her seventy-first birthday today.

The audience which attended the Philharmonic-Symphony concert under John Barbirolli's direction last night in Carnegie Hall had a special thrill, in addition to the pleasures provided by the orchestra. That was Josef Hofmann's cyclonic performance of Rubinstein's G major piano concerto.

Stuyvesant High School's team scored its fourth straight success and increased its lead by defeating Seward Park, 10 to 2, in one of four Division 1 P. S. A. L. team fencing engagements held on the strips of the Washington Irving High School gymnasium last night.
Representation without taxation is the theory of government of Uncle Sam's newest citizens in St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, it was reported today by Charles W. Taussig of New York.
The Catholic Church in Germany finds itself considerably hindered by the locking and sealing of the "Catholic Bishops' Central Office" here by the secret political police.
The high cattle country paid tribute to mothers-in-law today in an all-day celebration. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was guest of honor and a center of the spectacle.

Hailed as a sweeping victory for conservatism, results of the nonpartisan municipal, port and School Board elections here yesterday showed today that all left-wing nominees had gone down to crushing defeat and that proposals for expenditure of additional public funds were rejected overwhelmingly.

Two large charts, each five feet high and five feet wide, were used yesterday in General Sessions by William E. Schwanda, a lawyer, in the third day of his testimony as a State witness in the trial of two women and ten men in the so-called $2,000,000 Slovak Manor land fraud conspiracy.
Pig iron production in February, according to The Iron Age, made the infinitesimal gain of 0.6 per cent, based on the daily rate of 46,367 gross tons, compared with 46,100 tons in January.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 9, unless specified: At San Pedro: Henderson, Kanawha, Neches. Brazos, San Pedro to Navy Yard, Pearl Harbor.

The board of directors of the Henry Street Settlement and Visiting Nurse Service of New York has sent a message of greeting to Miss Lillian D. Waid, president emeritus of the organization, who will celebrate her seventy-first birthday today.

The audience which attended the Philharmonic-Symphony concert under John Barbirolli's direction last night in Carnegie Hall had a special thrill, in addition to the pleasures provided by the orchestra. That was Josef Hofmann's cyclonic performance of Rubinstein's G major piano concerto.

Stuyvesant High School's team scored its fourth straight success and increased its lead by defeating Seward Park, 10 to 2, in one of four Division 1 P. S. A. L. team fencing engagements held on the strips of the Washington Irving High School gymnasium last night.
The high cattle country paid tribute to mothers-in-law today in an all-day celebration. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was guest of honor and a center of the spectacle.

Hailed as a sweeping victory for conservatism, results of the nonpartisan municipal, port and School Board elections here yesterday showed today that all left-wing nominees had gone down to crushing defeat and that proposals for expenditure of additional public funds were rejected overwhelmingly.

A special meeting of stockholders of General Foods Corporation has been called for April 13 to consider a proposal to authorize 350,000 shares of preferred stock, of which not more than 200,000 shares are to be issued.

The three-story dwelling on a lot 17 by 102 feet at 344 East Seventyninth Street has been purchased by the Mardyke Realty Corporation, associated with the Alliance Realty Company of 25 Broad Street, through Butler Baldwin, Inc.
S. T. Bledsoe, president of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe,

President Roosevelt gave his endorsement today to a program of building trade executives to promote privately financed construction and provide steadier employment for the 6,000,000 building trades workers.
Sylvester Blish of New Rochelle, N. Y., was elected captain of next season's Fordham varsity swimming team by the letter men yesterday and Philip J. Bisceglia of Long Beach. N. Y.. was named manager.

Yesterday's disclosures, regarding securities pledged or deposited by clients with an important Stock Exchange house hitherto held in great respect, came with a shock to the entire Stock Exchange membership, and to every one conversant with the district's code of fiduciary and business ethics.
The United American Company of Chicago and the Iowa-Nebraska Light and Power Company of Lincoln, Neb., registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Holding Company Act.
Mrs. Maude Johnson of Port Huron, Mich., half sister of the late Thomas E. Edison, died here last night. Mrs. Johnson, who was 60 years old, had been in Henry Ford Hospital for nearly a year.

The Giant hitters were well ahead of the Giant pitchers today and that was well for the National League champions all around, for it took quite a bit of robust clouting on the part of Colonel Bill Terry's troupe to bring down the Phillies in the one-day tournament staged here.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange here moved irregularly in a narrow range yesterday to end with gains of 2 to 4 points. A statement by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration that cash payments to growers would not be expedited under the Smith provisions of the Farm Bill eased the market for a time,
William Mayoh, 34 years old, an unemployed pastry worker, ended his life yesterday in a 135-foot leap from Washington Bridge, over the Harlem River, to Highbridge Park, in the Bronx.
John A. Stevenson, executive vice president of the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company, was elected yesterday a trustee of the company. He joined it as an agency manager in 1928.

The New York University girls' basketball team easily defeated Hunter College, 33-19, yesterday, on the Evangeline gymnasium courts. Miss Katherine Birmingham of the Violet was the scoring star with ten points.
The Reichsbank's statement as of March 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Lawrence Marx, president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, will serve as associate chairman with Leon Fraser of the committee on contributions of the Greater New York Fund, Mr. Fraser announced yesterday at a luncheon of philanthropic leaders at the Wall Street Club.

A story of Supreme Court Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo's kindness to an Irish widow was revealed yesterday morning at the Bureau of Licenses when Mrs. Alice Williams came to renew the license on her newsstand outside the Franklin Savings Bank at Eighth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
Political conversations between Foreign Ministers Josef Beck of Poland and Count Galeazzo Ciano of Italy ended today with a communique phrased in strikingly friendly terms.

Mrs. Ida F. Craven, 49 years old, who was said to have defrauded many persons of more than $200,000 in stock-promotion schemes in the last four years, was sentenced yesterday by General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit to one to five years in the Women's State prison at Bedford Hills.

The colorful grandeur of ancient Egypt, its culinary art of today and other modern features and its promise for the future will be brought to the 1939 World's Fair in the Egyptian pavilion, according to plans made public yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair corporation.

Bennett Cerf, president of Random House, who spent the last month on the West coast visiting with his authors, has returned to New York. Among the writers he saw were Eugene O'Neill, Robinson Jeffers and Gene Fowler, all of whom promised him new manuscripts soon.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen will arrive today from Bremen and Channel ports. On board are Gordon Selfridge Jr., Lord Petre, Mr. and Mrs. E. Lansing Ray, Miss May Birkhead, Dr. Robert Reiner, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Meyer.

The qualifying trials for the thirteenth annual swimming meet of the Athletic Association of. Private Schools of New York were held at the Columbia University pool yesterday. The finals in all events will be held tomorrow night.

Clarence R. Hooker of this city, yachtsman and former stockbroker, died this morning on his power boat Sachem II, at St. Augustine, Fla., of thrombosis, according to word received here. He was born in New Haven sixty-nine years ago, son of Frank Hooker, president of the Henry Hooker Carriage Company.

The controversy between the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and the Atlas-Liberty and SunshineRadio Taxicab Owners Associations remained unsettled last night, despite efforts by Arthur S. Meyer of the State Mediation Board to bring the parties together and end the lockout that is keeping 4,000 cabs off the streets and 4,500 drivers idle.

Great Britain's efforts toward European appeasement were bolstered today by a concession from France to meet Italian demands on nonintervention in Spain. The government informed Italy and Germany of the concession.

The Forest Upholstery Works, Inc., manufacturers of upholstered furniture, leased the fourth and fifth floors, containing about 22,000 square feet of space, in 520-28 West Forty-third Street through Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc., brokers.

Each of the following reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: Capt. Donald H. Gerrish, Ch.-Res., June 30, 1938; Capt. Francis B. Redner, F. A.Res., Sept. 24, 1938; 1st Lt. Milbert D. Dunlap, Engr.-Res., Sept. 24, 1938.

A recent survey has established that excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System are "better distributed now than last Spring after the final increase in reserve requirements," the Federal Reserve Board reported today in its bulletin for March.

Eleven faculty members and seventy-eight graduate students of Columbia University have been elected to the Kappa Chapter of Sigma Xi, scientific research honors society, it was announced yesterday by Professor Harold W. Webb, president of the chapter.

Robert Hula, representing Iron and steel manufacturers in the Chicago district, urged today repeal of the long-and-short-haul clause of the Interstate Commerce Act as a means of increasing employment.
Jackasses and Presidential aspirations were all mixed up in the Senate debate today. Senator McKellar of Tennessee became enraged by an attack on the TVA by Senator Bridges of New Hampshire.
Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg announced to a totally unprepared public in a speech broadcast from Innsbruck tonight that next Sunday he would hold a plebiscite on the question of Austrian independence.

The heaviest casualties in the Caribbean war games, which ended today, resulted from fish poisoning in which nineteen out of twenty in the mess of Brig. Gen. Richard P. Williams of the marine fleet force were made seriously ill. Commander Joel T.
Arturo Toscanini sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary with the entrance of his stateroom guarded by two private policemen representing the National Broadcasting Company.

Sydney Baynes, conductor and composer of the waltz "Destiny," published in 1912, which sold more than 1,000,000 copies, died today at the age of 59.' His band, which specialized in light music, was one of the most popular British radio features.

Judson Crockett Van Di Grisse, member of an old Georgia family, died here today after a long illness at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Merle J. Unger. Mr. Van Di Grisse was born on the family plantation in Carrollton County, Ga.

The New York University girls' basketball team easily defeated Hunter College, 33-19, yesterday, on the Evangeline gymnasium courts. Miss Katherine Birmingham of the Violet was the scoring star with ten points.
The Reichsbank's statement as of March 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Judson Crockett Van Di Grisse, member of an old Georgia family, died here today after a long illness at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Merle J. Unger. Mr. Van Di Grisse was born on the family plantation in Carrollton County, Ga.

With imports of Easter merchandise sharply behind those of last year, conditions rivaling those of depression days have settled upon the import trade as a result of the current recession in business, importers and customs brokers reported here yesterday.

A meeting of performers opposed to the "subversive minority" in the Actors Equity Association will be held at 2 P. M. today in the Ambassador theatre, 215 West Forty-ninth Street, where plans will be made for the election of conservatives to the union's nominating committee.

Yale junior promenade guests who have arrived here for the annual week-end festivities tonight attended the English historical farce, "Ten Sixty-Six and All That," given in the University Theatre by the Yale Dramatic Association,- or the Yale-Harvard hockey game at the New Haven Arena.

Governor Lehman denied yesterday the petition presented by the American Legion and other organizations demanding the removal of Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, because he had appointed and retained Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, on his staff.

The Townsend Harris and Lincoln School quintets triumphed in games played yesterday, Harris vanquishing Brooklyn Academy, 21-19, on the Christ Church court in. Brooklyn and Lincoln defeating Riverdale Country Day School, 35-31, on the Lincoln floor.

Lumber production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to the highest point this year. It now stands at 62.1, compared with 57.4 for the previous week and 78.8 for the week ended March 6, 1937.

After ordering the arrest of two more election board officials of Hudson County, the Young Assembly committee adjourned today until next week, apparently to await the outcome of habeas corpus proceedings instituted in Chancery

American Consul General Thomas Bevan today protested to Polish authorities against the arrest of two New York girls, Ruth and Zina Dickstein, who have been held in the primitive jail at Zbaszyn on the Polish-German border since Monday night.

The marriage of Mrs. Margaret Wheeler Stewart, daughter of Mrs. Eugene Munsell of 975 Park Ave-' nue and of the late Alonzo Wilcox Wheeler, to Alfred Whittell of San Francisco, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Whittell, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The Rev. Dr. Ralph W.

The proposed increase of 25 cents a gallon in Fedcral taxes on distilled liquor would mean a rise of slightly more than 10 cents a quart in the price of whisky to consumers, distillers and package liquor
Diorite quarries worked when the tyrant Pharaoh Cheops made Egyptian multitudes build the Great Pyramid between 5,000 and 6,000 years ago have been found.

The board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association of America adopted here today resolutions with respect to the Maloney bill now before Congress providing for the regulation of over-the-counter trading in securities.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans by the Department of Hospitals for a fourstory hospital building, to cost $200,000 for a site in East Fifteenth Street.

Members of the executive and coordinating committees of the Welfare Council joined with the unemployment committee of United Neighborhood Houses yesterday in backing Mayor La Guardia's request for additional relief funds from the State.

Miss Dorothy Jones of Detroit, newly crowned Bermuda women's golf champion, lost to Mrs. D. Holmes of Truro, Nova Scotia, in the championship flight quarterfinal round of the Belmont Manor Golf Club's tournament today, 3 and 1.
Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange reacted again yesterday and, after touching the lowest figures in three weeks, ended with losses of 2 to 5 points.

Metropolitan skiing enthusiasts again will have to flee to the upper stretches of New York State, New England and Canada for their running this week-end. Snow reports yesterday indicated that nothing was in store for those depending upon the Catskills, Poconos, Berkshires and Litchfield Hills for cutting up tracks.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher-in-training in day secondary schools, other than junior high schools, in the subjects indicated, be issued, as of the dates indicated, to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year todate, while total bills discounted were at the lowest.

The decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission in the general freight rate case this week has caused some railroad officials to think about wage reductions, it was disclosed yesterday. It was asserted, however, that this development had not gone beyond the "thinking stage."
Eviction of 600 impoverished tenants of the Glen Alden Coal Company was begun today when wrecking crews employed by the company started tearing down the houses for which families have been

The Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, has invited its members to a preview on March 22 of two rooms from the New York residence of the late John D. Rockefeller, 4 West Fifty-fourth Street, soon to be demolished. From the following day on the exhibition will be open to the public.

Edward James Manning, a pioneer in the typewriter industry and a former vice president and general manager of the Royal Typewriter Company, died at the Hartford Hospital today of a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 72.

No group of workers gives more in public service and asks less in tangible rewards than the librarians. In the New York Public Library system these devoted servants, most of them trained in colleges and library schools, do not receive much more, on the average, than is paid by the WPA.
The formation of a new governmental organ to administer China affairs is being discussed within the government, but there are diverse opinions regarding organization and functions.
The House voted today to raise the tax on hard liquor from $2 to $2.25 a gallon and to impose a new excise tax on imported pork and imported pork products.

Many parties were given last night in connection with the benefit style pageant held during the dinner hour at Cafe Louis Fourteenth. The pageant, known as "Cinderella in Modern Dress," was arranged to augment the scholarship fund of the George Junior Republic.

The shadow of the coming Austrian plebiscite overhung the opening of the preliminary Anglo-German conversations between Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Foreign Minister and former Ambassador, and Viscount Halifax, the British Foreign Secretary, today and caused the former to cut short his visit here and plan to return to Germany before Sunday's vote.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a modification of the terms of a recent $8,233,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation so that it might use $2,233,000 of the money for maintenance.

The government has liberated Dr. Suarez Vientimilla, director of El Debate, and Commander Guillermo Andrade, who were- to be exiled to the eastern provinces and to the Galapagos, respectively, according to a report in the Telegrafo.

Phelps, Fenn Co. and Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., obtained yesterday a new issue of $1,300,000 of public relief and permanent improvement bonds of Minneapolis, Minn., on their bid of 100.234 for 2.20s.

Rumors of preparations for a new outbreak kept Hatboro in a state of tension today while negotiators sought a way to end the strike of C. I. O. workers at the Roberts Mander . Stove Company plant, scene of a tear-gas attack on strikers last night.

John Meehan, who died in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Tuesday, was president of the contracting firm of John Meehan Sons of this city. His age was 51. Born here, he was a brother of Austin Meehan, a Republican ward leader.

Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania will announce tomorrow his support of Thomas Kennedy, who has entered the race for the nomination for Governor with the support of John L. Lewis, head of the C. I. O. and the United Mine Workers.
Great Britain served notice today that she would never again send great masses of her manhood to fight and die in' the mud of future European battlefields.

Stocks eased in final hour and closed lower after drifting idly; turnover, 455,440 shares. Baltimore Ohio Railroad bonds declined sharply, United States Government and other issues lower; transactions, $6,718,000.
Turpentine firm, 27 1/2c; sales, 26 barrels; receipts, 60 barrels; shipments, 732 barrels; stock, 23,916 barrels. Resin firm; no sales; receipts, 504; shipments, 748; stock, 63,849.
George Tatarescu tomorrow will hand over the Foreign Affairs portfolio to M. Petrescu-Commen, former Minister to Germany. M. Tatarescu will remain in the Cabinet without portfolio.

Local observers in Lithuania are of the opinion that an opportunity exists for expansion of American exports to that country in view of the difficulty of getting certain goods from other nations, according to a consular report from Kaunas, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The weather man will appear in court here March 17 and on his testimony will rest the verdict of a reckless driving case. Victor Lomoro said the sun was in his eyes at 3:40 P. M. Feb. 25, when Constable Brown charged that Lomoro did not obey his signal to stop.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling: Gold coin and bullion....increased [Pound]60,000 Reserve in banking dept..

The Port of New York Authority purchased yesterday from the New Jersey Junction Railroad Company, the New York Central Railroad and the New York State Realty and Terminal Company, a holding company for the New York Central, twenty-two parcels of land on the west shore of the Hudson River in Weehawken.
The stock market drifted lower in leisurely trading until the final hour yesterday when selling pressure increased. Closing prices were at or near the lowest levels of the day.

The Administration's interdepartmental committee on banking, of which Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury is chairman, held another meeting today, but recessed without reaching any decision as to the advisability of pressing for legislation aimed at bank holding companies or any other important proposal having to do with the nation's banking structure.

A six-year plan to harness the nation's water resources at an over-all cost of $2,124,867,000 to Federal, State and local governments was sent to Congress by President Roosevelt today in a report by the National Resources Committee.
William G. Richardson, for nearly forty years a leading member of the faculty of the Polytechnic Institute of Baltimore, died at his home here today at -the age of 83.

George Edward Matthews, member of a pioneer Buffalo family and a leading figure in the printing and engraving business in the city for more than twenty-five years, died today after an illness of several months. His age was 49. He was president of the Niagara Photoengraving Company.
An attendance of 30,000 children and 7,000 adults in this city at free classes conducted by the WPA Federal Art Project is reported in a Five-Borough Directory issued by the project.

Two more estates, an ordinary customer and five more brokers and traders were added yesterday to the list of customers whose securities were apparently delivered, without their knowledge, out of their accounts in the brokerage firm of Richard Whitney Co. to Richard Whitney.

John J. MacCrum, retired Curb broker, of Brooklyn, died here today at the age of 70. Mr. MacCrum, who resided at 1,075 Lincoln Road, Brooklyn, had been a member of the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange in 1923-24.

Thomas Mann, Nobel Prize winner and an exile from Germany, in his first public lecture in this city since. his recent arrival assailed yesterday the "pseudo-values" of diatatorships and affirmed his belief in the final victory - of democracy. Nearly 2,000 men and women filling Town Hall gave the author an enthusiastic reception.

The report for 1937 of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $12,740,772 after charges, taxes and reserves for depreciation, but before mine depletion.

While the government press is content to print only official news from Vienna without comment-obviously in order to avoid hurting Berlin's feelings--the Catholic, liberal and progressive organs unanimously praise Kurt Schuschnigg, Austrian Chancellor, for his courage and determination.
