Those of you who plan making a fishing trip to Quebec this Spring or Summer will be glad to learn that the fishing license you buy will take in the fishing of your wife and children, providing these children are under 18 years of age.
Karl Kathered, 77 years old, who lived above his general store at Ellwood, near here, was burned to death early this morning in a fire that destroyed the building.

Sachs Quality Furniture, Inc., will open its new fashion floor, featuring women's apparel, today at its midtown store at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street. Belle Applebaum, formerly of Consolidated Millinery Company, has joined Irving C. Krewson Corporation as millinery buyer. Mae V.

New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from Jay F. Carlise Jr. to Henry Kamermayer, from Douglas R. Hartshorne to Robert H. Cox of Fenner Beane and from Riley Miles Gilbert to Clark M. Cavanee.

James B. Williams Jr., who is said to have effected one of the quickest "turns" to have been made with a New York Stock Exchange membership, has bought a seat on the New York Cotton Exchange, it was announced yesterday.
Governor Lehman, in a message to the Legislature today, asked it to authorize acceptance by the State of $2,777,777.77 of New York Port Authority bonds. The bonds, to be accepted
THE tales they tell these days are simply marvelous. Maybe it's the Snow White influence spreading through the pugilistic camps, or just the pixie in those cute little fight managers.

Every caprice of fashion which has clicked for the coming season had its hour and its audience yesterday at Bonwit Teller, where the fashion press reviewed the inspirations of Parisian and American designers.
The United Air Lines Transport Corporation reported yesterday a net loss of $754,487 for 1937, in contrast with a net income of $367,283 after Federal income taxes in 1936.

Frederick Brenchley, widely known in banking and social circles in New Orleans, died suddenly today at his home here. Mr. Brenchley, active in New York financial circles as a foreign trade banker, had just finished breakfast when he was stricken.

A concerted attempt on the part of long-established manufacturers of handbag initials to crush price competition, rather than the use of handbags as a retail 'loss leader," was named yesterday by A. M. Mittenthal, executive secretary of the National Authority for the Ladies' Handbag Industry, as the reason for the current "sharp-shooting" on initial handbags which has broken out in a number of cities.

Focusing attention on goods produced here, the first of a series of Made-in-America industrial expositions was opened yesterday morning by Bloomingdale Brothers with a special ceremony in the Little Forum of the store.

Seabiscuit will not run in Saturday's $10,000 San Juan Capistrano Stakes because of the "excessive" weight of 135 pounds assigned to him, C. S. Howard, owner of the 1937 handicap champion, said today.

Attacking the Bankhead amendment which exempts dealers in municipal securities from most provisions of the Maloney bill for regulation of over-the-counter markets, Robert E. Healy, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, asserted last night that such an exemption "smacks of unfair competition."
Money market was listless, the demand for funds being light, while quotations for all classifications were carried forward without change.
With a volume of $80,524,000 this week, engineering construction awards are 96 per cent above the same period of last year, when $41,088,000 was reported, according to The Engineering News-Record.
Sinclair Lewis's latest work, "The Prodigal Parents" (Doubleday, Doran), has exceeded in each of the five weeks since its publication the sales of "It Can't Happen Here," his previous book.
Denmark's famous gymnastic system, named- after its founder and leader, Niels Bukh, will in the future be adopted in Germany.
The Democratic National Committee is out of debt, but the Republican National Committee owes about $500,000, it was revealed today.

A net profit of $8,348,089 for 1937 was reported yesterday in the annual statement of the Borg-Warner Corporation and its subsidiaries. The profit was after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges, including $458,612 surtax on undistributed earnings.
Banks would be empowered to lend small business men up to $100,000 with government backing under a bill introduced today by Representative Mead of New York.

Finding that cotton cloth production at slightly less than 9,000,000,000 square yards established a new record last year, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, declared yesterday that the achievement of the new record volume was marred by adverse influences on distribution during the latter half of the year.

Many prominent figures were named by the military intelligence service report issued today as responsible for the revolutionary plot to overthrow Colonel Fulgencio Batista and his regime, which the army leaders claim to have broken up.

Edward Rosenwald, in 34 Fenimore Rd. Scarsdale. Westchester: Joseph Sylvester, through Thompson Co. on Easton Ave, White Plains, and renewals with Ruth W. Christie, in 85 Brite Ave, Scarsdale; Morris Krantz, in 257 Nelson Rd. Scarsdale; Jerome W. Blum, in 33 Cushman Rd, Scarsdale; Louise O. Meuer, Inc, broker.

A verdict of $10,000 damages was returned by a jury in Superior Court today in favor of Henry Barsha and David Weissman, writers, in a $150,000 plagiarism suit against Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studio and Loew's, Inc.,
The annual report of the North American Company for 1937, which is being forwarded to shareholders today, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $18,542,481.

The New York Americans were satisfied to tie the Boston Bruins in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Going into the final period a goal ahead of their rivals, the New Yorkers yielded a score which sent the battle into overtime. Neither team tried hard in the extra session and hostilities ended with the count still --2.

Spirited protests were made yesterday over the lack of provision for new schools and high schools in the 1938 capital outlay budget when the Board of Estimate held a public hearing on the budget at City Hall.

Purchases of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 5 exceeded sales by 59,682 shares, reversing the trend of the previous week, when sales exceeded purch. ses by 30,724 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Councilman Michael J. Quill, who was taxed by his Demociratic opponents in the City Council last Tuesday with having failed to pay an income tax though his brokerage account showed purchases of $16,000, made public a letter from his broker last night indicating that his holdings had never reached any such amount.

Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia, already at odds over additional help from the State for relief for New York City, split wide apart today, as the Governor made public a letter from the Mayor, and his own reply.

State Labor Commissioner John J. Toohey Jr. announced today the appointment of C. George Krueger of Jersey City to succeed the late Charles H. Weeks of Trenton as deputy corn lissioner in charge of the Bureau of General and Structural Inspection and Explosives.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company of New York has been appointed trustee for $199,000 of Gravesend-Sheepshead Bay Postal Stations, Inc., first lien sinking fund income bonds due on Sept. 1, 1951.
West Side residential properties were involved in most of the Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday.
British troops mopping up in Palestine's "bloody triangle" today killed at least thirty-two Arabs in a pitched battle.
Harry Caston Edmonds of Winnetka, Ill., leader in the property management field in Chicago since 1901, died yesterday in Presbyterian Hospital at the age of 60 years. He also was a bank director.
Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Prindle Benton gave a dinner at their home here tonight in honor of Dr. James Phinney Baxter 3d, president of Williams College, and Mrs. Baxter.

A pair of changed men will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight when Max Baer, former heavyweight champion of the world, and Tommy Farr, holder of the British Empire title, clash in the feature bout of fifteen rounds. So widespread is the interest in the transformation that has come over these gladiators that Promoter Mike Jacobs is confident the bout will attract at least 10,000 paying fans.

Success of the Treasury's refunding of approximately $455,000,000 of notes maturing on March 15 was assured this morning, even though all offerings for exchange had not yet been received, Secretary Morgenthau said. today at his press conference.

Any art week is spiced by what may be called a "novelty number." Gladdened or saddened, it is sure to be spiced, if only because such events constitute a break in the more or less methodical coming and going of group shows and one-man shows, important shows and unimportant shows, and just shows.

More than fifty Barnard College juniors will appear in "39 Steps," a musical comedy, tonight and tomorrow night in Brinckerhoff Theatre on the campus. The show is under the direction of Charlotte Phillipson. The plot was written by Irma Zimmer,...

A large attendance marked tonight's Orange Blossom ball at the Colony Club, which was decorated with orange trees and blossoms. Proceeds will go toward construction and equipment of a convalescent home.
Three longterm convicts escaped from the penitentiary here this morning and all day an army of prison guards and mounted police combed town and countryside.

Secretary Hull told Senator Lonergan of Connecticut by letter today that the State Department had approved the appointment of Major Radu Irimescu as Rumanian Minister to the United States, although the American Jewish Congress had raised questions concerning him which Senator Lonergan had transmitted to Mr. Hull.
The new Beverly Hills (Calif.) store of Saks-Fifth Avenue will be opened on April 18, it was stated here yesterday by I. A. Hirschmann, vice president of the Fifth Avenue establishment.

Following an abrupt resignation of the Premiership by Camille Chautemps this morning, Leon Blum, leader of the Socialists, agreed to try to form a Cabinet. Tonight he had not got far, but he was still trying.

The Maritime Commission announced today a schedule for eleven Port Authority conferences in North Atlantic coast cities, April 4 to 27. The schedule is as follows: Portland, Me., April 4; Boston, April 7; Fall River, April 11; Providence, April 13;

New York University will meet Colorado University and Temple will face Oklahoma A. and M. at Madison Square Garden Monday night in the semi-final round of the national invitation intercollegiate basketball tournament, which opened under auspicious circumstances Wednesday night.
The last gap in a $7,400,000 highway over 80 miles of bridges and little islands between here and the Florida mainland will be spanned April 1 and the Overseas Highway will be opened to traffic.

Registering his sixth straight victory, Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia last night downed Joe Diehl of Rockford, Ill., 125 to 120, in twenty-eight innings to take an undisputed lead in the world pocket billiard championship at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

Commenting on reports from Mexico City yesterday indicating that it had suspended all operations in Mexico and that the United States Embassy had intervened in its behalf, the United States Steel Products Company, export division of the United States Steel Corporation, issued the following statemerit:

Having voted on Wednesday against the Administration's plan for a "third basket" tax, the House of Representatives found itself confronted yesterday by the task of finding a substitute for it. Several tentative decisions were reached.

The State Banking Department is said to have been receiving an increasing number of pleas recently from savings banks and other financial institutions under its control for extension of time permitted for sale of properties which these institutions have taken over under foreclosure.

In a move to provide further embellishment for the nineteenth annual Knights of Columbus games to be held under his direction, Frank A. Brennan has arranged for timers to be stationed at 1,500 meters in the mile, 500 meters in the 600 and 3,000 meters in the twomile at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

After declining moderately during the greater part of February, business in the Pittsburgh district moved up a little last week, according to the bureau of business research, University of Pittsburgh. The gain in business resulted partly from increased industrial production and partly from increased freight shipments.
The San Francisco Examiner said today that Al Capone, Chicago gang chief, who a month ago was placed in Alcatraz Prison hospital because he was "mentally ill," has been returned to the prison yard.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

Spectacular putting carried Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., to a notable 1-up victory over Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, six times national champion, in their semi-final match of the Belleair women's open golf tournament today.
Administration leaders proposed today that the Administration's Government Reorganization Bill be modified and that night Senate sessions be held to hasten action on it.

Except for the newspapers controlled by Konrad Henlein, leader of the Sudeten German party, the Czechoslovak press generally wishes Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria success in the plebiscite, which, they 'declare, should contribute to peace and order in Central Europe.
Dr. L. R. Boynton, a physician here for thirty-six years, died today at his home at the age of 68. Born in Lakeside, N. Y., he was a graduate of the New York Homeopathic Medical College.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The uncertainty surrounding -the enactment of the Wage and Hours Bill suggests the advisability of considering a wage and hours measure for the textile industry alone.

Signs became evident tonight that a way had been paved for a- possible solution of the controversy between the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation over acquisition of the latter's properties by the TVA.
Chancellor Hitler today reappointed Dr. Hjalmar Schacht president of the Reichsbank for another four years. His new term will begin March 16, when the present one expires.

The text of the indictment against Richard Whitney follows: The People of the State of New York against Richard Whitney, Defendant: The.grand jury of the County of New York, by this indictment, accuse the defendant of the crime of grand larceny in the first degree, committed as follows:

Adjournment of Congress in sixty days without final action on the executive reorganization bill or whatever measure is proposed for the regulation and control of monopolies was made the Administration's legislative goal today by Representative Rayburn, House majority leader, after a conference with President Roosevelt.

As a result of his work in "Four Men and a Prayer," for which he was borrowed from Samuel Goldwyn by Twentieth Century-Fox, David Niven has again been drafted for another Fox epic, "Three Blind Mice."

A rise of $92,000,000 in brokers' loans, attributable to the market's preparations for the Treasury's operations and tax payments on March 15, was the principal feature of the weekly report of member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City as of Wednesday night, which was issued yesterday.

The Black Hawks virtually clinched a Stanley Cup play-off berth tonight, defeating the speedy Montreal Canadiens, 4 to 1, in a hard-played National Hockey League battle before 9,000 spectators. The victory, third straight for the American division third-place holders, put Chicago three games ahead

A charge of suspicion of homicide against Alex Cousinin, 19 years old, of 308 Cherry Street, was dismissed yesterday by Magistrate William Klapp in Homicide Court after Witnesses had testified that Herman Hermansen, 60, of 1,236 Bay Ridge Parkway, Brooklyn, had stepped into the path of Cousinin's automobile on Feb. 27 at West and North

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey today will reduce the price of domestic Grade C bunker fuel oil at New York 10 cents a barrel to $1.15. The price for bonded bunker C fuel oil will be reduced 5 cents a barrel.

Insurgent troops entered Belchite, twenty-five miles southeast of Saragossa, this afternoon. There was some resistance, and a brisk exchange of rifle fire preceded the entry. Colonel Juan Yague followed his troops into the town.
The stock markets here were quiet and generally weaker today, with most sections losing ground. Gilt-edge issues were lower, but, among the foreign bonds, Austrian loans attracted some support.

For many of us birthdays are painful occasions, they remind us so much of the things we should have done and didn't, and shouldn't have done but did. For Lillian D. Wald, founder of the Henry Street Settlement and of the Visiting Nurse Service, who was 71 years old yesterday,

More than 2,200 young journalists, representing school publications throughout the nation, began a three-day occupation of Morningside Heights yesterday to exchange newspaper experiences, seek solutions for their technical problems

Detective Charles S. Corbett, whose charge that a bribe of-$100,000 had been offered in the Drukman murder case was a principal factor in making-the case a political cause celebre, retired from the Police Department at midnight last night on a pension of $1,500 a year.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today the following proceedings were had: 633--Millar Brainard, petr., v. Commissioner Internal Revenue. Motion to dismiss submitted for petr. in support of motion, and by respondent in opposition thereto.
In the Senate the resources report was referred to the Commerce Committee. Senator Vandenberg, a member, said that group probably could not consider it at this session.

Reversing a six-month downward trend, domestic orders for machine tools showed a slight upturn last month and rose more than 10 per cent above the January level, according to the National Machine Tools Builders' Association.

The wheat market turned downward again today after a fair showing of strength early and prices dropped to new low levels on the current downturn, closing with net losses of 1/4 to 3/4 cent a bushel, the latter on the May, which felt the full effect of persistent scattered liquidation.

Three adjoining farms comprising 109 acres fronting on Smalleytown Road in Somerset County, N. J., have been purchased by Joseph Siccardi of Plainfield and Warrenville, who will develop the property into a country estate. The deals were made through Andrew Haye Son, brokers.

The New York World's Fair committee of the toilet goods industry has concluded its recent negotiations with announcement made yesterday that a building is being constructed by the World's Fair which will be placed at the disposal of Perfumery and Cosmetic.Exhibits, Inc.

Manasseh Miller, president of the Prudential Savings Bank, Brooklyn, and active in religious and welfare work, died yesterday afternoon at his home, 694 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, following an illness of three months. He was 58 years old.

A sharp decline was recorded in bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday, although the drop from the corresponding week in 1937 was shortened in the seventeenth of the unbroken series of declines from the previous year's level.
Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Harden Church of Pittsburgh will come to the Plaza today to join their daughter, Mrs. Henry L. Jones 2d of Kingston, Pa.

HAVE you read any good books lately? Yes And as this is one of our three-times-a-year weeks for recapitulation, here are some of the books published between Nov. 1 and March that stand out in this reviewer's memory for a variety of reasons. A rather determined effort has been made to arrange the books in no formal order whatever.

Horton Smith, tall Missourian who was the- golf tournament star a decade ago, shot a 65 today and ensconced himself far in front in the $3,000 Hollywood open with a 36-hole 131, eleven strokes below par.

Mrs. Masahiko Takami, the former Iku Kondo of Lyndhurst, N. J., died today at her home here at the age of 22. She was married last Nov. 28 to Masahiko Takami, son of Dr. and Mrs. Toyshiko Takami of Brooklyn.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today permitted- the Southern Pacific Company to assume obligation and liability, as guarantor, in respect to $2,500,000 of first mortgage, fifty-year, 5 per cent gold bonds of the El Paso Rock Island Railway Company, and $577,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust, fiftyyear, 5 per cent gold bonds of the Dawson Railway and Coal Company.

Demand for wool goods this week was erratic, with outside influences combining to produce a certain amount of uneasiness as to prospects for general business over the next few months, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.
In a brief ceremony the 10,000ton cruiser Savannah was put in commission today as the latest addition to the United States fleet.
Robert C. Eberle of Brooklyn, N. Y., outstanding 126-pound wrestler, was one of five members of the freshman class elected to the captaincies of Winter teams at Princeton University today.

Three members of the freshman class were among the six Princeton boxers who gained university championships tonight in the gymnasium as a fortnight of strenuous tournament competition was brought to a close before nearly 500 persons.
The Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission contracted today with a syndicate headed by B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., of New York for the sale of $60,000,000 in revenue bonds to build the 165-mile
Edwin Sommerich, long active in Jewish charities in the metropolitan area and for the last seventeen years a trustee of Temple Israel at Lawrence, L. I., died Wednesday night in his home,

Members of the Board of Estimate had their attention called yesterday to the absence of an American flag in their chamber at City Hall after George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, had questioned the patriotism of members of the Teachers Union.

Continued artillery duels across the Yellow River featured the SinoJapanese hostilities in North China yesterday. Chinese military authorities deny that the Japanese crossed the river. But Japanese guns have been placed on the high bluffs of the Yellow River opposite Tungkwan and they are raking the southern bank with fire, Chinese official reports say.

Dr. Henry Adolphus Cohen, former Honorary Police Commissioner of New York and departmental eye surgeon under Commissioner Richard E. Enright, died here this morning at his home at the age of 58. He had been ill with heart disease for years.
Reading Iron Company stockholders authorized today the liquidation of the company in accordance with the recommendations of the board of directors.
The trial of twenty-one confessed antiSoviet plotters will be resumed tomorrow, when Prosecutor Andrey Y. Vishinsky will summarize the multiple crimes before sentence is passed.

The families who occupied the five-story tenement house at 82 St. Marks Place, corner of First Avenue, which was ordered vacated when it seemed in danger of collapse, were allowed to enter the building yesterday to remove their belongings.

During the week ended March 9 member bank reserve balances increased $96,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $9,000,000 in money in circulation, $17,000,000 in Treasury cash,

Joseph W. Catharine, president of the National Association- of Real Estate Boards, today proposed on behalf of the association "an amendment to the Wagner Housing Act that would encourage privately-owned housing companies under such regulation that they would become public utility companies in the housing field."

The O'Sullivan Rubber Company, which is doubling its present quarters in an expansion move, has leased the entire fourteenth floor in the Postal Life Building at 511 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-third Street, it was announced yesterday. Butler Baldwin, Inc., and William A. White Sons were the brokers.

Awards of medals and ribbons in two classes--medalist and first--to outstanding publications among the 1,114 newspapers and magazines entered in the contest sponsored by the Columbia Scholastic Press Association,

Dr. Francis E. Townsend carried to the Supreme Court today his fight against a thirty-day jail sentence imposed upon him for contempt of a House Committee which investigated his old-age pension movement.
Ground was broken yesterday for the foundation of the exhibition building of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York at the New York World's Fair 1939. Floyd L.

The profit of the General Baking Company for the first seven weeks of 1938 was $280,000, compared to $84,000 in the corresponding period of 1937, Frederic H. Frazier, chairman of he board, said yesterday, at the annual meeting of stockholders.

The Rogers-Allen Act, passed by the Albany Legislature last Spring, instructed the State Department of Agriculture and Markets to conduct an audit of the books of the milk distributors. The results of this audit were announced on Feb. 7 last.
Edward K. Mills, president of the Morristown Trust Company, died at Memorial Hospital early today following an appendectomy. His age was 63.

City College inaugurated its 1938 baseball season yesterday when thirty-three men reported to Sam Winograd, new coach. Winograd announced that a general call for candidates would be issued as soon as weather conditions permit outdoor work.

All factors influencing bank reserves were working toward an increase in the current statement week with the result that member bank reserve balances went up $96,000,000 and the excess of reserves over requirements gained $80,000,000 to $1,470,000,000.

The annual report of the National Dairy Products Corporation and subsidiaries for 1937 shows a consolidated net income of $10,290,731, after all deductions, equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.53 a share on the common stock, compared to $13.282,028, or $2.01 a share, in 1936.

The esteem in which sportsmen throughout the nation held Stephen W. McKeever was in evidence yesterday at the funeral of the "Judge," who helped direct the policies of the Brooklyn baseball club for more than a quarter of a century.
Mrs. Joseph S. Knight of Haverford has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Josephine Knight, to Donald Campbell Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Foster Campbell Moore of Chestnut Hill.

Business must study "Mrs. Consumer, to analyze -her brain and to understand her' psychology," Mrs. Christine Frederick, consumer expert, declared yesterday, if business and industry expect to solve "women's problems of living" in the light of constantly shifting social and economic changes.

Cleveland's Indians and the New Orleans Pelicans played a 4-4 tie today in their first exhibition game of the season. It was called after nine innings. Ken Keltner, Indian rookie third baseman,' up from Milwaukee, was hit on the left elbow by one of Dick Oyler's fast pitches in the seventh. He fell in great pain, but examination afterward indicated he had suffered only a bruise.

Cecil Henry Polhill, one of the famous "Cambridge University Seven," died here tonight at the age of 78. The Cambridge Seven were prominent undergraduate athletes who came under the influence of Dwight L. Moody, the American revivalist, and became missionaries.
Since a Southern cycle is in the offing, where it has been since Mr. Selznick started looking for Scarlett, it is probably for the best that Owen Davis's "Jezebel" should have got in the first licks.

The first bad weather Manager Burleigh Grimes has faced since daily Dodger workouts were begun a week ago came today, but the rain held-off until all exercises, including a nine-inning ball game, had ended.
The expulsion of several hundred German colonists from Wolhymia on the Polish Ukrainian border has been ordered by the Warsaw authorities.

An apparent delay of ten days from the time State unemployment insurance checks. are written until they are mailed to the jobless was disclosed in figures released last night by the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor. Department.
Young King Farouk of Egypt formally opened the International Olympic Committee's nine-day conference today.

Arraigned in Federal Court here today on indictments charging him with embezzlement of funds of the First National Bank. of Secaucus while serving as receiver, John H. Ensor pleaded guilty to taking $5,100, but denied misuse of an additional $4,509, as charged.

Without comment Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman denied yesterday an application by several members of the Tidewater Boatmen's Union, Local 933-1, to restrain officers of the local from collecting dues and performing other functions pending trial of a suit for a permanent injunction and an accounting for funds heretofore collected.
Total resources of the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company on March 7 amounted to $30,007,254, compared with $30,971,286 on Dec. 31 and to $31,058,001 on March 31, 1937.

Officials to serve for the New York tracks during the coming racing season were appointed yesterday at a meeting of the stewards of the Jockey Club, who also issued licenses to sixty-seven trainers and three jockeys besides taking care of routine business.
The mathematicians ought to have something to say about the Moscow treason trial. In the last two years

The Agriculture Department forecast today that this year's orange crop would be the largest on record--68,606,000 boxes. The indicated production was put at 24 per cent larger than last year's harvested crop of 55,174,000 boxes.

Sardou's "A Scrap of Paper" will be revived by the Theodore Irvine Players tonight at the Studio of the Theatre, 15 West Sixty-seventh Street. Other performances will be given tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday evenings.
After winning the event five successive times, Miss Dorothy Paget's great jumper, Golden Miller, finally was vanquished in the Cheltenham Gold Cup Steeplechase today.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler submitted yesterday the high bid for a new issue of $2,235,000 of Chicago, Milwaukee, St Paul Pacific Railroad equipment trust certificates, Series S, offering a price of 99.033 for the 3 3/4 per cent certificates, which are to mature serially on April 1, 1939 to 1953. Evans, Stillman Co. and associates submitted the only other bid, offering a price of 97.9029.
Fire spreading rapidly today through a six-story downtown building forced more than 100 physically handicapped employes of Goodwill Industries, Inc., to scramble to safety. Five persons were injured.

Victorious Ann, a black mare that had not been to the races since her winning effort at Laurel last October, won the six-furlong fifth race, best offering on today's Troptcar Park card, at the liberal odds of 11 to 1.

Designation of trade agreement countries and summaries of trade with these countries, compared with non-agreement countries, is a feature of the new monthly statement of foreign trade by countries, the first of which was made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The qualities of Mahler's Fifth Symphony, played by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, may be begged for the moment, because the predominating impression of the performance was the extraordinary qualities of the leader and the orchestra.
The Department of Agriculture has appealed to all eligible farmers to participate in an election on Saturday on proposals to invoke marketing control provisions of the new Farm Act.

Sir Willmott Harsant Lewis and the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Sizoo will be guests of honor tonight at the dinner dance to be given in the Embassy suite of the Ambassador by the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas.

Men's Wear Clearances End Final clearances of men's wear by local stores this week drew a mixed response, according to retail executives yesterday. A few stores reported excellent activity in some of their low-price clothing offerings while others said the weather had hampered volume.

A further 2,080 miles of flying over the Arctic from Aklavik to longitude 81 degrees 40 minutes north to 110 degrees west, where we ran into clouds, and from there northeastward to longitude 82 degrees north and 100 degrees west and return, has made for us, in spite of the mileage covered, another disappointing day.
Directors of the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company today made known to stockholders that consolidated net earnings for 1937 amounted to $8,743,590. This result is equal to $4.37

No less than $135,000,000 is needed for "urgent" work in the New York metropolitan area for stream pollution abatement to protect the public health, shipping, recreation and the shell-fish industry, according to the report of the National Resources Committee which President Roosevelt sent to Congress today.

Bill Nowak, 19-year-old rookie second baseman claimed by both the Giants and Cleveland Indians, was ordered tonight by Judge William Bramham, minor league czar, to report immediately to the Jersey City Club, a Giant farm.

The World Jewish Congress executive committee today telegraphed to the Foreign. Ministers of France, Great Britain and Sweden, composing the League of Nations Council's committee on Danzig, calling attention to the Danzig Senate's reported decision to introduce the "Aryan clause" April 1 in all hospitals, clinics and services connected with social insurance.

Constitutional government is under attack in the United States by falsely labelled liberal movements" which actually are heading the country toward totalitarianism, Representative Samuel B. Pettengill of Indiana said last night in an address before the annual dinner of the Colgate Alumni Association of the metropolitan area in the Hotel Commodore.

Increases in deposits and total assets compared with Dec. 31, 1937, were shown by the Chase National Bank in its statement of condition as of March 7, issued yesterday in response to a call by the Controller of the Currency.
Jose M. Torres-Perona, editor of La Prensa, in 310 E 55th St; Edgar Calmer, in 12 E 97th St; Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc., broker.

Senator Smathers, Democrat, of New Jersey, sent a bottle of New Jersey champagne and a peck of New Jersey oysters to each of his ninety-five colleagues in the Senate today and waited for developments.

After something more than six years in which Broadway hasn't seen a play by Lula Vollmer, her "The Hill Between" opens tonight at the Little Theatre. Its characters are Southern mountain folk, as they were in her famous "Sun-Up," and the most important of them
New York broadcasters said yesterday that the action of Detroit and Cleveland. stations in banning the "swinging" of old ballads was not likely to lead to any anti-swing rule on Manhattan Island.
Carl Otto Flocke, head of the Flocke Studios here, designers and manufacturers of stained-glass windows, died of a heart ailment yesterday on his sixtieth birthday.

Mrs. Frances Ryan, only woman ward leader in the T. J. Pendergast Democratic organization, received the heavist sentence of nine vote fraud defendants who appeared today before Judge Merrill E. Otis of the Federal court.

Secretary Morgenthau invited today bids on two series of Treasury bills aggregating $100,000,000, one series of approximately $50,000,000 being the usual ninety-one-day bills and the other series being the same amount of the temporary issue of ninety-three-day "new-money" bills.

President Roosevelt transmitted to Congress the report of the National Resources Committee, conferred with Representative Rayburn on adjournment plans, and with Representative Ramspeck on wages and hours legislation,

TODAY--New England: Partly cloudy, preceded by snow, with rising temperatures over south; partly cloudy, possibly snow flurries and rising temperatures to slightly above freezing point over central and northern portions.
Mrs. Patricia Ryan's portrait of an "irresponsible," "drunken" and "abusive" husband was subjected to a searching scrutiny in Bronx County Court yesterday as Assistant District Attorney Martin Frank

The Salle d'Armes Vince trio of the Misses Maria Cerra, Madeleine Dalton and Geisha Fernandez won the women's national foil championship by defeating the Salle SantelliGreco team of the Misses Barbara Cochrane, Mildred Stewart and Lisel Lowenherz, 5--2, on the strips of the Fencers Club last night.

Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York and temporary chairman of the proposed committee to organize a 'union" to protect the interests of property owners, yesterday invited civic organizations to send representatives to a general committee meeting on March 23 at 4 P. M. atthe Hotel Commodore.
Governor Lehman refused to remove Stanley Isaacs s as Manhattan Borough President for his appointment of Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, as confidential examiner;
Tom Mooney convicted of the Preparedness Day bombing in 1916, failed on the first vote in the State Assembly today to win his freedom.

Declaring that "peace within the house of labor is mandatory" if the labor movement is not to suffer serious setback, Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers Union, second largest C. I. O. affiliate with an asserted
Nearly three years ago, when the President suddenly prolonged by two months a dying session of Congress by asking for heavy, new inheritance tax schedules, the House carried out his wishes.

KINGS BENNETT, FRED J. (March 23. 1937). Gross assets, $74,756; net, $46,743. To brother, Maynard N. Bennett, $2,000; sister, Mary Bennett, $10,000; wife, Lillian R. Bennett, residuary estate. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $47,976; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $23,065; jointly owned property, $150: miscellaneous property, $3,564. Lee, Bond. Swan Donoghue, attorneys, 92 Liberty St., Manhattan.

Mrs. Willis Glover Townes of Skylands, Woodbury, Conn., formerly of New York, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Robina Protheroe Townes, to Richard E. Shoemaker, son of Richard W. Shoemaker of Woodbury.
In a unanimous decision the Appellate Term of the State Supreme Court upheld yesterday the constitutionality of legislation limiting fees of employment agencies.

Prime Minister Mackenzie King introduced in the House of Commons today his much discussed measure to transfer from his government to Parliament the power to grant licensed for the export of hydro-electric power.

MANHATTAN DANCIK, JOHN (April 18, 1937). Estate, more than $10,000. To Maria Dancik, widow, executrix, 1,453 Lexington Ave., residue. Olga Dancik, same address, and Ellen R. Salma, 230 E. 71st St., daughters, executrices.

Richard Whitney, senior partner of the insolvent brokerage firm of Richard Whitney Co. and former president of the New York Stock Exchange, was indicted yesterday on a charge of stealing $105,000 in securities from a trust fund established by his father-in-law, the late George R. Sheldon, of which Mr. Whitney was one of the executors and trustees.

Temperate as the statement is which the committee of the 430 physicians publish in The Journal of the American Medical Association to explain their relation to organized medicine, it will be read with mortification, perhaps for with indignation, by thousands of physicians.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Gail Borden Jenkins of -this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Wooster Jenkins, to George Metcalf, son of Mrs. Frederick Martens of Brooklyn.

Increases in notes in circulation and Dominion Government deposits were shown today in the statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended on March 9. Holdings of sterling and United States dollars also were higher.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation in Febru-ary totaled 474,723 tons, a decline of 43,599 tons from January, reflecting the shortness of the month, and compared to 1,133,724 tons shipped' in February, 1937.

Senator Pope, an author of the Administration's farm program, said today that he was drafting a new system of processing taxes designed to raise $200,000,000 annually. About $500,000,000 a year now is available

In general, candidates for teaching licenses in the New York City school system are drawn from the lower levels of the graduating classes, Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the Board of Examiners, declared yesterday in making public a study of the comparative scholastic ratings of men and women candidates.

Lieut. Gov. Kennedy of Pennsylvania and the United Mine Workers came out for himself Wednesday as the Democratic candidate for Governor on a nine-point program and declared rather curiously that the Democratic party "is not owned and will not be controlled by any boss or bosses."

The startling decision of the Austrian Chancellor to hold a plebiscite [authoritarian style] next Sunday is evidence of his determination that Austria shall not be swallowed up without a struggle. His appeal to the people on' the formula, "A free and German, independent and social,

The Hamburg-American liner Hansa, arriving today from Germany and channel ports, has among her passengers Heinz Ruhe, Mr. and Mrs. Max Warnholtz, Captain J. McAinsh, John F. Gates, Alfredo Ferreyros, Mr. and Mrs. V. D. Drury, Henry Fryling, Mr. and Mrs. George D. Cobbett, R. C. Anderson and Miss Joan Fitzgerald.

Trading was fair to mostly slow. Lamb prices were strong to higher, the cow market weak to lower, other classes showed little change. Early trading in kosher meats was light with practically no veal business, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Thousands of children greeted former President Herbert Hoover on his arrival here today from Berlin. At a meeting at the university in his honor, the rector hailed him as the savior of Polish children eighteen years ago when he was the head of the American Relief Administration.

After discussing the constitutional convention at a meeting here today, the executive committee of the Republican State Committee adjourned early this evening after a five-hour session, ostensibly without reaching a decision on any question before it except one.

Semi-sport clothes were announced as the newest classification in men's apparel for retail selling at the. second Esquire Fashion Forum and Apparel Arts Retail Seminar at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

Eldridge St. 21, 25x100. 1/2 interest; Elias A. Ginandes to Lema Herstein, 52 Marshal St, North Adams, Mass. (correction deed). 86th St, 330 W, 20x102.2; Charles E. Buchner to Leopold Schepp Foundation, 167 Duane St, consideration $1,000, foreclosure.

Reports from consumer cooperative retail and wholesale societies in the United States for 1937 show that the volume of business of cooperatives rose more than 20 per cent over the preceding year, according to announcement yesterday by the Cooperative League of the United States of America.

Three new productions will open tonight as the week-end attractions in the Yiddish theatres. They are: "The Little Tailor," a comedy with music by Joseph Rumshinsky and Louis Freiman, at the Second Avenue Theatre; "In a Jewish Home," a dramatization of a radio feature,
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted an application by the New York Curb Exchange to delist the Class A common convertible shares, $25 par value, and the $10 par value common stock of the Allied Products Corporation, Illinois.

BEGGAR'S REVOLT, by Maurits Dekker. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50.) A historical novel of Netherlands under Spanish domination. A CHILD IN HER ARMS, by Louise Redfield Peattie. Putnam, $2.) A novel by the author of "American Acres."

Jimmy Foster, Britain's international goalie, scored a shutout tonight as Britain defeated Canada, 3-0, in a hockey game at Wembley. Britain swept the twogame series as the Canadians, who play as the Sudbury Wolves, lost by 4-3 at Harringay on Tuesday.

" Advertising Makes Work" will be the slogan for the annual .convention of the Advertising Federation of America, to be held in Detroit, June 12 to June 17, George M. Slocum, publisher of Automotive Daily News and federation president, announced yesterday. The week during which the convention will be held will be heralded as "National Advertising Week," he added.

During the century and more since Waterloo only two extensive reorganizations of the British Army have been carried out. The first was by Edward Cardwell seventy years ago. Viscount Haldane was the second, almost midway between his predecessor's and successor's.
J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, today issued a call for statements on the condition of national banks as of March 7.

The former Vietor property in Elmhurst, Queens, including the old Vietor homestead dating back to Colonial times, has been sold by the State Insurance Department as liquidator of the Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company.
Mayor La 'Guardia sent to the Legislature today a bill which would permit the city to-condemn and tear down any or all of the elevated lines in the city at "bargain prices."

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Brockway, daughter of Mrs. Fred John Brockway of 57 East Eightyeighth Street and the late. Dr. Brockway, to Harold S. Osborne of Upper Montclair, N. J., will take place at noon on March 24 in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest.
A. Grant Stockweather, former Livingston County Assemblyman, died today in his home here. He was 66 years old. He had been active in political and fraternal circles.
Town Hall, 11 A. M. "The Americas and World Peace," Edward Tomlinson. Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "World-wide Current Events," Mrs. Henry R. Caraway.

The Metropolitan Savings Bank sold 218 Eldridge St for $4,000 to the Lakeden Realty Corp, Jacob Silverman, president, who gave a purchase money thereon to the 306 East 74th St Corp for $3,000. due in three years at 5 per cent.

Thirty-two children, ranging in age from 6 to 15, will receive medals, ribbons or special prizes for the beat notebooks submitted in connection with the Philharmonic-Symphony Youth Concerts, tomorrow morning at Carnegie Hall at the sixth and last event of the series.

The quarterly statements of banks in this city, issued today, disclosed shrinkages in loans and deposits as of March 7. The statements were made in response to calls issued by the Controller of the Currency and the State Auditor.

Conway J. Cohalan, the thirteenth member of his family to attend Manhattan College, will captain the 1938-39 Jasper swimming team. He is the ninth Cohalan to represent the uptown institution in athletics, and is a cousin of Neil J. Cohalan, coach of varsity basketball and star of the Jasper eleven of 1927.

Serious disorders in various Austrian cities were precipitated by Nazis in protest aginst the plebiscite ordered for Sunday. In Vienna adherents of the Fatherland Front engaged in fights with them. More troops were ordered to Graz. Government efforts to gain support of the labor elements did not succeed.

Winners in a seven-hour battle against storm, poor radio reception and darkness, the seven passengers and crew of three aboard American Airliners' transcontinental sleeper plane, the Southerner, arrived here today after making a forced landing on a plantation field outside of Richlands, N. C.

Miss Jean Berry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Hall Berry of Montclair, N. J., has chosen the afternoon of May 20 for her marriage to John Hunter Walton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Walton of Brooklyn.

Confirmation of a contemplated change in the Yankee lineup for 1938 came today from Manager Joe McCarthy after he had watched-his Yannigans gang up on Charley Ruffing and hammer the right-hander for eight hits and six runs to down the Regulars, 6-4, in the came's second scrub game.

Dr. Francis A. Auleta, a practicing physician in this city for thirtyfive years, died yesterday at the Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 23 Union Avenue, Mamaroneck.
A sharp decline which began last October in New York State factory payrolls and employment was reported checked today by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

Declaring that business is "mentally sick," Dr. Louis E. Bisch, well known psychiatrist, yesterday urged captains of industry to stop "passing the buck," to call a moratorium on conferences, to rout fear and to get down to work.

In a stirring climax to a long match, Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club, former champion, yesterday rallied to win in the fifth game of his third-round test in the national amateur squash tennis championship.
Carl Ross, secretary of the Young Communists League, Inc., refused today to tell a Senate committee whether he would bear arms against Soviet Russia in case of war.

Senator Wheeler of Montana declared today that the Pennsylvania Railroad was "likely to milk the Wabash for the benefit of its own line." He made the statement while questioning witnesses at a Senate inquiry into railroad financing.

H. Gordon Selfridge Jr., director of Selfridge's of London, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen on a combined vacation and business trip. He will arrange for the visit of four employes of the store's provincial shops on a merchandising study tour.

Miss Kathryn Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Taylor of this place, will be married to M. Edgerton Newcomb, son of Mrs. Mortimer E. Newcomb, also of Westfield, on March 19 at the home of her parents.
Their most severe decline in many weeks was registered yesterday by railroad bonds in slightly more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

Dick Merrill said tonight that he would take off from Boston on a flight for Ireland next month, with Lord Forbes, 23-year-old British flying enthusiast and a nephew of the late Ogden L. Mills, as a possible companion.

The State Labor Conferenee adopted unanimously today. a resolution, at Premier A. G. Ogilvie's request, favoring the introduction of universal physical home defense training. Mr. Ogilvie said the resolution reflected

An order has been issued by the Federal Trade Commission directing Prendergast-Davies Company, Ltd., 601 West Twenty-sixth Street, New York, to abstain from certain unfair methods of competition in the sale of Sandy MacNab whisky, an imported product, it was announced here today.

A six-hour conference of spokesmen of the National Maritime Union, C. I. 0., and shipowners on the subject of new wage contracts was held yesterday afternoon at the offices of the American Steamship Owners Association. 11 Broadway.

D. C. Stephenson, former Indiana Ku Klux Klan leader serving life imprisonment for the death of Madge Oberholtzer, today made his seventh- legal attempt for freedom by filing, through his attorney, Mayor Alban Smith of Laporte, a petition for a writ of error coram nobis, which would reopen his case.

The French frano yesterday dropped further down to levels of depreciation it had not touched since 1926, when Poincare was saving it from its post-war collapse. On the news of the resignation of the Cabinet of Premier Camille Chautemps the exchange declined 3 points to 3.15 1/8 cents, the cheapest quotation since Oct. 30, 1926.

Feeling in excellent spirits, as well as he might be after seeing his Giants score their third straight exhibition victory yesterday by walloping the Phillies in Biloxi, Miss., Colonel Bill Terry took time out today to fire a verbal broadside into a new foeman who seems to be getting into his hair.
Continued dealing in the stock of Distilled Liquors Corporation, even

Ira H. Hubbel, who retired in 1935 as assistant to the general freight traffic manager of the New York Central Railroad for serving the company for fifty-two years, died of pneumonia yesterday at Misericordia Hospital. He lived at 312 West Ninety-third Street. His age was 70.

Alexander Langille, 26 years old, was killed and Victor Petelle, 25, was injured seriously today by falling brick at the bottom of a Delaware aqueduct shaft being sunk near here. Both men were laborers

According to an announcement received here by wireless Mrs. Kathleen Lawrence, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry G. Flint of Tanglelands, East Grinstead, Sussex, England, was married yesterday at East Grinstead to William Bruce May Jr. of New York and Ardsley-on-Hudson, N. Y.

Wholesale prices advanced again in the week ended on March 5, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The agency's index, based on 100 as representing the 1926 level, rose to 79.8 from 79.6 the preceding week, and compared with 86.1 on March 6, 1937.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation will refrain from unloading properties it has acquired through foreclosure except at "fair values and in quantities the market can absorb," Colonel Harold Lee, Deputy General Manager in charge of property management, declared yesterday.

Austro-German relations again entered a period of stress and strain that compromises the "German peace" Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg concluded at Berchtesgaden last month and celebrated by Hitler in his Reichstag speech on Feb. 20.

The Maroons just about ruined Detroit's hopes for a play-off berth tonight by defeating the Red Wings, 3 to 2, in a National Hockey League game marked by half a dozen penalties for fighting. Herbie Cain clinched the match for the Maroons, scoring two goals, one of them at 15:20 of the third period.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

Marching two abreast, with cards on their hats proclaiming themselves as the "Dressmakers' Brigade," 2,000 members of the Dressmakers Union staged a mass demonstration at 8 A. M. yesterday on West Thirty-fifth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues,

On his ninety-first birthday today, sixty-three years after his invention of animated screen pictures, forerunners of Mickey Mouse and associates, Caspar W. Briggs of this city received the distinguished service award of the Pennsylvania Arts and Sciences Society.
About forty wholesale liquor salesmen employed by the Federal Wine and Liquor Company, wholesalers, of 220 Hopkins Avenue, here, went on strike today and started picketing the offices of the company.
A contract was awarded by the War Department today to the Corbitt Company of Henderson, N. C., for fourteen six-ton, two-wheel semitrailer motor vehicles at a cost of $10,026.68.

M. L. Wilson, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, told the Senate Committee on Unemployment today that a new type of decentralized industrial community which would permit young people to raise some of their own produce on small acreage in their spare time was a partial answer to the problem of the millions of potential younger farmers now dammed up on farms.

The Maritime Association appealed yesterday to the Federal Government to eliminate provisions of the reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Great Britain which it maintains are unfair to the United States ports and have caused a diversion of freight to Canadian ports.
The Peoria Eastern Railway Company was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue at not less than par and accrued interest a promissory note for not more than $500,000.

The story of how a building-material company restored an abandoned sugar business to a thriving industry in Louisiana was told yesterday at a hearing in a stockholders' suit to bar a proposed stock transaction of the company.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Trowbridge of 895 Park Avenue and Noroton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Joan Trowbridge, to Kevin G. Rafferty.
Movements of vessels follow; all dates are March 9 unless otherwise specified: Culebra to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Badger, Decatur, Fairfax, Jacob Jones.
The annual report of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for 1937, issued yesterday. shows a net income after all expenses and charges of $3,768,777.

" The Life of Emile Zola" was adjudged the outstanding production of the year, Spencer Tracy was declared the blue ribbon-actor of the year for his work in "Captains Courageous" and Luise Rainer (the only artist to win the prize a second time)

With the door apparently closed definitely to diversion of highway construction funds or to new taxes to produce money for unemployment relief, Governor Moore proposed today to a group of State fiscal officers and legislators .that the municipalities carry the entire load this year,
President Manuel Quezon, denied having toasted. "the King, His Majesty Victor Emmanuel, Emperor of Abyssinia," at a reception today for the Italian good-will mission on its way to Japan.
Mrs. Spencer Turner, who returned recently from Hawaii, entertained with a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Mrs. Fisher Whitney.

James S. Hayden, an organizer and past president of the Flatlands Post of the American Legion, 2,295 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, died Wednesday at the Veterans Hospital in Washington after a short illness, according to word received here last night. He was 51 years old.

Daily average sales of variety stores in February were about 3 per cent below February, 1937, although the sales increased about 10 per cent from January, slightly less than the usual seasonal amount, the Department of Commerce announced today.

The Very Rev. Joseph Victor Ducattillon of the Dominican Order, who resides in Paris, will preach a series of Lenten sermons in his native language in the French Catholic Church of St. Vincent de Paul, West Twenty-third Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.

Following several days of intensified counter-espionage - activities around Long Island air fields, Federal authorities yesterday arraigned Otto Hermann Voss, a naturalized German mechanic employed in the Seversky aircraft plant, for espionage. Waiving examination, Voss was held in $10,000 bail.

The House passed the new Tax Bill today after three hours of continuous voting, in which a roll-call confirmed its former informal action eliminating a special levy of 20 per cent on the income of large closely held corporations. Adopted in place of the "third basket" surtax were new taxes on liquor and imported pork products. Final passage was voted 294 to 97.

Sixty-four candidates for varsity football honors at Princeton University gathered in the Nassau Tavern tonight to welcome Old Nassau's recently appointed gridiron staff at the annual Spring football dinner. Six weeks of out-of-season
The National Labor Relations Board issued its fourth complaint against the Ford Motor.Company today.. This time it charged the firm's Chicago plant with five violations of the Wagner Act.

The Attorney General's investigation of -the collapse of Richard Whitney Co. revealed yesterday that Whitney had used securities belonging to the Gratuity Fund of the New York Stock Exchange until E. H. H. Simmons, who preceded him. as president of the Exchange, insisted on their return safely last November.

City College's varsity wrestling team turned back Temple University, 22 to 6, at the Commerce Center of City College last night. The Beaver grapplers won five of the eight matches and gained draws in two.

German force has struck again, and this time its accomplishment is the conquest of Austria in every sense except that of outright annexation. The Schuschnigg Cabinet has. been forced to resign at the point of an ultimatum from Berlin.
There are no fewer than 2,000 masses said by priests every day in Barcelona alone and there are about 3,000 priests living peaceably in this city administering all the sacraments freely.

British and American sailors "took over" Manila today. A thousand seamen from warships of the two countries were entertained last night as guests of the city. A similar number was expected to appear tonight.

Not since the early days of the civil war when Generalissimo Francisco Franco's troops marched from Seville to the gates of Madrid via Badajoz and Toledo has his army made such a rapid advance as in the first three days of its offensive in Central Aragon.

A heated meeting of the Actors Equity Association held yesterday at the Ambassador Theatre 215 West Forty-seventh Street, required the presence of the police when right and left wing members clashed over allegations that attempts were being made to set up a special division for WPA actors.
Censorship has started. An order posted in the correspondents' room in the Central Telegraph Office tonight said all telephone conversations from the room must be in German.
The Merchants Association of New York filed a statement with a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today opposing the O'Mahoney- Borah Corporation Licensing Bill.

President Roosevelt today reasserted his commitment to the Federal Work Relief policy of the Administration, and within the hour 400 delegates from 150 cities -to the Community Mobilization for Human Needs took direct issue with him, going on record without a dissenting voice in

With unconcealed satisfaction Manager Joe McCarthy today put his world champion Yankees through their last training drill at Huggins Field before the beginning of the club's thirty-game exhibition schedule.
The Jersey City Chamber of Commerce Building Association is named defendant in a foreclosure action started yesterday by Mulligan Koenig, attorneys for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

Thousands of swastika banners are being carried by crowds of Nazis in the main streets of Vienna early today after a night of widespread demonstrations, which became violent shortly before midnight with the breaking of windows in Jews' shops.
In a report issued yesterday to employes of the General Electric Company it announced that $5,761,000 was earned under the general profit-sharing plan in 1937, compared with $2,938,000 in 1936.
The State Motor Vehicle Bureau called on police today for more stringent enforcement of the law requiring lights, front and rear reflectors, horns and adequate brakes on bicycles.

Opening a drive for its sixth consecutive New England championship, Brown University's well-balanced swimming team tonight qualified sixteen men in eight events as the fifteenth annual New England intercollegiate meet got under way at Amherst College's Pratt pool.

The Governmental Reorganization Bill debate was resumed in the Senate today, with Senators Burke and McNary assailing the "broad powers" conferred upon the President to regroup or abolish Independent agencies.

Two old friends of the pre - war, pre - Spanish War era have been with us in the news the last few days. It is good in these troubled times to see their honest faces again. Higher freight rates have just been granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission, and the I. C. C. was born fifty-one years ago in Grover Cleveland's first Administration.
The total capitalization of the Chicago North Western Railway Company, which the Interstate Commerce Commission should find permissible in the reorganization of that railroad, is approximately

At the very moment when German troops were crossing the Austrian frontier the British Government tonight delivered to Berlin one of the sharpest protests it has yet made in its post-war relations with Germany.
The Southern Pacific Company expended $32,588,000 on additions and betterments in 1937, according to the annual report of Hale Holden, president, issued yesterday.

Walter O'Keefe, entertainer, in Hotel Ambassador. Albert M. Pellegrini, in 181 E 93d St; Augustine K. Liechty, in 2,728 Spuyten Duyvil Parkway; First Madison Corp, broker. Mary Ellen Rourke, Robert S. Genteel, B. Harrison Newmann, Jeanne Hightmann, May Munsey, in Town House, 108 E 38th

Mgr. John F. Hickey of the Archdiocese of Cincinnati and spiritual director of the archdiocese Holy Name Society, died today at the rectory of St. Matthew's Church, Norwood, Ohio. Mgr. Hickey was noted for his unusual ability as a speaker.

Radio inquiries througholy Communist eighth route army in Shansi have failed to trace Dr. Norman Bethune, Montreal surgeon, and Miss Jane Ewen, a nurse of Vancouver, B. C., who left Hankow two weeks ago for Shansi to do army medical work.

Royal Reveler, a chestnut gelding owned by Miss Wilhelmine S. Kirby of Camden and Bedford Hills, N. Y., carried off blue ribbons in the middle and heavyweight hunter and open sweepstakes classes to take top honors for the first day of the Twenty-eighth Camden Horse Show on the estate of Mrs. Marion du Pont Scott today.

Governor Lehman today signed the Crews bill creating the New York City Parkway Authority. The Authority will absorb the Henry Hudson and Marine Parkway Authorities and use their spare borrowing capacity to finance parkway improvements in the Rockaways.
A total of $292,600,000 of openmarket commercial paper was outstanding on Feb. 28, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This is compared to

The Jamestown Furniture Market Association will hold its semiannual furniture market here April 27 to May 7, officials of the group announced today. The exhibition of new designs is expected to attract more than 1,000 buyers from all parts of the country.

A stamp-pad ink that penetrates most kinds of paper so quickly that there is little or no blurring of the impressions when they are rubbed immediately after they are made has been developed by C. E. Waters, chemist of the National Bureau of Standards, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Partners in two brokerage houses, one now defunct, were censured publicly yesterday by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, for carelessness in permitting the late Harold Russell Ryder, paroled from Sing Sing Prison, to which he had been sentenced for fraud, to, trade with them.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES reveals the plans of the Municipal Civil Service Commission to abolish forty-one exempt positions in the.Marriage License Bureau and fill these jobs with fifteen clerks from the Grade 1 list. The account stated that these clerks "would receive an average of less than $2,000, so the saving would be more than $70,000."

To forestall further criticisms of the Air Ministry Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today promoted the Earl of Winterton, Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, to a seat at the Cabinet table. Until now he has been minister without cabinet rank.

Mrs. Eugene H. Outerbridge and Mrs. J. E. Grote Higgens will sail today for Bermuda. They will be at the Princess Hotel for several weeks. Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Copley Thaw are passing a few days in Washington.
One British soldier was killed today as troops, planes and armored cars were brought into action in Palestine's "bloody triangle" against 300 Arab rebels.

The Federal Trade Commission set March 16 as a date for resumption of hearings on proposed rules for the wool textile industry after an all-day conference today, at which the rules were discussed in detail but during which several of those in attendance denied they officially represented the groups with which they were associated.
PATROLMAN--Joseph F. Myers, First District Traffic, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Jan. 3, 1910.

So much of paragraph 3, Special Orders 52, dated March 4, 1938, as continues Capt. Michael L. Mitchell, Med.-Res., on active duty with the CCC until June 23, 1938, is amended so as to continue him on active duty until June 12, 1938.

Four men and two women were arrested yesterday in front of District Office 72 of the Department of Public Welfare at 73 Stone Street. in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, on charges of disorderly conduct following a noisy disturbance in the relief bureau.
The House Immigration Committee recommended legislation today to deny citizenship to aliens belonging to organizations advocating other than democratic forms of government. Reporting the bill to the
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 5 amounted to 552,916 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced. today.

For the second time in two days Richard Whitney, senior partner of the brokerage film which bears his name and former president of the New York Stock Exchange, was arrested, fingerprinted, photographed, haled into court and held in bail yesterday on a charge of grand larceny in the first degree.
The appointment of William B. Reed as chief of the cost and sale realization division of the Bureau of Research and Statistics was announced by the National Bituminous Coal Commission today. Mr.

Judge Carroll Hincks of Federal court issued an order today allowing a common claim of $19,200,000 by bondholders of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company against the estate of the New Haven Railroad, now undergoing reorganization.
The Yokohama Specie Band, Ltd., has reported a net profit of 6,238,899 yen for the half-year ended on Dec. 31 after provision for bad and doubtful debts. This amount,

Conflicting views on Secretary Hull's policy of reciprocal trade agreements were presented today to 250 members of the New England Council in quarterly meeting. Analysis of replies to a council questionnaire was reported to show opposition to the treaties among New England manufacturers in the ratio of seven to one. James W.

Roscoe -Fertich of Muncie, Ind., secretary of the War Minerals Commission of the Interior Department, fell dead tonight at a reception given by the Indiana State Society for Paul V. McNutt, High Commissioner to the Philippines.

Thomas Wharton Sampson Phillips of Shadow Lake, this place, has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of his daughter, Miss Nancy Phillips of Kitchawan and New York, to Dr. Alvin Wilcox Howland of Philadelphia, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Alvin Howland of Adrian, Mich.
The Society of Jesus, the Catholic Church's famed, far-flung missionary organization, today opened its first general convocation in fifteen years.

Colonel Charles B. Hoyt of Sandwich, for several years president of the New Hampshire Old Home Week Association, died today at the Laconia Hospital after a short illness. His age was 78. For 36 years he had served as selectman in Sandwich.

THEY order these things differently in Hollywood, of course. To suggest the Civil War nothing less would do than a thunderous cycle of battles streaming with blood and guns and flags. Yet in that short and magnificent film, "The River," Pare Lorentz has another way.
Ernest G. Draper, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to membership on the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 11, unless specified: At San Francisco: Tuscaloosa, March 1; Arctic. At San Diego: Aylwin, March 7; Melville. At Coronado Roads, March 10; Saratoga.
Joe DiMaggio observed today: "I suppose it will wind up with the ballplayer signing the contract, as he usually does."
Macmillan has received from London advance sheets of "Pavements at Anderby," by Winifred Holtby, author of "South Riding" and "Letters to a Friend." The book will be published here in April.

George Arliss, whose performance in "Disraeli" is remembered as his outstanding contribution to the screen, is to revive the title character in "Suez" upon completion of negotiations between the actor and

Orders for pressed and blown glassware have become more plentiful this month and in some lines new business booked is ahead of the corresponding period last year, The American Glass Review will say today.

The Brazilian Ambassador to Peru, Lucillo Antonio da Cunha Bueno, died of heart disease at 2 o'clock this morning in the embassy a few hours after he had presented his credentials to President Benavides:

Department store sales in the metropolitan area fell sharply last week, with the volume of New York and Brooklyn establishments off 13.3 per cent and that of Newark stores down 17.6 per cent, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

An original musical comedy, "'39 Steps," concerning the attempt of the-students to raise money for a new building for the college, was presented by the Junior Class of Barnard College last night in Brinckerhoff Theatre on the campus.

With the lag in retail distribution accentuated by further employment and payroll cuts, retail sales this week dropped 2 to 5 per cent below the week before and 6 to 13 per cent under the corresponding period a year ago, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Assertions that Congress would. not tolerate any "partnership" with England or any other nation in the' control or ownership of any islands were made in the Senate today by Senators Lewis and Johnson, who coupled events in Europe

Secretary Wallace told the Senate Unemployment Committee today that although the Farm Security Administration had made a promising start in aiding destitute families to become self-supporting, "the job cannot be completed for many years."
