Electus Taylor Backus, a real esestate operator with the firm of Brown, Wheelock, Harris Stevens, 67 Wall Street, died Thursday at St. Luke's Hospital after a month's illness. Mr. Backus, who lived on North Wilton Road, Ridgefield, Conn., was 49 years old.

Declaring his allegiance to Thomas P. Kennedy for the Democratic nomination for Governor in Pennsylvania, Senator Joseph F. guffey formally broke with his colleagues, Governor Earle and State Chairman Lawrence, today.

Sino-Japanese hostilities in Shansi Province and North Honan have become warfare virtually without fronts between detached contingents. Rival troops are attacking each other from all points of the compass in a sort of magnified guerrilla struggle.

Ray Schwartz assigned to Hyman Joe Schechter a mortgage for $10,200 on 50-52 3d St. Two mortgages were assigned to Ruth Rosenstock and three others on 55. E 103d st: $7,500 by Max Sprung and $14,000 by Ray Reuben.

Edward T. Pierce, Police Superintendent, announced today that a woman's body discovered Monday in' a power turbine here had been positively identified as that of Mrs. Helen Werne, 45, a Buffalo housewife. Coroner Harry R. Emes said

ADLER--Joseph, on March 11, devoted father of Jesse, Herminie Cohen; beloved brother of Henrietta Levy, Clara Lyona and Birdie Adler. Funeral strictly private. BACKUS--On March 10, Electus T., son of the late Dr. Brady E. and Annie T. Backus of Ridgefield, Conn.
Trailing at the intermission, 9-8, the Immaculata High School basketball team rallied to beat St. Agnes High School, 27-22, on the winner's court yesterday.

WHOA up a minute! It was only, yesterday that General Hugh Johnson suggested President Robert Maynard Hutchins, of the University off Chicago as a non-political he go-getter" who might point the way out of the economic mess this country is in. But before Dr. Hutchins accepts the nomination there is something else he might clear up.

The Brazilian military mission visiting Chile on a good-will tour continued its inspection of the army, the aviation corps and military headquarters today. The mission is headed by General Pedro Goes Monteiro, chief of the Brazilian Army.

Mayor Wilson today made cuts totaling $1,023,455 in the city budget for 1938 and then returned the ordinance to the City Council, which he criticized in a ten-page message for passing a "hocus-pocus budget."
As had been indicated previously, the Association of American Railroads made known yesterday that it would seek to restore to the law the principle of fair return on investment in rate-making.

Art property of the late Mr. and Mrs. Percy A. Rockefeller removed from Owenoke Farm, Greenwich, Conn., brought $10,562 yesterday afternoon at the first of two auction sessions at the Parke-Bernet Galleries. The second session will take place this afternoon.
Playing for the final time in America this season, Colonel De Basil's Ballet Russe appeared tonight at the County Center here before an audience of 3,500 persons.

Mrs. Ethel Smolens, one of two women who, with ten men, are on trial in General Sessions in the alleged $2,000,000 Slovak Manor land fraud conspiracy, and an unidentified man made misrepresentations to Supreme Court Justice John H.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Price of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lillian Gertrude Price, to Alanson R. Fredericks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roswell T. Fredericks of Syracuse.
The strike in Stockholm's hotels and restaurants ended today. Meals were served in them for the first time since Jan. 17.

Robert H. Parsons, vice president of the Pacific Company, confirmed today a repot that he and various members of the Pacific Company's organization, together with Paul Buhlig, investment banker of Chicago, were negotiating with the Pacific Finance Corporation, owner of the Pacific Company, for the purchase of a substantial interest in it. This report was confirmed also by officials of Pacific Finance.

Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia climbed back into a tie for first place in the world pocket billiard tournament by defeating Onofrio Lauri of Brooklyn, 125 to 70, in thirteen innings, at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy last night.
THE HILL BETWEEN, a play in three acts, by Lula Vollmer. Staged by Robert Porterfield; setting by Tom Adrian Cracraft; produced by Robert Porterfield. At the Little Theatre.

21st St, 207-9 E, 2 5-story tenements, 47x 98.9; Central Savings Bank of N Y against Leo H. Larkin; due, $36,543; taxes, etc, $2,582; to plaintiff for $40,814. By RALPH W. LONG 22d St, 151-5 W. 2 5-story tenements, 67.6x 98.7; Dry Dock Savings Institution against Kate Meinken; due, $80,117; to plaintiff for $1;000.
Herbert Hoover today visited this ancient capital of the Kingdom of Poland. He was met at the station by a peasant band in provincial costumes and many notables.
The volume of new bond financing this week dropped sharply from the preceding period and, for the fifth consecutive week, was restricted exclusively to tax-exempt issues. The total of only $2,054,000

At least five attractions are going away from Broadway after tonight, three of them fairly long-term enterprises, two much shorter. The list includes "Many Mansions," from the Forty-fourth Street (157 performances); "Amphitryon 38,"

The attempt to enact the Administration's $1,120,000,000 Naval Construction Bill began this afternoon, when without a roll-call the House adopted a rule making the. bill its unfinished business and limiting debate to twelve hours.
Bishop Loughlin High School turned back La Salle M. A., 46 to 33, in the final of Manhattan College's invitation interscholastic basketball tournament last night.

Deciding that it was necessary to cut operating expenses because of the recession in traffic, increased taxes and higher prices of materials and supplies, the board of directors of the Association of American

Scoring heavily in every event except one, St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn carried off the team championship for the fourth consecutive year at the thirteenth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools swimming championships in the Columbia University pool last night.

Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey yesterday hailed as a "magnificent enterprise" the Silver Jubilee International Flower Show which opens Monday in Grand Central Palace. In a letter to Richardson Wright, chairman of the committee of the show, he declared that he was "proud and happy" that New Jersey was to have a share in it.

Columbia's fencers outpointed M. I. T. tonight, 152 to 10. Columbia took a 5-to-4 lead in the foils matches and Tech came back in the epee competition with 6 1/2 points to Columbia's 2 1/2. Tech was no match
Manufacturing and selling organizations furnished a large part of the commercial renting activity reported yesterday. Several entire floors were leased in the downtown mercantile district.

The Toms River striped bass "war" waxes and wanes, but continues to be topic of conversation and argument. We've had a number of letters on the situation down there, and since our recent statement to the effect that the men taking sixty or more fish a day were "fishermen, but not sportsmen." we've had a lot more.

Dr. William Albert Wirt, originator of the internationally known Gary School Plan and Superintendent of Schools in Gary since 1906, died this morning of a heart attack in his home at 760 Jackson Street. He was 64 years old.

Mrs. Eleanor Lassoe Savage of 123 East Thirty-fourth Street, daughter of Mrs. William Henry Lawrence of San Francisco and the late Jules A. Lassoe of this city, was married to Wilfred Waite Williams of New York yesterday afternoon at the Pierre.
Officials were gravely concerned today over the Austrian crisis, but Secretary of State Cordell Hull said there was nothing the United States intended to do about it.

As German soldiers were reported marching into Austria, alumni of Chicago University recalled a class they had attended on June 12, 1936. They were addressed by Frederick L. Schumnan, then Assistant Professor of Political Science on the Midway.
Here is a summary of the proceedings at President Roosevelt's inquiry into the intra-directorate row in the Tennessee Valley Authority as it took place today in the Executive offices:
The longsuffering stock markets here were depressed by today's Austrian developments and prices closed lower in practically every section.

Approximately 75 women from Pennsylvania, New York and the New England States tonight attended the opening events of the first New England Swimming Conference for Women, which will be concluded at Smith College tomorrow.

Miss Luz Davila, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Carlos Davila of this city, and Miss Anne-Marie Errante, daughter of Baron and Baroness Guido Errante, also of New York, were introduced to society yesterday at a reception and dance given for them by Mr. and Mrs. M.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation is undertaking proceedings in the Mexican courts, through Las Truchas Company, a subsidiary, to prevent if possible the proposed forfeiture of its iron ore deposits in the State of Michoacan, it was learned at headquarters of the company yesterday.

FITZPATRICK, ELIZABETH (April 27, 1937). Gross assets, $26,133; net, $24.099, To estate of Bridget F. Wheat and Ellen Fitzpatrick, sister. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $11,704. Scudder, McCoun, Stockton Kerfoot, attorneys, 25 Broadway.

The Indians learned today that Rollie Hemsley, catcher who was sent to his Missouri farm this week for breaking training, would rejoin them early next week. Manager Oscar Vitt would not announce a date for Hemsley's return, but almost every one on the team seemed to think he had set the time when the catcher left.

THE STORY OF INSTRUCTION. THE CHURCH, THE RENAISSANCES, AND THE REFORMATION, by Ernest Carroll Moore. (Macmillan, $4.) A continuation of Dr. Moore's previous Volume, "The Story of Instruction: The Beginnings."

It is increasingly evident .that the era of "rubber-stamp" legislation has ended in Washington and that Congress intends to assert its. own prerogatives in the matter of shaping national policies. Yesterday the House of Representatives rejected for the second time, and this time by a roll-call vote which
L. E. Foulkrod, for fifteen years regional sales director of the Star Brush Manufacturing Company, Inc., has been elected vice president in charge of sales and a director of the company.

Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address at the annual meeting of the Mobilization for Human Needs: I am happy again to greet the faithful workers assembled for their annual meeting in behalf of this national mobilization for human needs.

Ruling that "it would be setting a very bad. precedent" to permit a company "to come into court on behalf of defendants for a fee and pay fines," Magistrate Bernard Mogilesky refused yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court to allow a messenger from the Postal Telegraph Company to plead guilty and pay a fine for a client.

Accusing Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers of "sabotage, discrimination and racketeering," Isaac Penner, an electrical contractor of 200 West 'Seventy-second Street, announced last night he had laid off all the union men employed by him on five school and hospital jobs.

Townsend B. Martin's Bigey, champion 2-year-old here a year ago, returned to action today after being shelved since last October and displayed his old speed in winning the featured Hollywood Purse of five and a half furlongs at Tropical Park.

Consumer response to the battery of nine millinery windows displayed by Lord Taylor this week has enabled their millinery department to show a 39 per cent increase in millinery sales for the first three days of the week over the similar period last year, Walter Hoving, president of the store, announced yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Amory L. Haskell entertained with a large dinner at the Beach Club today where Mr. and Mrs. William S. Gould had a small group.

After a brief ownership, Loomis J. Grossman has sold the six-story apartment at 30 Crary Avenue, Mount Vernon, Westchester, to an investing client of J. J. Goodman, broker, for cash above the first mortgage of $157,000, which was extended for five years.
The William HNichols medal for excellence in chemical research-was awarded to Dr. Phoebus A. Levene of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research at a dinner at Lhe Hotel Pennsylvania last night.
Thousands of foreigners who have entered Brazil as tourists and remained after the legal time limit had expired are now in danger of expulsion.
Senate investigators heard testimony today that the Bethlehem Steel Corporation paid $10,000 to officials of the Johnstown Citizens Committee to "carry on" during the steel strike last June.

Miss Alison Bruere entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room of Sherry's for Miss Susanna W. P. Wilson, daughter of Paul C. Wilson of Washington and Mrs. Wilson (Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins), whose marriage to David Meredith Hare will take place today in the Church of the Resurrection.

The San Antonio Typographical Union today sent to unions throughout the country and to the Texas delegation in Congress a resolution asking Congressional investigation of the newspaper print stock situation.

The State, school and teacher should cooperate in combating the "great dangers" of "loose thinking, criminal living and organized effort for an overthrow" of the nation's democracy, State Senator Joseph R. Hanley declared last, night in opening the fourteenth annual junior high school conference, sponsored by the New York University School of Education.

It was learned here tonight that yesterday the French and British Governments jointly sounded out Italy as to whether cooperation could be expected in maintaining Austrian independence and that they received a firm negative reply.

Krogstad. A. N. (Lt. Col.), appointed as wing commander, with temporary rank of brigadier general, Air Corps, ordered from Kelly Field, Texas, to duty as wing commander, Second Wing, G. H. Q. Air Force, Langley Field, Hampton, Vs..

Mrs. Charlotte L. Richardson, widow of Charles F. P. Richardson, one of the older members of the Newport colony, died tonight at her residence, Beech Lodge. Mrs. Richardson was born in New York, the daughter of the late Clarence Pell and Annie Pell, and was the last of her immediate family, though she leaves several nephews and nieces.

Twelve hundred members of the Workers Alliance picketed the central offices of the Department of Welfare, 902 Broadway, for an hour and a half, beginning at noon, yesterday in a demand for more clothing for home relief recipients.

This is the way Chancellery sources here tonight pictured the march of the bloodless revolution in its critical hours. In the early afternoon yesterday, Wilhelm Keppler, German State Secretary, arrived by airplane.
A 49-year-old son of the service, Colonel S. T. Wood, was chosen today as head of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, succeeding Commissioner Sir James MacBrien, who died in Toronto last week.

The news from Austria struck Italy with the impact of an exploding bomb and left the official world here aghast. An official spokesman told an unusually large audience of newspaper men this evening that the Italian Government considered the situation so grave that it did not feel it could make any statement at present.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jay Madden of Brookside Park, this place, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Audrey Hammond Madden, to William Henry Chickering, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Lawrence Chickering of Piedmont, Calif.

Reports from Austria kept Berlin in turmoil after the noon hour yesterday and there was undisguised jubilation over the fall of the Schuschnigg Government and the emergence of a National Socialist regime in Austria.

Describing himself as an example of the folly of betting on horse races,-Henry B. Baumgarten of the United States Hotel, 263 Bowery, a gray-haired man who appeared older than his 56 years, was held without bail yesterday for a hearing next Friday by Magistrate Pinto in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, on a charge of being a fugitive from justice.

Revelations that the Spanish Government had in various ways been approached to come to an understanding with Italy and Germany, and so end the war, were made to this correspondent today by Premier Juan Negrin.
Penn Charter School, interacademic champion, closed its basketball season by defeating Horace Mann of New York on the Queen Lane floor today, 33 to 31.

A hearing has been called by the Securities and Exchange Commission for March 29 on an application by the Federal Water Service Corporation, New York City, for the approval of its acquisition of 5,000

The Philadelphia National Bank reported as of March 7 total deposits of $366,913,132 and total assets of $417,903,875, compared, respectively, with $370,312,761 and $423,027,158 on Dec. 31 last. The bank showed cash on hand and due from banks of $136,412,876, against $137,062,925; United States Government

The recent decline in vacancies in old New York tenements lends added interest to the measure recently approved in the State Legislature, and now awaiting action by the Governor, providing a new system of demolition for residential buildings which are deemed hazardous.

Miss Ruth Audrey Perry, daughter of Clay Perry, novelist, and Mrs. Perry, was married tonight to Howard McLean Graham of Pittsfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walton C. Graham of Denver. The ceremony was performed at Pilgrim Memorial Church, with the Rev. Wilfred T. Bunker, pastor, officiating.

With Dr. Serge Koussevitzky conducting, the Boston Symphony Orchestra presented last night the fourth concert of its current series in Brooklyn before a capacity audience in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

The London Times, which has been the foremost advocate- of AngloGerman reconciliation, this morning takes Germany sharply to task for her "open exhibition of overbearing force" and so follows the general line taken by all British newspapers editorially.

The engagement of Miss Eleanor Swift, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Swift of this city, to Lawrence Lowell Reeve, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Stanley Reeve of Brookthorpe, Haverford, Pa., has been announced by her parents.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, who arrived here shortly before Christmas, sailed early this morning on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen for their home in England. During the three months they have been here, Colonel Lindbergh has been engaged in neggtiations on behalf of the Pan American Airways, with which he is associated.

War talk coming at a time when the trade regarded the wheat market as in an oversold condition sent prices up nearly 2 cents a bushel from the early low point on the Board of Trade here today, and while much of the buying was regarded as short covering, the close was within a fraction of the top with net gains of 1 1/4 to 1 3/8 cents.

Dr. John Rogers, who was pastor of the First Presbyterian Church here a century and a half ago, will be one of the noted Presbyterian divines of that time to be portrayed in a dramatic pageant that will open the 150th annual General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the Municipal Convention Hall, Philadelphia, May 26.

Spokesmen for all C. I. O. international unions in the New York area pledged support last night to the Transport Workers Union in that organization's fight to defeat in the Assembly the Burchill bill providing for a limited type of collective bargaining for the 5,400 employes of the city's Independent Subway System.

M. M. Wyckoff, head of the Wyckoff Engineering Corporation; John T. Briggs, architect, and Philip Morris, former president of the Seaboard Investing Corporation, have organized the WyckoffMorris Modernization Plan, with offices at 7 East Forty-second Street. The concern will specialize in modernization projects on a contractural basis.

The courage of a telephone company "trouble shooter," who braved smoke and flames to tap a wire- and give the alarm for an excelsior fire near the North River waterfront yesterday morning, enabled firemen to curb the blaze before it could spread to a dynamite shack some sixty yards away.

Mr. Mrs. C. Donald Dallas of 912 Fifth Avenue and Katonah, N. Y., formerly of Chicago and Winnetka, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Dallas, to Stanley J. Keyes Jr., son of Mrs. Stanley J. Keyes of New York and Rye and the late Dr. Keyes.
A second claim to the estate of William Slavens McNutt, film writer, was made today by a woman who said she was his widow and only legal heir.
Governor Lehman appealed publicly today for support for his savings bank life insurance plan, now blocked in the Senate because or defections among the members of his own party.

The rise of this country's January excess of merchandise exports over imports to the largest figure of any month since 1929 was remarkable by itself. When contrasted with results in the first half of 1937, it was still more noteworthy. During the six months ended with last June, imports exceeded exports by $147,321,000--for the period

B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., head of the investment banking syndicate that on Thursday purchased $60,000,000 of revenue bonds from the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission, made known yesterday some details of the transaction and of the plans for distribution of the bonds. The purchase was one

Leases of business properties and sales of houses indicated yesterday a good demand for realty in Brooklyn. An improvement in the Borough Hall section will result from the leasing by the Lemmerman estate of the northeast corner of Myrtle Avenue and Washington Street to a client of Probst Probst, attorneys. The site, a plot 85 by 83 feet,

President Roosevelt met open defiance today in his efforts to investigate dissension in the Tennessee Valley Authority when Arthur E. Morgan, chairman of the board, refused to submit evidence in support of his charges against his fellow-directors and reiterated, instead, his demand for a Congressional investigation.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The uncertainty with reference to what will be a fair operating basis in wool, after the government loan and the British trade treaty are announced, is holding. up business in wool both here and in the West. Western holders

New Jersey Democrats in Congress came to the defense of William H. Kelly today with a plea to President Roosevelt that the Newark Internal Revenue Collector receive a hearing on Secretary Morgenthau's "demand for Mr. Kelly's resignation."

A revised plan of reorganization for the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation is being prepared and will be ready for presentation to the court in the near future, Colonel H. C. Rickaby, counsel for the Atlas Corporation, proponent of the plan, told Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday.

Tremont Ave, 115-9 E, 134.2x122x irreg; S. B. Realty Corp against Caherst Operating Co; due, $7,538; taxes, etc, $2,963; to plaintiff for $1,000. By MICHAEL ERCEG Ely Ave, 3,418, dwelling, 50x95; Home Owners Loan Corp against Marguerite Roland; due. $4.839: to plaintiff for $2.000.

Thirteen four-story apartment houses at 817 to 869 Hunts Point Avenue, the Bronx, have been sold by the Carnegie Estates, Inc., Charles Krapcofi, president, to Michael Kaufman, who was an active operator and builder prior to 1929. They occupy plots 39 by 100 feet and each house contains eight apartments of seven rooms each.

Aside from having inadvertently stopped a stray ball with the bridge of his nose instead of with what perhaps are the most agile pair of hands in baseball, Dick Bartell, premier shortshop of the National League, is ready to help the Giants bag another pennant, which would be his third since coming to New York.
Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Harris issued today an order temporarily restraining Huff Haskins, Inc., securities dealers in this city, from doing business in New York State.

The frano rallied a little yesterday after its severe declines of the previous few days,- rising as far as 3.18 1/4 cents, compared with its low on Thursday of 3.15 1/3 cents, and closed at 3.17 cents, up 1 7/8 points.

The Blizzard Men of '88, who gasped their way through the most calamitous -snow, wind and rain that ever buffeted New York City, are due for a shock today. When they file into the Hotel Pennsylvania ballroom for their annual luncheon, these veterans of the great two-story high snowdrifts are to be entertained by, of all things, a mechanical snow storm.

The Jamaica and Brooklyn Technical High School hockey teams gained the berths in the final round of the city P. S. A. L. play-off tournament when each accounted for triumphs at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Jamaica downed Manual Training, 3 to 2, while Brooklyn Tech conquered New Utrecht, 2 to 0. The final is slated for Friday at the Brooklyn rink.

One of the most important members bf "the best defensive infield in the National League" (the quotes from Executive Vice President Larry MacPhail) put on a major league uniform for the first time today and immediately became the center of attention in the Dodgers' camp.

Admission of Cornell as a member of the Eastern Intercollegiate Lightweight Football League was confirmed today as George Little, president of the league and director of athletics at Rutgers, made public the business of the annual meeting in New York in January. Cornell's admission brings the membership to seven teams.
Fifty years ago today, John Dwyer started in the employ of A. B. Darling, owner of the old Fifth Avenue Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-third Street. Today,

A retraction of charges that E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. defrauded the United States Government on wartime contracts has been made by Ferdinand Lundberg, author of "America's 60 Families," and the Vanguard Press, Inc., publishers of that book.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,203,000 bales, against 1,209,000 a week ago, 1,192,000 two weeks ago, 1,192,000 three weeks ago and 941,000 a year ago; of which American 794,000
An odd freak of the weather today led to the second accident our airplane has sustained during our efforts to locate the missing Soviet airmen.

Charles E. Clift Jr. and Harry A. Poth, each of whom brought a $10,000 damage suit against Mayor Hague and two other Jersey City officials for alleged police manhandling in the seamen's strike a year ago, withdrew as plaintiffs in Federal court today.

In defiance of a letter from Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman urging city magistrates. to impose heavier fines on flower vendors, Magistrate Sabbatino suspended sentence yesterday on a peddler in Coney Island Court, declaring that "nobody can tell me what to do except my Creator, through my conscience."

New York Stock Exchange member houses, when requested by customers, must provide statements of their financial condition, under a rule adopted yesterday by the institution's governing committee. Until further notice, figures to be provided will be those for Jan. 31, contained in the firms' most recent answers to Stock Exchange questionnaires.

A sharply divided Senate Commerce Committee, after receipt of protests from operators of smaller craft, postponed today a vote on a resolution proposing Federal operation of three fast liners in the intercoastal trade.
The House of Peers passed today the supplementary military budget calling for the appropriation of 4,850,000,000 yen to meet the costs of the war in China in 1938. The measure,
With due respect for the mile record of 4:04.4 made by Glenn Cunningnam on Dartmouth's indoor track, we should consider a number of aspects before we acclaim him' the greatest miler of all time.
President Roosevelt heard the three TVA directors discuss their internecine difficulties and told them to return next Friday for another hearing.

Andrey. Y. Vishinsky, prosecutor in the treason trial of twenty-one Russians, including some of the Soviet Union's most famous former leaders, delivered a five-hour summation today and concluded with a demand for the death penalty for all but two
Snow removal this Winter has cost the city $600,000, compared with $1,032,574 last Winter, William F. Carey, Commissioner of Sanitation, said yesterday.

Plans for erecting a modern apartment house on a plot in the Chelsea area were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by a syndicate of 171 to 177 Seventh Avenue and 147 to 165 West Twentieth Street, northeast corner, from the Ehret estate.

Pleading guilty to a charge of forgery in the third degree, Felix Justice, 46 years old, of 617 East 136th Street, the Bronx; who was one of the witnesses who fled the city rather than testify against Nick Montana, vice racketeer, was sentenced yesterday to serve from five to ten years in Sing Sing by Bronx County Judge James M. Barrett.

The annual report of Standard Brands, Inc., for 1937 made public today, shows a consolidated net income of $9,865,358 after all charges, including Federal and foreign, State, municipal and other taxes with $2,290 surtax on undistributed profits.

A large trust company in New York has appointed John F. James Sons, Inc., as agents to dispose of its realty holdings in Brooklyn. Although the contract has just gone into effect, one property already has been sold and offers are being considered for several others, according to Harold R. James, president of the realty firm.

A declaration by the Konoye government that it will not apply the national mobiliation bill in the present situation has placated its opponents. The government is hopeful that the measure aow will have smooth passage.

In the inquiry being made by the Regents into the character and cost of public education in the State of New York there is a discussion of the proper size for a school district. Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo, N. Y., and Mrs. G. Sidenburg of Greenwich, Conn., will meet tomorrow in the final round of the Belmont Manor Golf Club tournament.
The Rev. Mother Marie Majoux, Superior General of The Cenacle, died of a heart ailment on Wednesday in Paris, according to word received here last night. She was 75 years old.

The precipitate decline in railroad obligations continued yesterday in more active trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. Many pivotal loans sold at the lowest levels in several years and a broad list of so-called top-grade carrier issues joined with the secondary bonds in the broad decline.
The city of Chattanooga, Tenn., will be in the market on March 29 with a new issue of $2,382,000 of electric power bonds, it became known yesterday.

The New York University women's fencing team maintained its unbeaten record with an 8-1 triumph over the previously undefeated New Jersey State Teachers College foilswomen on the New York University strips at Washington Square yesterday. Miss Mary Ann Harris, captain of the Violet coeds, won three bouts for New York to give her team- its eighth triumph in as many starts. Miss Carol Fitzsimmons was the lone victor for the Jersey City squad.
