Amid the war clouds in Europe and the topsy-turvy economic ailments of America, too little has been said of the high adventure of rescue being carried on by Sir Hubert Wilkins in the Arctic. With characteristic intrepidity and doggedness he and his self-effacing Canadian pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, their radio men and ground crew,
Andrew T. Wheeler, one of the last surviving members of the Grand Army of the Republic in Maryland, died last night at his home here. Mr. Wheeler was 94 years old.

The Board of Tax Appeals upheld today the two-way stock transactions of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon M. Bodman of New York by which they showed losses in their income tax reports. Mr. Bodman, a brokerage firm official, had appealed from income tax deficiency assessments totaling $52,291 for 1931 and 1932.
ADLER, FREDERICKA M. (Feb. 22). Estate, more than $10,000. To Morton L. Adler, husband, executor, 970 Park Ave.
James MacMaster (Big Jim) Tweed, former school teacher and one-time king of South Jersey's berry-growing industry, died yesterday at his home here following a fall. His age was 86.

New York State Conference on Marriage and the Family, Hotel Roosevelt, 9:30 A. M. Luncheon meeting, 12:30 P. M. "Marriage and the Family and the Responsibility of the State," Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, Dr. Henry Pratt Fairchild,

Apparently disappointed at the refusal of the House to approve the "third basket" tax on closely held corporations, President Roosevelt said today that what the Administration had been seeking in its tax laws was to end special privilege where it occurred under existing revenue legislation.
The United Automobile Workers Packard Local 190 of Detroit broke loose in the American Bowling Congress tonight with a smashing 2,967 team score.
Newsprint production in February in Canada amounted to 202,601 tons, compared with 222,500 in January and 276,419 in February, 1937, the Newsprint Association of Canada reported today.

With tonight's games at Squadron A Armory in Manhattan and at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn, the regular indoor polo season comes to its close and the way is cleared for the start next Saturday of play-offs and the Eastern, Interscholastic and Intercollegiate championships.

Parents, not children, very often need to be educated to appreciate good music, artistic dancing, or worth-while radio programs, speakers asserted yesterday at the opening of a two-day conference on the place of cultural arts in this country.

Adolf Kuttroff, a pioneer in the dyestuff industry, left a net estate of $1,957,406 when he died March 23, 1936, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Five charitable agencies receive $10,000 each.

The investment of railroads in marine equipment at this port compares favorably with that of some shipping companies, J. J. Brinkworth, superintendent of the New York terminal district of the New York Central Railroad, told the

Cotton-mill activity increased last week. The daily average declined, but less than anticipated seasonally, and the adjusted index advanced to 87.2 from 86.2, the revised figure for the previous week. The index stood at 139.4 for the week ended March 6, 1937.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Henry Savery of Germantown have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Sophie Cope, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Stokes Cope, formerly of Awbury, Germantown, to Montague J. McGill of Oak Lane.

Aubrey Williams, director of the National Youth Administration, told a Senate labor subcommittee today that 3,500,000 youths were unable to attend high school because their parents could not afford it. He testified during a committee hearing on the proposed American Youth Act.

The Czechoslovak Cabinet met in special session tonight to consider the general situation in connection with events in Austria. President Eduard Benes presided. The Cabinet was represented as viewing the situation calmly.

Dr. Joseph Tenenbaum and B. Charney Viadeck, co-chairmen of the Jewish labor committee, made public yesterday a communication forwarded by the committee to the Austrian Consulate, 500 Fifth Avenue, announcing that the boycott would not be extended to Austrian goods.

Representative Bruce Barton last night told 400 Amherst College alumni that the government bureaucracy that has grown up in the last five years would never be abolished, and challenged education to man it with specially trained career

R. S. Rothschild, member of the Downtown Athletic Club, won the Metropolitan Class C squash racquets championship yesterday when he defeated J. N. Trainer Jr. of the Harvard Club in a four-game final on his home courts.

With a dramatic suddenness that stunned the world the German Army embarked yesterday on its first campaign beyond the Reich's borders and without. firing a shot achieved a victory that laid Austria prostrate at its feet, transformed the European equilibrium and set the borders fixed by the peace treaties into motion for a readjustment, of which the end is not yet in sight.

A suit for $400,000 against the National Distillers Products Corporation of New York was filed in the Dane County Circuit Court today by the Distillers Distributing Company of Madison, alleging breach of contract.

Reduction of the basic case load in the Emergency Relief Bureau by adding more bureau investigators, and a closer cooperation between Federal, State and city relief agencies, are sought in two resolutions to be introduced at the March 22 meeting of the City Council, it was learned yesterday.

Manhattan Alterations Chrystie St. 47-53; to 2-story offices and stores; Metropolitan News Co, premises, owner; J. J. Furman, architect; cost, $5,000. Lexington Ave, 2.116; to 1-story gasoline station; Socony Vacuum Oil Co, premises, owner; A. C. Benson, architect; cost, $4.500.

COMMERCIAL PAPER Yesterday. Thursday. For the best names .... 1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months' paper. Trade Here Off 11-12% in Week Department store sales here this week again were disappointing, but are expected to prove somewhat better than the 13.3 per cent decline for last week reported yesterday by the local Federal Reserve Bank.

Representing the first step in a program to provide more direct assistance to small merchants, formation of a bureau of smaller stores within the set-up of the National Retail Dry Goods Association was announced yesterday by Lew Hahn, general manager.

11:00 A. M.-12:30 P. M.-Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert; Rudolph Ganz, John Barbirolli, Conductors-WABC. 11:30 A. M.-12:00 M.-United States Army Band Concert-WOR. 1:50-2:00 P. M.-Carnegie Institute of Technology Symphony-WOR. 1:55-4:30 P. M.-Metropolitan Opera: Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor," With Lily Pons, Frederick Jagel and Others-WJZ. 3:00-4:00 P. M.-From London: Will Fyffe, Comedian; Orchestra-WOR. 5:00-6:00 P. M.-Play, "The Great Magician"--WEAF.

Glenn Cunningham in two races for the price of one admission will be the double-feature attraction that will jam some 16,000 spectators into Madison Square Garden tonight for the nineteenth annual running of the Knights of Columbus track carnival.

Edwin P. Cox, judge of the Fourth Virginia Judicial District and former Speaker of the House of Delegates of Virginia, died at a hospital here tonight. He was 67 years old. He had been ill only eight days.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Anne Vietor, daughter of Mrs. Thomas F. Vietor- of 791 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Vietor, to George Draper Arthur Jr., son of Mrs. George Draper Arthur of this city and the late Mr. Arthur.

By a margin of two votes a debating team representing Yale defeated Columbia yesterday in a discussion of the question, "Resolved: That labor be organized into strong national unions for purposes of collective barganining."

Summing up the results of Foreign Minister Josef Beck's Rome visit the official Gazeta Polska said today that Italo-Polish friendship was based on recognition of the important part Italy and Poland play in European politics.

Sir Arthur Henry Downes, public health. expert, died at his home here today at the age of 86. His research into the effect of light on bacteria and protoplasm was the first to reveal the destructive action of light on organisms of putrefaction and disease.

Two defaults and the inability of Ogden Phipps of Roslyn, L. I., to defend his title today limited the field in the national court tennis tournament to six competitors, four of whom advanced into the semi-final round. James H. Van Alen of New

Two of four bandits who invaded the Mattituck National Bank and Trust Company here at noon today climbed over an eight-foot partition with pistols in hand, pocketed cash estimated to total $2,500 'and, with their confederates, escaped in an automobile toward Riverhead.
Turpentine firm, 28 1/2c; sales, 32 barrels; receipts, 119 barrels; shipments, 90 barrels; .stock, 23,945 barrels.

The nomination of Thurman W. Arnold for assistant attorney general to enforce anti-trust laws was approved by a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee today after the Yale professor had been cross-examined for forty-five minutes.

The battle between the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company and militant property owners in the Saugatuck Valley progressed today when the company petitioned the Superior Court for permission to close more than eleven miles of public highways leading into the towns of Redding and Weston.

In the inquiry being made by the Regents into the character and cost of public education in the State of New York there is a discussion of the proper size for a school district. The conclusion reached after conferences with school administrators, board members, teachers, parents, taxpayers and others is embodied in the following recommendations:
A steadfast faith in the future of New Jersey applejack: emerged yesterday as a potent underlying cause in the failure of Richard Whitney and his stock brokerage firm.

Representative . Kennedy of New York. City told reporters today that Mayor-La Guardia was "grooming himself for the Gubernatorial race" in his controversy with Governor Lehman over the administration of relief in New York.

Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg had been sailing stormy seas ever since he assumed the Chancellorship of Austria after the assassination of Dr. Engelbert Dollfuss by the Nazis on July 25, 1934. It was the shaping up of recent events, however, that brought about his downfall. Previously he had

Today's major events: Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "Lucia di Lammermoor," afternoon, "Siegfried," evening, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony youth concert, last of season, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; Karl Ulrich Schnabel, pianist, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Mailaam concert, Bloch program, Town Hall, evening; "Aida," New York Hippodrome Opera Company, evening.
Austria's new Chancellor pruned an apple tree today while history was in the making.
The Democratic National Committee, its debts cleared and a balance of $7,297.61 on hand, is mapping a program to raise funds to meet the cost of this Fall's campaign.

St. Patrick's Day received judicial recognition in Kings County Court yesterday when Judge Peter J. Brancato informed Assistant District Attorney Sidney Gottesman that on next Thursday he would try no cases in which the defendant or defense counsel was Irish.
A dispatch from Vladivostok today said Soviet authorities were holding eight Japanese as hostages for the release of two Russian ships with crews and passengers detained in Japan.

Because the State Employment Service is now up to date in handling the registration of unemployment insurance applicants, 457 temporary employes will be laid off Tuesday, Paul Sifton, administrator of the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance of the State Labor Department, announced yesterday.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Member trading in round lots for their own accounts on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Feb. 12 was 22.84 per cent of the total volume, compared with 21.22 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Although she continued to insist that "everything went black" shortly before her husband, Patrolman Michael Ryan, was murdered on Oct. 31, Mrs. Patricia Ryan admitted yesterday when cross-examined in Bronx County Court that she now "knows" she picked up his service revolver, and without anger, shot and killed him.

The interchange of letters between Mayor La Guardia and Governor Lehman does not do much to clarify the relief situation. It merely reveals the Mayor in one of his less dignified moments and suggests a growing rift between two useful citizens who ought to be friends.

Max Baer came back to town last night and jumped right into the front ranks of contenders for the world heavyweight championship. The California battler decisively trounced Tommy Farr, the Welshman who holds the British Empire title, in a grueling fifteen-round struggle at Madison Square Garden and in so doing won back much of the prestige he lost when he was so ingloriously beaten by Joe Louis more than two years ago.

The unlicensed sea-going personnel of two ship lines selected the National Maritime Union, C. I. O. affiliate, as their labor spokesman, and the men of one line selected the International Seamen's Union of the American Federation of Labor, in elections sponsored by the National Labor Relations Board.

The United States liner President Harding arrives today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh. On board are Lieut. Commander A. Richard Gleitsman, Dr. Leland L. Kraus, Lieut. Commander William Bunkley, Herbert Peck Fales, William Barnes, Stephen C. Brown, Mr. and Mrs. David PriceJones.

More than 2,400 aspiring journalists who write and edit the nation's school publications, spending three days- away from their- classrooms to attend the Columbia Scholastic Press Association's fourteenth annual convention on Morningside Heights, heard on all sides

No settlement of the pending lockout controversy between the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0., and the Sunshine-Radio and AtlasLiberty taxicab associations is possible until the city code is amended to provide for effectual limitation of the number of cabs on the city streets, according to a statement issued yesterday by Arthur S. Meyer, member of the State Board of Mediation.

Olive Arnold, soprano, formerly active in this city as a radio singer, gave a recital last night in Town Hall, where she was warmly received by a large gathering. Mrs. Arnold, who is the wife of Edward Arnold, the screen actor, is a native of St. Paul. For the last five years

Lehigh wrestlers took a commanding lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association's thirtyfourth annual championships tonight by qualifying five men for tomorrow night's finals and picking up six points on falls along the way.
Byron Nelson, young Ryder Cup player from Reading, Pa., came from behind in a subpar finish today to win the $3,000, Hollywood open with a 72-hole score of 275, eight under par.
Dr. Julius Christian Zeller, former Vice Chancellor of the University of Mississippi, died of a heart attack in a drug store here last night. He was 66 years old.

The British Baptists have rejected the recent reunion scheme for the Church of Englaid and the Evangelical Free Churches and hold that further progress in the expression of Christian unity must be dependent on "unreserved mutual recognition."

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe ordered yesterday the forfeiture of bail of $10,000 furnished for Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, fugitive racketeer, when the latter failed to appear for retrial on an indictment charging that he violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Law in the dressed rabbit skin industry.
A conference with Federal housing officials gave impetus today to the New Jersey Housing Authority's drive for a $30,000,000 slum clearance program.

A revolution in the game of bridge comparable to that Harold S. Vanderbilt started thirteen years ago when he introduced contract to his fellow-passengers on a boat trip between San Francisco and Havana appears to be in the making over the new five-suit deck invented by a Vienna psychologist.
News of the abandonment of the Austrian plebiscite and the change of government stirred provincial populations this evening.

Dr. Arthur Seyss-Inquart is a Vienna lawyer of strongly nationalist sentiments who was appointed under the 1936 agreement as "conciliator" to bring about a rapprochement of the Fatherland Front followers in Austria with the Nazis.

El Paso Natural Gas Company and Subsidiaries-For 1937: Consolidated net income $1,866,004, after retirement reserve, interest, amortization of debt expense and Federal income taxes, compared with $1,071,828 for 1936.
Bernhard, A. D., orders of Feb. 10 revoked; to continue duty as Chief of Staff and Aide, Commander Aircraft Scouting Force. Canaga, B. L., to duty with Peruvian Government; previous orders revoked.

The German cruiser Emden left Corfu hurriedly this evening, having received unexpected orders to return to Kiel, Germany; The vessel sailed hastily after collecting the crew from shore Jeave. The cruiser was to have remained here for ten days.

Toward midnight S. S. [Nazi guard troops] men spread a huge Nazi flag over the yellow sofa in the chancellery on which Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss slowly bled to death in the attempted putsch of July 25, 1934.

Before Chancellor Schuschnigg stepped out, old Heimwehr men appealed to Fascist Prince Ernest Dudiger von Starhemberg, former Vice Chancellor, to return from his Swiss honeymoon and reorganize his now disbanded private army.

MAD ABOUT MUSIC, from a story by Marcella Burke and Frederick Kohner; screen play by Bruce Manning and Felix Jackson; music and lyrics by Jimmy McHugh and Harold Adamson; directed by Norman Taurog; produced by Joe Pasternak for Universal. At the Roxy.

Angus MacMillan Fraser, widely known bagpiper, who died on Sunday at the age of 64, was buried yesterday in Mount Olivet Cemetery in Maspeth, as his band of pipers played the Children's Lament. More than 400 were present at the burial, including representatives of the Clans MacDonald, Chisholm and MacKenzie.
For the first time in three weeks, both near deliveries on the Cotton Exchange sold below the 9-cent level and prices at the close yesterday were 5 to 9 points off.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Elizabeth Napier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Ferry Napier of East Orange, to John W. Gardner, son of Mrs. Harry E. Gardner, also of this city, took place this afternoon at the Gardner home.
Thomas Maclay Hoyne 2d, Everett E. Mellinger and Henry H. Cone Jr. plan to form Hoyne, Mellinger Co. on April 15. The New York

With 250 guests present, the Peddie School Alumni dinner was held last night at the Hotel McAlpin. The diners heard Dr. Wilbour E. Saunders, headmaster, tell of recent developments in their school, and later they paid tribute to John D. Plant, for years athletic director at Peddie, who has been at Bucknell since 1926.

New Jersey's $25,000,000 highway program has received Presidential approval, it was announced today by William H. J. Ely, State WPA Administrator, who described the program as "one of the most important ever devised and launched in New Jersey."

Michigan, defending champion, and Indiana took five qualifying places apiece tonight in the University of Chicago field house and remained favorites in the annual Big Ten indoor track meet. Iowa garnered six places.

Arthur S. Minges, father of Patrolman Arthur J. Mines of the queens Telegraph Bureau, died at his home, 341 Cornelia Street, Brooklyn, on Thursday evening after a brief illness. He was 60 years old. He had retired from the New

The news of the dramatic events in Austria has seriously impressed The Netherlands, where it is considered the most alarming intelligence for smaller European countries since August, 1914, when berman troops invaded Belgium.

Arriving buyers may register in this column by telephoning LAckawanna 4-1000. RETAIL BOSTON--Chandler Co.; Miss A. M. Gillis, jewelry, handkerchiefs, neckwear, scarfs; 50 W. 35 (Syndicate-Alliance). CHICAGO-R. R. Hosiery Co.; J. Reeder, women's hosiery, silk underwear; New Yorker.

Filling the spacious floor of the auditorium of the Payne Whitney gymnasium, nearly 1,500 couples danced tonight at the annual Yale junior promenade, transferred this year for the first time from the Woolsey Hall floor, to allow room for the dancers and chaperons.
Many pastors will preach sermons tomorrow advocating the cultivation of a spirit of optimism among the people of the United States both in regard to international relations and economic recovery.

New York will soon have a foretaste of "world of tomorrow fashlons," strikingly new styles based upon World's Fair themes, Grover A. Whalen, president of the 1939 Fair Corporation, announced yesterday.

A striking change has taken place in the atmosphere of Rome in the past fortnight. Perhaps it is more striking in contrast with the surcharged air in Central Europe, where even three days ago-before today's bombshell-the tension was so close to the snapping point that anything that is not a storm now seems like normal weather.
Army's astonishing boxing team, undefeated this season, paraded through the opening program of the Eastern Intercollegiate tournament tonight, leaving Syracuse's defending champions trailing.

Austria's fate was, really sealed on Feb. 18 when Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain resolved to part with his Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, and initiate negotiations with both Chancellor Hitler and Premier Mussolini. On the previous day,
Midwestern realty dealers heard today how England built more than 900,000 dwellings between 1932 and 1936 while the United States was building a much smaller number.

Speaking at a general 'meeting of Reichsbank stockholders, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht announced today a new and more conservative fiscal policy that is believed to contain those concessions to his economic views that enabled him to accept the Reichsbank presidency for another four years despite his previous threats to quit this month.

The Assembly of the California Legislature early today adopted a resolution for a legislative pardon for Tom Mooney, convicted of the 1916 parade bombing in San Francisco. A pardon measure failed of passage by only two votes in the Assembly early yesterday after Mooney had appeared personally to declare his innocence.

Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball and an ardent golfer, presented the Belleair. women's open golf championship trophy t Miss Marion Miley today shortly after the former Lexington, Ky., girl defeated Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, 2 and 1, in their final match.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Mahoney, 19 years old, a student at the College of Mount St. Vincent, 261st Street and the Hudson River, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, was reported yesterday as missing by her mother, who gave the same name.

In a letter to Thomas E. Colleton, State director of the FHA in New Jersey, Governor A. Harry Moore hailed the New Jersey National Home Show, to be held in Newark from March 19 to 26, as rendering timely and valuable service to the State. He also commended the recent amendments to the National Housing Act. Reduction of the required down payment to 10 per cent

International events have again assumed an important role in the thoughts of General John J. Pershing, who today expressed interest on learning that "Anthony Eden resigned while I was sick." He asked what brought "the downfall yesterday of Premier Camille Chautemps of France." He had not been informed of the Austrian situation.

Plans for reduced automobile insurance rates in this State as a reward for careful driving were discussed yesterday afternoon at a conference under the sponsorship of Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, in the State office building, 80 Center Street.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that Captain Edward McDonough, in command of the Morrisania police station in the Bronx, had applied for retirement, effective March 31. The captain has been on the force since 1903. He would be entitled to $2,950 a year as pension.

Trading in steer hinds and ribs and fresh pork cuts improved, other classes slow. Steer and lamb cuts sold unevenly. Fresh pork prices were steady to higher, other classes showed little change. Early trading in Kosher meats indicated beef to be strong to higher and other classes about steady, as reported .by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Joseph A. Lichtenthal, whose mother, two brothers and a sister were killed by smoke or flames when their home here burned in the early morning of Feb. 28, filed a notice with city officials today that he would sue the city for $200,000 as administrator of the decedents' estates. Mr. Lichtenthal, a 27-year

A man who said he was James Parsens, 37 years old, an unemployed waiter of 150 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, attempted suicide last night in the detectives squad room in the Bergen Street station by stabbing himself in the forehead with a paper knife he had grabbed up off a desk. He was taken in a serious

The Buena Vista Hotel, a fivestory frame and stucco building at 103 Second Avenue, Belmar, N. J., has been purchased by George Ginsberg of Belmar and Lakewood, who has operated the property for five years. It occupies a plot 150 by

Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg tonight made his valedictory. The speech was pitched in a very different tone from that of his address made in Innsbruck two nights ago in which he announced the plebiscite for this Sunday. The text of the speech follows.

Believed to be setting a precedent in the merchandising of men's shoes, London Character Shoes yesterday launched a new advertising campaign in newspapers, announcing that tags, containing a description of materials and methods, will hereafter be attached to every pair.
News has been received here of the engagement in Chicago of Miss Ruth Fisher, daughter of the late Walter L. Fisher, Secretary of the Interior in the Taft Administration, to Charles Edward Rhetts.

Hearings on a proposal to divert Lake Michigan water at Chicago neared an end today as New York witnesses questioned the right of Congress to authorize diversion of water to one watershed to the detriment of another.

Mrs. Jacob Umnitz of Erie, Pa., has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Charlotte Marthe Umnitz of this city, to Hartnell Lockridge of San Francisco. The marriage will take place here Saturday morning in the chantry of St. Thomas Church. The rector, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, will perform the ceremony in the presence of relatives and a few friends.
A. A. U. W. (Monmouth County Branch)-Meeting, Mrs. Joseph Hunter, speaker on "Better Personnel in Government," home of Mrs. Louis S. Thompson, Lincroft.

Assets, $28,797 gross; $25,628 net. To nieces. Florence C. Walker, Katherine Bennett, Margaret Green and Eliza Tull. Outstanding holdings in real property. Walter J. Sharkey, attorney, 89-31 161st St., Jamaica.
James A. Van Alen of New York and Charles H. Stockton of Boston gained the final round of the national court tennis championship today at the Tennis and Bacquet Club. They will meet tomorrow.

Passage of the amendments to the National Housing Act has brought about a complete change of sentiment in the building industry, both in the cities and in the rural areas, declares Joseph B. Mason, eastern editor of The American Builder.

INTEREST in growing native American flowers in gardens, even in small home gardens, continues to grow. Magazine articles, lectures and radio talks on the subject increase in number. But all too frequently the esentials of the successful culture of wildlings under garden conditions are not dealt with.

Enlarged to more than three times its normal size in order to accommodate the hundreds who desire to be heard, the Committee for Reciprocity Information in Washington tomorrow will begin eight days of public hearings on the pending Anglo-British trade agreement.

Flowers and fashions, appropriately associated with the near-by advent of Spring, are occupying the attention of many women of society now engaged in preparations for several style revues and floral exhibitions arranged in behalf of various philanthropic projects.

Mr. and Mrs. Everett Jefts Beede of Belmont, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Southworth Beede, to Frank Lincoln Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Phillips of Springfield, N. J.

Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 9 aggregated $7,306,000,000, or 15 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 19 per pent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

WITHIN two years the gladiolus has risen fast in favor. This rise can be traced to its increased usefulness as a cut flower, due to the development of new shades, greater clarity of color, longer flowerheads and slender spikes that are more graceful and in better proportion than heretofore.

PROMPTED, by the exhibition at the Whitney Museum, to remark that this must have been somewhat an off year for American sculpture, one feels at once that certain qualifying aspects of the case should be bracketed.

The voice of Chancellor Hitler of Germany was heard unexpectedly over the radio yesterday afternoon when European broadcast officials made a switch in the circuit from Vienna to Linz, Austria, to intercept "the voice of a local orator" in the latter city.

A resolution declaring that "the American people condemns the Monstrous invasion of Austria by Hitler's legions and calls upon this governmentt to officially express its condemnation to the Nazi government" yesterday was handed to Dr. ??ans Borchers, German consul general, by a delegation of pickets at his office at 17 Battery Place.

Declamation trials for candidates to deliver the valedictory and salutatory addresses at the commencement exercises to be held by Stevens Institute of Technology on June 11 will be held Monday, March 21, at 3:30 P. M. before the committee on academic functions.
How to find and train the right young man for the right job will be the purpose of a $162,000 experiment by the American Youth Commission, to start this month in four cities and three rural areas.

A deputy fire chief and four other firemen were killed instantly and another was slightly hurt tonight when a three-story brick wall toppled on them while they were wetting down the smoldering ruins of the Quackenbush Company department store's warehouse, which was ruined by a spectacular fire of undetermined origin this afternoon.

METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER has signed up with Technicolor and will do six films in the new medium next season, the first of which is to be Kenneth Robert's "Northwest Passage," starring Robert Taylor. At the moment Twentieth Century-Fox is the only major studio without color films on its program.

SOUTHERN PINES, N. C.-Southern Pines and the entire resort section is filled with race enthusiasts here for the fourth annual steeplechase races, to be held at the two-and-ahalf-mile Barber Estate course on Midland Road Saturday afternoon.

Army's boxing team marched triumphantly through the Eastern intercollegiate championships tonight with three individual titles, two -seconds and two thirds to break the Syracuse-Penn State monopoly of nearly a decade.

C. C. N. Y. defeated the M. I. T. fencers today, 19 1/2 to 7 1/2. Gaining on 8-1 lead with the foils, the New Yorkers prevailed in the saber matches, also by 8 to 1. In the epee competition M. I. T. set the pace, 5 1/2--3 1/2.

A ruling against United States and British oil companies was delivered today by Federal District Judge Manuel Bartlett on the companies' petition for a permanent injunction against the Federal Labor Board's wage decision.

AUGUSTA, Ga.--The second annual garden pilgrimage of the Garden Club of Georgia, which begins at Thomasville, in the south of the State, on March 22, will follow a trail of Spring flowering for more than 300 miles northward to Atlanta, where the gardens will be visited April 1, 2 and 3.

The time has come, Andre Philip, Socialist Deputy of France, told the Foreign Policy Association's semimonthly luncheon meeting yesterday, when the democracies must stand together and tell the dictators just what they will not accept.

Urging merchants to be "business statesmen, and not politicians," Saul Cohn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and head of the City Stores Company, in his first official message to the membership of the organization, issued yesterday, asserted that "never before in our commercial history has there been a more imperative need for a statesmanlike charting of the course of business."

Reports fou from automobile dealers throughout the country state that the national used car exchange week was a decided success and indicate that the way to recovery in the automobile industry has been cleared.

Young men who wish to become pilots of modern airplanes were warned today that to qualify for such jobs they must go through training more severe than that of a medical student before he receives a license to practice.
A Nazi movement started in Hungary today. Police and the army were alert for duty, and the guard at the Austrian border was strengthened.
Eighteen of the twenty-one defendants in Moscow's third great public treason trial within two years were sentenced to be shot at the final session of the military court at 4:30 this morning.

Vincent Sheean, author and former war corespondent, sailed for Spain yesterday on the French liner Paris to gather material on the Insurgent side of the Spanish civil conflict. He was accompanied by his wife,
A scientific controversy somewhat reminiscent of the farmer who gazed at a giraffe for the first time and pronounced that "there ain't no sich animal" has been precipitated by Dr. Irving Langmuir,

Members of the staff of the Bartol Research Poundation of the Franklin Institute, who have climbed mountains, sent balloons aloft and descended into mines in their investigations of. the cosmic ray, will seek to obtain additional data in an unusual laboratory being erected on the Swarthmore College campus.

Joseph W. Catharine, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, announced yesterday that a national conference to discuss real estate taxation matters will be held in Chicago April 6 under the auspices of the committee on real estate taxation of the national association.

THE latest edition of Audubon prints--seven subjects in the first group-has been endorsed by the National Association of Audubon Societies. These seven subjects were chosen, the society announces, from among the 400 prints in the "Elephant Folio" because of beauty of composition and coloring. An eighth subject is shortly to be offered.
An agreement with the C. I. O. enabled resumption of work today at the plants of the Roberts Maner Stove Company and its subsidiary, the Hatboro Foundry Company, after a five-week sit-down strike.

Three plays will be presented this week by amateur groups in Westchester County. The first, "The Night of January 16th," will be given Tuesday and Wednesday evenings by the Spotlight Players at the Ridgeway Theatre here; The leading role will be played by Polly MacAllister. Others in the cast are A. S. Platt, Albert W. Lockyear; Elwood D. Cromwell, Betty Stark, John Reid and Grace Mactarnahan.

The United Profit Sharing Corporation has notified the New York Curb Exchange of the extension to Dec. 31, 1939, of options granted to certain of its officers and directors to buy 25,400 shares of unissued capital stock at $1 a share.
Following is the text of Chancellor Hitler's proclamation to the German people as broadcast from all German radio stations by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels:

Prophetic words that Chancellor Hitler wanted to reshape the map of Europe and that France's only chance to meet the challenge was cooperation with Italy were spoken by Premier Mussolini to Bertrand de Jouvenel, son of the former French Ambassador to Italy, in an interview on the eve of-the outbreak of the Spanish civil war according to Jouvenel's story.

WITH hope for the defeat of the "emergency" gasoline taxes in this State at an end for this year, organizations having the interest of the motorist at heart have turned to a serious effort to -prevent, at least, diversion of the huge funds derived from motor vehicle fees and gasoline taxes from the road purposes for which they are intended for an indefinite period.
Five children, ranging from 4 to 13 years, were burned to death last night by flames which leveled the farm house of Archie Dunlap of Big Bank, Boularderie.
Miss Ludmilla Isnard and Fred W. Guild, winners of the tourney a year ago, scored yesterday in the opening round of the Island Court Club's invitation mixed doubles indoor tennis tournament.

Dr. Mildred Clark Clough, wife of Dr. Paul Wiswalt Clough, Associate Professor of Medicine in the Johns Hopkins University Medical School, and herself a member of the medical school and hospital staff of. Hopkins, died last night at her home, in her fiftieth year.

Kiss Parnel Bray of Norwalk, Conn., and Miss Ida Miller of Wilton, seniors at Bates College, are in charge of arrangements for the annual demonstration of the Women's Physical Education program at the college, to be held Thursday evening.

The crisis in the TVA directorate, which' came to a head last week when Chairman A. E. Morgan confronted the dissenting directors, David E. Lilienthal and H. A. Morgan, at a White House conference, is one of many which have affected the Tennessee River development since the TVA was set up in May, 1933.
Britons, who are ardent amateur aquarists, and of course are insular persons as well, are well over "one up" on Americans in the field of marine life culture in the home.

Modem Furniture. Museum of Modern Art, 14 West Forty-ninth Street, until April 7. Examples and photography of pieces designed by Alvar Aalto, Finnish architect. Also architectural drawings and photographs.

Public officials and officers of business, civic, cultural and patriotic organizations will be in the reviewing stand in front of the Arsenal Station in Central Park Thursday afternoon when the annual St. Patrick's Day parade up Fifth Avenue from Forty-fourth to 100th Street takes place, John J. Sheahan, chairman of the arrangements committee,. announced yesterday.

The New York Stock Exchange's committee on stock list has announced the striking from the list of twenty-eight foreign governnent and other foreign issues which have been suspended from dealings since May 16, 1936, because the issuers failed to register under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

Conimittees are being organized for the annual Kettledrum, New York's oldest charity fair, which will take place on April 8 at the Plaza. As for several decades past, the event will be for the benefit the Samaritan Home for the Aged now situated at 440 East Eightyeighth Street.

The penthouse apartment on the roof of the Berkley Building, 19 West Forty-fourth Street, has been leased to the Glass Container Association and is being altered into a modern, fully equipped experimental kitchen. The association has offices in the building, which is owned by the 19 West Forty-fourth Street Company, William H. Jeffers, managing director.

THE STORY OF RECONSTRUCTION. By Robert Selph Henry. 633 pp. Indianapolis: The Bobbs-Merrill Company. $5. By HENRY S. COMMAGER JUST before our entry into the World War Woodrow Wilson called for a "peace without victory," and alone of the representatives of the great powers at the Peace Conference he advised magnanimity toward the vanquished.

Attempts of Japanese forces in Shansi and Honan to cross the Yellow River at a dozen different points from the Great Wall in North Shansi to Chengchow have been repulsed according to local military sources.

HAVING grown all the everbearing strawberries at one time or another, starting years ago with the time-honored Progressive and ending more recent ly with Mastodon and Gem, the writer has no hestation in saying that the new Wayzata-listed by Eastern growers this year for the first time-is the best so far developed.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 11: COLONELS Loughry, H. K. (C.A.C.). General Staff Corps, one day's leave, March 12. Stone, F. P., Dental Corps, leave extended two months; upon own application, to retirement.

Joji T., a Cuban-owned filly ridden by a Cuban jockey, won the $2,000 added Lafayette Handicap for 2year-olds at the Fair Grounds today.. Cornelio Mojena brought the daughter-of Supremus from behind to pass Major B. and draw away from the determined challenge of Sir Witch in the four-furlong feature.
With interest focused on the outcome in Spring Valley, voters in eleven incorporated villages in Rockland County will go to the polls on Tuesday to elect village officers for the coming year.

A home show in miniature, the central point of which is a moderntype dwelling designed by Edward D. Stone, opened yesterday in Rockefeller Center at the Permanent Exhibition of Decorative Arts. and Crafts, by the Ladies Home Journal.

Intruction meetings for AAA field men, committee men, county agents and extension workers, through whom the. contact between the farmer and his government is effected under the new farm law, have provided the first concrete reactions to the operation of that law.

FIRST impressions are the strongest" is one of those slogans which may be as fal lacious as "Early to bed" and "Two's company." Nevertheless, two or three decades of my life were spent in striving to correct my earliest ideas of Billie Burke, who became the wife of Florenz Ziegfeld, subsequently my employer.

Mrs. Harvey D. Gibson, wife of the banker, received five broken ribs and back injuries when she was thrown from her dappled gray gelding Coq d'Argent during the Meadow Brook Hunt near Syosset this morning.
FAIRCHILD AVIATION INCORPORATED of Jamaica, L. I., has been appointed international distributor by the TaylorYoung Airplane Company of Alliance, Ohio.

Keener consumer interest in household products has widened the field of usefulness of the home economist and opened many new occupational avenues to her, according to a study made by the Institute of Women's Professional Relations under the direction of Mrs. Chase Going Woodhouse.

AT present writing it looks as if the major orchestral front will remain largely unchanged in respect to conductors. Fritz Reiner, retaining his position as head of the Curtis Institute orchestral department, will wield the baton of the lately reorganized Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra for one year; but that seems to be the only new move of any importance.

Protecting the move by the Municipal Civil Service Commission to reduce the staff of the Marriage License Bureaus under the city clerk from forty-one employes to fifteen, Robert L. Tudor, acting city clerk, and Philip A. Hines, first deputy city clerk declared the five borough offices are under-staffed.

Harvard's swimming team downed Yale for the second year in a row when the Cantabs registered a 46-to-29 triiumph over the Bulidogs tonight. While a capacity crowd of 2,800 fans looked on in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium pool, Harvard's swimmers captured eight of nine first places to record a decisive triumph.

Two of the largest-benefit fashion shows of the season will be given, next week in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. These exhibit tions of the dernier cri of leading couturiers are the "Paris et Nous" show on March 22 .in aid of the. West Side Thrift Shop and the event entitled "Masterpieces of 1938" on March 24 in behalf of the Generosity Thrift Shop.

PARIS. CONTRAST lends zest to almost everything in life. Paris couturiers are making the most of this fact in every domain of fashion this season. Their collections are built up of bold oppositions. Balloon-sized skirts are cheek by jowl with suits "stripped to the bone";

The men's wear trade, first field to experience consumer price resistance a year ago, will launch its Spring selling season tomorrow and is looking for an improvement in sales volume, which has fallen back considerably in recent weeks, manufacturing and store executives said yesterday.
Stanford's Indians captured their third straight Pacific Coast Conference basketball championship tonight, defeating the University of Oregon, 59 to 51, to win the play-off series.
Some interesting facts have been disclosed, points out the Owens-Illinois Glass Company, in a recent research to ascertain the origin of the manufacture of hollow glass blocks for building.

The pioneer American Insurance Company, Dallas, Texas, has filed a registration statement under terms of the Securities Act of 1933 covering 416,000 shares of no-par value common stock of which 50,000 are to be offered to agents or representatives of the registrant and 315,000 shares through underwriters, for estimated Proceeds of $6.300,000.

Surgeons working under an order hastily obtained from a justice of Children's Court performed an appendectomy on a 14-year-old Negro boy at Metropolitan Hospital early today, hoping to save his life despite a refusal by his mother to consent to an operation.

Former District Attorney and Mrs. Frederick Child Filley of Troy, N. Y., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Freda Child Filley, to Joseph Leggett Swensson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto J. Swensson, also of Troy.

THE golden-breasted swallows that swoop down upon San Juan Capistrano Mission, California, on March 19 have never failed to keep their date with the microphone, so on Friday at 7:45 P. M., and on Saturday at 2 P. M., the "mike" affiliated with WEAF's hook-up will be at the mission for a description of the birds' mysterious arrival from out over the Pacific.
AMONG the annual meetings and gatherings of exhibitors, officials and clubs connected with the International Flower Show, to be held during this week, these are the outstanding:

EVEN if it had not been such a dull week on the screen, the chances are that the highlight still would have been the disclosure that Katharine Hepburn has pretty legs. We hadn't thought about it before, any more than we have ever bothered to notice whether Miss Garbo's feet were as large as the wiseacres said.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired an important collection of drawings and paintings by Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, in whom Venetian painting of the eighteenth century reached its height.

A strong secondhalf recovery gave Wales an 11-5 victory over Ireland in an international rugby match played today before a crowd of 40,000. It was the third successive defeat for the Irishmen, who led, 5-3, at half time. The Welshmen won by a goal, penalty goal and a try to Ireland's goal.

High quarters of the League of Nations expect no attempt to be made to intervene through the League against the Hitler coup in Austria, but point out sardonically that the League powers do not lack legal basis for such action.

Wholesale houses reported a marked improvement in business this week, and the margin under last year narrowed to between and 8 per cent. With the big general dry goods firms, the number and size of orders increased.

European developments unsettled the foreign markets yesterday, precipitated a wave of arbitrage selling here at the opening of the Cotton Exchange, and caused an initial break of $1 a bale. For a few moments the market hesitated, but with quotations one-half a cent below the highs of last month, an aggressive buying movement on the part of consumers got under way the second hour.

The dramatic club of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel here will give its annual play on April 27 for the benefit of the college's building fund. The play will be 'Jane Eyre," an adaptation of the Bront novel.

" For the first time since the bugles sounded 'cease fire twenty years ago, Halifax is alive again with the stir and bustle of military preparations," The Halifax Daily Star said in a news story today.

To maintain academic freedom and the "spirit of liberty" on the campus, college professors must become affiliated with the labor movement, speakers said yesterday at a luncheon of the New York College Teachers Union at the Hotel Astor. About 800 members attended the meeting, held to celebrate the founding of the organization.

A new merit badge in fingerprinting has been added to the extensive merit badge program of the Boy Scouts. This program numbers more than a hundred hobby, nature and vocational subjects through which boys are encouraged to develop and discover their aptitudes.

Announcement has meen made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Ernest A. Egleson of Essex Fells, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Aiken Egleson, to Joseph W. Bower, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Bower of Montclair. N. J.
Frank E. Vanderhoof disclosed today that he had given to the Library of Congress original documents which, he said, supported his contention that he was the "fatheir of the NRA."

A sounder policy of conservation is taking form, according to Dr. W. Elmer Ekblaw, geographer of Clark University, who spoke today before the nature study and forestry sections of the Outdoor Recreation Conference now being held at Massachusetts State College.

Chairman Harrison of the Senate Finance Committee proposed today that tax relief to "encourage new investments and melt much frozen credit" go far beyond the administration-approved provisions of the House tax bill.

FICTION THE WORLD GOES SMASH. By Samuel Hopkins Adams. Houghton Mifflin Company. A story of 1940 and of a District Attorney's desperate fight against the racketeers. SEVEN AGAINST REEVES. By Richard Aldington. Doubleday. Doran Co.

ANOTHER victory will soon be recorded in the thrilling story of men against the sea--the completion of a $57,000,000 highway that marches 170 miles through swamps, islands and ocean waves from Miami to Key West.

With some of the finest skaters in the world, including National, European and Canadian champions, the Skating Club of New York expects to put on the best exhibition it has yet attempted in its fifth annual carnival at Madison Square Garden March 23, 25, 26 and 28.

The decision of the railway managements on Friday to move for a reduction in union wages was not accepted in railroad circles as a solution to the present situation of the railroads, but rather was it deemed an index to the seriousness of their fiscal position.
LONG before the illuminated manuscript went out as an instrument in the spread of learning the printed book had come to stay and for a while the two persisted concurrently.
Abolition of the Westchester County Park Commission as an economic and political expedient was under consideration here today, according to members of the county Board of Supervisors.

Sixty friends of Rudolph J. Schaefer, former commodore of the Larchmont Yacht Club, gave him a surprise party yesterday in the Nevins shipyard in City Island, to celebrate the nearing completion of his new yacht, Edlu II, which will be entered in the Bermuda race in June.

To the Drama Editor: In a recent conversation I mentioned that when I and my immediate assistants took over direction of the Federal Theatre for New York City last Fall, we were, in effect, undertaking the task of building a new business, although the project was then some two years old.

The Columbia University fencing team defeated Harvard today, 14 to 13. Although Harvard won the foil and saber events, the New Yarkers piled up points in the epee events. W. S. Long of Harvard won all three of his bouts in the foil competition, as did J. Shapero of Columbia in the eDee events.

Columbia's basketball team closed its season by easily defeating Cornell, 47 to 28, before 1,500 spectators in an Eastern Intercollegiate League. game at. the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night.

A week before the advent of Spring a four-storied garden with almost four acres of fragrant, multicolored blooms will give the public an advance notice of the coming season when the Grand Central Palace is opened tomorrow for the Silver Jubilee International Flower Show.

A statement signed by a group of educators, writers, editors, trade union leaders, legislators, churchmen, artists and actors, which called for international cooperation by the democratic nations of the world and condemned "isolationism," was made public yesterday by the American League for Peace and Democracy.
Contrasting viewpoints on labor problems, Sino-Japanese relations and other current questions are being presented in a series of weekly public affairs talks at Mount Holyoke College this semester.

The Census Bureau reported today that cottonseed crushed in the seven-month period, Aug. 1 to Feb. 28, totaled 4,956,484 tons, compared with 3,784,821 tons in the corresponding period ' year ago. Cottonseed-'on hand at mills on Feb. 28 totaled 1,159,767 tons, compared With 573,158 a year ago.

Miss Sarah R. Steinman of Deposit, N. Y., has been chosen president of the Women's Self-Government Association at Cornell University, the highest office to which a woman can be elected. Others chosen to office are Mary V. Dodds of. Pittsburgh, chairman of organized groups;
A pioneer movement in educating farm folk, which has 'already brought new prosperity as well as new culture to the countryside, is under way in Cambridgeshire, England.

GUEST speaker at the annual dinner of the Automobile Merhants Association of New York will be Dr. James Shelby Thomas, president of the Chrysler Institute of Engineering. Edward P. Mauder, general manager of the New York branch, Cadillac Motor Car Division of General Motors, will be toastmaster.

Former President Herbet Hoover ??nched with President Ignaz ??Ioscicki today and called on Marshal Edward Smigly-Rydz and ?/remier Felicien Slawoj-Skladkow-??ki. It is reported that he received the ??npression that leading Polish ??atesmen were not alarmed by the events in Austria.

A young Negro woman and a 3year-old Negro girl were killed, and six other persons, all Negroes, were injured, two of them critically, in a fire which swept. the three-story and basement rooming house at 843 St. Nicholas Avenue, one door north of 152d Street, at 2:20 P. M. yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read in THE, NEW YORK TIMES, recently the article "Expedition to Seek New Data on Van" and am glad to learn that Professor Robert. Casey of Brown University and friends of his from the University of Pennsylvania are raising funds for the expedition. Van was once the capital of former Armenia.

Mrs. Helen Keller, co-worker and close friend of the late Jane Addams in Hull House, died yesterday at her home at 6,602 North Ashland Avenue. She was 79 years old. Mrs. Keller was one of the first presidents of the Hull House Woman's Club.

Stocks improved and closed steady in quiet trading; turnover, 299,850 shares. Central European and Italian bonds weak; United States Government issues lower; other bonds irregular; transactions, $3,421,800.

LONDON.--Popular polo seems to be the latest by-product of the riding vogue in England Under a new scheme launched in Lpncashire, ponies can be hired at $1.25 a game and anybody who can get together a couple of teams can play.
Still hopeful of finishing in first place in the American Group of the National Hockey League, the Rangers will engage the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Bargain days for fresh eggs and rice are here. For a week beginning tomorrow these two products will be sold at cut rates in most of the city's groceries. This is part of a nation-wide drive, instigated by the United States Government, to' reduce surpluses of these products.

If tax laws were permitted to run counter to the best interests of industry, it would' be only a question- of time when business must yield to the influence; and if persisted in, the disorganization of business would be. inevitable.

FEW figures in American history are as fascinating as the great soldier and traitor, Benedict Arnold. Probably none presents so baffling a puzzle-a puzzle which, almost certainly, will never be resolved.

Pierce Butler, one of the two justices on the Supreme Court who are described by the Roosevelt Administration as conservative, will be 72 years old Thursday. Friends said he planned to spend the day working at home on argued before the tribunal.
The Works Progress Administration reported today that 2,166,878 persons were on its rolls during the week ended March 5. This was 90,621 more than in the previous week.
TRAVELERS in Holland note the phenomenally large number of flourishing florist shops, not only in the larger centers like Amsterdam, The Hague and Rotterdam, but in the smaller towns and villages.

The British Broadcasting Company, which always shuts down at midnight, stayed on the air early this morning with bulletins on the Austro-German situation. Intermingled with reports on the Nazi coup were dispatches about the Tommy Farr-Max Baer heavyweight fight in New York.
Auxiliary devices will enable the 200-inch "eye" for Palomar observatory to see billions of miles farther and over a larger field than when it was projected in 1928.

Daniel J. Doherty, national commander of the American Legion, declared here today "Austria would not be facing German invasion if it had an adequate national defense, and the United States faces the same danger of invasion if it does not guard against it in time."

Sales of reconditioned homes in several sections of Long Island for financial institutions have been closed by the United Associates, reports Harry Perlmutter, vice president in charge of the brokerage divisiON.

The political alliance of John L. Lewis and Senator Joseph F. Guffey is reported to have decided to place virtually a complete ticket in the primary campaign in opposition to the slate of. the Democratic State committee.

For the first time in twenty-four years, save for one or two fleeting visits, Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon set foot in Austria, his native land, as the victor at the head of a triuinphal procession of jubilant Nazis.

The United States Bureau of Standards has just destroyed one of the best arguments of the Hot Stove League. As the result of extensive tests with a mechanical batsman, it has discovered that there is no practical difference in the liveliness of National and American League baseballs.
History and Biography THE GREENWOOD HAT: Being a Memoir of James Anon. By J. M. Barrie. 12mo. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $2.75. Autobiographical chapters on his youth.

Elections in the three villages in. Putnam County will be held on Tuesday, when trustees will be chosen for two-year terms. There will be a contest in only one village, Brewster, where the present Republican trustees, John E. Pugsley and Alfred Dahm, will be opposed by two Democratic candidates, William E. Mahler and Thomas L. Brennan.

A delay in the scheduled opening Tuesday of two new elementary schools, with a combined seating capacity of 1,801, was predicted by Board of Education officials yesterday following the lockout of union electricians by the Penner Electric Company, which has city and State contracts for five school and hospital jobs.

Failing by nine to fill its quota of thirty-nine flying cadets, the Second Corps Area headquarters at Governors Island announced yesterday that thirty young men betwee the ages of 20 and 26 had been accepted for class that begins Tuesday at the Army Air Corps training school at Randolph Field, Texas.
Developments in Austria were being closely watched here today by Chinese Government officials for their possible effects on the SinoJapanese hostilities.

Senate investigators asked Mayor Daniel, W. Shields of Johnstown, Pa., today to explain what "windfall" enabled him to pay off $23,485 of indebtedness and back taxes on his family's property at about the time of last year's Bethlehem Steel strike.

Plans to insure the continuing effectiveness in the coming year of the 214 agencies of the New York Catholic Charities will be discussed today and tomorrow at the second annual meeting of the Cardinal's Conference on Charity at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Mme. Marie Flagstad, mother of Kirsten Flagstad, the Metropolitan Opera soprano, and the latter's younger sister, Mme. Karen Marie Flagstad Cerkal, arrived from Norway yesterday morning to accompany, the opera company on a three weeks' tour.

AFTER two months in office Thomas E. Dewey is apparently beginning to enjoy the job of District Attorney, which he took with reluctance. And he has turned the formerly easy-going place into a bastille against crime, with so many checks and guards that at first it has almost a comic aspect.
Dr. W. L. Poteat, president emeritus of Wake Forest College and former president of the SERVED State Baptist Convention, died at his home here tonight. He was 81 years old.

Conservation of natural resources being its principal function, the Department of the Interior, at the direction of Secretary Ickes, will observe this Spring the centenary of John Muir, one of the outstanding conservationists of history, who was born April 21, 1838.

RIGHT now, when the Hollywood moguls are reported in frantic search for novelties with which to challenge Walt Disney's creations and Charlie McCarthy, it is oddly fortuitous that a young man should pop up from Europe with a name and modest fame which should win him welcome.

Anthony P. Ruffalo, a lawyer of 60 East Forty-second Street, annaounced yesterday his acceptance Of. the. office of president of the National Youth Party. In- a letter .to Jules P. Sommer, chairman of the executive committee, Mr. Ruffalo pledged his efforts to renominate Governor Lehman, and, if the Governor should not be a candidate, to,
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:
Paced by Alan Pennington, Oxford University defeated Cambridge, 60 to 57 in the renewal of their ancient track and field rivalry at White City today.

The winds of March do a thousand things to entrance the photographer-and to baffle him. There is wind that comes up under a gray pall of cloud, whipping mist and spray in a stinging barrage, wind that shifts its direction without reason or pattern, and wind that changes abruptly from a zephyr to a gale.

Undergraduate members of the Student Curriculum Committee at Barnard College will begin a study of the organization and application of the courses offered by the departments of the college this week, Ruth Landesman, committee chairman, announced yesterday.

THIS is an exceptionally good story of the hottest week of the year in the office of the District Attorney of New York. The impression of heat, humidity and perspiration is so well put over that it is an ideal book to read on a wintry evening, and the tropical feeling also makes some of the fantastic behavior of respectable office workers seem accountable.

Resident Commissioner Santiago Iglesias of Puerto Rico announced today a proposed bill to liberalize the Insular Organic Act would not be introduced until the Puerto Rican Legislature had acted upon a similar resolution.
ROYAL CONDUCTOR: Music is one of the greatest interests in life for the tall, husky, athletic, 39-year-old heir to the throne of Denmark.

Alexander L. Pach, associated with the firm of Pach Brothers, photographers, most of his life, was found dead on Friday morning i his room in 421 West Fifty-seventh Street. He was 74 years old and had been ill for several years. The medical examiner's office gave the cause of death as general arterio sclerosis.

RECENT studies and practical experiments in lawn-making all seem to indicate that early Fall is the best time to establish new turf. Frequently, however, conditions make it imperative, or nearly so, that the lawn be started in the Spring. Where this is the case, extra early planting-just as soon as soil can be worked after frost is out-will overcome many of the usual disadvantages of Spring sowing.

Mrs. Curtis Bok of Philadelphia, lecturer and women's leader, will be a leading speaker at the annual School of Family Relationships at Pennsylvania State College in June. She is on the program for the family dinner.

WHAT with the ice ballets of Sonja Henie, Maribel Vinson, Karl Schaeffer and scores of others attracting tremendous audiences on the screen, in Madison Square Garden, in armories all over the country and even in semi-tropical Florida, a strong suspicion arises that the rink is producing dance developments which may be of considerable artistic interest before they are through.
The Provincial Electricity Board has authorized the St. Maurice Power Corporation to proceed with its proposed 162,000 horsepower development on the St. Maurice River at La Tuque, Que.

Easter lilies and lighted cathedral tapers decorated Christ Episcopal Church here today for the marriage of Miss Carolyn Hotchkiss Wear, only daughter of Colonel and Mrs. David Walker Wear of Binghamton and the Hotel Astor, New York, to John Sutherland Mitchell.

The Cambridge University Rugby team, which will make a fivegame tour of this country this Spring, is scheduled to sail from Southampton, England, Wednesday aboard the Cunard-White Star liner Queen Mary. The Cantabs are slated to arrive in New York on Monday, March 21.
NEW ORLEANS, La.--This city is planning a week of wholesale Southern hospitality and with lagniappe. Never before in the history of this city have citizens consented to open their homes o the public.

Whether automobile parking meters, which are now used in several Western cities, shall become part of the Washington scene, probably will be decided Monday. A Senate amendment to the District of Columbia Appropriation Bill authorizes the District government to install the meters experimentally and the District commissioners have announced that they will do so if the amendment sur- i vives what is expected to be the. final meeting of conferees on the measure Monday.

Miss Dorothy Louise Jessup, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Melville Jessup of Newark, was married to Leslie Thomas Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Jones of East Orange, this evening in the home of the bride's parents.

Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Hymanson of 1,225 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Hymanson, to Dr. Jules D. Gordon, son of Mrs. Jennie Gordon of 210 East Seventythird Street and the late Samuel I. Gordon.

Announcing yesterday that during the first week in March the New York, Jamaica, Brooklyn and White Plains FHA offices had issued insured mortgage commitments aggregating $2,562,700, Thomas G. Grace, State FHA director. said that those figures were very encouraging.

Few small apartments are vacant in Harlem. While the vacancy average for all tenements in that section of Manhattan is comparatively low now, the percentage of unoccupied flats of four rooms and more is much higher than for tenement units of smaller size.

The life of Paddy's Market, 50year-old shopping section in the Hell's Kitchen district of the West Side, was hanging yesterday by a thread. Because of a resolution adopted by the Board of Estimate on Feb. 3 empowering Commissioner of Markets Morgan to name the sites where markets may be set up, Paddy's Market is doomed on March 19.

A non-governmental program of social security for lay employes of the Protestant Episcopal Church has been devised by the Church Life Insurance Corporation, a subsidiary of the Church Pension Fund, according to Bradford B. Locke, executive vice president of both organizations.

Displaying well-balanced team power which proved too much for the Williams College mermen, Brown University asserted its swimming supremacy for the sixth straight year by capturing the fifteenth annual New England intercollegiate championships today before 1,500 fans in Amherst's new Harold I. Pratt pool.

The Hershey Bears defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 4 to 3, tonight to retain first place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League. Benson scored at the start for the Orioles, but thirty-seven seconds later Grant retaliated.

Mrs. William A. Winant Jr, is executive chairman of the committee in charge of the plans for the annual card part and fashion show for the benefit of the Faith Home for Incurables to be held Friday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
SIGNIFICANT of the strictness with which it is concerned with problems of individual relationships is the fact that the three principal characters in Mr. Spencer's new novel have no surnames.

Ground for a new building for Marymount College here will be broken and blessed by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar General of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, on the feast of St. Joseph next Saturday at 4 P. M., according to an announcement today.

Paintings, Chinese porcelain and carved jade, French and English furniture and other lots from the estate of Marie Louise Patterson (Mrs. Robert Patterson) will be sold at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries Thursday evening and Friday and Saturday afternoons.

TWO Englishmen named Bentley selected and illustrated these tales of the bandits of Broadway, the guys and dolls of the bootleg era, by our own and valued Damon Runyon. It is said that the book went over big in London.

ECONOMIC depression and social unrest do not paralyze the French literary output. The recent activities of the printing press bring to our notice two first-rate novels which show by the diversity of their excellence the wide range of French fiction.

Seventeen out of thirty-seven divisions of local department stores had advertising increases during February, according to the "breakdown," issued yesterday by-Media Records, Inc. The individual gains, however, were small. Total linage for the month was 2,504,213 lines, against 2,547,743 for February a year ago.

In May of this year the Columbia University Library will hold an exhibition to commemorate the thirtieth anniversary of the death of Edward MacDowell. We are anxious to make this the most comprehensive exhibition of MacDowell material that has yet been held, and for this reason would like to supplement our own collection with material lent by others.

With nothing new reported in New Rochelle by Murray Levine, members of Emergency Squad 8 of the Ryer Avenue police station did some more grappling in Indian Lake, Crotona Park, the Bronx, yesterday, on the chance they might recover the body of his son, 12-year-old Peter, kidnapped on his way home from school sixteen days ago.

The greatest runner of them all tried to complete an impossible double last night and found that it was precisely that-impossible. Amid the deafening din of a capacity crowd of 16,000 at the Knights of Columbus Games in Madison Square Garden,

WESTWARD across the world's greatest ocean one of the world's greatest battle fleets will steam this week as the navy starts its annual mimic war. For six weeks, from the West Coast to Wake Island, from Alaska and the Aleutians to the Equator and beyond, the United States fleet will work out its annual strategical exercises--known this year in the official parlance of the sea as Fleet Problem XIX.

ONE of the remarkable things about Yeats's long and distinguished literary career is his susceptibility to influence. His father, the painter, introduced him to Darwin, and promptly Yeats became a youthful materialist.

THE total income of the British Broadcasting Corporation in 1937 was $16,780,370, according to the annual report. The Listener, journal of the organization, in commenting on the report, said: "It seems a substantial enough sum for carrying on our broadcasting service.".

MOTORING about Long Island or going by rail to Philadelphia last May and April one noticed here and there an odd tree that carried high in air clusters of purple flowers. Unless buds were Winter-killed the flowering tree will be drawing attention this Spring.
A novel way to cope with unusual book delivery problems has been started at the New York University Washington Square College Library at the university's downtown center.

Their notebooks crammed with information and advice from leading newspaper men and writers, 2,450 budding journalists departed yesterday for schools in thirty-eight States and the District of Columbia as the fourteenth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastie Press Association closed with ?? luncheon in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore.

Lehigh dethroned Penn State as Eastern intercollegiate wrestling champion tonight by winning three individual titles in the annual tournament and winding up 'with the team crown by the narrow margin of two points over Princeton's - favored forces.

It is now six years since Japan changed the map of Manchuria, and a balance of Japan's gain and loss in that continental venture may be attempted.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Florence Virginia Demory, daughter of Mrs. Adam Richard Demory of this city and Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Demory, to Robert Moulton Coles Raetze, which took place on Feb. 26 in the Church of All Saintsby-the-Sea. Montecito. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. John de Forest Pettus.
Court de Kerkhove de Denterghem, Belgian Ambassador to Paris, has been appointed Ambassador to Rome and will be accredited to the King of Italy and Emperor of Ethiopia.

WITH Winter travel a thing of the past, Spring approaching, and the Summer vacation period in the offing, the American tourist is now scanning the horizon and considering plans for his next trip. Where will he go this year?

Payment of wages exceeding $147,000,000 to relief workers in up-State New York since the first project was started in August, 1935, until Jan. 1, 1938, was reported today by Lester W. Herzog, WPA administrator up-State.

The Great 'Blizzard of 1888,, fifty years old yesterday, took its annual dip into its Fountain of Youth-that is, the yearly dinner of the Blizzard Men of '88-and emerged refreshed and strong, ready to shine again as the biggest, baddest, meanest, coldest, toughest blizzard of all history.
The average Hunter College freshman prefers cultural activities to sewing and cooking, according to a survey made this week by journalism students at the college.

More than 300 attorneys, professors of law and jurists have sponsored a petition for discontinuance of the embargo on war materials for Loyalist Spain, according to the Lawyers Committee on American Relations With Spain, 150 Broadway.

Officials of the New Jersey College for Women announced today that Miss Alice Billman of Metuchen, a senior student, had received a Voorhees Fellowship for graduate study in chemistry. The fellowship, established from funds bequeathed in 1932 by Elizabeth Rodman Voorhees, is valued at $1,200.

Miss Mary Kendel of this city, from the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Kendel of Denver, was married to Hugh Randolph Conklin of New York yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Riverside Church. The ceremony was performed in the presence of a few friends by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick.

It will be Temple against Oklahoma A. and M. and New York University, metropolitan ruler, against Colorado in an all-championship semi-final of the national invitation collegiate basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. The winners will advance to Wednesday's final, with the losers meeting in a third-place play-off.

Prominent persons in the city headed by Miss Lillian D. Wald and Maurice P. Davidson have taken over the performance of "Schoolhouse on the Lot," 'a new comedy by Joseph A. Fields and Jerome Chadorov, the night of March 23 at the Ritz Theatre, for a Victory Theatre Party for Mayor Florello H. La Guardia and officials of the city administration. The committee.

The famous "Baker estate," which investigators estimate has drawn thousands of claimants to a mythical $300,000,000 fortune in the past half century, popped up again today. Six Western Pennsylvania men, convicted of using the mails to defraud in connection with the "estate,"

This city, which has two city halls, both in use, is facing complications with a church in getting rid of the older building at Fifth and Franklin Streets, which State and district relief organizations have occupied for nearly a decade.
Friends of the late Ramsay MacDonald were surprised to learn that the former Laborite Prime Minister left more than [pound]25,000.

MONTREAL, Que.-March sunshine and superb snow conditions have resulted in record week-end travel to the Laurentian Mountains. On a recent week-end 10,000 Winter sports enthusiasts, mostly skiers, journeyed to the Laurentians-a figure exceeded only by the Christmas and New Year's totals.

Engineering students at Rutgers University will be able to study fuel research and related problems under new conditions, because of an important addition in equipment, a specially built engine installed this week.

Well-informed officials indicated today that the Administration may ask John D. Biggers, Ohio glass manufacturer, to become its official business conciliator, with the title of Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

Agitation over the sovereignty of certain islands in the Pacific, claimed by both the United States and- Great Britain, has focused world attention on these little dots in the vast reaches of the South seas, which has been increased by the development of aviation.

If passed in its present form, the measure introduced by Senator Patman in Congress calling for the taxing of chain stores will probably bring about the extinction of many of the large chain organizations and lead to thousands of store vacancies throughout the nation, states Robert Tankoos of Tankoos, Smith Co., brokerage firm.
Dr. Arthur Seyss-Inquart, the new Austrian Chancellor, has long been a Nazi and since 1926 has definitely been interested in Austro-German "Anschluss." or union.

To the Art Editor: I TAKE it that Igor Steinvaloff's letter last Sunday, concerning art at the World's Fair, was aimed at least in part against my earlier letter regarding utility values in art. May I have a little space for rebuttal?

The Social Security Board got positive evidence yesterday that its campaign to educate the public in the need for social security account numbers was beginning to take hold. Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director, told of receiving the following message from the head of an up-State field M office of the board:

General Juan Yague today succeeded in forcing his way eastward from Belchite another fifteen miles to Azalia and then pushing straight ahead with half of his forces to capture Escatron, seven miles farther on.
Americans are willful. Americans are extravagant. America does not understand Japan. But, nevertheless, America has done many things for Japan.

THE Postoffice Department has been requested by Representative Francis H. Case of South Dakota to issue a stamp next year to commemorate the State's admittance to the Union on Nov. 2, 1889. As a design he has suggested a portrait of Sitting Bull, Red Cloud or another famous Sioux Indian, the Mount Rushmore Presidential figures, or some scene identified with the State's history.
