MR. HOWARD'S dramatic version of "Dodsworth" has appeared richly and smoothly at the Palace Theatre with Philip Merivale and Gladys Cooper in the leading parts. It has been praised for its fidelity to Sinclair Lewis's novel, but it does not give the impression of the original. The fault is not in Mr.

THE three leading garden club organizations contribute no small share of interest to the Flower Show. The support of the garden clubs-recent as compared with that of the Horticultural Society of New York and the Florists Club-has developed into a continuing activity.

Recent shifts in the merchandising policies of corporate chain grocery organizations as a result of competition from super-markets have posed a difficult problem for manufacturers of grocery products over the sales terms granted to warehouses of chains.

VERY few directors are going abroad this year in search of authentic Old World backgrounds, and one of these lucky voyagers is Clarence Brown, who will strive to isolate in some as yet unsuspecting Swiss canton a satisfactorily picturesque locale for Metro's forthcoming version of Robert Sherwood's "Idiot's Delight."

The University of Pennsylvania has created a Department of American Civilization, which is to administer a new combination of graduate courses in American history and literature for students who wish to specialize in the broad field of the development of social and cultural institutions.

" Essentials for Sustained Recovery" will be discussed at the.fiftyeighth -semi-annual meeting of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor March 25. Leaders in government, education, finance and industry will speak.

Penn State's fleet runners set three new gym records. tonight in the fifth annual indoor track meet at Catholic University. Olexy shaved 7.9 seconds off the mile open handicap record by his 4:34.1 flight, and Pierce, running the 880-yard handicap in 2:01.6, clipped 4-10 of a second from the record. Smith,

WHEN Robert Alexandre, the director, commenced filming "Monastery," the picture now at the Squire Theatre, he soon discovered that he would have to make it without any of the facilities of a modern studio. Accustomed to making his own rules and regulations for use while a picture is in progress, he also found that in this case the reverse was true.
Princeton University's football squad will begin. Spring practice Monday under Head Coach Tad Wieman. Despite the demands of baseball and other Spring sports, a turnout of forty is expected.
The Temple University gymnasts easily defeated Princeton today, 43-11, the Tigers taking only one first place. Fritz Snyder won the flying rings for the Orange and Black.

Acting on behalf of industrial interests and property owners in the immediate area, the Bronx Board of Trade, through its president, Roderick Stephens, has requested Senators-Wagner and Copeland and Representatives Fitzpatrick, Curley and Buckley to support the War Department's request for an appropriation of $1,900,000 to complete the improvement of the Bronx River.

FOR gardeners the new year is yet on the threshold--Nature's new year, that in primordial religious rites was celebrated with the sprouting of seed and the advance of green spears against the reeling cohorts of Winter.

Some administration leaders predicted privately today that the troubled European situation would help them to win House approval of the $1,000,000,000 naval expansion program next week. Representative Luckey, Democrat, of Nebraska, a leader of the opposition, agreed with them that the Nazi seizure of Austria had come at an opportune time for advocates of the big navy bill.

For an overwhelming human-interest story, this generation has had no such spectacle .as the latest Moscow treason trial, now in its final stages. But its historic significance far transcends the personal drama. What has happened and is happening to Soviet Russia is of vastly more importance than the fate of Stalin or his opponents.
ANUMBER of years ago, the departure platform of the Gare du Nord in Paris was the scene. one day, of a fateful farewell between "two young people just falling desperately, irrevocably in love."

Officials will be elected in forty-seven incorporated villages in Nassau County on Tuesday. The pre-election campaigns have been less lively than in previous years, although contests will be held in twelve villages.

Inventories of two of the largest distributors of domestics at the end of February were nearly 40 per cent below those of a year ago and one large distributor had commitments 70 per cent below a year ago, the Buscher Yarn Division of Turner Halsey Company reported yesterday.

A recheck of the active cash today revealed that $6,301 instead of $2,500 had been stolen in yesterday's holdup of the Mattituck National Bank and Trust Company by four armed men, who fled in an automobile.

Seventeen students from New York and vicinity were among sixty cited this week by the Rev. John F. Cox, dean of Holy Cross College, for good work during the first semester. James J. Morris of Brooklyn is highest ranking senior in the science course, and Gerald F. Whalen of White Plains is highest ranking freshman in the arts division.

William H. Kelly, who had been asked by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau to resign as Collector of Internal Revenue for Northern New Jersey, announced today that he had sent his resignation, effective April 1, to President Roosevelt last night.

FOR a quarter of a century one of Edith Wharton's best novels, "Ethan Frome," has been enshrined as an American masterpiece and now Bernard de Voto has examined anew the reasons for this beatification in an interesting but debatable preface-to a new edition, which is a model of design and craftsmanship for a trade book (Charles Scribner's Sons, $1.75).

A two-day congress of Hunarians and Hungarian Americans ving in the United States and Canda began here today with the object of proclaiming their opposi.on to the persecution of minorities 1 Central Europe.

The Studebaker Corporation earned $811,874 last year on sales of 91,475 passenger and commercial cars for $70,683,260, according to the annual report for 1937 made public today by Paul G. Hoffman, president. The earnings, equivalent to 37 cents each on 2,199,371 shares of $1 par common stock, compared with the 1936 net profit of $2,187,783 on the sale of 91,999 units for $68,928,724, or $1.01 a share.

Eight houses have recently been completed on a portion of the Joseph P. Day estate at Short Hills which was opened for home development last year and four of them have been sold for occupancy to young couples in Essex County, reports James Barrett, supervisor of sales.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls defeated the New York Rovers, 3 to 2, tonight to keep their hold on second place in the Eaftery Armateur Ice Iockey League. With the score 3 to 1 in favor of the Sea Gulls at the start of the final period the Rovers started a rally, but produced only one goal. The line-up:

A large number of merchandise prizes, including expensive cameras and enlargers, photoelectric exposure meters and leather albums, are being offered by Marshall Field Co. as prizes in their fifth annual and second international competition and salon.

Spring merchandise moved faster at the end of last week in the ninth district, though retail volume for the week remained at about the same level as the week previous. Better weather, deep price slashes and a heavy turnover in used cars acted to keep the indices from falling below.
Before a crowd estimated at 7,500, the Phoenix, a new 10,000-ton Treaty cruiser, was launched today at the New York Shipbuilding Company's plant here.
Royal Reveler, chestnut gelding owned and ridden by Miss Wilhelmine S. Kirby of Bedford Hills, N. Y., today was adjudged champion hunter of the twenty-eighth Camden Horse Show.

Examinations for regular license as teacher in day technical high schools were announced last week by the Board of Examiners. The tests will be held in the semi-technical modern languages (French and German) and in semi-technical mathematics. Applications must be filed by Friday.
Increased activityy in the steel industry of Vest Central and Southern Illinois .nd a gratifying response on the iart of the public to the used car ales drive featured business her his week.

TOURISTS coming to Mexico see little of the Mexican revolution about which they read before visiting its scene. That is because the Mexicans in charge of tourist promotion have failed to see the value of showing visitors from abroad, and particularly from the United States, what is being accomplished by way of developing Mexico.

Leslie MacMitchell, George Washington High School star, concluded one of the finest indoor careers ever enjoyed by a New York City schoolboy yesterday when he ran a magnificent 4:22.2 mile at the twenty-second annual Manual Training High School interscholastic

The Todd-Feld bill, known as the Nurse Practice bill, which was reported out of the education committees of both houses of the New York Legislature last week, will, if passed, forbid the practice of nurs-ing in this State without a license,

When a man shoved a knife against the ribs of George Cox, a guard in the Broadway and Seventy-second Street branch of the Chase National Bank, yesterday and demanded money, Cox suggested that he see the branch manager and nodded toward a door behind the man.

Governor Lawrence W. Cramer is unsympathetic toward the resolution adopted recently by a group of residents of the Virgin Islands on the subject of internal revenue taxes, it was announced last night at a hearing on tax proposals.

Physicians who have been treating cancer patients under a 1,000,000-volt X-ray machine, the only one of its type in the world, report "surprising results" during the first six months of experimentation.

The Canadian Supreme Court having declared that social credit -as Alberta proposed to establish it is unconstitutional,. not even Premier Aberhart. himself knows what his government is going to do about it, but he will probably know more after March .21 when a-Federal by-election in Edmonton will be made a test of public feeling.
Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Dorothy Low of this place, daughter of Mrs. Dorothy Lewis Low and Josiah Orne Low, to the Rev. Elvin Robert Newton,

Jack Tolson, 151,-triumphed over Joe Pennino,. 148, last night in the main event of eight rounds at the Ridgewood Grove before a crowd .of 3,000 persons. Harold Valan, 130, beat Willie Felice, 126 3/4, in six rounds.

Match Brothers, Brooklyn builders, announce the purchase from the Dime Savings Bank of an entire square block on East Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth Streets from Avenue V to Neck Road, Flatbush, in the Harkness estate section.

exhibits a knot garden planted with herbs at the International Flower Show. Knots originated in medieval times. The design of this particular garden was suggested by one of the beds in the knot garden at Hampton Court, England, its patterns being current during the reign of Queen Elizabeth.

Wilhelm Wachtel, Austrian painter, arrived yesterday on the United States liner President Harding to do several portraits on commissions arranged abroad. He is 62 years old and it is his first visit in this country. Mr. Wachtel was disturbed at the news from Austria but said he had no intention of staying away from Vienna.

By throwing Thomas Kennedy into the fight for the Democratic nomination for Governor this week John L. Lewis and the C. I. O. committed themselves to the most ambitious political drive this militant wing of organized labor has yet undertaken.

Continued heavy rains have hampered to a great extent early Spring activities connected with agriculture, the soil in California valleys being so full of water that preparations for early garden crops have not been possible in- many localities.

More than 300 members of the WPA Teachers Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate, demonstrated outside the WPA offices at 70 Columbus Avenue yesterday in protest against the threatened layoff of WPA teachers and other educational employes during the Summer months.

E. H. H. Simmons, who preceded Richard Whitney as president of the New York Stock Exchange, will be called as a witness tomorrow in the hearings being conducted by Ambrose V. McCall, Assistant State Attorney General, into last week's failure of Richard Whitney Co., of which Mr. Whitney was senior partner.

MEXICO CITY.-The future status of foreign capital in Mexico and the question whether Mexico can continue its present policies are the two major issues in the current financial battle between the Mexican Government and seventeen United States and British petroleum companies with investments in the country of $450,000,000. The direct conflict is one over wages.
A bronze plaque, to be placed in Radio City, will be dedicated to the memory of Guglielmo Marconi by the Italian Professional Women of America on April 3 in a ceremony at Town Hall.
ON the suggestion of Mme, Camille Flammarion, widow of the noted French astronomer, the Paris Municipal Council has decided to make the Obelisk of Luxor into a sun dial.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN is now completing an extensive modernization program. Footpaths, buildings, the rose, bog and morainal gardens, the hemlock forest--all have been repaired. More than a quarter of a million dollars has been spent on the two-acre greenhouse, called Conservatory Range 1.

At the age of 22 Tatiana Victorovna Fedorova, one of the youngest and prettiest of the world's parliamentarians, looks back to a remarkable career in politics, aviation and subway digging, but is content to remain a subway digger for the rest of her life.

Burleigh Grimes sat on the soft turf not far back of the third-base line today while his Dodgers were enjoying their first batting practice and he looked almost contented. Not quite, because the Lord of Burleigh and complete contentment are strangers, despite the fact he is a pipe smoker-and everybody knows what Marse Joe McCarthy says about baseball men who smoke pipes.
PRELIMINARY reports on resuits from the National Used Car Exchange Week, which has been in progress since Saturday a week ago, indicate greater success than had been anticipated.

Ruth and Zena Dickstein, who' are being held in a Polish prison by visa officials, are naturalized American citizens, it was learned yesterday. According to Mrs. Samuel Dickstein, of 111 Avenue B, a sisterin-law of the girls, the sisters, who live with their widowed mother, Mrs. Sadie Dickstein, at 312 East Eighth Street, left for Warsaw last June to visit an older brother, Abraham.

Senator Rush D. Holt, Democrat, of West Virginia, declared today that he would "rather retire from office than sit in the United States Senate as a puppet" of John L. Lewis, C. I. O. chieftain. Mr. Holt, who split with Mr. Lewis soon after he was elected in 1934 with support of the United Mine Workers Union, which Mr.

The new drug sulfanilamidee, which has yielded spectacular results in the treatment of bacterial infections caused by certain types of streptococcus, has also shown great promise in the treatment of undulant fever, also known as Malta fever, according to a report in the British medical journal, The Lancet.

THAT man is here again! He was offered as an entirely new character, a serious Baer. Many took him that way. Perhaps that was the right view. But to this observer he looked like the old Baer with a few new tricks. He posed. He made ferocious faces. He stalked around the ring calmly hitching up his trunks. He made wisecracks in his corner.

Secretary of Labor JOHN BROWN is a native-born New Englander, 45, married, and has a wife and two minor girls. He is a good citizen and a devoted husband and father. He went to work after he finished grammar school because he had to, in order to help his widowed mother care for the younger children in the family.

A group of prominent New York women have been appointed by Mrs. Samuel A. Lewisohn to serve as hostesses at the Public Education Association's benefit exhibition of portraits at the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, which opens tomorrow and will continue through Friday.

More than 1,000 new members were placed on the national rolls of the Society of Residential Appraisers during the past year, to give the organization its greatest growth for any year thus far, according to word received here by Frank D. Hall, president of the Greater New York chapter, from the society's national president, F. S. Cannon of Indianapolis.
Dedication exercises opening new building of Ninth Street Day Nursery and Orphan Home, 393 East Eighth Street, 2 P. M.

By winning five first places and scoring heavily in the remaining four events, Ohio State won the Big Ten swimming championship for the first time in history in the new Trier High School pool tonight.
Michigan won the Big Ten wrestling championship tonight with a total of 28 points, displacing Illinois, which finished third behind Indiana. The Hoosiers collected 25 points and the Illini 19.

An explosive said to be more powerful than those now in use yet safer and more economical to make and handle can be produced by taking into consideration the minute distances between atoms in molecules of chemical compounds, it is revealed in a patent granted here to Ingo W. D. Hackh, Professor of Chemistry in the College of Physicians and Surgeons, San Francisco.

The St. Joseph's women's basketball team had little trouble defeating Hunter College, 39 to 10, yesterday on the winner's court to register its seventh straight triumph of the season. Miss Jane Walsh paced the victors with' nine field goals for 18 points.
NASSAU, Bahamas.-On Wednesday and Thursday a team from the Royal Nassau Sailing Club and a team from the Nassau Yacht Club will compete for the Aloma Cup here.
The navy's annual war game, which some think is of greater significance today than ever before because of the international situation, will be marked throughout by great secrecy.

Science teaching in the secondary schools of this country is pitched to the level of a mythical "average" pupil, and as a result, the gifted student frequently is neglected, a survey comparing the physical sciences of the United States, France and Russia disclosed yesterday.

A goal by Miss Marie Tully, which broke a 19-19 tie, enabled the Savage women's basketball team to defeat Rider College today, 21. to 20. It was the final game of the season for the invaders, who concluded their campaign with a record of a dozen victories and one setback.

Tall, seven-branched candelabra bearing lighted tapers, white dogwood boughs, clusters of sweet peas and smilax provided the decorative scheme in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday for the marriage of Miss Carolyn Maynard to H. William Snell.

A break in the prolonged deadlock in new corporate bond financing finally appears to be assured. Steps taken by several large corporations, including negotiations between the prospective borrowers and investment bankers, reached last week a stage which gave a reasonable assurance of a resumption of corporate borrowing on a sizable scale within the next few months, barring unforeseen developments.

THE twentieth anniversaryy exhibition of the Brooklyn Society of. Miniature Painters will be held at the National Arts Club from April 7 to April 29. Work must be received by James J. Kelleher, 243 Lexington Avenue, on or before March 28.

Miss Rosanne Lawrence Wigham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald E. Wigham of 131 East Sixty-fifth Street, wore her mother's wedding gown for her marriage yesterday afternoon to Nicholas Cooke Jenks, New York broker. St. James's Church was decorated with ferns, palms and lilies for the ceremony, which was performed by the Rev.

Many instructive facts for mortgage brokers and realty interests in general will be found in the handbook of mortgage policies of the leading life insurance companies which was issued last week by the brokers' division of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

UNROMANTIC: Kennebunkport, a Maine town familiar to Summer visitors, took its name from an Indian word meaning "green banks." Originally the town was called Arundel, and by this name has appeared in the writing of Kenneth Roberts.

George M. Phillips of 128 Fort Washington Avenue, retired men's clothier, died of euremic poisoning Friday night in the Misericordia Hospital at the age of 69. For fortysix years, until a fortnight ago, the clothing store bearing his name was at 249 West Forty-second Street. Charles E. and Frederick A. Phillips, two of his sons, who have managed the business since 1923, recently moved it to 1,450 Broadway.

The third annual New Jersey national home show will open next Saturday in the 113th Regiment Armory, Sussex Avenue and Jay Street, Newark, and will continue through the following week, closing March 28.

Arrangements have been completed for the annual Spring meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club on Saturday and Sunday, March 26 and 27, at the Kilsyth Farm of Gerald M. Livingston, Huntington.

MIAMI, Fla.--Tuesday marks the limit of time within which Florida composers may enter their musical compositions for a song honoring the State, to be sung at the State convention of the Florida Federation of Music Clubs, scheduled to be held at the Miami Biltmore Hotel, Coral Gables, from March 29 through April 2. Lyrics,

The final figures covering the operations of the Siscoe Gold Mines in 1937 show a new production record, a new low level for costs and a new high level for profits and tonnage milled. Net profit was $1,186,551, equal to 25.57 cents a share, against $1,030,099, or 22.16 cents a share in the previous year.

Under the pressure of Germany's shock tactics against Austria the British Government began seriously and anxiously today to consider what it would do if the German mailed fist descended soon upon Czechoslovakia.

Winthrop C. Neilson, a vice president of the Aluminum Company of America and president of the Republic Mining and Manufacturing Company, died at his home here early today, after more than a year of poor health. He was born in Philadelphia sixty years ago.
Japan closely watched the Austrian crisis today, receiving hourly radio reports on developments.

Sweeping changes in the character of the steel industry in the last two decades appear destined to continue as a result of research and development work on the one hand and of aggressive sales efforts on the other.
Ulli Beutter of Germany plunged down Durrance Mountain today at a speed which at times neared the 60-mile-an-hour mark to place first in the international open downhill ski race.

The Duke of Kent will speak at the Pilgrims dinner to the United States Ambassador at Claridge's on March 18. Viscount Halifax, Foreign Secretary, will propose Mr. Kennedy's health and the Earl of Derby will preside. Mrs. Curtis Brown,

Camp Technology, the Summer surveying school of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will be opened this year to students of high academic standing from other colleges and engineering schools as well as properly qualified students in any course at the institute.

Senators who want a broad Congressional investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority contended today that developments at President Roosevelt's hearing into TVA's internal dissension had emphasized need for such an inquiry.

The dramatic vents occurring in Vienna Friday mut a new complexion on Italo-Gernan relations and, despite Italian rotestations that Adolf Hitler's oup is a normal and logical develpment in the Austrian situation, ealt the Rome-Berlin axis a severe ,low.

Accidents disable sixteen persons out of every 1,000. for a week or more annually and caused 7 per cent of all deaths in the nation, the United States Public Health Service announced today as the result of a health survey covering 740,000 families, made in 1935-36.

When the Insurgent cruiser Baleares was sunk Sunday, a new leaf was turned in the record of the Spanish civil war. It showed that Loyalist Spain at last has a navy that holds possibilities of such importance that it is worth giving the naval situation brief study.

Nicolai Berezowsky, Douglas Moore and Quincy Porter have been added to the executive board of the League of Composers. In addition to the lecture by Nadia Boulanger, April 1, at the Cosmopolitan Club, and the fourth broadcast, the league's plans for this season include a demonstration of certain new musical inventions.

A dinner was given last night by Mrs. Kelly Schofield in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Jeannette MacKelvie and George Lutley Sclater-Booth, who will be married on Tuesday in the chapel of St. Thomas Church.

Uneasy were the American Bowling Congress leaders tonight as the biggest scoring splurge of the forty-eightday tournament continued in high gear. Changes were recorded in the standings of each of the four divisions.

BENJAMIN WEST (now being honored at the Pennsylvania Museum) was not, as we look back at him, a giant; but neither was his a talent that can be discerned only, from our distant station in time, through a telescope.

Royal Mail, winner of the 1937 Grand National Steeplechase and one of the favorites for this year's running of the Aintree classic, was sold at auction today to Mrs. J. M. Evans for 6,500 guineas (about $34,125).

THE performance this week by the Schola Cantorum of J. S. Bach's "Passion According to St. John," a work that was formerly consigned to occasions of special musical or religious circumstance, is an indication of the new way that the modern public has come to look upon Bach and his art.
AMATEUR planters are inclined to think vegetables take a lot of space. Some, such as potatoes and Winter squash, do call for ample elbow room, and a few plants of these yield but little return.

WITH Spring not yet official, it is the pleasure of Ruth Selwyn to look this morning at the Christmas holidays-the next Christmas. holidays. Or even if it isn't a pleasure, she is looking in that direction just the same, gazing at an intimate musical show called "The King With the Umbrella." It is practically under your Christmas tree right now, with greetings from the producer, Miss S.

THE twenty-fifth International Flower Show opens tomorrow at Grand Central Palace with a display of gardens unequaled in Flower Show history. No effort was deemed too great, no care too precise in this silver jubilee year to bring living gardens and perfection of bloom to the Palace for the enjoyment of gardeners and flower fanciers.

President Roosevelt saw and heard himself lampooned before 600 guests at the seventeenth annual dinner of the White House Correspondents Association at the Mayflower Hotel tonight. It was all "off the record," with "no reporters present."
Heber M. Wells, Utah's first Gov ernor and prominent Latter-Day Saints Church official and business man, died there today of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 78 years old.

THE designation of' March 20 to 26 as National Wild-Life Restoration Week, as recently announced by President Roosevelt, marks a new 'drive to save America's natural resources. Business men, farmers and sportsmen are joining in this attempt to protect our animals, birds, fishes and their habitats, our flowers, trees and streams from any further such havoc as has been made by earlier generations.

Department. store sales improved seasonally this week, up 5 per cent from last week, and averaging even with a year -ago for the first time in two months. However, there was considerable irregularity among the four reporting stores, one up 7 per cent from a year ago and another off 10 per cent, with two unchanged.

Europe's "Black Friday," as The Sunday Times, in an editorial calls the German annexation of Austria, has produced unanimous condemnation of Germany's employment of "brute force" in the British press.
The change from an Austrian authoritarian regime to a Nazi authoritarian government today vitally affected the lives of every one in Austria. These were some of the outward appearances:

AMONG the more important events of the New York Fed eration of Music Clubs' convention to be held in Binghamton, N. Y., April 20-23, will be a choir festival in which a chorus of 300 voices will participate, a Junior Day, a lobby sing conducted by Geoffrey O'Hara and Edwin Weeks, and a sacred concert.

Preliminary reports received from various sections of the country regarding consumer response to the celebration of National Spring Millinery Week have been favorable, according to Walter K. Marks, chairman of the trade promotion committee of the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc.
Electric power lines surpassing anything now possible are foreseen in experiments with a steel ,vacuum tube described today at. Cornell University. The tube looks like a threefoot metal urn.

THE Snowden Marshall estate on the Mill River and Sugar Hill Road near Ridgefield, Conn., recently restored at a cost of about $75,000, has been sold for cash to Aaron A. Shapiro, head of the Martha West Stores on Madison Avenue.

The first threat of the National Maritime Union to tie up a government-owned ship because she was to be taken from her pier by a towboat company that is experiencing labor difficulties failed, it was learned yesterday.

MANY recent garden books like magazines-are "going pictorial." In many instances rich effects are obtained through natural-color photography, though much fine work is still being done in black and white.

The Ridgewood Polo Club's national junior champions defeated Essex Troop, 14 to 9, tonight in an exhibition game after the Troopers had defaulted to them in a semi-final of the New Jersey championships.

Twenty-one Westchester villages will conduct their annual elections on Tuesday. Ten will have contests, some with three or four political parties in the field, an propositions will be determined in scarsdale and Mamaroneck.
Eight of the army's giant "flying fortresses" led a friendly air attack on Tampa from Michigan today to demonstrate how the army can cover the nation in an emergency.

New York University's fencing team turned back the Saltus F. C., 18 to 9, yesterday on the latter's strips in the Twenty-third Street Y. M. C. A. to account for its sixth victory of the season. The Violet had been tied once and is undefeated.

RADIO is not as chivalrous as the stage and screen, but it is becoming more so. The mute "mike" has never devoted as much attention to the ladies as to male troubadours. In fact, the broadcasters have always favored man's voice, and, if asked why, they "pass the buck" to the audience, because they contend the stronger voice has the greater public appeal. Winsomeness,

SOMEHOW the impression has gotten about in America that gardening is only for Eve. There is no authentic information as to what happened in Eden before the expulsion. The Bible does not record who raised the vegetables, but there is an implication, at least, that even then the man had to delve and bend his back to get something done.
A new group of all-year cottages will be erected by Walter C. Hewitt, realty man of Northport and Huntington, L. I., on his company's property in East Northport.

Form went by the boards in the English Football League today with only one of the five championship contenders victorious. Middlesbrough downed the leading Arsenal eleven, 2-1, to take third place behind the Gunners aird Wolverhampton. The Wolves were beaten, 1-0, at Grimsby.

The value of building permits issued last year throughout the country was about $1,700,000,000, according to figures released yesterday by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor. This was an increase of about 10 per cent over 1936 and about equaled the level of construction in 1931.

The B. F. Goodrich Company has proposed to its workers a flexible work day and work week. The Goodrich local of the United Rubber Workers of America agreed to vote on the proposal and started preparations today for a ballot on March 20.
American machinery and services to the extent of $300,000,000 can be utilized by Manchukuo if plans Yoshisuke Aikawa outlined to this correspondent today materialize.
In a little under two weeks the trout season will open in New York. You're undoubtedly well aware of this fact, but are you prepared?
Army, in its last home indoor polo game, easily won from Princeton today, 15 to 4. It was the cadets' eighth victory in nine starts, Harvard having defeated them in midseason.

THE superior-person attitude adopted by some authors toward journalists has been castigated by W. P. Crozier, editor of The Manchester Guardian, in an address to the convocation of Manchester University. In his opinion.
For more than twenty-five years William A. Ruggles has been at work in the General Electric Research Laboratories in Schenectady at the task of obtaining a high vacuum.

A denunciation of Representative Maverick of Texas and other Representatives who have fought against the pending Naval Expansion Bill was contained in a speech made at Chapel Hill, N. C., by Earl Browder, head of the Communist party of America.

Several hundred thousand Catholic college and high school students throughout the United States are forming affiliates of the America Spanish Relief Fund, the national Catholic movement aiding non-combatant victims of the civil war in Spain,

The AAA's proposals to apply marketing quotas to restrict sales of 1938 cotton appeared to have won an overwhelming victory in a farmer referendum today. Unofficial tabulations from 658 of the nation's 1,500 cotton counties gave 1,019,499 votes for the quotas and 77,872 against.

Dates for three regional conferences to discuss real estate matters have just been set, announces the National Association of Real Estate Boards. The first will be that of the Great Lakes region, to be held in Chicago this week, beginning Thursday and continuing through Saturday. The States to be represented include Indiana, Michigan, Ohio, Illinois and Kentucky.
Months of battling with good old Bowditch, Dutton and Great Circle charts and all the other headaches of advanced navigation have ended for a dozen New York Power Squadron skippers.

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today an application by trustees of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad for authority to borrow $1,800,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The railroad plans to use more -than 65- per cent of the loan for rail and other track material.

HOT on the heels of the Philadelphia set and released without benefit of advance listing comes a Columbia album of Beethoven's First symphony played by the Vienna Philharmonic under Felix Weingartner. Little experience is necessary to estimate in advance how these two compare.

Commenting on Austrian events, The Netherlands press unanimously considers the German stroke extremely serious for the safety of smaller European nations and concludes that for her own independence this country cannot rely on any but her own strength.

Four students, three of them from New Jersey, will be initiated into Phi Beta Kappa at Wheaton College on Friday. Ruth MacCubbin of Montclair, Margaret Knights of Chatham and Dorothy Littlefield of Sanford, Me., are the senior candidates, while Janet Smock of Lakewood, N. J., is the only junior elected.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in somewhat smaller valume than in the preceding week and the individual calls were principally for parts of issues rather than entire loans.

The Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletio Union will hold women's gymnastic championships Saturday at the New York Turn Verein, starting at 7:30 P. M. For the past few weeks gymnastic clubs in the metropolitan district with women and girls in their membership have been engaged in elimination trials to select representatives for the junior and senior A. A. U. events.
Rosegill, the Urbanna (Va.) estate formerly owned by Henry L. Bogert of New York City, has been sold to Ben Temple of Lynchburg, Va., reports Previews, Inc.

PLANTING for the first time a city garden one finds to his surprise, and sometimes to his disappointment, that the plants he could rely on in the country do not easily adjust themselves to the city situation. The number of kinds of plants suited to urban use is limited. Even those which will succeed need special care.

An attempt is being made to solve the servant problem in Britain by the creation of "a vast fellowship of persons of goodwill." The task is being undertaken by an association called theWayfarer Guild, which is .to be divided into two sections consisting of "household employers" and "household workers," for no more is to be heard of "mistresses" and "servants."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Prime -Minister Neville Chamberlain's statement of British foreign policy to the House of Commons published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 8 contains declarations of principles equivalent to the American "good neighbor" policy and, if duly implemented, can initiate that new era in international affairs which was visioned as an outcome of the World War.

The Music School of the Henry Street Settlement, which serves also as a center of neighborhood music activities on the lower East Side, will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Parsifal" the evening of April 18.

A special appeals board of three leading educators will be established by the Municipal Civil Service Commission to pass on appeals from the contestants who failed in the written and oral examinations for the post of examiner on the board of examiners of the Department of Education.

Now that Austria has, for all practical purposes, become part of Germany, the question arises: What can the Reich get out of her? What are her natural resources that Germany can use? What are the gains of the Third Reich in the political and diplomatic field?

A former convict who had served three prison terms, then reformed. and kept out of trouble for twenty years while he worked into a responsible position, found himself yesterday one of seven defendants accused of the theft of phonograph records valued at more than $40,000 from the company that employed him.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Lindeman of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Jean Marie Lindeman, to Robert J. Jacobson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Jacobson of New York.

WITH the interest in rock gardens of the better type continuing to grow, many home owners whose properties are level, or nearly so, are faced with the problem of whether they can succeed in getting a satisfactory effect with this type of landscaping.
The twenty-sixth anniversary of the founding of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, will be celebrated by the New York chapter tonight at Temple Emanu-El.

Miss Betty Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Draper Lewis of chestnut Hill, this city, was married this afternoon to William Ripley Nichols, son of Mrs. William Ripley Nichols of Santa Barbara, Calif. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Leicester Lewis, the ??rector, in the Church of St. Martin??in-the-Fields.
Big Nels Stewart returned to his old stamping ground tonight and personally took a hand as the New York Americans turned back the Montreal Maroons, .3-1, before a slim crowd of about 4,000.

The Merchants Association of New York has filed with Senate leaders at Albany its "strong objection" to a bill passed by the Assembly making it a misdemeanor to sell imported merchandise. unless it carries a conspicuous mark of the country of origin.

The Department of Justice and the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today the indictment of Caroline Evans, Adrian White and N. J. Stokes of Denver by a Federal grand jury there for alleged violations of the Securities Act of 1933, the Mail Fraud Act and the conspiracy statutes.

The value of a college education in- department store occupations was questioned yesterday by city department store executives who spoke at the closing session of the annual two-day Career Conference of the Vocational Service for Juniors held in. the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Jumping into the lead at the outset, the Benjamin Franklin High School basketball team, winner of the P. S. A. L. Lower Manhattan Division crown, triumphed over Port Richmond, Richmond sectional titleholder, 37 to 23, yesterday at James Madison High_ School in acre a quarter-final contest. The winner will meet Evander Childs at trunk, Madison Square Garden on Wednesday.

Squadron A clinched its place in the play-offs of the Metropolitan League last night in its own ring when it defeated the First Division polo team, 14 to 6. Starting next Saturday night the Squadron players will ride against Boulder Brook and Evergreen Farms in the battle for the title.

LEIPZIG. BETWEEN Feb. 13, the fiftyfifth anniversary of his death, and May 22, the 125th of his birth, the Leipzig Stadttheater is giving a cycle of Wagner's operas. It is a cycle in the completest sense of the word-one that begins at the beginning and ends at the end. It does not avoid,

Two decades of progress in the development of contemporary Jewish Palestine are reviewed in a statistical report issued yesterday by the United Palestine Appeal, which is seeking $4,500,000 for the settlement in the Holy Land of refugees WIN from European countries.

Reeves J. Newsom, president-elect of the American Water Works Association, in a statement issued yes terday declared that municipalgovernments must realize they can no longer look to Washington for extensive grants for water-works improvements and that henoeforth elpansion of water-supply facilities must be financed largely by the cities themselves.

AGE and athletics ordinarily do not go together and when, recently, Dr. Graeme M. Hammond at fourscore years ran four miles he not only set up a new record but also upset tradition. Yet for him the performance was not difficult. Three times a week he circles the running track of the New York Athletic Club until he has covered three miles.. And while,

Religion, propaganda, curriculum, taboos and guidance in the junior high schools of the nation were discussed yesterday by panel members attending-the second day of the fourteenth annual Junior High School Conference, sponsored by New York University's School of Education.

Notre Dame trackmen placed in ten of eleven events to win the Central Intercollegiate Conference indoor track and field title and set a new scoring record of 56 points today. The old mark was 441 1/2 points, set by Notre Dame in 1929. Pittsburgh took runner-up honors with 241 1/2, while Michigan State was thired with 23.
Troops manning the powerful Maginot Line defenses facing the German border were held to their posts tonight as France took an increasingly grave view of the European crisis.

A large reproduction of the rock paintings on the roof of one of the galleries in Altamira Cave, near Santander, Spain, once occupied by prehistoric men of the late Paleolithic Age, has been received recently by the American Museum of Natural History as a gift from Professor Leo Frobenius,

Mr. and Mrs. William H. Dunne of this place gave a tea at their home this afternoon to announce the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Dunne, to John J. Kirby, son of Mrs. John J. Kirby of New York and the late Mr. Kirby.

The Toronto Maple Leafs were assured of at least a tie for first place in the National Hockey League's International Group tonight by battling to a 3-3 tie with the Canadiens. The deadlock dropped the Canadiens into third place in the sectional standing. The Leafs -now have 53-points, including tonight's deadlock, a nd the mericans have 45. with four more games to Dlav.

The German swastika was raised over the Austrian Legation at 2,343 Massachusetts Avenue in the fashionable Sheridan Circle section today in celebration of the coup executed by Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

The Columbia chess team scored its sixth consecutive triumph of the Winter today by turning back the Princeton club, 3 1/2-1 1/2. Three of the five matches resulted in ties, with Richard Arnson and Edward Schortman, both of Columbia, ringing up the only clear-cut verdicts of the day in defeating Peter Vermilye and Wolfgang Panofsky, respectively.

FLOWER SHOW week is a favorable time to plan the Spring and Summer campaign against garden pests. For the show will display the newest materiel for rearmament, and every conscientious gardener will be as fascinated by such trade exhibits as by the flowers themselves.

BARRIE died in June of last year, and the two volumes under review are pleasant commemoration of his singularly dualistic career as a journalist and a genius Barrie himself, in these various reprints of his early journalism,- with later comments, celebrates his flit acquaintance with the newspapers.

One of the earliest indications of Spring in the society colonies of the North Shore is the placing of gate markers, bearing the names of esstates, at the main and service entrances to the grounds, and this season, together with the newly painted and re-lettered signs of -the older places, there are many recently named homes.

Miss Eleanor Lois Knight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Octavius Knight of this place, was married to Donald Mason Wack of Point Pleasant this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur E. O'Donnell of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Westfield, in the presence of relatives and a few friends.
Al Vande Weghe, Princeton's Olympic back-stroke ace, added another record to his long list in winning the-150-yard back-stroke senior men's State A. A. U. championship in 1:35.9 tonight.
THE Payne-Boylan-radio station tax bill received a jolt during the past week when Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the. FCC, made public a letter--he had written to the House Ways and Means Committee.

In the third and fourth elections held under Georgia's new local option law, two rural counties voted today to legalize liquor. The Pierce County vote was 729 to 183 and that of Coffee County, with fragmentary returns missing, was 714 to 221 wet.

PROLOGUE TO GLORY-Tuesday evening at Maxine Elliott's Theatre. A comedy by E. P. Conkle, and based upon Lincoln's courtship of Ann Rutledge. Stephen Courtleigh plays the leading role, with another member of the cast being Ann Rutledge, great grandniece of the original.
AMONG the several rather technical operations which the amateur gardener must master before he can expect to achieve real successes none is more important than that of transplanting.

There was heavy buying of dollars in the Foreign Exchange market here today on account of movements of capital from Europe to the United States, following the latest developments in the Austrian situation. The dollar rate at one time hardened to 4.98 1/4 to the pound, compared with yesterday's $5.00 1/2, but the Bank of England came to the support of sterling, which eventually recovered slightly to $4.99.

Opposition to the proposed location of the low-rent-housing project to be erected in Queens, is expressed by C. Grant Keck, Long Island City broker, who advances several reasons why it would be disadvantageous to construct the development on the site selected.

Viscountess Milner, editor and proprietor of the well-known monthly The National Review, has released advance extracts from the March issue of The Review, in which the proposed trade agreement between the United States and Great Britain is discussed.

THE Negroes around Los Angeles talk like New Jerseyites and the Oklahomans talk like Negroes--that is, with a genuinely Southern accent. Since Oklahoma has contributed a large share of the population here, the Southern accent predominates among all peoples except the colored.

Thirty-two children, patrons of the Philharmonic-Symphony Youth Concerts, received medals, ribbons and special prizes for the best notebooks written in connection with the series yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall in the sixth and final concert of the season. Presentations were made by Rudolph Ganz, who conducted this season's series instead of Ernest Schelling, the regular director, and by John Barbirolli.

THE unique value of the modern daylilies to owners of small home gardens lies in the dependable succession of bloom provided by these hardy and easy-to-grow perennials. The new daylilies are sure to be a revelation to all who are unaware of the latest improvements in them and of how they have been blossoming out into a surprising number of new varieties.

The Texas New Orleans Railroad, a subsidiary of the Southern Pacific, operating, in Texas and Louisiana, filed today an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $60,607,000 of 4 1/2 per cent first and refundingmortgage bonds.

Models of faulty old - law tenements, with their wooden stairways, dark rooms and deteriorating construction will be exhibited together with models of housing projects constructed under government and private sponsorship at the National Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries at Grand Central Palace, March 28 to April 2.

Levin Baker Huntington, 67 years old, a fishing-tackle manufacturer of Baltimore, resident of Annapolis and native of New Rochelle, N. Y., was killed this afternoon when an unidentified steamer struck a launch in which he was fishing a mile off Hillsboro Light.

The diamond jubilee edition of the Manhattan College senior annual, The Manhattanite, will be ready for distribution on April 26, when Manhatta nwill mark the seventy-fifth anniversary of the granting of its charter by the Legislature, Brother Paul Edward, F. S. C., announced yesterday.
Department store sales in this district were 8 to 6 per cent above a year ago. Wholesale trade remained principally unchanged.
William J. Stevenson, general counsel and a director of the Nickel Plate Railroad, died at his home in Shaker Heights this morning of a heart attack. His age was 51.

Authorities at Yale are convinced that its bursary scholarships "have opened to self-supporting students such opportunities as to promise important changes in the entire concept of aiding students to work their way through college."

Audience participation in theatre performances was advocated yesterday at the closing session of the cultural arts conference held in the Lincoln School auditorium of teachers College. Children, especially, should be allowed to whistle, yell, climb on the stage and in other ways become part of the show, speakers held.

Economists who foster the sunspot theory of the,ups and downs of the business cycle were criticized yesterday by Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard College Observatory, with the assertion that they had not enough factual material on which to base such a theory.

A rush of briefs and statements today marked the closing hours for filing opinions on the forthcoming United States-Canada trade agreement. Officials said somewhat under 200 briefs had been received. Public hearings will begin April 4.

The Harvard varsity basketball team ended its season in a blaze of glory tonight before a crowd of 2,000 with a smashing 57-to-42 victory over Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game. Arnold Litman, Crimson forward, playing his final game for the team, gave a splendid exhibition both offensively and defensively.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler was enthusiastically welcomed everywhere in his native province in Upper Austria by Nazis in the towns and countryside. His big black automobile arrived about 6:30 this evening at Linz, provincial capital, where the Nazis prepared an overwhelming welcome for their leader.

THE Cotton Club has a new hit on its hands. Tapping with a lavish and expensive hand the supply of entertainment which the Negro race has to offer, Herman Stark, the club's boniface, opened Thursday night a tuneful, peppy and humorous production which keeps inviolate his institution's record for superior night club diversion.
Faculty clinics to aid students whose grades are below average have been established at Muhlenberg College this semester by President Levering Tyson and Harry A. Benfer, registrar.
Judge Louis Le Baron sentenced Leo Crowley, newspaper editor convicted of criminal libel, to 90 days in jail and fined the weekly Hawaii Sentinel $250 yesterday.

Forty young women students of Packer Collegiate Institute, Berkeley Institute, Pratt Institute and the Friends School, all of Brooklyn, will act as ushers at the "Light Buoy Jubilee," an evening of musical entertainment and dancing, on March 25 in the grand ballroom of the Hotel St. George for the benefit of the Industrial Home for the Blind in Brooklyn.
Colonel Frederic A. Molitor, consulting engineer, died after an extended illness at his home here today. He was 70 years old.

Three contests furnish the center of interest in village elections in Suffolk County on Tuesday. Patchogue and Lindenhurst are storm centers of a big effort by anti-administration forces to gain control of the village boards, while at Greenport a milder campaign is under way to unseat Trustee Frederick Locker who, unlike his running mate, Trustee Monroe L. Biggs, has failed to obtain Democratic support. Clear-cut issues are few elsewhere.
The Union College ski team captured enough points in the slalom events to win the final meet of the New York State Intercollegiate Ski Association today. The victor's point total was 283.4.
The New Brunswick High School basketball team defeated Asbury Park. 40-24, tonight in the Princeton University gymnasium to win the Central New Jersey championship in the Group 4 high school class.

Hundreds of Jews besieged their leaders tonight for advice amid a welter of uncertainties arising from Chancellor Adolf Hitler's nazification of Austria. Jewish leaders said they were sure that inspection and control of Austrian citizenships would soon be ordered to form a basis for the expulsion of recent Jewish immigrants, particularly from Eastern Europe.

Miss Evelyn Mary Adams, daughter of Mrs. Maude M. Adams of Newark, was married to Alwin William Geer. son of Mr. and Mrs. Fernandez Geer of Jacksonville, Fla., this afternoon in St. Peter's Episcopal Church here. The ceremony was performed by the vicar, the Rev. Jay Gould Secor.
This Far Western stronghold of organized labor chose a new garrison this week composed of political candidates pledged to end racketeering, violence and intimidation in labor's ranks.

Sons, brothers and husbands of Barnard College alumnae will compose the floor committee for an April Fool's Day party to be held the evening of April 1 in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. The event has been arranged by members of the junior committee of the Fiftieth Anniversary Fund

GENERAL VICTOR VUILLEMIN, new chief of the French Army air corps, is one of the most experienced aviators in France. He has devoted a quarter of a century, a?? half of his life, to military aviation as a pilot
To meet the need for current information on retail and wholesale trade, the Bureau of Census of the Department of Commerce is undertaking immediately a survey of business on a "major sample basis"

TOURNAMENTS seem to have habits,the same as individuals. The tradition of the Goldman Cup pair contest of the Eastern championships is that pre-tournament rankings mean nothing. The result is in doubt until the last scores are counted up,
Five homes have been sold at Fair Estates, Dry Harbor Road and Caldwell Avenue, Rego Park, L. I., reports Julius Land, president of the developing syndicate.
Department store sales this week made a particularly unfavorable showing in

War talk from Europe had only a temporary effect on the wheat market here today. Local buying and short covering carried prices up 1 cent in the early trading, but new outside interest failed to develop and later week-end evening-up and a sharp reaction in Winnipeg resulted in the upturn being wiped out.
The vociferous New England reaction to the reciprocity trade agreement with Czechoslovakia is decidedly unfavorable. "This treaty spells ruin," many declare.

A campaign for a $7,000,000 endowment for the New York State Merchant Marine Academy at Throggs Neck, the Bronx, to make it "the Annapolis of the American merchant marine" for the training of future ship's engineer and deck officers, was announced yesterday by Captain Jam s H. Tomb, U.S.N., retired, superintendent.
Frederick Ogden Farrall, builder and real estate developer, died early yesterday in his home, 164-05 Thirty-second Avenue, Flushing, after a long illness. He was 60 years old.

Announcement has been made by cable to relatives and friends here of the engagement of Miss Sheila Crawford Burton, daughter of Mrs. Louis G. Paget of New York and London and of Crawford Burton of 995 Fifth Avenue and Southampton, L. I., to Captain Eric Charles Yeldham of the Hampshire Regiment, aide de camp to Sir Archibald D. Cochrane, Governor of Burma.

Yale defeated Princeton in their annual fencing competition today. The varsity won, 161/2 to 101/2, and the freshmen triumphed 151/2 to 111/2. Captain Maurice Grasson. of the Eli varsity captured all three of his foils matches. Randall won all three of his epee contests and Phil Viscidi annexed his three saber bouts to assure Yale .the victory.

A description of the air-conditioning system in the new twelve story apartment house under construc-. tion at 25 East Eighty-third Street is provided by Sullivan A. S. Paterno, engineer, who installed the system.

AS a special representative of his government and the seed industry of France, Roger Vilmorin is coming to the opening of the Silver Jubilee International Flower Show in Grand Central Palace tomorrow.

THE MAN WHO MURDERED GOLIATH. By Geoffrey Hovnes. 274 pp. New York: William Morrow d Co. $2. THE man who telephoned the newspaper editor's office said that he was Walter Miller, the richest and most prominent resident of Los Pinos, Calif., and that he was about to shoot himself.

A terse message was broadcast today through eight States to Judge Harry W. Peyser of the Municipal Court, missing since 2 P. M. Thursday. The plea, telephoned to State police by the jurist's son, Frank, a Rochester lawyer,was-issued after clues in Boston and Auburn, Me., had failed to solve the mystery of the 50-year-old judge's disappearance.

Conditions bordering on near panic swept the money markets of the world yesterday as Europeans rushed to purchase American dollars and gold after Germany's conquest of Austria. The flight of capital, particularly from the smaller Continental nations, assumed gigantic proportions and brought an unprecedented volume of trading in the foreign exchange markets, both here and abroad.
Tomorrow morning oral hearings on the pending trade agreement with the United Kingdom and its dependencies and colonies open before the Committee for Reciprocity Information in Washington.

Oricla figures showed retail trade for the Fifth District in February was better than had been forecast. The decltke from 1937 was only 1 per cent, and cumulative volume for the first two months was practically the sanTe as that of the previous year.

A new theatre will be opened in Rockefeller Center upon completion in the Fall of the Associated Press Building under construction on the north block, with frontages on Fifty-first and Fiftieth Streets and Rockefeller Plaza, it was announced yesterday.

Chamber of Commerce Advocates Trunk Line to Serve 900 Acres in Flashing Area Construction of a trunk line sewer to serve some 900 acres of largely undeveloped property in the vicinity of Flushing, Queens, is urged by the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce.

The Protestant Church in ..Loyalist Spain, which has suffered so much persecution in its history, now finds itself in the paradoxical situation of having complete liberty of worship while the Catholic Church still awaits permission to Worship publicly.

Miss Mary Gilliland, 44, was married to a man more than twice her age today in the culmination of a romance which began fifteen years ago in a Connecticut boys' school. The bridegroom, Hubert Little of Woodmont. Conn., is 89.

PERHAPS there are no flowers of the year that give the same thrill as those early ones which appear while the snow is still flying and open out their blossoms above a counterpane of white. One of these is the dwarf Iris persica, which comes from Northern Persia.

A FEW weeks ago we announced the forthcoming publication in a limited edition by the Countryman Press of "A New Sketch Book" by Washington Irving. The Countryman Press now informs us that this book has been withdrawn from publication

LOS ANGELES IN another decade a century will have passed since a man strode through the streets of San Francisco holding a bottle of yellow dust aloft and shouting, "Gold! Gold dust from the American River!" That cry fang across the world. It created a new empire.
The Equity Builders syndicate of this city announces that it is constructing for individual owners a number of single-family homes in various communities of the metropolitan area.

Charles T. Cockey Jr., member of an old Maryland family, died last night at his home, Garrison Farm, in Baltimore County, at the age of 74. He was president of the Maryland Farm Bureap Federation and had been president of the Agricultural Corporation of Maryland.

A homer by Frank Hayes with one on in the seventh gave the Athletics a 7-to-6 victory over the Indians in an exhibition game today. In the first frame Ken Keltner of Cleveland and Babe Barna of the Mackmen hit four-baggers with two on.

Declaring that the women of today "lack the great leaders of yesterday" because they are not united in one common purpose, Mme. Belle de Rivera, founder and honorary president of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, urges the members of her sex to "bring themselves together" and use their "mighty power and influence" to preserve world peace.

Dr. E. J. Evans and George Katterman of the Dover Sportsmen's Club won the New Jersey State two-man 20-gauge skeet championship today. Dr. Evans shot a 91 and Katterman 95 for a 186 total. Katterman's mark also gave him the individual prize.

The Dartmouth swimmers won both relays and five of seven individual events from Navy, 47 to 28, as the Midshipmen closed their Eastern Intercollegiate League season with one victory against five defeats. It was Dartmouth's second circuit triumph in five meets.

Venezuela, which has been one of the most prolific countries in issuing air mail stamps, has released another deluge, this time eighteen in number and presenting three designs. A plane and oil derricks, above the inscription "Petroleo," are-pictured. on 15-centimos

AFTER the last General Instructions (A) to (M) have been read, after the last figures have been put opposite "Balance of Tax (Item 30 minus Items 31 and 32)," after a twentyfive-cent piece has been tossed on the notary's desk, and while the tongue still tastes the gum of an envelope addressed to "Collector of Internal Revenue," perhaps a little consideration may be given. to the Federal income tax.
Ossle Stewart, 163, Pittsburgh gained the verdict over Domenico Ceccarelli, 165 1/2 Italy, in the feature ten-round engagement at the Rockland Palace last night before a crowd of 2,500 persons.

Trade generally in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week increased over the previous week but remained below the corresponding period a year ago. A group of leading department stores reported sales were from 4 to 7 per cent below last year. Wholesale business also showed some improvement, but was from 5 to 8 per cent under 1937.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Mary Jane Kraham, sister, executrix, 77 Manhattan Ave., residue. DINKELMAN, BETSEY (March 1). Estate, more than $10,000. To Hebrew Orphan Asylum, 138th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Monteflore Home, Gunhill Rd., Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society,

A RADIO-ELECTRICAL instrument popularly called "the radio nurse" is being introduced by the Zenith Radio Corporation. The device comprises two small units, a microphone called a "guardian ear," which will pick up the faintest whimper of a baby at the crib and send it along to loud-speaker units located in the kitchen or any other part of the home.

A tea will be given on March 21 at Sherry's for members of the women's division of the special gifts committee of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, which has been organized on behalf of the 1938 Catholic Charities appeal from March 27 to April 4.
IN order to obtain the fullest measure of enjoyment from "arrangements," care must be exercised with the flowers composing them from the moment they are cut in the garden.

IN the welter of twoscore shows opening last week-groups and solos, oils and water-colors and prints; by American and Europeans, modernist and academicthree of the one-man attractions stood out for various reasons. One of these was the show of recent oils and water-colors by Ann Brockman at Kleemann's.

Amid considerable fanfare, which included the presence of Governor Leche and a brass band, the new Louisiana State University baseball stadium was formally inaugurated today, with the Giants and Phillies entertaining a gathering of 3,000.

Miss Susanna Winslow Perkins Wilson, only child of Paul Caldwell Wilson of Washington, D. C., and Mrs. Wilson (Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins), was married here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Resurrection, 115 East Seventy-fourth Street, to David Meredith Hare of New York.

A harmony luncheon designed to reduce factional strife in the City Council has been planned by the New York City League of Women Voters for Friday at 12:30 P. M. at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn. Representatives of the four political groups now active in the Council will contribute to a discussion of "Constructive Steps Toward Harmony in the City Council."

Approval of the Feld bill providing for a bond issue of $200,000,000 for school buildings and repairs was expressed yesterday by the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union. Under this bill, if approved by the voters, New York City would receive $100,000,000 for new buildings and $25,000,000 for repairs.

Students who stand at the head of the class are especially apt to be near-sighted and bespectacled, as cartoonists have always pictured them, according to a survey made at the University of Minnesota.
An interest in religion strong enough to warrant the continuance of the system of compulsory Sunday chapel attendance has been found on the Skidmore College campus.

Eastern entries fared well today at the opening of the Cleveland Classic, twenty - second annual all - breed show of the Western Reserve Kennel Club. A record crowd of fanciers witnessed the competition.

The ancient country of Egypt is in the midst of a building boom five years old, but still continuing with vigor, according to Ahmed Sidky, young Egyptian architect, who arrived in New York last week bringing with him the plans for the Egyptian pavilion his government will build for the New York World's Fair of 1939.

NE of the most interesting gardens at the International Flower Show last year was a Primula garden, using few plants other than primroses and delightful as the May days on which they bloom outdoors. Indeed, all of the exhibition gardens typical of Spring included Primulas naturalized under trees, edging tulip borders and used in a variety of ways.

Miss James Brashears, daughter of Mrs. Robert L. Swart, wife of Lieutenant Swart, was married to Lieutenant Thomas F. Williamson, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Otis Williamson of Montgomery, Ala., at noon today in the Bishop Seabury Memorial Church in Groton. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. C. R. Wagner. rector.

The NBC yesterday announced several changes in today's WEAF and WJZ programs because of events in Austria. A program of folkloristic music previously scheduled for today at 1:30 over WEAF from Vienna has been canceled and in its place a New York musical broadcast has been substituted.

It is too early to judge the effect of the special advertising campaign on used-car sales, but some degree of success is indicated by reports of titles recorded in the first three days in Cuyahoga County. The gain over the previous week was about 17 per cent.

Miss Ruth F. Woodsmall, general secretary of the World's Council of the Y. W. C. A. at Geneva, will be honored at a reception and tea given by members of the national board at 4:30 P. M. Friday at headquarters, 600 Lexington Avenue. She is arriving Tuesday on the Ile de France for a six-week visit to this country.
The theatre workshop and the dance groups of Wellesley College are working together toward the integration of speed, dance and music in a production unique to the theatre arts.

Savings, building and Joan associations will have $1,500,000,000 available this year for loans to families who wish to acquire homes without. waiting for insurance on the mortgage, the United States Building and Loan League reported yesterday.

Lyda Roberti, film actress, died today in her apartment of a heart attack. She was 32 years old and had been in poor health for the last two years., The heart ailment she suffered caused her to retire from active screen work. Her husband, Hugh Ernst, radio announcer, was with her when she died.

With troops moving throughout the countryside, with innumerable planes roaring overhead and with men called as reservists taking hurried farewell of their families, Bavaria presented today an even more war-like atmosphere than yesterday.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Mahoney, 19 years old, who had been missing from St. Vincent's College at Riverdale since Thursday, was found here yesterday, according to Acting Captain John G. Stein of the Missing Persons Bureau. Miss Mahoney is the daughter of Leo D. Mahoney, Rochester attorney, and Mrs. Marguerite Mahoney, clerk in the office of the Home Owners Loan Association in Syracuse.

The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace will award ten scholarships of $250 each for study at the Academy of International Law at The Hague this Summer, EA according to an announcement yesterday by Dr.. James Brown Scott, director of the endowment's division of international law, who is in charge of the awards.

Each of the following reserve officers will proceed from the station indicated after his name to Camp Dix, N.. J., at such time as will enable him to report to the commanding officer threat on March 21 for temporary duty in connection with CCC activities, and upon completion of this temporary duty each officer will return to his proper station:

The Board of Assessors today declined to comply with the order of Federal Judge McLellan that the members desist from assessing taxes on the former postoffice property, owned by the Federal Government but leased to private parties and used in part as a bus terminal.

PALM BEACH, Fla.-Golfers of the Everglades Club will swing into action tomorrow for the first annual men's and women's club championship. Winners will have their names inscribed on the new President's Cup, presented by Hugh Dillman, and winners and the runners-up will receive silver trophies.

BAUM--STARK-Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Stark announce marriage of their daughter, Katherine, to Joseph, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. E. Baum, taking place March 20. Reception 4 P. M., Chateau d'Or, 2,560 Ocean Ave., Brooklyn.

Activity in the sale and rental of Brooklyn properties is reported by two brokers of that borough. The Charles Partridge Real Estate Company amnounces sales of two six-family apartments at 1,759-81 Seventyninth Street for the South Brooklyn Savings Bank to Yetta Jacobowitz for investment;

Entering Austria from Switzerland by rail yesterday, this correspondent found all the frontier towns and villages quiet with the exception of St. Anton. At that point there was some excitement and there seemed to be anti-Nazi sentiment. The station was crowded with foreigners seeking to leave Austria.
IT would be an exaggeration to say that in the first decade of this century poetry in America was in extremis. Some very fine poetry was being written both in the United States and in Canada.

Much Gusto, a horse that is almost unbeatable over this track, returned to his high ranking in the local handicap division with a gamely earned triumph in the Orange Blossom Handicap of a mile and a sixteenth at Tropical Park today.

THAT the airplane, as its size increases, develops more temperamental whims Individual to each craft was pointed out last week by Lieut. Col. Robert E. Olds in relating the details of the recent flight of the six "Flying Fortress" bombers from Langley Field, Va., to Buenos Aires, Argentina. Colonel Olds spoke before the members of Air Service Post 501.
The Harvard polo team defeated Cornell, 12 to 7, tonight in the 124th Field Artillery Armory. Harvard's furious opening attack netted nine goals before Cornell could tally.

The second in a series of Springcard parties in behalf of the Social Service Auxiliary of the New York Polyclinic Medical School and Hospital will take place Wednesday afternoon in the Assembly Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

TRADE volume last week slipped farther under the figures of last year. The general business decline was responsible, with increased unemployment and wage cutting, but the later Easter was an important factor. Holiday trade had started at this time in 1937.

President Roosevelt was voted the "most prominent American today," Sinclair Lewis the "favorite author" and Gary Cooper the "favorite movie actor" in the annual senior poll of the Feddie School here. The results were announced today by William M. Fairhurst, editor of "Old Gold and Blue," annual yearbook published by the junior class for the seniors.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Despite the many excellent points offered by A. T. Shurick in his defense of price-control in the bituminous coal industry, it is very possible that we havne again been subjected to arguments which do not stand up under the test of analysis.

Two hundred and four students of New York University's Washington Square College at Washington Square East have been commended for high scholarship during the first term of the current academic year, it was announced yesterday at the university.

Yelling throngs pulled down -the memorial statue to the late Chancellor Englebert Dollfuss in the main street of Graz tonight. As the populace, soldiers and police shouted the. Nazi greeting of "Heil, Hitler!" a crowd gathered around the Dollfuss memorial and brought the figure of the little Austrian Chancellor, who was murdered in the abortive Nazi putsch of 1934, crashing to the street.

TIME was when Egypt was scratched off the Summer traveler's list. Today the hotels and pensions of Alexandria and Cairo are offering special rates for the warm-weather tripper and for cruise parties stopping off during the hot months to visit the Pyramids and palaces of long-dead Pharaohs.

The Tri-State rifle match for naval reserve teams in the third naval district will be held at Camp Smith, Peekskill, N. Y., June 5, according to an announcement yesterday at a luncheon of the United States Naval Reserve Officers Association of that district, in the Hotel Taft.
Young women of society will act as manikins in the fashion show which will be held during the luncheon hour on Tuesday at Le Coq Rouge for the benefit of the BideA-Wee Association.

With five of its components moving upward during the week ended March 5, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity advanced to 79.5 from 78.8, the revised figure for the previous week. A year ago the index stood at 106.7. The largest weighted gain was registered in the electric power production.

BECAUSE of a change In plane, Felicia Sorel and her ballet will be replaced by a vocal soloist as yet unnamed at the concert of American music to be given by Ferde Grof6, March 25, in Carnegie Hall, for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc. Other soloists will be Herman Wasserman, piano, and Abrasha Borodkin. 'cello.

Dr. Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, who performed yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, were able to offer their audience a program of exceptional contrasts. For it was the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which on the occasion of its fiftieth anniversary commissioned Paul Hindemith, among other composers, to write one of the most interesting of his later compositions for that occasion.

New tributes to the skill of American women as landscape architects are paid every Spring in thousands of gardens throughout the country. And this year will see added to their achievements the work of a woman landscaper on the staff of the New York World's Fair.
Events surrounding the suspension of Richard Whitney Co. from the New York Stock Exchange have brought to public notice the three separate organize- tions that are policing Wall Street.

Charles F. Noyes, founder and president of the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., who built up that forty-year-old realty concern from "practically nothing" to a $60,000,000 annual business in sales and rentas even during depression years, announced plans yesterday to turn control of the company over to his employes.

Cornwall and Otisville are the only two villages in Orange County where contests have developed for election to village offices on Tuesday. In the eleven other villages no petitions have been filed by opposing candidates but a write-in campaign is always held in several.

M. R. Bissell Jr., 56, president of the Bissell Carpet Sweeper Company, reported that an attempt was made by two men to abduct him early tonight. Police of East Grand Rapids immediately appealed to State police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation to join in a search for the men, who fled in an automobile.
No doubt many of the newspapers and magazines which opposed Mr. Roosevelt's re-election in 1936 did color and distort the news againts him, as the President says in his second Liberty article.
Plans are being drawn up for a new building to replace the Sacred Heart College, destroyed by fire Jan. 18 with loss of forty-seven lives.

The world's phosphate rock reserves amount to about 16,500 million tons. Our deposits of 6,500 million tons are larger than those of all Europe or all Africa. Of these, some 5,000 million lie in Idaho, native State of Senator James P. Pope.

Far from being overwhelmed by the tremendous problems pressing upon him from every direction, Britain's 69year-old Prime Minister, Neville Chamberlain, is thriving on a regime that would tax the strength of far younger men.

Officials at Steenookerzeel Castle, home of Archduke Otto, Habsburg pretender to the throne of Austria, beginning yesterday engaged in twenty-four hours of frantic telephoning to Vienna and other foreign capitals.

Alfred Jorgensen of Brooklyn escaped with slight lacerations when his cabin monoplane overturned as he made a forced landing in a field at Cranston today. Jorgensen was returning to Brooklyn after having flown his sister and brother to Boston yesterday.

Builders and development operators in and around Flushing are practically unanimous in predicting that the present year will witness the largest volume of home construction that has been seen in -the Flushing area for many years and many of them are anticipating a new construction record.

Speakers at the fourteenth annual dinner of the Bronx Real Estate Board to be held next Saturday at the Hotel Commodore include Jeremiah F.
