Cross, a member of the Bronx Advisory Board of the City Planning Commission; Henry G. Waltemade, president of the realty board, and James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx.

The annual dinner dance of the New York Alumni of Washington and Lee University will be given on the evening of March 25 at the Ambassador. Earlier in the day a reception and tea will be held at the hotel. Proceeds from the event will aid in providing the two scholarships given annually by the New York group to deserving students at the university.

SPRING, it can at last be safely said, is near. The crocus checkers in their furs and galoshes are prowling the parks once more, the song-sparrow announcers have been writing to the papers for almost a month, a pussy-willow spotter discovered a truckload of silvery Maltese catkins last Thursday, right in Times Square, and the Flower Show, which is the surest sign of all, will open tomorrow.
VISITORS to the thousand-odd dahlia shows held every Fall, commercial dahlia growers, and the number of dahlia roots and plants sold each Spring are all constantly increasing,
President Roosevelt's nomination of Thurman W. Arnold of Yale Law School to fill the shoes of Robert H. Jackson as Assistant Attorney General in charge of trust-busting,
The California Senate tonight killed by an almost unanimous voice vote an Assembly-approved resolution "pardoning" Tom Mooney, convicted of the 1916 San Francisco Preparedness Day parade bombing.

Unless those Senators who :stood against the President's Supreme Court Bill and who run this Fall are re-elected it will mean their replacement by "100 per cent stooges" and will be the first step in the breakdown of constitutional government in the United .States, Representative Samuel B. Pettengill, Indiana Democrat,' declared yesterday.

To give a new background to the meditations of the Holy Way of the Cross, Catholic religious service commemorating the events of the crucifixion, Father Henry F. Hammer, assistant rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, and Pietro Yon, organist and composer, have collaborated on a new musical arrangement for this service.
Miss Mathilde Mizener, daughter of Mrs. Frank Asbury Mizener of this place and North East, Pa., was married here this afternoon in Knowles Memorial Chapel to Charles O. Andrews Jr.,

Advocacy of the cause of the Spanish Government and support of the "humanitarian work" of the Musicians' Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy are announced in a statement signed by thirty American musicians, composers and performer.
John H. Mills, president of the Presbyterian Home for the Aged in Brooklyn and a life director of the American Bible Society, died here today of pneumonia at his home, 108 Salisbury Avenue.

A MORAL HISTORY OF WOMAN. By Sarah Parker White. Illustrated. 324 pp. Garden City, N. Y.: Doubleday, Doran Co. $3. THIS book is the work of an erudite woman who has had a wide experience as a practieing physician.

Max Baer, having vindicated himself in the eyes of the boxing public through his decision over Tommy Farr on Friday night, left for California yesterday with the confidence that he was "sitting pretty" in the heavyweight pictcure.

Blair Academy annexed its fourth straight New Jersey State preparatory school swimming championship at the Newark, Athletic Club pool tonight, compiling the highest team point total ever scored in the event.

Wisconsin's burly Chuck Fenske put together a brilliant, record-adorned double tonight as Michigan's irrepressible - Wolverines seized their fifth straight Big Ten indoor track title-a triumph aided by the amazing collapse of Indiana's famed distance running array.

WITHIN recent years there has been considerable discussion in garden clubs and elsewhere concerning the desirability of a more or less floral outdoor living room. But little if anything has been said about another outdoor room that it would be convenient to have on the other side of the house. Such a space-the intimate vegetable garden-would form a Summer adjunct to the kitchen.

The Jewish War Veterans of the United States announced yesterday they would extend the anti-Nazi merchandise boycott to include Austria "if the Nazi Government, as has been indicated by recent press reports, has taken over Austria and will continue in that territory the barbaric treatment of religious minorities, labor unions, fraternal organizations, etc., carried on in Germany during the past five years."

Of the $2,156,122 covering 3,360 loans made by the National City Rank of New York during 1934 for repairs and modernization to homes under the original Title I of the National Housing Act, 98.7 per cent has now been paid in full, according to Roger Steffan, vice president and credit officer of the bank.
Limitation of enrollment in the Syracuse University School of Journalism to seventy-five men and fifty women of the junior and senior classes was announced today by Dean M. Lyle spencer.
Two men were killed and two critically hurt late last night when an automobile in which they were riding struck a tree after missing an S-turn on Bedford Road near A here.

Governor Lehman today signed two bills presented by Assemblyman Mailler of Orange County dealing with mortgage investments. The first continues to April 1, 1939, the right to join in promulgating or consenting to reorganization plans relating to guaranteed mortgage investments. The second prohibits the guarantee of bonds, notes and other indebtedness secured by mortgages or deeds upon real property until July 1, 1939.
BAUM-SECKLER-Mr. and Mrs. Robert Seckler of Scarsdale, N. Y., announce the engagement of their daughter, Georgette. to Mr. H. James Baum, son of Mr. Joseph M. Baum of White Plains.

Stuyvesant High, defending champion, and New Utrecht continued to set the pace in their respective divisions of the P. S. A. L. team fencing competition as they both won decisive victories yesterday in the Washington Irving High School gymnasium.

To the Radio Editor: There are too many silly serial stories fed to intelligent housewives hour after hour, morning and afternoon. One scans the published announcements hoping against hope for something with a bit of intellectual stimulation, and pounding with glee on an occasional fifteen minutes devoted to some good chamber music, or a brief summary of current events.

Exclusive of the creams that anoint their faces, the rouge that reddens their lips and the powder that reduces the shine on their noses, women of New York State spend $32,777,000 annually in the 7,665 beauty shops of this commonwealth-of which $23,374,000 is exclusive to New York City. Legislation affecting this field soon is due to bring the economics of glamour forcefully into the consciousness of the consumer.

Of the many exhibitions of fashions now enlisting the interest and cooperation of women of society, one of the most unusual is being planned by the Women's National Republican Club for the afternoon of March 22, when a display of wedding gowns representing a period of many decades will be shown at the organization's clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

Seven little words are bringing concern to three national groups these days. They are: "Is repeal leading America back to prohibition?" There is no "yes" or "no" answer to this question, but the Federal Government, the liquor industry and the dry forces, after four years' legalized sale of alcoholic bever ages, are taking stock to find out what is happening in the liquor field.

In spite of the isolationist feeling provoked throughout the country by Japan's aggression in China, our exports to Japan continue to grow. Although her purchases are not important enough to American industry to stimulate a "war boom" here, and thus have largely escaped public notice, they are of vital importance to the overstrained Japanese war machine.

WITH THE CORNERS OFF. By Commander A. B. Campbell. 290 pp. Philadelphia: J. B. Lippincott Company. $2.50. IN this readable autobiography Commander Campbell has en deavored to set down his impressions of peoples, customs and incidents encountered by him in a varied career.

Of all the capitals of Europe's major countries Warsaw is certainly the one least excited or disturbed by the Austrian news. The opinion here is that the inevitable has happened and that it is all for the better that it happened without bloodshed. This is the view of Polish official circles.

Clarification and-unification of relief activities to bring about a "genuine partnership" between Federal, State and local governments was urged. at the final sessions today of this year's Community Mobilization for Human Needs.

Because table silver is one of the more permanent things one buys for the house, choice of a pattern that will look as attractive years from now as it does today is worth a great deal of concentration.

MR. SCHERMAN describes his book as a "pedagogical adventure," an attempt to lay bare some of the certainties of economics so that the "average intelligent person" may begin to understand a little more of the nature of the world we live

In a recent suit instituted by a landlord to recover rent from an alleged hold-over tenant, tried before Judge William J. Morris Jr., in the municipal court of this city, an interesting question regarding the tenant's liability was raised, points out Samuel R. Schneider, of the New York bar.

Confirmation of the need for a comprehensive and unified private welfare and health program on a city-wide basis was seen yesterday by Douglas Falconer, executive director of the Greater New York Fund, after a study of the geographic distribution of young people on relief.

As a dutiful New Dealer it is my custom to read Mrs. Roosevelt's column every evening. It sustains me; it gives me strength for the morrow. Particularly during the Winter months, when there is much work to do, it is refreshing to follow the mistress of the New Deal

Frederic T. Neumann of Wappinger Falls, blind student at Hobart College, is the only junior elected to Phi Beta Kappa this year. Despite his handicap of blindness, Neumann has headed his class in scholarship since his freshman year.

Educational institutions and civic organizations throughout the State will join on Monday in starting the first Rhode Island World Affairs Week, in which a variety of world problems will be weighed. Thousands are expected to attend the sessions.

Problems of collective security will be discussed at an all-day meeting of the Fairfield County League of Women Voters on Tuesday at the Packard Hotel, Stratford, Conn. Proposed national and State programs- of work will be considered at the morning session, led by Mrs. Louise Leonard Wright of Chicago, representing the national league, and Mrs. Cornelius Kruse of Middletown, State chairman.
German invasion of Austria and the establishment there of a Nazi regime ended any hopes exporters have entertained of expanding Austrian-American trade.

The decline in retail volume from last year's figures for Spring is largely to be attributed to the much later Easter date, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.
Three railread brotherhoods moved tonight to take a vigorous stand against wage cuts recommended by the Association of American Railroads at Washington.
Setting a new attendance record, the Providence County Kennel Club's twenty-second all-breed. fixture came to a successful close at Infantry Hall tonight.

Marking the commencement of construction work in the new Foxcroft development of A. Atwater Kent at Bryn Mawr, near Philadelphia, Pa., ground was broken last week for two new residences to be erected on Marple Road by Frank H. Wilson, builder.

Proposed trade practice rules for the fur industry, which were adopted at a conference held in New York last December, were made public by the Federal Trade Commission today. Subject to modification, the commission has tentatively adopted the "Group I rules," which are mandatory, and has tentatively received as an expression of the industry a rule In "Group II" which would be permissive.

The Swiss Government has reinforced its customs guards along the Austrian frontier and has ordered a company of frontier guards, stationed at Rheintal, to be ready to join them. The authorities deny having taken any military measures, properly. speaking.

RETURNING home from a business trip the writer found the furniture rearranged. The furnishings showed to better advantage. And perhaps of greatest value--there was an added spaciousness that increased the usefulness of the rooms.
Boulder Brook defeated Squadron C, 15-6, last night in a Metropolitan League polo game in the Squadron C armory. The New York A. C. trio triumphed over Evergreen Farms, 18 to 15.

Physical, education should be considered as an art, without losing its sleintifie background, Miss Dorothy Ainsworth, chairman' of the Department, of PhysicalI Education at Smith College, said today at the closing meeting of the New England Swimming Conference for Women held at Smith.

Business in local department and specialty stores this week dropped considerably lower than in the corresponding period of last year. The decline varied from 12 per cent to as high as 20 per cent in different large outlets.

Excitement in the financial markets over the rapid turn of affairs in Austria was confined yesterday chiefly to foreign exchange. All of the European currencies except the French franc were sharply lower in terms of the dollar and most of the rates touched new lows for the year.
Bernard V. Keevers, postmaster, former Representative in the General Assembly and town official, died yesterday at his home after a short illness. His age was 69.

The dramatic appearance of Thomas J. Mooney before the California Legislature last Thursday again centered attention upon a 'case which has plagued the conscience of California for more than two decades.

A boy must have some high-school training nowadays to qualify for the average beginning factory job. This is the consensus of more than 500 New England manufacturers canvassed by the CCC Office of Education in the First Corps Area.

Hitler marches on. With the democracies of Europe unable or unwilling to act, the German dictator has taken over control of his native Austria. Troops of the Third Reich are pouring into the little southern neighbor and, whether or not technically politically complete, Anschluss is taking place. The Fuehrer has gone over into Austria to watch it become completely German.

THE OTHER SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN. An Escape to the Amazon. By James Ramsey Ullman. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: Carrick Evans. $3. MESSRS. BROOKS ATKIN-son, Burns Mantle, Walter Winchell, Gilbert Gabriel and various other critics of the drama are in a large degree responsible for this book of travel.

A striking object lesson of the fact that there still is a good demand in many sections of Westchester County for costly houses is revealed in the announcement by the Cotswold Estates syndicate that plans have been completed for the constructiot this year of twenty residences in Scarsdale and the immediate vicinity in the $23,000 to $35,000 price range.

HEN Joseph P. Kennedy recently took up his post at the court of St. James he brought something new in American Ambassadors. Hay, Choate. Reid. Page, Davis-these and others in a long and distinguished line of envoys have sprung from what Andre Siegfried has called the "chosen race" of Anglo-Scottish Protestants in American public life.

Dr. F. G. Crawford, a member of the Syracuse University faculty for nineteen years, was appointed dean of the.College of Liberal Arts today to succeed Dean Karl C. Leebrick, who resigned to become president of Kent State University, at Kent, Ohio.

Mrs. Alexander H. McLanahan and members of her committee for the benefit matinee performance of "Parsifal" on Friday at the Metropolitan Opera House-which is to aid the Allianoe for the Guidance of Rural Youth-are now arranging a special Southern breakfast to be served at the St. Regls at 11:30 A. M. before the performance.

Lieut. Col. and Mrs. F. W. Clarke of Quebec gave a cocktail party for 400 aboard the steampship North Star here this afternoon. Receiving with Mrs. Clarke were Mrs. Maurice Cotton of Louisville, Ky., and Coconut Grove; Mrs. Herbert Jackson and Mrs. Walter V. Schulke.

Cardinal Hayes arrived home early last evening from Nassau, the Bahama Islands, where he has been for the last few weeks. He came by train from Miami. Traveling with the Cardinal were Mgr. Vincent Arcese, spiritual director of St. Joseph's Mountain School, Sullivan County, who is his Italian secretary, and Mgr. John J. Casey, his private secretary.

The powerful Lawrenceville School polo forces defeated the 112th Field Artillery today, 13 to 10. The score at the half stood 6 to 5 in favor of the Laurentians. The second half found the Artillery, led by, Hesson, trying to overcome the Red and Black. Captain Rose, who scored six goals, managed to stave off the attack.

The Rev. John J. Preston, pastor of St. Cecilia's Catholic Church here for. the last ten years, died this afternoon after two years of ill health at 17 Emerson Street, East Orange, the home of his brother and three sisters.

Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo, former New York State champion, had a walk-over in the Belmont Manor ladies' golf tournament final, beating Mrs. G. Sidenburg of Greenwich, Conn., 11 and 10, today, Mrs. Sidenburg won only one hole. Miss Wattles was 7 up for the first eighteen. Her opponent's putting and approaches were at their weakest. The winner was consistent throughout the match.
William E. Mallory, grandson of the founder of the Mallory Hat Company, of which he was treasurer, died of a heart attack today at his home. His age was 71.
Trends in the World of Modern Education

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 12, unless specified: San Diego to Navy Yard Mare Island, via San Pedro: Chandler, Hovey, Long, Southard. At Port Au Prince: S-20, Semmes. Babbitt, at Port Limon. Falcon, Provincetown to New London. Helm, Balboa, to Miami Henderson, at San Francisco. Medusa, San Pedro to Navy Yard, Mare Island.

Not since the trial of Mayor James J. Walker at Albany when Mr. Roosevelt was Governor, and never before in the White House, has there been so dramatic a hearing as that on Friday of the issue among the three directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
Mr. and Mrs. Howard Holbrook of Barrington, Ill., today announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy, to Guy Stillman, son of Mrs. Fowler McCormick and James A. Stillman, New York banker.

In a full day of running replete with interesting competition, the Babylon Hunt Club today completed four stakes of its annual Spring field trial meeting on the estate of Colonel M. Robert Guggenheim. This in spite of the fact that the start of the first stake was delayed by the late arrival of the supply of quail, as well as the mounts for the judges and spectators.

Lowell L. (Tony) Balcom, an artist and creator of caricatures in tin, died today of a heart attack at his home in Silvermine. Mr. Balcom, a leading member of the Silvermine Guild of Artists, was 50 years old.

Miss Janet St. Clair Mullan, a descendant of the De Witt and Jebb families and a daughter of the late State Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. George Vincent Mullan, was married yesterday afternoon to Frederick Geller Duncan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Duncan of New York.
Premier Eamon de Valera of Ireland left the whirring machinery of London government offices today for the quietude of Dublin still without an Angle-Irish agreement in his pocket.
Arthur O. Lee, who as a young railroad employee accompanied General U. S. Grant up the old Mount McGregor Inclined Railway on his last journey in 1885, died today of a heart attack at the age of 75.
Mrs. Edna Cratty of Long Island, WPA sewing project worker, shifted her sit-down vigil today from the White House to the Works Progress Administration.

FOR window box, hanging basket, ground cover or for edging, few native plants surpass in loveliness the woodsorrels. And notwithstanding their dantmess of bloom, their delicate, clover-like leaves, and their apparently weak stems they are exceedingly hardy and require little attention.
Pennsylvania closed its varsity swimming season by defeating Penn State at Hutchinson Pool today, 59-16. The Red and Blue made a clean sweep of nine first places.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of- reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors. therefore.

AT long last the Staatsoper has given us in sumptuous vesture and sovereign style a great masterpiece of lyric drama--a masterpiece either forgotten or else unheard beyond its native frontiers, Smetana's "Dalibor." Gustav Mahler,

BY the alchemy of energy and a vital style, William Seabrook turns the slow bubbling of America's melting pot into drama. This country contains about 15,000,000 persons who were born in Europe, countless other Americans who are, in a sense, "hyphenated" Americans.

New theories about the internal structure of solids, including metals, have opened up vast possibilities for new types of alloys for industrial purposes, according to Professor L. A. DuBridge of the University of Rochester.

Harry Thoens and F. A. Scola tied for the high-over-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday, each breaking ninety-nine out of 100. In the shoot-off, Thoens took the trophy with a run of 25. Scola had 23. The latter won the handicap trophy in Class A with a full card. In o Class B the prize was taken by J. H. Forsman.

ARTHUR HERRINGTON has been associated actively with every year's National Flower Show in the entire quarter-century of the institution's existence. For the first two years he was one of the judges; floor manager the third year, and since then secretary and general manager, contributing to the smooth running of this annual spectacle.

Elements of a sparkling revue will combine with the latest ideas in physical education when the biennial "Arena Demonstration" of Boston University's Sargent College of Physical Education is presented March 26.

Frederick V. Goess, vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, has been named president of the Mortgage Conference of New York, composed of savings banks, mortgage and insurance companies. Mr. Goess, Who has been treasurer of the conference, succeeds Robert L. Hoguet, head of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

Postmaster General Farley's announcement last week that the United States is to release postal adhesives presenting portraits of all Presidents who are no longer living foreshadows the most ambitious stamp-making program in the country's history,
Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Dillman were hosts to a large group tonight for motion pictures and dancing In the Sert Room at the Playa Riente with supper served later on the ocean-front terrace.

BECAUSE it is the first flower which can provide long drifts of color, the crocus is a prime Spring favorite. One satisfactory trait of the crocus family is its gratifying habit of reproduction from seed and from offsets, so that a few bulbs (or corms) will soon multiply incredibly, and new ones will appear in most unexpected places with many beautiful combinationsof purple, lavender and white-feathered, striped or solid.

TODAY Organ Recital, by Dr. Charles M. Courboin, at the American Academy of Arts and Letters: WOR, 12 M. Prelude, "The Deluge"........Saint-Saens Allegretto, Fifth symphony ..........Widor Prelude Chorale: Fervently Do I Pray For ....................... ... . Bach The Harmonious Blacksmith ........ Handel Music Hall of the Air symphony orchestra, with Erno Rapee conducting and Robert Weede, baritone: WJZ, 12:30-1:30 P. M.
HIGH speed modern motorways running right through commercial buildings in the congested districts is one of the revolutionary -proposals advanced for solving the traffic problem of Los Angeles.

No event in the recent history of Europe matches in importance Germany's conquest of Austria by force of arnis. Theoretically, there is still an Austrian State and there is still an Austrian Government. German troops are merely "keeping order."

Uday Shan-Kar and his Hindu company of dancers and musicians completed their final American tour with a performance at Carnegie Hall last night. Next week they are scheduled to sail for Europe and shortly afterward to - retire to Benares permanently to take up the work of their newly established All-India - Center for Dance and Music.

OUTSIDE window-boxes provide a type of gardening that affords pleasure both to the householder and the passerby. It frames decoratively the view from the window. In a city, where people especially the appreciate a glimpse of green leaf larn and gay blossom in the monotony of brick and stone, the well-arranged window-box becomes almost a service to the community.

The Department of Sanitation is rehabilitating about half of the 1,000 old-type garbage removal trucks that are being replaced by new equipment and the reconditioned trucks will be held in reserve for snow-removal and other general work, William F. Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, revealed yesterday.

Adolf Hitler's startling coup in Austria has dealt a severe blow to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's policy of striving to negotiate with Berlin and brought painful disillusionment to those British people who have clung to the conception of Hitler as a much maligned and misunderstood leader who is really deeply concerned to maintain peace.

With 38,000 fans attending the final big day of the Santa Anita Park meeting, Indian Broom raced the mile and a furlong distance today to win the $10,000 added San Juan. Capistrano Handicap from eight other candidates.

George W. Ahern, formerly with Elliott L. Brown, Inc., the Lawyers Mortgage Company, Realty Investing Corporation and the Metropolitan Title and Guarantee Company, has opened his own general realty and mortgage business at 350 Madison Avenue.

The German - American Mixed Claims Commission today granted to Robert Bonynge, the American agent, until May 12 to file additionaljevidence in relation to $50,000,000 of claims against Germany growing out of the war time munitions disaster at Black Tom and Kingsland, N. J.

Stephen Edwin Dillon, for the last thirtyfive years general manager of public utilities in Hot Springs, Ark., died there today at the age of 71 Born in Aurora, Ill., he formerly was Connected with various railroads as chief clerk and trainmaster. His widow, four brothers and five sisters survive.

The ground floor, basement and part of the upper floor in the two-story business building just completed by a syndicate at 15 East Fifty-second Street, on the site formerly occupied by the Harley Procter mansion, have been leased by Henri, Inc., Sylvic A. Gorini, president, who will open a large restaurant there with bar, lounge and catering department, on March 17.

Scoring a total of 59 points, the athletes representing Elijah Clark Junior High of the Bronx captured the team championship at the annual P. S. A. L. Junior High School indoor track and field games at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn yesterday morning.

Recruited from the cohorts of idle women who had become a problem to the matrons of railroad stations and department stores, the L Club has come into being--the first definite attempt to rescue the unattached women of 50 from aimless lounging in public places.

White Plains High School, winner of two straight W. I. A. A. crowns, tonight defeated Pelham Memorial High, 27-22, in the open class final of the sixth annual Westchester County invitation high school championship basketball tourney on the County Center court. Bob McGowan was high man for the victors with four field goals and a foul for 9 points.

TAKE Bergson. who broke the butterfly of Laughter on a wheel, and Max East man, who pulverized it with his super-colossal, as they no longer say in Hollywood, rotary machine, "The Enjoyment of Laughter." Both were theorists,

The Federal Trade Commission believes there is price-fixing and price-discrimination in- the sale of golf balls and has moved to stop the alleged practices. Golf ball manufacturers stoutly deny the charge.
THE woman who writes this book went alone, with native servants, into the almost completely unknown interior of Sierra Leone, in search of gold, and iron, and platinum, and chromium.

The Dialectic Society of the United States Corps of Cadets presented its forty - second annual hundredthnight show, "Pass In Revue," today at afternoon and evening performances. Thousands crowded the new gymnasium for both performances.

The Holy See, long embroiled with nazism, watched its advance into Catholic Austria today with deep concern. Although no official statement was issued, a brief comment in the Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper, reflected the anxiety. "No one in the world," it said, "can think the Osservatore Romano is indifferent to events so grave for the life of a people so near both geographically and spiritually.
Building conditions in the South, according to Moise H. Goldstein of New Orleans, are considerably better than in many other sections of the country.
Members of a group which asked President Roosevelt today for more Federal aid for youths who are jobless or unable to attend school said they found him sympathetic toward some of their proposals.

A new attempt is being made by Mrs. Louise Weiss, famous newspaper woman and feminist leader, to gain the right to vote for French women. She recently called a meeting of all French women decorated with the Legion of Honor and caused them to form association, the primary purpose of which will be to claim political rights for women in France.
THE season's first "Parsifal" and the -first appearance of Rose Bampton as Donna Anna in "Don Giovanni" are features of the final week of opera at the Metropolitan.

Retail trade here last week again fell behind last year's figures by a substantial margin as stores had to meet the high comparative figures of the pre-Easter period last year. Department store executives estimated the decline at about 11 to 12 per cent under the corresponding 1937 week.

The Chicago No-Jury Society of Artists, Inc., presents in its newly opened thirteenth annual exhibition an imposing list of newcomers. On view in. galleries at a Loop department store until the middle of March, the current display carries out the purpose of the society to bring forth the work of burgeoning talent.

David Dewey Burger, president and director of the Art Steel Company of New York, died in Miami, Fla., Thursday of a heart attack. Funeral services will be held today at the Park West Memorial Chapel, 115 West Seventy-ninth Street. He was 39 years old.

The financial markets last week had to contend with a frieght rate decision which was termed "inadequate" by railroad executives, the failure of a prominent Stock Exchange firm, the resignation of the French Cabinet with the attendant upset to the French franc, and German invasion of Austria.

To supply the enormous demand for fattened geese needed for pate de foie gras, the famous goose liver paste produced in Alsace, the majority of poultry men in the region now use electric machines that are equipped with nozzles which feed into the .goose's bill a steady ration of corn until the bird is almost out of breath.

The Jewish fight against antiemitism is not the fight of the ew alone, but must be the fight of all people interested in preservng democracy against fascist and Nazi aggression, speakers told more than 2,000 persons attending he opening session of the National Jnity Congress of the People's Committee Against Fascism and Anti-Semitism at Mecca Temple ast night.

Events in Austria were the mainspring that today caused Spain's two big labor unions, the Socialists U. G. T. and the Syndicalists C. N. T. to sign a peace pact whereby they agree to bury all past differences and to make common cause against fascism.

Appointment of a special committee to study the broadening of the scope of the New York Stock Exchange, including the questions of creating associate memberships, of dividing commissions with other institutions and of enlarging the list, was announced yesterday by Charles R. Gay, president.

Britain's adverse theatrical balance of trade will be still further increased during the next few months by the importation of many Transatlantic successes to meet the demand which cannot apparently be met by the available native material.

GARDENERS may not take time to ponder that in buying a plant and bringing it into flower they may be unfolding some of the romance of civilization, of far countries and of precious things lovely to behold. Yet they would find all these exemplified in the tree peony.

IT sounds altogether too simple, but one way to have become eventually the director of the Liverpool Repertory Theatre was to have been a sandy-haired young Scot not long from Edinburgh University, musically inclined, who happened to be playing the piano. for George Bernard Shaw's mother.

The amiable controversy between the United States and Great Britain over the sovereignty of South Pacific islands, particularly the islands of Canton and Enderbury in the Phoenix group, has revived interest in the explorations of the early Amercian whalers who combed these seas in their search for sperm whaies.

THERE is an inherent danger lurking in a serious essay on a subject such as play: the danger that there may seem to be something a trifle incongruous and therefore unintentionally amusing about the author's necessarily sober style.

A friendly wrestling match ended in death for Sam Wisloski, 41, and his brother, Andrew, 20. Locked in a wrestling embrace, their bodies were found by a sister, Mrs. Annie Kraft, 32, in the gasfilled kitchen of their home last night.

Susquehanna University's physical education program will be revamped next year with health activities, physical education and intercollegiate and intramural sports integrated into a health program to be required of all students.

THIS is the story of an unafraid woman who has seen a lot of the world as a newspaper reporter. Irene Kuhn observes, writes and works like a man-and then is quite capable of enjoying a new hat, cooking a good dinner or of lending her shoulder for another woman to cry upon.

Foreign correspondents felt the pinch of ??ightening censorship today in Nazi??ed Austria. S. A. (Black Shirts) men stood constantly at the side of the chief of Austria's oldest news agency, supervising all his calls and information to foreign journalists. They also tapped all outgoing telehone calls. The mail was watched.

Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College, urged the State yesterday to foster and finance education for marriage. He remarked on the time and money expended by the State on fisheries and asked:

The Fascist Grand Council met again this evening under Premier Mussolini's chairmanship to consider the situation brought about by Chancellor Hitler's coup in Austria, and after examining all documents relating to the case, including a letter which Hitler sent to Mussolini at the moment he was dispatching his ultimatum to Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg, issued a very noncommittal communique.
Students in the nursery school at Sarah Lawrence College are using cameras instead of pencils and notebooks to study child training.

Hundreds of persons prominent in society have subscribed to.the annual International Skating Carnival to be given in four performances at Madison Square Garden in it the near future as a benefit for the convalescent relief division of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service Bureau, the Carroll Club and the Carroll Vacation Camp.

In the first game of the season for both teams, the Long Island University rugby team scored an impressive victory over the New York Rugby Club yesterday, 6 to 3, on the North Meadow Field at Central Park. The mild weather brought out a crowd of more than 500 per-sons.

RECENT reports in the daily press of a decrease in the number of American elms hereabouts found infected with Dutch elm disease have been decidedly encouraging to home owners and all who appreciate the grace of trees. In New Jersey the number diminished from 5,504 to 4,215; in New York from 1,699 to 1,136.

DESPITE the wide interest in the heating of hotbeds with electricity by means of soil cables, this new aid to gardeners seems to have been handicapped from the very beginning. This has been principally due to the fact that most of the early experimenters followed their practice with manure-heated frames.

THE present Italian effort to bring still more opera to the public has had further encouragement from the Scala management this season with the application of a permanent popular price scale to the two galleries. In previous years such facilities had been restricted to certain non-subscription performances.

Lieut. Comdr: William S.Bunkley, senior medical officer assigned to the United. States Embassy in Moscow for the last fifteen months, returned yesterday on the United States liner President Harding, accompanied by his wife.

The important part that communities play in the final selection of a home will be presented at the Long Island Home Show in the Jamaica Armory from April 30 to May 7, under the sponsorship of the Long Island Real Estate Board and the FHA, Edward F. Hosinger, general chairman of the show, announced yesterday.

The legislative committee of the American Labor party announced yesterday its emphatic disapproval of the pending Burchill bill providing for a limited type of collective bargaining for the 5,400 employes on the city's Independent subway system.

The basketball team of the Third Battalion Marines, of the Brooklyni Navy Yard, will play the Sixth Battalion Marines of Philadelphia in an Eastern Marine Corps Reserve championship game at the Brooklyn Navy Yard court today.

DAVENTRY stations have announced their Spring schedules. Stations GSD, GSC and GSB, on 11.75, 9.58 and 9.51 megacycles, now send from 9:17 to 11:20 P. M., Eastern standard time, whereas the former evening period was from 9:12 to 11:15 o'clock.

Optimistm in Kansas City who have believed that the "unhorsing" of Tom Pendergast was in the offing received a Jolt when the Dacratio machine functioned who precision in the city primary this week and a Fusionist ticket failed to live up to expectation,.
For the second time this year France indulged this week in the luxury of a political crisis-and virtually every one agreed that she could not afford it.

Senator Vandenberg of Michigan outlined today his idea of a Congressional program. "I'd be willing to stand on it," he said in an interview. The Senator only smiled, however, when asked whether it could be considered a possible 1940 platform.

Three more taxicab fleets belonging to the Sunshine-Radio system have abandoned the joint lockout started a week ago by that group and the Atlas-Liberty system and have renewed operation of their cabs under the agreement made with the Transport Workers Union last December,

THE 1937-38. "crop of voices" is the best unearthed in the three years that the metropolitann auditions have been on the air, in the opinion of Wilfred Pelletier, who conducts the Sunday afternoon tryouts for candidates seeking a coveted place in the ranks of the "Met."

SEARCH for the individual in room decoration has a way of leading to the amusing. Gentle fun is being poked by present-day decorators at the furnishings of our grandparents' houses-just as fun is being poked by present-day producers at our grandparents' melodramas.

Total assets estimated at $114,000 for Federal tax purposes were indicated yesterday, when an application for the right to administer the estate of the late O. O. McIntyre, newspaper columnist, was made by his widow, Maybelle H. McIntyre, in Surrogate's Court.

Certain of the more sensitive railroad issues rallied moderately in quiet trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Despite this upturn in carrier issues, following one of the most severe declines in many months earlier in the week, the market generally drifted slightly lower on the day.

Combining the theory of the classroom with the practice of the home, high school pupils at the Yorkville Vocational School for Service Trades, 421 East Eighty-eighth Street, substitute flesh-and-blood babies for the conventional routine textbooks as they master the mysteries of nursery education.

An aggregate amount of $741,000 of 4 per cent bonds of New York City is among ninety-two issues of securities of taxing districts in thirty States amounting to $4,204,000 for which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today it would receive bids until noon on March 29 at its offices here.

A $50,000,000 loan program for wool producers, covering their 1937 and 1938 production, which has been approved by President Roosevelt and the Commodity Credit Corporation, was started today by Secretary Wallace, acting under the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938.

STUDY of the recent novelties and improvements in perennial plants may be counted on to assist the gardener to select hardy specimens that will give to his beds and borders the best possible color combinations, heights, forms and general decorative effects.

THE first two weeks in March have always found broadcasting at "dead center," with few changes in shows, but with numerous productions in their final weeks, just prior to shifts for which Spring gives the cue. March never comes in like a lion on the radio. Generally, September and October blow in the new shows, radically changing the pattern of broadcasting.

The basketball team of the Third Battalion Marines, of the Brooklyni Navy Yard, will play the Sixth Battalion Marines of Philadelphia in an Eastern Marine Corps Reserve championship game at the Brooklyn Navy Yard court today.

Total assets estimated at $114,000 for Federal tax purposes were indicated yesterday, when an application for the right to administer the estate of the late O. O. McIntyre, newspaper columnist, was made by his widow, Maybelle H. McIntyre, in Surrogate's Court.

Hal Seften, 31 years old, who came here from Kansas City several weeks ago, was arrested on Lexington Avenue between Fiftieth and Fifty-first Streets last night as a man who only a few moments before had attempted to hold up Alexander Klein, manager of a beauty shop at 459 Lexington Avenue, with a toy pistol.
Appointment of Mrs. Ewilda Miller Robinson, widow of Senator Joseph T. Robinson of Arkansas, to be acting postmaster of Little Rock was announced today by the- Postoffice Department.

The University of Pittsburgh tonight won its first Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association championship by scoring 40 points. Rutgers was second with 25 and Franklin and Marshall, defending champion, third with 24.

Accounts receivable in the garment trades in February were slower than in some time and collections averaged twenty days overdue, according to a survey published in the March issue of The Credit Executive, the magazine of the New York Credit Men's Association, which will be sent to subscribers tomorrow.

Speaking tonight to some 200 officers and directors of Federal savings and full loan associations assembled in the Hotel Taft here, at the second quarterly conference of the New England League of Federal Savings Institutions William H. Husband.

LONDON. - "Time, gentlemen, time," that familiar cry in London taverns which announces the daily closing of the establishment and causes law-abiding Britons to gulp their "bitter" and be off about their business, seems to epitomize the whole system of restrictions on English drinking habits.

With undisguised relief, Manager Joe McCarthy this morning announced the signing of Lou Gehrig to a contract for $39,000, a figure which makes him one of the highest priced players in baseball history.

The by New York University girls' basketball team lost its last game of the season to Connecticut State today, 15-13. Connecticut led all the way by virtue of Superior foul shooting, but Miss Clark of the Violets threatened to give New York the victory when she scored heavily in the late minutes.

Reported land in the Arctic Ocean about 400 miles north of Point Barrow, Alaska, may be some of the next territory to be claimed by the United States, it was learned today. The "land" was first reported by the Russian fliers who flew from Russia to the United States early last Summer.

Declaring that the further cut of 20 per cent in the acreage to be planted to corn in the eleven CornBelt States, recently ordered under the new Agricultural Adjustment Aet, will be dangerous to the food supplies of the nation, The Grain and Livestock Herald says the acreage planted to corn in these States last year was 14 per cent below the average for the five years from 1928 to 1 1932.

Austria's political future definitely was delivered into the custody of National Socialist Germany today. Any other conclusion deduced from the presence of the Reich's defense forces on what twenty-four hours ago was still sovereign Austrian soil or from the frenzied ovations showered on Chancellor Hitler as he motored over the turnpikes of his native land would seem to be artless quibbling.

Over Vienna, historic city of the Habsburgs, the red, white and black swastika banner of Nazi Germany flew yesterday. Over the air, in place of the classic Austrian melodies of Schubert and Strauss, came the "Horst Wessel Song," the second national anthem of the Third Reich. The Austria of song and story, the Austria of Dollfuss, of Schuschnigg, had gone down before the German might, and Adolf Hitler was in the land of his birth.

THE HOBBIT, OR THERE AND BACK AGAIN. By J. R. R. Tolkien. Illustrations by the Author. 310 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $2.50. THIS is one of the most freshly original and delightfully imaginative books for children that have appeared in many a long day.

Harry F. Wolf of the Montclair A. D defeated an old rival when he eliminated Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club to gain the semi-fina round of the national squash tennis championship yesterday.

Annunciation School defeated Sacred Heart's basketball combination, 30 to 15, yesterday in a firstround contest of the Catholic YouthOrganization parochial school championship tourney at St. Ann's Academy. In the same bracket St. Jerome School of the Bronx beat St. Peter's of Staten Island, 34 to 10, at the Bronx C. Y. O. Center.
The second experiment in the education of the public through the medium of mass meetings for bank depositors will be undertaken this week by the American Bankera Association.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, announced yesterday the appointment of Millard Hays Gibson, well-known consulting engineer, to the newly created post of assistant director of the Personnel Bureau in Charge of Graduate Placement for City College.

A $50,000,000 loan program for wool producers, covering their 1937 and 1938 production, which has been approved by President Roosevelt and the Commodity Credit Corporation, was started today by Secretary Wallace, acting under the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938.

STUDY of the recent novelties and improvements in perennial plants may be counted on to assist the gardener to select hardy specimens that will give to his beds and borders the best possible color combinations, heights, forms and general decorative effects.

The Blirchill bill providing for limited collective bargaining for the 5,400 employes of the city's Independent Subway System will not be passed by the-State Assembly unless Mayor La Guardia specifically requests such action, it was indicated here last night. In labor and political circles it was predicted that no such request would be made and that the bill, already passed by the Senate, would fail in the other house.
The monthly meeting of the New York State Safe Deposit Association will be held on Wednesday at the Paramount Hotel.

What Germany stands to gain materially from Anschluss is appraised on the basis of her territorial and other losses through the Versailles Treaty. The World War deprived her of roughly 70,000 square kilometers of territory and left her with a. population of around 64,000,000.
Prize winners in the recent contest for choral works by American composers were announced today by Ellen S. Woodward, assistant works progress administrator.
Differences between waterfront employers and longshoremen threatened tonight to tie up Los Angeles Harbor.

Severe fighting continued at many points in Shansi Province today,. with no decisive change in the situation. Chinese flank attacks in the southwestern part of the province are reported to. have caused the weakening of Japanese efforts to cross the Yellow River.

Mrs. Harvey Dow Gibson, wife of the president and chairman of the board of the Manufacturers Trust Company, who was injured yesterday when she fell with her horse while following the Meadow Brook hounds in a fox hunt, was reported today by Dr. Garrett Duryea, in charge of her case at the North Country Community Hospital here, as progressing as favorably as could be expected.

In Vienna at 1:30 P. M. yesterday I got a telephone call that the Paris express, leaving at 2:30, would be the last train over the Austro-Swiss border, provided nothing happened meanwhile to block even this exit. With my effects in suitcases, I reached the Westbahnhof twentyfive minutes before starting time.

A survey in which 13,528 young people in Maryland were interviewed has revealed dissatisfaction over the roles they play in the nation's economic system and discouragement over the economic outlook, the American Youth Commission announced today.

Sin is thought of today by many as an individual act of wrongdoing that arises from momentary carelessness instead of being considered the inevitable consequence of living by a philosophy that is basically sinful, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street.

IT was the day of another sensational failure on Wall Street, and a green young reporter for The New York Commercial Advertiser, assigned to the job (because no more suitable person was available) of finding out what had happened, stood uncertainly in the customers' room of the insolvent firm and waited.

Current reports covering industrial activity contribute a mixed picture, but give no cause for any real uneasiness. Most industries are maintaining a high level of activity, but new orders still are dwindling.

Chancellor Hitler, carter his first night in his native Austria as undisputed master of both Germany and Austria, visited the graves of his parents today in a little tree-shaded graveyard here, ten mliles from Linz.

BALTIMORE--National Millinery Co. B. Grossman, women's hats; 15 W. 38th (Room 601). BARNESBORO, Pa.-Luremberg's; M. Bonner, men's, boys' clothing; 45 W. 34th (Shafetz Bros.). BIRMINGHAM-Loveman, Joseph Loeb; A. L. Schoenberg, millinery; 128 W. 31st (City Stores Co.).

Trinity Ave (9-2631), w s, 300 ft n of 161st St, 50x100; Ida London to Elias D. Jaffe, 635 E 228th St; mortgage, $42,500. Main St (18-5638), e s, 125 ft n of Rochelle St, 75x200; also Horton St. s. 200 ft e of City Island Ave, 50x150, Joseph E. Butterworth to Hazel B. Moebus, 114 W 183d St.

Nine army planes left Mitchel Field today for Lakeland, Fla., all loaded with personnel who will take part in manoeuvres there. Eight of the planes are bombers that have been converted to transports with the addition of extra seats.

Enactment of the Patman bill for government control of the Federal Reserve banks "would be a long step in the direction of an undesirable type of control over our economic activities by the central government," according to a statement issued today by seventy-one members of the Economists' National Committee on Monetary Policy.
Just before the Austrian collapse on Friday, there is reason to believe, Viscount Halifax, British Foreign Secretary, sent to Joseph A. C. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations,
The texts of the German Anschluss law, proclaimed by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels before the German press in Berlin today, and two decrees by Chancellor Hitler follow:
Four champion teams will clash at Madison -Square Garden tonight in the semi-final round of the national invitation college basketball tournament.

Preparations for the annual Parents Day celebration on the Mall in Central Park May 8 were announced yesterday by Uncle Robert. Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, and Mrs. Campbell will receive a special invitation tomorrow, the announcement said.

The removal of the Winter Olympic Games from Japan in 1940 was foreshadowed today when the International Olympic Committee changed its charter to allow Winter and Summer games to be held in different countries.

Mr. and Mrs. Roy Briscoe Mattern of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna Ranken Mattern, to John McArthur Harris Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris of Germantown, Pa.

The annual report of the North American Edison Company for 1937, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income, after all expenses and charges, of $12,060,369, compared with $11,135,679 earned in 1936.
The deficit in France's trade balance increased in February, imports exceeding exports by 1,969,000,000 francs, compared with 1,441,000,000 in January.

Delegates to the National Unity Convention of the Jewish Peoples Committee for United Action Against Fascism and Anti-Semitism adopted yesterday a resolution directing a bill to outlaw "increasing discrimination" against Jews and other minorities be drafted for Congress.
Once again Mohandas K. Gandhi, cooperating with Lord Linlithgow, the Viceroy, has exercised his unique personal influence on the Congress (Independence) party.

There is a more insistent demand for justice in the relations of man to man in this modern time than ever before, the Rev. Francis X. Talbot, editor-in-chief of the magazine America, .declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier, 28 West Sixteenth Street.

The Maritime Commission will hold conferences here beginning Friday with shipping men, port and civic bodies and any others interested in the development of the merchant 'marine, according to a conference summons sent out this week by the Port of New York Authority in behalf of the commission.
The first in a monthly series of "book and author Juncheons," under the auspices of the American Booksellers Association, will be held on Wednesday, March 30, at Essex House.

This was a day when the Yankee crew could have used the power ordinarily supplied by Lou Gehrig, Joe DiMaggio and Bill Dickey. But neither Gehrig nor DiMaggio is in town and Dickey is on the sidelines.

Anthony Eden, former British Foreign Secretary, is visiting his sister, Countess Warwick, at Saint-Jean Cap Ferrat and will not go to London for the forthcoming debate in the House of Commons, it was learned tonight.

A paralyzed Spanish-American War veteran was taken to Atlantic City Hospital tonight in a condition recorded as very poor and his woman caretaker was jailed without bail a complaint charging cruelty and being a disorderly person.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions WILLIAM P. YOUNG BROS., INC., lumber dealers, 735-9 E. 9th St., Manhattan. and 43-16 Vernon Blvd., Long Island City-Voluntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Laws with current liabilities of $100,309 and total assets of $367,765.

Excitement was caused here today by the message from Adolf Hitler to Premier Mussolini saying: "I shall never forget this." It referred to Italy's apparent support of his coup, but it gave rise to rumors, circulated enthusiastically by Nazis, that Mussolini had agreed to return to the expanded Reich Southern Tyrol, which Austria lost to Italy in the World War.

Josef Hofmann made his fiftieth appearance with the PhilharmonicSymphony Society at its concert in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The pianist, who is celebrating the golden jubilee of his career in America, was heard in Chopin's E minor concerto, with John Barbirolli conducting the orchestra.

State control of California oil production was favored in a resolution made public today by the Oil Producers Agency, an organization for coordinating voluntary regulation of oil output. The poll was taken, according to Rush M. Blodgett, vice president,
Beating of Jews and plundering of Jewishowned stores increased today. Jews were disappearing from Vienna life. Few, if any, were to be seen on the streets or in the coffee houses.

Defeating the Red Bank Polo Club today, 13 to 11, in the final of the New Jersey eliminations, the 112th Field Artillery trio of Red Bank gained the right to meet the New York division winner in the Sherman Memorial tournament.
Champion Glynhir Golden, wire-haired fox terrier, was named best in show at the Western Reserve Kennel Club classic in the Cleveland Public Hall tonight. She had 1,265 competitors.

The Czechoslovak frontier with Austria has been closed for travelers with Austrian passports. Poles are allowed to pass through Czech territory on their way home if their papers are in order. Unlike the native population,
Ira V. Hiscock, Professor of Public Health at the Yale University School of Medicine, has been elected president of the National Health Council for 1938, it was announced yesterday.
Frank Storms led in Class 1 in a registered shoot at the North Jersey Gun Club today. I. Wortman, W. M. Frederick, W. F. Streelman and L. R. Slocum tied for second.

Gardner W. Kimball, former president of the Pennsylvania Institute of Certified Public Accountants, died of a heart attack at his apartment in Germantown yesterday at the age of 64. Born in Plainfield, N. J., Mr. Kimball in 1905 entered the employ. of Edward P. Moxey Co. and six years later became a member of the company.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

Hope Farm, a community for the shelter and education of underprivileged boys and girls, will be the beneficiary of a showing of paintings by Paul Cezanne, which will open March 28 at the DurandRuel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street, and continue there for three weeks. Mrs. Stephen C. Clark heads the reception committee for the opening afternoon, when a tea will be given in honor of a group of prominent men and women.

The money we make should be regarded as a means to practice the art of life as opposed to the trade of life, declared the Rev. John K. Benedict in a sermon yesterday at the Centenary Methodist Church, 166th Street and Washington Avenue, the Bronx.

A week of sharp and perhaps bitter debate appears to be in store for both chambers of Congress. The Senate will continue its discussion, which at times has been acrimonius, of the Government Reorganization Bill, while the House is scheduled to take up in general debate the naval expansion measure.

Governor Lehman, as Commander in Chief of the New York State National Guard and Naval Militia, has ordered the two organizations to start an immediate investigation of all non-citizens now enlisted in their ranks and to discharge any found to be aliens, it was announced here today.
The New York Americans, national soccer champions, bowed to St. Mary's Celtics, 3 to 2, in their American League fixture at Celtic Park .in Brooklyn yesterday.
The Red Sox lost their opening exhibition game today to the Reds, 6 to 2. There were some cheerful aspects to the defeat, however, for Manager Joe Cronin.
The jackass which Senator Bridges of New Hampshire told the Senate the Tennessee Valley Authority paid $4,500 to search for and purchase is dead.
The collapse of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Richard Whitney Co. was discussed in several sermons preached yesterday from pulpits in city churches.

The Folksbiene, a troupe sponscored by the Jewish Workmen's Circle, presented at the Bayes Theatre last night a farce comedy by Joseph Tunkel called "The Jesters." Mr. Tunkel has been known hitherto as a writer of witty feuilletons and one-acters.

Gross sales and other revenues of the United States Steel Corporation in 1937 amounted to $1,395,549,630, according to the annual pamphlet report issued today, a gain of 28.8 per cent over the $1,083,337,435 reported for 1936, and the highest figure since 1929, when the total was $1,493,505,485.

The National Academy of Design announced yesterday the winners of the prizes and medals that it awards each year in connection with its annual exhibition. This year there are three gold medals and fifteen cash prizes totaling $4,500.
After twenty-three years of service as pastor to lumber camps of the Adirondacks, the Rev. C. William Mason of Ithaca has retired. Mr. Mason, "sky pilot" to the woodsmen, was 70 years old on Friday.

Chastity today is both an individual and a social necessity, declared John Haynes Holmes, minister of the Community Church, yesterday in his sermon "Is Chastity an Outworn Virtue?" at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

The qualifications necessary for the youngmen who will be the "guinea pigs" in its program to train an officer personnel for an enlarged United States merchant marine .were announced by the Maritime Commission today.

With Broadway's year almost at the Spring, Marc Connelly and Bela Blau have decided to embellish it with a musical show. For production about April 25 they have acquired "The Two Bouquets," that gentle travesty on Victorian life and manners by Eleanor and Herbert Farjeon which London saw for 300 performances between August, 1936, and last May.

Mr. and Mrs. William Truffant Foster of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Faith Foster, to Hugh Kaul, son of Mrs. John L. Kaul of Birmingham, Ala., and the late Mr. Haul.

Meeting, New York City League of Women Voters, 151 East Fiftieth Street, 10:30 A. M. "Collective Bargaining-Government," Mabel Leslie. Town Hall, 11 A. M. "The Crisis in Central Europe," William E. Dodd.

Approval by the Board of Education of the bill pending before the Legislature to provide State aid for evening high and vocational schools was announced yesterday by James Marshall, vice president of the board and chairman of its law committee. Seven other bills dealing with school matters. were disapproved.

The Bridge World Magazine and Games Digest Magazine, both edited and founded by Ely Culbertson, have been merged with Autobridge, Inc., which is headed by Amster Spiro, city editor of The New York Journal American.
The speech of Walther Funk, the new Reich Minister of Economics, at the opening of the Leipzig Fair was taken as a sign that an active anti-foreigndebt. campaign was impending.

The deadlock that developed in the corn market some weeks ago continues, and prices on the Board of Trade held last week within a range of less than .1 cent a bushel, breaks to below 59 cents for the May drawing in fair support while, above that figure, there was somewhat free selling.

Living in the midst of materialism and its glorification of man, the city dweller must constantly guard against the worshiping of the false deity of bigness, the Rev. Howard David Higgins, Bishop of the New York and Philadelphia Synod of the Reformed Episcopal Church, declared yesterday morning at the First Reformed Episcopal Church, 317 East Fiftieth Street.

Arrangements were completed today for the funerals of the five firemen killed last night in the collapse of a brick wall as they were wetting down the ruins of a fire that destroyed the warehouse of the Quackenbush Department Store in the afternoon.

An upstanding pointer dog who answered all the questions put up by the judges was the winner of the open all-age stake in the final and most interesting stake of the Spring meeting of the Babylon Hunt Club, which was completed today.

Exultant Nazi circles appeared confident today that union with the German Reich was near. Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Austrian coup was celebrated in flag-bedecked streets and schools declared holidays after teachers explained to classes the significance of the event.

Despite the French Cabinet crisis and the rising excitement over the events in Austria the week's business interest was almost exclusively concentrated on questions of credit and banking, dominated by the impending annual meeting of the Reichsbank's stockholders.

In a 3,000word "appeal to the American people," the Shiunso [Purple Cloud] Society upbraids the United States for its severity toward Japan and outlines a new policy for America to follow if she desires peace in the Orient.

The Protestant National Confessional Synod ordered all Protestant church bells in Germany rung at 3 o'clock every afternoon to remind the nation that the Protestant leader, the Rev. Martin Niemoeller, is in a concentration camp.

The Lithuanian border incident of yesterday, in which a Polish soldier was killed in a clash with frontier guards, continues to cause excitement. The concentration of Lithuaniani soldiers on the frontier is reported from Kovno.
A 250-home village, costing more than $1,500,000, is planned here by private interests under regulations of the Federal Housing Administration.

Wheat prices dropped last week to new low levels on the current downward movement; the break ended on Friday morning, with the May and July futures only slightly above the inside figures of the season.

Representatives of American business and agriculture will appear before the Committee for Reciprocity Information at hearings starting tomorrow to say how far they are willing to go in making to Great Britain the trade concessions which are held essential to successful negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement.

Barring unforseen development, the 1938 session of the Legislature will end this week. With the adjournment resolution already submitted and leaders of both parties in the Senate and Assembly driving toward an early closing,

All vessels in the harbor are expected to "dress ship" with flags tomorrow in observance of Port of New York Day, it was announced yesterday by Robert A. Gertzen, chairman of the port display committee of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York.

A special performance of the Passion Play presented by the parish of Holy Family Roman Catholia Church was given here this afternoon in the Passion Play auditorium for the benefit of Jesuit missionaries in the Philippine Islands before an audience estimated at more than 1,300.

A self-portrait of President Roosevelt as he thought and acted in his dramatic first year in office is presented in a form more graphic than any one, including himself, could write in retrospect, in a selection of transcripts of White House press conferences now released for publication.
Money for lending was all the more scarce on the market this week as the internal political crisis and fears of international complications became disturbing factors.

Federal income tax clerks don't know whether the man was kidding or not, but here's what they received in the mail from a taxpayer assessed $7.40: "My salary was $400 a month. Somebody got my job, the finance company took my car, the bank took my home, my wife took the furniture and somebody took my wife.

The lard market was somewhat less active last week and prices were on the downgrade. Much of the trading was regarded as closing of spreads between lard and cottonseed oil, which caused heavy losses to those who had bought lard and sold oil futures.
Incorporation of new companies continued to decline in February, the Corporation Bureau of the Secretary of State's office announced today.

Two dance events made up yesterday's schedule. In the afternoon at the Barbizon-Plaza Loda Halama, billed as prima ballerina of the Warsaw Opera, made her New York debut in a program of Polish and character dances.

Most of the leading members of the Metropolitan Opera will take part in the "special gala performance" next Sunday evening at the Opera House in observance of Giovanni Martinelli's twenty-fifth season with the company.

The Department of Commerce has announced that the silver imports from Mexico during February were valued at $4,627,318. Base bullion silver imports from Mexico during the month totaled 4,658,110 ounces, valued at $2,079,564. Refined silver imports totaled 5,696,252 ounces valued at $2,547,754.

The Rev. Dr. George Arthur Buttrick declared himself strongly against the use of force by "saner nations" to oppose Japanese aggression in China or Hitler's entrance into Austria, in his morning serinon yesterday at the Madison Ave-nue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street.

Declaring that the seeds of the next war were planted at Versailles, the Rev. C. Everett Wagner, in his sermon at the Union Methodist Church, Forty-eighth Street, west of Broadway, warned yesterday that "only in peaceful methods can satisfactory settlements be made."

Addressing 400 delegates of Jewish organizations in Brooklyn yesterday, M. Maldwin Fertig, member of the governing council of the American Jewish Congress, called for concerted action to meet the new crisis brought about by the German invasion of Austria.
A white shaft nine feet loftier than the Washington Monument is today, to all outward appearances, complete on the old battlefield of San Jacinto, about twenty miles from this city,

The bonds and preferred stocks of the seven private utilities most vitally affected by the Tennessee Valley Authority's program are selling for $100,000,000 less than their value based upon market prices of similar securities in a group of utility companies free from Federal Government competition,

At the moment, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's position with the Reichsbank seems strengthened as reform of the method of financing the Reich's orders, which he has just made known, represents his personal success, and it is even possible that he negotiated it as a condition for abandoning his resignation plan.

The Al Building and Loan Association of Newark sold to the Quincy Housing Corporation of Brooklyn the two three-story buildings each containing three stores and ten apartments, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, at 353-59 Kearny Avenue, Kearny.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Carter Dickerman of 6 East Seventy-ninth Street and Dune Dee, East Hampton, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Honour Redington Dickerman, to James Oliver Brown of this city, son of William E. Brown of Rochester, Pa., and the late Mrs. Brown.

Miss Leontine Terry, daughter of Mrs. James Terry of this city, was married to Robert Lambie Hatch, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hatch of Altadena, Calif., yesterday afternoon in the Asylum Hill Congregational Church by the Rev. Dr. David McKeith.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Incredible as it may seem that an administration pledged to reduce unemployment should penalize the very action necessary to sustain employment, that is exactly what the government is doing in allowing the undistributed profits tax to continue in effect.

There is a "grave danger" that organized labor will not only defeat its own ends but will become a menace to contemporary civilization by "forgetting its personal character and considering itself what capitalism always thought it wascommodity," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheem, Professor of Fundamental Theology at the Catholic University of America, Washington, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Oppression of Ukrainians living in Poland and the "ruthless extermination" of Ukrainian national life there were decried, yesterday by speakers at a meeting of 700 Ukrainian-Americans called by the Organization for the Rebirth of Ukraine at the Ukrainian National Home, 217 East Sixth Street.

John J. Stamler, lawyer, member of the Elizabeth Municipal Water Commission and formerly prominent as a banker in this city and Newark, died suddenly at his home here last night. His age was 69. A resident of Elizabeth since 1890, he studied law here and was admitted to the bar in 1903.

The rich need the poor much more than the poor need the rich, because by giving, the rich gain "kindness in their hearts and grace in their souls" Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of,Catholic University told the annual Cardinal's Conference on Charity at its opening meeting yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Doubtful that Governor Lehman will consent to run for re-election or that Senator Robert F. Wagner can be drafted to head the Democratic State ticket, leading members of the American Labor party, it was learned yesterday, are considering the availability of City Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick as the Labor party's candidate for Governor.

Winning three games, drawing five and losing only one out of a total of sixteen scheduled, the Manhattan Chess Club took a lead of 5 1/2 to 3 1/2 against the champion Marshall Club at the rooms of the latter in the final round for the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League yesterday.
James H. Van Alen of New York and Newport, R. I., today won the national championship in court tennis, the oldest and most exclusive game in the world.
Just for a change, Glenn Cunningham was the chief topic of track conversation yesterday following two magnificent performances in the Knights of Columbus games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.
Miss Katherine Rawls of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Ralph Flanagan of Miami continued their assault on the national swimming record books today, each with one performance in better than record time.

The intenslfication of Italo-German political solidarity and cooperation, beyond the scope originally envisaged through the creation of the BerlinRome axis in the Fall of 1936, is predicted here as a result of the German political conquest in Austria.

Ernest Hemingway, author, entered the ring as referee of a Negro boxing match here last night and left it winner of the decision over a second. One of the fighters was floored in the last round and Hemingway started counting.

A young Negro, believed responsible for many burglaries in the Flatbush arid Sheepshead Bay sections of Brooklyn, was locked up on a charge of burglary yesterday after he had been trapped by detectives as he called at a jewelry store for a stolen watch left for repair.

According to a communique from Salamanca, Andorra has been captured and a cavalry division under General Ituarte Monasterio with motorized units of the Insurgent central column was tonight rapidly nearing Alcaniz.
The committee on new housing of the Citizens Housing Council will meet at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, at 3 o'clock this afternoon to discuss its program for low-rent housing.

A tea was given yesterday by Mrs. John C. Ten Eyck at her home, 455 East Fifty-seventh Street, for Countess Alice Hoyos, who will be married on Thursday to Mrs. Ten Eyck's son, John C. Ten Eyck Jr. The hostess was assisted in receiving the guests by Mrs. Coatsworth Pinckney.
Misbranding of hosiery will be discontinued by Baker - Cammack Hosiery Mills, Burlington, N. C., under a stipulation entered into with the Federal Trade Commission, the commission announces.

Dr. Sterling Temple, director of the Roessler Hasslacher chemical department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., at Niagara Falls, N. Y., has received the Jacob F. Schoellkopf Gold Medal of the Western New York Section, American Chemical Society, Albert E. Jennings Jr., secretary, announced yesterday.

A letter from Secretary of the Navy Swanson declaring that the Army Day celebration enables the American people to "learn more about national defense and the responsibilities and duties of the armed forces" was made public
Employers of more than 15,000 Western New York food industries workers were negotiating with the American Federation of Labor today for the unionization of their personnel.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler made public yesterday his annual report on the activities of the division of intercourse and education of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in which he turned, after several years of contemplating the national scene in the past to a Martian's view of the earth.
The police here today sought burglars who escaped with 144 pieces of table silver worth about $1,000 after breaking into the Cross River Road home of Dr. W. H. Wellington
Charlotte Ryan, former Metropolitan Opera soprano, has joined the faculty at the College of New Rochelle, it was announced today by Mother M. Clothilde, head of the Music Department.

Billions are spent to operate the armies of the world, but only a tiny fraction" of this sum supports the Salvation Army in ninetyfive different lands, it is emphasized in a pamphlet to be issued today by Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., chairman of the 1938 Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army.
Senator Joseph F. Guffey today declared that he would back the candidacy of Governor George H. Earle for the Senate seat now held by James J. Davis, Republican.

Albert F. Hoffman, vice president of the Hoffman Beverage Company, and Miss Emylyn Pique (Mitzi Mayfair), Broadway entertainer and motion picture actress, were married here last night at the home of Mr. Hoffman's mother, Mrs. Henrietta Hoffman.

Mercer St, n e cor W 3d St, 50x105, City Bank Farmers Trust Co, trustee, to Perry Dickie, 1/4 interest; same property, 1/4 interest, Perry Dickie to Amie Antoinette Dickie, his wife, 924 West End Ave. Also 32 W 28 St, 22.6x98.9, same to same, and same to same, 1/4 interest.

New York University's basketball team gained undisputed possession of metropolitan honors as the regular intercollegiate season came to a close, with most of the activity confined to the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

In a variation on the old-fashioned spelling bee, members of the Town Hall Club matched their wits and their knowledge of New York City lore in a "Know-Your-City Bee" last night in the clubhouse at 123 West Forty-third Street.

Mrs. Florence Scott Libbey, widow of Edward Drummond Libbey, founder of the Toledo Museum of Art, died while visiting in Pasadena, Calif., after a brief illness, according to a message received today by the trustees of the museum..

Jacob O. Zabronsky, president of the National Council of Young Israel, announced yesterday that Governor Lehman had been chosen to receive the council's first annual award for services as "humanitarian, Governor, outstanding Jew, civic leader and model for American youth."

A stiffening of court policy. in cases involving bookmaking was seen yesterday as the result f a letter sent by Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. to all city magistrates, in which he declared that in view of a recent Court of Appeals decision "it is assumed that hereafter defendants charged with bookmaking will be only rarely discharged."
Japanese salvage crews today refloated the liner Asama Maru, which had been aground in Saiwan Bay since last September's typhoon.

Miss Elsa Voorhees of Princeton, N. J., daughter of Mrs. John D. Jameson of this city and of Professor J. Dayton Voorhees of Princeton University, will be married to Theodore Spaeth Hauschka of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia,
