A threat to tube train service between New York and Newark appeared today when 170 night shift employes of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad voted here to ask the National Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, of which they are members, for permission to issue strike ballots.

The tenth anniversary of the dedication of the Bethany Lutheran Church, 163d Street, east of Third Avenue, was celebrated yesterday with special choral services and a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Ellis B. Burgess, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York.
The first annual Wildlife Week Dinner will be held on March 25 at the Waldorf-Astoria, with Lowell Thomas in the toastmaster's chair.

William E. Blewett, for fortythree years an employee of the New York investment banking house of Brown Brothers, Harriman Co., died here today after a long illness at the age of 68. Mr. Blewett retired to his Sparta, N. J., farm eight years ago after suffering a stroke.

Here on a "good-will" sightseeing visit, Albania's three smartly-clad Moslem princesses today stood silently before Bishop Fan Noli, their country's former premier, and heard him pray for their brother, King Zog-the man who sent him into exile.
Samuel Fox, 37 West Thirty-sixth Street, has been named exclusive sales representative for its line of men's sweaters and bathing suits by the Princeton Knitting Mills, Philadelphia, Pa.

Mr. and Mrs. Bradish G. Johnson have returned from New Orleans, and, with their daughter, Miss Adelaide G. Johnson, are at Hampshire House. Mrs. S. Clay Williams has come from Winston-Salem, N. C., to the Waldorf-Astoria.

An aggregate of approximately $124,850,000 is invested in public utilities in the Philippine Islands, according to statistics made public by the Philippine Public Service Commission and reported to the Department of Commerce by the office of the American Trade Commissioner at Manila.
The Indoor Polo Association announced tonight the award to Chicago of the national indoor polo championship tournament, with the 124th Field Artillery Armory as the scene of play.

Eighteen sightless boys and a man "Do a good turn daily" as one of the nation's most unusual Boy Scout troops. The blind boys wear uniforms work for merit badges just like scouts the nation over who can see.

Spring was just around the corner yesterday at the Grand Central Palace, where a small army of horticultural enthusiasts and workmen was putting the finishing touches on the twenty-fifth International Flower Show, which will open this afternoon at 2 P. M.

A merger of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, operated by a group of hotel men, and the Convention Bureau of the Merchants Association of New York was announced yesterday by Louis K. Comstock, president of the association, and Frank W. Kridel, chairman of the bureau's administrative committee.

A defense of the apostolic doctrine was given by the Rev. John R. Atkinson yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. "We have turned to various philosophires for comfort and they have all failed," Mr. Atkinson said.

Major Frederick George Jackson, one of Great Britain's most famous Arctic explorers, died here today at the age of 78. Major Jackson's first expedition, that in 1894-97, wherein he proved that Franz Joseph Land is an archi-. pelago and not a continent, also was his most successful, but he made many other expeditions in the course of his very active life.
The declining trend in retail prices was accelerated in February with quotations receding 1.3 per cent during the month, according to the Fairchild retail price index, issued yesterday.
Sammy Kaplan's two baskets in an overtime period gave the New York Celtics a 40-to-38 victory over the Brooklyn Visitations in an American League basketball game at the Hippodrome last night.
While Chancellor Hitler was proclaiming Anschluss with Austria today preparatory to his triumphant entry into Vienna, Field Marshal Hermann Goering, his deputy during his absence,

Taking on his own shoulders the heavy responsibility of Minister of the Treasury as well as Premier and with Joseph Paul-Boncour at the Quai d'Orsay as Foreign Minister, in place of Yvon Delbos, Leon Blum today constituted his second Popular Front Cabinet composed of Socialists with the promise of Communist support.
The Bourse this week was influenced above all by the political events at home and the rapid darkening of the international outlook.
Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which wil mature within twelve months amount to $4,155,833,900.
Appointment of a minimum wage board for the beauty shop business was announced yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

The totalitarian State is the "gravest menace to the freedom and peace of the world," declared the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, the chaplain of Columbia University, in a sermon yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel on the campus.
Daring Dick Durrance, Florida-raised skier, of the Dartmouth Ski Club, came from behind for the second consecutive year to capture the international open skiing tournament today.
An attempt by the Norswift S. C. to hold its invitation ski-jumping tournament on a hill covered with pulverized ice today at Silver Lake Park proved futile.

Five hundred and eighty-two Princeton undergraduates, 24.4 per cent of the student body, attained honor ratings in the first term of the current academic year, according to the honor roll released today by Dr. Robert K. Root, dean of the university faculty.
William R. (Billy) Woollatt, president and general manager of Thorncliffe Park Racing Associtation and former manager of Devonshire track at Windsor, Ont., died suddenly today at the age of 57.

Despite an increase in the actual volume of supplies on hand new restrictions have been imposed on the use of steel in the building industry. This is the result of expansion of public construction plans.
The Nancy Brown, owned by Mrs. Fred Hibberd, the former Lorna Whittelsey, and her husband, won the weekly dinghy series to day off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.
Putting on another fighting finish, the New York Rovers topped the Hershey Bears, 3 to 2, in an Eastern Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Mrs. Maude Owen Mason, known to thousands of Middlebury College alumni and students as "Mother Mason," died today, after a brief illness. For fifteen years she was superintendent of dormitories at Middlebury and a friend and unofficial counsel to many of the undergraduates.
Last week's financial picture did not change. Stock market averages declined some 5 points, yet remained above the low marks of the four past months.

Zita, tragic empress of a lost empire, prayed today for a miracle to save Austria for the Habsburgs. She spent long hours in the private chapel of medieval Steenockerzeel Castle while Archduke Otto, her son and pretender to a non-existent throne,. was reported on the way to consult friendly statesmen of France and Britain on Chancellor Hitler's Austrian coup.

Joseph B. Clark, who was defeated in 1931 when he ran as the candidate of the Vigilantes party for Supreme Court justice in Queens, died Saturday at his home, 97-28 Liverpool Street, Jamaica, at the age of 42. He first began to practice law in Jamaica in 1918, but was forced to retire from active practice fifteen years ago because of ill health.

Carlo Dalmazio Cardinal Minoretti, Archbishop of Genoa, died today after several days' illness. His age was 76. Archbishop of Genoa, the chief port of Italy and long the cradle of Italian seamen, Cardinal Minoretti's blessings are carried by two Italian liners, the Rex and the Conte di Savoii.

A sensational solo score by Woody Dumart with only 22 seconds of regulation play remaining enabled the Boston Bruins to defeat the New York Rangers in a thrilling National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Reinstatement of seven WPA theatre workers, dismissed for participation in a demonstration in the Federal Theatre Project on Feb. 1, was recommended yesterday by the joint appeals board of the five Federal Arts Projects in this city.
Steel production in February was 1,057,600 tons, the highest ever recorded for the month, and compared with 1,081,400 in January and 995,900 a year ago.

Cold storage holdings of fishery products in the United States on Feb. 15 were 11 per cent less than a year ago, but 33 per cent greater than the five-year average, according to the Commerce Department's Bureau of Fisheries. Holdings on Feb.

A mortgage for $13,800 on 29 Allen St, held by the Emigrant Bank from Alice Werstein and Benjamin Shakin. was extended to Aug. 11, 1942, at 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. The Emigrant Bank also extended to May 6, 1942, at 4 per cent, a mortgage for $14,800 on 204 W 133d St, held from Winslow Construction Corp.

The general industrial level is reported to be unchanged. In order to meet the labor shortage, the Reich Unemployment Board foreshadows the combing out of small retail and independent craftsman enterprises, the aim being to compel them to liquidate and transform the proprietors into wage earners in the State-fostered industries.
City Judge Robert D. Summers, who had served on the bench for seven years, died suddenly of a heart attack this evening at his home. He was 56 years old.

The report for 1937 of the United Aircraft Corporation, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net profit of $3,856,272 after charges, taxes, minority interests and reserves, equal to $1.52 each on the 2,524,751 shares of capital stock outstanding, including 6,544 shares reserved for issuance in exchange for the common stock of United Aircraft Transport Corporation.
A swastika flag flew on the Archbishop's Palace today. Some Catholics wore swastikas on their overcoats. Cardinal Innitzer made this appeal to his diocese:

Extra editions of Berlin papers rushed from the presses proclaimed tonight, "Anschluss Completed." The laws uniting Austria with the Reich are presented in heavy black type. Banner heads proclaim the absorption of the Austrian Army into the Reich Army. Chancellor Hitler's paper, the Voelkischer Beobachter, says:
Construction projects to cost $4,100,000 during 1938 have been submitted by the Wisconsin Telephone Company for approval, the State Public Service Commission announced yesterday.
On instructions from Washington, Rear Admiral Henry E. Lackey, here with the cruiser Raleigh, today accepted a bust of Guglielmo Marconi, which will be placed in the Capitol at Washington.

In a stormy discussion at the MacDowell Club last night of Federal legislation to create a bureau of fine arts, an audience openly hostile to certain features of the bill cheered speakers, headed by Dr. Walter Damrosch, who attacked the measure, and heckled several who undertook its defense..

The Giants' 1938 pennant machine thundered down the course today with all cylinders exploding and the result was almost an annihilation of Jimmy Wilson's forlorn Phillies in the concluding battle of a two-game series.

A new twenty-seven-acre waterfront park adjacent to the projected Queens Borough housing development in Long Island City appeared in the latest plans df Robert Moses, made public yesterday by the Department of Parks.
Sidney Hahn, real estates, in 152 W. 72d St. Edward Sulzberger, real estate, in 712 Madison Ave. Henry Klein, furniture, store at 788 Amsterdam Ave.; James J. Etchingham, Inc., broker.
The action at Washington of the delegates to the Community Mobilization for Human Needs has sharpened the issue between two contrasting programs' of relief.
BE YOUR AGE, by Marjorie Barstow Greenbie. (Stackpole, $2.) Advice on transition from adolescence to middle age.

Chess, or a game similar to it, provided entertainment and mental discipline for Mesopotamians of 6,000 years ago, according to evidence announced today by the University of Pennsylvania Museum and the American School of Oriental Research in Baghdad.

Dowager Lady Loch, one of the last great ladies of the Victorian age, died yesterday at her home in Chelsea at the age of 96. Her death, like that of her twin sister, Dowager Lady Lytton, in September, 1936 resulted from a fall.
The widow of Austria's slain Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss and her two children reached the Hungarian capital today as 3,000 Nazis held an enthusiastic demonstration.

Dr. Harry T. Mesh, a 27-year-old interne at Harbor Hospital, Brooklyn, died there early yesterday of injuries received in an automobile accident at Bay Parkway and Eighty-sixth Street when a pleasure car and an ambulance collided. Dr.

Chancellor Hitler became Commander in Chief of the combined German and Austrian armed forces today after the formal proclamation in Vienna of the political and geographic union of Germany and Austria.
Opposition to the proposed Federal Bureau of Fine Arts was expressed yesterday at the March meeting in the Hotel Astor of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc.
The second Hudson County education conference will be held on Tuesday at the Stevens Hoboken Academy. The conference will include a dinner in the evening at the Meyers Hotel,
The South Bend, Ind., Studebakers defeated the Crow Indian Agency team from Southern Montana, 50 to 46, in the first round of the national A. A. U. basketball championship today.
Once again beset by Continental happenings, the stock markets here relapsed this week into weakness following a transient revival.

Rowley Miller, '39, of Wayzata, Minn., outstanding both at wing and defense for two seasons, today was elected captain of the Princeton hockey- team for next Winter, it was announced by Coach Richard F. Vaughan.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 82.8, which compares with 83 a week ago, 83 two weeks ago, 82.4 three weeks ago and 82.4 four weeks ago.

Edward Margolies, who started as a bootblack and newsboy and became an important operator in New York real estate and one of the largest builders of theatres in the United States, died yesterday afternoon in Roosevelt Hospital of pneumonia after a three weeks' illness. He was 66 years old.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. will have a spectacular $500,000 display for the World's Fair, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair. "The Wonder World of Chemistry" will be shown in a functional building designed to represent greatly magnified chemical apparatus.
Collectors everywhere will endorse the quiet but determined way the United States Government has gone in lately
Trading on the Chicago Curb Exchange will cease permanently tomorrow at 2 P. M. and the Exchange will be dissolved.

W. Wellington Massee, in 19 E 98th St; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., brokers. Mrs. Theresa Morales, in 137 W 110th St; William C. Clark, in 6 W 77th St; Mrs. Myra Battel, in 226 W 72d St: August Baer, in 207 W 106th St;

Starting today, the Theatrical Costume Workers Federal Labor Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate, will launch a drive to organize workers engaged in the manufacture of theatrical wigs, shoes, rehearsal costumes, millinery,

Growing interest in apparel for pre-Easter selling produced some improvement in wholesale apparel business last week, although stores in general have not yet built up stocks for March and April selling.

" Anschluss" has been proclaimed and a small State which has fought a weary battle against fate ceased yesterday to exist as an independent nation. There are Austrians, long converted to the cause of Hitler, and ready to acclaim him as a savior, who will find satisfaction in this historic event.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

That a singer may reach prominence on the opera stage, but fail to meet the widely diverse requirements of the concert platform with like success, was once again evidenced by the recital given by Emanuel List, the Metropolitan bass, in Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Try as he might to make adequate headway in the purely lyric realm of song, Mr. List's most valuable contributions at this event all lay in the dramatic field.

About 15,000 persons, ranging from a 6-year-old drum major to 93-yearold John Leo Gibbons of Perth Flor Amboy, marched in the annual St. Patrick's parade here today as the rain reduced the number of spectators from the customary 200,000 to 75,000. Mr. Gibbons, a member of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, rejected the offer of an automobile, as he did in the snowstorm during last year's parade.

Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 31 per cent of capacity. This was up 1 point from the rate in the preceding week, the figure for which is revised to 30 per cent from 29 per cent, so that there were five successive weeks at about 30 per cent.

The Interocean Dirigible Corporation, which has taken over the plans of the Virginia Airship Corporation to build an all-metal dirigible on a Vi radical propulsion principle, announced today that it was applying to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to market 1,250,000 shares of stock on which the company placed a gross value of $16.250.000.

The Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices in February, based on 1930 as 100, was 105.8, against 107.7 in January and 103.9 in February, 1937. A percentage decline of 1.8 is shown from January, but the recession is partly seasonal.

Since Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg, until last Friday Austria's Chancellor, will not be able to supply the special introductory chapter he had planned for the American edition of his book, "My Austria," Knopf has arranged for a preface to the volume to be written by Dorothy Thompson. No publication date has yet been set for the book, but it will be issued at the earliest possible moment.

Walter F. Geiler, for thirty years associated with the Mellon Stuart Construction Company of Pittsburgh, Pa., died there Saturday of a heart attack at the age of 58. He was vice president of the firm.

Employes in the office of the Borough President of Manhattan will hold an election on March 25 to select from among their own numbers six members of a personnel service rating board, Stanley M. Isaacs, the Borough President, announced yesterday.

Mrs. Bessie Keyes, a medium, made the mistake of summoning spirits in the presence of six detectives last night, the police charged, and as a result she and her husband, Walter B. Keyes, were held in $1,000 bail today on charges of violating the fortune-telling laws.
Stocks lower for second consecutive week, erasing almost all of February's gains; turnover, 3,444,580 shares.
Visualize what happened in every city, town and hamlet in the United States in 1918 on Armistice Day and you will get a vivid picture of what ths Sunday in Vienna was like.

Exhibitions at two New York museums. and one of the big annual group shows help to swell the roster of new attractions in the art world this week. The Metropolitan is opening its exhibition of paintings and drawings by Tiepolo with a private view for members today and to the public tomorrow.

Clarence Darrow, famous criminal lawyer, recently described as one who thoroughly understood human nature yet loved his fellow-man, died this afternoon at his home here at the age of 80. For two months he had been confined to bed because of heart disease; for two years he had been retired, for many years he had been trying to retire.

Austria was formally incorporated into the Reich yesterday, despite previous assurances that she would retain her independence. President Wilhelm Miklas was.forced-out of office and Chancellor Seyss-Inquart decreed the change in status. Afterward Joseph Buerckel, Nazi leader in the Saar, superseded the Chancellor in charge. of the country.

Harry H. Weinberger, lawyer and organizer of the New Jersey Bankers Securities Company, which collapsed in 1929 with losses to investors of about $7,000,000, died this morning in Passaic General Hospital. He was 50 years old and had been stricken with meningitis Saturday.
The annual report of the New York City Omnibus Corporation and subsidiaries for 1937 shows a net income of $2,024,951 after providing $231,668 for amortization on the basis of the recapture contract.

The Bureau of Entomology said today that government and State scientists had found, after years of effort, a practical way to control the European borer that attacks early-market sweet corn in New York State.

Long Jack Winsett must have read somewhere that "hope springs eternal in the human breast" and decided that, being human, he has as much right to hope as any man, not to mention translating his hopes into action.

Mrs. Alma Clayburgh gave a tea yesterday at Sherry's for her daughter, Miss Alma Clayburgh, and her fiance, James Hooper Grew, who will be married on June 14. Guests included friends of the hostess and of Mr. Grew's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sturgis Grew, as well as friends of the engaged couple.

The Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut has adopted a "new deal program" in shipping laws, on the recommendation of its admiralty committee, and will press for legislation in Washington immediately, it was announced yesterday.

The National Association of Retail Grocers announced today the appointment of L. H. Buisch as director of organization. He formerly was associated with the merchants' service bureau of the National Cash Register Company.

Ancient relics and ceremonial silver valued at more than $2,000 were stolen from the synagogue of Congregation Kahl Abach Jeshurun at 12-16 Eldridge Street, on the lower East Side, on Saturday, according to reports to the police yesterday.

Alexander Hollander, a realty operator with offices in Paramus and Teaneck, died here suddenly today of a heart attack at his home, 6 Park Road. He was born forty-one years ago in New York, and, after graduating from the law school of New York University, practiced law there for several years before moving to Paterson and entering the real estate business.

Until Joe DiMaggio's name was brought into the conversation Colonel Jake Ruppert, owner of the world champion New York Yankees, was at peace with the world and every one in it yesterday. Lou Gehrig had affixed his signature to a $39,000 contract, news from St.

The January death rate of 11.8 per 1,000 population was the lowest ever recorded in the State for the month, Dr. J. V. DePorte, director of the division of vital statistics of the Health Department, reported today.
From Republicans in the House and the Senate today came attacks on what was termed President Roosevelt's attempt to "head off" and "smother" an investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
General "Billy" Mitchell's ghost will walk the halls of Congress again this week when the old "planeversus - ship" controversy gets another airing.

There are too many- people in our midst who say they need no religion, no God, church or synagogue, Rabbi Samuel H. Goldenson said in his sermon yesterday at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

Irwin Goodman of the Central Y. M. C. A. won the metropolitan A. A. U. junior 500-yard free style swimming championship yesterday in the Park Central pool. Goodman defeated Ted Bourie of the Boys Club with Jerry Levine of Park Central third. The time was 6:06.7.

The Angio German conversations that had been attempted as part of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's pacification efforts appear to be indefinitely postponed, if not completely broken off, because of the Nazi advance into Austria.

Under almost balmy conditions as far as the temperature was concerned, but with a southwest breeze that bore puffed weights of March in it, twenty-one sailing dinghies competed today in the regatta at the Larchmoit Yacht Club. Rain fell most of the time.

Now that the third great public treason trial in Russia has ended and only the epilogue-the actual shooting of the eighteen from Nikolai Bukharin down, who were condemned to death this morning-remains to be played, the question which puzzled the outside world after two earlier trials undoubtedly is rising againnamely, "Are the Moscow treason trials faked?"

Austria's tragedy is that no outside power really cared about Austrian independence. Many countries desired a free Austria in their own interest-Czechoslovakia as a first line of self-defense, Britain and France as a brake on German power, the Balkan States as a barrier to German expansion.

Shanghai's Chinese banking circles were thrown into near-panic today and the city's foreign importing and exporting business was virtually paralyzed as a result of the imposition of new foreign-exchange restrictions by the Chinese Government.

Properties in the Washington Heights and West Side areas proved attractive to buyers in deals announced over the week-end. Anthony Estates, Ltd., a syndicate headed by Anthony Morgan, has bought from Sadie Mortgenstern the six-story walk-up apartment house for forty-four families at 2 to 12 Broadway Terrace and 69 Fairview Avenue.

Forty-eight hours after former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's tragic farewell and within seventeen hours of the arrival of the advance guard of the German Army in Vienna, the existence of Austria as an independent State, even formally, was brought to an end last night.

Richard Whitney, indicted head of the firm of Richard Whitney Co., which was suspended from the Stock Exchange last week, will be arraigned in General Sessions Court this morning to plead on an indictment charging grand larceny.
The usual winners, Bud Moxham and Lenny Romagna, scored again in the weekly races of the Manhasset Bay Frostbite dinghy fleet today.
The reality of a personal God as opposed to an impersonal one was upheld by the Very Rev. E. Frank Salmon, dean of Christ Church Cathedral, Ottawa,

An explosion that was heard for several blocks caused serious injuries to one man and wrecked a laboratory of the Allied Recording Products Company on the ninth floor of the Leavitt Building at 126-132 West Forty-sixth Street, between Sixth Avenue and Broadway, at 10:30 o'clock last night.
Tomorrow is the last day for filing Federal income tax returns for 1937. Payment of part or all the tax must also be made tomorrow. The payments may be made in person or through the mall.

Denny Shute of West Newton, Mass., current P. G. A. champion, and his partner, Frank Moore of St. Augustine, Fla., were forced to traverse thirty-eight holes in order to win their first-round match in the annual international four-ball golf tournament at the Miami Country Club today.

As May or of Menands, Dr. John A. Scott also calls himself "father" of this village's 2,500 persons and "president of a business corporation." Dr. Scott thinks of Menands, which he has headed since its incorporation in 1924, both as "one big family" and as a "private corporation."

James Hazen Hyde, American now living in Paris, was elected yesterday to fill an associate's chair in the Academy of Moral and Political Sciences, vacated by the death of Dr. Thomas G. Masaryk, former President of Czechoslovakia. Mr.

As the site for a taxpayer, the block front on the south side of Roosevelt Avenue, between Ninetyfifth Street and Junction Boulevard, Queens, was sold by the Bouvelt Realty Corporation to the Thrift Construction Corporation.

John McNaught, retired newspaper man and writer, died here tonight at the age of 89. Mr. McNaught worked on the old San Jose Mercury, later as editor of the old San Francisco Call, on newspapers in Alaska, and in New York from 1907 to 1912 under the late Joseph Pulitzer on The New York World.
Roger Fawcett defeated Harry Thoens, 25-24, after a tie at 98, to take the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday.

When the President first proposed the undistributed profits tax in a special message to Congress on March 3, 1936, he cited as one of its merits that it would "effect great simplification in tax procedure, in corporate accounting and in the understanding of the whole subject by the citizens of the nation."
Rivers are like railroads-natural monopolies which cannot be broken up and which therefore have to be regulated. A river may be a State line, but it does not otherwise pay attention to boundaries.

The lack of a carefully thoughtout, continuing Federal policy on important issues, such as monetary, tax and agricultural problems, is largely responsible for unsettled business conditions, Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, a partner in Kuhn, Loeb Co., declared in an address last night.

Speeding to a house at 207 Nicholas Avenue, Port Richmond, S. I., yesterday in answer to a telephone call that some one had been killed, Deputy Police Inspector James McGrath, accompanied by several detectives, found Salvatore Pellegrino, 33 years old, a tailor, stabbed to death in the kitchen.

The Shubert Theatre, long one of the two Newark houses to present legitimate stage productions, has been sold by the Prudential Insurance Company to Jules J. Leventhai, New York theatrical producer and playhouse operator, at a price reported today to have been $300,000.

Operations in oats, rye and soy bean futures on the Board of Trade here showed little improvement last week. Oats closed 3/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel higher, the new crop months leading the advance, with the May at 30 1/8, cents and the July and the September at 29 1/4 cents.

MAYBE John L. Sullivan was a great actor, but the crowds turned out to see him strut the boards in "Honest Hearts and Willing Hands" for an entirely different reason. Maybe Whizzer White of the University of Colorado is a great basketball player, too, but certainly among the crowd at Madison Square Garden this evening there will be some spectators only vaguely interested in his basketball.
The First National Bank of Chicago in its statement of condition for March 7 shows total deposits of $857,693,232, compared with $870,994,243 on Dec. 31, 1937.

Cotton prices again drifted lower last week, and at the close had lost between 1/4 and 1/2 cent of the advance of 1 3/4 cents recorded since last Fall. Active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses for the week of 19 to 22 points.

The Polish Falcons of Elizabeth, N. J., who last night tied for the five-man team leadership in the American Bowling Congress, continued their high flying today when two of their members took a one-pin lead in the doubles standings.
The French wholesale price index of all commodities on March 5 stood at 611, compared with 613 on Feb. 26, and 611 on Feb. 19.

The resolution approved by the Fascist Grand Council last night makes evident that Rome has decided to swallow the bitter pill of Chancellor Hitler's Austrian coup with what good graces it can muster.

Carl Liscombe, diminutive Detroit forward, scored three goals in 1 minute 52 seconds to lead the Red Wings to a 5-to-1 National Hockey League victory over Chicago's Black Hawks before 10,031 spectators tonight.
Coal sales of the Ruhr are declining more than can be accounted for by the seasonal influences, and for the first time since the depression some working shifts in the mines there are being passed.

Beginning at 8 o'clock Monday morning, April 4, Eighth Avenue will become a one-way southbound thoroughfare and Ninth Avenue a one-way northbound street for a thirty-day experimental period, Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday.
Nazi leaders in Linz said tonight that the purge of "unfriendly anti-Nazi elements" was in full swing.

A capacity congregation of 2,200 tha persons in the Princeton University chapel heard this afternoon a program of choral works given by the combined choirs of New York, Rutgers and Princeton Universities and Lafayette College.

Mr. and Mrs. Willard Reid of 170 East Ninety-fourth Street have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Virginia Bill Reid, to Austin Cadwallader Hill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Hill of Milton, Mass., which took place Friday night in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Belford in Bronxville, N. Y.
Three of the seeded teams advanced in the fifth annual indoor invitation mixed doubles tennis tournament of the Island Court Club of Long Island City as firstround play was completed yesterday.
The North American Hungarian Democratic Federation was formed here today, with 96 organizations in the United States, representing a membership of 70,000, and 38 Canadian bodies, representing 60,000.
" The Old Man," the full page advertisement by Erwin, Wasey Co., in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 24, continues even at this date to attract nation-wide interest.

Formation of the New Mexico Gas Company to take over all properties formerly owned by the Consumers Natural Gas Company and its subsidiaries was announced yesterday by Ross Byron, president of the Southern Union Gas Company.

Japan, including Taiwan and Chosen, continued in 1937 to be the third largest buyer of American goods and the third largest source of imports into the United States, the Department of Commerce said today in an analysis of our trade with Japan.

The week's stock market opened quiet and irregular, but with prices tending somewhat lower. Thereafter no material change developed until yesterday, which witnessed an exceptionally sharp decline with losses of 2 to 6 points in an active market.

The St. Andrew's Rugby Club of South Orange opened its season with a 14-to-0 victory over the Pilgrims Rugby Football Club of Manhattan in Central Park yesterday. The game was played on a muddy field and rain fell during part of the time.

An exhibition of the art work of "problem children" will open tomorrow at the New School for Social Research, 66- West Twelfth Street, under the joint auspices of the WPA Federal Art Project, the New School, the Public Use of Art Committee and the HawthorneCedar Knolls School, a correctional institution at Hawthorne, N. Y.
Announcement, has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Georgia Saffold Oates to Philip Green Gossler of this city. The ceremony took place Saturday at the home of Charles A. Monroe in Greenwich, Conn.

Curtailed rent and clothing allowances and uncertainty about city relief funds are undermining the morale of relief clients, the New York chapter of the American Association of Social Workers warned yesterday in identical letters to Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guarda.
Decorations and furnishings of the once proud Leviathan will go on the auction block tomorrow. For ten days her panelings and paintings and other trappings will be sold.

Harold O. Voorhis, secretary or New York University, announced yesterday that through a gift from an anonymous donor the university had created four new competitive scholarships as part of a research project in the field of child art.

A modern day nursery and social center, housing the Ninth Street Day Nursery and Orphan Home, was opened yesterday afternoon at 393-95 East Eighth Street. Fully equipped and remodeled to care for 200 children at a cost of $52,000,

Dr. Frances Wood Lee Drew, pioneer woman practitioner of medicine, died yesterday at her home in Quincy at the age of 83. Dr. Drew, a descendant of General Robert E. Lee, maintained offices in Lowell for forty-five of the fifty-five years she practiced.

The decision of cotton and tobacco growers as expressed in referenda yesterday to use marketing quotas this year under the new Farm Act was hailed tonight by Administrator H. R. Tolley of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration as indicating the "overwhelming" support which these farmers will give to the new farm program.
Supply contracts valued at $3,598,371 were awarded in the week ended on March 10 by twelve Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.

Merging the talents of two academy winners, Warners will film "The Career of Sarah Bernhardt" late this Summer, with Bette Davis in the title role and with Norman Reilly Raine, whose script of "Emile Zola" won this year's academy award, preparing the scenario. George Brent will portray Edmund Rostand.

Temples and scriptures may lead away from rather than toward true religion, declared the Rev. John Paul Jones in his sermon yesterday morning at Union Presbyterian Church, Ridge Boulevard and Eightieth Street, Brooklyn.
On the sixth anniversary of his joining the Supreme Court bench, Justice Cardozo, ill since Dec. 13, was reported today to be slowly but steadily gaining ground.

John R. Sutton, for many years a leading wholesale dry goods merchant here, died today at his home at the age of 79. His father founded the firm of R. M. Sutton Co., which the son continued until his retirement a few years ago.
Several Opposition Deputies today asked Premier and Foreign Minister Milan Stoyadinovitch to make a declaration on events in Austria.
Manufacturers, retailers and consumers have been invited to a meeting in Madison Square Garden at 2:30 o'clock on next Monday to open a national cooperative drive for spending at lower prices.

A smoky fire yesterday in the cellar of the Elder Avenue Public Market, 1,202 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, caused the collapse of twelve firemen, three of whom were taken to Morrisania Hospital suffering from the effects of smoke.

Stocks of refined copper in the United States at the end of February, exclusive of those in plants or the warehouses of consumers, amounted to 326,244 tons, compared with 299,133 on Jan. 31, an increase of 27,111 tons, according to the Copper Institute.

A group of American export advertising agency executives and representatives of foreign publishers has drawn up a plan to stabilize rates and procedure in the placing of American advertising in foreign publications.
Many problems were raised by the quention of Ansohluss, union of Austria and Germany.

James Melton, in Hotel Ambassador, Park Ave and 51st St. John Palvo. in 315 W 97th St; Apartment Locating Bureau, broker. Robert Juzek. Mrs. Xenia Ruda, in 404 Riverside Dr; Dr. Aron A. Kaplun, in 46 W 95th St; Potter, Hamilton Co, Inc. broker.

Charles W. (Chuck) Ward, former big league infielder named Rutgers baseball coach to succeed J. Wilder Tasker, met his new charges for the first time today and mapped plans for the Scarlet's eighteen-game season.

Richard Whitney pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday to one indictment for grand larceny of $105,000. He also took the stand to confess before Judge Owen W. Bohan five other instances of "unlawful pledge of securities of customers of my firm."

Business in this country has been saved from the shock of recent developments in Europe through the working of the Tri-Partite Monetary Agreement, the stabilization fund, and the "sterilization" program, Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference this afternoon.
Hundreds of admirers of Clarence Darrow filed by his bier today in a funeral establishment where his body lay in a coffin unadorned by flowers.

The Japanese in Shansi Province have again underestimated Chinese strength and have "bogged down" in an attempt to clear the province of Chinese troops and consolidate their control of North China, General Hsu Pei-ken,

The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to reconsider its Feb. 14 vote by which it rejected a motion to report favorably the proposed Constitutional Amendment of Senator Burke, Democrat of Nebraska, providing equal rights for women.

Pending the presentation of additional evidence by Dr. Albert L. Colston, principal of the Brooklyn Technical High School, concerning an accident that resulted in the loss of a pupil's eye, the public reprimand of the principal and a teacher, ordered by the Board of Education last week, will be withheld.

With little of the fanfare -that marked the debut of its news broadcasts in Arabic, the British Broadcasting Corporation today started flashing news in Spanish and Portuguese to Central and South America.
Gross assets, $3,426; net, $1,584. To eight brothers and sisters or their estates. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $1,901. Harry Herschman, attorney, 457 W. 151st St.
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer yesterday announced a program of fifty-two feature-length productions and the elimination of Class B pictures as its policy for the 1938-39 season, which begins in the Autumn.
Walter, who has conducted the world's greatest orchestras in New York and the capitals of Europe, resigned today as a director of the Vienna Opera.

Setting a new course record for the outgoing journey in the afternoon with a scintillating 29, Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., and Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., continued their victorious march in the annual international four-ball golf tournament at the Miami Country Club today.

The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company reports in its annual statement for 1937, released today, a net profit amounting to $7,841,167 after all charges including taxes, interest on debentures, depreciation and $665,000 provision for surtax.

The total of bankers' acceptance outstanding at the end of February was $307,115,312, according to the monthly survey of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This amount reflected a decrease of $18,689,083 in the month and a fall of $93,992,448 in the preceding year.

William J. Graham and James C. McKay, Reno, Nev., gamblers, who were convicted here recently of mail fraud and conspiracy growing out of the operations of a confidence ring, surrendered yesterday to the United States Marshal to begin prison terms of nine years each imposed upon them by Justice Willis Van Devanter, who presided at their trial.
Three former employes of the big Woolwich arsenal trapped by the blond "Miss X" of the British counterespionage service, today pleaded guilty of smuggling out armaments secrets.

The National Hockey League teams headed into the last week of the schedule tonight, with Gordon Drillon, Toronto Maple Leafs' second-year star, still setting the pace for about 140 marksmen on the scoring records.

The general level of wholesale commodity prices was lower in the week ended on March 12, following advances in the two preceding weeks, as measured by the index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association.
John J. Donnelly, retired fire alarm telegraph dispatcher, died Sunday night at his home, 1,263 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, after a long illness.

Local and Federal authorities openly entered the Levine kidnapping case yesterday following a statement by the father, Murray Levine, that their activity would not preclude the "safety" of any one wishing to negotiate with him for the return of his 12-year-old son, Peter.

Anxious to avoid what the Treasury Department warns may be "severe penalties," the nation's taxpayers struggled late last night with their income tax returns, which must be filed before midnight tonight to come within the law.
President Roosevelt sent to Congress a message on the "alarming" condition of forests and proposing a five-point conservation program.

Rumors of a postponement of King Carol's visit to London because of the Austrian events are unconfirmed. It is pointed out that such a postponement would have to be proposed by Great Britain as Carol has been invited by her.

The Reich government now faces the task of regimenting Austria economically, and it is not clear whether as a whole the new problems created by unification will not prove greater than immediate aid to realizing the autarchy program contained in the German Four-Year Plan.
Chancellor Hitler left Linz this morning and thousands from surrounding towns enthusiastically cheered him on his way.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended on March 9:

The first registered Girl Scout in the United States, Mrs. Samuel C. Lawrence of Huntington, W. Va., is visiting the city in connection with the celebration of the twentysixth anniversary of the movement, it was learned yesterday.

The officials of the 1939 World's Fair were invited yesterday by the board of directors of the Broadway Association to use Broadway for the World's Fair Motorcade planned for April 30 in connection with the preview of the Fair.

The staff of the Austrian Consulate General at 500 Fifth Avenue awaited word yesterday what changes, if any, would be made in the personnel there as a result of the incorporation of Austria in the German State and the rapidly occurring alterations in the diplomatie corps of the country.

By ROBERT FISHEL 64th St, 137-143 W; four 4-story dwellings, 70x100.5: Lucius W. Mayer against Richland Realty Co; due, $78,500; to plaintiff for $38,000. 31st St, 342 E: 5-story tenement. 25x98.9; Arcola Realty Corp against Gertrude M. Brady; due, $11,329: taxes, etc., $1,197; to plaintiff for $500.
The able to hold the Bees in one week-end fireworks faded out in the American Bowling Congress to day. The leaders of the four events remained the same and for the most part remained unchallenged.

Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Hospitals Commissioner, reported to Mayor La Guardia yesterday that he could find no serious criticism against New York Hospital for its handling of the cases of a city fireman and a boy he had rescued from the East River last week.

Sailing for small craft on Long Island Sound and along the coast of Southern New England, New York and New Jersey will become safer with the introduction of a new method of displaying storm-warnning signals, according to E. B. Calvert of the Weather Bureau.

Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson stopped today all proceedings relating to the reorganization plan of the Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company, pending a hearing on a petition for dismissal of the-whole case.

Testimony that a Jersey City official warned drivers for the Garden States Bus Line that the city administration would not tolerate a national union was given here today at the opening of a hearing before Henry J. Kent, special examiner for the National Labor Relations Board.

Charging alienation of her former husband's affections, Nancy Pierson Brooks Macy Brill, well known in New York society, filed suit for $100,000 damages today against her wealthy former mother-in-law, Mary Hunsaker Brill.
Mrs. Grace Maud Billin Morgan, wife of the Rev. Thomas Morgan, pastor of the Second Avenue Congregational Church of Newark, died yesterday of a heart ailment at her home here.
Stocks steady and slightly higher in second-slowest trading of the month; turnover, 427,950 shares.

Galey Lord, Inc., New York commission house and fabric converter; Biberman Brothers, Inc., Philadelphia and New York dress manufacturer; and Lord Taylor, New York department store, have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease and- desist from representing as silk any fabrics not wholly comprised of silk, the commission announced today.
Former Mayor George J. Zimmerman was arraigned before Supreme Court Justice George A. Larkin today following his secret indictment on bribery charges in connection with a $15.000,000 sewer project.
Dan Jarrett, screen writer and former actor-playwright, died last night of a heart attack. Mr. Jarrett was born forty-four years ago in Boston.

A conspiracy to defraud the government of $1,134,000 in alcohol taxes was charged against nineteen persons today by Treasury Department agents here after the arrest of four men and the serving of a warrant on Police Chief J. Hamilton Gebhardt of Vineland, Gloucester County.

Hugh F. Graham, publisher of the Dobbs Ferry Register and Welfare Commissioner of the town of Greenburgh, died last night in the Dobbs Ferry Hospital at the age of 63. He was elected Village Trustee here in 1909, served twelve years and became Welfare Commissioner twenty years ago.

Governor Lehman has decided not to attempt to keep the Legislature in session to force the passage of the Savings Bank Life Insurance Bill. He sent word to the leaders today that he would insist on a vote on the measure in both Houses, but would go no further.

Current Federal, State and city housing programs will provide for few, if any, of the more than 600,000 families of New York City now living in physically substandard dwellings, the Citizens Housing Council reported yesterday.

Mr and Mrs. Frederick G. C. Lyon returned from Havana yesterday on the California and are at the Ambassador before going to their home in Oyster Bay, L. I. Mrs. E. Bruce Merriman of Providence, R. I., will come today to the Madison.

Mrs. Stella Crater, wife of the missing Supreme Court Justice Joseph Force Crater, made no defense against proceedings to evict her from her apartment at 40 Fifth Avenue when the case came up in the First District Municipal Court yesterday morning.

The triumphal entry of Chancellor Adolf Hitler into Vienna was followed by the exchange of telegrams between him and Premier Benito Mussolini, which, although evidently intended to reaffirm the closeness of ItalianGerman relations after the Austrian coup, served merely on the Italian side to emphasize the coldness with which Hitler and Germany now are regarded.

Lewis H. Pounds, former Borough President of Brooklyn, who was re-elected chairman of the Brooklyn Civic Council recently after fifteen years in that office, was guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon attended by members and guests at the Granada Hotel, Brooklyn.

Wearing a gown made in 1840, Miss Laura Margaret Haley, daughter of Dennis Frederick Haley, was married to Frank Howard Storms yesterday afternoon at the home of her father, 29 East Sixty-fourth Street. The Rev. Dr. George P. T.
Importers looked to Washington yesterday for a speedy ruling clearing up the question of the tariff treatment to be accorded by this government to merchandise shipped here from Austria.
The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today the nomination of Dr. Thurman W. Arnold, Yale professor, for assistant attorney general to succeed Robert S. Jackson, now solicitor general.

Over the vigorous objection of Senator Copeland of New York, the Senate today sent to the White House a bill amending the Federal Trade Commission Act to give the commission jurisdiction over the curbing of false advertising of food, drugs, cosmetics and devices, and the power to intervene to protect the consumer against unfair and deceptive acts in commerce.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., revealed in a letter to stockholders mailed yesterday, net income for 1937 of $50,299,623, equivalent, after preferred dividends, to $3.31 a share on the common stock.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow; HOGS Receipts 18,000, including 5,000 directs. Market mostly 10-15c lower than Friday's average; late sales on weights 250 pounds up, 15-25c lower; Top $9.70 sparingly;

Yale University and the city of New Haven will join tomorrow night in celebrating the thirty-fifth anniversary of Dean David Stanley Smith's association with the Yale School of Music by holding a recital of his compositions in Sprague Memorial Hall on the campus.

The union of Germany and Austria has created "the most solid front in the world" and Chancellor Adolf Hitler. awaits only "another convenient moment" to invade Czechoslovakia, William E. Dodd, former Ambassador to Berlin, told a Town Hall audience yesterday.

Former President Herbert Hoover and his party arrived here today from Tallinn after a pleasant crossing of the almost ice-free Gulf of Finland. All municipal and many private buildings were beflagged and a huge crowd gathered at the wharf to cheer Mr. Hoover.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain foreshadowed today a new kind of "national service"-voluntary now, but perhaps compulsory laterwhich would make Britain for the first time since 1918 a nation in arms.
The Beethoven Association dedicated the fifth concert of its season at the Town Hall last night to the memory of Claude Debussy.
Automobile production increased less than seasonably last week, and the adjusted index eased to 55.5 from 56.1. The figure was 98.1 for the week ended March 13, 1937.

Arguments on a review of the arrest and subsequent fining of two members of Jehovah's Witnesses for holding religious services on the beach here. without a city permit will be held by Supreme Court Justice Newton H. Porter on April 4.

Bernard Turkel, retired Kosher caterer and hotel proprietor, died of a heart attack on Sunday at Miami Beach, Fla. His age was 74. His home in this city was at the Kenmore Hall Hotel, 145 East Twenty-third Street.
Count and Countess Ferdinand Colloredo-Mannsfeld of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Countess Eleanora Colloredo-Mannsfeld, to F. W. von Meister, also of New York.

The twelve-family house on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 1,531 Fifty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, was sold by the Brevoort Savings Bank of Brooklyn to an investing client of Murray 0. Handel, broker in the deal.
" The Life and Death of Sir John Falstaff," fourth production by the Princeton University theatre intime this season, opened a six-day run before an audience of 150 in Murray Theatre last night.
The Rocky Mountain region tonight paid tribute to two of its favorite athletic sons, and to the man who first recognized their prowess.
For the British Government and the British people the events of the last few days have brought closer home than ever before a question from which there is no escape in the long run:

Tenture of office for the instructional and non-instructional employes of the four city colleges will come from by-laws to be enacted by the Board of Higher Education rather than from State legislation, according to two resolutions adopted unanimously yesterday by members of the board at a special meeting in the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.
For Mr. and Mrs. James T. Roche, whose wedding was an event of last week, Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. gave a dinner tonight at Casa del Pastor.
For the Brownlow-Gulick-Merriam report on Federal reorganization, which is the basis of the Byrnes bill, on which the Senate will vote tomorrow, these things should in fairness be said:
It is quite unlikely that you will find a gayer show in New York this week than the one made up of oils by Raoul Dufy at the Bignou, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.
Sigmund Freud, The 82-year-old "father of psychoanalysis," does not know yet that his Austrian homeland has been absorbed by Nazi Germany.

Seventy graduating students of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, the largest senior class in the fifty-four year history of that school, yesterday afternoon heard George M. Cohan advise them to take the theatre "very, very seriously if you are going to take it at all."

The report for 1937 of the Phillips Petroleum Company, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income, after all charges and reserves, of $24,113,874, the highest in the company's history.

Al Capone, Chicago gangster, lost a fight today to have the Supreme Court review the validity of a oneyear sentence to be served in the Cook County jail after his ten-year sentence to Alcatraz ends, probably next January.

Liquidation developed in the world grain markets today because of the less warlike reports from Europe, a complete flattening out in the demand from importing countries and more favorable weather for the domestic Winter wheat crop.
More than $169,500,000 was spent during February in all cities of 2,500 population and over in the United States for all types of building construction, according to the March 15 issue of Building.
The Presidium of the Supreme Soviet tonight doomed eighteen confessed treason plotters to firing squad sentences, which it seemed likely had been carried out already.

The United States fleet started its secret war game of 1938 today on a real wartime basis. A grim patrol was established off the harbors of Southern California and the fleet commander-in-chief, Admiral C. C. Bloch, imposed censorship of silence upon all forces. Never before has the fleet operated on this basis in its annual manoeuvres.

The number of business failures in the United States for the week ended March 13 was 269 compared with 242 in the week preceding and 170 in the corresponding week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Former Supreme Court Justice Alfred J. Talley gave a large reception yesterday at the Astor for members of the national committee to aid the Daughters of Mary, Health of the Sick, of which the host is chairman.
Dr. Edwin Howe Fiske confirmed yesterday a report that he had resigned several weeks ago as director of surgery of Kings County Hospital, Brooklyn.

The announcement by the Department of Agriculture of loans from 15 to 22 cents a pound on grease wool will be of little or no value to the fabric market until a decision is made on the problem of duties on raw wool and wool fabrics now pending in connection with the proposed reciprocal trade treaty with the United Kingdom, traders in wool goods said yesterday.

Mrs. Patricia Ryan's testimony that Patrolman Michael Ryan, with whose murder she is charged, was frequently intoxicated and beat her was bolstered in Bronx county Court yesterday when a defense witness, who said he was a friend of the couple, testified that on only two occasions had he seen Patrolman Ryan sober and that he had seen him beat the defendant on her wedding night.

Dr. Cecylja Klaften, known in Poland for her philanthropic and educational work among underprivileged Jews, arrived yesterday on the Batory of the Gdynia America Line. For many years she has been called "the Joan of Arc of the Polish Jews"

Premier Leon Blum and Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour this afternoon jointly received the Czechoslovak Minister, Stephan Osusky, in the Premier's office in the Hotel Matignon so as to give the visit special importance and personally assure the Minister of the fidelity of France to her engagements to his country.

Leave of absence for fifteen days, effective on or about March 26, to terminate not later than April 10, is granted 1st Lieut. Thorstein N. Buttedahl, Cav.-Res. Upon the expiration of leave Lieut. Buttedahl will be relieved from further active duty with the CCC, and will proceed to his home, Excel Riding School, P. O. BOX 782, Overlook Road, Morristown, N. J. He will revert to an inactive status April 10.

The Federal Trade Commission today announced proposed trade practice rules for the wood-cased leadpencil industry and set April 1 at its offices here as the date and place for a hearing at which any protests will be heard by the commission.
A four-weeks series of Saturday afternoon and evening silent film revivals will be offered by the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street, beginning this week.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange here improved early yesterday in sympathy with a sharp recovery in foreign cotton. The initial advance carried the May to 9 cents a pound, but active selling by straddle interests wiped out the gain and left the list 4 to 9 points lower than on Saturday.

The Swedish American liner Drottningholm will arrive today from Gothenburg. Among her passengers are Professor Knut Lundmark, Professor Arvid Lindau, Mrs. Anna Maigren, Miss Ruth Engstrom, Arnold Larson, Mrs. Anna Sumner, Axel Landergren and Gustaf Bergstrom.
The first and second all-league teams were selected at the sixth annual dinner of the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League, which was held at the Hotel Piccadilly last night.

FOR the diversion it afforded, if for no other reason, I had a good time with James Bramwell's "Lost Atlantis,"* a relatively compact. study of the evidence, scientific and otherwise, for the fabulous civilization said to have existed somewhere centuries and centuries ago.

Three seeded pairs advanced to the third round yesterday in the fifth annual invitation mixed doubles tournament at the Island Court Tennis Club, Long Island City. The second seeded team, Mrs. George B. Cabot and Henry Breck,
Mrs. Abbie Robbins Thayer, 29, widow of William N. Thayer, jeweler who died in his eighty-first year, was shot and killed today in the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Robbins.

Professor Paul S. Taylor of the University of California, authority on migratory farm labor, told the Senate Committee on Unemployment today that the problem of handling such families transcended State powers and responsibilities and suggested that interstate cooperation, guided by Federal leadership, was the logical basis for effective action.

President Getulio Vargas's new corporative State is expected to be strengthened domestically and foreign suspicion of it to be allayed through the activities of Oswaldo Aranha, former Ambassador to the United States, who takes office tomorrow as Foreien Minister.

Assailing Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, for his appointment of Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, as' confidential examiner, Senator McNaboe introduced a bill in the upper house tonight which would bar persons known to have radical beliefs from holding public positions, civil service jobs or posiLions, in schools throughout the State.

Pleading non vult to a charge of killing Miss Antoinette Imperiale, 22 years old, last Dec. 26, Vincent Franco, 26, was sentenced here today to life imprisonment by Common Pleas Judge Walter D. Van Riper.

Prepared to spend $2,000,000 in New York within a week's time, a delegation of thirty-three buyers and merchandise managers of Goldblatt Bros., Chicago department store owners, will leave for the East tomorrow;

Miss Ruth Auchincloss and Miss Edith M Sawin gave a tea yesterday afternoon in the Terrace Court of the Waldorf-Astoria for members of the debutante committee who will sell Spring flowers at the fas on show entitled "Paris et Nous," which will be presented in the grand ballroom of the hotel on March 22 for the benefit of the West Side Thrift Shop.

The annual report of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, issued following a meeting of directors today, showed a balance of income account transferred to profit and loss of $9,462,284, an increase of $3,433,100, compared with 1936.

Mrs. Edwin Martin Gibson of this city has announced the engagement of her only daughter, Miss Eleanor Tillard Gibson, to Gerald Foster, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. S. Foster of Stoneleigh Park, Westfield, N. J. The wedding will take place early in the Summer.
Austrian events have been overshadowed here by interest in Bulgaria's general elections. Yesterday's voting -in the Burgas and Plevna districts was attended by not the slightest disorders.

Dr. Henry Lee Hargrove of 461 Riverdale Avenue, Yonkers, a member of the faculty of Hunter College, became ill yesterday while on a New York Central train on his way to lecture at his evening classes and died before the train reached the Grand Central Terminal. His age was 69.

The numerous complaints of salesmen and the solutions for them were outlined yesterday, at a symposium on "Leadership" at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.
The diplomatic relationship between the United States and Austria came formally and undramatically to an end at 6 o'clock tonight.
More than 25,000 persons defied a steady downpour to catch a glimpse of the preview of Spring that the International Flower Show brought to New York yesterday at the Grand Central Palace.

Love ballads and locomotive imitations, shag dancing and recitations of Shakespeare sounded yesterday through the studio microphone at Steinway Hall, 117 West Fifty-seventh Street, where a varied group of contestants vied for the first prize of a trip to Paris offered by Saks-Thirty-fourth Street in connection with its "Springtime in Paris" fashion festival.

The fiftieth annual Brooklyn Food Show and Household Appliance Exposition was officially opened last night in the 245th Coast Artillery Regiment Armory, Sumner and Jefferson Avenues, Brooklyn, by Arthur R. Ebel, Commissioner of Public Works, in the presence of hundreds of visitors.
American helium gas, used in dirigibles, no longer would be available to Germany under a bill introduced today by representative O'Toole of New York.

Three fellowships of $1,500 each and five honorable mentions were announced yesterday by the Bureau of New Plays as it ended its second national play competition for college students and recent graduates.

The first competition in a proposed $70,000 program for the decoration of the United States Government Building at the New York World's Fair was announced today by the Treasury Department's Procurement Division.
Bernard E. Pollack of Josephthal Co. has been elected to active membership in the New York Security Dealers Association.

Ely Ave (17-4885), e s, 521 ft n of 222d St, 50x95; William H. Giegerich, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp. University Ave (11-3214), e s, 275 ft n of 190th St,. 125x100; Gilt Estates, Inc, to Jennie Goldstein, 115 Brightwater Court, Brighton Beach, N. Y.; mtg $130,680.

President Roosevelt, in asking Representative Sam McReynolds to remain in the House as chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, which he thought of leaving to run for the Senate from Tennessee, was motivated only by his value to the Administration's program and not by the knowledge that he would be succeeded as chairman by Representative Sol Bloom of New York, the White House announced today.

The Spanish Government Army is fighting with its back to the wall. Alcaniz, one of two keys to Aragon--the other being Caspe--fell into Insurgent hands today. Government forces are trying, to re-form their lines along the heights behind the city.

The statement read by Richard Whitney in General Sessions yesterday follows: On last Wednesday on March 9, at 1 P. M., I issued a public statement that I stood ready to make full answers to all questions concerning those actions in connection with the failure of my firm which I considered to be wrong and for which I assumed full and sole responsibility.

Following the recent death of Gabriele D'Annunzio, Little, Brown has released the news that for the last two years their safe has held the translation of his biography written by Tom Antongini, for many years confidential secretary to the poet.
Unable to persuade the conservative minority groups to join a Cabinet of National Union that would include Communist as well as other party representatives under Socialist leadership,

The Southern Pacific Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to authorize a loan of $14,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. It is one of the few railroads which owe the RFC nothing.

A protest against the proposed reassessment of Nassau County real estate by the J. M. Cleminshaw Company of Cleveland, appraisal engineers, at a cost of $190,000 was filed with the Board of Supervisors here today by John S. Thorp, chairman of the Democratic County Committee.
Meyer Bloomfield, a leading adviser on social and educational problems and for many years considered an expert in labor matters, was buried yesterday in Mount Pleasant Cemetery in Westchester County.

The necessity for price stability in the waste material field was stressed yesterday by Joseph Schapiro, president of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers, who declared that in the last few years waste dealers have lost markets to other raw materials chiefly because of price fluctuations.

The International Tin Plate Cartel, ineluding representatives of the industry in France, the United Kingdom, Germany, Italy and Norway, decided at a recent meeting at Paris not to change the existing world price levels of tin plate, according to a consular report from Paris made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The Federal Labor Board has presented to seventeen United States and British oil companies an ultimatum demanding that they pay the amount due under the Supreme Court oil wage decision prior to 3:35 P. M. tomorrow.

Despite a sharp Increase in traffic accidents over the past week-end, the weekly figures of the Safety Bureau of the Police Department showed an improvement over those of the corresponding week last year, it was announced yesterday.
Clarence Darrow was the strangest kind of "criminal lawyer" the courts have seen. He loved unpopular cases. In murder cases he took a passionate interest because he loathed capital punishment.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Sunday of Dr. Harry Hall Wilson in the Halifax District Hospital, Daytona Beach, Fla., at the age of 64. Recently he had been living at Holly Hill. Fla.
A labor dispute tied up the loading and unloading of twenty-six seagoing vessels in the harbor here today.

Louis Avalone, 36 years old, of 166 East 119th Street, emissary in the sale of part of the $16,000 in diamond rings obtained by three gunmen last April in the hold-up of a jewelry salesman on a B. M. T. subway train at the Bowery, was sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit for twenty to forty years.

The New York Americans will have a chance to better their hold on second place in the International Group of the National Hockey League when they face the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Estate, less than $5,000. To Jennie Van Nutt, daughter, 229 E. 63d St., residue. Leo Beccarelli, executor, 201 E. 62d St. COHN, EMMA (March 8). Estate, more than $10,000. To Janet Rosenthal, niece, 131 Bartlett Ave., Pittsfield, Mass., onefourth residue and $4,200;

The New York Curb Exchange has removed from unlisted trading Appalachian Electric Power Company first and refunding mortgage gold bonds, 5 per cent series, due on May 1, 1956, and Northern Texas Electric. Company 6 per cent preferred stock, par value $1.

A Congressional investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority appeared probable today as Senator Norris forsook his fight to have the TVA investigated by the Federal Trade Commission and introduced a resolution calling for a Senatorial investigation.
A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers received yesterday the award of a new issue of $2,750,000 of Erie County, N. Y., bonds on its bid of 100.13 for 2.90s.

Three Baltimore Oriole goals within five minutes, scored during the second half of the second period, defeated the New York Rovers in an Eastern Amateur Hockey Loop game, 3 to 2, at the Imperial Arena tonight.

Indications that the membership of the New York Stock Exchange is determined to give the organization an entirely new administration for the coming year developed yesterday at the first open meeting to allow members and firm partners to suggest names for the new board of governors.

The sentencing by Judge Robert T. Erwin in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas of five individuals who pleaded guilty to violations of the Securities Act of 1933 was called to public attention today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The uniformed force of the Fire Department, by a vote of three to one, has signified its approval of the plan to create a community: fund for charitable purposes, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday. A similar move was made recently by members of the Police Department.

The one-family residence at 218 Thirty-fourth Street in the Woodcliff section of North Bergen, N. J., was sold to Peter Leone, who will completely remodel and modernize the structure. Thomas Young Jr.

The forecast is for an expenditure of $38,000,000 by E. I; du Pont de Nemours Co. for 1938, all for additions to present plants for new units with the exception of $1,800,000 for maintenance and repairs, Lammot du Pont, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders in Wilmington yesterday.
Royal Mail, the 1937 winner, regained his position as favorite in the Grand National Steeplechase today as two more American-owned horses were scratched from the March 25 renewal at Aintree.

With the lead changing hands three times in the last forty seconds, Colorado won a hair-raising battle from the New York University basketball team before 12,000 frenzied spectators in Madison Square Garden last night.
The Treasury's regular ninety-one-day bills sold today at an average interest rate of 0.070 per cent compared with 0.073 per cent last week, and its temporary series of "new money"

With the franc a whole point lower with respect to the dollar Premier Leon Blum this morning took over charge of the French treasury. In doing so he declared, with relative optimism, that he did not consider the financial situation the gravest question of the hour.

" Prologue to Glory," which was to have opened this evening at Maxine Elliott's, decided yesterday to let it go until Thursday. More time needed for cutting and trimming, the postponement being the second.
Chicago Surface Lines--Twelve months to Jan. 31: Residue receipts after operating expenses and taxes, $5,090,508, compared with $8,045,772 in twelve months to Jan. 31, 1937, a decrease of $2,955,264.

Adolf Hitler had his triumph in Vienna yesterday afternoon. It was preceded by frenzied demonstrations on the route from Linz and became delirious in the capital. Vast throngs came from all over Austria, Germany and even Czechoslovakia to swell the city's multitude. On insistence of a crowd Hitler made a brief speech, but reserved his main address until today.
Mrs. Virginia Marguerite Hell, wife of Harry Hell, returned to her home at 217 Slocum Way this morning with her 11-day-old daughter Patricia, who is her twenty-fourth child.

Miss Helen McHale, unattached, scored a surprise victory in the New York State A. A. U. high board fancy diving championship last night at the Hotel St. George pool in Brooklyn. She topped a strong field, that included Miss Janice Lifson of the Women's Swimming Association, with 98.89 points.

During the month of February, the total awards in thirty-seven eastern States for building and engineering work totaled $119,038,000, or a decline of 37 per cent from the figure for the same month of last year, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

John H. Kelly, deputy sheriff of Westchester County and until two years ago secretary of the Republican City Committee of Yonkers for twenty years, died yesterday in St. John's Riverside Hospital at the age of 62. Before becoming attached to the Sheriff's office about thirty years ago, he was a deputy charity commissioner of Yonkers.

Led by George Selkirk, the Yankee big guns swung into action against the Reds today as the baseball season officially was opened at Plant Park, and bludgeoned a victory in a knock-down-and-drag-out skirmish, 11 to 9.
Bill McGee, third of four Cardinal pitchers, was the only one able to hold the Bees in check today, as the Red Birds lost an exhibition game, 7 to 5, to Casey Stengel's team.
No tears were shed today when the Chicago Curb Exchange ceased to exist as an organized securities market.

Dean Detton, 220, Salt Lake City, was declared the victor over Chief Thunderbird, 225, Victoria, B. .C., in 18.06 of the main wrestling attraction carded to a finish at the New York Hippodrome last night.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates March 13, unless specified: At Naval Operating Base. Norfolk: Badger, Decatur, Fairfax, Jacob Jones; March 14: New York, Wyoming.

A plea to crush the "communist" element in the Actors Equity Association and to preserve the "stability" and "dignity" of that organization is contained in a letter written by George Arliss and made public here yesterday by Louis Hallett, one of the faction opposed to the current Equity administration.
The Red Cross benefited to the extent of some $75,000 as about 25,000 persons attended. a flood-relief racing program at Santa Anita Park today. The regular Winter season closed Saturday.

James J. Braddock, former world heavyweight champion, turned fireman today and got off with two burned hands. A defective lamp is believed to have started a fire in the Braddock- home at 1,210 Park Avenue here.

" Let us march on to Kovno;" a Senator exclaimed, amid thunderous applause, in today's Senate session when an interpellation was made asking the government for a statement on the recent Lithuanian border incident in. which a Polish sentry was killed by a Lithuanian patrol.

The 7 per cent dollar bonds of the Republic of Austria collapsed yesterday in trading on the New York. Stock Exchange following confirmation of the conquest and formal transfer of that nation into a German State.

WHEN an old Olympic runner writes about the track game, his offering should and does command respectful attention. Veteran athletes say that one of the greatest 800-meter races ever run was the one staged at the Olympic Games of 1904 in St. Louis.

John Theofel, Democratic leader in Queens County from the Fall of 1928 until the Spring of 1934, is in a serious condition in Flushing Hospital from stab wounds in the throat, chest and both wrists, it became known yesterday.

Don Budge, national amateur tennis champion, thinks Mrs. Helen Wills Moody is ready for an attempt to win her eighth Wimbledon championship. But William (Pop) Fuller, the veteran coach who started Mrs. Moody toward seven American and seven Wimbledon championships, says she isn't. Mrs. Moody herself revealed that she was all set for a comeback in Europe.
Guards on the CzechoslovakAustrian border have been considerably strengthened, and not even residents of Czechoslovakia who are Austrian citizens are allowed to return.
Monroe St. 75, 25x100; Independent Order Brith Abraham to Samuel Sukup, 150 Liberty St. 5th St, s s, 275 e of Ave A, 25x92.6: Elizabeth Levine to Emigrant Bank (quitclaim).

Upsets of both major and minor nature marked the second round of the women's singles in the Bermuda tennis championship today, providing thrills for a large gallery as the seeded men players continued triumphant with little resistance.

The rule of the Securities and Exchange Commission on short selling was officially directed to the attention of members of the New York Stock Exchange in the following notice released yesterday by the committee on business conduct of the Exchange:
The Civil Service Commission's semi-annual report on government personnel disclosed today a reduction of 28,362 employes in the executive branch between June 30 and Dec. 31, 1937.

A client of Saul S. Goldman, attorney, has purchased the two-story building at 141 West Fifty-first Street, directly across from the Roxy Theatre, from Mrs. Helen S. Spengler, through the Cross Brown Company.

Home relief allowances were reduced by 10 per cent yesterday by the Board of Estimate after Mayor La Guardia had said the step was necessary because the city had failed to receive additional financial aid for relief from the State. On the basis of the appropriation for March, this would be a reduction of about $979,000 a month.
Following is the text of Home Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare's appeal on air-raid precautions, broadcast tonight to listeners on all British stations:

George F. Byrnes, director for the Federal Housing Administration in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Staten Island, died suddenly early yesterday in Long Island College Hospital. He had been taken to the hospital from his home at 205 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, Saturday morning. His age was 52.
