John R. Burton, president of the National Bank of Far Rockaway, L. I., was elected president of the Ohio Society of New York at its fifty-third annual dinner last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania.- He succeeds Wendell L. Willkie, utility executive, who has completed two terms.

Dr. Kerr Duncan Macmillan, president emeritus of Wells College, Aurora, died yesterday at a sanatorium here after long illness. His age was 67. Dr. Macmillan served as president of Wells College from 1913 to 1936.

William Lemuel Harvey of Minneapolis, president of the International Milling Company, died here yesterday at the age of 66. Born in Pittsfield, Ill., a son of Samuel Clemens Harvey and Julia Chapman Harvey,

Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, flew back to Berlin and to the monetary complexities of Austro-German Anschluss today after having taken the timebut only the time-necessary for hi monthly meeting here with Montagu Norman and other members of the board of the Bank for International Settlements.
By unanimous vote the Assembly tonight passed the Moffat bill under which a $100,000,000 bond issue for low-cost housing will be submitted to the voters at the next election.

Miss Barbara Hope Gatins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin K. Gatins, whose marriage to James F. Curtis Jr. will take place on the afternoon of April 5 at Sherry's, will have Miss Katherine W. Keilson for her maid of honor.

Labor and industry throughout the State were called upon today by the legislative committee which has been investigating discrimination in the employment of the middle-aged to cooperate actively with governmental agencies for a long-term program which would benefit persons over 40 years of age.

Having become more or less resigned to the fact that Clydell Castleman, his convalescing and recalcitrant right-hander, means to conduct his recovery according to his down ideas and therefore must remain out of all calculations for an indefinite period, Colonel Bill Terry today began taking a serious inventory of his 1938 pitching resources.

To take effect 8 A. M. March 16: LIEUTENANTS--John W. Waterhouse, from 48th Precinct to 18th Division, assignment to desk duty discontinued, and James P. McDonnell, from 7th Division to 48th Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued.

The Stock market here was generally dull today and, although few sellers were in evidence, most sections lost ground. Gilt-edge issues fell while among the foreign bonds, Austrian loans were marked down sharply.

Roswell Magill, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, informed the Senate Finance Committee today that the revenue bill passed by the House would not meet the needs of the government. With other tax experts he was closeted with the committee in executive session most of the day explaining the bill.

Plagued by price wars and uncertainty about general business, food distributors are pessimistic about the prospect of any immediate improvement in their sales, the American Institute of Food Distribution reported yesterday.

Robert E. Strawbridge Jr, chairman of the 1938 Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army, announced yesterday that five committees - representing insurance groups had been organized, with the following chairmen:

When the Opera Theatre Co. Inc. Alex E. Reoch, vice president, bought the old Grand Opera House, at the northeast corner of 8th Ave and 23d St, 113 1/2 feet on the avenue and 115.10 on the -street, and facing on 24th St for 200 feet, from Warco Trading Co. Inc.

The Adjutant General released the following orders today: Segrist, Second Lieutenant Charles C., having qualified Is placed on duty. He is to report to the commanding officer, Special Troops, 27th Division, for assignment to 7th Tank Company.
The Rev. Dr. Albert L. Whittaker, rector of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church here, died at his home this afternoon after an illness of several months.

With the exception of a few miscellaneous cuts which were active, trading was slow. Steer cuts were steady to higher, other classes about in line with last week's close. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef and veal to be about steady, lamb steady to weak as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
The annual report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation for 1937, issued for publication today, shows a net income of $13,573,490 after all expenses and charges.
Experiences of four Russian scientists who drifted on an ice floe for more than eight months, after establishing a weather station at the North Pole, are told here by the leader of the expedition.

Steel operations in the United States are scheduled at 32.1 per cent of capacity this week, as compared to 29.9 per cent last week, a gain of 2.2 points, or 7.4 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.

The 1937 annual report of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, which is being forwarded to shareholders today, shows a net income for the year of $20,126,408, compared with: $15,099,291 in 1936,

Contributors to Catholic charities are getting more for a dollar "than you can get any place else in the world," former Governor Alfred E. Smith said yesterday at the luncheon meeting at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria that closed the annual twoday conference on charities called by Cardinal Hayes.
Gains in deposits and in total assets were shown by the First National Bank in its statement of condition as of March 7, issued yesterday in response to the call of the Controller of the Currency.

Montana State and Central Missouri State Teachers, the two top-ranking college teams in the thirty-first national A. A. U. basketball tournament, tacked up triumphs in headline games in another long firstround program today.
Net investment income of the Home Insurance Company in 1937 was $5,451,329, compared with $5,178,642 in 1936. Net premiums were $65,046,622, the largest volume in the company's history.

With the aid of a sparkling run of 67 points, Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia recorded an easy 125-to-46 victory over Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y., for undisputed possession of second place in the world championship pocket billiard tournament at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy last night.

Elizabeth Jackson, Mary Maloney and Phyllis Wiegard have been elected presidents of the senior junior and sophomore classes at Barnard College for next year, the Undergraduate Association announced yesterday.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I present what I believe is the attitude of the insurance business with respect to the controversy over the Livingston-Piper bill?

Secretary of War Harry H. woodring, who arrived tonight aboard a government cutter from Jacksonville, was met at Palm Beach by Mrs. Woodring. They are visiting Mrs. Woodring's parents, former United States Senator and Mrs. Marcus Coolidge, at the Coolidge villa.

Arthur J. Lockwood, former Mayor of Glen Ridge and retired president of Temple Lockwood, a New York steel company, died yesterday at the home of his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Lemassena of 316 Washington Street with whom be lived.

With the payment of Austrian bonds now almost entirely dependent on the good-will of German authorities, Central European issues decreased in value more than [Pound]4,000,000 on the London Stock Exchange today.
In the Supreme of the United States today Chester Bordeau of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

The Camden Safe Deposit and Trust Company and the West Jersey Trust Company, both of this city, will be consolidated to form an institution with about $33,000,000 of deposits and $37,000,000 of resources, it was announced today in a statement issued jointly by Townsend Stites and Ernest L. Bartelt, respective presidents of the two banks.

Civic and shipping interests at a public hearing yesterday morning at the army building, 39 Whitehall Street, urged the army engineers to expand the project for the development of waterway facilities linking the East River with the World Fair's site.

Stewart McDonald, administrator of FHA, and Paul E. Stark, past president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, will make the opening addresses at the real estate conference in Washington, D. C.,
The Oxford eight, training for the annual intervarsity boat race April 2, rowed the full Thames course, Putney to Mortlake, in 20 minutes, 31 seconds, today.

Contending that their industries are being "sold down the river" in the hope of bettering conditions in other parts of the country, Representatives from New England voiced. vigorous protests today against the proposed reciprocal trade treaty with the United Kingdom, Newfoundland, and the British Colonial Empire.

A tract of land for immediate development in Chappaqua, Westchester County, has been purchased by Homecraft Associates, which has erected forty-nine residences in the Mayfair Acres community near White Plains.

A heating on the plan of reorganization for the first mortgage fee 5 3/4 per cent serial gold bonds of the Forty-five East Thirtieth Street Corporation will be held March 25 before Judge John C. Knox at the Federal Court, Foley Square, it was announced yesterday.

A bill intended to attract championship boxing and wrestling matches to New Jersey tonight won its first round in the Legislature, passing the General Assembly by 53 to 0. The measure proposes to reduce from 10 to 5 per cent the State tax on matches when a title is at stake. Assemblyman Frank S.

The Dodger camp was brightened today by something more than the guaranteed florida sunshine, for Leo Durocher came to terms with Brooklyn's executive vice president, Larry MacPhail, and Dolph Camilli agreed to start at once for camp.

Mrs. Brainerd F. Phillipson of this city and Remsenburg, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Charlotte Phillipson, to Harold Gray Hencken, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Hencken of Greenwich, Conn.

More than 2,000 members of the Committee for Industrial Organization and the Workers Alliance invaded the Capitol tonight as Nat M. Minkoff, American Labor party floor leader of the Assembly, read the telegram from Mayor La Guardia and the New York City Board of Estimate, announcing that the board had been "reluctantly compelled" to reduce relief allowances by 10 per cent.

Turpentine firm, 29 1/2c; sales, 134 barrels; receipts, 88 barrels; shipments, 723 barrels; stock, 23,356 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 350; receipts, 488; shipments, 2,141; stock, 62,645. Quote: B, D, E, $4.10; F, G, H, 1, K, M, $5.15; N, $5.45; WG, $6.45; WW, X, $6.70.

President Roosevelt told Congress today that the forestry problem was now "of a character to cause alarm to the people of the United States" and he recommended study by a joint Congressional committee of a five-point program of inquiry with a view to definite remedial legislation in 1939.
The Senate adjourned late tonight for the week and the Assembly until tomorrow night without agreement having been reached on relief financing.

The Interstate Commerce Commission permitted today the railroads to charge approximately the same rates as are charged on the trucksteamship route for shipments of citrus fruits in carloads from points in Florida to New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Boston, with certain reservations.

In the rollcalls on legislation in Albany in the last week the names of Assemblymen Minkoff, Monaco, Muccigrosso and De Matteo, Laborites, and Fitzpatrick, Democrat, were listed as having opposed-the Moffat bill to change the dates of the State fiscal year.

Amidst scenes of the wildest enthusiasm and through dense crowds of hundreds of thousands of jubilant supporters, Chancellor Hitler moved to the summit of his ambitions today when he made his triumphant entry into Vienna, capital of his native country, which so long resisted him and his political philosophy.

Prime Western zinc was available yesterday from one source at 4.25 cents a pound. Other sellers, however, were holding at 4.50 cents pound, but the consensus was that all distributors would be quoting 4.25 cents today.
President Roosevelt's conference on the plight of the nation's railroads will be held tomorrow, the White House announced today.

Under a plan approved unanimously by the Presbytery of New York yesterday, two churches in Manhattan and the Bronx will soon be eliminated, so far as their present functions and place in the organization' of the Presbyterian Church are concerned, and -their congregations combined with those of two neighboring churches.
The annual report of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company for 1937, issued yesterday, shows a net loss of $588,201, compared with a net loss of $447,758 in 1936.

Cornell University is to receive $598,219 from the estate of Daniel J. Tompkins, it was estimated in the transfer tax appraisal on his estate which was filed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn. The gross value of his estate is $699,737 and the net value is $662,130.

An all-Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball team, selected by the sports editors of seven "Ivy College" newspapers, was announced yesterday. Two players from Dartmouth, championship quintet, and one man each from Columbia, Cornell and Penn, were listed on the first team.

William Ormsby-Gore, Secretary of State for. Colonies, today announced another stop-gap quota for Jewish immigration into Palestine, which probably will maintain the flow at about the same reduced level as at present for another six months instead the approximate figure of 8,000 Jews permitted to enter Palestine during the eight months from August through the present month.

Funeral services for the Rev. George Richard Israel, a retired clergyman of the Dutch Reformed Church, will be held here at 10 A. M. Wednesday. Mr. Israel died yesterday in the Meyers Sanatorium at Park Ridge, N. J.
Coleman Avery, 58, former Ohio Supreme Court justice, died today, soon after police said he shot and killed his wife, Sara, and then turned the gun on himself.

The Flower Show, symbol of Spring rejuvenescent, is again with us. Opening its doors yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central Palace, where it fills every nook and corner of four entire floors, it invited the public to its twenty-fifth anniversary Silver Jubilee.

The first major experiment of the Roosevelt Administration was the National Recovery Act, and this was likewise the first complete failure, due to the decision of the Supreme Court invalidating the act in the notable "Schechter case."

In an analysis of the newly-passed Wheeler-Lea bill amending the Federal Trade Commission Act, the National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday warned its members to exercise great care to avoid violations of the amended act through "any misrepresentation or any lack of representation of a material fact" in their advertising.

Board of Trade figures for February, made public today, are as follows: Total imports, pound75,730,000; exports of British products, pound37,520,000; reexports, pound5,320,000; total exports, pound42,840,000; excess of imports, pound32,890,000.
The Frick Collection, I East Seventieth Street, - has acquired its first post-impressionist painting, Paul Cezanne's "Chestnut Trees at Jas de Bouffon," from Wildenstein. Co.

James Fairfax Hamill, 38 years old, attorney and prominent clubman, was found dead last night in his room at the Shelton Hotel, 525 Lexington Avenue. Death apparently was due to a heart attack, the police reported.
The Treasury's outpayments today probably will exceed its receipts, and over the tax-payment period of the next few days a fairly close balance is expected to result.

Under a resolution adopted by the New Jersey Legislature, the Port of New York Authority will conduct a census of New York-bound passengers on several railroads serving New Jersey on Wednesday, March 23, and Thursday, March 24.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: PATENTS 3933-Scott F. Hunt v. Fred A. Kommer and Otto Henning. Dismissed upon motion of appellee and consent of appellant. 3929-Michael H. Ackerman v. Albert T. Light, Argued.

Governor Lehman today signed the Reoux bill which allows marriage annulmen actions to be started when either person to the action is a resident of the State. The new law broadens the procedure which formerly was permitted only to the. resident plaintiff.

The Board of Elections was charged with "carelessness, inefficiency and waste" yesterday by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, in a report to a special meeting of the Board of Estimate.
BROTHER FLO, by George N. Shuster. (Macmillan, $1.50.) An imaginative biography. CONQUEST OF THE PAST, by Prince Hubertus zu Loewenstein.
Dizzy Dean, big right-hand pitching ace of the St. Louis Cardinals, was ordered to bed tonight with a sinus infection, result of a two-weeks cold.

With details of but one project pending involving a proposed grant of less than $50,000, the WPA has helped finance public works costing $7,147,000 in Puerto Rico since September, 1933, according to R. R. C. Hardman, resident WPA representative.

A showing of Easter fashions, entitled "Pandora's Box," will be presented in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's on April 7 during the luncheon hour for the benefit of the Sunnyside Day Nursery. The beneficiary, located at 221 East 104th Street, cares for children of working mothers.

Senator Minton, chairman of the Senate Lobby Committee, said today that his investigators were looking into an alleged campaign "to defeat the objectives of the Administration," and might hold public hearings on the subject when more data were gathered.

North American Aviation, Inc., mailed yesterday to its stockholders a letter calling a special meeting March 29 to approve the segregation of all air transport interests and operations from its manufacturing operations;

Exports of lint cotton from the United States in February amounted to 399,000 bales valued at $2,731,000, compared with 647,000 valued at $34,064,000 in January and 486,000 valued at $33,509,000 in February, 1937, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Mrs. Robert N. Smither gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 155 East Seventy-second Street, for Mrs. William Ottmann in celebration of the latter's birthday. Other guests were Mrs. Julian Wilson, Mrs. Christian W. Feigenspan, Mrs. William Paul Hoffmann, Mrs. Ralph R. Horton, Mrs. Thomas J. O'Neill and Mrs. Arthur N. Davis.

The 1938 P. G. A. championship will be played at the Shawnee Country Club, Shawnee-on-Delaware, Pa., July 10-16, George Jacobus, president of the Professional Golfers' Association, announced yesterday through The Associated Press.

Financial anemia-a deficiency in the flow of new capital-is the ailment from which business in the United States is suffering, Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, says in the current issue of the company's business bulletin.
James Talcott, Inc., has been appointed factor for the following: Charles W. Kessel, distributor of woolens; Charles Lindner, distributor of tie silks and rayons;

Child Study Association, one-day conference and exhibit, "Summertime and the Family," Hotel Pennsylvania, 10 A. M. Speakers: Stanley M. Isaacs, Sidonie M. Gruenberg, Mark McCloskey, Adele S. Mossler, James A. Mulholland, John P. Anderson, Clara Lambert, Fay Mac Cracken Stockwell, Willard L. Nash. Afternoon session, 2 P. M.
A severe break in Austrian Government 7s was the highlight of an otherwise dull and featureless market for bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Closer Chinese Government control of foreign trade was seen here today as one of the results of the new Finance Ministry regulations centralizing sales of foreign exchange at Hankow, headquarters of the Central Bank,

The greatest turnout of skeet shooters in the history of the sport is expected to be seen during National Wildlife Restoration Week, when hundreds of skeet clubs throughout this country, Canada and Panama will feature special shoots.
Yesterday's commercial leasing reports from brokers listed a number of transactions involving space in the mid-town district.

Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University, announced yesterday the names of forty-six students who have received scholarships for the Spring term in the woman's law class conducted at the Washington Square College by the Division of General Education.
Following is the text of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's statement at the opening of the debate in the House of Commons today on the Austro-German situation:

A plea of guilty to theft of 22 cents resulted today in a fine of $525 for Charles Edwards, 50 years old. Police Court Judge Harold C. Smith gave Edwards the alternative of working six months on county roads.

Upon leaving the White House today after a conference with President Roosevelt, Senator Guffey announced that the President had decided to accept the resignation of Charles F. Hosford Jr. as chairman of the National Bituminous Coal Commission.

Adrienne Sauat, 27-year-old Villefranche waitress, today married her second United States sailor within a decade. Today's husband is Michael George Lytpowski, 29, a seaman aboard the U. S. S. Raleigh, now anchored here.

Mike Belloise, 128 1/2, Bronx, outpointed Julio Gonzales, 132 1/4, Puerto Rico, in the feature eightround bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night before a crowd of 2,000 persons. Gonzales substituted for Ray Ingram, who was ill.

Resuming debate on the Government Reorganization Bill, the Senate today approved all committee amendments to the measure, added a few more sponsored by the bill's author, Senator Byrnes, and then set 2 P. M. tomorrow for a vote on the civil service amendment of Senator Walsh.

The sanguine hopes that liberalization of the mortgage insurance policies of the Federal Housing Administration would give a fillip to small home building and buying appear to be on the road to realization.

For the second year in succession Harry F. Wolf and Phil Moore, both members of the Montclair A. C., will play for the national squash tennis title in the final that is set for tomorrow at the Crescent Athletic Club's courts.

Charging that the Crucible Steel Company was conducting a "systematic series of lockouts to cripple the union," 2,050 workers declared themselves on strike today at the company's Jersey City and Harrison plants.
The Mengel Company and subsidiaries report bookings and billings for February and two months, together with unfilled orders on Feb. 28, as follows:

A provision placing wool felt hat bodies back in the tariff classification which provides for a tariff of 40 cents a pound and 75 per cent ad valorem is included in the customs administrative bill now before the Senate, according to a bulletin sent its members yesterday by the National. Council of American Importers Traders, Inc.

Rejected children-those who are unwanted by one or both parentsmay develop strong tendencies to lie, steal, play truant and run away from home, even if parents mask their antagonism with affection, according to a study of "Parental Acceptance and Rejection,"
A world-wide flight of capital to seek refuge in the safety of the dollar swept over the foreign exchange market yesterday in response to the fear of war evoked by Germany's seizure of Austria.

Tomorrow's village election here was thrown into confusion tonight when word arrived from Albany that the Court of Appeals, by unanimous vote, had reversed decisions by the Appellate Division and Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman on striking the names of the candidates of one party off the ballot.
The Nazification of Austria continued swiftly today under her new German masters after a day of orders and decrees aimed at nonNazi elements.

The Census Bureau reported today cotton consumed during February totaled 427,528 bales of lint and 47,888 of linters, compared with 434,740 and 44,892 during January this year, and 665,677 and 63,674 during February last year.
Discussions about a contract are still going on between the League of New York Theatres and the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union. At 2 P. M.
City College will take part in eighteen varsity baseball games, according to the 1938 schedule announced yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manage of atheletics.

By HENRY G. WALTEMADE Tremont Ave. 505-507 E, 3-story office and store building. 35.9x86.11 irreg; New York Dock Trade Facilities Corp. against Van Dyk Realty and Improvement Corp; due, $28.438: taxes, etc., $36; subject to mtg of $40,000; to plaintiff for $61,000.

" Shop Worn Angel," originally scheduled for Joan Crawford and from which she asked to be excused, is to reach the cameras at Metro with Rosalind Russell and James Stewart in the leading roles. Julien Duvivier will direct and will be aided by Maurice Maurice, the. studio's latest French importation.

President Roosevelt has accepted an invitation to participate in the observance of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the battle of Gettysburg at Gettysburg, Pa., early in July. The celebration will be held the first three days in July and the President has yet to determine which day he will be present.

The disappearance of Austria as an independent sovereign State and complete assumption of authority by the German Reich confront the new Germanic Empire with several vexatious problems affecting international diplomatic relations.

Mrs. G. H. Emick's Rollin Home, a gelding that began the Winter as a plater and now is one of the outstanding sprinters, today brought grief to dazed form players. The son of High Time, winner of five of seven previous Florida starts, was installed odds-on favorite in the featured Fort Myers Purse and finished a laboring third in a field of five.
Forty-six Princeton football players reported for Spring practice and worked ninety minutes today. Six lettermen were among the candidates who drilled under Head Coach Tad Wieman's new staff.
General Fedor von Bock, newly appointed commander of German troops in Austria, is the son of an army general and a one-time lieutenant in former Kaiser Wilhelm's crack footguards regiment.

Secretary of State Hull and Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, were charged on the floor of the House today with uttering false official statements on the question of whether an alliance or understanding of some sort exists between the United States and Great Britain.
The first contingents of Austrian soldiers to fraternize with Chancellor Hitler's troops on the "German" side of the Austro-German border arrived today at Munich and Lindau.
Baron Karl von Werkmann, Emperor Charles's last secretary and a prominent leader of the now liquidated monarchist movement, was reported today to be dying of bullet wounds.

Holding eleven men without bail for Special Sessions on charges of taking bets, Magistrate Folwell in Pennsylvania Avenue Court, Brooklyn, yesterday praised the action of the Court of Appeals in confirming the conviction of a Brooklyn
Texas independence, won by Sam Houston 102 years ago at San. Jacinto, is commemorated by a battlefield monument now

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday upheld an order of the National Labor Relations Board invalidating the agreement between the Consolidated Edison Company and its affiliates and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

Damage to Dr. Edward H. Barsky's emergency hospital unit on the Aragon front now appears to have been less than it was believed yesterday. Dr. Barsky, who arrived here this morning, told this correspondent of four harrowing days during the Insurgents' advance, culminating in the bombings.

The pamphlet report of the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston for 1937, issued yesterday, showed a net income after all expenses and charges, of $5,381,879, equivalent to $8.72 a share on the outstanding capital stock.
Large tracts of land along the banks of the San Juan del Norte River are being planted in bananas because of the appearance of the "sigatoka" leaf-spot disease in other banana producing sections.

A custom-made sedan owned by Major Edward Bowes, theatre and radio impresario, and bearing Maryland license plates, was found abandoned at 7 A. M. yesterday in front of 733 East Tenth Street, Brooklyn, by Patrolman Charles Johnston.

From Friday afternoon, following a noonday hold-up at the Mattituck (L. I.) National Bank and Trust Company, two State troopers and three New York City detectives maintained a tiresome watch in a furnished room at 39 West Seventyfourth Street.

Fast Day, devoted by the New England Puritans to fasting, humiliation and prayer, lost in time its religious character. Massachusetts abolished it and made April 19 Patriots' Day. Only in New Hampshire does it survive. Thursday, for more than a generation the fourth Thursday of April,

Funeral services were held here today for Fire Captain John Davenport, who was killed with four other fireman when the wall of the warehouse of the Quackenbush Co. department store collapsed upon them.

Accused of pushing Mrs. John Cuccia, 27 years old, from a window of his fourth-floor apartment at 33 West Forty-fourth Street, Peyton Murray, 30 years old, a Harvard graduate now in the advertising business, was held in bail of $5,000 in Felony Court yesterday on a charge of felonious assault. Magistrate Rothenberg ordered a hearing on March 22.

The CzechoslovaK mouse of Deputies was thrown into turmoil today by a demand by Karl Hermann Franck, vice president of the Sudeten German party, that the nation accede to German demands regarding its German minority of 3,500,000 or face the consequences.

Every so often we find an angler going to a lot of work to find out just what kind of fishing he likes best. What he is doing, really, is trying to decide which fish supplies him with the most sport and is "pound for pound" the best fighter.
The Republican State Committee refused today to call upon the Assembly to abandon its investigation of alleged ballot-box frauds in Hudson County.

Point-by-point discussion of the contract submitted by the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union to the League of New York Theatres will probably be concluded today, it was said yesterday afternoon at the conclusion of a meeting between union officials and the league's labor committee.
Chairman William Woodward of the Jockey Club threw his support today behind a bill designed to legalize dog racing in Nassau, Westchester, Erie and Monroe Counties as a one-year test.
A new world's record featured the opening match today in the annual national midwinter pistol championships at the Tampa police pistol range.

Rosedale Ave, 1,225; 25X99.9; Home Owners Loan Corp against Angelina Oliveto; due, $12,866; to plaintiff for $1,600. Tinton Ave, 1,132; 2-story dwelling, 20x134 irreg; Home Owners Loan Corp against Meyer Kopfstein; due, $9,851; to plaintiff for $500.

GENTON, CECILE RUSCH (Feb, 22). Estate, more than $10,000. To Henry Iselin, nephew, executor, Hewlett Harbor, L. I., joint interest in a trust of $60,000, also one-eighth -residue outright; Cecile Iselin Feer, niece, 4, Wulfingerstrasse, Winterthur, Switzerland, Adolphe Rusch Jr., Garden Rd., Red Bank, N. J., and William Iselin, 40 Orchard Dr., Greenwich, Conn., nephews, one-eighth residue each;

Held hitless for three innings, Cincinnati combined four singles, an out and a walk for two runs in the ninth today to defeat the Bees, 4-3. The Reds found Jim Turner and to Frank Gabler and Rookie John th, Niggeling for eleven hits. Johnny Vander Meer, Joe Cascarella and Joe Vitelli held Manager Bill McKechnie's former charges to six, three of which in the seventh were good for the Bees' three tallies.

Plans for closer relationship among tobacco distributors in the various trading-areas of the country are being developed by Joseph Kolodny, executive secretary of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors, Inc. Starting in Los Angeles at the end of this month, Mr. Kolodny will hold sectional meetings in

Testimony of an Armonk elope- wrecks ment, a pinochle game, a vanished husband and a wealthy mother in Monte Carlo led to the acquittal in Special Sessions yesterday of Mrs. Ghistaine Godfrey, 20 years old, accaused of stealing a chiffon dress last September at the Hotel Lombardy.

A joint Congressional investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority, instead of a single inquiry by committees of the House or Senate, seemed to be likely today as Senators began wrangling over who among them should participate.

In a match that lasted almost two hours Mr. and Mrs. William B. Weaver upset the seventh-ranked pair, Mrs. Amos R. E. Pinchot and Sewell Cutler, 4-6, 6-4, 9-7, to gain the third round of the fifth annual invitation mixed doubles' tennis tourney at the Island Court Club of Long Island City last night.

Forty freshmen, candidates for next Fall's Harvard varsity football eleven, reported to Coach. Richard C. Harlow and his assistants today for initial practice in the Briggs cage at Soldiers Field. No list of aspirants was issued, but practically all of last year's freshman squad was on hand.

John Wade, president of the Hudson County (N. J.) Checker Club for the last ten years, died last night at his home, 1,308 Hudson Street, Hoboken. Mr. Wade was born fifty-six years ago in Carbondale, Pa. He had been in the garage business for twenty-seven years. A brother, Leon Wade,

Two significant contributions have just been made to the discussion of inter-American relations. Just a week ago the envoys of Colombia and Santo Domingo delivered, through the office of the Pan American Union, to the United States and the Latin American Republics, the text of a proposal for an American league of nations.

Mrs. Mary Frances Barringer Rump, treasurer of Henry Rump Son, Ing, wholesale produce merchants, died on Monday night at the French Hospital at the age of 49. Mrs. Rump, a native of New York, lived at 378 Central Park West. Surviving are her husband,

Richard R. Hough, '39, of Trenton, N. J., Nassau -breast-stroke champion, has been elected captain of the 1938-39 Princeton swimming team to succeed James R. Simpson, '38, of Elizabeth, N. J., it was announced today by Coach Howie Stepp.

When Lena D. Wolff sold to Sophie Goldstein the parcel at 61 2d Ave for a consideration shown as $22,000 she took back a purchase money mortgage for $17,000, due ten years hence at 3 1/2 per cent for the first five years and four for the last five, $100, to be paid off quarterly beginning June 1, 1940. and Sophie Goldstein then conveyed the house to Philip Blechman of 84 2d Ave.

Oxford, in training for the boat race with Cambridge April 2, broke a 25-yearold practice record on the Thames tideway today, rowing from Putney Bridge to Chiswick Steps, a distance of slightly more than two miles, in 11 minutes 31 seconds.

Raymond Paul, 21-year-old boxer, was held without bail today in the death of Herman Gowdy, whom Paul knocked out in a boxing show last Friday. Gowdy, young Negro fighter, died last night of a skull fracture.

The Earl of Perth, the British Ambassador, again called on Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, this afternoon and they conferred for nearly and hour. There is reason to believe formal negotiations have begun and that the general problem of Anglo-Italian relations was discussed.

President Butler may be on vacation but he is still looking out for the world at large. The release to the news of his report as president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace had a timeliness that accentuated his observations concerning the state of the earth.
The House Merchant Marine Committee unanimously recommended today the subsidizing of a fast merchant fleet in the intercoastal trade, and revival of shipbuilding on the West Coast.
After a 200-mile drive across the jungle-covered mountain upland of the plateau of Upper Burma we reached one of Asia's deepest and least explored valleys, that of the Salween River.

Lorne Carr's two goals gave the New York Americans victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The obstinate Hawks fought the New Yorkers bitterly to the final whistle, but the best they could do was make one tally and they had to accept defeat, 2 to 1.

Birge, 2 Huntington Place. Norwich, on Thursday, March 17, at 3:30 P. M. BLANK-Harry, beloved husband of Jennie, dear father of Sidney, and Helen. Funeral Thursday at 2 P. M., Scheuer Chapel, 154th St. and Amsterdam Ave.
