A tornado struck this city and other communities in Southwestern Illinois and Northeastern Missouri this afternoon, killing sixteen persons, injuring more than 100, some probably fatally, and destroying buildings and other property.

After a protracted lull the Tientsin-Pukow Railway sector once more became a center for military activities when Japanese columns, advancing southward, were reported to have defeated Chinese forces at three points south of Yenchow in Southern Shantung.

Negotiations carried on over a long period have finally culminated in the sale of the old Grand Opera House, on the northwest corner of Twenty-third Street and Eighth Avenue, to the Opera Theatre Company, Inc., a subsidiary of the R.-K.-O. Theatres Corporation, by the Warco Trading Corporation,

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman denied yesterday a temporary injunction sought by four members of Local 791 of the International Longshoremen's Association to restrain Joseph P. Ryan, president of the international, and the officers of Local 791 from collecting dues or making contracts for the local.

Pimlico's handicapper, Charles McLennan, faced with the task of rating the two top horses of last year, ranked War Admiral over Seabiscuit today and thereby increased doubt the former would run in the $20,000 added Dixie Handicap. McLennan's weights gave War Admiral the top impost of 132 pounds and Seabiscuit 130.

The People's party, which was backed in the local elections in Lindenhurst tonight by the Republicans, put its candidates in the three trusteeships contested, defeating the Progressive-Liberty party slate, which was supported by the Democrats in the village. Trustee John Blankenhorn. retrained his place with 985 votes. John Whalen and Edward Schneider, his running mates, got 945 and 884 votes, respectively.

Andrew Ponzi; grimly protecting his unblemished record, scored his eighth straight victory last night at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy and moved a step closer to the world's pocket billiard championship.

Hundreds of friends of Clarence Darrow crowded into the chapel on the University of Chicago quadrangle today for a last glimpse of his face and to listen to a memorial address by Judge William H. Holly.

Colonel Jacob Kuppert, owner of the Yankees, cast an appraising eye over his expensive baseball machine today and expressed himself as highly satisfied with the dividends from his investment in baseball's ivory marts. The Yankee owner saw "Two Gun" Lou Gehrig, as pale a cowboy as could be uncovered anywhere, in his first workout.

Dr. Duncan MacCalman, former superintendent of the Maryland General Hospital and for years active in the Masonic order, died yesterday at the age of 73. A native of scotland, he came to this country when a young man.

Fourteen of the Greyhound operating companies asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to borrow $4,152,000 with which to buy 346 new coaches built by the Yellow Truck and Coach Manufacturing Company.

The Actors Equity Association's council unanimously approved a statement yesterday denying that it was controlled by any "subversive group" in the union and expressing confidence in Burgess Meredith, acting president, and Philip Loeb and George Heller, councilors.

Expanding the budget and giving the film a scope which was not anticipated when the story was bought, RKO announced today that they had assigned Richard Dix to the lead in "Ground Crew" and would make it one of their more impressive offerings.

Nearly forty agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, almost all of them from divisional offices outside the metropolitan area, paired off with local patrolmen here today in the most intensive search this community has ever known.

President Roosevelt will remain neutral in the factional contest over the nomination of a Democratic candidate for Governor in Pennsylvania, although the outcome of the May 17 primary may give control of the State's 1940 national convention to the group headed by Senator Guffey and John L. Lewis, head of the Committee for Industrial Organization.
This country has the most lawless group of young men and women to be found in any civilized land in the world, Dr. Jay B. Nash, Professor of Education, New York University, charged yesterday.

The city of Detroit, through John N. Daley, controller, will receive until March 30 tenders of its callable refunding bonds in the amount of approximately $419,000. Only the 1962 and 1963 maturities will be accepted. Tenders will be accepted on the basis of the highest net yield to the city as computed from the dollar price.

The board of directors of the Schenley Distillers Corporation voted yesterday to declare a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, payable on March 31 to holders of record of March 25. Last year the company paid' four dividends of 75 cents each on the common.

The one-story garage at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and 137th Street has been leased by the estate of H. A. Cram, Inc., to Harry Liebowitz and Morris Kaufman for two years. Butler Baldwin acted as broker.
Steel ingot output increased last week, when a minor seasonal decline was usual, and the adjusted index advanced to 40.7 from 39.3. The figure was 118.1 for the week ended March 13, 1937.

On behalf of Colonel William E. Butler, trustee for certificate holders, the Morris Realty Service Corporation has leased the property formerly known as the Castle Beach Club. on the Boardwalk, and the Plaza, Atlantic Beach, L. I., to Simon Schack and associates. The lessees will remodel the club and reopen it as the El Mirador. A board of governors is being selected to pass on membership.

Charles Edmunds Kimball,. 47, or Riversville Road, trust officer of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, who died on Feb. 3, left-real estate valued at $10,000 and personal property exceeding $25,000, according to the will admitted to probate today. The widow,

The present foreign policy of the United States-a continental nation separated by thousands of ocean miles from armed or embattled peoples of Europe and Asia-may be described in two ways. It is a nucleus of realism in a huge circle of idealism that shrinks and widens with events.

Entry blanks have been sent to owners and trainers for the nine stake events that will be run at the Summer meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club at Aqueduct from June 6 to 29. The races are topped by the Brooklyn Handicap at a mile and a furlong, with $20,000 added, set for decision June 25.

Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Corporation, a unit of Union Carbine and Carbon Corporation, has acquired nearly 200 acres at Texas City for construction of a chemical plant, a representative of the concern said here today. The first unit of the plant is expected to cost about $4,000,000.

A police alarm was sent out yesterday for a man described as Lawrence L. Devine, a 44-year-old butler employed in the home of Harry C. McClarity, vice president, manager and director of the Union Stevedoring Company, after he dis-. appeared on the same day that $19,500 in jewelry and cash vanished from the McClarity apartment. at 110 Riverside Drive, at Eighty-third Street. The police said he was wanted for questioning.
Sixty-five candidates for the Rutgers varsity football team ported to Coach Harvey Harman today in the Rutgers gymnasium and heard the new mentor of the Scarlet outline plans for Spring practice.
The swastika flag of Nazi Germany flew today over the Austrian Legation here. In announcing that Germany had taken over the Austrian Legation,

Pete Scalzo, 125 1/2, West Side, fought his way to his thirty-seventh straight triumph last night when he outpointed Nat Litfin, 125 3/4, Bronx, in the feature eight-round contest on the card at the New York Coliseum. A crowd of 11,000 persons, one of the largest of the season, saw Scalzo win from a willing and aggressive battler.

The New York Shipbuilding Company will lay off 2,500 employes at Its plant here between now and July, it was learned today. Completion of the United States cruisers Savannah and Phoenix will force a reduction in personnel from 4,800 to 2,200, according to Roy Campbell, general manager of the yards.
Miss Elizabeth Sabine, sophomore, of Chevy Chase, Md. was elected president of the Smith College Athletic Association, announced at the annual exercises tonight. Other officers included:

One of the larger events of the early Fall should be this: A musical version of S. N. Behrman's "Serena Blandish," with half the music said to be the work of the late George Gershwin and the rest by Vernon Duke, with a cast of Negroes, including Ethel Waters and Buck and Bubbles.

HENRY WILLIAMSON is one of the best, possibly the best, of modern writers on natural history. Until the other day I supposed that he was simply a mild and gifted young Englishman who lived. quietly with his wife and four children in rural Devonshire and' worked on stories' like "Tarka the Otter" and "Salar the Salmon."

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, New York City, a registered holding company, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for approval of the payment of dividends for 1938 on its 5 per cent and 6 per cent preferred stocks, 5 per cent preference stock and common stock out of its surplus account as designated on Dec. 31, 1937.

The plan of the Federal Maritime Commission to train young Americans as cadets and cadet officers on commercial ships with a view to their future careers as ships' officers was attacked yesterday by the United Licensed Officers Association, an A. F. of L. affiliate.
Mrs. M. Elizabeth Carden Ingersoll has established residence here and announced in a letter to a newspaper that she would seek a divorce from Ralph McAllister Ingersoll.

Turpentine steady, 29 1/2c; no sales; receipts, 94 barrels; shipments, 135 barrels; stock, 23,315 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 73; receipts, 1,032; shipments, 1,637; stock, 62,040. Quote: B, $4: D, $4.05: E, $4.10: F, $5; G, $5.05: H, $5.05; I, $5.05; K. $5.10; M, $5.10; N, $5.30; WG, $6.25; WW, $6.50; X, $6.50.

Half the 16,045 women employed in beauty shops in New York State earn less than $17 a week, including tips, according to a survey of the industry taken by the State Labor Department and made public yesterday.

Hayden, Stone Co., investment bankers; the estate of Charles S. Hayden and four other defendants in a suit brought by minority stockholders of the Crocker-Wheeler Electric Manufacturing Company have offered to return $345,000 to the corporation in settlement of the action.
Thousands of men and women enrolled all over Great Britain today in response to Home Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare's appeal last night for 1,000,000 antiair raid volunteers.
Dugal G. Campbell, Brooklyn Ford dealer, has been elected president of the Brooklyn and Long Island Automobile Dealers Association.

Premier Hendryk Colijn, broadcasting tonight, informed the nation of the government's grave concern with the European situation. Referring to yesterday's speech of British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain,

Oswaldo Aranha, former Ambassador to the United States, became Brazil's Foreign Minister this morning, an event that brought more than 12,000 congratulatory messages from Brazilians and several.hundred from abroad.
More than 2,000 Americans who left their homes to fight with-the Loyalists in Spain appear to be in danger in the drive of the Rebels to the sea, between Barcelona and Valencia.

Mendelssohn's overture to "A Midsummer Night's Dream" opened the concert of the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, Antonia Brico conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. The composition has been too long absent from our local programs.

Pennsylvania's Liquor Control Board, waging a drive against one-man clubs and places which sell beer as a sideline, estimated today that it would weed out nearly 2,000 taprooms by June 1, when it takes over beer licensing.
Avowing his belief in the necessity of political parties, Langdon W. Post was publicly received last night as a member of the American Labor party in a ceremony broadcast from radio station WEVD.
The La Guardia administration's bill for municipal bus operation reappeared in the Legislature today, this time amended so drastically that it is believed to have a good chance of passage.

Furnishings of the residence of the late Henry T. Sloane, 18 East Sixty-eighth Street, were sold on the premises yesterday afternoon under, the management of the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., for a total of $13.374.

There was little evidence of a business recession yesterday at the four New York offices of the Bureau of Internal Revenue as thousands of persons filed Federal income-tax returns before the midnight deadline, and as thousands of letters bearing cash, checks and stamps piled up in the offices of the collectors.

While discussing with alarm 'three daring hold-ups in Flatbush in the last ten days, members of the Flatbush Chamber of 'Commerce, meeting at the chamber's headquarters, 885 Flatbush Avenue, were startled last night by a fourth hold-up, directly across the street.
The Manhattan Chess Club held a 7-6 lead over the champion team of the Marshall Club yesterday after four of the adjourned games of their Metropolitan Chess League match were completed.

Dizzy Dean, the St. Louis T Cardinals' ace right-hander, remained confined to his hotel room tonight under physicians' orders to remain there for "at least two cha: days" until a sinus infection clears. Club officials said his condition was not serious, but they were taking no chances and would not permit. the hurler to resume training camp workouts until all danger was passed.
Mrs. Dorothy Douglas Low Wiechers of New York obtained a divorce today from Manolo Wiechers and immediately afterward married Peter F. Crossman, 47, of Palm Beach and New York City.

The National Retail Credit Association today blamed a "general decrease in employment throughout the country" for a decline in collections, credit sales and total sales in averaging reports from retail stores in forty-two cities.

Stuart A. Rice, chairman of the Central Statistical Board, told the Senate Committee on Unemployment today that he could see no great likelihood "that governmental budgets for relief and welfare, regardless of political and administrative changes, will again approach their pre-depression level."

Senator Royal S. Copeland, in an address last night to 1,500 shipping men at the Hotel Astor, attacked the efforts of the American railroads to obtain a competitive advantage over intercoastal and coastwise ship lines through the Pettengill bill as a threat to the commerce of the Port of New York.

The $314,000 Kips Bay-Yorkville Health and Teaching Center at 411 East Sixty-ninth Street will be dedicated today at 4 P. M. Speakers will be Mayor La Guardia, Edmund Ezra Day, president of Cornell University, and Dr. Livingston Farrand, president emeritus of Cornell. Health Commissioner John L. Rice will preside.

Jackie (Kid) Berg of England defeated Vincent Pimpinella of South Brooklyn in the feature event of ten rounds at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night before a sell-out crowd of 4,600 fans. Berg weighed 145, his rival 148.

The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation, in documents filed in the Monroe County Court House, disclosed today the purchase of two natural gas companies and one manufacturing gas concern in the suburban area, giving it a virtual monopoly of the business in the county. The purchase price of the franchises and physical properties was given as $104,001.

The Automotive Daily News estimated today that 175,000 used cars valued at about $50,000,000 were sold during "National Used-Car Exchange Week," which ended Saturday. The figures were based on a cross-check of manufacturers, dealers, and dealer associations.
New England spokesmen testifying today at a hearing on the proposed British trade treaty, characterized the reciprocal trade policy as one which involved 'robbing Peter to pay Paul."

President Roosevelt discussed railroad problems with representatives of railway management and labor and several government officials, and Philippine questions with Paul V. McNutt, High Commissioner to the islands.

Plans for new buildings filed in the Bronx for the first two months this year totaled $870,040 more than those filed during the corresponding period of last year, it was pointed out yesterday by Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx Board of Trade.

Governor Lehman, irked by the evidence that his intention not to keep the Legislature in session to pass the Savings Bank Life Insurance Bill had been interpreted as a weakening on his part toward the measure, cracked the whip again today and
Midafternoon today found the bulk of the United States Fleet under way from its San Pedro and San Diego bases for six weeks of mid-Pacific war manoeuvres.

The Association of Exciusive Specialty Shops, Inc., comprising eighty-eight specialty shops in New York, meeting last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, adopted a resolution approving the decision of the Fashion Originators Guild of America to eliminate supplementary Spring showings and to open showings of Summer lines during the week of March 21.

Although Temple University will be favored in its contest with Colorado University in the final game of the first annual national invitation college basketball tournament, which will be played tonight at Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association, the Rocky Mountain team will not lack for supporters.

Phil Spitalny's All-Girl Orchestra was announced yesterday as the winner of the achievement award of the radio committee of the Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries, for the most dis-. tinguished work of women in radio during the last year.
Mrs. E. Haughton's Grey Simon easily won the feature today for 3-year-olds and upward over five other claimers at one mile and a sixteenth at the Fair Grounds.

James Haddick, 17, dashed back into his burning home here today and died in a vain attempt to rescue his two brothers, William, 6, and Buck, 4. Members of the family tried to stop James when he heard screams of the younger boys.

Adolf Hitler has left behind him in Austria an anti-Semitism that is blossoming far more rapidly than ever it did in Germany. This afternoon the Jewish quarter of Leopoldstadt was invaded by triumphant crowds that called families from their houses and forced them to kneel and try to scrub from the pavements slogans such as "Heil Schuschnigg," which were part of the former Chancellor's plebiscite campaign.

Exotic blooms that grow in or near water, including many varieties of native plantings that will add beauty to homes in country or skyscraper -apartments, attracted the attention of many of the 30,000 visitors at the twenty-fifth annual Flower Show in Grand Central Palace yesterday. The exhibit, one of the most unusual in the show's history, was prepared entirely by women.

Several changes have been made in the personnel of the Cambridge rugby team, which will leave for New York from Southampton, England, today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary for a fivegame tour of the United States. The tour will start next Wednesday against Yale at New Haven.

Dr. Alfred C. Fones, a pioneer in dental hygiene in public schools, died suddenly of a heart attack tonight in a local theatre. He was 68. Dr. Fones won the Newell Sill Jenkins Memorial Medal of the Connecticut Dental Association in 1922 and the William Jarvie Fellowship Medal of the New York State Dental Society in 1926.

The Rev. Josiah Otis Ward, a retired minister of the Protestant Episcopal Church, died Monday in Bellevue Hospital of injuries received on Feb. 24 when he was struck by an automobile in Newark, N. J. Mr. Ward, who was 70 years old, had been living in recent years at the Home for Old Men and Aged Couples, 1,060 Amsterdam Avenue.

With stars from Europe and America appearing in solo and group numbers, the Skating Club of New York is planning to make its fifth annual international carnival at Madison Square Garden March 23, 25, 26 and 28 the most pretentious show it has yet presented. It is to be a charity show for the benefit of the Bellevue Hospital Social Relief Service and the Carroll Club.
The plan of reorganization of the Northern Texas Electric Company of June 15, 1937, has been consummated and notices have been sent to the company's security holders, it was announced yesterday.

The report of the El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on Jan. 31, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $1,942,808 after all expenses and charges, compared with a net of $1,141,105 in the year ended on Jan. 31, 1937, an increase of $801,703, or 70 per cent.

M. Harvey Taylor, former chairman of the Republican State Committee and leader of the party in Dauphin County, issued a statement today endorsing Gifford Pinchot for the Republican nomination for Governor.

The Democratic leaders in the Senate won today the first major test of strength over the Administration reorganization bill by defeating an attack on the civil service rearrangement provision by 50 to 38. The vote,

An enormous quantity of material, including more than 250,000 feet of early film, correspondence, business papers and press books, representing a record of his career as a producer from 1913 to 1924, has been presented by David Wark Griffith to the Museum of Modern Art Film Library, it was announced yesterday by that organization.

With Governor Lehman standing firm yesterday on his contention that the 10 per cent home relief cut voted by the Board of Estimate on Monday was both unnecessary and unjustifiable, relief recipients began to organize a protest against the reduction.

On Police Surgeon's certificate. to take effect 12 noon, March 16: PATROLMEN-Joseph E. Jordan, 52d Precinct at $1,500 per annum. Appointed July 7, 1920. John D. Geideman, Motorcycle Precinct 1, at $2,250 per annum. Appointed Aug. 12, 190.
Meeting, Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, Assembly Hall, Congregation Emanu-El, 10:30 A. M. "The New York State Constitution Can Be Improved," Justice Charles Poletti.

The experiences of four Russian scientists who drifted on an ice floe for more than eight months, after establishing a weather station at the North Pole, are told here in the second of two articles by the leader of the expedition.

After wreathing the Austrian heroes' monument, addressing another enormous crowd of his supporters to announce to them Austria's formal incorporation into Germany and witnessing a great military parade, Chancellor Adolf Hitler flew back to Munich tonight.

The chapel of St. Thomas Church was the scene of an international marriage yesterday afternoon, that of Miss Jeannette MacKelvie to George Lutley Sclater-Booth, a grandson of the first Lord Basing of Hoddington House, Southampton, England, and a cousin of the present Lord Basing, and heir presumptive to the title. The Rev.

Hannes Schneider of St. Anton, Austria, who more than any other man had taught the world modern skiing, is under arrest, presumably for his anti-Nazi sentiments. The writer has received very reliable informa tion that Herr Schneider, despite Vienna denials of his arrest, has been taken to Landeck, where he is guarded in a schoolhouse--which, the according to local Nazi authorities, should not be confused with a concentration camp.

John Sanford gave a dinner tonight at Villa Marina for Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien, Mr. and Mrs. Philip Hill, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Sanford, Mrs. Louise Leach, Mrs. William Randolph Hearst, Dr. Francis X. Mayr, Captain R. Amcotts Wilson and Robert Sweeny Jr.

Trading was mostly slow. The lamb market was lower, veal and calf weak to lower, fresh pork cuts uneven, other classes about steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be steady, lamb lower. Veal and calf about steady,, as reported by the United States Department of Agculture.

Mrs. Natalie Hanna Carr of Palm Beach, Fla., daughter of Mrs. Stuart Hanna of Cleveland, was married yesterday at the Municipal Building to Arthur B. Marvin of this city, son of Mrs. William B. Marvin of Montclair, N. J., and the late Mr.
Drexel Co. of Philadelphia headed the successful banking group in the purchase yesterday of a new issue of $8,350,000 of school bonds of the Board of Education of the city of Philadelphia.

Nathan Thomas Folwell 2d, vice president in charge of the New York office of Folwell Brothers Co., woolen textile manufacturers, died today in his home here. Born in Philadelphia, fifty-eight years ago, Mr. Folwell had been for the last twenty-seven years in charge of the New York office of the firm which his father, the late William Folwell, established in Philadelphia in 1857.

If Cookie Lavagetto can drive eighty-five or more brother Dodgers across the various National League home plates this year it will add just $650 to his earnings. Manager Burleigh Grimes will contribute the first $150 and Larry MacPhail, executive vice president, will take the other $500 out, of his hat (or the Brooklyn Trust Company) and drop it into Lavagetto's chapeau.
The texts of Chancellor Hitler's address and of Dr. Seyss-Inquart's greeting to him follow: German men and women:

Mrs. Helena Woolworth McCann, wife of Charles E. F. McCann and daughter of the late Frank W. Woolworth, five-and-ten-cent-store pioneer, died yesterday afternoon at her residence, 4 East Eightieth Street, after a brief illness.

The defeat of several incumbent village officials gave a surprise twist to the annual elections today in fortyseven Nassau County villages. In the twelve villages where contests were held, the voting was heavy, with county-wide interest centered on the contests for control in the villages of Hempstead, Freeport, Mineola and Lake Success.

Reports are at hand that Chancellor Adolf Hit ler has been advised to make use ol the favorable wind that blows into his sails, that it would be a mistake to temporize and waste the next few months in the enjoyment of his Austrian triumph, since the Frencial and British Governments, and, be hind them, their public opinion,

Governor Lehman today signed three bills, including the Kleinfeld bill, which permits any partnership, instead of only limited partnerships, as at upon present, to use the firm name of any partnership which has discontinued, or is about to discontinue business activities.

Former President Hoover attended this morning an economic conference with Prime Minister Aimo Cajander, Foreign Minister Rudolf Holsti, Finance Minister M. Tanner and Risto Ryti, the Governor of the Bank of Finland. Afterward President Kyosti Kallio gave a luncheon in Mr. Hoover's bonor.

The collapse of the Republican army in Catalonia is not merely a military collapse; it is a collapse of morale which has spread from the army to the rear areas. This demoralization has been caused by two things:

With the book club plan announced by R. H. Macy Co., Inc., evoking widespred interest in book and other lines in which resale price maintenance has been adopted, it was indicated yesterday that leading publishers will meet informally later this week to consider what action, if any, will be taken.

Greet Britain's first line air strength is somewhere between 1,500 and 1,750 fighting planes, Lieut. Col. Anthony J. Muirhead, Parliamentary UnderSecretary for Air, said in the House of Commons today. He opened the debate over Great Britain's bill for air defense for the coming twelve months.
The Loyalist forces held firm today, throwing back attacks in the Montalban sector and also attempts to push down the Andorra-Alcorisa road, according to a government communique.

Domestic sales of Buick cars in February were the highest for the month since 1928, totaling 9,336, against 5,141 in February, 1937, Harlow H. Curtice, president of the Buick division of General Motors, reported today. Export sales brought the February total to 10,329.

Consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States in February amounted to 23,868 long tons, compared to 29,429 in January and 51,887 in February last year, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

This is the colorful phrase in which Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, diagnoses the economic malady from which the country is now suffering. The capitalistic system, he points out, requires a continuous flow of new capital; and because that flow has been checked, business stagnation has resulted.

General John J. Pershing sat up for ten minutes today away from his bed, for the first time since Feb. 16; and his physician, Dr. Roland Davison, reported his further recovery from the recent critical illness.

Stamp collectors from every State and many foreign countries have sent nearly 70,000 pieces of mail here for the opening of air mail service between the United States and Bermuda tomorrow by Pan American Airways.

The Henry J. Byrne Company sold to the Atlantic Refining Company for-$23,000 four vacant lots forming a plot 100 by 100 feet, on the south east corner of Fourteenth and Erie Streets, Jersey City, for a gasoline Service station.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions CHAS. SHAFFER SON,. INC., contracting, 122 E. 42d St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 7Tb of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of about $200,000. Including secured claims, and assets of$76,855, exclusive of pledged collateral.

Now and then the American democracy's home news will give out a faint echo of events in the strong-arm sections of Europe. Hitler sets the German tanks and motor-trucks rolling down the express highways into Austria, and our own Police Commissioner Valentine sends

The Court of Chancery has granted Mrs. Margot Einstein Marianoff, daughter of Professor Albert Einstein of Princeton, a final decree of divorce against her husband, Dmitri Marianoff of New York City. The final decree becomes effective at once.

Shattered Government troops were in full retreat tonight before 100,000 Insurgents bent on tearing Government Spain apart and forcing a quick end to the Spanish civil war. Encountering only feeble rearguard resistance,...

A recommendation that railroad car rates on mixed merchandise between Jersey City and Philadelphia and between certain other Eastern cities be sustained as reasonable was made to the Interstate Commerce Commission today in a report by Claude A. Rice, examiner.

Henry Armstrong, 130, world featherweight champion, gave Baby Arizmendi, 132, a terrific beating in ten rounds tonight, but failed to knock the game little Mexican off his feet. A wildly excited crowd of more than 10,400 in Olympic Auditorium saw the non-title battle.

" Germany's Absorption of Austria" will be discussed by James G. McDonald at a dinner of the Economic Club in the Hotel Astor on next Wednesday. Other speakers will be Alexander F. Kerensky, Premier of Russia in 1917; General Hugh S. Johnson,

With deaths from pneumonia increasing, Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, appealed to physicians and residents yesterday to make use of the city's free pneumonia typing and serum stations in the five boroughs.

Five major steps will be followed in the plan for developing certified colors for cosmetics in advance of legislation on this question, it was announced yesterday by H. Gregory Thomas, director of the bureau of standards of the Toilet Goods Association in a bulletin sent to members.

Although the House of Representatives dislikes the National Mobilization Bill as much as ever, it does not dare to challenge the government at present on a defense measure, and after two days of private debate the parties' negotiating committee has agreed to pass the bill, subject to certain assurances.

Henry F. Wolff, lawyer and former local administrator for the NRA, left a net estate of $970,311 when he died July 28, 1935, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday His widow, Mrs. Mirlam M. Wolff, of the Hotel St. Regis, and their children are the principal beneficiaries.

Several dinners will precede the varied dramatic presentation to be given tonight by members of the Lakeview Players at the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street, for the benefit of the New York Women's League for Animals.

Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., and Miss Helen Dettweiler of Washington, D. C., paired for a best-ball 67, eight under women's par, on the High Park course today, and won the medal in Aiken's round-robin golf tournament.

For improvement with a six-story apartment building, two plots on the southwest corner of 178th Street and the -Grand Concourse, Bronx, have been purchased by Gustav Halpern, builder. One plot, 47 by 117 feet, was purchased through David Kraus and Ray Strubel, brokers., The other,

The Lehigh Valley Railroad has offered to pledge its $10,000,000 claim arising out of the Black Tom explosion of World War days as additional collateral for a loan of $778,000 which it seeks from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, according to correspondence on file today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Resolutions calling for standards of sterilization of wiper cloths used for cleaning industrial machinery and seeking lower freight rates on these cloths were adopted yesterday at the annual convention of the Sanitary Institute of America, held in the Hotel Astor. E. D.

A broad legislative investigation of the rules and regulations of the New York Stock Exchange and the practices of its members was urged today in a resolution submitted in the Senate by Thomas F. Burchill, Democrat, of Manhattan, and referred to the Finance Committee.

Because of recent efforts by some of the smaller securities exchanges, with sympathetic support of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to increase their activities, unusual interest attached to an order issued today by the commission calling hearings for April 5 and 7, respectively, on applications by the Philadelphia and Boston Stock Exchanges for unlisted trading privileges in several securities.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,382,100 barrels, compared with 3,339,700 in the previous week, an increase of 42,400, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Dr. James I. Wyer, director of the New York State Library for thirty years, who will be 69 on May 14, said today he would retire "within six months" and would marry shortly afterward.

Members of Eugene von Grona's American Negro Ballet and William Bowers, baritone, will appear in a joint performance for the benefit of the New York Urban League at 8:30 P. M. next Sunday at the Town Hall. The league,

A duel between Glenn Cunningham and Francis Slater in the 1,000yard race looms as the outstanding event in the senior indoor track and field championships which will be held on Saturday at the 113th Infantry Armory in Jersey City.

Coincident with the start of hearings in Washington yesterday on the Lanham proposal to revise national trade-mark legislation, various advertising and publication associations here started a drive against a mandatory trade-mark registration bill introduced in Albany by Assemblyman Moran of Brooklyn.

A journey from end to end of Austria today, the first day of Austria's incorporation in the German Reich, left an Unforgettable impression of the might of the German military machine and of the apparent change in Austrian character, as the outer world has understood it, that this historic event has brought about.

Mrs. Amos Mason Chace, the former Pastora Smith, of 125 East Fifty-seventh Street, a descendant of early American settlers, died on Sunday in Wickersham Hospital after a short illness. She was 89 years old.

Vatican theologians are examining the authenticity of two miracles reported to have occurred in the United States during the present generation. The Congregation of Rites, beginning beatification proceedings of Mother Frances Severio Cabrini, studied today two cures attributed to her intercession.

Having nothing at stake, the lowly Maroons spotted the Bruins two goals and then performed in such aggressive fashion that they held the American Division hockey champions to a 4-4 overtime tie tonight before a 12,000 crowd at the Boston Garden.

Dr. Frank Louis Sevenoak, retired educator and musician, who made his home at the Hotel Wendell here for nine years, died today at House of Mercy Hospital, where he had been a patient for ten days. His age was 79. He formerly had been acting president of Stevens Institute of Technology at Hoboken, N. J.

The Texas Corporation reported yesterday for 1937 a consolidated net income of $54,574,319 after charges, reserves and taxes, including $825,000 for undistributed earnings, equal to $5.02 a share on the 10,875,006 capital shares outstanding.

Harry H. Woodring, Secretary of War, said in an interview today that the United States was better prepared than at any time in its history for "whatever happens." There is small likelihood, he said, of the nation becoming involved in any European situation arising from German possession of Austria.

Mrs. Thomas H. Beck gave a luncheon yesterday in the French Room of the Cafe Louis XIV for Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, who recently returned from Italy. The luncheon took place after the semi-annual meeting of members of the board of directors of the Girl Scouts.

Theexecution of eighteen confessed conspirators against Soviet Russia was officially. announced tonight. A terse communique announced the death sentences, imposed at the end of Moscow's greatest treason trial c March 13, had been carried out, I without disclosing the exact time or u place.

Lippincott will soon publish a book by George Stevens, new editor of The Saturday Review of Literature, called "Lincoln's Doctor's Dog and Other Famous Best Sellers." The book, which will be illustrated, is based on Mr. Stevens's article of the same title which appeared recently in The Saturday Review.

Twenty-two candidates for Columbia University's baseball team reported to Coach Andy Coakley at Baker Field yesterday for the initial outdoor drill of the season. At least ten more players, now detained by other activities, will join the group in time for the opening contest with City College on April 6 on the Lion diamond.

The plan of reorganization proposed by the management for the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad fails to recognize the rights of bondholders, it was charged in a statement issued yesterday by a committee headed by James J. Kann for New Haven first and refunding bonds, 4 per cent debentures of 1957 and Providence Securities Company 4 per

Vice Chancellor W. Frank Sooy approved today plans for a financial reorganization of the Atlantic City Steel Pier, the oceanfront amusement enterprise here. The approval was made on application by a bondholders' committee.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, painted a gloomy picture of American industrial and economic conditions today in a speech transmitted for broadcasting to Great Britain. He said that this nation was menaced "not by a foreign foe that

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are March 15 unless specified: Antares, at Quantico. Arkansas, at Navy Yard, New York. Cassin, at Norfolk. Chaumont, at Honolulu, March 14. Schenck, at New Orleans.
The House Interstate Commerce Committee reported favorably today a revised version of the Copeland Pure Food and Drugs Bill, passed by the Senate nearly a year ago.

The National Academy of design opened its 113th annual exhibition with a preview last evening at 9 o'clock in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, where, beginning today, the public may examine the ninety-six entries by academicians,

Responding to a call for bids to construct transoceanic airliners with a performance heretofore unattained, the Seversky Aircraft Corporation of Farmingdale, L. I., presented to Pan American Airways yesterday plans for a flying boat designed to carry 120 passengers in luxurious staterooms at 300 miles an hour.

The first twenty-five corporations on the Pacific Coast to report to the San Francisco Stock Exchange on their operations in 1937 showed aggregate net profits of $31,753,312. This was 30 per cent more than their earnings in 1936. which totaled $24.416.564.
All over Austria excited crowds are cheering the union which German arms have brought to pass, and the cry that echoes through the swirling streets is a cry of triumph. Sieg heil! Hail victory!

Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., will play John Van Ryn of Austin, Texas, and Don McNeill, Kenyon of College star from Oklahoma City, will face Robert Murray of Montreal in the semi-finals of the men's singles of the twenty-fifth annual Bermuda tennis championships.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 15,000, including 5,000 directs; market unevenly 10-25c lower than Monday's average; practical top $9.55, small lot $9.60; bulk 180-270 pounds, $9.15-55 280325 pounds, $9.00-$9.10 good 350-550 pound packing sows, $7.90-$8.20; smooth butcher kinds to $8.35. Shippers, 1,000; estimated holdover 2,000.

So much of Paragraph 2, Special Orders 57, dated March 10, 1938, as relates to 2d Lt. Daniel D. Tompkins, C.A.-Res., is revoked. (3d M. A.) 2d Lt. Clarence B. Gragg, C.A.-Res., will proceed from CCC Co. 236, Camp SP-13 (N. Y), Chenango Forks, N. Y. (Railhead: Binghamton, N. Y.), to Camp Dix, N. J., at such time as will enable him to report to the commanding officer threat on March 21,

Statements by British Government officials that the rearmament program would be continued' and probably increased gave the export copper market renewed strength yesterday. Late in the day sales of the metal were made at 10.10 cents a pound c.i.f. European base ports, while in the forenoon a heavy volume of business was done between 9.90 and 10 cents.

Plans for a new college with an educational program based on study of "real life problems," were announced here today by Royce S. Pitkin, president of Goddard Junior College. The new institution will be called Goddard College, a Vermont School for Living, and will be located in nearby Plainfield on a 250-acre estate known as Greatwood warm.

A campaign to find suitable homes for more than 1,000 children now under institutional care in the city will begin today under the auspices of the Joint Home-Finding Committee for Jewish Foster Children.

The hearing to be held by the City Planning Commission today on the plan to rezone the East River area south of Fourteenth Street is but another step in a replanning program which rapidly is changing the greater part of the zoning map of Manhattan to conform with present-day needs.

Mrs. Sylvia Penner, wife of Isaac Penner, head of the Penner Electric Company, contractors, was badgered and pushed about by a hostile crowd yesterday when she picketed the offices of Local 3 of the Electrical Workers Union, 130 East Twenty-fifth Street, in support of her husband's cause in a dispute with the union.

The Hunter College varsity fenc ing team last night defeated the Brooklyn College women by 5 to 4 in a team match at Brooklyn College. This followed a victory of the Hunter freshman team over the Brooklyn College freshman women fencers by 5 to 3.

Stockholders of the Derby Oil and Refining Corporation will vote at their annual meeting on April 13 on the proposal of their directors to offer to preferred stockholders two and a half shares of common stock to be valued at $5 a share to apply on arrears on preferred dividends, it was disclosed in the company's pamphlet report for 1937.

A number of food enterprises figured in the commercial leases announced by brokers and rental agents yesterday. Isidore Fox took a store in 835 Seventh Avenue through Wood, Dolson Company for a grocery and delicatessen, Byrne Bowman, Inc., acting as brokers.

Reports current in radio circles that William Randolph Hearst is negotiating to dispose of his radio properties, including ten broadcasting stations, were denied yesterday by Joseph V. Connolly, chairman of the board of' Hearst Radio, Inc.

A resolution endorsing the ToddFeld Nurse Practice Bill, now before the State Legislature, was adopted last night at a meeting of members of District 13, New York Counties Registered Nurses Association, held in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

St Paul's PI (11-2911), n s, 95 ft w of 3d Ave, 28x108; New York Savings Bank to Bella Roth, 1,181 Grand Ave; mtg $12,300. Anthony Ave (11-2803), e s, 52 ft n of 176th St, 33x85; Carmela Cottone to Theresa Jesch, 1,040 E 232d. St; mtg $13,625. Tinton Ave (10-2665), e s, 148 ft s of 156th St, 25x160; A. Weitzman's Sons, Inc, to Sam Weitzman, 2,135 Wallace Ave.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 14: BRIGADIER GENERAL Fairbank, G. L., General Dispensary, Washington, D. C., will report to the Surgeon General for duty in his office.

There is noth Bing much new about the Boston Bees this Spring except their new manager and new training grounds. It's Casey Stengel instead of Mild Will McKechnie and it's Bradenton instead of old St. Pete for board and lodging.

Stocks closed higher, industrial shares rising 1 to 5 points; turnover, 760,220 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds irregularly higher, Central European bonds weakened: transactions, $5,799,400.

New life insurance for February showed a decrease of 17.2 per cent from the corresponding month in 1937, while the total for the first two months of 1938 was 14.7 per cent under that for the same period last year, the Association of Life Insurance Presidents reported yesterday to the Department of Commerce.

Voters turned out in large numbers in the two Orange County villages, Otisville and Cornwall, where contests for village officers were held. In the remaining eleven villages few voters went to the polls and in almost all the cases the present officeholders were re-elected.

In 1937 a total of 2,807,280 more passengers were carried on railroads and ferries operating in and out of New York City than in 1936, according to a report issued yesterday by the Transit Commission. In 1937, 289,783,026 passengers were carried, as compared to 286,975,748 in 1936.

Harry F. Halwig, undertaker, was busy today cleaning his license plates following a ruling by Justice Fay R. Newbury that hearses must carry World's Fair advertising. Justice Newbury fined one of Mr. Halwig's employes $5 yesterday for defacing license plates by painting out the World's Fair advertising line on them.

Resumption of the foreign demand for cash wheat, with importing countries taking around 1,000,000 bushels from North America and the Southern Hemisphere, more than offset the effect of the European political news and a further sharp decline in foreign exchange rates today.

The Nicaraguan Government put into effect today a new customs rate of exchange of two paper cordobas for one United States dollar for all import duties. The reciprical trade agreement between the United States and Nicaragua continues in effect.

The American Navy must be capable of defending the Western Hemisphere from "dictatorial governments" who are "seeking new fields to exploit," Representative James W. Wadsworth of New York told the House today, in speaking in support of the $1,120,000,000 Naval Construction Bill.

The New York Curb Exchange has been notified that on April 1 holders of Scullin Steel Company mortgage bonds, 3 per cent fixed and 3 per cent income, due in 1951, will receive fixed interest of $15 a $1,000 bond upon surrender of fixed interest coupon No. 3 maturing on April 1.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended March 10 increased in four out of five trade groups compared with the corresponding week a year ago, according to figures issued by Dun Bradstreet. The only division to show a decrease was commercial service. The detailed comparisons were as follows:

The Republican party retained control of a majority of the twentyone Westchester villages which held annual elections today. Scarsdale defeated five proposi- I tions calling for an elaborate vil- ] lage building program and approved one involving construction of a $52,000 firehouse. Mamaroneck voted to dredge its west harbor and build a yacht basin, having defeated the same proposition in two previous years.

Paul Williams of Pennsylvania, whose team finished in last place, captured individual scoring honors as the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League campaign came to an end this week. Williams, a junior, specializing in the free style, finished the six meets with a total of 57 points.

A dinner for members of the men's division of the 1938 Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army in Brooklyn was held last night at the Army's social service center, 28 Ashland Place, Brooklyn. Brigadier J. J. Newby, head of social service work in the borough, was host.

Arthur Ave, 2,402 to 2,412 (11-3077); 681 E 181st St Corp to East River Savings Bank; installments, 3 per cent; $10,500. Westchester Ave, 2,008 (14-3805); Avanor, Inc, to 2,008 Westchester Ave Corp, 100 Broadway; 5 years, 4 per cent; $50,000.

Loft, Inc., have notified the New York Stock Exchange that they have extended the various periods of the option granted to Phoenix Securities Corporation, within which Phoenix may purchase 400,000 capital shares of Loft, for a further period of nine months.

Montana State, only seeded college entry in the National A. A. U. basketball tournament, increased the third-round field to fourteen teams tonight by taking a thrilling battle from an unexpectedly strong New Mexico Normal quintet, 50 to 46.

The following members, having satisfactorily completed the course in the care and operation of motors and pumps used in the department, are designated as motor and pump operators and they are therefore qualified to be assigned to that duty in their companies or in any company to which they may be transferred, in preference to all other members who have not previously qualified:
James H. Harlow, 34, of Westport, a New York stock broker, was killed by a train at the South Norwalk station today. Police said he fell from the station platform.

With two bullets still in his body and in poor health, Detective Henry L. Hoffman of the safe and loft to squad, Police Department hero, at will retire today with a pension of $2,250 and a final commendation from Commissioner Valentine.

Health Day, the semi-annual occasion on which the city's elementary school teachers examine their pupils and "screen out" those they think need a physician's attention, was strongly criticized as "a farce" yesterday by Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof,
The annual Spring entertainment, or "Night of Nights," takes place this evening in the auditorium of Montefiore Hospital, on Gun Hill Road, the Bronx.

The French liner He de France will arrive today from Havre and Southampton with the following among her passengers: Sabry Pasha, uncle of the King of Egypt and Commissioner General of Egypt to the New York World's Fair, accompanied by his wife;

The contract for the addition to the Grand Central Annex Postoffice building has been awarded to the Millimet Construction Company, reports Brown's Letters, Inc. The approximate amount of the contract is $1,849,000.
Six liners due to arrive here in the next few days with 3,500 passengers from Europe have reported that stormy weather at sea would cause delays of from twelve to thirty hours.

Many luncheon parties were given yesterday at the fashion show and luncheon held at Le Coq Rouge for the benefit of the Bide-a-Wee Home Association, which cares for friendless animals. Costumes for all occasions, from beach togs to evening gowns developed in gray and yellow, were featured.
Two of the three villages in Putnam County had uneventful elections this afternoon, and in Cold Spring and Nelsonville incumbent officers were re-elected without opposition.

John A. Manning, industrialist and for five years president of the Albany Hospital, died today in his suburban Loudonville home. He was 68 years old. Mr. Manning headed the John A. Manning Paper Company and the Behr-Manning Corporation of Troy.

Two former heavyweight boxing champions, Jack Dempsey and James J. Braddock, are expected to attend the annual St. Patrick's Eve party of the Michael J. Kennedy Association at Palm Garden, 306 West Fifty-second Street, this evening. Mr. Kennedy,

Knowing, a 5-year-old gelding representing Henry Lustig's Longchamp Farms, scored the easiest victory of the meeting in the Flagler Purse of five and a half furlongs at Tropical Park today. Closing at 1 to 2, the Dunboyne gelding romped home by eight lengths in 1:05 4-5, equaling the fastest time of the session.

Breaking a thirty-year precedent of Vociferous demands for immediate and complete independence, Commonwealth President Manuel Quezon today tacitly assented to High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt's advocacy of indefinite American retention of the Philippines in the following carefully worded statement:

Repeal of a number of New Deal laws to end the fear and uncertainty of business and industry was urged last night in resolutions adopted by the National Republican Club on recommendation of its committee of national affairs, of which William S. Bennet is chairman.

To provide the site for new apartment houses, a corporation controlled by Samuel Turner, who built Turner Towers, and his brother, Jay E. Turner, purchased from the heirs of the late Richard Young the Young homestead property with 225 feet of frontage on Lincoln Road, containing more than an acre of ground east of Flatbush Avenue. Brooklyn.

The first in a series of four lectures to be held at the Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 East Ninetyfirst Street, for the benefit of the Duchesne Placement Bureau will take place Friday when Helen Swift Jones will speak on "A Garden Trip Through Majorca and Spain."
Mr. and Mrs. George B. Agnew of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Madelaine Dutilh Agnew, to Hastings Foote, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sterling T. Foote, also of New York.

BOBROW, JACOB (Oct. 15, 1935). Gross assets, $105,390; net. $89,516. To Blanche Bobrow, widow, $25,000 and life estate in residue; Herbert, Sheldon Boorow, sons, Cecella Fried and Ethel B. Altschuler, daughters, $15,000 each and succeeding temporary estates in one-fourth residue each; Pauline Ravitch, sister, $4,000; Luba Hoffman and Lydia Sturtz, cousins, $l,000 each; two specific bequests.

The Rev. Dr. W. Courtland Robinson, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church here, died in the Delhi Hospital early this morning. He was 72 years old. Dr. Robinson, who had been ill for a fortnight, was operated on last night.

President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull have taken under active consideration legal questions involved in the extinction of Austria, which it is fully realized pose a major diplomatic problem t for the United States.
A tax measure which will restore business confidence and still yield the necessary revenue to the government is the aim of the Senate Finance Committee, Chairman Harrison stated today.

President Roosevelt indicated today that consolidation of railroads might be compelled by the government as a way out of the carriers' predicament. It this were done, he said, a way would have to be found to take care of employes displaced as a result.

Central European dollar obligations tumbled to new low levels, while domestic loans moved irregularly higher in less hectic but nevertheless highly erratic trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
During Senate debate today on a provision in the Reorganization Bill to transfer the Forest Service from the Department of Agriculture to the Interior Department, Senator Barkley said:

Fear that the next blow to peace will come in Lithuania instead of Czechoslovakia rose today in League of Nations quarters, which are anxiously following Poland's rapid development of the recent frontier incident with Lithuania.

A model eye and ear clinic, with the latest devices, was prepared especially for the conference on the conservation of sight and hearing which opened yesterday at City College as part of the Frederick B. Robinson Scientific Series.

142d St. 231 W; to 1-story church; Church of St. Thomas the Apostle, 263 W 137th St, owner; J. L. Wilson, architect; cost $4,700. 2d Ave, 96; to 4-story tenement and stores; Bernard Barth, premises, owner; H. Hurwit, architect; cost $4,500.
Germany's annexation of Austria has caused the Swiss Army to speed completion of its defenses all along Switzerland's German and Austrian frontiers, now all German.
The consolidated net profit for 1937 of the Transamerica Corporation, the California, bank-holding company, was $12,798,324, according to an announcement here yesterday.

Soon after thirty-five pushcart peddlers from the Brownsville and East New York sections of Brooklyn were convicted yesterday of peddling without a license, their spokesman announced that they had organized a protective association because the City of New York was unfair to pushcart peddlers.

House and Garden will launch a newspaper advertising campaign in the six major marketing areas of the country to promote its "Ideal Home Products Parable," Charles E. Whitney, advertising manager, said yesterday.

Today's major events: Artur Rubinstein, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Rose Kunst, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; "Tristan und Isolde," Metropolitan Opera House, evening; John Franco, pianist-composer, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Madrigal Singers, Federal Music Theatre, 8:45 P. M.

The Mexican Government's order to foreign petroleum- - companies to comply with the Supreme- Court's decision upholding an arbitration award of wage rises was met today by a final statement to the Labor Board:

Marketing research executives, who have been making surveys on brand preferences, reported yesterday that the business slump has apparently encouraged renewed interest in distributors' brands, because of the price differential.
Members of Goodrich Local, United Rubber Workers of America, were advised by their negotiating committee today to vote against the wage reduction proposal of the B. F. Goodrich Company.
After a lapse of about six months gold has begun again to move here from Europe. It is, of course,

The Chesapeake Corporation has called a special meeting of stockholders for April 4 to elect directors and for "other purposes." Samuel Weinberg is with S. H. Junger Co. as manager of their trading department.
Hungary was the first among nations that formally notified the German Foreign Office today that she recognized the German-Austrian Anschluss (union).

The Opposition continues to attack Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch for his attitude in the Austrian affair, and to ask, elucidation of the situation of the Slovene minorities in Carinthia, which became Austrian after the 1919 plebiscite. An Opposition Deputy, Mita Dimitrievic, today asked the Speaker to make a declaration on the Carinthian situation.
The flight of frightened European capital to the dollar continued yesterday and our security and commodity markets moved higher. Leading industrial shares rose 1 to 5 points.
Several properties in the metropolitan area were reported yesterday as having been sold by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The United States reduced its idle shipping tonnage by 62 per cent in the last year, the Commerce Department estimated today. Some unused vessels were drawn into expanded foreign trade, but much of the idle tonnage was removed by scrapping.

Among the properties sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesroom. was the fourteen-story office and store building at 10-12 West Forty-seventh Street, which was bought in by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, for $600,000.

Following his stirring speech at the Vienna "liberation demonstration," Chancellor Adolf Hitler, creator of the "Holy Germanic Reich of Teutonic Nationality," flew back to Munich this afternoon and on his arrival at 7 o'clock received a rousing reception such as few conquering heroes have ever known.

Another important American art collection is to be sold. Announcement was made yesterday that the rare paintings, sculpture, tapestries and furniture collected by the late Mortimer L. Schiff, banker, would be sold at auction in London, probably early in June, in the galleries of Christie, Manson In explanation of the announcement Mr. Schiff's son, John M. Schiff, said:

Thomas N. Cooke of Greenwich, who negotiated many of the Merritt Parkway land sales to the State, testified for three hours today before the Parkway grand jury. Mr. Cooke's decision to testify reversed a previous stand when he challenged the legality of 'the grand jury. He arrived at the court house with his brother, 'George, his attorney. He. brought two suitcases full' of personal and business records which have been subpoenaed.
As frightened capital continued yesterday to flee from Europe to the United States, gold began to move here from London for the first time in nearly six months.
A warm welcome was extended to Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy, wife of the United States Ambassador, and a her five younger children when they landed at Plymouth tonight.

Women who will receive at the Hospital Ball to be given on Friday night at the Surf Club in behalf of St. Francis Hospital include Mrs. J. Hunter Barton, Mrs. Fred A. Poor, Mrs. Walter 0. Briggs, Mrs. George S. Hasbrouck, Mrs. Frank E. Gannett, Mrs. David. J. Molloy, Mrs. Walter S. Hammons, Mrs. De Witt Page, Mrs. Mark C. Honeywell and Mrs. Christian R. Lindback.

Approaching and putting with deadly accuracy, Ben Hogan of White Plains, N. Y., and Willie Goggin of San Francisco, upset Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., and Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., in the semifinal round of the annual international four-ball golf tournament at the Miami Country Club today, 4 and 3. Revolta and Picard were thwarted in their attempt to carry off title honors for the fourth consecutive year.

Sales in the replacement tire market are showing a normal trend, may with indications for a total volume for the year at least as large and probably larger than in 1937, P. W. Litchfield, president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said yesterday.

Frank Edward Lorson, head of New York electrical companies, died of a heart ailment yesterday in his home here. His age was 53. Mr. Lorson was president of Lorson Electric Company, an installation concern, and the New York Supply and Inspection Company, an equipment and service organization.

Arnold Shukotoff, secretary or the New York College Teachers Union, announced yesterday that the draft bill for teachers' tenure presented to the Board of Higher Education on Monday was not conpiled by the Teachers Union alone, but represented a consensus of groups which included the American Association of University Professors, Committee of Seven of the City Colleges, Hunter College Faculty Tenure Committee.

Despite the sharp declines in retail sales in large cities, notably in industrial areas, the volume of business in rural districts has held up well, and merchants in the country areas still are buying goods on a reorder basis which has continued to provide wholesales with a steady volume, it was reported yesterday.

Senator McNaboe is determined to put an end to this business once for all. He has introduced a bill according to which-and the exact wording is important-no person espousing a "doctrine that holds that organized government shall be overthrown by force or violence of by the assassination of the

The controversy between the Black Diamond Steamship Corporation and the National Labor Relations Board reached the Supreme Court today when the shipping concern asked a review of a Second Circuit Court ruling in favor of the board.

Village leaders of the two major parties combined forces today and defeated an attempt by the county Progressive party to enter local politics. Frank Schwartz and Joseph F. O'Brien, running on the Democratic and. People's tickets, were re-elected trustees by more than 200 votes over their nearest rivals.

Following the circulation of notices for 10,000 bales early yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered in sympathy with outside markets to end with gains of 4 to 7 points. With notices stopped promptly by two spot firms and 24,000 bales of the March still unsettled, although trading ceases at noon tomorrow, urgent covering advanced, the near delivery nearly $1 a bale at one time.

As speedily as they can manage it, 450,000 Girl Scouts throughout the country will don new uniforms which yesterday were approved by the board of directors at its semiannual meeting in headquarters, 14 West Forty-ninth Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick De Peyater of Winnetka, Ill., have announced the engagement and appreaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Jane De Peyster, to John M. van Beuren, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick T. van Beuren Jr. of Morristown, N. J.
The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the following additional applications from New York City for registration as brokers or dealers in the over-the counter market:

Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania will be the principal speaker at a consumers' mass meeting which will be held at Madison Square Garden next Monday under the sponsorship of the Hearn Deapartment Stores and leading ororganizations of the metropolitan trict.
President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull were urged yesterday by the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches not to recognize the German absorption of Austria.
Late returns from village elections held yesterday in Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk, Orange, Rockland and Putnam Counties indicated that the following had been elected:

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 12: COMMANDERS Grosskopf, H. L., previous order modified; to aide, commandant 11th Naval Dist., San Diego, Calif., instead 9th Naval Dist.

The question whether municipal and county bonds issued in this State, approximating $800,000,000, may be subject to California State income taxes has been placed before Attorney General Webb and his staff for study.
Temple's champion Owls placed three men on the all-Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball Conference team picked yesterday for The Associated Press by the six coaches.

The Prime Minister's statement on strengthening England's defense program, added to its causal factor, the developments in Central Europe, brought about all-around unsettlement on the stock market here today. After a morning of. heavy selling, most sections became calmer following the entry of bargain hunters in the market.
King Carol's state visit to Great Britain, fixed for next Tuesday, has been postponed, it is announced tonight, at the Rumanian King's own suggestion, in view of international developments.
Archduke Otto, heir to the Habsburg throne, in Paris tonight issued a statement declaring that the annexation of. Austria would never receive his approval nor that of the Austrian people.

General Jan Christiaan Smuts holds that the League of Nations is, like Lazarus, merely sleeping. During debate in the House today he said there were only two possible courses before the world, either the way of the League-consultation and understandingor to fight it out to the destruction of civilization and the world.

The Delco Frigidaire Conditioning Division of the General Motors Corporation annouriced today it has started production on a new type of moderate priced air conditioner suitable for use in residences, offices, hotels, hospitals, and similar establishments.

The New York Athletic Club, a team composed of Leo Nunes, Lieutenant Fred Weber and Captain Jean V. Grombach, won the national senior epee championship by defeating the Salle Santelli B trio of Warren Dow, Norman Lewis and Kevis Kapner, 5-3, on the strips of the Fencers Club last night.

The City Planning Commission will hold a final hearing at 10:30 A. M. today in City Hall on the proposed rezoning of a large section of the Lower East Side below Twelfth Street for business districts, retail districts and residence districts with a view to improvement of the section for residence purposes.

Richard Whitney was indicted yesterday for the second time, the Inew grand larceny charge being procured by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. The first- indictment wazj obtained by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.
The Republic Steel Corporation opened here today what is said to be the world's largest continuous strip mill, one costing $15,000,000.

Plans for a survey of the Board of Examiners of the city's school system were announced yesterday by Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the board. Every phase of the board's work is to be studied, and an evaluation made of the procedures now used.

Lured back from a Florida vacation by a telegraphic ruse, Max Friedman, 38 years old, of 250 East 176th Street, the Bronx, was arrested yesterday, accused of the theft of $128,000 from Butler, Herrick Marshall of 30 Broad Street since he was promoted to be assistant cashier of that brokerage concern in 1932.

Consolidated net profit of the National Cash Register Company and its subsidiaries amounted to $3,920,667 for 1937 after depreciation, provision for income taxes and $241,999 Federal surtax on undistributed earnings, minority interest and other charges, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Colonel E. A. Deeds, president. The profit was equal to $2.40 each on 1,628,000 shares of no-par capital stock and compared with $2,865,341, or $1.76 a share. in 1936.

At the annual meeting yesterday of the Universal Pictures Company, Inc., John D. Penick and Samuel I. Posen were elected directors to represent the first preferred stockholders, filling posts that have been vacant, while William Freiday, who has been representing common stockholders on the board, will hereafter represent the second preferred stockholders.

Dr. Erwin R. Stoekle, Milwaukee physicist, known in scientific fields for many developments in electron tubes and radio vacuum tubes, died last night in Boston, where he had gone for an eye operation.

Awards in decorative arrangement classes of the Garden Club of America, judged yesterday, were: Large Arrangement Featuring Rubber Plant--Mrs. David L. George, Garden Club of The Oranges. first; Mrs. Stephen C. Reynolds Jr., Millbrook Garden Club, second; Mrs. Benjamin Yates and Mrs. Moreau L. Stoddard, Fairfield Garden Club, third: Mrs. Stewart S. Hathaway and Mrs. James S. Hedges, Rye Garden Club, and Miss Mary P. Beckwith, Philipstown Garden Club, honorable mention.

Trading in shelled peanuts for future delivery was began yesterday at 11 A. M. on the New York Produce Exchange. John McD. Murray, president of the Exchange, made a formal address on the merits of peanut trading on a market far from the territory of actual production.
Mrs. Theodore Douglas Robinson, her son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Robinson, and her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Jacques B. de Sibour, are at the Cloister, Sea Island, Ga.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The time is ripe for the world to form a new League of Nations. The time to build a structure of honorable peace for all is before the test of armed strength discloses the weakness of those who deem themselves the mightiest.

Councilman Albert D. Schanzer, Brooklyn Democrat, said yesterday that he would present the agreed statement of facts covering disputed points in the Council's organization to Presiding Justice Frank Martin on the Appellate Division at 11 A. M. tomorrow.
Three grants for research and a bequest for student aid were among four gifts amounting to $46,500 received by Cornell University and announced by President Day to the board of trustees.

The formation of a committee for holders of Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad 5 per cent Series A bonds of 1975 headed by E. Stanley Glines of Glines Co. was announced yesterday. Mr. Glines also is chairman of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway bondholders' committee.
Raymonde Delaunois, French soprano, who is known here by her former association of twelve years with the Metropolitan Opera Company, gave a Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon.
Two third-period goals brought the Montreal Canadiens from behind to a 3-2 victory over Detroit tonight and ended the Red Wings' chances for a berth in the National Hockey League play-offs.

William F. Donovan, early glass manufacturer here, died today of pneumonia at the age of 75. Born in Cambridge, Mass., he was with the Libbey Glass interests in the East and came to Toledo with E. D. Libbey and Jefferson D. Robinson when they established the Libbey Glass Manufacturing Company.

Jesse Moate, 13-year-old seventhgrade pupil at Mix Run's one-room school, trudges to the little schoolhouse every morning so Miss Gladys Colegrove, his teacher, will not be "disappointed." He is the only pupil. Until recently there were four,

The Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper, criticized today Italy's failure to support Austrian independence. It replied to an explanation carried by the Cremona newspaper, Regime Fascista, which had said:

When Burgess Whitehead, the scholarly second base star of the Giants, was stricken with appendicities just about a month ago, it was generally feared that Colonel Bill Terry's 1938 pennant hopes had received a vital blow in the short ribs before the training season had, started.
Joe Louis looked as though he had been neglecting his fried chicken lately as he opened training today for his title defense, against Harry Thomas at the Chicago Stadium on Friday, April 1.

The man who sent the S 0 S from the blazing Morro Castle when she burned Sept. 8, 1934, with a loss of more than 100 lives, was arrested here today in connection with the five explosion of a bomb in police headquarters March 4. The prisoner, George White Rogers, formerly chief radio operator aboard the liner, gave up the -sea after the disaster and became a Bayonne policeman.

Underneath the surface of shattering events life goes on. It has its own laws. which cannot be changed by mandate, from any capital, by any lord of misrule, by any assertion of armed force. Men and nations may be carried away by passion, by the hypnotism of arrogant personalities, by the base desire for glory.
For the second successive day the Czechoslovak Parliament was thrown into an uproar today by the threatening statement of a Sudeten German [pro-Nazi] member.

As the result of poor classroom illumination, eye-fatigue, failure of pupils and inefficiency of teachers are found in many schools throughout the country, a report on a twoyear survey prepared under the sponsorship of the Illuminating Engineering Society and the American Institute of Architects disclosed yesterday.

Benjamin Franklin of Manhattan and Newtown of Queens won their way into the final of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament by coming through with smashing triumphs over rivals from other boroughs in a matinee doubleheader at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Thirty-seven members of the American League for Peace and Democracy, who were arrested Monday while picketing the German Embassy, are out on bail waiting trial' tomorrow morning on charges of violating a recent act of Congress forbidding demonstrations in the vicinity of foreign embassies and legations in the United States.
Manager Jack Adams received notice from owner James D. Norris today that he will pilot the Red Wings in the .National Hockey League again next season.
The little principality of Liechtenstein, wedged between Austria and Switzerland, announced today that its citizens were "unanimously determined to maintain independence."

A contest between Robert R. Young and Allan P. Kirby on the one side and appointees of the late O. P. and M. J. Van Sweringen on the other for control of the $2,000,000,000 railroad empire assembled by the Cleveland brothers was disclosed yesterday through the unexpected calling of a special meeting of the Chesapeake Corporation on April 4.

An important gesture aiming at removing British suspicions and smoothing the way in the present Anglo-Italian negotiations was made today when the Italian Government recalled part of the troops stationed in Libya.

Pointing to the possibility of "an epidemic of store-wide sales" to produce the added volume needed by stores at present, Hugo Sonnenschein, advertising manager of Bloomingdale's, in an address last night before the Metropolitan Controllers Association, declared it was essential that stores make sure that such efforts do not result in more volume with less profit. Mr.

France, in her apprehension over the possibility of a Fascist Spain as a neighbor, turned to Britain yesterday and, it was understood, won a promise of naval aid to safeguard her communication lines with Africa [Page 1.]

The lessons learned by the motionpicture industry during the Legion of Decency drive in 1933 and 1934 should be earnestly studied by the advertising profession, Martin Quigley of the Motion Picture Herald and Motion Picture Daily, yesterday told the luncheon meeting of the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association at the Advertising Club of New York.

Chairman Harrison of the Senate Finance Committee has asked for an estimate of what the effect on revenues would be if the highest surtax were cut from 75 per cent to 60 per cent. The request points to a possible reopening of a cardinal question.

Berlo Holding Company sold to Louis White the two, four-story flats, on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 324-26 Twenty-fourth Street, Union City. The buildings were sold subject to mortgages totaling $28,000. Rufo Ricchinto bought from Bertha M. K. Renner the four-story flat, on a plot 32 by 100 feet, at 229 Palisade Avenue, Union City.
At least fifty organizations of small business men have sprung up since the February "little business" conference, officials of the Department of Commerce estimated today.

One government bureau employs "only red-headed girls," Senator Ellender of Louisiana told the Senate today. Criticizing the administration of the civil service, he said he had been informed "that promotion often is made upon good looks."

A cloud of uncertainty overshadows the whole Continent of Europe at this moment. In the west the long deadlock in Spain has finally been broken and the desperate appeals of the Valencia Government for assistance suggest that a break-up of the Loyalist defense is imminent.

Faced with the legal obligation to assume control of the vast United States and British oil activities in Mexico, the government failed to act today, twenty-four hours after the companies' refusal to accept the ultimatum of the Labor Board.

William Green and other representatives of the American Federation of Labor assured President Roosevelt at a conference today of their cooperation toward passing a maximum hour-minimum wage bill this session.

Richard Whitney pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday for the second time to a charge of grand larceny. The two guilty pleas now on record against him for the misuse of customers' securities in safe keeping with Richard Whitney Co. were joined by. Judge Owen W. Bohan in a common date for sentence on March 28.
