Representatives of the American Labor party voiced serious objection yesterday to the proposal before the City Planing Commission to rezone the lower East Side chiefly for residential use.
Mighty Temple, flashing a brand of basketball that never has been surpassed in Madison Square Garden, routed Colorado in the final of the national invitation college tournament last night, 60 to 36.

A campaign attack upon the Earle administration by one of its own officers, Attorney General Charles J. Margiotti, now a candidate for Governor, led Governor Earle tonight to threaten to ask for Mr. Margiotti's resignation.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Helene Vige Kopstead, daughter of Mrs. Peder H. Kopstead of this city and the late Mr. Kopstead, to Caston Coles Edmonds, son of Mrs. Samuel Owen Edmonds of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mr. Edmonds.

Secretary Wallace urged farmers today to store their corn to establish an ever-normal granary for this commodity and told them that the time limit on applications for corn loans, which were to have been in by March 31, had been extended indefinitely to advance this objective.

The sons and daughters of Erin will pay their annual homage to St. Patrick today with the traditional parade that fills upper Fifth Avenue with the lilt of Irish tunes and brings celebrities of city, State and nation to the reviewing stand.

Harriet Dunham, in 67 Park Ave; George Bailey, in 450 E 49th St; William D. Cox, through Pease Elliman, Inc. in 530 E 88th St; Potter, Hamilton Co, Inc, broker. Mrs. Miriam Mitchell, in 254 E 52d St; Mrs. Mary McDonough, in 234 E 86th St; Cyrille Carreau, Inc, broker.
Fears of an impending shortage of petroleum were described today as unfounded by Ernest O. Thompson, chairman of the Interstate Oil Company Commission.
Mrs. Hoke Smith, widow of a one-time Georgia Senator, and Bernard Grant, formerly of Richmond, Va., were married today in Miami Beach Community Church by the Rev. Elisha A. King.
Henry T. (Dick) Merrill received the Harmon Trophy from President Roosevelt today, marking selection of him as the outstanding aviator of 1937.

While the search for his 12-yearold son, Peter, continued in New Rochelle Murray Levine, attorney; went.to his office at 475 Fifth Avenue yesterday to take up his practice for the first time since the boy was kidnapped three weeks ago this afternoon. Mr. Levine handles only civil cases..

Thirty days' grace, beginning today, has been granted by Chief of Police Filin to Muller to foreigners who entered Brazil under tourist visas good only for six months and remained illegally after their expiration.

In an atmosphere charged heavily with politics the Legislature passed and sent to the Governor today the most controversial bill of the session, the savings bank life insurance plan sponsored by Governor Lehman. For weeks it was balked by a revolt in the Democratic Senate.

Protection against price declines on present stocks of floor coverings for a period of at least ninety days was demanded by rug retailers of the metropolitan district at a meeting in the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.

Dartmouth's Indians, who finished on top in the close Eastern b Intercollegiate Basketball League race, placed three men yesterday on the loop's all-star squad for 1938, selected for The Associated Press by the seven coaches.

The three members of the Czechoslovakian Trade Treaty Commission, which successfully negotiated a reciprocal trade pact with the United States, to be provisionally effective April 16, sailed last night on the Hamburg American liner Hansa.
Twenty-three tentative dates for the championship regattas of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound the coming Summer were sent out yesterday to the member clubs.

Undaunted by the drenching rain, 2,000 persons stood inUnion Square from 5 to 6:15 P. M. yesterday listening to speakers denouncing aggression in Spain, China and Austria. The meeting, which was called by the New York City division of the American League for Peace and Democracy, was planned as a demonstration against Germany's annexation of Austria.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. O. affiliate of unlicensed seamen, has been designated as the bor bargaining agency of the seagoing personnel of three more ship lines as a result of elections sponsored by the National Labor Relations Board, it was announced yesterday.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler made a superbly dramatic re-entry into his capital late this afternoon after adding his Austrian homeland and the proud city of Vienna to the territories governed from Berlin.

" See How They Run," a play by George Savage, instructor of English at the University of Washington, won the play contest sponsored by the Federal-Theatre Project and the Dramatists Guild. More than 700 plays were submitted.

Following is the text of Premier Mussolini's address this afternoon before the Chamber of Deputies: In the last days a great event has occurred that has changed the political map.. of Europe. Austria has ceased to exist as a State and has become part of Germany. The plebiscite of April 10 will confirm the accomplished fact.

Assuring himself of at least a tie for second place, Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia vanquished Marcel Camp of Detroit, 125 to 78, last night at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy as the world championship pocket billiard tournament entered its final stages. Ponzi recorded his ninth straight victory in nine innings.

Home relief administrators in upState districts were instructed yesterday to ignore the request of the WPA for lists of able-bodied, unmarried young men on relief to be turned over to the recruiting service of the United States Army.

The Joseph H. Bearns prize of $900, given annually by Columbia University for a small musical composition, "to encourage young American composers of outstanding talent and promise," has been awarded this year to Miss Marie Elizabeth Marting, 25 years old, of Rutherford,
Youth today gets too little chance to live, Dr. Eugene Colligan, president of Hunter College, declared at an informal chapel of the college yesterday in the Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue.

The Netherland Social Democratic party executive today telegraphed an invitation to Karl Kautsky, Marxist theorist, who is now in Prague, to come to Holland, where they offer him and his wife a quiet refuge. It is understood the offer will be accented.

The French liner Ile de France arrived yesterday a day behind schedule with more than two dozen windows torn out along both sides of the promenade deck by poundng seas. The smashed panes had been replaced with temporary boarding when the liner came in.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The St. Patrick's Day observances here and over the United States form part of what we may Regard as a most remarkable racial-ceremony. It has been 1,500 years since the great man first trod Irish land, and despite their crowded centuries of trouble the people still remember him.

The Transamerica Corporation has reduced its holdings of shares of the National City Bank of New York from more than 10 per cent to about 8.75 per cent, according to the annual pamphlet report for 1937.

The Quentin Theatre, on the corner of Quentin Road and East Thirty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Jerome C. Mayer from the Hanswald Realty Corporation for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $12,500 running for fifteen years.

The American Committee on Maternal Welfare has prepared an educational film in dramatic form which is entitled "The Birth of a Baby" and which has been branded as "indecent, immoral and tending to corrupt morals" by the educational authorities of the State.

The Cardinals transferred their only holdout problem-Joe Stripp-to their Columbus farm today, but apparently without solving it. The third baseman was traded to the American Association club, along with Pitchers Nathan Andrews and Clem Dreisewerd, for Pitcher Max Lanier, a southpaw of considerable promise.

President Roosevelt discussed wages and hours legislation with William Green and other representatives of the American Federation of Labor . He presented the Harmon Trophy for the outstanding aviator of 1937 to Henry T. (Dick) Merrill.
Persistent reports of Insurgent victories in Spain tonight complicated British foreign policy, already confused and chaotic as the result of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Austrian coup.

The Literary Digest, which suspended publication temporarily on Feb. 24, filed a petition in Federal Court yesterday through George F. Havell, its president, for permission to reorganize under section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act.
How is France to give Czechoslovakia effective military aid against Germany's fortified Rhine? How is Russia to do it with Poland lying in habetween ?

The report of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday, shows a net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, taxes and other charges of $8,961,630.

Heavy income-tax collections brightened the Federal budget picture tonight. The Treasury announced that $615,947,718 was collected in the first fifteen days of March, an Increase of 18 per cent over the similar period last year.

Faced with the knowledge that their son is almost certain to die within a few months unless a blood donor volunteers for a transfusion, the parents of George Cestaro, 29 years old, of 2,354 First Avenue, who has been suffering from a rare blood disease since last November, appealed yesterday for some person who has had the disease to come forward.

The appointment of three business leaders as chairmen of sections of the committee on firms of the Greater New York Fund, Inc., was announced yesterday by Leon Fraser, chairman of the committee on contributions.

Harry F. Wolf of the Montclair A. C. extended his unparalleled record when he won the national amateur squash tennis championship for the ninth consecutive year yesterday at the Crescent Athletic Club courts.

The disciplinary committee of the House of Representatives will meet today to decide what to do. about Suehiro Nishlo, a Social Mass party member, who mentioned Joseph Stalin's name in the -debate on the Mobilization Bill last night.

Some 550 members of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York gathered in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Biltmore last night for their annual dinner. Dr. James Shelby Thomas, president of the Chrysler Institute of Engineering, was the principal speaker.

Mayor La Guardia abandoned as useless today his attempt to get the State to give directly to the city the additional relief monies he insists the city needs and, instead, inspired a roundabout procedure which would permit the lifting of the 40 per cent limit of State aid to all cities in the case of emergencies.

The Illinois Central Railroad disclosed today it was taking steps to reduce payroll expenditures by discontinuing certain positions and granting ten-day holidays without pay in April and May to certain employes.

With the approval of the Public Utility Commission, the New Jersey Power and Light Company turned over to the New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania Utilities, an affiliate, 55,850 shares of preferred stock of the Metropolitan Edison Company, with an estimated value of $4,312,303, in exchange for 341,350 shares of common stock of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company.
Representative Hoffman of Michigan told the House today the Labor Relations Board's decision in the Remington-Rand case was an instance of "oppression, injustice and deprivation of civil liberty."

George W. Lindsay, who served six successive terms in the House of Representatives from the Third Brooklyn District, died in his sleep early yesterday morning in his home at 40 Bushwick Place, Brooklyn. He would have been 73 years old on March 28.

From every corner of Manhattan, Girl Scouts crowded into a ballroom at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday to celebrate the anniversary of the founding of their organization. Tributes were paid to Juliette Low, who originated the movement twenty-six years ago at Savannah, Ga.
The full nazification of Austria is making rapid progress. The Freemasons' lodges were dissolved a few days ago and their contents were confiscated.

The United States Life Insurance Company announced yesterday its official entry into Colombia on March 9 and the appointment of A. B. Penry as general agent in Bogota. Mr. Penry has been in genreal insurance and agency supervision work in South America for many years.
A second-half goal gave Ireland a 1-0 victory over Wales in an international soccer tournament match today.
A wave of suicides is sweeping the country. The most sensational of them was that of the former Vice Chancellor, Major Emil Fey, who was found dead with his family early this morning.

Announcement has been made of the marriage on Tuesday night of Princess Mary Tourkasteanoff of Russia, who had been making her home here, to B. Stafford Mantz, vice president and treasurer of the Corporation Trust Company.

The opportunity for an imaginative voyage to distant lands was afforded to about 35,000 visitors to the International Flower Show in Grand Central Palace yesterday under the auspices of the Garden Club of America. The day's attendance,

Settlement of the three-day tie-up of shipping here. seemed even more distant tonight, following an allday conciliation conference called at Long Beach by Captain Edward V. Fitzgerald, Federal Commissioner of Conciliation.

Caught warm from Mississippi, Senator Pittman has assimilated too much of the ancient volcanic rhyolite and basalt of Nevada. It wouldn't be impolite to describe him geologically as intrusive granite.
Francis Jones of Detroit, the medalist, led the way through the first round of match play in the Belmont golf tournament today, defeating C. C. Hewitt, Brookline, Mass., 4 and 2.

The Securities and Exchange Commission will begin tomorrow hearings to determine whether the 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock and common stock of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company should be suspended or withdrawn from registration on the New York

Alexander Kipnis, eminent Russian-American basso, has canceled his engagement with the Salzburg Festival for the coming season as well as his return to the Vienna State Opera for the June Festival, it was announced yesterday by his American manager, Charles L. Wagner.

Defeating opposition from China on the one hand and the United States, Great Britain and France on the other, the International Olympic Committee today confirmed Tokyo as the site of -the 1940 Olympic Games and changed the dates to Sept. 21 to Oct. 6.

American Catholics contributed $647,000 in 1937 for the support of Catholic missions in foreign lands at home, it was announced yesterday by Mgr. Thomas J. McDonnell, national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith. He spoke at the annual meeting of the society at its headquarters, 109 East Thirty-eighth Street.
Miss Emily L. Peterson, since 1913 a Presbyterian missionary in India, where she was principal of the Central Girls Middle School at Saharanpur, died in India on Tuesday of cancer at the age of 58.

The Senate division. over the Wheeler amendment to the greatly modified Administration Reorganization Bill became so close today that Democratic leaders avoided a vote after general debate ended about 4 o'clock.

Representatives of Eastern clothing manufacturers and woolen jobbers, appearing at the hearings today on the proposed British trade treaty, Archi contended that the negotiations with Australia should be considered simultaneously.

The St. Peter's High School basketball team of Staten Island deheated Manhattan Prep, 42 to 34, last night in the semi-final round of the C. H. S. A. A. championship at Cromwell Center, Tompkinsville, Staten Island.

Max C. Nickelsburg, retired leather merchant, former head of Nickelsburg Bros., of Newark, died Tuesday at his residence, 315 West Eighty-sixth Street, after a long illness. Born sixty-three years ago in Worms, Germany, he came here in 1893.

Declaring that "absence of good faith and the fact of collusion" appears on the face of the proceedings, the Hudson Coal Company, through counsel, asked the Federal court of the Middle Pennsylvania District today to dismiss the petition for reorganization of the company which was filed twelve days ago by six bondholders.

Yesterday we completed the longest flight we have yet made in our search for Sigismund Levanevsky and his Soviet companion fliers, who were lost last August during a flight from Moscow to Fairbanks, Alaska.

Governor Frank Murphy, describing a minimum annual wage as "inevitable," expressed the belief today that Henry Ford was "the man best able" to start such a program. "I hope very much," the Governor told newsmen,
The will of Robert Paine Scripps, 42, principal stockholder of the Scripps-Howard newspaper chain, was filed here today, disposing of an estate unestimated in value.

Plans for a march on Albany, a mass demonstration at City Hall and a sit-in strike in relief offices throughout the city were laid by the Workers Alliance yesterday as the city prepared to make a 10 per cent cut in home relief allowances effective at the rate of 18,000 cases a day, beginning March 26.

Louis Hornyak and John Nozar of the Hungarian-American Social Athletic Club of Chicago, shook up the twoman team standing in the American Bowling Congress today. Hornyak and Nozar, with a count of 1,227, went into first place.
The Securities and Exchange Commission exempted today Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., of New York from provisions of the Publie Utility Holding Company Act.

While you sportsmen remain inactive and fail to announce your opposition to a ridiculous bill that would result in your being required to register every gun you possess, at a fee of $1 per gun, the machinery of legislation is moving forward.

The American Federation of Municipal Transit Workers, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, denounced the American Labor party yesterday as "a stooge for the C. I. 0." and accused it of permitting itself to be used by the C. I. O.

Mrs. Alice M. Andrews, mother of Archie M. Andrews, chairman of the board of Dictograph Products Company, Inc., died yesterday morning at her home in Pasadena, Calif., according to word received here. Funeral services will be held at the home on Saturday.

The unsettled political situation in Europe and reports indicating that export sales of domestic dark hard Winter wheat had aggregated 1,000,000 bushels sent prices of wheat soaring on the Board of Trade here today. Futures advanced 3 to 31/4 cents a bushel from the early low point, with the close near the top with net gains of 1 3/4 to 1 7/8 cents.

Items aggregating $30,000 found in the records of the electrical contracting firm of Hoffman Elias, 256 West Thirty-first Street, for which explanations of disbursement have not been satisfactory, were the basis yesterday for a State income tax violation charge brought by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey against two members of the firm.

Joseph Schapiro of S. Schapiro Sons, Baltimore, was yesterday reelected president of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers at the concluding session of the organization's twenty-fifth annual convention at the Hotel Astor.

The formation of a chamber orchestra of thirty-six men which will be heard during the next season's subscription series of sixteen concerts of the New Friends of Music at Town Hall was announced yesterday by I. A. Hirschmann,

Federal Judge William H. Holly today appointed Charles True Adams as permanent trustee for the Utilities Power and Light Corporation under Section 77b of the amended Federal Bankruptcy Law.. He said that Mr.

Artur Rubinstein, a brilliant individuality among the leading pianists of the day, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. He has an extraordinary technic, though he is sometimes careless of technical detail, for he is pre-eminently a highly gifted interpreter.

Poland will bring the strongest pressure on Lithuania to end the present state of "no war no peace" on the Polish-Lithuanian border, well-informed circles said tonight. This became known after a conference attended by Marshal Edward Smigly-Rydz, inspector general of the Polish Army (virtual dictator of Poland);

Mrs. Sarah Poultney Ellicott White, for many years active in philanthropic work, died at her home here today aged 74. She and her husband, Francis White, who died in 1930, were leading members of the Socity of Friends.

Marius de-Bruyn, 54 years old, a member of the firm of Von Bremen, Asche, de Bruyn, Inc., importers of liquors and groceries, with offices at 66 Leonard Street ended his life yesterday afternoon by shooting himself in the head in a room on the sixteenth floor of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Tariff concessions granted by Cuba on American-made cigarettes under the reciprocal trade agreement of 1934 are given credit by the Commerce Department for more than a 10,000,000-cigarette yearly increase in exports since 1935, according to a statement issued today.
Dr. A. C. Shoemaker, Pittston banker, died at his home in West Pittston today. His age was 69. A native of Wyoming, Pa., he received a degree in dentistry from the University of Maryland.
Explaining Belgium's policy of independenqe before the Belgian Chamber of Deputies today, Foreign Minister Paul Spaak declared that it was no use to hope for security. from the League of Nations.
Robert Bingham Downs, librarian of the University of North Carolina, has been appointed director of libraries at New York University, effective July 1, to succeed Paul North Rice,

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of March 14, 1938, upon the eligible list of holders of license as laboratory assistant in biology in day secondary schools other than, junior high schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said 1cense:

Counsel for Thomas J. Mooney told the Supreme Court today that the California Supreme Court "has become a party to the frame-up" of the prisoner, who is serving a life sentence for complicity in the 1916 San Francisco Preparedness Day bombing.
Before a crowded Riksdag Prime Minister Per Albin Hansson today asked a special grant of 50,

Continued nervousness over the political situation in Europe caused renewed weakness on the stock market here today, and most sections were subjected to heavy selling. Gilt-edge issues fell sharply, while among the foreign loans Austrian bonds showed a further drop. Transatlantic stocks were traded actively, but their climb to higher levels was restricted by profit taking.

Hugh Tevis, a grandson of former Governor George W. Baxter of Wyoming, has brought suit in Supreme Court to recover $1,805,397 from his mother, Mrs. Constance Leveson Gower, whom he accuses of diverting funds from his inheritance and from trust funds to her
An occasional beneficiary of the West Coast's theatrical joys, Broadway may now look forward to an October production of one of them.

Henry Jenkel, double bass player of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, died Tuesday at the Jay Brown Memorial Hospital in Providence, R. I. Mr. Jenkel was on tour with the orchestra and suffered a stroke after the Monday evening concert in Providence. He was 57 years old.

Every Spring Colonel Jacob Ruppert comes down here to St. Pete to sit in the shade and watch his hirelings work in the sun. Even in the training season he likes to make sure that he is getting a couple of runs for his money.

The Italian liner Vulcania, due late today from the Mediterranean, has among her passengers Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt, widow of the former President; Archbishop Edward Mooney of Detroit, Bishop John A. Duffy of Buffalo and Bishop James A. McFadden of Cleveland.

John Alexander Strauss of New York, firstyear student at the Harvard Law School and formerly one of the editors of The Harvard Advocate, died today of a streptococcus infection at the Phillips House of the Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 23 years old.
Although Britons of all classes-from "dukes to dustmen"-were responding today to the government's call for air-raid. volunteers the largest number of applicants appeared to be among the unemployed.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

Students of the Ridgefield School will present their thirtieth anniversary production this afternoon at the Amateur Comedy Club Theatre, 150 East Thirty-sixth Street. The group will appear in scenes from "Oliver Twist" and in "The Other One," a short play by Arthur Ketchum.

The directors of the. Mortgage Corporation of New York announced yesterday that they had authorized revision of its certificate of incorporation to take advantage of the amendment to the Insurance Law, as signed by Governor Lehman this week, giving trust powers to mortgage corporations organized under this statute.
Sam H. Grisman, theatrical producer and operator of five Broadway houses, disclosed yesterday that he had leased eleven theatres in nine cities between New York and the Pacific coast.

Charles H. Cotton, Civil War veteran, former Assemblyman and for several years Election Commissioner of the old City of Brooklyn, died on Tuesday in his home, 238 Willoughby Avenue, in his ninetyfourth year.

Properties in Yorkville passed to new control in transactions reported yesterday. Four five-story tenement houses at 420, 422, 424 and 426 East Eightieth Street were sold by the Maslor Holding Corporation to a client of Edward V. O'Donnell. Schindler Liebler and S. Henry Schmerz were the brokers.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull was urged yesterday in a telegram signed by Samuel Untermyer, as president of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League, to cancel Amer. ica's. commercial treaty with Austria. and demand the assumption by Germany of the $26,000,000 Austrian war debt to the United States. The message from Mr.

After deliberating an hour and a half, a jury in the Federal court of Judge John P. Barnes, decreed tonight that John Henry Seadlund, 27-yearold Minnesota woodsman, must die for the $50,000 ransom kidnapping of Charles S. Ross of Chicago.

Especially because of the Nazi treatment of Austrian Jews, the United Palestine Appeal and Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, urged increased support for the Jewish national home in Palestine in appeals last night on the eve of the Festival Purim. The occasion,
George H. Atwood, Minnesota lumberman and one time associate of the late James J. Hill and the late Frederick Weyerhaeuser, early rail and lumber leaders. died today at the age of 77.

" The republican government will not tolerate any persecution of Catholics," said Premier Juan Negrin yesterday. "My desire is that the church be permitted to carry on its legitimate activities under the fullest protection that the Constitution affords to all religious denominations, while at the same time regaining independent of all political action."

Miss Elizabeth Claire Rowe, daughter of Mrs. E. Eddy Rowe of this city and of Samuel Davis Rowe of Chicago, has chosen April 22 as the date for her marriage to James Edward Hosac, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wirt Edward Hosac of Bronxville. The ceremony will take place at Graymar, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Graham B. Grosvenor in Westbury, L.I.

In a speech' that failed to awaken the vehement applause attending many past utterances, although warmly cheered in some sections, Premier Mussolini assured the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon that all is well with the Rome-Berlin axis despite what has happened in Austria and that Italy and Germany, united as they are, can march shoulder to shoulder to insure a new European equilibrium.

The Rankin bill, liberalizing pensions for widows and dependents of World War Veterans, has been added to the legislation slated for enactment at this session of Congress, it was disclosed today by leaders.

Persons close to Paul V. McNutt, high commissioner to the Philippines, said today that President Roosevelt was not planning to seek renomination and would discourage any attempts by his admirers to "draft" him for a third term.

Declaring that lower tariffs will involve shutdowns of many mines and smelting properties in the United States, the American Zinc Institute, representing 95 per cent of the domestic zinc industry, said yesterday that dangers to that industry were inherent in the trade
More than in any of their three previous games, the Yankees' line-up resembled regular proportions today as the champions played host to their former neighbors, the Bees, at Waterfront Park.

Appointments The following ununiformed firemen, having completed their probationary period of three months satisfactorily, are appointed as firemen, fourth grade, with compensation each at the rate of $2,000 per annum, to take effect at 9 A. M., March 17:
Mrs. L. Beebe Wilder of Bronxville, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter , Miss Harrison Wilder, to Richard Davis Taylor, son of Dr. and Mrs. Clarence W. Taylor of Duluth, Minn.

Barcelona has been raided by Insurgent bombers at least eight times during this night of terror, and it is only 2 A. M. now. There has been almost no letup for four hours, and the planes are still coming over from Majorca.

The ranks of foreign importations continue to thin. It was learned today that Paramount had declined to exercise its option on Franciska Gaal, Hungarian actress, who has been seen on the American screen in "The Buccaneer."
A weird caravan which for months has been carrying the Panchen Lama's body toward Tibet was halted today at Kanze by bickerings between his partisans and those of the late Dalai Lama.

A solemn high mass of requiem for the Very Rev. Mother Marie Majoux, Superior General of the Society of the Cenacle, was celebrated yesterday at 10 A. M. in the chapel of the Cenacle of St. Regis, Riverside Drive and 140th Street.

The annual report of the Arnold Constable Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries, including the 721 Fifth Avenue Corporation, issued yesterday by Isaac Liberman, president, shows a net profit of $253,336 for the year ended on Jan. 31.
The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids on 1,435,600 yards of textiles, as follows (dated March 18, to be opened March 25, for delivery May 10):

The president, vice president and secretary of Campagnoli Co. of 41 Broad Street, dealers in overthe-counter unlisted securities, were arrested yesterday at the office of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., who charged them with stealing $165,000 worth of customers' stocks.
Retail credit collections during February dropped 1.14 per cent under the same month last year, according to the twenty-store index issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York.

Mayor LaGuardia threatened yesterday to turn on the city's street lights a half hour later in the future to save the city's money for needed projects that now are being hampered by "injunction suits" and "$12,000 and $15,000 salaries for lazy payroll loafers."

Emmanuel M. Cohan, trustee of Series K certificate issue of the State Title and Mortgage Company, has sold to an investor for cash through Henry Brinsley and Samuel Hurwitz, co-brokers, the two two-story apartment and store buildings at 28-14 and 28-16 Fortyfirst Avenue, Long Island City.

Mrs. Payne Whitney's 5-year-old Brush Hook scored a thrilling head victory over the Millsdale Stable's Infantry in the mile and sixty yards of the fifth race, best offering on today's Tropical Park program.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers, in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday, approved a modified plan of reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act for Adelphi College at Garden City, L. I. The plan had been previously agreed upon by the trustees of the college, the holders of mortgage certificates and other creditors. In giving his approval Judge Byers said:
The German Embassy took possession of the Austrian Legation today and

Nine prizes were awarded yesterday in the forty-second annual exhibition by artists of Chicago and vicinity at the Art Institute of Chicago, which opens with a reception this afternoon, according to an announcement here.

The tunnel approach to the George Washington Bridge at the Manhattan end has been completed and will be opened within a few weeks, when there will be a reorganization of the street 'routes used by buses going to and from the bridge in Washington Heights, it was learned yesterday.
After about a. half-hour more of general debate tomorrow, the House.of Representatives will begin consideration of amendments to the Administration's $1,120,000,000 naval construction bill.

The most tragic and inconsistent field in the recent history of the Grand National Steeplechase, to be renewed at Aintree on March 25, was reduced today to forty with Royal Mail, recently purchased by Mrs. Camille Clifford Evans, a clear favorite.

The indications are for rain and slightly warmer weather today, followed by generally fair and colder weather tonight and tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

After a violent quarrel in their flat on the top floor of a three-story tenement at 666 Lorimer Street, Brooklyn, about 3:30 P. M. yesterday, Louis Tazzalo, 48 years old, owner of a candy store on the ground floor, slashed his wife, Mary, with a bread knife and committed suicide by shooting himself through the head, according to the police.

General Robert E. Wood, president of Sears, Roebuck Co., was elected a director of the United Fruit Company at the annual meeting of stockholders held in Jersey City yesterday, bringing membership of the board to seventeen.

Arnold Lunn, president of the Kandahar Ski Club, telephoning from St. Anton, Austria, said tonight that the Arlberg-Kandahar ski races scheduled there for Saturday and Sunday had been canceled today because of the Nazi arrest of Hannes Schneider, Arlberg club president, on unstated charges.

Stock, nervous over European crisis, closed lower, erasing Tuesday's gains; turnover, 1,023,500 shares. Foreign bonds weakened 1 to 14 1/2 points; United States Government and other issues lower; transactions, $7,237,425.

William O Wall of Augusta, Ga., general claim agent for the Georgia and Florida Railroad since 1914 and also general safety and publicity agent for the railroad, died in the Hotel Pennsylvania, shortly after his arrival yesterday. He was 56 years old.

Armed with orders to buy $2,000,000 worth of merchandise for "Jack Gordon Day" to be held early next month, the contingent' of thirtythree buyers of Goldblatt Brothers, Chicago, arrived here yesterday.

A rise of about $1.50 a bale in the price of middling cotton in Liverpool brought an improvement in early trading on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday and the May delivery again reached 9 cents a pound.
The Governor signed several local bills, and in a short statement congratulated the Legislature for passing the Savings Bank Life Insurance Bill.

With thirty players competing, the qualifying rounds in the biennial tournament for the chess championship of the United States under the auspices of the National Chess Federation will get under way tonight at the Marshall Chess Club, Manhattan Chess Club and the West Side Y. M. C. A. Chess Club.
Strictly National Socialist party organs are already beginning to concentrate attention on about 200,000 Austrian Jews.

The St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company, known as the Cotton Belt, protested today to the Interstate Commerce Commission against the plan for its reorganization proposed by J. V. Walsh, examiner, which would reduce the interest in the road of the Southern Pacific Company from 87.37 per cent to 47.43 per cent.

Social workers in New York City this week reported relief clients coming into district welfare offices to "ask whether all relief has been stopped." Of course relief has not been stopped and, so long as there is need, will not be stopped.

Vinton Freedley, theatrical producer, returned yesterday on the Ile de France after an absence of four weeks. One of the objects of his trip was to ascertain whether a London musical show, "Going der Greek," bore any resemblance to his forthcoming musical comedy, "Greek to You."

The five-story building containing seventy-five rooms at 204 West 133d Street and the adjoining structure at 206 have been leased by Bradhurst Properties to a client of Lord's Valuation Service, broker in the deal in conjunction with M. J. Williams.
Water flowed over Niagara's ice bridge tonight as Spring temperatures shrank the greatest jam in the history of the gorge.

The Interstate Commerce Commission facilitated higher rate levels for the motor carrier industry when it issued an order today waiving the usual requirements and permitted the filing of a master tariff.
The toll of dead from the tornado which smashed through parts of Illinois and Missouri rose to nineteen today, as four additional fatalities were counted.

102d St, 334 E; 6-story tenement and store, 37.6x100.11, parcel 1 also 102d St, 336 E; 6-story tenement and store, 37.6x 100.11, parcel 2; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against John B. Ganzza, due on parcel 1, $26,804, taxes, etc., $1,489; on parcel 2, $26,073. taxes, etc., $1,099; to plaintiff for $1,000 each.

Irene Dunne, screen actress, and her husband, Dr. Francis Griffin, have adopted a 4-year-old girl whom they have named Mary Frances Dunne, it was learned yesterday at the County Clerk's office, where the adoption order is on file.

The last main contention in the defense of Mrs. Patricia Ryan was threshed out yesterday in Bronx County Court when psychiatrists clashed over the question of Mrs. Ryan's sanity on the morning of Oct. 31,

St. Paul's Episcopal Church, built in 1834 and one of the oldest Episcopal churches on Long Island, was adjudged today as "unsafe for public use and public worship" by Building Inspector Fred Ringrose.

New Rochelle, by taking five of seven first places, outclassed the rest of the field and retained the high school championship trophy in the annual Westchester games at the County Center tonight. The wearers of the Purple totaled 39 points to second-place Tuckahoe's 8.

Working at top speed in an effort to insure adjournment this week, the Assembly and Senate pressed through heavy calendars today, passing 180 bills, most of which were of minor or local significance. The Assembly took action on 101 bills, while the Senate passed 79.

George Breck Montgomery, general superintendent of construction for the Lincoln Tunnel, died of a heart attack yesterday at Miami Beach, Fla., according to a telegram received here by the Mason Hangar Contracting Company, with which he was associated. He was 57 years old and lived on Comstock Hill. Norwalk, Conn.

New business to the amount of more than $100,000,000 has been recorded on the books of the Federal Housing Administration since President Roosevelt signed on Feb. 3 the bill amending the Federal Housing Act, Administrator Stewart McDonald announced today.

The Giants spent a rather enjoyable afternoon "down on the farm" today, when they motored over from their Baton Rouge training camp, carefully inspected Travis Jackson's Jersey City hirelings and the proceeded to bowl over said hirelings in the ensuing exhibition game by a score of 11 to 4.

Longmans, Green announces for publication in October a book on George Gershwin by his friends, which will be edited and designed by Merle Armitage. In addition to containing unpublished photographs of George Gershwin, some sixteen of his paintings will be reproduced.

Miss Marion Miley, Lexington, Ky., playing with a sprained ankle, paired with Miss Virginia Guilfoil, Syracuse, N. Y., today in the first eighteen holes of the Aiken women's round-robin golf tournament and broke even against the medalwinning team of Miss Kathryn Hemphill, Columbia, S. C., and Miss Helen Dettweiler, Washington, D. C.

A rise of 2 points in steel ingot production to 32 per cent of the country's capacity has occurred this week without material aid from the automobile industry, the railroads or building construction, Iron Age says, the improvement coming mainly from miscellaneous sources, being partly seasonal in character and partly due to depletion of inventories.

With European markets, including London, in a panicky state yesterday over "war scares," security and commodity markets in the United States lost no time in taking the cue. Leading stocks were down 1 to 5 points on the day, and the turnover on the Stock Exchange reached 1,023,000 shares, the heaviest since Feb. 23.

After ousting a C. I. O. crew and signing on a crew of A. F. of L. seamen, the government- owned freighter, Independence Hall, sailed from its dock in Hoboken at 11:30 o'clock last night, more than twelve hours after it was scheduled to depart.

The reactions yesterday in the security and commodity markets to the over-night developments in Europe were somewhat different from those that normally would have been expected. It is true that grain prices advanced, but copper, which is essential in military operations, lost ground.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Macy Willets have come from New Marlboro, Mass., to the Berkshire. Mrs. Richard S. Aldrich has returned from Boca Grande, Fla., and is with her daughter, Mrs. Samuel Spencer of Washington, at the Ambassador before going to her home in Providence.

As the result of a treaty signed recently between Brazil and Bolivia, according to the Department of Commerce, both countries have agreed to construct railroads meeting in the interior of South America to aid in developing oil resources in the Bolivian sub-Andean zone.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Hall of Merion and Fieldstone Farm, Langhorne, Pa., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Kirk Hall, to John James Boericke Jr., son of Mrs. Boericke of

Conservative real estate men whose activity is centered in Long Island have been watching with more than their usual interest lately the trend of trading and of prices within the zone of influence of the World's Fair of 1939.
Members of the Cribside Social Service Committee of the Babies Hospital will hold their annual Spring sale in behalf of that organization tomorrow at the Nearly New Shop, 917 Eighth. Avenue.

Mrs. Grace Lewis, first president of the Northern Valley branch of the American Association of University Women and program chairman of the Englewood Woman's Club, died at her home here today after a long illness.

Cornelius Washington Kievit of 112 Gregory Avenue, Passaic, N. J., formerly advertising manager of The Passaic Daily News, now The Herald-News, died last night at the home of a son here. His age was 83. Mr. Kievit joined The News in 1900 and retired in 1926.

The Denver Safeways, 1937 national champions, and the Bartlesville (Okla.) Phillips, runners-up last year, moved into the National A. A. U. basketball tournament's quarter-finals tonight along with the four other seeded teams.

The second and third seeded pairs gained the quarter-final round yesterday in the fifth annual invitation mixed doubles tennis tournament at the Island Court Club of Long Island City. Mrs. George B. Cabot and Henry Breck, No. 2, and Miss Helen Bernhard and Jack S. McDermott, third on the list, were the successful teams.

Approximately 5 cents of the price paid for a $1.50 silk necktie and barely 8 cents of every dollar spent for silk stockings goes to Japan in payment for the raw silk used in such articles, Dr. Roy H. Akagi, counsellor to the South Manchuria Railway Company, asserted yesterday in a speech in which he defended Japan's activities in China and attacked the boycott movement here.

Retail stores comprised a large part of the business renting reported yesterday in the city. Mary S. Reynolds took the store at 435 Park Avenue, at Fifty-sixth Street, for an interior decorator's and gift shop.

The unflagging interest of the public in the Metropolitan's current presentation of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" was evident in the vast audience which attended the season's eighth performance of the work at the Broadway house last night.

A proposal that the Federal Communications Commission conduct an inquiry to prove or disprove charges that a radio monopoly exists was filed with the commission today by one of its members, T. A. M. Craven.

Pleading for an agreement between finance and agriculture for an "equilibrium dollar" whose value in terms of commodities would be regulated by the amount of money in circulation, Senator Thomas of Oklahoma yesterday charged Washington with initiating the present recession last March as a "deliberate and premeditated" step.

Mrs. Hortense Odlum, president of Bonwit Teller, has applied in Supreme Court for an annulment of her marriage to Dr. Porfilio Dominici, which took place in Paris on March 3, 1936, it became known yesterday.

Chinese guerrilla raids and smashing counter-attacks have pushed the Japanese back In several sectors and stopped them in the others. From Shansi Province, which the Japanese overran in a big offensive a week ago, came reports that the Chinese had recaptured Linfen and were making strong attacks on Chaocheng and Hwohsien.

Three New York Stock Exchange memberships were sold yesterday for $62,000, $60,000 and $60,000. Contrary to rumors in Wall Street, these were not the three seats belonging to Richard Whitney Co. The last previous sale, on March 1, was made at $67,000.

The semi-annual sinking fund requirements of the Czechoslovakian State loan of 1922 have been completed by the purchase of sufficient bonds in the open market below par, according to an announcement yesterday by Kuhn, Loeb Co.; the National City Bank and Kidder Peabody Co.

The General Investment Corporation applied yesterday in Supreme Court for permission to join one of its minority stockholders in a suit against various former directors, other individuals, the American General Corporation, the Amerex Holding Corporation, the Chase National Bank and the Trinway Corporation.
Five prize-winning choral works of the nation-wide competition sponscored by the Federal Music Project of New York City in cooperation with Carl Fischer, Inc.,

Congress should legislate sweeping changes in the nation's rail set-up, Fred W. Sargent, president of the Chicago North Western Railroad, said today. Testifying before a Senate subcommittee studying railroad financing, Mr. Sargent asserted the principal features of such legislation should include:

Tonight's major events: Philharmonic Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; "Don Giovanni," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15 P. M. Nelson Eddy, baritone, will appear in his only New York recital of the season Saturday evening at the Westchester County. Center in White Plains.

Manager Burleigh Grimes today made tentative application for some early season right-field insurance, the move apparently being inspired by the possibility that Heinie Manush may stage a real holdout.
Economists of the Department of Agriculture said today that the level of prices of farm products declined about 24 per cent in the last year, but that retail food prices did not fall correspondingly.

Immediately after his triumphant return today from the conquest of Austria by which he created, without firing a shot, a "Greater Germany" that is greater in territory and population than Imperial Germany before the World War, Chancellor Hitler issued a summons for the Reichstag to meet Friday at 8 P. M.

Elimination of the defending women's champion marked the fourth day of the Bermuda title tennis competition today. Miss Helen Pedersen of Stamford, Conn., holder of the crown, lost to Mrs. Virginia Rice Johnson of Boston, ranked thirteen in the United States, in a quarter-final match, 6--4, 0--6, 6--0.

A group of prominent industrialists, most of whom were at one time farm boys, met here today on the Cornell campus with a group of Northeastern States dirt farmers to discuss their mutual problems, as guests of the New York State Col- RE lege of Agriculture.
European influences governed Wall Street markets yesterday. Uncertainties in Central Europe and Spain caused one of the heaviest and most erratic trading periods in recent months.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., headed the successful banking group yesterday in the purchase of a new issue of $1,100,000 of public improvement bonds of the city of Rochester, N. Y.

Frank J. Taylor, former Controller, has quit as a member of the Brooklyn Advisory Planning Board, it was announced yesterday by Borough President Ingersoll. Louis C. Wills, former president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, was appointed to the vacancy.

Enactment of Senate Bill 1891, just introduced in the Legislature by Senator Esquirol, would "create a price monopoly for the exclusive benefit of distillers and wholesalers and would deprive all of the retail dealers in the State of New York of the privilege of purchasing fine wines and other alcoholic beverages directly from foreign sources,"

Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church yesterday ordered Hallgarten Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co. to account to the Bondholders Committee for Republic of Colombia for their actions as fiscal agents for a $9,000,000 issue of 6 1/2 per cent gold bonds of Medellin, Colombia, which has been in default since 1931.
The horses that once clattered-before they got rubber shoesthrough the streets of New York pulling noisy milk wagons will soon go to the green pastures that years ago took the horse-car dobbin.
Forrester Scott, Philadelphia lawyer, and Stanley Boynton, Springfield, Mass., aviator, were charged with attempted kidnapping at 9 o'clock tonight.

Lawrenceville School's crack indoor polo team defeated the Princeton varsity, 16 to 10, today in the 112th Field Artillery Armory for its third victory over the Tiger first-string trio this season. Getting off to a good start at the outset of the match, the Laurentians swung into the lead in the opening period and were in command thereafter.

A group of young women qualified for special detective work by education and by experience in any of a wide variety of activities, such as theatrical appearances, newspaper reporting, nursing, athletics, stenography or social work, will be established through a civil service examination for-policewomen to be held in about two weeks.

The Power Authority of the State of New York urged the Federal Power Commission today to permit it to intervene in the Niagara Falls Power Company license proceedings, stating that if permission were granted it would present a plan for coordinating Niagara and St. Lawrence and other power resources of the State.
Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch, Now it answering interpellations in Parliament today, declared: "The Little Entente was established originally against the Habsburgs rather than against Hungary.

Electric-power production declined last week, running counter to seasonal and long-term trends, and the adjusted index has declined to 92.6 from 94.1. The figure was 107.9 for the week ended March 13, 1937.

After a night's sleep and a "realistic reexamination" of High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt's radio address with his Cabinet, Commonwealth President Manuel Quezon announced today that he cannot agree to postponement of Philippine independence" or to permanent continuation of American sovereignty with all the fences that he thinks Commissioner McNutt proposes to put around the Philippine Government.
Frau Alwine Dollfuss, widow of assassinated Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss of Austria, and her two children left Budapest today for Italy.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is redemption agent for the outstanding scrip certificates issued in connection with the sale of common stock of the Outboard, Marine and Manufacturing Company.

Since the beginning of hearings on the proposed reciprocal trade agreement with Great Britain gave public notice that this negotiation has attained practical status, a small statistical and economic war has been fought on the desk of this correspondent.

Adoption of the new constitution of the New York Stock Exchange is expected tomorrow, for 983 ballots have been cast and sentiment in Wall Street is reported heavily in favor of the change. Ballots will continue to be accepted until the close of the market today.

Trading was generally only fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were held at stronger prices; the lamb market was steady to lower; fresh pork cuts uneven; other classes unchanged. Early trading in Kosher meats indicated beef to be stronger, lamb lower, veal and calf steady, as reported by The United States Department of Agriculture.

On behalf of 1,000,000 railway employes, the Railway Labor Executives Association declared today that it would resist the attempt of the carriers to reduce wages because the move was deflationary, would likely "inspire a nation-wide attack upon the entire wage structure" and would "produce national chaos."

Ralph C. Stiefel, known as the inventor of a machine for making seamless steel tubes, died in his Winter home here last night. He was 76 years old. Mr. Stiefel, who came here from Ellwood City, Pa., was a retired mechanical engineer and a graduate of Zurich University in Switzerland. zerland.

Under contracts announced yesterday, The Netherlands, Liberia, Finland and Luxembourg will transplant cross-sections of their national life to the 1939 World's Fair. The Netherlands exhibit will be the largest, including its colonial empire.

Traversing the thirty-one holes played in ten under par, the all-Chicago team of Dick Metz and Ky Laffoon won the annual international four-ball golf tournament at the Miami Country Club today, trouncing Ben Hogan of White Plains, N. Y., and Willie Goggin of San Francisco in the final by 6 and 5.

Authorities increased their pressure on newspaper correspondents today. Uniformed Storm Troop men entered the office of The Associated Press and took into custody Willy Jacobson, German-born veteran photographer, who is half-Jewish. There was no charge and no explanation.

Mrs. Frederic Van Lennep, a descendant of distinguished Connecticut families, died on Tuesday night of a heart attack in her home, 157 East Seventy-second Street. She was the former Miss Anita Trumbull. Her husband, who died many years ago, was a banker and broker and a member of an old New York Dutch family.

The government's weekly report of crop conditions issued yesterday follows: Except locally in the East, the week favored small grains, some heaving was reported in more northern sections and the drought is still unrelieved in portions of the Southeast, where oats are suffering.

Frank Knox, Chicago publisher, told North Carolina Republicans today that the American people should decide whether they wanted democracy and free competition or planned economy and a government vested in a supreme executive authority.

Cease and desist orders against Swift Co. on four counts dealing with the company's methods of selling meat and meat products to New York hotels and restaurants were under consideration by Secretary Wallace today.
Professor Thurman W. Arnold, who wrote "The Folk Lore of Capitalism," has had a satisfactory talk with Senator Borah.

The American Commercial Alcohol Corporation and wholly owned subsidiaries shows a profit for 1937 amounting to $1,043,117 after provision for doubtful accounts, interest, depreciation, normal Federal income tax and $31,133 surtax on undistributed income, according to the annual report of Russell R. Brown, president, issued today.

The House Merchant Marine Committee unanimously approved a resolution today calling on the Maritime Commission to retain in intercoastal trade three Pan Pacific line steamers the commission is negotiating to buy. The commission opposed the resolution.

Mrs. Dodge Sloane entertained with a large dinner at Concha Marina today. -Lady Borwick and Sir Gordon Ley.gave a dinner at Whitehall. Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Jergens were hosts to a large group for cocktails at Villa Amandri.
A courtship of forty-three years, begun in a church choir, ended in a honeymoon today for Charles Rudolph Dieffenbach and Miss Louise Sundermann, the bride he has never seen.
Former President Herbert Hoover left this afternoon by train for Stockholm, Sweden, in President Kyosti Kallio's private coach. Crowds gathered along the route for L glimpse of the popular visitor.
An investigation of the activities of the medical board of the City Department of Education and of Dr. Emil Altman, chief examiner, was advocated yesterday by the New York Teachers Guild.

Complete occupation of Caspe is expected to be effected tonight by the Insurgents, who have already encircled the city. A large force had been sent back, after the Insurgents had pushed thirty miles beyond, to mop up this menace to the left flank.
Prince Argo, owned and trained by Butsy Hernandez, came through with a surprise victory in the, sixfurlong ,dash for 3-year-olds which toppled the Fair Grounds card today.

Conferences were started here today looking to an early settlement of the conflict between the Tennessee Valley Authority and private power companies in the Southeast, and thus to activation of the longdelayed utilities construction drive throughout the country.

Everybody's Thrift Shop, 922 Third Avenue, held its annual ing yesterday at the home of Mrs. Rufus Patterson, 15 East Sixty-fifth Street. Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell was re-elected president for the coming year.
A program devoted to music by Johan Franco, Netherlands composer, was heard yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. It listed the Second Piano Sonata, written in 1933-34;

Building projects submitted terday included plans for a store building in Manhattan, three dwellings in the Bronx, an apartment and other houses in Brooklyn and numerous houses in Queens. The plans follow:
A Senate subcommittee heard the penalty provisions of the Borah- ma O'Mahoney industrial licensing bill termed today the "most drastic ever suggested in a Federal statute."

The Senate Finance Committee will open hearings tomorrow on the revenue bill, with R. V. Fletcher, general counsel to the Association of American Railroads, as the first witness. Other witnesses scheduled to appear include Henry H. Heinmann of the National Association of Credit Men, Donald Craig, representing the American Retail Federation, and Bond Geddes, for the National Association of Radio Manufacturers.

Surgeon General Thomas Parran of the Public Health Service, speaking as a doctor and not as an economist, urged Congress today to provide, "at whatever cost," useful Ar employment to those able and willing to work and to establish a national health program for the poor and underprivileged.
Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Thorne, who will leave Sunday for a six weeks' stay at Claremont, their home in Columbia, S. C., gave a dinner last night at the Ambassador.

A novel and interesting loan exhibition opened yesterday at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street. "Architecture as it has been portrayed by artists" is the theme, and the works assembled range from paintings by Italian primitives to oils, water-colors, prints and drawings by our contemporaries. Museums,
Noel Coward returns in his new musical romance, "Operette," presented at His Majesty's Theatre tonight, to the backstage life of Edwardian London which fascinated him in "Bitter Sweet."

The newly formed squadron of the Sons of the American Legion, of which the United Manhattan Post is the sponsor, will receive a charter at 8 P. M. tomorrow at the Capitol Hotel from Commander Joseph J. Burkhard of the New York American Legion.

German in-dustry has already begun to dream of Austria as an immense source of electric power to be carried over a united system to all parts of the Reich. No adequate survey of Austria's potential waterpower is available, but the amount of current so produced has doubled since the war, and electricity has largely taken the place of coal in industry;

Flagging interest in the Anglo-Irish talks has been received with the disclosure that Viscount Craigavon, Premier of Northern Ireland, is coming to London tomorrow for a conference with Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Malcolm MacDonald, Secretary for the Dominions.

Fresh from their victory over the Black Hawks and still fighting to hold their slender claim to second place in the International Group of the National Hockey League, Red Dutton's Americans will clash with the Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight.

A FRENCH family named Pasquier, of Paris and thereabouts, reappears upon our literary scene. Father. and mother and offspring, they are the chief characters in a massive novel by Georges Duhamel, the first five books of which are published today in a translation by Beatrice de Holthoir, as "The Pasquier Chronicles."*

Dr. Norman Bethune, Montreal surgeon, and Miss Jane Ewen, a Van-couver nurse, are safe and well In Sian, the Shensi capital, according. to word received here. The two, who left here recently to join the Eighth Route Army's medical service, had been missing for nearly two weeks.
The seriousness of the present inIternational situation was brought home to the British public this morning -with this announcement in The Times of London:
Paul Easterling's double in the eleventh today gave the Athletics an uphill 4-to-3 victory over Beaumont of the Texas League. Two were out when the winning run scored.

During the week ended March 16 member bank reserve balances increased $17,000,000. Additions to member banks reserve arose from decreases of $6,000,000 in money in circulation, $12,000,000 in Treasury cash and.

There is not a Bridget or Michael in this German populated town of 275, but every Herman and Frieda wore green today in honor of John Stewart, this town's St. Patrick. The story is that Stewart, a son of Erin who settled here in 1816, drove out the snakes here.
President Roosevelt will resume tomorrow his personal investigation of the row in the directorate of the Tennessee Valley Authority with the three disputants again before him.

In addition to an English and a German as well as Pacific Coast and Great Lakes yachts in the Bermuda race in June, Count Pehar Sparre of Sweden decided yesterday to enter the schooner Manitou with an "all-New England crew," as he said.

The Soviet res Union stepped to the forefront of the the troubled international scene today with a proposal for an immediate conference of most of the powers, including the United States. but excluding Germany, Japan and Italy, to deal with the menace to world peace presented by the current and aggressive acts in Central and Eastern Europe that threaten to be extended still further.

A vote on the vital section of the Byrnes Reorganization Bill remained blocked by a "baby filibuster" today while Senator Barkley, majority leader, and Senator Wheeler, leader of the insurgents, continued a drive for votes.

Following is the text of the proposal made in, Moscow yesterday by Foreign Commissar Maxim M. Litvinoff calling for a conference of most of the world's powers in an effort to halt aggression. The translated text was given out by Tass, official Soviet news agency.

The property known as 72-6 West Thirty-sixth Street, part of which is occupied by Keen's Chop House, was sold at auction yesterday to the Greenwich Savings Bank, plaintiff, for $160,000 in satisfaction of a judgment of $191,148 against Clemcois Realty Corporation.

Earnings and sales of the Eastman Kodak Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries in 1937 were the largest in the history of the company, according to the thirty-fifth annual report, to be made public today by W. G. Stuber, chairman, and F. W. Lovejoy, president.
Several sections of Northern Vermont and New Hampshire tonight reported good prospects for another weekend of skiing, but a majority of ski centers were in poor shape.
Augustus P. Loring, lawyer, former State Senator and retired president of the Plymouth Cordage Company, died suddenly today at his home, 277 Marlboro Street. He was 81 years old.

Shipments of canned tuna fish from Japan during 1937 totaled 583,761 cases, an increase of 208,829 cases, or 55.7 per cent, compared with 1936, according to a consular report from Tokyo, made public today by the Department of Commerce.
Sixty-one paintings from the estate of Marie Louise Paterson (Mrs. Robert Paterson), 280 Park Avenue, brought $49,582 last night at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries. Inc.

Approximately 20,000 officers and men under Major Gen. Charles D. Herron today began the Hawaii Department's annual manoeuvres. For fifteen days the soldiers will test the efficiency of the army's greatest troop concentration here and determine their ability to defend Oahu Island and Pearl Harbor.

Every seat in the Metropolitan Opera House has been sold for the benefit matinee today of "Parsifal," which has been taken over by the Alliance for Guidance of Rural Youth (formerly the Southern Women's Educational Alliance).
The Legislature moved along all day and far into the night to pass hundreds of bills as the members of both houses worked toward adjournment, finally set for 5 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

The New York Stock Exchange has stricken from listing and registration the George A. Fuller Company's $6 cumulative and participating prior preferred stock, no-par value, and $6 cumulative and participating second preferred stock, also no-par. These securities were suspended from dealings on March 7.

The marriage of Miss Constance Hope, daughter of Mrs. Eugene Bernstein of this city and the late Mr. Bernstein, to Dr. Milton L. Berliner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lazar Berliner, also of New York, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Bache Kayser, 18 East Seventy-first Street.

A few recovery movements by certain foreign dollar loans did not alter the broad downward course in bond prices yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. In slightly less active trading, pivotal issues in almost all of the major groups sank to new low levels in an unusually thin market.

The Treasury Department has leased for its Unemployment Census Bureau an area of 100,000 square feet in the building at 63 Vesey Street, where 3,200 workers will tabulate and file in vaults 60,000,000 cards. The Cross Brown Company arranged the lease.

The Weehawken Trust Company has sold the two-story business building at 529-31 Bergenline Avenue, on the corner of Schley Place, West New York, N. J., for investment to the 531 Bergenline Corportion, through J. I. Kislak, Inc., who will manage the property.
Francis E. Miller, manager of the metropolitan New York division of Seagram Distillers Corporation, has resigned, it was announced yesterday.
Capital hostesses received a temporary respite today from the first major problem of who-sitswhere at dinners since the Dolly Gann-Alice Longworth feud.

The Netherlands Chamber of Commerce in New York, Inc., entertained its president. J. Louis van Zelm, at a luncheon at the Netherland Club yesterday W. P. Montijn, The Netherlands Consul General here, presented to Mr. van Zelm the Officers' Cross of the Order of Orange-Nassau, conferred upon him by Queen Wilhelmina.

Cardinal Hayes issued a pastoral to the priests of the Archdiocese of New York yesterday in which he announced it was his "earnest prayer" that each Catholic would respond this year to the annual Appeal of Catholic Charities, which will be formally made during the week beginning March 27.

With all those things threatened for which France has stood during the last twenty years-national independence, personal liberty, collective security and peace-the Chamber of Deputies today spent five hours discussing the necessity of a national union government.
Miss Margaret F. Prentiss will give a dinner tonight in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Olive Sewall and Robert Herne Charles, whose engagement has been announced.

Since the ban was removed about a month ago on the granting of loans to industry by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, "quite a number" of applications have been received at regional offices, Jesse H. Jones, chairman, said today.

The Italian liner Vulcania arrived late yesterday, twelve hours behind schedule, after a stormy crossing from Mediterranean ports via Gibraltar, Lisbon and the Azores. Several promenade deck windows were smashed by seas in route and two heavy doors opening on the crew deck forward were damaged. None of the 525 passengers was injured, the officers said.

Government invasion of two important fields in banking-savings and housing-constitutes a serious problem, Henry S. Sherman, president of the Society for Savings, Cleveland, and president of the savings division of the American Bankers Association, asserted here today in an address at a regional conference of bankers of Indiana and eight other States in this area.

Mrs. Barger Wallach and Frank Shields, No. 1 seeded pair in the fifth annual invitation mixed doubles tennis tournament at the Island Court Club, Inc., yesterday made their way into the quarterfinal round of the event without having to take to the courts.

Wheat prices dropped around 11/2 cents a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today, the war scare in Europe seeming to have subsided. Much of the day's activity was at the opening and at the close.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

Elton E. (Tad) Wieman, the silent man of Princeton football who let his lines speak for him during his six years as assistant to Fritz Crisler here, sat in the seat of his erstwhile, chief today and exploded the myth of his taciturnity and dislike for the rostrum.
The Reichsbank's statement as of March 15 shows the following changes from the preceding .week, in thousands of marks:

The New Jersey Library Association's junior members' round table has near completion a catalogue which will make accessible to the public thousands of rare books owned by New Jersey collectors, it was learned today.
Three creditors petitioned Federal court yesterday for reorganization of the Continental Securities Corporation, a holding company, which has offices here and in Jersey City.
Lumber production increased more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index advanced to 64.6 from 62.1. The figure was 80.4 for the week ended March 13, 1937.

War Admiral's trainers, who term the 1937 "horse of the year," the perfect racer, predicted today he would beat the fleet Seabiscuit in the Dixie Handicap at Pimlico, May 11. "The only bad habit the horse has," Trainer George Conway said, "is his behavior at the gate. He's too anxious. But outside of that he's a wonderful little animal."

The Nicholas Murray Butler permanent intercollegiate philatelic trophy will be-presented at a dinner at 7 o'clock tonight to Robert B. Sykes Jr. of Brown University for the best entry in the first annual intercollegiate philatelic exhibition, now on view in the lounge of John Jay Hall, Columbia University, under the auspices of Filatelikus, campus stamp society.

In an effort to find a way to reduce-foreclosure expenses in this State, the Home Owners Loan Corporation has instituted its first two proceedings in the Federal Court for the Eastern District in Brooklyn.

Trailing by two goals in the first period, the Rangers waged a brilliant offensive to turn back their city rivals, the Americans, in the final meeting of the regular National Hockey League season between the two local sextets at Madison Square Garden last night.

W. Bruce Cobb, former chief attorney for the Legal Aid Society, was sworn in by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday as a justice of the Children's Court to succeed Justice Thomas C. Brown, whose term expired last Tuesday.

A hobby garden, a popular demonstration of 2,000 inexpensive plants designed to encourage amateurs to devote some of their leisure time to horticulture, won yesterday afternoon one of the coveted gold medals of the International Flower Show at the Grand Central Palace.

Herman A. Gray, chairman of the New -York State Unemployment Insurance Advisory Council, told the Senate Unemployment Committee today that before the maximum advantage could be derived from the unemployment compensation system its underlying principles would have to be reconsidered and fundamentally revised.

A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., offered publicly yesterday a new issue of $1,085,000 of city of Waterbury, Conn., 23/4 per cent street and general improvement and funding bonds, at prices to yield from 0.75 to 2.75 per cent, according to maturity.

An increase in notes in circulation and larger holdings of pounds sterling and of United States dollars were disclosed today in the Bank of Canada's statement for the week ended March 16. The volume of Dominion Government deposits was slightly off.

As had been expected, the weekly Federal Reserve report showed a large shift in the system's portfolio of "governments." Holdings of bonds rose $20,912,000, while holdings of notes declined a like amount. Most of this switch probably represented the system's conversion of maturing notes into bonds on March 15.

A net profit of $1,290,884 for 1937 was reported yesterday by the Niles - Bement- Pond Company of New Jersey and subsidiaries after deductions for depreciation, Federal income taxes, surtax on undistributed profits, $83,744 write-off of a worthless investment and $100,000 additional reserve for inventory shrinkage.
Various garden club prizes were awarded yesterday at the International Flower Show. Prizes given by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York, Inc.,follow:
Albert R. Knight, former executive of an oil company, was sentenced today to serve a term of three to ten years in the Delaware County Prison for arson.

Virginia C. Gildersleeve, dean of Barnard College and president of the International Federation of University Women, urged the university women of Canada to carry on the ideals of the federation in promoting understanding, friendship and cooperation among nations.
The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is studying the feasibility of a merger of the Chicago North Western and the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroads.

Countess Alice Hoyos, a descenddant of John Brevard, General Washington's adjutant, and John C. Ten Eyck Jr., whose grandfather was the late John C. Breckinridge, onetime Vice President of the United States, were married here yesterday morning. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of the Municipal Building by Robert T. Tudor.

A definite program for the small business men of the country will be established during the first national convention of the National Small Business Men's Association to be held some time in June, DeWitt M. Emery of Akron, Ohio, founder and president of the association, said here yesterday.

Release from prison of 372 Japanese educators, Members of Parliament, writers, labor leaders and workers was asked yesterday in a petition sent to the Japanese Ambassador by 100 liberals, labor leaders, artists, writers and educators in this country. The petition was made public by Vito Marcantonio, president of the International Labor Defense.

W. C. Stroube's Huskie Boy, the only 3-year-old in the field and longest priced of the five starters, romped to a hollow victory in the St. Patrick's Handicap before a good-sized crowd at Tropical Park today. The Bull Dog colt, a 7-to-1 shot, registered by five lengths, running the five and a half furlongs in 1:061-5. The track was fast despite light morning showers.

Lawrence Russell, retired lawyer and son of the late Justice Leslie W. Russell of the New York Supreme Court, died suddenly of a stroke yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Otto Bauermeister, at 169-32 Twenty-fourth Avenue, Flushing. His age was 70.

The Liechtenstein Diet's unanimous decision to maintain the principality's independence and treaties is deemed in Swiss circles to be all to the good but it has not seriously diminished the apprehension over this tiny country's fate at the hands of Chancellor Hitler.

A large tract of land in the immediate vicinity of the World's Fair grounds, lying between ForestHills and Corona, has been purchased by the N. K. Winston Development Company, Norman K. Winston, president, builders of many Long Island homes and apartments.

That financial markets would be thrown into great confusion by Germany's seizure of Austria, and by the subsequent rumors or conjectures regarding Germany's further attitude and the attitude of other Governments, was quite inevitable.
Stocks moved cautiously and closed lower, with gold shares at new lows for the year; turnover, 642,370 shares. All bonds declined, foreign loans weakest; transactions, $6,876,175.

A decline of $97,000,000 in brokers' loans, which more than wiped out the rise of $92,000,000 reported a week ago, was shown in the condition statement for Wednesday of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, which was issued yesterday.
It will be the Forty-ninth Street Theatre that houses Henry Forbes's revival of "The Wild Duck" (in modern dress), the opening date being newly listed as Thursday, April 14. Rehearsals next Monday.
Laura Alberta Sutherland, for sixty years an actress on the American stage, died yesterday in the Home for Incurables, 183d Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx, after a long illness, at the age of 75.
The first definite step looking toward the possible reorganization of the New York Curb Exchange, along lines followed by the New York Stock Exchange,

As a result of the favorable vote of the Albany Legislature on the Livingston-Piper bill urged by the Governor, any savings bank in New York State will be permitted to sell life insurance policies up to $1,000 for any one person after Jan. 1, 1939.

Denying London dispatches to the effect wa that the dominions were being consuited on the tense European situation, Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King declared today in the House of Commons that what it had received from the British Government had been in the form of information and not consultation.
Northeastern dirt farmers, meeting with a group of leading industrialists on the Cornell campus, took off the gloves today and bluntly demanded information on how the manufacturers controlled prices.

International monetary history was made yesterday when the new control devices employed by the United States and cooperating nations demonstrated their ability to overcome the "worst blow" since the tripartite agreement became effective late in 1936, a high Administration official declared today.

John McCormack, opera and concert singer, disclosed during a radio broadcast from Hollywood last night that he was thinking of running for the Presidency of Ireland and had taken the first steps toward establishing his candidacy.

Nearly a week has passed since, under threats from Berlin, the Austrian Nationalist Government was forced to yield to the Nazis, who promptly sent for German troops to assure the forcible annexation of Austria by the Reich.

Three new saints were recognized by the Secret Consistory today in the presence of Pope Pius. They were the Rev.
