Father Andre Bobola, a Polish Jesuit who was martyred in Russia in the seventeenth century; Salvador da Horta, an eighteenth century Spanish lay Franciscan and professor, and Giovanni Leonardi, Italian priest who founded the Clerics of the Mother of God.
Lovers of human liberty will deplore the news, sent by The Associated Press from San Francisco, that Mr. Sam Hecht,

Ireland celebrated her national festival with no diminution in the traditional religious and patriotic fervor. Both Catholic and Protestant churches were thronged with Shamrock-bedecked worshipers who came to pay honor to St. Patrick, the national Apostle, while flags were flown from all public buildings.

Andrew Ponzi was beaten for the first time in ten matches and Jimmy Caras of Wilmington remained a threat last night in a game between the two former champions in the world pocket billiard title tournament at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

The propriety of considering the tariff schedule on woolens in the trade treaty agreements was challenged today by Arthur Besse of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, New York, in asking for abandonment of negotiations on woolen rates in the proposed British trade pact.
Directors of the Briggs Manufacturing Company yesterday voted against declaration of a dividend on the common stock at this time: On March 31, 1937, a dividend of 50 cents a share was paid.

Another message from the President asking for sufficient funds to equip the regular army more thoroughly and make it a highly mobile force is expected to be sent to Congress within a few days, an authoritative source revealed today.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt were married thirty-three years today. It was on St. Patrick's Day in 1905. that they were wed in New York City, and President Theodore Roosevelt, uncle of the bride, was on hand to give her away.

Ian Douglas MacKenzie, 48 years old, vice president of the Smyth Manufacturing Company of Hartford, Conn., manufacturer of bookbinding machinery, was found dead early yesterday morning in the rear of the Princeton Club, 39 East Thirty-ninth Street.

The 1937-38 basketball campaign in these parts was officially put to bed and tucked in by the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association yesterday at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Lincoln at which the participants in the national intercollegiate invitation tournament were rewarded for their efforts.

Mr. and Mrs. George N. Patrick of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Law Patrick, to Kirkwood A. Tischler of New York, son of Otto Tischler of New Rochelle, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Janet Kirkwood Tischler.

A substantial measure of aid for the city's unemployed, faced with a 10 per cent cut in home relief allowances, was provided yesterday in an announcement by the State Department of Social Welfare that Federal surplus foods, with an estimated retail value of $1,853,000, had been allocated to New York City for distribution to the needy.

Passenger revenues of the Maine Central Railroad increased in 1937 for the fourth consecutive year, E. S. French, president, disclosed in his annual report issued yesterday. These revenues were $1,068,080 in 1937, an increase of 4.6 per cent from 1936. The number of passengers carried increased from 510,763 in 1936 to 604,766 in 1937, or by 18.4 per cent.

Herbert A. Johnson, representative in this country for Leipzig Trade Fairs, Inc., has been reelected president of the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, Inc., Dr. Albert Degener, executive secretary, announced yesterday.

The Washington Monument is slowly sinking and the leaning tower of Pisa moves periodically- in different directions, according to an address made. today by Dr. Dimitri P. Krynine, research associate in soil mechanics of Yale University, before the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Science.

The Mozart overture to "Idomeneo," with other music from that opera, found its way into the program of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Baybirolli, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.

Damage to a life-sized portrait by Ezra Ames of George Clinton, New York's first Governor, was revealed tonight when a case in which the oil painting was shipped from Washington was opened. Part of the frame was smashed and the canvas ripped at one side.

Purchases of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 12 again exceeded sales, with 139,746 shares bought on balance, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.
Trade practice rules for the wholesale jewelry industry, promulgated by the Federal Trade Commission under its trade practice conference procedure, were issued today.

Estate, about $1,600. To Hebrew Orphan Asylum, 20 per cent residue; Richard Wolf, 18 Cotswold Way, Scarsdale, N. Y.; Katherine Wolf. 144 W. 86th St.; Ralph Kraus, 51 W. 86th St.; Jane K. Schwartz, 86 Lincoln Ave., White Plains, and Marlon K. Walker, cousins, Far Rockaway, 16 per cent residue each. Herbert S. Brussel, 1.815 Park Ave., executor.

Factory employment in Pennsylvania increased slightly from the middle of January to the middle of February and wage payments rose about 4 per cent, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported today.

Edward G. Budd, president of the E. G. Budd Manufacturing Company, said yesterday at the- annual meeting of stockholders in Philadelphia that the volume of business had been so low for the first two months of the year that the company had not operated "in the black." The rail-car division is operating at a profit at present, however.

With the British Government still trying to evolve a foreign policy out of the shocks of the past few days, renewed rumors of an impending political crisis sped through Westminster today and appeared under sensational headlines in Opposition news papers.

The great cathedral bearing the name of St. Patrick was filled to overflowing yesterday morning with some 4,000 sons and daughters of Ireland who at a two-hour Pontifical mass in honor of their patron saint heard war characterized as necessary, at times, to prevent social chaos.
Secretary Morgenthau expressed satisfaction today at his press conference over the income tax reports, which indicate receipts about 18 per cent larger than a year ago.
At 2 P. M. today in the Hotel Astor the right and left wings of Actors Equity will formally launch their fight for control of the union's council.
The Maple Leafs, International Division leaders, handedtheRedWings their worst beating of the season, 7 to 2, in a National Hockey League game before 5,000 spectators tonight.

A significant change in public sentiment regarding the war debts, which may prove to be an opening wedge in settling the twenty-yearold issue, is revealed in a new survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Mrs. Margaret C. Keddie, who was the oldest living graduate of Hunter College and a teacher in New York City schools for fifty-one years, died yesterday morning in her sleep at her home, 365 West Twentieth Street. She was 82 years old.

Declaring that New York City relief officials were determined that "the true facts of relief mismanagement" should never be brought to light, Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens asked Governor Lehman yesterday to appoint a commission under the Moreland act to make a thorough investigation of relief in the city..

The Flushing Airport, consisting of 300 acres, has been offered to the New York City Housing Authority as a site for low-rental apartments. The offer was made by Robert W. Aldrich Rodger, president of Rutgers Town Corporation, who said he had an option on the property at 25 cents a square foot and was ready to sell it to the city at that figure.

Although weather conditions continue to retard the development of early Spring retail trade, the expecstation in the wholesale markets here is that next week will see improvement in the demand for women's apparel and accessories.

Princeton University's annual junior promenade, initial event of the Spring social season here, will be held in the university gymnasium tomorrow. The names of 604 young women who will attend were announced today by David W. Sidford of Summit, N. J., chairman of the Promenade committee.

E. Stanley Glines, Morton H. Fry, W. Rodman Peabody, R. Harland Shaw and C. Oliver Wellington applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to act as a protective committee for holders of fifty-five-year 5 per cent mortgage gold bonds, Series A of 1975, of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company.

WHEN Elliot Paul and John O'Hara appear with new books* on the same day the amazing and uncharted variety of the contemporary novel is illustrated spectacularly enough. Nothing could be farther apart-at first glance-than these two methods of writing, these two points of view.

Major Frederick Hanna, retired army officer and a consulting engineer with the firm of Martin H. Ray Associates, died of a heart attack early this morning at his home, 60 Palisade Avenue. He was 52 years old.

Dr. Joseph Schick, for the last twelve years rabbi of the West Side Jewish Center, 347 West Thirty-fourth Street, died at noon yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after four days' illness. Dr. Schick, who lived at 106 West Sixty-first Street, was 49 years -old.
The International Olympic Committee today announced five European cities had bid for the Summer events of the 1944 international games, but to the surprise of many observers, Rome was not among them.

Clement A. Shelton,. for more than ten years vice president of the Democratic Club of the Twenty-second Assembly District, and a former State Assemblyman from that district, died of a heart ailment early yesterday at his. home, 104 Shepherd Avenue. He was 41 years old.

Henry J. Davenport, Joseph W. Catherine, Robert A. McCurdy, Charles B. Tritschler, William A. Stewart and E. Stewart James are representing the Brooklyn Real Estate Board at the FHA conference in Washington today and tomorrow.

The West of Central Park Association, Inc., yesterday announced that its board' of directors had voted to protest to Police Commis sioner Valentine against the order making Eighth, Ninth and Columbus Avenues one-way streets.

Although he was alleged to have admitted on his arrest last Tuesday the theft of $128,000 from his employer, a brokerage concern at 30 Broad Street, Max Friedman, 38 years old, of 250 East 176th Street entered a formal plea of. not guilty in General Sessions yesterday to a grand larceny indictment.

A 70-year-old woman recluse, who, the police said, was apparently worth $100,000, was found dead on the floor of her home at 5,582 Broadway, the Bronx, yesterday when policemen, who were summoned by her niece, forced the door. According to the police, the woman had died several days ago of natural causes.

Urging dismissal of a suit by nine protesting railroads, counsel for New Jersey today told Federal Judge Phillip Forman that the basil question in their attack against the State's taxing methods was "whether a Federal court can forcibly compel a State to adopt a readymade formula against its constitutional and legislative will."

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh arrived in England tonight after a stormy Atlantic crossing on the liner Bremen. The couple, who remained in their suite during most of the voyage, left Southampton immediately for their Kent home.

Nine persons are being held by the military intelligence service, accused of complicity in the recently discovered conspiracy agianst the government. They are Manuel Mazzora, a former army captain; Aurelio and Jose Varona and Pio Carrasco, civilians;
Barcelona was subjected to a series of air raids throughout yesterday and was left terror-stricken. At least 1,000 persons were believed to have been slain, but the number may be many more.

Finding encouragement in the "side-wise" direction of business since the "appalling slump" in securities late last year, B. C. Forbes, financial writer and author, yesterday told the weekly luncheon of the Advertising Club of New York that, barring a major catastrophe here or abroad, the next substantial movement in this country would be in the right direction.

Robert R. Young, fighting to retain control- of the Van Sweringen rail empire, has offered to let the Guaranty Trust Company name a fifth man to the deadlocked Chesapeake Corporation board, unimpeachable sources reported today.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Walter Woolsey of 622 Larch Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Field Woolsey, to E. Macdonald Bacon, son of Mrs. James Bacon of Elmira, N. Y., and the late Mr. Bacon. The wedding will take place in New York in May.

Formal public opening of the new Spear Furniture Store, at 22 West Thirty-fourth Street, will be held on Monday, officials of the company announced following a preview of the modernized structure by trade and press representatives yesterday.

A general strike of 15,000 fur workers in New York City on March 30 was voted last night at a meeting in Cooper Union of 2,500 shop chairmen and active workers of the International Fur Workers Union. The meeting was under the auspices of the Furriers Joint Council.

Many Internationally known fart patrons, collectors and dealers are expected to be called as Witnesses in a $2,000,000 suit brought by Carl W. Hamilton, a collector and dealer, against Lord Duveen of Mill bank and others.

A grotesque three-headed figure, representative of Hitler, Mussolini and General Francisco Franco, was burned yesterday before 300 students on the City College campus as part of an anti-Fascist demonstation sponsored by the college chapter of the American Student Union.

A committee of 234 Columbia University alumni in Westchester County was announced yesterday to direct arrangements for a special performance of the Columbia varsity show, "You've Got Something There," at the White Plains Community Center on April 2.
Several "name" players bowed out today in a wave of upsets marking the first round of the amateur-professional best-ball match play golf tournament.

The match for the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League between the Marshall and Manhattan clubs came to an end at the Marshall rooms yesterday, when the last of the seven adjourned games was, recorded as a draw between Alvin C. Cass of Marshall and Nathan Grossman of Manhattan.

The season's first performance of "Parsifal" will take place today at 1 P. M. at the Metropolitan Opera House. Lauritz Melchoir will sing the title role, Kirsten Flagstad will be the Kundry, Friedrich Schorr the Amfortas, Emanuel List the Gurnemanz, James Wolfe the Titurel and Adolf Vogel the Klingsor. Artur Bodanzky will conduct.

Colonel Edgar Cotrell Leonard, president of the 106-year-old Albany, N. Y., firm of Cotrell Leonard, clothiers, died here today at the age of 75 following a cerebral hemorrhage. He had a Winter home here near Rollins College and served on the school's board of trustees.

The markets recovered their composure to some extent yesterday, responsive to the easing of the "war tension" and to the consequent improvement in prices abroad. The stock market started the day with a moderate advance but soon moved in hesitant fashion.

President Roosevelt authorized today the first contracts presented for his approval by Nathan Straus, administrator of the United States Housing Authority, providing for lowrent housing and slum-clearance projects in Austin, Texas; Charleston, S. C.; New Orleans, Syracuse and Youngstown, Ohio.
Delayed by fog, former President Herbert Hoover arrived by steamer from Finland six hours late and missed the luncheon

Reflecting changes caused by the requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the American Locomotive Company reported to stockholders its total annual net sales for the first time yesterday. These sales amounted to $50,447,450 in 1937, compared to $21,381,108 in 1936.

Housing and business properties in the Bronx and Brooklyn changed hands in deals announced yesterday. Bernard Jakubovitz, operator, added to his holdings by purchasing the six-story elevator apartment house at 125 Mount Hope Place. the Bronx.

Dr. Jose Benito Ramirez, the Minister of Finance, believes that the Nicaraguan Government will have a surplus of more than 1,000,000 cordobas at the end of the fiscal year despite the large sums spent on road building, public buildings, railway extensions and new wharves.

Harry J. Tompkins, manager of the real estate and mortgage department of the County Trust Company in White Plains, shot and killed himself about 10 A. M. today in his automobile parked beside Silver Lake here, according to police.

In response to the requests of many opera patrons who have been unable to secure tickets for previous performances of "Tristan und Isolde," a special, non-subscription production of this opera will be given at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday afternoon, April 16, as the last performance of the Metropolitan season. "Tristan und Isolde" also opened the present season.

Mayor La Guardia proposed today the levying of an occupancy tax of from one to six dollars a year, to be levied on all owners, tenants or concessionaires of properties used for profit, to provide funds to meet the interest charges on city loans for housing purposes.

The first of twenty-five suits against the Pennsylvania Railroad and its subsidiary, the Philadelphia, Baltimore Washington Railroad, because of operation of trains here, was decided today in favor of the defendants.

About forty members of the underwriting syndicate for the $43,000,000 of Pure Oil Company preferred stock were surprised and, in some instances, incensed by the type of information sought in a questionnaire sent out yesterday by Smith,
Miss Maria Cerra, Hunter College sophomore, representing the Salle d'Armes Vince, won the women's metropolitan open foil championship last night on the strips of the Salle d'Armes Vince.
H. J. Ruddle of Eastman, Dillon Co. has been elected a director of the Pacific Western Oil Corporation. Henry Borden has been added to the board of directors of Canadian Breweries, Ltd.

Mark E. Wheeler, Los Angeles policeman, became the national allround pistol marksman today by scoring 2,507 points out of a possible 3,000 with .22, .38 and .45 caftber revolvers after establishing a new world record in .45 caliber slow fire at the national midwinter pistol tournament.

Fresh codfish is for sale-cheap. Almost never before at this season has so much cod been brought into the Fulton Fish Market. Eighteen boats, all with heavy catches, were unloading simultaneously, beginning on Monday. Most of them came from fishing grounds not far from Atlantic City.
The Vassar College faculty committee on graduate study, through its chairman, Mrs. Sague, has announced the following elections to fellowships for the coming year:
As spot prices for many commodities advanced fractionally last week The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose twotenths of a point to 83.1 in the week ended on Wednesday.
Commander Ivan Papanin and his three companions were welcomed home from their Polar explorations today in a heroes' procession to the Kremlin, where Joseph Stalin received them.

Japanese forces in the Tsinpu sector have been increasingly active in their drive toward the south, which is apparently designed to join the forces that have advanced north along the railway from Pukow.
The Irish. in New York marched 50,000 strong under drab skies yesterday in their annual homage to St. Patrick, the patron saint of Ireland.

Stewart McDonald, head of the Federal Housing Administration, told a conference of real estate men today all previous Administration records were broken last week with more than $20,000,000 in mortgages submitted for FHA insurance.
Francis Jones of Detroit, the medalist, reached the semi-finals of the Belmont golf tournament today by defeating R. E. March of Bronxville, N. Y., 1 up.
Most of the Eastern Intercollegiate swimming records will be threatened tomorrow and Saturday, when representatives of sixteen colleges clash for the individual championships in the Harvard pool.

Major steps toward a more effective coordination of activity in the Protestant welfare field were taken during 1937, according to the eighteenth annual report of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, made public yesterday.

Several lines of economic activity in the Pittsburgh district decreased slightly last week and others increased less than seasonally, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Edgar Eugene Calvin, retired vice president and former -president of the Union Pacific Railroad, died today in his home, where he had resided since 1928, when he retired from active service at the age of 70 years. His age was 79.

Directors of Fletcher Joint Stock Land Bank of Indianapolis have given notice of the call for redemption on May 1, of $286,000 worth of bonds of the bank, according to an announcement by William B. Schiltges, president.

President Roosevelt met for a second time with his railroad conference group and appointed three of the Interstate Commerce Commissioners to draft rail legislation. He remembered his thirty-third wedding anniversary tonight by calling Mrs. Roosevelt on the long-distance telephone in California.

The Browns opened their exhibition schedule today with an 8-to-0 vietory over the Victoria Gulf Oilers, semi-pro team. The Browns bunched nine of their sixteen hits in the eighth inning to score six runs. Ollie Bejma, secondbaseman, collected four singles in five trips to the plate, while Beau Bell, who signed only Tuesday, got a single and double in three trips.

As financial representative of the Federal Home Loan Banks, which will have $24,700,000 of one-year 11/2 per cent consolidated debentures maturing on April 1, Everett Smith reported yesterday that on Feb. 28, the banks held $36,159,525 in cash, compared with $8,002,053 on June 30, 1937, the end of the last fiscal year.

Far more troops, tanks, airplanes, guns and supply trains than any one here can imagine to be necessary for the occupation of a country that so joyously consented to annexation as Austria is said to have done have been pouring through here continuously during the past three days.

Class I railroads paid $1,985,323,363 to their employes in 1937, compared with $1,848,498,422 in 1936 and $1,643,214,114 in 1935, according to a compilation released today by the Bureau of Statistics of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Although bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday exceeded those of the preceding period, as a result of the usual mid-month settlements and the first installment of the quarterly income tax payments, the rise was not equal to the sharp bulge which took place in the corresponding week last year.

Mrs. Ruth Appleton Wendell has re ceived a divorce here. from William G. Wendell on a cross-complaint charging cruelty. Mr. Wendell filed a suit on March 11 and his wife's answer and the cross bill were filed on Monday, with the case going to trial immediately.

The Long Island University five scored a 56-to-43 victory over the Millersville State Teachers tonight. Millersville, led by Harvey Ehemann, who scored twenty-five points, stayed in the running through the first half, but fell rapidly behind in the last due to the accurate shooting of Irving Torgoff and Art Hillhouse.
A departmental committee headed by the Hon. Edward Cadogan recommended tonight the abolition of flogging t as a court penalty. With that recommendation goes another to abolish birching for juveniles.

Mrs. Audrey Browne Beasley was married here today by Judge Thomas F. Moran to Franciszek A. Pajkowski, known as Frank Parker, Davis Cup tennis player. The wedding followed the obtaining of a divorce at Carson City on Monday by Mrs. Beasley from Mercer Beasley, now termis coach at Princeton University.
The Canadiens climbed back into second place in the International section of the National Hockey League tonight by trouncing their neighborhood rivals, the Maroons, 6 to 3.

The medalist team of Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia and Miss Helen Dettweiler of Washington came through the third matches of Aiken's round-robin women's golf tournament today with a one-point lead.

Manager Joe McCarthy celebrated St. Patrick's Day at Huggins Field today by looking over one of the Yankees' rookie pitchers for the first time in competition. The hurler was Atley Donald, young Louisiana right-hander and the occasion was a scrub game organized after overnight rain had postponed the morning workout.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. A. Hampton Gibson of 85 Summit Road of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Gibson, to Pierre P. Drujon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Drujon of Saintes, France. Mr. Drujon will arrive in this country next month and the wedding will take place here in June. The couple will reside in Bordeaux, France.

Joseph Patrick Kennedy, the first United States Ambassador of Irish descent at the Court of St. James, celebrated St. Patrick's Day by attending a full-dress levee at St. James's Palace in white tie and tail coat and bowing to the King.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad recommended today reconstruction of its Harlem River freight terminal facilities in New York City at a cost of $300,000, in a petition filed in Federal court.
Fourteen indictments charging embezzlement of $10,173.96 in city funds were handed up today against T. Lee Lemmon, former Cape May City Clerk and City Manager.

The address of Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, before the National Press Club today was as follows: In the course of the daily press conferences at the Department of State I have occasion to see many of you and to touch upon day-to-day developments in our foreign relations.

George E. Hayler, 65 years old, of 302 West Seventy-seventh Street was fatally injured last night when struck by an automobile as he was walking across West End Avenue at Seventy-seventh Street. He was taken to Roosevelt Hospital where he died in a short time.
The Government forces evacuated Caspe during last night, and General Juan Yague's troops entered the city at 8 o'clock this morning.

The First National Bank of Boston, in its statement of condition as of March 7, reported total deposits of $613,871,278 and total assets of $718,150,948, compared, respectively, with $615,939,169 and $720.348.364 on Dec. 31, last.

Trading was generally low. The markets were mostly unchanged throughout. Because of the Jewish holiday, Purim, trading in kosher meats was even lighter than usual for Thursday, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

President Roosevelt said "eternal vigilance is the price of liberty." a message read during the Purim Festival radio program of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee last night. The program was broadcast over a national network.

A long lease on the old property at 61 Fifth Avenue, a parcel held by the Hoffman family for more than forty years, has been taken by the Frank G. shattuck Company as the site for a new unit in the Schrafft's chain of restaurants.

President Roosevelt appointed a threeman committee today to report back to him in a week on recommendations "for immediate action by Congress in regard to the whole railroad situation, which is -critical."

Continuing the upward trend of recent weeks, engineering construction awards this week are 54 per cent above the figure for 1937, with a total of $53,284,000, as compared with $34,569,000, according to the Engineering News-Record.
Commenting on Secretary Hull's speech, The Daily Telegraph today expressed its gratification that the question of "international anarchy" was "so clearly understood

Mrs. George Austen of Charlottesville, Va., gave a luncheon yesterday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for Miss Helen Talcott Hope, who will be married this afternoon in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church to David Edward Austen, son of the hostess.

Fall lines of men's suiting fabrics will be opened by leading wool goods producers next week at declines of from 45 to 50 cents a yard from last year's opening levels, bringing values well below 1936 prices, it was learned yesterday.

The Bermuda title net tournament's biggest gallery saw some sparkling tennis today as Don McNeill, United States indoor champion from Oklahoma City, vanquished Robert Murray, Canada's No. 1 player, in a hard fought twohour three-set semi-final that reached thirty-nine games.

Gross assets, $13,119; net, $11,527. To William E. Corneck, son, residue; Jennie Crozier, cousin, $1,000; one other bequest. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $12,350. J. A. Angione, attorney, 2,989 Marion Ave.

Twenty-five games will be played by the Long Island University baseball team this season, with a contest against St. Peter's College in Jersey City April 6 opening its campaign and an encounter with the New York Athletic Club June 5 at Travers Island concluding its program, it was announced yesterday.
Dr. Edward Martin, surgeon, sanitation expert and educator, died today in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital, where he had been a patient for a week. He was 79 years old.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa will arrive today from Germany and the Channel ports. Among her passengers are Viscount Elibank, former Member of Parliament; Anthony G. Fokker, airplane designer and builder, and Dr. E. Foerster, German naval architect.

The Bangor Aroostook Railroad Company today applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to assume liability with respect to $1,500,000 of 21/2 per cent serial equipment trust certificates.

The stability of the State Insurance Fund for Workmen's Compensation payments be was questioned by leaders of both major parties tonight as the Assembly passed a bill reorganizing the present system of supervising the fund.
Debate and a preliminary test of voting strength on the Naval Construction Bill today revealed the firmness of the House's support of national defense measures.

Next week will see the largest gathering of fox hunters ever seen in New Jersey, if the plans for the banquet of the New Jersey Fox Hunters Association materialize. The dinner will be held at Moorestown.

A firm foreign policy which involves no retreat in the face of disruptive events in Europe and the Far East was presented to the nation today by Secretary Hull in an address at a luncheon of the National Press Club.

Investment bankers were warned today by John W. Hanes, new member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, that unless they find a way to supply the money to keep America's economic machine running the Federal Government may take this job away from them.

The general level of wholesale prices continued unchanged in the week ended on March 12, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 level as 100, stood at 79.8, compared with 79.6 a month earlier and 87.2 on March 13, 1937.

The Wall Street Riding Club, Inc., announced yesterday that it would hold its third annual charity horse show on Saturday afternoon and evening, April 2, at its headquarters, 7 West Sixty-sixth Street.

A dinner dance was given last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador under the direction of Prince Alexis Obolensky as a benefit for the welfare fund of the Russian Nobility Association, an organization devoted to aiding needy Russians in this country. Special divertissements featured the party.

On the twenty-first day since 1lyear-old Peter D. Levine vanished in New Rochelle, the Assembly spurred the hunt for his kidnappers yesterday by voting a $10,000 State reward for information leading to their arrest and conviction.

The report of the Securities Corporation General for 1937, issued yesterday shows a net profit of $61,758 after expenses and taxes, exclusive of net losses of $62,843 on investment securities sold, charged to general reserve account. This compares to a net income of $37,008 and net losses of $189,652 from securities sold in 1936.

Miss Elinore Stanley Warner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Olmstead Warner of Penn Valley, will be married to John Wyeth Sailer of this city, son of Mrs. William August Sailer of Roland Park, Md., and the late Mr. Sailer, on April 2.

A sharp whistle was sounded, indicating that Pepper Martin, the Mad Maestro of the Musical Mudcats, was summoning his orchestra for another session of Spring practice. All members responded except Bob Weiland, the big pitcher who plays the jug in the Cardinal symphony set.

Baron Maximilian Gevers, in 929 Ave; Peter Driben, in 346 E 52d St; B. Levi, in 444 Park Ave; Eva V. Smith, through Duff Conger, in 157 E 72d St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, broker. Julius Winkler, in 662 Lexington Ave; Henry S. Enock, through Mrs. Marie Buscn, in 313 E 51st St; Victor Withstandley, through Pease Elliman, Inc, in 345 E 57th St; Culver. HollydaY Co. Inc. broker.
Out of his love for the character of Abraham Lincoln, E. P. Conkle has written an absorbing idyll, "Prologue to Glory," which the Federal Theatre put on at Maxine Elliott's last evening.

Major General Franklin Wilmer Ward, for , eight years adjutant general in command of the State's military and naval forces, died in St. Peter's Hospital today of complications resuiting from an intestinal operation last month. He was 67 years old.

With final settlement of March obligations at noon yesterday, covering operations became less urgent and prices on the Cotton Exchange ended with losses of 2 to 6 points. A recovery in Bombay narrowed the differences between the two markets so that relatively few straddle accounts were reversed.

After being shot in both legs in a chase through the Pelham Bay Park section of the Bronx, by two policemen assigned to special duty searching for the "phantom burglar" credited with killing two members of the force, an unidentified man defied questioners early today at Fordham Hospital.

Heinie Manush, hard-hitting right fielder of the Dodgers, agreed to terms with Larry MacPhail late this evening. It is understood he will sign for $10,000, which is $1,000 in excess of the salary he received last year when he led the club in hitting and runs batted in.

Yesterday's panicky selling on the stock markets here appeared to be checked today as "bear" traders rushed to cover. An all-round rally took place and, despite a slight reaction in the afternoon, most issues closed higher.
Greta-Garbo, the actress, and Leopold Stokowski, the symphony maestro, said today that they were not planning to marry.
Drilling of fewer oil wells, with an increase in output from those in operation, was suggested before members of the American Association of Petroleum Geologists in session here today.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve.Banks showed total. gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted were at the lowest.

In a dispatch yesterday it was said that the League of Nations had never accepted the Swiss Government's declaration in the early years of the League that Switzerland was not bound by the military sanctions of Article XVI of the covenant,
The years are light and gay, Kind are the year's and long; Their passing like a play, Their sound a sweet sung song.

Robert Goelet and George V. R. J. InnesKer, Duke of Roxburghe, sold to the Belroy Realty Corp., C. Bertram Plante, president 404 E 17th St, a 5-story structure with a store and a 3-story brick on the rear of the lot, and they took back a purchase money mortgage for $5,000, payable 10 years hence, at 4 per cent.

Frederick S. Wildman, president of Bellows Co., wholesale wine and liquor importers, yesterday defended a bill now before the State Legislature which would prohibit retailers from importing wines or liquors direct from abroad.
Plans for active participation of the leading chain merchandising systems in the campaign to promote cotton merchandise, particularly during National Cotton Week beginning May 30,

Postmaster General James A. Farley called for a reawakening of spiritual values to save a world that "seems to be mobilizing for chaos" in a speech tonight at the annual dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick at the Elks Auditorium here.
Representatives of the millinery industry, appealing for tariff protection, told a committee of government tariff experts today the industry was "on the threshold of destruction,"

The Kansas City, Kan., Healeys advanced to the semi-finals of the National A. A. U. basketball tournament tonight by defeating the Central Missouri State Teachers of Warrensburg, only unseeded survivor of earlier play, 42 to 38.

Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio entertained with a dinner tonight at their residence. Mrs. E. H. G. Slater gave a large dinner at Costa Bella for her niece, Mrs. Curtis Brooke and Mr. Brooke of Providence, R. I., who arrived today to visit her.

George F. Taylor, a 32-year-old attorney who had been employed as a solicitor for the New York State Workmen's Compensation Insurance Fund, was found dead in his room at the Hotel Shelton at 2:15 P. M. yesterday.

President Rafael Leonidas Trujillo's candidates for President and Vice President of the Dominican Republic will be unopposed at the election May 16, according to notice filed yesterday with the Election Commission.

The John Fritz Medal, highest honor in the engineering profession, was presented last night to Dr. Paul Dyer Merica, vice president of the International Nickel Company and one of the world's leading metallurgists, in "recognition of his important contributions to the development of alloys for industrial uses."

The National Maritime Union, C. I. 0. affiliate of unlicensed seamen, protested yesterday to the Federal Maritime Commission against its proposal to establish training schools for young men seeking careers at sea. The schools would supply additional men for the relief rolls the union said.

Overwhelming adoption of the new constitution of the New York Stock Exchange was reported yesterday afternoon. Of 1,038 members voting, 1,013 approved.. Twentytwo voted against it and three turned in defective ballots.

With the Giants back to routine field manoeuvres, Colonel Bill Terry turned his attention today upon dividing his forces for the skirmishing of the forthcoming week-end, which promises to be the most intensive of the training campaign to date.

The Squadron A Yellows, with Walter Nicholls going well at No. 1, turned back their organization's Blues, 12-5, in a semi-final match of the Manhattan elimination in the Sherman Memorial indoor polo championships at Squadron A Armory yesterday. The winners will play another Squadron A team next week in the final round to decide the Manhattan circuit representative in this section of the Eastern championships.
The Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation in its report for 1937, issued yesterday, shows net income, after taxes, depreciation and expenses, of $24,770,845, equal to $11.19 a share.

With a $5,000,000 profit on its retail activities largely offsetting an extraordinary heavy loss in the manufacturing division, Marshall Field Co., last year had a net loss of $1,654,451, Frederick D. Corley, president of the $83,000,000 merchandising concern, disclosed today in the company's annual report to stockholders. Mr. Corley became chief executive officer of the company last December.
There seems to be no end to the work of rounding up supporters of the former regime, including prominent members of the Catholic and Jewish bourgeoisie, Freemasons, Socialists and Communists.
Henry B. Anderson, head of the law firm of Anderson, Gesser, Ferris Anderson, 20 Pine Street, died yesterday at his residence at Sands Point, L. I. He was 75 years old.

The Assembly passed tonight, by a party vote of 80 to 65, the Moffat bill repealing the capital gains and loss provisions of the Personal Income Tax Law. However, it was made clear during the debate that the Senate would hold out for Governor Lehman's bill modifying the tax, instead of repealing it, and that the Assembly would yield and pass the Governor's bill tomorrow.

The British Minister, Owen St. Clair O'Malley, conferred with President Lazaro Cardenas today, seeking a compromise for settlement of the oil wage controversy. It is stated he did not protest or bring pressure to bear.

Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis has conducted a thorough investigation of the St. Louis Cardinals' farm system and may release between twenty-five and 100 Class D players into free agency, it was learned today.
Frank Hughes, manufacturer, banker, insurance and real estate man of this place, died last night at his home, 76 Park Street, after an illness of several months. He was 77 years old.

Mrs. Elizabeth Rickard Mohun, daughter of Edgar Rickard of 277 Park Avenue, New York, and the late Mrs. Rickard, was married this afternoon to John Otis Thayer, also of New York, at the home here of her sister, Mrs. Graham Hoyt. The Rev.
Large Polish forces were massed on the Lithuanian frontier, ready to march on Kaunas unless an ultimatum is answered favorably this afternoon.

The rules of the National League have been adopted for the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League this year, it was announced yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, executive officer for the Central. Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics.

Richard Whitney, governor and former president of the New York Stock Exchange, now awaiting sentence for grand larceny on two counts, was expelled yesterday by the institution that he headed for five years.
The Private Library Department of Houghton Mifflin has now brought to completion the first Colelected Autograph Edition of the works of Willa Cather.
Miss Jeanne J. Kennard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Mortimer Kennard of this place, has chosen June 18 for her wedding to A. Gardiner Layng, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Montague Layng of Montclair.

In an effort to gain the blue ribbon of Pacific shipping the Nippon Yusen Kaisha, steamship company, aided by heavy government subsidies, is preparing to build two of the biggest, fastest and finest liners.

Coincident with the opening of hearings today on the new Revenue Bill by the Senate Finance Committee, Senator Pope of Idaho announced that he planned to introduce an amendment to the bill providing for the taxation of the finished products of the five basic commodities covered in the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938.
Thirty candidates for places in the United States chess championship finals started play in the elimination trials at the Marshall, Manhattan and West Side Y. M. C. A. chess clubs last night.

The appointment of five new disrectors and an executive committed of thirteen was announced yesterday by the Greater New York Fund. The executive committee headed by Francis D. Bartow, will be in direct administrative control of the fund and will be subordinate only to the board of directors.

The results of the first Nationally Advertised Brands Week, which was held Feb. 24 to March 5, "have exceeded all earlier expectations," Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers, said yesterday. While conceding that.

The preliminary annual report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries for 1937, to be released today, shows a consolidated net income of $10,236,148 after expenses and charges, but not including any income or losses on Spanish subsidiaries.

A chubby little deputy sheriff from Little Rock picked two horses "out of the blue" at Oaklawn Park today and cashed a $2 daily double ticket for $6,002.80, the second largest ever paid in American turf history.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Above all other considerations at this moment comes that of world- peace. The World War sowed the seeds of ruin everywhere. Another European war will do the same. Knowing this and the danger of our own country being involved, we yet do little to prevent its coming.
Five hundred and welve Spanish refugees previously housed in the French Embassy at Barcelona, Spain, were landed at Port Vendres this morning from the French torpedo boats Epervier and La Palme.

The Wabash Railroad Company, formed pursuant to the reorganization plan of the Wabash Railway Company that has been approved by a United States District Court in Missouri, applied today to the United States Commerce Commission for authority to acquire the property of the predecessor concern.

A mother who told officers she was ill and unable, to provide for, her family killed six of her nine children as they slept at a lonely farm, home near here last night, kissing each good-bye before and after shooting them.

On the eve of his departure tomorrow for London where negotiations are under way for the purchase of United Artists, Samuel Goldwyn broke his silence on production plans today and disclosed that "Graustark" will go before his Hollywood cameras next month with Gary Cooper, Merle Oberon and Sigrid Gurie.
Pope Pius today awarded to Mgr. James B. O'Reilly of New York City the designation of Domestic Prelate. Mgr. O'Reilly is national secretary of the Catholic Near East Welfare Association.

Governor George H. Earle, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Senator, abandoned today his position of neutrality in the fourcornered contest for Governor in the Democratic primary, and without mentioning John L. Lewis and the C. I. O., backers of Lieutenant Pope Governor Kennedy, gave blanket endorsement to the State committee's ticket.

In his discussion yesterday of American foreign policy in the face of a series of international crises in Europe and in Asia, Secretary Hull put into one eloquent sentence an accurate description of the real fear which now disturbs the peace-loving nations of the world:

The Association of American Railroads reported today that preliminary reports from ninety-one Class 1. railroads showed operating revenues of $205,973,953 in February compared with $268,408,458, correspondingly the year before, and $351,111,482 in the same month of 1930.

If word came that the entire population of Cincinnati, New Orleans or Washington, D. C., were to be put on trains some fine morning, carried from ten to fifty miles and brought back in the evening, we might wonder why, but we should unquestionably be amazed at the equipment and organization that made it possible.

A hint that the two new British battleships to be laid down during the coming year will mount 16-inch guns was given in the House of Commons tonight by John J. Llewellin, Civil Lord of the Admiralty, in the course of a debate over naval estimates totaling

The $1,000 Eli Lilly Co. Award in Biological Chemis try for 1938, which also carries with it a bronze medal, will be presidente to Dr. Abraham White, Assistant Professor of Physiological Chemistry at Yale University, it was announcedd yesterday.

The Governor spent the day signing emergency messages to expedite passage of legislation pending in both houses. The Senate completed legislative action on the Todd bill licensing registered and practical nurses;

Delaying the turning on of the city's street lights thirty minutes each night, as suggested by Mayor F. H. La Guardia, would save the city at least $100,000 a year. at the present rate. The Mayor made his proposal as a way to finance needed projects and services which he said were now being held up by the presence of $12,000 and $15,000 a year "loafers" on the payroll.
Two thousand Austrian Nazi Storm Troopers returned to Austria today from their camp at Wackernheim near Mainz. They had been quartered Rele there since 1934.

Jorge Saettone, 24 years old, the first of the 1938 recipients of the W. R. Grace Co. South American scholarships, arrived yesterday on the Santa Clara to begin his year of study and work with the General Electric Company at the engineering school in Schenectady.

An Ireland where love of liberty still lives was pictured as a bulwark against the tide of communism and dictatorship last night by speakers before the 154th anniversary dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick.
A "fifty-fifty plan of profit-sharing" in industry is outlined by Commander John B. Rhodes, U. S. N., retired, in the current issue of Iron Age.

Three local savings banks, all in Brooklyn have thus far decided to set up life-insurance departments under the Savings Bank Life Insurance Bill, enacted in Albany on Wednesday, a survey of the banks indicated yesterday.

The Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Battalion, 125 West Fortyfifth Street, reported yesterday for the period April 20, 1987, to Jan. 31, 1938, an income of $98,570, of which $70,932 was spent in materials sent to. Spain and $22,093 for publicity and administration, leaving a cash remainder of $5,544.
The biggest series since the American Bowling Congress opened two weeks ago was rolled today, but the brilliant 719-pin performance didn't worry the individual competition leaders.
Several thousand pieces of mail were destroyed early this morning as fire swept the mail car of a New York, New Haven Hartford local train bound from Stamford for New York City.

A dispute concerning the interpretation of a contract between Local 802 of the musicians union and Sam H. Grisman, who operates five Broadway playhouses including the Hudson Theatre, where the revue i "Who's Who" is current, threatens to start a labor war.

Tommy O'Connor, a minority in the strictest sense of the word (he was the only member of his race present), succeeded to an imaginary throne yesterday and for one day at least vindicated all Gaelic pretensions to royalty.

Sharp repercussions of the Nazi conquest of Austria are being felt on the Baltic as elsewhere in Europe. Poland has made imperative demands upon Lithuania. Under the guise of the "normalization" of Polish-Lithuanian relations,

Ferryboat trips around New York harbor, conducted, last Fall by the Board of Education, gave high school pupils a better understanding of the city and a greater insight into "many difficult problems" it faces, according to a report of the experiment made public yesterday.

There were two new impersonations in last night's performance of "Don Giovanni" at the Metropolitan Opera House. John Brownlee, the Australian baritone, took the title ro1e and Rose Bampton, young American, sang Donna Anna. Mr.

Although the sandhills are comparatively new in amateur hunt racing, fifty-six of the country's leading jumpers are entered on the five-race card at the meet to be held at the picturesque Barber estate tomorrow.
Clark Griffith of the Senators today announced he had traded First Baseman Joe Kuhel to the White Sox for First Baseman Zeke Bonura.

A collector of Philadelphia's new 2 per cent sales tax had this problem put to him over the phone by a dutiful citizen: "I've got a black eye and I'm buying a beefsteak. Since I'm not using it for food, which is exempt, I think I ought to pay a tax. The butcher doesn't know. How about it?"

The State Legislature has wished Governor Lehman a "happy birthday," ten days ahead of time. Members of the Senate concurred today in an Assembly resolution wishing the Governor "health, happiness and long life."

Fear that any reduction in duties on wool clothing may bring back sweatshop conditions in American industry was expressed by spokesmen for the Amalgamated Clothing Workers today at the hearings on the proposed British reciprocal trade treaty. More than twenty years have been

The Rev. Ernest R. Palen, pastor of the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street, has informed members of his congregation that he will hold personal conferences on "Knowing God Personally" at least on two afternoons each week.

In a Giornale d'Italia article of obvious official inspiration, Virginio Gayda announced today General Francisco Franco's final victory as "imminent and certain." There are rumors of armistices and compromises, he said, but such reports circulate in France every time the Insurgents gain a victory.

European events of the past week will be discussed in the sermons of pastors tomorrow and many will preach against war and especially against this country becoming involved in foreign entanglements. Catholic and high Episcopal churches will celebrate today the Feast of St. JoseDh.

In one of the most bitterly contested stretch duels of the season, Miss Mary Hirsch's No Sir was awarded the photo decision over T. D. Buhl's Gyral in the Key West Purse of a mile and a sixteenth at Tropical Park today.

The war in Spain reaches the apex of its horror and shame in the murders committed in Barcelona this week by Insurgent planes. Neither side comes to this crisis with clean hands. Both have previously bombed defenseless cities. But there has been nothing in this war, or in any European war, that can be compared with this dreadful assault upon helpless noncombatants.

Giving no indication as to where the fight will take place, Mike Jacobs, president of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, announced yesterday that he would stage the much-discussed battle between Joe Louis and Max Schmeling on Wednesday, June 22. Jacobs,

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that sugar delivered to United States markets under the quota law in the first two months of 1938, amounted to 815,210 short tons, raw value, compared with 744,892 for the same period last year.

Eighth annual city-wide conference of junior high schools, Hotel Astor, 9:30 A. M. Luncheon 1 P. M. speakers: Loretto M. Rochester, Paul A. Kennedy, Frederic Ernst, Professor Herman H. Horne, George H. Hickey.

Unable to maintain accuracy as well as Wayne Sabin the long rallies from deep -court, Don McNeill of Oklahoma City went down fighting in the final of the men's singles in the twenty-fifth Bermuda tennis championships today, 4-6, 6-3, 6-3, 6-4.
For the sixth consecutive period new bond financing this week was restricted exclusively to tax-exempt securities, further emphasizing the deadlock in the market for new corporate loans.

The shield bearing the double eagle arms of Austria was taken down yesterday from over the door of the Austrian Consulate General at 500 Fifth Avenue and the office, as representative in the United States of an independent nation, passed out of existence.

A funeral service will be held at 10 A. M. on Monday at St. Thomas Church, Ann Arbor, Mich., for George E. Hayler, engineer for the last twenty years with the public utility division of the Cities Service organization.

In view of the growing controversies over manufacturers' advertising and other service allowances to Retailers, the National Association of Retail Grocers, Chicago, yesterday suggested that it might be advisable to eliminate entirely these subsidies.

Showing the way by a 9-to-6 margin at the intermission, the Brooklyn College Girls' basketball team accounted for a 17-to-16 triumph over Hunter College in a. closely contested game played in the Brooklyn College gymnasium yesterday.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation was exempted today from the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 by order of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

With the Sniffen brothers, Harry and Larry, turning in fine exhibitions of team-work, the Stock Exchange Brokers conquered the Sands Point Tigers, 7 to 3, in a Metropolitan Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Four New York Stock Exchange member firms will dissolve March 31. They are W. H. Goadby Co., William E. Lauer Co., Loew Co. and Stern, Kempner Co. Emily C. Coady was admitted as a limited partner of MacQuoid Coady on March 15.

Bache Richards, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Beckman of 791 Park Avenue and of Frederick Lloyd Richards, also of this city, to Francis Warren Pershing,. only son of General John J. Pershing, will take lace here in St.- Thomas Church on April 22.

A new concrete plant with a capacity of 1,000 barrels, which cost more than $1,000,000, was turned over to the government today by the Puerto Rico Reconstruction Administration. It will be operated by the government-owned Puerto Rico Cement Corporation.

Poland was ready to send her troops into Lithuania unless that nation accepted by 3 P. M. New York time today the terms of her ultimatum. Chief stress was laid on resumption of diplomatic relations by March 31.

Ronald Dytch, 24 years old, of Dunellen, an employee of the Sherwin-Williams Chemical Company here, was sentenced today in Somerset Quarter Sessions Court to serve an indefinite term in Annandale State Reformatory after pleading guilty to holding up Mayor John C. Cuccia of Bound Brook last Friday night.

The Federal Reserve Board liberalized its margin rules tonight to help securities dealers outside of New York City. The amendments, which become effective on Monday, are of an extremely technical nature, but officials said they would have the following effects:

Wall Street, living up to its reputation as a thoroughfare which starts at a graveyard and runs to a river, remarked yesterday that, if it isn't one thing, it's quite likely to be another. More or less reassured by the degree of resistance of the market during the past week to European war scares,
An announcement by Pinehurst officials said today that amateur tennis players in the twentieth annual North and South tournament here April 11 would receive no expense money for the meet.

The strong tone of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech to the Reichstag tonight, particularly his reference to oppressed millions of German blood, once more disturbed a Britain already suffering an acute case of war "jitters."
Former President Herbert Hoover, completing a long European survey, said today: "I do not believe a widespread war is at all probable in the near future."

Weekly cotton statisticss are as follows: British stocks, 1,214,000 bales, against 1,203,000 a week ago, 1,209,000 two weeks ago, 1,192,000 three weeks ago and 943,000 a year ago; of which American 789,000 bales, 1 against 794,000 a week ago, 781,000 two weeks ago, 787,000 three weeks ago and 420,000 a year ago.

Avery Brundage, United States Olympic delegate, today termed the shift in dates for the 1940 Olympics a "bitter pill for the United States to swallow." The International Olympic Committee, meeting here, shifted the dates for the 1940 games at Tokyo from Aug. 25-Sept. 8 to Sept. 21Oct. 6.

Plans by the city Department of Markets for construction of a $30,000,000 wholesale market and food terminal on the Hudson River waterfront near the Washington retail market were revealed last night by Max Mencher, secretary of the department. Mr. Mencher spoke ata forum meeting of the New Era Club, 274 East BroadWay, near Montgomery Street.

The Most Rev. Bartnoiomew J. Eustace, for the last twenty-two years a professor at St. Joseph's Theological Seminary, Dunwoodie; N. Y., on Friday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral will be consecrated Bishop of the newly established Diocese of Camden, N. J., which takes in Southern New Jersey.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:. There was a triangle in 1914--BerlinVienna-Rome. There is an axis in 1938-Berlin-Rome. One of the ties which preserved the triangle was the agreement between Vienna and Rome: should either seek to change the status quo of the Balkans the other would be informed of the project and receive compensation;
Count Pehar Sparre of Sweden denied at his office here yesterday that he would enter the schooner Maniton in the Bermuda race next June. He said he had no intention of doing so.

The Toronto Maple Leafs and Boston Bruins, top finishers in the National Hockey League's two divisions, will begin their five-game series for the league championship and the Prince of Wales Cup at Toronto on Thursday, President Frank Calder announced today.

More than 2,500 men and women volunteer workers who will conduct the 1938 Catholic Charities Appeal of the Archdiocese of New York will meet tomorro after noon at various places in Manhattanm the Bronx and Richmond and Westchester Counties to receive instructions.

Miss Edith Elizabeth Korn, daughter of Mrs. Edward Korn of this J place and the late Mr. Korn, was married this morning in her home to Joseph Frank Wright Jr. of East Orange, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. A Frank Wright of Stewartville, Va. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William Weston Patton of Glen Ridge Congregational Church.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company, starting Monday, will comply with recent orders directing improvement of its subway and elevated service by providing additional trains and man power, the Transit Commission announced yesterday.

The number of aliens who had been engaged on public works projects was minimized yesterday by Nels Anderson, United States Director of Labor Relations of the Works Progress Administration, in an address at the annual conference of the National Council on Naturalization and Citizenship at the Hotel Astor.

The Standard Oil Company of Ohio reported-today for 1937 a-net income of $3,362,960, or $3.66 a common share, against $4,194,314 in 1936. This was after allowance of $431,245 for flood loss. Taxes totaled $17,619,546, or double the company's entire pay roll.
The Atlantic City Sea Gulls defeated the New Yprk Rovers, 4 to 3, tonight in an Eastern Amateur League hockey championship game.
United States Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy told his first British audience tonight that no nation could count upon American neutrality or American participation in another war.

With shooting well under way Columbia today completed the cast of principals for "Holiday" which features Katharine Hepburn and Cary Grant. Edward Everett Horton, who carried the role of Seton Cran in the 1930 version, has joined the troupe as Nick Potter, with Henry Daniell taking the Cran role.

While London authorities, headed by the Lord Mayor, today appealed for 101,000 volunteers for air-raid precautions, the Committee of the Metropolitan Water Board, which Is responsible for the water supply in 573 square miles with nearly 8,000,000 inhabitants, said: "A danger of the first magnitude is not being treated with a due sense of the urgency."

Professor Bertrand Holmes Wallace of the University of Vermont died suddenly here today. He was 63 years old. A native of Rochester, N. Y., he was graduated from the University of Rochester and taught in Chester, Pa.; Trenton, N. J.; Swarthmore, Pa.; Westboro and Arlington, Mass., before coming to Burlington in 1921.

As a result of the rising interest in political developments in Central Europe and their possible effect on. the world price of sugar, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange reported yesterday the production of beet sugar in Germany, Czechoslovakia,

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora refused yesterday to reduce the bail of J. Richard (Dixie) Davis and George Weinberg, both of whom are awaiting trial on indictments charging that they headed policy racketeers. Davis is held in default of $200,000 bail and Weinberg in default of $150,000 bail.

Organizations concerned with the production of radio programs figured prominently in commercial leasing reports yesterday. Phillips H. Lord, Inc., which produces the Gang-Busters dramas, has taken the entire twenty-fourth floor in 501 Madison Avenue, where smaller space has been occupied for several years. Alfred N. Williams Company, Inc., as agent of the building, arranged the lease.
The Earl of Perth called at the Palazzo Chigi this evening for his fourth conversation with Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano since the official opening of Anglo-Italian negotiations.

Tossing in the winning field goal with nine seconds of a three-minute overtime period to play, Eddie O'Connor led the St. Francis Prep quintet to a 32-to-30 triumph over St. Peter's High of Staten Island in the final game for the city Catholic High Schools Athletic Association title at the DeGray gymnasium last night.

The conference committee of small business men appointed at their recent convention was advised today by Secretary Roper that he and President Roosevelt "enthusiastically approved" their recommendation for a business advisory council to represent smaller business just as the present council now speaks for larger business groups.
The several weeks' old controversy between the Federal District of Managua and the Central American Power Company, an American company, over 'increased rates was settled today.

Benjamin Z. Sherman, president of the Brooklyn Infants Home, 1,358 Fifty-sixth Street, appeared yesterday before Magistrate Jacob Eilperin in Flatbush Court to defend the 100 tiny residents of the home against a charge of disorderly conduct.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech was broadcast here in Portuguese last night on a nation-wide hookup and was displayed prominently on the front pages or the newspapers today. It was interpreted as an authoritative American plea for a better understanding among men.

Lady Fairhaven, who had been at the Plaza since her return recently from Florida, left yesterday for New Bedford, Mass. Mrs. T. Handasyd Cabot of Villa Corbinelli, Florence, Italy, and her daughter, Mrs. George Pierce Metcalf of Providence, R. I.,

Pensloned On their own applications, to take effect 12 midnight, March 31: CAPTAIN-Edward McDonough. 42d Precinct, at $2,950 per annum. Appointed Jan. 31, 1903. To take effect 12 midnight, March 18: PATROLMEN-John H. Jacoby, Motor Transport Maintenance Division, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 19, 1910.
Floyd Orlin Hale of La Grange, Ill., chairman of the board of directors of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company, died today in the Hartford Hospital after a long illness. His age was 54.
Wolf (Hobe) Ferris, former Boston Red Sox player and a friend of Ty Cobb, died of a heart attack in front of I his home here tonight.

The South Carolina House of Representatives passed a bill today to-forbid the showing of drinking, murder or divorce scenes in motion pictures; to prohibit the advertising of intoxicants in State publications and to submit to the voters this Summer the question of return to State prohibition.
Chancellor Hitler tonight told the last Reichstag of the old Germany why he sent his battalions to Austria a week ago. He sent them, he said,

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market is for the most part marking time, pending the outcome of the proposed British trade treaty and the final determination of the wool loan terms.

Both the New York Yankees of the American League and the St. Louis Cardinals of the National League will return to St. Petersburg for the 1939 Spring training season, Al Lang, the city's baseball ambassador, announced today.

Three members of the Communist party, debating with three members of the Amerian Legion on the question "Resolved, That the American form of democracy is superior to communism," lost the decision last night before 1,500 persons in Erasmus Hall High School, 911 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

Whether Paddy's market which has been located in Ninth Avenue between Thirty-ninth and Fortysecond Streets for many years. is to end its existence today or whether it will remain, at least until after next week, was uncertain last night.
Control of seventeen United States and British petroleum companies, representing an investment of $450,000,000 in Mexico, was assumed tonight by 18,000 Mexican oil workers.

Francis E. Frothingham of Boston, president of the Investment Bankers Association, today urged bankers to stand adamant against further restrictive legislation. He spoke at a luncheon of the Central States group of the association.

The newspaper Diario Nuevo suggests an investigation of the movements and purposes of three Japanese fishing boats reported in Jiquilisco Bay, west of the Gulf of Fonseca. It says that the boats not only are fishing but have penetrated close inshore, taking photographs.

Members of the Headquarters Troop of Squadron C of the 101st Cavalry, New York National Guard, held an equestrian carnival at the troop's armory, 1,579 Bedford Avenue Brooklyn, last night in honor of former officers of the troop.

President Roosevelt said today that the reaction to Secretary Hull's speech yesterday was excellent. He had not seen the foreign comment, he ing added. Asked whether he contemplated any tangible steps aimed at restoring peace in Europe,

The first eleven weeks of unemployment insurance in this State have demonstrated- conclusively that the New York law is "administratively unworkable," Herman A. Gray, chairman of the State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance, declared yesterday.

The Assembly tonight killed the bill of Senator Twornmey, Kings Democrat, under which the State would have purchased the Bear Mountain Bridge for $5,500,000, after the charge was made by Assemblyman Fite, Poughkeepsie Republican, that enactment of the measure "means a great big piece of velvet for some one."
H. L. Broadbent, Australian flier missing for thirty-three hours, was found alive and apparently uninjured today on:-the tiny island of Sumbawa, 1,200 mites from Batavia.

In a defense of the Moscow trials made before 5,000 cheering Communists last night, Earle Browder, general secretary of the Communist party in America, charged that there is treason in high places in the American Government today.
New York hotels undoubtedly will experience better business during the approaching World's Fair of 1939 than they could expect in normal years.

The Italian liner Vulcania will sail today for Mediterranean ports with 525 passengers, including Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, member of the Board of Education of New York City; the Count and Countess Carlos Bobone; John T. Ridder, newspaper publisher, with Mrs. Ridder;

Mayor La Guardia reappointed Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch yesterday as a member of the New York City Housing Authority at City Hall. Mrs. Simkhovitch, who lives at 23 Barrow Street, will serve a new five-year term.

Robert A. Waters, president of the National Radiator Corporation, told the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today that R. K. Mellon and E. T. Weir had agreed to help pay for the Johnstown (Pa.) Citizens Committee's national advertising campaign during last Summer's Bethlehem Steel strike.

The Washington Monument is sinking, says Dr. Dimitri P. Krynine of, Yale University. It has sunk about an inch since 1884, and at that rate will be completely underground in about 350,000 years. We shall miss it sadly.

Dr. Arthur Richmond Crandell, former house physician at the Boston Children's Hospital and the Boston Lying-In Hospital, died here today at his home. He was 68 years old. Born in Taunton, son of Charles W. and Abbie Dean Crandell, he was graduated :from Harvard College in 1892.

Judson Randolph Bush for forty years a lawyer in Los Angeles, died at his ranch home in Carlsbad, near Oceanside, today. His age was 73. Mr. Bush was born March 9, 1865, in Morris Township, Green County, Pa.
Brett Wyckoff, Inc., has opened a country department, in charge of George F. Harris, to handle properties throughout the East and South.
A drawing of "an old swimmin' hole" won first prize of $100 yesterday for Robert Lee Hale Jr., of Darien, Conn., in a contest under sponsorship of Saks-Fifth Avenue.

Dr. Cyril Bradley Rootham, composer, who for nearly forty years had been prominent in the musical life of Cambridge University today at the age of 62. His unfinished symphony will be completed by Dr. Patrick Hadley his friend and former pupil.

22d St, n s, 187 ft e of 7th Ave, 67.6x98.9: Edward T. Higgins to Dry Dock Savings Institution; consideration $1,000, foreclosure. 2d Ave, 485, 24.8x100: W. A. Construction Corp to Kathleen J. Williamson, 118-28 197th St, St. Albans, L. I. (50 cents).

Allan Deutsch of 37-05 Ninetieth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, a member of the law firm of Deutsch, Berkowitz, Wilk Alper, was found dead, apparently of a heart attack, on a sofa in his office in the Knickerbocker Building, 152 West Forty-second Street, last night. His age was 51.

E. E. Engstrom, for sixteen years in charge of the housefurnishings division of National Can Corporation, has been elected president of the National House Furnishings Association, it was announced yesterday.

A source close to the Chancellery said today that Germany's opposition to the threat of Polish military action in Lithuania had been withdrawn in return for Polish acquiescence in a possible German annexation of the Free City of Danzig.

Arthur Carroll, chairman of the board of directors of the Sicilian Asphalt Paving Company, 41 Park Row, an organization founded ,by his father, General Howard Carroll, half a century ago, died Thursday night in Presbyterian Hospital of a heart attack. Mr. Carroll,

Archibald MacLeish's "Land of the Free," which Harcourt,Brace will publish March 31, is the result of an attempt to give an accompaniment of words to a selection of pictures-pictures on the one hand of small towns, prairie land,

From. far-off California, by indirect route, word came today from Joe DiMaggio, the Yankees' famed Holdout, but it gave little encouragement to the belief the Yankee slugger intends in the . immediate future to end his-endurance struggle with Colonel Jacob Ruppert's bankroll.

State Banking Superintendent William R. White has taken possession of the business and property of the New York Produce Exchange Safe Deposit and Storage Company, 2 Broadway, to supervise liquidation, the weekly bulletin of the banking department announced today.

Stocks closed with losses of 1 to 3 points, with rails lowest in six years; heaviest trading since Jan. 26; turnover, 1,577,760 shares. Bonds generally lower, rail and foreign issues weakest; turnover largest of year; transactions, $10,682,750.

The aristocratic orchid, queen of the floral kingdom in spite of being a comparative newcomer among cultivated flowers, was the center of attraction for more than 30,000 visitors at the Flower Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday.

A banking group composed of Watkins, Morrow Co., Kalman Co., Seasongood Mayer and Marx Co., obtained the award yesterday of a new issue of $313,000 of refunding bonds of Jefferson County, Ala., on a bid of 99.70 for 31/2s. The bonds will mature serially from 1941 to 1953.

Indoor polo enters its final stages with games on two fronts tonight.-- At the Squadron A Armory in Manhattan and at Squadron C in Brooklyn championship play opens and will continue through the early part of April. At Squadron A the remarkable.

Estate, $4,800. To Eleanor H. Davis, executrix, 130 E. 39th St. GALLAGHER, ANASTASIA (Dec. 19). Estate, $1,000. To Agnes C. Gallagher, executrix, 225 W. 14th St., $900; Anastasia Wooley, daughter, 60 Riverdale Ave., Monmouth Beach, N. J., specific bequest.

A falling off in the rate of transfer of home relief recipients to WPA will make impossible the filling of 20,000 new WPA jobs here by the end of this month, officials of the Federal relief agency disclosed yesterday.
A sweeping investigation designed to bring out all available information essential to the proper regulation

George Albert Thompson, artist and at one time instructor in the Yale Art School, died in his home here this morning. He was 69 years old. Born in New Haven, the son of Captain Charles Emory Thompson and Alice Bishop Thompson, he was graduated from the Yale Art School.

Colonel John Wing Prentiss, a senior partner of the brokerage firm of Hornblower Weeks, died yesterday morning at his home, 778 Park Avenue, of heart disease after a brief illness. He was 62 years old. He was at the office of his firm, 40 Wall Street, regularly until last Saturday when he suffered an attack.
Efforts to block the proposed withdrawal of three fast liners from the intercoastal trade encountered an obstacle today in an intimation from President Roosevelt.

The Salmagundi Club opened last evening with a stag its annual exhibition of water-colors and pastels by members, a large and diversified show containing nearly 150 examples of work by more than a hundred artists. It will be current until April 1.

The fourth annual Summer festival of the City of New York will take place this season from May 1 through July 31, it was announced yesterday by the Mayor's Municipal Art Committee, Mrs. Henry Breckinridge, chairman.

Mr. George Foster Peabody, who died a few days ago, lived into the year of the fiftieth anniversary of the real beginning of the sustaining organization of the Y. M. C. A. for Negroes under full-time leadership in America. He, with his brother, contributed the funds for the first standard modern building (erected in 1907).

Faced. with payment of fines totaling $66 for traffic violations or spending five days in jail Amerigo Bonglorino, 26 years old, of 42 Fourth Place, Brooklyn, paid $10 to a friend to serve the jail term and then went for another drive in his automobile, Detective Thomas Carroll testified in Felony Court, Brooklyn. yesterday.

Trade-practice rules for the carbon dioxide manufacturing industry have been promulgated by the Feideral Trade Commission under its trade practice conference procedure and were announced by the commission today.

The Rev. John A. McGeary, pastor of St. Aedan's Church, of which Mayor Frank Hague is a communicant, died this afternoon of a heart ailment at the age of 62. He had been in a coma for several days in the church rectory.
Representatives of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards have asked Federal Housing Administration officials to modify requirements on sizes of lots for new residence construction.

This hapless city was again subjected today to raid after raid by Insurgent planes from the base at Majorca. Since last midnight there have been six attacks, at 1:15, 4, 7 And 9:25 this morning and at 1:05 and 3 this afternoon.

Amid a feeling of tenseness quite without parallel in springtime exhibition baseball since the Ty CobbBuck Herzog feud of a bygone age, the Giants will advance upon New Orleans tomorrow to open their eighteen-game series with the Indians.

Little Jeff, chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. Lawrence B. Smith and Mrs. Landon K. Thorne of New York, today led a field of nineteen in the lightweight class, the feature event of the annual hunter trials. Fitzlee,
Garage properties in Brooklyn and the Bronx figured in transactions reported yesterday by brokers. Housing properties in the Bronx and Manhattan also passed to new control.

Miss Elizabeth Wise Macy, daughter of Mrs. Josiah Macy of this place, was married to James Suydam Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Jones of Far Hills, this afternoon in St. Peter's Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. David J. Montgomery.
The text of the address delivered by Joseph P. Kennedy, the United States Ambassador to Great Britain, at the Pilgrims Dinner in London tonight was given out by the State Department as follows:
United States Senator William H. Smathers of this city has purchased a large home at 5 South Osborne Avenue, Margate, near here, it was announced today.
