Distribution of Spring merchandise was slowed this week by bad weather and the diversion of cash to income-tax payments, and the decline in retail sales from the same week last year, when Easter shopping was at its peak, deepened to 9 to 16 per cent, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

In a marathon match that went nine extra holes before a decision was reached, Jack Toomer of Greensboro, N.C., and Oscar Evers of Jacksonville defeated Denny Shute, American P. G. A. titleholder, and Bill Stark of Jacksonville,

Rosalind Lopata, in 340 E 57th St; Jacques Duval, Frederick Drake, in 1 W 67th St; Anthony Billingham, in 38 E 50th St, Mrs. C. S. Goodrich, in 320 E 72d St; Hors Von Hennig, in 784 Park Ave; Mrs. Marguerite P. Krock, in 405 E 54th St; M. Comer, in 208 E 51st St; Helen HerbertSmith, in 42 Park Ave; Van Rensselaer Realty, Inc, broker.
All of the favorites advanced into the third round as play started in the sixth annual metropolitan badminton championships on the courts of the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

Robert R. Young, head -of the syndicate that controls the Alleghany Corporation, said last night that he had decided to include the Guaranty Trust Company among the opponents of himself and his associates in the contest for control of the huge Van Sweringen properties, which was brought into the open this week.

The Adjutant General released the following orders today: These officers, having qualified, are placed on duty: Calhoun, Capt. Douglas A., Medical Corps, is to report to the 105th Infantry, for assignment to Medical Department detachment. Northbridge, 1st Lt. John A., Medical Corps, is to report to the 102d Medical Regiment for assignment to Company G.

The New York Central System announced yesterday delivery of the first of ten giant new locomotives of the streamlined Hudson type, to conform to the design of the new streamlined Twentieth Century Limited.

The Austrian Consul General, Ludwig Jordan, and his staff were arrested today by the secret political police. Frau Jordan was ordered to remain in Munich and was forbidden to communicate with anybody.

The Hudson Coal Company and the Delaware Hudson Company filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a form required for "a person becoming, or ceasing to be, a parent or subsidiary of the registrant, provided that no report need be made as to any subsidiary the name of which would not be required to be furnished in the form of annual report appropriate for the registrant."

Secretary Hull declared today that enactment of a pork tariff, inserted by the House in the Tax Revision Bill, would be an attempt at economio suicide. "There is no more dangerous game than an embargo policy in foreign trade," he said.

James Caras of Wilmington, Del., forged into second place in the world's pocket billiard championship tournament at the Capitol 'Bowling and Billiard Academy last night by defeating Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia, 125 to 64, in twelve innings.

A resolution demanding that wholesalers provide protection against price declines on current retail stocks of both hard and soft floor coverings for a period of not less than -ninety days, and rebates on merchandise shipped during the ninety days preceding such declines, was adopted by representatives of three retail floor covering associations at a meeting last night at the offices of Jack G.
Fullest autonomy for Germans in Czechoslovakia came nearer realization today when the Cabinet Council decided that German districts are to be -administered by German nationals.

Indications of increased activity in Greenwich real estate are found in the fact that sales reported during the past week totaled over $500,000., Two homes, assessed in the $100,000 class, exchanged hands during the week and another estate was valued close to that amount.

President Roosevelt opposed pay cuts for railway workers, at his press conference, and continued his personal inquiry of the TVA with the directors of the Authority. The Senate debated the Government Reorganization Bill,

Displaying a plebeian taste in keeping with the circumstances, Borough' President Harvey of Queens ordered a hamburger sandwich yesterday when he inspected the new trailer-diner which will start out Monday to make hot lunches more accessible to WPA workers on highway.projects in the borough.

An' increase in man power of The Netherland Army within the limits of existing legislation was decided on by the government today. The number of conscripts of this year's class will be increased about 20 per cent, from 26,000 to 31,000.

A great Princeton medley relay team that had been knocking at the record door all season, without gaining entrance, smashed through the portals in the Harvard pool tonight in the opening day of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League championships.

Although they should not assume the functions of trade unionism, organizations of college teachers must unite in supporting the demand of the salaried scholar for academic freedom and civil and political liberties without economic pressure,

The Hudson County grand jury today indicted Joseph Scutellaro, 36 years old, of 611 Monroe Street, Hoboken, on a charge of murder in connection with the fatal stabbing on Feb. 25 of Harry- L. Barck, 74,

Trading was slightly improved. Steer hinds and ribs were weak to lower, some lamb cuts were lower, other classes mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated veal and calf to be steady, and other classes higher as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

In June of 1934 the President of the United States, by executive order, created a "Quetico-Superior Committee" to consult and advise with the various Federal departments and agencies concerned, together with the State of Minnesota, in formulating a program for the establishment of a Wilderness Sanctuary in watersheds through which runs the international boundary line between Canada and the United States west of Lake Superior, from Pigeon River to the Lake of the Woods.

The Rev. Carl McIntire, one of the "rebel" clergymen deposed. by the Presbyterian Church in the United States of-America in the Modernist-Fundamentalist controversy a few years ago, must quit the pulpit of Collingswood Pesbyterian Church, under a ruling today by Vice Chancellor Francis B. Davis.

The use of "storm troops to recapture our own institutions and government" may be necessary, New York State Commander Jeremiah T. Cross of the American Legion told 3,000 persons last night in a county mobilization of the legion at the State Armory, Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens.

The steamships Haiti and Colombia, which were recently purchased by the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Company from the Colombian Steamship Company, have been assigned by their new owners to the Puerto Rico and to the Cuba-Mexico services, respectively, it was announced yesterday.

A tax bill definitely encouraging to business should be in the hands of the d President within thirty days, Senator Barkley told the Senate today. n Senator Barkley made his statement in reply to an appeal by Senator Copeland that the Tax Revision Bill contain relief for business.

Presidents of companies with shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange have been asked to assist the stock list committee in making a survey of the results of the new proxy rule adopted on Dec. 22, last.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that the United States would, for the present, stand on the law applying the arms embargo policy to Spain and, as far as he knew, had no plans for modifying or repealing a it in the future.

EAST OF BROADWAY, by Octavus Roy Cohen. (Appleton-Century, $2.) A romantic novel. FATHER COLDSTREAM, by Julian Duguid. (Appleton - Century, $2.50.) A historical novel about Paraguay in the eighteenth century.

Pitt's powerful boxing team tonight sent six men into the finals of the Eastern Intercollegiate Conference tournament and dethroned Bucknell University as champion. Although no points were awarded in opening-round competition, the Panthers were assured of at least 18 points in tomorrow night's eight final bouts.

Revised minimum wage scales were submitted yesterday by the New York City Tunnel Authority to contractors for the Queens land section of the Queens midtown tunnel and contractors were asked to present their bids on the contract by March .29.
Webster Ave (12-3356), w s, 228 f n of Gun Hill Rd, 150x100; Adolf A. Berle Jr, trustee, to Waldbern Realty Co, Inc, 3,545 Webster Ave; mtg $83,600.

A daylight-working burglar who, the police charge, opened a locked door in sight of fifty or more persons and then, with sensitive fingers, solved the combination of a safe in ten minutes, was arrested yesterday afternoon with a companion as they left a crowded cafeteria at Thirtieth Street and Seventh Avenue.

Harry Wardman, English-born builder of many of the capital's apartment buildings and hotels, died tonight. He was 65 years old. Born at Bradford, Yorkshire, the son of a textile worker, Mr. Wardman came to this country when 20 years old.

Miss Virginia Holden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russel J. Holden of this place, has chosen April 2 as the date of her marriage to Henry Keep Jr., son of Colonel and Mrs. Keep of Elizabeth. The ceremony, which will take place in Trinity Episcopal Church, Cranford, will be performed by the Rev. Frank M. Sherlock, the rector.

Funeral. services for Mrs. Helena Woolworth McCann, wife of Charles E. F. McCann and daughter of the late Frank W. Woolworth, five and ten cent store pioneer, who died in her home, 4 East Eightieth Street, on Tuesday, were conducted yesterday morning at the Roman Cath- Or, olic Church of St. Jean Baptiste, Lexington Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street.

Responses to the recent call for a real estate "union" to fight extravagance in government indicate widespread support for the movement, Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said yesterday.

Manhattan North Moore St, 7, 18.9x75, for 3-story section station, Department of Public Works, City of New York, owner; F. B. McDuffee, architect; cost, $46,000. Alterations 37th St, 221-31 E: to 7-story telephone exchange; New York Telephone Co, 140 West St, owner; Voorhees, Gmelin Walker, architects; cost, $250,000.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 12 amounted to 556,664 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called upon the membership of the national securities exchanges and the over-the-counter market for cooperation in the preps aration of rules intended to make, available to the commission and to

Administration leaders in the Senate won a major victory today by defeating, 43 to 39, attempts by a coalition led by Senator Wheeler, Democrat of Montana, to amend the Reorganization Bill by limiting the power of the President in rearranging the governmental organization.

Miss Helen Talcott Hope, who numbers among her ancestors two early Governors of Connecticut, John Talcott and Thomas Hooker, was married yesterday afternoon to David Edward Austen. Dogwood, daffodils and a profusion of Spring blossoms decorated the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church where the ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. George A. Buttrick.

Retail trade here this week again suffered in comparison with the active buying of the pre-Easter period last year. While volume thus far is about on a par with that of last week, when a decrease. of 11 per cent was shown, poor isles results today would materially increase the percentage decline.

Jacques shortly Hoffmann, violinist, teacher and conductor, died last night at Beth Israel Hospital at the age of 70, following a fall downstairs earlier in the evening at the Malkin Conservatory of Music, where he had been teaching.

The Lithuanian Government is ready to accept all the demands made in the Polish ultimatum except the one that requires practically a "yes or no" answer, and explains that an acceptance accompanied by any "reasoning" will be considered a rejection, according to information received this afternoon by the League of Nations Secretariat.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Lamport of 1,185 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Lamport, to Joseph Satinsky, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. David Satinsky of Philadelphia.

The Hospital Ball in aid of St. Francis Hospital took place tonight at the Surf Club here. Several hundred members of the resort colony attended the event, which was sponsored by the Bath, Surf and Indian Creek Clubs and the Committee of One Hundred.

Sales of copper in the export market were made late yesterday at 9.85 cents a pound, c.i.f., European base ports. Earlier sales were made up to 9.95 cents, or at Thursday's final level. In the domestic market, the price was unchanged at 10 cents.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 11 per cent for the week ended March 12, compared with the same week year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank: of New York. For the week ended March 5 the sales of these stores were off 13.3 per cent.

The Countess of Covadonga, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bias Rocafort of Havana, was married here at noon today in the Central Baptist Church to E. H. Adkins Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. E. H. Adkins of Miami Beach.

Future wars will be determined in the air by great fleets of swift planes against which there will be no defense, according to Anthony H. G. Fokker, airplane designer and builder, who arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

Life not only goes on under the shadow of crisis and calamity, but often it is life in its minor aspects, one might almost say its trivial aspects. Even now the movie theatres in Madrid 'and' Barcelona are crowded.

The Phillies sent six young players, all members of the Centreville, Md., Eastern Shore League team last year, to Montgomery, Ala., of the Southeastern League today. The Phillies will retain control of all six players.
Recovery in the stock markets here continued today and prices generally closed higher. Gilt-edge issues were quiet and German and Austrian bonds went ahead.

Minnie Frowenfeld sold the dwelling at 50 W 71st St, to the Rexhold Realty Corp, James H. Cruikshank, president, at a price indicated as $13,000, the seller owning this house since Feb. 5, 1891, Rexhold giving a purchase money mortgage to the John W.

The medalist team of Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia and MIss Helen Dettweiler of Washington today won the Aiken round-robin women's golf tournament. The winners defeated Miss Alice Rutherfurd of New York and Miss Marion McDougall of Portland, Ore., 6 and 5, in the morning round,

Plinio Salgado, head of the dissolved Integralista [Fascist] party and five of his assistants were sought by police today following the discovery of an alleged nationwide plot to assassinate President Getulio Vargas and other government leaders.

Mrs. Jbsephine D. Williams of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Dorothy Elizabeth Deishley, to Edward J. McGoldrick Jr., son of New York State Supreme Court Justice Edward J. McGoldrick and Mrs. McGoldrick.

For the first time the Supreme Court was today asked to rule upon the constitutionality of taxing admissions to intercollegiate football games. Robert H. Jackson, Solicitor General, in a brief sent to the court,

After listening to four witnesses the New York County grand jury yesterday dismissed a charge of suspicion of homicide against. William King Loftus, 47 years old, a saxophone player, of 108 West Eightieth Street. in the death last Feb.

Max Lanier, a southpaw pitcher from Columbus of the American Association, was a hero as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Boston Red Sox today, 6 to 4. Although he allowed two runs in the inning he pitched-the ninthLanier struck out two men with the bases full before pinch - hitter Daughters's double drove in a pair.
Willard S. Karn, who was rated among the master contract bridge players in 1932, started suit yesterday in. Supreme Court to recover $1,000,000 from Ely Culbertson, the latter's divorced wife,

MANHATTAN CARMODY, JOHN H. (Jan. 18, 1937). Gross assets, $32,006; net, $27,714. To Mary R. Byrne, Loretta M. Ferrier, Rose Carmody, John J. Devine, Alfred Carmody, Frank Carmody, Josephine Burricelli, Lillien S. Collaren, Rose C. Patchell, John F. Byrnes and William F. Carmody, one-eleventh residue each. Chief assets, miscellaneous property, $14,236. William Joseph Flynn, 115 Broadway, and Thomas B. McAndrews, 270 Broadway, attorneys.

Charles L. Bradley, president of the Chesapeake Corporation, denied today that there was a fight on for control of the corporation. In a prepared statement issued through his attorneys, Mr. Bradley said:

After finding Winslow Tuttle, 34year-old broker, of Tenafly, N. J., guilty of driving while intoxicated, Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Traffic Court paroled him yesterday Until Monday so that he could get $100 with which to pay his fine.
Harmony in the City Council-the lack of it and the hope for it-was discussed yesterday at a luncheon called for the purpose by the New York City League of Women Voters in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today, Lewis O. Hutchinson of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

David S. Walton Jr., formerly treasurer and a director of the National Folding Box Company, died of bronchitis today in his residence- here. His father, a New York paper manufacturer, founded the business and was president of the company.

President Manuel Quezon's immediate and cordial agreement with High Commissioner McNutt's- suggestionmade in a recent Washington broadcast--of a "realistic re-examination" of the question of Philippine independence reflects a growing apprehension among Filipino leaders that separation from the United States in the near future might prove a disaster.
Two hundred members of the Parliamentary press gallery gave a party in the House of Commons tonight for Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain on his sixty-ninth birthday anniversary.
In THE TIMES of March 12, John Drebinger refers to Dick Bartell as the premier shortstop of the National League and the possessor of the most agile pair of hands in baseball.
Most of the members of the Lithuaniar Cabinet are reported to favor agreeing to meet Poland's ultimatum for the restoration of diplomatic relations and railway, air and other traffic by March 31.

The Southern New England Telephone Company has arranged for the private sale of $8,000,000 of thirty-year, 31/4 per cent debentures at 102, according to an announcement today. The sale was made to a small group of institutions and was completed through Charles W. Scranton Co. of this city.

The Philadelphia Inquirer will say in a copyrighted dispatch from Washington, to be published tomorrow, that State Department officials are reported to be investigating "the workings of a Nazi-inspired effort to launch a chain of pro-Nazi, antiSemitic newspapers throughout the United States."

The Legislature worked on through the early hours of this morning, aiming at an adjournment scheduled for 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon and adding, through the long hours, to a substantial record of achievement during the day session yesterday.

The Pennroad Corporation, a railroad holding company whose relations with the Pennsylvania Railroad recently were investigated by the Senate Railroad Committee, disclosed yesterday in its annual report substantial transactions in railroad stocks that were consummated in 1937.

The United States reclaimed yesterday its title to the money-center of the world as. a result of the continued heavy flight of capital from Europe to gold and the dollar. At the same time, the American Stabilization Fund, by its purchase of sterling in the morning, estimated at upward of $10,000,000 in the New York market, staved off the danger of a collapse in the British currency.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated March 17: COLONELS Miles, S. (F. A.), General Staff Corps, three days leave. March 21; relieved from detail as a member of the General Staff Corps, Washington, D. C., June 30. and assigned to the 18th F. A.. Ft. Sill, Okla Smith, R. H., C. A. C., Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, to 1st C. A. Dist., Boston, Mass., June 1.

John M. Savage former member of the American consular service in England, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 73 years old. He was a native of Rahway, N. J., and a son of the late Judge George W. Savage of Rahway. Mr. Savage was in the consular service for thirty years. After his retirement he lived in New York until four years ago, when he came here.

James Parker Waite, head of the J. Parker Waite Agency, 55 John Street, a special agency for the Travelers Insurance Company, died of a heart attack Thursday night at his home, 285 Riverside Drive. His age was 58.

The general aspect of Caspe, which had been the capital of Aragon since the beginning of the civil war, is today even more desolate than that of Alcaniz. Considerably less than half the civil population of about 10,000 remained when the Insurgents completed their occupation of the city yesterday, but many residents who hid in the hills while the battle was raging began to return to their homes yesterday.

Eighteen candidates for the six vacancies on the nominating committee of the Actors Equity Association were named yesterday at an Equity meeting in the Hotel Astor. Tellers will. start at 10:30 A. M. today to count the ballots and the six it successful candidates may be announced later in the day.

Wheat futures advanced nearly 2 cents a bushel at the extreme today, but most of the gain was wiped out by a dip which developed later. The close, however, was on a rally, and the list ended with net gains of 7/8 to 11/8 cents.

After a four months' investigation of election practices in Yonkers, the November Westchester County grand jury handed up a presentment here today excoriating election inspectors for their "carelessness" and "ignorance," and urging the Legislature to strengthen the election laws.
Mr. and Mrs. Grover Loening and mer Mrs. George Luke Mesker gave a large tea today at the Four Arts Count Jerzy Potocki, Polish Ambassador, and a member of Mrs. Mesker's house party.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated March 16: COMMANDERS. Clark, J. C., Washington, D. C., to instruction, Naval War College, Newport, R. I.. in June.
The University of Chicago retained its Central A. A. U. indoor track and field championship tonight with 31 1/2 points as one meet record was broken and two were equalled.

The Department of Agriculture said today that farmers' reports on intentions to plant this year Indicated 94,595,000 acres to corn and 22,282,000 acres to Spring wheat. The corn acreage would be 2 per cent smaller than last year; the Spring wheat acreage, 6.2 per cent smaller.

The California Prune and Apricot Growers Association and leading prune packers today announced formation of the Prune Export Association under the terms of the Webb-Pomererie Act. Uniform selling prices have been established for exports of prunes to all foreign markets, ineluding Canada.

Senator -Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, co-author of a resolution for a Congressional investigation of the TVA, issued a statement tonight in which he implied that the Administration feared a thoroughgoing study of this agency.

Your correspondent was requested this afternoon to call at the Vienna police presidency during the evening. On arrival I was received by the head of the press police, Hofrat Zoffal, who courteously said he must inform me that the Gestapo [secret police] headquarters in Berlin had instructed him to tell me "politely" to "leave Vienna within three days" counting from tomorrow.

Pennsylvania's Forty- fourHour Work Week Law, besieged in court since it became effective in January and later drawn into the State's Democratic primary campaign, was declared unconstitutional today by Judge W. C. Sheely in the Dauphin County Court.

Five present governors of the New York Stock Exchange and one member were suggested to that institution's nominating committee yesterday as possibilities for the new post of chairman of the board, created in the new constitution adopted on Thursday.

John Alden 3d, said to be a direct descendent of the central figure in Long follow's poem, was born here yesterday to Mr. and Mrs. John Alden Jr., maintaining a 300-year-old tradition that the first child born to a John Alden is always a boy.

Oxford's oarsmen are taking off weight for their annual boat race with Cambridge April 2. Ten weeks ago the heaviest crew in the 109-year history of the race with an average weight of 184 pounds, they now average 180 pounds.

Fear that any reduction in duties on wool clothing may bring back sweatshop conditions in American industry was expressed by spokesmen for the Amalgamated Clothing Workers today at the hearings on the proposed British reciprocal trade treaty.

Heads of the American railroads voted today to ask the leaders of the railroad unions to share with the managements in the task of trying to solve the financial light of the carriers resulting from soaring expenses and declining revenues. A joint conference was requested from the unions.

Karl Kautsky, 83-yearold Marxist theorist, 'arrived here by airplane today from Prague, where he sought refuge one day hefor the German occupation of Austria. He said that, despite all he had witnessed in recent years, his faith in socialism was as strong as ever.

An order of the State Labor Relations Board calling an election to determine a collective bargaining agent for employes or certifying a collective bargaining agent is not a final order subject to court review, the Court of Appeals ruled today.

Carl P. Herbert, director of the St. Paul Bureau of Municipal Research, told the Senate Committee on Unemployment today that relief must be recognized as a permanent problem and that the "hand-to-mouth" policies must be abandoned.

Colelection ratios on open credit accounts receivable of department stores showed a decrease of 1.1 per cent for January of this year compared with the same month of 1937, but an increase of 3.3 per cent over last December, the Foreign and Domestic Commerce Bureau reported today.

Ralph Simmons, president of the Ralph Simmons Corporation, insurance brokers, with offices at 90 John Street, died of a heart attack Thursday evening at his home, 44 Gramercy Park. His age was 58. The son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Simmons, Mr. Simmons was a native New Yorker.
Prior to their departure for England, Australia's test cricketers opened a three-day
58th St, 348-52 W; three 4-story dwellings, 50x100.5; Dry Dock Savings Institution against Title Guarantee and Trust Co. trustee; due, $55,241; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Appointment by President Roosevelt of a committee of three Interstate Commerce Commissioners-Messrs. Splawn, Eastman and Mahaffie-to submit a week from now a plan for "immediate action by Congress" to relieve the railway situation, apparently means that other expedients than outright railway consolidation will be considered.

BADMINTON Metropolitan Class A championships and veterans' tournament, at Old Sixty-ninth Badminton and Tennis Club, Twentysixth Street and Lexington Avenue, 2:30 P. M. BASKETBALL Metropolitan Catholic high schools invita- tion tournament, at Columbus Council K. of C., 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn,

Do you remember the League of Nations ? Do the Manchurians, the Abyssinians, the Spaniards, the Austrians and the Chinese? I can't help feeling that a book about the League has something of the air of a requiem about it these days while Europe's democracies-among others -are standing with their faces to the flames. It's not doing its work-but neither is any one else.

Municipal bond dealers, after a fairly busy period this week, will have a "breathing spell" next week, as only $4,834,515 in new State and municipal bonds have thus far been scheduled for sale. This compares with the revised total of $27,203,457 for this week.

" Parsifal" again impressed' immense audience and cast its curious spell when it was given as the last of the special Wagner matinee performances of the season yesterday in the Metropolitan Opera House.
Henry D. Mygatt and F. Kingsley Rodewald, partners in the closed brokerage firm of Richard Whitney Co., filed separate petitions in bankruptcy in Federal Court yesterday. Mr. Mygatt,

European developments unsettled trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices broke sharply to end with a loss of 30 to 35 points. At one time quotations showed a decline of $2 a bale, or $4 a bale below high records of last month.

Twelve additional results were recorded last night in the national chess championship preliminaries at the Marshall, Manhattan and West Side Y. M. C. A. Chess Clubs. Those with scores of 2-0 when play stopped at 11 o'clock Thaddeus E. Knorr of Hillside, N. J., in Group A;
Mercersburg's well-balanced team retained the title in the thirtyfourth annual national prep school swimming championships at the Penn A. C. tonight before a capacity crowd.

Sweden is in the midst of a building boom of such proportions that there is now a shortage of labor in the construction and other industries, Professor Gunnar Asplund of the Stockholm Institute of Technology and one of the outstanding architects of Sweden said yesterday.

The management of the Dundee Textile Company, Montclair, was restrained temporarily today by Federal Judge Phillip Forman from acting on a proposal to reduce the company's capital stock by $65,000 at a meeting next Monday.

The report of the Connecticut Light and Power Company for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday; shows a net income of $3,752,959 after all expenses and charges, equivalent, after preferred. dividend requirements, to $3.27 a share on the outstanding capital stock.
Below are given nominal com parative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.

Joseph (Socks) Lanza, so-called czar of Fulton Market, who is serving a two-year prison sentence for racketeering in the fresh water fish industry, wept yesterday when Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe imposed an additional six-month term on his plea of guilty to similar activities in the salt water fish trade.

The German war veterans' organization and the organization of graduates of the new universal service army and the post-war Reich army were united by decree today. The new organization is under Chancellor Adolf Hitler's personal command, and other connections with former associations have been severed.

The Nabor Athletic Club from Chicago's Northwest Side fired the first gun in the week-end shelling of the American Bowling Congress leaders tonight, toppling 2,990 pins to move into first place in the five-man t standings.

With Frank Shields and Mrs. Barger Wallach showing the way with a 6-1, 7-5 triumph over Mr. and Mrs. William B. Weaver, all four of the top-ranking pairs reached the semi-final round in the fifth annual mixed doubles invitation tennis tournament at the Island Court Club, Inc., yesterday.

Princess Catherine Gagarin, wife of Prince Serge Gagarin, died of a heart ailment here yesterday at her home on Bedford Road at the age of 50. Princess Gagarin was born in St. Petersburg and was married in 1909 to Prince Gagarin, a diplomat in the Czarist regime.
Miss Margaret F. Prentiss entertrained with a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Elizabeth Olive Sewall and Robert Horne Charles, whose. engagement has been announced.
Counsels of moderation to Poland and of resignation to Lithuania are being given by Paris, with no hope of support being held out to the latter if she should refuse to accept the Polish terms.
The Legislature and Governor Lehman united today in preserving the status quo so far as New York City's transit unification question is concerned.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is re- 2 flected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The the wee value of the foreign trade of Colombia during 1937 amounted to $180,609,000, compared with the $146,790,000 in 1936, an increase of about, 24 per cent, according to the Bureau of Foreign- and Domestic Commerce.

The position that Germany and Austria have held in the international wheat trade for the last few years should not be altered by the absorption of Austria by Germany, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics said today in its monthly review of the world wheat situation.
The Reconstruction Finance Corporation sold to Elisazetta Santeramo the four-story building containing a store and three apartments on a lot 24 by 66 feet at 640 Park Avenue, West New York.

CHARLOTTE,. N. C- J. B. Ivey Co.; Mrs G. McNeely, better dresses; Miss R. Gillian, sportswear; 1,412 Bway (Cavendish Trading Corp.). CHICAGO-Chicago Mail Order Co.; R. Anderson, cheaper sportswear, dresses; 53 W. 23d. DENVER--May Co.; R. R. Patrick, silverware; 1,440 Bway.
James Roosevelt, asked to run for Lieutenant Governor of Massachusetts in the September primary, told. a Bay State delegation today that he would require "a few weeks" before giving "a final reply."

The United Mine Workers of America, nucleus of the Committee for Industrial Organization, is seeking early repayment of $40,000 from the Pennsylvania Democratic Committee, the money to be used, at least in part, to help finance the C. I. O.'s Gubernatorial campaign against this same committee.

Members trading in round lots for their own accounts on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Feb. 19 was 20.97 per cent of the total volume, compared with 22.84 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

A discouraging weather forecast and reports of good conditions at only a few Winter sports are as tonight left New England skiers with little to cheer about. In New Hampshire, conditions were reported "excellent" at the Crawfords and "good" at Berlin, Littleton, Gorham and Whitefield.
The arrest of Nikolai Vassilevitch Krylenko, former Commissar of Justice, was indicated today by the publication of "wrecking" accusations against him.

In an outspoken defense of the Insurgent cause in Spain, Cardinal O'Connell of Boston, arriving on the Carinthia yesterday from a vacation in Nassau, pictured General Franco as a defender of Christian civilization, and warned that the United States was becoming infected with the same evil forces that are at the root of Europe's troubles.
A summary of the important parts of the proceedings in President Roosevelt's second day of inquiry into the intra-directorate dispute of the Tennessee Valley Authority is as follows:

Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne, in submitting the annual report of the Conservation Department, advocated the adoption of a ten-point program for the expansion of conservation activities throughout the State.

Glenn Cunningham again defeated Gene Venzke and Archie San Romani tonight, winning a special three-quarter mile run at the New Jersey A. A. U. indoor track championships. His time was 3:10.9. The time was 71/2 seconds behind the record of 3:03.4 set by Lloyd Hahn in New York in 1925,

An international "power consortium" of private monopoly interests, in which the Aluminum Company of America has been "omnipresent," is playing a major. part in blocking public development .of power in the international section of the St. Lawrence watershed,
Two United States Army observation planes locked wings in midair near Fort Stotsenburg today and crashed, killing two fliers and injuring a third.

Miss Barbara Dempsey Chase of this city was married this afternoon to George John Charles Mercer Nairne of Meikleour House, Perthshire, Scotland, son of Lady Violet Astor, in the Montecito Episcopal Church of All-Saints-by-theSea.

Power Memorial Academy of Manhattan got off to a fine start in defense of its 1937 laurels by beating Brooklyn Prep, 42 to 32, as the ninth annual metropolitan Catholic High Schools invitation basketball tournament got under way yesterday at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, clubhouse in Brooklyn.

President Roosevelt today gave Dr. Arthur E. Morgan an ultimatum to agree by Monday at 1:30 P. M. to produce evidence in support of his charges of dishonesty and malfeasance against his fellow-directors in the Tennessee Valley Authority or stand convicted by him of "contumacy."

Miss Edythe Langdale Fancourt, daughter of Walter F. Fancourt Jr. of Roxborough was married this afternoon to Morton H. Fetterolf Jr., grandson of Mrs. George Smith of New York and son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton H. Fetterolf of Highlie, Meadowbrook.

The resignation of Dr. Ernest Schelling as director of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra because of the "burden of private affairs," was announced last night by Frederick R. Huber, municipal director of music. Dr. Schelling has been unable to conduct this season.

More baseballs were belted lopsided by the Dodgers in two and a half hours of batting practice today than in the entire previous time in camp. Manager Burleigh Grimes, who finished the arduous pitching chores, was getting his men ready to open their grapefruit league season against the Red Sox here tomorrow.

Fred Pralle, fresh from the University of Kansas campus, provided the tinder which flared into a 45-to-39 victory for the Kansas City (Kan.) Healeys over the Bartlesville (Okla.) Phillips in a dramatic semi-final in the National A. A. U. basketball tournament tonight.

ANDERSON-Henry Burrall, at his home, Sands Point, L. I., March 17, 1938, father of Henry Hill and Joseph Larocque Anderson. Funeral Saturday, March 19, at 11:30 A. M., Trinity Church, Roslyn. L. I. Interment private. ANDERSON-Association of Ex-Members of Squadron A, Inc. With sincere regret announcement is made of the death on March 17, 1938, of Henry B. Anderson.

The Missouri Pacific Railroad disclosed yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission the terms of the deal sponsored by O. P. and M. J. Van Sweringen, whereby the Missouri Pacific was to acquire certain real estate and terminal properties from a Van Sweringen holding company for E about $20,000,000.

Prince Hadji Tahar ben Mohammed Ibn Saud Wahabi, Sherlif Hashmi, died yesterday at the age of 108 in Roosevelt Hospital. Soldier of fortune, friend of Presihents and intimate of kings, he had traveled over the world and was active until shortly before he died.

William A. Hamm, administrative assistant to the Board of Examiners and first assistant in history and civics at Walton High.School, the Bronx, was nominated yesterday to be assistant superintendent of schools by the Board of Superintendents.
Editors of student publications chosen in college elections completed at Barnard College yesterday include Miriam Weber, The Quarterly, literary magazine; Flora Ginsburg, The Bulletin,

The course of events in Europe has shown the worthlessness of German promises. Time and again the Nazi Government has affirmed its devotion to the cause of peace. And time and again it has confronted Europe with a new crisis brought about by its resort to force.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that a "tentative accord" had been reached with a group of ship owners on the question of employment of unlicensed seamen, which is one of' the most important items in a wage contract which the union and the ship lines are trying to draft.
Neil Petree has sold to a client of Louise 0. Meuer, Inc., broker, the English-type residence of nine rooms and four baths at 31 Morris Lane, Murray Hill, Scarsdale, Westchester.
Lester Brockelhurst, 24, of Galesburg, Ill., who confessed he killed three men after his arrest in New York City for a minor traffic violation, died in the electric chair here today.

Sales of the Climax Molybdenum Company in the first two months of. this year were ahead of the results in the like period in 1937, Max Scbott, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

The course of events in Europe has shown the worthlessness of German promises. Time and again the Nazi Government has affirmed its devotion to the cause of peace. And time and again it has confronted Europe with a new crisis brought about by its resort to force.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that a "tentative accord" had been reached with a group of ship owners on the question of employment of unlicensed seamen, which is one of' the most important items in a wage contract which the union and the ship lines are trying to draft.
Neil Petree has sold to a client of Louise 0. Meuer, Inc., broker, the English-type residence of nine rooms and four baths at 31 Morris Lane, Murray Hill, Scarsdale, Westchester.
Lester Brockelhurst, 24, of Galesburg, Ill., who confessed he killed three men after his arrest in New York City for a minor traffic violation, died in the electric chair here today.

Sales of the Climax Molybdenum Company in the first two months of. this year were ahead of the results in the like period in 1937, Max Scbott, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

By a sort-of."reverse alchemy" gold has been turned into radioactive mercury- in a 5,500,000-volt atomsmasher, Dr. Lee A. Dubridge, University of Rochester scientist, revealed today. The experiment was one of three achievements for the huge cyclotron announced by the physics professor who has just become dean of the university's Faculty of Arts and Sciences.

The House voted into the Administration's $1,120,000,000 Naval Construction Bill today provision for a minimum naval air force strength of 3,000 airplanes, thus making it possible to increase the service to any size deemed necessary for national defense without Congressional action.

A new test of whether refusal to bear arms in defense of the United States was a bar to citizenship was sought from the Supreme Court today by Abraham Warkentin, a Mennonite, who lost a plea on this line in the Seventh Circuit Court.

The New York Railroad Club was told last night that in 1963 the average man may be getting his food from "soilless farms," living in a world in which bacteria will be vanquished, wearing clothing of fireproof artificial fabrics made from cellulose or spun glass and occupying a house lighted, cooled, heated, humidified and air-cleaned automatically the year 'around by electricity.
Next week will see the theatre giving one of its final splurges of the season: four openings, arranged in this order:

The Legislature today continued for another year New York City's present taxing power for relief purposes, with only one concession to Mayor La Guardia's demands for new powers. The Governor contends that new powers are unnecessary, and the Legislature agreed.

Officers of the San Francisco i Stock Exchange and the Curb Exchange completed today a plan to merge the two markets subject to approval of members. The merger is designed to eliminate the expense of operating the Curb Exchange,

Following are the principal passages from the speech Chancellor Hitler delivered before the Reichstag tonight: "I have summoned you in order to give a report on events the importance of which you all appreciate. Moreover, I must bring to your cognizance decisions that concern the German people and the German Reichstag itself."
" Not an inch of Spanish territory will be ceded by us to any foreign power," Generalissimo Francisco Franco declared today in an interview with the Havas [French]. News Agency.

A consolidated net profit of $1,983,609 for 1937 was reported yesterday by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation. This was after deductions for depreciation, amortization, expenses and excess manufacturing and airport facilities, Federal income taxes, minority interests and $112,795 provision for surtax on undistributed earnings.
Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Meyers of 272 West 90th St. announce the engagement of their daughter, Gloria, to Mr. Eugene L. Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Berman.of Chicago.

The appointment of Harry J. Rockafeller, Rutgers 150-pound coach, and Edward Masavage and Frank Long, members of Harvey Harman's staff at Pennsylvania, as assistant coaches for Harman at Rutgers, was announced today by George E. Little, director of athletics.

Building costs throughout the country are definitely declining, reports the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which points out that an encouraging significant factor is that February building costs in four cities were lower than the costs for February, 1937.
The "stork derby," Charles Vance Millar's contribution to the fantastic side of competition, yielded its $500,000 prize today to four Toronto mothers in equal parts of $125,000.

As part of Lehigh University's inspection trips program, whereby students study the application of theory to industrial and commercial pursuits, about 150 men will make off-campus visits during the next two weeks.

Colonel Bill Terry and his Giants made a noble effort to carry New Orleans by storm today, but unfortunately, in swooping down upon the Indians in a great circle, they got caught in their own backwash and the result was most upsetting.

Tom Yawkey's eighteen-carat Red Sox finally found a team they could beat today. After dropping three straight in the Grapefruit League they helped Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers open their own local season by nosing them out, 4-3, scoring all their runs off young George Jeffcoat in the first three frames.

The General Electric Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries, the Electrical Securities Corporation and the G. E. Employes' Securities Corportion, have obtained from the Securities and Exchange Commission exemption until Dec. 31, 1939, from provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1936 which would require registration.

An educational venture, wherein mothers are taught the principles of child care and given the latest' theories of child psychology is meeting with enthusiastic response at the city's $12,500,000 Ten Eyck housing project in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, it was learned yetserday.
Mr. Wilmurt has missed the point of my letter about the present-day playwright and his production problems. Most certainly I do not want to "skimp on the whole. production";

Music has a therapeutic charm to heal as well as soothe the maladjusted and the ill, according to a report of the Federal Music Project in New York, which for three years has been conducting classes in seven city hospitals and two women's prisons.

Captain Don Bradman and Vice Captain Stanley McCabe of the Australian test cricket team hit centuries today against West Australia. The tourists started a three-day match yesterday. After dismissing the Western provinces for 192 runs Friday, the test team tallied 391, Bradman making 102 and his colleague 122.

An attempt to extend to all the schools of the country the fight against tuberculosis, scourge of American youth, will start April 1, as part of the "Early Diagnosis Campaign" of the National Tuberculosis Association, which is seeking to extend tuberculin testing and X-ray chest examinations as a standard principle of school health programs.

Many large corporations, which have their employes insured under the group plan, are trying to develop means whereby this insurance may be kept in force, despite the additional burden on the companies of unemployment and security fund taxes, insurance executives said yesterday.
A large supper dance was held tonight at the Ardsley Country Club. Among the hosts were Mr. and Mrs., Ward Clark, Mrs. Maude H. Bush and Mrs. Esmond B. Gardner.

HERE Mr. Glasscock tells the story of what oil did to Oklahoma and to the adventurers who took chances there and sometimes cashed in at the rate of $10,000 or better a day. It is a book well packed with facts and anecdotes concerning one of the greatest get-rich-quick booms in the memory of living men.

Wadsworth A. Parker of Metuchen, N. J., retired assistant treasurer of the American Type Founders Company, died suddenly today of a heart attack in a tourist home here. His age was 74. He arrived Thursday en route from Florida to his home.

A leader In the Investigation of labor problems and policies, the industrial relations section at Princeton University is now serving as a source of information for an everwidening circle of students both within the university and without.

Samuel H. Silberman of Stamford and Thomas N. Cooke of Greenwich, real estate brokers, were formally placed under arrest today under indictments for conspiracy in splitting sales commissions with G. Leroy Kemp, the State's land agent for the Merritt Parkway... They were released in bonds of $5,000 each.
Former Premier Nicolas Iorga in a Neamul Romanesc article urges Rumanians not to follow foreign rightist or leftist tendencies but only to seek Rumania's interests.
A novel Spring entertainment now in prospect is a preview supper dance to be given on April 21 in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria for the benefit of the Federation of Big Sisters.

Special arrangements were made yesterday by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for an examination tomorrow of Richard Whitney, indicted broker and head of the firm of Richard Whitney Co., which failed.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, speaking last night at the annual dinner of the Westchester County Democratic Committee at the New York Athletic Club, Travers Island, declared President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman were just as popular now as they were in 1936.

FACING Lafayette Square, halfway between the White House and the home of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, stands a ninestory limestone building. It might be a bank, except that there are no tellers' wickets on the ground floor.

All Poland gave a sigh of relief at noon today when newspaper extras and loudspeakers informed the public that there would be no war with Lithuania, no march on Kaunas, because the Lithuanian Government had fully and unconditionally accepted the proposals contained in the Polish Government's ultimatum of last Thursday.
MARCH winds, according to legend, bring April showers, yet to the amateur photographer they also bring the first of the magnificent cloud formations of Spring and Summer.
Miss Millicent Bancroft, daughter of Mrs. Walter Bancroft of Buffalo and London, England, was married here yesterday afternoon to William Brown Cleland, Canadian sportsman.
The prolonged debate in the Senate over the government reorganization bill has centered in part around the provision to alter the present Federal accounting and auditing system.

The chairman of one of John L. Lewis's C. I. 0. locals, which labor leaders had expected to give unified support to the Governorship candidacy of Lieutenant Governor Thomas Kennedy, attacked the C. I. 0. political leadership today and announced support of Charles A. Jones, the Democratic State Committee's candidate for Governor.

The night owl and the keeper of late hours will have to form the reception committee to welcome back Spring this year. for the vernal season will steal in under cover of darkness tomorrow at precisely 1:43 A. M., when many New Yorkers are fast asleep, the Hayden Planetarium advised yesterday.
IN New York, where space is so precious, stark service must be the function of every building. It would be improvident to spend money on imaginative architecture.

For his first American recital yesterday. afternoon atTown Hall, Kurt Appelbaum, young German pianist played the Schubert G major sonata, Op. 78;-the Beethoven sonata in E flat, Op. 7; the Mozart B flat sonata, K.333, and the Beethoven sonata in C minor, Op. 111.

A social club for women more than 50 years old, who have no home ties and limited social life, which was established by leaders in the field of social welfare, received the commendation of the city administration last week at dedication exercises held in the club's new quarters at 229 Lexington Avenue.

Miss Carolyn Mary Howell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Rushton Howell of Wayne, was married this afternoon to David Andrew Gordon Mutch, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Andrew Mutch of Wynnewood. The bridegroom's father is the former pastor of the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church.

In a monograph which is entitled "Axial Bifurcation in Serpents," and which comes from the press of Duke 'University, Dr. Bert Cunningham collects for his fellowbiologists 170 verified cases of twoheaded snakes, some of which also had two tails or parallel spinal columns.

America should express firmly democracy's disapproval of the tactics of dictatorship, rabbis advocated in sermons here yesterday. Some of them praised Secretary Hull for his speech before the National Press Club on Thursday when he declared America stood for peace but would not retreat before the forces of international anarchy.

Maritime employment would be sharply reduced and would not be offset by an increased railroad personnel if the Pettengill bill, which is now before Congress, were passed, according to William H. Chandler, traffic manager of the Merchants Association.

Pointing out that a group of representative Manhattan loft structures showed a larger operating deficit during 1937 than in 1935, Leon Spear, vice president of Spear Co., Inc., real estate operators, stated yesterday that owners of such property face a further loss in 1938 as a result of the jump in the tax rate.
Despite the plea of Arnett A. Booth to "lay all the blame on me, Governor Homer A. Holt said today he would not intervene in the execution Monday of three convicted kidnappers of Dr. James I. Seder.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Douglas P. Arnold of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Howie Arnold, to David Jameson Bond, son of Walter H. Bond of Garden City, L. I., and the late Mrs. Bond. Miss Arnold was graduated from the Buffalo Seminary and, in 1937, from Vassar College.

The 1937-38 season of the Metropolitan Opera Association closed last night as it began sixteen weeks ago-with a Wagner music-drama attended by an audience that packed all available seats and standing room. "Tristan und Isolde" opened the season; "Goetterdaemmerung" closed it.
The old floating bath, once a familiar sight in the waters surrounding Manhattan but discontinued because of insanitary conditions in 1915, is due for a comeback-in a new and glorified form.

St. Peter's College, Jersey City, will present Friday evening in the Collins Auditorium on the campus an intercollegiate symposium on Spain, with Ogden Haggerty Hammond, United States Ambassador to Spain from 1925 to 1929, as chairman.
Columbia's baseball team met Manhattan at Baker Field yesterday in the first practice game of the season for both teams and defeated the Jaspers by 5 to 3 in seven easygoing innings.
The people living in the vast watershed of the Columbia River are watching intently the strife 2,500 miles away among the directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Mr. and Mrs. J. T. C. Hopkins Jr. of Port Deposit, Md., have announced to friends here the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Catherine Wylie Hopkins, to William Norman Taylor of Cristobal, Panama Canal Zone, son of Mrs. Harry Brinckerhoff Doyle of New York and of William David Taylor of Cristobal.

Despite their tearful pleas that disbarment was sufficient punishment, Louis Muraskin, 42 years old, and his brother, Abraham, 28, both lawyers, were sentenced yesterday to serve two years each in a Federal penitentiary for complicity In a bankruptcy fraud.

Premier Koloman Daranyi today denied rumors of forthcoming changes in his Cabinet and internal policy. He explained that recent events abroad had not the slightest influence on the course of domestic affairs.
TWO worth-while pamphlets on safety made their appearance last week. One is the fifth illustrated booklet in the Sportsmanlike Driving series published by the American Automobile Association.

Invitations will be sent out this week for the Ball of Tomorrow, the entertainment to be given by the Junior League of New York on April 29 in the Business Administration Building at the grounds of the World's Fair.

A concert of modern American music has been arranged for Friday evening at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc. Mrs. J. Philip Benkard is chairman of the arrangements committee for the event.

WITH the building of roads and the stabilizing of the country, Greece has been opened to motorists. Not long ago the choice of travel there was limited; one went where there was a road and an inn. As for the food, those who were wise took it from Athens. All that is now history. A good road runs north to Delphi; another down into the Peloponnesus.
AGAIN the American all-wave radio listener has had an exciting week along the international dial as Chancellor Hitler manoeuvred to change the map of Europe.
Following three mysterious fires in five weeks, the liner Berengaria is to be laid up for at least seven months, according to the Liverpool correspondent of The Sunday Times.

The Skidmore Alumnae Clubs of the metropolitan area are now arranging their annual Spring dance, which will take place on the night of April 2 at Sherry's. Net proceeds will augment the scholarship fund of Skidmore College.

SIX years ago I ventured to make a prophecy (in The Architectural Forum) in regard to theatre building. As it seems to be coming true I venture to repeat it: The commercial theatre has been so overbuilt that even a sudden return of prosperity could hardly fill the theatres already

CLEARLY there is a shift from complexes to reflexes in current analysis of human nature, and the supremacy of the psychoanalyst who drew his deductions largely from observation of those who were sick in body and soul seems to be weakening.

An increase of 19.8 per cent in revenue passenger-miles flown by domestic airlines last February as compared with the corresponding month of 1937 was announced yesterday by Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America.
College Women's Club of Jackson Heights-Guest day. John Mason Brown, speaker on "Broadway in Review," 3:30 P. M., Jackson Heights Clubhouse.

Henry Wilfred (Bunny) Austin, England's 31year-old stylist of the tennis courts, announced today he would not be available for Davis Cup play this year. Ace of the British team which lost the cup to the United States last Summer,

Form ran true without a single disaster to any of the top-seeded entrants in the metropolitan badminton championships as play in the men's and women's singles advanced through the semi-final round last night on the courts of the Old Sixty-ninth Badminton Club in the 165th Infantry Armory.
Coal operators of the country, without price regulation since abandonment of the Bituminous Coal Commission' schedule, are working for cooperative price fixing.

One thousand women with a talent for parenthood are wanted by the Joint Home Finding Committee for Jewish Children. And it will not be easy to find them, in the opinion of Mrs. Arthur Lehman, who heads the committee, for the attributes of the foster mother are of a highly specialized nature.

Moot trials and jury schools have failed to make Nassau County women jury-minded, according to John S. Thorp, Jury Commissioner at Mineola, who reports that approximately 1,000 women have registered for service.
Times Square crowds got a demonstration last night of the surprise technique in radical demonstrations. Pulling anti-Hitler placards out from under their coats, several thousand members of the

Two current exhibits of children's art demonstrate the growing recognition of the importance of creative work in the curricula of schools ranging from correctional institutions to those advocating progressive education.

Joe Beggs was seized with a fit of wildness as the Yankees resumed hostilities with the Cardinals in the Grapefruit League today and the world champions became one down to the clan of Frankie Frisch in the series that has now spun past its third chapter.

With 10 per cent of the applicants for unemployment insurance in this State complaining that they were not receiving benefits due, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews put into effect yesterday an emergency procedure designed to speed the handling of disputed claims.
Thirty-five newsboys from. the Burroughs Newsboys Foundation of Boston arrived in New York yesterday morning.
IN control of automobile accidents, Sweden, noted for her social experiments, can again challenge American interest. Among her recent steps in the field of traffic safety are:

Miss Jane Peets, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur J. Peets of this city, was married here tonight to William Ernest Hayes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Hayes of Keyport, at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur H. Ryan, pastor of the First Baptist Church.

Supported by an increaring weight of medical, editorial and popular opinion, the American Committee on Maternal Welfare last week carried to the State Board of Regents its-fight to obtain an unrestricted license in New York for the showing of its educational film production, "The Birth of- a Baby.
FOR the past five years the most impressive reports have been coming out of France about Georges

ALTHOUGH the theatre looks drab to the oldsters whose memory goes back twenty or thirty years it looks bright to hundreds of young people. Gotham is bulging with apprentices. They will give their right arms for a chance to show what they can do. In many cases,
New regulations to improve the appearance of licensed stands in order to make them attractive to visitors to the World's Fair were announced yesterday by Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses.

Miss Harriet Frances Haffenreffer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolf Frederick Haffenreffer of this city, was married to Philip Bacon Hosmer Jr., son of Mr. Hosmer and the late Mrs. Hosmer of Chicago, in the First Congregational Church here today.

Some 160 members of the New York Alumni Association of the State Normal School at Potsdam, N. Y., heard yesterday a prediction that normal schools in the State would soon have the right to grant degrees.

More petitions from business for elimination of the undistributed profits tax principle, a return to a flat-rate tax on capital gains, a reduction of the higher surtax rates, and a broadening of the tax base marked the second day's hearings of the Senate Finance Committee on the pending Tax Bill today.

Professor B. Owens of Stanford University, president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said today he couldn't predict whether his organization would take an official stand on the shift in dates of the 1940 Olympic Games at Tokyo.

Miss Ruth Allgeier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Allgeier of West Orange, was married to Siegfried Gerold Bart, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. B. Bart of East Orange, this afternoon in St. Cloud Presbyterian. Church by the pastor, the Rev. R. Lloyd Roberts.

Representative and Mrs. Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane B. Celler, to Sydney B. Wertheimer Jr., son of Mrs. Sydney B. Wertheimer of New York and the late Mr. Wertheimer.
ONCE more, and for the hundred and thirteenth time, the National Academy steps out as an exhibiting organization. The list of guest artists is ten times as long as the list of prizes;

From Texas to the Carolinas and from Cairo to the Gulf, the South's planters of cotton and tobacco returned to their acres this week after giving the principle of crop control the most complete endorsement it has had since the first row of cotton was plowed under in 1933 in a desperate attempt to raise the price of that staple.

The New England A. A. U. hockey tournament, scheduled today, was postponed indefinitely, it was announced by James E. Darke, A. A. U. Hockey Commissioner for Rhode Island. Lack of entries was the reason, Darke said.
Dr. Charles Henry Leonard, who during his sixty-eight years of practice here performed more than 175,000 vaccinations against smallpox, died today at his home at the age of 97.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 16, aggregated $8,469,000,000, or 16 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 22 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

ONLY a poet and, perhaps, only a young poet could have written this beautiful and distinguished first novel In it May Sarton has created a little world of some half dozen people and she has given them rich, bountiful life, not only pregnant with meaning for this present instant of time in which she has placed them, but deeply rooted in that humanity which is ageless.

Strange paradoxes in the status of women in various countries are apparent from a "listening post" in Geneva at the present time, according to Miss Ruth Woodsmall, general secretary of the World Y. W.

The engagement of Miss Margaret E. Baerlocher, daughter of Mrs. George C. Baerlocher of this place and the late Mr. Baerlocher, to Eugene F. Frey, son of Mrs. Mayre V. Frey of Orange and the late John Q. Frey, has been announced by her mother.

Three programs devotedAto Latin, Byzantine-Russian and new American music will feature the third annual choir festival on Fridar and Saturday, sponsored by Congregation Emanu-EI, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street.

Charles H. Reis, building developer in Bergen and Passaic Counties, reports the sale of forty-three homes during the last four weeks in his two residential communities at River Edge, Bergen County, and Allwood, near Passaic, Passaic County.
George W. Todd, founder with his brother Libanus of the Todd Protectograph Company, died tonight at his home here at the age of 78. He had been ill for four years.
Cabin Fire, a 5-year-old bay gelding owned by L. W. Robinson Jr. of Indiana, Pa., won the $1,000 Yadkin Steeplechase, two and a half miles over brush, with a time of 5 minutes 34 seconds today.

Reports that Senator King of Utah has introduced an amendment to the pending customs administration bill, by which the United States Customs Court would be deprived of its jurisdiction in a large portion
Glenn Cunningham went through his usual routine tonight at the annual senior Metropolitan A. A. U. indoor track and field championships in the Jersey City Armory.
The Navy fencers closed their season of dual matches today by defeating the New York Fencers Club, 17 to 10. The Navy won with foil and saber, each by 7 to 2, but lost with the epee, 6 to 3.
FIGHTER: Some weeks ago, afterr defeating the English boxer Tommy Farr, James J. Braddock, former world's heavyweight champion,
The Kansas City Healeys rallied in the second half tonight to beat the Denver Safeways, defending champions, 40 to 38, and win the National A. A. U. basketball title.

General John J. Pershing in his sickroom in Tucson, Ariz., and other West Point men in camp and barracks the world around were reunited last night for half an hour in celebrating the 136th anniversary of the Military Academy.
Coming from behind in the final period, New Brunswick's powerful quintet captured the New Jersey Group 4 basketball title tonight, defeating Memoral High of West New York, 27-24.

Frederick Marquard of 99 Autumn Avenue, Brooklyn, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Ruth Marquard, to Richard Parker Sawyer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alpha R. Sawyer of Chestnut Hill, Mass.

The income tax, increasingly important source of government revenue, produced $2,148,663,876 for the Federal Government during the fiscal year 1937, and preliminary figures for the first payment, due last Tuesday, on 1937 income, indicate a considerably higher return for the fiscal year 1938, which ends June 30.
EUROPE'S Summer tourist plans-subject, of course, to change in case of further international complications-begin this year at one of its principal gateways, Glasgow, Scotland,
Housing projects should have a more advanced place in city planning than the newly formed City Planning Commission seems willing to give them, Miss Helen Alfred, executive secretary of the National

A Federal court hearing here today on a petition by six bondholders for reorganization of the Hudson Coal Company was adjourned by Judge Albert W. Johnson after he had reached an understanding with counsel for both sides that he would pass later upon preliminary questions of law raised in the argument.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey tanker Esso Boston was launched here this morning at the yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company as the eighth of ten oil carriers in a $16,000,000 construction program begun in 1936.

George T. Dunlap Jr. of Pinehurst won the championship of the Tin Whistle Club today for the fifth consecutive year with a score of 69, 75-144. He established a lead in the first round Thursday over the championship course and although he was far off his best form today on the No. 3 course

PALM BEACH, Fla.-Because of the recent surfeit of large charity affairs, members of the Woman's Guild of Betheda-by-the-Sea have waited until this week for their annual benefit; this, a large bridge tea, will be held tomorrow afternoon in the rectory and Cluett Memorial Gardens, noted for their large variety of rare tropical plants.

Joseph Cefalo, whose number was the first to be drawn in the draft for the World War, died today after a long illness at the age of 43. Cefalo, son of Italian immigrant parents, was an awning-maker in Boston when the late Newton D. Baker, then Secretary of War, drew his number in Washington.

Police of the Missing Persons Bureau broadcast an alarm yesterday for Charles Anatra, 48-year-old dress contractor of 2,030 Seventythird Street, Brooklyn, after several pieces of his clothing had been found earlier in the day on Shore Road near Seventy-fifth Street, Brooklyn.
Abraham Sherr of 900 West End Avenue has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Estelle G. Sherr, to Frank P. Schwarz, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Schwarz of this city.

Is there a rift between business and educations This question was raised recently in a forum at Teachers College, where leaders from business sat down with educators for a discussion of mutual problems. In the following article the dean of Teachers College presents education's point of view, with suggestions for bringing the two groups together again.

President Roosevelt has been urged to respond favorably to the invitation of the Soviet Government for a conference to save the world from aggression in a message sent to the White ouse by the American Student Union.
THREE HUNDRED years ago a group of Swedes founded a colony on the banks of the Delaware near-what is now Wilmington.

Turning a deaf ear to the recommendation of the town advisory committee, Nahant voters today blocked an appropriation of $2,000 for the entertainment of President Roosevelt on his visit here next June to attend the wedding of his son, John, and Miss Anne Lindsay Clark.
Joseph M. Chapin, president of the Watchung Coal Company of West Orange since 1927, died here last night at his home, 61 Cleveland Street.

The sale of the art property of the late Marie Louise Paterson, which began on Thursday, ended yesterday afternoon at the ParkeBernet Galleries. Altogether the sale netted $80,452.50, the final session alone realizing $20,990.

The crisis between Poland and Lithuania has apparently been settled, or at least postponed, through the acceptance by Kaunas of the terms of the ultimatum of Warsaw. Faced by the threat of military invasion, with a Polish force three or four ticdes the size of the Lithuanian Army perched on the border ready to advance, the Cabinet of the little Baltic country bowed before the danger to its national existence.

Members of the Teachers Union and other organizations here have started a drive to gain clemency for Sidney Babsky, a former New York City school teacher who was recently captured by Rebel forces in Spain.

Colonel Duncan G. Harris, whowas major of the Third Battalion of the 305th Infantry during the Argonne offensive, and William J. McGinnity, a sergeant with the 305th during the World War, will be guests of honor of the 305th Infantry Association at a dinner tomorrow night at the Seventy-seventh Division Clubhouse. 28 East Thirty-ninth Street.

Winning in all three divisions, the Yale varsity fencing team defeated Harvard, 16 1/2 to 10 1/2, in the Harvard indoor athletic building today. Captain Maurice Grasson of Yale, son of Coach RobertGrasson, was outstanding, annexing all his epee bouts by one-sided scores.

A runaway horse injured three men yesterday morning on East Sixty-sixth Street, between Second and York Avenues. Frightened by an automobile horn, the animal, hitched to a wagonload of produce, bolted east on Sixty-sixth Street.
It is too early as yet to evaluate the results of the famous drifting expedition of the four Soviet scientists who voluntarily marooned themselves on a floe.
Among the 687 patents granted by the United States Patent Office this week the following attracted Inter est because of their novel character:
Alex C. Johnson, retired vice president of the Chicago North Western Railway Company, died yesterday in his Winter home here at the age of 70.

Concern over Spring style trends calling for the display of artificial flowers on hats and lapels, and over the conditions under which they are made by home workers has motivated plans for a luncheon discussion marking the first day of Spring tomorrow. Mrs. Felice J.
The Hershey Bears defeated the New York Rovers, 4 to 2, tonight and moved two points nearer the championship in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League.
In preparation for flower and garden exhibits planned for the coming season by Connecticut women's clubs, a variety of programs is scheduled featuring speakers on various aspects of gardening.

Willie Mosconi, youthful Philadelphian, brought about a triple tie for first place in the world championship pocket billiard tournament by defeating Andrew Ponzi, another Philadelphian, 125 to 118, in 28 innings as the round-robin schedule was completed last night at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

The committee of physicians sponsoring a set of principles and proposals aimed to improve the distribution of medical care among the American population has appealed to medical men for funds. The appeal was sent out by Professor John P. Peters of the Yale University School of Medicine, secretary of the committee.

Mme. Wilhelm A. F. Ekengren, widow of the former Minister from Sweden, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Laura Christina Ekengren, to Richard H. Hawkins of Pittsburgh. The wedding will take place April 23 in St. John's Church here.

Announcement has been made to friends here of the engagement of Miss Julie Hamilton Butler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. C. M. Butler of Conyngham, Pa., to Arthur Brown Deisroth of Hazleton, Pa., son of Mrs. Arthur Deisroth and the late Mr. Deisroth. The wedding will take place next August.
ALL commanders and assistant commanders of Soviet airships are engineers graduated from a special institution of higher learning maintained under Moscow to train dirigible personnel.
Impressed by the courage of a blind Nevada gold miner, a New York radio entertainer paid for an

Despite freight rate increases in the past six months, estimated at $240,000,000 a year, the railroads and their difficulties were again the subject of a succession of conferences at Washington last week.

EASTERN college students were lately asked, "What New Yorkers would you most like to meet?" They headed their lists with Mayor La Guardia. That was easy. Then, knitting their young brows and looking over the field of 6,999,999 candidates remaining, they wrote, in great numbers, "Robert Moses." And that wasn't so hard, either.

Spring was definitely forecast last week on the campus of New Jersey College for Women by the selection of committees for the leading events of the Spring calendar. Mo st important is the committee for Senior Week,
C. E. Davison's Chance Ray captured the $2,000 added Hammond Handicap at the Fair Grounds today when Mrs. Sam Orr's gelding, Orinoco, was disqualified.

THE Englishman started out in February, to meet the Spring. And in the railway station in Paris the amplifier called out a list of stations that was itself sonorous and alluring: "Limoges," it announced, "Cahors, Montauban, Toulouse, Carcassonne, Narbonne, Perpignan."

A bipartisan move to repeal the neutrality acts has taken definite form in Congress, it became known today. The object is to remove what are considered embarrassing restrictions and to permit a reversal of the Administration's foreign policy and the complete abandonment of an isolationist viewpoint.

NOTHING in tournament bridge is more unpredictable than the number of pairs that will enter a mixed - pair contest. The Long Island Bridge League expected about sixteen pairs for its annual mixed-pair game at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn last Sunday.

The first of the 1938 real-estate tax bills based on the new high basic tax rate of $2.80 will be mailed to property owners tomorrow by the Department of Finance. By the end of the week all the 800,000 property owners will have received their bills, which cover the entire year.
SIR HARRY LAUDER, 67 years young, came a roamin' in the gloamin' down the transatlantic wave lengths during the past week with all the spirit of a youthful troubadour.

Miss Dorothy Kenyon, recently appointed to a committee to study the legal status of women by the Council of the League of Nations, will be honored at a reception today at 4 P. M. at the Cornish Arms Hotel, 311 West Twenty-third Street. She sails on Saturday for Geneva.
Donald Vernam, 23 years old, of Trenton, parachute jumper, was killed, and Otto Vannest, 31, of Washington Crossing, critically injured late today in an airplane crash at a private flying field.
The Lithuanian acceptance .of the Polish ultimatum has lessened but by no Ed means ended the anxiety in League of Nations and Lithuanian quarters here.
THE distinction of Edmund Wilson's criticism, unusual enough in our age of confusion, has been to keep his eye, separately and collectively, on both objects, the objects being life and literature.
Dr. Francis I. Nettleton, medical examiner, health officer and former Mayor here, died today in his home at the age of 63.

Mr. and Mrs. Vincent F. McLarney of Hempstead, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Scanlan McLarney, to Eugene G. Rae, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Rae, also of Hempstead.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Godfrey Heller of Bayside, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Austin Heller, to Robert V. Hagan, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Thomas Hagan of Sharon, Mass.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: American public opinion has been aroused by the introduction of ghetto benches for Jewish students in several Polish universities.
After being at odds with the rector, the Rev. Kenneth Ripley Forbes, for months, the vestry men and other officers of St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church here, today resigned in a body.
