The week-old tie-up of the port by the liftboard dispute between employers and longshoremen became more acute tonight when one stevedoring concern broke away from the operators' group and will attempt to load a citrus cargo on the Italian motorshiD Edda.

Three "complete" houses designed to appeal to persons of varying tastes and incomes are grouped in the 1938 "Bride's House," opening tomorrow in the Savoy Plaza Hotel, 11 East Fifty-eighth Street, under the sponsorship of House Beautiful. Wallace W. Heath is the architect.

American women as a class have won the "unchallenged status of being the best dressed women in the world," Emil Alvin Hartman, director of the Fashion Academy in Rockefeller Center, yesterday declared at the annual luncheon of the academy at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

NOTHING can quench the music-loving gayety of the mid-Danubian nations. In what was Austria the situation may be disturbing, but the Viennese have never surrendered to gloom in centuries of MittelEuropa strife and upheaval.

Defending the Board of Elections against charges of waste and inefficiency in its printing contracts, S. Howard Cohen, president of the board, declared that most of the board's printing was mandatory under the State Election Law.

MIAMI, Fla., March 19.-Miss Ann Welch, daughter of Mrs. Laura Welch of Miami, was married to Wilbur C. Brewer today on board the yacht of Mrs. F. Donald Coster of Fairfield, Conn. Justice of the Peace Rawls Johnston officiated.

Stricken with a heart attack as he was entering the Agua Caliente, Mexico, race track grandstand, Joseph Michaels, clothing manufacturer and financier of Rochester, N. Y., died yesterday, it was disclosed today. His age was 88.

German for eign trade dropped again in Feb ruary after suffering a severee loss in January. The trade balance was again unfavorable, though reduced from 37,000,000 marks to 17,000,000 marks by drastic cuts in imports, affecting chiefly European countries.

Chicago's thr new tumor institute, to be devoted ing exclusively to cancer research and treatment and education for combating cancer, will open Monday. It is incorporated as a non-profit organization.
Dr. and Mrs. John W. Burke have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Atkinson Burke, to Richard Woolen Emory, son of Mrs. German H. Emory and the late Major Emory of Baltimore.

President Will Harridge of the American League has been looking over the teams on the citrus circuit. As usual, he foresees a real race in the American League this year. It's a Harridge habit, and the tall, thin, dark-complexioned leader of the American League is not one to change his habits carelessly.

The Music Department of Washington Irving High School will sponsor an entertainment Friday afternoon and evening and Saturday afternoon to aid the Student Welfare Fund. The program is to take the form of a "World Cruise," with music, songs and dances typical of ports the world over.

DANE COOLIDGE has practiced the craft of Western fiction for many years and has published a score or more of volumes. Today he has no living superior in his chosen field. Each new tale that he writes is a masterpiece in its genre.

Mrs. William Howard Koppelman of Louisville, Ky., has announced to friends here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Josephine Koppelman, to Richard Chamberlin Scott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Lyon Scott of New York and Martha's Vineyard, Mass.
Property divisions, the racial question and voting procedure were dominant issues in the arguments among Southern Methodist leaders today over unification with northern branches of the church.
The United States is awaiting fuller official information on the seizure of American oil organizations by the Mexican Government before indicating whether she will protest.

Despite strong arguments by opponents, the Legislature passed this morning by large majorities in both houses the McNaboe bill barring persons advocating subversive doctrines from holding public positions, civil service jobs or positions in schools throughout the State.

WE are living in revolutionary times. Within a week the forces of fascism have struck twice in Austria and in Spain. Adolf Hitler is the leader and symbol of these forces--the moving spirit behind the gigantic tides which are sweeping over Europe, battering down old boundaries, old ideals, old ways of life.

New England industry, led by the New England Council, representing all six States, and by the associated industries of Massachusetts, protests strenuously against the projected reciprocity pact with Great Britain.

The brewers of the nation are prepaying to observe happily the fifth anniversary of the return of legal beer on April 7-a day that marked the rebirth of their industry and benefited many others, the United Brewers Industrial Foundation reminded yesterday.

MOST travelers abroad delight in the oddity and variety of the foods served in the different lands. From the moment the visitor debarks at, say Plymouth, or Southampton, and boards a train for London, he is intrigued by "different" foods and ways of serving them.
Japanese cherry trees here may produce their finest show of blossoms during the first week of April, park officials said today.

President Roosevelt has been named an "honorary curator of wild- life of--the Boy Scout nature museum of the Kips Bay Boys Club, 301 East Fifty-second Street, by the- members of the Scout troop attached to the club, it was announced yesterday.

Three members of the faculty of the College of New Rochelle will conduct a symposium on the Constitution of the United States on Tuesday evening in the sports building on the campus. The Very Rev. Francis W. Walsh, president of the college, will preside.

WITH distinct emphasis on aircraft manufactured by. Southern California's $75,000,000 aeronautics industry, gates of the third annual National Pacific Aircraft and Boat Show will open here on April 2.

The St. Regis Paper Company and it subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1937 a net income of $1,188,875 after interest, depreciation, Federal and foreign income taxes (including approximately $176,000 for surtax on undistributed profits), subsidiary preferred dividends and Other charges.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler was said by diplomatic sources today to have demanded that Czechoslovakia abandon her military alliance with Soviet Russia--but the Czech Government showed no indication it would comply.
Club presidents, program chairmen and directors of the Westchester County Federation of Women will meet for their annual luncheon Friday at the Bronxville Women's Club.
The Crescent Athletic Club defeated the Columbus Council K. of C., 57 to 40, on the latter's court in Brooklyn last night in an Eastern Athletic Club Basketball League contest.

" We don't dig no gasoline-we dig coal!'; which expression has united Whitwell almost to a man in a unique sixtyday test of community cooperation that all hope will put the skids under the depression here.

Despite brilliant playing on the part of Frank Shields, former Davis Cup star, he and his partner, Mrs. Barger Wallach, met defeat yesterday in the semi-final round of the fifth annual invitation mixed doubles tennis tournament at the Island Court Club, Inc.

Mrs. Einilie Benson Welsh, wife of Major Blanton C. Welsh, U. S. A. retired, died here today at her residence, 24 Upper Mountain Avenue, after an illness of three weeks, of a cardiac affection. She was born seventy-five years agb in Old Short Hills, N. J., and had lived in Montclair since 1898.

Miss Kathryn Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Taylor of this place, became the bride of M. Edgerton Newcomb, son of Mrs. Mortimer E. Newcomb, also of Westfield, at the home of the bride's parents, 17 Stoneleigh Park, this afternoon.

She has bought well over a million books since she became chief buyer for the New York Public Library five years ago, but Miss Eliza Marquess still finds enthusiasm to spare for her own private collection.
Mr. and Mrs. Isadore S. Koeppel of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Gertrude Koeppel, to Dr. Samuel Meyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Meyer of Brooklyn.

The disappearance of Austria as an independent State and its incorporation in the German Reich was formally accepted as a fact today by the United States through a statement issued by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

The stroke by which Chancellor Hitler established his claim over Austria, following as it did the resignation of Anthony Eden as the British Foreign Secretary, has aroused grave concern in Washington.

PITTSFIELD, Mass.-With the arrival of Spring, rainbow and brook trout activities have started at Pittsfield. The Onota Lake Rainbow Trout Rearing Association has opened its second annual campaign to raise a budget of $2,105, with the aid of the Pittsfield Sportsmen's Club, the Pittsfield Chamber of Commerce and the Berkshire Hills, Conference.

CHART-MAKERS who map the sharp decline in employment are very busy these days. Their graphs, with zigzags, curves and angles, are displayed before Senate committees, relief boards, State and city officials and welfare agencies.

A MOVIE camera in tow of a lone Hollywood explorer poked its lens at various casual pedestrians in a Vienna street some weeks ago and stopped before the red carpet and tubbed palms of the Hotel 'Bristol.

The Census Bureau reported today that the cotton spinning industry operated during February at 98.9 per cent of capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 93.5 per cent during January this year, and 144.8 per cent during February last year.

Substantially pure Vitamin A-a preparation so concentrated that it is almost 15,000 times more potent in this vitamin than ordinary medicinal cod-liver oil -has been isolated in the Severance chemical laboratory at Oberlin College, Oberlin, Ohio.

The Rev. James Gilbert Mason, a former Prohibition party candidate for Governor and one of the oldest Presbyterian ministers in the United States, died at ,his home last night. His age was 96.

Johnny Kelley, Arlington marathon star, started from scratch today and won his fifth consecutive Medford 20-mile road run. Taking the lead at the seven-mile mark, the former Boston marathon champion withstood a home-stretch challenge by Gerald Cote of St. Hyacinthe, Que., and romped across the finish line 20 yards out front.

TODAY marks the start of National Wild Life Conservation Week, in observance of which America's 1,129,827 Scouts, Cubs and their leaders have been invited to join by the General Wild Life Federation. Throughout the land lads in khaki will do special conservation work.
Miss Caroline H. Sullivan, who taught public school children in Haverstraw for forty-six years and belonged to a family of sisters who had been school teachers, died yesterday at her home.

LAST year about 373,650' persons sailed from American and Canadian ports for Europe. Of these 153,301 were third-class passengers. It is estimated that some 20,000 Americans were drawn to England in May by the coronation.

Estate, more than $10,000. To the Home for the Aged of the Little Sisters of the Poor, 213 E. 70th St., residue; Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Detroit, Mich., $3,000; Priscilla Starret, 214 Classon Ave., Brooklyn, $1,000; eight minor bequests. Harry J. Camp, 1,481 12th St., Brooklyn, executor.

A special performance of the Columbia University 1938 varsity show, "You've Got Something There," will be given at the Community Center here on April 2 under the auspices of a committee of more than 200 Columbia alumni of Westchester County.

A sharp controversy between floor-coverings retailers and, their suppliers over the necessity for protecting stores against inventory losses when prices decline flared up here last week following sharp price reductions on linoleum and felt-base goods.

Dr. and Mrs. Philip Carter Washburn of Greystone Park, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Gale Washburn, to Walter Lee Savell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Savell of Forest Hills, Queens.

Russell Mablethorpe, trainer of O. J. Jackson's Mythical Ray, today announced the gelding will not start in Wednesday's Lincolnshire Handicap, and thus put an end to a "dream double" craze sweeping the betting public.

The investment banking community, scarcely recovered from its battle against some of the restrictive provisions of the Maloney bill for regulation of over-thecounter securities markets, was presented with new problems by certain developments last week.

An official communique this morning announced that diplomatic relations with the Barcelona Government had been broken off because of failure of negotiations over the in vasion of the Madrid consulate in May, 1937,

Members of the Sunshine-Radio System, Inc., one of the two large taxicab fleet associations which several weeks ago locked out its employes, will hold a special meeting tomorrow morning to consider liquidation of their organization.

The first-place tie in the English Football League was broken today when Arsenal went ahead with a 5-1 victory over Grimsby Town at Highbury. Stoke City held the Wolverhampton Wanderers to a 2-2 deadlock and the Wolves were forced to share second berth with Preston North End, winner by 2-1 over Manchester City at Maine Road.

Persons interested in construction features will have an opportunity during the next ten days of inspecting the recently constructed but undecorated and unfurnished model home, erected in the Hartsdale Acres development in connection with the forthcoming Westchester County Home Show.
To the younger generation of men in Wall Street Mr. Noyes is probably best known as the financial editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Miss Mary C. Willard was elected president of the Elizabeth Junior League, succeeding Mrs. Harold S. Brewster, at a meeting in the Elizabeth Town and Country Club here this week. Other officers, all of whom will assume office at the annual meeting in May, include:

Thirty-nine anthracite operating and sales companies have joined in a petition to the Interstate Commerce Commission, seeking clarification of the ruling authorizing railroads to increase the freight rates on hard coal 10 cents a ton, it was revealed here today.

Frederick William Kruse, former presiding justice of the Appellate Division, Fourth Department, Supreme Court, died in his home here last night, after a long illness. He was 85 years old. Justice Kruse had been retired for the last fifteen years.
The feature of the foreign exchange market here today was the all-round improvement in sterling. The currency was supported by the large sale of gold by the British Exchange Equalization Fund.

A resolution directed at aggressor nations failed to receive the necessary unanimous approval for passage at the New England Model League of Nations, which held its final assembly at Massachusetts State .College today.

" ESTHER DE CARPENTRAS," an opera-bouffe in two acts, with book by Armand Lunel and music by Darius Milhaud, received its premiere recently at the Paris Opera-Comique. It was written between 1925 and 1927.
The American Labor party called on Mayor La Guardia yesterday to rescind the 10 per cent cut in home relief allowances voted by the Board of Estimate last week.
PARIS-To get the latest news in Paris, the easiest, most practicable way is simply to dial INF-1 on the telephone, and a three-minute bulletin will come -over the, wire immediately.

The marriage of Miss Edith Burton Anderson, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold G. Anderson, to Donald Anderson Steele, son of Mr. and Mrs, Fred W. Steele of New Bedford, Mass., took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.
The 161st session of the Legislature adjourned at 6:16 P. M. today after a continuous sitting of 32 hours and 16 minutes. The vigil set an all-time record, the previous record being exactly 32 hours.

The old-fashioned stereopticon is at last coming into its own, not as a parlor plaything familiar to the older generation but as a contributing factor to the serious appreciation of the fine arts, according to research which is being done at Smith College.

A new policy stressing freedom and increased democracy for resident students has been adopted by the undergraduate Residence Halls Association and the management of the dormitories at Barnard College.

Although held down at many points, the Rebel attack succeeded today in driving the Loyalists from La Codonera, south of Alcaniz. It was the old story of intense bombing, a heavy artillery barrage and then a mechanized attack against the poorly armed government forces.

Assertions from Romine that -Father .Juan Vilar, Barcelona priest who has been. working for the -reestablishment of public worship, had been expelled. from the Jesuit order and suspended from his priestly duties were indignantly denied by Father Vilar. today.

Miss Eleanor Alling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willis Alling of 151 West 105th Street, was married to Charles E. Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Allen-of Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Three buildings at the southeast corner of Fairfield Avenue and Main Street, Bridgeport, Conn., have been leased for forty-two years by the Moncard Realty Company of New York, announces Albert M. Greenfield, president of Albert M. Greenfield Co., Inc., co-brokers who negotiated the lease. Total rent charges, it is said, will aggregate more than $1,000,000.

IN a book a little over 200 pages in length, Marjorie R. Clark and S. Fanny Simon, two women who are recognized authorities in the labor field, have told the story of the labor movement in this country.
Supply contracts valued at $3,060,182 were awarded in the week ended on March 17 by fifteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.

THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM, perhaps partly inspired by the exhibition of work by the two Tiepolos, now current at the Chicago Art Institute, opened last week its own show of eighteenth century Italian art.
There are conflicting reports of the cause of the sinking in the North Sea of the German steamer Clau?? Boge while en route from Oslo?? Norway, to the Spanish Insurgen port of Huelva today.
THOSE who have marveled at the rich and gratifying Irishness of Sara Allgood in the Paul Vincent Carroll play, "Shadow and Substance,"
FOR the third time in sixty years Britain has called upon a civilian to reorganize her army and her military policy. On each occasion crisis led to the decision.
THE Metropolitan Opera season of 1937-38 came to an end last night with Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung."
Philadelphia's fifteenth Flower Show will. be held in the Commercial Museum, Thirty-fourth and Spruce Streets, beginning at 1 P. M. tomorrow and continuing through Sunday.
Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, former world chess champion, was the guest last night of members of the Faculty Club of Columbia University, 117th Street and Morningside Drive. After a dinner,
Cornell's track team closed its indoor season tonight by overwhelming its up-State rivals, Colgate and Syracuse, in their annual triangular meet in the Cornell drill hall.

The names of student officers for the current academic year at New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance at Washington Square East were announced yesterday by Mildred K. Parker, secretary of the university's student activities office. Those elected include:
Fulton County "old-timers" scanned the vital statistics on the spring lamb yield today and concluded war cannot be far away.
Harvard student debaters have discovered a cure for the gradual decline of interest in college forensics, and a record number of fifty undergraduates is now actively engaged in debating.

Alfred Letourner, French veteran, and Omer DeBruycker of Belgium, whirling. into an undisputed lead less than two hours before the finish, won the thirty-ninth Internationl six-day bicycle race which ended at the Stadium at midnight tonight.

On the eve of his eightieth birthday, and in recognition of fifty years of service, Max 0. Tietze was honored at a surprise party given by officials and employes of Best Foods, Inc., at the company's general offices at 88 Lexington Avenue Friday.

ALBERT J. GUERARD, whose first novel, "The Past Must Alter," will be published in April by Henry Holt Co., was born in Houston, Texas, and lived there for ten years. He then went to California, where he has since resided except for the time spent in study at Harvard and at King's College, London.

The future of horse and dog racing in the State was considerably changed today as the Legislature passed the Dunnigan pari-mutuel resolution and the Quinn bill legalizing dog racing in four counties for a oneyear "test" trial.

THE Eastman School of Music of the University of Rochester will hold its eighth festival of American music April 25-29. The programs arranged by Dr. Howard Hanson, director of the festival, include orchestral, choral and chamber works.

Establishment of a government body comprising members of the Federal Trade Commission, the National Resources Committee and the Department of Justice, to which industrial plans drawn up jointly by trade associations and labor unions would be submitted, is suggested by C. Henry Heppenstall of Philadelphia in a letter to the business editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A resident of Saddle River Borough who has been voting regularly for the last forty-five years finally became a citizen of the United States in Naturalization Court here this week. The new citizen, who is 71 years old, has served on the election board of his borough for twelve years, and for eight has been judge of the board.

Submission and adoption of constitutional amendments fixing 'the number of United States Supreme Court members at' nine, and providing for compulsory retirement of all Federal judges at a fixed age, were urged in reports made public yesterday. by the Committee on Federal Legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

Miss Margaret Weissmann, runnerup for the national crown last year, captured the metropolitan A. A.- U. senior gymnastic title yesterday at the New- York Turn Verein. Miss Weissman of the home club defeated ed - a team-mate, Miss Ann Bolgiano.

lady Henrietta Diana Juanita Finch-Hatton, younger daughter of the Earl and Countess of Winchelsea and Nottingham, has chosen April 26 as the date for her marriage to Peter Frank Tiarks of Westcote Manor, Edgehill, Warwickshire.

Further declines in sales volume of liquor package stores of the metropolitan area occurred here last week. Retail sales were reported down more than 15 per cent in some cases and to average close to 10 per cent below the levels of the corresponding period last year.

Herbert Adams, sculptor, received the medal of the president of the National Academy of Design last night at the academy's annual dinner in the galleries of the Fine Arts Society, 215 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Miss Nancy Dyer, daughter of Mrs. Shelby T. Harbison of Lexington and the late Samuel A. Dyer, was married to William Donlon Edwards, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Perry Edwards of San Jose, Calif., tonight at the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx has announced a plan to solve the difficulties that have arisen in the selection of a site in the Bronx for the erection of Public School 114. He says the Mayor, apparently favors his proposal.
THE comparative lull in auction activity is to be interrupted at least four times this week by sales here and abroad. Three of them will take place at the major galleries.
HENRY MILLER was a talented, brilliant and untiring actor-manager, a courteous and kindly gentleman and a temperamental tyrant with a hot temper and a picturesque and pitiless flow of words.
ANCIENT Poland, a land of plains, forests, mountains and medieval cities stretching from the Baltic Sea to the Carpathians, is comparatively untraveled territory for American tourists.
Robert E. Sherwood's "Idiot's Delight," revised to meet the Lord Chamberlain's objections, will be produced at the Apollo Theatre on Tuesday.
WHEN George Arliss returned from England a few months ago his trip was-termed simply a visit and no hint was given that the veteran actor contemplated renewing the work-a-day life in Hollywood.
With a glittering color motif of gold and electric blue, the MiCareme supper dance to be given on Thursday by the Beaux-Arts Institute of Design will have a European carnival setting.

From the University of Wiscon sin, from Duke University, from the University of Cincinnati, from the United States Public Health Service comes the news that. in nicotinic acid a chemical has been discovered which promises to cure pellagra.

Financing of $6,500,000. for the Hotel New Yorker was revealed yesterday when a mortgage for that amount by the Hotel New Yorker Corporation t6 the Equitable Life Assurance Society was recorded in the Register's Office.

Declaring that the oil companies are not disposed to stand idly by and see their investment of $450,000,000 in the Mexican petroleum industry confiscated, W. S. Farish, resident of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, yesterday expressed the hope that the Mexican authorities "will realize the injustice of their position and permit us to restore normal activities on the terms offered, which were fair to all interests concerned."

Maintaining their undefeated records, the fencers representing Stuyvesant High and New Utrecht High continued to show the way in their divisions by scoring victories in the P. S. A. L. team fencing championship tournament at Washington Irving High School yesterday morning.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

The University of Minnesota Athletic Department announced today it had scheduled a game with the University of Arizona to open the 1939 football season. The game will be played in Minneapolis Sept. 30.

The possibility of a theatrical labor war resulting from differences between Sam H. Grisman theatre operator, and Local, 802 of the Musicians Union, was eliminated last night when Mr. Grisman closed his show, "Who's Who,"

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Varick Howell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wilson Howell of this city, to Donald Farrington Sealy, only son of Frank Linwood Sealy, composer and organist, and Mrs. Sealy of Scarsdale, N. Y., has been announced by her parents.

A strong impetus to trade practice conferences, satisfaction of the demands for anti-trust law revision, elimination of the need of Federal licensing laws and better protection for consumers against misleading advertising were cited yesterday by association lawyers as the most important benefits of the WheelerLea act, amending the Federal Trade Commission Act.
In two non-commercial radio addresses over two national networks, General Hugh S. Johnson tonight attacked the pending reorganization bill as "an insidious assault on democracy."

Miss Katherine Brehme, member of the faculty of Barnard College, has been awarded the 1938-39 fellowship crusade grant of $1,500, it was announced yesterday by the committee on fellowship endowment of the American Association
Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Constance Luft Moss of 36 East Seventy-second Street to Tevis Huhn, sportsman and former member of the United States Diplomatic Service.

St. Michael's High of Union City, N. J., winner of the competition in 1932 and 1934, was eliminated in a second-round game as the ninth annual metropolitan Catholic high schools invitation basketball tournament, sponsored by the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, continued on the Columbus clubhouse court in Brooklyn yesterday. The wedding of Miss Margaret Frances Roosevelt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Roosevelt of this town, to George Frederick Mullen of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Mullen of New Haven, will take place April 23 in St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Milford.

The Bureau of Mines estimated today that a daily average supply of 3,361,700 barrels of domestic crude oil would be needed to meet the nation's demand in April. This was 29,900 barrels less than the estimate for this month and 137,600, or 4 percent, less than the actual daily production in April, 1937, but 2 percent higher than the demand for domestic crude oil then.

Broadway changes as time passes, and many of its landmarks pass out of existence to make way for new store buildings to meet the changing demands of trade. Not all of the old symbols of an earlier day are blotted out entirely when modern business passes them by as obsolete structures.

The Philadelphia Sword Club defeated Columbia's fencers, 16 to 11, on the Columbia strips yesterday. Surpassed in the epee matches, 5-4, the Philadelphians triumphed in the saber contests, 7 to 2, and the foil bouts, 5-4.

After a lapse of four years a Rugby team from England will visit the United States again when the Cambridge University fifteen arrives tomorrow on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary for a three-week trip, during which five games will be played.

Scotland holds the international Rugby championship for the first time since 1933. Victors over Ireland and Wales earlier in the season, the Scots brought the current tournament to a close today by defeating England, 21 to 16, in a match packed with thrills.
THE list of artists who will participate in next season's Town Hall Endowment series has been announced by the Town Hall Music Committee, through its chairman. Walter W. Naumburg.

FEW careers in history have been more dramatic than that of Adolf Hitler. A little more than five years ago people talked of him as a starry-eyed fanatic who would soon pass from the scene. Today he is the dominant figure in Europe, a dictator whose every move stirs the world.

Cambridge oarsmen went "sight seeing" down the Thames to Chelsea Bridge today, breaking the monotony of training over the usual PutneyMortlake course for their annual race with Oxford on April 2. The Light. Blues paddled exceptionally well, averaging twenty-five strokes per minute as far as Wadsworth. Thereafter they dropped to sixteen.

Professor Eugene Staley of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy announced yesterday that the report of the committee of experts of the Conference on World Economic Cooperation, to be held in Washington late this week, would recommend "whole-hearted support" of Secretary of State Hull's program for reciprocal trade agreements.

Nothing more typical of the disadvantages of democratic parliamentary, regime among a people like the French, has ever been seen than the debate last Thursday when Premier Leon' Blum presented his new Cabinet to the Chamber of Deputies.

Changes are taking place in the design of small residences which enable builders to offer a more efficient dwelling at lower costs than the same accommodations would have entailed under the room arrangements of former years, points out Arthur E. Allen, architect,

One hundred and four undergraduate students at City College were elected officers of twenty-nine member houses of the City College house plan for the Spring semester, according to James Peace, director.
All Japan's well organized machinery for welcoming approved guests is functioning for the visiting Italian Fascist mission which arrived in Tokyo this afternoon.

More than double their present supply of radium is needed for treatment of cancer of leading United States hospitals in the East and Middle West, according to hospital authorities interviewed in a regional survey.

The modernized- Spear furniture store, which has been under construction for more than ten months at 22 West Thirty-fourth Street, adjoining the Empire State Building, will be officially opened tomorrow forenoon, it was announced yesterday. The cost of the work was $300,000.

The Jewish Consumptives Relief Society of Denver, Col., will hold its thirty-fourth annual convention for three days at the Hotel Astor beginning March 26. Three thousand delegates are expected to attend.

SPRING finds the Netherlands at its best. This season the American tourist who wants to get away from the beaten path of overpublicized "sights" is being directed to many unfamiliar scenes worthy of his notice.
Allentown High dethroned Trenton in the interstate public high school swimming championship meet at the Penn A. C. today by scoring 22 points.
IT has been nearly four hundred years since the first white man looked upon the Mississippi, and for three centuries thereafter the great valley knew desperate battle and bloody feud,
Any fair appraisal of the events and developments in Washington during the last few weeks cannot help accentuate the idea that Congress is reasserting itself.
Dog owners in Managua would rather pay heavy fines and the cost of hospitalization of the victims bitten by their dogs, rather than have them muzzled or killed.
The new restaurant under construction for Longchamps in the Paragon Building, 253 Broadway, opposite City Hall Park, will be opened on Tuesday.

PLLANS for the fifth annual Bennington Festival of the modern dance, to be held next Summer under the auspices of the Bennington School of the Dance at Bennington College, were announced in the quarterly bulletin of the college which was issued last week.
Cornelius Comegys, member. of the Lackawanna County bar since 1883, died today at his home after two weeks' illness. He was 79 years old and a native of Greensboro, Md.
BIENNIAL or annual as the case may be, the large exhibitions devoted to contemporary American art, held throughout the country, are on the increase.

Miss Dorothy Craig Barnum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Morton Barnum of Naugatuck, was married to Josiah Gillespie Venter of New Haven at the home of her parents today. The Rev. Edward R. Hance, pastor of the First Congregational Church, officiated.

A 19-year-old Newark probation violator was in Hudson County jail, Jersey City, last night, accused by Federal agents of attempting in six notes to extort $30,000 from Murray Levine, New York attorney, whose 12-year-old son, Peter, was kidnapped near their New Rochelle home on Feb. 24.
A divorce on ground of cruelty was granted here today to Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Ingersoll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Alexander Carden of 969 Park Avenue, New York City,
THIS is the book of the film which Pare Lorentz produced for the Farm Security Administration of the Department of Agriculture, and which is now being shown in the motion-picture theatres.
AFAITHFUL recollection of the childhood of one of the underprivileged who was later to become a writer of note, "Under the Open Sky" is a searing document.
Glen Houghland of New York is pretty well cured of writing notes to himself.

The competitive festivals of the junior clubs affiliated with the New York Federation of Music Clubs will be held next Saturday at Public School No. 11. Following the contests in the morning, a junior rally is scheduled at which silver cups and other prizes will be distributedt. Susan Boice,
Events of the week have directed attention to the border between Poland and Lithuania, which for nearly eighteen years has been a no-man's land.

Lithuania, faced by 100,000 Polish troops, accepted Warsaw's ultimatum yesterday and ended the Baltic war scare. Diplomatic relations will be resumed March 31. Anti-Polish sentiment was intensified, but the government demanded strict discipline. Some members of the Cabinet were expected to resign and a national government, to resist any further Polish demands, was suggested.

The Senate Lobby Committee decided today to study the record of yesterday's hearings on alleged lobbying against the Government Reorganiztion Bill before acting on the refusal of Dr. Edward A. Ruumely to produce his files.

IN the Victorian Eighties a four-wheeler stopped at the grim facade of the Arts Club in London. Snatches of verse recited in a flutelike voice floated from the cab windows as the driver climbed off the box and assisted two unsteady gentlemen into the club.

Delegates from forty-one peace organizations will assemble here this week, 1,000 strong, for a conference on world economic cooperation. On Friday the delegates will visit members of Congress and government officials to state their views.

The Securities and Exchange CommisSion has called a hearing for April 4 on a declaration by the Louisiana Steam Generating Corporation, Baton Rouge, La., covering issuance of $1,000,000 of 3 per cent unsecured notes payable on Nov. 19, c 1940, to the Engineers Public Service Company, as evidence of loans for the declarant's construction

Officers of the New York National Guard and Naval Militia, in the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, are acting on the order of Governor Lehman directing them to ascertain if any aliens are enlisted in either service and to discharge those who are not citizens.
Bates College debaters leave here Sunday evening for Meriden, Conn., to oppose representatives of Georgetown University for the mythical Eastern debating chamnionship.

Dr. Luther Gulick, director of the Institute of Public Administration and Professor of Municipal Science and Administration at Columbia University, told the City Club today that "the threat to American democracy does not come from abroad so much as it comes from within."

Trooper William T. Graydon, 22 years old, who became a member of the New York State Police last August, was killed early today when an automobile he was driving went out of control on a curve and crashed into a tree on the Bronx River Parkway Extension here.

Evidences of improvement in national realty conditions were indicated in the report issued yesterday by the division of research and statistics of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board revealing a sharp decrease in foreclosures during the month of January on non-farm real estate as compared with the foreclosure record for December, 1937.

About fifty persons, who identified themselves as members of the Communist and Socialist parties, yesterday picketed the German Consulate at 17 Battery Place with signs protesting the annexation of Austria by Germany.
In behalf of the Yorkville-Speedwell Unit a rummage sale will be held the week beginning April 4 at a shop to be announced later.
