Dawson 5-2; A. Axelrod defeated Taylor 5-0, and Dawson 5-4; S. Bergman defeated Gordini 5-1, and Meister 5-1.

Knute Anderson of Moline, Ill., smashed 746 pins, fourth highest score in the thirty-eight-year history of the American Bowling Congress, as he went to the top of the standings in the individual event tonight.

The Owl, Temple University's humor magazine, is celebrating its tenth anniversary with a special thirtytwo-page issue, in which one of the features is a review of cartoons published during the last decade, showing the change in their technique.

Completing a hazardous 400-mile trip, part way afoot, partly in rickshas and partly in a Chinese army truck, five American women missionaries arrived here Wednesday from Hofei, a small Anhwei city seventy miles west of Wuhu, after many thrilling -adventures and- a number of narrow escapes from death.

A SHARP decline in the total dollar volume of real estate sales made last month in Manhattan is shown in the monthly sales analysis by the Real Estate Board of New York. The drop from the previous month reflects the continued

For improvement with a $75,000 beach club and restaurant, a large ocean-front tract of land in the R. B. Allen Corporation. development at Beach Hampton, East Hampton, L. I., has been purchased by Mrs. Ella Barbour, owner of the Barbour Restaurant at 1 West Fiftysecond Street.
AMONG the many statesmen who appear in the glass that Mr. Slocombe holds up not only to Geneva but to other related capitals is the striking figure of Anthony Eden.
A. Ray Katz. vie president of the American General Corporation and first president of the Associated Jewish Charities, died today in a Rio de Janeiro hospital following an operation for appendicitis.

A CONTINGENCY comparable to the Shumiatsky incident, in which the head of the Soviet film industry was deposed for injecting sex appeal and the Irish Rebellion into Robert Louis Stevenson's "Treasure Island," looms on the Golden Coast.

The annual carnival of the Skating Club of New York, which has been established as an important fixture on the Spring sports and entertainment calendar, will be presented at Madison Square Garden Wednesday evening.

Fur-skin sales of the members of the American Fur Merchants Association during February totaled $2,350,716, compared with $4,777,937 in the same month last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the association.
As this is written it seems certain that the two great Eastern flower shows, at New York and at Boston, will again break all previous records for attendance.

A Mexican divorce decree was held valid by Justice Jacob Panken in the Court of Domestic Relations yesterday, although the New York courts in the past have refused to recognize the validity of such decrees.

SIX-CYLINDER motor cars were almost twice as popular with the driving public in 1937 as any other type, according to a recent survey made by E. P. Feely, manager of the Chevrolet market analysis department.

The distinction of being the first bank in this State to arrange the financing of a mortgage under the 10 per cent down payment plan offered by the amendments to the National Housing Act goes to the Washington Irving Trust Company of Tarrytown, N. Y.

ASTOR-In Old Chicago: Alice Faye, Tyrone Power.* BELMONT-Dawn Over Ireland;* Un Carnet de Bal, French film, opens Friday night. CAMEO--The Ski Battalion, Russian film.* CAPITOL-Merrily We Live: Constance Bennett, Brian Aherne. CENTRAL-Midnight Intruder and Call the Mesquiteers. CONTINENTAL-Merlusse, French film.
TO have been a reader of Jung's earlier writings is to anticipate that something of genuine significance will be said whenever he may speak of psychology and religion.

Athletic awards for the Winter season at Mount Holyoke College were announced today by Miss Barbara Palser of Worcester, president of the athletic association. In addition to all-Holyoke letters and class numerals, the honors included athletic pins.

After winning the St. John's University metropolitan invitation rifle tournament for three successive years, the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute riflemen were defeated by the New York University nimrods by three points for the honors in the ninth annual shoot at the Manhattan School of Firearms range yesterday.

The proposal of several upper classmen at Brothers College of Drew University that the student-sponsored marriage course become a permanent feature of the curriculum met with a setback today when The Drew Acorn, student weekly,

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday that evidence would be presented to the grand jury tomorrow against Wilford Harris, 43, of 305 West 150th Street, a Board of Education building inspector, that he took $125 from a contractor on the promise he would arrange to have an order of plaster accepted.

1st Lt. Charles W. Rodgers Jr., lnf.-Res., P. O. Box 8, Denville, N. J., 311th Infantry (D), Is ordered to active duty, effective March 20, at headquarters, Elizabeth Reserve District, Room 15, P. O. Building, Elizabeth, N. J., for training. Date of rank: Jan. 14, 1934. He will revert to an inactive status on April 2.
THE Manhattan Opera Com pany, a group planning to give opera in new English translations, has been formed and is arranging auditions at the van Dyke Studios.

The five-story theatre building at 247-49 West Forty-eighth Street, fronting forty feet, adjoining the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue, will be sold at auction in the Vesey Street rooms under foreclosure tomorrow by Henry Brady. On Friday he will sell the four-story building at 2,160 Broadway, northeast corner of Seventy-sixth Street, abutting the Manhattan Towers Hotel.

Plans for encouraging the compulsory use of arbitration in settling disputes between real estate brokers and between brokers and clients have been announced by Frank S. O'Hara, president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York, who has appointed Percy M. Bibas, chairman of the ethics committee of the Westchester County Realty Board, head of a special committee to sponsor the more widespread use of arbitration throughout the State.

Frank Moore of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N. Y., paired with Bobby Dunkelberger of High Point, N. C., and Jimmy Thomson of Shawnee, Pa., and Carl M. Dann Jr. of Orlando, Fla., won their 36-hole semi-final matches on St. Augustine links today in the fourth annual national amateurprofessional best-ball match play championship.

The local press reports that former Premier Octavian Goga of Rumania spent last week in Vienna, where he witnessed the overthrow of the Schuschnigg regime. He has now returned to Bucharest, it is said, where he reported to King Carol.

Charles F. Kint, president of the John C. Winston Company, publishers, was killed tonight when he fell two stories in a stair well at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel, where he had gone to attend a banquet.

AMONG the score or more of exhibitions which fell to the lot of the present reviewer last week were group and solo shows which ranged from the work of old masters to that of neophyte moderns. Oils, water-colors,

The other day we suffered from' a pre-Spring anxiety, so we decided to run up to the Croton area and look over the streams. The Big Day is only a couple of weeks off, and we just wanted to make sure the streams weren't too high or too low or too medium. They aren'tthey're just right.

The markets moved on the war news last week to the virtual exclusion of all domestic influences. The threat of a gene al European war produced a panicky flight of European capital to the dollar, a drop in stock and bond prices, a rise in wheat and corn and a break in cotton. Relaxation of the war tension yesterday served to diminish somewhat the already wide swings in prices on the week.

HOPING that 1938 will be a good travel year, the French tourist authorities are hard at work preparing an eclectic program of colorful events for the amusement and edification of the foreign visitors expected during the season.
In an intercollegiate gymnastics meet today Army defeated the Massachusetts Institute of Technology team, 50 to 4.
Miss Mary Alice Mead, life-long resident of Greenwich, died today at her home at the age of 77. A daughter of the late William H. and Pamelia Ray Mead, Miss Mead received her education here.

With enrollments for this Summer's Citizens' Military Training Camps already past the 5,000 mark for this area, fewer than 1,800 more applications can be accepted from young men of New York, New Jersey and Delaware, according to official figures made public yesterday at the army's Second Corps Area headquarters on Governors Island. The corps area quota is 6,800.

The marriage of Miss Carolyn Sayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bradner Sayer of Maplewood, to Edward A. Wortmann Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wortmann, also of Maplewood, took place this morning in the home of the bride's parents.

Activity in the wholesale market last week maintained its pace, according to a special summary of market developments prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.
Six dual meets, as well as the New England intercollegiates, are listed on the schedule of the varsity track team at Wesleyan University.

Miss Barbara Lea, daughter of Mrs. Virginia Townes Lea and the late Harry Greene Lea, was married this evening to Joseph Dunglinson, son of the Rev. Joseph Dunglinson, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church here, and Mrs. Dunglinson. The ceremony was performed by the father of the bridegroom at the home of the bride.

Protests by civic and business organizations against the proposed World's Fair motorcade up Fifth Avenue, Seventh Avenue and Broadway on Saturday, April 30, have forced a change in plans, it was revealed yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine.

ARGAIN opportunities in European travel are occupying the attention of many a prospective tourist these days. Despite international discord, vacationists are not overlooking the fact that highly favorable rates of exchange and liberal concessions on hotel and railway accommodations will give the American dollar added value abroad this Summer.

The following WPA Federal Art Project exhibitions are on view this week: Bureau of Child Guidance, 46 Forsythe Street-Children's paintings and prints. The A. I. C. P., 231 East Seventieth StreetColor lithographs and water-colors.
Dave Clark, 173 1/4, Detroit, outpointed Charles (Trader) Horn, 179 1/2, East Side, in the feature eight-round bout on the program at the Rockland Palace last night before a crowd of 2,500 persons.
THE English are again being asked why they refuse to drink coffee. It is being pointed out to them that the Continent drinks half a cup a day and the United States a cup and a half;

Oxford University defeated Cambridge University in the annual varsity hockey game today, 1-0. Captain Fred McLean of Unity, Saskatchewan, scored the lone goal of the listless contest on a pass from Ogden Glass of Montreal with but five minutes of play remaining in the third period.

Trailing for most of the first half, the Queens Rugby Club rallied to tie the score at 3-all just before half time and then went on to score a decisive 11-3 victory over the Hofstra College Rugby Club at Central Park yesterday. It was the second triumph of the year for the winners.
A bill introduced in the National Assembly today proposed an appropriation of $12,500,000 for the purchase of Japanese land holdings in Davao Province.

Dr. Irving H. Berg, dean of the University College of Arts and Pure Science of New York University, announced yesterday the election of twenty-three seniors to membership in Phi Beta Kappa, national honorary scholastic society.

Childhood and old age, the extremities of life, provide the broadest fields of activity for private social work in this city, the Greater New York Fund announced yesterday after a survey of the functions of more than 800 private health and welfare agencies.

A drop of about 25 per cent in the number of persons registering with the United States Employment Service in search of jobs and filing claims for unemployment compensation benefits was recorded in February as compared with January, Secretary Perkins announced today.

College officials of New York City, assembled at a dinner of the Association of First Assistants in New York City High Schools at the Aldine Club, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, last night, were almost unanimous in naming sound training in English composition as the greatest contribution that the high schools can make in preparing students for college.

Increases in four components of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity were more than offset by three losses for the week ended March 12, and the combined index has eased to 79.2. This compares with 79.6 (revised) for the previous week, and 106.9 for the corresponding week a year ago.
Purchase of the valuable Wymberly Jones DeRenne library by the University System of Georgia for $60,000 was approved today by the Board of Regents.

An all-day State-wide conference on New Jersey election laws and the proposed legislation to revise them has been called for Friday at the Y. W. C. A. in Jersey City by the New Jersey League of Women Voters.

The second annual Children's Flower Show, to be held on Tuesday and Wednesday from 10 A. M. till 10 P. M. at Germania Hall, Sixteenth Street and Third Avenue, will include a scene from "Snow White," staged by the Garden Center of the Little Gardens Club of New York.

Among the many native American plants that have gone without recognition here until after we began to get them back from European seedsmen is the Clarkla, a hardy annual of great beauty, and often used as a greenhouse flower for cutting.

A suitcase containing $7,000 in jewelry and clothing belonging to Mrs. Gerald F. Warburg, the former Natica Nast, of 1,109 Fifth Avenue and Brookville, L. I., was stolen from a station wagon in front of her New York home last Friday afternoon, it was learned this morning.

An illuminated scroll, expressing gratification over the manner in which Levitt Sons, builders, have completed the Strathmore-at-Manhasset developments at Manhasset, L. I., and voicing appreciation of that firm's gift to the community of the historic Onderdonk Mansion, was presented last week to the builders by the board of governors of the Strathmore Association.
The expulsion order conveyed to this correspondent last night was revoked today by the Gestapo secret police] of its own volition without any action on his part.
England has just lived through her most anxious days since fifty German divisions smashed the British front in Firance exactly twenty years ago.
Eleven bills reported favorably by the House Pensions Committee would provide yearly pensions of $1,200 each for eleven widows of distinguished officers of the army and navy. as follows:

Foreclosure proceedings on a first mortgage for $250,000 against the Jersey City Chamber of Commerce Building Association, in whose building the chamber has had its offices since the structure was erected in 1925, have been filed in Chancery Court in Trenton, it was learned today.
WITH Spring officially scheduled to begin its dance across the wave lengths tomorrow, the broadcasters turn to such melodies as Strauss's "Voices of Spring" and Rachmaninoff's "Floods of Spring,"
A claim to share in the control of the Suez Canal seems likely to be made by Italy before long.

Organization of a group of fortytwo lawyers by Kenneth M. Spence to aid in raising a $600,000 fund for the 1938 Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army was announced yesterday by Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., General chairman.

Every aid for the enjoyment of the performance has been arranged for the special matinee today of "Our Town" at the Morosco Theatre, which will be attended by more than 900 blind persons and their guides.
In view of the recent report of the President's Advisory Committee on Education, the movement among youth-serving agencies to coordinate their activities takes on a new significance.
Toronto and the New York Americans put on the wildest period of scoring at Maple Leaf Gardens this season, firing nine goals in the third session before the Leafs gained an 8to-5 triumph.

BIEN'S SINGLES Third Bound Mills P. Baker, Garden City Casino, defeated Fred Fullin, Westport, 15-6, 15-6; Wayne Sikes, Old 69th, defeated Paul Vancso, Central, 2-15, 15-7, 15--8; William Markham, Old 69th, defeated Julian Burgess, Garden City Casino, 15-2, 15-5; George Harris, Central, defeated James Ogsbury, Garden City Casino, 15-7. 10-15, 15-8.
Members of the audience will compose the jury in the play, "The Night of January 16th," to be presented here Saturday evening at the Woman's Club.
CZECHOSLOVAKIA, now in the European spotlight, has recently added time to its short-wave broadcasts to the United States.

A RATHER widely maligned form of travel is the conducted tour. It is not, in fact, designed for the highly traveled person, but its appeal is far wider than many now believe. More, a great many persons who regard themselves as well-traveled might reasonably expect to find their enjoyment enhanced and their store of travel knowledge enriched by changing over from individual expeditions to a group tour.

On police surgeon's certificate, to take effect 12 midnight, March 20: PATROLMAN--Henry G. Schriever, Motorcycle Precinct 2, at $2,250 per annum. Appointed Jan. 17, 1923. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., March 21:...
The first benefit of any kind to be held by the Sunnyside day Nursery in its fifty-six years of existence will be a showing of Easter fashions during the luncheon hour at Sherry's on April 7.
Henry Ford disclosed plans today to produce fabricated farmhouses from the pine and cypress of his 90,000-acre plantation.

Miss Clarice Johnston O'Hara, daughter of Gordon Henderson O'Hara and the late Mrs. O'Hara of this place, was married this afternoon in the First Congregational Church here to Alton Clinton Warner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alton Bennet Warner of Schenectady, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Don Ivan Patch, pastor of the church.

Speakers who will address the Middle Atlantic Division of the Model Assembly of the League of Nations at Rutgers University April 7, 8 and 9, were natned today by Richard P. McCormick, senior from Tenafly, who is to act as secretary general of the assembly.
Two young Canadians, both from Saskatchewan, won the highest award for girls in the Empire Essay Contest on ideas for an Empire Youth Movement. They are Jessie L. Robertson and Edith Joyce Olding.

The completed New York approach to the George Washington Bridge, including the half-mile-long tunnel between the Bridge Plaza and Highbridge Park, will be in operation in time for the World's Fair in the Summer of 1939, the Port Authority announced yesterday.
LIKE picking names for Pull man cars, the task of finding appropriate titles for Holly wood's vast output of pictures is one which apparently requires the concentration of great and ingenious minds.
Mr. and Mrs. F. Rogers Parkin of Spruce Farm, Bound Brook, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Miller Parkin, to Frank B. Martin Jr. of Greenville, S. C.
Mr. and Mrs. Herman Levy, residents of this town for a half century, will celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage tomorrow with a reception at their home.

THE proclamation of the political and geographic union of Germany and Austria, as announced in Vienna last week, conceivably means a termination of the philatelic record of Austria, which as monarchy and republic has contributed more than one-ninth of all postage stamps printed since such adhesives were first used in 1840.

Unification of the -building industry to combat some of the abuses now prevailing in that field is urged by the Indianapolis Chapter of the Indiana Society of Architects in a communication to the American Institute of Architects. The institute will consider the problem of reviving building. at its' seventieth annual convention in New Orleans, La., April 19 to 22.

The Jersey City International League team routed the Giants' second nine today, 18 to 3, swamping Hy Vandenberg and Don Brennan in an avalanche of twenty-five base hits. Joiner, Radon and Rollie Stiles held the New Yorkers to ten well-scattered blows.

Presenting as feature exhibits two model homes, one for all-year use and the other of the Summer bungalow style, the third annual New Jersey National Home Show opened last night In the Sussex Avenue Armory, Newark. There are more than 100 exhibitors utilizing 140 booths.
Two women's swimming cham pionships will be decided today in the Hotel Shelton pool-the New York State A. A. U. 100-yard free style and metropolitan A. A. U junior 100-yard free-style.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Barr Kayser of Belmont, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Barr Kayser, to Parker Mead Morrell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Parker Morrell of Bronxville, N. Y.

While the program for the Spring meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club scheduled for this week-end will be curtailed, the event will not be abandoned. This was decided at a meeting of the board of governors and after Consultation with the American Kennel Club. The open all-age stake will be dropped and Saturday and Sunday will be devoted to the running of the members' non-winners stake.

The eleventh annual horse show of the Round Hill Club Stables will be held on April 9 at the indoor ring of the club. Miss Emily Stevens of Bedminster, N. J., and Louis Waring of New York will be the judges. Dr. John A. McCreery is chairman of the show committee.

Federal aid to New York State, excluding relief funds, increased from $8,000,000 in 1933 to $22,000,000 in 1937, according to the first of twelve volumes of data being collected by the State Constitutional Convention Committee for the guidance of delegates to the convention next month. This first volume of 900 pages was issued yesterday.

One of the largest single-family home developments to be undertaken in Forest Hills, L. I., for some time was started last week when ground was broken for a group of medium-priced homes within the $10,000 class on Ruskin Street near Continental Avenue,

Estimating that the number of motor vehicles registered in New York City and its environs will increase steadily during the next twelve years . and probably will reach the record figure of 2,878,800 in 1950,
Few of the millions who have known and loved Vienna, especially those who have loved her for her faults, would recognize her today in her brandnew swastika dress.

THREE and a half hours from Hong Kong is Macao, terminus of the China Clipper and one of the most picturesque and colorful colonies in the Far East. For the last quarter of a century, Macao has suffered under the misnomer of "Monto Carlo of the Far East."
The annual gift horse party of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work will play an important part this year in an intensive campaign now being conducted in behalf of the organization.

In an office just behind the Eiffel Tower is the Scientifio Office of Fisheries of France. There sits M. Le Danois, the director, an internationally known oceanographer. It is his task and that of his staff to tell French fishermen where particular species of fish are running in shoals.

Thirty-six extra-curricular groups at Hunter College have elected almost 300 officers for the Spring term. Designed to develop student interest outside of the classroom, the organizations include departmental clubs, discussion groups,
Bringing to an end the most extensive debate board schedule in Swarthmore forensic history, three juniors will represent Swarthmore College on a tour starting next Saturday and continuing to April-2.

The Targum, Rutgers University campus newspaper, issued today its first edition under a new staff headed by Earl Reed Silvers Jr. of Rahway, as editor-in-chief, and Joseph K. Wright Jr. of Camden, as business manager.
The Earl of Kinnoull, holder of one of the oldest British titles and one of the few Laborite members of the House of Lords, died today at the age of 35.

The 1,000 largest banks in the country held on Dec. 31 last 77 per cent of the total commercial bank deposits, according to a compilation by The American Banker. The first 100 banks held more than 52 per cent of all deposits.
THOUSANDS of Americans are already laying their plans for going abroad this Summer, undeterred by international upheavals in Europe. They are, naturally, watching the political horizon,

Dr. Emma Perry Carr, head of the Chemistry Department of Mount Holyoke College, will be honored by a luncheon on Saturday of the Mount Holyoke College Club, at the Hotel New Weston. She will talk on "The Place of Scientific Research in the Liberal Arts College."

WASHINGTON.-The art of knife throwing, ships' figureheads, post riders of colonial times, family names, street-cries and the history of wheeled vehicles were among. the topics on. which the division of bibliography of the Library of Con. gress was called upon by Congress men and others to compile lists of books last-year.
Bonds called last week for sedemption before maturity were in small volume again, only one large retirement being among the new listings.

A fund of $1,000,000 to carry on mission work, set up seminaries and homes for orphans and aged persons and to restore paintings and other art objects damaged by rain seeping through a leaking roof of the Russian Orthodox Greek Cathedral of St. Nicholas, at 15 East Ninety-seventh Street, was started last week, it was announced yesterday.

As a crowning touch to Harvard's domination of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League championships in the Cantab pool tonight, a beautifully balanced team of Crimson sprinters shattered the league record for the 400-yard free style relay with a sizzling 3:33.2 performance, a full three seconds better than the old mark, one also of Harvard manufacture.

MIDWAY in the Lenten season one may offer the result of a brief in quiry into the subject of fish, about which nearly everything has been written, and everything is known, except how to make fish liked by the head of every house.

William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, and Lewis J. Valentine, Police Commissioner, were enjoined yesterday from evicting at midnight the 120 pushcar peddlers from Paddy's Market on Ninth Avenue between Thirtyninth and Forty-second Streets.

Mr. and Mrs. Lester Brion of Roslyn, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucille Louise Brion, to 'William Juhring Broadhurst, son of Mrs. William Channing Broadhurat of New Rochelle.

Robert W. King of 104 Elm Street, who retired in 1932 as head of the glove importing firm of his name in New York, died here today in the Mountainside Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage which occurred last evening as he arrived home for dinner.
Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Worswick gave a large tea at their villa for their guests, Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Wood Robert Jr. of Washington.

The annual fashion show sponsored by the students of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel in White Plains for the benefit of the missions will take place on Friday evening in Preston Hall on the campus. Miss Muriel Mazao of White Plains is chairman.
Mrs. Stanley Loth of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jeanne Frances Loth, to Nathaniel Rubin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barnett Rubin of Poughkeepsie, N. Y.

A cross-section of a department of New York City school systemthe one dealing with arts and crafts--was presented by a picked group of pupils at the Hotel Astor yesterday, giving an opportunity to 2,700 teachers who attended the eighth annual city-wide conference of junior high schools to inspect some of the skilled work performed in the classrooms.

Increased interest in Spanish language and literature is noted on the Cornell campus as one of the by-products of the civil war in Spain. Enrollment in Spanish courses, which has been more or less stationary for several years, has shown a marked rise during the current term.

Weakness in the price of wheat in Liverpool and a lessening in the political tension in Europe resulted today in a decline of around 1 1/2 cents a bushel in wheat futures at the opening of the Board of Trade.

John C. Campbell of 125 Heller Parkway, president of the Newark Wire Cloth Company, died last night at his home after a brief illness. His age was 78. He spent more than sixty years in wire cloth manufacture.

Still conscious of the severe liquidation which followed the large advance buying of the early part of 1937, both distributors and manufacturers in major merchandise lines have now swung to the other extreme and have made the smallest commitments in many years, a survey yesterday showed.

The Rev. Carl McIntire, pastor of Collingswood Presbyterian Church, plans to preach as usual at tomorrow's services in spite of a ruling of Vice Chancellor Francis B. Davis ordering him to leave the pulpit.

The ideal chrysanthemum blooms early--that is, in September--is Winter hardy, and of good color, form and foliage. It is for such a plant that hybridizers have been striving for many years, since chrysanthemums are, of course, no garden novelty but part of our heritage of flowers.

The question of whether the Congressman has the right to park any time he wants in a no-parking area has become a great issue in the national capital, where, because the city has more automobiles for its population than any other community in the country, the parking problem is a major headache.
Mr. and Mrs. Frank Stickle of Maplewood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth M. Stickle, to A. Dombey Wadsworth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Wadsworth of Maplewood.

The first performance of an acting version of Christopher Morley's novel, "The Trojan Horse," will be staged by Sock and Buskin, Brown University dramatic society, in Faunce House Theatre from Wednesday through Saturday.

THERE was a time when the atmosphere surrounding the Isles of Scilly, lying off Land's End, England, was redolent of the acrid smell of burning kelp, when that industry was the chief means of the people's subsistence.

For each pound of coal used in freight engines, the railroads of the United States moved eight and three-fifths tons of freight and equipment one mile, according to J. J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads.

The second in a series of forums on "What Chanee Does Your Child Have in the Community," conducted by the Bronx Community Advisory Council, will be held Wednesday at 8 P. M. at Public School 55, Washington Avenue and St. Paul's
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:
LESS than 100 years ago, when Jules Verne wrote "Around the World in Eighty Days," his hero found that even the solitary railway line in India, between Bombay and Calcutta, had not been completed.

Two model homes, one of four rooms and the other of five rooms, in the Glen Meadows Park development on Haines Boulevard, between King and Ridge Streets, Port Chester, Westchester County, will be opened for inspection next Saturday, announce Richard L. Plaut and W. Robert Blum,

Charles (Chuck) Fenske, Wisconsin's great distance star, tonight raced the fastest indoor mile in Midwestern track and field history-4 minutes 8.9 seconds-in the feature event of the tenth annual Armour Tech relay games.
Lee Cadien, vice president, secretary and a director of Celanese Corporation of America, died of coronary thrombosis late Friday night in New York Hospital. He was 47 years old.

Starts J. Cotsworth, assistant manager of sales -in the Philadelphia offices of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, died last night after a long illness at his home in St. Davids, Pa. His age was 58.
With the curtain rung down on the Bukharin-Rykoff trial in Moscow by the summary execution of eighteen of the twenty-one accused, Alexander A. Troyanovsky,...

The contract for the erection of a new social building on the campus of the Clark School in Hanover, N. H., has been awarded by Dr. Clifford Pease Clark, founder of the institution, to the Hegeman-Harris Company, Inc., New York builders.
Harvard's varsity polo team defeated Princeton, 10-9, at the armory tonight.

The assumption by public relief agencies of major responsibility for the alleviation of physical distress has enabled the Jewish Social Service Association to concentrate on the "restoration to families and individuals of the capacity to maintain themselves and to lead a productive life in the community," Ira M. Younker, president of the association, said yesterday in reviewing its work for 1937.

A survey of the suburban situation at the close of the first thirty days of business under the new provisions of the National Housing Act, indicates that there has been a definite upward trend in residential and apartment house construction, says William J. Brede in the April market letter of the New York Title Insurance Company.
Scores of lowlands residents fled today when the Missouri River left its banks here after a huge ice gorge broke twenty-five miles to the north.

The Pennsylvania State College and Theta Alpha Phi, national honorary collegiate dramatics fraternity, will sponsor a theatre conference April 23 in connection with the national convention of the fraternity at the college.
President Roosevelt issued a proclamation today designating April 6 as Army Day and inviting Governors of all the States to make similar proclamations.
The faculty of Wilson College has awarded fellowships for next year to the following alumnae: Betty I. Brown, '30, of Pittsburgh, to study field biology at Radcliffe.

Public higher education in California completes three-score years and ten this week and President Robert G. Sproul has announced that all campuses of the University of California will join in observing Charter Week, beginning today.

A proposal for thorough investigation of industrial life insurance companies was blocked in the closing hours of the legislature by Senator Dunnigan, Democratic leader of the Senate, although the way was cleared for some inquiry about such companies.

A two-day benefit for the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., has been arranged for April 5 and 6 at Arnold Constable Co. Women of prominence in this city and Westchester will serve as hostesses at the store and a liberal percentage of sales made will be donated to the beneficiary, which develops "problem" children toward adjustment and future good citizenship.

Defeating Miss Adele Raettig of Hoboken, the only woman competitor among the thirty entries, Thaddeus E. Knorr of Hillside, N. J., prolonged his winning streak in Group A of the United States chess championship preliminaries at the Marshall Club yesterday.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler will bear the brunt o the electioneering campaign for th Anschluss plebiscite and the Reichstag elections scheduled for April 10 throughout the new Greater Germany.

Miss Mary Dublin, a former teacher of economics at Sarah Lawrence College, has been appointed general secretary of the National Consumers League. She succeeds Miss Lucy Randolph Mason, who resigned to work with the C. I. O. in the Southern States.

A health demonstration week with six New Jersey communities united in a campaign against syphilis will open tomorrow under the auspices of the West Essex League of Women Voters. The drive, continuing through April 9, will be directed by Mrs. Elliott Harrington of West Caldwell.

SPRING THAW-Tomorrow evening at the Martin Beck Theatre. A new comedy by Clare Kummer, with Roland Young, Mary Philips, Lillian Emerson, Guido Nadzo, Jane Gordon, Robert Wallsten, J. P. Wilson and Esther Mitchell in the cast. About a husband and wife. SCHOOLHOUSE ON THE LOT-Tuesday evening at the Ritz Theatre. A play about a child star and school in Hollywood, the authors being Joseph A. Fields and Jerome Chodorov.

Billy Zimmerman scored nine goals to lead Ridgewood, national junior indoor polo champion, to a 16-to-10 triumph over Boulder Brook tonight. Held to a single goal in the first halt, the hard-riding Zimmerman cut loose and scored four goals in each of the last two chukkers.

Founders' Day was celebrated Thursday by the Jewish Institute of Religion, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street, at a luncheon at the. Hotel Riverside Plaza. The luncheon was given by the Alumni Association and the student organization.

ODD pieces of jewelry, picked up in the far corners of the earth, have been selected by French fashion leaders as the smartest accessories for 1938-which will not only serve to spur on those travelers who collect jewels, but will bring to light many unusual pieces that returned wanderers already have in their possession.

Conservative forces of the Actors Equity Association scored a decisive victory yesterday over the liberal wing of the union, electing their full slate of candidates for the Equity nominating committee by a margin of 2 to 1.
Mr. and Mrs. Max Cooper of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pearl Cooper, to Dr. George Liberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Liberman, also of Brooklyn.
Mr. and Mrs. George G. Black of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edna E. Black, to Dr. Abraham L. Kornblith, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Rachnil Kornblith of Brooklyn.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis Alexander of 225 West Eighty-sixth Street and Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Louise Alexander, to Hans Frese, son of Mrs. Anna Frese of Passaic, N. J., and the late J. H. Frese.

Lord Beaverbrook, owner of The Daily Express of London, predicted yesterday that there would be no war in Europe for at least two years. He cabled to John J. Bergen, head of the banking firm of John J. Bergen Co., 40 Wall Street, this message:

Jan Kiepura, the Metropolitan's new Polish tenor, evoked unbounded enthusiasm at his first American recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Kiepura possesses invaluable assets of personality and showmanship that aided him materially in winning his triumphant hold on the large audience. His geniality,

The St. Cecilia Club will give its sixty-sixth concert on the night of March 30 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The organization, which is maintained by private membership, was founded thirty-two years ago by Victor Harris, its conductor emeritus.
Forty boys and girls, members of Fr the art classes conducted by the be Catholic Youth Organization, will hold their second annual outdoor art exhibition tomorrow in Washington Square.

The Jewish and Catholic welfare agencies have for years been closely federated or unified. The Protestant welfare organizations to the number of 152 have now made appreciable progress toward a like federation.

Two robbers, weal ing dark glasses, walked into the Majestic Theatre yesterday in Times Square, where the musical play "Three Waltzes" is playing, held up the manager and his assistants and escaped with $3,700. In their haste they overlooked $2,200.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John W. Bradshaw of Upper Montclair of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Bradshaw, to Harold C. Smith, son of Mayor William C. Smith of Fulton, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Smith. Miss Bradshaw was graduated from St. Lawrence University in 1937, and her fiance was graduated there two years earlier.

Six German-made cuspidors in the main corridor of City Hall threatened yesterday for a short time to provoke an international incident. The tension was the greater because the same cuspidors last Summer had aroused the indignation of

Dr. Walter Damrosch, noted conductor, faces disciplinary action by his union, the Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802, A. F. of L., unless he can "prove" certain statements he is alleged to have made about the organization in speeches opposing the Pepper-Coffee Federal Arts Bill, it was learned yesterday.

FISlHEL-DANIELS-Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fishel of New York wish to announce the marriage of their son. Richard Edward to Dorothy Elisabeth Daniels daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William David Daniels of Oak Park, Ill., on Friday, March 18, at Mount Neboh Temple. Rabbi Abraham Felnberg officiated.

With the promise of Spring weather ahead, shoppers are assembling their Spring outfits, down to the last accessory, for wear on the first warm day. And accessories are a more important part of the costume this season than they ever have been.

PINEHURST, N. C.-A crowded calendar of sports activity is scheduled for the remainder of the month at this mid:outh resort. Golf will occupy the center of atention, with horse events and tenhis also on the program.

BROADWAY being what it is in hot weather-i. e., no bargain-an agreeable rumor has it that the Music Box will be host this Summer to the revue Max Gordon is planning. The rumor goes on to say that Sam H. Harris will be his associate in the production, and it all seems reasonable.
Nearly ten years ago, when relief was first beginning to grow into one of the city's major undertakings, Mayor James J. Walker looked over the figures for the first monthly relief appropriation.
THE wanderlust is being aroused these days by brightcolored announcements of Spring trips to Italy, to the Adriatic, to sunny climes and blue seas.
Hitler's coup d'etat in Austria was discussed by Mussolini in a speech of which the substance is, if one may use light words in grave times, that it's tough, but II Duce likes it.
What will become of Vienna now that Austria has been "coordinated"? The war left the town shabby, worn down at the heel, a grande dame living on a glittering past.

Reacting from its violent weakness of Friday, the foreign exchange market recovered strongly yesterday. The headlong flight of capital from Europe to this country was checked by the news that Lithuania was yielding to the demands of Poland, thus easing the tension in Central Europe.

A patrolman was dismissed from the Police Department and another was suspended yesterday. The man dismissed, Leonard J. Smith, 39 years old, of the Jamaica Precinct, Queens, had been found guilty in a department trial of accepting gratuities from an attorney in connection with "ambulance chasing."

Some 8,000 representatives of organizations interested in all branches of safety work, from the highway to the bathtub, will attend the ninth annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council at the Hotel Astor on April 19, 20 and 21, Colonel John Stilwell,
Declining dollar volume and higher overhead costs are spurring experimentation in a number of ways by retailers to increase sales productivity, a survey here yesterday disclosed.

The memory of Amelia Earhart, aviator who disappeared while flying the Pacific, will be honored here in May during the national celebration of the twentieth birthday of the United States air mail, according to Mrs. Teresa V. Ball, postmaster of Rye.

The New Deal was criticized here today by Arthur T. Vanderbilt of Newark, president of the American Bar Association, for "wholesale appointments to executive administrative bureaus without regard to civil service."

After an ownership of about a year,. Shire Estates, Inc., sold the three four-story apartment houses at 40-11, 40-15 and 40-19 Seventyninth Street, Jackson Heights, L. I., to a client of the Kennedy Agency of Flushing.
During the past two years fraternities have integrated their group life with that of Union College socially and culturally.

Making a clean sweep of the nine epee bouts, Princeton's cub fencers defeated the New York University freshmen, 16--11, today in the university gymnasium galleries. Ray Dudley and William Bausch, with six victories apiece, paced the Tigers to their fourth triumph in six starts.

A seven-year survey of the work of the international ORT Union in rehabilitating and reorganizing the oppressed Jewish peoples of Eastern Europe was made public yesterday by B. Charney Vladeck, majority leader of the New York City Council and chairman of the American ORT Federation, which is seeking $450,000 in the United States to continue the work.

Addressing the 3,000 Communist cell leaders from the five party districts in Paris, Maurice Thorez, secretary general of the Communist party, tonight called on French workers for national union. He was greeted with cries of "Thorez in power!" and "Open the frontier to Spain!"
Paintings collected by the late Mr. and Mrs. Percy A. Rockefeller and removed from their home at Owenoke Farm, Greenwich, Conn., as well as canvases from the residence of the late Henry T. Sloane,
THE Metropolitan Opera may have finished its regular season, but New York will not be wholly bereft of opera. Not, at least, for a while.

Early-season activity at lakeshore communities in New Jersey and other localities is reported by many developers and builders. They credit the recent amendment to the National Housing Act permitting FHA insurance of mortgages on Summer homes as having much to do with this favorable condition.
Directed by General Li Taungjen, commander of the fifth war area, Chinese troops have scored an important success in Southeastern Shantung, according to military reports received here.
Organ Recital by Dr. Charles M. Courboin, at American Academy of Arts and Letters: WOR, 12 M.
The Mexican Government today strongly protested in a note to Joseph Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, against both the seizure

More than 400 persons attended a concert given by the Williams College Glee Club, sponsored by the Williams College alumni and Greenwich Country Club at the latter club tonight. Dancing followed the program.
At the end of a week which has witnessed a series of crises in Europe, our new Ambassador to Great Britain, Mr. Kennedy, made an address in London which has necessarily attracted wide attention.

Legal experts of the Administration contended today that President Roosevelt could remove Arthur E. Morgan from the chairmanship of the Tennessee Valley Authority if Dr. Morgan refused to answer questions at a White House hearing Monday.

SOME of the trade journals, those obedient and affectionate industrial servants, have been chiding the New York critics recently for their unceremonious handling of some of Hollywood's sacred cows, but how can any one keep a straight face at the antics of the infant industry?

The following Foreign Service changes since March 1 were announced by the State Department today: William P. Cochran Jr. of Wayne, Pa., now in the DePartment of State, designated Third Secretary of the Embassyat Lima.

Mrs. Edward W. Freeman of Riverdale was a luncheon hostess yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's. Among her guests were the Misses Dorothy Freeman, Katharine Freeman, Elizabeth Foss and Beatrice Meyer.
Mrs. and Mrs. F. H. Boyd of Chattanooga reported today the theft of $2,800 in cash, a diamond pin valued at $75 and clothing valued at $25.
The volume of American goods exported to Czechoslovakia last week showed no change from preceding weeks, officials of the American-Czechoslovakian Chamber of Commerce reported here yesterday.

ROMANCE sweeps all before it in Paris Summer evening fashions. Yesteryears' charm of historic "beauties" (the "swan-necked" Empress Euginie, gallant Marie Antoinette, appealing Marguerite Gautier) enters into the glamour of today's vital feminine costuming.

The Easter holiday season, as in years past, will bring to the attention of younger members of society a round of subscription dances, these entertainments in many cases having been arranged to conclude the series begun in the Thanksgiving or Christmas recesses for the diversion of future debutantes and young men at home from college or school for the vacation period.

A "cavalcade" of the high spots of the late Martin Johnson's jungle films will be shown by Mrs. Osa Johnson, the explorer's widow, at a "Martin Johnson.Memorial Night" in Carnegie Hall on April 1, it was announced yesterday. Mrs. Johnson will lecture at the showing of the film, which is entitled "Jungles Calling."
IT was to be expected that the success of "Mourning Becomes Electra" would encourage man agers to experiment commercially with O'Neill's earlier plays.
The twenty-fifth Bermuda tennis championships ended today and Mme. Sylvia Henrotin, the brilliant French star, captured the women's singles title in the finest final on record here.

More than three and one-half years have elapsed since the Federal Communications Commission was authorized by Congress to supervise and regulate the communications business in the United States with its capital investment of more than $6,000,000,000.

CONGRESS at this session is not expected to levy a tax on broad casting stations, and reports from Washington further indicate that it is doubtful if hearings on the Payne-Boylan wattage tax bill will be held before the legislators adjourn.
Four men were killed and five were injured today in a head-on collision of two trucks in a fog eight miles northwest of this place. Zach Morris, State highway patrolman, identified the dead as:

The marriage of Mrs. Florence Capern Parker of Riverside, Conn., widow of Ernest E. Parker, to Norman E. John of New York and Ridgefield, Conn., took place here yesterday noon in the chapel of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

The marriage of Miss Irma Erbacher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Erbacher of Scotch Plains, to George Houser Litch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lincoln Litch of Bloomfield, N. J., took place this evening in the home of the bride's parents.

A study of the culture of the Seneca Indian Reservation at Alleghany State Park, near Salamanca, with special emphasis on the Indians' medicinal and economic use of herbs and plants, will be sponsored by the University of Buffalo this Summer with the cooperation of St. Lawrence University.
Albert Beck wants to save the city of Buffalo some money, and so he has offered to serve as City Councilman "free of charge."

The "peaceful settlement" of the Polish-Lithuanian conflict was welcomed tonight by the Diplomatische Korrespondenz, Foreign Office organ, a well as by the German press, which commends the Po1ish Government on its moderation and the Lithuanians on the wisdom of their surrender.

Mexican expropriation of foreign-owned oil fields, it was estimated tonight, will cost British investors [Pound]40,000,000. The Mexican Eagle Oil Company's [managed by Royal Dutch Shell $4 shares always have been a favorite speculation in London and at one time during 1937 there were extensive dealings at around 32s each.
CONCERT PITCH. By Elliot Paul 413 pp. New York: Random House. $2.50. MR. PAUL'S new novel is a step backward in time and feeling from his recent "Life and Death of a Spanish Town."

About one-fifth of the houses built throughout the country during the boom year of 1926 will be cleared of mortgage debt this year, according to George W. West, chairman of the home owning committee of the United States Building and Loan League.

The Detroit Lions will play all of their 1938 home games in the National Football League in Briggs Stadium, it was announced tonight. The stadium, the remodeled Navin Field, home of the Detroit Tigers, has a seating capacity exceeding 58,000. Heretofore the Lions had played in the University of Detroit Stadium, which accommodated only 25,000.

TWELVE fast silver planes, flying in close formation, streaked along the ice-bound shoreline of Lake Huron recently, headed inland a few mile to Camp Skeel, northern flying base of the First Pursuit Group of Selfridge Field, Mich., and coasted down out of the flecy cloudstudded sky for landings on the snow-overed flying field.

The engagement was announced today of Miss Frances Clark, eldest daughter of Sir William and Lady Clark, to Maurice Hamilton Fyfe, formerly of Ottawa, a son of Professor and Mrs. William Hamilton Fyfe of Aberdeen.

A rising demand for farms is reported by Previews, Inc., which points out that within recent weeks it has received a large number of requests for properties of that type in Bucks County, Pa. Much of this demand, the firm believes, is due to increasing transit facilities and to the desire of many persons to get away from the noise and confusion of the city. In addition,
Six men were injured today in an explosion that set fire to a tug and oil barge discharging gasoline at a terminal at suburban Eastport.
Gathering most of its points in the track events, Wesleyan swept to a 72 1/2-40 3/4 victory over Massachusetts State in a dual track and field meet in the Physical Education Building today.

Miss Katherine L. Wetherill, who for three years, including 1937, was reserve All-America goal keeper on the mythical championship field hockey team, died today at the home of her parents, Mr. And Mrs. J. Lawrence Wetherill, in Merion.

In view of the general election last year the government promulgated only a one-year defense program. The Council of Defense, over which Prime Minister J. A. Lyons presides, however, has lately been studying an acceleration of this program and the promulgation of further plans.

Baron Odo Neustaedter - Stuermer committed suicide today. The former Security Minister and Heimwehr leader fol-lowed the example of his comrade, Major Emil Fey, as both were involved in the suppression of the 1934 Nazi putsch when Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss was assassinated.
THE semi-official archives of the cinematic art which are being faithfully assembled by the Museum of Modern Art Film Library were considerably augmented a few days ago when David Wark Griffith,
Ken Maynard's horse, "Tarzan," munched hay in McGee's mule barn today, detained in this Eastern Arkansas village through the intricacies of legal procedure.

The first news of the Austro-German Anschluss was for Italy a stunning blow. The bottom seemed to have dropped out of the whole system Italy had built up in Central Europe over many years of patient endeavor, and even the Rome-Berlin axis-another creation of which Italian diplomacy is particularly proud-appeared to be tottering toward extinction.

Establishment of an archaeologlcal laboratory at Columbia University and plans for extensive research involving archaeological expeditions of graduate students to North Dakota and to Central and South America were announced yesterday by officials of the Columbia Department of Anthropology.

The European political situation appeared less tense yesterday and the more hopeful outlook caused a sharp recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange here. Following Fri'day's break of almost $2 a bale, opening quotations improved $1.50 a bale, which carried new crop months above the 9 cents level.

The work of the Church Mission of Help, a social agency of the Protestant Episcopal Church, in helping girls of all denominations is praised by lay and church leaders in a biennial report of the society.

The nineteenth annual show of the Cincinnati Kennel Club opened today with 707 entries, making it one of the largest exhibitions held here. Among the judges were Mrs. Barney J. Houston, Mrs. T. H. Carruthers and Mrs. John F. Nevis, all of Cincinnati.

The coveted Fenwick Medal, which is awarded annually by the Garden Club of America at the close of the International Flower Show, was given last night to Mrs. John R. Delafield of the Millbrook Garden Club for an exhibit suggesting an oil painting.

Labor, the dominant force in Mexico today, did. not halt with taking possession of the United States and British oil companies in the early hours of the morning but instead accentuated the government-backed drive against the equally important foreign mining industry.

In an effort to raise a fund of $100,000 to assist the rehabilitation of indigent blind musicians in the United States more than forty men and women attended last week a meeting of the Advisory Committee of the National Bureau for Blind Artists, Inc., in the home of Mrs. John Henry Hammond at 9 East Ninety-first Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Minder of South Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy K. Minder, to Paul C. Davis, son of Mrs. G. C. Davis of Chatham and Rudolph J. Davis of North Arlington.
Hans Lange, associate conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, obtained a divorce from his wife, Mrs. Amalie Lange, by a decree signed today by Judge Oscar Nelson. The musician charged desertion.

Thirdparty powers need not fear any action from Japan in closing the doors to trade investment opportunities in China. Instead the Japanese Government realizes the task of China's economic rehabilitation is

Stocks closed with gains of frac-tions to 2 points in the largest Saturday trading since Feb. 5: turnover, 442,070 .shares. Bonds made general- recovery, with best gains registered in foreign list; turnover was the largest for a short session since Jan.. 22: transactions, $3,699,075.

Miss Janet Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Robinson of Ithaca and Sheldrake-on-Cayuga, Ovid, N. Y., was married this afternoon to Donald Elwood Stokes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry De Forrest Stokes of Maplewood, N. J. The ceremony, which took place at Robindale, the Robinson country home, was performed by the Rev. Edwin H. Dickinson of Ovid Presbyterian Church.

The Spanish War approached another-and perhaps its final-crisis last week, twenty months after a series of uprisings in the Iberian peninsula set the spark to the greatest civil struggle since the Russian Revolution.

Mr. and Mrs. John L. Snowber gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for their daughter, Miss Peggy Snowber, to celebrate her birthday. Among the guests were the Misses Constance Heide, Sally Ann Conway, Joan Hanigan, Audrey Pichetto and Dorothy Whalen.
FIRST RACE-Purse $700; claiming; 4-year-olds and upward; one mile and seventy yards.

LAST Fall, exactly thirty-three producers had turned thumbs down on a play of mine called "Haiti." This formidable roster of names was in no way depressing to me; nor did I feel any desire to curse the theatre.
THIS is the first of the Highway Tour books planned by the Federal Writers' Project; and the first and most emphatic thing to say about it is that it is excellent.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Fisher of 670 West End Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Fisher, to Arnold Dresden, son of Dr. and Mrs. Marcus H. Dresden, also of this city.
Squadron A galloped to victory Over Evergreen Farms last night in the second game of the twin indoor polo card at Squadnon A Armory to reach the final of the Metropolitan League championship.

The New York A. C. polo team of Tom Bradley, Willie Nicholls and Johnny Pflug proved much too strong for the Yale trio in an exhibition game at Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, last night. After conceding the Blue five goals by handicap, the Winged Foot riders triumphed by 19 to 8.
For the first time in its 114 years, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute will provide Summer courses for outside students.
THERE is usually a period, not long after the death of an eminent writer, when his reputation suffers an eclipse, from which it often emerges at a later date. Thomas Hardy died ten years ago,

Mrs. James H. Edwards, chairman of the nominating committee of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs, has announced the candidates for office to be elected at the convention in May. They include:

Mr. and Mrs. Rube Vise of Far Rockaway,, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Vise, to Lester Sherwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Sherwin of Woodmere, L. I., and this city.

Ground was broken today for Gerard Hall, the $300,000 dormitory and library building which will be the third unit in an $850,000 building program begun in 1933 at Marymount College, a Catholic institution for girls on Marymount Avenue, here.

Last Tuesday, when the Senate Finance Committee got the Revenue Bill as passed by the House, Chairman Harrison announced that the committee aspired to a tax measure which will restore business confidence and at the same time yield the anticipated revenue.

The Montreal Canadiens assured themselves of at least a second-place tie in points in the National Hockey League's International Group tonight when they battled the New York Rangers to a 1-1 stalemate before a crowd of 10,000.
A former prisoner, as well as experts in the field of public law, will comprise the lecturing faculty of the School for Successful Law Administration, 36 West Forty-fourth Street.
In spite of the business recession, more students than usual have decided to take up graduate work after leaving college, according to a survey made by Dean Henry T. Brown Jr. of Haverford College.
More families are in a position to buy homes than ever before, declares Anthony Cinque, president of the Twin Oaks Construction Company, Brooklyn builders. Mr.
Legal sale of liquor has the approval of Voters in five Georgia counties, following a 28-to-1 wet majority turned in yesterday by Chatham County (Savannah).

A total of $73,390.18 was spent in 1937 for the operation and maintenance of the Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys here, according to the twenty-first annual report made public by Harry V. Osborne, president of the board of managers. The home is maintained for New Jersey boys who have met adversity in their homes.

Alumnae of the University of Pennsylvania living In New York and New Jersey will effect permanent organizations in both areas at a joint meeting Saturday at 2 P. M. at the University of Pennsylvania Club, 37 East Thirty-sixth Street.

William Hodson, Commissioner of Welfare of New York City, told the Senate Unemployment Committee today that the unemployment insurance acts must ultimately be modified so that the basic payments to the unemployed will provide an allowance for dependents during the compensation period.

As plans for the Federal and State housing projects are advanced, a reserve of skilled workers, ready to enter the building and construction fields, is being developed at the Board of Education's High School of Building and Metal Trades, 237 East Thirty-seventh Street.
The dramatic group of the Marymount College French Club will present Ordeaneau and Thomas's comedy, "Marraine de Charley," in the college auditorium tomorrow.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, .dated March 17: COMMANDERS Arnold, M. B., 15th Naval District, to Asiatic Station, June 22. Goodhue, W. E., the Marblehead, to 13th Naval .District, Seattle, Wash.. June 23. Wentworth, R. S., to staff, Naval War College, Newport.
The work of the Bethlehem Day Nursery in caring for children of working parents representing twelve nationalities will be aided by a concert the evening of April 19 at Carnegie Hall.

The United Rubber Workers of America has indefinitely postponed by request of the United States Department of Labor a referendum set for tomorrow, to pass upon the proposed wage and hour adjustments at the B. F. Goodrich Commany plant.

The Teachers Union will call a meeting April 9 "to work out means of rendering substantial justice for substitute teachers" in view of the defeat of the Steingut bill by the State Assembly, it was decided yesterday afternoon at a meeting of 300 substitute teachers called by the union at Manhattan Industrial High School, 12 Lexington Avenue.

The University of Michigan's wellbalanced track team scored in ten of the eleven events it was eligible to enter to win its fifth consecutive Butler University indoor relays team championship tonight with a total of 40 1/2 points.

Mercersburg, Pa., Academy, scoring nine of the eleven events and capturing four firsts, ran away with Cornell University's first indoor interscholastic track meet in the drill ball today. Mercersburg scored 39 points to 16 for New York City's De La Salle Institute.
The "careful and prudent" daytime speed limit of all motor vehicles other than heavy trucks and buses would be increased to fifty miles an hour July 1 under a bill passed today by the Legislature.

Three residents of the Manhattan area are among seventeen students at Georgian Court College who have been nominated for the dean's list, highest honor for excellence in studies at the woman's institution here.
Chancellor Hitler has taken on in Austria one of the most subtle tasks of statesmanship that has been attempted in many years.

I Editor The New York Times Book Reeview: READ with much interest Katherine Woods's review of my "Louisa May Alcott," with the expectation that I might find in the remarks of so reputable and experienced a reviewer the pros and cons of genuine criticism.

Last week brought still more power to Europe's dictators. The democratic nations, confused, worried, sought some way short of war to stem their progress, but as the week ended it was not certain that success would attend the effort. The result was turmoil-turmoil heard around the world.
THE influence of Swedish art on home decoration is increased this year by the celebration of the 300th anniversary of the arrival of Swedish colonists in Delaware.

With a considerable volume of Spring business remaining to be done, most clothing manufacturers last week decided to delay the opening of new Fall lines until after Easter, reports in the local market Indicated yesterday.

The Soviet proposal for a conference of non-aggressive powers to consider a halt of Fascist aggression will be discussed at a meeting at Mecca Temple Auditorium, 130 West Fifty-sixth Street, Thursday evening at 8 o'clock under the auspices of a committee of which Corliss Lamont is chairman. A. A.

The National Labor Relations Board today ordered the Thompson Taylor Company, spice, coffee and cocoa processors of Chicago, to bargain upon request with the engineers' and firemen's unions of the American Federation of Labor,

A collateral reading program at Drexel Institute of Technology to encourage engineering students to broaden their intellectual interests by independent reading in diversitied fields is reported as a success after one term's operation.

AMATEUR: There was a Negro boxing match in Key West last week and novelist Ernest Hemingway agreed to referee. One boxer was knocked down. Hemingway began to count. The fighter's second threw a towel into the ring. Hemingway kicked it out,

Homely women, if such there be, have found a champion in Senator Ellender of Louisiana, who told his colleagues the other day that in the Federal civil service "promotion often is made upon good looks."

For at least the 161st year, according to legend, the swallows returned on schedule today to the old San Juan Capistrano Mission. With clocklike regularity the birds come on St. Joseph's Day and depart on San Juan's Day, Oct. 23.

Following yesterday's' announcement of an attempted Integralista coup to seize control of the government and set up a fascist regime, newspapers today prominently featured a photograph of 3,000 daggers with their points embedded in a wooden table.
To the underlying aims of National Wild-Life Restoration Week, which opened yesterday, all men of good-will must give support.

CORK has had a tradition of realism in Anglo-Irish letters for some thirty years, ever since Lennox Robinson and some other early Munster dramatists dragged skeletons out of Cork closets and rattled their bones.
When in doubt about what is inside a cannon shell, bury it, officials of the Watervliet Arsenal have decided.
BACK from California for an indefinite stay in New York, Paul Whiteman, dance band leader, confesses that he has never overcome his amazement of radio as "an upside-down business."

A. L. Burns won the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday, breaking 98 out of 100 to lead in a field of twenty-three gunners. A. L. Cornwell and G. E. Churchill, each with a total of 99, tied for the Class A handicap prize. Cornwell won the shoot-off, 25-23.

The Athletics walloped the Phillies, 21 to 18, today in a slugging bee in which nine homers were made. Chuck Klein of the Phils connected for two of the circuit clouts. The others were hit by Martin, Arnovich, Scharein and Mueller of the Phils, and asson, Johnson and Easterling of the Athletics.

A total of 20,000 women, "with more than a sprinkling of men," is expected to attend the consumers' mass meeting to be held tomorrow afternoon in Madison Square Garden to mark the launching by Hearn's Department Store

President Roosevelt will return here Wednesday, on the way to Warm Springs, to dedicate a civic center named for him two years after he visited this tornadowrecked city and gave survivors a stimulus for rebuilding.

John Stillvell Bennett, 82 years old, descended from early settlers in Brooklyn, the Stillwell and Bennett families, died on Friday at his home, 1,750 West Sixth Street, Brooklyn, on the site of what was once the Stillwell farm.
A partial rental payment of $3,000,000 to the companies underlying the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company was ordered today by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in a two-to-one decision.

Attorneys for John Henry Seadlund, kidnapper, challenged the constitutionality of the Lindbergh law today in a notice of appeal filed ten minutes after he was sentenced to die in the electric chair on April 19.
Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell C. Katz of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Helen Katz, to Donald I. Peyser, son of Mr. and\Mrs. Henry Peyser, also of New York.

With the entrance of various associations into the field with cooperative advertising, campaigns on all types of automatic refrigerators are expected to reach a new alltime peak next month, according to executives in the field yesterday.

FOUR years ago, when Paul Hindemith was invited by the Turkish Minister of Cul ture to reorganize the entire musical structure of Turkey along Western ideals, he was faced with a task that may well have discouraged a man of lesser knowledge, organizing ability and determination.

Haverford College foilsmen completed their season today by tying Rutgers, 8 1/2--8 1/2. The outstanding fencer of the day was Captain Aaron Goldman of the visitors who scored 2 points in both the foils and saber divisions.
Harold J. Laski, Professor of Political Science at the University of London, declared last week that the annexation of Austria by the Nazis illustrated the need of dictators maintain their prestige.

Nelson Eddy sang at the Westchester County Center before a capacity audience of 6,000 persons tonight. The concert marked his one metropolitan area appearance in a tour which began on the Pacific Coast last January. He was accompanied by Theodore Paxon, pianist, who also played several solos.

Mr. and Mrs. James H. McCorry of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Helen McCorry, to Philip Voss of New York and Albany, son of Emanuel Voss of New York and the late Mrs. Voss.

Plywoods that rebuff termites, cement-top shingles which do not curl, stain-proof wainscoting and abrasion-resistive floor coverings are among the new developments in building materials which are being displayed in the exhibition of modern plastic at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.

The winners of a competition in architectural design for low-cost apartment houses in outlying sections of the city were announced yesterday by the New York Society of Architects, sponsor of the contest.

Henry I. Harriman, former president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, was announced yesterday as the chairman of the special committee of the Twentieth Century Fund which has undertaken the study of short selling the request of the New York Stock Exchange. The committee has nine members.
