WITH the first volume of the English Music Society, Columbia gives general release to another collection that hitherto has been available only to subscribers.

The yielding of Lithuania to the demands of Poland, thus tending to abate the force of a new European crisis, spurred a recovery yesterday in all sections of the bond list on the New York Stock Exchange.
British especially Fascists staged one of their biggest demonstrations in months tonight, marching through London's West End shortly before theatres closed.

The A. V. Publishing Company, which publishes four week newspapers as official organs of the Amerika-Deutscher Volkesbund, the leading pro-Nazi organization in the United States, is planning to establish four more papers in different sections of the country, James Wheeler-Hill, executive secretary of the Volkesbund, said yesterday.
A New York Central passenger train hurled their automobile twenty-five yards away from a crossing

Of the many entertainments given in the interests of Madison House for several years, one of the most heavily subscribed is the fortieth anniversary ball to be given by the Junior Board of the organization on Saturday at the Plaza.

Following a series of conferences, the FHA last week set up a field organization to service all applications for insurance of multi-family and group housing mortgages under the new FHA program, Miles L. Colean, Deputy Federal Housing Administrator, announced yesterday.

Undersea earthquakes, underwater volcanoes and lava flows, sudden lowering of atmospheric pressure have all been suggested to account for the huge ground swells and breakers that wash away seaside homes, wreck piers, batter moored boats and annually do millions worth of damage along the coast of Southern California.

The speech by Secretary of State Cordell Hull Thursday was warmly welcomed in League' of Nations quarters, which found it "very timely." They express the hope that it will encourage and stiffen the British, on whom attention here continues to center.
The Long Island Real Estate Board's demonstration model home, erected in conjunction with the Long Island National Home Show, will be opened at 2 o'clock this afternoon.
Cornell's women fencers won their first meet of the season today by defeating New York University, 6-3, in foil contests.
In-the past week Germany has 200,000 reserves to her military strength by incorporating the Ausstrian Army-small, but rather well trained-in the German Army.

NOW that cruise sponsors have discovered Dubrovnik, Dalmatian port on the Adriatic Sea, it is included in many Mediterranean jaunts. That this medieval Ragusa emerged from centuries of oblivion. is due in part to the Spanish civil war, which set many a sun-loving sybarite adrift in search of a new Arcadia.
Where an abrupt change in grade is indicated in the garden, planted dry walls have long been. used as a substitute for grass-covered banks.

Miss Jane de Peyster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic A. de Peyster of Winnetka, Ill., was married to John Mohlman Van Beuren, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Van Beuren Jr. of Morristown, N. J., at noon today in the home of the bride's parents.
Viola Kruener of Flushing was among those elected this week to Sigma Lambda Sigma, senior honor society at Keuka College. Miss Kruener is president of the Cooperative Student Government.

Miss Grace Kirch of Pelham Manor, as winner of a short-story contest, will receive a trophy tomorrow evening from the New York branch of the Women's International Association of Aeronautics, at a meeting in the Hotel Astor.

THE States of Jersey have recently issued two new George VI copper coins of one-twelfth and one-twenty-fourth of a shilling values. The obverse of these coins shows a profile of King George VI facing left. Around the outer rim is a continuous legend, which is rather an innovation on British coins, for usually there is a break In the wording of the legend.

A sum of $8,000,000 for investment this year in mortgages on homes in and around New York City has been budgeted by the Investors Syndicate of Minneapolis, Minn., announces C. J. Ryan, vice president in charge of real estate investments of that firm.

Fifth Annual Corporate Communion of the Catholic League of the Bureau of Attendance and the Board of Education at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, Seventy-first Street East of Broadway. 9 A. M., to be followed by Communion Breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria, 10:30 A. M.

Otto Planetta, who was hanged in July, 1934, for the murder of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss, is to be honored by the new regime. His case 'will be brought before a court and at the conclusion of trial the body will be exhumed and buried in a grave of honor.

The investment in an engineering education made by graduates in the class of '29 at Worcester Polytechnic Institute is now yielding them an average return of 31 per cent, according to a survey of class incomes by Herbert F. Tayloi, graduate placement director.
The N. Y. U. mermaids defeated the Swarthmore College co-eds by 30-27 in the Swarthmore pool today. The visitors took four first places. Miss Myra Williams was outstanding for the Swarthmore team,

The Interocean Dirigible Corporation, New York City, of which David Burnet of Lakeland, Fla., is president, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1983 covering 1,000,000 shares of $1-par value common stock.

Canadian mines produced 361,086 ounces of gold in January, according to figures released by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. This figure compares with 361,671 ounces for December and 382,545 in January, 1937.
Carroll F. Norton, an organizer and the last president of the First National Bank of Hempstead, died here today at his home on the corner of Hilton Avenue and Mulford Place, in his eighty-sixth year.

ONCE again milk has been tossed into the great churn of public debate. Farmer, distributor, consumer--each joins the discussion, while New York City and State officials seek a formula to bring peace to an industry long disturbed by conflicting elements.

Al Davis of Brownsville knocked out Benny Rubano of East New York in 2 minutes and 20 seconds of the second round of the scheduled six-round feature bout at the Ridgewood Grove last night. Davis weighed 136 pounds and Rubano 134 1/2.

The number of persons engaged on WPA projects in the nation may reach 2,500,000 before the end of this month, which would be an increase of more than 1,000,000 over last September, according to a report completed by Aubrey Williams, acting Federal WPA administrator.
The collection of 885 rare bells of Nathaniel Spear Jr. of New York City will be exhibited beginning tomorrow for two weeks at the Spear Auditorium, 22 West Thirty-fourth Street.
Nicholas Timm of the realty firm of Timm Behrens was the chief speaker at the meeting last week of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board.
Replying to a statement by Charles L. Bradley, president of the Chesapeake Corporation, that its directors "are unable to agree on certain important matters," Robert R.

CONCENTRATING on the first all-industry campaign to move used cars, the automotive industry, during National Used Car Exchange Week, sold more than 175,000 vehicles, valued at between $45,000,000 and $50,000,000.

Fingerprints on file at the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington served yesterday to identify a man shot Thursday night in the Bronx by two patrolmen as Lee C. Valentine, 48 years old, of Cambridge, N. Y., wanted in Pittsfield, Mass., for breaking jail on May 1, 1922, while awaiting trial on a charge of breaking and entering.

When Vassar College freshmen plan their programs for the next three years, as they will do immediately after Spring vacation, they will have a new major available, the drama. Courses in drama have been offered by the English department, but now the faculty has set up an interdepartmental major field to be administered by a separate division of drama.
TWO proposed acts to regulate flying in New York State are now pending before the Legislature in Albany and the aircraft industry is watching closely their progress toward passage.

To Carlos Chavez, who conducted last night's broadcast of the NBC Symphony Orchestra from Radio City, one is indebted for, a hearing of the Sibelius Fourth symphony, one of the masterworks of the modern literature.

Mrs. C. Arthur Emmons of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ruth Wyckoff Emmons, to Anthony Eric Eaton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Eaton of Chester, N. Y. Miss Emmons, was graduated from Newark State Teachers' College.

INTERIOR decoration in France is still under the spell of influences from which a new trend may be said to have resulted. No striking novelty of formula or design is presented, but decorators as a whole are striving to produce an ensemble that will establish them as worthy successors to the masters of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries.

The Southern Pacific Company filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission an objection to a plan for reorgani ation of the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway proposed by J. V. Walsh. an examiner.
TRADE totals held up fairly well through the week at their reduced levels from last year but reports did not cover Saturday's business. That day a year ago marked the peak of Easter shopping.

The Junior auxiliary of the House of Rest, a hospital for the treatment of men, women and children afflicted with pulmonary tuberculosis, is arranging details for one of the long-established entertainments of the Spring season-the annual Butterfly Ball.
A cablegram from the Orient today established the "First Lady of China" as an official member of the Wellesley College senior class.

ROYAL reminiscences some times suggest that blue blood flows but faintly from the point of a pen. This superb autobiography is different. It has cost a prince much that makes life worth living-his status in society, his country, his instincts and his illusions.

Five novices in the legislative halls, representatives of the 483,000 American Labor party votes cast in the 1937 election, finish the 1938 session of the State Legislature with little in the way of bills passed but with the satisfaction of having played a substantial part in the deliberations.
Mrs. Vachel Lindsay, widow of the poet, was announced today as the new head of the Oxford School here, effective at the close of the present curricular year.

Striking out in the interests of efficiency and economy in government, the Women's City Club has drawn up a summary of proposals involving reforms in election procedure and judicial set-up which will be recommended to the State Constitutional Convention.

COLONEL ALEXANDER P. DE SEVERSKY'S proposal to build for Pan American Airways a flying boat with capacity for 120 passengers was one of the principal topics of discussion in aviation circles during the last week.

Two important recommendations were presented before the meeting of the Citizens Housing Council last week by Albert Mayer, chairman of its new housing committee. One was that serious consideration be given to the feasibility of constructing two-story houses on the group or row plan. The second called for a revision and simplification of the Multiple Dwelling Law.
The Hollis Woman's Club will be hostess to the Queens County Conference of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs, meeting Friday at the Y. M. C. A., Jamaica.

Easiest Way, heavily campaigned 7-year-old from the Cosgrave Stable of Toronto's James Cosgrave, followed his recent victory with another sterling effort to annex the Coconut Grove purse, mile and a furlong headliner at Tropical Park today.

From 500 to 600 questionnaires have been sent to members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association whose annual sales are less than $500,000, with the answers to provide the basis for the future program of the recently formed Bureau of Smaller Stores

Orders for the first lot of three large amphibian planes to be placed on the regular service to Magallanes will eventually be placed in Germany, it was admitted today when the high price of American machines was discussed.

AIRLINES strike across Africa, and motor roads also zigzag through desert, bush and jungle. But there are still many far outposts and remote corners that can be reached only by the old, primitive ways of transport. Oldest of all is the safariafoot with porters or camels over narrow paths.

The metropolitan women's and men's squash racquets associations will close their 1938 season officially with the sixth annual mixed doubles championship beginning Thursday at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn.

Miss Elise Pumpelly Gregg, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. James E. Gregg of this place, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Emir Allen Gaw, son of Mrs. Esther Allen Gaw, dean of women of Ohio State University, and of the late Henry Gaw.

The Israel Orphan Asylum presented last night its annual all-star show and fashion pageant in Madison Square Garden before an audience of 21,000 persons which not only filled every available seat in the garden but included hundreds of standees.

Senator Copeland made public today a letter from President Roosevelt opposing passage of a resolution by Senator McAdoo calling for the purchase of three "luxury" liners by the government and their operation in intercoastal trade.
The strangest sporting pilgrimage in the world started tonight when thousands of racing fans converged on Aintree to place their "jump Sunday" bets on next Friday's Grand National Steeplechase.
Mrs. William J. Strawbridge of Paoli, the former Miss Mary Gwynn Vaux, and Miss Eleanor Widener Dixon,
WHAT does a theatrical producer do when he's not producing? Did his latest exertion suffer a reversal, does he sulk? Give himself up to hasheesh or despair? Profess repentance? Demand a retrial?
BRAZIL is being used as a football field. The players are the nations of Europe and the ball in use is the radio-broadcast ball, kicked here and there,

DESIGNED to relieve present congestion and to facilitate traffic between the city and seashore points, as well as for the 1939 World's Fair, three highway projects are now under construction in Long Island.
Mrs. B. Aurelius Gill of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. H. Aurelia Gill, to Dr. Richard B. Nicholls, son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Nicholls of Newport News.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Larkey of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Larkey, to Jerome H. Spitz, son of Mrs. Minnie Spitz and the late Louis Spitz of Paterson.

The pace of retail trade quickened somewhat with the approach of Easter, but comparisons with a year ago still showed declines in most districts last week. Stores in some districts continued to cut prices to stimulate volume, with unsatisfactory results.

The State Labor Relations Board will proceed immediately to hold a collective-bargaining election among the furnishing salesmen of Wallach's, Inc., clothing stores, under a decision of the Court of Appeals.

Magistrate Klapp issued bench warrants in Harlem Court yesterday for the arrest of Harry Douglas, 20 years old, of 3 East 116th Street, and Mary Brown, 33, of 227 West 141st Street, Negroes, when they failed to appear on charges of aiding and abetting in contriving a lottery."

Technicians of the motor boat world who like to argue all hours of the night arid are notorious for it will have their chance Tuesday at the Hotel Lexington. President George W. Sutton Jr. of the Marine Trades Association will introduce Walter Smith of Henry B. Nevin's City Island
The annual card party for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Brooklyn Wellesley Club will take place next Saturday afternoon at the Brooklyn Edison Building.
Travelers on country roads during the past fortnight have noted many trucks or farm wagons loaded with household goods or implements.

Bryn Mawr College's broad scheme for correlating the teaching of the sciences will affect the social as well as the natural sciences. After establishing sociology as a major subject for undergraduates this year, the college has decided to add work in anthropology to the curriculum of the Department of Sociology and Social Economy, starting in the Fall.

The Quebec Labor Department today appointed Pierre Gosselin, departmental. official, as arbitrator in a walkout last night of more than 250 printers in Quebec district which forced five daily newspapers to suspend regular publication and tied up business in a half dozen commercial printing shops.

EIGHT youngsters recently stood before the microphone of the city's own radio station and-without the slightest sign of shame-accepted medals betokening their choice as the Politest Boys and Politest Girls of Manhattan, Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.
Secretary Wallace endorsed today the bill of Senator McNary, Republican of Oregon to permit the Deapartment of Agriculture to approve marketing agreements for any commodity.

Miss Hester Dey Church, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Hudson Church, was married last night to Oswald Elmer of Elizabeth, son of Mrs. Marie Elmer of Egg Harbor and the late Dr. John Ulrich Elmer of St. John's Episcopal Church of Elizabeth. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Littleton A. Hubbard.
A SPECIAL program will be presented tonight by the Metropolitan in commemoration of Giovanni Martinelli's twenty-fifth season with the company.
Relief at the acceptance of the Polish ultimatum by Lithuania, and the avoidance of further complication and embitterment of the European situation, dominates all other feelings today in Paris.
ONE by one the various French colonies are replacing current stamps with colorful sets pictorial in character. French Guinea's newcomers offer a striking example.

The first phase of a $500,000 program of expansion for Ohrbach's, at Market and Halsey Streets, Newark, will be completed on Thursday, when 65,000 square feet of additional space will be opened to the public, according to announcement issued for publication today by Nathan M. Ohrbach, president.

Catholic Charities of New York spent $772,323 last year for family care, aiding 67,833 persons, according to the organization's annual report made public yesterday. Total disbursements for the year were $1,276,450.

John Marshall, 73 years old, former assistant editor of The News and Courier and great-grandson of the Chief Justice of the same name, died last night at his home here. A native of Markham, Va., Mr. Marshall came to South Carolina in 1888 as Assistant Professor of English at Wofford College, Spartanburg. Later he edited a newspaper at Greenwood and then joined the paper here.

Rotary International announced today it had disbanded its eleven clubs in Austria because Chancellor Hitler seized the country for Germany. Chesley R. Perry, secretary of the international organization, issued the announcement.

A grief-stricken father learned early today that his playful attempt to quiet that his playful attempt to quiet his 6-month-old son had resulted in the child's death. The baby, tossed in the air from the father's arms, struck its head on the edge of an iron bedstead ad died a few minutes later.

Holding that capitalism and communism are two great errors of our day responsible for plunging the world into economic chaos, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen advocated yesterday "the Christian golden mean of just distribution of private property" as the only practical solution of the problem.
A crowd of 12,000 saw the New York Rovers go down to defeat in their final home contest in the Eastern Hockey League at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

The exchange situation has made it necessary again to limit the importation of passenger automobiles into Chile by quota, according to a cable message received by the Department of Commerce from the United States Embassy at Santiago.

Mrs. Sarah F. Kelliher, a resident of Brooklyn since 1919, died there yesterday at her home, 81 Seventyseventh Street. Mrs. Kelliher, who was born in Chemung, N. Y., seventy-nine years ago, was the widow of Daniel Kelliher, who died in 1912. She is survived by two daughters, Leona Kelliher and Mrs. Thomas Milan, and a son, Paul Kelliher.

The line-ups and dates for the Stanley Cup play-offs, the postseason series which decides possession of hockey's most coveted award, were settled last night as the National Hockey League season ended, The Associated Press reported.

Playing his second season in the big time, Gordon Drillon of the Toronto Maple Leafs took the National Hockey League scoring title for 1937-38, with a two-point advantage over a teammate, Sylvanus Apps, according to unofficial statistics reported tonight.

A smooth-haired foxterrier, Champion Nornay Saddler, owned by the Wissaboo Kennels of Westbury, L. I., tonight was named for best-in-show honors by Enno Meyer at the nineteenth annual exhibition of the Cincinnati Kennel Club.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Governor Herbert H. Lehman have consented to be patrons for a bridge to be given at the Hotel Commodore the evening of Friday, April 8, in aid of the Little Sisters of the Assumption, whose convent is at 246 East Fifteenth Street.
Ex-Judge Samuel Barnard Adams, dean of the Savannah bar and one of Georgia's most distinguished citizens, died tonight at his home after an illness of several weeks. His age was 84.

Defeating Barnie F. Winkelman of Philadelphia, former University of Pennsylvania captain, Milton Hanauer of Manhattan, New York State champion in 1926, yesterday recorded his fourth consecutive triumph in Section A of the United States chess championship preliminaries at the Marshall C. C. Hanauer, adopting the English opening, won in forty moves.

Professor Perley Ason Ross, physicist and member of the Stanford University faculty, died in Palo Alto today of a heart attack at the age of 54. The writer of numerous contributions to X-ray research, Professor Ross also was an amateur astronomer.

The Right Rev. William G. McDowell of Birmingham, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Alabama, died here today following a week's Illness. His age was 55. He was stricken during his annual visit to Mobile churches.

Plans for the establishment this year of regular transatlantic air mail lines with perhaps two American companies participating are being considered by the Postoffice and Commerce Departments, it was learned today.

Stricken with a brain hemorrhage at his home in Beverly Hills, Austin Parker, author and aviator and one-time husband of Miriam Hopkins, motion picture actress, died here today in Good Samaritan Hospital.

It is Max Gordon's pleasure this evening to celebrate the first day of Spring by installing "Spring Thaw" at the Martin Beck Theatre--though this is probably a coincidence, for it had the same title last January, when it was first tried out. By any name at all,

Paulina Ruvinska, who appeared in piano recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, disclosed a continuing development as an interpreter. Her technique, in the three seasons she has been before the public here, has always been sufficient to her needs; it is clean and decisive.

A dry-cleaners' mark in a discarded topcoat enabled New York detectives to arrest and get a confession from the fourth member of a gang' of six men that robbed the Bank of Mattituck at Mattituck, L. I., of $6,300 on March 11, it became known yesterday at Police Headquarters.
Stocks remained in the background this week on the Boerse, attention being centered on foreign-currency bonds.

There is every reason to hope that the bipartisan movement which has begun in Washington for repeal of the Neutrality Act will succeed in achieving its objective. The act as it stands carries a false promise of security for the American people.

Prices of corn for future delivery held last week within a range of 2 to 2% cents a bushel on the Board of Trade. The fluctuations, however, were the widest to date this year, with the May at the lowest point since last December under selling induced by the break in wheat.
After a six-month trip through British Guiana and parts of Brazil, Dr. William Hall Holden of the TerryHolden scientific expedition -will return to New York tomorrow.

Behind the jubilation over Anschluss, nervousness was felt in financial circles here, while among the general public there circulated rumors, partly incredible, of still impending coups. Among those mentioned were moves against. Czechoslovakia,

The hope of mankind is in those men and women who are possessed with a "craving hunger for righteousness," the Rev. Dr. C. Jeffares McCombe said yesterday morning in his sermon in the Methodist Episcopal Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

Twelve thousand slum dwellers, in five cities, will eventually be better off because of contracts signed with the United States Housing Authority and approved last Thursday by President Roosevelt. They will pay a monthly rental of as little as $2.75 a room in Austin, Texas, as high as $4.25 in Syracuse and Youngstown.

During the quiet of a Sunday afternoon in the theatrical district yesterday, nearly 500 blind persons escorted by guides went to the Morosco Theatre to hear a performance of "Our Town," by Thornton Wilder.

JOSEPH ALSOP AND TURNER CATLEDGE, Washington newspaper men, say that they have done their best to present an accurate, complete and unbiased account of the New Deal's Supreme Court fight in their book called "The 168 Days."* They haven't been particularly successful. The book is lively and in some respects brilliant (don't pass it by simply because you have read a few brief extracts in The Saturday Evening Post),

The New York Maritime Council, composed of nine unions affiliated with the C. I. O., appealed yesterday to the special Senatorial committee appointed to investigate the shipping labor situation to study the operations of ship lines as well as the unions.

Byron R. Newton, Tax Commissioner of Queens and former Collector of the Port of New York, died at his home, 218-15 Fortieth Avenue, Bayside, Queens, last night at the age of 76. Death was due to a paralytic stroke which Mr. Newton suffered on March 12.
Hitting the ball hard and often, the cubs walloped the Pirats, 14 to 7, in an exhibition game today. The Chicagoans combed Pitchers Lucas and Klinger for all of their runs in the first five frames.

The money market this week witnessed a considerable cheapening of the call money rate, which fell from 21/2 and 23/4 per cent to 2 per cent. The discount on trade bills hardened from 31/4 to 33/4 per cent.

A majority move designed to effect an investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority by a Senate committee, composed of those who are known to be impartial toward the TVA, was expected to be made early this week. Any action by the Senate will follow expiration of the "deadline" of 1:30 P. M., tomorrow, which President-Roosevelt set for Arthur E. Morgan, chairman of the TVA, to agree to produce his evidence against the other two directors.

The marriage of Miss Fritzi Mutterperl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Mutterperl of 262 Central Park West, to Ludwig S. Bickhardt, also of this city, son of Saly Bickhardt of Jerusalem, Palestine, formerly of Frankfort-on-Main, Germany, and the late Mrs. Bickhardt, took place yesterday afternoon in Temple Ansche Chesed.

That the avalanche of unfavorable political news which has struck the markets since March 11 so far has not resulted in a world-wide panic is, in the opinion of observers here, attributable to three causes:

The Catholic hierarchy was called upon yesterday in an open letter signed by sixty-one Bishops, representing the Protestant Episcopal and the Methodist Episcopal Churches in thirty-six States, "to bring the might of your influence to bear on General Francisco Franco" in an effort to prevent further bombings of noncombatants in Spain.

The first robin, working in conjunction with the Long Island Railroad's "Fishermen's Specials," seems to be the official harbinger of Spring, now that the railroad has announced that the first special will run on March 27 to Canoe Place, for flounders.
Flying Officer A. E. Clouston and his companion, Victor Ricketts, reached New Zealand this morning to set a new England-New Zealand flight record.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,291,827,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills.

At a time when Mexico's tariff policy and nationalization of industry threaten strained relations with the United States, the Department of Commerce today published a study of Mexican trade with the United States which showed that despite the tariff increases effected last year exports to Mexico reached the highest value of any year since 1930.

A few hours before his departure from Amsterdam for Monte Carlo tonight Bruno Walter, former director of the State Opera in Vienna, learned that his daughter Lotte had been arrested in Vienna. She was the only member of the family who remained in the conductor's Vienna home.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Russell Grace of The Crossroads, this place, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elise L. Grace, to Augustus Silliman Blagden Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Blagden of Ambler, Pa.
A giant log raft crunched against: a bridge pier and broke up in the swift currents of the Susquehanna River today, bringing death to one man.

France was described as being "psychologically afraid to fight now," and so concerned with her own internal affairs that she might not interfere with a peaceful German invasion of Czechoslovakia, in a lecture here tonight by Dr. Gerhart Niemeyer, lecturer on politics at Princeton University.

Princeton University seniors, who have repeatedly expressed preference for a Phi Beta Kappa key over a varsity "P" in recent years, stand firmly behind their institutions educational system, according to the results of a special poll of the class of '38 conducted by The Daily, Princetonian, undergraduate newspaper, announced today.

Dr. John W. Rustin, pastor of Mount Vernon Methodist Episcopal Church, South, startled some members of his congregation today by announcing that he played bridge. "You don't have to hide out in the bushes to find out about it, either," he said.
Delegates to the annual meeting of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, at the Hotel Astor, voted yesterday to create an enlarged transportation fund of $250,000.

The pamphlet report of the W. T. Grant Company for the year ended on Jan. 31 shows consolidated net earnings of $3,401,725, equal to $2.78 each on 1,189,354 common shares after deducting the preliminary dividend of $87,278 paid on Jan. 1 on the 5 per cent preferred stock.

Leaders of both political parties expressed satisfaction today with the accomplishments of the 1938 session of the Legislature, viewed from a political angle. The non-controversial nature of the session left little for either major party to accuse the other of blocking during the coming Fall campaign.
Army officers estimate that a youth with six months' Civilian Conservation Corps training could be turned into a pretty good soldier in a month in event of war and general mobilization.

Christian civilization is facing a more crucial test today than in 1914 and the Christians of the world must unite to force the keeping of the peace in Europe, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, the pastor, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Several elections were held in different parts of France today, but they did not give a definite idea as to whether opinion was shifting. Deputy Antoine Pinay, a moderate belonging to the Left Republican group, was elected Senator at Saint-Etienne to the seat formerly held by the late Senator Fernand Merlin, a Radical Socialist. Mr.

Giles R. Scofield, '39, of Rochester, N. Y., guard and center, has been elected captain of the 1938-39 ?? inceton quintet, it was announced tonight by R. Kenneth Fairman, basketball coach and acting-graduate manager of athletics.

A survey of relief conditions in twenty-eight States disclosed "shockingly low standards" of direct relief in many communities, the American Association of Social Workers reported last night. With unemployment mounting in the face of inadequate local and State funds, welfare practices in many areas have "deteriorated" to pre-depression levels, Walter West, executive secretary of the association said.

In celebration of its twentieth anniversary the New. York Urban League presented William Bowers, baritone, and members -of Baron Eugene von Grona's American Negro ballet in a joint concert given last night at Town. Hall before a large and demonstrative audience.

Lithuania's unqualified acceptance of the Polish ultimatum eliminates immediate danger of armed invasion, but does not assured peaceful relations between the two countries. Reports from the Lithuanian capital and from Geneva continue fearful that Poland's peremptory demand of last week, backed by a display of last week, backed by a display of overwhelming military strength along the border, was a first step toward ultimate absorption of its weaker neighbor.

The Japanese forces north of Suchow- are only nineteen miles from their goal and it is expected they soon will cut the Lung-Hai Railway. Following strategy that has been repeatedly successful in the last eight months of warfare the Japanese Army suddenly ceased pressure near Kaifeng, Chengchow- and Tungkwan, where the Chinese were expecting a massed frontal attack to cross the Yellow River,

Despite expert medical attention, a young buck struck early today by an automobile driven by Miss Helen A. Hale, a nurse of the Pilgrim State Hospital, Brentwood, died a few hours later at the headquarters of the State Police here. The buck.

The franc weakened notably at the beginning of this week under the two-fold influence of the events in Austria and the formation of a new French Socialist government. There was no massive exporting of capital, however, because those in France who could export did so long ago.

Eight proposed amendments to the State Constitution that have a bearing on a large-scale low-rent housing program for this city will be discussed this afternoon at the third of the series of public meetings being held at the Town fall Club under the auspices of the Citizens Housing Council.

The 1938 Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army will launch a campaign for $600,000 at a dinner tomorrow night in the Hotel Pierre, it was announced yesterday by Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., general chairman.

Opposing viewpoints on how Secretary of State Cordell Hull's reciprocal trade agreements, .program would affect the various American farm groups were presented last night by Allen Kline, vice president of the Iowa Farm Bureau Federation and Louis J. Taber,

Three hundred teachers attended a meeting of the Educators Division of the American ORT Federation held at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday as part of the campaign to raise $450,000 for the federation. The money is to be used to provide technical and agricultural training for victims of anti-Semitism in Germany, Austria, Poland and other Eastern and Central European countries.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 82.3, which compares with 82.8 a week ago, 83 two weeks ago, 83 three weeks ago and 82.4 four weeks ago.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 12 the Latvian Minister in Washington, Alfred Bilmanis, denied "categorically" my statement that according to official Soviet sources the Latvian consul, 'Bissenieks, gave to Nikolaeff, the real assassin of Kiroff, 5,000 rubles for his terroristic act and asked from him "some letter for Trotsky."

Work on the WPA's museum project at the State Education Building has been delayed because of a shortage of expert translators, Dr. Robert D. Glasgow, State entomologist, has revealed. The work involves translation of valuable foreign papers and reports.

Liechtenstein is a small State, but there are those who love it. Its princely house, an ancient Austrian family, bought its sixty-five square miles in 1719, and it has been independent ever since. Lying between the Vorarlberg and Switzerland, its connection with Austria was long closest.

After twenty-three years at 212 Fifth Avenue that Liggett Myers Tobacco Company will move its executive offices to Rockefeller Center, where it has leased two florrs in the International Building. Leonard J. Beck, Inc., negotiated the lease, and the new quarters will be occupied next Fall.

The BorahO'Mahoney Bill providing for the Federal licensing of all corporations engaged in interstate commerce and the Administration's proposal to permit President Roosevelt to reorganize Federal departments was denounced today by the Illinois Chamber of Commerce.

The corrected manuscript of Arnold Zweig's new novel, "The Crowning of a King," has been received at the Viking Press office. The, book, final selection of the Grischa series, to which in recent years Zweig has been devoting himself, will be published in the late Spring.

The New York Civic Orchestra, under Eugene Plotnikoff, inaugurated the new series of all-Tchaikovsky concerts, sponsored by the Federal Music Project, last night at the WPA Theatre of Music. Katherine Bacon, the assisting artist, was heard in the piano concerto in B flat minor.

Ralph Wolf was elected president of the Harmonie Club for the year 1938-39 at the annual meeting held last night at the club building at 4 East Sixtieth Street. Max Reichenbach was named vice president and Edwin Blun was re-elected as treasurer. Announcement of the elections was made by Maxwell Steinhardt, who was re-elected secretary of the club.

There was an outdoor art exhibition in-Washington Square yesterday afternoon. It was not the annual Spring show of the adult artists, but a show by Catholic children. The pictures were tacked to the high green fence that encloses the tennis courts at Thompson Street and Washington Square South. There were sixty-seven on the fence and five' on easels. All were done at the free WPA art classes at four Catholic centers.

A contest for the Democratic leadership of Queens County between James C. Sheridan, present leader, and State Committeeman James A. Roe, head of the Unity faction, at the primary election September is certain, supporters of Mr. Sheridan said yesterday. Mr.
Mrs. Edward James Patterson of this city has sent out invitations for the marriage of her daughter, Miss Margaret Patterson to Morrill Wiggin of Brookline, Mass.

Marco Polo, according to a Skidmore College student, was a great traveler who "discovered the North Pole and named it for himself." The History Department revealed this examination "boner" among others. From the Biology Department came the following:
A new airport opened at Uaxactum, in the State of Peten, gives access to important ancient Mayan ruins believed to contain many archaeological treasures.

Stocks slumped to lowest levels in several years in most active trading in two months; turnover, 4,873,870 shares. Bonds declined sharply, with foreign issues at lowest levels since 1922, rails since 1932; trading heaviest since week ended on Jan. 29; transactions, $39,279,225.
The Boston Bruins ended their fourteenth National Hockey League season and their seventh as American Division champions tonight by overwhelming the Chicago Black Hawks, 6-1.
Scandinavian Foreign Ministers will meet in Oslo April 5 and 6 to review Europe's troubled relations as they affect the northern nations.

The treasury Department has no intention of discontinuing the sale of United States Savings Bonds, comonly known as "Baby Bonds," "either at the end of this fiscal year or at any other time in the foreseeable future,"

The Baltimore S. C. held the New York Americans to a 0-0 tie in an Interesting American Soccer League game yesterday at Starlight Park before 5,000 fans. Gilbert Schuerholz, the Orioles' goalie, and his team-mate Bill Ernst, at outside right, were outstanding.

The three sisters of Albania's King Zog paid a visit to Philadelphia today, staying just long enough to attend church twice and to receive representatives of the Albanian-American colony before catching a train back to New York.

Successful, at least for the moment, in riding out the storm brought on by -Germany's annexation of Austria, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain is expected to indicate this week Britain's policy in the event Chancellor Adolf Hitler should apply similar "power politics" toward Czechoslovakia.

Failure of the State Senate to pass the Moffat $100,000,000 slumclearance bill marred "a good legislative record in the field of social legislation," Harold Riegelman, chairman of the Legislative Advisory Committee of the County Republican Committee, reported yesterday to Kenneth F. Simpson, chairman of the county committee.

Miss Helen Downes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Downes of this place, has chosen April 9 for her wedding to Donald W. Light, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee R. Light of Dillon, Mont. The Rev. Dr. Archibald Black, pastor of the First Congregational Church, will perform the ceremony at the home of the prospective bride.

Among Premier Leon Blum's conferences today was a long interview with Pierre C. Fournier, governor of the Bank of France. The conference gave rise to reports that the government will soon be obliged to take measures to meet the financial situation outlined by former Premier Camille Chautemps before his resignation.

Dorothy Kenyon, former Deputy Commissioner of Licenses, was guest of honor at a reception given yesterday afternoon by the Third Assembly District organization of the American Labor party at the Cornish Arms Hotel, 311 West Twenty-third Street.

The California wine industry, which has been considering the possibility of a cooperative advertising campaign for almost a year now, is expected to complete plans today for such a drive at a meeting in San Francisco, according to reports from the Coast.

David F. Broderick and a group of associates have bought control 90 of the Service Fire Insurance Company of New York, it was announced yesterday by Mr. Broderick. He is president of D. F. Broderick, Inc., insurance agents,

William Randolph Hearst has appointed Clarence J. Shearn, former Supreme Court Justice and expresident of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, to reorganize the vast publishing and business holdings that for nearly half a century have made him an important factor in American life and politics.

More than 1,000 members of the Greek community of the city crowded the Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 319 East Seventy-fourth Street, to witness yesterday morning the solemn investiture of Father Methodios Kourkoulis, rector of the church for the last thirty-four years, with the title of Grand Archimandrite of Istanbul.

The French equalization fund has intervened only moderately in the foreign exchange market this week and the opinion prevails here that it has not lost much gold, as it was able at times to repurchase gold as well as to sell.

162d St (9-2461), n s, 128 ft e of Grand Concourse, 106x145; Dillerwood Realty Co. Inc. to Edwin Realty Corp, 369 E 149th St. Albany Crescent (12-3266), e s, 119 ft s of 231st St. 46x131: Rebanna Realty Corp to Moepearl Holding Co, Inc. 1,678 Grand Ave.

The Cathedral of St. John the Divine has raised $183,000 toward the $1,000,000 required to complete its building program, Bishop William T. Manning announced yesterday morning. The Bishop rearranged the order of the morning service to enable him to take

Business in the securities markets here so far this week has remained quiet, although there has been some liquidation of high-priced government bonds and domestic shares. The Telegraaf's share index on Thursday fell to the year's lowest, 226.72, against 239.87 last week and the highest for 1938 of 240.97. On Friday it recovered to 227.35.

With a perfect exhibition of position play, Jimmy Caras of Wilmington, Del., conquered Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia, 125 to 24, in seven innings, in the first game of the play-off series for the pocket-billiard championship of the world last night at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.
Although admittedly blocked in its effort to identify the real parties at interest in a $700 Bahaman corporation which bought a block of Alleghany Corporation stock in September for $225,000,
The quarter of a century-that Giovanni Martinelli has spent as a leading tenor with the Metropolitan Opera was crowned with a gala performance last night at the opera house.
A walk through the streets of this former capital of Austria toddy reveals a very strange Vienna.

When William Robinson, restaurant own- an er, found a bear cub while hunting $1, in Canada two years ago he thought that it would make a fine petand it did until it emerged from hibernation recently in a playful mood. A teddy-bear no longer,

Allerton Ave, 725 to 731 (16-4510); A. C Estates, Inc, to New York Life Insurance Co; installments, 5 per cent; $55,000. Bryant Ave, 1,171 (10-2753): Rose Cobert to Chemical Bank and Trust Co; extends mtgs to Oct. 1, 1941, at 5 per cent; $38,600.

After more than two days spent questioning seven youths, the police of this area announced tonight that they had cleared up between 200 and 400 burglaries reported along a twenty-mile stretch of the South Shore of Long Island in the last two years.

An aerial photography program for 1938 which would provide sky views of 1,300,000 square miles, a large part of the farm land of the United States, was announced under way today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

Enoch Morgan's Sons Company, 439 West Street, New York. has made a stipulation with the Federal Trade Commission to cease representing that Sapolio powder and toilet soap protect the skin and that the soap is penetrating and will invigorate or stimulate the skin, preventing chapping and removing stubborn stains or hidden discolorations, the commission announced today.

Poland ordered her troops to leave the Lithuanian frontier yesterday. Difficult negotiations were expected over trade and railroad and river traffic and predictions were made in Warsaw that anti-Polish tendencies would flourish in Kaunas.
Two of three doomed kidnappers were baptized today in the fountain at the State penitentiary while fellow-prisoners peered curiously from barred windows into the brick-paved court yard.

Of most legislative bodies on adjournment it may be said that they have left undone some of the things they ought to have done and have done some things they ought not to have done. Occasionally it may also be said that there is no health in them. The 161st session of the New York State Legislature, which ended Saturday afternoon, certainly did not earn this last condemnation. It killed some good measures.

Ted Shawn and his company of men dancers gave their fourth Sunday evening of dancing at the Majestic Theatre last night before an audience of good size. The program consisted in the main of repetitions from the previous recitals -in the series, but also contained a few additions.

H. Donn Keresey, president of the Anaconda Wire and Cable. Company, has been appointed associate chairman of the committee on contributions of the Greater New York Fund, Inc., it was announced yesterday. He will assist Leon Fraser,

One outoome of the Central European crisis aas been the resumption of the Flight of capital to the United States. British, in addition to Continental European funds, have been flowing in fairly heavy volume n that direction. American securities, as well as American currency, save been bought freely by operators in London and on the Continent.

Gray Goose, driven by Hugh Gingras of Rockledge, Fla., and owned by George C. Cannon of New Rochelle, N. Y., roared to victory in the 225hydroplane race, feature of the twenty-fifth annual Biscayne Bay regatta today.

Apparel for pre-Easter selling held the center of attention in the wholesale market last week. Reorder volume increased, with concentration on "best-selling" items indicating retail attention to the promotion of carefully selected types. Calls for better and medium-price dresses improved.
Four men and a woman were arrested today on charges of trying to deliver French fortification and mobilization plans for the Italian frontier to a "foreign power."
Mrs. T. Halsted Myers will return this week to the Savoy-Plaza from Honolulu. Mr. and Mrs. John L. Boatwright have come from Nassau, in the Bahamas, to the Chatham.

Professor Moe Berg of the receiving department of the rich Red Sox strolled down the steps of the Sarasota Terrace Hotel and said to Al Schacht, a distinguished visitor: "Wheel out the private chariot, Al. I refuse to be a bus boy again."

The problems of the actor in the legitimate theatre will be discussed by Philip Tonge today at a luncheon-symposium to be hold by the Cultural Circle at the Hotel Astor. Another symposium, having for its general subject

Casey Stengel is one down to Burleigh Grimes, but has not yet begun to worry about where he will be at the end of the season. The Dodgers, sometimes gay and sometimes grim, made up for their opening-day shellacking by the Red Sox with a 12-8 runaway over the Boston Bees today, collecting sixteen hits for a total of twenty-six bases.

Hoboken met a three-hour water shortage today with the stoicism of a city long famous for its beer. The shortage developed at 11 A. M. when a 36-inch water main broke at Hoboken Avenue, two feet south of the Hoboken-Jersey City boundary line.
Closing its annual convention here today, the New Jersey conference, National Council of Jewish Juniors, elected Mrs. Rose Isaacson of Atlantic City president.

Close finishes featured an A. A. U. aquatic meet in the Hotel Shelton pool yesterday as Miss Elizabeth Ryan of the Women's Swimming Association of New York supplied the highlight with a thrilling triumph in the New York State 100yard free-style championship.

Last week's demoralized financial markets had in mind nothing but the turn of events in Central Europe. Unavoidably, as is always the case on stock exchanges, imagination as to possible consequences was stimulated to the uttermost pitch.

The Brooklyn Jewels strengthened their hold on first place in the second-half standings of the American Basketball League by defeating the Brooklyn Visitations, 43 to 39, while the New York Celtics upset the Philadelphia Sphas, 37 to 34, virtually eliminating the 1937 champions from the title race, before a crowd of 4,500 at the Hippodrome last night.

Magma Copper Company-For 1937: Net profit before provision for depletion, $1,456,332, compared with $1,297,990 in 1936, a rise to $3.57 from $3.18 a share. Sales of copper amounted to $4,224,485, against $2,958,403.

A young radio operator at the United States Navy Radio Compass Station here was shot and critically wounded early today by a fellow operator with whom he had been on friendly terms. At Southampton Hospital, where the wounded man was taken, his condition was said to be grave tonight.

War talk from Europe was largely responsible for extremely erratic price changes in the wheat market last week and in a large degree obscured what many traders regard as a gradual weakening in the price structure, both here and abroad.
The National Farm School's commencement exercises today were attended by more than 3,500 people from Philadelphia, New York and other cities, a record turnout.

Forrester H. Scott, American attorney, and his friend, Stanley Boynton, an aviator, who were arrested last week on a charge of trying to abduct Mr. Scott's two children, are scheduled to appear for hearing before a magistrate tomorrow.

Price-fixing by government fiat and the stifling of competition are "ineffective and eventually lead to a planned economy," according to Dr. Karl F. Goerdeler, until recently Commissioner for Price Control in Germany.
The Red Wings, dethroned world and National Hockey League champions, beat the Rangers, 4 to 3, before 5,000 spectators tonight for their first victory of the season over the New York team.

A purchase money mortgage for $18.000, due two years hence, at 5 per cent, or sooner, at the option of the mortgagor, was given by the 110 Post Ave Realty Corp, Harry Freed, president, to Bella J. Sutton on the plot on the north side of Post Ave, 100 feet east of Hawthorne St, 150x150.

The amicable temporary adjustment of the Polono-Lithuanian conflict was received with satisfaction in the Wilhelmstrasse if only for the reason that another international flare-up following Austria's annexation was the one thing that Chancellor Hitler obviously desired to escape at this time.
Harry Thoens, A. L. Cornwell and A. L. Burns, all Class A gunners tied for the High-Over-All Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

Members of Caritas Guild, an organization recently formed by the alumnae of the Academy of Mount St. Vincent-on-Hudson, are sponsoring sewing classes, which are being held on Monday nights during the Lenten season at the headquarters of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae.

An old-fashioned coffee party and musicale were held yesterday afternoon at the- David Mannes Music b School, 157 East Seventy-fourth Street. The event was arranged by members of the ladies' auxiliary and by Mr. and Mrs. Mannes.
The Intercity Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament, with New York - opposing Chicago, will be staged at Madison Square Garden tonight. A crowd of 20,000 fans is expected for the start at 8:30.

The French wholesale price index on March 12 was 614, compared with 611 one week before and 613 two weeks before. The rise was due principally to the depreciation of the franc and to gains in the prices of imported products.

Fire destroyed the electrical appliance manufacturing plant of the Poloron Products Corporation third on Bradford Road, beside the tracks of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, here today. The Fire Chief John Gibson said the loss chang was about $150,000 and that the cause had not been determined.

Commenting on the new map of Europe and the rise of the totalitarian States, the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, yesterday told an audience of 1,600 city employes in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that "there is little cause for alarm." He spoke at the fifth annual communion breakfast of the Bureau of Attendance of the Board of Education.

The examination of Richard Whitney by Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall, an inquiry designed to clear up the unanswered questions concerning the failure of the broker and his firm, Richard Whitney Co., will begin in Mr. McCall's office at 10:30 A. M. today.

The entire world, especially European and Asiatic countries, was pictured as "in dire need. for salvation achievable - only through the power of God," by the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, the presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States,
One hundred and forty-five Junior League organizations in the United States, Canada, Mexico and Hawaii spent $515,778 on community activities during the last fiscal year,

The time has come "for the combined forces of decency, Americanism and religion to unite and create a solid front against greed, hate, materialism and fear," the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, the rector, said yesterday morning in his sermon at Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

East Houston St, 312, 24.8x93; Irving and Charles G. Spergel to Mollie Spergel, 1,455 St John's Pl, Brooklyn (quitclaim). 118th St, 226 E, 27.5 1/2X101; Frank Porco Realty Co. Inc, to Anna L. Kneer. 233 W 77th St; mtg $12,000. Bleecker St; 165. 25x100; Hamerton Company, Inc, to William Spiro, 2,157 Amsterdam Ave (50 cents).
Exports of meat products from the United States in 1937 amounted to 123,639,625 pounds, a decrease of 11,720,510 pounds from 1936, while imports from foreign sources aggregated 191,906,012 pounds,

Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, will receive the Albert Einstein Medal for Humanitarianism at a ceremony at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Sunday afternoon, April 3, James W. Gerard, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday. She will be honored for a "lifetime of devoted service to every communal cause in the country."

Speaking of the friendly relationship between this country and Canada, the Right Rev. Dr. Derwyn T. Owen, Archbishop of Toronto, said the stronger the bond of friendship between the British Empire and the United States the better it would be for the destiny of the world today.
God will save the Jews from Hitler as He saved them from Haman, declared the Rev. Francis K. Shepherd in a sermon yesterday at the North Baptist Church, 232 West Eleventh Street.

An overflow gathering of 10,000 baseball enthusiasts which included New York's own No. 1 fan, former Mayor James J. Walker, witnessed ?? variety performance today that must have satisfied the most acting.
Designed to inform traffic violators wishing to plead guilty to the exact amount of their fines, a new form of summons has been prepared and will be placed in general use soon throughout the city.

Gertrude Lawrence, who appears each week-day evening on the stage of the Plymouth Theatre in "Susan and God," stepped into the pulpit of the Broadway Temple, 174th Street and Broadway, and declared that plays with religious themes were becoming increasingly popular because they reflected the need of people disillusioned by leaders who were bringing them to war and bloodshed.

A resolution calling on the United States to sever diplomatic relations with Poland and urging the American people to boycott manufactured products of "unhappy Poland" was passed by acclamation yesterday by 2,500 Lithuanians meeting in Cooper Union to protest Poland's aggressive attitude toward her small neighbor.

Robert R. Fothergill, former major league baseball player, died in St. Joseph's Mercy Hospital here today at the age of 39. The former Detroit Tiger outfielder, coach of baseball at Lawrence Institute of Technology since January, was taken to the hospital Thursday night when he collapsed as the result, his physician said, of a nervous ailment.
A light and fluky wind from the south made conditions unfavorable for sailing in the weekly dinghy series off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today.

Hundreds of business and industrial leaders will serve on the committee having charge of the preview of the World of Tomorrow be presented by the New York world's Fair 1939 on Saturday, April 30, it was announced yesteray by Grover A. Whalen, presient of the fair corporation.

Valentina Snigirevskaya, for two years secretary of the Moscow bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, has been arrested. She is the third secretary of an American organization to be arrested within three months, the two others having been the secretary of the Moscow bureau of the American-Russian Chamber of Commerce and the secretary of the International News Service.
It has been said that nothing in this world is permanent but change. But in these days the changes come

The Rev. Dr. Frank Stanton Burns Gavin, Professor of Ecclesiastical History at the General Theological Seminary and a widely known Anglo-Catholic, died yesterday morning of pneumonia in St. John's Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 47 years old.
Our Lady of Good Counsel High joined the ranks of second-round survivors in the ninth annual metropolitan Catholic schools invitation basketball tournament yesterday.

The occupation of Enderby and Canton Island by the United States and Washington dispatches indicating that claim also would be laid to lands in the Antarctic and Arctic have given rise to speculation here whether Canada might have to dispute possession of territory under the latter category.

The report of the Kennecott Copper Corporation for 1937, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $49,822,393 after all charges and taxes, but before mine depletion. This was equal to $4.60 each on 10,821,652 capital common shares outstanding and it compared with $25,490,765, or $2.36 a share, in 1936. Gross operating revenues last year were $148,550,441, against $106,269,983 in 1936.

If Americans sincerely believe in democracy, "now is the time to exercise positive, rational convictions," declared the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams in his sermon yesterday morning at the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Henry and Clark Streets. Brooklyn.
Little change is shown in the survey of loom activity for the week ended March 12, released for pubdication today by the National Rayon Weavers Association. In the staples and linings division,

Alfred C. Nichols Jr., assistant executive of the Chicago Council, Boy Scouts of America, has been appointed director of camping of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday by Louis W. Noel, acting chairman of the foundation's camp committee.

With the exception of parts of Southwestern Kansas and Northwestern Oklahoma, the condition of Winter wheat showed fairly general improvement last week. Grain men who attended the farmers' cooperative elevator convention at Enid, Okla.,
Early blooming of the tung trees in the Gulf Coast tung belt may result in a poor crop of tung nuts this year, the chemical division of the Department of Commerce has reported.
Leading from the start, the Essex Yacht Club won the sailing dinghy team match today from the Larchmont Yacht Club, the score being 74 points to 71. Class X craft were used, four to a side.

Labor's Nonpartisan League has named Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, and Jacob Baker, president of the United Federal Workers of America, as members of a joint committee with the Farmers Union

A large amount of early-season activity in the Atlantic Beach section of Long Island is reported by Joseph P. Day and William L. Austin Jr., Inc., sales agents for the Atlantic Beach Sales Corporation.

Federal Trade Commission hearings in New York this week have been anbounced as follows: Trade practice conference, manufacturers of infants' and children's knitted outerwear, Hotel New Yorker, Monday. 2 P. M.

Simon Mann came down to town today for his first trip since Winter bound him in his lonely home in the Ramapo Mountains. The bent old man replenished his stock of tobacco, bought some sweets and started- for home.

With facilities taxed by the "initially heavy load" of registrations for unemployment insurance and with the recession cutting the number of job openings, public employment offices in this State placed only 6,184 persons in private jobs in January, according to The Industrial Bulletin, published by the State Labor Department.

The possibility that the liner Berengaria, which is now laid up for "repairs" following a series of mysterious fires, may be permanently withdrawn from service was suggested by The Daily Herald today.
Mr. and Mrs. James F. Forsyth of South Orange announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Jane Forsyth, to Richard Donald McCarty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred L. McCarty of Orange.
The Mystery Men of St. Louis, despite a mysterious collapse in their third game, swept into first place in the five-man event at the American Bowling Congress tonight with a 3,035 count.

Seventeen Princeton squads will compete in 140 events in seven sports this Spring, according to schedules announced today by R. Kenneth Fairman, acting graduate manager of athletics at Princeton University. The Spring card for the Princeton Polo Association is still incomplete.
